title: Sojo's Back Leaves Yanks Uneasy About Utility Spot
description: Luis Sojo woke up Tuesday morning with so much stiffness and soreness in his lower back that it was difficult for him to bend over. He immediately told the Yankees about his condition, and they immediately grimaced because Sojo is their only utility infielder and a valuable reserve.

title: Max Mandell, Founder of Nursery School, Is Dead at 90
description: Max Mandell, who grew up with a mother who didn't love him and a grandfather who did, died on Saturday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 90 and as the founder of the Mandell Nursery School and Kindergarten had devoted his life to making up for a mother's rejection by passing on a grandfather's love to generations of young children.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: More Growth for Visa
description: Visa USA Inc., logging its seventh straight year of growth of 10 percent or more, said today that consumers and businesses spent 16 percent more on Visa credit and debit cards last year, for a total of $610.3 billion. The total is expected to rise to $1 trillion in three years, Visa said. It said its share of personal consumption expenditures rose to 10.5 percent, from 9.6 percent in 1997. It had 52.8 percent of the market.

title: Backstroker's Enforced Rest Turns Out to Be a Blessing
description: For many athletes, a stress fracture in the back might mean disaster: a season lost, a career gone. For 23-year-old Lenny Krayzelburg, the world's best backstroke swimmer, it has turned out to be a blessing.

title: Has Adultery Lost Its Comic Appeal?; Future Philanderers
description: To the Editor:

title: These Bombs Don't Help
description: The air strikes against Yugoslavia were supposed to stop the Milosevic war machine. In fact, the bombing campaign has jeopardized the lives of more than 10 million people and set back the fledgling forces of democracy in Kosovo and Serbia.

title: Founder of Zambia Is Declared Stateless In High Court Ruling
description: Kenneth D. Kaunda, the father of modern Zambia and the country's President for 27 years, was declared a stateless person by the country's High Court today.

title: Metro Business; New Offices for Insurer
description: Health Plus PHSP leased 18,000 square feet of space on Monday at 205 Montague Street in downtown Brooklyn, a five-story building built in 1963. The six-year lease is priced around $25 a square foot. The owner of the building, Treeline Companies, of Carle Place, N.Y., was represented in the deal by Ingram & Hebron Realty of Brooklyn Heights.

title: 3 G.I.'s Missing in Macedonia After They Reported Attack
description: Three American infantrymen patrolling Macedonia's border with the Yugoslav province of Kosovo were missing today after reporting by radio that they had been surrounded and were under fire, the Pentagon said.

title: Court Upholds I.R.S. Penalty For Church Ad In '92 Election
description: A Federal court has upheld a decision by the Internal Revenue Service to revoke the tax-exempt status of an upstate New York church for taking out newspaper advertisements that strongly suggested that Christians not vote for Bill Clinton in the 1992 Presidential election.

title: Evolution, With a Beat You Can Dance To
description: AS William Gibson, the seminal cyberpunk novelist, observed, ''The street finds its own uses for things.'' Billboards and back-alley nightclubs routinely grab bits and pieces of high technology or high culture and bend them into strange, vibrant new shapes.

title: Viag Says Profit Growth Is Unlikely This Year
description: Viag A.G., Germany's No. 3 utility, which canceled an $8.7 billion merger with Algroup earlier this week, warned yesterday that it would be difficult to surpass last year's earnings in 1999, as losses at its telecommunications unit widen and as profit from the energy business stagnates. Viag expects start-up losses at its phone unit to rise to 950 million marks ($520 million) this year.

title: From Foe to NATO Chief -- Javier Solana Madariaga
description: Javier Solana Madariaga, the Secretary General of NATO, is running the biggest air operation the alliance has carried out in its 50 years of existence. This is the same man who opposed Spain's entry into the organization as a young Socialist opposition politician in the early 1980's.

title: DaimlerChrysler Co-Chairmen Deny Defections Are Problem
description: The co-chairmen of DaimlerChrysler A.G. responded angrily yesterday to recent reports of managerial troubles after last year's merger, insisting that the recent defection of a half-dozen former Chrysler executives did not pose a problem.

title: Serbs Shelling Wide Swath of Kosovo
description: Serbian forces are now shelling villages, towns and cities across a wide swath of Kosovo, refugees arriving here said today. The shelling drove more than 10,000 ethnic Albanians from their homes, according to figures from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe..

title: Joining the On-Line World
description: To the Editor:

title: Counting Blue Moons? Think Again, Because Definition Is Wrong
description: It was supposed to be a banner year for blue moons, with one in January and another that rose last night, as March drew to a close.

title: Moscow to Send Ship to Monitor the Conflict, Irking the U.S.
description: Russia announced today that it is sending a military reconnaissance ship to the Mediterranean to monitor the conflict in Yugoslavia, a move criticized by the United States State Department as unhelpful as NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia intensifies.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: States Keep the Lid on Gambling
description: To the Editor:

title: Dreaming About His Neighbor's Wife
description: If you like modern white-on-white interiors and coy, mild-mannered characters who prattle on about next to nothing, ''Thrane's Method,'' Unni Straume's handsome but fatuous evocation of Norwegian middle-class ennui, might appeal to you. The film, which New Directors/New Films is showing at the Museum of Modern Art this evening at 6 and Saturday at 3:30 P.M., is the portrait of Mol (Petronella Barker), a ravishingly beautiful, enigmatic woman, and the dull, plain-looking men who buzz around her.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: People
description: * Jeffrey J. Wilks was named to the new position of executive vice president and senior account director at BBDO New York, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group, to oversee the agency's Duracell account. He had been executive vice president and managing director at Ammirati Puris Lintas, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Relying on the Competence Of Strangers
description: A MANHATTAN jury was startled when a woman carrying a garment bag interrupted a murder trial. She turned out to be the justice's personal shopper. ''She took out three or four outfits, and the judge chose from among them,'' said Kevin Scott, one of the jurors. Then the trial resumed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAYTON, ROBERT HESTER
description: CLAYTON-Robert Hester, Jr. Holland Lodge #

title: How Ms. Clean Does It (for $400 a Day)
description: SHE doesn't do windows. But Megan Miller Goldsmith will crawl behind refrigerators, wash walls, blow the ancient dust from top-shelf books, and wage chemical warfare on grout until it surrenders to a blinding white.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Potted Azaleas

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICCI, JOHN
description: RICCI-John. Professor Emeritus, NYU, died March 30, age 92. For all his 43 years as a faculty member, he was a great teacher and scientist. He was the pre-eminent authority on phase rule and heterogeneous equilibrium. Consultant Oak Ridge National Lab. Article Encyclopaedia Britannica. Highest honor NYU Alumni Assn. Especially remembered for great integrity, clear thinking and warm personality. Met wife Ada Juliani in Italy. She and brother Mario survive. Ricci and Juliani families will be at Flowers Funeral Home, 714 Yonkers Ave., Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9. Instead of flowers, send contribution to J.E. Ricci Memorial Fund, NYU.

title: Militia Leader Arkan Is Indicted in War Crimes; Yugoslavs Are Warned
description: The international war crimes tribunal disclosed today that it had warned Yugoslav officials they would be held accountable for violence against civilians in Kosovo and announced that it had indicted the notorious Serbian militia leader known as Arkan.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell against the Japanese currency on American bond weakness and concern over dollar sales in Japan at the end of the fiscal year there. The dollar settled in New York at 118.97 yen, down from 120.36.

title: INSIDE
description: Computers Ready for 2000

title: Tracking the Majors, or a League of Your Own
description: EACH winter I feel the warmth of Florida and Arizona radiating from every newsstand as dozens of annual baseball preview issues trumpet the arrival of spring training.

title: Mr. 'Cold Pizza' Earns Respect In Japan With Deft Tinkering
description: When Keizo Obuchi was seeking the Prime Minister's job last summer, he was dismissed as having ''all the pizazz of a cold pizza.''

title: Western Countries Organize Security Plans for Refugees
description: France announced today that it would send 10 airplanes to the borders of Kosovo to protect refugee convoys from Serbian forces, and Italy plans to send police officers to Albania to bring order to refugee camps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMHY, NATHAN
description: CAMHY-Nathan (Nissim). On March 30, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Miriam, adored father and father-in-law of Marna and Stuart Novack, Robyn and Mitchell Blaser, Melissa Camhy and Eric Levine, cherished Papoo of Eric and Tracy, Elana, Alexandra, Heather, Adam, Michael, and Rachel, affectionate uncle, devoted brother of Gabriel and the late Esther and Rose. Private graveside services were held March 31.

title: Landlord Faces Charges That He Raped a Tenant
description: A Bronx landlord was arrested yesterday on charges of raping one of his tenants, the police said.

title: Rider Is Given 1-Game Penalty
description: Isaiah Rider, no stranger to suspensions, drew another yesterday from the National Basketball Association and missed the Portland Trail Blazers' home game last night against the Sacramento Kings.

title: Golf's Low-Tech Days
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Mature Ewing Still Is a Mirage
description: THERE is an impression -- and we all know how deceiving impressions can be -- but there is a thought that Patrick Ewing grew up Tuesday night. Some reporters used just that kind of language in commenting on it. They didn't mean that Ewing grew physically. For he stands 7 feet tall. Nor did they mean chronologically, in terms of the physical as well as the basketball. Patrick Ewing is 36, after all, and is in his 14th season as a professional basketball player.

title: Pine Valley Named Nation's Top Course
description: Pine Valley Golf Course, tucked away in the scrubland of southern New Jersey but wielding heroic stature as perhaps the toughest test of golf in the world, has been named the No. 1 course in the country for the 14th consecutive year by Golf Digest magazine.

title: Bank of New York Deal
description: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it had bought the Capital Company of America Client Services L.L.P., expanding its reach into the commercial mortgage servicing business. The bank, the world's largest processor of stock and bond trades for institutional investors, would not disclose the purchase price or the size of Capital America's servicing portfolio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ADRIENNE
description: COHEN-Adrienne. Passed away on March 31, 1999, at the tender age of 55. She was survived by her beloved husband, Barry, and sons, Seth and Mitchell. She was also survived by her mother, Yetta; brother, Neil; two daughters-inlaw, Elisa and Beth, and four beautiful grandchildren, Samantha, Sydney, Spencer and Ryan. Funeral services will be held on Friday, April 2, at 9:00 AM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Children and Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope John Paul's Top Diplomat Will Visit Officials in Belgrade
description: Pope John Paul II, seeking to open a diplomatic channel to end the violence in Yugoslavia, is sending the Vatican's top diplomat to Belgrade.

title: Behind Closed E-Mail
description: IT'S a politician's nightmare: a request from a newspaper reporter to read all the E-mail the public official has received in the past four months.

title: One Year, Old Lament: No Budget
description: For the 15th year in a row, the state finished its fiscal year today without a budget in place for the new year, an event now so routine that, instead of the outrage it once engendered, it was met in the Capitol with quiet resignation.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special section on retirement on March 21 about older volunteers misidentified the publisher of the book ''Prime Time: How the Baby Boomers Will Revolutionize Retirement and Transform America,'' by Marc Freedman. The book was published by Public Affairs, not Prime Time Books.

title: NATO Had Signs Its Strategy Would Fail Kosovars
description: The top civilian and military leaders of NATO settled on their strategy against President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia despite several military assessments and intelligence warnings, and even a clue from a Yugoslav general, that bombs alone could not stop Serb forces from carrying out a purge in Kosovo.

title: To Punish Serbia, Recognize Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARR, KATHERINE
description: FARR-Katherine. Beloved wife of the late William Farr and the late Sidney Zweig. Beloved mother of Martin E. (Barbara) Zweig, The Money Manager from ''Wall Street Week With Louis Rukeyser''. Loving grandmother of Zack and Alex Zweig. Also survived by Mollie Zweig. Sister of Perry (Ethel) Schwartz. Martin Zweig will receive visitors on Monday evening, April 5 at the Harmonie Club, 4 E. 60St from 6-9pm

title: G.D.P. Growth Fails to Carry Profits With It
description: In the early 1990's, it was the jobless recovery. Now it has become the profitless boom.

title: Demise of Quick Draw Lottery Brings Mixed Reviews at Bars and Restaurants
description: At bars, restaurants and delicatessens around New York City yesterday, managers and patrons reacted with dismay, indifference and even relief to the news that a popular video lottery game would come to an end at midnight last night.

title: Where The Fish Watch You Eat
description: THE Red Sea Star Restaurant began with an underwater vision and ended up a vision underwater: a whimsical restaurant deep in the Gulf of Eilat, where diners devour fish platters under the scrutiny of fish peering in at them through portholes.

title: To Punish Serbia, Recognize Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Investors Stick to Big Names in Quarter
description: In its final sprint to the 10,000 mark, a peak once scarcely imagined, the Dow Jones industrial average showed that stock market investors intensified what had already seemed an inexhaustible preference for the biggest and best.

title: Fun for Pranksters
description: YOU'D think pranksters would be at their wits' end. Real-life headlines -- President's DNA tested in sex scandal, Baltimore Orioles play baseball in Cuba -- seem stranger than fiction, defying anyone to come up with an eye-catching practical joke on April Fool's Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGOR, IRVING
description: SAGOR-Irving. The Board of Governors and Members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member, Irving Sagor. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest condolences to his family. Bernard Steinweg, President Heidi Klein, Secretary

title: It's the 21st Century Arriving Early
description: Kosovo could be a template for the century to come.

title: Pro-Serb Rally Voices Protest On U.S. Policy
description: A band of demonstrators in New York yesterday protested the bombing of Yugoslavia by NATO and American forces, some wrapping themselves in Serbian flags, some pinning a black target to their chests as a symbol of solidarity with the people of Belgrade, nearly all questioning the version of events reported in the American news media.

title: Impediments to an Accurate Census
description: House Republicans are up to their usual mischief on the census. Fearing a loss of House seats, they have proposed legislation that would disrupt efforts by the Census Bureau to produce accurate, adjusted population counts in time for the states to draw state and national legislative boundaries.

title: Drawing Youth To Seats And Stage
description: Attracting new audiences to opera is a major component of the New York City Opera's mission. On that score, at least, the company can report success with the season's first performance of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' on Tuesday night. A noticeable number of young people in the audience laughed at the fumbling servant Leporello's catalogue of his master's sexual conquests as if hearing it for the first time. They laughed as well at the Don's compulsive womanizing (which Mozart invites us to do, since during the course of the opera every one of his seductions is a hapless failure) and cheered when the Don ultimately went down to eternal fiery torment through a trap door in the stage floor.

title: Connecticut Says Deal Is Near On Obstacle at Stadium Site
description: Just two days before a deadline requiring them to show progress on a plan to build a stadium for the New England Patriots, Connecticut officials said today that they were close to a deal to remove the biggest obstacle to the plan: a steam plant on the site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESCON, FLORENCE
description: MESCON-Florence on March 27, 1999 in Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved wife of Howard. Devoted mother of Richard and Michael. Dear mother in law of Miriam. Cherished grandmother of Andrew, Jennie, David, Daniel and Hannah. Adored sister of Shirley Leitstein and aunt of Robert, Alex and Bruce Leitstein. We will hold her in our loving memory forever. A graveside service will be held at 10:30am on Friday, April 2 at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Saw Mill River Road, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

title: Poll Finds Whitman In Lead for Senate
description: A survey of New Jersey voters showed Gov. Christine Todd Whitman leading by 16 percentage points over former Gov. Jim Florio in a matchup for the United States Senate seat to be vacated by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg next year. Neither Mrs. Whitman nor Mr. Florio have formally declared their intentions in the race.

title: Jury Pool Is Selected In Pizza Delivery Killings
description: After a screening process that lasted six weeks, a pool of 51 potential jurors has been selected for the trial of the 20-year-old Sussex County man accused of ambushing and murdering two pizza deliverymen in April 1997.

title: When Teachers and Students Are Cheated
description: To the Editor:

title: States Keep the Lid on Gambling
description: To the Editor:

title: Pepsi Spinoff in Lackluster Stock Offering
description: An initial public offering yesterday by Pepsi Bottling Group Inc. provided a stark contrast to the pyrotechnics of recent Internet offerings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, GRAENUM
description: BERGER-Graenum. It is with great sorrow that the Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Graenum Berger, a prominent figure in the social work arena. As a founder of the Henry Kaufmann Campgrounds, the Usdan Center for the Creative and Performing Arts, and the Wurzweiler Education Program, all affiliated with UJA-Federation, he brought joy and enlightenment to a world of children and adults. Whether directing Group Work Activities at UJA-Federation, or inspiring the Jewish community to liberate Ethiopian Jews, his was a life devoted to the service of others. In recognition of his dedication to the Jewish community, the Graenum Berger Bronx Jewish Federation Service Center is named in his honor. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife, Emma; his son, Michael; his daughters-inlaw, Sandra and Anita; and to his six grandchildren. May all who benefited from his kindness and wisdom be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: LACROSSE: ROUNDUP
description: SYRACUSE

title: Harold Steinberg, 77, Publisher Of Reference Books and a Writer
description: Harold Steinberg, a former co-owner and executive of the Chelsea House publishing company, died on Friday at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 77 and had moved to the Kateri Residence nursing home in Manhattan from East Hampton, N.Y., three years ago.

title: Blair's Balkan Edge
description: Oddly enough, of all the political leaders of the NATO countries, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain is emerging as the one with the clearest objectives in Kosovo and the fewest domestic constraints. If NATO finds that air strikes are not enough to curb the aggressive policies of Slobodan Milosevic, Mr. Blair will probably be at the forefront of any debate to escalate military force.

title: UNITED AUTO HAD SHARPLY LOWER LOSSES IN 4TH QUARTER
description: United Auto Group posted sharply reduced losses for the fourth quarter yesterday and said it was in preliminary talks about a possible strategic investment in the company. The New York-based company said that in the last three months of 1998 it lost $5 million, or 22 cents a diluted share, from continuing operations, compared with a loss of $25 million, or $1.34 a share, a year earlier. United Auto Group said it had retained J. P. Morgan to work on securing a deal with a strategic investor. United Auto's stock fell $1.1875, to $7.75.

title: NATIONWIDE MUTUAL AGREES TO SELL ITS REINSURANCE UNIT
description: The Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, the fourth-largest insurer of United States homes and cars, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its reinsurance business to the American Agricultural Insurance Company for undisclosed terms. Nationwide may get more than $30 million in cash for the unit, according to a person close to the transaction. American Agricultural provides coverage to insurers owned by state farm bureaus. It is owned by the American Farm Bureau Federation of Chicago and 28 farm bureau insurance companies. Nationwide is selling the reinsurance unit to focus on selling homeowner and auto insurance to consumers. Shares of its Nationwide Financial subsidiary rose $2, to $42.

title: SUNRISE TO ACQUIRE 3 MIDWEST TV STATIONS FROM SINCLAIR
description: The Sunrise Television Corporation, an affiliate of the investment group Hicks, Muse Tate & Furst Inc., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire three Midwestern television stations from Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. for $81 million. The stations are WICS-TV, the NBC affiliate in Springfield, Ill.; WICD-TV, the NBC affiliate in Champaign, Ill., and KGAN-TV, the CBS affiliate in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Sunrise owns 14 television stations in seven states. It had revenue of $67.1 million in 1998. Sinclair had revenue of $736.8 million in 1998. Sinclair is acquiring the three stations from the closely held Guy Gannett Communications in a six-station deal expected to close in the second quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERGER, AKIVA JOSEPH
description: WEINBERGER-Akiva Joseph. We are saddened by the sudden loss of Joseph Weinberger, beloved husband of Gertrude, devoted father of Hillel and Mark and their wives, Elaine and Deborah, respected grandfather of Levi, Avi, Noam, Sarah and Ezra. A Learned Man. A Survivor. Mr. Weinberger's goodness and spirit will be warmly rememebered by those of us whose lives he touched. Our condolences to the Weinbergers and the many family and friends affected by Joe's untimely passing. Leon M. Wagner and Family

title: Modernism Stakes a Claim In the Rustic Woods
description: BLUEPRINT -- In a land of quaint wooden lodges with steep roofs and creaking porches, a lake-front house in northern Wisconsin is unabashedly modern. The 8,000-square-foot homestead of a Manhattan couple, their five adult children, grandchildren and assorted friends had to accommodate two people alone for the weekend as easily as a house party of 20. Creature comforts were a high priority: ''We wanted all the cold guests coming in from swimming in the lake to be able to take a hot shower for 30 minutes simultaneously,'' the owner said.

title: Justices Seem Ready to Tilt More Toward States in Federalism
description: With its deep divisions over Federal authority versus state sovereignty on full view today, the Supreme Court appeared on the verge of tilting even further in the direction of the states than it had gone in a series of recent 5-to-4 decisions.

title: Open Sesame For Programs
description: Q. How can I get a program to start automatically when I turn on my computer?

title: Continental Names New Chief Executive
description: Continental A.G., the world's No. 4 tire maker, has named Stephan Kessel as its chief executive, replacing Hubertus von Grunberg, who said he would step down on June 1. Mr. Kessel, 45, joined the company in 1985 and became a management board member in 1997. Mr. Grunberg, 56, said he was resigning for personal reasons.

title: Serbs' Revenge: NATO Web Site Zapped
description: In an electronic assault on NATO's presence in cyberspace, computer users in Serbia managed to temporarily disable the alliance's site on the World Wide Web last weekend and cause intermittent outages over the last few days, NATO officials said Wednesday.

title: Despite Past Friction With U.S., France Is a Full Partner This Time
description: PARIS  France, often cast as a reluctant ally in U.S.-led military ventures, has shed that image in the NATO offensive against Serbia, Western officials said Wednesday, noting that French forces were engaged in the forefront of the air assault and that Paris has been an unblinking advocate of a showdown with Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav leader.

title: PANAMSAT SHARES TUMBLE ON LOWER SALES PROJECTIONS
description: Shares of the Panamsat Corporation, the biggest provider of commercial-satellite services, tumbled yesterday after it disclosed that next year's sales would be $100 million less than forecast. Panamsat's stock fell $6.25 a share, or 16 percent, to $31.125, in Nasdaq trading. Technical problems with some of the company's 19 satellites are expanded to limit service expansion. Panamsat is 81-percent owned by the General Motors Corporation's Hughes Electronics Corporation unit, which made some of the malfunctioning satellites. More than 70 percent of Panamsat's sales comes from transmitting television programming and other video feeds.

title: Banned Belgrade Station Turns to the Internet
description: As part of a clampdown on news organizations last week, the Serbian police raided the offices of Radio B92, the single independent radio station in Belgrade, and pulled the plug on its transmitter. Unfortunately for the police, they had no way to pull the plug on the Internet, where the radio station continues to put out its reports.

title: MORE ON THE CONFLICT
description: AID TO REFUGEES -- France said it would send planes to guard refugee convoys, and other NATO countries announced aid plans. Page A13.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS PLUNGE. Soybean prices fell sharply as investors interpreted a Government report as showing there will be no end soon to a supply glut. In Chicago, soybeans for May delivery fell 17.75 cents, to $4.8375 a bushel.

title: Turning a Single Computer Into an At-Home Network
description: For homes where family members or roommates constantly fight over use of the computer, a California company offers an answer short of group therapy: a buddy system that shares hard drives. Specifically, the technology, which sells for $149 from Vega Systems in Emeryville, Calif., allows people to use a single computer while working on different monitors, using separate keyboards and mice.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Judge in Microsoft Trial Sets a Long Timetable

title: Turning Coupon Users From Clippers Into Clickers
description: THE shoppers weren't the problem. Three years ago, the marketing company Supermarkets Online decided to test the idea of offering grocery coupons over the Internet. The company created a Web site offering coupons that consumers could print out and redeem at their favorite supermarkets.

title: I.B.M. vows to pull ads from Web sites that lack clear policies on protecting consumer privacy.
description: SAYING it hoped to ward off Government regulation and increase consumer confidence in electronic commerce, the International Business Machines Corporation, the second-biggest advertiser on the Internet, said yesterday that it would pull its ads from Web sites that lacked clear privacy policies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MAXWELL E.
description: MILLER-Maxwell E. On March 26, 1999, cherished friend and mentor. Winston Kulok & Family

title: Motorola Offers Mobile Phone That Can Span Continents
description: Paving the way for worldwide wireless phone use (and possibly some whopping roaming charges), Motorola is introducing a new mobile telephone that can be used in the United States, Europe, the Middle East and Asia.

title: EU Makes Plans to Aid Refugees From Kosovo
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union will discuss plans next week to take in refugees from Kosovo and set up a new fund to finance relief operations and repatriate displaced persons, officials said Wednesday.

title: Horror and Pity at Young Serbian Thugs
description: As Emir Kusturica demonstrated with ''Underground,'' the anguish in the Balkans may be better conveyed through raucous, stinging satire than by more conventionally compassionate means. For him and now for Srdjan Dragojevic in ''The Wounds,'' the madness and moral chaos of wartime call for rowdy cinematic outrage in response.

title: Piece of Janis Joplin's Heart, and Soul, in Cleveland
description: The combination of theater and rock-and-roll, the success of which has long been devoutly wished by theater producers eager to build new audiences, has rarely flourished in regional theaters, where the subscribers that sustain them tend to be graying and traditionalist. But at the venerable Cleveland Play House here (at 83 years old rather graying and traditional itself), the melding seems to have worked in its current production.

title: Elegant Resort Faces an Inelegant Battle Over Gambling
description: The paradox of a luxury resort in a working-class county has always been apparent here in southeastern West Virginia. But now it is fueling a political fight, pitting the values of rural Christian fundamentalists against a life style of golf, aromatherapy and finger bowls with breakfast.

title: 92% of Federal Computers Ready for 2000
description: The White House said today that 92 percent of the Federal Government's essential computer systems were free of year 2000 problems, but predicted that Americans would have difficulty reaching some foreign countries by telephone or airplane, because some computers overseas would not be fixed by early next year.

title: Lawrence D. Duke Sr., 86; Fought the Klan in Georgia
description: Lawrence Daniel Duke Sr., a retired state judge who as a young prosecutor fought for civil rights and against the Ku Klux Klan in rigidly segregationist Georgia, died on March 24 at Fayette Community Hospital in Fayetteville, Ga. He was 86 and lived in nearby Tyrone.

title: Move Signals A Power Shift At Conde Nast
description: In a transition that re-establishes him as one of the company's central players, Thomas A. Florio, the publisher of Conde Nast Traveler and the former publisher of The New Yorker, was named publisher of the Conde Nast men's title GQ yesterday. He replaces Jack Laschever, 38, who is resigning for medical reasons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELSON, CDR. NATHANIEL O.
description: ABELSON-Cdr. Nathaniel O., of New York City. Born April 3, 1920, died March 30, 1999. A graduate of the Harvey School, Katonah, NY, Philips Andover Academy, Andover, Mass., and Yale University, New Haven, Conn, Class of '42. Grew up in Boston, Mass., a member of the U.S. Naval Reserve, the Veteran Corps of Artillery, the Explorers Club, and the New England Society. Geographer, United Nations Map Collection from 1945 to 1980. He leaves a wife, the former Elaine Stanton Noyes, and a daughter, Mrs. Nancy Stanton Knox. Services will be held on Saturday, April 3, at 2 PM, at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park and 92nd St., Manhattan, in the Chapel. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

title: NATO PLANS WEEKS OF BOMBING TO BREAK GRIP OF SERB LEADER
description: NATO opened its expanded bombing campaign against Yugoslavia today, and alliance officials said they were planning weeks of air strikes intended to undermine President Slobodan Milosevic's hold on power.

title: To Punish Serbia, Recognize Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: In Every Color, Finding the Blues
description: Looking for a sure cure for the blues?

title: An Echo of 'Daily Show' on 'Late Late'
description: The names are impossible to keep straight (''Late Night,'' ''Late Show,'' ''Late Late Show''), which is why real people think of the shows as ''Conan,'' ''Dave'' and ''Craig Kilborn, that guy from Comedy Central.'' His version of ''Late Late Show'' began on Tuesday (12:35 A.M. on CBS), following David Letterman and going head-to-head with Conan O'Brien. More important, Mr. Kilborn replaces Tom Snyder in that slot and instantly zaps CBS into the 90's.

title: Our Towns; Losing a Battle To Rattles And Fangs
description: THE warmth of early spring is seeping into the granite shoulders of Bald Hill here in the Hudson Highlands, and any day now it should spur several dozen eastern timber rattlesnakes coiled in a rocky den to end their seven-month hibernation and disperse into the surrounding woods.

title: JB Oxford Holdings Will Restate Earnings
description: JB Oxford Holdings Inc., an on-line brokerage firm, said today that it was restating earnings for the second quarter of 1998 after the Securities and Exchange Commission determined it must record an interest charge of $2.5 million.

title: Examining Hitchcock at 100: An Interactive Museum Exhibit
description: THE scene on the screen is intimately familiar: a blond woman smokes a cigarette, oblivious to the ravens gathering on a set of monkey bars in the schoolyard behind her. By the time she finally notices a bird landing next to dozens of others, the suspense is almost too much to bear. So you click on the Pause icon and go back in five-second intervals, trying to figure out how the scene was made.

title: Joy in Webville
description: After the last pitch has been thrown, the Web springs into action. Here's a selection of baseball-related sites offering game reports and current information:

title: Devils Set Sights On Bigger Goals
description: The Devils finished the month the same way they started it. Their lopsided 7-1 victory over the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim tonight at Continental Arena was their seventh victory of the month, clinched a playoff spot and put the Devils a step closer to the Atlantic Division title.

title: Islanders Give Rangers a Lift
description: For the second straight game, the Islanders helped the Rangers. Tonight, the Islanders aided the Blue Shirts' slim playoff hopes by beating the Panthers, 5-3, at the National Car Rental Center. The Rangers and the Panthers remain tied with 72 points in their pursuit of the Boston Bruins (77 points) for the final playoff berth in the East. The Islanders lost to the Rangers on Monday.

title: AT HOME WITH: Ruth Lord; A Child Unnoticed Amid the Antiques
description: ''DID the du Ponts have any small children?'' a middle-aged man asked the docent as the tour group stood in the delicate 18th-century yellow-cream-paneled dining room of Winterthur, the 175-room mansion created by Henry Francis du Pont for his collection of American decorative arts.

title: Philip Morris Verdict Helps To Spur Fall In the Dow
description: Stocks fell yesterday as investors sold shares of Philip Morris after a jury found the company liable for $81 million in damages for the death of a smoker, and hopes faded for a quick settlement of Microsoft's antitrust trial.

title: Microsoft Judge Sets Date In May for Trial to Resume
description: The presiding judge in the Microsoft antitrust trial today tentatively set May 10 as the date for the trial to resume and laid out a longer timetable for additional testimony, oral arguments and written submissions, virtually insuring that the trial will not end much before 2000.

title: A Croatian Town Pockmarked by a Milosevic War
description: This ruined city beside the Danube is as good a place as any to meditate on the years of misery and score-settling that may lie ahead when the Serbian campaign in Kosovo comes to an end.

title: Johnson's Injury Gives Sprewell A Starting Spot
description: The debate over whether Latrell Sprewell should start was resolved today, but his placement in the Knicks' starting lineup for Thursday night's game against the Cleveland Cavaliers had no one smiling except Sprewell.

title: Excerpts of Statement By the District Attorney
description: Following are excerpts from the statement by District Attorney Robert T. Johnson after the arraignment of four police officers in the Diallo case:

title: Police Still Sorting Out Shooting of an Officer
description: The police said yesterday that they were still trying to determine who shot Detective Sgt. Mark Smith on Tuesday afternoon with his service weapon while he tried to break up a fight.

title: Leiter Has Shaky Hip After Doing Little Twist
description: With the regular season five days away, the last thing the Mets wanted to hear today was that their opening day starter, Al Leiter, might be injured.

title: Justice Who Was a Prosecutor Under Giuliani to Oversee Trial
description: Justice Patricia Anne Williams, who was named yesterday to preside over the Amadou Diallo case, is a Yale-trained lawyer who once worked under Rudolph W. Giuliani when he was United States Attorney.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 12 about the poetry editor Harry Ford described the formation of Atheneum Publishers incompletely. Atheneum, where Mr. Ford worked for 28 years, was created in 1959 by Alfred Knopf Jr., Simon Michael Bessie and Hiram Haydn, not by Mr. Knopf alone.

title: Cosmic Questions, Interim Answers
description: FOR THE TIME BEING

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the jazz musician Theodore McRae on Monday misstated the location of the Institute of Jazz Studies at Rutgers University in New Jersey, to which he was a contributor. It is on the university's Newark campus, not at Rutgers in New Brunswick.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Tuesday with a theater review of ''The Countess'' misstated the theater where it is playing. As noted in the review, the play is at the Greenwich Street Theater, which is at 547 Greenwich Street, at Charlton Street in the South Village; it is not at Greenwich House.

title: BMW Shares Fall on Worries Over Rover
description: Investors hammered shares of the Bavarian car maker BMW today, after the company's top executives gave analysts a vague and unconvincing description of their strategy for repairing Rover, the troubled British subsidiary.

title: MERCANTILE BANCORP TO LAY OFF 750 MORE EMPLOYEES
description: Mercantile Bancorp said yesterday that it would lay off another 750 employees, bringing its total number of recent layoffs to 1,400. The St. Louis-based bank holding company, which initiated a revamping plan in September, said it would also close another 12 branches this year. Of the 1,400 employees laid off, about 650 workers received notice in late 1998, and about 750 more -- many of whom are managers -- will be notified this year. The bank had about 11,000 employees last year. Costs tied to the layoffs and branch closings were accounted for during the company's fourth quarter, when it posted revamping costs of $45 million, or 19 cents a share.

title: CENTRIS IS IN PRELIMINARY TALKS THAT COULD LEAD TO SALE
description: Centris Group Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks with other insurers that could lead to its sale. Centris, a provider of medical and specialty insurance lines, said it had received inquiries from other insurance companies interested in acquiring it. The company said it had held preliminary discussions with other companies in the last several years and was currently in talks that could lead to a transaction. Centris had revenue of $168.3 million in 1998. The shares of Centris were up 6.25 cents yesterday at $10.5625.

title: Maternity Ward Fashions: Knit Caps, Chip ID's and Bar Codes
description: JAYLEN CARR drooled, wailed and burped in his mother's arms a day after being delivered here at Saddleback Memorial Medical Center. With unfocused eyes and powerful lungs, he looked and sounded like a lot of other day-old infants.

title: Paraguay Glides From Desperation to Euphoria
description: ''Goodbye 20th century, goodbye assassins,'' reads a fresh scrawl of graffiti a block from the plaza where snipers killed five protesters who were demanding the overthrow of the President of Paraguay less than a week ago.

title: Eclectic Bill Shaping Up For Next Woodstock
description: The promoters of Woodstock '99, a three-day rock event commemorating the 30th anniversary of the seminal rock festival, recently announced that they would reveal this year's lineup of bands next Thursday. But in the meantime the names of some of the top performers have begun to leak out, giving shape to an eclectic bill with potentially wide appeal.

title: For Americans, Davis Cup Mission Is Twofold
description: They are not panicking yet, but the 1999 United States Davis Cup squad, which faces the British team of Tim Henman and Greg Rusedski in the first round this weekend in Birmingham, England, is playing for more than pride.

title: Youve Got Infected Mail!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: BASEBALL: ROUNDUP
description: Charges Upheld Against McLain

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LINDER, JOAN
description: LINDER-Joan. April 1, 1929December 11, 1997. Miss you everyday, especially today. The Family

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions on Monday about the declining rate of abortion in Russia misstated the location of the abortion clinic shown. It is St. Petersburg, not Moscow.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They came under small-arms fire. They reported over the radio that they were surrounded. No more was heard from them.''

title: Wake-Up Calls at Home, Complete With Advertising
description: Thanks to the Internet, deep sleepers can get the same wake-up service they enjoy at hotels for free at home. But they'll have to put up with the dulcet tones of early morning marketing.

title: Russian Woes May Aid U.S. Emissions Goals
description: The United States and other industrial countries may find it easier and cheaper than expected to comply with a proposed treaty to fight global warming, thanks largely to reduced fuel consumption in Russia, the Government's energy-forecasting agency said today.

title: Serbs Seek Iraqi Help For Defense, Britain Says
description: The British Government said today that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia had formed a ''close relationship'' with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and that they had stepped up their military cooperation in the face of a common threat from American air strikes. American officials, however, were skeptical about the degree of cooperation.

title: A High-Definition Gambit; Chinese Test U.S. Market With Cheaper HDTV Sets
description: Think ''Made in China,'' and plastic toys, T-shirts, sneakers and simple tape recorders come to mind, all assembled cheaply in anonymous factories for foreign brands.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall Street's winners: The old familiar faces.
description: MERRILL LYNCH & COMPANY underwrote more securities than any other Wall Street firm in the first quarter of 1999, while Goldman, Sachs & Company was the leader in mergers and acquisitions, according to rankings announced yesterday.

title: Judge Bellacosa to Leave Court of Appeals Before Term Ends
description: Judge Joseph W. Bellacosa, perhaps the most conservative member of the New York State Court of Appeals, announced yesterday that he would step down from the state's highest court next year, a few months before his 14-year term was scheduled to expire.

title: Minister Is Convicted In Sexual Assault of Girl
description: A Union County jury yesterday convicted a minister in Jersey City of charges that he sexually assaulted a girl in his parish over a six-year period beginning when she was 10 years old.

title: Melissa And Her Cousins
description: MELISSA is a new and spectacularly promiscuous computer virus, one that has infected tens of thousands of computers worldwide since its discovery less than a week ago. It has already cost millions of dollars in lost productivity, experts estimate.

title: Economic Scene; No Comfort in New Solvency Figures
description: The Administration boisterously pointed this week to new actuary studies showing that Medicare and Social Security will remain solvent for a few more years than previously estimated. Social Security would not go bankrupt until 2034, rather than 2032, and the Medicare trust fund would last until 2015 rather than 2008.

title: Accounts
description: * Diamond Walnut Growers Inc., Stockton, Calif., to Gardner, Geary, Coll & Young, San Francisco, to handle its account, which had been at Young & Rubicam San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $6 million.

title: Van Horn to Return; Nets Hope Not to Relax
description: Keith Van Horn, with his crossover dribble and powerful spin moves, will return to the Nets' lineup Thursday night against the Atlanta Hawks. After missing the last two games with a sprained right ankle, the star forward practiced at full speed today. He left the court with every intention of reinjecting his potent offense into the Nets' game plan.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MOOG INC., East Aurora, N.Y., a maker of aerospace parts, will supply military and commercial aircraft parts to Boeing Co. under two contracts valued at about $1 billion over 10 years.

title: WINSLOEW AGREES TO $245.9 MILLION BUYOUT BY TRIVEST
description: Winsloew Furniture Inc., which makes aluminum furniture for patios and offices, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired for $245.9 million after the Trivest Furniture Corporation, a new company controlled by Winsloew's chairman, Earl Powell, raised its offer. The Powell-led management group will pay $33 a share, $3 more than its previous bid. The company had 1998 sales of $141.4 million. On March 5, Trivest offered about $223.5 million. Winsloew had 30 days to solicit other proposals. Trivest first offered to buy Winsloew on Jan. 18 and take it private. Its stock rose $2.3125 a share yesterday, to $29.8125.

title: Has Adultery Lost Its Comic Appeal?; Cues From the Screen?
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Changes At Ammirati Puris
description: Executive changes have been made at Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which is also forming a direct-marketing partnership.

title: Definitely Not at the Opera
description: To the Editor:

title: PRIMUS IN DEAL FOR LONDON TELECOM'S CANADIAN NETWORK
description: Primus Telecommunications Group said yesterday that it had agreed to buy London Telecom Group for the equivalent of $50 million in cash, to become the third-largest long-distance provider in Canada. Primus will acquire the closely held London Telecom's Canadian network, along with the assets of Wintel CNC Communications Inc. and Wintel CNT Communications Inc. The Toronto-based London Telecom, whose network reaches 95 percent of the Canadian market, has more than 130,000 customers. The Canadian units of the AT&T Corporation and the Sprint Corporation are the top two long-distance providers in Canada. Primus had 1998 sales of $421.6 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARRIS, JOSEPH
description: HARRIS-Joseph. December 13, 1900-April 1, 1983. Dearest loving husband of Sylvia & dearest loving father of J. Robert and James B. Dearest loving grandfather and great-grandfather. A great business & theatrical legend in his own time. Original producer of Broadway shows, ''Sweet Charity'' and ''Mame''. Dad, you're the greatest ever. We all dearly love you and miss you so very much. God bless you forever. All our love. Your loving sons, Bob and Jim

title: Short-Lived Dose of Shirt-Sleeve Temperatures
description: It was decidedly shirt-sleeve weather, and all across the region yesterday, people doffed their jackets and overcoats to take a walk, appreciate spring's blooms and otherwise enjoy a day that reached 73 degrees in Central Park.

title: Essay; Who's Losing NATO?
description: NATO's military objective was clear: to ''degrade'' Serbia's ability to drive the ethnic Albanians out of its province of Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, HERMAN
description: ROSENBERG-Herman. April 21, 1902-April 1, 1998. It's been one year since you left us, and you are missed. Love, Ruth and Carla.

title: Shows, Walks and Talks
description: For the City Gardener

title: Ariel Smith, 16, Is Juggling His Young Life From the Saddle
description: Reports of a storm hitting Connecticut and the upper reaches of Long Island and heading in the direction of the race track were heard, but so far at Aqueduct there was nothing more on a resolutely gray day recently than a lingering winter chill, the thump of hoofbeats and, if one listened closely in the grandstand, the frequent sound of mutuel tickets being ripped in half.

title: Bidding a Perfect Contract, But With a Hilarious Result
description: The Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, which ended Saturday in Vancouver, British Columbia, was a triumph for the team led by George Jacobs. All three pairs -- Jacobs with Ralph Katz, the reconstituted partnership of Alan Sontag and Peter Weichsel, and the Italian world champions, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace -- performed with great efficiency throughout a long, hard week, winning all but one of its matches by wide margins.

title: Giuliani's Loyal, Boring, Ideal Top Adviser
description: EVERYBODY agrees on one thing about Tony Coles: He is the man who knows a lot but won't say too much.

title: Kitsch Ascendant
description: KITSCH has history, too, and bad taste, just like good, has its fashions. Inspiration struck someone the day velvet car dice were born, just as surely as it did Duchamp or Daumier. An artist had first to imagine and paint those card-playing dogs before they could become a figure of fun in beer ads.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Saving a Space For a Rudy Site

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, BERNARD
description: KANE-Bernard, 72. Of Delray Beach, Fla., and Ardsley, NY. Survived by his beloved wife, son, daughter and four grandchildren. A leader in the field of elevator modernization and computerization. Co-founder of New York Elevator and Computerized Elevator Control. An accomplished aviator and enthusiastic volunteer pilot for Angel Flight Northeast. Services at Westchester Riverside Memorial, Mount Vernon, Noon, Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARP, HELEN S.
description: CARP-Helen S. Of Mill Valley, CA, on March 30, 1999. Predeceased by husband Bernard, and sister Lenore Rottenberg. Survived by sons David and Joel, and daughter-inlaw Dorothy. Remembered and cherished by those who truly knew her. Contributions may be made to The Alzheimer's Assoc, or The Amer Assoc for Cancer Research.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph with an obituary on Saturday about Arthur E. Raymond, who led the team that designed the DC-3 airplane, was published in error. It was a picture not of Mr. Raymond, but of Lewis K. Sillcox, who was president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in 1954, the year Mr. Raymond received the Spirit of St. Louis Medal from the society. Mr. Sillcox died in 1989.

title: BP Amoco's Leader Remakes an Oil Giant, Again
description: For a man in a hurry, Sir John Browne is, by all appearances, remarkably composed.

title: Between Tech Fans And Naysayers, Scholarly Skeptics
description: OF all the forces that permeate daily life, perhaps nothing merits the close scrutiny of scholars more than technology. There are plenty of people who are critical of technology. They range from extremists like Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabomber, to popular authors with a less fanatical approach, like the astronomer Clifford Stoll (''Silicon Snake Oil'') or the unyielding naysayer Kirkpatrick Sale (''Rebels Against the Future'').

title: $5.6 Billion Deal by Yahoo Reported Set
description: Yahoo is expected to announce today that it has agreed to buy Broadcast.com in a stock swap valued at $5.6 billion, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: When Teachers and Students Are Cheated
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: An Automotive CD Player That Uses the Car Radio
description: The upside of the newest in-car CD player from Emerson is that it requires no installation. The downside is that there is a slim chance the CD player will play music in nearby cars, potentially leading to some ugly music-related road rage.

title: From Dublin to Broadway, Spinning Tales of Irish Wool
description: When Conor McPherson was 10 and growing up in Dublin, he would gather his friends in his family's garage and entertain them with ghost stories of his own invention. Seventeen years later, he is still telling stories, but the stage and the audience are considerably larger. Along with Martin McDonagh, Sebastian Barry and Billy Roche, he is a leader -- and, at 27, the youngest -- of a wave of Irish playwrights who are bringing new vitality to the contemporary theater.

title: U.N. Rights Investigator Offers Another Blistering Report on Iraq
description: President Saddam Hussein's rule in Iraq has one of the bleakest human rights records of any country since the end of World War II, an investigator for the United Nations said today.

title: Everybody Flocks to Arab Towns on Israeli Campaign Trail
description: The roar of the crowd's shouting, ''Bibi go home!'' was barely audible in the tightly guarded City Hall, where Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was whisked to speak to a handpicked audience from this Israeli Arab town.

title: N.C.A.A. to Make Changes In Eligibility Requirements
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, given time by a Federal appeals court to develop new eligibility requirements for Division I athletes, said yesterday that it was likely to have revised rules in place by September.

title: In Honoring an Officer, an Impassioned Plea
description: Just hours before the second-degree murder charges were unsealed against four police officers in the death of Amadou Diallo, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir visited another part of the Bronx to rename a street in honor of an officer who died in the line of duty, where they made impassioned speeches urging greater respect for the police.

title: See the Wallpaper, See It Glow, Bugs and Bunnies in a Row
description: FORGET powder-pink puppies and baby-blue kittens. Night skies and kimono-clad bunnies are among today's wallpaper offerings for the toddler set -- or perhaps their parents. Judy Kennedy, a stylist at York Wallcoverings in York, Pa., sees nostalgia for the 1960's -- black lights and psychedelics -- as influencing children's decorating this year. Indeed, lava lamps inspired York's three-dimensional black-light-sensitive wallpaper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULTZ, ANNE
description: SCHULTZ-Anne (nee Sager). On March 28, 1999. Formerly of Miami and West Palm Beach, Florida. At the age of 84 passed away after a brief illness. Predeceased by her loving husband Samuel. Beloved mother of Heather Greenfield and Carol Schulz. Dear sister of Nathan, Bertha, Jack, Samuel and Jerri. Devoted grandmother of Jennifer, Eden, Noah and Jonah. For more information contact I.J. Morris 1-800-382-4145.

title: Rather Interviews Clinton on '60 Minutes II'
description: In a coup for CBS's fledgling news magazine program ''60 Minutes II,'' President Clinton gave his first exclusive interview in nearly 15 months yesterday to Dan Rather of CBS News, the new program's senior correspondent, as well as the anchor of the ''CBS Evening News.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUGGER, WILLIAM
description: DUGGER-William. In Windham, ME. Formerly of Port Jefferson, L.I., NY. Private services only. There are no visiting hours. If desired, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, 52 Federal St, Brunswick, ME 04011. Conroy-Tully Funeral Home, 172 State St, Portland, ME.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: When Fate Is in the Driver's Seat
description: Shards of memory often tell a story best, as Marcel Proust and James Joyce, among others, have taught us. The Margaret Jenkins Dance Company from San Francisco took this nonlinear lesson to heart on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater with the New York premiere of ''Breathe Normally,'' a polished mix of speech and movement.

title: Stealth Gives Plane Mask, But Not Cloak, Experts Say
description: The loss of an American stealth fighter in Yugoslavia on Saturday did not represent a failure of its radar-evading technology, experts said today.

title: Improved Ways to Track Everything
description: IMAGINE never again finding out after an airline journey with several ups and downs that your luggage turned left when you turned right. That would be possible, of course, if the tag slapped on your bag at check-in was smart enough to follow you through your plane changes. With a new ''smart label'' developed by Motorola, those little paper tags stuck on your suitcase -- and a lot of other labels, as well -- may become a lot more useful.

title: Two Rivals in Clerical Union Are Charged in Embezzlement
description: After seeking to blame each other for the disappearance of tens of thousands of dollars from their union's treasury, the former president and the former treasurer of a union local representing City University clerical workers were both indicted yesterday on charges of embezzlement.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Cars' Weekday Access to Prospect Park Is Cut
description: Faced with growing complaints about the dangers cars pose in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, city officials announced yesterday that they would ban the vehicles from the park during most of the day.

title: Russia to Seek Debt Write-Off
description: Russia said today that it would ask creditors to forgive as much as 75 percent of its Soviet-era debt, as the ruble's devaluation and insufficient revenue make it impossible to meet all its foreign debt payments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, BESSIE
description: GOLDMAN-Bessie. We sadly mourn the passing of Bessie Goldman, beloved mother of our dear friend and counsel, Robert Goldman and mother-in-law of Claire, our dear friend. Esther and Jack Friedman

title: Hopeful Prime Ministers Hover at I.R.A. Disarmament Negotiation
description: For the third consecutive night, Prime Ministers Tony Blair of Britain and Bertie Ahern of Ireland pressed Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders Wednesday night to compromise in the bitter dispute over the disarmament of the Irish Republican Army. The dispute is blocking the advance of the peace effort in this British province.

title: Walt Disney Lived Here
description: ONE of Manhattan's funkiest co-op buildings is for sale -- a bohemian neo-Tudor town house of 10 studio apartments with 10 fireplaces, and a roster of famous former tenants, including Douglas Fairbanks Jr. and Walt Disney. In 1926, Mabel Normand, a silent film star, dedicated the Greenwich Village building at 102 Bedford Street, near Christopher Street by standing on one of its gables and smashing a bottle of Champagne on the new roof.

title: U.S. Farmers Covet a Forbidden Crop
description: Dennis Carlson sold his first wheat, grown on a field borrowed from his parents, in 1975, when he was 14 years old. He earned $4.51 a bushel and resolved to follow his father, grandfather and great-grandfather into farming.

title: Yugoslav Athletes' Thoughts Not on Games
description: In this Andalusian city, the basketball star Sasha Djordjevic played a game Sunday with a black band around his arm and a rectangular piece of cloth covering his name on the back of his jersey. In Madrid, the soccer star Predrag Mijatovic, wrapped in a Yugoslav flag, marched outside the United States Embassy.

title: Subpoenas Issued In Quorum Suit
description: Federal prosecutors issued subpoenas today to 200 hospitals in about 40 states currently or formerly managed by Quorum Health Group Inc.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first day of Passover and Holy Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Going for Control and Subtlety, Not Showy Display
description: The Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble came to Davis Hall with an interestingly varied collection of new and familiar dances. What stood out most about the company's performance on Friday morning, however, was the expressiveness and individual charisma of its 12 well-trained young dancers.

title: Grolier Interactive Presents Color-Coordinated Software
description: With hardware vendors scrambling to create stylish peripherals to complement Apple Computer's trendy translucent iMac, it was probably only a matter of time before software manufacturers followed suit. Grolier Interactive has just created a special edition of its popular multimedia encyclopedia CD-ROM that is specifically tailored for iMac users.

title: At Ruined Factory, Anger and Accusations
description: In the first guided tour conducted by the Yugoslav Army since it issued wartime press passes on Tuesday, journalists were shown significant bomb damage today in two central Serbian towns roughly 60 miles south of Belgrade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMER, BETTY
description: COMER-Betty. Wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Paula Slavsky (Stephen) and Donna Sparberg (Andrew). Grandmother of Matthew, Melissa, Mark and Neil. Sister of Gladys Hymes and Lillian Wallis. Loyal employee of the Riese Organization.

title: Raiders of Lost Art Loot Temples in Cambodia
description: One of the boldest and most destructive temple robberies ever carried out in Cambodia might have gone undiscovered for months or even years if Claude Jacques had not wandered into an antique shop in Thailand last December.

title: Man Dies From Injuries After Falling Down Shaft
description: A midtown building custodian who fell down an elevator shaft on his first night on the job Tuesday died yesterday of massive internal injuries, the police said.

title: 4 Officers Enter Not-Guilty Pleas To Murder Counts in Diallo Case
description: Four New York City police officers were arraigned on charges of second-degree murder and suspended from police duty yesterday in the shooting death of Amadou Diallo, marking a new stage in a case that has riveted, and riven, the city for weeks.

title: National News Briefs; Nation of Islam Leader In Washington Hospital
description: The Nation of Islam leader, Louis Farrakhan, has been hospitalized in Washington, fueling concerns about his health.

title: To Punish Serbia, Recognize Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Refuses Leniency Plea, Sentencing Lawyer to 7 Years
description: A former lawyer who had been accused of joining the criminal activities of his clients was sentenced to just over seven years in prison yesterday by a Federal judge in Manhattan who refused requests for leniency.

title: Mitsubishi Electric to Cut Global Work Force by 10%
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, one of Japan's big, diversified electronics makers, announced a broad overhaul today that will reduce its global work force by 14,500, or 10 percent, over the next three years to help increase profit. More than half the job cuts will be in Japan.

title: And Now Your Local Weather
description: There are 290 bales of hay in the barn loft, enough to last my four horses well into the warmth and the tall grass that I presume is coming. Every couple of weeks, since late October, I've gone to visit two brothers who raise hay and milk-cows on a Massachusetts hillside. While the brothers stack bales in my pickup, they grouse about the weather and the calamitously low price of hogs and the $6 drop in the price per hundredweight for milk. I write a check for the hay -- a commodity whose price never seems to fall -- and, as part of the deal, I bring news of the weather in other parts of the country -- the snow that fell in south Texas in early December, the high winds last month in Lander, Wyo., the knee-high oats and the peach orchards now blooming in central California.

title: In Grim Week, Pep Talk From the President
description: The Clinton Administration's top foreign policy officials gathered in the Oval Office on Monday morning after the Balkans went through a wrenching weekend. Serbian forces had accelerated their campaign of ethnic murder and expulsions in Kosovo and an American F-117 stealth fighter had gone down just west of Belgrade.

title: Memory Takes New Shape
description: IN the last few years, computer and electronics stores have become crowded with handheld digital devices that are capable of stirring technolust in the most analog of hearts.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENFELD, RONALD
description: ROSENFELD-Ronald. One year, six months, two weeks, six days and two Passovers. But who's counting? Your Loving Sole Mat

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDT, CLAIRE
description: BRANDT-Claire (nee Grabois) on March 30th, 1999 at the age of 89. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Loving mother of Neil and Susan and Lawrence and Lois. Cherished grandmother of Michael and Minna, Richard, Heather, Brooke and Gary Fishkind, and Michelle. Proud great-grandmother of Zachary Brandt Fishkind. Funeral service Friday, 9 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York. Contributions may be made in her memory to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: Has Adultery Lost Its Comic Appeal?
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasuries Fall, Bringing Worst Quarter in 3 Years to a Close
description: Bonds fell yesterday, finishing their worst quarter in three years, as a report on manufacturing activity in the Midwest raised concern that brisk economic growth will quicken inflation later this year.

title: With Hornets in a Jam, Stern Enlists Jordan
description: Michael. The mere mention of the name conjures up a kaleidoscope of images and a lifetime of memories. Having conquered the basketball universe, where does the next challenge lie for the world's most prominent athlete?

title: Lowe Acquires Stake In Zipatoni Company
description: The Lowe Group in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, said yesterday that it had acquired a minority stake in the Zipatoni Company in St. Louis, a marketing services agency with billings estimated at $160 million from clients like the Miller Brewing Company, the Coca-Cola Company and the Energizer Company. Terms were not disclosed. Under the agreement, Zip atoni will remain an autonomous company and operate under its current name and management.

title: Belgian Financier Buys Bouygues Stake
description: The Belgian financier Albert Frere has bought 1.1 percent of Bouygues S.A., Europe's largest construction company, becoming the third corporate raider to buy a stake in the company in four months. Mr. Frere, who controls billions of dollars of assets through a cascade of nine holding companies, recently bought 290,000 Bouygues shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYNG, LILA HOTZ
description: TYNG-Lila Hotz. On March 31 at the age of 100 years and 5 days. Born in Chicago, she died at her home, Lu Shan, Gladstone, NJ. Beloved mother of Henry Luce, III and Peter Paul Luce; mother-inlaw of Leila Hadley Luce and Elizabeth Bardsley Luce; grandmother of Lila Luce, H. Christopher Luce, Meredith Luce Billingsley, Elisabeth Luce, Christena McNicol and Clare Abbey. Memorial service 4PM Thursday, April 8, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Ave. at 73rd St. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Spence School, 22 East 91 St, NY, NY 10028, would be appreciated. She will be interred at Graceland Cemetery, Chicago.

title: To Punish Serbia, Recognize Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: To Punish Serbia, Recognize Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazilian Central Bank Plans A Currency Insider Inquiry
description: The nation's central bank said today that it is conducting an investigation into accusations that several domestic and foreign financial institutions used inside information about an impending shift in exchange-rate policy in January to profit from the devaluation of the currency.

title: Big Board Adjusts Its 'Circuit Breakers'
description: In its quarterly adjustment of the so-called circuit breakers, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday set the level for a trading halt in United States equity markets at a drop of 1,000 points, up from 900 points last quarter.

title: The Kosovo Refugee Emergency
description: While NATO warplanes attack Serbia, the alliance must also tend to the needs of a tidal wave of refugees fleeing Serbian atrocities in Kosovo. In the past eight days, nearly 150,000 Kosovars have arrived in Albania, Montenegro and Macedonia, three of Europe's poorest republics. Clinton Administration officials fear that could grow to one million in the days ahead. These refugees need food, shelter and medicine. The lands receiving them need help as well, lest the burden of caring for so many foreigners tear apart their own fragile societies.

title: Stewart Practicing Damage Control
description: Bill Stewart has seen plenty of ugliness during his three months as coach of the Islanders, but the ugliest situation of his brief tenure is one he brought on himself.

title: Many Hospitals in New York Quit Plan for Fewer Doctors
description: Two years ago, dozens of teaching hospitals across New York State embraced an unusual pilot program to ease the nationwide glut of physicians. The Federal Government would pay bonuses to the hospitals if they trained fewer doctors, just as it once paid corn farmers not to grow corn.

title: U.S. and Europe at Impasse On New World Trade Chief
description: A month before the head of the World Trade Organization is to leave his post, the search for a successor reached a stalemate today over the inability of the 134 members to decide between the two finalists.

title: Has Adultery Lost Its Comic Appeal?; Make It Dark Comedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Book Casts a Spell Over Adults; Young Wizard Is Best Seller And a Copyright Challenge
description: For a junior wizard, 11-year-old Harry Potter has stirred up quite a steaming caldron of magic -- one that has brought him fame, glory and a tiff over international copyright laws.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAIKIN, SOL CHICK
description: CHAIKIN-Sol Chick. April 1, 1991. Now and forever in our hearts and minds. We lovingly remember your intellect, humor, humility and strength. We follow the precepts and examples you established in life. Eric, Stacey, Lee and Shana

title: The Mild West: Davy Crockett Meets Armani
description: FOR 18 years Maya Lin's reputation has been etched in stone. ''Every time there was a bombing or a plane crash, I would get a fax,'' the designer of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial said. Eventually, Ms. Lin made a conscious decision to avoid being typecast ''as a person whose work concerns death and destruction.''

title: Worlds and Words Collide as Four Are Arraigned in Diallo Case
description: Opposing worlds collided yesterday as the unsealing of indictments in the Amadou Diallo case brought nearly all the players in New York City's seven-week-old political drama striding across protest lines, making pronouncements and wading through jeering and cheering crowds.

title: The Man Behind the Exams; New York's Education Chief Pushes Agenda of Change
description: When Richard P. Mills came to New York as its Education Commissioner three and a half years ago, the state had just drafted a detailed set of blueprints, contained in thick bound volumes, for how to teach nine subjects from English to science in every grade from pre-kindergarten through high school.

title: In America; Finding What Works
description: The conflict between the police and large segments of the community in New York City is worsening, not easing. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir have made the unsettling and potentially very divisive suggestion that a recent slight increase in homicides may somehow be linked to the protests against police misconduct.

title: A Cabbie's-Eye View of New York City's Streets
description: The quintessential New York experience -- a ride in a yellow taxi -- is now available on line. An 18-year veteran cabbie, Clever Da Silva (he was named after a soccer player in his native Brazil), has mounted a camera on his dashboard and is broadcasting live images from New York City streets over the Internet at two-minute intervals (www.NY-Taxi.com). Mr. Da Silva expects to have streaming video available by the end of April.

title: Prosecution Opts to Bring Top Counts For Shooting
description: In preparing the indictment of four police officers in the shooting death of Amadou Diallo, prosecutors in the Bronx faced a choice of going solely for the highest possible murder charges or including a series of lesser charges that they could fall back on later if necessary.

title: Return of the 'Heart Bill'
description: The New York State Legislature has passed and sent to the Governor a bill decreeing that any state corrections officer who comes down with a heart problem is suffering from a job-created disability and thus entitled to a tax-free pension worth three-quarters of his or her pay. The only real surprise is the timing. This is the sort of special-interest giveaway that usually gets passed under cover of the chaotic last-day race to adjournment.

title: States Keep the Lid on Gambling
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, GERTRUDE KAPLAN.
description: BERMAN-Gertrude Kaplan. 79. Of Palm Beach, FL, died March 30, 1999, after a long illness. Beloved wife for 58 years of Bennett; loving mother of Jeffrey and Helaine; sister of Leonard; and grandmother of Justin and Jordan. She was a long-time resident of Palm Beach, FL. She was a friend to many people in Palm Beach and in New York. As an active member of her community, she gave her time and support to Haddassah, the Sirocca Medical Center of Beersheva, Israel, and the Haifa University. She was a founder of Morse Geriatric Center in Palm Beach, FL, and was a founding member of the Morse Women's Auxiliary. Above all, she was a woman with a loving heart and a strong character who was devoted to her family. Funeral services will be held at Temple Israel in West Palm Beach, FL, April 4, 1999, at 11 a.m. Graveside services will be in New York at Old Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Blvd., St. Albans, Queens, NY, April 5, 1999, at 11 a.m.

title: Albanian Fighters Say They Aid NATO in Spotting Serb Targets
description: A spokesman for the Kosovo Liberation Army said today that guerrillas in Kosovo are aiding NATO forces in their bombing campaign of Serbian targets in the province.

title: Demanding Brat Meets Mild Mentor
description: It explains a great deal that Shaw wrote ''Caesar and Cleopatra,'' one of his ''Three Plays for Puritans,'' while on his honeymoon, during which he was also convalescing under his wife's ministrations from a variety of ailments that included an abscessed foot and a broken arm. His Cleopatra is a superstitious and demanding brat with violent tendencies while Caesar is a patient, mild-mannered, wise and benevolent ruler whose interest in the girl queen is only that of mentor and has nothing to do with sex.

title: Clinton's Speech on Kosovo: 'We Also Act to Prevent a Wider War'
description: Following are excerpts from an address today by President Clinton at the Norfolk Naval Air Station, provided by Federal News Service, a private transcription company:

title: Robert Chandler Jr., Agronomist, Dies at 91
description: Dr. Robert Flint Chandler Jr., a retired agronomist with the Rockefeller Foundation and a leader in the fight against hunger in Asia, died on March 23 at Waterman Hospital in Eustis, Fla. He was 91 and lived in nearby Mount Dora.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: 'Susannah' at the Met
description: Carlisle Floyd's ''Susannah'' had its Metropolitan Opera premiere on Wednesday, in a production starring Renee Fleming and Samuel Ramey, above. Though this rare example of a successful American opera is just right in size and difficulty for more modest theaters, it is dwarfed at the Met.

title: From NATO, Much Rhetoric and Few Details About the Air Strikes
description: WASHINGTON  Kenneth Bacon, the Pentagon spokesman, is as somber, cautious and understated in his press briefings as almost anyone in Washington.

title: Military Court Will Examine Soldiers' Cases
description: Three American soldiers captured along the border with Macedonia will appear before a Yugoslav military court that could charge and try them, the state news agency, Tanjug, said today.

title: Court Authorizes the State Audits That Giuliani Had Tried to Block
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani exceeded his authority when he blocked state auditors from reviewing how effectively New York City's government is managed, the state's highest court ruled yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The dollar climbed against the Japanese currency in thin pre-holiday trading as Japan's economic outlook remained bleak. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.43 yen, up from 118.97 on Wednesday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Silent Peaceniks
description: Last time, they hung white sheets from their windows. That was in 1991 when the United States started lobbing cruise missiles into Baghdad. But it was not Iraqis who were waving the traditional flag of surrender -- it was peace-minded Germans. Never mind that they were not the targets. They wanted to demonstrate their moral superiority in the face of American ''cowboy imperialism.''

title: Canary Wharf Debut Proves Lackluster
