description: Canary Wharf Group P.L.C. made a lackluster debut yesterday on the London Stock Exchange as official trading in the company, a Docklands property development group, began. Canary Wharf's shares closed at 331.5 pence -- only 1.5 pence above its offering price, set on March 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDLENER, JASON CRAIG.
description: REDLENER-Jason Craig. Dear cousin Jason, if a heart is not judged by how much you love, but by how much you are loved by others, then I will never meet anyone who was loved as much, and by so many people as you. Your sister Amy said that maybe you went to Heaven because God needed some renovation work done. I'd like to think that you are building a stairway to Heaven so that it will be easier for the rest of us to get there. Look in on us now and then. Just a smile, a wave of your hand, or make an animal sound or two. But, I'd give the world for one more of your hugs. Thanks for making me feel like part of your family. I will never forget you. John Cassese.

title: Poor Gate A Problem For Team In Florida
description: A decade ago, the Mets' spring training facility here was considered state of the art. But if attendance doesn't increase soon, the Mets could be packing for good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFMAN, SOPHIE
description: WOLFMAN-Sophie. On April 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Rita Lipton and Myra Robbins. Dear sister of Annette Goldstein. Adoring grandmother of Nina, Hunter, David and Laura Lipton, and Clare, and Bruce and Lloyd Robbins. Greatgrandmother of Kim Robbins and Harris Lipton. Services private.

title: Aomori Journal; Out of the Mist Looms, Maybe, the First Japanese
description: When he was a boy, Tomihiro Yoshizaki used to dig for arrowheads in some strange mounds of earth outside this city in northern Japan.

title: Police Accountability: a Novel Concept?
description: To the Editor:

title: China Hesitates, Then Confirms Premier's Visit
description: Angered by the NATO bombing in Yugoslavia and renewed attacks on China's human rights policies, senior Chinese officials were seriously debating on Thursday whether Prime Minister Zhu Rongji should postpone his visit to the United States, scheduled to begin next week, said a Chinese person with knowledge of the debate.

title: With Pride, Albanians Befriend Refugees
description: In a muddy outdoor recreation center in this capital city, the Albanian Army has set up 200 tents around an empty swimming pool to house 2,000 of the Kosovo refugees who poured across the border and were bused here for relocation.

title: In Diallo Case, All Sides Seek Answers in Science
description: With the indictments barely unsealed against four police officers in the Amadou Diallo shooting, a battle is already taking shape over physical evidence in the case, as lawyers and experts seek to buttress their own versions of what happened based on entrance wounds, bullet trajectories and other forensic details.

title: Hillary Clinton to Assist a Possible Rival's Fund-Raising
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has agreed to appear at a fund-raiser for Representative Nita M. Lowey, another potential candidate for a Senate seat from New York, in an effort to allay concerns that the First Lady's prospective candidacy is disrupting the fund-raising efforts of other Democratic hopefuls, party officials said yesterday.

title: More New York Banks Seen Adding an A.T.M. Surcharge
description: It's getting much harder to avoid a surcharge at the automated teller machine.

title: Koufax's Change-Up: He Talks With ESPN
description: When Sandy Koufax spoke reluctantly to Charley Steiner at the Dodgers' spring training complex in Vero Beach, Fla., 20 years ago, the interview ended when Steiner, who was then with RKO Radio, asked about the Hall of Fame left-handed pitcher's reputation for reclusiveness.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: I wouldn't be caught dead in Zanzibar after 10 P.M. And I wouldn't be missed. Zanzibar is a wildly popular new restaurant and lounge at Ninth Avenue and 45th Street. After 10, if you're there for dinner, it's like eating inside your woofer.

title: Accounts
description: * Todd Oldham Jeans, New York, part of the Sun Apparel Inc. unit of Jones Apparel Group, to RDA International, New York, as the first agency to handle the sportswear manufacturers account. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Despite Eden, Snakes Stay In Fashion
description: As lowly reptiles go, the serpent has had a remarkably high-profile career.

title: Of History, Ideals and the Art That Keeps Art Fresh
description: Despite its stately, gray-flannel title, ''To Conserve a Legacy: American Art From Historically Black Colleges and Universities'' at the Studio Museum in Harlem is a lively and provocative crazy quilt of an exhibition, with so many shades, layers and conceptual angles that it's hard to know what to pay attention to first.

title: CADMUS COMMUNICATIONS AGREES TO BUY MACK PRINTING
description: The Cadmus Communications Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Mack Printing Group for $200 million in cash, stock and debt. Cadmus, based in Richmond, said the acquisition of the privately held Mack would increase its annual revenue by more than 40 percent and solidify its position as the world's leading producer of scientific, technical and medical journals. Mack Printing, based in Easton, Pa., prints more than 500 scientific, medical and technical journals and has annual revenue of about $165 million. Cadmus has annual revenue of about $400 million.

title: Walking Along a Crooked Path
description: Manipulating time and fate are ways to turn even a trite narrative into something startling. And these methods have become more pervasive as filmmaking adjusts to the arbitrary logic of the interactive game. So the same kinds of chronology tricks that have influenced films as different as ''Sliding Doors,'' ''The Matrix'' and ''Run Lola Run,'' the last an opening-night feature at the New Directors/New Films series, now shape another work in this festival, ''Following,'' a black-and-white film noir with a difference. The usual elements of scheming and deception are well represented here, but they are made all the knottier by shifting time frames.

title: There's a Catch on Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Promise, and Pitfalls, of Fuel Cells
description: FUEL cells, devices that produce electricity from hydrogen with only water as a byproduct, are emerging as the auto industry's darling technology of the future -- the most promising alternative to the internal-combustion engine. Manufacturers are racing to become the first to put such a vehicle on the market.

title: Monday Night Games at 9
description: ''Monday Night Football'' will return on ABC for its 30th season in its customary 9 P.M. Eastern starting time and without the roundly criticized pre-game show that emanated from ESPN's noisy Sports Zone bar in Baltimore.

title: Fund Accountant Faces Charges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had filed administrative charges against Carroll A. Wallace, an accountant with KPMG L.L.C., stemming from the S.E.C.'s investigation of the Rockies Fund Inc.

title: New Video Releases
description: Beloved

title: West Talks of Plan to Rebuild Kosovo as Protected Enclave
description: Western officials are discussing a plan under which NATO troops would escort ethnic Albanians back into Kosovo after Serbian forces there have been routed by bombing, and would set up a self-governing enclave under allied protection, a senior NATO diplomat said today.

title: A Giddy Bacchanalia of Imagery and Explosions
description: There is new if temporary treasure to be found at the Museum of Modern Art right now, and it lies at the center of the engrossing, challenging exhibition of early drawings by the German painter Sigmar Polke. The third gallery in this show, which has been organized by Margit Rowell, chief curator of drawings, and is devoted to works from 1963 to 1974, presents only four drawings, all dated 1969-71.

title: Report Finds Shared Guilt Inside Kosovo
description: A report to the United Nations Human Rights Commission today accused both Serbian and Albanian forces of committing numerous killings and other atrocities in Kosovo before NATO began its air strikes.

title: It's Official: BP Is Planning To Buy ARCO
description: BP Amoco, which is still integrating the oil giant Amoco, officially announced its acquisition of the Atlantic Richfield Company yesterday and said it would cut about 2,000 jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOUNT, LESTER A., M.D.
description: MOUNT-Lester A., M.D. Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and New York Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of Lester A. Mount, professor emeritus and consultant emeritus of clinical neurosurgery. A worldwide lecturer, he made many outstanding contributions to medical education, research, and practice in the field of neurosurgery. An author, he published in many books and journals. An esteemed colleague and teacher, he served Columbia Presbyterian for more than 50 years as a professor of clinical neurosurgery and acting chairman of the Department of Neurosurgery at the Neurological Institute. In 1989, he received the highest award given by the American Association of Neurological Surgeons, the Harvey Cushing Medal. His commitment to improving the lives of patients was unsurpassed, and his work in the management of subarachnoid hemorhage and intracranial aneurysms was invaluable to the world's understanding of neurosurgery. A long-time friend and colleague whose many contributions enriched the Neurological Institute, he will be greatly missed and his memory cherished. We extend our deepest sympathy to Dr. Mount's family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. Vice President for Health Sciences & Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons David B. Skinner, M.D. Vice Chairman and CEO New York Presbyterian Hospital William T. Speck, M.D. President & COO New York Presbyterian Hospital

description: ''A lot of people say the

description: BASKETBALL

title: Senator Eases Opposition to Encryption Software Exports
description: In a surprising about-face, Senator John McCain said this week that he was abandoning his support for the Clinton Administration's policy requiring that law enforcement agencies be given keys enabling them to unlock scrambled data.

title: Sehorn Tests Knee (Just Don't Tell Giants)
description: Jason Sehorn, recovering from major reconstructive knee surgery, didn't tell the Giants he was planning to defend his championship in the ''Superstars'' competition when it was held last month in Jamaica.

title: Referee's Jury Award Is Severely Reduced
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan reduced an $8 million jury award to $350,000 yesterday for a woman who was passed over as a National Basketball Association referee.

title: Free Spirits Cope With the Demands of Their Faith
description: FOR THE RELIEF OF UNBEARABLE URGES

title: BHI AND CARLISLE HOLDINGS SAY THEY PLAN TO MERGE
description: The BHI Corporation said yesterday that it planned to merge with Carlisle Holdings P.L.C. and that the newly formed company would make a bid of up to $454.5 million in cash and stock for Corporate Services Group P.L.C., the troubled British contract-employment concern. BHI said that Carlisle shareholders would receive one share of the new company for every 43.058 Carlisle shares and that BHI shareholders would receive two shares of the new company for each BHI share. Carlisle, a staffing and maintenance-services company, and BHI, a banking and maintenance-services company, are investment vehicles of Michael Ashcroft, the Florida businessman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARR, KATHERINE
description: FARR-Katherine. Beloved wife of the late William Farr and the late Sidney Zweig. Beloved mother of Martin E. (Barbara) Zweig, The Money Manager from ''Wall Street Week With Louis Rukeyser''. Loving grandmother of Zack and Alex Zweig. Also survived by Mollie Zweig. Sister of Perry (Ethel) Schwartz. Martin Zweig will receive visitors on Monday evening, April 5 at the Harmonie Club, 4 E. 60 St from 6-9pm

title: Nets Win a Big One, But Williams Is Lost
description: These are ill-fated times for the Nets. After numerous injuries, the firing of their coach and disappointing play, their finest victory of the season tonight was overshadowed by a season-ending injury to Jayson Williams, their top rebounder and spiritual leader.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR DROPS. Sugar prices fell more than 5 percent on persistent concern that a global glut will overwhelm weak demand. In New York, sugar for May delivery fell 0.32 cent, to 5.59 cents a pound.

title: New methods of agency payments drive a stake through the heart of the old 15% commission.
description: THE 15 percent commission on media spending that clients pay advertising agencies as their fee was once standard in the advertising business. Now it is about as dead as the three-martini lunch.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about candidates' efforts to win the votes of Israeli Arabs in the Israeli election on May 17 misidentified a town visited this week by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. It was Shefaram, not Shfayim.

title: There's a Catch on Social Security; A Fairer Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Seven Strolls In the Sky
description: As a city walker ever in search of new paths, especially those close to water, I decided to explore the pedestrian walks on New York bridges.

title: Lawyers in Louima Case at Odds Over Evidence
description: Prosecutors in the trial of four police officers accused of brutalizing Abner Louima asked a judge yesterday to restrict defense lawyers in their handling of evidence the prosecution is required to turn over to them, and the lawyers responded that the restrictions would hinder their efforts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELSON, COL. NATHANIEL O.
description: ABELSON-Col. Nathaniel O. The Veteran Corps of Artillery, State of New York, records with sorrow the passing of our comrade Colonel Nathaniel O. Abelson on March 30, 1999. John E. Connelly, III MG, Commandant

description: Bobby Stewart did not like almost being the goat. So the senior wing from Maine decided to be a hero.

description: To the Editor:

title: Company Killer or Retail Guru?; An Executive's Often Painful Path Through 4 Businesses
description: As 1997 began, J. Peterman, the catalogue retailer known for its quirky merchandise, seemed poised for big things. For starters, in an astonishing public-relations windfall, the super-sitcom ''Seinfeld'' was featuring even more episodes in which the character Elaine worked for the company. Peterman had also just won the rights to sell reproductions of the clothes and jewelry worn in the movie ''Titanic.''

title: Julie Heffernan
description: P.P.O.W. Gallery

title: Courtroom Broadcasts
description: Senator Charles Schumer, the New York Democrat, has teamed up with a Republican colleague, Charles Grassley of Iowa, to address a nagging affront to open government -- the bar against televising Federal court proceedings. Their newly proposed ''sunshine in the courtroom'' bill would give Federal trial and appellate judges discretion to allow unobtrusive cameras to cover proceedings in their courtrooms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALLENT, WILLIAM J., DDS.
description: TALLENT-William J., DDS. Offices in East Tremont section of Bronx for 51 years, Wednesday, March 31, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Matilda M. (nee Witte). Loving father of Mary Louise Chudd and Barbara Zigarelli. Also survived by six grandchildren. Funeral from Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Ave., Bronx, on Monday, April 5, at 10:00 AM. Mass of Christian burial St. Benedict's Church at 10:30 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. Visiting Saturday 2:00-5:00 and 7:009:30, and Sunday 7:00-9:30.

title: When Two Would Be a Crowd: The Case of the Missing S.U.V.
description: IT woke up to be the king of the hill and the top of the heap, but the Ford Excursion, the world's largest sport utility vehicle, is not coming to New York, New York. At least it will not make it there for the New York auto show, which opens tomorrow at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARNOWICH, YETTA, KATZ
description: ARNOWICH-Yetta, KATZSteven. In cherished memory of a beloved mother and a devoted grandnephew. Jeann

title: A Petite 'Susannah' In a Great Big House
description: ''Susannah, Susannah!'' one felt like calling out. ''What's a nice girl like you doing in a place like this?'' Such a big opera house, such a little opera.

title: Refugees Tell of Methodical Emptying of Pristina
description: In a chilling display of force, Serb gunmen are systematically emptying Kosovo's capital city, Pristina, marching its ethnic Albanians out through gantlets of masked, heavily armed Serbs, refugees crossing the border today said.

title: Jean Blackburn
description: Deven Golden Fine Art

title: Optimism Over the Internet's Growth Leads Shares Higher
description: Stocks rose yesterday as Yahoo's acquisition of Broadcast.com raised expectations for consolidation in the on-line industry and lifted prices for SBC Communications and other telephone companies on optimism that the Internet's growth will increase demand for data transmission.

title: One Year Later, Doping Scandal Resurfaces in Belgium and France
description: The drug scandal in professional bicycle racing erupted on two fronts today, with the Belgian police yanking the top-ranked professional team out of a race and the announcement that one of the sport's top officials is under criminal investigation in France.

title: There's a Catch on Social Security; Saving, in Other Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Views on State Police Sharply Divided by Race
description: Views on whether the state police do a good job and on whether troopers engage in racial profiling are sharply divided by race, according to a Quinnipiac College poll released yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: IMMULOGIC PHARMACEUTICAL CORP., Waltham, Mass., which specializes in developing vaccines for substance abuse, said it would liquidate the company and return nearly $37 million to shareholders.

title: RWE and Veba to Sell Venture
description: The German utilities RWE A.G. and Veba A.G. said today that they had agreed to sell the fixed-line business of their phone venture Otelo to Mannesmann Arcor for 2.25 billion marks, or $1.24 billion.

title: S.E.C. Investigating Security Price Manipulation in London
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether a portfolio manager at Oechsle International Advisers, a Boston money management firm, tried last year to manipulate the price of a security traded on the London Stock Exchange.

title: Clinton, Appealing for Public Support, Says Milosevic Is Accountable for G.I.'s Safety
description: Denouncing the Serbs' capture of three American soldiers, President Clinton vowed forcefully today to pursue the Balkan bombing campaign and appealed to the nation for ''determination and resolve.''

title: In Surprise Move, Gotti Asks to Be Returned to Jail
description: Six months after he won a hard-fought battle to be released on bail for $10 million, John A. Gotti stunned a Federal courtroom today when he asked a judge to put him back behind bars.

title: Rollicking Best Friends, Until a Man Steps In
description: ''The Dreamlife of Angels'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 9. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Dark Yarns Casting Light
description: If a story is told well enough, you'll follow it anywhere, even when it's leading you to places you never intended to go. Take the plain-spoken, utterly alluring tales unfolded by the denizens of the rural Irish bar in ''The Weir,'' Conor McPherson's beautiful and devious new play at the Walter Kerr Theater. At first, they seem to beckon like comfortingly well-worn paths into realms of folklore both exotic and familiar, Gaelic variations on the sorts of campfire ghost stories you recall from childhood.

title: On My Mind; Exporting Kosovo
description: Buoyed by their role in helping turn a Balkan civil war into shivering, desolate, crowds of refugees, a political booby trap for America unmatched since Vietnam, a perversion of NATO purpose and a planning debacle, the 15 nations of the European Union are now trying to export their collective political wisdom to shape the Mideast, which may God in Heaven forfend.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: There's Trouble In Revival City

title: Flurry of Economic Reports Suggests Growth Is Not at Risk
description: Manufacturing strengthened in March as consumer spending on automobiles, computers and furniture remained strong and export orders grew for a second month.

title: There's a Catch on Social Security; Undermining the System
description: To the Editor:

title: Brakes Being Put on Reckless Skiers
description: Whizzing down Crescendo and cutting across Swinger, hot-shot skiers and snowboarders on these intermediate slopes now run into a speed trap on snow. Yellow banners suddenly caution: ''Speed control in progress'' and ''No Warnings.''

title: Gasoline Prices Jump 12%
description: United States retail gasoline prices surged 12 percent in the last two weeks, according to a survey by the American Automobile Association. The 11.8-cent rise in the average price of regular self-serve gasoline to $1.088 a gallon, as of Tuesday, was the largest increase for any survey period since gas prices surged 23.2 cents in August 1990 after Iraq invaded Kuwait. The association's surveys are usually issued monthly, though this report was for the two weeks that ended on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESCON, FLORENCE
description: MESCON-Florence on March 27, 1999 in Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved wife of Howard. Devoted mother of Richard and Michael. Dear mother in law of Miriam. Cherished grandmother of Andrew, Jennie, David, Daniel and Hannah. Adored sister of Shirley Leitstein and aunt of Robert, Alex and Bruce Leitstein. We will hold her in our loving memory forever. A graveside service will be held at 10:30am on Friday, April 2 at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Saw Mill River Road, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

title: Prosecutors of 4 Police Officers Have Few Examples to Guide Them
description: No New York City police officer has ever been convicted of murder for actions in the line of duty, police officials and criminal justice experts said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article on March 19 about a House vote on a system to defend against missiles referred incorrectly to R. James Woolsey, a member of a panel that briefed the House on the issue. Mr. Woolsey, a Washington lawyer who has served as Director of Central Intelligence and Under Secretary of the Navy, has never been an admiral.

title: The Theater District
description: Frequently asked question: Where can I eat near the theater district? Here are a dozen options. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: On Kosovo, Time For New Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORRENTE, LINDA
description: CORRENTE-Linda. Editor, graphic designer, and former member of the Literature Panel of the New York State Council on the Arts, died at home on March 28 to the profound sorrow of her family and that wide circle of friends whose lives she touched. A.B., with honors, 1975, Mount Holyoke College; M.F.A., 1977, Columbia University. In 1987, with Daryln Brewer Hoffstot, she launched Poets & Writers Magazine, the largest non-profit literary trade magazine in the United States. She is survived by her husband, Starling Lawrence, and her step-children, Dune, Peter, and Joshua; also by her mother, Jane Corrente, her brother Robert, her sisters Susan Corrente and Martha Moutafis, her nephews Simon and Matthew, and nieces Michaela and Celia. Memorial service in the Congregational Church, Norfolk, CT, at noon on Saturday, April 17. In lieu of flowers, and to honor her love of birds, donations to The Francis Beidler Forest, 336 Sanctuary Rd., Harleyville, South Carolina 29446 (The Four Holes Swamp Audubon Sanctuary).

title: INSIDE
description: Murdoch in Sports Deal

title: Douglas Gordon: 'Through a Looking Glass'
description: Gagosian Gallery

title: People
description: * Mike Amour, managing director for Europe at TBWA Worldwide, Paris, a unit of Omnicom Group, was named to the new post of executive vice president and business development director in New York.

title: Nazi Crimes Bring Man 2 Life Terms In Britain
description: For more than 50 years, Anthony Sawoniuk lived a quiet existence in Britain, settling in South London and earning a modest living as a railway cleaner and ticket collector. But he was a man harboring dark secrets from the distant past, and they have finally caught up with him.

title: On Kosovo, Time For New Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Setting a Schedule Is the Next Legal Step
description: Now that the four police officers charged with killing Amadou Diallo have been arraigned, the next step in the legal process will come at the end of the month, when their lawyers and Bronx prosecutors are to appear before a judge to set a schedule for the pretrial proceedings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, CARL
description: EHRLICH-Carl. Cherished husband of Helen. Devoted father of Richard and Ruth, Michael and Susan, Amy and Joseph Fins. Adoring grandfather of Joseph and Robert, Daniel and Jacob. Caring brother-in-law of Jefferson B. Cohen. A man of great character. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 9:30 AM Friday. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Temple Emanu-El of Lynbrook or City Harvest.

title: Not Exactly A Familiar Italian Touch
description: Modernworks was founded only two years ago, but anyone who attends new-music concerts regularly will know most of its players. Madeline Shapiro is its director and cellist, and on Monday evening, when the group played a concert of 20th-century Italian works at Lang Recital Hall at Hunter College, the roster also included Ora Orhenstein, the soprano, Judith Pearce, the flutist, Jean Kopperud, the clarinetist, David Taylor, the trombonist, Conrad Harris and Wolfgang Tsoutsouris, violinists, Veronica Salas, violist, and Philip Bush, pianist.

title: When Stately Homes Were 'Public' Libraries
description: A Stately Home in 18th-century England simply had to have a library. Whether small or very grand (like the one designed by Robert Adam for the Earl of Bute at Luton Hoo in Bedfordshire, 144 feet long with 30,000 books) it would hold treasures from past and present, meaty texts on robust paper with engraved illustrations, encased in fine bindings. And the use of such a library would not be exclusively reserved for its owners: long before public libraries came into being, it was a given that country ministers, doctors, lawyers, even a schoolchild in search of enlightenment could browse among the books of the local manor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANDE, SARINA
description: GRANDE-Sarina, on March 30, 1999. Patron of the arts and opera. Listed in Who's Who of American Women and very active in ItalianAmerican charitable organizations. Beloved wife of the late Frank Grande. Sister of Santa D'Angelo and the late Carmelo and Liborio D'Amato. Aunt of Marie Kallmeyer, Aimee Wallas and the late Frank D'Amato, and great-aunt of five nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Friday, 7-9 PM, and Saturday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Saviour Church, Park Ave. at 38th St., Monday, 10 AM. Interment to follow.

title: Shift Expected In Top Post Of Complex In Manhattan
description: Gov. George E. Pataki will appoint Timothy S. Carey, the state's top consumer protection official, to head the agency that runs the Battery Park City development in lower Manhattan, administration officials said today.

title: Hachette Names New Publishers
description: Hachette Filipacchi Magazines in New York, a unit of Lagardere Group, said yesterday that it had named new publishers at four of its magazines.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Making Good On a Promise

title: William Henry Dial, 91, a Disney Ally in Florida
description: William Henry Dial, a lawyer, banker and civic leader in Florida who helped reinvent Orlando, a little town of citrus groves, as a vacation and convention mecca known the world over, died on March 23 at his home in Orlando. He was 91.

title: Few Details in 'Stomach Turning' Case
description: In the 10 days since a young woman ran terrified and naked down a gravel street here in southwestern New Mexico and told a harrowing tale of rape, torture and escape, the authorities have repeatedly hinted at even worse horrors inside the double-wide trailer home at 513 Bass Road.

title: A Reading of 'Novelettes' Divided Into Two Chapters
description: Schumann, at least the young Schumann, composed in short episodes linked by key, theme or simple force of will. The ''Novelettes'' are no different, only more prolific. One vignette fades into the next, and after three-quarters of an hour one is overwhelmed by the sheer volume of them. Think of the composer as a stringer of beads: necklaces like the ''Papillons'' or ''Kreisleriana'' fit nicely around the neck. The ''Novelettes'' hang somewhat clumsily to the floor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, RUTH V.
description: FISHER-Ruth V. On March 31, 1999 in Aventura, Fla. at the age of 88. A 1st grade teacher in the NYC public schools for over 30 years, she continued to give generously in service to her community in retirement. Loving mother of daughter, Jody (Joan) Young and son-in-law Larry Young. She was also proud grandmother of Eliot, Leslie, and Robert Young and GG (great-grandmother) to Josh and Evan Young. She joins her husband of 58 years (Samuel G. Fisher) who died in 1991. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Quincy Bog Natural Area, Rumney, NH 03266.

title: 'The Woodcut Print'
description: Marlborough Gallery

title: Lottery Hooks Gamblers, And Albany
description: FOR the first time in nearly four years, New Yorkers were unable yesterday to throw money away on a state-run numbers game that made life tougher for some people with gambling problems.

title: Murder 101, In High School
description: Teen-agers misbehave in droves on screen these days, but for extreme juvenile delinquency the ground was broken a decade ago in ''Heathers,'' Michael Lehmann's controversial film about a pair of originals who righteously liquidate those who displease them.

title: Touring European Art Songs In a Bass-Baritone's Debut
description: Vocal debut recitals have something in common with Olympic figure skating. Much as a skater executes a sequence of technical feats, ideally arranged in a way that makes balletic or narrative sense, singers' introductory programs tend to be self-consciously varied, assembled to touch on different styles and languages and emotional temperatures. Both balance athleticism and artistry; they just use different muscles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYNG, LILA HOTZ.
description: TYNG-Lila Hotz. On March 31 at the age of 100 years and 5 days. Born in Chicago, she died at her home, Lu Shan, Gladstone, NJ. Beloved mother of Henry Luce, III and Peter Paul Luce; mother-inlaw of Leila Hadley Luce and Elizabeth Bardsley Luce; grandmother of Lila Luce, H. Christopher Luce, Meredith Luce Billingsley, Elisabeth Luce, Christena McNicol and Clare Abbey. Memorial service 4PM Thursday, April 8, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Ave. at 73rd St. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Spence School, 22 East 91 St, NY, NY 10028, would be appreciated. She will be interred at Graceland Cemetery, Chicago.

title: Public-Hospital Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Protecting DiMaggio's Dignity
description: JOE DiMAGGIO once had a question for Morris Engelberg, his lawyer who lived next door to him in Florida.

title: ALLIES HIT TROOPS AND BRIDGE; SERBS MAY TRY 3 CAPTURED G.I.'S
description: Allied forces today destroyed a bridge over the Danube River in Serbia and attacked a Serbian mechanized column that had been involved in the purges in Kosovo, Pentagon officials said.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Ogden Buying Theme Park
description: The Ogden Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Raging Waters, a 50-acre amusement park in San Dimas, Calif., with 25 water-themed rides and slides. Terms were not disclosed. Earlier this month, the New York-based Ogden said it would break its three business lines into two separately traded public companies to prop up its lagging stock price. One company will consist of Ogden's entertainment and aviation services business, and a second will be made up of its energy operations.

title: GILLETTE SAYS WHITE RAIN SHAMPOO BUSINESS IS FOR SALE
description: The Gillette Company, the world's largest maker of razors and blades, said yesterday that it planned to sell its White Rain shampoo business and focus on premium-priced consumer products that are market leaders. Gillette, which also makes Duracell batteries, Oral-B toothbrushes and Braun appliances, said it was getting in touch with potential buyers, which it would not identify. The sale would include a St. Paul factory that employs about 340 people. White Rain, a low-priced shampoo that has about $100 million in annual sales in the United States and Canada, does not fit with Gillette's focus on higher-priced products like its Mach3 razor that are sold worldwide, a spokesman said.

title: Discovery Bolsters a Hope for Regeneration
description: The concept of regenerative medicine -- using the body's own stem cells and growth factors to repair tissues -- has come closer to reality with a discovery about the special human cells from which all bone and connective tissues are derived.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a plan by the Mercantile Bancorporation to lay off 750 employees was outdated. The planned layoffs were initially disclosed and reported in January. They were repeated in a recent regulatory filing, not announced anew.

title: Patience and Tenacity in Kosovo
description: As the setbacks mount in Kosovo, including the capture of three American servicemen, it has become clear that this conflict will not produce another lightning military victory for the United States. For a superpower lately grown accustomed to swift, decisive and relatively bloodless military ventures abroad, the war in Kosovo seems likely to require great patience and a high tolerance for uncertainty. That is especially true for President Clinton and his advisers, who must resist the temptation to react to every battlefield reversal with an instant, improvised escalation of combat.

title: NATIONAL GOLF BUYS 21 COURSES AND SECURES CREDIT LINE
description: National Golf Properties Inc. said yesterday that it had bought 21 golf courses for $176.2 million from a venture that includes a company led by its chairman. National Golf, a real estate investment trust based in Santa Monica, Calif., also said it had secured a $300 million line of credit to help pay for the purchase and to repay $93 million of debt. The purchase expands National Golf's holdings to 151 courses in 26 states. The golf courses were among 45 owned by Cobblestone Golf Group, which was acquired on Wednesday for $393 million by a venture of the American Golf Corporation and Clubcorp Inc. American Golf is led by National Golf's chairman, David G. Price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITTELSTADT, MONICA
description: MITTELSTADT-Monica. See notice under PROUNIS-Monica Mittelstadt.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a personal computer being offered by the Microworkz Corporation for $299 misstated one of the details of the offer. It does indeed include Microsoft Windows 98 software.

title: Just in Time, Rowland Reaches an Agreement on Stadium Site
description: Gov. John G. Rowland announced today that he had reached a tentative agreement to remove a steam plant on the proposed site of a stadium for the New England Patriots, but warned that other pitfalls could lie ahead.

title: From Altman, a Salome Story With Southern Sugar and Spite
description: The sweet assurance and guerrilla wit of Robert Altman's vintage ensemble films makes a serenely captivating return with ''Cookie's Fortune.'' In this seamlessly copacetic treat, Mr. Altman once again dreams up a well-rounded community of symbiotic oddballs, then effortlessly lures the viewer into their world. With a fine cast working on a single, nicely eccentric wavelength, he and the screenwriter Anne Rapp turn picturesque Holly Springs, Miss., into a hotbed of grudges, power struggles, family secrets and historical footnotes, all presented with the same rueful overview. ''On this site in 1897,'' reads a sardonic sign in the local liquor store, ''nothing happened.''

title: Barry McGee: 'The Buddy System'
description: Deitch Projects

title: 3 New Executives At Merkley Newman
description: Merkley Newman Harty in New York, part of Omnicom Group, said yesterday that three new executives had joined the agency to handle its recently awarded account for Mercedes-Benz of North America, as its chief creative officer departs.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Wild (and Unleashed) Coyote Is Captured in Central Park
description: He was first spotted Tuesday night by an alert police officer. The next night, he was spotted again, and dozens of officers were called in to join the search. As a police helicopter buzzed overhead, he emerged from the brambles, running furiously. And then, he was gone.

title: United States Takes On Britain
description: In 1900, when a young, patrician American named Dwight Davis first challenged the British to a team tennis competition, the British accepted a visit to the United States, but their best players, Laurie and Reginald Doherty, did not attend.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: The Diallo Case Unfolds
description: Now that the Amadou Diallo case has moved into the courts with the arrests of four white policemen, a calm should begin settling over the streets outside New York City's government offices. Demonstrators, who have been venting their anger over Mr. Diallo's death in a barrage of 41 police bullets, have made their mark, elevating their fears about local police tactics into a national issue. Minorities have sent City Hall a clear message that no one in their neighborhoods should be forced to exchange the fear of crime for a fear of police.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: U.S. Agents Seeking Clues To Who Made E-Mail Virus
description: Federal agents hunting for the author of the Melissa computer virus obtained a court order yesterday seeking background information from America Online, one day after seizing a computer from a Florida Internet access provider that may hold clues to the origin of the virus.

title: Foreign Affairs; Bomb and Call in George Mitchell
description: Have you ever played one of those video arcade games where you try to shoot as many targets as you can in a set period of time? When you start such a game a little sign flashes up and asks: ''One Player or Two?'' Well, the Clinton team's approach to the Kosovo crisis reminds me of such a game. The U.S. put a quarter in, pressed ''One Player,'' and took aim against the Serbian armed forces. Unfortunately, it forgot that war is an interactive game and that somebody else was playing -- someone able to run up the score on us.

title: Pro Bono Accounts
description: * The New York Police Department to Arnell Group Brand Consulting, New York, as the first agency to handle recruiting campaigns aimed at minority residents for the department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, HERBERT P.
description: FRANK-Herbert P. On March 31, 1999 at the age of 89. Beloved husband of the late Gwen, loving father of Ellen and Lee. Cherished grandfather of Lisa, Wendy, John, Stephen and Julie and great grandfather of Carly. President of Washington Beef Company, Inc. since 1940, founded by his father in 1904. Funeral service at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 79th Street and 2nd Ave on Friday, April 2nd, 11:30am.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ARTHUR T.
description: KATZ-Arthur T. Died peacefully on Thursday morning. Beloved husband and best friend of Ruth. Loving father of Steven, Paul (Yoko) John (Tracy) and proud grandfather of Jed and Spencer. Brother of Alice (Marty) and Richard (Verna) and dear uncle. Graduate of Dartmouth 1956, former president of Holbrook Shirt Company and later involved with commercial real estate with Edward S. Gordon. Service at Gutterman's, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, 12 noon Sunday April 4, 1999. In lieu of flowers donations to The American Cancer Society.

title: Doctor in Embryo Mix-Up Is Cited Over Another Case
description: With state health officials investigating the case of an embryo mix-up that caused a Staten Island woman who underwent in vitro fertilization to give birth to a black baby and a white baby, the Manhattan doctor who performed the procedure has been cited in another case for collecting donor eggs without a license.

title: Jets Getting Featured TV Treatment
description: The 1999 National Football League schedule features the Jets on ''Monday Night Football'' three times and once on national television Sunday night. On Dec. 5 at Giants Stadium, the Jets will play the Giants, who open their season on the road -- against Tampa Bay -- for the first time in six years.

title: Tactics of '95 Bosnia Crisis May Not Fit Kosovo Case
description: One perception driving the Clinton Administration's strategy of carrying out punishing NATO air strikes against Slobodan Milosevic is the idea that the only language he understands is force.

title: Mortgage Costs Could Ambush the U.S. Economy
description: Charles Gradante and his wife, Lee, were on the verge of refinancing their co-op on Sutton Place in Manhattan late last year, but a big remodeling project so consumed them that they failed to get around to it.

title: SERVICE CORP. TO CUT JOBS AND TAKE $100 MILLION CHARGE
description: The Service Corporation International, the world's largest funeral-home and cemetery owner, plans to take first-quarter pretax charges of as much as $112.1 million for cost cuts, including 800 job cuts, and repurchase of a note. The company said yesterday that it would take $80 million to $90 million in pretax charges for severance costs, business and facility closings and that it had terminated acquisition and construction activities. The job cuts, about 3 percent of its work force, came mostly in France. It will also take a pretax charge of $22.1 million for buying back $200 million of floating-rate notes. Service Corporation's shares fell 93.75 cents, to $13.3125.

title: There's a Catch on Social Security; A Nickel a Share
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: American League

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Relationship Transcends Politics

title: Baffert Is Set to Put Colts and Fillies to the Litmus Test
description: His star 3-year-old colt, Exploit, has been retired. His instant star, Straight Man, was unbeaten until he ran fourth last Saturday at Turfway Park. His all-purpose star, General Challenge, ran fifth in the Louisiana Derby last time out. And his star fillies, Excellent Meeting and Silverbulletday, seem likely to race mainly against other fillies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNELLY, THOMAS F.
description: DONNELLY-Thomas F. Age 81, of Port Washington, L.I. on April 1, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Dr. Marguerite. Loving father of Marguerite, Hugh, Mary E. Donnelly and Anne Florio. Devoted grandfather of Anne, Laura, Aidan, and Mara. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc Funeral Home, 128 Main St, Port Washington. Visiting hours Saturday 2-4 and 7-9pm, Monday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Tuesday 10:30am St. Peter of Alcantara. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale.

title: Canada's Eskimos Get a Land of Their Own
description: A bold attempt to right past wrongs and bring hope to an entire region was launched as this day began and the map of Canada was redrawn to make room for the new territory of Nunavut.

title: For Rangers, Defending Mighty Ducks Is a Top Priority
description: With the Rangers uncertain of the status of Petr Nedved for the final eight games of the regular season, the first of which is Friday night against the Mighty Ducks at Madison Square Garden, they are focusing instead on things that they can attempt to control.

title: Residential Real Estate; Manhattan Apartments Drawing New Wave of Foreign Buyers
description: As Manhattan's robust housing market continues to attract a steady number of foreign buyers, the main change is where those buyers are from.

title: Police Accountability: a Novel Concept?
description: To the Editor:

title: Janine Antoni: 'Imbed'
description: Luhring Augustine

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Passover and Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: OUTDOORS; Cast Off: City Slickers Pursue Trout
description: Amid the backdrop of sprawling country estates and gleaming Range Rovers, anglers came out in force yesterday to participate in the traditional opening of the New York State trout season.

title: Murdoch Said To Be in Deal With Liberty
description: Rupert Murdoch is taking a strong step toward increasing his hold over sports programming, agreeing to buy out the 50 percent stake owned by John C. Malone's Liberty Media in a venture that controls a dozen regional sports networks, according to people close to the transaction. As part of the deal, they said, the News Corporation will also double its stake in the New York Knicks, Rangers, Madison Square Garden and Radio City Music Hall to 40 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVIDON, ARCHIE
description: AVIDON-Archie. On March 29,1999. Beloved husband of the late Betty. Cherished father of Florence & Louise. Dear brother of Ruth. Devoted Grandpa of Susannah, Deborah, Sarah, David, Miriam, Naomi & Andrew. Great grandfather of seven. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Another Misplay Puts Irabu on Hot Seat
description: Hideki Irabu failed to cover first base on an innocent grounder to the right side today, and what should have been the final out of the exhibition season in Florida turned into another misadventure for the beleaguered Yankee pitcher.

title: CBS to Buy King World in $2.5 Billion Deal
description: CBS Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy King World Productions Inc., the syndicator of television hits like ''The Oprah Winfrey Show,'' ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Jeopardy,'' for $2.5 billion in stock.

title: Photographic Memories
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Still a Cadet, but Already Proven in the Field
description: ALISON JONES is two months away from graduating from the United States Military Academy, itching to go to Kosovo and battle-tested in a way that few cadets are when they leave the crenelated walls of West Point.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: PRISONERS

title: FAMILY FARE
description: What's Up, Doc? It's Easter!

title: Former Team Official Recounts the A.B.L.'s Dizzying Descent
description: Allison Hodges had faith in the American Basketball League.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUP, LOUIS, (LOUIE).
description: KRUP-Louis, (Louie). On March 30, 1999. Devoted husband to the late Mollie. Loving father to Arlene Hirschler, Rita Weissberg, Phyllis Engelberg and son-in-law Betzalel Engelberg. Cherished grandfather of Peter, Mitchell (Karen); Hillary, (Mauricio); Rebekah, (Tom); Ron; Keren; Maya and Danna. Very special great-grandfather of Jamie, Jake, Adam and Ariana. Louie was a pioneer in the discount appliance business and ran a successful business in New York City for over 60 years. He was also active in the Jewish community and served as president and president emeritus of Congregation Zichron Moshe. He will missed by all who knew him. Services Sunday at 11:00 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Student Smoking Declines Amid a State Campaign
description: One year after Florida started a statewide educational anti-tobacco campaign intended for teen-agers, smoking among middle school students has declined by the largest margin observed in the United States in almost 20 years, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported today.

title: Girls Loved Him, Pedophile or Not
description: ''His were sad, scrawny little nymphets, bedraggled and half-undressed, or rather semi-undraped, as if participating in some dusty and dreadful charade,'' said Vladimir Nabokov, the Russian translator of Lewis Carroll's ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland.'' Nabokov noticed ''a pathetic affinity'' between Carroll, who photographed little girls clothed and naked, and Humbert Humbert, the pedophilic narrator of his own ''Lolita.''

title: Moscow, Seeking Role, Asks Again for Talks
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin fired off another peace offensive today, even as a Russian military reconnaissance ship was heading into the Mediterranean in a open demonstration of Moscow's anti-NATO stance in the Yugoslavia conflict.

title: Finding Room for More Than One Faith at Passover Table
description: As thousands of Jews gathered on Wednesday night in homes around the city for traditional Passover seders, worshipers at the United Spiritual Church of God, a Guyanese storefront church in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, celebrated Passover in their own way: praising Jesus Christ, dancing ecstatically to Caribbean and African rhythms and eating a decidedly non-Jewish seder meal.

title: Woman Agrees to Prison For Fatal Car Crash
description: A woman who was driving drunk when she sped into a tree, killing six children in the car, would serve at least 17 years in prison under a guilty plea agreement she entered yesterday, the Camden County prosecutor said.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Now Nixon The Comedy

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Clinton Says U.S. 'Takes Care of Its Own' : Milosevic Is Warned Not to Mistreat Captives
description: WASHINGTON  President Bill Clinton gravely warned President Slobodan Milosevic on Thursday that the United States would hold him responsible for the safety of three U.S. soldiers captured near the Macedonia-Yugoslav border. He said NATO would pursue its air campaign undeterred.

title: Police Shoot Teen-Ager They Say Pointed Gun
description: A police sergeant who was trying to issue a summons to a teen-ager for drinking on a downtown Brooklyn street corner yesterday shot him three times after the youth pointed a gun at the sergeant during a struggle, the authorities said.

title: Graenum Berger, 90; Aided Ethiopian Jews
description: Graenum Berger, an American who campaigned long and successfully for having Ethiopia's Falashas, who are also called Ethiopian Jews, transported to Israel, died on Wednesday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 90.

title: Divided Missouri to Vote on a Right to Carry Concealed Guns
description: In what both sides of the gun debate here are calling a momentous showdown, Missouri will be the first state to let voters decide in a statewide referendum next week whether to allow people to carry concealed weapons in public.

title: European Trash Hauler Says Profits Rose 32%
description: Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux S.A., Europe's biggest private independent power producer and trash hauler, indicated yesterday that its second-half profit rose 32 percent, driven by growth in its energy division and expansion abroad. Income from operations at the utility, also the world's biggest water company in terms of clients served, rose to 410 million euros ($442 million) from 310 million euros. For the full year, profit rose 25 percent, to 760 million euros.

title: Misanthropes Only a Mother Could Love
description: The milk of human kindness hasn't merely soured in Peter Mullan's transcendently nasty comedy, ''Orphans.'' It has so poisoned the air of Glasgow that its clammy atmosphere seems charged with petty malice. The story of three brothers and a sister, each of whom goes grotesquely haywire after the death of their beloved mother, the film gleefully rubs our noses in comic misanthropy that makes American movies like ''The Ref'' and ''Very Bad Things'' seem almost like rays of sunshine.

title: Edward Keating: 'Exile New York'
description: Leica Gallery

title: On Kosovo, Time For New Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigration, the Issue-in-Waiting
description: In times of plenty, it's easy to celebrate our historically high levels of immigration as a boon to the economy. But even with low inflation, a tight labor market, budget surpluses and the Dow hovering around 10,000, we shouldn't fall prey to the illusion that potential problems caused by immigration can be ignored indefinitely.

title: A Mexican Governor Drops From Sight in Drug Investigation
description: Federal authorities have intensified a drug investigation that is focusing on the Governor of the State of Quintana Roo, calling him for new rounds of questioning and warning that protests by his allies will not halt the inquiry.

title: F.C.C. Chief's Letter Raises Concern on Merger Plans
description: In a rare public step, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission encouraged the Ameritech Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. yesterday to help draw up terms that would promote competition so the commission would approve the companies' pending $62 billion merger.

title: On Kosovo, Time For New Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Expressing Inwardness Within Cacophony
description: Blur made an abrupt musical left turn with its 1997 album, ''Blur'' (Virgin). As standard-bearers for 1990's Britpop, Blur had been writing smart, neatly organized pop-rock songs observing peculiarly English characters. Then, after exposure to the Lollapalooza festival, Blur discovered anarchic noise and ambiguous lyrics, and it hasn't looked back. At Roseland on Tuesday night, it played through its new album, ''13'' (Virgin), as if the songs were armatures to hold all the cacophony -- bristling, resonant, bluesy or disruptive -- that the band could layer on.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: The Immigrant Cycle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKEY, MARYANNE
description: DICKEY-MaryAnne, March 29, 1999. Beloved daughter of John and Irene Dickey. Loving sister of Diane Dickey and Jane Webster. Cherished niece of John Roman and Mary Ann Smith. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Saturday, April 3, 1999, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial 10 AM, Monday, April 5, 1999, at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89 St.

title: G.I.'s in Macedonia Believe 3 Were Seized by Armed Serb Villagers
description: It was around 4 P.M. Wednesday when the three-man American reconnaissance unit radioed in to base to say they had come under fire. The reply came back asking if the message was a joke. But the unit was not joking. ''We're taking direct fire, they said. ''We're trapped.''

title: Presidential Appeal On Balkan Bombing
description: Denouncing the Serbs' capture of three American soldiers, President Clinton vowed to pursue the Balkan bombing campaign and appealed to the nation for ''determination and resolve.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANAHAN, REV. WILLIAM F.X.
description: LANAHAN-Rev. William F.X. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the former faculty member of Cathedral College on March 28. Reposing at Edward F. Lieber Funeral Home, 9 E. Valley Stream Blvd., Valley Stream, on Saturday, April 3rd, from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. Funeral Mass Monday, April 5th, at Holy Name of Mary Church, 55 East Jamaica Avenue, Valley Stream, at 10:45 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: On Kosovo, Time For New Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Authentic Hornblower, Where Grim Meets Ghastly
description: The squeamish are advised to pop a couple of Dramamine before sailing with Horatio Hornblower. You're in for some rough seas.

title: Big Board Proposes Lower Quote Fees
description: The New York Stock Exchange proposed lower fees for stock quotations yesterday as investor demand for the latest trade information surged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAYTON, ROBERT HESTER, JR.,
description: CLAYTON-Robert Hester, Jr., of NY and Quiogue, NY, passed away on March 28, 1999 in West Palm Beach, FL. He was the beloved husband of the late Maria F. Clayton and is survived by his brothers Ralph and James, both of Deland, FL, his sister Nancy Meeks of High Point, NC, and 18 nieces and nephews. Mr. Clayton was the Managing Partner of Coggeshall & Hicks later to become Laidlaw, Adams and Peck where he was the President and Chief Executive Officer. He graduated from Brevard College, volunteered for active duty in the US Navy where he served as a pilot, and received his Master's degree from Columbia University in Business Administration. An avid croquet player, he was elected to the US Croquet Club Hall of Fame. Funeral and burial services will be private with a memorial service to be scheduled at a later date.

title: Youth in a Balletic Duet With Experience
description: There were many reasons for rejoicing when the ABT Studio Company presented three new ballets on Wednesday night at the Kaye Playhouse. The group, sponsored by American Ballet Theater and directed by John Meehan, trains young dancers and provides them with stage experience. Many of its fledglings are eventually taken into Ballet Theater or other troupes. The Studio Company also allows both novice and experienced choreographers to try out new ideas.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a Chinese maker of television sets trying to break into the United States market misidentified the company. It is the Konka Group, not the Konda Group.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Amid Many Holy Days, Clerics Urge Cease-Fire
description: As celebrations of Easter, Christianity's holiest day, draw near for the faithful worldwide, a growing number of Roman Catholic, Orthodox and Protestant leaders are calling for an end to hostilities between NATO nations and Yugoslavia.

title: Witnesses Found in '97 Killing Involving Diallo Case Officer
description: Investigators looking into a 1997 Brooklyn killing by one of the officers charged with murdering Amadou Diallo say they have recently found three important witnesses in the Brooklyn case.

title: Bill Advances to Treat Nicotine as a Nonprescription Drug
description: In an effort to tighten state rules on tobacco sales and more severely punish stores that sell to minors, an important legislative committee approved a bill today that would regulate nicotine as an over-the-counter drug.

title: Uncovering The Secrets Of a Cruel Childhood
description: Dominique Swain did a glorious job as the title character of Adrian Lyne's ''Lolita'' last year, capturing the attitudes and behaviors of a barely adolescent girl. But when Erika Isabel de la Cruz Ramirez plays the title character of ''Paulina'' at age 13, huddling in a graveyard, hiding from the man who keeps her as a sexual prisoner, she is what a real Lolita might have looked like: amazingly young.

title: Sprewell the Starter Rides the Bench During Knicks' Rally
description: Latrell Sprewell absorbed a glorious introduction. Laser lights and flashbulbs escorted him onto the court as member of the Knicks' starting lineup. This is what he had campaigned for, the thrill of being a starter.

title: No Matter How Far Out, Comics Still Cross Paths
description: Imagine, if you will, an evening with Roberto Benigni doing impressions of Stevie Wonder, Edith Piaf, Fidel Castro, Marilyn Monroe, Barbra Streisand and the Pope. Now imagine him impersonating them all in a lip-synching show, with paper headdresses, costumes and props affixed to his scalp and torso.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIN, MARIE A.
description: FREIN-Marie A. On April 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Eugene. Loving mother of Marie Burke, John, Eugene, Ann Luca, Regina Coronata, Joseph and the late Lawrence. Also survived by thirteen wonderful grandchildren. Reposing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28 St., NYC, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Resurrection, Monday 10AM at Immaculate Conception Church, 14th Street and 1st Avenue, NYC. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: CBS to Buy King World For $2.5 Billion in Stock

title: Intel Awards Account To Messner Vetere
description: The Intel Corporation said yesterday that it had awarded Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, its business-to- business advertising account, which had been at Havas's sibling agency Euro RSCG DSW Partners in San Francisco for the last nine years. Billings were estimated at $25 million. Joann O'Brien, a spokeswoman for Intel in Santa Clara, Calif., said that the company had moved its account to Messner Vetere because ''the scope and size of the agency's operations make it best prepared to handle this growing business.''

title: CHURCHILL DOWNS IN TALKS TO BUY HOLLYWOOD PARK TRACK
description: Churchill Downs Inc., owner of the race track where the Kentucky Derby is run, said yesterday that it was negotiating to buy the Hollywood Park race track in Inglewood, Calif., from Hollywood Park Inc. The purchase would also include some land surrounding Hollywood Park, the two companies said. Churchill Downs, based in Louisville, Ky., is trying to consolidate the horse-racing industry. In January, it agreed to buy the Calder Race Course in Miami for $86 million. Hollywood's shares rose $1.25 each yesterday, or 12 percent, to $11.5625. Churchill Downs' stock was up $1.625 a share, to $29.625.

title: Ulster Talks Miss Goal But Blair Sees Gains
description: Talks to resolve the last issues blocking the formal start-up of the Northern Ireland peace plan adjourned inconclusively today, but Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said he thought they had established a ''satisfactory basis'' for a final settlement.

title: Carvin Wins 400 Freestyle
description: When the Phillips 66 spring national championships ended last night in East Meadow, N.Y., Chad Carvin left with one gold medal for swimming. If they gave medals for medical comebacks, he would collect there, too.

title: Again, for Families and Friends, Yellow Ribbons
description: A dreaded symbol of war began to mark the landscape in three communities today, as friends and family of the American soldiers captured along the border of Macedonia and Kosovo hung yellow ribbons on their clothing, in their yards and along the streets.

title: Huntington Housing Official Indicted in Theft of Subsidies
description: The chairman of the Huntington Housing Authority was indicted today by a Federal grand jury here on charges that he stole Government funds, laundered money, evaded taxes and extorted money from several Long Island construction companies.

title: Already Burdened, Western Europe Is Reluctant to Take in Kosovo's Outcasts
description: The huge numbers of ethnic Albanians fleeing Kosovo are raising acute concerns in west European countries about the potential arrival of tens of thousands of refugees in societies already strained by high unemployment, sluggish economic growth and simmering resentment of foreigners.

title: Harold Greenwald, 88, Expert On Psychology of Prostitutes
description: Harold Greenwald, a psychotherapist whose doctoral dissertation on the psychology of prostitutes evolved into a best-selling 1958 book, ''The Call Girl,'' and a Hollywood movie, ''Girl of the Night,'' died on Friday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 88.

title: Illegal Immigrant Workers Being Fired in I.N.S. Tactic
description: When Federal immigration agents came to the fruit-packing warehouses here in central Washington, there were no sudden raids, no emergency deportation hearings, no buses waiting to take hundreds of illegal immigrant workers back to the Mexican border, more than a thousand miles away.

title: Dutch Pension Funds Offer to Buy Lender
description: ABP and PGGM, the Netherlands' largest pension funds, offered to buy Nationale Investeringsbank N.V. for $2.04 billion, but minority shareholders of N.I.B., the state-controlled Dutch corporate lender and investment bank, called the price insufficient. The pension funds, which said in December that they planned to buy the Hague-based bank, extended their bid to N.I.B.'s preferred shares and offered 29.95 euros for the common shares. That was 10 percent less than N.I.B.'s share price on Wednesday.

title: Still Not Such a Nice Place to Visit
description: Goldie Hawn and Steve Martin are appealing performers, but none of the energy, professionalism and gameness they display while portraying a married couple facing problems galore in the remake of ''The Out-of-Towners'' can surmount the mess that surrounds them in this misguided comedy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROUNIS, MONICA MITTELSTADT.
description: PROUNIS - Monica Mittelstadt. Age 36. On March 31, 1999. Beloved wife of Othon. Mother of Alexa. Daughter of Charles and Angelica Mittelstadt. Sister of Simone Mailman and Charles Mittelstadt, Jr. Memorial service at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 5th Avenue at 55 Street, Wednesday, 10:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Amherst College, C/O Development Office, POB 5000, Amherst, MA 01002, The Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60 Street, NY, NY 10022 or The Marrow Foundation, 400 Seventh St N.W., Suite 206, Washington, D.C. 20004.

title: A Moon for the Misinformed
description: So now it turns out that the ''blue moon'' that appeared on Wednesday -- supposedly the second blue moon of the year -- really wasn't. In fact, the first blue moon of the year, spotted back in January, really wasn't, either. What started out as one of those remarkable years in which two blue moons were to lighten the skies will actually end up as a year in which not a single blue moon emerges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, GRAENUM
description: BERGER-Graenum. Beloved husband of Emma. Loving father of Colonel Michael Berger. Cherished grandfather & great-grandfather. Service Sunday, 10:30AM, at the Pelham Jewish Center, 451 Esplanade, Pelham Manor, NY. Contributions to American Friends of Hebrew University of NYC, Graenum and Emma Berger Scholarship Fund for Ethiopian Jews.

title: Woman Arrested After Newborn Is Found Dead in Trash
description: A 20-year-old woman was arrested yesterday after a baby boy she had given birth to in the stairwell of a Harlem apartment building was found dead in the building's trash chute, the police said.

title: Gambling Requires More Than Luck; Fungible Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACCAGLINI, HELEN
description: BACCAGLINI-Helen. The Office of the Inspector General, NYC School Construction Authority, records in sorrow the passing of Helen Baccaglini, the beloved mother of our colleague, friend and mentor, Edmond Baccaglini. We extend our deepest sympathies to all members of her family.

title: American Atheists Group Is Moving to New Jersey
description: American Atheists Inc., whose missing founder filed the 1963 lawsuit that led to a Federal ban on prayer in public schools, is moving its headquarters from Austin, Tex., to New Jersey.

title: All the King's Horses and All the King's Men Were Still Optimistic
description: Wall Street cheered this week as the Dow Jones industrial average finally closed above 10,000. Many analysts are counting on a continuing bull market. Who knows? They may be right. And then again, they may not. Stock market predictions are a tricky business, as you can see from a look back at what was said 70 years ago, before and right after the Oct. 29 crash. Joyce Jensen compiled these quotations from ''The Great Crash, 1929,'' by John Kenneth Galbraith (Houghton Mifflin, 1997); ''The Stock Market Crash of 1929,'' by James Crane Kellogg 3d and William E. Downey (J. C. Kellogg Foundation, 1954); ''The Experts Speak,'' by Christopher Cerf and Victor Navasky (Villard Books, 1998); ''The Day the Market Crashed,'' by Donald I. Rogers (Arlington House, 1971), and ''The Big Board: A History of the New York Stock Market,'' by Robert Sobel (The Free Press, 1965).

title: Let Teachers Write the Tests; Art of Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, HARRY EDSON SR.
description: MORSE-Harry Edson Sr. Born June 12, 1915 in Washington, D.C. died on April 1, 1999 after a brief illness in Los Angeles, CA. His wife, Dorothy Morse, preceded him in death. His children: Joan Brooke, Harry E. Morse, Candice Smith and Robert Morse, ten grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren survive him. Services will be held at St. John Fisher, Palos Verdes, California, on Monday, April 5, at 2PM. Interment will be at Klein Memorial Park FM 2920, Tomball, Texas. In lieu of flowers the family requests that memorial contributions be made to any state Masonic home for children or the charity of your choice. McCormick Mortuary, Redondo Beach, California, Directors 310-540-7444.

title: Slavery's Clear Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: D'Alema Faces Communist Walkout Over Easter Bombing
description: ROME  Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema of Italy struggled to keep his cabinet together on Friday in the face of a threat by his Communist partners to withdraw its ministers unless a truce in the war between NATO and Yugoslavia was achieved over the Easter weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITTELSTADT, MONICA
description: MITTELSTADT-Monica. See notice under PROUNIS-Monica Mittelstadt.

title: North Korea's Food Near End, Aid Workers Say
description: The food scarcity engulfing North Korea will worsen in the next two months because Government rations, on which a majority of the population depends, are running out and will not be restocked until the summer harvest, a senior aid official said today.

title: Krog Wins Hobey Baker Award
description: Jason Krog of New Hampshire, who led the nation in scoring, was named the winner of the Hobey Baker Award today as college hockey's player of the year.

title: 4 Sides in War: Serbs, NATO, Clouds, Politics
description: There has been fog and rain over Yugoslavia for most of NATO's 10-day air campaign, but politicians and their assessment of public sensitivities have grounded just as many bombing runs as the weather has.

title: Japanese Stock Prices Mixed; Export Companies Fare the Best
description: Japanese stock prices closed mixed today, with the shares of export-dependent companies benefiting from the dollar's gains against the yen.

title: Business Travel; Halcyon Days for Airlines, If Not for Many Passengers
description: These are truly boom times for the nation's airlines: their earnings are stronger than ever and they flew a record 611 million passengers last year without a single fatality. And they did so while maintaining their on-time performance and without a significant increase in officially registered complaints.

title: U.S. Grapples With Issue Of Finding Refugees Homes
description: Senior Clinton Administration officials say the United States will have to consider accepting some of the hundreds of thousands of ethnic Albanian refugees who have fled Kosovo in recent days, if only to encourage reluctant European nations to do the same.

title: Helping Balkan Refugees
description: These are some of the organizations that have substantial ground workers who are helping refugees from Kosovo. Updates on many of their activities are at http://www.internaction .org/kosovo/detail.html

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPMAN, WALTER
description: LIPMAN-Walter. Beloved husband of Ruth, devoted father of Ilene (Harvey) Burstein, loving grandfather of Staci and Joshua Burstein, adored brother of Michael (Gloria) and the late Carol. Graveside services Sunday, April 4th at 10:30 A.M., at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York. (516) 957-2277. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him.

title: Judge Denies Defense Bid To Postpone Louima Trial
description: The judge in the case of four police officers charged with brutalizing Abner Louima yesterday denied a postponement request made by defense lawyers who said news coverage of the case and of the police shooting of Amadou Diallo had given rise to anti-police sentiment in the city.

title: Cost of Guards Said to Prompt Gotti Request to Return to Jail
description: John A. Gotti requested to return to jail because the cost and intrusiveness of guards and other conditions of his bail will no longer make sense once he begins spending much of his days on trial here, his sister and a lawyer said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, F. MORGAN
description: PALMER-F. Morgan. On March 22, 1999, devoted husband of the late Susan B. Palmer, father of F. Morgan Palmer Jr, and Thomas P.F. Palmer. Contributions may be made in his memory to The Church of The Holy Trinity Garden Fund, 316 East 88th Street, New York, New York 10128.

title: Today, Parents Need All Advice They Can Get; No Operating Manual
description: To the Editor:

title: Chemistry of Alienation and First Love
description: The pain, yearning and confusions of youth are mingled in ''Tokyo Eyes,'' filmed by a French director in the Japanese capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALLENT, WILLIAM J.
description: TALLENT-William J., DDS. Offices in East Tremont section of Bronx for 51 years, Wednesday, March 31, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Matilda M. (nee Witte). Loving father of Mary Louise Chudd and Barbara Zigarelli. Also survived by six grandchildren. Funeral from Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Ave., Bronx, on Monday, April 5, at 10:00 AM. Mass of Christian burial St. Benedict's Church at 10:30 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. Visiting Saturday 2:00-5:00 and 7:009:30, and Sunday 7:00-9:30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, BERNARD
description: KANE-Bernard. It is with deep sadness that the Board of Governors and members of Elmwood Country Club record the loss of our esteemed member, Bernard Kane. He and his family have been members of Elmwood for over 30 years. Bernard had a distinguished career in the elevator industry where he was an acknowledged leader. To Barbara, Douglas and Laurie and all the grandchildren, we offer our most sincere condolences. We will greatly miss Bernard's presence at Elmwood. Services at Riverside Memorial Mount Vernon, Friday, April 2 at 12 noon. Ken Goodman, President

title: Man Is Charged In the Creation Of E-Mail Virus
description: After a global search for the author of the fastest-spreading computer virus in history, investigators in New Jersey arrested a 30-year-old software programmer on Thursday night and charged him with writing and sending out the now-famous Melissa virus.

title: About New York; Sacred Week For Agitator And His Flock
description: THE REV. ROBERT CASTLE began his Good Friday observance with a procession and a vigil. At 7 in the morning, he emerged from the parish house at St. Mary's Episcopal Church, where he is the priest in charge, and headed down West 126th Street greeting the few souls who were outside. With his rumpled clothes, shaggy beard and baseball cap, Father Castle looked like an absent-minded uncle. But a block away from his church, he was very much the pastor when he joined with 20 other people and shepherded them into a nondescript building.

title: Mitsubishi and Volvo Reportedly Reach Deal
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation will jointly develop trucks with Volvo A.B., the Japanese newspaper Sankei reported, in a move analysts say could lead to the Swedish company's taking a stake in Mitsubishi, Japan's No. 4 car maker. The partnership will include the marketing and the sale of medium-duty trucks, the newspaper said, citing a Mitsubishi executive. Both companies declined to comment.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: On 10th Day, Blasts Wrench Rainy Belgrade
description: Two enormous blasts wrenched a rainy Belgrade awake at 1 A.M. today and hurled flames 12 stories high in the allies' first strike at this Balkan capital.

title: Allied Troops Ordered To Assist Refugees; Reinforcements Sent : Third of Kosovars Now Forced Out, NATO Says
description: PARIS  NATO declared Friday that the forced flight of ethnic Albanians from Kosovo had produced an "extremely grave" regional crisis across the Balkans and had emptied the Yugoslav province of one-third of its population in the past 12 months.

title: BURNHAM PACIFIC PROPERTIES ANNOUNCES CUTBACKS
description: Burnham Pacific Properties Inc., one of California's largest retail property owners, plans to cut one-fourth of its work force, or about 40 jobs, and take a first-quarter charge as it closes three offices and hires other companies to manage its properties. The company, based in San Diego, said yesterday that it would take a restructuring charge of about $1.5 million in the first quarter.
