Burnham Pacific said the move would cut its 1999 funds from operations by 1 cent a share and its 2000 funds from operations by about 2 cents a share.

title: THESTREET.COM PLANS TO SELL 5.5 MILLION SHARES
description: TheStreet.com Inc., the financial Web site co-founded by the hedge-fund manager James J. Cramer, disclosed yesterday that it planned to sell 5.5 million common shares for $11 to $13 each in its initial public offering. The company, an on-line publisher of financial news based in New York, first filed for the offering in February, and said at the time that it would seek to raise as much as $75 million. It amended that filing yesterday. At $13 a share, the sale of 5.5 million shares would raise about $71.5 million before expenses, and TheStreet.com would have an initial market value of $326 million, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company has yet to turn a profit or reach the $5 million mark in annual revenue.

title: Rangers' Hopes Dealt A Blow
description: It was a grim showing for two star centers of the Rangers last night in a critical game against Anaheim at Madison Square Garden. Petr Nedved tried to play with injured ribs, skated for about a minute in the first period, and sat the rest of the night. Wayne Gretzky grimaced after an early hard hit from Kevin Haller, then took four minutes in penalties for trying to spear Haller.

title: Time to Unlock City Files
description: After two years of trying to wheedle ordinary data out of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's City Hall, State Comptroller Carl McCall and his auditors won an important victory this week in New York State's highest court. The State Court of Appeals ruled that the Comptroller's office has the right to audit how the city has been delivering its services in such areas as welfare, street cleaning, parks and police. As a Republican running for re-election in 1997, Mayor Giuliani had balked at the demand for performance audits by Mr. McCall, a Democrat. The Mayor labeled the requests for extra data as ''partisan'' and gave Mr. McCall access only to financial records of the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEVERTZ, ALLAN H.
description: GEVERTZ-Allan H. On April 1, 1999 at the age of 70. Devoted father of John and the late Bruce. Father-in-law of Susan and Jacqueline. Adoring grandfather of Rebecca, Annie, William, Justin and Andrew. Funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday, 10AM. Interment will be private. Friends may also call at Campbell's on Monday, from 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: While U.S. Airlines Thrive, Traveler Complaints Grow

title: Lucien Aigner, 97, Pioneer In Candid News Photography
description: Lucien Aigner, a pioneer in candid news photography in the 1930's whose best-known photographs include one of a rumpled Albert Einstein in front of a blackboard, died on Monday in a nursing home in Waltham, Mass. He was 97.

title: Let Teachers Write the Tests; Performance Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Stop Him Before He's Billed Again
description: In the years since Mario Puzo and Marlon Brando lifted their imaginary Mafia to the realm of myth, the gene pool of the real five families has gotten pretty shallow. John J. Gotti proved that making wise-guy talk as if Federal wiretaps did not exist is really not the smartest thing for a don to do. Now it looks like his son and accused heir, 35-year-old John A. Gotti, is having trouble making ends meet despite the booming economy. He has, in fact, done something that his alleged predecessors in La Cosa Nostra would have found unthinkable. Mr. Gotti the younger said to a Federal judge, Put me in jail, please. Surprised prosecutors regarded it as an offer they couldn't refuse.

title: Sheldon Kopp, 70, Psychologist Who Wrote About Self-Esteem
description: Sheldon Bernard Kopp, a clinical psychologist and author of books designed to bolster the reader's self-esteem, died on Monday, his 70th birthday, at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He lived in nearby Silver Spring, Md.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIESENFELD, STANLEY
description: RIESENFELD-Stanley. Adored husband of Nancy. Beloved father of Danielle and Lauren, Michelle and Adam. Dear son-in-law of Jackie and Harvey, loving brother-in-law of Judy, Barbara and Ken. Cherished uncle to Jodi, Lisa, Jonathan and Jessie. ''He was special to all who knew him''. Services Sunday 11am at Congregation Knesseth Tifereth Israel, 575 King Street, Port Chester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAYTON, ROBERT HESTER
description: CLAYTON-Robert Hester, Jr., of NY and Quiogue, NY, passed away on March 28, 1999 in West Palm Beach, FL. He was the beloved husband of the late Maria F. Clayton and is survived by his brothers Ralph and James, both of Deland, FL, his sister Nancy Meeks of High Point, NC, and 18 nieces and nephews. Mr. Clayton was the Managing Partner of Coggeshall & Hicks later to become Laidlaw, Adams and Peck where he was the President and Chief Executive Officer. He graduated from Brevard College, volunteered for active duty in the US Navy where he served as a pilot, and received his Master's degree from Columbia University in Business Administration. An avid croquet player, he was elected to the US Croquet Club Hall of Fame. Funeral and burial services will be private with a memorial service to be scheduled at a later date.

title: HOCKEY; Way Out West, Two Eastern Schools Meet for the Title
description: Six years ago, when the University of Alaska-Anchorage was named the host school for this year's National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey championship, the athletic director Tim Dillon had what many people thought were unrealistic dreams.

title: China Mobile Phone Deals
description: Lucent Inc. and Motorola Inc. signed contracts today valued at approximately $20 million to expand mobile telephone networks in China based on the C.D.M.A. standard. Lucent will supply base station equipment, software and management services to an existing network in the southern province of Guangdong. Motorola will sell equipment to build an additional 35 base stations for its network in Beijing, the New China news agency reported. C.D.M.A. stands for code division multiple access.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROUNIS, MONICA MITTELSTADT
description: PROUNIS - Monica Mittelstadt. Age 36. On March 31, 1999. Beloved wife of Othon. Mother of Alexa. Daughter of Charles and Angelica Mittelstadt. Sister of Simone Mailman and Charles Mittelstadt, Jr. Memorial service at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 5th Avenue at 55 Street, Wednesday, 10:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Amherst College, C/O Development Office, POB 5000, Amherst, MA 01002, The Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60 Street, NY, NY 10022 or The Marrow Foundation, 400 Seventh St N.W., Suite 206, Washington, D.C. 20004.

title: Refugees Flee One Nightmare, Find Another
description: Hounded from their homes and herded by police cars and tanks into columns that snake through the valleys of southern Kosovo, the flood of refugees leaving the Serbian province surged by more than 78,000 people today.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes of Business Day on Wednesday about the appointment of Mark Shahriary misidentified the company that named him president. It is Teledesic, not Teledisc.

title: City Will Pay Hells Angels To Settle Suit
description: The Giuliani administration has agreed to pay $450,000 to seven members of the Hells Angels motorcycle club and two of the bikers' girlfriends to settle a lawsuit over a police raid on the group's local headquarters in the East Village last year.

title: Somewhat Lost in Time
description: The first Monday after daylight saving time clicks in, the number of car accidents in Canada goes up 8 percent. That alone, in my book, is reason enough to do away with daylight saving time, or at least reason enough not to visit Canada.

title: Elite Forces Standing By If Air Power Won't Work
description: Lieut. Charles-Philippe D'Orleans had no hesitation in describing the 2,500 French troops deployed with him in Macedonia. ''They are highly mobile elite forces, the best we have,'' he said.

title: Hughes Electronics Collects U.S. Payment
description: The Hughes Electronics unit of the General Motors Corporation has collected $154 million in damages from the United States Government, ending a 26-year legal battle over patented technology used to help orient communications satellites.

title: Unit Formed to Fight Official Misconduct
description: The Division of Criminal Justice has formed a unit to fight misconduct by local officials, , a spokesman for the division said yesterday.

title: Facts at Briefings Scarce, But Polemics Are Abundant
description: For more than a week now, NATO civilian and military spokesmen here have been giving daily briefings to journalists from around the world. But these briefings are very different from those that journalists got in Vietnam, the Persian Gulf or Bosnia.

title: Making the Most of a Swoop and a Flurry
description: Small gestures produce remarkable payoffs in the music of Lois V Vierk, whose compositions were performed on Monday night at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation. A sustained open interval, a swoop, a repeated note or a rhythmic flurry can become the foundation for rhapsodic invention and a final exuberant release. Experimental Intermedia was where she gave her first New York concert 15 years ago, and the program marked the occasion with three 1990's pieces and one from 1981.

title: SCIENTIFIC TECHNOLOGIES BUYS LUNDAHL INSTRUMENTS
description: Scientific Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Lundahl Instruments Inc., a privately held maker of ultrasonic industrial sensors and controllers. Terms were not disclosed. The products made by Lundahl, based in Logan, Utah, are used in the automation of industrial processes and vehicle-collision avoidance. Scientific Technologies, based in Fremont, Calif., makes safety equipment for machinery and sensors used in automation, in military equipment and on toll highways. It had sales of $43.5 million in 1998.

title: Bond Market Rises Sharply On Jobs Data
description: A smaller-than-expected increase in nonfarm payroll jobs last month, in part a result of a decline in manufacturing jobs, set off the bond market's best rally in four weeks yesterday.

title: Refugees Arriving by Thousands Turn Fields Into Sprawling Camp
description: The valley hummed with thousands of voices, the hillside and fields below shifted constantly with crowds of people.

title: A Little Show With the Food and Wine
description: Andrea Smith invited people to sip, munch and watch when he presented ''The Salon Project: Creation in Motion'' on Thursday night at Performance Space 122. The audience was seated at cafe tables, and food and wine were available at no extra cost. The program Mr. Smith concocted was a multimedia stew of choreographic, musical and dramatic works. It was hard to discern what guiding principle, if any, led to the selection of these items. Yet several morsels were artistically tasty.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday on the decrease in smoking by Florida students in the sixth to eighth grades misstated last year's decline in some copies. It was 19 percent, not 19 percentage points.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a plan for CBS to buy King World Productions Inc. misstated the ownership stake in CBS Inc. that the deal would give to Oprah Winfrey. As the article reported correctly, her share of CBS will be one-half of 1 percent, not 1 percent.

title: A Reminder
description: Daylight saving time resumes at 2 A.M. tomorrow. Clocks are set ahead one hour.

title: Hyundai to Take Over Oil Refining Business
description: Hyundai Group agreed yesterday to take over Hanwha Group's oil refining business by assuming 3 trillion won ($2.5 billion) of debt, giving Hyundai, South Korea's largest conglomerate, a bigger hold on one more industry just as the Government is calling on it to scale down. The Hyundai Oil Refinery Company said the deal would increase its share of the market to 25 percent from 13 percent.

title: Storm Kills 9 as They Trek From Mexico
description: A freak spring snowstorm trapped several dozen illegal immigrants in wilderness mountain terrain east of San Diego overnight, leaving at least 7 people dead, some still possibly missing and more than 50 rescued in a sprawling search effort over slushy hillsides north of the Mexican border, immigration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph with a News Summary item about Kosovo yesterday was published in error. It showed Ibrahim Rugova, a moderate ethnic Albanian leader, not Jakub Krasniqi, a spokesman for the Kosovo Liberation Army.

title: Schwab Says Adviser Referrals Are Up
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation said today that it had referred 4,000 investors to financial advisers in the first quarter, a 50 percent increase over a year ago.

title: Big Stock Options for Oxford Health Chief
description: The chief executive of Oxford Health Plans Inc., Norman Payson, received $9.53 million in salary, bonus and stock options last year as he worked to turn around Oxford, the troubled health insurer.

title: Top Giuliani Aide Said to Experience Race Bias by Police
description: At the height of the public furor over the police shooting of Amadou Diallo, Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington -- the highest-ranking black member of the Giuliani administration -- told Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of being harassed more than once by police officers for what Mr. Washington considered to be racial reasons, according to people close to the administration.

title: Charges May Be Dropped in Diallo Protest
description: The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday that he would probably ask for the dismissal of charges against the 1,200 people who were arrested for civil disobedience last month during the daily protests over the police killing of Amadou Diallo.

title: An Excess of Caution
description: The success of the military campaign against Yugoslavia depends on whether Slobodan Milosevic believes his regime and his own safety are threatened.

title: Way Paved for Philadelphia To Develop Naval Shipyard
description: Agreements signed this week by the United States Navy and the City of Philadelphia have cleared the way for the city to develop the huge shipyard that was shut down four years ago in a round of military base closings.

title: Gambling Requires More Than Luck; What's True Payoff?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday about NATO airstrikes in Yugoslavia omitted the key for identifying different types of target areas. A corrected chart appears today on page A4.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about on-line coupons used an obsolete name for a company that offers E-centives, redeemable on line. While it used to be called Emaginet, its name is now E-centives Inc.

title: Jury Sentences Marine in Ski-Lift Incident to Dismissal
description: A military jury today sentenced the navigator of a jet that severed ski lift cables in the Italian Alps last year, killing 20 people, to dismissal from the Marine Corps for obstructing justice by destroying a personal videotape he shot during the flight.

title: U.S. Is Investigating Big Board on Oversight of Floor Traders
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into how the New York Stock Exchange has handled the regulation of its floor brokers and an investigation of their trading.

title: International Business: Retooling Fortress Wallenberg; Swedish Empire, Under Siege, Scrambles to Adapt
description: What's in a name? If the country is Sweden, and the name is Wallenberg, then the answer is just about everything.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He was a very solitary person; he was a quiet neighbor. I'd hear his modem go off once in a while.''

title: Utility Company Revises Earnings
description: Western Resources Inc., a Kansas utility, said on Thursday that it would restate 1997 and 1998 earnings because regulators had ordered changes in income reported by its Protection One monitored-security company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREYER, LILLIAN
description: FREYER-Lillian. on March 31. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Barbara Freyer and Dr. Stuart Freyer. Adored grandmother to Daniel (Joanne), Adam, Jesse Freyer and Roger Taub. Devoted sister to Morris Golde, Michael and Belle Golde and Sonny Freyer. Special aunt and grand aunt. Services private.

title: Vera Tolstoy, Granddaughter of the Novelist, Dies at 96
description: Vera Tolstoy, a Russian refugee who became a teen-age bride in Czechoslovakia, worked as a hairdresser in Prague, sang Gypsy songs in Paris, sold perfume in New York and spent 25 years with the Voice of America in Washington, died on Monday at her retirement home in New Smyrna Beach, Fla. She was 96 and the last living link to her grandfather Leo Tolstoy.

title: Drawn Back to Calcutta By a Need to Feel at Home
description: Amit Chaudhuri is homesick, and so he is returning to India.

title: Krajicek Wins Opener vs. France
description: There were plenty of marathon matches on the opening day of Davis Cup World Group play.

title: Waterfront Profligacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARASCH, CHARLOTTE
description: KARASCH-Charlotte, R.N. (nee Fischer), age 86, of Lakewood, NJ, on April 2, 1999. Beloved wife of Philip Karasch. Devoted mother of Rose. Dear sister of Ada Wikler. Loving aunt of Daniel, Norma, and Jeanne Wikler, Marjorie Senechal, Rita Kravitz and Linda Schwartz. There are no services at this time. Cremation Service of Ocean, Inc, Brick, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMHI, CLAIRE
description: KAMHI-Claire. Beloved mother of Steven, Arnold and Helene Smith, daughter of Marcelle Corcos, grandmother of nine, great-grandmother of two. Died April 1, 1999. Services at Boulevard Chapel, Sunday 11:30 AM, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, (516-295-3100).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYNG, LILA HOTZ
description: TYNG-Lila Hotz. On March 31 at the age of 100 years and 5 days. Born in Chicago, she died at her home, Lu Shan, Gladstone, NJ. Beloved mother of Henry Luce, III and Peter Paul Luce; mother-inlaw of Leila Hadley Luce and Elizabeth Bardsley Luce; grandmother of Lila Luce, H. Christopher Luce, Meredith Luce Billingsley, Elisabeth Luce, Christena McNicol and Clare Abbey. Memorial service 4PM Thursday, April 8, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Ave. at 73rd St. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Spence School, 22 East 91 St, NY, NY 10028, would be appreciated. She will be interred at Graceland Cemetery, Chicago.

title: Gambling Requires More Than Luck
description: To the Editor:

title: Teen-Age Mayor Startled by All the Attention
description: Just two years ago, a fresh-faced teen-ager walked into the office of Nancy Bryant, the village clerk here, and astonished her with a request: How could he run for the town board? She shooed him away, saying he was too young, but advised him to go to board meetings and educate himself on local issues until he turned 18.

title: U.S. Trade Panel Approves Investigation on Steel Dumping
description: The United States International Trade Commission found today that a surge in imports of low-priced carbon steel plate from Japan, South Korea and four other countries may have injured American steelmakers enough to warrant consideration of punitive tariffs.

title: A Sofa's Secret and Other Whimsies
description: One of the best films at this year's New Directors/New Films series is a bracingly imaginative six-vignette Czech feature that explores, among other things, a kinky means of yanking upholstery buttons from the seat of a sofa. Its title is ''Buttoners,'' not just for this peculiarity but also for the others that give it such an artfully subversive tone. As directed by Petr Zelenka with unassuming cleverness, this black comedy has an air of whimsy and a will of steel as it watches destiny play tricks on a carefully interwoven set of characters. Meanwhile, a pervasive radio station asks, ''What makes this century so special?'' And the film tries, in its wisely indirect way, to supply an answer.

title: Fire Smoldering Under Kremlin Scorches Prosecutor Again
description: Remember Yuri I. Skuratov, Russia's chief prosecutor? He's the man President Boris N. Yeltsin tried to squeeze out of office and whose job was saved by the upper house of Parliament last month in a resurrection that was suddenly overshadowed by the broadcast of an explicit tape of his romp with two prostitutes on a Government-run television station.

title: Foreman Subpoenaed in Corruption Investigation
description: The former heavyweight champion George Foreman has been subpoenaed to testify before a Federal grand jury in New Jersey that is investigating allegations of corruption by the International Boxing Federation, said a lawyer Foreman retained a week ago.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VERITAS CAPITAL FUND L.P., New York, a private equity firm, agreed to acquire Sierra Research, Buffalo, a high-technology military company, and Zeta, San Jose, Calif., a maker of high-quality electronic systems for the aerospace and military industries, from Sierra Technologies Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: No. 2 Japanese Shipper To Cut About 500 Jobs
description: Mitsui O.S.K. Lines Ltd., Japan's second-largest shipping company in terms of revenue, will slash about 24 percent of its 2,100-strong work force by March 2001, its president, Masaharu Ikuta, said at a news conference. The company will save $40 million to $50 million by eliminating about 500 jobs from the parent company in the two-year period, Mr. Ikuta said. The job cuts include workers at affiliate companies who are paid by the parent.

title: How World Stock Markets Fared in the First Quarter
description: The first quarter was not a period of substantial turmoil in world markets, with one notable exception. Brazil's devaluation of its currency touched off a panic in emerging markets. Unlike the 1998 Russian debt crisis and the 1997 Asian currency crisis, Brazil's crisis was shorter lived. It quickly bounced back, spurred largely by the naming of Arminio Fraga as its new central banker and the Government's adoption of a credible economic restructuring program.

title: Deceptive Leads on the Way To a Cavendish Teams Title
description: One of America's finest players, Edward Manfield of Philadelphia, died of a heart attack at 55 on Monday, shortly after returning from the Spring National Championships in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Hurricane Forecaster Predicts Active Storm Season for '99
description: This year's hurricane season in the Atlantic is likely to be ''very active'' with a chance of damaging storms striking Florida and the East Coast, a leading hurricane forecaster said today.

title: Angry Judge Orders Jailing For a Lawyer
description: A Legal Aid lawyer was handcuffed to a chair, charged with contempt and sentenced to 10 days in jail yesterday by a Criminal Court judge in Manhattan who scolded him for being noisy and rude after a brief exchange during a court session.

title: The Nets Are Downcast As Williams Has Surgery
description: As the Nets practiced today at their state-of-the-art Champion Center, their minds were far from Saturday's home game against the Miami Heat. They ran through shooting drills without emotion and addressed the news media with sullen expressions and somber tones. Despite beating one of the hottest teams in basketball Thursday night, the Nets appeared dazed and dejected.

title: Lila Luce Tyng, 100, First Wife of Henry R. Luce
description: Lila Hotz Luce Tyng, the first wife of Henry R. Luce, founder of Time Inc., died on Wednesday at her home in Gladstone, N.J., five days after her 100th birthday.

title: Let Teachers Write the Tests; Confidence Lacking
description: To the Editor:

title: Gambling Requires More Than Luck; Political Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARR, KATHERINE
description: FARR-Katherine. Beloved wife of the late William Farr and the late Sidney Zweig. Beloved mother of Martin E. (Barbara) Zweig, The Money Manager from ''Wall Street Week With Louis Rukeyser''. Loving grandmother of Zack and Alex Zweig. Also survived by Mollie Zweig. Sister of Perry (Ethel) Schwartz. Martin Zweig will receive visitors on Monday evening, April 5 at the Harmonie Club, 4 E. 60 St from 6-9pm

title: How Cats (Journalists) Chase Very Elusive Mice (the Details of War)
description: NATO Spoken Here

title: Battery Reminder
description: Daylight time begins at 2 A.M. tomorrow; clocks should be set ahead an hour.

title: The Anarchic Lure of Virus Writing
description: In the world of cyberspace, the sport of virus writing has become the latter-day equivalent of the urge to write ''Kilroy was here'' on the wall of the school auditorium. And it is a hobby with a growing following.

title: Today, Parents Need All Advice They Can Get; Dangerous for Children
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Privatization Proposal Stirs Public Passions in Mexico
description: At a recent hearing on President Ernesto Zedillo's proposal to privatize Mexico's electric power industry, Government workers who oppose the plan broke out singing Mexico's national anthem.

title: Let Teachers Write the Tests; Standardized Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Attack Has 'Barely Begun,' Clinton Warns Milosevic
description: As allied forces prepared their attack on downtown Belgrade today, the White House warned President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia that he had ''barely begun'' to feel NATO's bombers and cruise missiles attack.

title: Apocalyptic Meditations: Every Faith Has a View
description: Apocalypse? Now? It depends who you're talking to. One in four Christians believe that Jesus will return in their lifetime, an Associated Press poll reported in 1997. The idea, popular in some groups, that the apocalypse and the coming of Jesus will occur on Jan. 1, 2000 is derived, -- imperfectly, perhaps -- from the Bible, which nowhere gives an exact date for the event.

title: Dig in Texas Fails to Find Atheist Figure Or Her Family
description: Federal agents searched two remote sites in Texas today, stepping up the search for the body of Madalyn Murray O'Hair, the atheist leader who disappeared in 1995 with her son, her granddaughter and $500,000 in gold coins, Government officials here said.

title: Collapsed Lung Will Keep Lindros Off the Ice for Flyers
description: The Philadelphia Flyers suffered a serious blow to their Stanley Cup aspirations yesterday. Eric Lindros, who may be the most dominant player in the National Hockey League, will miss the remainder of the regular season with a collapsed right lung.

title: Jets Gain Respect, and a Brutal Schedule
description: For a team that once spent 12 straight weeks on the road because the Mets did not want them trampling their precious grass, the Jets are learning that being good, and famous, is a mixed blessing.

title: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Beliefs; A year after a much-criticized Vatican document on the Holocaust, Jewish and Christian scholars find even its weaknesses a tool of reconciliation.
description: Last Sunday, on the brink of a week when Jews and Christians were to remember and re-enact core moments of their faiths, it was appropriate that Jewish and Christian scholars should gather to discuss a document called ''We Remember.''

title: A Tribute to a Gay Student Who Was Slain
description: ''Remembering Matthew Shepard: A Vigil in Dance,'' presented by the MorganScott Ballet on Tuesday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, paid homage to Mr. Shepard, the Wyoming college student murdered in October, with rousing music and luminous, joyous dance.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Rupert Murdoch's plan to buy the 50 percent stake owned by Liberty Media in their joint sports venture misstated the status of his purchase of the British soccer team Manchester United. Mr. Murdoch's satellite company, BSkyB, has bid for the team. It does not own it.

title: Gambling Requires More Than Luck; Against the Law?
description: To the Editor:

title: Korea Outlook Improves
description: South Korea's economic growth this year may exceed the 2 percent forecast by the International Monetary Fund just two months ago, the lender's top Asian official said today.

title: What's On at Lincoln Center Festival '99
description: The long-delayed premiere of the 16th-century Chinese opera ''The Peony Pavilion'' and a series of nine concerts devoted to African-American gospel music are among the highlights of Lincoln Center Festival '99, which runs from July 6 to 25.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Guadalajara Journal; Daylight Savings, the Worst of Times
description: The temperate plains of midland Mexico have become the cradle of a citizens' revolt, an upswell of discontent against the despotism of the national authorities in Mexico City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANZ, FLORENCE
description: GANZ-Florence. Beloved mother, grandmother and great grandmother. We all loved you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHMAN, ARLYNE
description: GERSHMAN-Arlyne. Loving wife, mother and grandmother of five, died March 30 in Tarzana, CA. Funeral on Sunday, April 4th, Parkside Memorial Chapel, Brooklyn, New York, at 10:00 A.M.

title: Op-Art; This Page Brought to You by . . .
Ex-Police Chief Breaks Ranks, Testifying Against His Men
description: He has admitted everything: the payoffs, the kickbacks, the shakedowns and the bribes. In his resigned and raspy voice, he has declared himself a liar, a loan shark, even a common thief.

title: Corrections
description: A version of this chart, showing the types of targets NATO has emphasized, ran yesterday without the key.

title: Royal Opera Finds Drama In Concert Of Favorites
description: With the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden closed for renovations since 1997, the orchestra that accompanies the company's performances has busied itself with touring, sometimes with staged productions, sometimes with concerts of arias and overtures. New York audiences have had both: two summers ago, the Lincoln Center Festival imported the Royal Opera's staging of Pfitzner's ''Palestrina,'' and on Sunday afternoon, the orchestra, conducted by Edward Downes, brought four young English singers for a concert of favorites by Verdi, Weber, Strauss, Puccini and Wagner at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: McDougal Witness Describes Pressure From Prosecutors
description: Two parts of the wide-ranging investigation of President Clinton converged here today, when a woman testified in behalf of a former business partner of the President and his wife, Hillary.

title: NISSAN MAY END DAIMLERCHRYSLER TRUCK PACT
description: In the first sign of an overhaul after selling a 37 percent stake to Renault S.A. the Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest auto maker, said yesterday that it might end its light-truck venture with DaimlerChrysler A.G. DaimlerChrysler had been in talks about taking a stake in Nissan but abandoned those plans last month. ''Renault aside, we're reviewing each of our product plans, and the same goes for trucks,'' a Nissan spokeswoman, Miki Obana, said. The company declined to comment on a report in a Japanese newspaper, Nihon Keizai, that it might also end its agreement to make minivans with the Ford Motor Company. Ford would say only that it has an agreement with Nissan to produce minivans through 2004.

title: An Environmentalist on a Different Path; A Fresh View of the Supposed 'Wilderness' and Even the Indians' Place in It
description: On the short flight from Chicago on a clear cold day, the descent into Madison is not a bad way to begin to understand William Cronon and the ideas that have made him a pivotal and provocative figure in the growing field of environmental history.

title: When Play Is Physical, Camby Sits For Knicks
description: Coach Jeff Van Gundy hands out Marcus Camby to the crowds as if the lanky, amiable forward were a candy treat. On special occasions, Van Gundy allows everyone to get a little taste of Camby's talents.

title: The Second Front in the Balkans
description: The torrent of refugees surging out of Kosovo has overwhelmed the international effort to help them. If more assistance is not rushed to the region by the United States and its European allies, thousands of lives will be imperiled. President Clinton's pledge of more financial aid for humanitarian organizations is welcome, but the scale of the exodus requires the immediate mobilization of American and European governmental resources to transport water, food, clothing, medicine and temporary shelter to the regions that border Kosovo.

title: Columbia University Explores How to Profit From Educational Offerings on the Internet
description: Joining the race to the Internet and its riches, Columbia University has formed a company and hopes to make a profit by providing courses, research and other university material on line.

title: China Manages to Keep Its Economy Humming
description: Construction teams still work around the clock in China's largest city, one sign among many that the nation's overall economy is defying predictions by outsiders who expected it to sputter this year.

title: Partisan Churches
description: Religious groups that want to engage in partisan politics have every right to do so, but they must play by the same rules as everyone else. A Federal District Court judge defended this principle this week when he ruled that a church engaging in blatantly partisan activities can be stripped of its tax-exempt status and its right to receive tax-deductible contributions.

title: Amid a Flurry of Demotions, Mets Make Kinkade's Day
description: One demoted Mets player said he was upset enough to jump off a bridge. Another stormed out of the team's training base without a word. And still another asked to be traded today, as the Mets pared down to their opening-day roster.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: THE YOUNG SEMINARIANS
description: The number of men studying for the priesthood has plummeted. Those at Mount Saint Mary's Seminary say it's the world, not the church, that has to change. A report by Jennifer Egan, in The Times Magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, SHAPIRO, AMY S.
description: KLEIN-SHAPIRO-Amy S. Lovingly remembered today and always. The family

title: Let Teachers Write the Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; For Harrick, An Honor That Stings
description: IN the spirit of rewarding deeds at the appropriate level, I have come up with an annual post-season collegiate athletic award of my own: the Great Barracuda Award.

title: Mayors Express Support For State Police Program
description: In the wake of steady criticism of the state police from prominent blacks around the state, a group of rural mayors have joined together to express their support for the force and to praise its community policing program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANDE, SARINA
description: GRANDE-Sarina, on March 30, 1999. Patron of the arts and opera. Listed in Who's Who of American Women and very active in ItalianAmerican charitable organizations. Beloved wife of the late Frank Grande. Sister of Santa D'Angelo and the late Carmelo and Liborio D'Amato. Aunt of Marie Kallmeyer, Aimee Wallas and the late Frank D'Amato, and great-aunt of five nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Friday, 7-9 PM, and Saturday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Saviour Church, Park Ave. at 38th St., Monday, 10 AM. Interment to follow.

title: Jobless Rate In U.S. Hits 29-Year Low
description: The nation's jobless rate dropped in March to its lowest level in 29 years, the Labor Department reported yesterday, falling from 4.4 percent in February to 4.2 percent in the latest of many signs that the labor market in the United States remains remarkably robust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELLER, IRWIN
description: MELLER-Irwin. On April 2, 1999. A stockbroker with Grayson and Burger in Greenwich, Connecticut. Beloved and loving husband of Carola. Devoted father to Louise Meller and Jay Lukowski and John and Rita Meller. Doting grandfather to Aliza and Rebecca Lukowski and Kevin Meller. He was also a loving uncle, great uncle and great, great uncle. Born in Brooklyn, New York, son of the late John and Lena Payman Meller, he was a World War II Navy veteran attaining the rank of Lt. Commander. Funeral services on Sunday, April 4th at 11 A.M., in Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, New York. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Catholic Bishops Seek End to Death Penalty
description: In their first statement in 19 years focusing exclusively on opposing the death penalty, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops issued a call yesterday to ''all people of good will, and especially Catholics,'' to work to end capital punishment.

title: Climbing Brooklyn Bridge as Stunt, Man Falls to Death
description: A 27-year-old man apparently hoping to gain a spot in the Guinness Book of World Records fell to his death yesterday morning while scaling a steel suspension cable on the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Browns Rushing Into Existence
description: Al Lerner recently watched his first indoor practice and nearly got trampled. Lerner, the billionaire owner of the expansion Cleveland Browns, lingered on a sideline, his hands in his pants pockets, when halfback Malcolm Thomas raced full speed toward him.

title: Yankees Must Make a Decision, and Soon
description: Wearing the same disheveled clothes and the same dour expression from the surreal day before, Hideki Irabu sat inside a conference room yesterday and listened to men speak to him about his precarious career with the Yankees. As usual, the Yankees are unsure if the words penetrated Irabu's consciousness.

title: Today, Parents Need All Advice They Can Get
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Officers, One Likely Strategy
description: Two words among the thousands in New York State's penal code will decide the fate of the four police officers who fired 41 bullets at Amadou Diallo. The words are ''reasonably believes.''

title: Low Prices Have Sapped Little Oil Producers
description: Even after a 30 percent jump in crude oil prices last month, Terry Smith, the general manager of the Tidelands Oil Production Company, is not sure it is time to begin reopening oil wells.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN SLIPS. The dollar gained after a senior Japanese Finance Ministry official spoke against excessive yen strength, which raises the cost of Japanese exports. The dollar rose to 120.55 yen yesterday, from 120.43.

title: Abroad at Home; Time To Get Serious
description: United States policy toward the terrorism of Slobodan Milosevic has been constrained in the past by our public's wariness of military involvement abroad. We remember Vietnam, and Somalia.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Jobless Rate Plunges

title: Mendoza Named to Start As Irabu Awaits Fate
description: Don Zimmer acted swiftly the day after the misadventure of Hideki Irabu by naming Ramiro Mendoza as the Yankees' starter for Wednesday's game against the Oakland Athletics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SATNICK, ANNA
description: SATNICK-Anna. On April 1st, 1999, at age 90. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Loving mother of Roslyn Radler, Elliott Satnick, Robert Satnick and Marsha Bassen. Devoted grandmother of 12 and greatgrandmother of 19. She will be long remembered. Services and interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, ADELAIDE
description: SHAW-Adelaide (nee Miller). On March 30, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Alan & Linda. Dear aunt of Roger & Fran Nemet and Susan Nemet. She will be deeply missed. Service is on Sunday, at 11:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Statehouse Journal; School Crisis Chips Away at New Hampshire's Anti-Tax Stance
description: Does this sound like the New Hampshire known for its ferocious aversion to taxes?

title: A Riddle at the Register; When Is a Knish Tax Free? When It's Frozen, of Course
description: Sure, it was a small thing, but to shopkeepers, it was a milestone nonetheless. Last year, New York abolished marshmallow discrimination, the long-standing rule that while marshmallows were subject to the sales tax, mini-marshmallows were not.

title: LEAR BUYS A CANADIAN CAR-SEAT PLANT FROM PEREGRINE
description: The Lear Corporation, the world's leading maker of automobile seats, has bought a seat and door-panel plant in Canada from Peregrine Inc. for an undisclosed sum. The plant, in Windsor, Ontario, employs 1,231 workers, more than half of Peregrine's total work force of 2,200, and makes parts for the Chevrolet Lumina and Monte Carlo and other General Motors cars. Peregrine had sales of $420 million last year. G.M. is Lear's largest customer.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSHEN, HARRIETT BESS BURRESS
description: GROSHEN-Harriett Bess Burress. On April 1, age 69. Born in Jonesboro, AK, she died in her home in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved daughter, wife, sister, sister-in-law, mother, mother-in-law, aunt, grandmother and friend. All who knew her were touched by her grace, kindness and humor. Memorial service: 1:00 PM Saturday, April 3 at the Kenilworth Church, 24 Kenilworth Place, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sentto God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, NY, NY 10013 attention Contributions. We carry her love, Susan, Penny, Erica, David and Marc

title: Courier, in Old Form, and Martin Put U.S. Ahead
description: He had watched Jim Courier scratch and claw and crack forehands like the Courier of old against Tim Henman. He had watched Todd Martin dismiss the world's fastest server with uncanny ease. And now the British Davis Cup captain David Lloyd had reached an unexpected conclusion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ARTHUR T.
description: KATZ-Arthur T. Died peacefully on Thursday morning. Beloved husband and best friend of Ruth. Loving father of Steven, Paul (Yoko) John (Tracy) and proud grandfather of Jed and Spencer. Brother of Alice (Marty) and Richard (Verna) and dear uncle. Graduate of Dartmouth 1956, former president of Holbrook Shirt Company and later involved with commercial real estate with Edward S. Gordon. Service at Gutterman's, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, 12 noon Sunday April 4, 1999. In lieu of flowers donations to The American Cancer Society.

title: For Madrid Boys, Fate Is Uniformly Grim
description: You don't have to be a 15-year-old boy from a housing project on the outskirts of Madrid to empathize with the frustrations of Rai (Crispulo Cabezas), Javi (Timy) and Manu (Eloi Yebra), the three Spanish teen-agers who are the subjects of Fernando Leon de Aranoa's bleak film, ''Barrio.'' This powerful neo-realist movie plumbs the adolescent male psyche with such relentless accuracy that the characters' anxieties about work, sex and the future take on a universal resonance. If you ever spent a restless self-questioning summer trapped at home, pining to be older and fretting about how you would make it through adolescence, ''Barrio'' will take you back to those excruciating times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, MARK
description: SANDLER-Mark. On April 2, 1999 at the age of 93. Beloved husband of the late Edythe, loving father of Nancy and David Gavrin and Ellen Sandler. Dearest grandfather of Andrew, Beth, Barbara, Joanne and Meredith. Great grandfather of three. Funeral service at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, Sunday, April 4th at 10:30AM.

title: Film Scores As the Base To Work On
description: In the last decade, Terence Blanchard's creamy-sweet trumpet tone has led him into film soundtracks, specifically, a close collaboration with Spike Lee, in which jazz is often used in its romantically idealized form for mood-setting. The career-turn made him more of a soloist than a band player, and while he has continued to play regular nightclub jazz sets -- periodically with the alto saxophonist Donald Harrison, a partner from the early 1980's -- his bands haven't caused much of a stir in some time.

title: NATO HITS BELGRADE CENTER FOR FIRST TIME, RAZING COMMAND SITES FOR KOSOVO FIGHTING
description: After nine days of hesitation, NATO attacked the center of Yugoslavia's capital, destroying the headquarters of the security forces carrying out President Slobodan Milosevic's offensive against the ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

title: Algerian Journalists Assert Their Independence Just by Surviving the Purges
description: Omar Bellouchet's name is not on the ballot for the presidential election on April 15, an election that many of Algeria's voters see as a gateway to democracy. But many Algerians consider him and others like him at least as important to hopes of freedom as any of the presidential candidates.

title: One Missed His Chance and One Didn't
description: When Mane was a teen-ager he had his chance. He was such an outstanding soccer player that he was invited to play for a professional team in Lisbon, but he turned down the offer and stayed at home in the Cape Verde islands. Now, turning 50, he struggles to make a living at the small bar he owns and goes home to a disappointed wife and a disappointing grandson (a lousy soccer player) at the end of the day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIN, MARIE A.
description: FREIN-Marie A. On April 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Eugene. Loving mother of Marie Burke, John, Eugene, Ann Luca, Regina Coronata, Joseph and the late Lawrence. Also survived by thirteen wonderful grandchildren. Reposing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28 St., NYC, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Resurrection, Monday 10AM at Immaculate Conception Church, 14th Street and 1st Avenue, NYC. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, IRA
description: KRAUSS-Ira. Of New York City and Delray Beach, FL, passed away April 3, 1999. Beloved husband of Tobi; loving father and father-in-law of Maxine & Vincent J. Hilliard, Joanne Krauss & Robert L. Nowicki; brother of George; devoted grandfather of James, Robert and Richard Hilliard, and Jessica and Robert Nowicki; accountant to Aaron Copeland and many others. Graveside Services Tuesday April 6 at 1PM, New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Choirgirls
description: The Sopranos

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-4-99 -- Vocal Minority; The Tyranny of the Slugger
description: As the baseball season begins and the nation turns its eager eyes to St. Louis -- will Mark McGwire hit 71 this year? -- I'm feeling a bit disaffected. I think pitchers understand. It was, after all, the Indians' Hall of Fame spitballer Stanley Coveleski who once remarked, ''Lord, baseball is a worrying thing.'' The source of my concern is the source of so many other people's pleasure: all those home runs last season. A record 5,064 of them were hit, while more people than ever -- about 70 million -- attended major league games. The postulate seems clear: if you hit them, we will come.

title: Chasing Glory, Piedmont Style
description: THE setting sun -- and the rush-hour commuters -- lead the way westward on Interstate 66 from Washington. After an eternity -- but only about 30 miles -- the traffic gradually begins to thin, the town house developments, shopping centers, and hi-tech office parks become fewer and farther apart, and the first discernible shapes and shadows of the Blue Ridge Mountains appear on the horizon. The driver has entered another world: Virginia's northern Piedmont region, more commonly called the Virginia hunt country.

title: Volatile Issues Await China's Premeir in U.S.
description: Zhu Rongji, China's charismatic Prime Minister and the driving force behind its current ambitious economic reforms, arrives in the United States next week determined to fight the downward spiral in Chinese-American relations.

title: Members of the Club
description: THE COLOR OF TRUTH

title: Fewer Doctors: Who Benefits?
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 4, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIESS, GERALD G.
description: RIESS-Gerald G. On April 3, 1999. Beloved husband of Regina. Devoted father of Lillian Pincus and father-in-law of Robert Pincus. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan and Lauren. Co-founder and past President of Liberty Lodge #

title: A Meaty Drink
description: Why take steroids when you can drink Pindar Vineyards's 1995 reserve cabernet sauvignon?

title: Rediscovering An American Classic By Way of Britain; A Country of Lesser Giants
description: PICTURE a Mount Rushmore in honor of the monumental characters of American drama. What faces do you see there, carved in stone? Willy Loman, Blanche DuBois, Theodore (Hickey) Hickman and Mary Cavan Tyrone. But has our country yet produced drama worthy to set beside the Greek tragedians, Shakespeare, Calderon, Schiller, Ibsen, Chekhov? I think not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEVERTZ, ALLAN H.
description: GEVERTZ-Allan H. On April 1, 1999 at the age of 70. Devoted father of John and the late Bruce. Father-in-law of Susan and Jacqueline. Adoring grandfather of Rebecca, Annie, William, Justin and Andrew. Funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday, 10AM. Interment will be private. Friends may also call at Campbell's on Monday, from 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There are 13 million people who are at the same time against him and for him. He will be even stronger now than before it started. I don't know why American analysts even get a salary.''

title: A Robust 'Wanderer'
description: SCHUBERT: 'WANDERER' FANTASY (ARRANGED BY LISZT), SYMPHONIES NOS. 3 AND 8

title: Concealing While Revealing: O'Neill's Way With Truth
description: ''I do not think that you can write anything of value or understanding about the present. You can only write about life if it is far enough in the past. The present is too much mixed up with superficial values; you can't know which thing is important and which is not.''

title: Derek Jeter: The Pride of Kalamazoo
description: The scout was a careful man, never given to hyperbole, distinguished and respected, with a courtly manner that earned him the nickname of the Prince in his days as a pitcher. He watched 17-year-old Derek Jeter play baseball in the summer of 1991 in Kalamazoo, Mich., tracking him into the spring of 1992. He liked Jeter's arm and lean frame and his speed, but the scout looked for more.

title: Celebrating Spring With a Light Dinner
description: SOFT-SHELL crabs, spring lamb and fava beans are now coming into their peak season. Joe Trama, the chef at Grace's Marketplace in Manhattan, puts together a light spring dinner to celebrate the season. It begins with a salad made with crisp sauteed soft-shell crabs served on a bed of arugula mixed with blood oranges and slivers of fennel. The main course is roast spring lamb flavored with rosemary, thyme and cinnamon, served with fava beans tossed in lemon juice and olive oil. Strawberries with creme fraiche rounds out the meal perfectly.

title: Fury Over Diallo Case Barely Resonates at Giuliani Events Upstate
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had not yet addressed the 700 business and political leaders squeezed into a college gymnasium to eat filet mignon and hear his tips for transforming troubled cities into centers of prosperity. But as the dinner rolls were passed, Peter Goold was already exuding enthusiasm about New York City's graffiti-free subways and litter-free streets.

title: A Trade to End The Balkan War; Before Ground Troops
description: To the Editor:

title: Learning the Air-Fare Ropes
description: CHARLES BITTENBRING says he knows one thing about air fares: They are too complex for the average mortal.

title: POSTINGS: 54 Condo Town Houses and 108 Rental Apartments in Edgewater, N.J.; On a Pier in the Hudson, Modular Homes
description: For a few minutes it dangles above the Hudson River before a crane lowers the housing module onto its perch on a pier jutting 800 feet into the water in Edgewater N.J.

title: Flocking to the I.R.S. Site
description: The Internal Revenue Service has been reaching out to taxpayers on the Internet since 1996, and this year, taxpayers are reaching back in record numbers. From Jan. 1 through last Sunday, the I.R.S. Web site was visited 573.6 million times, up from 231 million during the same period a year ago.

title: It's Never Too Late to Shoot the Jumper
description: NOT wanting to lose her touch, Barbara Frasca of Wethersfield made it a point during a recent two-week vacation in Florida to get out and shoot baskets almost every day.

title: Ideas & Trends; Help! There's a Mausu in My Konpyutaa!
description: TOSHIYKI SHIMIZU picked up a computer instruction manual and frowned.

title: Housing Developer's Plan Roils Stony Brook
description: THE Ward Melville Heritage Organization, a nonprofit group that is the major force in historic preservation in Stony Brook, is in hot water with village residents again, this time over a plan to sell 36 acres overlooking the village center to a developer who wants to turn the property into a 40-house subdivision.

title: Activism's New Face
description: To the Editor:

title: State Backs Debated Plan For Turnpike Link With Route 1
description: State environmental experts last week announced their approval of the proposed Route 92 in Middlesex County, a $350 million project to connect the turnpike with Route 1. The decision put them at odds with Federal environmentalists, who have said the road should not be built because of its adverse effect on wetlands.

title: Riding the Wild, Perilous Waters of Amazon.com
description: As the author of a new book, I am among those with warm feelings toward Amazon.com. My book received strong, initial reviews. But my publisher is a small house, with limited funds for marketing. When people ask where they can find my book, you bet I send them to Amazon. If that makes me a ''bovine missionary,'' so be it.

title: All the President's Women
description: Uncovering Clinton

title: Distance Learning; A Sampler of Cyberschools
description: Everyone seems to be jumping on the distance-learning bandwagon, prodded by the possibilities of the Internet.

title: Blackboard: Scholarships; The $23,390 Question
description: Is truth in the eye of the beholder? Students at the University of Richmond want to know. And the person posing that question, a senior philosophy major named Larina Orlando, is $23,390 richer just for the asking.

title: Hopscotching at 10,000, Dow Gets Our Attention
description: It was easy to dismiss the Dow's close above 10,000 last Monday as merely symbolic, just one more market milestone -- and a not very enduring one at that, given the index's fall later in the week.

title: Meiji Treasures Displayed in Delaware
description: Fifteen years after Commodore Matthew Perry led an American fleet into Tokyo Bay in 1853 and began to open Japan to the West, the Shogun warlords there put down their swords and the Emperor was restored to power. The years that followed, until 1912, are known as the Meiji era.

title: An Older and Wiser Horatio
description: Gregory Peck stars in CAPTAIN HORATIO HORNBLOWER, Raoul Walsh's 1951 adaptation of C.S. Forester's tale of a heroic British captain battling the French, and sometimes himself, during the Napoleonic Wars. Mr. Peck's captain is more experienced and less disarmingly awkward than the midshipman who becomes the hero of the new Hornblower series on A&E tonight, but the focus of this colorful high-seas adventure is the same: heavy doses of cannon booms, sword swishing and storm-swept decks with just enough romance (supplied by Virginia Mayo as Lady Barbara) to keep the rigging tight. There's the midnight boarding of a Spanish warship, the sneak raid of Hornblower's lone ship on a French port and the his mates from their captors in France. The drama of this well-calculated film may be less complex than Forester's fiction, but Mr. Peck and a manly cast that includes Robert Beatty and James R. Justice keep the galleons rolling - MONDAY at 10 P.M. on AMC.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 14 about art exhibitions in Europe included an outdated reference to the closing of a show in London. The show, ''Neurotic Realism: Part One'' at the Saatchi Gallery, has been extended to Aug. 15.

title: Lives; Instant Intimacy
description: Generally, the rule in the subway is silence. This is not, of course, to say that you are in a silent world. You are in a metal car weighing several tons, riding on rimless metal wheels, driven by crackling electrical charges and surrounded by hard, reverberant surfaces. The noise, especially on corners, when all the moving metal parts of the train seem to rub horridly together, is high, piercing and cacophonous enough to drive you mad. So that simply standing alone in the subway car, without anyone else in it, you are under a kind of attack.

title: Government Is Ready for Y2K
description: Through a combination of subtle pressure and public exhortation, a White House official named John A. Koskinen has galvanized a small army of Federal computer managers to get their machines in shape for the year 2000.

title: NATO, In A Corner
description: If the current bombing campaign in Yugoslavia fails to end the bloodshed in Kosovo soon, the United States and NATO will have suffered a very serious defeat and will face a very unpleasant choice: Do we tuck our tail between our legs or do we mount a land campaign involving several hundred thousand troops and the certainty of substantial casualties?

title: On the Trail Of Peconic Radiation
description: ''Misleading Fallout From Radiation'' was a reasoned and balanced reply to the anti-radiation extremists. One point that could have been more forcibly made, however, is that if all manmade radiation were eliminated, we would still be subject to radiation received from space. Thus, we can never exist in a no-radiation environment.

title: Violinist Takes Helm of Performers Group
description: WHEN the pianist Joel Rosen died on Nov. 17, the future of Performers of Westchester -- the organization he founded and nourished through 18 years -- seemed in doubt. Now that concern has passed. ''It is a new era without Joel,'' said Linda Caigan, a member of the board of directors. ''But we are indeed fortunate to have the superb violinist Alexander Simionescu assume the role as artistic director. He has extended himself with a positive energy that we all feel, and our new lineup is varied and exciting. Clearly, Joel's spirit will continue.''

title: Riding the Wild, Perilous Waters of Amazon.com
description: Peter de Jonge's article (March 14) left me in awe not only of Amazon.com's organizational acumen but also of its ability to round up investors, despite its constant losses. While the article mentioned Amazon's annual sales and how many credit-card numbers it has on file, I would be curious to find out the size of its average order. It's one thing to be ''customer-obsessed'' when you're selling big-ticket items. It's quite another when the sale involved will gross the equivalent of dinner for two at Wendy's. Although you might think that a sale is a sale, as the owner of a tiny mail-order business I've found invariably that our most demanding, time-wasting customers are our smallest.

title: Warnings Ignored
description: In a survey of anglers fishing in the Hudson River in the summer of 1996, the State Health Department found that despite warnings some fishermen were eating fish contaminated with polychlorinated biphenyls and serving them to others.

title: Some Trimming at Invesco
description: The Invesco Funds Group, based in Denver, is asking shareholders to approve eight fund mergers and the closure of three other funds, reducing the number of Invesco offerings by about 25 percent. The vote is scheduled for May 20.

title: Small Business Success
description: The results of a State Tax Department report last month show that New York's one million small businesses account for half of the state's total employment and nearly half of all business receipts.

title: Jennie Shi, Phillip Choo
description: Jennie M. Shi, the daughter of Zin-Tzai and Chu-Shung Shi of Hazlet, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Phillip H. Choo, a son of Young Bok Choo and Myung Hak Choo of Gadsden, Ala. The Rev. Thomas C. Wray, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Knicks Needed To Make Changes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DEALS AND DISCOUNTS
description: SCANDINAVIA ON YOUR OWN -- An 11-night independent tour of Finland, Sweden, Norway and Denmark is offered by Norvista starting at $1,999 a person, double occupancy, including round-trip flights on Finnair from New York. Weekly departures start May 2 and run through October, with the lowest prices in early May and in October; peak-season departures, June 13 through Aug. 29, start at $2,399. The itinerary, called Scandinavian Enchantment, includes two overnight cruises (cabins provided) -- one from Helsinki to Stockholm, and one from Oslo to Copenhagen -- and an excursion by rail and boat between Bergen and Oslo. It also includes hotels, buffet breakfasts, smorgasbord dinners, other transportation in Scandinavia and museum admissions. Reservations: (800) 526-4927 or (212) 818-1198.

title: Q&A/Richard E. Evans; The Market as Less of a Guessing Game
description: STORIES abound of chimpanzees exceeding the financial pundits by throwing darts at newspapers to pick stocks. Most people, by contrast, try to pick their stocks more scientifically, using judgment or relying on the judgment of someone else. But Richard E. Evans of Hastings-on-Hudson, said that because judgment is so fallible the best way to invest is by minimizing judgment.

title: Translating Miles
description: To the Editor:

title: Roosevelt Islanders Make Case for Self-Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Weed a Little, Feed a Little, Cut a Little
description: Prune late-summer and fall-blooming shrubs like Japanese bush clover (Lespedeza thunbergii), bluebeard (Caryopteris x clandonensis) and butterfly bush (Buddleia davidii) to within two or three buds of the low framework of old wood. Finish pruning and fertilizing roses before there is an abundance of new growth.

title: Some Managers Manage to Find the Needles in the Global Haystack
description: SOUTH KOREAN beer. Japanese pinball. A globe-trotting British cybergame adventuress who wears tight T-shirts and packs two pistols.

title: What the Jumans Didn't Know About Michael
description: In retrospect, we can see that Louise Wise Services was misguided. However, with a different shuffle of the same genetic cards, the outcome might have been a happy rather than a tragic one. Instead, we are left with an example of how a myth that originated as a way of dealing with our helplessness against a frightening condition is reinterpreted as deliberate deception.

title: Blackboard: Guides; Campus As Architecture
description: Enclosed neatly within Yale's boundaries is a virtual time line of historically significant styles: the Puritan-era, barnlike Connecticut Hall, a prototype for American colleges that was built in the 1750's; the Gothic, otherworldly Dwight Chapel of the mid-1800's; and the modern, utilitarian Kline Geology Laboratory designed by Philip Johnson in 1963.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Boscobel Etiquette Program

title: Fallen Friends
description: To the Editor:

title: By Paste Pot and Stealth of Night
description: LAMPPOSTS and telephone poles in the East Village and on the Lower East Side commonly serve as informal community bulletin boards, bearing advertisements of theatrical events, notices of available apartments and announcements of rallies.

title: Sunday Best
description: Back in the 40's, country people would have their pictures taken after church by a visiting photographer. We decided to revive that tradition in the mountains of eastern Kentucky, where the churchgoers were dressed in clothes evocative of that earlier time but every bit as stately as their own Sunday best.

title: Private Sector; O.K., You're Famous; Now Get Back to Work
description: He was the toast of the international banking community. But not, on this occasion at least, for his financial expertise. Kenneth Lipper, chairman of Lipper & Company, which manages $5 billion for pension funds and wealthy individuals, shared the Oscar last month for best documentary feature for ''The Final Days.'' Mr. Lipper was co-producer of the film, which is about Holocaust survivors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMAN, HALINA
description: NEUMAN-Halina. On April 2, 1999. Loving mother of the late Jola Hoffman. Cherished grandmother of Kenneth, Marc, David and Estes Hoffman. Great-grandmother of Jay, Leah, Phoebe, Stephen and Michael. Halina was a Holocaust survivor, pianist and teacher. She will be greatly missed. Graveside services Sunday, 1:30 PM at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Private Sector; An On-Line Reincarnation
description: Dan Dorfman's ability to move stocks has long been well known. As a financial journalist for USA Today, CNBC and Money magazine, Mr. Dorfman over two decades often sent stocks soaring with predictions of takeovers or other news -- some of which actually panned out.

title: Corrections
description: A review in the Book Review last Sunday about ''Me,'' a satire by Garrison Keillor, misspelled the surname of a former coach of the New York Jets. He was Weeb Ewbank, not Eubank.

title: As Big Gains Increase the Bite, More Funds Try to Offset Taxes
description: TAX-MANAGED mutual funds -- those that seek to maximize after-tax gains rather than gross returns -- are among the latest trends in the fund industry. More than half the 22 such funds tracked by Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher, were introduced after 1996, and combined assets in them have grown from $3.19 billion to $15.36 billion over that period.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WHAT THE PEOPLE KNOW

title: You Don't Have To Be Jewish
description: SEVEN years ago, Rabbi Yakov M. Dombroff found himself before the state's highest court on the losing end of a lawsuit.

title: India Offers Rights to Attract Its Offspring's Cash
description: The Indian Government this week initiated a program that will make it easier for people of Indian descent sprinkled around the globe to travel to their familial homeland and to invest in it, but stopped short of giving them the right to vote, as many of them have sought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIESENFELD, STANLEY
description: RIESENFELD-Stanley. Adored husband of Nancy. Beloved father of Danielle and Lauren, Michelle and Adam. Dear son-in-law of Jackie and Harvey, loving brother-in-law of Judy, Barbara and Ken. Cherished uncle to Jodi, Lisa, Jonathan, Jessie, and sister-in-law to Patty. ''He was special to all who knew him''. Services Sunday 11am at Congregation Knesseth Tifereth Israel, 575 King Street, Port Chester.

title: Knicks Try To Heal In Mind And Body
description: With a victory over the Indiana Pacers just four days ago, Coach Jeff Van Gundy did not need to remind the Knicks of strategies or tendencies as they worked out today at SUNY-Purchase. But what the team did need before flying off to face the Pacers in Indianapolis for a nationally televised game on Sunday afternoon was the gentle stretching and massaging of the training staff and the not-so-gentle massaging of their minds by the coaching staff.

title: Before Circle in Square
description: To the Editor:

title: Hopscotching at 10,000, Dow Gets Our Attention
description: It was easy to dismiss the Dow's close above 10,000 last Monday as merely symbolic, just one more market milestone -- and a not very enduring one at that, given the index's fall later in the week.

title: Baffert's Charges Lead in the West
description: Bob Baffert is back in charge of the 3-year-old division.

title: Hershiser And Yoshii Competing
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine will have to decide soon between Masato Yoshii and Orel Hershiser as his fourth starter.

title: 4 Who Won With Technology
description: MANY mutual fund managers eked out small gains in the quarter just ended, with the average domestic diversified equity fund returning just 1.26 percent, according to Morningstar Inc.

title: Life From the Sea, Life to the Classroom
description: OFTENTIMES, Cory Weyant, a commercial fisherman from Freeport, can be found smoking eels in his smokehouse. Sometimes, he's out on the bay, catching clams or trapping crabs and fishing for bait. But on cooler days, Mr. Weyant can be found working as a pedagogue.

title: Dow Finishes Above 10,000 Before Getting a Hangover
description: The trek of the Dow Jones industrial average has looked like an assault on Everest lately -- a steady march toward the summit for its select group of 30 stocks, leaving most of the others behind at base camp.

title: Only Compare
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-4-99 -- The Ethicist; The Bad Cop
description: 'I was in a cab when a cop threatened the driver: hand over $20 or be issued a $100 ticket (for a made-up offense). The driver grudgingly accepted. I worried that if I intervened it would end up worse for the driver. Did I do the right thing?'

title: Chef Makes Mom Proud, Diners Happy
description: ''THE kid can cook,'' said the smiling woman as she left Trio in Patchogue. Kevin Stahl, the chef and owner of this restaurant on West Main Street, is no kid. He is old enough to have graduated from culinary school and worked elsewhere (the Country House in Stony Brook) before he opened his own place last summer. Still, the happy diner was just echoing the sentiments of the restaurant's hostess that evening, who, incidentally, was Mr. Stahl's mother. To our mothers, we all remain children.

title: Uninvited Visitor Gobbles the Greens
description: ONE of the best things to happen to salads in decades is that zippy Italian green called arugula. It's literally a weed in Italy, and it would grow just as easily in anybody's garden if not for one tiny problem: the flea beetle.

title: The View From/Westport; Open for Discussion: World of Children's Books
description: A DOZEN children, each one accompanied by a parent, sat on carpeted steps in the program room of the Westport Public Library on a recent Sunday afternoon, listening as 9-year-old Carey Chiaia outlined the story of the book ''Ben and Me'', by Robert Lawson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, JOHN J., ESQ
description: ROSS-John J., Esq. On April 3, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth (nee Doonan). Loving father of Elizabeth Rutigliano, John, Mary C.S.J., Dolores, Bernard and Bernadette Devlin. Fond brother of James, Thomas and Helen Ross. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor, 9105 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Thomas More Church, Wednesday, 9:30 AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Visiting Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-10. ''And until we meet again, may God hold you in the palm of His hand.'' In lieu of flowers donations to Providence House would be appreciated.

title: BUSINESS/INVESTING; Hopscotching at 10,000, Dow Gets Our Attention
description: It was easy to dismiss the Dow's close above 10,000 last Monday as merely symbolic, just one more market milestone -- and a not very enduring one at that, given the index's fall later in the week.

title: NATO Is Wary of Proposals To Help Arm Kosovo Rebels
description: With the NATO bombing campaign in Yugoslavia so far unable to deter the atrocities in Kosovo, and the United States unwilling to commit ground troops, the idea of arming the Kosovo guerrillas has garnered support from a number of politicians and former policymakers.

title: The Market Looks Greater Than the Sum of Its Parts
description: ALTHOUGH it's fun to see who's hot and who's not among mutual fund managers each quarter, the real value of the performance figures lies in the stock market intelligence they provide. A look behind the numbers can help reveal the overall market's strength or weakness. Closer scrutiny can help gauge the current mood and vulnerabilities of investors.

title: It's the Year of 'Giselle,' If Anyone Needs to Be Told
description: IT'S a ''Giselle'' kind of year. The many outings of this hugely popular ballet, loved by audiences and dancers alike, have included a United States tour by Alicia Alonso's Cuban National Ballet and Mats Ek's insane-asylum version at the Paris Opera Ballet. A newer version, the Russian choreographer Boris Eifman's ''Red Giselle,'' played at City Center in New York, and now the newest of all, San Francisco Ballet's ''Giselle,'' will have its premiere here at the War Memorial Opera House on Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 21 about Cassandra Wilson's latest recording misstated the given name of her father and the instrument he played. He was Herman Fowlkes, not Henry, and he was a bassist, not a baritone saxophonist. The article also omitted Ms. Wilson's songwriting contributions to the album. She wrote 4 of its 12 songs.

title: A Quick Path To Prices
description: FOR decades, investors have had difficulty tracking closed-end funds. While they could easily follow the tick-by-tick prices of such funds on various markets, they could readily determine the value of a fund's holdings only once a week, in newspaper listings that disclosed the funds' net asset values as of Friday's close.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Take Good Care of My Baby; In Tipping the Balance Toward Adoption, Those Closest to Foster Care Are Pleased
description: SUZANNE and Robert Dunn of Hamilton Township have pushed foster parenthood to the legal limit. They have five, the maximum allowed, and want ''more than anything'' to adopt them all, said Mrs. Dunn, as they did with two earlier foster children. But the children's biological mothers, who might not even recognize them face to face, have not surrendered their parental rights -- and the state has not cut them off.

Cherished grandfather of Marisa Brown, William Paley, Rebecca Hart, Megan Hart, Daniel Nidel, Brett Nidel and Sam Nidel. Services Sunday, 9:15 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

description: COLE-Charles J. Happy Birthday, Dad. Thinking of you with much love and affection today and always. The Gang

description: WERRIS-Shirley, 83. Died March 5, 1999 in Manhattan. Patron of the New York City Ballet; supporter of Alvin Ailey Dance Company, The Jewish Museum, etc. An avid reader and world traveler, she devoted her life to the arts. Survived by nieces and nephews in California. Shirley was much loved.

title: Russians See and Read Another Slant to the War, With Milosevic as a Patriot
description: Since the cold war ended, no other event has so divided the West and Russia as the NATO bombing of Yugoslavia. The chasm is so deep that even words have taken on opposite meanings. While Americans and Europeans talk about the ''genocide'' of Kosovo Albanians by Serbs, many Russians talk about the ''genocide'' of Serbs by American bombs.

title: With Stronger Regulations, Inspectors Check Rides
description: State inspectors are preparing to hit the boardwalks and amusement parks to inspect New Jersey's 1,400 rides and water slides before the season begins, William M. Connolly, director of the Division of Codes and Standards, the office that oversees amusement rides, said last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, IRVING
description: COOK-Irving. On April 3, 1999. A longtime resident of Mamaroneck, he was the former owner of Cook's Restaurant in Larchmont, and a longtime member of Larchmont Temple. Loving father of Elizabeth Cook and Doris Klein. Dear father-in-law of Mordecai Klein, M.D. Cherished grandfather of Caroline and Amanda Postel, and Zoe, Zev and Talia Klein. Services will be held at Larchmont Temple, Monday 10AM. Interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery will follow the services.

title: 92d St. 'Y' Gets an Approval To Build a 5-Story Building
description: After a two-year battle with neighborhood residents, the 92d Street Y.M.H.A. has cleared a major obstacle to its effort to construct a five-story building on a narrow lot at 125 East 92d Street to accommodate its expanding adult education program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, MARK
description: SANDLER-Mark. On April 2, 1999 at the age of 93. Beloved husband of the late Edythe, loving father of Nancy and David Gavrin and Ellen Sandler. Dearest grandfather of Andrew, Beth, Barbara, Joanne and Meredith. Great grandfather of three. Funeral service at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, Sunday, April 4th at 10:30AM.

title: Immigrants' Group
description: Following the lead of other chapters of the American Jewish Committee, the White Plains group of the national organization is forming an immigrants' advocacy coalition, called the Westchester Immigration Network.
