description: To the Editor:

title: Bypassing Louvre Lines With On-Line Tickets
description: Visitors to Paris can now avoid long lines for entrance to the Louvre. Advance tickets are available on the Internet through Ticket Web, an Oakland-based on-line ticketing company. The tickets, good for admission any time until Jan. 31, 2000, to the Louvre's permanent collection, can be purchased at www.ticketweb.com or through the Louvre's Web site, www.louvre.fr. Tickets are also available at (510) 594-1400; fax (510) 594-1401. Ticket Web accepts Mastercard and Visa.

title: A Note for Seinfeld
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; Yuppie Foxhole
description: The moment we've been dreading has arrived. Put down that Restoration Hardware penguin cocktail shaker. Climb out of that Pottery Barn French Deco leather club chair. Finish up that echinacea-flavored focaccia. Drop that titanium driver. (That means you, Mr. President.)

title: Savoring Sushi and Blue Plate Specials
description: DESPITE its reputed affluence, the northwest corner of Connecticut has been something of a culinary Sleeping Beauty. The restaurant revolution taking place elsewhere has, for the most part, passed it by.

title: POSTINGS: Former College of Staten Island Building; Classrooms Become Offices
description: After sitting mostly vacant for the last five years, the former academic building of the College of Staten Island -- one of three buildings that once made up the college's north shore campus -- is being reborn as a modern office building.

title: Industry's Next Growth Sector: Memory Lapses
description: The graying of America has created an emerging industry: a wave of herbal and dietary supplements, books, courses and even clinics aimed at healthy people who are having trouble remembering and concentrating.

title: The World; The Powell Doctrine Is Looking Pretty Good Again
description: REMEMBER the Powell Doctrine?

title: A Pilgrim's Perils in an Ancestor of B-Movies
description: ''THE Pilgrim's Progress,'' written in 17th-century England by a Puritan preacher named John Bunyan, is a book many people have heard of but few have read. Yet it was, along with the Bible, one of the runaway best sellers in America before the Civil War.

title: At This Time of Year, Easy on the Rye
description: ''What happens to our bread business during Passover?'' sighed John Mulloy, president of Ginsburg's bread bakery here. ''It dies!''

title: A Season of Sacrifice
description: A cruel irony of the horror in Kosovo is that the events there are unfolding in one of the holiest seasons of the year for the religions that dominate the countries gripped by the conflict. By accident of the lunar calendar, the observances of Easter, Passover and the Muslim feast of sacrifice, Id al-Adha, all occur this week, and few worshipers caught in the spirit of deliverance reflected in each holiday will fail to be struck by the seeming absence of anything redeeming about the war in the Balkans. But if solace can be drawn in the coincidence of these days of prayer, it is in the lesson of how much these religions have in common at a time when so many of their adherents are in conflict.

description: COMBAT

description: American League

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ECKSTEIN, REBECCA S.
description: ECKSTEIN-Rebecca S. Died April 1, 1999 after a long illness. Beloved mother of Enid Eckstein and cherished friend of many. She is also survived by granddaughter Kayla Monks and numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. Memorial service details will be forthcoming. In lieu of flowers donations should be sent to Hospice of Washington, 3270 Upton Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20016 or La Clinica del Pueblo, 1470 Irving Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20010.

title: A Reminder
description: Daylight Savings time began at 2 A.M. this morning. Clocks were set ahead one hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITTELSTADT, MONICA
description: MITTELSTADT-Monica. See notice under PROUNIS-Monica Mittelstadt.

title: Private Sector; Keeping Schweppes Bubbling
description: JOHN M. SUNDERLAND, 54, the elfin-faced chief executive of Cadbury Schweppes, has always been afraid of heights and for years resisted flying. Yet there he was last year in Interlaken, Switzerland, donning paragliding gear and leaping from an Alpine crag in full view of a gaggle of underlings.

title: A Hotel's Immovable Women; Residents Evoke Allerton's Glory to Defy Developers
description: Past rows of vacant rooms, at the end of a corridor deep in the dust of demolition and renovation, a handwritten sign taped to the door of No. 701 is like a muffled cry: ''Occupied. Please do not touch.''

title: Making Tenements Modern
description: ''WHAT'S a tenement?'' asked Daniel Khodadadian, a 28-year-old physician doing his residency at Lenox Hill Hospital, as he stood, keys in hand, ready to enter his own renovated tenement building at 167 East 77th Street a few days ago.

title: Sports of The Times; An Inherent Tropism Toward Tackiness if Major Leagues Sell Out
description: EVERYBODY was wondering just how baseball might respond to its epic 1998 season. Now we know. The weasels are thinking of renting out the uniforms to advertisers.

title: A Wry Look at the Days When a Don Was a Don
description: EARLY in Harold Ramis's comedy ''Analyze This,'' the trusted old consigliere to the mob boss played by Robert De Niro voices a complaint common to movie mobsters: things aren't what they used to be; there's no longer any honor among thieves. But in many ways in this sendup of a mob movie, things are what they used to be.

title: Total Recall
description: In a conference room in the library of Carleton College, a small liberal arts school about 40 miles south of Minneapolis, 20 or so students were sitting around a horseshoe of desks, their shoulders hunched, buzzers clenched in their fists. They were concentrating on the man in front of them, Eric Hilleman, their coach, who was flinging carefully phrased questions at them in disciplines from chemistry to history to pop culture and waiting for, encouraging even, the quickest response.

title: For a Few Hours at Least, It's O.K. if the Bread's Burning
description: Flames leaped on nearly every sidewalk in Borough Park Wednesday morning, and smoke engulfed the area. But who cared? Certainly not the people lining up for apricot cake at Schick's Bakery on 16th Avenue, or the hundreds of others going about their business as embers flew.

title: Backtalk; An Angel on His Shoulder at the Final Four
description: Going to the Final Four is quite an experience, especially if you start out without a ticket.

title: 1999 BASEBALL PREVIEW; A GLOVE AFFAIR
description: Six million baseball gloves are sold in the United States each year; maybe 2,000 end up on the hands of major leaguers. For most of these players, there is no piece of equipment more important than their glove, which makes sense: bats break and balls disappear into the stands, but a player's glove is always waiting for him on the bench. Last season, home run balls got all the attention; it seems appropriate now to give equal time to gloves.

title: Having Our Colors Done
description: WERE we filled with envy? Tinted by our obsession with money? Consumed with longing for a more natural life? Who knows why everyone seemed to like the color green so much in the 90's?

title: A Reissued Novel Focuses On Italian-American Women
description: TUCKED on a shelf inside a corner cabinet in the living room of Helen Barolini's Carpenter Gothic cottage here sits a crudely shaped tin heart with a tubular sheath for a backing. On close examination, the heart reveals a border hammered along the outline with three circles delineating the forms of a simple flower.

title: On the Trail Of Peconic Radiation
description: ''Misleading Fallout From Radiation'' [Opinion, March 28] noted that the Suffolk County Legislature has appropriated $300,000 for an independent analysis of plutonium levels in the Peconic River as well as a health and environmental assessment of contamination in the river, which is largely the result of 50 years of nuclear operations at Brookhaven National Laboratory.

title: Our Towns; Even a Suburb Lacks Space To Walk a Dog
description: MORE about dogs, and the people they own.

description: Monica's Story

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASEROFF, CELENTHA (NEE ORENS)
description: GLASEROFF - Celentha (nee Orens). On March 31, 1999. Suvived by spouse, Daniel; son Alan and Daughter Aleta G. Estreicher; grandchildren Michael, Rebecca, Bruce and Hannah.

title: Just Like Old Times, Unfortunately, for Riley and His Team
description: It was like old times, how Pat Riley kept the locker-room door shut yesterday. And how, when it opened, you could have mistaken the place for a morgue.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-4-99; Crashing the Academy
description: When it comes to mechanics and technology, I have always fit the cliched bill of the longtime professor of English, the sort of person capable of fracturing a light bulb's innocent neck during installation. But there has been one exception to my losing war against all tech, high and low: computers, which, through word processing and info-tracking, place the powers of Prospero at one's fingertips. And I'm not alone: purportedly technophobic humanities teachers, English professors in particular, have led the way in bringing computers into class. Amazon.com, course Web sites and on-line student discussion groups are now mainstays of humanities teaching. But it seems the tables are turning. Prospero's Ariel seems to be morphing into Caliban: as technological and market pressures outpace our humble efforts to digitize, it becomes increasingly possible that our precious computers will consign us to early retirement.

title: A Crowd-Pleasing Campaign
description: New York transit officials had a short-lived and, in the end, ill-advised idea to make the trains run on time: Ordering subway conductors not to use the word ''please'' in announcements over the public-address system. As in, ''Please stand clear of the closing doors.''

title: HIP Members Are Given 2 More Weeks to Switch Plans
description: The judge overseeing the dissolution of the state's fourth largest health maintenance organization last week granted 50,000 former policyholders an additional two weeks to find new coverage.

description: GALLAGHER-Ellen Lloyd, R.N., Ph.D. The Board of Directors, Administration, Medical Staff, Employees and Volunteers of Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center and Saint Agnes Hospital, mourn the death of our esteemed colleague and friend, Ellen Gallagher, Vice President of the Florence D'Urso Pavilion of Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center. Ellen was a dedicated health care professional whose commitment to quality patient care was an inspiration to all who had the privilege of working with her. Our deepest sympathies are extended to her beloved husband, Jim, and loving children, Joan, Gavin, Nancy, Graham, James, Devin, and Wade. Edwin S. Mruk, Chairman Board of Directors, Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System & Our Lady of Mercy Med Ctr William F. Harrington, Esq. Chairman, Board of Trustees Saint Agnes Hospital Gary S. Horan, FACHE President and CEO, Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System

title: In the Stampede to Big Stocks, Some Managers Are Left Behind
description: DESPITE some sharp ups and downs, the bull market in large-capitalization stocks plowed forward through the first quarter, confounding some money managers and rewarding others.

title: How Clinton Approved the Strikes on Capital
description: A few hours before American cruise missiles struck downtown Belgrade overnight, President Clinton met with his top advisers in the Cabinet Room of the White House, and weighed what one White House official who was at the meeting described today as the fundamental question: ''Can our air power make Milosevic sue for peace?''

title: Riding the Wild, Perilous Waters of Amazon.com
description: Even if Jeff Bezos doesn't fulfill his goal of branding Amazon.com as the one-stop shop for everything, his company will be known as one of the first paved roads in the jungle of the Internet.

title: Kazan's Motives
description: To the Editor:

title: Even War Can't Shake What-Me-Worry Wall St.
description: IT was the subject of considerable head-scratching among investors last week that even as the Dow Jones industrial average was closing above 10,000 for the first time, an already grim situation in Kosovo was getting worse. While the euro tumbled on bulletins from the front, the Dow ended the week up 10 points, at 9,832.51. Its relative ebullience in the face of horrors overseas seemed oddly disconnected, at best.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Insight column last Sunday, an interview with the Goldman Sachs strategist Abby Joseph Cohen about the prospects for the stock market, misstated the valuation of Dell Computer shares. At the time, Dell was trading at a premium to the price-to-earnings ratio of the Standard & Poor's 500; the stock was not trading below the market multiple.

title: In America; Beyond the Diallo Case
description: The killing of Amadou Diallo was cold-blooded, but it probably wasn't murder. It appears that one or more of the officers genuinely believed Mr. Diallo had a gun and that all four officers, imagining danger when in fact there was none, panicked and began firing.

title: Longhorns Dominate
description: University of Texas sprinters dominated the Texas Relays yesterday before a sellout crowd of more than 20,000 at the new Mike A. Myers track stadium in Austin, Tex.

title: Brand Mulls His Future At Duke
description: PERHAPS the measure of Elton Brand's greatness is not how he won every award available to a college basketball player but rather how he -- and Duke -- lost the national championship.

title: For the Countertenors, Recognition and Roles
description: ONCE upon a time, there was a countertenor who had his niche to himself. ''The most remarkable countertenor of the 20th century,'' Sir Michael Tippett called Alfred Deller. The quote blazes off the recent reissue of the Deller Consort's John Dowland anthology ''Awake Sweet Love,'' on Vanguard, which dates back to 1966.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWEN, MORTON H.
description: ROWEN-Morton H. Died peacefully on March 25th, at age 86. Loving husband of Ruth and father of Elizabeth Green and Kathryn Schonzeit.

title: The Nation; On Social Security, The Good News Is Bad
description: AT first blush, the news last week from the Medicare and Social Security trustees was good. The economy over the last year has been so strong, actuaries found, that even with no changes in the law, the Medicare system should be solvent until 2015, seven years longer than expected, and Social Security reserves should be sufficient to pay full retirement benefits until 2034, two years more than anticipated.

title: What Happens If Process Server Doesn't Serve?
description: FOR two decades, thousands of documents passed through an obscure but flourishing process-serving company here, a couple of blocks from the courthouses in Nassau County's legal and government hub.

title: Dustin Ray, Elysabeth Bidwell
description: Courtney Elysabeth Bidwell, a daughter of Mrs. Philip J. Moloney of Greenwich, Conn., and J. Truman Bidwell of New York, was married yesterday to Dustin Shon Ray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Ray of Belvidere, Tenn. The Rev. Timothy Siemens, an ecumenical minister, officiated at Rosecliff, the historic house in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Michial Lewis, a Baptist minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Hopscotching at 10,000, Dow Gets Our Attention
description: It was easy to dismiss the Dow's close above 10,000 last Monday as merely symbolic, just one more market milestone -- and a not very enduring one at that, given the index's fall later in the week.

title: Assuring That Water Travels to Thirsty Souls
description: FROM the banks of the Hudson at Storm King Mountain, three miles north of West Point, the views are majestic. Some years back, Route 9D through the Hudson Highlands just missed the final cut for the dozen Most Scenic Highways in America. A long line of nonscenic telephone poles alongside the river marred the nomination.

title: How Does a Garden Grow? Slowly, and With Thorns From the Neighbors
description: ''It looks like it was planted by the military,'' said Siobhan Nicolau, who has lived in the East Village since 1964. ''Last year the earth was all cracked and the flowers died. We half expected to see iguanas walking around.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANN, SIDNEY H.
description: VANN-Sidney H., 68 years old. Died peacefully April 2 in Florida. Loving husband of Ginger, devoted father of Martin, Barbi, Guy and Claudia. Dear brother of Herb and Fred Vanefsky. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 12:30 P.M. on Sunday.

title: Who Really Suffered
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebel Officer Tells of Massacres Despite NATO Bombing
description: Speaking from inside Kosovo, a top commander of the rebel army today described what he called massacres of civilians in parts of the province and continuing attacks by Yugoslav air force jets, tanks and artillery against villages despite 10 days of NATO bombing.

title: Trying to Make Hay Until the Sun Shines Again
description: THEY were famous. They were feared. They were profiled in glossy magazines. Now many managers of value funds are bleeding assets as the funds, as a group, lag behind broad benchmarks like the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. How are some of these managers coping?

title: Shirtsleeves to Shirtsleeves
description: The Rise and Fall of

title: Travel to Iran
description: To the Editor: We were disappointed by the article on Iran. Although Ms. Sciolino is an experienced journalist who has reported from Iran, she traveled within the bubble of a tour group. I would not normally describe group tourists as ''intrepid,'' as the author does, but the adjective applies in an unintended way to tourists who try to smuggle liquor, attempt to hug Iranian women in public and barge into restrooms of the opposite sex in order to use ''Western'' toilets.

title: A Power Struggle in Paradise Pits the Rich Against the Rich
description: WHEN he sold Hebrew National, the family cold-cuts business, for more than $100 million six years ago, Isadore Pines did not imagine that he would spend his retirement stirring up his neighbors on this idyllic redoubt a short ferry ride south of Miami Beach.

title: Tartan Day Parade Makes Humble Debut
description: In a city where the ambition of just about every ethnic, immigrant and religious group is to block traffic for a few hours and hold its own noisy street parade, it must be said that the Scots have been laggards.

title: Boats Of Lead, Ignoring The Tide
description: A RISING tide does not necessarily lift all boats; when seas are turbulent, some founder. And that is an apt metaphor for the stock market.

title: She Will Dare Any Fashion
description: There has yet to be an outfit that Isabella Blow, London editor, stylist and fashion muse, couldn't wear without fear. At last month's Paris collections, her arrivals brought out the cameras. She changed clothes several times a day, preferring the fashions of London's avant-garde designers. The piece de resistance was a blowing-in-the-wind dress and coat of garbage bags. For a teatime show, she wore an organza dress, top left, with 10 separate dress fronts placed mille-feuille style on a transparent sheet. Then there was a multicolor jersey dress and matching color fox bolero. And who could forget the shoes with toe-holders?

title: Blackboard: Attitudes; Their Bodies, Their Selves
description: More than 50 percent of adolescent American girls diet to lose weight, while 13 percent engage in anorexic or bulimic behavior. Thirty-one percent of 10-year-old girls are afraid of being fat. In fact, according to the Harvard Eating Disorders Center in Boston, eating disorders rank as the third most common illness among females.

title: Starting Over
description: So this was it, then, the moment Dan Quayle had been working toward just about every second of the six years since he turned the house keys over to Al Gore. With Richard Nixon as his guiding spirit, the former Vice President had been in political rehab -- writing to set the record straight, reading as if the final exam were tomorrow and speaking wherever he got invited by the conservatives who admire him above all because he is still standing. Now at last, he hoped, his comeback could begin. And there he was on ''Larry King Live,'' a little grayer and a lot more intense, speaking with great ferocity even through a meandering account of his day: he had been on his way to Washington, but then the plane had to circle for the longest time and then it got rerouted and then. . . . Finally, even Larry King, whose interview subjects can generally count on the same kind of grilling they'd get from a friendly cabby on the way to the airport, asked if there wasn't something he wanted to announce. Yes, Quayle said, he was running for President. ''I love proving people wrong, and I am going to do it again,'' he told King, who observed that while Quayle's chances seemed poor, the news was not all bad: ''You're not a joke like you once were.''

title: Mr. Sinatra Wins
description: Mr. Sinatra, a 5-year-old horse with a long but inconsistent record, gave one of his finest performances yesterday when he outran the favored Laredo by more than five lengths to win the Westchester Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIDDER, ETHELETTE
description: RIDDER-Ethelette. Christie's pays tribute to the memory of our esteemed colleague, Tommie Ridder. We mourn her loss & extend our condolences to her family.

title: College and Money; And Never Lie About Your Grades
description: At first glance, the letter seemed promising. ''We have reviewed your background and are impressed with your accomplishments,'' wrote Martha Day Smalley, the recruiting coordinator for the consulting firm McKinsey & Company. ''However, we are unable to offer you the opportunity to interview with us.'' With one sentence, the door is slammed shut, any hope of an interview dashed.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the distribution of grants from the National Endowment for the Arts misstated the previous affiliation of the N.E.A.'s chairman, Bill Ivey. Mr. Ivey was director of the Country Music Foundation, not of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

title: Huskies' Long Road to a National Title
description: WALT DROPO, at 6 feet 5 inches, was the tallest member of the University of Connecticut's men's basketball team during his three years on the varsity in the 1940's, which were interrupted by two and a half years in the Army during World War II.

title: We'll Stay, Squatters Insist
description: Nearly seven years ago, a small group of squatters occupied an abandoned and decrepit six-story brick building at 713 East Ninth Street, between Avenues C and D. As their numbers swelled to 40 to 60, they built dozens of apartments, repaired the roof and connected the building to utility lines.

title: A Waterfront Walkway Takes a Detour to Court
description: On the walkway next to the marina in the Lincoln Harbor residential and commercial complex here, a young couple walk hand in hand, a woman sits on a bench sipping a soda and a businessman in shirt sleeves strolls along, taking in the early spring sun that glistens off the buildings of midtown Manhattan across the Hudson River.

title: The Figure She Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEATOR, KATHERINE F. (NEE KANE)
description: TEATOR-Katherine F. (nee Kane). Suddenly on April 2, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Joan Meagher, Lawrence, Raymond, Michael and the late Susan. Cherished grandmother of nine and adored great grandmother of six. Viewing at the David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Ave. (near Kimball), Yonkers, Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, St. Barnabas Church, 9:45 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: What About . . .
description: To the Editor: Re ''What's Doing in Tucson'' by Judith Anderson (Feb. 7): I enjoyed the article but think that one very important place was missing. When visiting Tucson, I have always spent several hours at the Pima Air Museum. It is a ''must'' on my list of places.

title: First-Time Homebuyers
description: To the Editor:

title: Felicia G. Magruder, Ex-Countess, Dies at 93
description: Felicia Gizycka Magruder, an American heiress who was kidnapped as a child by her father, a continental count, died on Feb. 26 at the Regency retirement community in Laramie, Wyo. She was 93 and moved to Laramie from New Canaan, Conn., in 1995.

title: Corrections
description: A compilation last Sunday of recent newspaper headlines using wordplay based on Shakespearean text erroneously included two headlines that did not draw on Shakespeare. Those two -- from The Boston Globe of March 22 and The Telegram & Gazette of Worcester, Mass., of March 18 -- used variations of the expression, ''All's fair in love and war,'' which is from ''Frank Fairleigh,'' an 1850 novel by Francis Edward Smedley.

title: Crime
description: Perfect beauty takes many blinding guises in A SIGHT FOR SORE EYES (Crown, $24), a suspense novel by Ruth Rendell that is itself a flawless piece of craftsmanship. But to the tormented characters who obsessively pursue their objects of desire -- including a redheaded woman, a mint-condition Edsel and the reflection of the beholder's own face in the mirror -- the worship of beauty leads directly to murder and madness.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-4-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Inmates,

title: Watercolor and Photography, Meshing in a Single Genre
description: LYNN MOWRER of Magnolia and Mike Sproch of Collingswood may initially seem to be artistic worlds apart. Although Ms. Mowrer is a watercolor painter who uses accents of rich color and Mr. Sproch is a photographer who produces black-and-white gelatin-silver prints, they nicely complement each other as they exhibit together at the Markeim Art Center. Because this show is presented as separate exhibitions with works by each artist displayed in adjoining spaces, the connection may seem less obvious. However, both artists deal primarily with still-life subject matter.

title: Serving the Less Fortunate For Credit and Just Because
description: FOR the last few years, Stacy Joseph, a senior at Half Hollow Hills West High School, has volunteered regularly at a soup kitchen in the basement of Trinity Lutheran Church in Wyandanch. Last summer, Floyd Feather, a sophomore at Port Washington High School, spent almost every day volunteering at the Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation office in New Hyde Park. Kara Kandel, a senior at Syosset High School, volunteers regularly for a group that holds special events for underprivileged and handicapped children.

title: Unavoidably Detained
description: THE ELECTRICAL FIELD

title: As It Opens to Outsiders, Cuba Is Infected by Crime
description: Never mind that one robber had second thoughts and was replaced at the last minute or that another did not shoot as planned. Or that the bounty was only $6,000 instead of the expected $30,000, or that the whole gang of seven men was arrested in less than three weeks.

title: Some Tips On Caring For a Lawn
description: WHILE neighborly lawn-care advice is always plentiful this time of year, plant experts say that not all advice is necessarily good advice.

title: Visit to Greece in a Glass
description: Pinot gris has emerged as Oregon's hallmark white wine, just as pinot noir is its signature red.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHON, MAE KANE
description: MAHON-Mae Kane. On Wednesday March 31, in her 96th year. Beloved wife of the late Richard J. Father of Mrs. Cornelius Shields, Jr., Richard J. Mahon, Jr., and William Kane Mahon. Grandmother of Allison Shields, Cornelius Shields, IV, and Maria Hohner Mahon. Reposing at Meserole Funeral Home, Inwood, NY, Monday April 5, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial 10:30 AM Tuesday April 6 at St. Joachim Church, Cedarhurst, NY.

title: Officer Resigns After His Arrest in Drug Raid
description: A New York City police officer was among 11 people arrested yesterday morning before dawn in a drug raid at a Staten Island bar, the police said, and he resigned from the Police Department several hours later.

title: George Rapee, 83; Won World Bridge Titles
description: George Rapee, one of the world's foremost bridge players, died Thursday at his home in Floral City, Fla. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAW, HAROLD E.
description: WARSHAW-Harold E. Of Hackensack, NJ, on April 2, 1999. Beloved husband of Beulah (nee Wolfson). Devoted father of Donald Warshaw, and Dr. Carole Warshaw. Devoted father-in-law of Renee. Loving grandfather of Julian. Services from Temple Emeth, 1666 Windsor Road, Teaneck, NJ on Tuesday at 1:30 P.M. For further information call ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 1-800-522-0588.

title: THE GUIDE
description: British Printmakers

title: Local Files Charges Seeking To Block Secession of Lawyers
description: Eight hundred lawyers who work for the City of New York are facing an unexpected obstacle to their efforts to pull out of a 23,000-member teamsters' local and form a new teamsters' local of their own.

title: With or Without Toe Shoes, a Spring Extravaganza
description: IF the many, varied dance performances in the state this month were being presented by a single sponsor or grouped in one locale, they would be called a festival, named something like Danceorama, perhaps, or New Jersey Struts It. But dance is enjoying a spontaneous explosion in northern and central New Jersey, with an array of classical and modern ballet; modern and jazz dance; ethnic, folk, tap and spoof, and foreign and homegrown events.

title: What the Jumans Didn't Know About Michael
description: Sorry, but I can't bring myself to read any article that has in its title ''An Adoption Tragedy.'' Adoption has become an increasingly important way for many of us to have a family, but the only news the average person reads about it is when something goes wrong.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Remembering Slavery

title: Diverse Coalition Plans March To Protest Police Misconduct
description: A group of politicians, business executives, religious leaders and community groups who banded together in response to the shooting death of Amadou Diallo have turned their energy to organizing a large demonstration aimed at illustrating the breadth of emotion about police misconduct.

title: The Nation; When Privacy Is More Perilous Than the Lack of It
description: HIDDEN in the Microsoft Word document that carried the Melissa virus around the world last week was a seemingly innocuous serial number that helped Federal agents identify the computer responsible for the program.

title: Victory by California Assembly Candidate Is First for Greens
description: When fellow Green Party members persuaded Audie Bock to run for the State Assembly last December, they told her she had a choice. She could run a symbolic campaign by putting her name on the ballot -- or she could campaign seriously.

title: The Haves Have It and the Nots Don't
description: Baseball people have probably spent more time this winter talking about the growing disparity in team payrolls than they have about this year's top rookies or even Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRY, RICHARD JOHN
description: BRY-Richard John, 1914-1999. Harvard Class of '35, decorated member of the Signal Corps (Okinawa). Adored husband of Betty and honored father of Ellen, William and John. Dick was a published author, creative chef and textiles executive. We will miss his wry wit, his green thumb and his love of a good book. Dick leaves behind a loving legacy in Tracy, John, Spencer, Hannah, Max, Sam, Lily and Oliver. And a last, loving thought from Betty-Our love was so complete, and at the last moment of holding you close to me I felt your being become part of me; you would remain within and part of me always and forever-never apart again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOROKER, MAE
description: TOROKER-Mae. On April 1st, 1999. Most devoted wife of the late Abraham. Dearest mother of Rita, Elly and Larry. Beloved sister of Seymour, Doris and the late Dinah. Much loved grandmother of Edmond, Patricia, Cathy, Andrew, Marc and Suzanne. Great-grandmother of Jared, Ali, Samantha, Shelby, Glenna, Hannah, Rebecca, Austin and Sloan. Your hopes, dreams and teachings will live with us forever. Service Sunday, 11 AM, Riverdale Temple.

title: Several Red Sea Reefs Open Again to Divers
description: In response to requests from tour operators and scuba divers, the Egyptian Government has decided to allow diving once again off about 15 islands in the Red Sea where it had been prohibited because of ecological concerns. It is now permitted at Zabargad, Rocky, Brothers and Abul Kizan islands, with limits on the number of divers.

title: Princeton Plans to Stop Streak of 'Nude Olympics'
description: Keep your shirt on, Princeton. Keep your pants on, too, or face a year's suspension. That is a recommendation of a committee at Princeton University that would end the annual ritual known as the Nude Olympics.

title: Approaching the Task of Social Security Reform; Increase Productivity
description: To the Editor:

title: Doubts on Bottled Water
description: Americans spend about $4 billion a year on bottled water. Is it worth it? Not from the standpoint of purity or healthfulness, says the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental advocacy group.

title: Howdy, Neighbor!
description: The guy at the next desk helps himself to your stash of chewing gum without asking. Or the woman behind you keeps erupting into laughter reminiscent of the Wicked Witch of the West. What kinds of co-worker behavior have tortured you at the office -- and how have you dealt with them? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Travel to Iran
description: To the Editor: We enjoyed reading Elaine Sciolino's recent article on Iran (Feb. 28).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREYER, LILLIAN
description: FREYER-Lillian. on March 31. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Barbara Freyer and Dr. Stuart Freyer. Adored grandmother to Daniel (Joanne), Adam, Jesse Freyer and Roger Taub. Devoted sister to Morris Golde, Michael and Belle Golde and Sonny Freyer. Special aunt and grand aunt. Services private.

title: Riding the Wild, Perilous Waters of Amazon.com
description: Let's not forget the value of casual interactions with our actual neighbors. Amazon.com encourages us to stay inside and surf the Net, rather than explore the world outside our offices and homes. By booting up and logging on, we limit our possibilities instead of creating them.

title: In New Land Of Eskimos, A New Chief Offers Hope
description: Part of Paul Okalik's story strikes a sad and familiar note here in the north.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBUD, DR. JULE
description: EISENBUD-Dr. Jule. The Board, staff and members of the American Society for Psychical Research mourn the passing of Dr. Jule Eisenbud. Dr. Eisenbud was an eminent psychiatrist, psychoanalyst and psychical researcher with the courage and vision to explore the uncharted realms of human experience. His ideas about the unconscious nature of psychic experiences were insightful and compelling, and will continue to illuminate the path of future research. His extraordinary intellect, insight and compassion will be deeply missed. He will not be forgotten. Patrice Keane, Executive Director American Society for Psychical Research

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEDIN, GORDON WEBSTER
description: HEDIN-Gordon Webster. On December 5, 1998 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father of Anne Hedin Thompson and Mark Gordon Hedin. Loving grandfather of Hugh Gordon Thompson, Olivia Thompson and Beatrice Thompson. Memorial service April 8, 5PM, Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 91 St. Contributions in his memory may be made to the ASPCA or charity of your choice.

title: In Theory; A School of Your Own
description: The Charter School of Wilmington sits atop the old district high-school building like Rome on its ruins. The old school was phased out in the mid-90's in favor of four themed mini-schools, the educational innovation of the moment. That moment turned out to be very brief: two of the mini-schools -- the Banking and Finance School and an academy based on the progressive theories of Ted Sizer -- did not even attract enough students to open. The Charter School of Wilmington absorbed the Math and Science mini-school and opened on the third floor of the building in 1996.

title: Seeing a Familiar Haunt Again, but in a New Light
description: The gloomy winter and the bright spring have provided the proof. The glorious fullness of light that the architects John M. Carrere and Thomas Hastings envisioned 90 years ago for the New York Public Library's main reading room has returned the Beaux Arts space to its former splendor.

title: A Broker Whose Line Is Specialty Food
description: SIX kinds of olive oil and a dozen or more different types of tea compete for shelf space in specialty markets, put there by Ron Maiorino, a food broker in Chappaqua.

title: As the Key Turns: Misery and Joy
description: MOST of the world's joy and misery, I am told, are caused by sex and real estate. The following two tales concern real estate, which I know more about.

title: Blackboard: Liberal Arts; I'm a Technogeek, Too
description: That cum laude is nifty, but how well do you surf? Operating on the fear that today's art history majors might be tomorrow's unemployed, the Virginia Foundation for Independent Colleges, which counts 15 liberal arts schools among its members, has developed a computer-proficiency certification program designed to prove that humanities scholars can be employed in a technoworld, thanks to their extracurricular Web surfing and chat-room navigation.

title: L.I. Team to Orioles: In Cuba, We're No. 1
description: WHEN the Baltimore Orioles played the Cuban national baseball team in Havana last Sunday, broadcasters and headlines across the country noted that it was the first such visit by a Major League Baseball team in 40 years.

title: A County Park Where the Leash Police Let Dogs Run Free
description: Although New York City is cracking down on unleashed dogs in its parks, the Passaic County Freeholders and Parks Department has taken a different approach. At Goffel Brook Park in Hawthorne, a county park, there is a 50-by-150-foot area marked off by a 4-foot-high fence that has been set aside for recreation for dogs and their owners.

title: Travel to Iran
description: To the Editor: It is very hard to know how Iranians view Americans traveling in their country. Last April, a group of us touring through the Oriental Institute in Chicago had mixed experiences.

title: Student Life; Room With a Viewpoint
description: Just as every college campus is its own mini-metropolis, with a population, government and services, so there is an array of housing options as varied as any small city's. The classic residence hall -- double rooms, communal bathrooms at either end of a long hallway -- is just one possibility. Now, many colleges offer dorms that resemble hotel suites, that are indistinguishable from apartments in urban high-rises or that look as if they sprang up in a subdivision of town houses.

title: The Very Writerly Chekhov
description: WRITERS must write, day by day, hour after hour. In everyone they meet, they see a character for a story. When the writer's train of thought goes to alternative pathways of life, he or she gets back on track with a new story idea. Sometimes the wheels of the writer's mind come to a standstill; that is called writer's block. Or they go nowhere; then it is just a bad story. But a writer's course is never derailed.

title: 1 Man Dies and 9 Are Hurt in Apartment Fire
description: A man was killed and nine other people were injured yesterday morning when fire swept through an apartment building on the Lower East Side, officials said.

title: In Bourges A Lively Past, Cast in Stone
description: I HAD always supposed that this ancient cathedral city in the heart of France got its name from the oldest French word for town -- bourg, from which comes the adjective bourgeois, with it connotations of comfortable prosperity. What could be a more classic town than Bourges, this settlement on a hilltop surrounded by rivers, one-time capital of France, now the chief city of the region. Today, with its grand old buildings preserved, its pretty shops, traditional family restaurants, chiming church bells and the ageless footsteps coming and going in the streets that are once again for pedestrians only, Bourges seems to incarnate centuries of European urban pride.

title: The Debate Over Keeping Leetch
description: Talk-radio intensity and newspaper competition sometimes raise the dialogue about New York sports from comfortably shrill to manic-depressive. Mix in the passion inherent to hockey and the affection for a star player with a Stanley Cup ring and you have a volatile concoction. So before the Brian Leetch/free-agency debate reaches a flash point, it might be appropriate to analyze the options for both sides in a clear-eyed, cool-blooded and calculating way.

title: Hopscotching at 10,000, Dow Gets Our Attention
description: It was easy to dismiss the Dow's close above 10,000 last Monday as merely symbolic, just one more market milestone -- and a not very enduring one at that, given the index's fall later in the week.

title: Ideas & Trends: Change-Up for McGwire; A Slugger Pitches Questions
description: MARK McGWIRE'S eyes lit up as if he'd just seen a down-the-pipe fastball. Expecting yet another, ''Can you hit 70 home runs again?'' question-and-answer fest, the St. Louis Cardinals slugger was asked if he'd like to reverse roles and pose questions to other people for a change. ''That's great,'' he said, clearly relieved. ''I love it!''

title: Goodbye to Technology, Hello to Comfort
description: David Bouchier's piece [''Out of the Attic for the 21st Century,'' Out of Order, March 28] struck home with me. A week ago, in the midst of a research paper for school, the PC died. I went to my 15-year-old word processor and after two sentences it too went belly up. I suspect it was a case of acute jealousy, having felt spurned for 12 months since the accursed PC came into my work room and took its place on my desk. My copier went down that same afternoon, a clear-cut case of electronic conspiracy.

title: More Advice for Levi
description: To the Editor:

title: Hopscotching at 10,000, Dow Gets Our Attention
description: It was easy to dismiss the Dow's close above 10,000 last Monday as merely symbolic, just one more market milestone -- and a not very enduring one at that, given the index's fall later in the week.

title: Chronicle of a Circumspect Circumnavigator
description: IN 1889, the celebrated and flamboyant New York journalist Nelly Bly set out to travel -- by ship, ox cart, camel, elephant and rickshaw -- around the world in less than 80 days, just topping the fictional record set in Jules Verne's novel. Nowadays, such globe-trotting is much less arduous; with enough money, and a good travel agent, you can do it in less than 48 hours on commercial flights. Yet, curiously, the ''round the world'' idea still retains its air of adventure and romance.

title: Eskimos Get a New Land
description: Existing maps of North America became outdated with the addition of a new territory called Nunavut in the far reaches of Canada's icy north. Roughly the same size as Mexico, the region has only 27,000 people (85 percent of them Eskimos, or Inuit) in 28 communities. Caribou outnumber people 28 to 1.

title: Edward A. Manfield, Bridge Champion, 55
description: Edward A. Manfield, a world champion bridge player, died on Monday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 55.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THINE IS THE KINGDOM By Abilio Estevez. Arcade, $25.95.

title: Laughing All the Way To the Office
description: The workplace can be pretty grim. But there is an antidote: humor. Applied in the right doses, it can transform a job into a joy.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Practical Traveler column on March 21, about guidebooks to New York, incorrectly rendered the name of Cynthia Baker, an author of ''Frommer's 99 New York City.'' She does not use a middle initial.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY; National Title Goes To Maine
description: MAINE 3, NEW HAMPSHIRE 2

title: Q&A/Diane E. Randall; When Housing Is More Than Shelter
description: LAST year, 15,917 people used state-supported homeless shelters in Connecticut, and 16 percent were children under the age of 12. And, said the director of the Partnership for Strong Communities, Diane E. Randall: ''We expect these kids to perform on the Connecticut Mastery Test? They don't know where they're going to do homework at night, where they will be that night? I find this shocking.''

title: Commercial Property /New Jersey; In Piscataway, a Central Laundry for Region Hiltons
description: THE squat, yellowish green building looks much the same as any of its neighbors at the Rutgers Industrial Park in this Middlesex County township. But the 100,000-square-foot building's interior is distinct from all others.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Testament

title: Jerusalem
description: The typical tourists in Jerusalem fill their days with official sites because, from the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial to the al-Aksa Mosque, there is so much history to be seen. But the real, throbbing, conflicted city often gets overlooked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, LIONEL S.
description: STEINBERG-Lionel S. The Officers, Board of Directors and Staff of the American Associates, BenGurion University of the Negev mourn the passing of our dear friend and Board of Chancellor Member, Lionel Steinberg of Palm Springs, California. Lionel was a successful farmer, philanthropist and political activist. We extend heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife of 25 years Katrina, and their children Billy, Barbara and Mary and grandchildren Janine and Ezra. Jules I. Whitman, President Kenneth L. Tucker, Chairman Robert H. Arnow, Chairman Emeritus, BGU Board of Governors

title: When They Were Good
description: The Kindness

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; But Is It Art? Sure!
description: Rather than claiming to have constructed a definitive history of performance art, RoseLee Goldberg acts like a diligent film editor or museum curator to assemble PERFORMANCE: Live Art Since 1960 (Abrams, $60), a collection of photographs of performance art. There are shots of Marina Abramovic weeping as she scrubs cow bones and Yasumasa Morimura striking a pose as Scarlett O'Hara. While such images may be difficult to comprehend, much less to form into a coherent narrative, Goldberg does isolate what the works of this genre -- inspired by everything from classical theater to digital animation -- share: origins in a world on the verge of information overload, a world more and more coming to resemble an outlandish theatrical event, a world devoid of stable definitions. And although she has divided the images into such ostensibly tidy categories as ''The Body'' and ''Identities,'' Goldberg ultimately refrains from defining these inherently unclassifiable works; she seldom goes beyond asserting that an artist's works ''have an underlying social commentary'' or put forth a ''sophisticated take on American society.'' Goldberg in fact works much like a performance artist, allowing the images to speak for themselves. ''Performance,'' accordingly, mimics the culture that informs them; readers are barraged with data and are subjected to a parade of fragmented images in the place of real, firsthand experience. In the end, Goldberg's self-conscious, anticritical stance is admirably respectful to the spirit of performance, but one wishes she had not forfeited eloquence to make her point. Christina Cho

title: Is the U.S. Income Gap Really a Big Problem?
description: IN economics, the facts alone don't usually tell the whole story.

title: New Season for Stars and One-Game Wonders
description: More than 50 years after the ball was hit, Joe Cleary can still see the bad hop. Coming in for the Washington Senators in his first major league game, with two runners on base and one out, Cleary got the first Boston batter to hit what looked like a perfect double-play ball. Instead, it skipped into the outfield. Then the roof fell in.

title: A Trade to End The Balkan War
description: To the Editor:

title: The Caribbean in a Mamaroneck Storefront
description: DINERS plagued by restaurant hauteur will find their humor restored at Jubilee, a plain but lovingly tended storefront eating spot that brings the tastes of the Caribbean to Mamaroneck. We cannot recall a more welcoming place or one that serves food with such good cheer and enthusiasm.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Internal Combustion Novel
description: ''All of my fingers have been broken from being stomped on,'' says T-Bird Murphy, the teen-age narrator of Eric Miles Williamson's first novel, EAST BAY GREASE (Picador USA, $23). ''My head's been knocked so many times, I wouldn't be surprised if I was permanently stupid.'' Set in Oakland during the 1960's and 1970's, this novel is a lively -- not to say wrenching -- contribution to a seldom recognized genre: the Internal Combustion Novel. As in Harry Crews's ''Car'' and Joseph Torra's more mystical ''Gas Station,'' the hero of ''East Bay Grease'' spends his days in an environment that's so filthy nothing can ennoble it. T-Bird may be the best trumpeter in the Jack London High School band and a pretty smart kid despite all the hard knocks he's taken, but it would take a miracle to get him out of the asphalt hell he inhabits along with his mother, a bikers' moll, and his father, an auto mechanic and a savage rube. Only in the sour air of the dockside bars, in punishing work and in music does he find relief. Williamson so convincingly depicts the cruelty of some of his characters that he seems almost scared of them. The feeling is contagious. Yet when T-Bird is finally ready for his shining moment soloing with Los Asesinos, a Mexican-American band as brilliant as it is tough, Williamson's writing becomes transcendent. His prose cuts loose in torrid rhythms that evoke the peril and exuberance of jazz. Sally Eckhoff

title: Food; Pressing the Flesh
description: Boneless slices of meat of uniform thickness travel under many names. What the French call an escalope, the Italians call scaloppine and the Americans alternate between a cutlet and a paillard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEPTIMUS, LEWIS I.
description: SEPTIMUS-Lewis I. On April 1, 1999. Age 84. In Houston, TX. Beloved husband of the late Helen Grapel. Loving father of Joyce Kent and Dr. Edward Septimus. Beloved grandfather of Adam, Steven, Jennifer, Joshua and Daniel. Memorial service to be held Monday, April 5th, 11AM at the Community Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Ave, White Plains. For direction, please call the Church at 914-946-1660. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Leukemia Society of America.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Lawyer Who Became a Hero
description: 'CLARENCE DARROW'

title: Two Distinct Peoples With Two Divergent Memories Battle Over One Land
description: The conflict between Serbs and Albanians, currently embodied by the sight of Albanian families desperately fleeing Serbian pursuers in Kosovo, has a very long history that is deeply felt, if selectively recalled, by those condemned to live it. At the same time it has never been much understood or appreciated beyond the southern Balkans.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Paths for Icon and Journeyman
description: MICHAEL JORDAN wishes to own a team. Oliver Miller wants a team to own up. These two basketball heavyweights of different classes were in the news last week, challenging old-line typecasting from opposite ends of the pro sports spectrum and getting all-too-predictable results.

title: What About . . .
description: To the Editor: I read Daisann McLane's Frugal Traveler column ''Into the Wild, Wet World of the Everglades'' (Feb. 14) with interest since my husband and I explored that area last March. Too bad she missed the historic bed-and-breakfast inn known as On the Banks of the Everglades, the former Bank of Everglades. A full breakfast is served in the bank's old vault, and rates range from $50 for a small room to $105 for a suite. The owner, Patricia Flick Richards, has a toll-free phone, (888) 431-1977, and a Web site at www.banksoftheeverglades.com.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE UMBRELLA COUNTRY By Bino A. Realuyo. Ballantine, paper, $12.95.

title: On Sunday, 'Let Us Pray' or 'Let Us Play'
description: ROMAN CATHOLIC and Protestant churches are filling today as parishioners gather for the most important religious celebration on the Christian calendar. For many churches, the Easter celebration marks an annual high point for attendance, the one Sunday when even rarely seen parishioners are likely to attend.

title: BUSINESS/INVESTING; Hopscotching at 10,000, Dow Gets Our Attention
description: It was easy to dismiss the Dow's close above 10,000 last Monday as merely symbolic, just one more market milestone -- and a not very enduring one at that, given the index's fall later in the week.

title: Howard U. in Washington Looks to Its Neighbors
description: A COOPERATIVE effort by Howard University and the Fannie Mae mortgage-financing agency is bringing new life to Le DroitPark, a neighborhood rich in architecture and African American history, but full of boarded-up town houses left vacant by the exodus of the black middle class from the inner city.

title: Capital Demonstration Widens Support for Diallo Rallies
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Led by the relatives of victims of police brutality from across the country, more than 1,000 demonstrators marched past the Justice Department today as protests inspired by the death of Amadou Diallo shifted from New York to the nation's capital.

title: Design by Committee
description: To the Editor:

title: Allies to Send 6,000 Troops To Albania to Aid Refugees And to Guarantee Security
description: NATO said today that it was planning to send a force of 6,000 to 8,000 troops to Albania to provide security and emergency relief for the masses of Kosovo Albanians who have been driven there from neighboring Yugoslavia by Serb forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYNG, LILA HOTZ
description: TYNG-Lila Hotz. The Trustees and staff of China Institute are saddened by the death of Lila Tyng, mother of Trustee Emeritus Henry Luce, III, and grandmother of Trustee H. Christopher Luce. We extend our deepest condolences to her entire family. Torrey L. Whitman, Presient

title: Testing His Limits, on the Set and Off
description: WHEN the actor Jay Mohr showed up for the first day of filming the new movie ''Go,'' a dark, offbeat comedy about a group of Los Angeles slackers whose lives collide after a botched drug deal, he had his doubts about the director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELLER, IRWIN
description: MELLER-Irwin. On April 2, 1999. A stockbroker with Grayson and Burger in Greenwich, Connecticut. Beloved and loving husband of Carola. Devoted father to Louise Meller and Jay Lukowski and John and Rita Meller. Doting grandfather to Aliza and Rebecca Lukowski and Kevin Meller. Dearest brother of Mimi Gurfein. He was also a loving uncle, great uncle and great, great uncle. Born in Brooklyn, New York, son of the late John and Lena Payman Meller, he was a World War II Navy veteran attaining the rank of Lt. Commander. Funeral services on Sunday, April 4 at 11 AM, Daylight Savings Time, in Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, New York. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

title: Held Captive in a Tower By the View
description: ON the long flight to Rome I read ''A Room With a View'' one more time, disappointed again that E. M. Forster's characters abandon warm Tuscany too soon for cold England. Although my destination, Siena, was not Florence, I looked forward to something like the ''beautiful hills and trees and marble churches opposite'' that Lucy Honeychurch, the young Englishwoman, and her chaperone and cousin, Charlotte Bartlett, could see from their window in the fictional Bertolini hotel.

title: Hopscotching at 10,000, Dow Gets Our Attention
description: It was easy to dismiss the Dow's close above 10,000 last Monday as merely symbolic, just one more market milestone -- and a not very enduring one at that, given the index's fall later in the week.

title: Couch Learns Reality of Being No. 1
description: Tim Couch was anointed as the top pick in the National Football League draft months ago. The title did not come with a crown, but it should have come with body armor. That is because Couch is now taking more shots than he ever did as a quarterback for the University of Kentucky.

title: In Judge's View, Billboard Is a Matter for the City
description: Despite complaints by neighborhood residents that it is a danger as well as an eyesore, a Manhattan judge has ruled that a giant billboard at Bond and Lafayette Streets can stay up for now.

description: Because of the quarterly Mutual Funds Report, part 2 of this section, the regular weekly Investing features are not included today. They will resume next Sunday.

title: Allergies and Pesticides: Spraying in Schools
description: JOSH WOJCIK, a junior, is glad to be back at Killingly High School. He said he missed three months of classes last spring because of allergies to herbicides that had been sprayed on the school's playing fields.

title: The Many Types and Importance of Paintbrushes
description: BRUSHES are important tools in any kit. Inexperienced do-it-yourselfers tend to think that all brushes are alike. This might seem like a logical assumption, considering that all brushes are made up of only three components: the fibers or filling, the handle and the ferrule.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, ANNE M.
description: FITZGERALD-Anne M. 92, a 35year Larchmont resident, died April 1 in Rockwall, Texas. She began her fifty-year career in the electric utilities business with Bond and Share in 1922, joining Electric Power and Light Corporation in 1935. She later rose to become corporate secretary and assistant treasurer of Middle South Utilities, Inc., positions she held until her retirement in 1971. A pioneer in her era, she was the first woman appointed as an executive of a utility. She is survived by her sister, Mary V. Buckley of Rye; a niece, Mary Alice Roberts of Rye; two nephews, Patrick J. Buckley of Larchmont and John J. Buckley, Jr. of Washington, D.C.; 11 grand nieces and nephews; and a great-grandniece. Visitation will be Monday evenings from 7-9 PM at John J. Fox Funeral Home. Mass of Christian Burial will be Tuesday 10AM at St. Augustine Church, Larchmont. Interment will be at Calvary Cemetery following Mass.

title: Milosevic Wears the Smile of a Player Who Sees the Game Going His Way
description: President Clinton may seem tired and worn these days, but President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia is looking on top of his little world.

title: Fixed-Price Feasts From the Southern Hemisphere
description: Palm trees flank the entrance to a week-old temple for carnivores, Churrascaria Plantation.

title: A Sparrow Not Kept An Eye On
description: THREE of the century's top-of-the-line American plays in major productions -- ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' and ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' at Hartford Stage and ''The Glass Menagerie'' at Yale Repertory -- highlighted the current theater season's forecast in Connecticut. But great expectations ended up as bitter disillusionments.

title: The World; A High-Tech Threat With a Low-Tech Track Record
description: THE warnings from Washington were clear. Spy satellites and high technology eavesdropping equipment will be monitoring your forces in Kosovo, the Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic was told last week. Any evidence of atrocities carried out by Serbian soldiers will be forwarded to the War Crimes Tribunal in the Hague.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAULFIELD, GOELL, CATHERINE
description: CAULFIELD - GOELL - Catherine M. ''Cathy'' on April 2nd, of New York. Wife of the late Kermit Goell, sister of James Caulfield, Rosemary Orozco, Margaret Monaghan, Eileen Casey, Maureen Caulfield and the late Eugene Caulfield. Sister-in-law of Patricia Caulfield, Margaret Caulfield, Harry Monaghan, and John Casey. Aunt to 21. Great aunt to eight and friend to many. Cathy was born in the Bronx and lived in both NYC and Hunter, NY. Cathy was a tenant advocate with the Legal Aid Society. Countless clients benefited from her tenacious pursuit of justice in their behalf. She will be remembered, by those fortunate enough to have known her, for her style, zany humor, sense of fair play and determination to do the right thing. Cremation will be at Rosehill Crematory, Route 1 and 9 (North), Linden, NJ on Monday at 2 pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Ann Wigmore Institute, Carr 115 KM 20, Aquado, PR. Lawton-Turso Funeral Home, Hoboken, NJ for information.

title: Giving Due Credit To the Elderly
description: Although I know that a newspaper is obliged to report various sides of any issue, it troubles me that a front-page article in the Long Island section [''Influx of Elder Centers Worries Dix Hills,'' March 28] should devote considerable space to the viewpoint of those who oppose a proliferation of assisted-living facilities. We must think of who the people are who are residing in these facilities. Think about what they have done to change the face of Long Island and develop it into the great place to live that it is.

title: The MetroStars' Season-Opening Streak Ends
description: The MetroStars' piquant start to their fourth Major League Soccer season came to a crashing halt tonight at Giants Stadium in front of 20,978 fans and a national television audience.

title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; Art and Politics Vie In a Battle to Honor A Monumental War
description: IN a bustling model shop below his offices in downtown Providence, R.I., the architect Friedrich St. Florian delicately lifts a clay study of a 2,000-year-old emblem of death. It is a cenotaph, and it represents the sacrifice of the 508,000 Americans who died in World War II. He sets the model into a tilted clay plane, jaggedly fissured to suggest the seismic upheaval of the war. Out of the middle of this plane will rise a beacon wrapped in a sculptured armature. The combination of cenotaph and light symbolizes, he says, ''triumph over darkness, democracy over tyranny.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESTON, BARBARA GRASSI THORNE
description: PRESTON - Barbara Grassi Thorne. April 2, 1999, of Armonk, NY. Wife of the late John N. Thorne, Jr., and Seymour Preston. Mother of Angela Sturgis, Zoe Thorne and Bridget Thorne. Sister of E. H. A. ''Bud'' Grassi. Also survived by five grandsons. Memorial service at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford, NY, Wednesday, April 7, 11 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be to the American Cancer Society.

title: A Planned Radar Tower Has Residents on a Fight Path
description: Neighbors of Floyd Bennett Field, where the Federal Aviation Administration plans to erect a $6 million radar tower, say they intend to keep fighting the project.

title: BENEFITS
description: Shakespeare Inspiration

title: Our Grass Is Greener but at What Cost?
description: WESTCHESTER residents' passion for lush green lawns has put the county in the highest ranks of pesticide users in the state, with potentially serious consequences for the health of its citizens, a report from two Albany-based environmental groups contends.

title: The Lustiness Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX
description: SINCE Colonial times, New Jersey has been known as the garden state. We earned our name because we can grow so many varieties of fruits and vegetables. Thanks to the mineral deposits from the glaciers, our soil is very rich with nutrients that plants need. Compared with other states, our state produce is the most diverse. We are known for blueberries, cranberries, peaches, potatoes, corn, tomatoes, lettuce, apples, and many more products. Despite this success, the shocking fact is from 1978 through 1987 farmland acreage statewide decreased by more than 18 percent. Because of the building of office complexes, houses, and roadways, our farmlands are disappearing.

title: DATABANK: March 26-April 2; Internet Companies Fuel a Nasdaq Rally
description: Fresh from a quarter in which it gained 12.6 percent, the Nasdaq composite index climbed 3.06 percent for the week - its best performance since late January.

title: Stories in Romanesque
description: THERE are Romanesque cathedrals in England, France and Germany that stun you by their magnitude, but the French country churches of Poitou-Charentes, which I began to explore last summer, take you by the hand with an intimacy that belongs to the ground on which they stand and to the ancestors who built them nearly a thousand years ago. They are earthy yet exalted, social yet sublime. This, you feel, is what churches were like before the Church got at them.

title: Soomie Ahn, Casper Sorensen
description: Soomie Lee Ahn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jaehoon Ahn of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday in Washington to Casper Thorsted Sorensen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Sorensen of Struer, Denmark. The Rev. Young Jin Cho, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the St. Regis Washington hotel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVINE, BERNICE S.
description: LAVINE-Bernice S. Of New York City. In her 91st year. On April 2, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Phillip S. Lavine. Adored mother of Doris Siegel and Jack W. Lavine. Loving grandmother of Richard Meth (Melissa), Stephen Meth (Dorothy), Deborah Fleitz (David), Paul S. Lavine. Loving greatGrandma of Rachel Meth, Justin Meth, Michelle Meth. She will be remembered and loved by all. Services Tuesday, April 6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARR, KATHERINE
description: FARR-Katherine. Beloved wife of the late William Farr and the late Sidney Zweig. Beloved mother of Martin E. (Barbara) Zweig, The Money Manager from ''Wall Street Week With Louis Rukeyser''. Loving grandmother of Zack and Alex Zweig. Also survived by Mollie Zweig. Sister of Perry (Ethel) Schwartz. Martin Zweig will receive visitors on Monday evening, April 5 at the Harmonie Club, 4 E. 60 St from 6-9pm

title: Duke and UConn To Play at Garden
description: Duke and UConn could be rematched next fall at the Coaches vs. Cancer IKON Classic at Madison Square Garden.

title: Intellect Versus Love (Guess Which Wins)
description: IN the beginning, two lovers dance a flirtation waltz. As a coda, an unpartnered other woman, a social climber, sits in solitude, her own undoing.

title: The Right Moment for Tender Summer Bulbs
description: IT is time to think about summer bulbs. These are the tender sort that cannot live through winter underground. Yet they all need an early start if they are to bloom during the summer months.

title: 1999 BASEBALL PREVIEW
description: This preview was writen by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish.

title: At Last, a Body Shop for Tuning Up That Flabby Aura
description: I HAVE been called many things in my life, but I must say, sunny has never been one of them.

title: Hopscotching at 10,000, Dow Gets Our Attention
description: It was easy to dismiss the Dow's close above 10,000 last Monday as merely symbolic, just one more market milestone -- and a not very enduring one at that, given the index's fall later in the week.

title: High-Speed Amtrak Begins to Roll, Slowly
description: WHEN Florida's Governor, Jeb Bush, ended state financing in January for the proposed 320-mile high-speed rail project that would have linked Miami, Orlando and Tampa, the future of high-speed train service in the United States suffered an apparent major setback.

title: The Easter Parade in a Mall? Next They'll Fire Bert Parks
description: Reports of the malling of Atlantic City's 122-year old Easter Parade have been greatly hyperventilated.

title: Distance Learning; Class Is in Session. Now What?
description: The essential challenge of distance learning is overcoming distance. Educators are now relying on a variety of technologies, on line and off, to break down classroom walls.

title: Rediscovering An American Classic By Way of Britain; The 'Iceman' of Kevin Spacey
description: KEVIN SPACEY, resplendent in black, from T-shirt to running shoes, is sitting amid the empty seats of the Brooks Atkinson Theater, watching the international scrum of lugs, louts and losers who frequent Harry Hope's bar in ''The Iceman Cometh'' by Eugene O'Neill.

title: 1,500-Year-Old Art In Body and Spirit
description: ''DON'T try this at home,'' the young female announcer said, as the kung fu master leaned his full body weight on an eight-foot-long stick. One end of the stick rested under an assistant's foot, while the pointed end seemed about to pierce the master's throat. A sudden whack by a third man broke the shaft in two but left the master's body intact. This exercise, the announcer said, showed the extreme concentration a kung fu master can achieve. ''His body is strong like metal.''

title: More Advice for Levi
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-4-99 -- Shop Talk; Greetings From The Fishbowl
description: Berkowitz's film, about his efforts to find a girlfriend, is in theaters now. Twenty-five years ago, the groundbreaking documentary ''An American Family'' gave television audiences an intimate view of the Loud family. Here, Berkowitz and Loud discuss what it's like to live one's life in front of an audience of millions.

title: Roosevelt Islanders Make Case for Self-Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBECK, PETER MARTIN
description: ROBECK-Peter Martin. Of Pacific Palisades, CA., formerly of New Canaan, CT and New York City; on March 30, 1999, after a long illness; at age 81. As founding president and chairman of Time-Life Films, Mr. Robeck and the British Broadcasting Corporation co-produced such television milestones as ''The Ascent of Man,'' and ''America,'' and created ''Masterpiece Theatre.'' He was born in Marinette, Wisconsin, on May 18, 1917. He attended Hollywood High School and UCLA, and served in the Army Air Corps during WWII. Mr. Robeck is survived by his wife Trudy Robeck; his daughter, Torrey Robeck of New York City; his son, Stephen Robeck and granddaughter, Loren, of Los Angeles. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Pacific Palisades (CA) Library Assn, for the purchase of recorded books.

title: Women Are Speaking Out to Heal Trauma of Rape
description: Betty Liebert was getting into her car to go home after a night out with friends when a man hit her from behind and took from her all her life had been.

title: Zimmer Lashes Out at Steinbrenner as Irabu Returns
description: Fed up with George Steinbrenner's role in the handling of pitcher Hideki Irabu, the Yankees' interim manager, Don Zimmer, strongly chastised Steinbrenner tonight, asserting his intention to run the team the way he wanted and all but challenging Steinbrenner to fire him.

title: Distance Learning; The British Are Coming
description: The campus of Britain's largest university is spread over 30 neatly landscaped acres in this efficient, prefabricated city about 45 minutes from London. Inside its 30-odd buildings, work is proceeding apace. About 1,000 faculty members are doing research in dozens of fields and preparing course materials for more than 100,000 students in Britain and abroad. In one low-slung building in the center of campus, members of a BBC production staff are putting together television programs, videos and CD-ROM's for use in the courses; in several enormous warehouses off to one side, the materials are being divided into thick packets and then mailed to students.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEITZ, PATRICIA
description: SEITZ-Patricia. Darling Pat. Gone one year but never out of my mind. Miss you and our luncheons together. Sleep well, My Darling. Love, Florence C

title: Music Meant to Be Worked At, Not Just Listened To
description: HOW do you listen to music that wasn't meant to be listened to? And how do you perform a work that wasn't meant to be performed?

title: Ideas & Trends: Citizens as Allies; Rethinking the Strong Arm of the Law
description: WITH the shooting death of an unarmed African immigrant by four police officers, New York City has grimly discovered there is a price for the tough law enforcement tactics that have led to its steep drop in crime: estrangement between police and citizens, something that many cities successfully combating crime have managed to avoid.

title: The Nation: Fighting Mandatory Deportation; Veterans Lead a New Charge
description: FEAR of crime and resentment against immigrants are perennial themes of American politics, and Congress touched both when it revised American policy toward legal residents in the mid-1990's. Non-citizens, even permanent residents, were made subject to deportation for a wide range of crimes that had previously been considered too minor. There was, at least according to immigration officials, no flexibility in deciding whom to deport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROUNIS, MONICA MITTELSTADT
description: PROUNIS - Monica Mittelstadt. Age 36. On March 31, 1999. Beloved wife of Othon. Mother of Alexa. Daughter of Charles and Angelica Mittelstadt. Sister of Simone Mailman and Charles Mittelstadt, Jr. Memorial service at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 5th Avenue at 55 Street, Wednesday, 10:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Amherst College, C/O Development Office, POB 5000, Amherst, MA 01002, The Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60 Street, NY, NY 10022 or The Marrow Foundation, 400 Seventh St N.W., Suite 206, Washington, D.C. 20004.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELCH, JOHN
description: WELCH-John. 71. Of New York City, formerly of Boston on March 26 after a short illness. He was the son of the late John and Grace Welch of Boston. A graduate of Roxbury Latin School, Philips Exeter Academy and Harvard College, he also held a MA from Boston University. In New York he worked at HIP and later as an editor at the Sterling Publishing Company. He is survived by his brother Rev. Thomas D. Welch of Butler, Tenn. and sister, Barbara Welch of Westfield, Mass. There will be a funeral mass at the Church of Our Saviour, Park Ave at 38 St on Tuesday, April 6, at 11AM. Burial will be in St. Joseph Cemetery, West Roxbury, Mass on April 7th at 1:30PM. Memorial donations may be made to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60, NY, NY 10022 or The New York City Ballet, 20 Lincoln Plaza, NY, NY 10023.

title: Blues Over Blue Moons
description: That howling heard last week was probably just the neighborhood dogs sounding off at the full moon, the second in March -- and thus, by common understanding, a blue one. Then again, it could have been a reaction to the disclosure by the venerable astronomy magazine Sky and Telescope that the common understanding of blue moons was based on a misunderstanding, perpetrated by the magazine 53 years ago.

title: Ending Car Theft
description: To the Editor:

title: Litchfield Landmark Yields to the Future
description: SINCE 1751, Litchfield has been the seat of one of Connecticut's largest judicial districts covering most of the region from Hartland to Bridgewater. For more than two centuries there has been a courthouse on the green, and the country's first law school was founded in 1775 by Tapping Reeve, just south of the green.

title: Corporate Love Letters: YouStink.com
description: BY now, the whole world knows there's no hotter property than companies that make Internet Web sites. Now here's something even hotter: Web sites that make fun of companies.

title: Pity for the Plagiarist
description: Love the idea of a weekly column on ethics. However, with all due respect to Randy Cohen's life experience in television, why not broaden the field of contributors to include some age, sex and cultural diversity in this potentially engaging forum?

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-4-99 -- Questions for John Ashbery; A Child in Time
description: Q:

title: Rationed War News From Kosovo
description: When democracies send their military forces into combat, citizens need to know as much about the battles as sensible security precautions permit. In the case of Kosovo, with Western reporters barred by Serbia from covering the conflict on the ground, NATO and the Pentagon must provide a detailed account of the effectiveness of the air war. It is a responsibility they have so far largely failed to meet.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: David Blaine; A Few Magic Moments
description: DAVID BLAINE arrived at the Upper East Side apartment of his manager, Jonny Podell, just in time to watch himself on television on Tuesday night. ''Entertainment Tonight'' was about to beat the drums for the latest spectacle of Mr. Blaine, a magician. Tomorrow at 10 A.M., he will be buried, for a week, on the banks of the Hudson River.

title: BUSINESS/INVESTING; Hopscotching at 10,000, Dow Gets Our Attention
description: It was easy to dismiss the Dow's close above 10,000 last Monday as merely symbolic, just one more market milestone -- and a not very enduring one at that, given the index's fall later in the week.

title: A Treasured Few
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Bombs Belgrade Again, Widening Strikes
description: NATO struck Yugoslavia's capital tonight for a second time, hours after announcing that the alliance was planning to send 6,000 to 8,000 troops into Albania to help the masses of refugees who have fled there from neighboring Kosovo.

title: Flying With Class
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Dance Cultures in 1 Bronx
description: AFRO-CARIBBEAN, Cherokee Indian, Irish step and contemporary with a Japanese flavor are among the types of dances from various cultures to be celebrated over the next two weeks as six dance companies based in the Bronx begin a series, ''Dancing Across Cultures: 1999 Bronx Festival of Dance.'' Performances begin on Friday at Lehman College.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about day-care programs for Alzheimer's patients misidentified an organization that runs two such programs in Suffolk County. It is the Community Programs Center of Long Island, not the New York State Adult Day Services Association.

title: Charter Schools Are Accountable
description: I was disappointed at how incorrect Barry Edelson's March 21 opinion essay [''Chilling Facts of Charter Schools''] was in describing charter schools.
