The author fails to recognize two very important concepts -- charter schools are public schools, and as a result are accountable to the public.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUSSELL, KATHRYN V.
description: RUSSELL-Kathryn V. On April 4, 1977. Dearest friend, always kind and thoughtful. May you rest in peace with God throughout eternity. You will always be remembered. Howard

title: McCain Keeps Pressing Case for Troops
description: Senator John McCain spent more than five years as a prisoner of war in Vietnam and learned, he says, the dangers of limited measures. He is now a forceful advocate of all-out intervention in the Balkans.

title: Allies' War by Consensus Limiting Military Strategy
description: Soon after the bombing of Yugoslavia began last week, Italy's NATO representative, Amadeo de Franchi, pointed out in an alliance meeting that the air strikes were causing some difficulties for his Government.

title: At the U.N. Activists Vie With Vatican Over Abortion
description: In a novel twist to the fight over legal abortion, an organization of Roman Catholic activists has begun a drive to demote the diplomatic status of the Vatican at the United Nations, though in reality it only hopes to curb its lobbying style.

title: Major League Scheduling: The High, Hard One
description: AS one ages, appreciation grows for what knowledgeable baseball fans call the inside game, the strategic decisions that managers and players make after weighing a near infinity of variables: righty or lefty, the pitch count, number of men on base, strength of the shortstop's arm, May or September. It is like solving an immense, ever-morphing math problem. Except in this case, thousands of fans are poised to heap abuse if, during long division, someone forgets to carry the one.

title: Pleas in Diallo Case
description: After weeks of protests calling for their arrest and indictment, the four New York City police officers whose 41 shots killed an unarmed African immigrant on Feb. 4 were suspended from duty and arraigned on charges of second-degree murder and reckless endangerment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, GRAENUM
description: BERGER-Graenum. The Board of Directors of the Usdan Center extend our condolences to the family of Graenum Berger. We remember with affection and esteem his inspiration in helping to create Usdan. The vision he imparted also provided superb guidance and support. His was a true friendship over many years. Jerrold Ross, President Dale Lewis, Executive Director

title: A Call, a Heart, and Life Begins Anew
description: Charlie had been getting weaker, and his shuffling walks down the long halls of his hospital ward were becoming torturous. Doctors feared that if he did not get a heart soon he would die. But so far there had been no match. Charles Schultz had seen 18 other patients get hearts. Yesterday, his own wait would have been a year.

title: Home Learning; Computers 'R' Us
description: If only it were 1985, a millennium ago in the world of computers. Then Team Concepts' Comquest Disk Master and Vtech's Master Pad Deluxe would be considered brilliant inventions rather than fodder for the toy box, and their creators might be billionaire monopolists building large homes in the great Northwest.

title: Paid for Their Performance
description: Rankings that weigh the performance of a company against its chief executive's pay have a way of rankling corporations whose track records have disappointed investors - and these lists are no exception. (For fairness, Money & Business apprised companies if their leaders made the lists of low performers.)

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Big Brother Is Listening
description: The issue that gray February day was one of delicate balance: how to assure the freedom to discourse on Hitler's ''Mein Kampf,'' as one participant put it, but not to use the word ''Jew'' as a verb, to lecture on sexuality but not to refer to female students as ''babes.''

title: Sexual-Abstinence Grants Put to Broad Use by States
description: For all the uproar when Congress set aside $50 million a year for states to create abstinence-education programs teaching the benefits of delaying sex until marriage, every state in the nation ultimately applied for the money when it became available in fiscal 1998.

title: Columbia Men Defeat M.I.T.
description: The Columbia men's varsity heavyweight crew, in its only race of the season on its home Harlem River course, successfully defended the Alumni Cup, defeating Massachusetts Institute of Technology for the second successive year.

title: Pipeline Alternatives
description: Columbia Gas Transmission, the lead company in a consortium that is seeking to lay a natural-gas pipeline from Cortlandt south to Mount Vernon, has received permission from the county to survey a five-mile section of the North County Trailway.

title: Problem at Top
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Group Battles to Save Luxury Liner 'Big U,' and Glory of Its Day
description: An enormous luxury liner lies empty and dark at the municipal pier here, pulling against its shore lines and straining, people who are fighting to save it say, for open water.

title: A Trade to End The Balkan War; A Limited Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBENBAUM, BRICKNER, VICKI
description: LEBENBAUM - BRICKNER - Vicki. Beloved wife of Howard. Devoted mother of Silas. Dear sister of Judy Luxenberg and Marcie L. Kammel. Loving aunt of Stacey Faber, Doug and Jennifer Luxenberg, Stella L. Kammel, Ben, Alexis and Jack Brickner, Brian and Josh Rubin. We love you, Mommy! Services at BoulevardRiverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, 10 AM, Sunday, April 4, 1999.

title: Style; The Studio System
description: When the photographer Shelby Lee Adams went back to Kentucky recently, it was to do something that was a first for him -- he was to take fashion pictures, a group of which are shown on the following pages. Being included in the world of fashion is fresh territory for Adams's subjects, too, the citizens of Leatherwood and Lost Creek, two Appalachian communities situated near Hazard, Ky., where the photographer was born almost 50 years ago. On and off, he has spent the last 25 years portraying life in this region, so when letters went out inviting the residents to participate in these new photographs, the recipients knew who was asking.

title: Company Cools Its Beer Ads Featuring Animals in Heat
description: After a public outcry in Harlem over an advertising campaign for Steel Reserve Beer that featured images of tortoises and rhinoceroses engaging in sex, the Steel Brewing Company in California is discontinuing the advertisements nationwide, and has put a formal apology to residents in four local newspapers.

title: Settling the Microsoft Case
description: After a decidedly uneven presentation of its case in court, Microsoft has come forward with a proposal to settle the antitrust suit it has been challenging since last year. The word from the Justice Department and some of the 19 state attorneys general prosecuting the case is that Microsoft's initial offer does not address their concerns about what they regard as anticompetitive conduct by the company. But the department and the attorneys general are right to pursue a possible settlement with Microsoft. A negotiated agreement, if done right, would be preferable to years of litigation, appeals and uncertainty for businesses and consumers in the fast-changing computer and software industry.

title: Fewer Doctors: Who Benefits?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, BERTHA
description: SILVERMAN - Bertha. Beloved wife of the late David L. Loving mother of Yvonne Archer and Sidney B. Adored sister of Frances. Cherished grandmother of Diane Archer Presser, Ellen Archer Gracer, Emily Silverman Lowenstein, David L. Silverman and Julia R. L. Silverman. Great-grandmother of seven. Services today, 9:45, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, (Riverside Building), Amsterdam Ave, corner 76th Street, NYC.

title: Portraits Painted With Cameras
description: 'Photographic Tableaux: Tina Barney's Family Album'

title: Lonesome George
description: All Too Human

title: The World; An Agony Promising New Days Of Agony
description: ALL is dark again in southeast Europe. Close your eyes and those long lines of ragged ethnic Albanian refugees traipsing out of Kosovo fuse with so many other processions of the Balkan bedraggled: one million Greeks out of Turkey in 1923, 500,000 Turks out of Greece in the same year, over 750,000 Muslims out of Bosnia in 1992, and 175,000 Serbs out of Croatia in 1995. Where will it end?

title: Approaching the Task of Social Security Reform; Government Meddling?
description: To the Editor:

title: Wyoming City Braces For Gay Murder Trial
description: At sunrise on Sunday, the Rev. Stephen M. Johnson and fellow worshipers will gather for an Easter service on a bleak, windswept hill here. They will stand by a small cross of stones, a rough marker of the spot where Matthew Shepard was beaten, robbed and left to die, lashed to wooden fence poles.

title: Corrections
description: The front page of the Arts & Leisure section today refers incorrectly in some copies to the division of the section. It is in one part today, not two.

title: Piazza Embraces New York Challenge
description: As Mike Piazza prepares to enter his first full season as the centerpiece of a rebuilt Mets offense and claim his place on the most demanding of sports stages, he remains an enigmatic superstar.

title: Out of the Closet and Into the Streets
description: TALES OF THE

title: A Real Open House: 56 Children at Last Count
description: VONETTA Lawrence and Patsy Carthan-Warlock did not need social service professionals to draw up a plan for their future. They made their own, here on Spring Street, as Vonetta's mother died and her grandmother, who was caring for her, fell ill. She would spend a night, then a weekend, then whole weeks, with the neighbor everyone called ''Miss Pat,'' and at 12 the girl would officially become Ms. Carthan-Warlock's foster child.

title: When an Annual Report Is Hazardous to Your Health
description: Another day, another new mutual fund. The number of fund offerings has exploded in recent years, and the excuses that fund companies give for starting them grow flimsier each day. More and more portfolios are tied to eccentric stock indexes, obscure industry subsectors and ever more esoteric investing styles. The logical end? Following are excerpts from an imaginary annual report:

title: A Video Is Said to Depict Mass Killings by Serbs
description: A Kosovar refugee who said he escaped a massacre in his village last week gave the BBC what he said was a videotape of the aftermath of the incident that shows the bodies of nearly 100 men who he said were killed by Serbian forces.

title: BEST SELLERS: April 4, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Preservation Group Issues List of Endangered Sites
description: The Broad Street train station in Newark, built about 1906, is in danger of being demolished or significantly altered to accommodate modern trains, according to Preservation New Jersey, a private, nonprofit historical preservation organization. The station was one of the 10 most endangered historic sites in the state named by the group last week. The annual list is compiled to encourage people to try to save the buildings.

title: Britain Takes Doubles And Cuts the U.S. Lead
description: Tim and Greg. Greg and Tim. They are the reason tennis is a year-round topic again in Britain, and the reason the seating capacity of the National Indoor Arena had to be expanded twice to meet ticket demand for a first-round Davis Cup encounter with the United States.

title: Blackboard: Adult Education; Talk Like an Egyptian
description: Old languages never die, they just morph into catchy phrases: ''Calepa ta kala'' (''Beauty isn't easy,'' classical Greek), ''Carpe diem'' (''Seize the day,'' Latin), ''Wan an'' (''Good night,'' Mandarin ) and (''Living forever,'' Egyptian hieroglyphics).

title: In Glow of Explosions, Serbs' Defiance Smolders
description: For the second day in a row, NATO air strikes hit Belgrade, with large explosions at about 4:30 A.M. today (9:30 P.M. EST) at what Serbian television said were two industrial sites and a police academy.

title: Reader, I Divorced Her
description: FALLING

title: Distance Learning; Education.com
description: With his silver hair, V-neck sweater over a crisp Oxford shirt, genteel European accent and background as a conductor with orchestras from Israel to Boston, David Sonnenschein is no one's idea of a technogeek.

title: Quiz; Twentieth-Century Facts
description: 1. What three cities did the 20th Century Limited link during its 65-year history?

title: Exercising In the War On Cancer
description: JACQUELYN GILBERT had just finished 20 weeks of chemotherapy and 4 weeks of radiation treatment in her battle against breast cancer. She was, by her own description, wiped out -- not exactly someone you would expect to see working out at a health club.

title: From Down and Out To Sales and Profits
description: Community Access, a nonprofit organization that helps homeless people acquire housing and job skills, opened a store last week dedicated to selling products made by their clients and those of other service organizations.

title: Travel to Iran
description: To the Editor: The outrage and indignation expressed by Elaine Sciolino's ''intrepid, well traveled and well prepared'' little band during their visit to Iran suggests either considerable naivete or downright arrogance on their part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, ADELAIDE (NEE MILLER)
description: SHAW-Adelaide (nee Miller). On March 30, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Alan & Linda. Dear aunt of Roger & Fran Nemet and Susan Nemet. She will be deeply missed. Service is on Sunday, at 11:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: IN MY... BRIEFCASE: STUART A. SMITH
description: MAYBE it's predictable that Stuart A. Smith carries a corkscrew in his battered brown leather briefcase: He founded the Smith-Madrone Vineyards and Winery in California's Napa County 28 years ago and now runs it with his brother, Charles F. Smith 3d.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: VARIETY characterizes this week's array of colorful screen stories, which include an elaborate production of a biblical drama, a Japanese version of Shakespeare, a Hitchcock espionage thriller and a turbulent tale of revolutionary Mexico.

title: Bigger Plans Come to Light For Subway Power Station
description: When neighbors mobilized a year ago against the reopening of an old subway power substation at 154 West 16th Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, they expressed concerns about congestion in the area and electromagnetic fields. Recently, they learned that New York City Transit has even bigger plans for the 1917 building.

title: The Lure of Same-Sex Harmony in Country
description: FROM the days of the Carter Family and the Louvin Brothers, close melodic harmony singing has served as one of the defining elements of traditional country music. In the mining country of Appalachia or the hollers of Tennessee -- places where one might be lucky to own a washboard, a string bass or a Sears, Roebuck guitar -- the prettiest instrument a person had might well be her own voice, intermingled with one or two others, bringing forth gospel music or traditional ballads.

title: Variable Annuities
description: The quarterly tables listing the performance of variable annuities were not available for publication today. They are scheduled to appear next Sunday in Money & Business.

title: Reassembling Art Shattered In a Quake
description: FROM afar, it looks like an Italian neo-realist director's vision of Camelot: the 13th-century Basilica of St. Francis (San Francesco), its sides ribbed with scaffolding, the base of its bell tower warmed by a blanket of winter mist. As a visitor draws closer, the cathedral's solemn mass comes into view, looming unshakable and solid. Two tonsured Franciscan friars huddle under an umbrella beneath the archway at the lower basilica. Only on entering the upper basilica is one reminded of the recent tragedy, and then only vaguely. Here 28 miles of gold-hued aluminum scaffolding transform the narrow nave into a sort of solemn dirigible. The ceiling vaults above the entryway and the altar -- vaults that collapsed 18 months ago during an earthquake, shattering ceiling paintings attributed to Cimabue and Giotto and killing four people -- have been entirely rebuilt and reinforced.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-4-99 -- On Language; Each Other
description: The two were not only made for each other,'' wrote The Washington Times about star-crossed lovers, ''they deserve one another.''

title: Out of the Dust Emerge Lustrous Buttons
description: A button is a generally a humdrum item, barely worth noticing. But the buttons made by J. Carucci & Sons of Lyndhurst stand out on designer clothing and have even been displayed at the Smithsonian. The Carucci buttons are not mass-produced from plastic but are ground and polished from the shells of oysters and abalone to make mother-of-pearl.

title: Battery Reminder
description: Daylight time began at 2 A.M. today; clocks should be set ahead an hour.

title: The Undermanned Nets Still Overcome the Heat
description: There was no way the Nets were supposed to win this game. They had won only six times in 30 games this season and never twice in a row. They were playing the powerful Miami Heat, which had embarrassed them by a total of 49 points in two previous victories. And their warrior-like center, Jayson Williams, was out for the season with a broken right leg.

title: From Queasy Seaman to Dashing Hero
description: Andrew Benson realized early in the planning for ''Horatio Hornblower'' that an eight-hour television voyage would rapidly run aground if the mini-series' creators could not locate a romantic hero with the telegenic qualities of a small-screen matinee idol.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Demarest, N.J.; Small Town, Large Sense of History
description: ALTHOUGH just 10 miles from midtown Manhattan, the 2.5-square-mile Bergen County borough of Demarest has a bucolic, small-town ambiance. Its tree-lined streets have few traffic lights and there is no industry and just a handful of apartments.

title: Where the Big Ones Are Always Reeled In
description: Fishing enthusiasts visiting Fort Lauderdale, Fla., don't have to be on a boat to enjoy their sport. This winter the World Fishing Center, a museum and recreational complex, opened with exhibits and hands-on displays about freshwater and saltwater fishing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNINGTON, WALTER G. JR.
description: DUNNINGTON-Walter G. Jr. On April 2, 1999 at the age of 72 in Hobe Sound, Florida. Devoted husband of Patricia MacPhee Dunnington, loving father of Walter G. Dunnington III and India M. Dunnington. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Woodberry Forest School, Woodberry Forest, Virginia. Funeral service to be held at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church, Orange, Virginia, at 11 A.M. on Tuesday, April 6, 1999. A memorial service in New York will be announced at a later date.

title: Private Sector; Better Luck With Yukon
description: G. Richard Wagoner Jr., the president and chief operating officer of General Motors, invited scores of guests to a reception at Grand Central Terminal on Monday night followed by a party to celebrate the N.C.A.A. men's basketball championship game. A former Duke University basketball player, Mr. Wagoner unveiled two big sport utility vehicles, the Chevrolet Suburban and the GMC Yukon, then sat down in front of a wide-screen television to cheer for his alma mater.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Sports of The Times; McGwire, Sosa Step To the Plate
description: Hitting home runs is not like singing an encore at a concert. To answer the applause, Bruce Springsteen or Whitney Houston can always turn to the band and do one more, but this season it won't be that easy for Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa to do what they did last year, much less improve on it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAHERTY, WILLIAM VINCENT
description: GAHERTY-William Vincent. 77, died in his Pawling, NY home on April 1. Beloved husband of the late Renee, he is survived by his four children and six grandchildren. He graduated from Manhattan College and served as an Officer with the 388th Bombardment Group in World War II. Graduating from New York Law School, he worked with the IRS before succeeding his father in the food business. He was also a member of the New York Athletic Club. Funeral Mass will be at Holy Trinity Church in Sherman, CT on Monday, April 5 at 11AM. Interment immediately following the service at Quaker Hill Cemetery. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Hospice, 70 S. Hamilton St., Poughkeepsie, NY 12601.

title: The Religion of Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Endpaper; Let Me Edutain You
description: Every semester, as required by my university, I distribute and collect evaluations of my course in American studies, taking class time to make sure most of the 150 students fill out the forms. Since I already have tenure, the evaluations are essentially for my edification. After I read them, they will be filed away and forgotten.

title: Missile Defense Fails Test
description: For the sixth time in a row, the Pentagon's experimental missile defense system flunked its most basic test and failed to intercept a missile, forcing engineers at Lockheed Martin back to the drawing board and costing the company $15 million in penalties.

title: Silicon Valley Aftershocks
description: WHEN Dan Scheinman joined Cisco Systems in 1992, he was a neophyte in the ways of Silicon Valley. Leaving a job as an associate at a law firm, he was offered his choice at Cisco of a signing bonus or stock options in the company.

title: Saluting Words And Music
description: Short stories, City Center, Asian Americans, a hospital and millinery are cause for celebration.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-12

title: Mutual Funds Report; What's Killing the Value Managers?
description: Think value investors have it tough these days? Just ask William J. Nasgovitz, portfolio manager of the Heartland Value fund, whose own mother recently tried to pull her money out of the fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTENFELD, SAUL WAYNE
description: GERSTENFELD - Saul Wayne. The Officers, Trustees, Trustees Council and Membership of the Brooklyn Bar Association mourn the passing of Saul Wayne Gerstenfeld, a Trustee of our Association, and extend condolences to his family. Paul A. Golinski, Esq., President Avery Eli Okin, Esq., CAE Executive Director

title: MUSIC; Sounding Out a Provocative Pianist -- and Poet?
description: THE structure that informs the abstraction of music and the equivocal nature of language have been two lifelong preoccupations of the Austrian pianist and writer Alfred Brendel. Varied aspects of Mr. Brendel's talent -- musical and literary -- will be on display this month at Carnegie Hall. Beginning on Friday evening, Carnegie presents him in seven events including solo recitals, lieder recitals, a chamber music concert, a concerto appearance and the first reading of his poetry in this country.

title: $81 Million Smoking Verdict
description: In another legal setback for the tobacco industry, an Oregon state jury awarded $81 million to the family of a man who smoked Marlboro cigarettes for 40 years before his death.

title: Digging Out the Humor in a Serial Killer's Tale
description: DURING the 1980's, the unisex bathrooms at downtown Manhattan clubs would get pretty crowded at the height of an evening, but it was never this bad. Here on the set of ''American Psycho,'' in the restroom of the nightclub that serves as a stand-in for the Tunnel, what with the camera crew, the boom operator and the lights, there was barely space for the elaborately costumed extras -- girls in kitsch cocktail dresses and guys in designer suits -- to slip into a stall for a good snort of cocaine. (Actually, vitamin B powder.)

title: Offering Good Food and Fine Feelings
description: ''I LIKE this place already,'' said a friend as we sat down at Tomatoes in Rockville Centre. That was not an unusual reaction, judging from the crowds that have, from its opening about a year and a half ago, continued to pour into this conveniently situated spot at 242 North Sunrise Highway (594-2977), across the street from the Long Island Rail Road station.

title: Evil's Interrogator
description: Gitta Sereny is sitting deep in an armchair. She is dressed in slacks and a simple polo-necked sweater, her hair freshly washed. She gives me a long look. ''Well,'' she says, ''do your worst.'' We are sitting in the living room of her apartment on an anonymous block in Kensington, in West London. It is a comfortable room in the corner of the building, and the morning light is streaming in. The pure notes of Cecilia Bartoli, playing on the stereo, float discreetly in the background, and the air is scented with the coffee that Gitta's husband, Don Honeyman, has just placed on the low table between us.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: EAST HARLEM

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE TALE OF A DOG

title: Sarah Dunn and David Rosenthal
description: SARAH DUNN and David Rosenthal each moved from Philadelphia to Los Angeles in the same condition -- hopeful, young and broke.

title: Cheever Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Rats, but From Where?
description: Ruth Mang Fischer's grandparents bought the house at 2985 Briggs Avenue back in 1919, when her mother was 5 and there were still farms in the area. For 80 years, family members have lived there, including her son, who lives there now. And despite waves of development that brought the construction of many six- and seven-story apartment buildings in what was once a neighborhood of single-family homes and open spaces, Ms. Fischer said there was never a rat problem. Until this year, that is.

title: Finding a Sign Among the Petals
description: THE SETTING -- Maybe the city's floraphiles were making a beeline to the spring flower shows that opened last week, but a lecture last Monday evening by Louis Friere, perhaps the city's only psychic flower reader, drew a cozy crowd of eight people, none of whom brought flowers.

title: Pity for the Plagiarist
description: Randy Cohen (The Ethicist, March 14) suggests that a plagiarist, ''with her low level of moral inhibition and high level of chutzpah, should flourish in modern America.'' A few pages later, William Safire (On Language) writes that he got through high school because his friend in chemistry let him crib. He goes on, ''Helping a flunking friend'' is ''a value that needs restoring.'' Then comes Andy Newman (Gray Zone: ''Dangerous Crossing'') writing, without disapprobation, about the ruses practiced by parents intent on sending their children to better school districts. I enjoyed all three writers, although one wonders if they reflect an attitude that attempting to beat the system is not only fodder for a cute column, but also normal behavior.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Beans of Brooklyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLIBER, ROSE DUBERSTEIN
description: HOLIBER-Rose Duberstein, 93, on February 26, in Rockville, MD. Beloved mother of Joel Holiber and Corinne Szabo. Remembered lovingly on her birthday, April 5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONEYS, WILLIAM J.
description: CONEYS-William J. Of Tewksbury Township, NJ, on Thursday, April 1. Beloved husband of Janis Cunningham Coneys. Devoted father of James & William Coneys III, and Kathleen Coneys Hall, and the late Kevin Coneys. Loving grandfather of Trevor Hall. Loving uncle of Kimberely, Peter and Daniel Cunningham. A Funeral Service was held on Saturday, April 3 at the North Reform Church, Newark. For information contact Bailey Funeral Home, Peapack, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESSION, MARIE N.
description: HESSION-Marie N., 84, passed away on April 1, 1999 at her home in Bellport, Long Island, after a long illness. She was the loving wife of Professor Charles H. Hession and devoted mother of four children. A graduate of Brooklyn College and Columbia University, she taught economics at Brooklyn College and served during World War II with the OPA in Washington, DC. She also did research for the Conference Board and the National Bureau of Economic Research. During her marriage of 53 years she also assisted her husband in many academic projects, including the writing of an important biography of the economist, John Maynard Keynes. Mrs. Hession was past-president of the Faculty Wives Club of Brooklyn College, the Fireplace Literary Club, and the Garden Club of Bellport. She was a member of the First Unitarian Church of Brooklyn and a trustee of the Unitarian Fellowship of Bellport. She was devoted to her family and is survived by her husband Charles, sons William, John and Edwin, and daughter Ann Marie, as well as six grandchildren.

title: Blackboard: Politics; Look Who's Talking
description: Students want to hear from the capitalist (Bill Gates), the poet (Maya Angelou) and the maybe-Senator (Hillary Clinton) -- the school year's top requested speakers, say booking agencies and universities. And not surprisingly, no one wants to hear about Washington. ''We're not getting asked about the impeachment at all,'' said Theo Mall of the Kepplers Associates agency in Arlington, Va. ''No one wants anything political. I've suggested historians, and it's fallen on disinterested ears.''

title: The Show Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: Closed-End Funds Could Provide a Window to Emerging Markets
description: INVESTORS looking to ride the resurgent, though risky, emerging markets might consider closed-end funds. Emerging-markets closed-end funds are up 10.7 percent on average through late March, and some funds like Templeton Russia, the India fund and Turkish Investment are up 30 percent or more.

title: Pictures of Inaction
description: To the Editor:

title: Neighbors Rally Round Gay Couple Fighting Eviction
description: Landlords and tenants are eternal enemies, it seems, and all the more so when their disputes are waged in an area being gentrified. One such spot is the East Village, the site of one of the latest such battles.

title: Drop Anchor, No Problem. But Now Try Pulling It Up.
description: Competitive sailors, buoyed by tactical skills and time on the water, generally assume a take-it-or-leave-it approach when it comes to physical fitness. As chewing gum is to a baseball player, fitness training has been a personal thing for sailors. Not anymore.

title: Where the One That Got Away Got Started
description: THE first fish I ever caught was a plump Jersey catfish, plucked from a creek near home. I forget how old I was at the time, but I was so excited that when the poor thing expired I wrapped it in newspaper and tucked it away on a shelf in my parents' garage for safekeeping.

title: Social Services Scheme
description: Westchester police detectives have arrested a long-time employee of the County Department of Social Services in the alleged theft of more than $100,000 in cash payments from the Medicaid system. Webb Baker, 48, of Bethel, Conn., was taken into custody on March 22 as he arrived at his office in White Plains and was later arrested.

title: Making Art Difficult
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Americans Give More, and Not Hurt?
description: FIVE years ago, Claude Rosenberg, a retired San Francisco investment manager, began touring the country, telling Americans that they could easily double their annual giving to churches and charities without lowering their standard of living, or their wealth, one iota.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Easy Riders, Raging Bulls: How the

title: SOAPBOX
description: The New Jersey Agriculture Society, dedicated to educating the public about the importance of agriculture in daily life, holds an annual essay contest for schoolchildren. The topic was ''Why we should preserve farmland in New Jersey.'' The winners were honored last month at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton. Here are the entries by two of first-place winners, Devan Hardwick, an eighth grader at the Alloway Township School, who won the eighth and ninth grade division, and Tara Davitt, a seventh grader at North Arlington Middle School, who won the sixth and seventh grade division.

title: The Way He Was
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The front-page article last Sunday, about misleading or confusing parking signs, misstated Barry Glass's title. He is an administrative law judge with the Parking Violations Bureau, not a senior administrative law judge.

title: PULSE; Motorcycle Modes
description: SCOOTER: Pop stars and fans ride Vespas in Europe, Velociferos (center) here.Style icon: Audrey Hepburn's princess in ''Roman Holiday'' and retro-chic stars like Dean Martin (above left).

title: The World: Storm Front; A New Collision Of East And West
description: FOR Americans who never thought much about Kosovo, if at all, until the terrible stories and images began to emerge of Albanians in flight from an evil man called Slobodan Milosevic, it might have come as something of a rude shock last week that other countries, like Russia or Greece, seemed to actually see the United States and NATO as the bad guys for bombing Yugoslavia.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on March 21 with an article about the production of an ESPN series in Westport on the century's best athletes misidentified a man shown searching the tape library. He is Bryan Delancey, an associate producer, not Mark Shapiro, the coordinating producer.

title: On the Road With Gypsy Song and Dance
description: IN a rehearsal room above City Center, three Russian guitarists, the Kolpakov Trio, struck up a bouncy, slightly mournful gypsy tune. Kalyi Jag, a Hungarian group, joined in, strumming guitars and tapping on a milk can, playing a variant of the tune that came through their own tradition. Taraf de Haidouks, from Romania, chimed in with the hammered strings of a cimbalom and stuttering, breakneck lines from its accordionist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMAN, PAUL
description: BAUMAN-Paul. Of Boca Raton, FL, died on April 3, 1999, at 77 years old. Beloved husband of Diane; adoring father of Elizabeth, Pamela and Deborah; devoted grandfather of Jacob, Sasha, Hanna and Sophie; dear brother of Judah and Ruth. One of the original settlers of Jersey Homesteads, now known as Roosevelt, NJ. Brilliant lawyer, 1950 graduate of Harvard Law School, World War II Bronze Star and Purple Heart recipient. Benevolent supporter of the arts and of humanitarian and liberal causes. Great friend to many. Lover of books, music, The New York Times, conversation and golf. Retired partner of Brauner, Baron, Rosenzweig & Kligler; Director of the Herman Goldman Foundation. His intellect, humor, caring and strength were extraordinary. Memorial services will be held on Monday, April 5, at 3:30 PM, at Gutterman-Warheit, 7240 North Federal Highway, Boca Raton, FL, and on Friday, April 16, at 12 noon, at Riverside Memorial, Amsterdam and 76th Street, NYC.

title: Curtains Up: A Razzle-Dazzle Road Show Hits New York
description: THE previews are over and the glittering cast has settled in for a nine-day run. It's not exactly the Great White Way, but it's just a few long blocks from Broadway. And where else in New York can one see so many cars that aren't yellow?

title: Hollywood and Vine
description: TARZAN FOREVER

title: PULSE; Motorcycle Modes
description: SPORT BIKE: Futuristic candy-colored speed toys like the Ducati 916 and Honda Blackbird have appeal in the Porsche Belt.Style icon: Teen-age riders in the hyperviolent Japanese cult comic ''Akira'' (top).

title: Four Artists Taking Measure Of the Earthly Landscape
description: AN exhibition with the portentous title ''Mysteries of the Earth'' has to be more than an ordinary landscape show, even if the landscape tradition is its basis. The show at the Mattatuck Museum in Waterbury isn't out of Jules Verne, but cumulatively it has enough drama to justify the title.

title: A Trade to End The Balkan War; Just Split Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Calling It a Day After Time-Change Rituals
description: IF you feel fretful and tired this morning, you're not alone. A whole hour of sleep has been snatched away by the barbaric imposition of daylight saving time. Not only have we suffered this Congressional act of robbery, but most of us will also waste half the morning trying to reset all our clocks and watches. Before digital technology came along, this was easy: move the hands of the clock, and it was done. Now we have to find the instructions for each timepiece, all printed in minuscule type and all different, and manipulate buttons the size of deer ticks according to an incomprehensible ritual: ''Press C to change flashing digits; press F on time signal to correct seconds,'' and so on.

title: A Modernist Plays With Identities
description: FROM time to time one still comes across the idea that modernist music, by its very nature, is ugly and inexpressive, and that the newly tuneful composers of the last couple of decades have saved the art from going down some blind alley. If evidence were needed to counter that notion, a recent CD of solo works by Brian Ferneyhough (Etcetera KTC 1206), played by the extraordinary musicians of the Australian group Elision, would do the trick.

title: Squeezing In Soul Time; New Yorkers Take Five From the Workday to Feed the Spirit
description: RICK HAMLIN'S time for God begins each weekday morning as the A train rolls out of the 125th Street station in Harlem and pulses down the express track toward midtown. It ends maybe five minutes later when the subway pulls into the 59th Street station and Mr. Hamlin opens his eyes.

title: Why Top Returns Are Not in the Stars
description: WHEN it comes to picking among the thousands of mutual funds out there, investors want a rating system that separates the wheat from the chaff. Unfortunately, the most popular rating services get only half of the equation. They do a good job of pinpointing the chaff of the investing arena, but are not much help in identifying the wheat.

title: A Farewell to a Radio Comrade
description: Stepping into the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Wednesday morning was like stepping back in time, with words like ''comrade,'' ''revolutionary'' and ''warrior'' echoing off the stone walls.

title: Kasparov Is Mowing Down His Would-Be Challengers
description: Garry Kasparov has the wrong idea about how to get someone to challenge him for world supremacy. What he wants is millions in prize money and the additional glory that victory in a new match would bring.

title: Prison for Baptist Leader
description: The former president of the National Baptist Convention, the nation's largest black religious organization, was sentenced to five and a half years in prison for swindles that brought him more than $4 million during his tenure. The Rev. Henry Lyons, 57, who was also ordered to repay almost $2.5 million, was convicted in February of selling bogus convention membership lists to companies seeking to do business with the group's members.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-4-99 -- How It's Done In Nairobi; Buckle Up, Hold Your Breath, Say a Prayer
description: It was Friday evening, rush hour in Nairobi, and Sammy Inanga, a 48-year-old construction worker, was one of four people in the front row of a van jammed with 23 people. The legal limit for such vehicles is 18, but traffic law is subjective in Kenya. And in a city where the commuting options are limited, these vans -- known as matatus, after the Swahili word for three shillings, or the original price of a ride -- maintain a terrifying reign over the streets.

title: Half a Mile Long, and Nearly Forgotten
description: For more than a century, a 2,500-foot defunct railroad tunnel under Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn had largely been forgotten by the city. So when Bob Diamond, an engineering student with a penchant for trains, went seeking maps of the old tunnel at Borough Hall in 1980, topographers questioned how the structure could exist just blocks from their office without their knowing about it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENKUS, RHODA
description: HENKUS-Rhoda. On April 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Lorraine and Jeffrey Goldstein, Ira and Susan Henkus. Loving sister of the late Robert Swerny and Abigail Schnipper. Cherished grandmother of Deanna, Lisa, Kevin, Gary and Scott. Services were held on Friday at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', Rockville Centre. Interment in Beth Moses Cemetery.

title: Board Backs Group Home
description: Members of Community Board 15 ignored neighborhood opposition and its own subcommittee last week when it voted to approve the opening of a group home for mentally retarded adults on Avenue S. But some local opponents said they hoped their concerns about the sale of the house to a social service agency, Bais Ezra, would prevent it from opening.

title: The Cool Precision Of Heifetz?
description: THE young Siberian Maxim Vengerov continues to stake out his ground among the most gifted and engaging violinists of, let's say, the last 25 years. Let's say that, because ''half-century'' or, indeed, ''modern times'' has an inescapable ring of hyperbole. Yet Mr. Vengerov's magnificent new recording of Brahms's Violin Concerto, with Daniel Barenboim and the Chicago Symphony (Teldec 0630-17144-2; CD), immediately brings to mind classic performances available on compact disk.

title: Why a Priest
description: 'Watch people's faces when we come in the door,'' Tom Holloway says. Holloway is a 29-year-old fourth-year Catholic seminarian at Mount Saint Mary's Seminary, and on this stunningly cold winter night, he and six other seminarians have driven to a diner not far from Emmitsburg, Md., where the seminary is situated, to have dessert. Holloway and two others in their fourth and last year, Brian Bashista and Damien Cook, are wearing clerical attire, or ''clerics,'' as they call them: black slacks, black shirts, Roman collars. They have already been ordained as deacons; they've made ''solemn promises'' of celibacy and obedience, and can perform baptisms and preside at marriages, as well as preach. They will be ordained as priests later this spring.

title: Blackboard: Politics; Ken Starr's Other Job
description: It's a tough life, prosecuting the President and teaching at a prestigious law school, but if anyone can do it, it's Kenneth W. Starr. Mr. Starr, whose name is usually attached to the conservative Pepperdine University in Malibu, has taught at the New York University School of Law since 1992. Barring catastrophes (canceled flights, Senate hearings), his constitutional law class meets alternate Fridays at Vanderbilt Hall, across from the chess tables in Washington Square Park. Security guards attend, roll call is taken and unwelcome visitors are asked to leave.

title: Jurors Will See Dueling Images of John Gotti
description: A soft-spoken, selfless, self-made businessman who lavishly supports charities for abused and abandoned children.

title: Alaskan Recruit Chooses Blue Devils
description: Carlos Boozer Jr., a 6-foot-9-inch forward out of Juneau-Douglas High School in Alaska, announced yesterday that he would attend Duke next season to play for Coach Mike Krzyzewski. He was also considering St. John's.

title: Million Miler Takes Off, in His Own Plane
description: This is the story of the little airplane that could. Or, to put it another way, of the small-time entrepreneur who didn't realize that he couldn't.

title: What the Jumans Didn't Know About Michael
description: I read Michael Juman's blaming the orphanage as a need to find a cause, someone to hold accountable. And, secondly, I heard it as a need to know that his family would have loved him even with his defects. We become desperate when we are sad and afraid. It seems clear that the Jumans did love Michael, without reservation.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column on March 7 about the placing of 13 stone pillars in Van Cortlandt Park around 1900, as a test of building materials for Grand Central Terminal, misstated the circumstances of the test. It was ordered not by Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, the owner of the New York Central Railroad, but by his successors at the railroad. (Cornelius Vanderbilt died in 1877.)

title: Roosevelt Islanders Make Case for Self-Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, HAROLD
description: STEINBERG-Harold. On March 26, 1999. Beloved and devoted husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Founder of Chelsea House Publishers. Contributions may be made to the East Hampton Library, Harold Steinberg Memorial Fund.

title: Speeding? You Mean Points Aren't Good?
description: CALL us The Unforgiven.

title: Rumor Might Have It, But Have It Dead Wrong
description: Q. Help! I overheard on the way to a staff meeting that resumes are being accepted for my job as managing editor of a quarterly magazine for a nonprofit group. I know my performance isn't the problem. After all, when I started two years ago, I organized my department from scratch and have reformatted the magazine; reader interest has increased, and we receive nothing but raves with each issue. Instead, the catalysts seem to be office politics -- a new director of communications has arrived -- and the fact that I had to be away for a week because of a family emergency. I'm still invited to meetings and otherwise treated as if nothing is wrong, but I have decided to look for other work. How should I be handling this?

title: Sony Gives Up on 007
description: In a James Bond caper with a decidedly 1990's twist, the prize was not a nuclear bomb, or killer satellite, but -- what else? -- a movie deal.

title: Putting in a Cellar, Status Symbol of the 90's
description: WHATEVER happened to rumpus rooms? There were millions of them a generation or so ago, and now not a trace can be found of that seemingly unique American institution. Oh, we have family rooms and dens and libraries and home theaters and the ever-so-promising great room, but the rumpus room has gone the way of the dodo. Does that mean that we as a country or as individuals have calmed down, tamed by our architecture into more sedate lives?

title: Poetic Justice
description: The River Sound

title: Petty or Principled?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a proposal to expand the Roosevelt Field shopping mall misidentified the court that overruled two recent decisions by the Town of Hempstead Board of Zoning Appeals. It was the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, not the State Court of Appeals.

title: Park Fans Win Tug of War Over Gansevoort Peninsula
description: It juts into the Hudson just south of 14th Street, a spit of land amid a sea of rotting piers. For years, Gansevoort Peninsula has been at the center of a dispute between the city's Sanitation Department, which uses it to store vehicles and salt for de-icing streets, and local residents and politicians, who wanted the land included in the Hudson River Park being built along the waterfront. Last month, park advocates won the battle.

title: What the Jumans Didn't Know About Michael
description: For obvious reasons, it is wrong for adoption agencies to withhold vital, biological information from adoptees. Recognizing this, Lisa Belkin (March 14) should have gone way beyond concerns over hereditary diseases. Unfortunately, most people, given the option, would not adopt a child they know to be ''sick.'' I give the Jumans credit for recognizing this shortcoming in themselves (''We would have said no about this'').

title: If Holly Golightly Had Grown Up
description: THE funny thing about Marguerite Littman is the way her friends tell stories about her. Mrs. Littman, for those in the dark, is one of those rare personalities who fly just below the media's radar, although the list of people who have dined (or lunched or tea-ed) at Marguerite's would be impressive. Tennessee Williams, David Hockney, Jerry Hall, Bill Blass, Bianca Jagger, Andy Warhol and the Princess of Wales have all been there, feasting on her legendary Southern charm, like good gumbo or memoir material. Truman Capote is said to have modeled his foremost Southern heroine, Holly Golightly, after her, while Liz Taylor simply borrowed her drawl for ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, GERTRUDE
description: BERMAN-Gertrude. The Univeristy of Haifa family mourns the passing of longtime friend and supporter Gertrude Berman, beloved wife of Bennett and loving mother of Helaine and Jeffrey. Gertrude and Bennett helped to establish the Berman Center for Psychological Counseling and its faculty will miss her support and advocacy. May the entire Berman family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and of Jerusalem. Yehuda Hayuth, President Yael Metser, Vice President Paul Jeser, American Society

title: For Kosovars, Losing Homes Means Losing All Wealth
description: The stark evidence of the failure of NATO air raids to prevent Serbian forces from driving hundreds of thousands of ethnic Albanians from Kosovo is in the haunted eyes of almost 300,000 who have already been driven out, and in their unconfirmed but uniform tales of horror.

title: Donna Lee and Raymond Lohier Jr.
description: Donna Hae Kyun Lee and Raymond Joseph Lohier Jr., lawyers in Washington, were married there yesterday at the Meridian House. Judge Robert P. Patterson Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIETHOF, HELEN
description: RIETHOF-Helen. Died March 24, 1999, at age 92. Helen led an inspiring and spirited life. Originally from Prague, she fled with her children in 1938; settled in Pittsburgh, then NYC. Spokesperson for CARE. Executive Secretary, New York Psychoanalytic Institute. Beloved by family and friends. Contributions to: Webster Branch, NY Public Library, 1465 York Ave, NY, NY 10021.

title: Mayor Says He Sees Both Sides Of Plan Not to Try Protesters
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he could ''see both sides'' of the plan by prosecutors to drop charges against the 1,200 people arrested for civil disobedience last month over the police killing of Amadou Diallo.

title: Lynn Goldsmith, Sid Schneider
description: Lynn Natalie Goldsmith and Sid Schneider were married on Thursday by Rabbi Gary M. Golbart at the Bellagio Hotel in Las Vegas.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, ELLIOTT
description: BERNSTEIN-Elliott. February 22, 1954-April 2, 1994. Gone five years, but I see you in my dreams. You are missed so much. Love, Mom

title: Travel to Iran
description: To the Editor: It actually is easy to travel alone to Iran. In June 1998, I went to Iran alone on a trip that I booked for myself directly with Caravan Sahra, a tour company in Teheran. I had gotten the name and fax number of this company from a 1997 article in the Travel section.

title: Deborah Lewis and Murray Legge
description: Deborah Eve Lewis and Robert Murray Legge were married last evening by Rabbi Joel Braude at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: Gaining Space and Optimism, Two Galleries Head North
description: HORACE GREELEY'S advice to go West for success has been modified by a couple of galleries fronting the Hudson. They recently went upriver after their former locations were no longer viable. In each case the move has been an expansive one: the galleries have acquired more physical space and have a general glow of optimism.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the new-found unity of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries misstated Iran's ranking among the world's leading oil producers. It ranks fourth; it is not among the top two.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE TWILIGHT OF

title: Inviting Himself to the Party, A Rival Helps the Governor
description: While most of New Jersey's Republican Party idled in a state of suspended animation last week, waiting for Governor Whitman to decide whether she'll run for the Senate next year, a recent convert to the G.O.P. gave the Governor a small, but significant, bit of good news.

title: Owner Gives Green Light To Dig Into History
description: It looks as if a 19th-century hole in the ground on West 11th Street, one with potentially historic significance, just might be excavated after all. The owner of a property with access to the old cistern said last week that he would gladly allow preservationists to dig before a new building goes up on the site.

title: Fewer Doctors: Who Benefits?
description: To the Editor:

title: If They Can Make It There: Performers Venture Into 'the City'
description: FOR music and dance groups who want to get to Carnegie Hall, or any other Manhattan venue, the route is still ''Practice!'' But taking a bow on a Big Apple stage is not an end in itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNO, CHRISTOPHER
description: BRUNO-Christopher, on March 30, 1999. Dear brother of Dolores Rose and Ethel Anderson. Loving uncle of Bruce and Jane Anderson. Devoted companion of the late Julian Moses. He will be deeply missed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an article last Sunday about the financial holdings of Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia misstated the performance of some of his investments. His initial $80 million investment in Canary Wharf, a London real estate development, had grown to $218.2 million through March 25, not to $4.4 billion. In addition, the annual rate of return on the Prince's investment portfolio cannot be readily calculated from information he has released; the rate cited in the article for a portion of the portfolio was based on incomplete information.

title: Living Black and White
description: Amid a world of newsstands chockablock with color publications, a magazine has emerged -- in black and white -- devoted to New Jersey. It is called Nj, subtitled The Magazine for New Jersey, and three issues have been published so far. It is published by Eileen Clancey-Nolan, who moved to Summit 11 years ago from Manhattan, where she was the photography editor at Newsweek, and several former Newsweek colleagues also living in the state. The cover of the first issue, in the summer of 1997, was a photo of girls seated on a bench at a baseball field, and the main article was about charter schools that were starting up. Subsequent cover articles have been about Robert Blake, the children's book author, and on living with juvenile diabetes. The next issue, due out early next month, is to feature, suitably, women entrepreneurs in New Jersey. The magazine, $3.50 an issue, can be found in book stores, Kings supermarkets and stationery stores.

title: Tribute to Marian Anderson
description: MARIAN ANDERSON lived in Danbury for most of her later years, and her name has been memorialized in the concert hall at the Danbury Music Center. And on Saturday afternoon at 5, the Alfred E. White Chorale will offer a tribute to the much loved contralto in the form of gospel music and spirituals. Though no admission will be charged, seating is limited. The number to call for more information is (203) 748-1716.

title: Blackboard: Degrees; They Will, They Will
description: In the movie ''Love Story,'' Ryan O'Neal opines that love means never having to say you're sorry. If only he'd attended Allentown College of St. Francis de Sales, he could have learned that love also means having to say ''I'm wrong,'' ''I'm listening'' and even ''I love you.''

title: Riding the Wild, Perilous Waters of Amazon.com
description: Amazon.com seems admirably focused on customer service at this early point in its existence, perhaps believing, like Nordstrom, that satisfied customers are the building blocks of every successful enterprise. The only gripe de Jonge seems to have is that the stock price has risen too fast.

title: The View From/Rye Brook; Painters Herald Easter And Promise of Spring
description: THE boy in the picture was wearing bunny slippers. Those were footwear with ears, eyes, nose and whiskers at the toes, resembling little rabbits on the move. They seemed especially appropriate for Easter, which is why 10-year-old Josh Danzig included them in his entry in a spring window-painting contest last weekend at the Rye Ridge Shopping Center here.

title: In the Deep South, It's Permitted to Die, Just Not on Purpose
description: APROPER Southern lady knows what to do when she finds a relative upstairs in bed with a bullet through her brain and the pistol still dangling from her right hand. When this happens to Camille Dixon (Glenn Close, dressed like a blend of Blanche DuBois, Isadora Duncan and a Talbot's catalogue cover) in Robert Altman's new film, ''Cookie's Fortune,'' she simply rearranges things to make it look like murder.

title: No Longer the Punch-Line State; Lauryn Hill, the Sopranos and others are unapologetic New Jerseyans.
description: NEW YORK, let me take you out to New Jersey and bring New Jersey back,'' the most popular woman in hip-hop shouted to the sold-out Madison Square Garden theater on March 24. It was an invitation Harrison Ford doesn't hear every day.

title: Habitats / Upper West Side Duplex; A Downstairs Bedroom
description: PENNY SCHLOUGH wasn't exactly looking for a dark apartment. But when she found the duplex on the Upper West Side, she didn't mind that the bedroom was slightly underground.

title: Blackboard: Style; Haute Education: Clothes Make the Feminist
description: Dennis Rodman, Madonna and Courtney Love aren't the only ones making political statements through fashion. Consider professors. What better way to explore the relationship between dress and identity than by becoming the medium and the message?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHURTLEFF, MARY (NEE PRINCESS TROUBETZKOY)
description: SHURTLEFF-Mary (nee Princess Troubetzkoy). On April 3. Panihida, Sunday April 4, Church of the Transfiguration, 35 Sickletown Road, Pearl River, NY at 6PM. Funeral Service at same church on Monday 10AM, followed by burial in St. Nicholas Russian Orthodox Cemetery in Norwich, CT.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Purists may raise an eyebrow about a documentary photographer participating in a fashion story, but Shelby Lee Adams, who was born in Hazard, Ky., left home to study art and returned with a camera, is not fazed in the slightest. ''I think of my work as subjective,'' says Adams. ''It is documentary, but as an artist exploring his native territory.'' Adams, who lives in Massachusetts, is having a show in Arles, France, starting July 7. His most recent book is ''Appalachian Legacy.''

title: The Top Cop: Man in Black Tie
description: IN the midst of the political crisis surrounding the killing of Amadou Diallo by four plainclothes police officers, New York City's Police Commissioner, Howard Safir, sped across the country in a corporate jet, spent the night in a $700 Beverly Hills hotel suite and schmoozed with biggies at the Academy Awards.

title: Soul Mates Aging, One Missive at a Time
description: ''LOVE LETTERS,'' A. R. Gurney's spare, epistolary duet for the stage, is -- as the author himself has pointed out -- a quasi-play.

title: Board of Trade Staying Put But Gets Smaller City Deal
description: The Board of Trade plans to modernize its current trading complex at the World Trade Center, but it will do so with $31 million in government incentives instead of a $98.5 million deal it had won three years ago after threatening to move to New Jersey.

title: Atlantic Division Title Is on the Devils' Minds
description: DEVILS 4, PENGUINS 2

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-4-99 -- Word & Image; Last Gasp for Fair Air
description: What's a fair political campaign? Surely only the kind that brings the candidates before the voters on generally equal terms to define and defend themselves. In America today, that ideal is never even approached. Our campaigns are fought mainly with television ads whose cost overwhelmingly favors the candidates with the most money. The real competition is for big contributions, actually bribes, that must eventually be repaid with political favor and privilege.

title: For Las Vegas Gamblers, Now It's Debt in Venice
description: Another Las Vegas milestone will be reached on April 22 when gondolas appear in the desert, courtesy of the Venetian Resort Hotel Casino, across the Strip from the Mirage. Besides the Grand Canal, other Venetian landmarks reproduced at the hotel are the Campanile, St. Mark's Square, the Ca' d'Oro and (for unlucky bettors) the Bridge of Sighs.

title: A Market Flourishes, Another Fights for a Life
description: At the Pathmark across Bergen Street from the trauma center at University Hospital, the parking lot was bustling as families carried bag after straining bag of groceries to their cars. For years before the supermarket was built, a local nonprofit developer struggled to convince city officials that a store on the site would flourish.

title: Giving a Guerrilla Journalist the Freedom of Cable
description: IN the debut episode of ''The Awful Truth,'' the new series created by the guerrilla-style documentary filmmaker Michael Moore, viewers meet Christopher Donahue, a Florida man with a life-threatening pancreatic illness. Mr. Donahue desperately needs a transplant, but his health care provider, Humana, refuses to pay for the operation.

title: Here Come The Wives
description: Margaret Talbot was too simplistic in her article on Elizabeth Dole and Hillary Clinton (March 14). This is not about women capitalizing on their husbands' careers. It is about ambitious people capitalizing on name recognition. Men do it all the time. Consider the Bush family, the Humphrey family, the Gore family, the Roosevelts, the Kennedys, etc. It's the power of the name, and has nothing to do with gender. If the sons can do it, so can the mothers!

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 29 of the Arts & Leisure section today about countertenors misstates the location for an April 27 recital by David Daniels. It is Avery Fisher Hall, not Alice Tully Hall.

title: Joining the Lineup In the West 90's
description: ALOUETTE +

title: The Internet Expands Small School's Walls
description: WHEN Anna Chiaramonte, a teacher, goes to her second job a couple of nights a week, she doesn't have to venture farther than her son Michael's bedroom.

title: SOAPBOX; Passover With Glitzer
description: PASSOVER traffic is always awful. I tap my husband's hand as he mutters that we'll never make it to the Holland Tunnel. We pass my old building, and I wonder if Glitzer still lives there. And I think about how different Passover was two years ago.

title: Pity for the Plagiarist
description: Cohen's column is a good addition to the magazine. While it's too bad that the culture's moral compass (read leadership) has lost its magnetism, people are clearly clamoring for an ethical authority to counter our contemporary ethos of ethical ambiguity. The likes of Randy Cohen and Dr. Laura might actually help to restore parental confidence enough for adulthood, abandoned in the late 1960's, to be reclaimed and for young people to learn that ethics, like charity, can be taught through a number of vehicles, but really should begin at home.

title: Ewing Pulls a Power Play to Help the Embattled Van Gundy
description: At 36, Patrick Ewing makes no apologies for becoming a creature of habit. Same workout regimen. Same fade-away jump shot. Same restaurants after the game. Same old Patrick.

title: Where Fans Find Art, Emotion and Fun
description: SIDNEY LUMET, the director of nearly 40 movies, including ''Twelve Angry Men,'' ''Network'' and ''The Pawnbroker,'' once described filmmaking as a complex technical and emotional process that is part art and part commerce. Mr. Lumet also said ''it's heartbreaking and it's fun.''

title: Englishing a French Classic (With Their Approval)
description: FRENCH theater buffs still speak with reverence of Jean Vilar's production of ''Le Cid'' at the 1951 Avignon Festival as the definitive modern version of Corneille's 17th-century masterpiece in verse. True, few people actually saw the two acclaimed performances with Gerard Philipe in the lead role, but no matter. When the Anglo-Irish director Declan Donnellan innocently suggested presenting ''Le Cid'' in French at Avignon in 1998, the festival's current head, Bernard Faivre D'Acier, looked decidedly alarmed.

title: Grand View, but No Patrons
description: When Riverbank State Park, the multipurpose sports complex built atop a sewage treatment plant on the Hudson waterfront at West 145th Street, opened in May 1993, thousands of people went there each day for the Olympic-size indoor pool, ball fields, basketball courts and picnic areas. But the 145-seat cafe, with a grand view of the river and the Palisades, had few visitors.

title: Ornate Old School Is Stripped of Gothic Details
description: As workers began removing the slate roof, gargoyles and copper turrets from a century-old, Gothic-style school building on East 99th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues last week, neighborhood residents were rushing to stop its demolition.

title: Counting Homeless In Fairfield County
description: BRYAN MCFADDEN knows the streets of Norwalk better than anyone. This was where he grew up, dealt drugs, lived in the shelters, earned jail time, eventually got sober, and finally found his way back to his life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPEE, GEORGE N.
description: RAPEE-George N. Died peacefully April 1, 1999 in his Floral City, FL home at the age of 83. Beloved husband of Joellen Hall Rapee. Loving father of Christina Winkler. Proud, caring grandfather of James Governale and William Winkler, Jr. He retired to central Florida following a successful career in New York as a commercial real estate lawyer. George's two passions were his animals and playing bridge. He was a World Champion three times over, earning the highest possible rank, World Grandmaster. Funeral services will be private with a memorial service to be held in New York at a later date in May.

title: In the Region /Connecticut; In Greenwich, Concerns Over Sales of Large Estates
description: WHENEVER a large property goes on the market in Fairfield County local conservationists and planners worry that a developer will buy it and subdivide it into more suburban sprawl, reducing an already depleted supply of open space.

title: Meet Your Clubs On the Links
description: SKIING and golf are two of the most popular sports for vacationers. And they share another trait: the equipment essential to each is bulky and inconvenient to take on a trip.

title: David Brooks, 83, Lead Actor in 'Brigadoon' on Broadway
description: David Brooks, an actor who created the leading role of Tommy Albright in the 1940's Broadway musical ''Brigadoon,'' died on Wednesday at the Jewish Home and Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: What About . . .
description: To the Editor: The article on Jacksonville, Fla. (''What's Doing in Jacksonville,'' by Ruth Rejnis, Jan. 17) did not mention Ragtime in Jacksonville Beach. Ragtime is delightful, fun and has excellent seafood.

title: Q & A
description: They Shall Return

title: But Will It Work?
description: The Revival Of Pragmatism

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a chart last Sunday about middle-school and high-school reading test scores omitted a shaded key to a map of the city's community school districts. The map used five shadings: the top of the scale indicated the highest student performance, compared with a benchmark based on students' family income and English proficiency; the bottom indicated the lowest performance. The map also omitted the label designating District 21, in southwestern Brooklyn.

title: Roaring Over Plan For More Jets
description: Rankled by a Federal plan to eliminate a rule that limits the number of flights out of La Guardia and John F. Kennedy Airports, residents from both shores of Queens claimed last week that the proposal would erode the few breaks they get from the racket of jets over their homes.

title: High Income, No Tax: A More Exclusive Club
description: The number of Americans who make $200,000 or more, yet managed to pay no Federal income taxes, fell to 1,820 in 1996, down about one-third from a peak of 2,675 in 1995, new Internal Revenue Service data show.

title: Ms. Rich, Mr. Weinmann
description: Ginger Grace Rich and Richard A. Weinmann were married last evening at the Inn at Great Neck, in Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LISKIN, ELLIOT
description: LISKIN-Elliot. April 5. On this, Elliot's birthday and every day... always loved and remembered... ''and the memories linger on.'' Children, 6 grandchildren & Joyce

title: Snows Claim Another Life Along Border With Mexico
description: A 10th body has been found in a mountainous area of the Mexican border east of San Diego where more than a hundred immigrants, who had been working their way north on foot through deep canyons, became trapped by a spring snow storm.

title: PULSE; Motorcycle Modes
description: CRUISER: Harley-Davidson is still the classic American heavyweight, favored by rugged individualists who ride in packs.Style icon: Marianne Faithfull, the doomed free-loving heroine of the 1968 film ''Girl on a Motorcycle'' (below).

title: Word for Word/Bibles; There's the Good Book, and Then There Are All These Books
description: IF someone in Afghanistan were to title a cookbook ''The Koran of Barbecue,'' it's a fair bet that the mullahs would show their appreciation by employing its wisdom to roast the author himself on the spit.

title: A Trade to End The Balkan War; Where Is Compassion?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, MILTON
description: COOPER-Milton. Retired attorney, age 89, died on March 31. Husband of the late Freda Weiner. He is survived by his children Alan and Beth, and siblings Lillian, Ruth and Stanley.

title: Streetscapes /The Grand Concourse in the Bronx; Will It Be City's Thinnest, Longest Historic District?
description: A LECTURE, an exhibition -- and landmark designation? Supporters of the Bronx's four-mile-plus Grand Concourse are hoping to make it the city's thinnest, longest historic district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, CHARLES C. III
description: ADAMS-Charles C. III. Age 61, of New York, NY, died with dignity on April 1, 1999 after a three-year courageous battle with ALS. Mr. Adams attended Groton School and Harvard College. He was a Senior Vice President with Chemical Bank before opening the New York office of R.W. Corby & Co. He served as Master of Holland Lodge #

title: PULSE; Motorcycle Modes
description: MOTOCROSS: The Yamaha YZ 250 and Honda CR 125 are off-road racing bikes adopted by weekend puddle jumpers.Style icon: Daredevil Steve McQueen in 1971 desert-racing documentary ''On Any Sunday.''

title: Backtalk; A Voice Calls, and So This Listener Will Follow
description: Let's clear up a few things right off the bat:

title: Disco Foes Win a Round, But the Music Isn't Over Yet
description: Residents of lower Broadway won a victory March 16 when the State Liquor Authority refused to transfer a liquor license from the defunct Bowery Room at 1 Bleecker Street to a discotheque planned at 372 Broadway, near White Street. But the club's owner has vowed to fight on.

title: Canadas Territorial Instincts
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Fed Cup Match Moved to U.S.
description: The April 17-18 Fed Cup encounter between the United States and Croatia will be played in Raleigh, N.C., the United States Tennis Association confirmed yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, CHRISTOPHER
description: WILLIAMS-Christopher. 46, horticulturist of White Plains, NY on April 3, of cancer. Beloved son of the late Dr. Raymond M. Williams and Jean Williams-Harris. Loved brother of Michael, Maureen, Timothy, Kathleen, Terrence, Colleen, Patrick, Jeanie, Kevin, Meghan and Jennifer. Playful uncle of 23 nieces and nephews. ''We will miss you, Chris.'' Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Sorrows R.C. Church, White Plains, Wednesday 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave NYC 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEVERTZ, ALLAN H.
description: GEVERTZ-Allan H. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member Allan H. Gevertz. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn his passing. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Saturday about White House warnings to President Slobodan Milosevic misattributed one statement. It was Vice President Gore, not President Clinton, who said the Yugoslav leader had ''barely begun'' to feel the damage of NATO's attacks.

title: Kosovo Killings Bind Both Sides In Net of Terror
description: From a distance, the truth in Kosovo is simple. Serbs, emboldened or maddened by NATO bombings, are on a rampage that has caused nearly a quarter of the ethnic Albanian population of the southern Serbian province to flee.

title: Everyone Wants to Use the Parks; New York's Wilderness
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EASTMAN, HENRY E.
description: EASTMAN-Henry E. On April 3, 1999. Beloved husband of Ursula. Loving father of George. Fatherin-law of Jacquie Raines. Loving grandfather of Eric, Adam and Jennifer. Services to be held 12 noon on April 5, 1999 at ''The Riverside,'' 180 W. 76th St., NYC.

title: People
description: * Donald B. Fries, associate publisher and advertising director at Life magazine, New York, part of the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner Inc., was named publisher, succeeding Edward McCarrick, who left to become publisher of Time magazine, New York, also published by Time Inc. Also, Gene Foca was named to the new post of associate publisher of Life magazine. He keeps his title as director of consumer marketing.

title: The Internet magazine Salon gets a new address and plans its first extensive marketing campaign.
description: OF all the changes set to be announced today by Salon, the on-line magazine published by Salon Internet Inc., perhaps the biggest is a new address.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, CHARLES C. III.
description: ADAMS-Charles C. III. Age 61, of New York, NY, died with dignity on April 1, 1999 after a three-year courageous battle with ALS. Mr. Adams attended Groton School and Harvard College. He was a Senior Vice President with Chemical Bank before opening the New York office of R.W. Corby & Co. He served as Master of Holland Lodge #

title: Media Talk; Book by Koch Calls Mayor 'Nasty Man'
description: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York may have missed his chance for a celebrity arrest outside Police Headquarters, but he is seizing the opportunity to needle the present occupant of City Hall with the publication of a collection of his various newspaper columns titled, ''Giuliani, Nasty Man.''

title: Schools Profit From Offering Pupils for Market Research
description: During recess one recent morning, 35 second graders squirmed with glee in the Watchung School auditorium at the prospect of receiving their own disposable cameras and a creative assignment: recording their lives and tastes through photographs and words.

title: Sports of The Times; The Past Is a Drag On Iverson's Future
description: ALOT of people are pulling for Allen Iverson to make it. The women who kept a vigil in a Virginia courtroom during his 1993 trial. The former Governor of Virginia who granted Iverson clemency after he served four months in prison. The university and the coach who accepted Iverson when other schools backed away. Even a growing number of bored-to-tears members of the news media who feel that the National Basketball Association should drop its Victorian pretenses and embrace Iverson as the league's new marquee player.

title: For Zimmer and Yanks, It's Play Ball (Please)
description: The Yankees hurriedly buried their spring-training skeletons today before rushing off to Oakland for Monday night's season opener. The Yankees' owner, George Steinbrenner, insisted that the interim manager, Don Zimmer, was autonomous; Hideki Irabu apologized to his teammates before today's workout, and Zimmer concluded the meeting by saying it was time to play ball and win some games.

title: Trying to Balance Friendship With the West and Loyalty to Serbia
description: At the bus station this morning, nervous people with suitcases were skipping out on Montenegro, convinced that soon there will be bloodshed in this mountainous Yugoslav republic.

title: Diversity in Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERK, FRANCINE B.
description: BERK-Francine B. On April 3, 1999. Beloved wife of Alan. Mother of Michael. Daughter of David Brecher, sister of Janet and Susan. Service Monday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Free Web Music Spreads From Campus to Office
description: Late last year Glen Richards, a 37-year-old former computer programmer, decided to make his extensive collection of 78-r.p.m. jazz records from the 1920's available on-line at no cost to other enthusiasts. He created a Web site from his home in Houston and began converting his records into computer files using a method of digital compression known as MP3, which allows music to be sent quickly and easily over the Internet.

title: A Challenge to Domain-Name Speculators
description: Tom Kaplan is a stockbroker by day, managing money for wealthy clients who gamble their fortunes in regulated markets. But his off-time is spent on a new and controversial investment game in which he and two partners have wagered tens of thousands of dollars on catchy words and names that they hope to resell as valuable Internet addresses.

title: Sports of The Times; Zimmer Speaks Mind and Lives to Tell Tale
description: HE uncapped the vial and dug out his morning dosage. The pills clattered on the desk, like dice on a sidewalk.

title: Champions Aren't Immune To Disappointment's Pangs
description: Bridge is a game of triumphs and disasters, satisfactions and disappointments. The most disappointed player of 1999, or at any rate a candidate for the title, is the French world champion Pierre Chemla.

title: The Devils Impale the Ranger Season That Never Was
description: The Devils swept the season series from the Rangers for the first time in the history of the rivalry, winning today by 4-1.

title: INSIDE
