description: The Politics of Acid Rain

title: Market Place; The Melissa virus on the Internet gives software developers a chance to increase their brand exposure.
description: IN the Cupertino, Calif., offices of the Japanese software developer Trend Micro, an avalanche of pizza boxes tumbled to the floor from time to time last week, and the company pool table was commandeered as a cot. Both were a result of programmers' working through the night to create software that would clean the Melissa virus from computers.

title: Tyrannized by Weaklings
description: Democracies have always had great difficulty when they confront dictators. Dictators don't behave rationally. They impose self-defeating policies on their own countries. They lead them into disastrous wars against others. And they don't even pursue their own ends to best effect.

title: SERB CONSCRIPTS DRIFT INTO HIDING
description: Vladimir, like an unknown number of other young Serbs, is on the run.

Funeral service will be held at Temple Shaaray Tefila of Westchester, Bedford Corners, NY, today, at 2 PM.

title: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report; Far too many Internet retailers hide the true costs of purchases. And that hurts the industry as a whole.
description: CAR dealers have a reputation for waiting until the last minute to reveal hidden charges to unwary customers.

title: Sikhs Celebrate Faith and Numbers
description: While Christians celebrated the ancient holiday of Easter this weekend and Jews the even older Passover, Sikhs gathered by the thousands in New Jersey to begin a commemoration of the relatively new anniversary -- only 300 years -- of Khalsa, the concept at the core of their faith.

title: What's Past Is Past; Will Sammy Hit 71?
description: Where have you gone, Donnie Mattingly? Gone and forgotten? New York does not turn its lonely eyes to you. New York might not even remember you.

title: Misery and Disease Sweep Macedonian Camp
description: Every few minutes stretcher-bearers struggled through the crowd today, slipping and falling on their way up the muddy slope in their haste to get another patient to the medical tent. Others charged the hill with children in their arms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYERSBACH, DR. GERTRUDE C.
description: REYERSBACH-Dr. Gertrude C. Of Boston. Beloved daughter of the late Paul and Olga Fontheim Reyersbach. Born in Oldenburg, Germany in 1907, Dr. Reyersbach emigrated to the United States in 1937, having completed her training in pediatrics in Germany. After practicing pediatric medicine in New York, Cincinatti, and Philadelphia, Dr. Reyersbach came to the Massachusetts General Hospital and was on the staff there and at the Children's Hospital. She also held a teaching appointment at the Harvard University Medical School, and had an extensive private practice. She retired from the practice of medicine in 1990, and died peacefully on April 2, 1999 at the age of 91. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Children's Hospital, 300 Longwood Avenue, Boston, Massachusetts 02115. Funeral Services will be conducted Tuesday, April 6, at 2 PM at the Bigelow Chapel of Mt. Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge. For information, contact J.S. Waterman & Sons-Waring Funeral Home, Wellesley, MA.

title: Nguyen Has Made His Own Long Journey, and the N.F.L. Is in Sight
description: These days Texas A&M linebacker Dat Nguyen is asked as much about his life story as he is about the skills that are leading him toward the National Football League. It is easy to understand why.

title: Editorial Observer; The Russian Way of Corporate Governance
description: As Russia pleads with the International Monetary Fund for money to keep it from defaulting on its international debts, the country's Government seems to believe that an I.M.F. seal of approval will lead to a resumption of the flow of private capital into the country. Don't bet on it.

title: New Defense Against an Old Killer
description: The biggest infectious killer in the world today is not AIDS or malaria, but that old devil tuberculosis. Antibiotics largely controlled TB by 1960, but it came back in the late 1980's, often in strains resistant to the drugs traditionally used to treat it. While TB is epidemic in some poor countries, it can be spread on a long plane flight, and immigrant-rich New York City was the center of an American outbreak that peaked in 1992. The Health Department controlled it with a new treatment that involves watching patients take their medicine, which has proved cheap and effective worldwide. To prevent the further spread of drug-resistant tuberculosis, countries and international organizations need to invest money now in treatment everywhere.

title: Airborne in Thought, Word and Deed
description: ''Tongue of a Bird' certainly lives up to its name. The play by Ellen McLaughlin chatters so obsessively about birds and flight, conjures avian imagery so frequently, that one would think the whole endeavor had been hatched by an undergraduate ornithology department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NACHTIGALL, WALTER

title: Get Tough With China
description: In 1994, when President Clinton formally separated China's ''most favored nation'' trading status from its human rights record, he insisted that this did not diminish our commitment to pursuing a vigorous human rights policy. The Administration even went so far as to claim that economic growth and liberalization in China, fueled by increased trade with the United States, would actually promote political liberalization.

title: Masters: Where Tradition Is a Permanent Illusion
description: As the world's best players prepare for Thursday's opening round of the Masters, one topic is even hotter than David Duval, who claimed his fourth victory of the year yesterday at the BellSouth Classic.

title: R. C. Benitez, 81, Dies; Led Cold War Rescue
description: Rear Adm. Rafael C. Benitez, who directed an extraordinary rescue operation when his submarine caught fire in one of the first American undersea spy missions of the cold war, died on March 6 at Memorial Hospital in Easton, Md. Admiral Benitez, who saw his submarine sink but lost only one of his 77 crew members, was 81 and lived in Easton.

title: U.S. Holds Off Britain in Davis Cup
description: Adrift on an angry sea, Jim Courier refused to sink below the surface. The arena and its 9,400 predominantly British occupants were rocking. Courier's American Davis Cup teammates were bobbing up and down in their chairs, screaming encouragement in a futile attempt to be heard over the chant: ''Go, Greg, go. Go, Greg, go.''

title: A Museum Talks to Children Without Talking Down
description: There is a moment in a poem by Elizabeth Bishop when a 7-year-old girl, sitting in a waiting room with her aunt, suddenly realizes with terror that she is bound to the world of adults, irrevocably one of them. ''Why should you be one, too?'' she asks herself and adds, ''I scarcely dared to look/To see what it was I was.''

Commission officials said yesterday that they were drafting a rule that would outlaw cellular conversations by drivers unless their cars are pulled over and stopped.

description: India's governing Hindu nationalist party is facing a political showdown with its largest coalition partner, a very public test of wills that has much of the nation speculating about whether the year-old Government is about to fall.

title: Patents; A Federal agency, in transition, reaches out to independent inventors with a new department.
description: THE Patent and Trademark Office is in transition, after the resignation late last year of its Commissioner, Bruce A. Lehman. Mr. Lehman led the office from 1993 until late 1998 -- years that saw intellectual property transformed from a sleepy area of law and business to one of the driving engines of a high-technology economy.

description: For David Clark, an M.I.T. computer scientist, research is like ''an expedition into the future.''

title: Federal Study May Give New York Allies in Acid Rain Fight
description: For years, scientists have viewed the Adirondack Mountains in New York, where hundreds of lakes and streams can no longer sustain life because of chronically high acidity, as the region that suffers the most from acid precipitation.

title: Media Talk; NFL and Petersen Plan to Go 'Inside'
description: In September, NFL Properties Inc. and Petersen Publishing, publisher of 160 magazines from Guns & Ammo to Teen, will introduce NFL Insider Magazine. It will be appear eight times a year, during football season, and will, its publishers say, have a staggering-sounding circulation of one million readers with the first issue.

Walter Thompson Company unit of WPP Group P.L.C. Billings for the account, which had been handled by Adair-Greene Advertising in Atlanta for the last four years, were estimated at $30 million.

description: Pope John Paul II, in a passionate but somber Easter message assailing violence and callousness in Yugoslavia, appealed today for a ''humanitarian corridor'' to bring urgent relief to hundreds of thousands of refugees from Kosovo.

title: Honors
description: * The Advertising Club of Richmond presented its annual personal honors to the co-founders of Barber Martin & Associates, Richmond. They are Robert Barber, president and partner, and William V. Martin, executive vice president and partner.

description: THACHER-Peter Shaw. Of Stonington, CT, died April 3, of brain cancer. 1956-1971, Officer at US Mission to the UN at NYC. 1973-1983, Deputy Director of the UN Environment Programme. Committed to global and environmental planning. Survived by wife, Mary (McGrath) Thacher, three children, Anne T. Tate, Linda T. Visscher and P. Shaw Thacher, Jr., one granddaughter. description: NATO cruise missiles and bombers struck Serbia hard again early this morning, the 13th day of the bombing campaign, with targets ranging from the Air Force headquarters in Zemun, in greater Belgrade, to a factory in Nis, the Serbian state television reported.

title: A Crackdown On Registrants
description: Network Solutions, the company that assigns Internet addresses, is again trying to curb what it terms registration abuses by speculators aiming to turn a quick profit.

title: Silverbulletday Must Run Either Derby Day or Oaks Day
description: Bob Baffert's quartet of standout 3-year-olds emerged from a wildly successful weekend healthy and ready for more, and today Baffert discussed which ones might bring him an unprecedented third consecutive Kentucky Derby victory on May 1.

title: The Business of National Public Radio
description: The nation's public radio stations, already forced to become more business minded as Government subsidies shrink, are coming under new pressure to behave more like commercial stations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEINRICH, HILDA J.
description: HEINRICH-Hilda J. On April 3, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Kurt A. Heinrich, M.D. Loving mother of Jean and Eric Loeb, and Dr. George and Debra Heinrich. Cherished grandmother of Andrew and Marc Heinrich, Carol and William Meyers, Dr. Susan and Andrew Zeitlin. Adoring great-grandmother of Benjamin, Leah and Sarah Meyers, and Jacob Zeitlin. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Monday, April 5, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to the Brandeis Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, HELEN ABERSON
description: MAYER-Helen Aberson. Born in Syracuse, NY, June 17, 1907. She was most well-known for being one of the first female hosts of a radio program in 1932 in Syracuse. She graduated from Syracuse University in 1929. In 1938, Helen coauthored with Harold Pearl the well - known children's story, ''Dumbo, The Flying Elephant,'' which Walt Disney produced as a picture in 1939. Subsequently it became world famous on TV. During World War II, Helen worked for the O.W.I. in Washington, D.C. After the war she worked as secretary-treasurer of R.J. Mayer & Co., Inc., an import-export firm. Helen passed away in New York, April 3, 1999. She is survived by her husband of 55 years, Richard; her son Andrew Mark Mayer; and her grandson Andrew Charles Francis Mayer. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Tuesday, 4 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the National Parkinson's Foundation or the UJA.

title: Lionel Bart, 68, Songwriter; Created the Musical 'Oliver!'
description: Lionel Bart, the composer, lyricist and playwright best known for the musical ''Oliver!,'' died on Saturday in Hammersmith Hospital in London, his longtime hometown. He was 68.

title: An Amateur Captured Nazism In Her Lens
description: A distinct genre has grown up along with the children and grandchildren of the Holocaust's Jewish survivors and victims. Grappling with a past that is both painfully immediate yet forever beyond their reach, they have created family memoirs that range from extraordinary to sincere but ineffectual. What makes Lisa Lewenz's film ''A Letter Without Words'' so exceptional and gripping is the rare cache of films her German-Jewish grandmother left behind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ARNOLD M.
description: SCHWARTZ-Arnold M. Retired First Sergeant. Age 65, a retired Battalion Administrator, Department of the Army, died April 2, at his home in Conway, SC, due to an illness acquired during his participation in the Desert Storm Campaign. Mr. Schwartz was born in Brooklyn, NY, the son of the late Phillip Schwartz and the late Dorothy S. Schwartz. His careers included lengthy service in the New York City criminal justice system, as well as 30 years service in the United States military. Mr. Schwartz was a veteran of both the Korean War and the Persian Gulf War. His assignments also included Operation ''Wintex 83'' in the Federal Republic of Germany. He was a member of the Shomrim Society, New York Veteran Police Association, Veterans of Foreign Wars and the Disabled American Veterans. His awards and commendations include the Legion of Merit, the Bronze Star, the Meritorious Service Medal with oak leaf cluster, the Army Commendation Medal with four oak leaf clusters, the army Achievement Medal with three oak leaf clusters, the Army Reserve Component Overseas Training Ribbon, the Armed Forces Reserve Medal, the Army Service Ribbon, the Defense Service Medal with Bronze Service Star, the Army Component Achievement Medal with Hourglass, the Southwest Asia Service Medal with three bronze service stars, the Saudi Arabia Kuwait Liberation Medal and the Kuwait Liberation Medal. Mr. Schwartz is survived by his wife Janice M. Schwartz, of Conway, a son David P. Schwartz and wife Lisa DeAnne Schwartz, of Hamilton, GA, a daughter Janice E. Schwartz, of Myrtle Beach, two granddaughters and three sisters. Interment will be at Arlington National Cemetery, VA. The family requests that expressions of sympathy be made in Mr. Schwartz's memory to either St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, PO Box 50, Memphis, TN 38101; or Myrtle Beach Humane Society.

title: Preaching, and Picking Pockets, on a Racial Frontier
description: THE MITT MAN

title: Artest Expected To Enter Draft
description: The St. John's sophomore forward Ron Artest is expected to announce a decision about his future, and all signs point to him entering the National Basketball Association draft, someone close to the team said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUTZ, ALBERT WILLIAM, SR.
description: LUTZ-Albert William, Sr. 85, of Asheville, NC. Died Tuesday March 30 in Pineville, NC. He was employed as a management consultant moving to Asheville from Rockville Centre, NY in December 1980. Mr. Lutz was predeceased on July 26, 1981 by his first wife Margaret Mary Colby. He is survived by his wife Mary Jane; children Albert Lutz, Jr., Barbara A. Bishoff, Dianne Rappa, Michael W. Lutz, and Lawrence R. Lutz; and nine grandchildren. Memorials may be made to St. Eugene's R.C. Church, 72 Culvern St., Asheville, NC 28804.

title: Soviet Defector Says China Had Accident at a Germ Plant
description: The most senior defector from the Soviet germ warfare program says in a new book that Soviet officials concluded that China had suffered a serious accident at one of its secret plants for developing biological weapons, causing two major epidemics.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: NATO Plans Airlift of 100,000 Kosovo Refugees
description: The NATO alliance offered today to assume responsibility for the hundreds of thousands of Kosovo refugees, announcing that it would coordinate an airlift by its member nations to bring in supplies and take out almost 100,000 people to temporary shelter on American and European territory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOENIG, CAROL (NEE GLICKMAN)
description: SHOENIG-Carol (nee Glickman). 54, of Leawood, KS. Born in New York City. Beloved mother of Jeremy, Liora and Jonathan. Wife of the late Harold. Devoted daughter of Shirley and Cy Glickman. Cherished sister of Barbara (David Kasell), Susan (Dr. Jeffrey Weinberg), Lynn (Eli Moore). Adored aunt of 22 nieces and nephews. Treasured by all who knew her. Contributions to Israel Cancer Research Fund or M.S.K.C.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEUSTEIN, HAL
description: HEUSTEIN-Hal. The Board of Directors of the Subcontractors Trade Association (STA) is deeply saddened by the passing of Hal Heustein, a dear friend and former member of the Board, on March 26, 1999. Hal, a known figure in the building industry, has been involved with New York City's construction business for over 30 years. Hal received the STA ''Subcontractor of the Year Award'' in 1996. He was founder and President of Woodworks Construction, Inc. He will surely be missed by his friends and associates. STA invites you to join at a memorial service in his honor on Tuesday, April 6, 1999, at 3 p.m. at Campbell's Funeral Home, Madison Avenue and 81 Street, NYC.

title: Media Talk; More Journalists Are Critical of the Media
description: It is no longer just the public that is disappointed with how the news media cover events. Journalists increasingly find fault with how they do their jobs.

title: For Refugees, a Haven, But New Horrors Await
description: Kosovo refugees are spread across the stony hillsides here after days of agonizingly slow, terror-stricken flight from Serbian forces, sleeping in the open or under the thin shelter of plastic sheets stretched over their farm carts.

title: Diversity in Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Adding Firepower, Not Progress Reports
description: The 24 Apache helicopter gunships and the long-range rockets President Clinton has ordered to Albania mark an important threshhold in the 12-day NATO campaign. They are weapons of the United States Army, operated by its soldiers. And they represent the kind of firepower that could, if the order came, become the vanguard of an invasion force, though the Administration insisted that was not its plan.

title: Devils More Relaxed And Ready for Playoffs
description: When a team gets ahead as early and wins as easily as the Devils did against the Rangers yesterday, the victorious coach sometimes searches hard for faults to fret about, things that were not perfect. Jacques Lemaire might have done that. Does Robbie Ftorek, the former Devils assistant who replaced Lemaire after last season, fear his team will develop bad habits or become complacent, as it seemed to do in the second half of a 4-1 victory yesterday in the Meadowlands?

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Student Prevails
description: Eliza Shufford, a 21-year-old pre-medical student, won her first Grand Prix event yesterday when she and her horse, Lover Boy, posted the only clear round in a five-horse jump-off at the $75,000 Grand Prix of Florida in Tampa.

title: War Waged on the Web: Killers Without Context

He was 82 and had been a founder of the Balloon Federation of America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMAN, PAUL
description: BAUMAN-Paul. Of Boca Raton, FL, died on April 3, 1999, at 77 years old. Beloved husband of Diane; adoring father of Elizabeth, Pamela and Deborah; loving father-in-law of Bertil Lundqvist and Dr. Steve Levine; devoted grandfather of Jacob, Sasha, Hanna and Sophie; dear brother of Judah and Ruth. One of the original settlers of Jersey Homesteads, now known as Roosevelt, NJ. Brilliant lawyer, 1950 graduate of Harvard Law School, World War II Bronze Star and Purple Heart recipient. Benevolent supporter of the arts and of humanitarian and liberal causes. Great friend to many. Lover of books, music, The New York Times, conversation and golf. Retired partner of Brauner, Baron, Rosenzweig & Kligler; Director of the Herman Goldman Foundation. His intellect, humor, caring and strength were extraordinary. Memorial services will be held on Monday, April 5, at 3:30 PM, at Gutterman-Warheit, 7240 North Federal Highway, Boca Raton, FL, and on Friday, April 16, at 12 noon, at Riverside Memorial, Amsterdam and 76th Street, NYC. Contributions may be made to the Harid Conservatory, Boca Raton, Florida.

title: Political Memo; For Albany Nonchalance Over Budgets
description: Over the last 15 years, through fiscal feast or famine, there have been two sure things in Albany. Members of the New York Legislature will nearly always win re-election. And the state budget will be late -- sometimes maddeningly so. Don't think they aren't related.

title: LUCENT TO BUY MOSAIX FOR $145 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Lucent Technologies Inc., the world's largest maker of telephone equipment, agreed yesterday to buy Mosaix Inc. for about $145 million in stock to add software that manages telephone customer service. Lucent will pay 0.1927 share for each share of Mosaix, valuing it at $10.77 a share, a 29 percent premium over Mosaix's closing price on Thursday. Mosaix shares rose $2.3750, to $10.75, yesterday. Shares of Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., rose $3.0625 to close at $58.9375, after splitting 2 for 1 yesterday.

title: GILLETTE SAYS FIRST-QUARTER EARNINGS TO FALL SHORT
description: The Gillette Company, the world's largest producer of razors and blades, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings per share would be about a penny below analysts' expectations because of weak sales in Latin America and in its Braun appliances unit. Gillette said it expected earnings of about 24 cents a share. It earned 23 cents a year earlier. About two-thirds of Gillette's sales come outside the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNINGTON, WALTER G. JR.
description: DUNNINGTON-Walter G. Jr. The Boards, Faculty and Staff of the New York Presbyterian Hospital and the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences of Cornell University are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and esteemed Trustee, Walter G. Dunnington. Following in a tradition of distinguished service set by his father, the late Walter Grey Dunnington, Sr., he served on the Board of the Hospital for over 37 years, lending his support and leadership to a wide variety of Board endeavors that have benefitted patient care, research and medical education. We will miss his wisdom and insight. Our deepest condolences are extended to the Dunnington family. New York Presbyterian Hospital Daniel B. Burke John McGillicuddy Co-Chairmen, Board of Trustees David B. Skinner, M.D. Vice Chairman & CEO William T. title: WELSH CARSON GETTING BANCTEC FOR $525 MILLION
description: Banctec Inc., a Dallas company that provides banking software and data-processing equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to be purchased by Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe, the New York-based investment firm, for $375 million in cash and $150 million in assumed debt. Under the agreement, about 97 percent of Banctec's common stock will be converted into the right to receive $18.50 in cash for each share, a 42 percent premium to Banctec's closing price last week. The merger is expected to be completed in the third quarter, if approved by Banctec's shareholders. If not, Banctec will pay Welsh, Carson a breakup fee of $12 million.

title: Liberty Media Increases Stake In General Instrument to 18%
description: The General Instrument Corporation said today that the Liberty Media Group, the cable television programming distributor run by John C. Malone, had increased its stake in General Instrument, the leading maker of television set-top boxes, to 18 percent, becoming its largest shareholder.

description: European oil companies are preparing for an investment boom in Libya after the nation turned over two suspects in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am airliner, clearing the way for the United Nations to lift sanctions.

title: Rendezvous With Trout, and Nature; Raising Fragile Fish, Students Encounter a Larger World
description: It was 90 minutes after dawn, and the hatchling brown trout were hungry, nosing into a steady current of cold, clear water, hunting for insect larvae or anything else that came along.

title: HANGER TO BUY NOVACARE ORTHOPEDIC CLINICS
description: Hanger Orthopedic Group Inc. will buy the orthopedic clinics of the industry leader Novacare Inc. for $417 million in cash and $38 million in assumed debt, more than doubling its operations in the United States. Hanger, which makes artificial limbs and other prosthetic devices and operates clinics where patients have them fitted, will buy 369 clinics from Novacare, which is leaving the business to focus on contract rehabilitation and outpatient physical therapy services. Hanger will have about 625 clinics after the transaction. Shares of Hanger, based in Bethesda, Md., rose $1.8750, to $14.8750. Novacare, of King of Prussia, Pa., rose 43.75 cents, to $1.6250. Novacare also said that it was considering options, including a sale, of its portion of the Novacare Employee Services business.

title: Play Ball!
description: If the 1998 season proved anything, it is that good baseball can erase a lot of bad feelings. When the season began, the sport seemed adrift, torn from its old moorings by too many labor disputes, too many greedy owners, too many inflated salaries. Then came the thrilling late-summer home run duel between Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa and the magisterial performance by the New York Yankees, and all of a sudden baseball's disaffected fans came back.

title: Beijing Prompts Airline to Divert Dissident
description: A prominent exiled dissident who tried to return to China was diverted today by the airline he was traveling on after it received a warning from the Chinese Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLDS, HERBERT VINCENT
description: OLDS-Herbert Vincent. Formerly of Lynn, MA and Arlington, VA, died on April 3, 1999. He was 85 years old. Born December 19, 1913, he was the son of Herbert V. and Mary Emerson Olds. He attended the Loomis School in Windsor, CT and graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University in 1934. He also did post-graduate work at the University of Virginia, the University of Mexico, Columbia University, and the American University in Washington, DC. He was married for 57 years to Mary Elliott Rankin of Lorraine, OH until her death in 1994. Mr. Olds had a distinguished 30-year career in the U.S. Foreign Service, during which he held various assignments as a consular or political officer in Havana, Cuba; Rotterdam, the Netherlands; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Bogota, Colombia; and Brussels, Belgium. Mr. Olds also opened the first U.S. Consulates in Bujumbura, Burundi and Kigali, Rwanda and served as Consul General in Bujumbura for two years. He also held assignments in the Office of Personnel and the Bureau of African Affairs at the State Department in Washington, DC. He was interned in the Netherlands and Germany for part of World War II. Mr. Olds is survived by four children, Margaret L. Olds of York, PA; Anne K. Lombardi of Falls Church, VA; Michael V. Olds of Newport Beach, CA; and John C. Olds of Pebble Beach, CA. He is also survived by six grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Another daughter, Patricia E. Frantz, died in 1977. Following his retirement in 1964, Mr. Olds traveled extensively in Europe, Russia, Asia, Australia, New Zealand and the Caribbean. A passionate opera buff, he also served as a volunteer and occasional supernumerary for the national Opera Society of Washington, DC and was proud to have performed in the role of the Cardinal in the world premiere of Alberto Ginastera's opera, Bomarzo. Mr. Olds had spent the last year living at the home of his daughter, Margaret, in York, PA. Following cremation services and burial will be private.

title: Drifter Gets 4 to 12 Years In H.I.V. Case

title: Gotti Pleads Guilty To Rackets Charges On Eve of His Trial
description: Less than a day before his trial was to begin, John A. Gotti, accused of being the acting boss of the Gambino crime family, pleaded guilty today to being part of a criminal racket that involved bribery, extortion and the threat of violence. In return, he faces a maximum sentence of seven years and three months in Federal prison and a $1 million fine.

title: Subway Killing Suspect Is Ruled Fit for Trial
description: A man with a history of mental illness who is accused of pushing a woman to her death in front of a subway train was found fit to stand trial for murder yesterday by a Manhattan judge.

title: Early Wynn, Pitcher Who Won 300 Games, Dies at 79
description: Early Wynn, the Hall of Fame right-hander who won 300 games over 23 seasons, dominating American League batters with a legendary meanness to match his talent, died Sunday night at an assisted-living center in Venice, Fla. He was 79.

title: Memorial for Flora Roberts

Among those to speak at the memorial, which is open to the public, are the playwrights Wendy Wasserstein, Alfred Uhry and Tina Howe; the songwriters Richard Maltby and David Shire; the choreographer Susan Stroman, and the singer and pianist Barbara Carroll. Ms. Roberts died in December at age 77.

title: Buoyed by Stocks, Foundations Increased Their Giving to $19.5 Billion Last Year
description: The nation's foundations, reaping the benefits of a robust stock market, gave away a record amount of money last year, according to a study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, DORIS M.
description: GREENE-Doris M. Loving mother of Paul, Marc, Eric their wives Sheryl and Elysa. Grandchildren Daniel, Kali and Leah. April 2, 1999. description: The American Academy of Pediatrics has begun recommending that all infants be checked at birth for hearing loss.

title: Ordeal for Albanians Still in Kosovo
description: Last week, Ismer Mjeku managed to call his uncle in Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, a few times to find out just how much life had deteriorated in his hometown.

title: People
description: * Brenda Christensen was named to head a new public relations division at Ayzenberg Group, Pasadena, Calif., as director for client services. She had been public relations director at Goldmine Software Corp., Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEINER, PAULA
description: SCHEINER-Paula. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Eric Scheiner on the loss of his mother. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, THOMAS M.
description: GIBSON-Thomas M. Age 63, of Colts Neck, NJ, died April 4 at home. Mr. Gibson was a registered patent attorney and senior partner at Hedman, Gibson and Costigan, Avenue of the Americas, NYC. He is survived by his wife Judy; two sons, Timothy and Christopher; two daughters, Loretto Rizzo and Kathleen Gibson; and one grandson. Funeral liturgy 11 AM, April 7 at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church, Marlboro, NJ. Visitation April 6 from 2-4, 7-9 PM at the Freeman Funeral Home, 47 East Main St Freehold, NJ.

title: A New Trophy for America's Attic
description: The Breitling Orbiter 3, the first manned balloon ever to make a non-stop trip around the earth, will be permanently housed at the Air and Space Museum in Washington, its owners have announced.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Circuit City is learning the high price of new video technology.
description: WITH consumers spending freely, Circuit City Stores Inc. looks poised to cash in on a rebound in sales of televisions, cordless telephones and other electronics, not to mention the growing interest in all things digital.

title: Fitness: 4 Minutes And $600 Later
description: Promoters of a hot new exercise machine make a profound claim: a four-minute workout that really works.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYNG, LILA HOTZ
description: TYNG-Lila Hotz. The Directors and staff of Spence-Chapin Services to Families and Children extend their sympathy to the family of Ms. Lila Tyng, a long-time board member and honorary director of the agency. Katharine S. Legg, Exec Director

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Anti-Tank Copters Will Go Into Action Against Serbs In Kosovo Soon, Allies Say
description: NATO today gave its military commander the authority he wanted to send 24 United States Apache helicopter gunships to Albania, with surface-to-surface missiles and about 2,000 American soldiers who will use them to attack Serbian forces across the border in Kosovo.

title: Immigration Boosts Our Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits on Thursday, about computer viruses, misstated the availability of free on-line updates for the Mc Afee Virus Scan software program from McAfee, a division of Network Associates. The updates are available indefinitely, not just for a year.

title: Isn't Kosovo Just Like Tibet?
description: To the Editor:

title: Profits at Large Manufacturers Fell in Last Quarter of 1998
description: Profits after taxes at large manufacturers fell during the fourth quarter of 1998 to their lowest level in three years, the Commerce Department said today. Retailers' profits rose in the period.

title: An Ear for What Women Want
description: Michael Kors was at Bergdorf Goodman a couple of weeks ago to meet customers, and was reminded of a day early in his career when he went to a store in Minneapolis where Bill Blass -- one of his idols, then and now -- was making a personal appearance.

title: Inside The Cell, Experts See Life's Origin
description: Look inside the machinery of a human cell and you would see that its working parts are composed largely of proteins and its data storage is handled by DNA. But look a little closer and a third agent seems to be running many of the trickiest parts of the show.

title: When No One Read, Who Started to Write?
description: The Sumerians had a story to explain their invention of writing more than 5,000 years ago. It seems a messenger of the king of Uruk arrived at the court of a distant ruler so exhausted from the journey that he was unable to deliver the oral message. So the king, being clever, came up with a solution. He patted some clay and set down the words of his next messages on a tablet.

title: Net.bank Shares Surge After Upbeat Report
description: Net.bank Inc., the first profitable Internet bank in the nation, said today that it added 8,000 new accounts in the first three months of the year, 2,000 more than expected. The company's offer of high interest payments and low fees has helped increase total accounts to 24,634, almost three times the number it had a year ago, the company said.

title: Isn't Kosovo Just Like Tibet?
description: To the Editor:

title: W.N.B.A. Comes of Age: A Labor Dispute
description: Here we go again.

title: Long Road for Women
description: To the Editor:

title: No. 2 Executive Departing Ammirati
description: Richard J. Hadala, who only seven months ago joined Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York as the No. 2 executive from a background in consulting rather than advertising, is leaving effective immediately, the agency announced unexpectedly late yesterday.

title: In Pizza Case, Two Theories About Motive For Slayings
description: Thomas J. Koskovich murdered two pizza deliverymen in April 1997 for the experience of killing and as a springboard to a life of crime, an assistant prosecutor charged today at the start of Mr. Koskovich's trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, SOL
description: HALPERN-Sol. Of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, formerly of L.I., died March 30, 1999 at age 84. Devoted husband, father, grandfather, brother, companion and friend. He founded a successful law firm in Mineola, NY and was an avid boatsman. He lived life his way. We knew he cared and we'll all miss him.

title: United Rentals Makes Offer For Acquisition-Minded Rival
description: United Rentals Inc., the nation's largest equipment-rental company, offered today to buy the Rental Service Corporation for $553 million in an effort to block Rental Service from buying Nationsrent Inc.

title: Reporter in Chiquita Case Reveals a Source in Court
description: A closely watched case involving crime and the ethics of journalism took an unusual turn today when a former investigative reporter disclosed in court the identity of a confidential source for a stinging collection of articles last year about Chiquita Brands International Inc.

title: Relatives Find Frustration And Relief In Extradition
description: Among the relatives of those killed in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, the extradition of two Libyans suspects brought a heated mix of reactions yesterday. Some, like Aphrodite Tsairis of Franklin Lakes, N.J., saw the extradition as a positive step in their crusade for justice.

title: Interbrew to Invest In Russian Brewer
description: Sun Brewing Ltd., Russia's biggest brewer by sales, and Interbrew S.A. of Belgium, the world's No. 4 brewer, said yesterday that they would join forces in Russia and Ukraine to lift competitiveness and win market share from a rival concern, A. O. Baltika.

title: Worldwide Unit Formed by Snyder
description: Snyder Communications Inc. in Bethesda, Md., said yesterday that it had combined its various agencies handling direct-marketing services to form a unit called Brann Worldwide that will be based in Cirencester, England. The unit, described as one of the largest dedicated to direct marketing, will handle accounts for advertisers like Coca-Cola, I.B.M., Procter & Gamble and Visa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MURIEL
description: FRIEDMAN-Muriel of Blauvelt, NY, passed suddenly on April 4, 1999, at the age of 70. She had lived a wonderful, compassionate, and dedicated life. She was a graduate of the Columbia University School of Social Work and had a distinguished career. Her intellect, good humor, caring, and innerstrength helped her overcome her physical disabilities and she served as a beacon and positive role-model for those people whose lives she touched at numerous social agencies including: Jewish Family Services of New York, St. Dominic's Home, and Rockland Childrens Center in Orangeburg, NY, the Rockland County Association for Retarded Citizens, and the Child Development Center in Pomona, NY. In retirement she also volunteered for the Rockland County Cancer Society, Nyack Hospital, the Rockland Parkinson's Group, and the NYS Commission on Quality Care for the Mentally Disabled. Muriel was devoted to her family and will be honored by her husband Dan; daughters Judy, Susan, and Lisa; their husbands/ partners Harry, David and Ronnie; and her grandchildren Tracey, Rachel, and Ruben. Services will be held at Hellman Memorial Chapels, 15 State St., Spring Valley, NY at 11AM today.

title: Spirituality as a Composer's Driving Force
description: Listening to a program of John Tavener's serene, religiously inspired music at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity on Saturday evening, it was difficult not to be struck by the unusual turns this English composer's career has taken.

title: INSIDE
description: Search Powers Expanded

title: Dreyfus Corp. Places Account in Review
description: The Dreyfus Corporation said yesterday that it would begin a review for its account, which had been handled by Grace & Rothschild in New York since September. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Seeing and Then, Finally, Seeing
description: SLACKJAW

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDNOR, LUCILLE O.
description: REDNOR-Lucille O. On April 5, 1999. Widow of Dr. Daniel J. Rednor. Beloved mother of Linda Rosner, Barbara Ciongoli and Jon Miller. Cherished grandmother of Adam, Gary, Happy, Jamie, Greg, Alessandra, Kenny, Jordan and Joshua. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday 5:30-8PM with service Wednesday, 10AM. Interment to follow at Beth Olam Cemetery.

title: Wal-Mart Agrees to Settle Lawsuit Against Amazon
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the giant retailer, has agreed to settle a lawsuit against Amazon.com that had accused the company, the No. 1 Internet bookseller, of having raided Wal-Mart's workers to learn about its computer system, the companies said today

title: Ban on Commercial Bass Fishing in Hudson Could Be Eased
description: New York State environmental officials provided the first detailed account today of the steps they may soon take to reopen the long-closed commercial fishery for striped bass in part of the Hudson River -- and it immediately became clear that this would be a process fraught with contention.

title: Serb Forces in Kosovo Under Attack as Weather Clears
description: NATO directed its most ferocious air strikes yet on Yugoslav armored forces operating in Kosovo, and struck Belgrade and the country's two other largest cities tonight in an intensified attack made possible by two consecutive nights of clear weather, NATO and Pentagon officials said.

title: Delivering the Lockerbie Defendants
description: Yesterday's surrender of two Libyan intelligence agents brings the long and frustrating search for justice in the Lockerbie case near an acceptable end. It is more than 10 years since a bomb concealed in luggage brought down Pan Am Flight 103 in Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people, and more than eight years since a United States grand jury indicted the two men on charges of having personally planted the explosive. They will now be tried in the Netherlands under Scottish law, in a diplomatic compromise that satisfies all essential American and British requirements.

title: . . . And the big get, well, bigger. Agency companies continue the buying spree.
description: TWO big agency companies are on the acquisition trail again in deals that underscore the urgency with which the global giants are seeking to expand their services.

title: 'Junior' Seems More Son Than Boss
description: His father was the man who worked himself up the company ladder and transformed himself into the Dapper Don, the one with the expensive suits and agile criminal mind, the big man around town who instilled fear and respect. He was, of course, John J. Gotti, the head of the Gambino crime family.

title: A Stiff and Proper Sentence
description: Russell Henderson's decision to plead guilty to the kidnapping and murder of Matthew Shepard is little consolation to the Shepard family, but it provides an appropriately severe sentence for one whose apparent anti-gay hatred led him to destroy a young life. The sentence of two consecutive life terms saves Mr. Henderson from the possibility of the death penalty but makes it virtually certain he will spend the rest of his life in prison. It is not yet clear whether he will have to testify against Aaron McKinney, the co-defendant who will be tried for capital murder this summer.

title: Yanks Play Against 125 All Season
description: IT'S nice to be king.

title: A Milestone on the Road to Ultrafast Computers
description: A group of I.B.M. researchers said last week that they had designed the building blocks of a new kind of computer memory that could fundamentally alter computer design early in the next century.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOSHINSKY, IRVING
description: MOSHINSKY-Irving. Our loving husband and father. We miss you terribly; wish you were here. Romola, David and Donna

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDES, ROSALIE GALLERT MAYER
description: WALDES-Rosalie Gallert Mayer. Born October 27, 1913 in New York City to Minnie Emily Gallert Mayer and Joseph L. B. Mayer. She was a sister to David and Myron (Mickey). She grew up in New York City and Sharon Springs, NY. She attended the Ethical CultureFieldston Schools, graduating from Vassar in 1935. A member of Phi Beta Kappa, she pursued graduate work in architecture at Cornell. She was an avid equestrian and hunted with several packs down the East Coast. She married Milo Waldes on September 24, 1942. Three children, John, Thomas and Helen completed the family. Roly was an enthusiastic botanist, growing orchids from seed, creating prize winning floral arrangements; she was a champion road rally navigator acquiring several Long Island championships with Milo. She was an award winning photographer; one of her photos hung at the 1963-1964 New York World's Fair. Roly travelled widely: she caught a trophy tuna in Nova Scotia, helped Milo photograph the East African Plains wildlife, investigated the pyramids of Mexico and Egypt, explored Europe, the Near and Far East, North and South America, Micronesia and Australia. Roly volunteered throughout her life: from the Women's Auxiliary Armed Forces to Civil Defense and as secretary for the Roslyn Visiting Nurse Association 27 years, as a Friend of the Zoo Docent for 28 years, in her local Vassar Club, as well as for the Boy and Girl Scouts. She loved completing The New York Times and London Times crossword puzzles, playing a vigorous hand of bridge and stimulating, scintillating conversations in several languages. Roly was a student of life, wife, mother to John, Thomas and Helen and beloved grandmother of David, Brian and Elizabeth. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9pm with services Thursday 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in Rosalie's name to a charity she supported: Vassar College; Friends of the Zoo (The New York Zoological Society); The New York Public Library or The Bat Conservancy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYES, JANET
description: KAYES-Janet. On April 3, 1999. Beloved mother of Barbara and William, dear friend of many. She will be deeply missed. Respects may be paid at her home, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, 1-7PM.

title: Immigration Service Blocks Judge's Order to Release a Palestinian
description: A Palestinian man who Federal officials have been trying to deport for the past year was ordered released by an immigration judge who said the Government had failed to prove that he had any links to terrorist organizations, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Not Enough Cruise Missiles to Go Around?
description: As the war against Yugoslavia entered its second week, there were ominous reports that the United States was running short of cruise missiles, the weapon of choice in this war as well as the recent attacks against Iraq and Osama bin Laden.

title: Fall From Roof Kills 2-Year-Old
description: A 2-year-old girl who had apparently wandered away from her baby sitters fell from the roof of a three-story Brooklyn apartment building yesterday afternoon and died at a hospital, the police said.

title: Central Bank Cuts Rate in Malaysia
description: Malaysia's central bank cut its key three-month key interest rate for the first time in five months in hopes of pulling the economy from recession. The rate at which it lends to banks was reduced to 6.5 percent from 7 percent, effective yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, THERESE STERN
description: KATZ-Therese Stern. We extend heartfelt condolences to Rose Rauner on the loss of her beloved mother, Therese. Throughout Mrs Katz's lifetime she personified the highest level of tzedekah and chesed. May the loving memories of this special ''woman of valor'' bring consolation to Rose and her husband Wolfgang, and the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Stuart Tauber, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINIK, SARA CYDNEY
description: WINIK-Sara Cydney. On March 31, 1999 at age 96. Beloved wife of the late Leslie Winik and the late Gerald Campe. Beloved mother of Lois Campe Kraus and Joel Marie Blumenthal. Stepmother of Laurence J. Winik and Richard Winik. Devoted grandmother of 10 and great grandmother of 12. Services and interment private.

title: A Revolution By Degrees For Japan
description: Since March, a number of Japanese companies have announced extensive overhauls, job cutbacks and internal realignments previously considered taboo in corporate Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLER, EVELYN M.
description: HALLER-Evelyn M. Of Eastchester, N.Y., formerly of Bronxville, N.Y. On March 27, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Peter H. Haller. Survived by her brother John Magnus, her niece Erica Magnus and many friends. She was a noted animal sculptor and member of the Society of Animal Artists. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society or the Humane Society.

title: Mexico Hunts For Governor In Drug Case
description: Mario Villanueva Madrid, the governor of the state of Quintana Roo who disappeared last month after authorities announced that he was the target of a drug investigation, failed to appear today at a swearing-in ceremony for his successor on the final day of his six-year term.

title: Corrections
description: The New York Lotto numbers yesterday for Saturday's drawing were printed incorrectly. Corrected numbers appear today, on page B4.

title: Political Memo; For Giuliani, Often Maverick, Party Support Isn't Assured
description: For all the differences between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rudolph W. Giuliani, none may be more important than this: The Democratic First Lady is assured the support of her party if she runs for Senate next year. But the Republican Mayor faces the prospect of a complicated primary, fought in front of Republican voters who have long been wary of him.

title: Temper Tantrums Hurting The Knicks
description: When Chris Dudley bounced the ball hard onto the Market Square Arena floor in frustration on Sunday and missed as he tried to catch the bounce, he drew a technical foul that proved a costly and untimely miscue. It was much like when he threw the ball and connected, striking Shaquille O'Neal in the back in the fourth quarter of a loss against the Los Angeles Lakers last week, and reminiscent of the routine loss of composure by nearly all his teammates.

title: Immigration Boosts Our Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams's Leg Break Is Bad
description: Sal DiFazio, the agent for Jayson Williams, is worried. And maybe the Nets should be, too.

title: Brazil, Though Struggling, Proves Surprisingly Resilient
description: When the price of imported wheat rose more than 50 percent earlier this year, Lawrence Pih, the president of Brazil's largest flour mill, anticipated the worst.

title: 2 LIBYAN SUSPECTS HANDED TO COURT IN PAN AM BOMBING
description: More than a decade after Pan Am Flight 103 exploded over Scotland, killing 270 people, the two Libyans charged with planting the bomb arrived in the Netherlands today to face trial for the crime.

title: Foreign Affairs; More Sticks
description: The question we are wrestling with in Kosovo today is this: How should America react when bad things happen in unimportant places?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the history of conflict between Serbs and Albanians misspelled the surname of the contemporary British historian who observed that no lands have ''suffered more from the whims of international politics'' than the Balkans. He is Norman Davies, not Davis.

title: Serbs Claim Key Kosovar Again Meets To Negotiate
description: As Serbia tried to clean up today after NATO's heaviest bombing raids so far, Serbian television once again gave prominence to images of a moderate ethnic Albanian leader, Ibrahim Rugova, showing him in meetings with a senior Yugoslav official and the Russian Ambassador.

title: Diallo Defendant Is Cleared in a '97 Killing
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday that one of the police officers charged with murdering Amadou Diallo in the Bronx two months ago had acted properly when he fatally shot another man in Brooklyn in 1997.

title: Posada Has Tools of Ignorance for Brilliant Career
description: Catchers bear the tools of ignorance, as the saying goes, the inference being that anyone playing the position must be lacking in brain matter to willingly absorb so much physical punishment.

title: Visiting the Doctor, via the Dining Room
description: Gloria Belisle is probably not the kind of patient doctors had in mind when they first envisioned treating medically underserved people from afar with high-technology diagnostic tools.

title: Bradley and McCain Feed From Bitten Hands
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey devoted years to scorning the campaign finance system as riddled with loopholes and ruled by wealthy interests. But that has not deterred him from partaking in it himself.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Wintry Uranus

title: NATO Says Photo Shows Villagers' Eviction
description: NATO officials released a surveillance photograph today that showed Yugoslav forces herding residents from a village in Kosovo, and said other photographs depicted their homes being destroyed, in what they described as concrete evidence of President Slobodan Milosevic's campaign to remove ethnic Albanians from the province.

title: Tyco Completes Acquisition of AMP
description: Tyco International Ltd. completed the $12.22 billion purchase of AMP Inc. today, adding the world's biggest maker of electronic connectors to its array of industrial businesses.

title: President's Strategy: 'Our Plan Is to Persist Until We Prevail'
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's remarks on Kosovo at the White House today yesterday and from an exchange with reporters, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company:

title: Anti-Tumor Agent May Also Gain Role Against Heart Disease
description: Endostatin, a compound that has been in the news for its promising ability to cut off the blood supply to tumors in animals, has now been shown to reduce the buildup of plaque, the fatty deposits that clog the heart's blood vessels. The finding could open new approaches to treating coronary artery disease.

title: A DaimlerChrysler Shuffle
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. said it sacrificed some United States sales of its M-Class sport utility vehicle, to bolster European supply before it starts making the vehicles there next month. In March, M-Class sales dropped 19 percent, to 3,328, from March 1998. That follows a 10 percent decline in February, despite a double-digit increase in overall United States sales of sport utility vehicles. M-Class sales for the year are down 10 percent, to 9,408. DaimlerChrysler attributed the drop to a tight supply created by increased M-Class shipments from Tuscaloosa, Ala., to Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMMINGS, CELE
description: CUMMINGS-Cele. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Gayle Morrow and Jay Cummings. Sister of Paula Grindell. Adored grandmother of Brooke and Walter Edelstein, Jill and Robert Spiegel, Dina and Marc Bean. Cherished great-grandmother of Megan, Casey, Ryan and Georgie. She will always be loved and missed by her family. Services on Tuesday, April 6th, at 12 Noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERK, FRAN
description: BERK-Fran. We will miss your intelligence, wit and warmth. Our grief is only surpassed by the love you had for those surrounding you. Our deepest condolences to her beloved husband, Allan; son, Michael; sisters, Susie and Janet, and her father, David. The Katz Family

description: FEDER-Lillian (nee) Borodkin of West Palm Beach, FLorida. On April 3, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Eugene, devoted mother of Ronald B. Hermann and Carol Goodman, loving grandmother of 7 grandchildren and 9 greatgrandchildren. Services were held Monday. For information, call ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 1-800-522-0588.

description: COMBAT

title: Rangers' Slim Hope Of Playoffs Stays Alive
description: The Rangers are not out of the playoff picture, not just yet. They eluded elimination tonight with a 5-1 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers, who were playing without several star players and in front of one shaky goalie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMS, MIRIAM MOTTSMAN
description: SIMS-Miriam Mottsman. On April 4, 1999. Beloved wife of 62 years of Seymour (Chuck). Devoted mother of Barbara, sister of the late Janet Zuckerman. Services Tuesday, April 6th, 1PM, Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Agency to Quit The Dell Account
description: Goldberg Moser O'Neill in San Francisco said yesterday that it would resign the account of the Dell Computer Corporation after almost 11 years. Billings were estimated at $70 million. The resignation comes soon after one of the nine Dell assignments handled by Goldberg Moser, for the home and small-business division, was placed in review. That assignment has billings estimated at $30 million.

title: McGwire Hits One Beyond
description: The cheers for him rock the stadium. It is opening day of the baseball season here, and there is always a full house for this event, but this one is special. Because of him, because of what he has done. And tonight in Mark McGwire's first time at bat this season, he received a standing ovation from the 47,806 fans, with flashbulbs sparkling in a drizzle, and the fans remained standing as he walked on a 3-2 pitch from the Milwaukee left-hander Rafael Roque. Then they booed the pitcher for his, to them, lack of fortitude.

description: Palestinians Plan Bond Sale To Help Cover Deficit

title: Oil Company Confronts Cluster of Brain Tumors
description: It was not until the summer of 1996 that Edward Paschke, a 54-year-old chemist working at the Amoco Research Center here, realized that his life might be in danger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMAN, PAUL
description: BAUMAN-Paul. The partners and staff of Brauner Baron Rosenzweig & Klein, LLP mourn the loss of our good friend and retired partner. He practiced with the firm for more than forty years and his leadership, intellect and sage advice will be missed by all of us and by his many clients and friends. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Diane, his daughters, Elizabeth, Pamela and Deborah, his grandchildren, Jacob, Sasha, Hanna and Sophie, his brother and sister, Judah and Ruth and their families. Brauner Baron Rosenzweig & Klein, LLP

title: Social Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: The Worst Of Times? It Ain't So
description: BASEBALL was back yesterday, offering New Yorkers a new season of dreams and a more rounded perspective on life: despite anger over police behavior and troubled race relations and fears for Kosovo's future, things cannot possibly be as bad as they sometimes seem. Maybe baseball does not cleanse the world of all sin. But for millions of people, it comes awfully close.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

description: ASIA

description: NACHTIGALL - Walter. The Friends of Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design deeply mourn the passing of Walter Nachtigall, beloved brother of our esteemed Board Member and colleague, Gertrud Nachtigall Kissiloff. We extend our deepest condolences to her, her husband Bill, their son Ari and the entire family. Romie Shapiro, Chairman of the Board Harry Bauer, President Eillene Leistner, Executive V.P.

title: Corrections
description: A byline was omitted in Arts & Ideas on Saturday from a profile of William Cronon, an environmental historian. The writer was Janny Scott.

title: Isn't Kosovo Just Like Tibet?
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Police Searching Car May Include Passenger's Things
description: Police officers who have probable cause to search a car for illegal drugs can search the personal belongings of passengers who are themselves under no suspicion of illegal activity, the Supreme Court ruled today in its latest decision expanding police authority over motorists and their passengers.

title: Lucille Lortel, Patron Who Made Innovative Off Broadway a Star, Is Dead at 98
description: Lucille Lortel, whose pioneering efforts to bring innovative theater and adventurous new playwrights and actors to the American stage earned her the title Queen of Off Broadway, died on Sunday at New York Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. She was 98 and had homes in Manhattan and Westport, Conn.

title: Of Millions Born in Print, 55 Stories of the Century
description: Annually for the last 83 years an editorial venture has sifted through several thousand published short stories to choose two dozen or so as America's most notable. ''The Best American Short Stories of . . .'' (filling in the year) has been the series title since 1915.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARTLAND, ALICE (NEE CALLAN)
description: GARTLAND-Alice (nee Callan). On April 5, 1999, of Hampton Bays, NY and Hallandale, FL. Beloved wife of Owen, loving mother of Pat, Daniel and his wife Palma, Alice and her husband Dr. William E. Hardy, Kevin and the late Rev. Owen Gartland. Devoted grandmother of Theresa, William G., Alisa, Kara, Jodi, Lori, Danielle and Brian. Also survived by seven great-grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. Cherished sister of Nellie McDonald of County Monaghan, Ireland. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, 11 AM at St. Rosalie's Roman Catholic Church. Interment Sacred Hearts Cemetery, Southampton, LI. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Vincent de Paul Society of St. Rosalie's Church would be appreciated. Family will receive friends today 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at R.J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 94 East Montauk Highway, Hampton Bays, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, CLARA
description: HELLER-Clara. On April 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Toni Hall and Francesca Heller. Grandmother to Jordan Heller-Skolnik. Services Friday April 9, 12PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Dispensing Of Drugs On Internet Stirs Debate
description: Dr. James De Yarman specializes in performing hair transplants at his clinic in San Diego. Last September, he took his expertise on line, setting up a site on the World Wide Web called DrPropecia.com. There, he offers information about the drug Propecia, which promotes hair growth in men. Prospective patients can fill out an on-line medical history form, which Dr. De Yarman reviews for a $50 fee. If he determines that the drug would be useful for a patient, he then prescribes it and sells it to him.

title: Accounts
description: * Thompson's Co., Upper Saddle River, N.J., part of the Sherwin-Williams Woodcare Group division of Sherwin-Williams Co., to Hanft Byrne Raboy & Partners, New York, to handle creative and media planning duties on the Thompson's Wood Protector account, which had been at SBC Advertising, Westerville, Ohio. Billings were estimated at $10 million. IDM International, New York, retains media buying duties.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE AND PANDA FORM $1.3 BILLION VENTURE
description: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc. formed a joint venture with closely held Panda Energy International Inc. to build three Texas power plants for $1.3 billion. The venture, Texas Independent Energy, plans to have the natural gas-fired plants in service by 2002. Each will be able to generate 1,000 megawatts of electricity, enough to light one million homes. Public Service, based in Newark, is looking for new revenue sources because it is losing its monopoly over power sales to 2.5 million New Jersey customers in August. Texas has encouraged companies to build power plants to avoid shortages.

title: Toronto Exchange Trading Is Interrupted
description: The Toronto Stock Exchange halted trading of equities and derivatives for two and a half hours today because of technical problems, the exchange said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, RICHARD WALTER
description: BURKE-Richard Walter. Age 55, of Mendham Township, NJ on Saturday, April 3, 1999. Husband of Elizabeth (nee Martin) Burke. Father of Catherine Elizabeth and R. Brady Burke, brother of John Burke of Pound Ridge, NY, son of the late John and Ellen Burke of Lands End, Sayville, NY. Mass of the Resurrection will be offered on Wednesday April 7, at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, Mendham. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn. Visitation Tuesday 79pm at Bailey Funeral Home Inc, 8 Hilltop Rd, Mendham. Memorial gifts to be made to Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 513 West Mt. Pleasant Ave, Livingston, NJ 07039

title: Urging a Freer Flow of Scientific Ideas
description: In the old, cold-war days, when university scientists gathered together, they would turn to complaining about how secrecy strictures sometimes kept them from sharing their work. They usually meant pesky national security restrictions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACK, MINNE
description: SACK-Minne. On Saturday, April 3, 1999, Minne V. Amdur. Beloved wife of the late Jack Sack, former All-American football player, University of Pittsburgh. Beloved mother of Joan Lois (Randall H.) Pakula. Beloved grandmother of Terri and Michael Pakula. For more information contact Ralph Schugar Chapel, Inc. 1-888-621-8282.
