description: MAHONEY-Agnes I. Of Tuckahoe, NY, on April 3, 1999. Sister of Catherine Mueller. Aunt of Paul. Service and interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHAN, ALFRED E. (ACKIE)
description: NATHAN-Alfred E. (Ackie). Died peacefully in Florida, April 3, 1999. Born in NYC, April 20, 1914. Loving father of Nancy, B.J., and Stacey. Brother of Richard Nathan. Grandfather of Brad, Jenevieve, Maxfield, Austin, Griffin and Liam. Great-grandfather of Grady.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the recent increase in mortgage rates misstated the minimum size of mortgages classified as large. It is $240,000, not $227,150.

title: It's New Day, But the Mets Are Stranded AT the Gate
description: The Mets spent the off season spending money and making trades to become potential post-season contenders.

title: Market Research in Classroom: Who Gains?
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I know what I did. I'm very sorry for what I did. I am ready to pay for what I did.''

title: Canadian Accounting Merger Is Dropped
description: The two accounting giants, KPMG and Arthur Andersen, called off their proposed Canadian merger yesterday after partners of KPMG Canada disagreed over whether they should leave their firm to join a rival.

title: Social Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: A Don Juan's Undoing: The Real World
description: Juan, the head of an engineering firm in ''Bitter Lemon'' (''La Piel Del Limon''), by Jaime Salom, is no Don Juan, even though in middle age he tries to find fulfillment with a woman much younger than his wife. Given what this Spanish playwright says about modern men and women through this familiar plot, he might have called it ''Don Juan Done In.'' (That would give an audience a better clue to the content than the translator's ''Bitter Lemon.'')

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLD, SIDNEY
description: GOLD, SIDNEY-April 6, 1972 27 years have passed and our memories of you dear Father still remain strong in our hearts. You are deeply loved and missed. Your children: San, Joel& Stephen

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEITZER, LORTEL, LUCILLE
description: SCHWEITZER - LORTEL - Lucille. The members of the family and friends mourn the passing of beloved Lucille on April 4. The ''Queen of Off-Broadway'' died peacefully at the age of 98, working as the great innovator of avantgarde theatre until the very last. Her dedication and perceptiveness will never be duplicated. The Lucille Lortel (NYC) and White Barn (Westport) Theatres continue in this great lady's name remaining an inspiration to theatre artists. The funeral will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 10AM on Tuesday, April 6. She is survived by the children of her brother, violonist Waldo Mayo. A public memorial will be scheduled for a later date.

title: New York's a Jungle, and One Scientist Doesn't Mind
description: At 47, Dr. Michael J. Balick, who directs research and training at the New York Botanical Garden, is among the few scientists in the world to earn a living as an ''ethnobotanist.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, RICHARD S.
description: PERRY-Richard S. Of Baldwin, NY, husband of the late Ruth Carolyn Richards, father of the late Judith Ann Perry, on Saturday, April 3, 1999. Mr. Perry was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School Class of 1937. A World War II Navy veteran, he was president of William Iselin & Co., New York, NY. He is survived by his son, Richard S. Perry, and grandsons, Petty Officer 3rd USN Christopher T. Perry and Schuyler N. Perry of Sandy Hook, Conn. Reposing at WeigandPensa Funeral Home, 2283 Grand Ave., Baldwin. Visiting hours Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Services Wednesday, 11 AM. Cremation private.

title: Multiple Sclerosis Group Is Sued by the State
description: The state has sued the Multiple Sclerosis Association of America and two former leaders, contending that telephone solicitations misled potential donors and that association money was used for travel and other personal expenses by the son of the group's founder.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The dollar rose against the Japanese currency as a survey showed business confidence in Japan improved less than expected in the first quarter. In New York, the dollar settled at 121.83 yen, up from 120.43.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, SIDNEY S.
description: BERMAN-Sidney S. Died in his sleep on April 5, 1999 at age 83, retired attorney. Husband to the late Bernice Berman. He is survived by his daughters Ellen and Jackie and his three grandchildren Stephanie, Paul, and Daniel. He is also survived by his loving companion and friend Shirley Etra, her three children Julie, Gina and Jon, and four grandchildren Diana, Max, Alex and David. A memorial gathering is scheduled for Sunday April 18, at the home of Shirley Etra beginning at 3PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROUNIS, MONICA MITTELSTADT
description: PROUNIS - Monica Mittelstadt. Age 36. On March 31, 1999. Beloved wife of Othon. Mother of Alexa. Daughter of Charles and Angelica Mittelstadt. Sister of Simone Mailman and Charles Mittelstadt, Jr. Memorial service at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 5th Avenue at 55 Street, Wednesday, 10:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Amherst College, C/O Development Office, POB 5000, Amherst, MA 01002, The Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60 Street, NY, NY 10022 or The Marrow Foundation, 400 Seventh St. N.W., Suite 206, Washington, D.C. 20004.

title: Yanks and Berra in Exchange
description: The Yankees' 1998 World Series trophy went to the Yogi Berra Museum yesterday, and Yogi Berra will go to Yankee Stadium on Friday. Berra, who has not been at the Stadium since he was fired as manager 16 games into the 1985 season, will throw out the ceremonial first ball before the Yankees' home opener against the Detroit Tigers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORTEL, LUCILLE
description: LORTEL-Lucille. On April 4, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Louis Schweitzer. Fondly acknowledged as ''The Queen of Off-Broadway'' and as one of the founders of the modern Off-Broadway theatre movement. Nurturer and benefactor to all who entered the portals of Off-Broadway in the past 50 years: playwrights, directors, actors, designers, managers and producers all enjoyed the benefits of her wisdom, friendship and support. Lucille Lortel is a towering figure in world theatre of the 20th Century who will be missed by one and all and never forgotten. The League of Off-Broadway Theatres and Producers Barry Grove, President

title: Dutch Bank to Acquire S.& L. in Philippines
description: The Dutch bank ABN Amro Holding N.V. agreed today to buy a controlling stake in the Philippine savings and loan Great Pacific Savings Bank, a unit of House of Investments Inc. No details were provided. Last year, House of Investments bought the BankAmerica Corporation's 39 percent stake in the BA Savings Bank and renamed it Great Pacific. At the end of 1998, Great Pacific had total assets of 5.484 billion pesos ($142 million) and loan assets of 4.564 billion pesos, with 25 branches in the Philippines.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the muralist Lucienne Bloch on March 28 misspelled the given name of her father. He was Ernest Bloch, not Ernst.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE DROPS. Coffee prices fell on expectations of further selling of beans by growers taking advantage of prices that reached a 2 1/2-month high last week. In New York, coffee for May delivery fell 2.75 cents, to $1.073 a pound.

title: Gadfly Weighs Selling Japan Airlines Stake
description: The biggest shareholder in Japan Airlines, Eitaro Itoyama, said yesterday that he was considering selling his 4 percent stake in the carrier, Asia's largest airline, to a unit of the Evergreen Marine Corporation of Taiwan for at least 31.5 billion yen ($259 million). Mr. Itoyama, who said the airline ''hasn't treated me decently as the largest shareholder,'' hopes to conclude talks with Evergreen by the end of next week.

title: Isn't Kosovo Just Like Tibet?
description: To the Editor:

title: Creative Director For M&C Saatchi
description: The New York office of M&C Saatchi said yesterday that Marty Cooke had joined as executive creative director less than a week after his departure from a similar post at Merkley Newman Harty in New York.

title: Youth Team Starts Fast In Nigeria
description: UNITED STATES 1, ENGLAND 0

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, IRVING
description: COOK-Irving. Beloved husband of the late Norma and long-time, devoted friend to me and my family. Rosalind Kaufman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRATH, ALBERT NICHOLSON
description: McGRATH-Albert Nicholson. On April 4th, 1999. Beloved son of the late Lillian Nicholson McGrath and John Francis McGrath, M.D. Beloved brother of Edward H., S.J., of Orissa, India, Robert W., M.D., of Georgetown, SC and the late Lillian Ryan and John F., Jr., M.D. Also survived by ten nieces and nephews and twenty grand-nieces and nephews. Founder and President of Friends of LaGuardia Place, a community organization that created a park in the Village in honor of the late Mayor of New York, Fiorello LaGuardia. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC, Tuesday, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:30 AM, St. Joseph's R.C. Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to Friends of LaGuardia Place, 532 LaGuardia Place, Box 260, NY NY 10012, would be appreciated.

title: CENTENNIAL HEALTH CARE SINKS AFTER BUYER PULLS OUT
description: Shares in the Centennial Health Care Corporation plunged as much as 88 percent yesterday after the New York investment firm Welsh, Carson Anderson & Stowe called off plans to buy the nursing home operator, citing a Medicare investigation by the Federal Government. Centennial, which is based in Atlanta, had agreed in October to be acquired by Welsh, Carson for $290.4 million in stock and debt. The transaction, in which Welsh, Carson would have paid $16 for each Centennial share, was to have closed April 15, Centennial said. Centennial shares fell $4.1875 to close at $4.3125, after trading as low as $1 after the announcement. Centennial said last week that it had received a subpoena from the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services seeking records relating to how the company calculates Medicare reimbursements.

title: A Syndrome With a Mix of Skills and Deficits
description: Adam S. was clearly a bright little boy. He began reading at age 2, and as a preschooler would lecture friendly adults -- actually, any adult who would listen -- about state capitals or Presidents or famous painters.

title: Macedonian Delays Endanger Refugees, Relief Agencies Say
description: With tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians fleeing Kosovo backed up in dismal conditions at the Macedonian border, international relief officials accused Macedonia today of endangering lives by processing the refugees too slowly.

title: No. 1 Chases The Big One That Got Away
description: On the final day of last year's Masters, David Duval appeared on the verge of victory.

title: News Reports Bolster Support for Bombings
description: The television images of refugees staggering out of Kosovo are having a powerful effect on public opinion across Europe, turning pacifists and anti-NATO activists of decades ago and NATO critics of just a week ago into supporters of sustained bombing.

title: Man Pleads Guilty In Wyoming Slaying
description: In a case that focused widespread attention on violence against homosexuals, a 21-year-old man pleaded guilty in the beating death of a gay college student and was ordered to serve two consecutive life sentences. Had he gone to trial, the man could have been sentenced to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDS, EDNA
description: RICHARDS-Edna. On April 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Mother of Stephen Richards, Eileen Corbin and John Richards. Grandmother to Stephanie, Paul, Peter, Jay, Matthew, Mica and Bill, and great grandmother to Lindsay. Service today, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, ELSIE
description: COOPER-Elsie. Beloved and devoted mother of Noel and of Susan Gittelman. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Will be missed always and forever. Services were held April 5th.

title: Ameritech to Sell Half of Wireless Business to GTE
description: In perhaps the first major telecommunications acquisition to be described as a ''step forward'' for racial diversity, the Ameritech Corporation yesterday announced a deal to sell roughly half of its wireless telephone business to a venture led by the GTE Corporation for about $3.3 billion in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLTAX, JENNIE
description: BOLTAX-Jennie. Of Los Angeles, CA, died on April 5, 1999 at 94 years old. Beloved wife of the late Joe Boltax, loving mother of Rosalyn Dronge and Albert Boltax (Deannie), loving grandmother of Michael Dronge and Samantha Boltax.

title: Riyadh Journal; Rival Princes Ease Desert City's Horizon Skyward
description: This capital stretches 40 miles from end to end, spread across the desert like a landlocked Los Angeles. It is said to be growing faster than any other city in the world, with a population doubling every nine years.

title: INTEL MAY CUT PROCESSOR PRICES AS MUCH AS 25 PERCENT
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's largest computer chip maker, is expected to cut prices on nearly all of its computer processors next week to increase demand and fend off competition, analysts said. Wholesale prices of Intel's Celeron chips, used in low-cost personal computers, are expected to be reduced as much as 25 percent, while Pentium II chips will be cut as much as 16 percent and Pentium III chips by as much as 17 percent. Intel shares rose $6.625 yesterday, to $127.50, their biggest one-day gain since January. A rival chip maker, Advanced Micro Devices Inc., which has been gaining market share at Intel's expense, said it would also cut prices on its K6-2 processors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, SYLVIA
description: LEVINE-Sylvia. Age 82, of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, formerly of Utica, NY, died April 3, 1999 in Florida. Devoted mother of Pamela & M. Barry Levy, Merrick, NY, and Donald & Linda Levine, FL; darling grandmother, great-grandmother and sister. Funeral was held Monday in Utica, NY. Period of mourning, Thursday-Wednesday at 3212 Clubhouse Road, Merrick.

title: Vital Medical Training
description: To the Editor:

A retired Government Bond Broker, his career included many years of service with Fundamental Brokers Incorporated. Family and friends may call at Hegarty Funeral Home, Old Bridge, NJ, Wednesday, April 7, 2-4 pm and 710 pm. Mass, St. Ambrose Church, Old Bridge, Thursday, April 8, 11:30 am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mission of Mercy, c/o St. Joseph's Church, Emmitsburg, MD.

title: A Less Invasive Alternative for Fibroids
description: For Kristie Wolek, the trouble started about a year ago, when her periods became so heavy that the blood loss made her severely anemic. She was exhausted all the time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARRUS, MARY
description: MARRUS-Mary. On April 1. Beloved mother of Zipporah Bodek and Naomi Rosen. Wife of the late Jacob Marrus. Devoted grandmother and great-grandmother. Treasured by all who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, GRAENUM
description: BERGER-Graenum. Helped to create the Henry Kaufmann Campgrounds Inc. 45 years ago. He nurtured our growth with his honesty, judgement and unfailing support. In doing so, he touched the lives of hundreds of thousands of day campers in the NY area. We are all honored to have known him. We extend our condolences to his entire family. The Board and Staff of the Henry Kaufmann Campgrounds Inc. Thomas J. Tisch, Chairman Walter H. Blum, Assoc. Chairman Walter L. Harris, President Jeffrey A. Coopersmith, Executive Director

title: Russia's Role in Kosovo
description: The road to peace in Kosovo may yet run through Moscow. Despite Russia's rhetorical belligerence about the NATO air campaign and Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov's failed diplomatic mission to Belgrade last week, Russia has the credentials and motivation to play a constructive role in ending the conflict. Doing so will require some straight talking by the Russians to their Serbian cousins, and a degree of cooperation with Washington that may be awkward for the Kremlin, but Russia could greatly enhance its international stature by brokering a political settlement.

title: A Relief Phone Line
description: The Agency for International Development has established a toll-free telephone number and Internet site to encourage charitable donations to private groups helping to feed and shelter the hundreds of thousands of refugees who have streamed out of Kosovo.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: By Design; In a Peasant Mood
description: Designers from Valentino to Marc Jacobs went romantic for spring, with pretty notions like the peasant blouse, the ultra feminine alternative to the ubiquitous T-shirt. Bergdorf Goodman has two sheer cotton peasant blouses by Mr. Jacobs: a cap-sleeved dot print ($365) and a three-quarter-sleeved solid in pale blue, lilac or white ($400). A cap-sleeved cotton blouse in pink or white by Theory is $135.

title: Isn't Kosovo Just Like Tibet?
description: To the Editor:

title: Visions in the Darkness, Mostly From Electrons
description: The Japanese Minimalist electronic composer Ryoji Ikeda makes stainless-steel music. It's not of the physical world; nowhere in it can one recognize a traditional instrument. His pieces are constructed out of sine waves and tiny electronic connection noises, short beeping tones and radio static, and the occasional report of an astronaut or some news commentary.

title: Immigration Boosts Our Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Countless Refugee Accounts Give Details of Mass Killings
description: Refugees pouring into Albania from Kosovo are providing detailed firsthand accounts of mass killings and burned bodies in villages where Serbs were forcing out ethnic Albanians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAN, STEPHEN
description: CHAN-Stephen, age 88, of Palm Beach, Fla., died after a threeyear battle with Parkinson's disease on Saturday, April 3, 1999. Mr. Chan was an accountant and a managing partner of Eisner and Lubin. He was a benefactor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a trustee of NYU's Institute of Fine Arts, a trustee of the Hagop Kevorkian Fund, a founder of JASA, on the board of Bronx Lebanon Hospital, a founder of Westchester Reform Temple, a member of the Palm Beach Country Club and Fenway Golf Club. He is survived by his wife, Miriam Nelson Chan; son, Robert Chan, daughter, Janet Chan of New York City, daughterin-law, Amy; son-in-law, Tyler Donaldson, and three grandchildren, Jack, Laura and Adam. His family would like to thank all his friends for their kindness and prayers. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, April 6, 2:00 PM, Temple Israel, North Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANZ, IRVING
description: GANZ-Irving. Of Yonkers, NY and Boynton Beach, FL, passed away April 4, 1999. He is survived by his children Robert (Linda), Karen Ganz (Jeff Harris), and two loving grandchildren, Jennifer Ganz (Jeff Durand) and Kevin Ganz. Donations may be made in memory of Irving Ganz to the Alzheimer's Association. Services will be held Tuesday, April 6, 10:00 AM, at Levayah-Garlick Funeral Home, 1091 Yonkers Ave., Yonkers, NY.

title: VITAL SIGNS: CALCULATIONS; 2000 Baby Race Gains Momentum
description: It is a date that has already crept into millennium folklore: Friday, April 9.

title: George to Join Vikings as Backup Passer
description: The Minnesota Vikings, who were led to the National Football Conference championship game last season by Randall Cunningham, are taking a chance on another quarterback with something to prove.

title: Sports of The Times; Doubleday Is Silent On Possible Mets Sale
description: NELSON DOUBLEDAY, the Mets' co-owner, was smiling. The Mets had not yet fallen behind the Marlins, 3-0, in the first inning of what would be a sad 6-2 loss in yesterday's season opener, and when he was asked to assess his team's future, he gushed.

title: How to Make The Familiar Look Funny
description: It was a shock when the three dancers of the Seattle-based troupe 33 Fainting Spells took their bows at the end of ''Maria the Storm Cloud'' on Saturday night at Dance Theater Workshop. True, they had just sung their way through a fairly straight rendition of the Jimmie Rogers song ''It's Over.'' But with those bows, the three became recognizably ordinary human beings.

title: Cyclist Killed by Garbage Truck on East Side
description: A 29-year-old bicyclist was killed on the Upper East Side yesterday after he collided with a van, fell to the pavement and was hit by a garbage truck, the police said.

title: RESCARE TO ACQUIRE PEOPLESERVE FOR $114 MILLION
description: Rescare Inc., which provides residential training and support services to people with mental retardation and other disabilities, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Peopleserve Inc., one of the largest closely held companies in the business, for about $114 million in stock, plus $56 million in debt. The combined company will have estimated revenue of more than $800 million and serve about 26,000 individuals with special needs, Rescare said. Rescare is based in Louisville, Ky., and Peopleserve is in Dublin, Ohio.

title: Ex-Financier Pleads Guilty in $20 Million Ponzi Scheme
description: The former chairman of a financial services company in Suffern, N.Y., has pleaded guilty to charges that he defrauded hundreds of investors of more than $20 million.

title: Japan Business Survey Uncertain on Growth
description: Japan's Deputy Finance Minister, Koji Tanami, said yesterday that the Bank of Japan's survey of business confidence was within expectations and that it is unclear whether the economy is on the way to recovery. The central bank's quarterly survey showed the first improvement in seven quarters in the expectations of major manufacturers.

title: Needed on Several Fronts, U.S. Jet Force Is Strained
description: Just a few weeks ago, senior American officials described United States fighter jet patrols over northern Iraq as critically important. But when the air war over Kosovo began, those flights were suspended in order to send combat and support planes to southern Europe.

title: William J. De Lancy, 82; Headed Republic Steel
description: William J. De Lancy, who ran the Republic Steel Corporation during some of its toughest times, died from complications of Parkinson's disease Friday at his home in Shaker Heights, Ohio, his family said.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a dispute that threatens to topple India's coalition Government misidentified the Cabinet post of George Fernandes, whose dismissal has been demanded by Jayalalitha Jayaram, leader of one party in the coalition. Mr. Fernandes is the Defense Minister, not the Defense Secretary.

title: Three New Nonfiction Prizes Awarded
description: The newly created J. Anthony Lukas Prize Project honored three nonfiction authors yesterday, with the largest award being a $45,000 grant to a freelance writer who has been struggling financially to finish a book about six World War II veterans from New Jersey.

title: Palestinians Planning to Offer Bonds on European Markets
description: The Palestinian Authority hopes to cover part of a $150 million budget deficit this year by selling the first Palestinian bonds, the authority's financial affairs chief said here today.

title: Talk About a One-Woman Show!
description: This town, a cluster of buildings at a crossroads, can be seen from miles away, where the highway bends and swoops down to a slightly lower elevation. Lonely seeming on the vast desert floor, with the mountains towering and dim in the distance, this is a place where a tree could fall and no one would hear it, if there were a tree. The temperature climbs to near 120 degrees in the summer, and the wind actually whistles when it blows, which is nearly all the time.

title: Huntington Board Suspends Head of Its Housing Authority
description: The chairman of the Huntington Housing Authority, who was indicted last week by a Federal grand jury on charges of defrauding the Government, was suspended today by the Huntington Town Board, which urged Federal officials to continue investigating the housing agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITKIN, SHIRLEY
description: WITKIN-Shirley. We are deeply saddended by the death of Shirley Witkin. As a philanthropist and a member of a noted philanthropic family, her generosity was essential in creating North Shore University Hospital's Julia and Israel Waldbaum Dialysis Center. She was also an admired member of the hospital staff. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family. Saul Katz, Chairman, Board of Trustees North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Privacy Isn't Dead Yet
description: It seems self-evident that information about your shoe size does not need to be as well guarded as information about tests ordered by your doctor. But with the Federal and state governments' piecemeal approach to privacy protection, if we release information about one facet of our lives, we inadvertently expose much about the others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVLIN, VIVIENNE K.
description: DEVLIN-Vivienne K. Most beloved mother, retired teacher, Sacred Heart Academy and Lindenhurst Schools, formerly of Babylon Village, died April 4, 1999 at home surrounded by loved ones. She is survived by her six children, Philip Fergus, Cecily Anne, Akiva Zohar, Sheila Marie, Maureen Elise, and Ellen Louise. In lieu of flowers, she has requested donations to The University of Notre Dame in memory of her beloved brother, Fergus Ford Kelly, Class of 1937, a Navy pilot killed in World War II. The family will be receiving friends and loved ones at LaGrange Inn, Thursday from 4:308:30 P.M. A Memorial Service will be held at 7:30 P.M.

title: Immigration Boosts Our Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Hutu and Tutsi Ask: Is a Unified Rwanda Possible?
description: There is a stone jail with six windows on a rocky hill in eastern Rwanda. All but four of the 221 prisoners are charged with crimes related to the genocide, the very logical madness, that broke out five years ago this week, when one group of Rwandans tried to annihilate the other.

title: Weighing Mental Patients' Treatment
description: The case of a schizophrenic man accused of pushing a woman to her death under a subway train in January has generated new interest in proposals authorizing involuntary treatment for mental patients in New York.

title: Patient Charged in a Killing After Confessing to His Therapist
description: A psychiatric patient in a Brooklyn hospital who confessed to his therapist on Sunday that he had killed a woman was arrested on murder charges after officers found the body of a woman who had been stabbed to death in her apartment, the police said yesterday.

title: Drone on the Range: Adventures in the Mild, Mild West
description: Their arms dangling limply, their distracted gazes fixed in the middle distance, the cast members of ''Cowboys and Indians'' stand a little too close to one another and converse as if emerging from altered states. ''My God, your high spirits could not be more unwelcome,'' an actor says, in a monotone as flat as the prairie.

title: After Spies, New Foes: Capitalists Gone Amok
description: It is that twilight hour when the table lamps are lighted before the draperies are drawn closed, the time before cocktails, when a late winter's afternoon surrenders meekly to nightfall. At his secluded, almost secret home in a private corner of Hampstead, John le Carre is talking about his best-selling new novel, and the hour seems to suit this discussion of treachery and transition.

title: Gay Murder Trial Ends With Guilty Plea
description: In a case that has focused national attention on violence against homosexuals, a 21-year-old roofer pleaded guilty today to kidnapping and murdering a gay college student and was sentenced to serve two consecutive life sentences.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Defining a Century In Short Stories

title: A Picture Changes 1000 Minds
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: AS PART OF SHIFT, REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES CHANGES ITS NAME
description: Republic Industries, the automobile retailer, changed its name to Autonation Inc. to emphasize its focus on selling and renting cars and trucks. Republic has used the name Autonation USA for its used-car stores. As part of the name change, effective immediately, the company, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., changed its New York Stock Exchange trading symbol to ''AN'' from ''RII.'' H. Wayne Huizenga, its chairman, joined Republic in 1995 and shifted its focus from trash hauling to auto retailing by acquiring car dealerships. Autonation, which owns National Car Rental Systems Inc., Cartemps USA and Alamo Rent-A-Car Inc., sold its alarm business in 1997 and shares in its solid-waste unit last year.

title: Lost Cookbooks of the Internet
description: AN American living in Japan was looking for a copy of the 1946 ''Woman's Home Companion Cook Book,'' which his mother cooked from when he was a child. He sent an E-mail to Around the Kitchen, an Internet cookbook store in Connecticut run by Louise Pennisi (www.aroundthekitchen.com). She found him a copy. He sent another E-mail, asking for a copy to send his sister in Illinois as a surprise, so that they could cook the same dishes. Ms. Pennisi described the ending, by E-mail: ''He later wrote, telling us he could hardly understand her through her tears when she phoned him to thank him.''

title: 5 Analysts at Cowen Are Moving to Merrill
description: Daniel Lemaitre and most of his medical technology analysts at the SG Cowen Securities Corporation are leaving the firm to join Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROUNIS, MONICA
description: PROUNIS-Monica. The Rye Country Day School, Class of 1980 expresses its deep sadness at the loss of our classmate, Monica Mittelstadt Prounis. Monica was a true class leader, an unusually bright and influential presence at our school. We will always remember her laughter and energy in the classroom, the hallways and on the playing fields. We extend our sympathies to Mr. and Mrs. Mittelstadt, Chuck, Simone, Othon, Alexa, and the rest of the Mittelstadt and Prounis families.

title: BMG and Universal Said to Form Internet Venture
description: The nation's two largest record companies, Universal Music and BMG, are expected to announce today that they have formed a joint venture to create a series of Internet sites to promote and sell music, record industry executives said yesterday.

title: People
description: * John Diefenbach was named to the new post of partner at the New York office of Wolff Olins, London. He had been chairman and chief executive of Diefenbach Elkins, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: Ruling Allows Tariffs by U.S. Over Bananas
description: The World Trade Organization handed the United States a significant but only partial victory in its long-running dispute over banana trade today, authorizing the Clinton Administration to impose roughly $191 million in sanctions against European-made goods.

title: A Balkan Quagmire We Should Avoid; Bombing as War Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESLIN, PHYLLIS STACY.
description: HESLIN-Phyllis Stacy. Beloved wife of James J. Heslin, on April 5, 1999. Services are private.

title: First-Quarter Auto Sales Said to Be Fastest Start Ever
description: When the General Motors Corporation reports its sales of cars and trucks in March on Wednesday, the first quarter of 1999 will most likely go into the books as the best start ever to a sales year for the United States auto industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERK, FRANCINE
description: BERK-Francine. I knew Fran as a sweet and friendly neighbor. My heartfelt condolences to you both, Allan and Michael. Marion Hollander

title: Marketers in Classrooms
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Officer Finds Added Cost for Civil Disobedience
description: The New York City Police Department has ordered a former Chief of Patrol, William Bracey, to turn in the gun it issued him 53 years ago. The reason: Last week, Mr. Bracey, 79, for the first time ever, got himself arrested.

title: Uncensored Student Aid
description: College financial officers who thought they were calling the United States Department of Education's Pell Grant processing office last month got an unusual recorded announcement.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Corrections
description: The Antiques column in Weekend on Friday about snake jewelry reversed the sites of two New York auctions being held this month. ''Fine and Period Jewelry'' is to be at Phillips on Sunday, not at Doyle's; and ''Important Estate Jewelry'' is to be at Doyle's on April 21, not at Phillips.

title: The Balkan Conflict; Faster Aid for the Refugees
description: President Clinton has achieved a great deal in recent days by rushing assistance to the desperate refugees from Kosovo, but much remains to be done. The United States now estimates that nearly a million of Kosovo's 1.8 million ethnic Albanians have fled their homes, and nearly half a million of them have left Kosovo. Medicine, tons of food and hundreds of tents are on the way to the region, thanks in large part to an American airlift. But the White House must continue to direct the aid effort to insure that bureaucratic inertia does not impede the flow of supplies and that the Balkan area is not destabilized by the sudden population shift.

title: TCI Music's Shares Soar on Liberty Deal
description: Shares of TCI Music Inc. more than tripled yesterday after Liberty Media Group, a cable-TV programmer, proposed swapping its Internet and interactive-TV assets for greater control of the music-video company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: College Teaching Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Sichuan and Hunan, Grand in Name and in Fact
description: EVERY once in a while, I come across a restaurant that fascinates me. Grand Sichuan International is such a place, notable not only for its terrific Sichuan and Hunan food, but also for its remarkable approach to its clientele.

title: Let Immigrants Organize for Better Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHLER, IRA J.
description: HECHLER-Ira J. The Board, Staff and 350 member theatres of the Alliance of Resident Theatres/ New York mourn the loss of our Vice Chairman, Ira J. Hechler. An enthusiastic theatre-goer and generous arts patron, Ira was deeply committed to A.R.T./New York and New York City's not-for-profit theatres. We extend our love and condolences to his wife Marilyn, sons Jon and David, and their families. His wisdom, guidance, generosity of spirit and passion for the theatre will be sorely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOROWITZ, ESTELLE
description: LOROWITZ-Estelle. On April 5. Beloved wife of the late Hy; devoted mother of Harry, Amy and Steven Schreiber and the late Michael. Cherished grandmother of Jenny, dear sister of Jack Kramer, adored aunt, and sister-in-law, loyal friend. Service Friday, 11:30AM, in ''Parkside,'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn (near Avenue V).

title: HAIN FOOD IS IN $80 MILLION DEAL FOR NATURAL NUTRITIONAL
description: Hain Food Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Natural Nutritional Group Inc. for $80 million to expand its natural- and organic-food business. Hain Food, which had 1998 sales of $104.3 million, said it would pay $70 million in cash and a five-year, $10 million convertible note. Natural Nutrition Group makes natural foods under its Health Valley, Breadshop's and Casbah brands. The purchase and other recent acquisitions will raise annual sales for Hain to about $300 million. Hain lines include Arrowhead Mills, Earth's Best and Alba Foods. Shares in Hain Food rose 15.62 cents, to $17.

title: Lindgren Shows His Stuff, but Isles Lose
description: Like most teams that are not going to the Stanley Cup playoffs, the Islanders are in training camp mode, using the final games of this season to prepare for the next season.

title: Edison Schools Say Students Gain
description: The Edison Project, whose ambitious plan to become the first national for-profit school system has attracted interest from educators and investors alike, is releasing a report today saying its students are gaining ground on state and national tests significantly faster than students in other schools.

title: Clear Shapes and Charm In Russian 'Swan Lake'
description: One never quite knows what to expect from the new Russian ballet troupes that regularly tour the United States these days. The Russian National Ballet, which performed on Sunday afternoon at the Brooklyn Center at Brooklyn College, was formed during the late 1980's in Moscow. The company's artistic director, Sergei Radchenko, and Mariya Bylova, Sunday's Odette-Odile, performed with the Bolshoi Ballet. But there were nearly as many other new Russian troupes represented as there were dancers in the roster. But there was little individuality in the generally bland performing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITKIN, SHIRLEY (NEE WALDBAUM)
description: WITKIN-Shirley (nee Waldbaum) of Clearwater FL on April 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leonard E. Witkin. Loving mother of Barbara Wood, Joan and Dennis Gross, Susan and Keith Loeb. Devoted grandmother of Lauren, Mara and Jill Sierchio, Allen, Karen and Mark Loeb and stepgrandchildren Alex and Stephanie Gross. Dear sister of Ira and Bernice Waldbaum and the late Phyllis and David Karin. Cherished aunt of many nieces and nephews. Retired Director of Medical Records at North Shore University Hospital. Funeral services were held April 6. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to a favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGDON, WILLIAM MICHAEL,
description: LANGDON-William Michael, 82, was recognized for his 40 years of exemplary service and commended for his unfailing devotion to CARE in his efforts to help the needy around the world. Died March 25, 1999. He served in the U.S. Army in the South Pacific during World War II from 1941-45. He rose in the ranks to become a 1st Lieutenant in the 163 Field Artillery. He was honored with both the Air Medal for bravery and the Bronze Star. He was a caring, compassionate man of integrity who will be forever missed by Eloise Harsnett Langdon, his surviving wife of 50 years; one son, Gregory and wife Jeanne, and his granddaughter Alexandra; and one daughter, Heidi Tracy Langdon. Sports was his lifelong interest. A memorial service will be held in the future.

title: In the Stars: All Together In Love and Coincidence
description: In ''Lovers of the Arctic Circle,'' a sweepingly beautiful film about romantic obsession, an 8-year-old schoolboy named Otto lets loose a flock of paper airplanes bearing messages. They all ask the same question.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNINGTON, WALTER G., JR.
description: DUNNINGTON-Walter G., Jr. The members of the Board of the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy mourn the loss of a dear friend and faithful supporter, Walter G. Dunnington, Jr. We are saddened by his passing and extend our deepest sympathy to his bereaved wife, Pat, our devoted board member and cherished friend, and our sincere condolences to their family. Toni Peebler, President

title: Giuliani Ally Weighs Run For Mayor and Party Switch
description: Fran Reiter, a former leader of the state Liberal Party and longtime political adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, has decided to join the Democratic Party in preparation for a possible bid for mayor of New York in 2001, Ms. Reiter's associates said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, WILLIAM J.
description: WHITE-William J., 71, of New Canaan, Conn., died Monday, April 5, after a long illness. He is survived by his wife, five children and eleven grandchildren.

title: CONSUMER-ELECTRONICS RETAILER TOPS ESTIMATES
description: The consumer-electronics retail chain Circuit City Stores Inc. said yesterday that fiscal fourth-quarter earnings rose 52 percent on demand for digital videodisk players, satellite TV dishes and wireless telephones. Circuit City, which also operates the auto retailer Carmax Group, said net income rose to $87 million, or 86 cents a diluted share, from $57.4 million, or 58 cents, in the period a year earlier. Circuit City was expected to earn 85 cents, the average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. Sales at Circuit City stores open at least a year rose 8 percent in the 1999 fiscal year. The gains offset losses from Carmax and from the start-up movie-rental technology called Digital Video Express, or Divx. Shares of Circuit City rose 6.25 cents, to $3.9375 yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYNG, LILA HOTZ.
description: TYNG-Lila Hotz. It is with deep sadness that the Board of Directors and Staff of Berkshire Farm Center and Services for Youth record the passing of Lila Tyng. She was a vital and generous member of our Board for 36 years. She put her skills, charm and love of children to work on behalf of Berkshire Farm Center, helping it to grow to a state-wide organization. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her sons and the entire family. Charles H. Mott, President

title: Giulio Einaudi, Italian Author And Publisher, Is Dead at 87
description: Giulio Einaudi, a doctor, author and founder of the Italian publishing house he built into a European wellspring of fine literature, intellectual thought and political theory, died on Monday at his country house near Rome. He was 87.

title: 2 Big French Banks Reject Takeover Offer From Rival
description: The boards of two big French banks, Societe Generale S.A. and Paribas S.A. voted today to reject Banque Nationale de Paris S.A.'s $39 billion hostile takeover bids.

title: Venice Journal; With Claws Drawn, Italians Duel Over 250 Cats
description: Rich tourists in Venice flock to the island of Giudecca, site of the Cipriani Hotel. Homeless cats take up residence on San Clemente, a lush island nearby on the lagoon. The cat shelter menu is not as varied as the hotel's, but feline guests are served fresh pasta with kidney sauce every day by doting volunteers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 13 about organized-crime defendants and the F.B.I. in Boston referred incompletely to the status of some defendants. While the authorities say two defendants, Stephen Flemmi and James Bulger, were informers for the F.B.I., there has never been any claim that the other defendants in the case, Francis Salemme and Robert DeLuca, ever served as informers.

title: Injury to Arnott Forces Devils to Juggle, but Badly
description: A recurring hip injury to Jason Arnott forced the Devils to break up their most productive line tonight against the Carolina Hurricanes and the loss of Arnott showed in the scoring sheet. The Devils suffered a 4-2 loss, ending their eight-game undefeated streak, and will now have to wait another game or two before they clinch their third straight Atlantic Division title.

title: Let Immigrants Organize for Better Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOYKO, JEFFREY
description: BOYKO-Jeffrey. Memories of you are always with us. Ellen and Gordon

title: Russian Tycoon (and Yeltsin Adversary) Is Charged With Fraud
description: Russia's chief prosecutor issued an arrest warrant today for Boris Berezovsky, the tycoon and political mover who has taken a sensational tumble from the graces of Russian high finance and of President Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: Many Fear Where They're Going, as Well as Where They've Been
description: The Macedonian Government sent more refugees from Kosovo abroad today, some of them against their will, and the stories of families being broken up in the crush and refugees being sent to unknown destinations bred more fear in the camps here.

title: Contractors Are Accused In a Nuclear Cleanup Case
description: Two Federal contractors used a computerized accounting scheme to overbill the Energy Department by at least $85 million for cleanup work at the Hanford nuclear reservation over the last 12 years, a former budget analyst for the contractors asserted in a lawsuit filed today in Federal District Court in Spokane, Wash.

title: Ambroise Roux, 77, Pompidou Adviser and French Management 'Godfather'
description: Ambroise Roux, a prominent and influential figure in the French industrial and financial worlds who was a key adviser to Georges Pompidou, France's President from 1969 to 1974, died on Sunday in his home in Montfort-l'Amaury in north central France. He was 77.

title: A Balkan Quagmire We Should Avoid; Greater China Stake
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAWAMURA, SHIGEKUNI
description: KAWAMURA - Shigekuni. The New York University community mourns the loss of Shigekuni Kawamura, an esteemed alumnus, trustee and friend. Over many years and across many miles, he supported this University and advanced its goals, helped in making NYU a global institution, and furthered the interests of education and the arts. He will be greatly missed. L. Jay Oliva President Martin Lipton Chairman

title: Small Serbian Town Is Stricken By a Deadly 'Accident of War'
description: At about 10 P.M. on Monday, Stana Stojanovic, a 62-year-old pensioner, was watching ''Esmeralda,'' her favorite soap opera, when she heard the airplanes flying low over this little coal-mining town.

title: THEGLOBE.COM IN $43 MILLION DEAL FOR ATTITUDE NETWORK
description: Theglobe.com Inc., a company that lets Internet users set up home pages, said yesterday that it would acquire the game-related Web publisher Attitude Network for about $43.1 million in stock. Theglobe.com will also assume $5.1 million in debt. Theglobe.com, based in New York, now has 9.3 million registered users and said it would gain an additional 2.3 million in the acquisition, most of them in the demographic group that advertisers covet -- 18- to 44-year-olds. Attitude Network publishes sites for computer game enthusiasts. Theglobe.com, derives most of its revenue from advertising and subscriptions.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Media Talk column of Business Day on March 22 about journalists' efforts to interview Sante and Kenneth Kimes, a mother and son accused of killing a missing Upper East Side millionaire, referred incorrectly to the payment of air fare and hotel expenses for the Kimeses' defense lawyer, Mel A. Sachs, and a colleague on a trip to Grand Cayman. They were not paid by the news program ''Fox Files.''

title: Dow and S.& P. Retreat, but Nasdaq Edges a Bit Higher
description: Stocks fell from record levels as Gillette led consumer companies lower after the world's largest maker of razors said its earnings would not meet expectations because of slow Latin American sales.

title: Banana Journalism
description: In a Cincinnati courtroom this week, Mike Gallagher, a former investigative reporter for The Cincinnati Enquirer, acknowledged that protecting the confidentiality of a source was ''one of the highest responsibilities a journalist has.'' Then he proceeded to reveal to the court the name of one of his major sources. As a former colleague of Mr. Gallagher said after witnessing the breaking of one of journalism's most hallowed and least flexible rules, ''Gallagher sold out everybody.''

title: A Balkan Quagmire We Should Avoid; Next, Vojvodina?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWABE, INA (REGINA) L. KAHN.
description: SCHWABE-Ina (Regina) L. Kahn. Died peacefully April 5, 1999, after a long illness. Widow of Erwin S. Schwabe. Stepmother of the late Robert Schwabe. Mourned by her sister Helen D.K. Lessing, her nieces Joan C. Lessing and Pamela R.L. Friedman, her grandniece Elizabeth Lessing Friedman and her grandnephew Paul Lessing Friedman. Her memory will live on among the many friends she cultivated during a lifetime of almost eighty years during which she was involved in a wide variety of interests.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Jury Anonymity Is Seen as Pivotal Factor in Gotti Plea Talks
description: For months, Government prosecutors and lawyers for John A. Gotti had haggled over whether the accused Mafia figure would plead guilty in his racketeering and extortion case. And every time he seemed on the verge of agreeing to such a deal, the talks would collapse, and his lawyers would defiantly declare that the Government's case was weak and that they were heading to trial.

title: Underground, Creative Rap Is Thriving
description: SIX young men sat around a table nodding their heads and tapping their hands in time to the thumping beat flowing from a boom box. One of them, a dreadlocked Harlem poet who calls himself Vast -- as much for his intelligence as his girth -- stood up and began rhyming to the music. But quicker than anyone could say ''One-two, you don't stop,'' the tape ended, abruptly filling the room with an unexpected silence.

title: Judge Upholds Ban On Assault Weapons
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a challenge to the state's ban on assault weapons, ruling that supplemental guidelines issued by the state's Attorney General adequately clarify which guns fall under the law, officials said yesterday.

title: Finding a Treasure In a Sea of Red
description: YEARS ago in this country, long before Beaujolais was the wine of choice among first-time drinkers, Valpolicella, a red Italian wine that can be equally light, fruity and fragrant, was enormously popular -- and just as importantly, affordable. A staple in neighborhood Italian restaurants, it was frequently the wine that inspired people to make their first foray into the wine aisle of a liquor store or into one of the few wine shops that existed then.

title: 2 Libyans Formally Charged In 1988 Pan Am Bombing
description: In a short session that the United States and Britain had awaited for more than a decade, the Scottish police formally charged two former Libyan intelligence agents today with the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland in 1988.

title: A Balkan Quagmire We Should Avoid
description: To the Editor:

title: With Aid Effort Overwhelmed, NATO Will Take Over Coordination
description: NATO announced today that it was coordinating all transportation of food, relief supplies and medical care to the Kosovo refugees, as well as airlifting them to temporary camps, after two days of relief efforts by individual member countries.

title: Steak, Twice on the Fire
description: COOKING a steak simply, and to perfection, is easy -- as long as you have a grill. Cooking a steak in the broiler or oven usually means sacrificing a good crust, and using the stovetop can set off the smoke detector.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 29 about competition in the kosher food business referred incompletely to the ownership of the Glatt Mart, a store in Brooklyn. Jerry Schockett is a co-owner, with Mendy Bauman.

title: Learning Is Good, But Glory's Even Better
description: The earth trembling beneath his feet, the old scholar is facing a daunting challenge: publish and perish.

title: The Balkan Conflict; A Phony Cease-Fire Offer
description: Keeping NATO's 19 members united in their determination to confront Slobodan Milosevic has been a difficult challenge for President Clinton, and it got harder yesterday. Belgrade's declaration of an Orthodox Easter cease-fire in Kosovo, coupled with an errant NATO bombing raid on the Serbian town of Aleksinac, were just the kinds of developments that can start to unravel a coalition of disparate nations. NATO properly rejected the cease-fire, which came with no long-term peace proposal, but the offer may be the first sign that Mr. Milosevic is looking for a way out of the conflict.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Banking System and the Sword; A Regulator Sets His Agenda For Japan's Financial Giants
description: As a samurai, Hakuo Yanagisawa would have never bothered to sheathe his sword. He spends his time feinting and darting and backing his adversary -- Japan's banking system -- against the wall. The establishment seems ready to yield.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PLATINUM FALLS. Platinum fell on expectations that supplies from South Africa would keep users well stocked as delays in Russian exports drag on. In New York, platinum for July delivery fell $5.90, to $356.20 an ounce.

title: Dining in Koreatown and Its Outposts
description: WEST 32d Street, the heart of Koreatown, is lined with restaurants that advertise ''BBQ'' and ''Open 24 Hours'' in bright neon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENENDEZ, DOLORES
description: MENENDEZ-Dolores. April 6, 1999. Loving mother of Alvaro, Antonio, Manuel, Teresa, Dolores Vilgertshofer, and Victoria Moskowitz. Cherished grandmother. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday, April 8, 2-4 and 6-8 PM. Funeral private.

title: Business Travel; Airlines and travel agencies woo small businesses with perks usually reserved for bigger customers.
description: TRADITIONALLY not beneficiaries of special discounts and other travel privileges like large corporations, smaller businesses are now being wooed with such perks by travel agencies and airlines.

title: REUTERS TO BE MAIN FINANCIAL NEWS PROVIDER FOR E*TRADE
description: Reuters Group P.L.C., the world's largest provider of financial information, signed an agreement to be the main provider of financial news and data to E*Trade Group Inc.'s Web sites. Customers of E*Trade, the on-line brokerage firm based in Palo Alto, Calif., will receive news and market data from Reuters Investor, a service of that London-based Reuters. Financial terms of the agreement, which spans several years, were not disclosed. The Reuters American depository receipts, which equal six Reuters shares, rose $1.8125, to $90.6875. Shares of E*Trade rose $3.375, to $76.

title: Yankees Average $3 Million a Man
description: From the team that last year won more games in the regular season and post-season than any team before it comes another first: the first team average salary to hit $3 million.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today for the seventh day of Passover, tomorrow for the eighth day of Passover and for Orthodox Holy Thursday and Friday for Orthodox Good Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMHI, CLAIRE
description: KAMHI-Claire. The officers, directors and shareholders of Dune Alpin Farm mourn the passing of their fellow neighbor and shareholder, Claire Kamhi, on April 1, 1999.

title: Clemens Brims With Excitement
description: The Yankees knew only one half of Roger Clemens's pitching personality before he took the mound for the season opener Monday night. They had seen him only as an adversary, someone who glared at them and often made them look foolish at the plate and occasionally bounced fastballs off their ribs.

title: A Local Favorite, Aspiring to Be More
description: THE casually dressed couple seated next to us at Celadon, a new restaurant on the Upper East Side, oohed and aahed over each course. Then they were gone. Another couple, in jeans and khakis, took their place, and before we got to dessert, they were finished and out the door. Next came two serious chaps with briefcases, obviously direct from work. They took a table, had a quick dinner, and then were gone, too.

title: Mary Ainsworth, 85, Theorist On Mother-Infant Attachment
description: Dr. Mary D. Ainsworth, a developmental psychologist whose work revolutionized the understanding of the bond between mothers and infants, died in Charlottesville, Va., on March 21. She was 85.

title: THE CHEF
description: I LOVE the complex taste of rhubarb. Its mix of sweet and sour reminds me of the harshness and warmth of spring itself. Using it in a cobbler seems perfect; it's like a hint of the brilliance of the coming season cloaked in a wintery sort of dessert.

title: NATO Decides It Will Keep Bombing, Rejecting Milosevic's Unilateral Holiday Truce
description: NATO resolved tonight that it would keep bombing Yugoslavia until President Slobodan Milosevic agrees to withdraw all his attacking forces from Kosovo, to let refugees return with an international military force to protect them, and to negotiate a political settlement, Western diplomats said.

title: U.S. Takes Step Toward Tobacco Suit
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it had hired a law firm that represented Minnesota in its lawsuit against cigarette makers to consult with Government officials as they considered legal action of their own against the tobacco industry.

title: A Balkan Quagmire We Should Avoid; Military Quick Fix
description: To the Editor:

title: Korean Food: Just Waiting to Be Discovered
description: IN a city that emphatically embraces Thai, Japanese and Indian food, as well as Chinese dishes from a dizzying number of regions, there is still one major Asian cuisine so unknown to many New Yorkers that it's as if it were meant to be a secret.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOGATY, DR. NINA.
description: BOGATY-Dr. Nina. February 16, 1955 to April 7, 1997. Darling, you live ever in our hearts and souls. Your Loving Family

title: Sports of The Times; The Lessons Of Family And Team
description: IN the sunshine on an otherwise funereal morning, Donnie Walsh recalled the first time he met Harry Jackson, and the lasting impression the father of the point guard had made.

title: Michael Manuel, Director, 70; Worked at Met
description: Michael Manuel, a director and writer who worked for a decade at the Metropolitan Opera, first as the company's executive stage manager and then as the co-general director of the Met's national touring company, died on Monday at the Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, N.J. He was 70 and lived in New Hope, Pa.

title: SUNSTONE HOTEL SHARES UP ON $376 MILLION TAKEOVER BID
description: Shares of Sunstone Hotel Investors Inc., a real estate investment trust, rose yesterday after a group of investors including top Sunstone management offered to acquire the hotel owner for as much as $376 million. Shares of Sunstone, which operates Marriott, Holiday Inn and Hilton hotels in the Western United States, rose $1.4375, to $9. SHP Acquisition L.L.C., formed by Sunstone's chief executive, Robert A. Alter, and other key executives, said it had offered to pay $9.50 to $10 a share for Sunstone, which owns 56 hotels. It became a target after its shares fell more than 66 percent in the last 12 months.

title: Magic Guard Getting Notice
description: When Darrell Armstrong entered the Orlando Magic's locker room following last night's game, about 10 minutes behind his teammates after he made the round of television and radio spots, the first question was about his sluggish start. Before he could answer, Anfernee Hardaway interrupted: ''You've got expectations now. They're going to be on you to do it every night.''

title: Computer Work Is Halted At Nuclear Weapon Labs
description: The Energy Department said today that it had suspended all scientific work on the computers containing America's most sensitive secrets at its three nuclear weapons laboratories over fears that security lapses make the computers vulnerable to espionage.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a letter published yesterday on teen-age smoking misstated the population of New York. New York has about three million more residents than Florida. The letter also rendered a sentence incorrectly. It should have said that New York spent less than one-tenth as much as Florida to reduce smoking.

title: Agencies That Help The Kosovo Refugees
description: These are some organizations with workers on the ground helping Kosovo refugees. Updates on their activities are at http://www.interaction.org/kosovo/detail.html:

title: Dueling Goals for Education
description: These days you can't run for public office, whether the city council or the United States Senate, without having an education plan. This phenomenon, especially noticeable in last fall's elections, has been evident in two recurring themes nationwide: the push to raise standards for teachers and the call to reduce class sizes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, JOSEPH
description: HOFFMAN-Joseph. Passed away April 4, 1999 in Hollywood, FL at the age of 96. Formerly of Great Neck, N.Y. He leaves his devoted wife of 64 years Ruth, son Richard of Hallandale, FL. and daughter Frances Swirsky. Papa Joe to Peter and Douglas Genzer and great granddaughter Rachel. He will be remembered as a loving, kind and gentle soul. Contributions may be made to The Boys' Club of N.Y. and Joe DiMaggio Children's Hospital-Memorial East, Hollywood, FL. We will love you forever.

title: Reed Is Top Expansion Pick
description: The Women's National Basketball Association held its expansion draft yesterday, adding four players to the rosters of the league's two new teams, the Minnesota Lynx and Orlando Miracle.

title: Police Question Man Suspected In 45 Rapes
description: A man suspected of being the serial rapist who has attacked 45 women in the Bronx, upper Manhattan and Westchester County since 1993 was being questioned by detectives in the Bronx last night, investigators said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDNOR, LUCILLE O.
description: REDNOR-Lucille O. On April 5, 1999. Widow of Dr. Daniel J. Rednor. Beloved mother of Linda Rosner, Barbara Ciongoli and Jon Miller. Cherished grandmother of Adam, Gary, Happy, Jamie, Greg, Alessandra, Kenny, Jordan and Joshua. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday 5:30-8PM with service Thursday, 10AM. Interment to follow at Beth Olam Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HATFIELD, HURD
description: HATFIELD-Hurd. Memorial April 12, Community Church 40 E 35 St 3PM. In lieu of flowers contributions New Church 112 E 35 St 10016

title: Entirely Preserved Inca Mummies Found
description: After climbing to the 22,000-foot summit of a volcano in northern Argentina, archeologists have found three frozen Inca mummies, 500-year-old remains of a ritual sacrifice, which are so well preserved that blood is still present in the heart and lungs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Malone's Liberty Acquires Stake in News Corporation

title: PARENTS IN PRISON: A special report.; As Inmate Population Grows, So Does a Focus on Children
description: Baba Eng had been a prisoner at Sing Sing for 22 years, serving a life sentence for murder, when a new inmate walked into the shower room one day and stared at his face.

title: Favorite's Role Goes To Duval, This Time
description: At Tiger Woods's news conference today, the first question referred to David Duval.

title: Genetic Damage in Young Smokers Is Linked to Lung Cancer
description: Smoking during childhood or adolescence may lead to lasting or even permanent genetic damage in the lungs that increases the risk of lung cancer, even after the smoker quits, researchers are reporting today.

title: U.S. Reviews '97 Killing By Officer In Diallo Case
description: A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that his office had been monitoring a case in which one of the police officers who killed Amadou Diallo fatally shot another man in 1997 and would decide whether a Federal inquiry into the earlier shooting was necessary.

title: INSIDE
description: China's Premier Arrives

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENTON, ERWIN S.
description: KENTON-Erwin S. On Sunday, April 4th, of Silver Spring, MD. Father of Donna, Gary, Ann, Jeffrey and Stacey. Grandfather of five. Interment at Sharon Gardens, Val Halla, NY, Friday, April 9, at 1pm. Shiva April 10 & 11 at 7PM in the home of Ann & Allen Perper, Silver Spring, MD. Memorial contributions to So Others Might Eat, 71 O St NW Washington DC 20001.

title: As Governors Spar, Shippers Weigh Leaving
description: After months of negotiations with two of the largest shipping lines in New York Harbor, the Port Authority has been paralyzed by squabbles between the Republican Governors of New York and New Jersey that have prevented it from making final lease offers to the two lines, to keep them from moving their operations to Baltimore.

title: Calendar
description: Museum Show at Brewery

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HANLEY, CHARLES J.
description: HANLEY-Charles J. April 7, 1977. Dad, we all have wonderful memories of a great father and a true gentleman. The Children

title: Compassion From the Middle East For Strangers in a Strange Land
description: With tears in his eyes, Avi Pazner, 60, who was the first Israeli Ambassador to Albania, surveyed the tent city of Kosovo refugees that rings an empty swimming pool in the heart of this city. Dropping to his knees, he extended a plump green apple to a miserable little boy who hugged the cane of his elderly grandfather.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, THELMA
description: GOLDMAN-Thelma on April 5, 1999. Beloved sister of Frances Goldman, the late Birdye Grund and the late Arnold Goldman. Dear aunt of Rena, Fred, and Lee Berman, Pamela, Richard, Jessica and Bradley Weltman. Graveside service Friday 12:30pm at New Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ.

title: Knicks Scratching Heads Over a Collapse at Home
description: It was just like Coach Jeff Van Gundy. He jammed his hands deep into his pockets and clenched his jaw until his lip pouted out as he turned and walked away from the court. It was an all too familiar scene when Patrick Ewing rubbed his eyes, sighed deeply and stared into a vacant space long after the questions ended.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When children are not in contact with their parents, it is a breeding ground for idealization, and when the parent is a big-time criminal, they can turn them into legends.''

title: Tie Rack of Britain Accepts Italian Offer
description: The British clothing designer and retailer Tie Rack P.L.C. said yesterday that it had accepted a takeover bid of 43.5 pence a share in cash from Frangi S.p.A., an Italian maker of silk ties and scarves, valuing Tie Rack at $:22.6 million ($35.9 million). Frangi said it had agreed to acquire or had commitments regarding stock representing 45.6 percent of the equity of Tie Rack, which operates 426 shops in 30 nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, ELEANOR
description: SUSSMAN-Eleanor. The light has gone out of our lives. Our beloved Ellie has lost her valiant fight with cancer leaving her devoted husband Morton, adoring children, Michael (Lee), Daniel, Yaakov (Shira), loving sister of Charlotte (Herb) Davidson, & grandchildren. She brought the love of music to a generation of East Rockaway students and to friends and admirers throughout the country. Services at ''Boulevard-Park West,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI at 12:30 P.M. on Friday, April 9, 1999.

title: A Viola Soloist (a Rarity), And a Bernsteinian Pianist
description: Not many violists have been able to sustain a solo career. The instrument has never been able to shake its perception as a bridge between the bright-toned, assured violin and the deeper, plaintive cello, both of which, unlike the viola, have extensive solo repertories.

title: Hernandez Leads Yankees to No. 1 On Road to Repeat
description: David Cone has a respectable reputation as a prognosticator. Before last year's playoffs, he thought that Scott Brosius would star, that he had ''a glint in his eye.'' Brosius was named the most valuable player of the World Series.

title: After Flood of Donations, 15 More Students Are Awarded Times Scholarships
description: In the month since The New York Times published an article about six New York City high school students who won Times scholarships for high achievement in the face of overwhelming obstacles, private donors have contributed more than $150,000 -- enough to send 15 more scholarship finalists to college.

title: A Proud Immigrant Family and a Closeted Gay Son
description: ''Head On,'' an overheated domestic drama about the frustrations of a closeted gay Greek-Australian who lives with his straitlaced immigrant family, strains so desperately for a tragic kitchen-sink realism that in several crucial scenes the movie loses its grip and escalates into strident melodrama.

title: 2 British Cable Concerns Consider Asset Swaps
description: Cable and Wireless Communications P.L.C. and Telewest Communications P.L.C., Britain's two largest cable television companies, said yesterday that they were discussing ''corporate options'' that might include transferring various businesses. Cable and Wireless P.L.C., the controlling shareholder of Cable and Wireless Communications, is considering selling the unit's cable TV network to Telewest in return for shares in Telewest, people close to the planning said yesterday. The two companies gave no details about their talks in their statement yesterday.

title: Clinton Seeking Moscow's Help In Kosovo Crisis
description: The Clinton Administration has approached Moscow to serve as a go-between with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia in a new attempt to find a diplomatic solution to the conflict in Kosovo.

title: Are Hate-Crime Laws Necessary?
description: The attack on Matthew Shepard, a gay student, was senseless and appalling, but the usefulness of more hate-crime legislation is questionable (editorial, April 6).

title: Accounts
description: * Fabian Couture Group International, Lyndhurst, N.J., to Transfusion L.L.C., New York, to handle the account of the maker of tuxedos and accessories, which had been at Domsky & Simon, Philadelphia. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: Maker of IV System to Stop Using a Plastic
description: Baxter International, one of the largest manufacturers of intravenous health care products, said yesterday that it had agreed to develop and introduce intravenous systems that do not use polyvinyl chloride plastic tubes and bags.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Australian Cheeses Make Inroads in New York

title: Melissa Virus Defendant to Plead Not Guilty
description: David L. Smith, the Aberdeen, N.J., man accused of disrupting computers around the world with the Melissa virus, will plead not guilty at his first court appearance, scheduled for Thursday, his lawyer said today.

title: S.E.C. Web Site Now Offers Mutual Fund Fees Calculator
description: Front-end loads. Deferred sales charges. Annual operating expense ratios.

title: Reforms Punish Poor, Veteran Socialist Says
description: Welfare's sudden death has stunned many residents of the central city here, but few have expressed more dismay than an elderly gentleman on a poverty-pocked block who has been monitoring the neighborhood's civic affairs since the Great Depression.

title: Citing 'Primitive' Hatreds, Clinton Asks Congress to Expand Hate-Crime Law
description: Citing the dangers of ''primitive'' hatreds from Kosovo to the Old South, President Clinton today urged Congress to expand the definition of Federal hate crimes to include incidents based on a person's sexual orientation, sex or disability. The current law covers crimes based on race, color, religion or national origin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGAN, JULIA (BURGEVIN).
description: EGAN-Julia (Burgevin). Of Kingston, New York, and Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Burgevin of Kingston. At Ponte Vedra Beach, on April 3rd. Member of the DAR, Colonial Dames of America, Church Club, Daughters of the Cincinnati, New York Junior League. Surviving are her daughter, Roxandra Antoniadia, New York City; her grandchildren, Gabrielle, Poughkeepsie, NY, and Theodore, New York City; her sister, Frances Livaudais, Boca Raton, FL; and her brother Edwin, Poughkeepsie, NY. Memorial Mass April 23, 11:00 A.M., at Resurrection Episcopal Church, 115 East 74 St., New York City. Interment April 25, 1:30 PM at Wiltwyck Cemetery, Kingston.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; John Malone has moved the Liberty Media Group into a big stake in the News Corporation.
description: EVERY time John Malone gets part of a company, the price seem to rise.

title: Finding Their Lives in the Ashes; For Many Displaced by Fire, Little Is Left but Problems
description: First the co-op board said two months. Then four. Now they are saying six to eight -- at least. But the people displaced from their homes on the Upper West Side are grimly preparing for a year's absence.

title: Truth in Bottling
description: Some people drink bottled water because they think it tastes better, others because they think it confers special status. But most people drink it because they believe it is safer than tap water. Is it? A new study by the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental advocacy group, says that some bottled water contains contaminants and chemicals and that ''blanket reassurances from the industry that bottled water is totally safe and pure are false.'' The group recommends tighter Federal oversight as well as a higher standard of truth in advertising. It makes a compelling case.

title: Honors
description: * Howard Draft, chairman and chief executive at Draft Worldwide, Chicago, part of Interpublic, was named the Charles S. Downs Direct Marketer of the Year for 1999 by the Chicago Association of Direct Marketing.

title: Deal With Nets Is a Bonus For the Yankee Partners
description: George Steinbrenner and his limited partners in the Yankees' ownership would receive $225 million in a deal with the owners of the Nets that is still being negotiated, two business executives said yesterday.

title: Classics Joining TNT's Movies
description: Looking to raise the prestige ante in a continuing challenge to HBO for supremacy in made-for-cable television movies, TNT, the main entertainment channel of the Turner Broadcasting empire, announced a schedule of movies for the next television season that is conspicuously heavy on the literary classics.

title: In the Balkans, No Wars Are 'Local'
description: The humanitarian nightmare in Kosovo may be reason enough for NATO's involvement in the former Yugoslavia, but for the United States there are vital strategic stakes involved as well. These stakes justify the use of any NATO measures needed to defeat Serbia, including the use of ground troops, because nothing less than the future contours of Europe are now being decided.

title: Keating Pleads Guilty to 4 Counts of Fraud
description: Charles H. Keating Jr., the banker who came to symbolize the widespread failures in the savings and loan industry of the 1980's, pleaded guilty today to four counts of fraud and admitted taking almost $1 million from a company that was financially insolvent.

title: One Family Exits Mexican TV Empire
description: In a momentous but amicable parting of ways by two of Mexico's most powerful business dynasties, the Aleman family announced today that it was selling its 14 percent stake in the holding company that controls Grupo Televisa S.A., the largest broadcast network in Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHR, AUGUSTE
description: MOHR-Auguste. In San Francisco, California, April 5, age 90. Beloved wife of the late Ernest Mohr. Executive Director of Temple Anshe Sholom of Kew Gardens. Loving mother of Ruth and Cy Tukeman & Bill and Harriet Mohr. Devoted grandmother of Mark and Sally Tukeman, Erica Tukeman and Tara Mohr. Great-grandmother of Sammy and Gabi Tukeman. Dear sister of Hilde Thal and the late Elsbeth Weilheimer and of Harry Weilheimer. Dear aunt and cousin. Auguste was a life member of Hadassah. Contributions to Hadassah and Blue Card.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: A Protein-Rich Fruit

title: Russia Starting Key Talks With I.M.F.
description: The International Monetary Fund and the Russian Government will begin a critical round of negotiations later today that is aimed at completing an economic program and loan package to avert a threatened default on Russia's foreign debt.

title: New Chief Is Named at Xerox, Amid Altered Copier Landscape
description: As expected, the Xerox Corporation named G. Richard Thoman, 54, as its chief executive yesterday. He replaces Paul A. Allaire, 60, who remains as chairman.

title: Milstein to Find Out Whether He Is the Redskins' New Owner
description: Howard Milstein will learn today in Atlanta if the changes he has made to his financing plan have swayed enough doubters to allow him to be voted in as the principal owner of the Washington Redskins.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO GAINS. The dollar fell against Europe's single currency after the Serbian authorities declared a unilateral cease-fire in Yugoslavia. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0848, up from $1.0708.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKETT, JOHN E.
description: HACKETT-John E. Suddenly, on Friday, April 2nd, 1999. John E. Hackett, beloved husband of Colette Lavoie. Born on May 15, 1943, Mr. Hackett was the son of Marielle Teryazos nee Gohier and of the late Guy Hackett. He was the father of Sophie, Guy and Alexandre whose mother is Lalage Hackett nee Wright. He is also mourned by his brother Robert (Susana Abreu) whose daughter is Nadia Hackett. Mr. Hackett is resting at the Desourdy Wilson Funeral Home, 4 Vale Perkins, Mansonville, Quebec, J0E 1X0, 450-263-1212, fax 450-263-9557. Visitation will be held on Friday, April 9, 1999 from 7-10 PM. Funeral service will be held on Saturday, April 10, 1999 at 2 PM from St. Cajetan Catholic Church in Mansonville followed by the interment at St. Cajetan Catholic Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory can be made to the Heart and Stroke Foundation of Sherbrooke, 2630 King Ouest, Sherbrooke, Quebec, J1J 2H1 or to the University Geriatric Institute Foundation of Sherbrooke, 1036 Belvedere South, Sherbrooke, Quebec, QC J1H 4C4 would be gratefully appreciated by the family. Please take note: Saturday, the day of the funeral, the Funeral Home will be opening at noon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLY, GEORGE
description: MULLY-George, suddenly and unexpectedly at home on Easter Monday, at the age of 73, much loved husband of Ann Mully. Loving stepfather of Max Born (Sue Saunders), Sebastian Born (Sue Thompson) and Georgina Born (Andrew Barry). Grandfather of Kip, Lily, Rosie, Theo and Clara. He will be greatly missed by all of his family, friends and co-workers. ''He was a man, take him for all in all, we shall not look upon his like again.'' Friends may visit at the Central Chapel of Hulse, Playfair & McGarry, 315 McLeod Street, on Thursday, April 8, from 7-9 PM, and Friday, April 9, from 2-4 PM. Reception to follow at the Hulse, Playfair & McGarry Resource and Reception Center, 328 McLeod Street. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Canadian Cooperative Association would be appreciated by the family.

title: At Tip Time, Restaurants Do the Math
