description: RESTAURANTS aren't sure that customers get the idea behind tips. Diners seem to have this notion that they're voluntary, a show of appreciation, something that's done only because they feel like doing it.

title: The Judas Function and Other Mockeries
description: The Residents, lest you forgot during the nine years since their last tour and never saw the elaborate CD-ROM projects they have devoted their energy to during this decade, are the 26-year-old band whose members' identities have never been divulged. They appear in photographs and performances with giant, veiny eyeballs on their heads, crowned with top hats.

title: For a Night, Mets Get What They Paid For
description: So this was why the Mets opened their checkbooks during the off season.

title: Allies Seek, Serbs Hide
description: When the skies cleared over the Balkans on Monday, it seemed to be a promising day for NATO's high-tech warplanes to attack Yugoslav tanks in Kosovo. But few, if any, heavy weapons were hit that day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, HELEN R.
description: CAREY-Helen R. Of West Orange, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, on Monday, April 5, 1999. Funeral from Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Road, Westwood, NJ on Thursday at 9AM. Funeral liturgy at St. John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church, Hillsdale, NJ at 10AM. Entombment, Garden of Memories, Township of Washington, NJ. The family will receive their friends on Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: Teachers Union Leader Is Elected to Full Term
description: Members of the United Federation of Teachers, the nation's largest local teachers union and an important political force, yesterday elected Randi Weingarten to a full two-year term as president.

title: Center-Poor Nets Will Consider Signing an Ailing 7-7 Muresan
description: The Nets are one of a small band of teams showing interest in Gheorghe Muresan, the tallest man to play in the National Basketball Association, and are considering signing him to a 10-day contract within the next week, according to an official in the Eastern Conference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPHS, GEORGE
description: JOSEPHS-George. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of a most cherished member of its extended family. George's love of his fellow man, the Jewish people and the state of Israel was both legendary and exemplary. Together with his beloved Miriam, his soul mate in life and partner in Tzedakah, he worked tirelessly to improve the quality of life for others. George first visited Boys Town almost three decades ago, and inspired by the school's mission of turning young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures, he founded the Bergen County Friends of Boys Town. George's caring, warmth, friendship, humor and unparalleled dedication to so many noble causes will endure as a lasting tribute. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec V.P.

title: Funeral for Jesse Stone
description: The funeral for the songwriter and arranger Jesse Stone, who wrote ''Shake, Rattle and Roll,'' is scheduled for today at 2:30 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Citicorp Center at Lexington Avenue and 54th Street in Manhattan. Among those scheduled to appear are the Harlem Blues and Jazz Band and Ahmet Ertegun of Atlantic Records. Mr. Stone died on April 1 at 97.

title: The Gypsies Of 6 Nations Slap, Flash And Dazzle
description: The Roma people, more commonly known as Gypsies, have always been great entertainers. ''Gypsy Caravan,'' a splendid program featuring six distinct groups of musicians and dancers from India, Russia, Romania, Bulgaria, Hungary and Spain, pays tribute to the Roma as concert artists of wide range and supreme virtuosity.

title: State Seeks Rangel's Ouster at Apollo
description: After months of attacks on the foundation that runs the state-owned Apollo Theater, Pataki administration officials said yesterday that they were seeking a resolution of the conflict in which United States Representative Charles B. Rangel would step down as chairman of the foundation and Time Warner Inc. would play a major role in revitalizing the Harlem landmark.

title: A Matter of Merit
description: Colleges that award merit scholarships are highly sought after, but colleges that award Merit Scholarships may receive a letter from a lawyer from the National Merit Scholarship Corporation.

title: Cue Cards Offered To Remind Officers Of Good Manners
description: They have been praised as brave and effective, or condemned as belligerent and brutal. But no one has ever portrayed New York's police officers as urban Andy Griffiths, ''aw shucks''-ing and ''Mornin' Ma'am''-ing their way through the mean streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORTEL, LUCILLE
description: LORTEL-Lucille. Lucille's reception in heaven must be deafening. We join the applause. Outer Critics Circle Marjorie Gunner, President

title: Mexican Officials Issue Arrest Warrant for Governor in Hiding
description: Mexican authorities today issued an arrest warrant for the maverick Governor of a Caribbean state that became a cocaine smuggling center during his six-year tenure, which ended on Monday.

title: Nets Think Big and Keep On Rolling
description: The Nets are rolling like a boulder down a steep hill now and their momentum is such that nobody, in their minds, can stop them. With 4-0 written in big, blue letters on the chalkboard of the visitors' locker room at the MCI Center tonight, they talked about confidence, destiny, intimidation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VERITAS DGC INC., Houston, a company that collects seismic data for the petroleum industry, agreed to buy the smaller Canadian rival Enertec Resource Services Inc. for $33.5 million.

title: Storyteller Tries to Lift Up a Ravaged Land
description: THE organizers of the People's Poetry Gathering, a three-day festival going on in a half-dozen downtown locales this weekend, were proud to announce, among their poets, a West African griot, or storyteller and history-keeper, one Kewulay Kamara, who was raised in Sierra Leone.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLOSHOK, RITA
description: MOLOSHOK-Rita. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIRKIN, THEODORE B.
description: MIRKIN-Theodore B. On April 5, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Hermine, loving father of Steven, Jeff and Carissa. Cherished grandfather of Max. Loving uncle of Susan, Beth and Barry. Graveside Services Thursday 10AM at Mt Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y. For information contact Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. Forest Hills, NY.

title: Woman Arrested After Police Find 2d Son, Not Robbers, Shot Boy
description: A Bronx woman who told the police on Monday night that her 8-year-old son had been shot by robbers was arrested yesterday after investigators determined that another son had accidentally shot the boy, the police said.

title: So Loutish and Repulsive, He's Certainly, Well, a Pig
description: In her fiercely combative one-woman show, ''Nothin's Easy and Nobody's Happy'' at Musical Theater Works, Colette Hawley has created one of the most repulsively funny characters to be seen on a New York stage in quite a while. ''Addicted to Love,'' the final sketch in her 70-minute show of comedy, songs and autobiographical observations, finds Ms. Hawley donning a plastic porcine snout and pink ears to impersonate a fourth-rate lounge performer in an Atlantic City nightclub called Raging Pig.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about a prayer vigil at the 75th Precinct in Brooklyn misidentified a man who stood with Evadine Bailey, whose son was killed by the police in 1997. The man was Charles Barron, a family spokesman, not Ms. Bailey's husband, Lord Bailey.

title: U.S. Chooses Guantanamo Bay Base in Cuba for Refugee Site
description: The White House said today that it had selected the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba as a temporary home for 20,000 refugees from Kosovo, despite warnings from some refugee groups that the base will be more like a prison than the ''safe haven'' described by the Clinton Administration.

title: Luck and the B Train Win a Race for a Yankee Fan
description: It was not Mae-Ann Gilbert's worst subway ride. That, she said, would have been the morning rush hour in 1988 when the No. 3 train struck and killed a woman and other passengers cursed the victim for making them late. Nor was it her most unpleasant experience in a contest. That came in 1984, she said, when she was the first-ever black contestant in the Miss Staten Island pageant and her appearance on stage was greeted with stony silence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEYSOR, ALLAN L. (GUS)
description: KEYSOR-Allan L. (Gus) of Setauket, New York, suddenly on April 2, 1999. Loving husband of Nancy. Dear father of Edward, Dwight and John. Allan served for twenty-six years in the United States Navy and Naval Reserves before retiring as a Captain in 1989. At the present, he was the Vice-President and General Counsel for Curative Health Services in Hauppauge, New York. A memorial service will be held Friday, April 9th. Cremation was private. Information O.B. Davis Funeral Homes, 4839 Nesconset Highway, Port Jefferson Station, NY.

title: Dodging Science
description: A new report finds that it is all too easy to get through four years of college without ever taking a demanding science course. As a result, says the report, which was issued last month by the National Research Council, an arm of the National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering, students lack sufficient grounding in science, math, engineering and technology.

title: Gunman in Brooklyn Lot Wounds Three and Flees
description: A man stepped out of a sport utility vehicle in a Brooklyn parking lot yesterday and shot two men and a teen-ager, wounding all of them, the police said. All three were in stable condition last night, the police said.

title: Couple Go on Trial in Theft of Piece of a Crashed Jet
description: When Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded and crashed off Long Island in July 1996, killing all 230 people on board, some investigators initially theorized that the jetliner might have been brought down by a missile.

title: A Good-Humored Chinese Premier Arrives for U.S. Visit
description: The Prime Minister of China, Zhu Rongji, began his visit to the United States today, determined to defuse rising tensions between the two countries with a business-like agenda, trade concessions and an ample supply of good humor.

title: NATO Dismisses a Milosevic Bid and Steps Up Raids
description: President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia announced a unilateral cease-fire by Serbian forces starting today. But NATO flatly dismissed the statement and seized on another rare day of clear skies to intensify its aerial bombardment of Serbian forces and supplies.

title: A China Trade Deal Is Now Up to Clinton
description: With 24 hours remaining before the arrival of China's Prime Minister, President Clinton struggled tonight to decide whether to strike the broadest trade agreement in Chinese-American history, in return for American agreement to usher China into the World Trade Organization. But his top advisers were deeply split about whether to take the deal.

title: UNILAB TO ACQUIRE PHYSICIANS CLINICAL LABORATORY
description: The Unilab Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Physicians Clinical Laboratory Inc. for $36.1 million in cash, stock and a note, in a deal that combines California's two largest regional independent medical testing companies. Physicians Clinical, which does business as Bio-Cypher Laboratories, had sales of $60 million in 1998. Unilab operates primary testing sites in California and had revenue of $217.4 million in 1998. The transaction includes one million Unilab shares, $8 million cash and a $25 million convertible note.

title: Rubble to Rebirth: Tales of the Bronx; Art Captures a Changing Borough
description: The film ''Fort Apache, the Bronx'' begins with a disclaimer: ''The picture you are about to see is a portrayal of the lives of two policemen working out of a precinct in the South Bronx, New York. Because the story involves police work, it does not deal with the law-abiding members of the community nor does it dramatize the efforts of the individuals and groups who are struggling to turn the Bronx around.''

title: Out of This Nettle, Pluck Flavor
description: NETTLE soup, a dish from my childhood, is a ritual of spring and early summer that I have steeped my own offspring in -- over their original objection that ''no one else eats this stuff!''

title: New Chairman For Rapp Collins
description: Rapp Collins Worldwide in New York, the direct marketing agency that is part of the Diversified Agency Services unit of Omnicom Group, said yesterday that Malcolm Speed would join as chairman and chief executive.

title: Dell Expands Venture With Linux Vendor
description: The Dell Computer Corporation said today that it would install Red Hat Software Inc.'s version of the Linux operating system on some of its computers and take a minority stake in the closely held Red Hat. The actions are a show of support for Linux, an alternative to the Microsoft Corporation's Windows operating system.

title: Kosovars Still Flee Across Albanian Border as Serbs Burn Villages
description: The long, ragged lines of refugees continued to cross the border from Kosovo here as darkness fell today, despite the cease-fire declared by the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Man With Sword Is Shot by Officers on Train
description: A man who the police said menaced riders on a commuter train bound for Long Island was shot eight times and critically injured by police officers yesterday after he threatened them with a three-foot-long sword, the authorities said.

title: Are Hate-Crime Laws Necessary?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, FRANCES (NEE HOLLANDER).
description: LEVIN-Frances (nee Hollander). Age 91, of Palm Beach, Florida and New Jersey died peacefully on April 6, 1999. Beloved wife of the late George and beloved mother of the late Richard. Grandmother of Carol Levin and Marjorie (Charles) Van Dercook. Greatgrandmother of Gina, George, Charlotte, Archie and Rebecca. Funeral services on Friday, April 9 at 11:00AM at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Forest Avenue, Paramus, New Jersey. Contributions in her memory can be made to the United Jewish Appeal or to the Richard Levin Research and Rehabilitation Foundation, One Longfellow Place, Box 1217, Boston, MA. 02114.

title: Leading Indicators Rise for a Fifth Month
description: The index of leading economic indicators posted its fifth consecutive monthly increase in February, suggesting that the economy will keep growing well into its ninth year of expansion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEDIN, GORDON WEBSTER.
description: HEDIN-Gordon Webster. On December 5, 1998 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father of Anne Hedin Thompson and Mark Gordon Hedin. Loving grandfather of Hugh Gordon Thompson, Olivia Thompson and Beatrice Thompson. Memorial service April 8, 5PM, Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 91 St. Contributions in his memory may be made to the ASPCA or charity of your choice.

title: BP AMOCO PLANS TO BUY REMAINING 50% STAKE IN SOLAREX
description: BP Amoco P.L.C. plans to pay $45 million to buy the 50 percent interest in Solarex that it does not already own, creating what it called the world's largest solar-energy company. ''This acquisition is another significant step towards our target of building a $1 billion solar business over the next decade,'' BP Amoco's chief executive, Sir John Browne, said yesterday. The company will be renamed BP Solarex and will build on the current business activities of Solarex and BP's solar division. Solarex, previously a 50-50 joint venture between Amoco and Enron Oil and Gas, had annual revenue of $58 million last year.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Dividing an Office Tower to Get the Most From It
description: It's a modern marketing variation of divide and conquer -- dividing a building to better conquer the downtown real estate market. That is what the owners have done as part of a $60 million renovation at 60 Broad Street, a 39-story, million-square-foot office building that features a series of setbacks leading to a tower.

title: EMC's Account Placed in Review
description: The EMC Corporation, a maker of data storage systems for corporate computer networks, said yesterday that it would begin a review on its North American advertising account, which has been at Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass., for five years. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELMAN, MILTON
description: GELMAN-Milton. Beloved husband and devoted friend to Evelyn. Loving father of Philip and Florencia Gelman, and Melissa and Michael King. Dear brother of Beverly and Sandy Mayer, and Lynn and Michael Bell. Services Friday, April 9th, 10AM at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 E. 87 St. Contributions in his memory may be made to Project Ezra, 197 East Broadway, NY NY 10002.

title: Metro Business; Food Company Deal
description: Hain Food Group Inc., a natural and snack food company based in Uniondale, N.Y., has agreed to buy the closely held Natural Nutritional Group Inc. for $80 million to expand its natural- and organic-food business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEINER, DELLA F. (NEE BERKOWITZ).
description: LEINER-Della F. (nee Berkowitz). on April 4, 1999, age 96. Beloved wife of the late Philip A., dear mother of Dr. Barbara L. Claster and grandmother of Saundra M. Claster, both of NYC. Services and burial will be in Cleveland. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Temple-Tifereth Israel Library Fund, Temple East, 26000 Shaker Boulevard, Beachwood, Ohio 44122.

title: Ueberroth Joins Kissinger on Panel
description: Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, and Peter Ueberroth, whose stewardship of the 1984 Summer Games in Los Angeles brought the Olympics into the modern era of commercialization, have been appointed as American representatives to a panel entrusted with reforming the Olympic movement in the wake of the Salt Lake City bribery scandal, an Olympic official said last night.

title: Homage to an Architect Who Sought God in the Details
description: The fate of the turn-of-the-century Budapest architect Lipot Baumhorn and his work can be seen as a metaphor for the modern Jewish experience in Hungary: optimism, splendor, destruction, oblivion and, since the fall of Communism, rediscovery and revival.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Monday, about a redesign for the on-line magazine Salon, misstated the name of the owner of a Web site that sold its address to Salon. He is Roy Fredericks, not Frederickson. The article also misidentified one magazine that will carry Salon's new advertisements. It is The Atlantic Monthly, not American Monthly.

title: Taiwan Group Denies Interest in Japan Airlines
description: The Evergreen Group of Taiwan is not planning to buy a stake in the Japan Airlines Company from the airline's top shareholder, a spokeswoman for the chairman of Evergreen, Chang Yung-Fa, said yesterday. The top shareholder of J.A.L., Eitaro Itoyama, said Monday that he was considering a 31.5 billion yen ($259 million) bid from Evergreen for his 60 million shares, or 4 percent stake, in the airline, which is Asia's largest.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Kumquat Delivers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSCHALK, H. ROBERT.
description: MARSCHALK-H. Robert. Philip Morris Companies Inc, notes with sorrow the death on April 4, 1999, of retired Board Member, H. Robert Marschalk. Mr. Marschalk served as a Member of The Philip Morris Companies Inc, Board of Directors from 1966 until his retirement in 1986. He was named Director Emeritus in 1984. ''Bob was a major force in guiding the growth of Philip Morris and Marlboro in the 1950's and 1960's'' said Joseph F. Cullman 3rd, Director Emeritus and Chairman Emeritus, Philip Morris Companies Inc. ''He was an important factor in the dynamic growth of Philip Morris by bringing in his vast knowledge of product development and strong marketing skills to the Philip Morris effort, especially as it related to opening up foreign businesses.'' Mr. Marschalk was an active Director on the Boards of a wide range of other corporations and community organizations, including the Thyssen Bornimisza (a holding company in Monaco), several Equitable Money Market Account Companies, T-Cell Sciences, Piedmont Management Corp, The World Wildlife Fund, and the Silvermine Guild of Artists. The Philip Morris Board and Employees extend their deepest sympathy to his devoted family. A Memorial Service will be held in New Canaan, CT, at a later date.

title: The Long Reach of Internet Stock Mania
description: There is no doubt that Internet companies can create tremendous wealth overnight, but can the current Internet mania by investors help management bring a labor union to heel?

title: Cabby Acquitted of Obstructing Actions of Police in Taxi Protest
description: A Queens taxi driver who was arrested and had his cab impounded last year apparently because the police believed he was part of a cabby protest was acquitted by a jury yesterday.

title: Pension Fund At Nissan Has $4.76 Billion Shortage
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest auto maker, detailed the extent of its pension financing shortage today, disclosing a gap almost twice as large as analysts had expected.

title: Threesomes Replace Twosomes at Masters
description: For the first time since 1962, the Masters will have threesomes instead of twosomes on Thursday and Friday. With a field of 96 players, the largest since 1966, there was concern that 48 twosomes might not finish before dark, and that some players would be teeing off either extremely early or extremely late.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KEMPLER, EDWARD
description: KEMPLER-Edward. 21 years have passed today that you left us. Tomorrow is your birthday. We think of you every day. Phyllis, Mark and Ro

title: Renault Weighing Link To Auto-Goods Retailer
description: Renault S.A. is discussing forming a joint venture with the Autobacs Seven Company, a Japanese car products retailer, to sell auto goods in Europe, Philip Cottard, a spokesman at Renault's Tokyo office, said yesterday. Renault agreed last month to invest $5.4 billion in the debt-ridden Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest car maker.

title: Boneless Little Birds, Too Tender for Words
description: FOR tiny birds, quail have always had a big problem. Their little bones can make anyone tackling them with knife and fork feel like Gulliver in Lilliput -- and wonder whether the flavor is worth the bother.

title: A Balkan Quagmire We Should Avoid; Ghost of Credibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHSBAUM, STANLEY
description: BUCHSBAUM-Stanley. April 5, 1999. Beloved husband of Frances, beloved father of Joel, brother of Ruth Kaufman and Gladys Turer.

title: Lindros Is Urged To Miss Playoffs
description: The Philadelphia Flyers' captain, Eric Lindros, shouldn't try to return from his collapsed lung this season, even for the playoffs, said Carl Lindros, his father and agent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHMIDT, PAUL
description: SCHMIDT-Paul. A celebration of the life and work of Paul Schmidt will be held on Tuesday, April 13 at 4:00 PM, at The Public Theater, 425 Lafayette St. All are welcomed.

title: 'Paper Curtain' Snags Kosovo Refugees
description: USTI NAD LABEM, Czech Republic  As hundreds of thousands of ethnic Albanians flee Serbian troops to an uncertain future in poor neighboring countries or in refugee camps in distant lands, a smaller exodus is unfolding here in the economically depressed industrial cities and devastated forests along the Czech-German border.

title: Let Immigrants Organize for Better Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: A Meringue of Semiotics and Erotic Casualness
description: SURRENDER, DOROTHY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ERICH
description: KATZ-Erich. The Cherry Lane Minyan deeply mourns the passing of Erich Katz and extend sincerest condolences to his wife, Elizabeth, and to the children Eleanore, Henry an Daniel, and the entire family. We will certainly miss his guiding advice and presence at Cherry Lane. May the family be comforted among the Mourners and Zion of Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMMINGS, CELE
description: CUMMINGS-Cele . Our heartfelt condolences to Gayle Morrow, her children and grandchildren, and to her brother, Jay Cummings, on the loss of their mother, Cele. May her memory live in their hearts forever. The Shanker Family

title: Marketers unite behind an initiative to increase the amount of 'family friendly' programming.
description: A SERIOUS effort by marketers to urge more ''family friendly'' television programming has picked up speed, with more than a score of leading advertisers now supporting plans to stimulate producers to develop -- and networks to schedule -- such shows.

title: WORKFLOW IN DEALS TO EXPAND ITS GRAPHIC-ARTS BUSINESS
description: Workflow Management Inc., a commercial printer and office-products supplier, said it had bought five companies and agreed to buy a sixth for a total of $55 million to expand its graphic-arts business. Workflow bought the commercial printing and packaging companies Superior Graphics in New York; Sundog Printing in Alberta, Canada; Pacific Admail in California; Freedom Graphics in New Jersey, and Premier Graphics in Columbia, S.C. Workflow Management, with 1998 sales of $353.4 million, said the purchases would give it high-profile clients including Caterpillar, Coca-Cola and Microsoft.

title: Computer Security: Wariness Advised
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, CLARA
description: HELLER-Clara. On April 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Toni Hall and Francesca Heller. Grandmother to Jordan Heller-Skolnik. Services Friday April 9, 12PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: How Suspects Were Moved, Very Discreetly, to Court
description: The operation was intricate, complex and above all secret. No one except Hans Corell, the chief legal counsel for the United Nations -- not even Secretary General Kofi Annan -- knew the details surrounding the logistics for the surrender of the two Libyan suspects charged with planting the bomb that downed Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.

title: Cardinal Holds a Meeting With the Parents of Diallo
description: John Cardinal O'Connor met for 40 minutes yesterday with Amadou Diallo's parents, and both sides emerged expressing hope that the public outcry over Mr. Diallo's death in a hail of police gunfire would help heal racial tension in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAN, STEPHEN
description: CHAN-Stephen. The President, Boards of Governors and Overseers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion record with deep sorrow the death of Stephen Chan, Chairman and Trustee Emeritus of the Hagop Kevorkian Fund. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his beloved family. He has left our world with a rich legacy. May his family be comforted together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, Pres. Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors Dr. Paul M. Steinberg, Special Assistant to the Pres.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Small-Town Clan Is Going National

title: Liberties; President Frat Boy?
description: We've all been exhausted by the faux culture wars of the Clinton era.

title: Titanic Disasters
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, RAYMOND F.
description: WILSON-Raymond F. Composer, of New York City, formerly of Huntington, New York, on April 7, 1999. Loving companion of Vera Kaltinick. Son of Calvin Wilson. Fond brother of Leslie LaGuardia, David, Matthew & Daniel Wilson. Visitation on Thursday, 7-9 PM, Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave, Huntington. Services on Friday evening. Burial Saturday at Melville Cemetery.

title: Philip Morris Ousts 3 Top Miller Beer Executives
description: Moving to improve the sagging fortunes of its Miller Beer unit, which has lost market share and volume in recent years, Philip Morris dismissed three top Miller executives yesterday, including the chief executive and the head of marketing.

title: Bombs Won't Make A Balkan Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERGER, AKIVA JOSEPH
description: WEINBERGER-Akiva Joseph. We are saddened by the sudden loss of Joseph Weinberger, beloved husband of Gertrude, devoted father of Hillel and Mark and their wives, Elaine and Deborah, respected grandfather of Levi, Avi, Noam, Sarah and Ezra. A Learned Man. A Survivor. Mr. Weinberger's goodness and spirit will be warmly remembered by those of us whose lives he touched. Our condolences to the Weinbergers and the many family and friends affected by Joe's untimely passing. Leon M. Wagner and Family

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOROWITZ, ESTELLE
description: LOROWITZ-Estelle. On April 5. Beloved wife of the late Hy; devoted mother of Harry, Amy and Steven Schreiber and the late Michael. Cherished grandmother of Jenny, dear sister of Jack Kramer, adored aunt, and sister-in-law, loyal friend. Service Friday, 11:30AM, in ''Parkside,'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn (near Avenue V).

title: The Eagle as Icon: Predator or Fat Hen?
description: EVEN wars have logos these days, at least on television, and the coverage of the conflict in Kosovo invariably features the Albanian eagle, splashed across the screen like the NBC peacock. The eagle, carried by Kosovo's ethnic Albanians, is angular, Gothic, almost medieval in style. With its two heads and dragonlike claws, it seems to sum up the ancient nature of the conflicts in the Balkans -- and the fears Americans have of an area they don't understand. It's a feathered version of all the fears of foreign entanglements we've worried about since Washington's farewell address.

title: Give Children of Convicts a Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: A 2-Way Watch-Phone Dick Tracy Would Love
description: Science fiction writers may have to come up with some other symbol of the future: the watch-phone actually exists.

title: $100 a Ticket?! Here's Why
description: Every time the producers of ''The Iceman Cometh'' want to have a light bulb changed, they need to use a three-man crew, each member earning $43.36 an hour. To fashion the three women's wigs they needed, the producers paid $2,250, saving at least $750 each by having molds made of the actresses' heads and having the hairpieces made in England. And $3,000 went for dirtying up some of the show's rented costumes to make them more appropriate to the Bowery-like mise en scene.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLUNKETT, NANCY PALMER
description: PLUNKETT-Nancy Palmer. In North Branford, CT, April 5. A long-time resident of Stamford. Widow of Robert G. Plunkett. Mother of Anne, Bob, Peter, and Mary. Also survived by six grandchildren. A memorial gathering will be held in the Reese Room at Evergreen Woods, 88 Notch Hill Road, North Branford, on April 24, at 11:30. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Nature Conservancy, 1815 North Lynn Street, Arlington, VA. 22209.

title: Jury Weighs Freedom for Mental Patient
description: During the nearly two decades he has spent in state psychiatric hospitals, Albert Fentress has been a model patient, his lawyer says. He teaches desktop publishing to other patients and helps run a small business. He has made hundreds of supervised trips to museums, ball games and picnics. His doctors even let him roam the hospital grounds unescorted.

title: Fox Moves To Reclaim Some Ad Slots
description: In a move that could help radically alter the relationship between broadcast networks and their affiliated stations, the Fox network is unilaterally reclaiming for itself more than 20 percent of the commercial time now sold by its local affiliated stations in prime time.

title: Key Democrat Faults Choice For Top Court In New Jersey
description: In a sign of intensifying opposition to Attorney General Peter G. Verniero's appointment to the New Jersey Supreme Court, the Legislature's top Democrat yesterday released a study of the qualifications of every justice named to the bench during the last half-century and said it raised ''troubling questions'' about whether Mr. Verniero had the judicial background or legal expertise to merit confirmation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESLIN, PHYLLIS STACY
description: HESLIN-Phyllis Stacy. Beloved wife of James J. Heslin, on April 5, 1999. Services are private.

title: A Quaint Custom Recalled
description: In the early decades of this century fashionable Manhattan hotels presented recitals in which soloists took turns in the spotlight, each playing a work or two then ceding the stage to a colleague and returning to play again later, sometimes in duets. In both format and repertory the Monday evening duo vocal recital by Patricia Racette and Russell Braun, part of Lincoln Center's Art of the Song series, called this quaint, forgotten programming style to mind.

title: INSIDE
description: School District Is Indicted

title: Collections of Music for the Spirit
description: THE first piece of music some children are likely to hear is not a popular tune or even a lullaby, but a hymn. A mother's favorite, or the choir's rendition at a family christening or wedding or funeral, can conquer time and elevate the soul.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHLER, IRA J.
description: HECHLER-Ira J. Respected and admired Board Member of the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor, L.I. Active champion and supporter of the arts. His presence and voice will be greatly missed by all his colleagues.

title: Sol Hoffman, 67, Labor Leader In Garment Industry in Northeast
description: Sol Hoffman, a longtime labor leader in the Northeast, died on March 27 at a friend's home in Jersey City after suffering a heart attack. He was 67.

title: Court Drops All Charges In Protests For Diallo
description: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge dismissed disorderly conduct and other charges yesterday against the 1,166 demonstrators arrested during last month's wave of daily protests over the police shooting of Amadou Diallo.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Credits to Roll On 'Judge' Koch

title: G.M. Sales Fell in March, Missing Auto Makers' Boom
description: The General Motors Corporation missed out on sizzling vehicles sales in March, reporting today that its car and truck sales fell more than 2 percent from those in the month a year earlier.

title: Don't Mock Politeness, Embrace It
description: THE MAYOR missed a golden opportunity this week when he said that police officers would be given palm cards with instructions on how to be more polite. Not that it was a bad idea. But he could have struck a real blow for civility by announcing that courtesy cards would be handed out from now on to every single New Yorker, in or out of blue.

title: Doctor's Effort to Move Practice Leaves Patients in a Tug of War
description: It happens all the time in the legal and financial world: lawyers or stockbrokers jump from one firm to another, taking their clients -- and the clients' money -- with them.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDNOR, LUCILLE O.
description: REDNOR-Lucille O. On April 5, 1999. Widow of Dr. Daniel J. Rednor. Beloved mother of Linda Rosner, Barbara Ciongoli and Jon Miller. Cherished grandmother of Adam, Gary, Happy, Jamie, Greg, Alessandra, Kenny, Jordan and Joshua. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday 5:30-8PM with service Thursday, 10AM. Interment to follow at Beth Olam Cemetery.

title: Ahold and Gastronoom Strike $156 Million Deal
description: Royal Ahold N.V., the world's No. 6 supermarket owner, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Gastronoom for 318 million guilders, or $156 million, to corner 10 percent of the 14 billion guilder Dutch institutional food-supplying business.

title: Intelligence Report Points To 2d China Nuclear Leak
description: In early 1996, the United States received a startling report from one of its Chinese spies. Officials inside China's intelligence service, the spy said, were boasting that they had just stolen secrets from the United States and had used them to improve Beijing's neutron bomb, according to American officials.

title: DUPONT TO INVEST $220 MILLION IN ALLIANCE WITH WEBMD
description: DuPont said yesterday that it would invest $220 million in an Internet health care program with WebMD Inc. WebMD, which began in October, offers doctors and consumers information about medicine and managed care. The deal will help DuPont, the nation's largest chemical company, increase its life-sciences business. Last month DuPont said it would issue a new class of stock to track the performance of the business; it also plans to expand the unit through alliances and acquisitions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLOSHOK, RITA STERN
description: MOLOSHOK-Rita Stern. Of New Rochelle, N.Y. Died Monday, April 5, 1999 in Boca Raton, FL at age 72. A funeral service will be held Friday, April 9th, 10AM at Temple Israel, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd, New Rochelle, N.Y. She is survived by her beloved husband Norman, her sons Matthew, William & Thomas & their wives Judith and Deborah, her adoring grandchildren Rachel, Jared, Hannah, Darcie and Logan, her brother Aaron Stern and sister Gertrude Levy and their families.

title: When Dead Men Tell Their Tales
description: It is often challenging and ghostly work, evaluating the wishes of a writer who is dead, deciding whether a hidden manuscript is worthy of display and therefore should be published. For authors who are important or popular, or both, there is pressure to keep the property alive, their bodies of work available and visible, to generate not only art but cash. To do so, there has to be something new. Enter the literary executor, and lo and behold, bingo, what was in the vaults is now on the bookshelves.

title: What's Funny at Microsoft? Blocking Netscape's Web Site
description: Microsoft has the reputation of being a ruthless, cutthroat competitor but, hey, that doesn't mean the company doesn't know how to have fun. In an on-line tutorial for Microsoft's Back Office Server 4.0 (www.microsoft.com/backofficeserver/guide/accessfund.asp?A=2), there is a section called Exercise 2: Control User Access to Internet Sites that teaches customers how to block certain Web sites. The example site used by Microsoft: www.netscape.com.

title: In Criminal Law, Motive Does Matter; Punish the Thought?
description: To the Editor:

title: The IA-64 Chip: Intel Breaks the Mold
description: FOR two decades, the Intel Corporation has built its astonishingly successful computer chips on the same basic plan or architecture. The 8086 gave way to the 286, 386, 486 and Pentium, a kind of 586, which is why many people call this line of chips the x86.

title: Out of Playoffs Again, Muckler Notes Progress
description: There was little talk today among the Rangers about Thursday night's game against the Blackhawks in Chicago. Instead, the conversation was about the games that got away this season. A loss to the Tampa Bay Lightning, the worst team in the National Hockey League. A devastating loss at home to the Boston Bruins. The brutal start of the season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Internet Hoax Roils Shares Of Pairgain Technologies

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMAN MOYER, MARCIA
description: LEHMAN MOYER-Marcia. On April 7, 1999. Mother of Elise Bon Rudin. Grandmother of Marko Bon. Sister of Suzanne Zimet (Arthur) and Jacqueline Cummings (Victor). Aunt of Andrew, Abby, David and Nina. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Lahey Clinic Hospital, Hartley Fund, Quality Resources Dept., 41 Mall Rd., Burlington, MA 01805, Attn: Pamela Reznick, LICSW, greatly appreciated.

title: Pushing Politeness Cards at a Police Roll-Call
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir went to a roll-call at a Harlem station house yesterday morning to take their campaign for a more polite police force to officers on the front lines.

title: Americans, in Poll, See U.S. Involvement Growing
description: Two weeks into the NATO air campaign against Yugoslavia, most Americans expect the conflict there to drag on for months or years, to involve the deployment of United States ground troops and to cause the loss of American lives, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: 2 Women Accused of Brutalizing Learning-Disabled Roommate
description: Two Passaic women have been charged with holding their learning-disabled roommate hostage in a trash-strewn apartment for nearly a month while intermittently burning her with hot metal spoons and beating her with wooden table legs and a metal pipe, the authorities said today.

title: Yahoo's Earnings Performance Was Strong in the First Quarter
description: Yahoo Inc., whose Internet sites include a range of features from chat rooms to news and search services, said today that first-quarter earnings soared and revenue almost tripled, buoyed by growth in advertising and commissions from on-line sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, MARY
description: O'CONNOR-Mary. April 6, 1999, of Manhattan, NY. Devoted sister of Joseph, Jane, Charles and the late Edward O'Connor. Devoted aunt of 12 nieces and nephews. Reposing at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, New York, NY 10014. Viewing hours are from 2 to 5 and from 7 to 9, Thursday and Friday. Mass of Resurrection on Saturday, 10:30 AM, St. Josephs Church, Sixth Ave and Washington Place, Manhattan. Interment to follow at the Calvary Cemetery in Queens.

title: A Lingering Virus
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombs Won't Make A Balkan Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Blackstone to Form a New Financing Unit
description: The Blackstone Group in New York is expected to announce today that it is starting a unit called the Blackstone Mezzanine Group. It will provide financing for middle-market leveraged buyout funds and public companies that need money to grow but are too small to secure high-yield debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASIELLO, JOHN E.
description: MASIELLO-John E. Dearest and most beloved brother of Michael and Sam. Loving uncle of Domenick and Marianne and David DiRezze. Reposing at Farenga Brothers Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Avenue, Bronx, Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 9:30AM at Immaculate Conception Church.

title: Diplomatic Principles for Kosovo
description: As Serbian forces continue to advance across Kosovo in a brutal campaign of ethnic cleansing, talking about the terms of a political settlement may seem premature. But with diplomatic activity stirring and NATO's air strikes starting to undercut Slobodan Milosevic's military base, it is not too early for the Clinton Administration to start thinking about the broad shape of an acceptable peace deal. President Clinton has led the way this week by forcefully enunciating some core principles that are likely to be at the center of discussions between the United States, Russia and other nations now pursuing a diplomatic track.

title: U.S. Warns on Antigua Money Laundering
description: The Treasury Department warned banks today to be especially careful of financial transactions routed through Antigua and Barbuda, saying that changes in the Caribbean nation's law ''threaten to create a haven for money laundering.''

title: Seagram Selling Some Film Assets
description: USA Networks Inc. agreed yesterday to buy some of the Seagram Company's film assets, guaranteeing a supply of programming for USA's cable networks and television stations.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD AND BEA SYSTEMS IN E-COMMERCE PACT
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that it had formed a three-year, $100 million alliance with BEA Systems Inc. to provide electronic-commerce software to link and create applications. BEA Systems, of San Jose, Calif., develops message-management software. Its E-commerce and software products will be sold in Hewlett-Packard computer systems to help direct and speed information across all applications and systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, JAMES A. (ARCH)
description: COLLINS - James A. (Arch). March 29, 1999. Survived by sisterin-law Mrs. Claire (Peter) Collins of Wilton, CT., niece Sarah Collins Beeler of Washington, D.C., and nephew Peter Collins Jr. of Tucson, AZ. Friends may call at the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Avenue, Bklyn, NY on Friday 2-5PM and 7-10PM. Mass of the Resurrection Holy Innocents Church, Saturday 10AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEMENTS, CHRISTOPHER A.
description: CLEMENTS-Christopher A., 38. Of New York City. Died beautifully in the arms of his beloved partner, John Noonan of NYC on April 4, 1999 after a long illness. Adored son of Barbara Meredith of NYC and William Clements of Cheverly, MD. Cherished brother of Stephen Clements of Riverdale, MD. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Actors Fund, 729 Seventh Avenue, NY, NY 10019.

title: Officer and Other Driver Disagree About Fatal Crash Involving a Police Car
description: A police officer's account of how his cruiser struck a car before it hit and killed a pedestrian in Pennsauken, N.J., on Tuesday differs from that of the other car's driver. The officer said a third car obscured his view, causing the crash, but the driver of the car that was hit said she saw no other car, according to Lee Solomon, the Camden County Prosecutor.

title: Punter Is Signed
description: The Jets yesterday signed punter Dirk Johnson, who had 10 boots for the Seattle Seahawks as a rookie in the preseason last summer before being cut. Johnson, who played for Northern Colorado, where he also performed at safety, averaged 39.8 yards for the Seahawks in the exhibition games. He joins recently acquired punter/quarterback Tom Tupa on the Jets. GERALD ESKENAZI

title: Everyone's a Skeptic
description: To the Editor:

title: Marbury Limits Iverson but the Streak Ends
description: The long-overdue winning streak the Nets were so proud of is over. And the defense that had them speaking confidently about intimidating opponents has been humbled.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: A Line of Furniture Is Big on Spritely
description: No, these are not candies: they are pieces of furniture. The 68-inch-long purple Blob Bench (below, $2,400) and the blue M:Bench/Table/Lamp (above, $3,700, 46 inches in diameter) are from the first furniture collection by Patrick Chia, 30, a Singapore designer. Some of his colorful fiberglass furniture was chosen by Philippe Starck for the lobby of the Mondrian Hotel in Los Angeles. The entire eight-piece line is available at Totem Design, 71 Franklin Street (Broadway). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: National News Briefs; Utility Is Set Back In Energy Dept. Suit
description: A Federal judge has ruled that a Minnesota utility that is seeking $1 billion in damages from the Federal Government because of a delay in setting up a nuclear waste repository must try to reach a settlement with the Energy Department before it can sue.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Thursday describing the technology that makes the F-117A fighter plane stealthy mislabeled another craft shown in a comparison of radar-screen images. The B1-B is simply a bomber, not a radar-evading stealth plane.

title: NATO BOMBERS HIT SERB FORCES; REFUGEE FLOW HALTS ABRUPTLY: DIPLOMATIC FLURRY
description: The NATO allies opened a diplomatic offensive today aimed at probing for signs that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia might be ready to back down, even as they continued air attacks against Yugoslav military targets in Kosovo.

title: Walks, Talks and Exhibitions
description: Swedish Design

title: Counselor at Youth Home Is Accused of Running a $3 Million-a-Year Drug Ring
description: A counselor at a Manhattan group home for teen-age boys was accused yesterday of running a $3 million-a-year drug ring at a public housing project in Queens with another man.

title: Mendoza Fits Bill As Starter
description: Ramiro Mendoza will return to the Yankees' bullpen once Hideki Irabu's probation expires and Andy Pettitte recovers from his various injuries. The Yankees are undoubtedly a better team with the versatile and durable Mendoza available in relief, after all.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Science and Politics Mapped on a Woman's Body
description: WOMANAn Intimate GeographyBy Natalie Angier398 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $25.

title: Bidder for Redskins Withdraws His Offer
description: Facing the prospect of not having enough votes for approval by the National Football League owners, Howard Milstein withdrew his group's $803 million offer to buy the Washington Redskins from the estate of Jack Kent Cooke.

title: Republicans and Census
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Pension Guarantor Can Be Sued by Workers
description: After reading a memo leaked by a whistle-blower, a Federal judge reversed her opinion yesterday and ruled that the Federal agency that takes over failed pension plans has a responsibility of loyalty to workers in such plans and can be sued for violating that duty.

title: Rental Service Sues Two Rivals
description: United Rentals Inc., the No. 1 United States equipment rental company, sued Nationsrent Inc. and the Rental Service Corporation today, accusing them of violating proxy and tender offer rules after United Rentals made a hostile $1.36 billion bid for Rental Service.

title: In Criminal Law, Motive Does Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Loss for the N.R.A.
description: The National Rifle Association poured $3.8 million into its bid to win passage of a ballot referendum in Missouri that would have lifted the state's longstanding prohibition against carrying a concealed weapon -- at least three times the amount spent by the other side. But Missouri voters proved too sensible to be swayed. On Tuesday they defeated the ''right to carry'' referendum, and the idea of looser gun laws, by a 52-to-48-percent margin.

title: Giuliani Changes Rules on City Hall Protests
description: The Giuliani administration has backed away from a plan to require City Council members to accompany groups holding news conferences and demonstrations on the steps of City Hall, but starting this week, it will limit such gatherings to two a day.

title: People
description: * Robin Danielson, president and strategic planning director at Mad Dogs and Englishmen, New York, was named to the new position of chairwoman, sharing duties with Nick Cohen, chairman.

title: Contrary Son Makes Macy's Garden Bloom
description: MOST of the time, Russ Ireland's gardens are ruled by the vagaries of the seasons. Daffodils bloom in April, wisteria in May, peonies in June, hydrangeas in July, dahlias in August, and so forth.

title: Lester A. Mount, Neurosurgeon, 89
description: Lester A. Mount, a leading neurosurgeon associated with Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and New York Presbyterian Hospital, died March 28 at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 89 and lived in Bronxville.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIDES. The dollar rose against Europe's single currency after NATO rejected a cease-fire in Yugoslavia and stepped up attacks. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0772, down from $1.0848.

title: Starwood Stock Advances 3% On Upgrade by Merrill Lynch
description: The shares of Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc. rose $1.1875, or 3 percent, yesterday, to $31.25, after Merrill Lynch upgraded its rating on the company's stock.

title: Milosevic's New Version of Reality Will Be Harder for NATO to Dismiss
description: NATO has rejected Slobodan Milosevic's latest move, a unilateral cease-fire, as insufficient for the bombing to stop, but again it is the Yugoslav President who is creating the facts to which the West is responding.

title: Pinball Wizards Have a New Game To Conjure Up Fun
description: RELEASING the plunger and launching the silver ball into play. Listening to the raucous sounds of points piling up. Snapping the flippers to bat the ball up to the bumpers. Shooting at virtual images? Pinball may never be the same.

title: Starting Moonflowers
description: Q. Please help. Last year and the year before, I planted moonflower seeds, and nothing came up. I even soaked them longer than overnight, seeded them in shade, sun, just name it. Not one of the seeds sprouted. Can you give me some advice for this year's attempt?

title: 3 Publishers to Start Russian Business Paper
description: The Financial Times Group, a unit of the British media company Pearson P.L.C., and The Wall Street Journal, the Dow Jones & Company unit, said today that they would join with Russia's Independent Media, the publisher of The Moscow Times, to start a Russian-language daily business newspaper.

title: Snyder Acquires Media Syndication
description: Snyder Communications Inc. in Bethesda, Md., said yesterday that it had acquired Media Syndication Global in New York, a marketing and media services company with estimated revenue last year of $40 million from clients like Bank of America, Fleet Financial Group and Wells Fargo. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Winner of Masters Must Show Toughness and Keep His Head
description: The golf course has changed, but the keys to victory have remained the same. Whoever wins the Masters, which begins Thursday at Augusta National Golf Club, will take a familiar path to victory. The winner will need a superb week of putting on Augusta's lightning-fast greens. He will need precise approach shots, to avoid the sure-fire trouble spots that lead to bogeys, double-bogeys, or worse. And perhaps most important, the winner will need nerves of steel on the weekend, the unshakable belief that he is tough enough, good enough and composed enough to finish the job.

title: Traveling the Home Galaxy, Even Before 2001
description: Earthbound Internet surfers can explore the solar system at a site set up by the National Geographic Society last month.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today for the eighth day of Passover and for Orthodox Holy Thursday and tomorrow for Orthodox Good Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Unusual Group of Craftsmen In an East Village Showcase
description: The artisan spirit lurks everywhere. Proof is at Goods, a 600-square-foot shop that opened last month in the East Village. Goods sells objects -- from candles to rag rugs and furniture -- made by people with mental or physical disabilities. A mentally disabled woman in Brunswick, Me., made the baby quilt below ($150).

title: Shares Up 18% As Revlon Says It Seeks a Buyer
description: After weeks of speculation that it was about to be sold, Revlon Inc., the cosmetics giant, said yesterday that it was interested in selling part or all of the business.

title: Families Torn Apart On the Way To Safety
description: Last week, Venera Limani, an 18-year-old university student from Kosovo's capital, Pristina, lost her home and all her belongings. Yesterday, on the border of Kosovo and Macedonia, she lost her family.

title: Feel Blue? Seeing Red? Jaundiced Eye? Have They Got a Room for You
description: At the Time, a new hotel at 224 West 49th Street, color is treated as an amenity. When guests check into the hotel (much of which is still a construction site), they can choose their room's color scheme -- red, blue or yellow. When all 192 rooms are open in May, the red rooms will be equipped with strawberries and apples for nibbling, the blue rooms blackberries and blueberries, and the yellow rooms pineapples, bananas and lemons. A vial of scent (to open or not, as you wish) will also evoke the color, said Adam D. Tihany, the Manhattan architect who designed the $40 million hotel. To stimulate the mind, a brochure in each room will offer an excerpt from Alexander Theroux's book of essays ''The Primary Colors'' (Henry Holt, 1994), which inspired Mr. Tihany's design for the hotel.

title: Joy of E-Mail Lights Up the Life of a Retarded Teen-Ager
description: MY 15-year-old son charges down the back stairway and into the kitchen with an entrance reminiscent of Kramer entering Jerry Seinfeld's apartment. ''We have to check my E-mail,'' he announces. ''Jenn is sending me an E-mail.''

title: Japan Beginning to Flex Its Military Muscles
description: When Japan fired warning shots at suspicious boats that ventured into its territorial waters last month, it was the clearest signal to date that this staunchly pacifist country is taking its gloves off.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: British Outrage Heads for Brooklyn
description: Visitors to the Brooklyn Museum of Art this fall may be in for a shock. Rather than sun-dappled Impressionist landscapes or forthright Rodin bronzes, its classical galleries will be filled with work by young British artists who have made a worldwide reputation creating art that disturbs and outrages. Prominently featured will be Damien Hirst's infamous dead shark floating in a tank of formaldehyde, Marc Quinn's cast of a man's head made of his own frozen blood and Ron Mueck's sculpture of his naked, dead father, reduced to the length of three feet.

title: From the Eye and Hand Of a Visionary Architect
description: Lebbeus Woods, an architect and visionary, draws a world where buildings ignore the expected traditions. Windows have no sills, openings have no doors, roofs do not enclose. ''Lines of Flight,'' an exhibition of more than 70 of his drawings from 1981 to 1991, is at the Henry Urbach Architecture Gallery in Chelsea through May 15. Futuristic buildings like ''D. Quad 9M with Ground Shields,'' below, look as if they are rising from an urban apocalypse. The drawing, from the 1987 ''Centricity'' series, is $9,500.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP INC., Baltimore, which runs television and radio stations, agreed to sell three radio stations serving the Norfolk, Va., area to Barnstable Broadcasting Inc., Newton, Mass., for about $24 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, EBEN CLARKE
description: HALL-Eben Clarke, 82. Formerly of Riverside, CT, died in Vero Beach, FL. on April 2. He leaves behind his wife, Jane Turhane Hall, two daughters, Susan Mygatt and Sarah Hansel, and seven grandchildren.

title: Books to Bytes: The Electronic Archive
description: THE research library of today presents a comforting image: cool marble stairs, orderly rows of volumes, a familiar, musty scent. But gradually, as computer work stations replace stacks and the clack-clacking of keyboards is heard above hushed voices, that image is becoming a quaint reminder of a closing era.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEETE, PAULINE
description: LEETE-Pauline. Beloved mother of Constance and Susannah; loving sister of Shirley Jarmol; good friend to many, died April 3rd. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Central Suffolk Hospital, Riverhead, N.Y. A service will be announced.

title: In Bronx, Regents Coaching Is Extended to Teachers, Too
description: Michael Marlowe, a professional testing coach, fancies himself something of a stand-up comic. He has to be, to get through to his usual audience of reluctant high school students whose affluent parents are pushing them to ace the S.A.T.'s.

title: Lottery Effort Clears Hurdle With Big Vote In the South
description: A legislative measure to allow South Carolinians to vote on the lottery hurdled its tallest obstacle today as the Republican-majority House of Representatives passed the bill by a comfortable margin.

title: Politics and the Watershed
description: There is no higher environmental priority for New York City than protection of the watershed around the upstate reservoirs that supply 10 million people with high-quality drinking water at remarkably low prices. But in recent months there have been disturbing signs that the city's devotion to this vital task is not as strong as it ought to be. There have also been charges from the environmental community that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has allowed his statewide political ambitions to compromise his commitment to watershed protection.

title: NATO BOMBERS HIT SERB FORCES; REFUGEE FLOW HALTS ABRUPTLY: THOUSANDS VANISH
description: Tens of thousands of refugees from Kosovo waiting to cross the border here vanished in the middle of the night, ordered out of a column stretching 20 miles or more by Serbian forces and sent walking to an unknown fate.

title: The Motor Helps A Scooter Scoot
description: Silent, smooth and sleek. That's Buzz, the new 48-pound electric scooter (above) by the Huffy Bicycle Company. Buzz, in lime green, red or blue, has a top speed of 15 miles an hour on its 13-mile rechargeable battery. Designed for campgrounds and parks, it folds to 10 by 10 by 39 inches. Its Web site promotes it as perfect for spins in the Hamptons -- but try that at your own risk. ''It can be driven on private property but not on public highways, since it can't be registered,'' said Joe Picchi, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles. Buzz is $649 through www.getabuzz.com.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about a Passover service at the United Spiritual Church of God in Brooklyn misidentified a woman in a dark robe. She was Eileen Drayton -- not the Rt. Rev. Carmel Ward, who led the celebration.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about David Carbaugh, a former accountant at the Hanford nuclear reservation who has accused contractors of cheating the Government, misidentified his former employers there. He worked for the Westinghouse Hanford Company and later for Fluor Daniel Hanford Inc.; he is not a former employee of the Energy Department.

title: Sports of The Times; Don Zimmer Is No Mere Caretaker
description: THE Yankees return for their home opener with two victories and one loss. And by the way, who gets credit for the Yankee record until Joe Torre comes back?

title: Metro Business; Former Bank Tower Sold for $100 Million
description: The former headquarters of Bankers Trust Corporation, at 14 Wall Street in downtown New York, across the street from the New York Stock Exchange, has been sold for about $100 million to a group of investors led by Laurence Gluck and Arthur Wrubel.

title: Everyone's a Skeptic
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSTWICK, ALLAN
description: BOSTWICK-Allan. We mourn the loss of our member and extend heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends. Temple Sinai of Long Island Paula Winnig, Rabbi Evelyn Maltman, President

title: Knicks Are All Out of Answers
description: It was time to give up and usher an end to this miserable night by turning the floor over to the Knicks' reserves. Crestfallen and drained, Coach Jeff Van Gundy waved Larry Johnson off the teal-trimmed court with about 7 long minutes left in the game.

title: Feeling Lucky? It's MTV Time
description: We like to believe that we are special, that inside us glows a beautiful, complex ember and if anyone took the time to find it they would understand just how unique we are and how much we have to offer. Yet at the same time we have our doubts about that ember and whether it really exists. So most human beings end up spending their lives seeking the approval of other human beings -- the more envy and adoration the better -- just to make that ember burn brighter in their imagination. This is the origin of the ambitions that are the lifeblood of places like Hollywood. And on Tuesday the streets around Hollywood and Vine were burning bright with 1,033 little embers, all in the minds of teen-agers and 20-somethings who crowded around the Palace, each hoping that MTV producers would recognize that he was more special than the other 1,032 people around him.

title: Bombs Won't Make A Balkan Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Missouri Rejects Bid to Allow Concealed Guns
description: Missourians have narrowly voted down the nation's first statewide ballot proposal to allow concealed weapons.

title: New Commissioner Says Programs Will Get Funds
description: The new state education commissioner said yesterday that New Jersey's urban districts would get some money this year for preschool and all-day kindergarten programs, and that rules for implementing them might be modified to address local concerns.

title: Afghanistan's Record Still Poor on Human Rights
description: Despite the apparent relaxation of some restrictions on women in Kabul, the United Nations special investigator for Afghanistan said today that Taliban officials had not moved to significantly restore human rights to the country's citizens.

title: Kosovo Is Causing Breaks And Shifts in the 2 Parties
description: The crisis in Kosovo is causing rifts in both political parties and changing the traditional policy positions that grew out of the Vietnam War.

title: Al Taylor, 51, Artist Noted for Quirky Sculpture
description: Al Taylor, an artist whose quirky linear sculpture and drawings brought lyricism and charm to the austerities of Process Art, died on March 31 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 51 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bombs Won't Make A Balkan Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tribute In Song To the Man In Black
description: Everyone wore black, and many wore long, tapered gunslinger's jackets as they paid sartorial tribute, as much as anything else, to Johnny Cash in a concert at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Tuesday night.

title: A Tiny Personal Computer Is So Small It Can Be Worn
description: With his latest invention, Vaughan Pratt, a professor of computer science at Stanford University, has taken one small step for a man and one really tiny step for mankind.

title: China Pact Near, Clinton Outlines Benefits for U.S.
description: With a partial trade accord with China nearly in hand, President Clinton argued today that America would benefit by helping guide the world's most-populous nation toward economic stability.

title: Everyone's a Skeptic
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; The Other America
description: During the daylight hours the interior of Nellie Perez's home is nearly as dark as night. She lives with her disabled husband and five others in a dangerously rickety shack in Guadalupe, a tiny poverty-racked town tucked in the midst of one of the most affluent areas in America.

title: Janitors Stage Protests Over Wage-Cutting Contractors
description: More than 500 members of New York City's largest janitors' union held 10 demonstrations in Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday to protest a growing practice in which building managers hire contractors who pay their janitors far less than the union's rate.

title: Metro Business; Insurers Are Fined
description: The New York State Department of Insurance announced yesterday that it has fined 14 insurance companies for failure to pay claims within 45 days of receiving them.

title: Autos Pace a Rise in Consumer Borrowing
description: Borrowing by consumers grew at a faster-than-expected pace in February as the auto industry posted record sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORTEL, LUCILLE
description: LORTEL-Lucille. From early on you nurtured my love for theatre in so many ways. Your advice to ''Always make theatre your first passion,'' has become a part of me. That was your first commandment, which you lived fully & faithfully throughout your gifted life. Your days and nights were filled with theatre and you raised the bar in redefining what it means to be ''of the theatre.'' We shall miss you dearly, but your first passion-theatre, continues to inspire us as you live on in our hearts and fond memories. Thank you for the unmatched generosity of your encouragement and support. God bless. Veronica M. Kehoe, The Gypsy Road Company, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERSTEIN, BENJAMIN H.
description: SILBERSTEIN-Benjamin H. On April 6, 1999 of Syosset, LI. Beloved husband of Eileen, devoted father of Pamela and Jonathan, cherished father-in-law of Shari Silberstein and Bernard Sellem, dear brother of Dorothy Klein. He served in the U.S. Navy and was a veteran of WWII. He was a long time member of the Midway Jewish Center of Syosset and past member of the Town of Oyster Bay Planning Commission. Services today, 2 PM, at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, LI.

title: NEW DEVELOPMENTS AND PURCHASES FOR DUKE REALTY
description: Duke Realty Investments Inc., a large commercial real estate developer in the Midwest, said yesterday that it had spent $148 million in new developments and acquiring land and industrial properties. The Indianapolis-based Duke said it had bought six buildings and started development of eight properties totaling 3.3 million square feet. The acquisitions include properties in Chicago, Cincinnati and Minneapolis. The purchases bring Duke's total acquisitions this year to $198 million, with an expected return of 11.4 percent. Including the most recent acquisitions, Duke owns 514 properties with 63 million square feet of space. It also owns more than 2,000 acres of land.

title: With Economies Soft, European Bank Considers Rate Cut
description: Hans-Joachim Becker thought he had endured the worst, until a few months ago.

title: Advanced Micro Hurt by Shipment Drop
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., the Intel Corporation's biggest rival in the computer-chip market, said today that it shipped fewer-than-expected microprocessors in the first quarter and that sales were below expectations.

title: Fanciful and Funky in Loose-Limbed Inventions
description: The young dancers in Eliot Feld's company, Ballet Tech, just stand and howl toward the end of a ballet called ''Paper Tiger.'' And there is also an occasional bark. At his silliest, Mr. Feld is often at his most ingenious and his most serious.

title: Yes, It's a Wine Trough, But Please, No Lapping
description: When Ed Rawlings, the Manhattan architect of the Veritas restaurant, at 43 East 20th Street, was asked to create a console for wine, he combined the worlds of humans and horses. He created a wine trough. In the stainless steel unit, left, bottles in the trough are separated by springs. The unit ($7,000) is 5 feet 1 inch tall, 3 feet wide and 7 inches deep. Mr. Rawlings also designed a 7 1/2-foot-tall illuminated chilled display case ($10,000) and a single 18-inch-wide trough ($700). Delivery time is two to three months. Information from (212) 627-0110.

title: Beware of Polls on the War
description: As the American public struggles over what to make of our military involvement in the Balkans, polls on the subject must be read with caution. Nationwide surveys by various news organizations have found concurrence on a few fundamental points, but there is disturbing ambiguity on many others. Ordinary people are having difficulty deciding about this hard-to-understand conflict in a little-known part of Europe.

title: Gillick to Head Selection Committee
description: Pat Gillick, the former general manager of the Toronto Blue Jays and Baltimore Orioles, was named yesterday as chairman of the 12-man committee that will select the players for the United States baseball team that will play in the Pan-Am Games this summer. Bob Watson, the former general manager of the Houston Astros and the Yankees, was named vice chairman.

title: A Graphics Card Is Putting The Home DVD Into Range
description: The venerable home video may be the verge of a major upgrade. Technology is emerging to make it the compression of digital video images much more affordable, which in turn will make it possible to record, store and display digital images, and even to create home DVD's.

title: New Data on Babies of Women With Birth Defects
description: A new report from Norway describes the first large study to provide information about the lives of women with birth defects and the health of their children: the women are less likely than others to have children, and those who do give birth run an increased risk of bearing a child with the same birth defect that they themselves have. But most children born to women with birth defects are healthy, and they face no increased risk of any type of defect except their mother's.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: FREDDIE MAC, McLean, Va., as the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation is known, named Pat Sheehy senior vice president to oversee marketing, sales and strategy of its single-family securitization unit. He had been executive vice president at Norwest Mortgage Inc.

title: Many See Their Future In County With a Past
description: Forsyth County has become the fastest-growing county in the nation for many of the reasons that attract people to the green edges of metropolitan areas: broad backyards for patios and swing sets, good schools, a deep lake, all just 25 miles up the highway from the corporate towers of Atlanta's inner suburbs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, DOROTHY
description: WEINSTEIN-Dorothy. Formerly of Woodmere, LI. Beloved wife of the late Milton, devoted mother of Michael and Susan, Charles and Elizabeth and the late Stephen, dear sister of Mary Astor, Shirley Vorspan, the late Sidney Nitchun and Rebecca Rockmuller, loving grandmother of Amy and Eric, Mindy and Gregory, Jessica and Seth, adored great-grandmother of Amanda, Emma and Daniel, cherished aunt and great-aunt. Services are today 10 A.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Metro Business; PaineWebber Signs Lease
description: PaineWebber Inc. has signed a long-term lease for 266,560 square feet of space in a new 15-story office building in Jersey City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLTAN, SARAH
description: SOLTAN-Sarah 89. Of Aventura, Florida, passed away April 6, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Oscar Soltan. Devoted mother of Wilfred (Ricki) and Murray (the late Bette Jane). Loving grandmother of Gail, Helene, Lisa Paige, Andrew and Emily and great grandmother of Hannah and Dylan. Active volunteer at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital, Miami, Florida. Graveside Services Friday 11am New Montefiore Cemetery, Long Island, NY.

title: No Amnesty for 2 Men Who Killed Black Leader in South Africa
description: Ruling in one of its most emotionally charged cases, South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission today denied amnesty to the two men who had assassinated a popular black leader on the eve of South Africa's first post-apartheid elections.

title: At Pelican Lake, Birds of a Feather Roll in Style
description: A FEW miles, as the pelican flies, from the warm green waters of the Gulf of Mexico, tan bodies gathered round a patio table. The conversation paused when an engine rumble neared. A new neighbor was moving onto Southern Breeze Drive. ''Nice,'' Kraig Brechbuhler said as the newest home on the block rolled by, its burgundy-and-gold sides sparkling in the noon sun.

title: Dallas May Have Broken Salary Cap Rules
description: The National Football League is investigating accusations that the Dallas Cowboys may have violated the league's salary cap rules. If guilty, the team could face multimillion-dollar fines and even the temporary loss of services of the three players involved in the dispute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, FRANCES (NEE HOLLANDER)
description: LEVIN-Frances (nee Hollander). Age 91, of Palm Beach, Florida and New Jersey died peacefully on April 6, 1999. Beloved wife of the late George and beloved mother of the late Richard. Grandmother of Carol Levin and Marjorie (Charles) Van Dercook. Greatgrandmother of Gina, George, Charlotte, Archie and Rebecca. Funeral services on Friday, April 9 at 11:00AM at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Forest Avenue, Paramus, New Jersey. Contributions in her memory can be made to the United Jewish Appeal or to the Richard Levin Research and Rehabilitation Foundation, One Longfellow Place, Box 1217, Boston, MA. 02114.

title: Clearing the Electronic Underbrush
description: MULTIMEDIA can lead to a multi-mess. All those perfect pictures of home entertainment centers never show the tangle of wires that make it all work or the piles of CD's and videos that have no home. A few choice investments can corral the clutter.

title: Treasury Issues Gain, With Yields Falling to 3-Week Lows
description: Treasury bond prices rose yesterday, and yields fell to three-week lows as traders took heart from statements by two Federal Reserve officials that inflation is at bay.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; Tender Perennials Add Color to Long, Hot Summers
description: GARDEN fashion is fickle. It used to be perennials versus annuals. Then it was pastels versus hot, read vulgar, colors. Now that beginning gardeners have learned what a rhizome is, and red and orange have been reborn as respectable garden colors, it's time for another category of plants to elbow its way into the garden.

title: Screen Decor: Adding Art
description: Q. How do I use a photograph as my computer desktop's background?

title: Lacking Ground Troops, General Seeks More in Air
description: NATO's senior military commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, said today that he wanted significantly more American and allied warplanes to intensify NATO's attack on Yugoslavia. The Pentagon assured him that he would get what he wanted.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Humorous Campaign For E*Trade Group
description: The first consumer brand campaign for E*Trade Group Inc., the on-line brokerage firm, from its new agency, Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, takes a sardonic tack to contrast investing on-line with traditional means of buying and selling securities.

title: Bombs Won't Make A Balkan Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: An Overcrowded Tent City 'Is Beautiful' to Many Just Arrived From Kosovo
description: The Hader family of Kosovo held a pathetic picnic today. They ground a plastic beach umbrella into a field of rubble, laid down their coats like blankets over the rocks and sat single file sharing their last bottle of water and their final, stale loaf of bread.

title: Internet Hide And Seek
description: He did his best to remain anonymous, but within days after an expert programmer released the Melissa computer virus into the world late last month, the police reported that his identity had been cracked. Investigators used a tracking mechanism the Microsoft Corporation had secretly installed in its Office software to gather information on its customers surreptitiously.
