title: Two Voices From the Past That Echo in Today's Bias
description: Among the treats of ''Writing New York,'' the new Library of America anthology edited by Phillip Lopate, are generous excerpts from a pair of remarkable 19th-century diaries that speak to us from a charmed distance in a sometimes uncharmingly immediate way.

title: Memory vs. Storage
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Card Solicitations Soared in 1998
description: Credit card issuers mailed a record 3.45 billion offers for plastic in 1998, a 15 percent jump from 1997, according to a new study.

title: Corrections
description: A summary yesterday of developments in the Kosovo crisis referred incorrectly to the projectile that NATO officials said had accidentally struck a residential area of the Serbian town of Aleksinac. It was a bomb, not a missile.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is not our home. But right now it is beautiful to us.''

title: Economic Scene: Limits of Economic Diplomacy; Modest Goals in Push to Bring China Into Trade Group
description: Trade officials from the United States and China are scrounging for a deal that would allow President Clinton and Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to announce today that the two countries have come to agreement on China's application to join the World Trade Organization. If the issue were narrowly about trade and economics, the two sides would probably have little trouble shaking hands.

title: The Premiere of a Koolhaas Fantasy
description: New York has served itself a little slice of architecture: the new Second Stage Theater on Eighth Avenue and 43d Street. Designed by Rem Koolhaas, the awesomely talented Dutch architect, in association with Richard Gluckman of New York, the 296-seat playhouse is an architectural hors d'oeuvre, really just a piece or two of sushi on a plate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZELIGA, LORETTA MICHEL FONDILLER POSTEK
description: SZELIGA-Loretta Michel Fondiller Postek. April 4, 1999. Beloved mother to Carol Berman of Venice, CA., and Judi Darnell of Atlanta, GA. Beloved grandmother to Amy, Christina, Traci. Beloved great-grandmother to Chelsey and Blaine and one on the way. Big sister to Evelyn, Anita, Ruthie and Bob. Predeceased by son Richard, husband Fundi, husband Stanley, and sister Doris. Former family counselor with Daytop, ex-editor of the Marine Workers Historical Society Newsletter, and lifelong activist for civil and human rights.

title: 4 Hartford Policemen Charged in Corruption Inquiry
description: State and Federal authorities arrested four current and former Hartford police officers today on charges that they used their badges and batons to force prostitutes to perform sex acts and pose for lewd photos.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Prosecutor Says Indictment of Austin Schools Will Help Deter Test Tampering
description: The county attorney in Austin, Tex., said today that indictments against the city's school district and a top administrator for manipulating statewide assessment tests scores were a hard but necessary measure to prevent tampering.

title: Kosovo Conflict Threatens Unity of Germany's Social Democrats
description: FRANKFURT  - Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder has been working to keep his Social Democratic Party united behind NATO's air strikes against Yugoslavia, but dissent on the issue has emerged inside his party in advance of a special party congress Monday.

title: Krone, 35, A Pioneer As Jockey, To Retire
description: Julie Krone, who started as a curiosity, became a champion jockey and then came back from a collapsed career to win her 3,500th race in February, is expected to announce her retirement today.

title: Immigrants Wanted
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Encourage China Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombs Won't Make A Balkan Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow and S.& P. 500 Set Records; Financial Shares Rally
description: The Dow Jones industrial average and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index set records yesterday, led by a rally in bank and brokerage stocks.

title: A Political Era Fades in Florida's Condos
description: Their accents have not faded, even after decades in the Florida sun. It has been years since they worked on the Newark docks, pressed shirts in Manhattan or argued with their delegate in a Brooklyn union hall, but passers-by can hear echoes of Flatbush in Sam's deli in Deerfield Beach, or the Bronx on a Broward County boardwalk.

title: Key to Music Deal Is E-Promotion
description: At first glance, the new joint Internet venture between Universal Music and BMG seems to be an effort to squeeze out the booming on-line music stores, like CDNow and Amazon.com. Indeed, the two big record companies yesterday introduced a site, Getmusic.com, that does compete with these sites by selling compact disks.

title: Sports of The Times; Ike's Tree Re-enlists as Augusta Hazard
description: OF the thousands of trees that decorate the Masters at Augusta National, it's the only one with a name: the Eisenhower Tree, or Ike's Tree.

title: CAPITAL AUTOMOTIVE REIT INCREASES PROPERTY HOLDINGS
description: Capital Automotive REIT, an owner of auto dealership property, acquired 22 properties in the first quarter for $88 million, expanding its holdings in five states. The company paid $84.2 million in cash and $3.8 million in operating partnership units for properties in California, Florida, New York, Ohio and Texas. Including the most recent purchases, Capital Automotive, of McLean, Va., has acquired $600 million in properties since its initial public offering in February 1998. It owns 142 properties with 215 automotive franchises in 19 states.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, THELMA
description: GOLDMAN-Thelma on April 5, 1999. Beloved sister of Frances Goldman, the late Birdye Grund and the late Arnold Goldman. Dear aunt of Rena, Fred, and Lee Berman, Pamela, Richard, Jessica and Bradley Weltman. Graveside service Friday 12:30pm at New Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ.

title: 9 Yugoslavs Are Warned Of Liability For Atrocities
description: The State Department warned nine Yugoslav commanders today that they faced possible prosecution for war crimes.

title: Bronx Suspect May Be Rapist Of 51 Women
description: A 38-year-old man who the police say may be responsible for the largest series of rapes in recent years has been arrested and charged in four of those attacks, the authorities said yesterday.

title: NATO to Allow Cypriot President Into Belgrade to Try to Fetch U.S. Soldiers
description: The Acting President of Cyprus has been given safe passage by NATO to fly to Belgrade on Thursday morning to try to bring home the three American soldiers who were captured by Serbian forces near the Kosovo border last week.

title: You Think Your Commute Is Bad? Try This
description: FOUR hours on an interstate being tailgated by hulking 18-wheelers, cut off by speed demons in red sports cars and surrounded by menacing sport utility vehicles with darkened windows is good preparation for Rollcage. This new driving game from Psygnosis, which was developed by a British company, Attention to Detail, is the latest in the gaming genre that uses the automobile as both a means of transportation and a means of destruction.

title: Campaigns are aiming at vacationers who might purchase a product linked with a happy time.
description: PROVING once again that nothing is sacred, not even vacation time, companies are zeroing in on those precious moments spent in sunny, snowy or neon-lit spots to market consumer products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONOUGH, THOMAS W.
description: McDONOUGH-Thomas W. Of New Canaan, CT on April 6, 1999. Beloved husband of Joan Marie McDonough. Loving father to Donough P. McDonough and Bridget S. Rudner. Adored grandfather of Tara, Lillian, Susanna, Quinn and Donough. Formerly a resident of Brooklyn, Garden City and Southold, NY. Former member of the New York Stock Exchange and the Buttonwood Club. His passion for life was surpassed only by his devotion to his family. A Memorial Mass will be held Friday, April 9, 1999 at 10:00 AM at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church, 40 Maple Street, New Canaan, CT. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Yale Organ Transplant Fund, Yale School of Medicine, 333 Cedar Street, New Haven, CT 06520.

title: Governing World Trade
description: The World Trade Organization, which is supposed to be the key element of an open and fair international trading system, faces major challenges just as it is on the verge of being leaderless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, FRANCES
description: KAYE-Frances. On April 7, 1999. Age 96. Beloved wife of the late Otto. Devoted mother of Morley & Mary Ellen, and Adley Bressner. Loving grandmother of Peter and Mary, Jon and Karen, Andrew & Keren, James and Jodi, & Amy & Jay. Cherished great-grandmother of Rachel, Emily, Matthew, Barrie, Amanda, Noah, Michelle, and Samara. Forever young at heart. A private graveside service.

title: Drug Survey of Children Finds That End of Grade School Is a Crucial Time
description: The first national drug-abuse survey to include elementary-school children among the respondents suggests that youngsters become more vulnerable to the lure of drugs once they leave the familiar environment of primary school and strive to fit into middle school.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a new project at the computer science laboratory of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology misspelled the surname of the laboratory's director. He is Michael L. Dertouzos, not Dertouzous.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Tea-leaf reader alert: Minutes of the Fed's policy-making sessions include some intriguing phrases.
description: THE minutes of the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the Federal Reserve, can be more illuminating than the cryptic utterances of the central bank's chairman, Alan Greenspan.

title: Fake News Account On Web Site Sends Stock Price Soaring
description: One of Wall Street's oldest frauds has been updated for the Internet age.

title: As Always, Please Touch
description: IT is hard to reconcile the quiet figure of Vito Acconci, aspiring architect, with the swath he has cut as an artist over the last 30 years. Can this kind-eyed 59-year-old, almost lost among the computer-aided design stations and unopened crates in his cavernous new Brooklyn studio, be the same man who, in his 1969 ''Following Piece,'' recorded a month of days spent stalking strangers through the streets of New York? Or who, in his infamous ''Seedbed'' installation of 1972, broadcast his erotic fantasies about gallery-goers to them as they walked above him on a plywood ramp and he indulged himself in privacy below?

title: In Vending Machine, Brains That Tell Good Money From Bad
description: IF you feed a dollar into a machine and it obstinately spits it back at you -- no matter how carefully you smooth away the tiny folds and wrinkles -- chances are you're nowhere near a Las Vegas, Nev., casino. In their ongoing efforts to separate fools from their money, casino operators have been among the first to adopt the latest bill validator technology.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the first 15 people awarded director's fellowships at the New York Public Library's new Center for Scholars and Writers misspelled one winner's surname. He is Howard Markel, not Market.

title: This Old Team: A Knick Eyesore
description: What happened to the Knicks here at the Charlotte Coliseum last night was not the culmination of a season headed toward oblivion. No, this franchise is in much worse trouble than that.

title: Red Norvo, 91, Effervescent Jazzman, Dies
description: Red Norvo, one of jazz's early vibraphonists and a gifted band leader whose groups greatly influenced American music and backed singers like Mildred Bailey, Billie Holiday and Frank Sinatra, died on Tuesday at a convalescent home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 91.

title: Microsoft Plans An Upgrade Of Windows 98
description: Microsoft will ship an upgraded version of Windows 98 next year because of delays in developing a consumer version of its Windows 2000 system, the company said today.

title: EARNINGS FOR FIRST QUARTER EXCEED EXPECTATIONS
description: Alcoa said yesterday that first-quarter earnings unexpectedly rose 5.3 percent as recent acquisitions helped it combat low metal prices with increased shipments and lower costs. Net income rose to $221.1 million from $209.9 million a year earlier. Profit fell to 60 cents a diluted share from 62 cents because the company issued stock to purchase Alumax Inc. in July, but it beat the 54-cent average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. Alcoa plans to trim a total of $1.1 billion from expenses through 2000, mainly by improving efficiency at acquired and existing plants. The shares rose $2.9375, to $44.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWABE, INA (REGINA) L. KAHN
description: SCHWABE-Ina (Regina) L. Kahn. Died peacefully April 5, 1999, after a long illness. Widow of Erwin S. Schwabe. Stepmother of the late Robert Schwabe. Mourned by her sister Helen D.K. Lessing, her nieces Joan C. Lessing and Pamela R.L. Friedman, her grandniece Elizabeth Lessing Friedman and her grandnephew Paul Lessing Friedman. Her memory will live on among the many friends she cultivated during a lifetime of almost eighty years during which she was involved in a wide variety of interests.

title: British Telecom Buys 20% Stake in Smartone
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that it had paid about $:240 million, or $383.2 million, for 20 percent of the Hong Kong mobile-telephone operator Smartone Telecommunications Holdings Ltd. The transaction has received all necessary approvals.

title: COGECO CABLE PLANS TO ACQUIRE CABLEWORKS OF ONTARIO
description: Cogeco Cable Inc., one of Canada's biggest cable-TV companies, said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Cableworks Communications Inc. for $162.5 million (Canadian), or $108.2 million (United States), to expand in Ontario, where Cableworks is based. The Montreal-based Cogeco Cable, a unit of Cogeco Inc., will buy Cableworks from Levfam Holdings Inc. As much as $27.5 million (Canadian) of the price may be paid in Cogeco Cable subordinate voting shares. The deal, which is subject to regulatory approval, would add 64,000 cable customers to Cogeco Cable's 800,000 in Ontario and Quebec.

title: Selling Space On Trash Cans
description: Advertisers looking to gain visibility on city streets will soon have another piece of so-called street furniture on which to advertise: municipal trash cans.

title: Jury at Conspiracy Trial Shown Flight 800 Seats
description: The twisted remains of four passenger seats from the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, which exploded and crashed off Long Island in 1996, were entered as evidence today in the trial of a couple charged with conspiring to steal parts of the wreckage to prove their theory that the jetliner was downed by an errant Navy missile.

title: NATO Bombing of Bridges in Yugoslavia Disrupts Trade on Europe-Asia Link
description: The bombing by NATO of bridges along the Danube in Yugoslavia has stranded scores of freighters from Budapest to the Black Sea and paralyzed shipments of oil, iron ore and farm goods to Western Europe.

title: A Bolder Annan Fears 'Genocide'
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan today put the United Nations firmly behind punishment for ethnic purges, declaring that ''impunity is unacceptable'' for such terrible violations of human rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIDZ, HARRY H.
description: LIDZ-Harry H., April 5, 1999, age 86. Veteran of Abraham Lincoln International Brigade 1937. He will be missed by his brother, Arthur; sister-in-law, Shirley; niece, Sandy, and nephew, Franz.

title: Disney and Miramax Collide Over Church Issues in New Film
description: In an embarrassment for Miramax Films, its owner, the Walt Disney Company, has termed a new Miramax movie ''inappropriate'' because of content involving Roman Catholics and said the film should not be released under a Disney label.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, PHILIP
description: McMAHON-Philip. The Soldiers', Sailors', Marines' and Airmen's Club are deeply saddened by the death of their esteemed colleague and Board Member, Philip McMahon, after a long illness. He was devoted to the SSMAC, and, in the 1980s, during the influx of women in our Military Services, was a prime mover along with Board Member, Pamela Cole, in the upgrading of quarters for the Club's Servicewomen guests. Philip was one of a kind. His boundless knowledge of fine arts and Far Eastern cultures led to encouragement by his friend, Alan Priest, legendary Curator of Far Eastern Antiquities for the Metropolitan Museum. While Philip's professional reputation for absolute integrity as a pioneer in the rarified world of fine arts appraising soon caused him to be sought after throughout the world, his forte was his enormous capacity for friendship-a trait that was the true measure of the man and which stood him in good stead throughout his lifetime. His friends today encompass all walks and ways of life, which made his association with SSMAC aptly representational. Friends may call from 5 PM to 7 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 81st St. and Madison Avenue, New York, on both Thursday and Friday, April 8 and April 9. Interment with final words will be held at 1 PM at the Obolensky family plot at the Rhinebeck, N.Y. Cemetery on Saturday, April 10th. In lieu of flowers, an offering is requested for the Abbey of Our Lady Melleray, 6500 Melleray Circle, Peosta, Iowa. You are already missed. R.I.P. Ivan Obolensky, President Soldiers', Sailors', Marines' and Airmen's Club

title: No More Easy Rides: Condo Boards Flex
description: NEW YORK CITY'S condominium boards, long known as bastions of liberality and laissez-faire, are getting tough. Some boards are even considering changing their bylaws so that they can reject buyers outright -- just as co-op boards do.

title: How to Encourage China Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITKIN, SHIRLEY
description: WITKIN-Shirley. The Board of Directors and staff of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center are deeply saddened by the passing of Shirley Witkin, a major supporter of our mission and member of our Society of Sponsors. Mrs. Witkin left a legacy of caring for all those touched by her extraordinary generosity. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Joseph Gurwin, President Alfred W. Levy, Chairman Herbert H. Friedman, Exec VP Stephen M. Levy, Director of External Affair

title: Essay; Meanwhile, in Israel . . .
description: ''Bring an end to the expulsions and the killing in Kosovo,'' says Foreign Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel, which has a field hospital in operation near the Macedonian border.

title: Arnold F. Habig, 91, Builder Of a Billion-Dollar Company
description: Arnold Francis Habig, who built a small Indiana woodworking shop into Kimball International Inc., died on March 29 at Memorial Hospital in Jasper, Ind., his birthplace and seat of the diversified billion-dollar company. He was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, MYRON (MIKE)
description: POSNER-Myron (Mike) of Cliffside Park, NJ. Beloved husband of Gladys. Devoted father of Donn, loving grandfather of Maxwell. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Englewood, NJ, Friday 11:30AM.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE PLUNGES. Gasoline prices plummeted after weekly inventory figures showed less-than-expected declines. In New York, unleaded gasoline for May delivery fell 3.17 cents, to 50.51 cents a gallon.

title: In Criminal Law, Motive Does Matter; Not a Deterrent
description: To the Editor:

title: Henderson Does It All For Mets
description: There is a sound this time of year that Rickey Henderson hears. It is the sound of a bell.

title: Honoring Victims of the Rwandan Blood Bath
description: The floor of the church is now covered with moss. The burned-out roof is open to the sky, and in a macabre memorial just down the hill, the corpses of people who died are now mummified, lying twisted on shelves, some with rosaries around their necks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFF, MARGARET V.
description: RAFF-Margaret V., on April 7, 1999, survived by brothers Herbert Kingman Raff of NYC, and Edson Duncan Raff of Garnett, Kansas and Bora Bora. Affiliated with American Red Cross and headed Brooklyn Chapter for many years. Services private. A memorial service will be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations to American Red Cross would be appreciated.

title: Sticks and Stones Can Hurt, but Bad Words Pay
description: DISPUTES over the content of words and Web sites are nothing new. These days, they usually involve people fighting to filter what children see on the Web, or other people fighting for their right to speak, print or send via computer any words they like. Now an Internet filtering company has added a new twist to the battle over what is banned: it is accusing another company of stealing its list of banned words and Web sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS (MARKOWITZ), ROBERT
description: MARKS (MARKOWITZ)-Robert. Of Stamford, CT. loving husband of Ricky Levine-Marks, died Saturday, April 3, of complications from Multiple Sclerosis. He is survived by two sons, Ross and Jonathan; his brother Jerry Markowitz; his sister Elayne Antis; two stepchildren, Carrie and Alex Levine; and a granddaughter, Lily. Memorial donations may be made to the Multiple Sclerosis Society, Western CT Chapter, One Selleck St., suite 500, Norwalk CT. 06855. Rest comfortably. You will be deeply missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGAN, JULIA (BURGEVIN)
description: EGAN-Julia (Burgevin). Died at Ponte Vedra Beach, FL on April 3. Interment April 24, 1:30 PM at Wiltwyck Cemetery, Kingston, NY.

title: Accessible via Modem, The Library of Congress
description: In 1990, James H. Billington, the Librarian of Congress, persuaded Congress to provide the first $1 million to start building a national library without walls.

title: Times Promotes Executive
description: Thomas E. Helling, group director for the corporate and financial advertising teams at The New York Times, was named vice president for advertising sales yesterday.

title: Ex-I.B.M. Executive Charged In Multimillion-Dollar Scheme
description: A former I.B.M. executive in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., man who bought discontinued computer parts were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges that they were part of a conspiracy to swindle the company out of at least $20 million worth of surplus computer equipment, including huge mainframe computers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELLERS, BROTHER JOHN
description: SELLERS-Brother John. Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation mourns with profound sadness, the loss of Brother John Sellers. His unique sound was an inspiration to Alvin Ailey and thousands of fans who enjoyed his singing both along side the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and and as a solo gospel and blues artist. Mr. Sellers' inimitably throaty voice, fascinating stories and wonderful sense of humor will be greatly missed by all the artists and staff who worked with him at the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANSEN, JAMES T.
description: HANSEN-James T. January 17, 1999, Moorestown, NJ. Survived by wife, Doris (nee Anderson), daughters, Heather Hansen Cornell, Laurel Hansen Trice, son, Gregory James Hansen, sister, Ingrid Johnson, ten grandchildren. WWII veteran, U.S. Navy, Guadalcanal Campaign. Photographer LOOK Magazine, 33 years. Taught photography Columbia School of Journalism. Picture Editor, M.D. Magazine and Religious News Service. Played soccer with Sporting Club GJOA, Brooklyn, NY. Authored The GJOA Years.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, WILLIAM J.
description: WHITE-William J., 71, of New Canaan, Conn., died Monday, April 5, after a long illness. He is survived by his wife, five children and eleven grandchildren.

title: As a Border Camp Is Broken Up, Refugees Are Scattered and Families Separated
description: It is clear that they left in a hurry. Abandoned belongings and plastic bags littered the ground. Baby food and even identification cards were dropped in the mud.

title: From Baptism of Fire to Kosovo: Clinton as Commander in Chief
description: Very few people outside of Baghdad remember the name of Layla al-Attar. But President Clinton does.

title: When Worlds, and Fears, Collide; Brookhaven Tries to Allay Concerns About Research
description: Out in the pine barrens of eastern Long Island, about an hour and a half from Manhattan if traveling by car -- or 0.0003 seconds if traveling at the speed of light -- an experiment is about to begin that will attempt to re-create the kind of primordial stew from which the universe is thought to have emerged.

title: Not 'Comedy Central,' but Livelier Than Statecraft
description: Facing his biggest diplomatic challenge as China's Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji arrived here today intent on surprising his hosts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWLAND, MALCOLM B.
description: ROWLAND-Malcolm B., 69, of Verona, NJ, on April 5. Graduate of The Hill School & Yale University '53, Lieutenant USN Civil Engineer Corps, principal engineer, Ebasco Services, Inc., New York City. Private memorial service on April 8. Survived by wife, Alaine T.; daughters, Emily T.R. Malone and Dr. Anne M. Rowland; a sister, three granddaughters, and four nieces. Contributions may be sent to The Point O'Woods Yacht Squadron, Point O'Woods, LI, NY 11706.

title: Retailer Doubles Slice Of British Mail Ordering
description: Otto Versand G.m.b.H., the world's largest mail-order retailer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Freemans catalogue retailer from Sears P.L.C. to double its market share in Britain.

title: An Auction for Friends of Faux
description: The bamboo, marble and stone to be auctioned next week are pure illusion. The auction benefits the Isabel O'Neil Studio, where students are taught 70 painted finishes. On Tuesday at 6 P.M., 150 objects, and furniture from 10 room settings by designers like Mariette Himes Gomez, Bunny Williams and Eric Cohler will go on the block. Mr. Cohler donated Angelo Donghia side chairs (left, estimated at $1,200 to $1,500 for the pair) that studio artisans painted in tortoise shell over gold leaf. Free viewing starts today at the New York Genealogical and Biographical Society, 124 East 58th Street. Tickets from $175 for the evening: (212) 348-4464.

title: Allies Fire at Missile Battery in Politically Shaky Republic
description: After a week without air attacks here, NATO warplanes fired on a Yugoslav Army missile battery in this tiny Yugoslav republic on Tuesday night.

title: Bombs Won't Make A Balkan Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Milstein Withdraws Redskin Offer
description: Howard Milstein withdrew his group's debt-laden, $803 million offer to buy the Washington Redskins from the estate of Jack Kent Cooke today, after three months of occasionally contentious wrangling with the National Football League.

title: Everyone's a Skeptic
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the future of the state-owned Apollo Theater misstated the involvement of Time Warner Inc. Pataki administration officials said only that the company would play a major role in revitalizing it; company officials said there was no decision on the specifics of the involvement. The state officials did not say they were seeking to have Time Warner take over the theater's management.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPKO, STAN
description: POPKO-Stan. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member Stan Popko. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: A PC for $25.99 a Month, And All the Miles Are Free
description: In the spirit of the information superhighway metaphor, it seems only fitting that, as with automobiles, it is getting increasingly easy to lease computers rather than buy them outright.

title: If These Walls Could Speak (and They Will)
description: FEW outsiders were ever allowed into the private world of Renzo Mongiardino. Friends and family perhaps, or an associate or two, would join the legendary interior designer quietly, for long evening talks or small dinners at his richly moody apartment in Milan. Otherwise, Mr. Mongiardino, who died last year at 81, lived a life of scholarly solitude, surrounded by books, busts and brocades, attended only by an elderly and singularly uncommunicative Sicilian housekeeper, who sat in the kitchen, a stern figure in penitential black, silently darning the maestro's socks.

title: When Finesse Means More Than a Maneuver in Cards
description: George Rapee, who died at his Florida home a week ago at 83, was one of the great figures in the game for more than 60 years. He won three world titles, and for the period in which he was most active, 1942-80, he had the best record of success in major team championships, with six Spingold Team victories, eight Vanderbilt Teams and seven Board-a-Match Teams.

title: The Titanic's Mystique in Digital Packages
description: JAMES CAMERON'S TITANIC EXPLORER

title: 1,000 Deloitte Consultants Form Company
description: The Big Five accounting firms may be too successful at what was once a secondary business: consulting.

title: Mitsubishi Is Reported in Deal With Mazda
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, Japan's fourth-largest auto maker, will form a business alliance with the Mazda Motor Corporation, an affiliate of the Ford Motor Company, the newspaper Nihon Keizai reported today.

title: Don't Look to Russia for Help on Kosovo
description: The Clinton Administration was right to reject Slobodan Milosevic's cease-fire proposal -- entering into negotiations now with Serbia, which has largely achieved its military goals in Kosovo before NATO has achieved much of anything, would be an admission of defeat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONNEGRA, CARMEN
description: FONNEGRA-Carmen. On April 3, 1999 at the New York Hospital. Retired from Mobil Oil Company. Long time volunteer at St. Patrick's Cathedral. A requiem mass will be celebrated at Our Lady's Chapel, St. Patrick's Cathedral, on Friday, April 9 at 10:15 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Duking It Out
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Sprewell Comfortable in Confusion
description: It was an odd coping mechanism. There was Latrell Sprewell, surrounded by a ring of despondent figures in the locker room, and he started reciting logic and lines that seemed to be lifted from the musical ''Annie.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, LEONARD J.
description: MARX-Leonard J. April 7, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth Kahn Marx, dear father of Jane Moss, cherished grandfather of Jon and Maggie, loving brother of Josephine Luria. Funeral service Friday April 9, 1999, 11AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Interment will follow at Easton Cemetery, Easton, PA. Contributions in his memory made be made to Central Synagogue or the New York Public Library.

title: E.D.S. Executive Shuffle
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the second-biggest United States computer-services company, named Troy W. Todd, 70, as executive vice president in charge of improving employee performance. The appointment, announced today, comes less than two weeks after two executives resigned and analysts speculated that the company's chief executive, Richard Brown, would dismiss top executives under a cost-cutting plan. Mr. Todd, a former United Telecommunications Inc. human resources executive, is charged with returning E.D.S. to a ''performance-based culture,'' a spokeswoman, Diane Coffman, said.

title: After Flopping Twice, What Will Rangers Do?
description: Last night's game between the Rangers and the Chicago Blackhawks matched Original Six teams. Both franchises represent major television markets that are important to the National Hockey League. Both will miss the Stanley Cup playoffs for the second consecutive season.

title: Norway Oil Producer To Sell Some Assets
description: Saga Petroleum of Norway said yesterday that it intended to sell up to 2 billion Norwegian kroner ($257 million) of nonstrategic assets as part of its reorganization program. The assets to be sold include Saga's 14 percent stake in Block 1 offshore Angola, which the company is in the process of putting up for sale.

title: Corrections
description: A music review and a picture caption in Weekend last Friday about Andras Schiff's piano recital at Carnegie Hall on March 29 included an erroneous identification supplied by his management for his instrument. It was a Hamburg Steinway, not a Fabbrini. (Angelo Fabbrini is not a manufacturer but a master technician who worked extensively on the instrument, which Mr. Schiff brought from Italy for the concert.)

title: 'Immediacies of the Hand' -- Recent Abstract Painting in New York
description: Times Square Gallery

title: Police Politesse
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's effort to create a more polite police force deserves less of the sophisticated cynicism that we enjoy so much in New York City and more celebration about the civilizing possibilities. As Dennis Walcott of the New York Urban League has been saying for some time, good police manners could do for community relations what fixing broken windows does for crime rates. Just as mending windows and pursuing small infractions appears to keep down serious crime, so small courtesies between police and public might yield better community relations on a deeper level.

title: A Very Charming Guest (Too Bad About the Lincoln Bedroom Thing)
description: China's Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji, charmed his dinner audience tonight with his knowledge of American history and his candor, drawing applause when he recited part of the Gettysburg Address and smiles at his honesty in complaining that his legs fell asleep as he stood in the lengthy receiving line.

title: H. Robert Marschalk, 83, Ex-Drug Company Head
description: H. Robert Marschalk, who rose from a salesman for the Vicks Chemical Company to president and later vice chairman of its successor, the Richardson-Merrell Drug Company, died Sunday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 83 and had prostate cancer, said a spokesman for Philip Morris, where Mr. Marschalk was a director for 20 years.

title: Residential Real Estate; Furniture Center Converts to Luxury Apartments
description: After nearly 70 years as a showplace for fine furniture and antiques, the wedding-cake-style structure at 305 East 63d Street is being reborn as the neighborhood's newest luxury rental apartment building.

title: Americana? Philadelphia, Of Course
description: As American antiques go, it is hard to think of anything more famous than the Liberty Bell. So it's not surprising that the annual antiques show in Philadelphia, home of the bell and cradle of liberty, has exceptional examples of Americana.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a form of autism called Asperger's syndrome misstated the name of a branch of the National Institutes of Health that has collected data on the condition. It is the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, not Child Health and Mental Development.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Chinese Treasures

title: Negotiate With a Dictator?; Missing Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Daniel J. Martinez and Peter Rostovsky
description: The Project

title: Sports of The Times; For the Paraguay Pro, Par at the Masters
description: WITH birdies on the third and fourth holes, his name went up early on the Masters leader boards, but it was a new name.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA DROPS. Cocoa prices fell to a five-year low as Ghana began selling beans it will harvest next month, adding to already brimming global supplies. In New York, cocoa for May delivery fell $55 a metric ton, to $1,079.

title: Darlene Geis, 81, Author and Editor
description: Darlene Geis, an author and editor, died on March 25 in a fire at her home in Manhattan. She was 81.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBER, HARRY D.
description: SILBER-Harry D. Age 81. Of Tamarac, FL and Kew Garden Hills, Queens. Died April 5, 1999. Beloved husband of Lucille. Loving father of Michelle Cohen, Gail and Sheldon Silber. Cherished grandfather of Michael and Deborah Cohen. Mr. Silber was born in Brooklyn where he attended Yeshiva Chaim Berlin. He served in the Army Air Corp during WWII. He developed and owned the Butterfield Market in Manhattan, invested in real estate and devoted most of his time to his family and work. He was a spiritual man who donated to many religious causes. He leaves behind a brother Sam and two sisters, Mollie Greenberg and Miriam Harris. Memorial services will be held today, April 9th, at 1 P.M., at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York. Interment follows at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, New York. He will be missed by his family.

title: Graduation Is the Best Revenge
description: What does it say about ''Never Been Kissed,'' the latest and dumbest in the deluge of high school comedies from Hollywood, that the most despised nerd in the senior class, a girl who is humiliated at the prom by having dog food poured down the back of her dress, is better looking than the actual prom queen or any of her attendants? That nerd, Aldys (Leelee Sobieski), who leads a high school math team, is not much of a role. But Ms. Sobieski lends the character about the only dignity to be found in this bogus, bottom-of-the-barrel Cinderella story.

title: Suspect in Arson Attack Is Arrested in the Bronx
description: After a seven-week search, the police arrested a man yesterday who they say repeatedly stabbed an elderly woman in her Harlem apartment, then lit a fire to cover up his crime.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ABU, HAKIMA, AHMAD MUSTAFA
description: ABU-HAKIMA-Ahmad Mustafa. Professor, scholar, historian and world authority on Eastern Arabia, born August 28, 1923, in Abbasiyya, Palestine, died April 9, 1998, in Ottawa, Canada. A truly contented man, wherever he traversed he brought optimism and love to the lives of many, many people around the world. Always remembered in our hearts, thoughts and prayers. Family and Friends

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, IRVING S.
description: COHEN-Irving S. May 6, 1928 to April 9, 1996. Third Year in Heaven. To lose a loved one is hard to bear but death can never take away the love, memories, joy we share. They are ours forever. Your wife, Mary, children, grandchildren

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about a tribute to Johnny Cash at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Tuesday misidentified the composer of ''Ring of Fire,'' sung at the tribute by June Carter Cash. It was by Mrs. Cash and Merle Kilgore, not by Mr. Cash.

title: Heaping Portions
description: Some people like dainty little bits of food, artfully arranged and presented. For others, only plates heaped high will do. Here are a dozen places to go for huge portions. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Cross at Green? No. In Between.; Only a Few Jaywalkers Are Getting Tickets, or Qualms
description: On Eighth Avenue, during afternoon rush hour, they stride four abreast in traffic lanes as if marching in a parade, then cross en masse on the diagonal, mid-block, to stream into the Port Authority Bus Terminal.

title: Denver's Hispanic Residents Point to Ills of the Uninsured
description: Erica Aguilar, a Mexican-American born in Denver, is 21 years old and has three children, ages 4, 2 and 8 months. The children have Medicaid, and for them she uses the city's La Casa Family Health Center.

title: Police Profiling Debate Hinges on Issue of Experience vs. Bias
description: The police consider it a crucial crime-fighting tool based on street savvy. Critics contend it is a potentially fatal weapon that betrays deep institutional racism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODZELEWSKI, STELLA
description: MODZELEWSKI - Stella. The Leadership of Continuum Health Partners, Inc. and its HospitalsBeth Israel Medical Center, St Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center and Long Island College Hospitalnote with sadness the passing of Stella Modzelewski, beloved mother of our dear friend and colleague, Donald Modzelewski, V.P. for Reimbursement and Budget. To Don, his entire family, and all of his mother's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Robert G. Newman, M.D., President and CEO Thomas J. Hayes, Executive Vice President and CFO

title: Capitol Hill Is a Barrier To China Goal
description: To complete the process of bringing China into the global trading system, the Clinton Administration must not only resolve the outstanding economic issues between the two countries but must also persuade Congress to amend a trade law that lumps China with a group of pariah nations.

title: The Clothes That Made The Woman and Man
description: The Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art did not build one of the world's greatest collections of Western dress by sitting on its hands. It went out and shopped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPKO, STANLEY C.
description: POPKO-Stanley C. On April 6, 1999 (Stanart Studio). Beloved brother of Eleanor Gallina. Dearest uncle of Chad and Christopher Gallina. Reposing at the William F. Coster Funeral Home, Route 25, Cutchogue, NY, this evening from 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. Graveside funeral service Saturday, 11 a.m., at First Presbyterian Church Cemetery, Route 25, Southold, NY. Memorials may be sent to VNSNY Hospice Care, 41-61 Kissena Blvd, Flushing, NY 11355.

title: Whitman Plans Senate Race, Starting Fund-Raising Effort
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey said today that she planned to run for the United States Senate next year, raising the prospect of a rematch with the man she ousted from the statehouse six years ago, Jim Florio.

title: Love, Honor and Duty In Codified Old Castille
description: When Chimene slips into her mourning clothes in Declan Donnellan's revelatory new production of ''Le Cid,'' it is not an anonymous servant who dresses her. It is the man for whom she grieves, her father, Don Gomes, slain in a duel with her lover, who helps her off with her undergarments and on with her black shoes and dress.

title: Police Officer in Orange, N.J., Is Shot to Death as She Confronts Robbery Suspect
description: A police officer in Orange, N.J., was fatally shot last night by a man she was trying to question about an armed robbery, the authorities said. The officer, Joyce Carnegie, 38, was shot in the head and abdomen about 8:30 P.M. and died an hour later.

title: China's Prime Minister Denies Secrets Were Stolen
description: Spicing his denials with humor and compliments to his American hosts, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji asserted today that China had never stolen nuclear secrets from the United States.

title: Class Size Can Attract Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, HON. DANIEL J.
description: SULLIVAN-Hon. Daniel J. Acting Supreme Court Justice (Ret.), Bronx County, 72, Beloved husband of the late Susan. Cherished father of Susan, Daniel, James, Richard, and David. Loving fatherin-law. Adoring grandfather of 12. Friends may visit Friday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM, at the New Hyde Park Funeral Home, 506 Lakeville Road, New Hyde Park, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 11 AM, at Maria Regina R.C. Church, Seaford, NY. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONNEGRA, CARMEN
description: FONNEGRA-Carmen. On April 3, 1999 at the New York Hospital. Retired from Mobil Oil Company. Long time volunteer at St. Patrick's Cathedral. A requiem mass will be celebrated at Our Lady's Chapel, St. Patrick's Cathedral, on Friday, April 9 at 10:15 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Prince Naseem Hamed Sets Out With a New Trainer
description: Prince Naseem Hamed, the flamboyant featherweight, makes his 1999 debut tomorrow night in a 12-round World Boxing Organization title bout against Paul Ingle in Manchester, England. And for the first time in his career, Brendan Ingle won't be in his corner.

title: BELGRADE ASSERTS 'PEACE' IN KOSOVO; NATO DISMISSING IT
description: The Yugoslav Government asserted today that ''peace has been restored in Kosovo,'' declared an end to its military offensive and urged all refugees to return home while new political arrangements are negotiated for the province. NATO dismissed the statements and said its bombing campaign would continue.

title: Behind the Big Shift on Windows
description: Microsoft's decision not to blend its consumer and business Windows operating systems into a single product reflects profound changes in the consumer personal computer marketplace that have surprised both the software giant and its partner, Intel.

title: A Monster in the Lake Or Just a Cuddly Blue Guy?
description: Doug's First Movie

title: N.H.L.: ROUNDUP
description: BLACKHAWKS 6, RANGERS 2

title: Gladys Hasty Carroll, 94, Maine Novelist
description: Gladys Hasty Carroll, a novelist who wrote about the rural Maine of her childhood, died last Thursday at a hospital in York, Me. She was 94 and lived in South Berwick, Me.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, CLARA
description: HELLER-Clara. The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists mourns the passing of Clara Heller, long time member, devoted colleague, cherished friend and widow of George Heller, one of AFTRA's founding fathers and the union's Executive Secretary from 1946 to 1955.

title: Nets Upbeat Despite Loss
description: After a 96-92 loss to Philadelphia on Wednesday ended the Nets' four-game winning streak, New Jersey's Kendall Gill scanned a near-empty locker room with satisfaction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEANEY, THOMAS B.
description: HEANEY-Thomas B. On April 8, 1999 of Manhasset, NY. General Manager of Deepdale Golf Club. Beloved husband of Mary E.. Loving father of Stephanie, Scott and Shawn. Devoted grandfather of 9. Brother of Margaret, James and Robert. In repose at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Friday 3-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:45AM, St. Marys R.C. Church, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Cancer Society.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: NATIONWIDE MUTUAL INSURANCE CO., Columbus, Ohio, named Galen R. Barnes president and chief operating officer, succeeding Richard D. Crabtree, who retired. Mr. Barnes had been president and chief operating officer of the company's Nationwide Insurance Enterprise unit.

title: Auschwitz Survivor in Belgrade Now Fears NATO
description: Aca Singer, who lost 65 members of his family in the Holocaust, says he didn't survive Auschwitz to die from an American bomb.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE POUND GAINS. A cut in a key interest rate by the Bank of England spurred the pound's biggest gain against the dollar in three months. In New York, the pound settled at $1.6049, up from $1.5959.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The first Chez Louis, David Liederman's East Side homage to the Paris bistro L'Ami Louis, opened in 1985 and closed in the 1991 recession, which wiped out dozens of New York restaurants. Now Mr. Liederman, he of David's Cookies, has opened a new Chez Louis in Rockefeller Center, and it's as if the eight-year hiatus never happened.

title: In the Mass Misery, One Family's Ordeal
description: The Bllaca family was dining on pasta and beans when the masked Serbian policemen kicked in the kitchen door of their home in Kosovo, jamming the butt of a rifle into Mehdi Bllaca's head.

title: Class Size Can Attract Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRCKHEAD, SALLY KING
description: BIRCKHEAD-Sally King. Retired singer and actress. Beloved sister of Olivia Fogarty, Francesca Shakespeare and Godfrey Birckhead. Died early Thursday morning, March 25th. Burial services will be held at St. Mary's church, Portsmith, Rhode Island, Saturday April 17, 2pm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSTWICK, ALLAN M.
description: BOSTWICK-Allan M. It is with sadness that the many friends and family of Allan Bostwick mourn his passing on April 7. Funeral services at 9:30 AM, Friday, April 9, 1999, at Temple Sinai, 131 Washington Ave., Lawrence, LI. Contributions to Temple Sinai.

title: Parallels Drawn Between the Vietnam War and Attacks on Serbs
description: It is now an official relic of the Vietnam war: a ragged chunk of an American B-52 bomber, with landing gear still attached, poking up from the surface of a small pond in the center of Hanoi.

title: CAP GEMINI IS ACQUIRING BEECHWOOD FOR $200 MILLION
description: The French computer services company Cap Gemini S.A. said yesterday that it was acquiring Beechwood Inc., a telecommunications-software maker in Clark, N.J., for about $200 million. Cap Gemini said the company would be combined with its United States telecommunications division and would be led by Ron Ponder, the chief executive of Beechwood. Beechwood, which helps phone companies manage the capacity of their networks, route calls and offer services like video conferencing, was created in 1988 and has 400 employees.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: A Downsized Neo-Pimpernel

title: Iraq Rejects Panels' Efforts to End Impasse on Security Council
description: Iraq has angrily rejected the recommendations of three special panels that have tried to find a solution to the diplomatic impasse over Iraq on the Security Council.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Circular Firing Squad
description: Boy, I sure hope the Clinton team loses this war in Kosovo, because if it wins, there will be no one to pick up the Nobel Peace Prize. If I read The Washington Post, New York Times and Wall Street Journal correctly, everyone in this Administration has already blamed everyone else in this Administration for failure in Kosovo.

title: Rebels in Mexico Retake a Town Hall Seized by Police
description: The Zapatista rebels, in a bold challenge to the Government, sent more than 1,000 unarmed followers today to retake the town hall in an Indian village in Chiapas State only one day after they were ousted from the building by the state police.

title: A One-Man Confrontation Band, Loudly
description: If that's Michael Moore coming at you, beware. Once the man gets his prey in his lens, there's no shaking him off. As confirmed by ''The Awful Truth,'' his new series of half-hour agitations, he is insistent, persistent and far beyond embarrassment.

title: Gillian Jagger and Charles Sargeant Jagger
description: Phyllis Kind Gallery

title: On My Mind; Do We Understand?
description: Do Americans understand that while we have been bombing the Serbs, the following took place:

title: No Guantanamo Airlift
description: Bowing to pressure from refugee groups and aid organizations, the Clinton Administration suspended plans to airlift Kosovo refugees from Macedonia to the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Instead the United States will build barracks for them in Albania.

title: CRESCENT PLANNING TO SELL $500 MILLION OF PROPERTIES
description: Crescent Real Estate Equities Inc., led by the investor Richard Rainwater, plans to sell $500 million to $650 million of its office properties this year, according to company documents. Crescent, a real estate investment trust, has 9 to 12 potential assets marketed as a package to a limited group of buyers, according to a copy of a slide show presentation the company is making to analysts and investors. The copy was posted on the company's Web site. The company has been meeting with analysts and investors to provide details on how it plans to raise its shares, which are down 39 percent in the last year.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Are you asking me to tell you the truth? To tell you the truth, I was really reluctant to come.''

title: Why Is Belgrade a Target?
description: The world's democracies have a responsibility to relieve the suffering of the people of Kosovo, to insure that the refugees can return to an autonomous nation and to help rebuild the province and prosecute war criminals. That is why I voted my support for President Clinton's initiatives and for the use of American soldiers in keeping the peace in the region.

title: Until the Erotic Encounter With the Rat, It Was Cool
description: Francois Ozon's exquisitely unsettling ''See the Sea'' was one of the high points at last year's New Directors/New Films series. Now Mr. Ozon returns with a black comedy that means to be no less disturbing than his expert thriller. But ''Sitcom,'' which is sardonically filmed with the snappy look of a television comedy, has a sour streak that eventually poisons its humor. Mr. Ozon pushed the limits of shock value much more effectively with the carefully measured violence of ''See the Sea'' than he does with this frontal assault.

title: Tenet Healthcare Stock Up 21% Despite Drop in Quarterly Profit
description: Shares of the Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the nation's No. 2 hospital chain, rose 21.2 percent today after it told investors its operations were improving despite a drop in its fiscal third-quarter profit.

title: Racing's Tiny Giant Reaches the Finish Line
description: At a glance, one might think she's still a schoolgirl, still the small high school kid who began racing 20 years ago at age 15 on Michigan state and county fair tracks near her Benton Harbor home, and who grew up to be the best female jockey ever and, yes, one of the best jockeys, period, of our time.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today for Orthodox Good Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Negotiate With a Dictator?; Another Hitler
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDENBAUM, MELANIE
description: LINDENBAUM-Melanie. On April 7, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Markus. Loving mother of George and Susan. Devoted grandmother of David Lindenbaum, Josh and Gary Walden. Great grandmother of Aaron, Marcel and Michelle. Dear aunt of Alice Green. Service Friday 1:00 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Distracting Detours in the Hunt for a Final Exit
description: EAST OF THE MOUNTAINS

title: Europeans Cut Key Rate More Than Foreseen
description: Confronted with an economic slowdown over much of the Continent, the European Central Bank surprised almost everyone today by reducing interest rates to one of the lowest levels European nations have ever seen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAWAMURA, SHIGEKUNI
description: KAWAMURA-Shigekuni. It is with deep sorrow that we note the passing of our dear friend, Shigekuni Kawamura. He was a faithful supporter of the Institute, on whose Board of Trustees he served for ten years. He will be remembered for his belief in the value of international exchange and for his commitment to creating a borderless world for knowledge-sharing. He will be greatly missed. Henry Kaufman, Chairman, Board of Trustees, Allan Goodman, President, Institute of International Education

title: Another Journey Up and Downstairs
description: Imagine a world so bizarre that nannies are hired without even meeting the children, much less getting their approval, a place so exotic that a lady can cover her infidelity by pretending she is going to the theater to see Sarah Bernhardt.

title: Hershiser's Met Deubt Is Spoiled By Expos
description: It was difficult to tell what cost the Mets more tonight: Orel Hershiser's inconsistency on the mound or the Mets' uncharacteristic inability to field the ball behind him.

title: Bidding Under Way For Polish Bank
description: Unicredito Italiano S.p.A., Italy's third-biggest bank, said yesterday that it and the German insurer Allianz A.G. were bidding for a 52 percent stake in Bank Pekao S.A., Poland's No. 1 bank by assets, which the Government is selling.

title: Mrs. Whitman Looks to the Senate
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey is planning to run for the Senate in 2000. Her announcement that she is setting up a fund-raising committee is as positive a declaration of candidacy as is seemly from a sitting Governor who must convince voters she intends to stay focused on the state's business for the next year and a half.

title: Court Calls For Evidence, Not Politics
description: The president of the Yugoslav war crimes tribunal has sent letters to all NATO foreign ministers asking them to provide the court with all the information they have of war crimes in Kosovo.

title: Record of the Week
description: VINICIUS CANTUARIA: ''TUCUMA'' -- (Verve/Polygram). The distance between the late 1950's bossa nova tracks by Joao Gilberto and Vinicius Cantuaria's new record, ''Tucuma,'' is wide, but connected by a thread of inward seriousnes. Mr. Cantuaria, a composer, singer and guitarist from Brazil now relocated in New York, has made a remarkable second American release, one that's highly conscious of its roots in bossa nova while being an utterly post-modern marvel of production and song structure.

title: Panel Drafts Rules for Human Embryo Study
description: Federally financed scientists who wish to study human embryonic stem cells, the primordial cells from which the body develops, came a step closer to their goal today as a panel of biologists and lawyers drafted guidelines under which the research may go ahead.

title: At Long Last, Aaron Basks and the Fans Just Love It
description: The dual pursuit of Roger Maris's home run record last year created so much good feeling among the fans and the hitters chasing it that Henry Aaron watched with envy.

title: CISCO AGREES TO PAY $445 MILLION FOR TWO COMPANIES
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the No. 1 network-equipment maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Fibex Systems and Sentient Networks Inc. for $445 million in stock to acquire products that add voice services to data networks. Cisco plans to acquire the closely held companies in two separate transactions. The acquisitions may help Cisco win sales from telephone companies, which are looking for ways to add traditional voice features to new data networks. Shares of Cisco fell $1.125, to $117.625.

title: Offensive Linemen Are the Priority
description: With the National Football League draft just over a week away, Giants General Manager Ernie Accorsi is not eager to tip his hand. But unless someone presents an offer that can't be refused, Accorsi will wait to use the team's first-round pick, No. 19 over all, on an offensive lineman in a draft filled with glamorous quarterbacks.

title: Pulp Friction, With Drugs, Energy and Attitude
description: Borrowing truckloads of inspiration from ''Pulp Fiction,'' Doug Liman's ''Go'' has three interrelated sections. It begins and ends at the same time and place, turns a banal spot into its central setting (supermarket instead of coffee shop), flirts with drugs and violence and lets its characters riff amusingly on assorted trivia, in the manner of ''le Big Mac.'' But derivative as it is, ''Go'' has a powerful personality of its own.

title: Bottled Water's Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Bayer Plans to Invest $4.4 Billion in Asia
description: Bayer A.G. said yesterday that it planned to invest about $4.4 billion in Asia in the next 10 years as it continues its expansion outside Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANENBAUM, STANLEY
description: TANENBAUM-Stanley. Age 77. Of NYC and South Egremont, Mass. Died on Monday, March 29, 1999 after being hit by a car while cycling in the Berkshires. If friends so desire, memorial donations may be sent to the Berkshire Humane Society, C/O Finnerty and Stevens Funeral Home, 426 Main Street, Great Barrington, Mass. 01230.

title: Judge Says Record Libel Case Should Be Retried
description: The case that resulted in the largest libel verdict in history was tainted by the deception of the plaintiffs, a Federal district judge said yesterday. He said that the case, which pitted a Texas brokerage firm against The Wall Street Journal's parent company, should be retried.

title: Citizens' Summons to Make the Police Less Fearsome
description: This is a 30-second commercial that is being broadcast on New York City television stations to promote a rally scheduled for Thursday in protest of New York City Police Department practices. It is being produced by New Yorkers for Law, Order, Peace and Justice, a coalition formed in the wake of the Amadou Diallo shooting, with money raised from labor unions, Democratic political leaders and black business leaders.

title: G.E. Reports 14% Increase In First-Quarter Earnings
description: The General Electric Company said today that its first-quarter earnings rose 14 percent as it took more profit from sales hurt by low prices for some of its products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERRY, RANDY
description: TERRY-Randy. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Friar Randy Terry on April 7th. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Services will be held on Friday, April 9th. 12:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St., and Amsterdam Avenue. (212) 362-6600 Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot Executive Director

title: Was Milstein Judged By Millions or Manner?
description: Howard Milstein will not say if he is frustrated or incensed at the National Football League for erecting the obstacles that forced him to withdraw his application to buy the Washington Redskins for $800 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WIENER, GABE M.
description: WIENER-Gabe M. Our beloved Gabe, not a day passes that we don't think of you and miss you. You will always be in our hearts and your music plays on forever. We love you. M, D, & J

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDENBERG, BEATRICE
description: SEIDENBERG-Beatrice. April 7 We mourn the loss of our beautiful sister Bea and ''Aunt Bebe''. You will be in our hearts forever. The Brief and Maltz families

title: Pentagon Says Yugoslav Army Is Now Cut Off
description: Providing the first details of damage to support their claim that the 16-day bombardment is taking a steep toll, Pentagon officials said today that NATO's air campaign had effectively cut fuel and ammunition supply lines to the 40,000 Yugoslav Army troops and police fighting in Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, GRAENUM
description: BERGER-Graenum. The Graenum Berger Bronx Jewish Federation Service Center expresses its profound sorrow upon the passing of Graenum Berger, one of our founders. He returned his soul to his Maker after more than fifty years of distinguished and dedicated labor of love for the Jewish community. He personified and fulfilled the fundamental Jewish teaching that the purpose of our sojourn on earth is to serve and enable others. His commitment to chesed and tzedakah for his Jewish brethren in need through compassion, undaunting effort and excellence will continue to inspire and serve as a role model. May the Al-mighty comfort his life's partner and beloved wife, Emma, son, Michael and the entire family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and spare them further sorrow. David Roth, Chairman Asher Moskowitz, Director

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Streep's 4 Reasons To Shun Y2K Baby

title: Mayor Weighs Whether Police Helped Safir In Private Suit
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is looking into reports that two police detectives were sent to the home of a woman who was involved in a car accident with the wife of Police Commissioner Howard Safir, city officials said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Weill's Daughter to Lead Start-Up Finance Company

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UTILICORP UNITED INC., Kansas City, Mo., an international electric and gas company, said it would take its $43.2 million offer for Aquila Gas Pipeline, San Antonio, a natural-gas company, directly to shareholders because it was unable to reach an agreement with Aquila's management.

title: Weapons That Protect
description: To the Editor:

title: Antarctica: As Gorgeous and Deadly Today as Ever
description: Standing astern of Shackleton's whaleboat while watching computer-generated waves play across movie screens off her bows, I could almost feel the sting of freezing brine thrown up by the mountainous Cape Horn rollers.

title: 2 Are Charged in Murder Of Rap Artist in Queens
description: Two men have been arrested and charged with the murder last month of Freaky Tah, a popular rap performer from Jamaica, Queens, the police said yesterday.

title: Sealed Borders Bring NATO New Problems
description: President Slobodan Milosevic's unexpected decision to seal Kosovo's border to fleeing refugees took NATO by surprise, and officials say they are now struggling to deal with the consequences.

title: Patients Have a Right to Choose Their Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Serbs Fortify As Location Of Refugees Is a Mystery
description: Serbian forces were positioning tanks and artillery along the Kosovo border today, just one day after tens of thousands of refugees vanished when the Serbs turned their convoys back from the border.

title: Gucci Says No To New Offer From LVMH
description: Gucci Group N.V. rejected a sweetened takeover offer today from LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the French luxury-goods company, intensifying one of Europe's most bitter takeover battles.

title: I Brake for Iambic Pentameter
description: POETRY doesn't sell many cars, not even bad ad copy doggerel. This month, though, Volkswagen is using cars to sell poetry.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: It's Not the Usual Menage a Trois
description: However many films you may have seen, you probably haven't seen anything like ''Twin Falls Idaho'' on screen. One of the most eerily effective films at the New Directors/ New Films festival this year, it takes the real-life closeness of the identical twins Michael and Mark Polish into the realm of haunting fantasy. These arrestingly gaunt, watchful-looking brothers star in the film as conjoined twins, Blake (Mark) and Francis (Michael) Falls, whose delicately balanced interdependence provides a rare brand of tension.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day on April 2 about earnings for the European company Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux referred imprecisely to its business. It is a provider of energy, water, waste-disposal and communications services. It is not primarily a trash hauler.

title: For Three Tied for Lead, the Azaleas Are in Bloom
description: The first round of the Masters was everything that Brandel Chamblee imagined, everything that Scott McCarron hoped for, everything that an experienced major winner like Davis Love 3d expected.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Impersonal War On the Adriatic
description: As night falls over the Adriatic Sea, a matter-of-fact voice summons a few hands to the combat room of this warship. A bank of monitors light up. A course is plotted, a button pushed. Thirty seconds later, a flame lights the sky and a Tomahawk missile, barely seen, streaks eastward.

title: A Mix and Match Of Treasures
description: If jazz has been about one thing over the last 100 years, it has been about transformation. Jazz musicians changed the sound of European instruments to reflect the needs of the new environment. They transformed staid melodies and songs, making them hop with the heat of improvisation. And jazz's endless revision of standard pop harmony created a new way of thinking about chords, one based on the idea of replacing the old and simple with the new and complex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBERMAN, HILDA ZIRN
description: LIBERMAN-Hilda Zirn, April 5, 1999. Dear wife of Melville Liberman. Loving mother of Stuart Z. Liberman. Loving grandmother of Tracy and Cari-Anne Liberman. Dear sister of Ruth Manshel. She will always remain in our memory with love. Service private.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Beijing Delays Trial Of Man Who Urged Greater Democracy
description: Chinese officials have postponed the trial of a democracy advocate, which was scheduled to start this week, after the United States Embassy here urged them to drop or postpone the case.

title: RYDER SYSTEM SAYS IT IS LOOKING FOR A NEW PRESIDENT
description: Ryder System Inc., the nation's largest truck-leasing company, said yesterday that it was looking for a new president and chief operating officer, two days after it warned that first-quarter earnings would be lower than expected. M. Anthony Burns will relinquish the title of president after Ryder, based in Miami, finds a replacement, a Ryder spokesman said. Mr. Burns will remain chairman and chief executive. Ryder said on Tuesday that it expected per-share earnings of 30 cents to 35 cents, less than the estimate of 36 cents in a survey of eight analysts by the First Call Corporation before the warning. Ryder earned 50 cents a share in the quarter a year earlier.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: High in the Polls and Close to Home, Bush Navigates by the Center Line
description: Ask Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the early favorite for the Republican Presidential nomination, about the prickliest issues of the day, and his carefully wrapped responses are those of the ultimate Rorschach politician: voters can see what they want to see.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about an Easter service on the South Rim of the Grand Canyon misspelled the name of the area. It is Mather Point, not Maher Point. The area is named for Stephen T. Mather, founder and first director of the National Park Service.

title: Barbara Bloom -- 'The French Diplomat's Office'
description: Peter Blum

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, BERNARD
description: STEIN-Bernard on April 8, 1999 of Hartsdale, NY. Beloved father of Barbara and Zachary, bestfriend and loving companion of Ellen Koch, cherished father-in-law of Gene Tullio and Vicky Stein, devoted grandfather of Marcie, Lizzie, Randi, Peter and Justin. He will be greatly missed by his friends and family. Services are private.

title: Disney Combines a Book Unit With ABC in Reorganization
description: Moving to exploit the synergy of books, entertainment and news, the Walt Disney Company restructured its publishing group yesterday by combining its adult book division, Hyperion, with the ABC network.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Still Bringing Out the Animal, and Animals
description: ONCE was a time the circus came to town and the children followed it dancing, but these days the children are more likely to be given coloring books by the animal rights people that feature a circus elephant weeping, and the trainer might be singled out on a Web site for abuse. This drives Gunther Gebel-Williams, the legendary animal trainer, nominally retired, nuts.

title: Town Relocating to Escape Jet Noise
description: When Louisville International Airport opened the first of two new parallel runways four years ago, residents of this town five miles away were offered a chance to escape the new waves of noise.

title: Agents Say 3 Sold Viagra Without Prescriptions
description: Three men were arraigned yesterday on Federal charges that they illegally sold the drug Viagra without a prescription to undercover agents at two businesses in midtown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, EDWARD P., K.M.
description: LYONS-Edward P., K.M., of John's Island, Vero Beach, FL, and Greenwich, CT. Retired Vice Chairman of the Olin Corporation, passed away on Thursday, April 8, at his home. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Whyte Lyons, and five children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELMAN, MILTON
description: GELMAN-Milton. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to his wife, Evelyn, our Trustee, and the family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd. Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, JAMES
description: CLARK-James. Of Palm Beach died on April 7, 1999. He is survived by his wife Irma and his children Susan and Harlan Ellis, Terry and David Brooks and Shelly Clark. Grandfather of Robert, Carl, Julia, victoria, Andrew and Elizabeth and sister Hilda Gertler. Service Sunday 10AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The 75-Year Plan
description: The economy is growing. Inflation is well under control. The budget is moving into surplus. And this economic strength has shrunk the Social Security deficit. Now is the time to close it completely.

title: Read All About It: Testimony Omitted From Microsoft Trial
description: The judge trying the antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation is likely to find himself in the unusual position later this month of reading articles about testimony in the trial that has not yet been heard in court.

title: A New Strain On the Cost Of Health Care; Latest Medical Devices Bring Bigger Bills
description: Managed health care plans and the Medicare program have had some success slowing growth in spending for doctors, hospitals and home care agencies. But managed care has been much less successful reining in spending on new life-enhancing medical devices and procedures.

title: The Missing Refugees
description: After weeks of terrorizing ethnic Albanians and forcing them out of Kosovo, Serbian forces are now apparently yanking them back. They have closed and mined the borders with Macedonia and Albania. Two nights ago, perhaps 80,000 refugees waiting to get into Albania simply vanished, forcibly turned around by Serbian troops and pushed back into Kosovo. The same may have happened to some 10,000 refugees on the Macedonian border. No one knows where all these people are and how they are being treated. NATO must find out as soon as it can, and warn Belgrade not to abuse them.

title: ONEX IN $271 MILLION CASH DEAL FOR AMERICAN BUILDINGS
description: The Onex Corporation, the world's largest maker of in-flight meals, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the American Buildings Company for $271 million in cash to expand its portfolio of companies. Onex, which includes a sugar refinery and an auto-parts company among its holdings, said it would pay $36 a share, a 65 percent premium to American Buildings' closing price on Wednesday. American Buildings, based in Eufaula, Ala., makes metal building frames and roofing, and had 1998 sales of $440.7 million. Its shares rose $13.0625, to $34.9375. Shares of Onex rose $1 (Canadian), to $55.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISER, MOSES
description: WEISER-Moses. The Board of Directors of Congregation Chasam Sopher express their deep sorrow over the loss of their President, Moses Weiser, who was the soul of the shul. A beloved, scholarly man who promised to devote his life to the religious needs of his people, if he survived the Holocaust, fulfilled that commitment by decades of unheralded service to the Congregation. His contribution will be memorialized when the annex to the synagogue is completed. The new building will bear his name for eternity. The entire Jewish community has lost a great man who in his own quiet manner gave so much to so many in honor of the memory of the six million who did not survive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOARE, GEORGE P. JR. ESQ.
description: HOARE-George P. Jr. Esq. Of Short Hills, N.J. on Tuesday, April 6, 1999. Husband of Marie O'Reilly Hoare. Father of Ms. Kathleen H. Thompson, George P. Hoare, III, Ms. Marie Therese Kennedy and Ms. Anne Nassar. Son of Aurora R. Hoare. Brother of Dr. Raymond Hoare, Dr. Anne Koons and Ms. Aurora Hoare. Also survived by 4 grandchildren. Funeral Mass in St. Rose of Lima Church, 50 Short Hills Ave., Short Hills, Saturday, April 10 at 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, E. Hanover. Friends may call at Smith and Smith, 415 Morris Ave. Springfield, NJ, Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Heart Association, 2550 Rt. 1, North Brunswick, New Jersey 08902-4301.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Humana Finds That the Going Gets Tougher
description: Resurrecting concerns about whether managed care companies do much real managing, starting with their own businesses, Humana Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit would come in well below forecasts.

title: Sam Shaw, 87, Film Producer and Photographer
description: Sam Shaw, a film producer and photojournalist famous for his photographs of Marilyn Monroe standing over a subway grate with her skirt billowing, died on Monday at a hospital in Westwood, N.J. He was 87 and lived in Tappan, N.Y.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Jewish Children Near and Far

title: Delusions Of a Failed Bohemian
description: Based on an obviously early novel by Julian Barnes, ''Metroland'' assails its hero's bourgeois family life in a London suburb. From the film's standpoint, Chris Lloyd (Christian Bale) has sold out and abandoned his dreams. He is aggressively reminded of that by the arrival of his best friend (Lee Ross), who spells his name Toni, writes poetry, boasts about sexual conquests and roams the world. One of Toni's postcards: ''Africa's where it's happening. Vibrant culture. Great people. Thinking of hanging out here for a while. Eat the rich. Love, Toni.''

title: Jurors Begin Deliberating Contempt Case Against Susan McDougal
description: A Federal jury of six men and six women began deliberating today whether Susan H. McDougal is guilty of criminal contempt and obstruction of justice for refusing to talk to a grand jury about the Arkansas financial dealings of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: American in Accord With Flight Attendants
description: American Airlines, the nation's second-largest airline, said today that it had reached an agreement with its flight attendants' union on the integration of Reno Air Inc., the low-fare carrier that American bought last year.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series.
