Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 13.

title: Badge May Earn A Shot at the Derby
description: He is named for a song Eric Clapton wrote more than 30 years ago, but should favored Badge win tomorrow's $600,000 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, his connections may be humming a different tune -- say, one composed by Stephen Foster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYNG, LILA HOTZ
description: TYNG-Lila Hotz. The staff, children and families of Berkshire Farm Center and Services for Youth join our Board of Directors in expressing our sorrow on the passing of Lila Tyng. She was a Board member from 1949-1985 and is still remembered by staff and Berkshire alumni for her immeasurable contributions to children and families. Thousands of people came to know Berkshire's work through her efforts as Benefit Chair and many remain part of the Berkshire community today. Our deepest condolences go to the entire family. Rose W. Washington, Executive Director

title: SUNY Faculty Leaders Say Faith in Trustees Is Gone
description: Saying the trustees have failed in their responsibilities, faculty leaders at the State University of New York are calling on colleagues to sign a no-confidence declaration and for the board of trustees to be replaced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOCKLEY, MARY
description: SHOCKLEY-Mary. On April 8, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Charles Linwood Shockley. Devoted mother of Robert. Interment today at St. Michael's Cemetery.

title: European Interest Rate Cut Sends U.S. Gauges to Records
description: Europeans cut interest rates yesterday, igniting stock markets in midsession here, and all three major market gauges climbed more than 1 percent to new records.

title: Rebels in Kosovo Reported Hard Hit, but Still Fighting
description: Guerrillas of the Kosovo Liberation Army, who have been waging a war of independence for the Serbian province, told foreign diplomats today that they have been hit hard and that Serbian forces have pushed them into the hills.

title: Class Size Can Attract Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Shimla Journal; A Tale of 2 Lovers, and a Taboo Recklessly Flouted
description: Their love was forbidden, and for three years they furtively indulged it, meeting in the wheat fields at the village's edge. Desh Raj was 23, Nirmala 17. The end of their lives began on March 27, the day they eloped.

title: The White House and China
description: Differences between Washington and Beijing over human rights, Kosovo and Chinese admission to the World Trade Organization were already casting a shadow over this week's visit to America by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China. Then came a new report yesterday that China may have stolen neutron bomb secrets from the United States during Mr. Clinton's first term. Earlier accounts said China had stolen design information about other American nuclear warheads a decade ago.

title: Accounts
description: BankAmerica Corp., Charlotte, N.C., to TN Media, New York, a unit of True North Communications, to handle media duties on its account, with billings estimated at $80 million to $100 million. Those duties had been handled by GSD&M, Austin, Tex., part of Omnicom Group, before BankAmerica merged with Nationsbank to form the new BankAmerica Corp.; TN Media had handled media duties for Nationsbank before the merger. Two TN siblings, Bozell Worldwide, New York, and Temerlin McClain, Irving, Tex., handle the creative duties on the account.

title: On Kawara -- 'I Read'
description: David Zwirner

title: In Greek, Latin, Whatever, The Tragedies Speak to All
description: Ah, the life of the Off Off Broadway critic! Rushing off to see ''Hamlet'' performed by Czech puppets. Or a white South African woman discussing apartheid while posing nude. Or an Asian-American musical about railroad labor and detention camps. (These are real examples, by the way.) Or most recently, four hours of Greek tragedy on East Fourth Street, in the original Greek.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORTEL, LUCILLE
description: LORTEL-Lucille. The Department of Ophthalmology remembers with love and great affection Lucille Lortel, not only a patron of theatre and the arts, but also a patron of mankind. D. Jackson Coleman, M.D. Chairman Department of Ophthalmology New York-Cornell

title: Where Literary Legends Took Shape Around Boston
description: Last week, on a crisp, cloudless afternoon, I stood in a forest clearing on a rise above Walden Pond, just at the spot outside Concord, Mass., where Henry David Thoreau built the cabin in which he lived from July 1845 to September 1847. For a few splendid minutes, I had the place all to myself. I could look at things as Thoreau did when he explored the thicket of ideas about self-reliance and spiritual immanence that he later shaped into ''Walden,'' one of the great works of American transcendentalism.

title: Diallo's Tale Raises the Bar For Refugees
description: IN death, Amadou Diallo has become an important symbol on several fronts, but one is not much to brag about. He was -- and there is really no polite way to say it -- an immigration cheat. When you talk to immigration lawyers, you realize that in filing a fraudulent claim to political asylum, he did no favor for foreigners genuinely in need of a haven from oppression.

title: BELL ATLANTIC ORDERS $1.8 BILLION IN EQUIPMENT
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that it had ordered $1.8 billion in phone equipment from Alcatel S.A. and Northern Telecom Ltd., as it expands the capacity of its network to handle data communications. Bell Atlantic, based in New York, is buying $600 million of so-called digital-loop carriers, which combine residential and business phone traffic at high speeds, from each company over five years. It is also spending $400 million on phone switches from Nortel and $200 million on equipment from Alcatel to increase the capacity of its existing copper lines. Shares of Northern Telecom rose $8.125, to $76. Alcatel's shares climbed 87.5 cents, to $24.875. Bell Atlantic shares were up $1.4375 at $55.1875.

title: NATO's Generals and Civilians Clash Over Bombing TV
description: NATO's military leaders vowed today to bomb state-controlled Serbian television off the air, leading to a public clash with the alliance's civilian officials, who have not granted the generals the authority to strike the television targets.

title: Negotiate With a Dictator?; Pipe Dream of a Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: A Devoted Soul Takes an Obsessive Turn
description: A maid servant devoted to her mistress in a provincial French town finds solace in her drab existence with a pet parrot. As her employers die off, cumulative loss deals the maid a final blow: the parrot expires as well.

title: John Hartwell, 83, Retired Head Of Financial Management Concern
description: John M. Hartwell, an investment counselor and mutual fund manager, died April 2 in New York City, his wife, Sheila, said. He was 83.

title: ITS MARKET SHARE DOWN, OCEAN SPRAY WILL CUT 100 JOBS
description: Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc., the largest producer of canned and bottled juices, said yesterday that it would cut about 5 percent of its work force, or 100 workers, because its market share had declined and cranberry prices had fallen. All the cuts will be at the headquarters in Lakeville, Mass., where the staff will be reduced by 15 percent, said a spokesman, Chris Phillips. Ocean Spray, a cooperative of cranberry and grapefruit growers that employs 2,000 workers, will also reorganize its operations. Ocean Spray's share of the cranberry-juice market declined to 60 percent from 70 percent over the last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLAVIN, JEFFREY
description: SLAVIN-Jeffrey. With deep sadness, we extend our sympathy to our dear friends Goldie and Barry and their children Pamela, Michelle and Jamie on the untimely and tragic loss of their beloved son and loving brother, Jeffrey. Susan and Paul Beck and Family

title: Laidlaw Plans To Cut Jobs
description: Laidlaw Inc., the biggest North American maker of ambulances and school and intercity buses, said today that it was cutting 2,200 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, because of lower revenue from ambulances.

title: Mary Kelly -- 'Mea Culpa'
description: Postmasters

title: With History on Yanks' Left, Pitching Tilts Right
description: The greatest Yankee teams have had great left-handed pitching since the opening of Yankee Stadium in 1923. David Cone, a right-hander, will take the mound today in the team's home opener against Detroit.

title: Dickson Concepts to Repurchase Assets
description: Dickson Poon, chairman of Dickson Concepts International Ltd. of Hong Kong, offered to personally buy control of the luxury retailer's assets outside Asia, including Harvey Nichols P.L.C. of Britain and ST Dupont of France, for $1.53 billion (Hong Kong).

title: Bottoms Up To Illusions
description: The silence is so taut that it hurts. It descends around 11 P.M. at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, the resounding soundlessness of a crowd of hundreds scarcely daring to breathe, much less cough or whisper or unwrap one of those notorious lozenges.

title: Negotiate With a Dictator?; Selective Outrage
description: To the Editor:

title: Parcells Weighs Quarterback Plans
description: Coach Bill Parcells surfaced yesterday after a 36-day reprieve from the news media, looking fit with his personal weight-lifting regimen but still juggling an entire Jets team.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: 'Le Cid,' in Brooklyn
description: Declan Donnellan's revelatory new production of ''Le Cid'' opened Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, with Sarah Karbasnikoff and William Nadylam, above, as the passionate lovers and with the action relocated to mid-20th-century Spain.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the arrest of a suspect in rapes in the Bronx, upper Manhattan and Mount Vernon referred incorrectly in some copies to a Bronx pawnshop where the police said he had tried to sell stolen jewelry. It is Citi Pawn Brokers at 341A East 149th Street, not New York Pawnbrokers at 301 East 149th Street.

title: Potential Successor Is at Ease in the Center
description: ''Do I want to be governor?'' Donald T. DiFrancesco asked today at his district office here. ''Every legislator wants to be governor.''

title: 9 Men Plead Guilty to Slaughtering Cormorants to Protect Sport Fishing
description: Nine men from sport-fishing communities along the eastern shore of Lake Ontario pleaded guilty yesterday to charges stemming from the shotgun slayings of more than 1,000 federally protected birds last summer, prosecutors said.

title: MacManus Acquires Sherry Group
description: MacManus Group in New York said yesterday that it had acquired Sherry Group, a public relations agency in Parsippany, N.J., whose clients include Federal Express, Jansport and Marriott. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Abbott's Profits Climb by 13% Despite Drop in Some Drug Sales
description: Abbott Laboratories, one of the nation's largest makers of pharmaceuticals and medical tests, said today that its first-quarter profit rose 13 percent as higher sales of medical equipment helped offset a decline in sales of some drugs.

title: TV Ad to Promote Rally on Police Takes Ominous Tone
description: In an unusually ambitious effort to publicize a political rally, organizers of a protest against the New York City Police Department started a television campaign yesterday that invokes alleged misdeeds by the department.

title: Georgia, Judging That Most Judges Shouldn't, Readies Replacements
description: In one of the most sweeping attacks on corruption in the former Soviet Union, most of Georgia's judges are to be forcibly retired next month and replaced by new ones chosen by competitive examination.

title: DNA Evidence Links Rape Suspect to 17 Attacks in Region, Authorities Say
description: DNA evidence has linked a Bronx man to 17 rapes in the Bronx, upper Manhattan and Westchester County, police officials said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: A Shift at Microsoft

title: Bellinger Will Take the Good News
description: Clay Bellinger was summoned into the office of the Yankees' interim manager, Don Zimmer, last weekend, suspecting that, after 10 years in the minor leagues, he would finally be told he was going to the big leagues.

title: New Video Releases
description: A Soldier's Daughter Never Cries

title: Europeans, Facing Sluggish Economy, Cut Interest to 2.5%
description: Confronted with an economic slowdown over much of Europe, the European Central Bank surprised almost everyone yesterday by reducing interest rates to one of the lowest levels Europe has ever seen.

title: U.S.-CHINA TALKS FAIL TO PRODUCE MAJOR TRADE DEAL
description: President Clinton and China's Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji, fell short today of reaching a major trade deal that China has long sought, even though the two leaders said they made significant progress in negotiations to usher China into the organization that sets the rules for global commerce.

title: Negotiate With a Dictator?
description: To the Editor:

title: Head Selected for S.& P.
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies has appointed Leo C. O'Neill to the new position of president of its Standard & Poor's division.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Cable Maker Unhappy With Takeover Proposal
description: BICC Group P.L.C., the world's No. 3 cable maker, said yesterday that a revised takeover proposal by Wassall P.L.C. still failed to reflect the company's value.

title: Gasoline Prices Likely to Peak in May
description: Gasoline pump prices should peak for the year in May after a gain in crude oil prices and a series of refinery problems on the West Coast, the Department of Energy said this week.

title: The Blue Grass Draws Closely Matched Field
description: The 75th running of the Blue Grass Stakes, the Eastern finals for the Kentucky Derby, drew one of its most closely matched fields today when eight colts were entered led by Wondertross, Vicar and Cat Thief.

title: Conspicuous Consumption, Baroque Style: Flaunting the Power and the Glory
description: When Antonio Cardinal Barberini died in Rome in 1671, his art collection, hauled from one family palace to another, included 116 cartloads of paintings and 91 cartloads of sculptures, medals, busts, figurines and pedestals, along with a large harp. Conspicuous consumption was the rule of princely and papal life in 17th-century Rome, where everything from the intricate folding of dinner napkins to the construction of vast outdoor squares was meant to display the power of power.

title: Judge Likely to Keep Verdict Against Gun Makers
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that he was inclined to uphold a precedent-setting verdict in which a jury found that 15 gun makers were negligent and 3 of them had to pay damages in a case in which a Queens teen-ager was shot and severely wounded with an illegally obtained handgun.

title: Cadillac signs a long-term accord for signs in Times Square.
description: THE automotive brand promoted as the standard of the world is taking a long-term parking space in the neighborhood promoted as the crossroads of the world.

title: Daughter of Citigroup Chief To Lead a Financial Start-Up
description: Two years ago, Wall Street was stunned when Jessica M. Bibliowicz, daughter of the financier Sanford I. Weill, abruptly quit her father's company after clashing with James Dimon, her boss and a man widely seen as Mr. Weill's heir apparent. To some, it seemed as if Mr. Weill was favoring a man he viewed like a son over his own daughter.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Who Chopped Down the Cherry Trees? Not the Usual Suspect
description: Eating a leisurely picnic lunch today under a canopy of Washington's famous cherry blossoms, Mark Taylor suddenly snapped to attention. Out there. In the Tidal Basin. Splashing around. There he was: the beaver.

title: Sunny Skies Bring Sunny Moods, Again
description: Sunlight gleamed off the water in the fountain in Bryant Park. The weather was unusually warm for April and Lilu Wilis, sitting nearby, was of good cheer. ''I came here to get a tan and to get splashed,'' said Ms. Wilis, a 23-year-old assistant office manager. ''It's just beautiful!''

title: At a Hospital, Uncertainty As Succession Plans Change
description: The executive who was expected to become the next head of New York Presbyterian Hospital may not get the job after all, and a nationwide search is likely to find a new leader for the health care giant, several doctors and hospital officials said.

title: An Embattled Albright Tries To Fend Off Her Critics
description: Madeleine K. Albright's limousine left her Georgetown house just after 7 this morning to take her to a State Department building where her colleagues are torn between their admiration for her principled stand against a dictator and their remorse over the human repercussions of the Kosovo conflict.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSH, GEORGE E. SR.
description: BUSH-George E. Sr. On April 7, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Mary A. (nee Conway). Loving father of Dr. George E. Jr., Virginia M. Reidy and the late Dr. John S. Grandfather of seven and greatgrandfather of seven. In 1981 Mr. Bush married Margaret Mulhill who predeceased him. Mr. Bush, a lifelong parishioner of Holy Name, served the church in several ministries. Visiting Friday, 2-5 and 79PM at M.J. Smith Sons, 248 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 11AM at Holy Name RC Church.

title: Kerry James Marshall
description: Jack Shainman Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEECE, DONALD
description: TEECE-Donald. Of Mahwah, NJ. On April 7, 1999 (Hospital Administration Memorial Sloan-Kettering). Husband of Penelope. Father of Andrew, Douglas, Christina and Kathryn. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Visiting Higgins Funeral Home, 321 South Main St., New City, NY, Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Memorial services Saturday, 10:30 AM, at New City Methodist Church, New City, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, LESTER
description: LYONS-Lester. Beloved husband of the late Helen, devoted father of Judith and George, cherished grandfather of Amber, dear sonin-law of the late May and Rabbi Israel H. Levinthal. Services Sunday at Beth-El Synagogue of New Rochelle, Northfield Rd at North Ave., New Rochelle. For further information call I.J. Morris Inc. 1-800624-8282

title: Art and Courage Forged in a Cauldron of Adversity
description: Frank Hurley was 28 in 1914 when he shipped out as a photographer on Sir Ernest Shackleton's expedition to cross Antarctica. Hurley had been to Antarctica already. Three years earlier he had gone with his compatriot Douglas Mawson, the Australian explorer, and the film he made about Mawson's trip was one of the things that got Shackleton interested in having his own trip filmed and photographed.

title: British Airways Will Close Base in Queens
description: British Airways, one of the largest employers in Queens, plans to shut its American headquarters at the former Bulova watch building near La Guardia Airport -- a move that union officials fear will result in the loss of hundreds of jobs.

title: Recipe Calls for Flour, but This Hash Is Far From the Kitchen
description: Running on a dirt trail through Inwood Hill Park in upper Manhattan I vaulted over a fallen oak. Landing in front of a puddle, quickly side-stepped it like a running back eluding a tackler, wondering as I did whether I was lost. Scanning the woods as I ran, I spotted a clump of white flour, a beacon amid the mottled carpet of fallen leaves. I was back on track.

title: Shoppers Beat U.S. Retailers' Expectations
description: Retail sales surged in March, exceeding expectations for the sixth consecutive month, figures released today showed. Consumers apparently pushed the economy to grow faster in the first quarter than earlier estimated.

title: Don't Hide the Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Customs Service Will Review Drug-Search Process for Bias
description: Faced with complaints that black and Hispanic people are unfairly singled out for searches at airports and border crossings, the United States Customs Service created an independent panel today to study how customs inspectors look for drug smugglers.

title: 'Talbot's Friends and Relations'
description: Hans P. Kraus Jr. Fine Photographs

title: Nippon Steel Seeking Partner for Alliance
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation, the world's second-largest steelmaker, may team up with other steelmakers to cut costs, said its president, Akira Chihaya. ''Within our steel divisions, in areas where fixed costs are obviously too high, we're looking at forming alliances with companies with similar operations,'' he said.

title: Graham Gillmore
description: Linda Kirkland Gallery

title: Class Size Can Attract Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Patients Have a Right to Choose Their Doctors; Chichikov's List
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Myhrum, 72, Director of Children's TV
description: Robert Myhrum, an Emmy-nominated director who worked in children's television, died last Friday while vacationing on his boat in Boca Grande, Fla. He was 72 and had homes in Manhattan and Peru, Vt.

title: U.S. Plans Refugee Barracks in Albania and Drops Airlift
description: Bowing to pressure from refugee groups and aid organizations, the Clinton Administration has suspended plans for an airlift of Kosovo refugees from Macedonia to the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Instead the United States will build barracks for them in Albania, according to Administration officials.

title: Sports of The Times; For Grunfeld, Future Rides On Knicks
description: IF the bleeding doesn't soon stop, Ernie Grunfeld surely knows where this is going because he has already been there, eight years ago, in one of those fancy sky boxes atop Madison Square Garden.

title: Devils Clinch the Division Title, But Any Celebration Is on Hold
description: The Devils clinched their third straight Atlantic Division title tonight with a 1-0 victory over the Washington Capitals, becoming the first team to take a third straight crown since the Philadelphia Flyers 12 years ago.

title: Edward Tripp, 79, Creator Of New York Encylopedia, Dies
description: Edward Tripp, who served as editor in chief at Yale University Press for 13 years, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Franklin, N.C. He was 79.

title: 'Star Wars': The Conditions
description: They're counting the days here.

title: All Tangos, Played, Danced and Sung
description: The composer Astor Piazzolla, who died in 1992, was engaged in a difficult stylistic balancing act. He took South American tango music -- the traditional, gritty, erotic tango, not the tidy, playful equivalent you encounter in American ballroom dancing -- and infused it with elements of classical music and jazz. The idea was to turn the dance into something musically elaborate without losing its authenticity.

title: ABC Plans a Cable Channel To Repeat Its 4 Soap Operas
description: In the second move this week that pitted the interests of a broadcast network against those of its affiliated stations, ABC announced yesterday that it would create a 24-hour soap opera cable channel. The decision means that for the first time in broadcast history, a network's entertainment programs will be repeated on a different channel in the same day.

title: Negotiate With a Dictator?; World War II Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Don't Buy A Used Car From Either Of Them
description: Joe Carnahan's maniacally frenzied little film, ''Blood, Guts, Bullets and Octane'' is set in the desert wasteland around Needles, Calif., where Sid (Mr. Carnahan) and his partner Bob (Dan Leis), two motor-mouthed used-car salesmen, are desperately trying to keep their failing business afloat. Just when they are about to throw in the towel, their sleazy broker hands them an opportunity to make $250,000 simply by letting a 1963 Pontiac LeMans sit in their lot for 48 hours.

title: Lawyer Likens the Melissa Virus to Graffiti
description: The 30-year-old computer programmer accused of creating the fastest-spreading computer virus in history made his first appearance in court today, and afterward his lawyer suggested that whoever wrote the virus should be considered a sort of graffiti artist rather than ''an international cyberterrorist.''

title: Brooklyn Man Faces Racketeering Charges
description: A Brooklyn man who was acquitted of murder but convicted of weapons possession in the highly publicized killing of a black teen-ager 10 years ago was charged yesterday with racketeering and other crimes that prosecutors said he has committed more recently as an associate of organized crime.

title: Reed Elsevier Talks Reported
description: Shares in Reed Elsevier P.L.C.'s two parent companies rose following a report that a rival, Wolters Kluwer N.V., is discussing a merger with the British-Dutch publisher, which has failed to find a new chief executive.

title: Walking? Beware the Male Driver
description: SAFETY experts have always known that although male and female drivers have roughly equal numbers of car crashes per mile driven, men are 70 percent more likely to be driving in a crash when someone is killed. But that statistic lumps the fatalities together, whether the victim is the driver, a passenger, a person in another vehicle or someone on the street.

title: Harvey to Sell Stake
description: The Harvey Entertainment Company, which owns the rights to animated characters like Casper and Richie Rich, said today that an investment group led by Roger Burlage had bought a controlling stake for $17 million in cash and stock. Mr. Burlage, the former chairman of Live Entertainment Inc., will be named chief executive. Harvey will issue series A convertible preferred shares and warrants in exchange for $11.5 million in cash and $5.5 million common shares of the Kushner-Locke Company, a film and television concern. The company also said today that it had a fourth-quarter loss of $5.87 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on April 2 about New York City bridges referred incorrectly to High Bridge, between the Bronx and Manhattan at 174th Street, which opened in 1842 as an aqueduct carrying water from the Croton Dam. It no longer serves that purpose; the last time water ran through its pipes was in the mid-1950's.

title: Ethnic Slaughter In Bosnian War
description: The father addresses his daughter, a young woman named Vera, who is holding her newborn. ''You should have killed yourself,'' he says.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: PRISONERS

title: Walker Is Named With 14 Others
description: Herschel Walker, an outstanding running back at the University of Georgia and later in the United States Football League and the National Football League, was named yesterday to the College Football Hall of Fame.

title: Denmark's Central Bank Cuts Key Interest Rates
description: Nationalbanken, the Danish central bank, cut its key money-market lending rate yesterday by half a percentage point, to 2.90 percent. The decision followed the European Central Bank's half-percentage-point reduction on Thursday in its refinancing rate to 2.50 percent.

title: Smaller Classes Are Just the Beginning
description: To the Editor:

title: Dresdner Bank Profit Jumps 55% for Year
description: Dresdner Bank A.G. said yesterday that 1998 net income rose 55 percent as a result of lower taxes, and it forecast higher operating profit for this year as it cuts costs and reduces its exposure to developing regions. The bank's net income rose to 1.858 billion marks ($1.02 billion) last year as its tax bill fell to 758 million marks from 1.612 billion in 1997. Pretax profit was battered by the cost of covering bad loans in regions like Russia and Asia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, HELEN E.
description: PETERS-Helen E. Formerly residing on West 12th Street, New York, NY. Died on April 8, 1999. Requiem Mass at St. Bernard's RC Church, 328 West 14 St. NY, NY, 10:00 AM, Tuesday, April 13.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Thursday about an on-line tutorial for Microsoft's Back Office Server 4.0 gave a date incorrectly in paraphrasing a comment from Kevin Breunig, group product manager for the program. He said the tutorial was written in 1997, not 1987.

title: Smaller Classes Are Just the Beginning
description: To the Editor:

title: China to Allow U.N. Rights Investigation
description: A United Nations investigator said today that China had agreed to allow him to examine allegations of torture in China.

title: Germany Reports Rise In Consumer Prices
description: German consumer prices rose in March, increasing the annual inflation rate for the first time in 18 months, as rising wages led to an increase in the cost of rent and telecommunications. Prices rose a tenth of 1 percent in the month and four-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier, the Government said yesterday.

title: Sun Healthcare Is Hit Hard By Medicare Payment Cuts
description: Reeling from severe cuts in Medicare payments for elderly nursing home patients, Sun Healthcare Group yesterday reported heavy losses for the fourth quarter and all of 1998.

title: Storms and Twisters Ravage the Middle West
description: A line of powerful storms and devastating tornadoes has swept across the Midwest the last two days, killing six people, injuring dozens of others and leaving a swath of damage hundreds of miles long.

title: Olympic Champion Settles Dispute With Her Father
description: The bitter dispute between the Olympic gymnast Dominique Moceanu and her father, Dumitru, which touched off a criminal investigation by the Houston police and led to an order of protection against the father, has apparently been settled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, LEONARD J.
description: MARX-Leonard J. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Leonard Marx. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Martin I. Klein, President

title: Wheelchair Game At Alumni Hall
description: St. John's will be host to the 23d annual Wheelchair Basketball Classic to benefit Wheelchair Charities Inc. today and tomorrow at Alumni Hall in Queens. The games, between teams of boys and girls all-stars from New York area high schools, are from noon to 5 P.M. both days. Tickets are available at the St. John's box office on days of the games.

title: One City, 2 Booksellers and a Bit of Bad Blood
description: Seattle has long prided itself on being an unusually literary city, where writers congregate and the drizzly climate often begs a resident to curl up in a chair and read. At its bookish heart, most Seattleites would agree, is the Elliott Bay Book Company, where customers can browse amid the cedar shelves or listen to some of the 500 or more programs annually that make up its pioneering series of author readings.

title: 'Don't Push Us,' Yeltsin Warns West On Balkans
description: No, President Boris N. Yeltsin did not order Russian nuclear missiles to be targeted at NATO countries taking part in the bombing of Yugoslavia. Nor did he formally endorse the joining together of Russia, Belarus and Yugoslavia in a geographically awkward Slavic union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNO, LENA
description: BRUNO-Lena. The law firm of Gusrae, Kaplan & Bruno deeply mourn the passing of Lena Bruno, beloved mother of our partner Cirino M. Bruno. We express our sympathy to the family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLEY, SYDELLE
description: BERLEY-Sydelle. On April 9, 1999. Beloved mother of David (Estelle) and Noah (Rhoda). Adoring grandmother of Sam, Alexander, Saul and Eve. Devoted sister of Murry Diamondstein. Funeral services Sunday, 11AM, Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 76 Road, Forest Hills. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care.

title: Checketts Is Losing Patience
description: Dave Checketts, the president of Madison Square Garden, put everyone in the Knicks' organization on alert today in the aftermath of the team's listless loss to Charlotte on Wednesday.

title: Sports of The Times; Jordan Adds A Shortstop To His Team
description: MICHAEL JORDAN sat in a luxury suite at Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon, watching the Yankees open the season by annihilating Detroit in a rain-shortened game, and adding to his growing aura of invincibility. Jordan said he was on hand as a fan, though he admitted that it took more than his love of the game to come out on a miserable Friday. In fact, Jordan was also on hand to support Derek Jeter, his latest client and a player who, in many ways, reminds Jordan of his athletic self.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUMPHREYS, FRANCES BRYAN
description: HUMPHREYS - Frances Bryan. Died at Meadow Lakes, Heightstown, NJ, on April 8, 1999 at age 89. She was the widow of Gustavus Aldridge Humphreys, a urologist who practiced in New York City and Bronxville. He predeceased her by 21 years. Born in Titusville, PA, on January 11, 1910, she attended and graduated from Columbia School of Social Work in 1935. (It was then called the New York School of Social Work.) She lived with her family in Bronxville, NY from 1941 to 1990 when she moved to Meadow Lakes. During the time in Bronxville, she worked with the Jenny Clarkson Home for Girls, the Westchester Family Consultation Service, as well as with the Bronxville PTA and the League of Women Voters. She served on the Bronxville school board for a number of years and worked for Planned Parenthood. She is survived by her three children: Joseph Humphreys of Amelia Court House, VA, Thomas Humphreys of Somers, NY, and Mary Waite of Chicago, Il; and three grandchildren Jason and Cynthia Waite, Chicago, Il and Sarah Humphreys, Amelia Court House, VA. Also surviving her are her niece and nephews Jane Wasson, Denver, CO; John Edmondson, Washington, D.C.; Bryan Edmondson, Summit, NJ and Sam Bryan, New York City, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Planned Parenthood of New York, Hawthorne Center, 11 Skyline Drive, New York, NY 10532

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about British Airways' plan to close its American headquarters in Queens misstated the airline's profit figure for last year. It was $771 million, not $77 million.

title: Real Estate Chief Leaving Lazard
description: Lazard Freres & Company said yesterday that Arthur Solomon, who oversaw $3 billion of real estate investments for Lazard and its clients, had left the firm.

title: An American Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: An American Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Escaping From Prison and From the Self
description: Prisons, real and metaphorical, frame ''Trans,'' the atmospheric first feature written and directed by Julian Goldberger.

title: Will Hong Kong Pay if China Joins Trade Bloc?
description: For China, which has spent years trying to claw its way into the world's club of trading nations, the benefits of such an expanded reach and strong connections are clear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEARNEY, MARY A. (NEE WHITE)
description: KEARNEY-Mary A. (nee White). On April 8, 1999. Beloved wife of the late John H. Devoted mother of John T., James V., Kevin M. and the late Joseph P. Loving grandmother of Rosemarie, Maureen, Cathey, Michael, Jennifer, James, Megan, Kate, Christine, Elisa and Sean. Dear aunt of Thomas Jones, Cathy Battle and Eileen Lavin. Also survived by 11 grandnieces and nephews and one great-grand nephew. Funeral Monday, 9AM, from McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 9:45AM, Our Lady Help of Christians R.C. church. Interment St. John's cemetery. Visitng Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. In Memoriams to Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn, 191 Joralemon St, Brooklyn, New York 11201,

title: Reporter or Criminal?
description: To the Editor:

title: Are the Bombs Following Me?
description: My wife, our two children and I live in the center of Belgrade. It's a very pleasant part of town, and convenient, too -- except when NATO is waging an air war. Now we see our neighborhood through different eyes, as a set of potential targets.

title: Street Boys Of Jakarta: Hopeless, Undeterred
description: ''Leaf on a Pillow,'' the Indonesian filmmaker Garin Nugroho's dispassionate portrait of lower-class street life in Jakarta, hits you in the face with almost unimaginable squalor and a patchwork of teeming sights and sounds that are more than the senses can take in. The film, which has a sketchy screenplay, follows three footloose boys -- Sugeng, Heru and Kancil -- who portray dramatized versions of their own directionless lives.

title: Slain Woman Is Recalled as a Dedicated and Generous Colleague
description: As a cold rain fell on the desolate intersection of South Day Street and Freeway Drive West, a man walked up and placed a bouquet of mixed flowers at the base of a lamppost, which was circled by a rain-soaked purple ribbon.

title: On China, A Failed Strategy; Dealing With Taiwan
description: To the Editor:

title: ARRESTED DEVELOPMENT AT THE WHITNEY
description: On the eve of its biggest show, the museum is grasping for purpose. Just what does it want to be when it grows up? A report by Arthur Lubow, in The Times Magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, REV. MSGR. THOMAS V.
description: McMAHON-Rev. Msgr. Thomas V. On April 8, 1999. Age 90. Former Pastor of the Church of the Resurrection of Rye, N.Y. Beloved brother of Daniel of Fort Lauderdale, FL., the late Winifred Jordan & Rev. John McMahon, S.J. Cherished uncle of Marita and Daniel McMahon, and Mary Ann, Donald, Daniel, Thomas and John Jordan. Dear great uncle of five great nieces and six great nephews. The family will receive friends Saturday 2-4 and 7-9PM, Sunday 2-4PM at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, and 7-7:30PM at the Resurrection Church, to be followed by a Mass of the Eucharist Sunday, 7:30PM. Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of the Resurrection Monday, 10:30AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Catholic Near East Welfare Association, 1011 1st Avenue, NY, NY 10022 would be appreciated.

title: For Yankee Fans, No Excuse Will Do
description: The rain didn't matter. Traffic? No problem. And as thousands of fans proved yet again yesterday, that nettlesome little matter of work was not about to stand between the Yankee faithful and their rite of spring, the home opener in the Bronx.

title: How U.S. and China Failed to Close Trade Deal
description: On a bitterly cold day in Beijing in early January, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, was given a startling message by Zhu Rongji, the Chinese Prime Minister who was remaking the country's economy.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I know some people think being part of a contest makes the process seem trivial. We planned to have a baby all along. It's been fun and we got a lot of good free stuff. ''

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE JUMPS 5.7 PERCENT. Prices rose after the Government cut its forecast for production in Florida, the nation's largest orange-growing state. The May contract rose 4.75 cents, to 87.9 cents a pound.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a nationwide search to replace the retiring president and chief executive of New York Presbyterian Hospital, Dr. David B. Skinner, misstated the job history of Dr. William T. Speck, the hospital's chief operating officer, whom Dr. Skinner had once named as his successor. Dr. Speck was president of Presbyterian Hospital in 1996 when it merged with New York Hospital, not of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Columbia University's Health Sciences Division, Presbyterian's main academic affiliate, was not a party to the merger.

title: Apache Copters May Take Month to Be Combat-Ready
description: Four days after NATO approved the deployment of two dozen American Apache helicopter gunships to attack Yugoslav tanks, frustrated NATO and Pentagon officials now estimate that it could take a month before the helicopters are available to fly into Kosovo.

title: Kosovo Albanians Trickle Across Macedonia Line
description: Yugoslav forces are continuing to force ethnic Albanians out of their homes in southern Kosovo, newly arrived refugees said today.

title: Campus Protesting Made Easy
description: Spring is the season that student protests become as inevitable as fistfights on ''The Jerry Springer Show.'' This year colleges across the country are seeing the largest crop of demonstrations, marches, sit-ins and strikes in nearly two decades.

title: Smaller Classes Are Just the Beginning
description: To the Editor:

title: Invisible Tenant in New Tower?; Some Say Times Square's Conde Nast Building Is Jinxed
description: A glazier who spends his days clinging to the sides of skyscrapers, Dan McGough doesn't really believe in goblins, poltergeists or jinxed job sites. But every day, before he reports to work at the accident-plagued Conde Nast building in Times Square, Mr. McGough, 30, crosses himself and mutters a little prayer.

title: Coca-Cola Bid for Orangina Rebuffed by French Court
description: The Coca-Cola Company's plans to buy Orangina faded yesterday when France's highest administrative court refused to overturn a Government ruling that had blocked the sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, CHARLES R.
description: KATZ-Charles R. Passed away on April 8, in Tamarac, FL. Beloved husband of Edythe, loving father of Barbara and Martin Rosen, Jack and Elena Katz, Janet and Richard Greenspan. Step-father of Bonnie Austin, Ann Green and Jodi and Dan Murphy. Devoted grandfather of Larry and Laura, Deborah, Douglas, Russell, Lisa, Zachary, Alexander, Dawn, Elliot, Sarah and Alexandra. Greatgrandfather of Matthew. Formerly of New Rochelle and Manhattan NY. A graduate of NYU Law School, he committed his life to the Advancement of the Labor Union Movement. He will be greatly missed by all of his family and friends. Contributions in his memory may be made to Vitas Hospice House, Columbia University Hospital, 7201 North University Drive, Tamarac, FL. 33321.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREFOUSSE, DR. RASHELLE F.
description: TREFOUSSE-Dr. Rashelle F. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Dr. Rashelle F. Trefousse. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: W.N.B.A. Talks to Resume Under Pressure of Deadline
description: After more than a week away from the bargaining table, representatives of the Women's National Basketball Association and its players union are tentatively scheduled to resume talks by Monday in the hopes of making progress toward a contract.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: While Dodging Drops, Cone Just Pours It On
description: David Cone drove to Yankee Stadium through the drizzle yesterday, knowing that it was going to be a long and brutal day. Gusty winds. Pelting rain. Dropping temperatures. Repeated repairs to the mound. These were the kind of inclement conditions in which the Yankees would usually protect Cone's precious fingers by stashing him for a day and not letting him pitch.

title: Is More Privacy a Good Idea?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about an Internet music venture by Universal Music and BMG misstated BMG's market position. Ranked by album sales in the United States, BMG was the fourth-largest record company, not the second, in the fourth quarter of 1998, according to Soundscan, which tracks sales. The article also misstated the ownership of the Elektra Nonesuch label. The owner is the Warner Music Group, not BMG.

title: OAKWOOD HOMES' 2D-QUARTER RESULTS BELOW ESTIMATES
description: The Oakwood Homes Corporation of Greensboro, N.C., the producer of manufactured housing, said yesterday that its second-quarter results would be below Wall Street's expectations because of a loss on the sale of asset-backed securities in January. The company said it had expected a gain on the sale. It now expects profit for the quarter ended March 31 to be 5 cents to 10 cents below the 27 cents a share predicted by analysts polled by the First Call Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERRY, RANDALL NEAL
description: TERRY-Randall Neal. On April 7, 1999. Beloved husband of Beth. Dear father of Austin Greg. Cherished son of Seymour and Elsie Terry. Adored brother of Howard Terry and Jacalyn Terry Gantzer. Loving uncle. Services were held Friday, April 9 at ''The Riverside,'' interment followed at the Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: China's Premier Twice Voices Displeasure Over Not Getting Into the Club
description: China and the United States took steps today to protect the environment and to increase airline traffic between the two countries, but Prime Minister Zhu Rongji left little doubt that he considered those agreements a poor substitute for the big trade deal that he hoped to clinch as the centerpiece of his visit.

title: ALLIED WASTE TO ADD TO ITS DUMPS AND TRANSFER STATIONS
description: Allied Waste Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire dumps, transfer stations and other assets in New York, Pennsylvania and Florida from Waste Management Inc. for $85 million. Waste Management, which is based in Houston, agreed last year to sell the assets in order to satisfy regulators and clear the way for its $1.1 billion acquisition of Eastern Environmental Services Inc. The deal created a combined entity with estimated revenue of $450 million in the metropolitan New York waste market, or about 20 percent of that market. Under the deal, which is expected to close by June 30, Allied, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., will acquire three transfer-station operations in the New York City area, two collection and three landfill operations in Pennsylvania and two collection operations in Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLAVIN, JEFFREY
description: SLAVIN-Jeffrey. The Shelter Rock Jewish Center of Roslyn, New York expresses its profound sorrow on the untimely and tragic death of Jeffrey, beloved son of Barry and Goldie. He was a source of joy to his parents and family. May God comfort them. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster Stanley Shanies, President

title: Fire Warning Forces Jet Back to Kennedy
description: A London-bound British Airways Concorde was forced to return to Kennedy International Airport yesterday after signaling possible engine trouble, an airline spokesman said. None of the 83 passengers aboard were injured.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSMAN, DAVID
description: KASSMAN-David. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Devoted father of Andrew, Neil and Mitchell. Dear father-in-law of Joyce, Laurie and Maria. Cherished grandfather of Stacey, Erica, Alexandria and Jared. Services Sunday 12:15PM at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Heart Association.

title: Producer Prices Edge Up as Oil Costs Jump
description: Producer prices rose less than expected last month as the biggest increase in oil prices since the Persian Gulf crisis in 1990-91 was offset by falling prices for computers and a variety of other products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARDENAS, REV. JUAN, PH.D.
description: CARDENAS-Rev. Juan, Ph.D. April 19 1916 -April 4 1999. Of NYC and Miami Beach, Florida. To my beloved husband of forty-five years, and our beloved father: ''May you rest with your Creator.'' Dora Cardenas Dora L. Cardenas, MD Abbey Martinez, M.S.W. Eunice Fernandez, Grandchildren

title: Russia's Shareholders
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, MIRIAM B.
description: HOROWITZ-Miriam B. The Program in Judaic Studies of Yale University mourns the passing of Miriam B. Horowitz, a woman of valor and a generous supporter of this program. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends.

title: Clinton Urges Petition Drive to Pass Health Plan
description: With Congress reconvening next week, President Clinton flew here today to try to whip up public enthusiasm for the Democratic proposal to establish a ''patient's bill of rights.''

title: Brazilian Devaluation Hurts Bic's Sales
description: Bic S.A., the world's largest maker of pens and lighters, said yesterday that the devaluation of the Brazilian currency, the real, had pushed its first-quarter sales down 6 percent, to 273 million euros ($294 million).

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on March 16 about sleep deprivation misspelled the surname of the chief of the division of sleep and chronobiology at the University of Pennsylvania Medical Center. He is Dr. David F. Dinges, not Dingess.

title: With NATO in Charge, Relief Looks Less Neutral
description: The new partnership of NATO and the United Nations refugee agency is bringing supplies and shelter to hundreds of thousands who have fled Kosovo, but some fear it is straining the traditional neutrality of aid groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINER, ETTA
description: KLEINER-Etta. Beloved and devoted mother of Judy Koplik and Sidney. Dear sister, loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM, ''Parkside'' Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn (near Avenue V).

title: FUND OF GOLDMAN SACHS SEEN IN SOUTH KOREA INVESTMENT
description: A fund of Goldman Sachs Group L.P., the New York investment banking partnership, plans to pay $500 million to buy about one-fifth of Kookmin Bank, South Korea's largest retail bank, according to a person close to the deal. Under the agreement, details of which are likely to be announced next week, the Goldman fund would buy $300 million of new shares and $200 million of bonds that would later be swapped for stock in Kookmin. An economic slump and rise in bankruptcies have saddled the bank with bad loans.

title: The Elegance of Old Japan, With Echoes of the West
description: Saeko Ichinohe knows how to make multiculturalism work. In her new ''Part III: The Tale of the Genji,'' performed on Tuesday night at the Clark Studio Theater at Lincoln Center, Ms. Ichinohe creates a sense of delicate, sometimes powerful Japanese ritual with colors that are drawn at least as much from the Western modern-dance palette as from traditional Japanese dance.

title: Acid Rain's National Reach
description: When people think of the ravages of acid rain, they tend to think mainly of dead and dying watersheds in the Northeastern United States, particularly those in New York's Adirondack Mountains, where hundreds of highly acidified lakes and streams can no longer sustain aquatic life. But an exhaustive Federal study has now concluded that acid rain has spread its poisons far and wide, damaging sensitive watersheds in the Southeastern United States and in ecologically significant areas of the West like the Sierra Nevada, the Cascade Range and some parts of the Rocky Mountains.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend yesterday about ''Twin Falls Idaho,'' which is being shown today in the New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art, reversed the attributes of the film's identical twin brothers. Blake, not Francis, is the dominant one.

title: Olazabal's Savvy and Wit Propel Him Into the Lead
description: It was a day for Jose Maria Olazabal to display his talent on a worldwide stage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, RUTH S.
description: HELLER-Ruth S. On April 9, 1999. Of Brooklyn, NY. Age 84. Beloved wife of the late Max Heller. Loving and devoted mother of daughter Matilda Katz & son Aaron Heller. Loving grandmother of ChaimMeir Katz, Shiphra Schorr, ChanaDaphna Shiffer, Chaim-Meyer Heller and Sara Lee Heller. Greatgrandmother of Bracha, Dina, Chananya, and Dovid Schorr. Funeral services will be Sunday, April 11, 1999, 11:30 AM, at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave. and Ave. M. Interment will follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. Shiva will be at 1268 East 28th St., Brooklyn, NY and 521 Northwest Drive, Silver Spring, MD. She will always be cherished in our hearts.

title: Women Seek Parity In Money At Slams
description: In 1970, a group of female tennis players, frustrated by the disparity in tournament prize money with their male counterparts, formed the first women's professional tour. Last week, another group of female pros signed a petition authorizing the WTA Tour to demand equal prize money with the men at all four Grand Slam championships.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EATON, Cleveland, said it had completed its $1.7 billion purchase of Aeroquip-Vickers Inc., Maumee, Ohio, an international manufacturer of engineered components and systems for industrial, aerospace and automotive markets.

title: At Home Abroad; Ends And Means
description: NATO now has three irreducible war aims: the removal of all Serbian military, paramilitary and police forces from Kosovo; the return of all the ethnic Albanian refugees, and their care and protection by an international force.

title: U.S. Warns Russia: Don't Provide Help To Serbian Military
description: The United States has quietly warned Russia against providing military intelligence or assistance to Yugoslavia, senior Western officials said today.

title: Cypriot Fails in Effort to Gain Release of 3 Captured G.I.'s
description: President Slobodan Milosevic today chose not to make a goodwill gesture toward the West by releasing three captured American soldiers. Instead he used the visit of a Cypriot politician to make another kind of propaganda point, about the civilian damage caused by NATO's bombing.

title: H. S. Kessler, 56, Animal Hospital Founder
description: Howard S. Kessler, a Manhattan veterinarian and former president of the board of the Bide-a-Wee Association, died on Thursday at the Southampton Hospital in Southampton, N.Y. He was 56.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO GAINS. The dollar fell against the euro after the European Central Bank reduced its benchmark rate to 2.5 percent Thursday. The euro settled at $1.079 yesterday, an increase from $1.074 Thursday.

title: Childs Takes It On the Chin, but Knicks Hold On
description: Chris Childs spit a tooth into his hand and fixed a menacing stare on Dikembe Mutombo, who trotted away innocently. It was all Childs could do not to dart toward the Hawks' towering collection of pointy elbows and bony kneecaps and start swinging away without regard to Mutombo's yard-long reach advantage.

title: Menifee Set to Test Mettle In the Blue Grass Stakes
description: Three weeks before the Kentucky Derby, the people who invested their time, money and passion in Menifee were standing at the crossroads of his career.

title: Shipyard Strikers Demand 'Justice'
description: As Marvin Lowrie, a 52-year-old machinist, walked the picket line outside the giant shipyard here, there was pride laced with bitterness when he talked, pride that his shipyard produces the world's most sophisticated nuclear aircraft carriers.

title: Principal Charged With Selling Cocaine
description: The head of a private elementary school in Brooklyn who has run a food program for the poor for years and publicly spoke about the dangers of drugs was charged yesterday with selling cocaine to an undercover investigator at the school.

title: Princeton's New Philosopher Draws a Stir
description: Not since 1940 when City College tried to hire an atheist and advocate of free love, Bertrand Russell, has the appointment of an academic philosopher by an American university created such a commotion. The choice of Peter Singer, a world renowned animal rights advocate, for a chair in bioethics at Princeton University's Center for Human Values, has agitated the genteel college town as well as the field of bioethics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, LESTER
description: LYONS-Lester. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle mourns the passing of our long time member & Honorary Vice Pres. Heartfelt condolences to the family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Dorothy Fox, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, KONSTANTIN
description: GREGORY-Konstantin. Of Stamford, CT (formerly Thousand Oaks, CA) on April 8. Beloved husband of Marcelle, adoring father of Cynthia and proud grandfather of Lloyd. Devoted brother of George, Mary, Michael and Theodore. Requiem Saturday, April 10 at St. Michael the Archangel, Greenwich, at 11:30. His life was wholly devoted to the happiness of others. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Glaucoma Research Foundation, 490 Post St., San Francisco, CA 94102.

title: Religion Journal; Interfaith Award Bears Walter Cronkite's Stamp
description: A couple of years ago, the Interfaith Alliance, a relatively small organization with the big-time goal of countering the political activities of religious conservative groups, sent a fund-raising letter that turned out to be a news maker.

title: Talk, Too, As Topics Trip By
description: Tere O'Connor's ''Hi Everybody!'' certainly wasn't boring. It couldn't have been. Mr. O'Connor changed his choreographic mind so often in it that no single subject ever grew dull. As presented on Thursday night at the Kitchen by Tere O'Connor Dance, the 45-minute piece touched on such matters as cancer, Alzheimer's disease, war, peace, retirement communities, gay marriage and homophobia, to name only a few of the topics that whizzed by to outbursts of recorded music by James Baker.

title: Jerome Robbins Memorial
description: ''Broadway Celebrates Jerome Robbins,'' a memorial for the director and choreographer, who died last year, will be held on Monday at 2:15 P.M. at the Majestic Theater, 245 West 44th Street, Manhattan. Participants in the memorial, which is open to the public, will include George Chakiris, Helen Gallagher, Maria Karnilova, Arthur Kopit, Robert LaFosse, Natalia Makarova, James Mitchell, Faith Prince, Herbert Ross, Jerry Bock and Sheldon Harnick.

title: Venezuela's New Leader: Democrat or Dictator?
description: To the adoring, impoverished masses who catapulted him to power, Hugo Chavez Frias is El Comandante, their protector and benefactor, the bold leader who will wipe out 40 years of inequality and corruption and redirect this country's enormous oil wealth to better their lives.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq and S.& P. Indexes Set New Highs Once Again

title: Emmett Colvin, 80, Lawyer for Jack Ruby
description: Emmett Colvin, a criminal defense lawyer from Texas, died on April 2 at his home in Fairfax, Va. He was 80 and had retired to Virginia from Dallas three years ago.

title: Sports of The Times; The Shark Is Prowling In a Date With Destiny
description: FROM the 18th fairway, Greg Norman's ball floated onto the green yesterday, skipped past the flagstick and spun to a stop about 10 feet away. The way so many of his approach shots once did. And the Masters gallery that had waited for him clapped, the way they once did, in a burst of appreciation.

title: Donald Savage, 81; Tracked Evolution of Apes
description: Dr. Donald Elvin Savage, a paleontologist who tracked the evolution of the earliest anthropoid apes, died on Monday at a hospice in Rossmoor, Calif. He was 81 and had recently moved there from his home in nearby Clayton.

title: Compaq Says Profit Outlook Is in Trouble
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said late yesterday that its profits would be less than half of what analysts had expected, dragged down by declining sales and a shift into lower-margin products.

title: Don't Let Libya Off the Hook
description: Although Libya has finally handed over two suspects charged with planting the bomb that brought down Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland more than a decade ago, the United States should not assume that full justice is being done.

title: About New York; Empty Crib, Full Schedule In Court
description: A NEVER-USED white crib sits in the sunniest room of Celia Angel's railroad flat on Lexington Avenue at 107th Street. Resting in it are a comforter, a new doll and an unopened package of diapers. She has a second crib in storage in case two of her grandchildren, Manuela and Pedro Jose, come over.

title: Agencies That Aid Refugees
description: These are some organizations that are helping Kosovo refugees. Updates on their activities are at http:// www.interaction.org/kosovo/ detail.html

title: MONSANTO AGREES TO SELL ITS NSC TECHNOLOGIES UNIT
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its NSC Technologies unit to the Great Lakes Chemical Corporation for $125 million in a continuing effort to focus on its life sciences businesses. Since November 1998, Monsanto, which is based in St. Louis, has been shedding businesses that do not fit with its long-term life sciences focus. It has announced plans to sell its Stoneville Pedigreed Seed Company and completed the sales of its Ortho Lawn-and-Garden business and its Wellbridge Health and Fitness unit. NTC Technolgies makes and sells intermediate and bulk chemicals to the pharmaceutical industry. Great Lakes, which is based in Indianapolis, produces specialty chemicals used in fire extinguishers, in water treatment and in life sciences applications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, EVELYN
description: KRAUSS-Evelyn. Loving mother, loving friend, she meant the world to all of us and we will miss her dearly. She died April 8, 1999, much as she lived-with courage and spirit in the comfort of her home and with her family. Devoted wife of the late George G. Krauss, she is survived by her daughters, Stephanie Farrell and Georgette Krauss; her grandchildren, Deirdre and Stephen Farrell; her son-in-law, Paul Farrell. Service was held in her memory at the Branch Funeral Home in Smithtown, NY.

title: For Albanian, an Odd Role in Belgrade
description: For most of the last 10 years, Slobodan Milosevic, as the main generator of aroused Serbian nationalism, has been trying to ignore Ibrahim Rugova, 53, a literary historian who until recently was the unquestioned leader of Kosovo's Albanians.

title: Excerpts From Ruling on California Savings and Loan
description: Following are excerpts from a ruling by Chief Judge Loren A. Smith of the United States Court of Federal Claims ordering the Government to pay $909 million to Glendale Federal Bank, a California savings and loan association, for breach of contract. The breach was determined to have occurred when the Government changed the rules on how savings institutions must count their assets.

title: Get the Census Right
description: To the Editor:

title: An American Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Dole Is Shunning 'Dead End' Abortion Fight
description: Stepping carefully into the debate on abortion that has roiled her party for years, Elizabeth Dole said today that as a possible Republican Presidential candidate, she would not be drawn into ''dead end debates'' over a constitutional amendment to ban abortion, because ''it's not going to happen.''

title: INSIDE
description: Joy in Mudville as Yogi Returns and Yanks Win

title: Police Seek Robber in Officer's Killing
description: On foot and in squad cars, scores of police officers canvassed the streets, backyards and parking lots of this small city northwest of Newark today, searching for an armed robber who is believed to have shot and killed a police officer Thursday night after she stopped him for questioning.

title: Ira J. Hechler, 80, Financier Known for Corporate Buyouts
description: Ira J. Hechler, a financier and private investor known for friendly corporate buyouts in the 1980's, when hostile takeovers dominated the corporate landscape, died last Sunday at New York Hospital of complications resulting from a heart attack, a family representative said. He was 80.

title: Fast Start Pays Off For Dallas
description: STARS 3, RANGERS 1

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALINA, ARTHUR
description: MALINA-Arthur. On April 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving father of Jane & Victor Levinson and Richard and Wendy Malina. Cherished grandfather of Nick Levinson and Julie Moll, Lynn Levinson & Roderick Kreisberg, Maggie Malina, Tom Levinson, Cathy Malina, Emily Malina and greatgrandfather of Nate Levinson. Devoted brother of Edythe Charnas and the late Fred Malina. Dear brother-in-law of Ben Charnas, Evelyn Malina and Murray and Sylvia Levitan. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 Street, on Sunday, April 11th at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital, or a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESNICK, ELLIOT I.
description: MESNICK-Elliot I. On March 24, 1999, Princeton, New Jersey. Beloved husband of Edith, adored father of daughter Leslie Dilworth and son Gary, adored grandfather of Wyatt and Andrew Gallery, Joshua and Jessica Mesnick.

title: How the Masters Looks
description: In the venerable world of golf, the Masters Tournament at the Augusta National Golf Club in Augusta, Ga., is a relative newcomer among major tournaments. The first Masters was held in 1934; the first green jacket -- awarded to the winner -- was presented in 1949, and the first telecast of the Masters appeared in 1956. You would never guess that from the coverage. Tradition has accrued to the Masters at a rate that is nearly unfathomable, and nothing chokes up a network sportscaster like tradition. The azaleas bloom, the pine-straw in the rough enforces a deep hush, and nowhere on earth is the subject of grass discussed so thoroughly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERRY, HERMAN
description: CHERRY-Herman. April 10, 1992. The part of me that is you will remain. Regin

title: COMPASS GAINS ON NEWS IT REJECTED AMSOUTH BID
description: Shares in Compass Bancshares Inc. rose 8.7 percent, to $28.8125, yesterday after a report that the bank had rejected a takeover offer from the rival AmSouth Bancorp in December. ''This puts some pressure on the company to consider more seriously an offer from AmSouth or some other company,'' said Michael Granger, a bank analyst at Fox-Pitt, Kelton Inc. Compass and AmSouth, both in Birmingham, Ala., are the fourth- and third-largest banks in Alabama, respectively. According to people close to the situation, AmSouth offered Compass shareholders 1.43 shares of its stock for each Compass share -- which would have represented a 60 percent premium for Compass shareholders and valued the bank at about $4.7 billion. Officials at AmSouth and Compass declined to comment.

title: A Young Man and a Society Without Pity or Remorse
description: Like ''Tokyo Eyes'' and ''Trans,'' which are also in the New Directors/ New Films series, the Chinese film ''Xiao Wu'' deals with a young criminal alienated from his society.

title: WEST COAST S.& L. WINS $909 MILLION FROM GOVERNMENT
description: A Federal judge tonight ordered the Government to pay $908.9 million to a California savings association that nearly went bankrupt after Congress and the Bush Administration imposed tougher accounting standards on the industry a decade ago.

title: Piazza Connects in First Inning, and the Mets Never Look Back
description: For much of last summer, Mike Piazza felt he was pressing every time at bat.

title: Helen A. Mayer, Dumbo's Creator, Dies at 91
description: Helen Aberson Mayer, who wrote the children's story that inspired the 1941 Walt Disney cartoon, ''Dumbo,'' died last Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, GRAENUM
description: BERGER-Graenum. The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourns the passing of Graenum Berger, a dynamic humanitarian who made a significant contribution to the Jewish communal world. As a determined advocate for Ethiopian Jewry, he founded the American Association for Ethiopian Jews, and was a long time partner of JDC. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Emma, and his family. Jonathan W. Kolker, President Michael Schneider, Executive VP

title: Is More Privacy a Good Idea?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Tells Albany to Aid Failing Hospitals
description: In a strongly worded letter, a Federal agency has warned the Pataki administration that many of the state's most financially troubled hospitals will go bankrupt or default on their loans unless the state does more to help them.

title: Op-Art; Egg Donor Needed
description: Lynn Harris is co-creator of the Web site breakupgirl.com. J.D. Heiman, whose books include "Now What? A Guide to Jobs, Money and the Real World," is writing a satiric novel about publishing. Paul Sahre is a graphic designer.

title: Fans Get a Reward
description: Out of respect to those who sat through the rainy home opener, the Yankees announced they would give another ticket in exchange for a stub from yesterday's game. Fans will receive a tier box or reserved seat to one of the following games: next Thursday, against Baltimore; April 20 or 21, against Texas; May 12 or 13, against Anaheim. BUSTER OLNEY

title: Computers' Play Improves, Especially in Tricky Hands
description: If you test a computer's power to ''think'' by making it play chess, it earns an A+ grade. It will be remembered that Deep Blue, a computer program, defeated Garry Kasparov, the world chess champion, in a recent match.

title: Harris Is Unlikely Star As Nets Defeat Raptors
description: Keith Van Horn and Stephon Marbury were the likely saviors. Van Horn had used his crossover dribble and athleticism to work the former Knicks warrior Charles Oakley to death. And Marbury, the brazen point guard, is always looking to deliver in the fourth quarter. But tonight, the unusual happened at Continental Arena.

title: Rally to Promote Port Leases Widens Gap Between States
description: In a sign of the escalating tensions between the governors of New York and New Jersey, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman plans to go to the World Trade Center on Monday for a union rally intended to push the two states to stop squabbling and sign leases with two of the largest shipping lines in New York Harbor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, HON. DANIEL J.
description: Sullivan-Hon. Daniel J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of Hon. Daniel J. Sullivan, a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, Pres. Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: On Making It Big Without Selling Out
description: Foolish Waise sort of grows on you. This is, after all, a streetwise black stand-up comic who performs with a microphone in one hand and a glass of white wine in the other. His humor can be painfully simplistic, consisting sometimes of the observation that there are white people in his audience and boy, are they nervous! A lot of the time he just seems to be trying to see how many times he can use the vulgar slang terms for sex and genitalia in a single sentence.

title: Complexity To Challenge The Players
description: It's been quite a while since Joanne Brackeen has played the top level of jazz clubs in New York. She was the pianist for Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers in the late 1960's, and she has played solo and with small groups at the city's smaller piano bars for decades. But a new record, ''Pink Elephant Magic'' on the Arkadia label, is bringing her more attention, and she started a five-day run at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night, to culminate in a live recording this weekend.

title: Via Dolorosa: Walking on Sacred Soil and Doing Battle Over It
description: The English playwright David Hare visited Israel and the Palestinian territories for the first time two years ago. On his return, he wrote ''Via Dolorosa,'' a monologue which he is now performing on Broadway. Here are excerpts.

title: Bank of Japan Board Leaves Rates Unchanged
description: The Bank of Japan's board kept borrowing costs unchanged at its regular fortnightly meeting yesterday and did not indicate that it planned a sizable increase in the supply of money to the banking system.

title: Smaller Classes Are Just the Beginning
description: To the Editor:

title: To the Stunts and Villains Add a Pair of Jackie Chans
description: Long, long before scientists figured out a way to clone sheep, filmmakers had divined the secrets of turning one actor into two.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Yanks Keep Focus and Fire in Rainy Home Opener
description: Footprints became man-made ponds in the Yankee Stadium infield yesterday, and there were likely to be more groundskeepers than players on the field at any given moment. The first home baseball game should be played in sunshine and pristine uniforms. Instead, the Yankees' home opener was all about mud stains, rakes and drying compound.

title: Genentech Drops Nerve Drug For Diabetics After Tests Fail
description: Genentech Inc., one of the world's largest biotechnology companies, said yesterday that Neuleze, its highly anticipated drug to promote nerve growth in diabetes patients, would not be sold in the United States because late-stage clinical trials had failed to prove the compound worked.

title: Another Countdown to the Millennium Begins
description: In New York, the Fitzpatrick Manhattan Hotel was bracing for it. With night approaching, the manager was reporting a rush of last-minute orders for bouquets and requests for dinner reservations at the most romantic spots in town.

title: Safir Defends Use of Police After Accident
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday defended the Commissioner's decision to send two detectives to the home of a Queens woman who was involved in a minor car accident with Mr. Safir's wife, saying the visit was an appropriate inquiry into a potential security risk.

title: NATO Reconnaisance Fails To Locate Missing Refugees
description: Three days after Serbian troops closed border crossing points from Kosovo into Macedonia and Albania, NATO reconnaissance planes have failed to locate any of the tens of thousands of refugees who were turned back from the frontier.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES TO PURCHASE ICI SPECIALTY COATINGS
description: PPG Industries, the auto paint maker, agreed yesterday to buy the specialty coatings business of the British company Imperial Chemical Industries, adding a maker of coatings for industrial uses. Terms were not disclosed. The business, based in Germany, makes specialty coatings for manufacturers of buses, trucks and rail cars and had about $16 million in 1998 sales, the companies said. PPG, which is based in Pittsburgh and also produces fiberglass, flat and fabricated glass and chemicals, said a year ago that it would shift its focus to its more profitable businesses, including coatings and paints.

title: India's Tattered Coalition Frays a Bit More
description: India is going through another paroxysm of finger-pointing, hand-wringing, arm-twisting, head-counting and back-stabbing as its third coalition Government in three years threatens to come apart.

title: Where Victims Turn Into Aggressors
description: When Rebecca West was working on ''Black Lamb and Grey Falcon,'' the Serbs were the good guys. World War II began as she was writing what she called ''A Journey Through Yugoslavia,'' which she dedicated ''To my friends in Yugoslavia who are now all dead or enslaved,'' and she argued that Germany was carrying on a tradition of ''self-infatuation and a quiver of hatreds for all but the chosen Teutonic people, the most poisonous being dedicated to the Slav.''

title: Berra Returns, And Fans Relish It
description: Before Bob Sheppard could complete the introduction of yesterday's special guest, the fans stood among the raindrops and screamed. More than 50,000 pairs of eyes gazed toward the Yankee dugout, looking for the beloved man who had come back home to Yankee Stadium. They were searching for Yogi Berra.

title: Tokyo Journal; Long Mandibles, Sleek Carapace. A Steal at $300.
description: Yumiko Tanuma held the 3 1/4-inch-long beetle in her hand, tried not to think of it as an overgrown cockroach and stroked it gently.

title: Political Memo; Council Plan on Arts Alters Routine Budget Battle
description: It is one of the most predictable sequences in the annual budget theatrics at City Hall: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani slashes funding for museums and other cultural institutions, and the City Council rushes to restore the lost money.

title: Britain Blocks B Sky B Effort To Take Over a Soccer Team
description: British Sky Broadcasting's $1 billion takeover of the English soccer team Manchester United was blocked by the Government today, the third major setback this year to Rupert Murdoch's plans for expansion in television and sports broadcasting in Europe.

title: More Americans Canceling Or Delaying European Trips
description: The Balkans conflict and refugee crisis have started to hurt leisure and business travel well beyond the combat zone, with increasing numbers of Americans scrapping or delaying plans to visit Europe during what ordinarily would be one of the best times to go.

title: Reconsidering Patients' Rights
description: Just about everyone on Capitol Hill professes interest in producing legislation that protects patients from unfair health insurance practices. But the prospect of actually passing meaningful protections, as opposed to talking about it, is uncertain. President Clinton tried to whip up support for Democratic proposals yesterday, but the Republicans are balking at Democratic plans as too burdensome on the managed-care industry.

title: Business as Usual
description: Before yesterday's game, Don Zimmer smiled knowingly when asked about whether he and George Steinbrenner were back on good terms after the Hideki Irabu flap. ''I said that two days ago, and it's the same way,'' Zimmer said, recalling Thursday night's annual welcome-home dinner held for the Yankees. ''He just grabbed me, and we had fun,'' he said, referring to Steinbrenner's playful bearhug.

title: Telecom Italia Shareholders To Vote on Defense Strategy
description: Shareholders of Telecom Italia S.p.A. will decide on Saturday whether to approve the company's proposed defense against Olivetti S.p.A.'s $65 billion takeover bid, and investors and analysts said today that it was still unclear whether the proposal would draw enough support.

title: Serbs Seal Off 700,000 Refugees Who Face Starvation, U.S. Says
description: About 700,000 ethnic Albanians have been uprooted from their homes by the Serbs and are still in Kosovo facing the risk of famine as food stocks quickly dwindle, Administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, EDWARD P.
