description: LYONS-Edward P. The College of New Rochelle community records with sorrow the death of Edward P. Lyons, devoted husband of alumna Margaret Whyte Lyons and member of the Board of Trustees for almost 20 years. Edward Lyons was passionate about the mission of this College. His wise counsel which he shared unreservedly and his quiet witness of vibrant faith helped to shape the College through the past three decades. Generations of students, faculty and staff will benefit from his extraordinary devotion and faithfulness to this College. We mourn his loss and celebrate his life. Jean Baptiste Nicholson, OSU Chair, Board of Trustees Stephen J. Sweeny, Ph.D., President

title: ESKIMO PIE TO CUT JOBS AND FOCUS ON LICENSING ITS NAME
description: The Eskimo Pie Corporation said it would sell its plants and cut as many as 85 jobs as it moves to get out of making ingredients for ice cream bars and frozen desserts in favor of licensing its brand name. The company also said it would continue talks with Canada's Yogen Fruz World-Wide Inc., the largest frozen-yogurt store franchiser. In December, Eskimo Pie refused a $45 million buyout offer from Yogen Fruz, which now owns a 17 percent stake in the company. Eskimo Pie said it would sell plants in New Berlin, Wis.; Bloomfield, N.J., and Russellville, Ark., that make chocolate flavoring, packaging and yogurt mix.

title: A 'Madame X' Returns, Scandalously, of Course
description: A famous painting came to life on Thursday night at the Kaye Playhouse when Dances Patrelle presented ''Madame X.'' Francis Patrelle's new ballet, inspired by the John Singer Sargent portrait of a proud woman in an elegant black dress, told how Virginie Avegno Gautreau, the woman in that painting, scandalized society with an extramarital affair.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Austrian Rothschilds Decide to Sell; Sotheby's in London Will Auction $40 Million in Art Seized by Nazis
description: A year after the Austrian Government agreed to return about $40 million worth of art and objects that the Nazis confiscated from the Austrian branch of the Rothschild family, members of the 256-year-old banking dynasty have decided to sell the collection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALSAM, RUTH ROSALIE
description: BALSAM-Ruth Rosalie. On April 9, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Artur. President of the Artur Balsam Foundation for Chamber Music. She will be deeply missed. A gathering of friends will be held Tuesday, April 13, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Artur Balsam Foundation, 825 West End Ave., New York, NY 10025.

title: KERAVISION EYE PRODUCTS CONCERN WINS F.D.A. APPROVAL
description: Keravision Inc., a start-up eye products company based in Fremont, Calif., won Food and Drug Administration approval yesterday to sell its implants for correcting mild nearsightedness. Keravision's Intacs product, two transparent crescents inserted into the cornea to change its shape, offers an alternative to surgery with eye lasers at a cost Keravision has said will be comparable. About 22 million Americans are nearsighted, although the device is only cleared for use in people with mild vision problems.

title: Serving Chef Under Glass; Kitchen Celebrities Are Relying on Image Builders
description: Bob Thomas, a stocky, amiable 29-year-old chef, stands in front of a green upholstered wall, a spotlight illuminating his face and blue sweatshirt while a video camera rolls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACIA, DR. SALVATORE C.
description: PACIA-Dr. Salvatore C. Beloved husband of Elena Lemmo Pacia. Devoted father of Ellen Kehoe, Claire Santoro and Dr. John Pacia. Dear brother of Josephine and the late Antoinette D'Angelo and Mary Nocera. Survived by 8 loving grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. Reposing at Farenga Bros Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Ave., Sunday, 2-5 & 7-9:30PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Holy Rosary Church, Monday, 10 A.M.

title: AT&T TO BUY A CELLULAR BUSINESS FROM BELLSOUTH
description: The AT&T Corporation, the nation's largest phone company, agreed yesterday to buy the BellSouth Corporation's cellular business in Honolulu to expand its nationwide network. The amount was not disclosed, but a person close to the deal said AT&T was paying about $160 million. Honolulu Cellular Telephone provides cellular services to a market with a population of about one million. Wireless companies are trading markets and networks to increase their coverage in the regions they focus on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, SEYMOUR
description: LEVY-Seymour. Beloved husband of Elaine. Brother to Charles and Sylvia Leeds. Father to Jane and Edward Chiusano, Richard and Amy Levy, loving grandfather of Marc, Jason, Denise, Melissa, Emma and Jonah. Services at Gutterman's Chapel, 516-921-5757, 9am Sunday.

title: 3d Death This Year At a Jail in Nassau
description: A 34-year-old man serving a sentence for drug dealing was found dead this morning in his cell at the Nassau County jail, and the police said they suspected illegal drugs as a cause.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Wednesday erred in describing the guilty plea of a former Cincinnati Enquirer reporter, Mike Gallagher. Mr. Gallagher pleaded guilty to state, not Federal, charges.

title: Bob Peck, 53, Actor Of Stage and Screen
description: Bob Peck, who appeared in the film ''Jurassic Park'' as well as on stage and television in Britain, died on Sunday in London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEANEY, THOMAS B.
description: HEANEY-Thomas B. The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed General Manager. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Irwin H. Kramer, President

title: Crime in Nassau County Fell Less Than Reported
description: The streets of Nassau County, it turns out, are not quite as safe as previously thought.

title: Whereas a Studious Juror Nearly Causes a Mistrial for McDougal
description: The trial of Susan H. McDougal on charges of criminal contempt and obstruction for refusing to testify before a Whitewater grand jury about the Arkansas financial dealings of President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, briefly teetered on the verge of a mistrial today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLAND, NORTON DAVID
description: GOLAND-Norton David. On April 8, 1999. Of Lake Worth, Florida. Formerly of East Rockaway, NY. Loving husband of Lee for almost 50 years. Adored father of Janis (Alan) Goldberg, Karyl Goland and Joan (Don) Fisher. Beloved brother of Betty. Cherished grandfather of Stacey, Michael, Robert and Lauren. Services Sunday, April 11, Boca Raton, FL. For further information GuttermanWarheit Memorial Chapel, 800992-9262

title: On China, A Failed Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Broker Pleads Guilty to Fraud In New Issues
description: As part of its investigation into corrupt activities in the securities industry, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday that a former stockbroker at Duke & Company, a defunct New York brokerage firm, had pleaded guilty to attempted enterprise corruption. The broker, Pasquale D'Onofrio, who is known as John, will be sentenced on Oct. 21 and faces up to 15 years in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, ARTHUR
description: GOODMAN-Arthur. On April 8, 1999. Of East Williston, New York. Beloved husband of Helen. Dear brother of Sylvia Solomon. Services on Sunday, 10AM at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Long Island.

title: Police Chiefs Say Criticism Of Departments Is Valid
description: Police chiefs meeting here to examine how their officers could earn more public trust said today that complaints about police misconduct were often valid and that departments had far to go to meet demands for more accountability, respect and courtesy.

title: Unicef Fears for the Youngsters Who Are Fleeing Alone
description: The executive director of the United Nations Children's Fund says that more and more children fleeing Kosovo are unaccompanied, and she fears the number may rise substantially unless steps are taken to insure that families are kept intact.

title: Is More Privacy a Good Idea?
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Officers Get 250 More Reasons to Live in the City
description: Hoping to persuade more New York police officers to live in the city, the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development plans to offer about 250 houses at half price to law enforcement personnel who agree to live in them for at least three years, Federal officials announced yesterday.

title: Rifle Is Found Buried Near Home Of Slain Abortion-Clinic Doctor
description: Nearly six months after a Buffalo-area doctor who performed abortions was shot to death at his home by a sniper, law enforcement authorities reported yesterday that they had recently discovered a rifle buried in the ground in woods behind the doctor's house.

title: GOODRICH TO DELAY ITS PURCHASE OF COLTEC INDUSTRIES
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said yesterday that it would delay its purchase of Coltec Industries until a judge ruled on motions from Allied Signal Inc. to block the transaction. Shareholders of Goodrich and Coltec approved the deal in separate votes yesterday. Goodrich, the 12th-largest aerospace company in the nation, plans to buy Coltec for about $1.21 billion in stock and $790 million in assumed debt and other liabilities. Allied Signal, the 10th-largest aerospace company, filed a suit in February saying it had a strategic alliance with Coltec, an aerospace-components maker, that prohibits the companies from competing with one another.

title: Suffolk Police Official Claims Religious Discrimination
description: A high-ranking Suffolk County police official has filed a Federal civil rights suit against the county and its Police Commissioner, charging them with denying him promotion to inspector because he is Jewish.

title: Brother John Sellers, 74, Blues Singer, Dies
description: Brother John Sellers, a singer known for his raw and earthy rendition of blues, jazz and gospel music, died on March 27 at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: The Refugees Look Back at a Wasteland
description: The interior of Kosovo is a wasteland of burned villages and wandering farm animals, empty of ethnic Albanians but swarming with Serbian forces, refugees allowed to cross into Albania said today. They said that the Serbian forces included tank columns moving in all directions and that troops were taking up quarters in the ravaged houses.

title: Uneasiness Shadowing Orthodox Easter Rite
description: As Orthodox Christians from Moscow to Belgrade and from Athens to Bucharest start celebrating Easter at midnight services tonight, the usual joy of this most sacred of holidays has been tinged with feelings of unease, grief, fear and anger over the continuing conflict in Yugoslavia, home of their Orthodox brethren the Serbs.

title: A Father's Pride
description: To the Editor:

title: South Africa: Getting face to face with a great white
description: I saw the great white, and she saw me, and I'm sure she was a lot less impressed than I was. Had she been able to peer into the boat, she would have seen nine off-green humans lying on their backs with their eyes shut, trying to control the waves of nausea rolling over them as they waited for two hours, anchored off Gansbaai, South Africa, in a swelling sea under a hot sun, for a shark to appear. Our captain, Gerrit Boshoff, and our dive master, Schalk De Klerk, remained irritatingly perky, lolling on the outboard motors only 18 inches above the water, telling jokes and occasionally asking solicitously, ''How you doing, sir?''

title: A Wagnerian Ring
description: To the Editor:

title: Arkansas Tempers a Law On Violence by Children
description: After two boys shot up their schoolyard in Jonesboro in March of last year, killing five people and riveting a nation, Paul Kelly feared the worst for Arkansas's juvenile justice system. The boys, 11 and 13, were too young to be prosecuted as adults under state law, and angry lawmakers seemed to be trampling each other in their efforts to make it easier to imprison youngsters.

title: Corrections
description: A review in the Book Review last Sunday about ''The Revival of Pragmatism,'' a collection of essays edited by Morris Dickstein, misstated the title of a book on esthetics by the philosopher John Dewey. It is ''Art as Experience,'' not ''Art and Experience.''

title: The Stalwarts
description: Jeannette LarsenPatron of modern art, San Francisco

title: Water Park Plan Isn't Gliding Forward Now
description: A city plan for a water park at Orchard Beach seemed to be moving along a month ago. But residents of City Island have deluged the Parks Department with calls and letters opposing the plan because of concerns about traffic, and the department now says the park plan will not proceed unless it gets widespread support from the beach neighbors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARLOCKER, ALICE STOCKTON
description: HARLOCKER-Alice Stockton. Of Darien, CT on April 4, 1999. Mother of Carol McBee, Gay Tice and Lisa Ridabock. Sister of James & Howard Stockton. Grandmother of three. A funeral service will be held Wednesday, April 14, 1999 at 11:00AM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1864 Post Road, Darien, CT. Memorial contributions may be sent to St. Luke's Parish Book of Remembrance, P.O. Box 3128, Darien, CT. 06820 or to the Discovery Museum, 4450 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, CT. 06604.

title: Doffing Restraint
description: The Fifth Avenue Easter Parade is never about marching bands (much to the disappointment of expectant tourists). The parade dates from the 1880's, when the city's newly rich built their mansions and churches above 34th Street. As they paraded along in their finery, they were avidly watched by milliners and designers scouting the upper crust for the latest fashions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, DAVID
description: SHULMAN-David. Beloved husband of the late Nettie. Survived by daughter and son-in-law Geri and Bud Telchin, son and daughter-in-law Michael and Laurette; grandchildren Allison, Douglas and Robert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, ETHEL
description: SILVERMAN-Ethel. (nee Rubin) Coconut Creek, Florida. On April 7, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Rochelle Schneider and Mark Silverman. Dear sister of Sarah Benson and Phil Rubin. Loving grandmother of seven grandchildren. Services ''Wien & Wien'' 129 Engle St. Englewood, NJ, Sunday, 1PM. Should friends desire contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, or Vitas Hospice.

title: Berliners
description: A sampling of opinion about the city's future as a cultural capital, compiled by Kevin Cote, editor of Zitty, a biweekly guide to cultural events in Berlin.

title: Washington Talk; Soft Money and Some Not-So-Hard Promises
description: Bookshelves in the capital are sagging with countless handsomely bound, carefully researched, long-forgotten reports proposing laws and policies that, were they ever to be adopted, would affect millions of Americans.

title: Taste This!
description: Good taste is easy to recognize -- or so Lauren Bacall would have us believe in her commercials for Fancy Feast cat food. Alas, in the mercurial worlds of interior design and decoration, deciding what constitutes good taste has become a rather complicated endeavor. Take the example of mid-century modern furniture. Originally conceived as affordable design for the forward-thinking, it was banished, barely three decades later, to attics and garage sales. Now, at the close of the century, its fortunes have turned yet again, and it is plucked from those attics, Cinderella-like, and whisked away to rarefied furniture galleries, where it wears not ballgowns, but dizzying price tags.

title: Stalemate
description: Endgame

title: Grist for Orwell
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: THE INK DRINKER

title: Amid SoHo's Art, Some Artful Food
description: ABYSSINIA +++

title: Nematodes, for a Good Night's Sleep
description: Black vine weevil is as destructive as it sounds: its larvae feed on and destroy the roots of rhododendrons (a favorite), daphnes, roses, blueberries and many other shrubs. Some people wait until adults emerge in summer, hand-picking them by the hundreds at night when they feed. But it's more effective to spray the soil now with beneficial microscopic nematodes that control the weevil's grubs and those of cutworms and Japanese beetles.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SINGER, HERBERT
description: SINGER-Herbert. Two years have passed. You are always in our hearts. There will never be another caring generous husband, father and grandfather like you. Leona and your loving family.

title: OUTDOORS; The Inventor Who Helped Novices Cast Like Pros
description: In the fall of 1947, the fisherman R. D. Hull arrived at the headquarters of the Zero Hour Bomb Company on Easton Street in Tulsa, Okla., with a prototype of what would become America's most popular fishing reel. It was made from the metal lid of a can of Folgers mountain grown drip grind coffee, an 11-inch-long piece of wire, a wooden sewing thread spool and braided nylon line.

title: A Matter of Timing For Return of Torre
description: Joe Torre was relaxing in a plush maroon chair behind his desk at Yankee Stadium yesterday, just like always. There was a pile of white lineup cards tempting him from a few inches away, just like always. There was a calmness in his voice and a serenity spread over his craggy face, just like always. Only it was not just like always.

title: Sing Ho for Those Swashbuckling Sailors
description: Things are seldom what they seem,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALSAM, RUTH ROSALIE
description: BALSAM-Ruth Rosalie. On April 9, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Artur. President of the Artur Balsam Foundation for Chamber Music. She will be deeply missed. A gathering of friends will be held Tuesday, April 13, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Artur Balsam Foundation, 825 West End Ave., New York, NY 10025.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: NO VOICE FROM THE HALL

title: Lynn Underwood, John McCormick
description: Lynn Ann Underwood and John Bradley McCormick were married yesterday by the Rev. Albert Scherer at the Roman Catholic Basilica of St. Stanislaus in Chicopee, Mass.

title: Mature Subject Matter
description: Amy M. Spindler (March 21) writes, ''There has always been something fishy about the whole youth movement in couture.'' Then, in the fashion layout, you feature Faye Dunaway, a woman so ''face-lifted'' that she looks like a frozen cartoon. For this feature to have resonated, you should have chosen someone who has aged gracefully and naturally. The selection of Dunaway, looking as she does, makes this seem like satire.

title: Where Have All the War Dividends Gone?
description: THE aerial bombardment of Serbia and Kosovo has been going on for more than two weeks, but so far, Wall Street has been unmoved by the barking dogs of war.

title: In the Region /Long Island; Giving Lower-Income Buyers a Down-Payment Lift
description: A COUPLE now living in a crowded two-bedroom apartment in Brentwood will soon move with their two sons into a four-bedroom Cape Cod in East Massapequa. Considering tax benefits, it will cost them only slightly more than their current $839-a-month rent, thanks to a $10,000 Nassau County grant.

title: Serial Mom
description: Starr Bright Will Be

title: Seriously, China Learning Sex Is Fun
description: There are two sides to the sexual revolution that is sweeping through China.

title: Building a Capital Where Triumph Is Taboo
description: STENDHAL once remarked of Berlin that he had no idea ''who thought of planting a town in the middle of this sand.'' Out of the damp sand, not far from the Reichstag, beneath the countless cranes that are the sentinels of this city's shifting heart, a hole has been dug. It is huge even by the standards of this home of excavational excess; it will, so the planners say, one day house Berlin's new central railway station, a hub of north-south and east-west lines worthy of a European capital reborn.

title: Spotlight on an Unseemly Critter
description: The J.B.J. Discount Pet Shop on Houston Street is crawling with roaches, and its owner, Linda Uhram, couldn't be happier. Six years ago, looking for ''something different'' for the shop, which she has run since 1996, Ms. Uhram bought two Madagascar hissing cockroaches from an animal importer for $10 each. One died, she replaced it, and her current inventory of 4,000 roaches are all descendants of that original couple. Each roach sells for $15.

title: Report Card: How the Island's Third Graders Are Reading
description: The State Education Department released its latest school report cards yesterday, providing a window on student performance on Long Island and around the state.

title: In the Pine Barrens, a Town Built on Hard Work and Snuff
description: The tiny town of Helmetta, tucked in a corner of the Pine Barrens in Middlesex County, is on both the national and state historic registers, but that does not automatically provide protection from development encroaching on the mill town that was built around a once-thriving snuff industry.

title: A Playwright Reports in Person
description: YOU might not fully appreciate it when it happens, but the most memorable and gutsy moment of this theatrical season to date is when David Hare, a slim, trim, unassuming figure in his 50's, wearing gray slacks and an open-neck shirt, steps onto the stage of the Booth Theater to begin his performance playing David Hare in his own ''Via Dolorosa.''

title: Screen Stars
description: In an era in which computers become obsolete 20 minutes after you buy them, I have a more pressing concern: I'm about to become obsolete myself.

title: Payback
description: SECOND HAND SMOKE

title: PULSE; Vintage Frames (80's and Older)
description: With designers from Tommy Hilfiger to Christian Dior mining retro styles for sunglasses, one hardly need dig through dusty old pairs at the flea market.

title: Top Figure-Skating Coach Is Accused of Sexual Misconduct
description: For two decades, Richard Callaghan and Craig Maurizi worked together in the sport of international figure skating. Callaghan was first Maurizi's coach, then his colleague, and the two together coached some of the most promising skaters in the United States. Throughout, they enjoyed considerable success.

title: From India, Instruments for Soul Music
description: Five years ago, Keshav Hunter took a yoga class for the first time and was intrigued by the devotional music played during the meditation session. Soon, he began learning how to play such music himself.

title: Breaking a Family Tradition
description: For a time, it looked as if the son would go the way of the father, toughing it out in great style. But John A. Gotti had learned another lesson from watching his father: If the Government wants to put away a mobster, it can be pit-bull relentless. It tried John J. Gotti four times before convicting him of murder in 1992.

title: The Pilgrimage From Tiananmen Square
description: How do revolutions get started? Obviously rebellions begin with serious discontents, about oppression, corruption and so on. The protest movement that began at Tiananmen Square in Beijing 10 years ago this month was not really a revolution, although it could have turned into one. Oppression and corruption were certainly two of its root causes. But there were other influences, of a more cultural nature, that inspired the protesters. One of them was a television movie made a year before, in 1988. It was titled ''Yellow River Elegy.''

title: THE GUIDE
description: Asian Mask Making

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINIG, JUDY
description: EINIG-Judy. April 7, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Marvin. Mother of Steven and Janet, Robert and Beth, Marlon and Halee. Loving grandmother of Morgan, Ilana, Ross, Summer and Max.

title: New Jersey Isn't First To Supply Dog Runs
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil: A bit of jungle near Rio's beaches
description: The hundreds of thousands of visitors who travel to Rio de Janeiro each year go there thinking not of eco-tourism but of sun, sand and shopping. Yet within the limits of the sybaritic city lies a natural wonder, Tijuca National Park and Forest, 13 sprawling square miles of jungle, mountain peaks, trails and waterfalls that offer travelers a miniversion of the Amazon.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Close to Home

title: Man's Best Friend, and Doesn't Bite
description: A CHINESE proverb says, ''The only way to keep a family in existence for generations is to think cabbage-stalks nice.'' The humble cabbage has long been associated with poverty and endurance. Since a bit of it, boiled, might be the only food available, countless cooks have encouraged their families to like it.

title: How Can We Help the Children of Inmates?; America's Prison Boom
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; Cowboy Feminism
description: As that wacky Freud gloomily observed, ''My God, what does a woman want?''

title: First Strikes Against Bias
description: Q. I am black and a middle manager at a large company. Before joining it several years ago, I made sure the company had strong anti-discrimination policies and rising numbers of black and Hispanic employees. But now it's apparent that members of racial minority groups are concentrated in departments like public relations and human resources, with limited prospects for promotion. Some colleagues are considering a group complaint to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Should I join them, or should I try to find a department that gives blacks the best chances? Or should I leave?

title: There at the Creation
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Guard Recommends Licensing Boat Captains
description: A Coast Guard task force created after several fishing boats sank off the New Jersey Coast last winter has recommended licensing boat captains and mandatory safety inspections for their boats.

title: The Master
description: THE MAKING OF THE MASTERSClifford Roberts, Augusta National,and Golf's Most Prestigious Tournament.By David Owen.Illustrated. 289 pp. New York:Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: A Cross Between Grandma and Jughead
description: Let me say this up front: I'm from Philadelphia, and pizza sauce is important to me. Though I grew up with it served primarily on steak sandwiches, I can appreciate a rich sauce whether it's on a cheese steak or a hamburger.

title: Still Missing
description: DESIRE LINESBy Christina Baker Kline.343 pp. New York:William Morrow & Company. $24.

title: Stopping a Hostile Takeover of Another Kind
description: IN a natural world, wild flowers, shrubs and trees would grow together in a rich blend of biodiversity. Would that this could be true. But humankind has intervened and, because of that, certain plants are running amok. These galloping species have earned a certain notoriety and are called invasive exotics: weeds taking over acres and acres of land.

title: Fassel's Son a Draft Prospect
description: John Fassel, son of the Giants' head coach, Jim Fassel, is a wide receiver from Weber State who is eligible for the National Football League draft. The younger Fassel is 6 feet 4 inches and 188 pounds, and has been timed in 4.67 seconds for 40 yards.

title: PRIVATE SECTOR; But Does She Do Windows?
description: When Jack Rudin, the New York real estate executive, and his wife, Susan, wanted some help with the yard work, they called on Bette Midler. It helps that the yard is Central Park and that Ms. Midler has an apartment facing it. At a party last week honoring contributors to the Central Park Conservancy's Perimeter Association, for which Mrs. Rudin is co-chairwoman, Ms. Midler provided the star power.

title: A Small Horde Is on the Heels Of Olazabal
description: The leader board at the Masters is bunched as tightly as rush-hour traffic in Manhattan, with 16 players within five shots of the lead. Few Masters have entered the final day with so many contenders and so many intriguing possibilities.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: I NEED A SNAKE

title: What Kind of Peace in Kosovo?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle Of a War Foretold Years Ago
description: Andre Malraux, the French writer, once warned a Serbian visitor of the danger of an ''Algerian war'' in Kosovo. ''And your Algeria,'' he added, ''will not be on another continent, but in your heartland.''

title: Tag, You're It
description: ''I tagged 11 people on Saturday,'' Peter Cohen said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEANEY, THOMAS B.
description: HEANEY-Thomas B.. The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed General Manager. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Irwin H. Kramer, President

title: New York Politics May Hold Up Most of Nation's Tobacco Cash
description: The court fight over New York's share of the national tobacco settlement -- a battle primarily between Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- threatens to delay distribution of the money for all 46 of the states involved, lawyers and advocates involved in the settlement say.

title: Paintings That Offer Viewers A Look Out the Window
description: JANE FREILICHER and Fairfield Porter are realist painters who were also Long Island neighbors until Porter's death. What links them more closely, however, is that they were in the center of the circle that grew around the founding generation of the New York School of Poetry: John Ashbery, Frank O'Hara, Kenneth Koch and James Schuyler.

title: A Revival And, as Ever, A Revelation
description: THE very name Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater suggests several foods for thought. More than a nod to its founder, it implies identity with American dance, whatever that might be, and it calls itself not company or troupe, but Dance Theater, a term that blends two wide-ranging arts.

title: Check Out Your Driver
description: The Supreme Court handed a warning to automobile passengers: You give up your privacy rights when you get into the car, and if the driver gets into trouble with the law, so may you.

title: The Poor Neighbor
description: RUSSIA UNDER WESTERN EYES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, REBECCA (BEA)
description: SACKS-Rebecca (Bea). Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Norman Sacks and Phyllis Stern. Cherished grandmother of Laura, Karen, Lisa and Jamie. Great-grandmother of Danny, Alex, Remy and Cody. Services were held Friday, April 9.

title: In Tribute, Soldini Seeks Record at Site of Tragedy
description: It would seem that victory in a single-handed yacht race around the world would merit a nap in an Alpine meadow, or a walk in the park at least. But for Giovanni Soldini, the Italian likely to win the Around Alone sailing competition, another sea adventure is on the horizon.

title: Rose's Turn
description: I enjoyed Rebecca Johnson's profile of Charlie Rose (March 21). Perhaps his viewers are not looking for controversy -- or for Sam Donaldson shouting unanswerable questions. Perhaps they enjoy intelligent conversation with interesting people, on a simple set where the words are what matter. (Although Rose often does ask, politely, the potentially embarrassing question.)

title: Product Notebook
description: 1. Handmade 18-inch

title: Linda Lapos and Paul Wirth
description: Dr. Linda L. Lapos and Paul G. Wirth were married yesterday by Msgr. John P. Murphy at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Allentown, Pa.

title: A Doctorate Too Dry For Its Own Good?
description: THE Depression inspired thousands of young people to become economists. The War on Poverty and the Great Society in the 60's were similarly inspiring, and the upheavals today should be, too. What more noble work, after all, than coming to understand, and perhaps alleviate, the wage stagnation, the global pressures, the layoffs, the job insecurities and the long working days that weigh on so many people.

title: Turkey, Relenting, Shows the Works Of a Kurd Patriot
description: PROBABLY no Turkish film has had the worldwide impact of Yilmaz Guney's ''Yol,'' a harrowing look at what is portrayed as a land of harsh military rule and feudal codes.

title: Parents' Fundamental Right To Choose Schools
description: In his opinion essay, ''Chilling Facts of Charter Schools'' [March 21], Barry Edelson of the Roslyn public school district expressed great dismay over New York's new charter school legislation. No one should be surprised that public school administrators on Long Island, earning $100,00 a year, or public school teachers typically earning $80,000, get upset over the possibility of losing their educational finance monopoly and seeing parents actually given some freedom of choice as to which school to send their children.

title: Noises Off: A Muzzle for Cell Phones
description: THERE are places where cellular phones are as unwelcome as fire ants at a picnic. Just ask Laurence Fishburne.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on March 21 about open-microphone sessions at music clubs misidentified the singer shown. She was Janet Mack, not Ilona Chambers.

title: Winnie Mandela Back in South Africa's Spotlight
description: To those who wrote Winnie Madikizela-Mandela's political obituary a couple of years back: look again.

title: BOOKEND; April Again: Five for National Poetry Month
description: He Said

title: When Is a Pianist Not Just a Pianist? Brendel Demonstrates
description: Alfred Brendel, one of this era's definitive classical pianists, often gives performances in clusters. He is to appear this week in a solo recital in Newark and later this month in Princeton, playing Schubert lieder, with the baritone Mat thias Goerne. Both programs are to be presented at Carnegie Hall in this month's series focusing on the pianist as concerto soloist, recitalist, accompanist, chamber musician and poet, reading from his first book in English.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, RUTH S.
description: HELLER-Ruth S.. On April 9, 1999. Of Brooklyn, NY. Age 84. Beloved wife of the late Max Heller. Loving and devoted mother of daughter Matilda Katz & son Aaron Heller. Loving grandmother of ChaimMeir Katz, Shiphra Schorr, ChanaDaphna Shiffer, Chaim-Meyer Heller and Sara Lee Heller. Greatgrandmother of Bracha, Dina, Chananya, and Dovid Schorr. Funeral services will be Sunday, April 11, 1999, 11:30 AM, at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave. and Ave. M. Interment will follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. Shiva will be at 1268 East 28th St., Brooklyn, NY and 521 Northwest Drive, Silver Spring, MD. She will always be cherished in our hearts.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Bringing Markets To Milk
description: PONDER a perverse question: What public policies would pummel the poor? Here is one answer: Impose a levy that falls more heavily on them than on the rich, singling out a staple in the diet of poor families and driving up its price.

title: In Charleston, Spoleto Blooms Again
description: Charleston, S.C., has been making news in the performing arts since it staged America's first opera in 1735, and this spring, the 300-year-old city will welcome dancers, musicians and actors and their audiences for the 23d Spoleto Festival U.S.A.

title: The Sunny Side of the Cascades
description: NO matter what the weather's doing in Seattle, you can bet it will be better in the Methow Valley on the eastern side of the Cascade Range: hotter and sunnier in summer, snowing feathery powder instead of drizzling steadily in winter, crisper in autumn, fresher in spring. But mostly just plain drier.

title: Refinancing Second Mortgages
description: MOST homeowners are aware that they may save money by refinancing their current mortgage to a loan with a lower interest rate.And they have also heard they may be able to save more money by using a home-equity loan or line of credit to pay off high-interest-rate credit card debt.

title: The Travails Of Europe: A Manager Sees Hope
description: IT wasn't so long ago that experts figured Europe was picking up enough economic momentum that the world would scarcely notice if American consumers could no longer prime the world economy with their free-spending ways.

title: Correction
description: An entry in the Benefits column last Sunday about a fund-raising dinner this Tuesday misstated the name of the sponsoring environmental organization. It is the Natural Resources Defense Council, not the National Resources Defense Council. For information and tickets: (212) 573-6933.

title: Judicial Wrongdoing Needs Continued Exposure
description: I read with interest your groundbreaking expose [''What Happens If Process Server Doesn't Serve?'' April 4] of a judicial system that is out of control. Norman Yellon's fraud on the judicial system for two decades required the tacit knowledge of the clerks of the courts as well as the knowledge of the major law firms that used his service.

title: Despite Acquittal, Teacher Faces Loss of Job
description: A Florham Park elementary school teacher, who was acquitted last month of criminal charges that he fondled 12 female students, could still face administrative charges by the school system that could jeopardize his job, board members and state officials say.

title: News on Piazza Sobers Mets: Out 2-3 Weeks
description: Throughout the 11 innings of their game with the Expos here today, the Mets' thoughts were at least partly in New York, where Mike Piazza was undergoing a magnetic resonance imaging test of his right knee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYNG, LILA HOTZ LUCE
description: TYNG-Lila Hotz Luce. Grosvenor Neighborhood House would like to express its gratitude for many, many years of loyalty and friendship to our work. Her warm, thoughtful, and consistent contributions as a Board Member from 1946 to 1958 and as a Board Associate from 1958 to 1997 will always be remembered with deep appreciation. Grosvenor Neighborhood House Mrs. Arthur Cowen III, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILENO, ANTHONY JR.
description: SILENO-Anthony Jr.. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Anthony Sileno Jr., associated with The Times from 1959 until retiring in 1998.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-11-99 - Salient Facts; Fewer Fish in the Sea
description: WHAT'S THE NEW ENDANGERED ENTREE?

title: Ms. McCarroll And Mr. Attar
description: Deborah Anne McCarroll, a daughter of Lillian and John McCarroll of Manhasset, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Mark Monzer Attar, the son of Janice Summerlin of Tampa, Fla., and Dr. Monzer Attar of Lubbock, Tex. The Rev. Jeffrey Johnston performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: Attorney General Backs Pesticide Notice Bill
description: The state Attorney General, Elliot Spitzer, said last week he supports a bill in the State Assembly that would require 48 hours' notice to neighbors before adjoining lawns and shrubs were sprayed with pesticides.

title: Charity Plea In Italy Draws Money Used To Pay Priests
description: Using stark images of sick and starving children, the Roman Catholic Church in Italy is beginning its annual fund-raising drive.

title: In This Fight, Landlord Covers Bases
description: Apparently jittery over the 134,000-square-foot Home Depot that opened across the street in January, the owner of a shopping plaza is preparing for the possibility that Pergament Home Center, its anchor tenant, may lose the battle between the supersized home-supply retailers. The two stores are on opposite sides of 48th Street, south of Northern Boulevard.

title: Checkbook Is Open, Chemistry Book Closed
description: For the past eight years, the Knicks' team president, Ernie Grunfeld, has left other general managers envious while he dips into the league's largest revenue pool with a crane's scoop. But after seasons of using cash piles to facilitate trades and patch up mistakes, Grunfeld has helped turn an organization that once contended for a title into a money pit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLBE, NATHAN
description: OLBE-Nathan. Age 97, of Jackson Heights, New York, passed away peacefully on April 4, 1999, in a nursing home in Largo, Maryland. His wife, Elfriede, died in 1974. His first marriage to Fernande Briefel ended in divorce. Beloved father of Ellen Tillier, and stepdaughter, Ellen Kohlberg, adoring grandfather of Paul Tillier and Anne Tillier de Castro, doting great-grandfather of Leo and Clara de Castro. He will also be dearly missed by his son-in-law, Alfred Kohlberg Jr., his grandson-in-law, Fernando de Castro, as well as by his nieces, nephews, neighbors, friends and other relatives. Born in Poland, in 1901, he met the many challenges of his long life, which spanned the century, with courage, determination and optimism. His kindness, warmth and cheerfulness were legendary. As doyen of a large family and the last of his generation, his death marks the end of an era. A memorial service, to be held in New York, will be anounced at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ECKSTEIN, REBECCA S.
description: ECKSTEIN-Rebecca S.. A service will be held in memory of Rebecca S. Eckstein, on Sunday, April 18th at 2 PM.,. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, DR. HOWARD S.
description: KESSLER-Dr. Howard S.., DVD, Director of the New York Veterinary Hospital on 74th St. and Lexington Ave. died on April 8, 1999. The cause of death was cancer. Dr. Kessler was one of the most respected veterinarians in the United States with a practice that included some of New York's most prominent citizens and he was involved in many pet charities. Dr. Kessler was the son of Arthur and Gail Kessler. He is survived by his mother, his sister Lois Kessler, his brother Barry Kessler, MD and hundreds of friends who loved him. Dr. Kessler will be buried on April 12, 1999. The funeral will be held at 12 noon at Beth El Synagogue, 500 Jerome Ave., Margate, NJ. Charitable contributions may be made to The American Cancer Society.

title: The Top Schools
description: The New York State Department of Education is releasing annual report cards on individual public schools, including last year's performance on statewide exams. The state has already reported that, overall, third graders' performance on the reading exam dipped slightly, with 84 percent meeting minimum requirements compared to 86 percent the previous year. In sixth grade, minimum reading competency fell 3 percentage points to 83 percent. And on the English Regents exam, 67 percent passed, about the same as the previous year. The highest performing schools were typically in affluent suburbs or focused on the gifted and talented. What follows are the top 25 schools based on the percentage of students achieving the highest levels on the exams. The ranking does not include schools in which fewer than 20 students took an exam, and some schools were exempt from the Regents test. For schools without a free lunch program, figures are estimated. RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOROWITZ, HENRY
description: HOROWITZ-Henry. April 11, 1994. TO MY FATHER A giant pine, magnificent and old, Stood staunch against the sky and all around Shed beauty, grace, and power. Within its fold Birds safely reared their young. The velvet ground Beneath was gentle, and the cooling shade Gave cheer to passers-by. Its towering arms A landmark stood, erect and unafraid, As if to say, ''Fear naught from life's alarms.'' It fell one day. Where it had dauntless stood Was loneliness and void. But men who passed Paid tribute-said, ''To know this life was good, It left its mark on me. Its work stands fast.'' And so it lives. Such life no bonds can holdThis giant pine, magnificent & old. In loving memory-always. Linda and family

title: Corrections

(James Forrestal was his father, the nation's first Secretary of Defense.)

title: Too Much Cash? Just Give It Away.
description: Flush with cash from the soaring stock market, the nation's foundations gave away a record amount of money last year, according to a recent study. Foundations made an estimated $19.5 billion in grants in 1998 to not-for-profit organizations, according to the Foundation Center, a New York group that tracks foundation giving. The amount represents an increase of about 41 percent since 1996.

title: The Glow at the End of the Dial; No Hits, All the Time
description: Rising out of the thick scratchiness of an ancient 78-r.p.m. record, the sound of a stringed instrument travels through the darkened bar, vaguely bluesy, yet with a distinct Middle Eastern tonality. A rich male voice joins in, singing something garbled and foreign. In a cramped booth in the back, the disk jockey, a manic Allen Ginsberg look-alike, stands behind a pair of turntables and a stack of machinery, furiously pulling records and CD's, squinting to read the labels. ''This is Greek hashish music,'' he yells at me. ''In the late 20's, they'd go to these clubs and take these drugs and then they'd go elsewhere and sing about it all night. There are places like this still in Queens. I went to a nightclub once and interviewed this 87-year-old musician for two hours, and at the end of the interview he asked me where he could score! It's unbelievable.'' He grins and turns up the music.

Luecke of Madison, Conn. The Rev. Charles C. McLaughlin performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Anselm in Brooklyn.

description: After pleading poverty, a pricey paint job and a stack of costly environmental projects awaiting financing, the Delaware River Port Authority announced Tuesday that it will try to raise tolls on its four bridges and its commuter rail line by as much as 50 percent.

title: Staying Safe In the Wild
description: WHEN injuries happen on trips in the wild, or even on casual outdoor vacations, a case can sometimes be made for blaming the victim. Failing to wear a helmet on a bike, skipping vaccinations before going camping, jumping off a boat in the middle of a lake: Such actions, or inactions, are invitations to danger.

description: IN the world according to Guare -- John Guare, that is -- the more things change, the more they, well, don't change.

title: Yank Fans Imitate Artwork By Clemens
description: Roger Clemens will inspire the imagination of Yankee Stadium's decorators like no other pitcher in club history. While he made his debut as a Yankee there yesterday, a half-dozen amateur artists tried to keep up with Clemens's strikeouts, in varying fashions. Hanging from the grandstands, there were K's in script and K's in medical tape and, in honor of Clemens's nickname, silver rockets hung by one fan.

title: The World; War Teaches NATO What Its Role Is

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENIN, ALBERT
description: BENIN-Albert. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the death of Albert Benin, a devoted friend of the Jewish communities of New York, Israel and France. By creating scholarship funds for the support of scientific study, he enabled students here and in Israel to further their knowledge of the world around us. A true citizen of the world, he will be missed by all whose lives he touched. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Lynn Korda Kroll, Chair, PG&E Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

description: IF the Masters really begins on the back nine on Sunday, as so many here like to say, it will be an even more difficult back nine at Augusta National today, particularly and possibly poignantly because of changes on two of the four finishing holes.

title: The Glow at the End of the Dial; Ira Glass Is, Um (Pause, Delete) . . . Listening: The Perfectly Edited World of His 'American Life.'
description: One minute after midnight, Ira Glass, host of the public-radio program ''This American Life,'' is huddled over his computer, editing an interview using digital software in his chaotic Chicago office. The voices on the tape are those of Glass and Alexa Junge, story editor of the NBC sitcom ''Friends.'' For more than four hours, Glass has been agonizing over every stammer, every breath, every millisecond between words in what originally was a 12-minute chat. ''Should I laugh there?'' he whispers to himself. ''No. I should not.''

title: The Dangerous Necessity of Eating
description: SUPERMARKETS don't scare me any more. For years I was terrorized by the health police. ''You are digging your grave with your teeth,'' they said. ''If you die, it's your own fault.'' Guilt and anxiety fought a losing battle against a healthy appetite and a hyperactive food industry. When I went shopping, I carried a magnifying glass to read the tiny lists of ingredients and nutrition information on packages, and a chemical dictionary to translate them.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMMONS, DEBBY AND LENNY
description: SIMMONS-Debby and Lenny. Gone all too soon. Always in our hearts. Mom and Dad

description: COMBAT

title: Arthur M. Hettich, 73, Executive Who Guided Popular Magazines
description: Arthur M. Hettich, a retired senior executive for The New York Times Company's magazine group and a former president of Family Circle magazine, disappeared on Monday while swimming off Grand Turk Island in Turks and Caicos and is presumed drowned, according to his family. He was 73.

title: Trashcraft, or Making an Art of Garbage Cans
description: Some art, critics say, is trash. But can trash -- or receptacles for it -- be art? The Alliance for Downtown New York thinks so. These sleek modern garbage cans, designed by the architecture firm Cooper Robertson & Partners, are replacing 600 corroding ones south of City Hall. Each one costs $500, and local businesses are being asked to ''adopt'' -- that is, pay for -- them. The waste bins are part of a program called the Downtown New York Streetscape Plan, which aims to give lower Manhattan a ''much needed face lift, transforming it into a lively and dynamic 24-hour, seven-day-a-week community,'' said Valerie Lewis, a spokeswoman for the alliance, which manages the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Business Improvement District. ''We wanted a trash basket that easily seconds as a work of art,'' Ms. Lewis said. ''We think these modern and stylish new baskets meet the challenge.'' What else is planned? New street names and signs in the first year of the program, followed by reconstruction of lower Broadway in the next five years, including new sidewalks, granite curbs, street and pedestrian lights, building facade lighting and seasonal plantings.

title: Capturing Ears on the Internet
description: ''HELL'S BELLS,'' a raucous anthem by the rock group AC/DC, blared from loudspeakers as Michael Robertson, the chief executive of MP3.com, walked to the podium. It seemed an unlikely introduction at last month's New York Music and Internet Expo for a man who wore a conservative camel hair sports jacket -- and who had an evangelical Christian background.

title: Stopping a Hostile Takeover of Another Kind
description: IN a natural world, wild flowers, shrubs and trees would grow together in a rich blend of biodiversity. Would that this could be true. But humankind has intervened and, because of that, certain plants are running amok. These galloping species have earned a certain notoriety and are called invasive exotics: weeds taking over acres and acres of land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUDES, BERNARD
description: HUDES-Bernard. Died on April 5, 1999. Beloved husband of Bessie. Loving father of Matthew and Ellen, and their spouses Qui and Michael. Proud grandfather of Colette, Simon, Adam and Daniel. Survived by dear brother Ira, his wife Sylvia, and well loved nieces and nephews.

title: The Deal Is Done. The Work Begins.
description: DAVID HADFIELD still winces when he recalls the 1989 merger of Coopers & Lybrand and some international operations of Deloitte, Haskins & Sells. ''We figured they're both accounting firms, they trade in the same markets, so of course their cultures would be the same,'' said Mr. Hadfield, who was a consultant with Deloitte at the time. ''We couldn't have been more wrong.''

title: Ideas & Trends: Shall I Compare Thee to a Swarm of Insects?; Searching for the Essence of the World Wide Web
description: GAZING through a computer screen onto the vast expanse of the World Wide Web, one feels like an explorer perched at the edge of an endless wilderness. It's a bit of a letdown, then, to learn how very finite the whole place really is.

description: HEINRICH-Hilda J.. On April 3, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Kurt A. Heinrich, M.D. Loving mother of Jean and Eric Loeb, and Dr. George and Debra Heinrich. Cherished grandmother of Andrew and Marc Heinrich, Carol and William Meyers, Dr. Susan and Andrew Zeitlin. Adoring great-grandmother of Benjamin, Leah and Sarah Meyers, and Jacob Zeitlin.

title: On the Trail of Savory Mexican Salsas
description: VILLA DEL SOL in Westport is indeed a house of the sun. The new Mexican restaurant has turned a limited space into a fiesta of bright colors, beginning with a canopy of rounded barrel staves covered with Mexican striped fabric extending along the center of the narrow room. Woven striped chair seats and matching curtains, vases and plates add festive accents to a large menu of Mexican specialties, many of which are new to the local dining scene.

title: Helicopters: More Towns Are Starting To Say No
description: A FANTASY for those stuck in traffic and a convenience for corporate executives, the helicopter is the ultimate freedom machine. Unencumbered by flight plans or runways, these air taxis can take off at a moment's notice and land a few steps from a passenger's final destination.

title: Kathryn Peck, Brian Rutenberg
description: Dr. Kathryn Peck, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at Tisch Hospital in New York, is to be married this afternoon to Brian Rutenberg, an artist in New York. The Rev. John Bucki is to perform the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Snobbery and Murder in Legal Chambers
description: HAVING previously focused on crime in the worlds of publishing and medicine and at a nuclear power station, P. D. James turns her sights, and her keen insights, on the London legal community in ''A Certain Justice.'' Following other adventures of the fictional New Scotland Yard detective Adam Dalgliesh, this 1997 novel has been adapted for television in a three-part series beginning on Thursday on ''Mystery.''

title: Bound for Glory
description: Tell Jeffrey Bilhuber, a Manhattan interior designer, that a copy of ''David Adler: The Architect and His Work,'' by Richard Pratt, sold recently at a garage sale for a few dollars, and he just might burst into tears. ''That's how much I care,'' he says of the book, which is filled with photographs of chic Georgian exteriors and interiors in Jazz Age Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, JAMES
description: CLARK-James. Of Palm Beach died on April 7, 1999. He is survived by his wife Irma and his children Susan and Harlan Ellis, Terry and David Brooks and Shelley Clark. Grandfather of Robert, Paul, Julie, Victoria, Andrew and Elizabeth and sister Hilda Gertler. Service Sunday, 10 AM, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Peter Thacher, Diplomat, 72; Helped to Lead a U.N. Agency
description: Peter Shaw Thacher, a former State Department official and a retired deputy executive director of the United Nations Environment Program, died on April 3 at a nursing home in Mystic, Conn. He was 72 and lived in Stonington Borough.

title: Where the Albatross Is King
description: I WOULD never have set foot on Midway Atoll had I not turned 50 at the right moment. I was in search of a place I had not visited, never even dreamed of visiting, to mark the passage of the years. It happened that my neighbor knew of such a place, the remote isle in the north Pacific named Midway that was the scene of a decisive World War II naval battle but that had been off limits to tourists for more than half a century. She was conducting a major project in historical archeology there.

title: Drastic Action to Seal Leaks of Nuclear Secrets
description: The current furor over the Clinton Administration's handling of evidence of Chinese atomic espionage is now forcing the Administration to scramble to plug leaks at America's three major nuclear weapons laboratories, where it has been accused of responding sluggishly to security problems.

title: Bachelor Parties to Make a Satyr Weep
description: IN every man's life there comes a time when he must ask himself, On a scale of Alan Alda to Maxim magazine, where do I fall? His bachelor party is one of those times.

title: J. P. Morgan's Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Thalia Is Gutted, Dismaying Lovers of Art Deco
description: The Thalia Theater, on 95th Street off Broadway, for years a beloved revival movie house, was also known for its classic Art Deco interior. Last week, some preservationists were furious when they learned that the 292-seat Art Deco theater was gutted. It will be used as a staging area for builders preparing to erect a 22-story apartment building above it, and then turned into a new film and performance space.

description: In two weeks, the largest summit meeting in American history is happening here. Presidents, Prime Ministers, soldiers and statesmen from 42 nations will gather to honor the 50th anniversary of NATO.

title: Medicating the Mentally Ill
description: Since last January, when Kendra Webdale was pushed in front of a Manhattan subway train by a man with a history of mental problems, politicians in Albany have been debating whether to make it easier to force people with mental illness to take their medication. Andrew Goldstein, the man accused of shoving Ms. Webdale to her death, had been repeatedly hospitalized for schizophrenia, but seemed to have a pattern of dropping out of his treatment programs and neglecting to take his medicine.

title: Backtalk; The Lessons of Losers and Champions
description: March Madness bottomed out 15 days ago after Michigan State lost to Duke in a semifinal game of the Final Four. Minutes before the final buzzer in Florida, the first fire was set here. Soon more than 5,000 people were rampaging through downtown, drinking and shooting videos of each other breaking windows, throwing bottles and vandalizing cars, including a police cruiser. There was discussion that long night of calling out the National Guard.

description: LAURIE DELIA and her kindergarten class at Claude Chester School in Groton pondered a question. ''If someone comes along and wants to fight with you, what should you do?'' asked Ms. DeLia.

title: The Tornado Next Door
description: The guy at the next desk helps himself to your stash of chewing gum without asking. Or the woman behind you keeps erupting into laughter reminiscent of the Wicked Witch of the West. What kinds of co-worker behavior have tortured you at the office - and how have you dealt with them? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELLA FEMINA, CONCETTA
description: DELLA FEMINA-Concetta. On April 10, 1999. Beloved wife of Michael. Mother of Joseph, Jerry and Barbara. Grandmother of Donna, Michael, Danielle, Elisa, Jodi, Mark, Jessie and J.T. Greatgrandmother of Zoey, Zachary, Francesca, Mario Jr., Jack and Gia. Sister of the late Ferdinand. Funeral mass at Our Lady of Pompeii Church, 25 Carmine St., Monday, 11:00 AM. Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday 6:00 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 381 Park Ave. South, NY NY 10016.

title: Douglas Borthwick, Heather Waters
description: Heather Lynne Waters, a daughter of Nancy Waters Ray of Rockledge, Fla., and the late Jed L. Waters, was married yesterday to Douglas Cameron Borthwick, a son of Hilary and David Borthwick of Doylestown, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Thomas A. Hughart performed the ceremony at Central Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Art Career Follows After Collecting
description: SHE started out like many young marrieds decorating a new home one picture for over the sofa, another for over the bed. But those works, lithographs by Renoir and Picasso, bought for a few hundred dollars in the early 1950's, set Dr. Noel Frackman on the path to collecting.

title: Natural Selection; Revisiting the Classics of 20th-Century Design
description: The 20th century has seen a continuing tug of war between design and decoration. Design, with its connotations of architectural rigor, is a word used primarily as shorthand for modernism and its reductive influence on domestic rooms and their contents. Even this century's period-revival furniture, with few exceptions, displays a spareness that would have struck its original makers as downright bizarre. Modernism's chief legacy, however, is not the ubiquity of tubular-steel chairs, but rather a scorched-earth approach to the quantity of furniture a room should hold and the busy-ness of its walls and floors.

title: The Making of A Fugitive
description: Samuels is right to recognize the similarity between civil rights activists and pro-life protesters, when he describes the atmosphere among the protesters in Fulton County Jail. The civil rights movement and the pro-life movement have similar aims: to protect the most helpless among us, and to awaken the conscience of a nation.

title: The 'Leonardo' of Condoms
description: A CONDOM confrontation is taking place in a Federal courtroom in Newark in an emotionally charged dispute over the exquisite architecture of the prophylactic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, ROBERT N.
description: JACOBSON-Robert N.. On April 9, 1999, age 73, at his home in Harrison, NY. He was born to Daniel and Selma Jacobson on April 16, 1925, in the Bronx, NY. He served in the US Navy during WW II. Cornell University graduate with a BA in 1949, and MBA in 1950. On October 19, 1969, he married Siri Hauge, in NYC. Mr. Jacobson was Vice-President, Director of Customer Relations for International Flavors and Fragrances, NYC. He is survived by his wife Siri. Loving father of Patti, David, Per Robert, Kari and Lisa. Devoted grandfather of Travis and Megan. Visiting on Monday, 2-4 and 6-9 PM, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY. Funeral service at the Rye Presbyterian Church, on Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment to follow at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY. Memorial contributions would be appreciated to HHT Research in honor of Robert N. Jacobson, Yale University School of Medicine, 100 Church Street South, PO Box 7611, New Haven, CT 06516, attn: B. Sargent.

title: Works of Prose and Images Mark Overview of a Career
description: WHEN an exhibition takes a broad overview of an artist's career, it can be as perplexing as it is informative. Sometimes, exhibition organizers better serve the artist and the viewer when a cohesive, chronological presentation of one or two key aspects of a career is examined, thus yielding a clear and concise study of stylistic and technical developments.

title: Style; Footnotes
description: 1. Talk about a model of cool! Devon, on the catwalks of Paris and New York last month, wearing clothes from the fall collections.

title: Outrage Over Spano Abortion Vote
description: NICHOLAS A. SPANO'S vote in the State Senate is a symbolic one when it comes to abortion issues; the Republican-controlled Senate is solidly against abortion, and Mr. Spano's support of a woman's right to an abortion does not change that. Nor does the Senate endorsement of legislation limiting abortion change the fact that the Democratic-controlled Assembly consistently rejects any abortion restrictions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVEY, JANE F.
description: LEVEY-Jane F.. Writer, thinker and teacher. Died at home of acute myelogenous leukemia on Sunday, April 4, 1999 surrounded by loving friends and family. She is survived by her father Marvin Levey of Englewood, N.J., stepmom Suzan Gordon, three sisters, Marcy, Edee and Hilary, and brother Harlan. Jane graduated from Brown University in 1984, worked for several years at Yale Press and was a graduate student in U.S. History at Yale University. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, April 18th, at 1:30PM in New Haven, CT. at Battell Chapel, Elm and Cottage Streets.

title: Working to Prevent a 'Silent Exodus'
description: The hundreds of people who fill the main sanctuary of the Korean American Presbyterian Church of Queens in Flushing every Sunday sit stiffly as the senior pastor, the Rev. Young Choon Chang, preaches the ways of God to them in Korean. They murmur solemn hymns, following the lead of string musicians and a robed minister who waves his arms in broad strokes to keep time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, KONSTANTIN
description: GREGORY-Konstantin. Of Stamford, CT (formerly Thousand Oaks, CA) on April 8. Beloved husband of Marcelle, adoring father of Cynthia and proud grandfather of Lloyd. Devoted brother of George, Mary, Michael and Theodore. Requiem Saturday, April 10 at St. Michael the Archangel, Greenwich, at 11:30. His life was wholly devoted to the happiness of others. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Glaucoma Research Foundation, 490 Post St., San Francisco, CA 94102.

title: Teeming, Tempting Cairo
description: THE waiter leaned forward and set my bowl of soup in its place. He adjusted the silverware around my plate. Then he addressed me, in a conspiratorial tone.

title: An Inauspicious Start For a Chinese Premier's Visit
description: Curse the stars, or whatever one blames for bad timing, but Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China walked into a minefield when he visited Washington on the second stop on his nine-day, six-city tour of America. The 70-year-old Chinese leader, known for his hands-on management of his nation's economy and for his blunt speaking style, impressed people in the capital with his candor. But he blamed American politics for the failure to close a deal for China to enter the World Trade Organization, an agreement both Chinese and American negotiators said was agonizingly close.

title: Hoping for an Instant Replay
description: On opening day of the baseball season in St. Louis, the luster, the drama and anticipation -- the pure pleasure -- of much of last season appeared to have hardly faded at all. As soon as Mark McGwire came up to bat in the Cardinals' half of the first inning, the sellout crowd of nearly 50,000 stood and cheered. And they kept standing in prolonged homage as the millennium's Sultan of Swat -- the huge, rippling-muscled man who last season hit 70 homers, breaking Roger Maris's hallowed, single-season home-run record by an amazing nine -- walked. He struck out in the third inning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, SIDNEY
description: COHEN-Sidney. Age 82. Died peacefully at home on April 9 after a short illness. A devoted husband and lover, ardent musician, scientist and friend, who gave more than he received and who embodied the true essence of an intelligent, progressive and compassionate human being. He is the beloved husband of Murial Goldberg Cohen and the late Eva Cohen, and loving father of Robert Cohen. He is also mourned by his brother and sister-in-law Albert and Adele Cohen, his cousin Bernice Ferman and several nieces and nephews. He will be greatly missed by his stepchildren Victor Goldberg and Linda Silberstein, Norman and Diedre Goldberg, Nadine and Rick Solomon, their children and his close friend Victoria Wolf-Knapp. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the 92nd Street Y, 60 + Program, 1395 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10128. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYNOLDS, EUGENE P. SR.
description: REYNOLDS-Eugene P. Sr.. Of the town of Newburgh, NY. A mailer machinist for The New York Times, Edison, NJ. Resident of Newburgh since 1972 and former resident of Astoria, Queens. Died April 1, 1999, at home. He was 61. The son of John Sr. and Anna Duffy Reynolds, he was born March 16, 1938 in New York City. Mr. Reynolds was a member of the International Typographical Union of America and New York Mailers Union. He started a chapter of Alcoholics Anonymous at The New York Times in Edison, NJ, calling the group ''Best of Times.'' He pulled many young people into the group and changed their lives. Survivors included his wife, Gladys Dickinson Reynolds at home; two sons, Eugene P. Reynolds Jr. of Clintondale, NY and Robert Reynolds of Wallkill, NY; two daughters Diane Kopaskie and Denise Fleischer, both of Wallkill, NY; and two brothers Richard Reynolds of Newburgh and James Reynolds of New Paltz, NY; eight grandchildren; several nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by one sister Ruth Mazer and one brother John Reynolds Jr. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Orange County Hospice, 800 Stonybrook Court, Newburgh, NY 12550.

The purpose is to allow the plane, which has two engines, to fly the fastest route across the Pacific even when emergency airfields along the route are closed by bad weather.

title: The Making of A Fugitive
description: It is misleading to suggest that laws prohibiting violent behavior pushed anti-choice zealots to commit even more vicious attacks against clinics. Prior to the passage of the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act (FACE), in 1994, extremists had already established a pattern of reprehensible crimes. Even though the premeditated killing of abortion providers continued after FACE, one can only imagine the horrors that might have been perpetrated in the absence of a strong national law. In fact, anti-choice violence declined by more than half after FACE, primarily because extremist organizations and their members were, for the first time, subject to vigorous Federal prosecution, resulting in fines and imprisonment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, DOROTHY
description: ROSEN-Dorothy. Age 94, of heart failure, at her home in Tucson, AZ. Preceded in death by her husband, Theodore. Devoted mother and mother-in-law of Augusta and Henry Feinstein, Green Valley, AZ, and Ina and Irwin Rubenstein, Leucadia, CA. Beloved grandmother of Ione and Tony Stiegler, Ira and Juliana Rubenstein, and Ilana Rubenstein. Adored greatgrandmother of Ari, Cara and Rosalie. She devoted her life to helping others. She was the President of New York Chapter of Hadassah, 1951-53, and member of the National Board and President's Council. Active and helping others until her death, she had a keen intellect and was an avid reader. Donations to Hadassah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEAGLE, EDWARD
description: FLEAGLE-Edward., 90, a resident of Glen Cove since 1977, died Wednesday, April 7, 1999, at his home. Born in Yonkers, NY, on December 13, 1908, he was the son of Edward E. Fleagle, Sr., and Elizabeth (Bahret) Fleagle. Fleagle was a graduate of Yonkers High School, Pratt Institute School of Architecture, a post graduate of Columbia University and Beaux Arts School of Design. He married Agnes Flanagan of Rockland in 1947. From 1934 until his retirement in 1978, Fleagle owned and operated an architectural practice in Yonkers. Fleagle designed over fifty college and school buildings including Westchester Community College; College of Mt. St. Vincent, Riverdale; Elizabeth Seton High School and College, Yonkers. Fleagle was a recipient of numerous national design awards throughout his career. In 1974 he was elected to Fellowship in the American Institute of Architects, was past president of Westchester A.I.A. and member Emeritus of Maine Chapter A.I.A. Recently he was honored as the oldest living A.I.A. fellow living in the United States. In 1977 Fleagle received a gold medal from the Westchester A.I.A. for his outstanding contribution toward the betterment of the physical environment of Westchester County. He was the first to receive this award which was sponsored by the County Government and the Westchester architects. He served as trustee of the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers from 1950 to 1973, including terms as president of the board; vice chairman and chairman of the Westchester Planning Board for twenty-three years. Fleagle served as trustee of St. Thomas Aquinas College in Sparkill, NY, trustee for Peoples Westchester Savings Bank and its predecessor Peoples Savings Bank of Yonkers for 32 years until his retirement to Maine. He was a parishioner of St. Bernard's Catholic Church. Together with his wife, Agnes Flanagan Fleagle, they established the Fleagle-Flanagan Scholarship Trust for high school graduates continuing their education in college and technical schools. Surviving is his nephew, Gerald R. Westcott, Jr., of Leola, PA, and personal caregivers, Vicki, Linda, Patti, Heidi, Eileen, Gail, Yvonne. His wife, Agnes Flanagan Fleagle, died September 27, 1993, and his sister, Helen Westcott died previously. Calling hours and prayers were Friday, April 9, 1999, at Carpenter Funeral Home, 306 Broadway, Rockland. The funeral mass was celebrated Saturday, April 10, 1999, at St. Bernard's Catholic Church, 150 Broadway, Rockland, with the Rev. Valmont Gilbert officiating. Burial followed in St. James Cemetery, Thomaston. Memorial donations may be made in his memory to the FlanaganFleagle Education Trust, c/o Cynthia Webre Shuman, 5953 Green Tree, Houston, Texas 77057.

title: RIO

title: Crossroads of Half a Million Lives

To make a long, tedious story short, I did follow his footsteps, though I can't afford Mamaroneck, the trains are now reliable and Grand Central is once again the city's crown jewel. (I still refuse to wear raincoats.)

title: In America; Senior Citizens on the Bread Line

While much of America was experiencing an economic boom, she was making a demoralizing move from her comfortable home in the Phoenix suburb of Youngtown to a low-income residence in nearby El Mirage. Having reached her 70's (''I won't tell you exactly how old I am,'' she said), Ms. Heuser, a widow, frequently found herself without money for food.

Belying this placid tableau east of Salida, Colo., the 125-pound ewe raised her head as we approached, her heart pounding wildly. It wasn't love at first sight. She bolted down the railroad tracks.

title: In Art, Too, The Sound Is Spooky
description: IT may seem odd that a video artist like Douglas Gordon should be drawn to Alfred Hitchcock's ''Vertigo'' by its soundtrack. But having previously manipulated the images of movies like Hitchcock's ''Psycho'' and Rouben Mamoulian's ''Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde,'' Mr. Gordon wanted this time to probe the psychological dimension of music scores. And with ''Vertigo,'' a good measure of the spookiness of the 1958 thriller starring James Stewart and Kim Novak is provided by Bernard Herrmann's music.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-11-99 - Family Affair; Separated at Birth
description: Once upon a time, a year ago, a woman named Donna Fasano sought high-tech help in conceiving a baby. By accident, her fertility doctor implanted in her womb not only Mr. and Mrs. Fasano's own fertilized embryo, but that of another couple as well. And this past December, Donna Fasano gave birth to two genetically unrelated babies, one white, one black -- ''twins,'' ostensibly, but about as much alike as Arnold Schwarzenegger and Danny DeVito. Like all such stories from the medical frontiers of baby-making, this one sounds a lot like science fiction. But at its heart, it is something much older -- something much more like a fairy tale.
