title: The View From/Washington; Small Church Nearly Bursts With Sound of New Pipe Organ
description: TWO weeks ago, on Palm Sunday, parishioners filled nearly every available seat at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington. There was a sense of anticipation in the air. When the organist, Mark Scholtz, played the processional hymn ''All Glory, Laud and Honor,'' the congregation sang along enthusiastically.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIN, ELIOT DEY
description: SCHEIN-Eliot DeY. Of South Salem, NY. On April 2, 1999 after a courageous struggle, at age 58. President of Schein/Blattstein Advertising, professor at Pace University, author, columnist, speaker, past president of NY Direct Marketing Club and a leading voice in the industry. Eliot was a devoted son of the late Max and Claire (Rosenwald) Schein. The loving partner of Elizabeth Krajcsik. A good-hearted and loving nephew and cousin. A caring and cherished ''adopted'' uncle. And an attentive and unswervingly loyal friend. He loved life and all that was good and fine in it. He touched many lives and will be missed by all. To those who wish to pay tribute Eliot would no doubt suggest live each day, savor its gifts, and do the right thing. A Memorial Service will be held 4pm on on Thursday, April 15th, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Fixing Damage to Carpets and Floors
description: THE floors in homes, whether they be wood or covered with vinyl or carpeting, take a lot of abuse. Floors exposed to heavy traffic suffer occasional damage and require spot repairs. The most common repairs for vinyl flooring include flattening blisters and patching tears or scratches. Common carpet repairs include removing burns and stains and regluing loose seams.

title: Doing a Double Take Over an Annual Report
description: One thing about Tenneco Inc.: It may not officially confirm rumors, but it doesn't let them die down either. Nine months ago, Tenneco first floated the idea of splitting into two companies, one making automotive products and one making packaging. Since then, Wall Street has waited in vain for a definitive announcement.

title: New White Plains Plan
description: After months of rumors and delays, Tishman Speyer Properties has presented a revised -- and significantly scaled down -- proposal for developing a business district in White Plains, George Gretsas, a spokesman for Mayor Joseph M. Delfino, said.

title: For the Market In Second Homes, No Vacation
description: KEN Davis has been looking for a second home in Vermont for several months now, but hasn't yet found what he wants at the right price. ''I've put bids on a few properties,'' he said, ''but they weren't my dream houses, so I could afford to let them go.''

title: Hard News for Kosovar Newspaper Editor
description: Since the first NATO air strikes in the Balkans on March 24, life at the Albanian- and English-language semiweekly newspaper Illyria has taken on a frenzied pace, even as the paper's 10 staff members worry about family and friends from Kosovo.

title: Is Paris Resisting?
description: RED GOLD

title: Aftershock
description: WORKING WITH AVAILABLE LIGHTA Family's World After Violence.By Jamie Kalven.320 pp. New York:W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95.

title: Industrial Age Ghosts Granted New Lives
description: EASTERN Connecticut is dotted with old mills, reminders in brick and stone of a time -- the last half of the 19th century and first half of the this century -- when the region was famed worldwide for its textile industry.

title: Michele Molotsky, Richard Smith
description: Michele F. Molotsky and Richard C. Smith were married last evening at the Willow Grove Inn in Orange, Va. Ed Tucker, an Orange County (Va.) marriage commissioner, officiated.

title: The Knife and Fork Takes Another Roll of the Dice
description: At a time when this city can't tear down landmarks fast enough, here is the story of the one that got away.

title: Bridgemarket and Its Neighborhood
description: To the Editor:

title: A Suggestion for Using Quantities of Day-Old Food
description: Perhaps the food pantries and people serving the hungry, as mentioned in ''The Many Faces of Hunger'' on March 14, could get a van or two and a storage place with refrigeration. That way workers could pick up day-old deli, dairy, produce, bakery and bread products Monday through Friday and take them to a storage place.

title: Sales to Minors
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed legislation to prevent the sale of tobacco and alcohol to minors by using scanners to verify ages. The legislation encourages merchants to install bar code and magnetic strip scanners at cash registers in stores and entrances to bars and nightclubs.

title: Michelle Gerwin, Scott Carlson
description: Dr. Michelle Gleason Gerwin and Scott Alexander Carlson were married yesterday in New York. Msgr. Harry J. Byrne officiated at the Society of Friends Meeting House.

title: Stewart Lee, Joel Sherry
description: Stewart Lee, the daughter of Kristina Knapp Lee and Bishop Peter James Lee of Richmond, was married yesterday to Joel Stephen Sherry, a son of Melinda and Stephen Sherry of Lakeshore, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Thomas R. Milam, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd at General Theological Seminary in New York.

title: Hips and Lips
description: To the Editor:

title: Brow Tools For Him And Her
description: The importance of eyebrows may have diminished in the course of evolution. But tell that to the women beating a path to the Avon Centre Spa (Fifth Avenue and 57th Street), where Eliza's Eyebrow Essentials (right, unopened) is outselling all other products. By Eliza Petrescu, Avon's renowned eyebrow designer, the $85 arch deluxe set includes two types of tweezers (pointed and slanted), engineered by Ms. Petrescu for what she called ''maximum force and response''; trimming scissors; a round brush, and tony products like an evening Brow Enhancer (for color and shine). Plus, there's ''Eliza's Extraordinary Eyebrows,'' a booklet that shows how to calculate ideal brow size and shape. Sample plucking tip: ''Eyebrows too far apart can create an off-balance or 'who me?' look.'' Last month, Avon introduced Eliza's Grooming Kit for Men (opened). It's $52 for a brow shaper; tweezers; nail files; orange stick, to push cuticles; foot cream, and other unguents for the survival of the well groomed.

title: Sound and Light At a London Theater
description: The 16th-century Rose Theater -- the first Elizabethan theater on London's Bankside, now an archeological project -- will be the site of a new sound and light show, narrated by the actor Ian McKellen. The 20-minute exhibition, which focuses on the history of the theater, will open on Wednesday for a run of about two years, to raise public awareness and funds. A re-creation of the Rose was recently featured in the movie ''Shakespeare in Love.''

title: Mature Subject Matter
description: I commend you for using a beautiful, mature woman as a model, but the photographer wasn't very kind to her. Dunaway looks either grim, angry or downright dour. Why is it that all models have to look sullen? The younger ones can get away with it, but for an older woman, there is nothing more beautiful than a smiling face.

title: Mediterranean Dishes That Favor the Waist
description: HERE are several dishes that comply nicely with the Mediterranean diet pyramid. Based on grains, they take advantage of vegetables and involve sparse amounts of cheese and fat. None of them require meat, fish or poultry.

title: 'Sleepy Hollow,' on the Thames
description: IT was a clear, brisk March morning in the Chilterns, a pastoral stretch of England's Thames Valley, to the west of London, and the film director Tim Burton was looking skeptically at the sky. ''What we really want is lousy weather,'' said Emmanuel Lubezki, the cinematographer, who shared Mr. Burton's concern over glimpses of sun in a country where clouds can prevail for weeks on end. Before long, the elemental status quo was restored, the skies darkened and an essential gray returned to ''Sleepy Hollow,'' a movie being freely adapted from Washington Irving's American classic.

title: OPINION; Raise the Bar for Teen-Age Drivers
description: THE recent series of fatal car crashes on Long Island involving teen-age drivers highlights the need for New York to adopt stronger teen-age licensing laws. Automobile crashes are the leading cause of death among teen-agers nationwide and teen-agers are over-represented in motor vehicle crashes. In New York, 16- and 17-year-old drivers represent only about 1.4 percent of licensed drivers, yet account for almost 5 percent of all fatal crashes. Behind each of these statistics is some family's personal tragedy, but the greatest tragedy is that these deaths were preventable.

title: Nets Are Set to Honor A Past Guiding Force
description: Imagine you're an impressionable kid out of the University of Maryland in the early 1980's, looking for friends with similar interests at your new job. You're reliable, responsible and mature for 22.

title: Do Small-Cap Analysts Matter?
description: Is the Wall Street analyst becoming irrelevant to the top executives of America's smaller companies and the mutual fund managers who own small-capitalization shares? Possibly, according to a survey by Tempest Consultants, a London-based firm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZ, ERNA
description: SPITZ-Erna., April 9, 1999. Loving mother of Eve Sabot. Loving grandmother of Karen Sedell and Bruce Sabot. Loving great grandmother of Roblyn & Jason Sedell & Aaron and Ariel Sabot. Services 1:30PM, Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road.

title: Stagnant Medicaid Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Property /High Technology; Wiring as the Tip of the Telecommunications Iceberg
description: NOW that the 1920's vintage Graybar Building, on Lexington Avenue at 44th Street, has been rewired, tenants will be able to sign up for high quality digital telephone service, E-mail and direct access to the Internet.

title: Hobey Baker Winner Signs With Islanders
description: Jason Krog, winner of the Hobey Baker Award as college hockey's best player this season, signed with the Islanders today. The Islanders expect him to play in the National Hockey League next season, General Manager Mike Milbury said.

title: Doggy in the Windows
description: Some seek out breeders to select expensive pets with aristocratic blood lines; others visit shelters to take in animals no one else wants. A New Jersey couple have saved mileage for the latter. Betsy Saul, and her husband, Jared, a medical resident, started a Web site at their home in Hillsborough called Pet Finder, (www.petfinder.org) a few years ago. They listed animals mainly from shelters in New Jersey; there are currently around 100 shelters and rescue groups in the state on the site. Now they have gone national, listing more than 200 shelters in about 30 states, with about 2,500 animals needing adoption. There are dogs and cats, of course, but also iguanas, hamsters parrots. And, at this time of year, rabbits need homes, too. The Sauls say some shelters attribute more than half their adoptions to Pet Finder and say that fewer pets adopted through the servie are returned. The site also includes a section in which people can post pets they can no longer keep and a pet-wanted section.

title: Yankee Ends Real Corker Of a Mystery
description: Jason Grimsley, a relief pitcher in his first season with the Yankees, was among those who flocked to see the movie ''Mission: Impossible'' in 1996, and as he watched Tom Cruise and an accomplice crawl through an air duct to steal secret information, memories of Grimsley's own impossible mission came back to him.

title: The World; Pol Turns Fugitive: (Yawn) It's Mexico
description: A MEXICAN GOVERNOR suddenly runs afoul of the top authorities. Instead of appearing in court to defend himself, he goes on the lam. Later, he sends a message from a clandestine location saying he is being persecuted by aides to the Mexican President and fears for his life.

title: Morey Bernstein, Proponent of Bridey Murphy, Dies at 79
description: Morey Bernstein, the Colorado businessman who pursued an amateur interest in hypnotism all the way back to 19th-century Ireland as he coaxed a young mother into recounting a previous life as a woman named Bridey Murphy, died on April 2 at his apartment in Pueblo, Colo. He was 79.

title: Bed-and-Breakfast Tour in Quiet Corner, With an Added Benefit
description: TEN bed and breakfast accommodations will open their doors for more than a peek when the third annual house tour in the Northeast Corner of the state, benefiting Paul Newman's Hole in the Wall Gang Camp, gets under way.

title: Princeton Men Dominate Event
description: Princeton's men's heavyweight crew yesterday swept the Child's Cup regatta in Philadelphia, intercollegiate rowing's oldest cup event dating from 1879, winning the varsity race for the sixth consecutive year, over Pennsylvania and Columbia. Princeton, last year's national intercollegiate champion, had five new oarsmen in the eight-man crew that won its third race of the season.

title: O'Keeffe Still Lifes At Phillips Collection
description: From Saturday through July 18, the Phillips Collection in Washington will be full of petunias, autumn leaves, green apples, shells, crosses, doors, bones -- all the subjects of artworks in ''Georgia O'Keeffe: The Poetry of Things.'' The exhibition, which includes 69 paintings and works on paper dating from 1908 to 1963, focuses solely on her iconic still life paintings.

title: THE NEW BERLIN -- Building on the Rubble of History; A Capital Reinstated And Remodeled
description: NO major European city displays its fractured history more visibly than Berlin. In just the 19th and 20th centuries, it was successively headquarters of the Prussian kingdom, the second German Reich, the Weimar Republic and the Nazi regime. It was then flattened by Allied bombers, occupied by the four victorious powers and divided into hostile camps, with its eastern sector becoming the capital of the Communist German Democratic Republic. And each political moment was recorded in its buildings, avenues and empty spaces. By the time East Germany imploded in November 1989, Berlin resembled a sprawling museum of architectural history.

title: Washington State: Sitting and waiting for killer whales
description: We settled not long ago into a perch in the rocks that rise above the far western edge of the continent, ready for marine theater below. It can try the patience of an urban American to watch and wait for something that may not even come. But at Lime Kiln Point State Park, a half-day's trip from Seattle on the western shore of Washington's San Juan Island, that is what you do.

title: Accusations of Overcharging At Nuclear Cleanup Sites
description: Cleaning up radioactive pollution at former nuclear weapons plants has been tedious for workers and expensive for taxpayers, although generally profitable for the contractors. Now an accountant for two contractors at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington state has filed a suit that says the contractors have been illegally marking up their bills, adding overhead charges to expenses that do not qualify.

title: The Victim Forgives, Others Wish to Forget.; Freedom Looms for Amy Fisher, and the Island Groans
description: ENOUGH already about Amy Fisher!'' Anita Marullo of Massapequa said the other day. ''I've heard about her and heard about her, and I'm indifferent to the whole thing. I hope she's straightened out, and I wish her well.''

title: El Salvador: A park brimming with possibility
description: El Salvador isn't the first country that comes to mind when eco-tourism is mentioned. Much of the country has been deforested, and air pollution often engulfs the capital, San Salvador, in a hazy film. But two hours west of San Salvador on the Guatemalan border, El Imposible National Park, a 12,000-acre tropical forest in the Apaneca Mountains, is the last refuge for many wildlife species that used to flourish all over the country before agriculture, industry and urban sprawl encroached.

title: Hear the Applause
description: To the Editor:

title: Tequilaville-on-the-Hudson
description: Once the most sophisticated question a tequila drinker would ponder was: Salt? But now at restaurants around town, that liquor made from distilled cactus goo has become as upscale as Bordeaux, or single-malt Scotch. Tequila menus have been turning up at places like Pablo's, 1584 Second Avenue (82d Street), which offers 43 varieties. Cafe Frida, a month-old Mexican restaurant at 368 Columbus Avenue (77th Street), sells 25 tequilas, including a house brand of mescal (unrefined tequila with a worm at the bottom) from Oaxaca, and has just started tequila tastings. Most brands are not downed with salt, but sipped like grappa. At L-Ray, which opened last fall at 64 West 10th Street, there are 33 varieties of tequila, smooth, silky and expensive. Shots range from $6.50 for Sauza Hornitos or Monte Alban to a staggering $50 for Herradura Seleccion Suprema. Gerad Argeros, a bartender at L-Ray, said patrons sometimes scoff at $50 shots, only to end up ordering them after a few rounds. ''One night, these guys ordered six shots of the $50 tequila,'' he said. ''But I don't think they could really appreciate it. By that point, they were speaking pidgin Mexican.'' DAVID KIRBY

title: Pate Putts His Way Into Contention
description: Some golfers do not make seven birdies in a year, but today Steve Pate made seven consecutive birdies at Augusta National for a Masters record.

title: Food; Greek Fire
description: Vea Kessissoglou is speaking sotto voce, her words, like her footsteps, absorbed by the thick carpeting in her parents' home in Astoria, Queens.

title: Kathleen Turland, Gregory Berzolla
description: Kathleen Louise Turland, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Turland of Troy, Mich., was married yesterday to Gregory Renato Berzolla, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Renato L. Berzolla of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Edward L. Mullins performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Cranbrook in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: Report Card: How the County's Third Graders Are Reading
description: The State Education Department released its latest school report cards yesterday, providing a window on student performance in Westchester County and around the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, EDWARD P.
description: LYONS-Edward P.. The College of New Rochelle community records with sorrow the death of Edward P. Lyons, devoted husband of alumna Margaret Whyte Lyons and member of the Board of Trustees for almost 20 years. Edward Lyons was passionate about the mission of this College. His wise counsel which he shared unreservedly and his quiet witness of vibrant faith helped to shape the College through the past three decades. Generations of students, faculty and staff will benefit from his extraordinary devotion and faithfulness to this College. We mourn his loss and celebrate his life. Jean Baptiste Nicholson, OSU Chair, Board of Trustees Stephen J. Sweeny, Ph.D., President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLEY, SYDELLE
description: BERLEY-Sydelle. On April 9, 1999. Beloved mother of David (Estelle) and Noah (Rhoda). Adoring grandmother of Sam, Alexander, Saul and Eve. Devoted sister of Murry Diamondstein. Funeral services Sunday, 11AM, Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 76 Road, Forest Hills. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, EMIL
description: ABRAMS-Emil. Suddenly on April 4th. Husband of Evelyn, dear father of Mark. Father-in-law of Merrilee, grandfather of Jonathan and David. Memorial service was held on April 6th.

title: Just How Serious Is Corzine? Well, the Knives Are Drawn
description: Coming soon to a New Jersey Democratic club near you: the Jon S. Corzine story.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Bringing Out the DeadBy Joe Connelly. Vintage Contemporaries, $12.

title: Expressing Government Power Without Pomposity
description: FOR nearly a half century, the Federal Republic of Germany studiously avoided creating grand Government buildings. The self-consciously modest, modern West German capital that arose in Bonn after the demise of Nazi Berlin stood in pointed contrast to the overblown classicism favored by the Third Reich -- an architectural declaration of ''Never Again.'' Federal ministries in the small Rhineland town set up operations in unassuming quarters, and Government chiefs from Ludwig Erhard to Gerhard Schroder have occupied a squat, low-slung official residence nicknamed the Chancellor's Bungalow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERRY, RANDALL NEAL
description: TERRY-Randall Neal. On April 7, 1999. Beloved husband of Beth. Dear father of Austin Greg. Cherished son of Seymour and Elsie Terry. Adored brother of Howard Terry and Jacalyn Terry Gantzer. Loving uncle. Services were held Friday, April 9th at ''The Riverside,'' interment followed at the Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island. TERRY-Randall Neal. On April 7, 1999. Beloved husband of Beth. Dear father of Austin Greg. Cherished son of Seymour and Elsie Terry. Adored brother of Howard Terry and Jacalyn Terry Gantzer. Loving uncle. Services were held Friday, April 9 at ''The Riverside,'' interment followed at the Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: Credit Is Due
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-11-99; Test Run
description: As anyone who's recently sat on a subway or an airplane or at a ballpark can attest, the prevailing trends in seating design don't exactly emphasize comfort. But the famed Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas may just have found a solution. At the new home he designed for the Second Stage Theater in New York, he took his client's suggestion and had the seats covered with Levagel. That's an Italian poly-whatsis material that functions, as its manufacturer says, ''like a liquid and a solid at the same time'' and stays just a bit cooler than whatever touches it. Normally used in wheelchairs and bicycle seats, Levagel is designed to provide a superior posterior experience by custom-molding to the body that's sitting on it.

title: On Interest Rates, Don't Let the Data Lull You
description: INVESTORS worried about rising interest rates were calmed recently by news of a decline in manufacturing jobs in March and a slowdown in the rise of average hourly earnings, a key measure of inflationary pressures.

title: Survivor of Cold War: An Expatriate Packard
description: NODAR CHECHELASHVILI is a man with a sweep of silver hair and a classic American tale -- of youth, of a car, of romantic summer drives to the beach. But the cast of long-dead characters, like Lavrenti P. Beria, Stalin's hated secret police chief, are towering figures in Soviet history. And the story, stuck in a sad cul-de-sac, still awaits an ending.

title: Police Exam Bill Vetoed in Suffolk
description: A bill passed by the Suffolk County Legislature in March intended to eliminate autobiographical questions on the police exam has been vetoed by County Executive Robert Gaffney. The goal of the bill was to increase minority officers on the police force, according to Legislator David Bishop of Babylon, chairman of the Public Safety Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, RUTH M.
description: SMITH-Ruth M.. On April 9, 1999, in her 58th year. Beloved wife of Hy. Loving mother of Sarah and Zachary. Devoted grandmother of Tehila, Khava and Shira. Funeral Services, Monday 10A M at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: The Making of A Fugitive
description: I am offended by the mention of the ''rescue movement'' in the same breath as the civil rights movement. One is a noble part of this nation's history and the other is representative of extremist violence that results in terror and death. As a physician, I was troubled by the lack of attention paid in your article to the men and women who have lost their lives and suffered injuries at the hands of these so-called missionaries.

title: Bold Strokes
description: Picture an artist's studio in which the 'canvases' are fabrics rather than paintings. In the imaginary studio shown here, the textiles, in their diversity of color and pattern, hint at great moments in art history, from still lifes of the Old Masters to Impressionism, from Abstract Expressionism to minimalism. Furnishing in light-toned wood serve as a neutral foil for the artistic array, while brightly hued accessories, in everything from glass to acrylic, complete the tableau. For product information, see page 102.

title: Steven Mau and Carol Rial
description: Carol Ann Rial, a daughter of Bea and Wayne Rial of Central, S.C., was married yesterday to Steven Michael Mau, a son of Barbara and Howard Mau of Kailua, Hawaii. The Rev. Elizabeth A. Levy, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony at Studio 450, a loft space in New York.

title: In the Dark
description: I read Stephen Kuusisto's Lives column (March 21), about how Braille is being supplanted by reading machines, as nothing less than an affirmation of humanity, in a world of less time and more technology. That final line -- I'm going to read Walt Whitman in the dark, without batteries'' -- brought tears to my eyes.

title: Trail Guide
description: A new guide to the Hutchinson River Parkway Trail is available from the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMMINGS, CELE
description: CUMMINGS-Cele. The Officers and Board of Directors of Five Towns Community Chest extend condolences to the family of Board member Gayle Morrow on the passing of her mother, Cele Cummings, whose special spirit will continue to shine through her loving family.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE LAST CHEATER'S WALTZ

title: Habitats / The East Village; Duplex, With Fish Pond At Bottom of the Stairs
description: THE matching of person and place is mysterious and impossible to predict. Every sighting is like a blind date, fraught with possibility -- and the potential for disappointment. Maybe that's why apartment hunting is so difficult for some people.

title: Sports of The Times; W.N.B.A. Challenged By Union
description: LONG before she graduated from Notre Dame law school and worked on both sides of the employee-relations street, Coquese Washington understood the repercussions of a labor war. She grew up in Flint, Mich., and her parents worked for General Motors, in rebellious union shops. Her father went on strike. Her mother was laid off. Families went broke. Familiar stores became boarded-up shells, and her city the backdrop in ''Roger and Me,'' Michael Moore's bitterly anti-corporate film.

title: Which Spouse Wields The Power at Tax Time?
description: Handling the money used to be a sign of authority in marriages, but with financial options and couples' work time expanding, the most powerful partner may now be the one who can talk the other into the task -- especially at tax time.

title: Shrewd Serb Tactics Downed Stealth Jet, U.S. Inquiry Shows
description: Air Force investigators now believe that Yugoslavia jury-rigged its system of radars and communications to shoot down an F-117 stealth fighter two weeks ago, and as part of an accelerated air campaign Pentagon officials are sending forces that could help avoid a similar incident.

title: Putting in a Cellar, A 90's Status Symbol
description: WHATEVER happened to rumpus rooms? There were millions of them a generation or so ago, and now not a trace can be found of that seemingly unique American institution. Oh, we have family rooms and dens and libraries and home theaters and the ever-so-promising great room, but the rumpus room has gone the way of the dodo. Does that mean that we as a country or as individuals have calmed down, tamed by our architecture into more sedate lives?

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: HOTEL

title: Alou Thinks the Expos Will Stay in Montreal
description: The Olympic Stadium sit-in lasted only one day.

title: What Kind of Peace in Kosovo?
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER; Motion and Commotion: The Juggler's Art, From Two Very Different Practitioners
description: EXPERIMENT: hold a ball out in front of you at arm's length. Drop it. Now, try to catch it with the same hand before it hits the floor.

title: Reading Scores As a Piece Of a Larger Puzzle
description: FEW have praised them. Most have come to dread them. And all said they would be glad to put aside the yearly ritual of the state report cards.

title: Biting Hands Before They Feed Him
description: For a man in search of a foreign partner to contribute capital and skill to his struggling bank, Masao Nishimura, the president of the Industrial Bank of Japan, is a surprisingly vocal critic of Western companies and their financial advisers.

title: The 'Cabaret' Days Are Gone; Now It's Shades of Gray
description: THE Image: Trapped on a plane a few years ago, I decided to start watching the film ''Company Business'' when the opening credits faded and a title saying ''Berlin'' came on the screen. After all, I was flying to the United States from Berlin, so I was curious. The film wasn't actually made here, as soon became obvious. But the reason I gave up on it was an early scene involving Gene Hackman and Mikhail Baryshnikov, playing a C.I.A. agent and a K.G.B. agent, respectively. They were in a situation in which they needed to make a phone call. Mr. Hackman spotted a bar, an ordinary enough looking place, and went in. Suddenly, there were Barbra Streisand, Dolly Parton, Liza Minelli and Diana Ross. And in the spotlight, crooning, was Marlene Dietrich as Lola in ''Blue Angel.'' Drag queens all, leering at poor Gene.

title: Girls' Schools Gain, Saying Coed Isn't Coequal
description: Arlene Gibson, the headmistress at Spence, remembers the bad old days, the early 90's, when girls' schools had to convince parents of the benefits of single-sex education.

title: Heart of the Swamp
description: BONE BY BONE

title: Activist Courts Are a Threat To the Rule of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Has Urban Allies in Bid to Ease Environmental Rules
description: New York's business leaders have long worked with their Republican allies in the Capitol in an unsuccessful campaign to scale back rules requiring companies to conduct extensive cleanups of polluted industrial sites that they want to develop.

title: Lives; A Joyful Noise
description: 'I can't call you later,'' I told my friend in tragic, adolescent tones that implied a parent lurking in the background and three hours of algebra homework looming. ''I have a piano lesson.''

title: Jennifer Shore, Brian Tramontozzi
description: Jennifer Paige Shore, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan E. Shore Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., was married last evening at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Brian Anthony Tramontozzi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony G. Tramontozzi of Upper Saddle River, N.J. Msgr. Robert J. Fuhrman officiated at the ceremony, in which Rabbi H. Philip Berkowitz took part.

title: Lack of Seat Belts Is Scary in School Buses
description: To the Editor:

title: In Defense of a New Path To On-Line Stock Trading
description: ''Hidden Costs in On-Line Trading,'' by Gretchen Morgenson (March 28), examined the rise of electronic communications networks, or E.C.N.'s, in on-line stock trading. The article described how the networks aim to give individual investors instant market access, letting them compete head-on with professional traders. But it also noted a study last year by the National Association of Securities Dealers, which said investors could have found better prices elsewhere on 8 out of 10 stocks they trade. The article drew these responses:

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; How Father Knew Best
description: MY father had two investment caveats -- and I heard them often as I was growing up: Don't buy mutual funds, and don't touch principal. I knew that if he ever caught me doing either, I'd be in big trouble.

title: Tuned In to the Past, and Repairing It, Too
description: BILL MORSE eyed two early-1920's radios in his shop. ''The one on the right is homemade,'' he said. ''Normally, back then, somebody on the block would make sets for the neighbors.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, SIDNEY
description: STERN-Sidney. NACOEJ (The North American Conference on Ethiopian Jewry) mourns the loss of an exceptional Board member, voluteer and friend. We share the grief of his beloved family, Barbara, Marian, Paula and Remy. Richard E. Giesberg, President Middie Giesberg, Chair

title: Help for the Chutzpah-Challenged
description: BARRY GREENBLATT, a 911 supervisor for the New York Police Department, was standing in front of a class of eight, somewhat anxiously describing a science show he had watched on television the night before. He fidgeted momentarily and stuttered slightly. Then Mr. Greenblatt was asked to walk across the room in front of everyone.

title: Saving Social Security, and the Poor; Women Don't Benefit
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A review of the Mercedes-Benz Gelaendewagen in the Automobiles section on March 21 referred incorrectly to the vehicle's tax treatment. Because the Gelaendewagen is a sport utility with a loaded weight of more than 6,000 pounds, it is not subject to the Federal luxury tax.

title: POSTINGS: A $44 Million, 21-Story Building; New Condos on East End Ave.
description: Foundation work has begun at the southwest corner of 84th Street and East End Avenue for the first new residential building in more than a decade along the avenue on Manhattan's East Side.

title: In Women's Groups, Back to 'Girl Talk'
description: IT'S a Saturday evening in the East Village, and the streets are pulsing with bar-hopping young people. But Candace Walsh and her posse of girlfriends -- most of them artists and writers in their 20's and 30's, mostly single -- have gathered in her one-bedroom apartment for Beauty Parlor Night.

title: Blond Venus Rides Again
description: In ''Marlene,'' the musical play opening tonight on Broadway at the Cort Theater, Sian Phillips (left) fully inhabits the role of Marlene Dietrich -- with the help of the dress, the coat and the wig. A dead ringer is in the details.

title: Decline of Leetch
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-11-99 - Questions for Doug Liman; Youthful Discretions
description: Q:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLAND, NORTON
description: GOLAND-Norton. We grieve with our daughter-in-law Janis and her family on the loss of her beloved father. Charlotte and Murray Goldberg

title: The Making of A Fugitive
description: As I read David Samuels's article (March 21), I found myself overwhelmed by the negativity of the anti-abortion movement. Just once, I'd like to hear about someone doing something positive to remedy the root problem: unwanted pregnancy. Where are these protesters when schools try to institute comprehensive programs of sex education that teach both abstinence and contraception? Nobody visits an abortion provider on a whim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESSNER, MARIAN
description: ESSNER-Marian. Of Rye, NY, on April 10, 1999. Beloved wife of Howard. Deovted mother of Mitchell and Kathy. Grandmother of Jordan and Sarah. Mother-inlaw of Reggie Sprogis. Sister of Vreni Sauter. Previously appointed by the governor to New York State Developmental Disability Council. Funeral service Monday, 11 AM, at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Epilepsy Foundation of Southern New York, PO Box 1745, Pearl River, NY 10965, would be appreciated.

title: For Psychiatric Center, Park or Development?
description: Acombination of environmentalists and builders is calling on the state to abandon plans to sell most of the 552-acre Kings Park Psychiatric Center to a private developer.

title: India -- A secure (and noisy) place for birds
description: We awoke in the bird sanctuary of Bharatpur to the shrieks of peacocks, the mimicry of magpie robins and the assorted cries, tweets, cheeps and caws of one of the most astonishing concentrations of avian life on the planet. My husband, Barry, and my son, Max, 8, complained that the racket had disturbed their slumber.

title: BOOKEND; April Again: Five for National Poetry Month
description: He Said

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTHELF, RHODA J.
description: GOTTHELF-Rhoda J.. On April 5, 1999. Rhoda died after a short illness in Tamarak, FL. She leaves behind her loving son David. People wishing to pay a Shiva call, may do so on Sunday and Monday between 12PM and 9PM at Rhoda's home. A memorial service will be held at 4PM on May 16 at Rhoda's home in New York City. People wishing to make a donation in her memory, can do so through the City of Hope, 30 West 26th Street, N.Y., NY 10010.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-11-99 - The Ethicist; The Doctor Is in Trouble
description: 'I am a psychiatrist, and I'm afraid a respected colleague is slipping dangerously. One of my patients mentioned that his wife's therapist (that's my colleague) has been forgetful, inattentive and inappropriately angry. This could indicate a serious problem. Must I intervene on such unreliable information? Is it possible without violating my patient's or my colleague's rights?' H.K., New Jersey

title: The World: Lonely Hearts; Libya Wearies of the Cold Shoulder
description: HIGHLY placed visitors invited lately to the palatial desert tent of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi sensed in the Libyan leader's conversation a yearning to be readmitted to the world. Me, a terrorist? he would plead. Of course, he was always an unpredictable loner and he did spend decades bankrolling revolutionaries and guerrilla leaders, especially in Africa. But why are they -- now often heads of government just as he is -- getting all the invitations to London and Washington while he is left stranded in the sand?

title: State Is Monitoring More Tick Diseases
description: WHILE concerns about Lyme disease are widespread, health experts in Connecticut expect an increase this year in reported cases of a lesser-known but more painful and debilitating tick-borne illness.

title: Mixed Results, and Mixed Emotions, on State Reading Exams
description: DESPITE its painful fiscal transformation from prince to near-pauper, the Shoreham-Wading River School District is still making educational headway.

title: Mourning a People's Advocate
description: THE SETTING Several hundred mourners packed the front courtyard of Charas/El Bohio Cultural and Community Center on East Ninth Street Tuesday evening to mourn Armando Perez, 51, an outspoken neighborhood advocate and community board member who died after being found cut and bleeding on April 3 in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Culinary Memories Of the Old West
description: In the Old West of the 19th century, Shorty Long worked the cattle drives as a cook, making flapjacks and soups for hungry cowboys in Texas, New Mexico and Montana. After locating Shorty's original recipes from various archives in the Southwest, Sheldon Kasloff opened Shorty Long's Pancake and Stew House two weeks ago at 1431 First Avenue, near 74th Street.

title: No Place Like Home, Luckily
description: EVER since I broke the news last week that sex and real estate cause most of the world's misery and joy, I have been overwhelmed with tales. Of real estate. Mostly miserable.

title: Dorms Threaten To Make College Elitist
description: To the Editor:

title: VIEWS; When the Hives Arrive and Tomatoes Thrive
description: ONE day late last month a dozen cardboard boxes from a supplier in Canada were delivered to the Russo family's Orchard Lane farm in Chesterfield. Inside each was a hive of bees ready to pollinate the thousands of tomato plants that had started flowering in the farm's 11 greenhouses.

title: As Camera And City Both Grew
description: FROM stage photography to society event portraits and then ship photography, the Byron Company documented the essence of New York City life from the turn of the century until the beginning of World War II.

title: Myth With Matter, In Three Dimensions
description: IF his wish is to reflect popular sentiments the beliefs, hopes and dreams of ordinary people -- Laszlo Ispanky pushes all the right buttons. Mr. Ispanky is an especially prolific sculptor whose exhibition at the Museum of the American Hungarian Foundation here presents many diverse aspects of his endeavor.

title: Refereeing The Future
description: AS Bill Kennard raced through a whirlwind of meetings in Southern California one day last month, his passions and preoccupations as the nation's top telecommunications official quickly became clear.

title: Bradley, in Dig at Gore, Embraces Big Ideas
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley cast himself today as the candidate of big, ambitious ideas in a not-so-subtle contrast with Vice President Al Gore, who has recently put forward several relatively small-bore policy initiatives.

title: Is That Ticking (Pause) a Bomb?
description: KNOWING that Alfred Hitchcock never previewed his movies, nor even saw them with audiences after they were released, I asked him in 1963 (when he was 64), if he didn't ever miss hearing them scream.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: POETRY
description: A DAUGHTER'S LATITUDE

title: INSIDE
description: NATO's Blighted Birthday

title: BENEFITS
description: Growing in Stages

title: What We Want
description: To the Editor:

title: Northeastern And Harvard Win
description: The Harvard men's heavyweight crew won the Stein Cup, and Northeastern took the Arlett Cup on the Charles River at Boston yesterday. In its first race, and with new oarsmen in six of the eight seats, the Crimson defeated Brown by 2.3 seconds in a time of 5 minutes 46 seconds. Northeastern, also racing for the first time, beat Boston University by 7.8 seconds in their 2,000-meter duel.

title: Helen Knapp, Charles Cagliostro
description: Helen Rex Knapp and Charles Walter Cagliostro were married yesterday in Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Dawson Ambosta performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKMAN, SHIRLEY
description: MARKMAN-Shirley. Beloved wife and best friend for 54 years of Martin. Loving mother of Barbara and Bruce Spiegel, Marcia and Irwin Siegel and David and Deborah Markman. Adoring grandmother of Erica, Richard, Lilly, Jared and Meredith. Cherished sister of Stanley and Cynthia Gingold, Ruby and Herbert Janof and Dorothy and the late Al Weintraub. Devoted aunt, cousin and friend. We will miss your loving kindness and generous spirit which inspired

title: Fur Coats Are O.K. Here
description: AS you enter the Eskimo Museum in Churchill, Manitoba, the first thing you see is a stuffed polar bear in a glass case, staring at you with frozen black eyes and a bared-tooth grimace. A plaque tells you that the bear was killed and donated to the museum in 1969.

title: Embattled Suits Wiggle Their Pinstripes
description: WILLIAM D'ARIENZO, elegant in his brown suit, brown shirt and brown handkerchief, leaned back in his chair at the Transfusion advertising agency near Union Square and smoothed the air in front of him with his hands. ''I want to be absolutely clear on this,'' he said. ''We have made a philosophical commitment not to attack the casual.''

title: Karla Olivier and Reeves Carter
description: AFTER Reeves Carter grew up in Indiana and graduated from the Georgetown University Law Center in Washington, he moved to New York, expecting to fall in love with an artistic, chronically late, possibly tattooed woman -- his idea of a young New Yorker. ''I thought I would find some actress-art student-waitress,'' he said.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: POETRY
description: GIRLS ON THE RUN

title: Elizabeth Kardos and David Cowen
description: Elizabeth Sarah Kardos, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank L. Kardos of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married last evening to David Jack Cowen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cowen Jr. of Convent Station, N.J. Rabbi Barry H. Green officiated in the Pegasus Suite of the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Do as I Say, Not as I Do
description: Let's get one thing straight: i'm a design journalist, not a designer. People seem to think that just because I write about beautiful rooms, I can whip them up myself. If I had a dime for every time someone said to me, ''I'll bet your apartment is gorgeous!,'' I'd be flying to Paris for dinner on my private jet. The reality of the situation may disappoint you, but here it is: I can be as timid and indecisive as you can. (To those of you who are bold and assertive, my apologies.) I was over 40 before I screwed up the courage to paint my walls something other than white. And I was well into my 30's before I had the gumption to tackle a major furniture decision.

title: Prints That Were Always Meant To Be Prints, Not Paintings
description: WHEN you see a show of most artists' prints, you know you're seeing a sideline, although, one hopes, an illuminating sideline, pursued with integrity. That is true even of artists, like Jim Dine or Jasper Johns, whose talents are often displayed to best advantage in their prints rather than painting or sculpture.

title: In Papers, Making White Excite
description: CAN Great White really do for printer paper what Frank Perdue did for chicken? Can Xerox persuade consumers that a paper by any other name would not print as sweet? Does the public believe that one company's sheet of white stuff is all that different from another's?

title: A Flirtatious Argentine Starlet
description: Torrontes, a white grape prominent in Galicia in Spain, is so obscure elsewhere that masterly wine literature often ignores it. Thus, lucky Argentina, where it flourishes, can keep a sea of its delicious light wine for itself.

title: 10 Offensive Linemen Could Go in First 2 Rounds
description: Ernie Accorsi, the Giants' general manager, looks at the group of offensive linemen in next week's National Football League draft and sometimes he can't believe his eyes.

title: The Power of Violent Images
description: MATHEW KOSBOB, of Stamford, died recently, three weeks short of his 19th birthday, of injuries he received during a beating by several classmates three and a half years ago. Smashed in the head with cans of beer and kicked in the chest repeatedly, Mathew suffered irreversible brain damage that left him unable to walk, talk or eat.

title: Style; Chic-a-Boo
description: Like fashion itself, Devon is wonderfully coy - part gamine, part glamour queen.

title: The World: The Muslim World's View; Two Cheers (If That) for U.S. Bombs in Kosovo
description: TWO weeks into the Western bombardment of Yugoslavia, with the air attacks aimed at punishing Christian Serbs for their persecution of Kosovar Muslims, the Islamic world was presented with an American military campaign that it could identify with. After all, the United States and its allies were clearly siding with Muslims this time, not reflexively bashing Iraq or unstintingly supporting Israel.

title: New Roman Catholic Leader Protests Abortion at Rally Outside Clinic
description: Signaling his willingness to maintain a highly visible role in the fight against abortion, Bishop James T. McHugh, the new spiritual leader of Long Island's 1.3 million Roman Catholics, led a peaceful rally here this morning outside a Planned Parenthood clinic.

title: Foreign Policy's Big Moment
description: So now Al Gore, Bill Bradley, George W. Bush, John McCain, Elizabeth Dole, Pat Buchanan and other potential 43d Presidents of the United States are struggling over whether and how we should fight in Kosovo. Suddenly there is the possibility that we could see the fiercest foreign policy argument in a Presidential campaign since Ronald Reagan and Walter Mondale debated how to thwart the Soviet Union of Konstantin Chernenko.

title: Spare Change
description: Ask the architect Lee Mindel, and he'll tell you: the well-designed space can accommodate a myriad of shifts in style. ''If you can solve the problem of a space through architecture,'' Mindel explains, ''then that architecture can transcend style. The measure of a good space is, can it stand empty? With objects in it? And can those objects change?''

title: Q&A/Sherry Perlstein; Children and Parents, in Emotional Need
description: THE budget for the Child Guidance Center of Southern Connecticut has tripled in the 12 years since Sherry Perlstein joined as executive director. But even today's $2 million is not enough to address the growing number of severely disturbed children and dysfunctional families in need of the center's mental health services.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: American Psycho
description: Vulgar Favors

title: Tuneup
description: CRAZY FOR YOU

title: Latin Roots Leave Room For All-American Ambitions
description: TAKE it with a grain of salt, and maybe a squeeze of lime, when the Latin Playboys declare ''It's not about hip, you won't get it, it's a Latin trip'' in the middle of their second album, ''Dose'' (Atlantic, CD, 834173). They're not making a policy statement. Whether or not the Latin Playboys aspire to hipness, any kind of Latin separatism is the furthest thing from their musical intentions. The Latin Playboys assimilate whatever they like, from slide-guitar blues riffs to Indonesian gamelan gongs; it's a Latin trip simply because they're not going to let go of roots, either.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUNER, MORTON
description: PUNER-Morton. April 3, 1999, in San Tropez, France. Beloved husband of Adeline. Son of the late Jacob and Sarah Puner. Loving brother of Sherley and Herman Plasse. Uncle of Terry, Barbara, Jonathan, Beatrice, Andrew. Great-uncle of Amitai, Ori, Eitan, Jacob, Leah, David, Sandra, and dear cousin of many.

title: The News at The Daily News Is Not Good; Financial Problems Bring Cutbacks and a Growing Sense of Distrust
description: Helen Kennedy, The Daily News's reporter in the Balkans, is heading home. On-the-spot coverage of the war and refugee crisis in Kosovo is more than her newspaper can afford right now; its newsroom budget has just been trimmed by 5 percent. She is returning to a newsroom where no raises will be given this year and where reporters must get approval before taking a source to lunch.

title: Jessica Chun and Douglas Chia
description: Jessica Y. Chun and Douglas K. Chia, both lawyers, were married yesterday in Wayne, Pa. The Rev. Abraham Myung performed the ceremony at the Wayne Presbyterian Church.

title: Austin, in the Big Time, Gets an Airport to Match
description: ROBERT MUELLER MUNICIPAL AIRPORT is three miles from the state capitol. That's what's good about it. Otherwise, it's small, overcrowded and poorly laid out, and parking is almost impossible.

title: As a Newspaper Grows, So Do Some Teen-Agers' Skills
description: On the third floor of a loft building on a desolate stretch of St. Nicholas Avenue, near 117th Street, some 35 young journalists, mostly teen-agers, are gathered in the bright newsroom of Harlem Overheard, a free quarterly newspaper. Some type away at computers; some discuss story ideas, headlines and page layouts. Others are on the phone making pitches to potential advertisers.

title: Airport Inspections
description: After the discovery of small amounts of ethylene glycol, a toxic de-icing fluid, in storm drains late last year at County Airport in Harrison, County Executive Andrew J. Spano has ordered daily inspections for all official vehicles there.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WALERSTEIN, JEFFREY DAVID
description: WALERSTEIN - Jeffrey David. April 7, 1964-April 14, 1989. It's been ten very difficult years. Miss that sharp mind, endearing personality and loving individual. Thanks to all who have helped perpetuate Jeffrey's memory through making contributions to The Jeffrey David Walerstein Foundation. Love ya, Jeff. Mom, Dad and Mar

title: Erotic, Exotic
description: In this slim volume, Michael Ondaatje -- who was a respected poet long before the success of ''The English Patient'' brought him fame as a novelist -- writes plainly about beautiful things. The center of gravity of the poems in HANDWRITING (Knopf, $22) is not in the language -- which is generally direct and unpatterned, proceeding in curt lines and stanzas -- so much as in the richly sensual images, which are drawn largely from the history, mythology and landscape of India and China. Ondaatje uses the serene juxtapositions of haiku (''This year's kisses / like diving a hundred times / from a moving train / into the harbour'') or the directness of a catalogue (''Palanquins carried the weapons of a goddess. / Bamboo tubes cut in 17th-century Japan / we used as poem holders'') to eliminate the need for explanation and exposition, leaving us with the things themselves. Even when telling a story -- as in ''Buried,'' which recounts the history of a Buddha statue buried for safekeeping during a war -- he contracts the narrative to a few concrete images, giving his verse a mysterious reticence. And the erotic strain in the book -- always below the surface of its lush descriptions -- bursts into full bloom in the sequence ''The Nine Sentiments'': ''Walking through rainstorms to a tryst, /

title: Meditations on the Unthinkable
description: READING THE HOLOCAUST

title: Influence Peddling
description: Fashion designers are turning out home furnishings faster than you can say 'synergy.' But just because a dress and a chair share a label doesn't mean that they embody the same vision. The best examples of the crossover from fashion house to your house -- modeled here by Alek Wek -- share a sensibility you can spot from across the room.

title: What Kind of Peace in Kosovo?
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A/Filomena Gentile; Disabled Woman Seizes Program's Lifeline
description: FILOMENA GENTILE, 81, is ready for her monthly book club discussion group. Because her sight is severely impaired, she has listened to her book on an audio tape. And because her sight problems inhibit her ability to get out of her house, her book discussion group takes place by telephone. The group of similarly homebound people recently read ''The Color of Water'' and ''Shipping News.'' The current selection is ''The Great Gatsby.''

title: THE NEW BERLIN -- Building on the Rubble of History; Once Again, a City Rewards the Walker
description: IT'S safe to go walking again in Berlin. In fact, the time has come for city lovers to reclaim Germany's once and future capital as a spiritual home. For it was here, in the early decades of the century, that flanerie -- the practice of strolling leisurely around a big city just to take in the sights -- came into its own as a modern art form. After 12 years of Nazi brutality and 44 years of cold war, this gentle art has once again become a possibility.

title: The New York Times Business Best Sellers
description: HARDCOVER

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ERPF, CARL K.
description: ERPF-Carl K.. ''Buddy.'' May 15, 1925-April 11, 1984. Someone who was loved and will always be loved.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 21, about James Charles Kopp, an anti-abortion protester, misstated some details about court proceedings involving Randall Terry, a former head of Operation Rescue, an anti-abortion group. Both Terry and Operation Rescue were sued by the National Organization for Women on charges of conspiring to deny access to abortion clinics. Terry settled the case, and Operation Rescue went to court and lost. Neither he nor the group was ever pursued by Federal prosecutors under RICO, the statute designed to fight organized crime.

title: Student Insularity Mutes Their Outrage
description: The students at Rutgers University lined up to stuff their book bags with maps, time lines and other handouts about the crisis in Kosovo, then elbowed their way into a ''teach-in'' that amounted to a crash course on the hundreds of years of Balkan conflict that preceded NATO's bombing of Serbia.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUHRMAN, HENRY
description: LUHRMAN-Henry. You left us 10 years ago today, but you have never left me. Love, Terry

title: April 15: The Deadline for Incremental Rate Applications
description: With April 15 only four days away, harried investors are rushing to open their ''Incremental Rate Applications'' for 1998. That is, their ''Indivisible Retirement Allowances.'' Or was it their ''Income Ratification Arrangements?''

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Jennifer Samsel And John Wilson
description: Jennifer Noel Samsel and John Triplett Wilson were married yesterday in Canton, Mass. The Rev. James F. Findlay performed the ceremony at the United Church of Christ.

title: Restaurants; Expanding Horizons
description: THE Village Gourmet has almost everything restaurants crave: an ideal corner location, multiple cozy nooks, plenty of character, attentive service, a varied menu, very reasonable prices, and a built-in take-out area and retail wine shop.

title: Correction
description: The Practical Traveler column on March 28 about mass transit in Southern California misstated the Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus route that goes to the Getty Museum. It is the No. 561. (The No. 434 goes to Malibu and the former Getty site.)

title: Ideas & Trends; Joblessness Is Down. Prices Aren't Up. Go Figure.
description: MEETING in February to review interest rate policy, members of the Federal Reserve fretted, as they always do, about the possible resurgence of inflation. But their discussion soon turned to whether the central bank's system of spotting incipient wage and price pressures might be malfunctioning.

title: A Soprano Who's in Demand Everywhere, Almost
description: LAUREN FLANIGAN, the workaholic American soprano, is 40, feisty and, best of all if you are interviewing her, blunt. Her career has been one of the most dynamic, unpredictable and tumultuous of the last decade. She has wowed audiences from San Francisco, where she was born to a working-class Irish-American family with leftist leanings, to Milan, Italy, where in recent seasons at La Scala she won frenzied ovations for her vocally intense, dramatically riveting performances in Verdi's ''Macbeth'' and ''Nabucco'' and earned critical comparisons to Callas.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARROLL, JEAN MARY, M.D.
description: CARROLL-Jean Mary, M.D.. A memorial service for Jean Mary Carroll, M.D., will be held at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 116th St. and Broadway on Saturday, April 17, 1999 at 10:30AM.

title: Measuring Executive Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORTEL, LUCILLE
description: LORTEL-Lucille. The Vera Institute of Justice joins the arts community in celebrating the life of Lucille Lortel, former trustee and widow of our founder, Louis Schweitzer. Her energy and enthusiasm will be missed.

title: Putting the Voluntary Into Community Service
description: ''Serving the Less Fortunate for Credit and Just Because'' [April 4] does not address an underlying issue: That true community service is based on volunteerism. What was described was mandatory community service, requiring students to provide uncompensated service to organizations and agencies in order to earn a high school diploma or for college admission. Forcing students to work for free is the wrong way to go about instilling good citizenship skills in young people.

title: Fixing Damage to Vinyl Floor Covering and Carpets
description: THE floors in homes, whether they be wood or covered with vinyl or carpeting, take a lot of abuse. Floors exposed to heavy traffic suffer occasional damage and require spot repairs. The most common repairs for vinyl flooring include flattening blisters and patching tears or scratches. Common carpet repairs include removing burns and stains and regluing loose seams.

title: Word for Word/Home Suite Business; Make Money While You Sleep! In Your Dreams.
description: GET-RICH-QUICK schemes have been around since the Garden of Eden. But with the rise of home businesses in this era of prosperity, magazines for small-scale entrepreneurs are fairly bursting lately with come-ons to put you on Easy Street.

title: When Cats Scratch (And They All Do)
description: THERE are few actions more irritating than a cat clawing household furniture -- a truth even ardent cat lovers cannot dismiss. Though it can drive nearly anyone to distraction, there is an instinctive reality at hand, a reality, once understood, that provides solutions.

title: In the Region /Westchester; Trump Pushes 2 Golf Projects Long in Negotiation
description: SINCE giving up plans for his first Westchester project in 1996, Donald J. Trump, who is known for his showmanship and having his named emblazoned on many of his other projects, has kept a fairly low profile in the county.

title: Involving the Community In Police Partnerships
description: As Sgt. Steven L. Rogers walked out of the principal's office in the Franklin Middle School, a student greeted him with a thumbs-up sign.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: THE BOXER AND THE PRINCESS. Written and illustrated by Helme Heine. Margaret K. McElderry. $16. (Ages 4 to 8) Max was a very delicate young rhinoceros, lacking a thick skin both physically and emotionally. In desperation his parents got him armor, but that only made things worse -- he grew grimy and introspective -- so he went off to see the world. And, of course, met and rescued a perfect princess who saw right through all his defenses. A love story.

title: Commuter Gang's Question On Yiddish Is Answered
description: To the Editor:

title: What About Quality?
description: To the Editor:

title: Menifee Wins in Final Furlong, Making Him a Top Derby Entry
description: Menifee, the hometown horse named for a county in Kentucky, thrust himself into the front ranks of candidates for the Kentucky Derby today when he ran down Cat Thief in the final furlong and won the $750,000 Blue Grass Stakes by a length and a quarter.

title: Camden Sprinters Roll to Victory
description: Camden (N.J.) High School's sprinters tallied three impressive victories yesterday in boys' varsity events at the Kings Relays at Midwood High School in Brooklyn. Camden easily captured three relays, at 400 meters (43.6 seconds), 800 meters (1 minute 29.7 seconds) and 1,600 meters (3:20.6).

title: Info and Java, but Not Much Taste for Latte
description: Taking a leaf from a private-sector book, two libraries in Brooklyn are serving their own blends of coffee and information.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-11-99; Bombs and Blockbusters
description: Trying to imagine what war in Kosovo might be like, I've been unable to resist images from the vivid battle epics of the past season, ''Saving Private Ryan'' and ''The Thin Red Line.'' It may be sheerest coincidence that a real war has arrived right in the midst of a nationwide vogue for a bygone war. But one way or the other, the depiction of the Second World War in these two films, as well as in Tom Brokaw's best-selling oral history, ''The Greatest Generation,'' is subtly influencing the way I and most other Americans think about the crisis in the Balkans.

title: Romantic Ideal
description: JACQUELINE DU PREHer Life, Her Music, Her Legend.By Elizabeth Wilson.Illustrated. 466 pp. New York:Arcade Publishing. $27.95.

title: Miss Martin And Mr. Simonds
description: Anne Wallace Martin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Middleton A. Martin of McLean, Va., was married yesterday to William Haskell Simonds Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Simonds of Locust Valley, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. John C. Harper performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: SOAPBOX: SPRING STREET; A Steel-and-Mortar City Has Its Own Way of Signaling a Season
description: IT got me nervous when I saw rosy bud eyes sprouting on canes that were green as sugar snap peas when it snowed two weeks ago.

title: In the Region /New Jersey; Mack-Cali Turns to Developing to Spur Growth
description: UNTIL recently, the Mack-Cali Realty Corporation was on a buying spree, acquiring office buildings or family-run real estate companies. Now the Cranford-based real estate investment trust is dipping its toe into the development arena in its home state.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-11-99 - On Language; Hit On
description: Noah Webster, the political activist, journalist and educator who began his lexicographic career in the tempestuous Federal era, asked Basil Hall, a British naval officer, why he considered all American contributions to the English language unworthy. Hall's reply: ''Because there are enough words already.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KORNBLIT, FLORENCE L.
description: KORNBLIT-Florence L.. Lovingly remembered on the 10th anniversary of her death by her husband, Ralph, her children, Mitchell and Sandra and Peter, her granddaughter, Elizabeth, and her sisters, Estelle Weisberger and Shirley Katz. You are always in our hearts.

title: Union Cards And Mascara At Factory
description: Few of the women who work at the Mana Products cosmetics factory on Queens Boulevard near Van Dam Street can afford the $19 Erno Laszlo mascara or $18.50 I Natural powder that the company makes. Many wear no makeup to work, for who is there to greet them at the doors at 7 A.M.? Just the union organizers who have been showing up since February to organize the 250 employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELTENSTEIN, PAT LIVERIGHT
description: FELTENSTEIN-Pat Liveright. On March 24, 1999, in Lake Worth, FL, aged 89. Widow of Milton, mother of John Henry King and Jeffry Howard King, grandmother of Tammy Jeanne, Heather and Jeff, Jr. She was a free spirit-courageous, outspoken, perceptive, exciting, a woman ahead of her time, never afraid to seize life and live it to the fullest. She gave as good as she got. Her artistic sensitivity and creativity were of the highest order. Perhaps the finest portrait photographer of her time, she possessed the uncommon power to illuminate a person's soul on film. As many said, she was a very special person. Her passing dims the lives of her family and friends, but she will always remain in our memory with love.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A classic melodrama of Black and Tan Ireland, a top Elvis Presley film, an appealing rustic comedy and a dazzling tour of Rome head the television film list this week.

title: Practicing the Steps Even Before the Dance
description: THERE is no cookie-cutter approach to merging two companies successfully into one.

title: Long Beach Italian With Sophistication
description: THE Caffe Laguna/Laguna Cafe situation is enough to confuse anyone. Caffe Laguna opened in Long Beach last August. A month later, the Laguna Cafe made its debut in Roslyn. Aside from similar names and worth-the-trip-food, the two restaurants have little in common.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCK, TILLIE
description: STOCK-Tillie. Wife of the late Lawrence, beloved mother of Susan and Gary, mother-in-law of Adah and David, grandmother of Lee and Todd. Burial Sunday, April 11, Riverside Cemetery, Saddlebrook, NJ. Donations to the American Lung Association appreciated.

description: FIRE TRUCK

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 30 of the Arts & Leisure section today about the soprano Lauren Flanigan misstates the opening day for Richard Strauss's ''Intermezzo'' at the New York City Opera, in which she sings the lead role. It is Tuesday, not Thursday.

title: Hurd Hatfield Memorial
description: A memorial will be held for the actor Hurd Hatfield tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the Community Church, 40 East 35th Street in Manhattan. Mr. Hatfield, who played the title character in the 1945 movie version of Oscar Wilde's novel ''The Picture of Dorian Gray,'' died in December at the age of 80. Speakers will include the director Albert Marr.

title: The Romance of Communism
description: LOVE IN EXILE

title: The Real Divide
description: Are the culture wars still upon us? It is always being said they are, and that they have got nastier with time. It is even said that, in the battle over President Clinton and his scandals this past year, the culture wars reached a grand finale, and decades of controversy over the sexual and moral ideas of the 1960's neatly exploded into a full-scale political crisis. All of which sounds entirely plausible. But is it true?

title: Children's Shows Offer Concerts and Stories
description: MANY events occur today, beginning at 11:30 A.M. at the Rosenthal Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in Pleasantville, where the first of two Cushion Concerts -- the second is at 1 P.M. -- finds Richard Kapp and the Philharmonia Virtuosi performing ''Carnival of the Animals'' by Saint-Saens. The program will be repeated next Sunday at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. at the Hoff-Barthelson School in Scarsdale.

title: When Too Many Park And Ride
description: OVER the last several months, parking at the Deer Park station of the Long Island Rail Road has become so difficult that commuters have resorted to leaving their cars virtually everywhere.

title: Men and Women Are Both From Earth
description: CEASEFIRE!

title: Chinese Premier Plays to the Many Audiences in U.S.
description: Chinese leaders, tutored by their own experts and legions of ''foreign friends'' who pass through Beijing, have learned a lesson over the years: America is not a one-party dictatorship.

title: Pension Protection?
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A theater review on March 28 about ''Wuthering Heights'' at the Paper Mill Playhouse misspelled the surname of the actress who played Catherine. She is Libby Christophersen, not Christopherson.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about complaints about a process-serving company misspelled the given name of the freelance reporter who uncovered the case and gave the information to the authorities and The New York Times. She is Colleen Callan, not Coleen.

title: Baby's Death Leads To a Foundation To Aid Other Infants
description: SOMETIME in the early morning hours of Sept. 17, 1995, a 7-month-old boy, Alexander Williamson-Noble, died of SIDS. He was survived by his parents, his twin brother, Robert, an older sister, Florentina, and another brother, Andrew. What makes Alexander more than a statistic is that in his death, he became the driving force for the Considering Alexander Foundation, started by his parents, Esmeralda and Hugh Williamson-Noble.

title: The View From/Rye; From Lakes to Woods, Volunteers Help the Parks
description: JILL REMBAR wanted to establish a working relationship with spiders: she loves the outdoors but has never been fond of crawly things. So she signed up for the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservations' Volunteers in the Parks program and spent 20 hours learning just about everything there is to know about habitats at Cranberry Lake Preserve in North White Plains and the Marshlands Conservancy on Post Road here. Soon, she will start sharing her knowledge with groups of schoolchildren at those parks.

title: Ms. Greenman, Mr. d'Albert
description: Catherine Calais Greenman and Richard Benedict d'Albert were married yesterday by the Rev. Nancy W. Hanna at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: A Guilty Plea in the Kidnapping And Murder of a Gay Man
description: In Laramie, Wyoming, where the murder of Matthew Shepard six months ago provoked national soul-searching over violence against gay people, Russell A. Henderson pleaded guilty to kidnapping and murdering Mr. Shepard, a college student. He was sentenced to serve two consecutive life terms in prison.

title: Serial Decorating
description: Change is inevitable. things change, people change, tastes change. If that's so, why are we devoting an issue of Home Design to the subject? Because at this moment -- in the history of design, of rooms and of taste -- change isn't merely a factor, it's the factor. The question most frequently asked of design editors is: ''What are the newest trends?'' Their answers (''Copper!'' ''Chinoiserie!'' ''Flea market chic!'') have traditionally served as weather vanes for the consumer, but at the end of the 1990's, do we really care which way the wind is blowing?

title: Five Airlines Join In a New Alliance
description: Smoother transfers and enhanced frequent-flier partnerships are the main goals of Oneworld, an alliance among five international airlines.

title: On the Earnings Radar, Clearer Skies Ahead
description: Corporate earnings growth remains below the double-digit annual pace it hit during much of the 1990's. But after a lackluster increase of 3.7 percent last year, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index seems back on track to reporting decent first-quarter gains, according to First Call Corporation of Boston, which tracks the earnings forecasts of Wall Street analysts.

title: Nicholas Martin, Rebecca Toon
description: Rebecca Jane Toon a daughter of Erika Toon and Col. Robert Toon of Fort Knox, Ky., is to be married today to Nicholas Ivor Martin, the son of Judith Martin and Dr. Robert Martin of Washington. Rabbi Harold S. White is to perform the ceremony at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

description: Bourbon Street has come to Bell Boulevard in Bayside, Queens, in the form of a Cajun/southern food restaurant that opened two weeks ago. At 40-12 Bell Boulevard, between 40th and 41st Avenues, the place is owned by Mark Boccia, a Flushing native. and Joe Cannella, who is from Bayside.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, a sample question in the special Education Life section on Sunday, with an article about college quiz bowls, misstated Leonhard Euler's polyhedron formula and his birthplace. The formula is is V + F - E = 2 (not V + E - F = 2); the birthplace was Switzerland, not Sweden.

title: What Did You Do in the Cold War, Daddy and Mommy?
description: HOW is a man of middle age supposed to feel when he is told, some three decades after his inglorious stateside military service, that he played an essential part in the defeat of godless Communism?
