description: MARRUS-Mary. On April 1. Beloved mother of Zipporah Bodek and Naomi Rosen. Wife of the late Jacob Marrus. Devoted grandmother and great-grandmother. Treasured by all who knew her.

title: A 'Garbage Summit' and a Call to Arms
description: The company that leases the Red Hook Container Terminal from the Port Authority is exploring a venture with Waste Management Inc. to use its piers to transfer containers of garbage from trucks onto oceangoing barges. Neighborhood residents say the proposal is further proof that Brooklyn's waterfront communities are being targeted for more than their fair share of places to handle the city's garbage.

title: Baker Is Seen as the X Factor in the Beefed-Up National League West Race
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers should be favored to win the National League West, right? They certainly spent enough of Rupert Murdoch's money, didn't they?

title: California Dreamin' Made to Order
description: Kara Varian Baker, a California jeweler with something of a West Coast philosophy, has brought her collection east and recently opened a downtown boutique, named for herself.

title: If It Moves, Shoot It
description: The French photographer Jacques Henri Lartigue (1894-1986) believed that happiness was his birthright. He was not all wrong. He was the cosseted youngest child of an eccentric and prosperous family of inventors. Lartigue's one regret, the critic Vicki Goldberg writes in JACQUES HENRI LARTIGUE, PHOTOGRAPHER (Bulfinch/Little, Brown, $95) was that he couldn't remain forever a child. When he did finally grow up, he was absent-minded, charmingly impractical and oblivious of earthly problems. His fanciful photographs, which he began taking at the age of 6, were equally devoid of darkness. Filled with antics and inventions, fashion and coquetry (Lartigue was also arguably the first fashion photographer), wind, sun and flying machines, they captured the end of the belle epoque in all its whimsy and privilege. He was fascinated by speed and the suspension of time and gravity. Whether it was a car careering around a curve, a man prankishly leapfrogging over a cafe chair or a high diver on his descent, Lartigue was intent on ensnaring action in midair. Often his photographs were purposely unbalanced. He strove to catch the tentative and unstable -- the vertiginous tilt of a glider landing on a grassy field or a spread-eagled cat frozen in midair while batting a ball. ''Jacques Henri Lartigue, Photographer'' is beautiful: the black-and-white prints have been gorgeously reproduced, giving this volume more the feel of a portfolio than a book. Goldberg's comments are illuminating. But most of all, she lets these exuberant images speak for themselves. Andrea Barnet

title: Go Ahead, ChemLawn, Make My Day
description: THE other day, as we were racing to leave the house, the telephone rang. ''I'll get it!'' my 6-year-old cried, diving for the phone. As I fumbled for keys and jackets, I listened. ''Hello?'' Noah said. Then, ''What? WHAT?'' Finally, he slammed down the receiver, making us all wonder who had offended him so mightily.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Kips Bay; Cohesive, With a Relaxed Ambiance
description: KIPS BAY may be one of the East Side's more murkily defined areas. But it's a resolutely urban hybrid -- quintessential metropolitan neighborhood, ethnic enclave, institutional alley and midtown business district -- that has seen steady growth over the last two decades or so.

title: Stuffed
description: Welcome to my lovely home. That's O.K., just kick those boxes aside. They arrive every day, deliveries from my Ebay on-line auction raids. Careful of the box marked ''fragile,'' it's probably that rare McCoy hunting dog bookend I bid an insane amount of money on. I'll bet I won't even like it. Nevertheless, I am compelled to own every McCoy pottery dog item that exists.

title: In Defense of a New Path To On-Line Stock Trading
description: ''Hidden Costs in On-Line Trading,'' by Gretchen Morgenson (March 28), examined the rise of electronic communications networks, or E.C.N.'s, in on-line stock trading. The article described how the networks aim to give individual investors instant market access, letting them compete head-on with professional traders. But it also noted a study last year by the National Association of Securities Dealers, which said investors could have found better prices elsewhere on 8 out of 10 stocks they trade. The article drew these responses:

title: Senior Yugoslav Details Casualties and Peace Talks
description: More than 300 civilians have died and nearly 3,000 more have been wounded in the NATO bombings that began March 24, a senior Yugoslav official said today. Serious talks were progressing with the moderate ethnic Albanian leader Ibrahim Rugova on forming an interim government for Kosovo, he added.

title: Symphonic Tribute To Duke Ellington
description: THE Danbury, Norwalk, Eastern Connecticut and Hartford Symphonies will be performing this week, along with the Hartford and New Haven Symphony Pops.

title: Mom as the Chief Executive
description: HOW to explain what seems to be a sudden interest in linking family life to business management skills?

title: War in an Era of Ethnic Conflict
description: Reflecting on NATO's setbacks in Kosovo, former Senator Sam Nunn dryly observed on NBC's ''Today'' show that the alliance has so far proved to be less effective at waging war than it was at deterring one during the long confrontation with the Soviet Union. With Congress reconvening this week, a noisy debate over NATO's strategy and performance is sure to be joined. It ought to be informed by a realistic sense of the limitations of air power and a healthy appreciation for the complexities of this conflict. Important lessons can already be gleaned from this war that may help the United States and its allies prevail in Yugoslavia as well as future conflicts.

Sole of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Rabbi Chester B. Diamond performed the ceremony at Temple Adath Israel B'rith Sholom in Louisville.

title: After Tuning Up an Opening, Kramnik Wins a Gem With It
description: As his anti-Gruenfeld goes, so goes Vladimir Kramnik.

title: Hundreds Gather to Protest City's Auction of Garden Lots
description: About 500 community gardeners, many from other states, rallied in Bryant Park yesterday, chanting ''Stop the Auction! Stop the Auction!'' singing along with Pete Seeger and vowing to preserve the 700 community gardens that have been grown on trash-strewn vacant lots.

title: Levi's Blues
description: So Levi Strauss plans to hook up with Lauryn Hill (a pop star) and ''The Mod Squad'' (a mainstream motion picture) to capture the hearts of the teen-ager audience (Hal Espen, March 21).

title: The Curse of the Whitney
description: The waiting room to the executive offices of the Estee Lauder Companies is vast and formal, dominated by a commanding 40th-floor view of Central Park and by the color blue that Mrs. Lauder favors. But the office occupied by her son, Leonard, who is the chief executive officer, is far more hodgepodge and comfortable. Although as a collector, Leonard is best known for his Cubist paintings, here in the place he meets the outside world he displays a selection of major works of 20th-century American art -- by Agnes Martin, Claes Oldenberg, Joseph Cornell, Robert Rauschenberg and Kenneth Noland. His decision to champion modern American art in public is, characteristically, a considered one: as chairman of the board of the Whitney Museum of American Art, and the trustee who over the past 20 years has been most important in the struggle to shape the museum's identity, he wears his commitment on his sleeve. On the afternoon we met, that shirt sleeve was blue, with contrasting three-button white cuffs and a white collar. His manner was gracious and candid. Having built and now commanding one of the world's largest beauty and cosmetics companies, he has nothing left to prove.

title: Dueling Over Dumbo: Commerce vs. Parks
description: Reflecting different visions of who should work and play in the waterfront area between the Manhattan and Brooklyn bridges, community board members and a developer have drafted dueling plans for the neighborhood called Dumbo.

title: New Election System Proposed for Babylon
description: Babylon residents may decide this summer whether the town will be the first on Long Island to scrap at-large elections of town board members for a district system that proponents say would increase minority representation.

title: How Island Woos Lights, Camera and Action
description: WHEN Rudolph Valentino trudged through hot desert sand in the 1921 film ''The Sheik,'' audiences were visually transported to exotic Arabian lands. Sort of. What they were actually seeing were the sands of the Hamptons, where the movie was filmed.

title: Streetscapes /City Center; From Shriners' Mecca Temple to Mecca for the Arts
description: CITY CENTER is midway through a $1.8 million facade restoration on its spectacular Moorish-style building at 131 West 55th Street, built in 1925 for the Shriners as Mecca Temple. The structure's freshly cleaned soft brown sandstone now plays off against the brightly colored tile and terra cotta of the entry screen. But after the front is finished, there is also the roof, and the auditorium, and the mechanical systems. The two-decade-old renovation project has a long way to go.

title: Glam Dunk
description: Several years ago, Jeffry Weisman, a San Francisco designer, moved into an elegant Nob Hill apartment, which he then renovated. Like its occupant, the apartment was smart, handsome, well-mannered and perfectly turned out; it had creamy walls and an impeccable mixture of antique and contemporary furnishings. Then Weisman met Andrew Fisher.

title: Heaven's Net
description: THE PEARLY GATES

title: Defense Lawyers For Poor Clients May Get Pay Raise
description: KEVIN A. RANDOLPH, a Hartford lawyer, worked as a special public defender early in his career, taking court-assigned cases for defendants who could not afford to pay for their own lawyers. But no longer. One reason he declines such cases are the low fees that Connecticut pays independent lawyers to defend indigent clients.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about concern over conversion of large estates in Greenwich, Conn., into subdivisions referred incorrectly to the status of plans for the Spring Creek property. No plan to convert it into a subdivision has been submitted to town authorities. The article also misstated the use of funds raised by Connecticut's conveyance tax. They now go into the state's general revenues. Under a proposal before the Legislature, additional conveyance taxes levied by towns would be used to purchase open space.

title: Inmates Again Shackled During Birth, Critics Say
description: Nine years ago, after reports that pregnant inmates were being kept in shackles during labor and delivery, a Federal court ordered the New York City Department of Correction to stop the practice. It also prohibited the routine shackling of inmates after they had given birth, requiring the department to consult a physician before using restraints.

description: ''Now who would choose to build a golf course next to a pig farm? Didn't they read the sign? It says 'pig farm,' not 'rose garden.'''

title: Some Profitable Broadening For the Boss's Portfolio
description: How do you send a chief executive's compensation soaring if his own company's shares are merely doing well? In the case of SBC Communications, one of the Baby Bells, the board's answer seems to have been to sweeten the pay of its top executive, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., with shares in a hot telecommunications software company he doesn't even run.

title: A Slavic Spirit For Beethoven
description: The Beethoven string quartets, a specialty of the Tokyo String Quartet in its earlier configurations, have been notably absent from one listener's experience of the group since Mikhail Kopelman became first violinist in 1996. So a special curiosity attached to the performance of Beethoven's C major ''Razumovsky'' Quartet (Op. 59, No. 3) that ended the Tokyo's concert on Wednesday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

description: Stephon Marbury was in no position to offer critiques. Chris Childs and Charlie Ward had just stifled him, cut him off at his every move and basically rendered him and his dazzling game powerless in the Knicks' 93-78 victory this afternoon at Continental Arena.

description: Telecom Italia S.p.A., Italy's No. 1 phone company, has failed to win shareholder support for fending off Olivetti S.p.A.'s $65 billion hostile offer. The rejection opens the way for foreign rivals to join the bidding.

description: The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and senior Administration officials talked more openly today about the possibility that American ground troops would be sent into Kosovo, but insisted again that President Clinton had no intention for now of sending soldiers to do battle there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TINNEY, JOSEPH L., JR.
description: TINNEY-Joseph L., Jr. Of NYC and Longport, NJ. Suddenly, April 7, 1999. Beloved father of Maria Tinney Dagit. Loving grandfather of Gregory and Michael. Fatherin-law of Daniel Dagit. Also survived by sister Joan Byrne, nephews and nieces. Worked as manager of Commercial Production at Colgate Palmolive, producer for Ziv-United Artists, Dancer-Fitzgerald, William Esty and WCAU-TV, Philadelphia. Director of televised Catholic Mass for homebound people, member of Directors Guild of America and University Glee Club of New York. Graduated from Univeristy of Penssylvania and served as a lieutenant J.G., in the US Navy, WW II. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, April 14, 11 AM, at St. John Vianney, Gladwyne, PA. Call Rectory for directions, 610-642-0938. Family will receive friends at church prior to Mass. Memorial service in NYC, on Wednesday, April 21, at 3 PM, at St. Jean Baptiste Church, East 76th St and Lexington. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions to the American Cancer Socieity.

title: A Champion of the Tourist Class

A tanned woman in a white bikini walking a solitary line on a Palau beach. These images -- those that grace the current covers of travel magazines -- suggest a world of Zen serenity and connubial bliss.

description: When Majria Shala's favorite cousin drove her to Kennedy International Airport for an Easter visit to Detroit, she remembers him making a little joke: ''Maybe when you get back, I will be gone to liberate Kosovo.''

description: Semiconductors in the 1970's. Software in the 1980's. Biotechnology in 1991. The Internet in 1999.

description: Lieut. Col. Leofric Boyle, a retired British Army officer who played an important role in saving from extinction the Arabian oryx, a type of antelope, died on March 21. He was 100.

title: Air Traffic Control System Appears to Pass 2000 Test
description: A large portion of the air traffic control system appeared to function smoothly early today as the clocks in radar centers around Colorado rolled over from Dec. 31, 1999, to Jan. 1, 2000, in a dress rehearsal for New Year's Eve.

title: Reform Test in the House
description: Returning to Washington today after two weeks off, Congress faces debates over taxes, budgets, the minimum wage and Kosovo. But the first priority for House members, beginning Wednesday, should be to sign a petition demanding that Speaker Dennis Hastert schedule a prompt vote on campaign finance reform. The petition route has been forced by Mr. Hastert's repeated rejection of requests, even from fellow Republicans, to schedule consideration of such legislation rapidly enough for it to pass before the next election. Many Republicans supporting reform are loath to join with Democrats to challenge the Speaker. But if they do not, its chances could slip away.

title: On Orthodox Easter, a Respite From War and Scarcity
description: This Orthodox Easter sent the Serbs special tribulations, Gordana Perazic mused today outside the Church of the Holy Mother of God in Zemun, where Patriarch Pavle, head of the Serbian Orthodox Church, conducted services. ''But our tables are full, thank God,'' she said.

title: Eliminate Hurdles for Second-Career Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Albright and Counterparts Gather to Show Solidarity
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, on her first visit to NATO headquarters since the bombing began, arrived here tonight for a gathering of foreign ministers intended to show that the 19 members of the alliance are unified behind the air strikes against the Belgrade Government.

title: Sports of The Times; Checketts Stays Afloat Over Mess He Created
description: ON days like yesterday when everything seemed so right, so wonderful, you looked at the Knicks and wondered, ''So what's the problem?'' They stormed the Nets' home court and flattened a team that is supposedly on the rise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, HELEN E.
description: PETERS-Helen E. Formerly residing on West 12th Street, New York, NY. Died on April 8, 1999. Requiem Mass at St. Bernard's RC Church, 328 West 14 St. NY, NY, 10:00 AM, Tuesday, April 13.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDING, GEORGE M.
description: GOLDING-George M. On April 10, 1999. Beloved husband of Phyllis (nee Marks). Loving father of Jacqueline and Andrew. Adoring grandfather of Daniel and Emily. Funeral service Monday, 1 PM, at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY 10538. Interment at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastingson-Hudson, NY. Please no flowers.

title: Control of Gucci Is Still in Dispute
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., the world's No. 1 luxury goods maker, said today that the French retailer Pinault-Printemps-Redoute S.A. had obtained effective control of Gucci Group N.V. and as such was the only company that could bid for all of the Italian-founded fashion company.

title: An Advocate for Refugees With Her Hat Firmly in Hand
description: SHEPPIE ABRAMOWITZ barely had time to toss aside her red slouch-brim hat before she was working the telephone -- cajoling and hectoring Administration officials to do favors big and small for the masses of Kosovo refugees who now wander the earth in despair.

title: Tests Suggest Gains by CUNY In Its Programs For Teaching
description: Two years ago, when the New York State Board of Regents announced that it would shut down teacher education programs that did not meet its standards, several programs at the City University of New York appeared to be in danger.

title: Air Attacks Darken Easter for New York's Serbs
description: ''This,'' said Dr. Zorka Milich, a professor of literature at Nassau Community College, ''is the saddest holy day for Serbs.''

title: 3 Industries Pass Tests for Year 2000 Computer Glitch
description: Three major industries racing to prepare their computers for the Year 2000 -- securities, electric utilities and the airlines -- all passed important testing milestones in recent days.

title: Serbian Populace: Innocent or Guilty?
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Networks' Tough Talk Leaves Local Stations Fuming
description: They have been partners in a highly successful marriage for most of the century, ever since William S. Paley put the two together for CBS radio. But for broadcast networks and their affiliated stations, the relationship, if not permanent estrangement, is certainly on the rocks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARNICK, MARTIN
description: GARNICK - Martin. Painfully missed for your warmth, intelligence, wit, modesty, and generosity of spirit. You were a wonderful friend, colleague and brother. Rest easy. Dick Zeiger

title: With Casino, St. Regis Mohawks Hope to Reverse Their Fortunes
description: In the Mohawk language, there is a word for ''greetings'' -- sekon -- and a word for ''money'' -- ohwista -- but there is no word for what tribal leaders see in the crimson-red Akwesasne Mohawk Casino, now open for business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, ROBERT N.
description: JACOBSON-Robert N. Beloved husband of Siri (nee Hauge). Loving father of of Patti, David, Per Robert, Kari and Lisa. Devoted grandfather of Travis and Megan. Visiting on Monday, 2-4 and 6-9 PM, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY. Funeral service on Tuesday, 10 AM, at the Rye Presbyterian Church. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery. Memorial contributions would be appreciated to HHT Research, in honor of Robert N. Jacobson, Yale University School of Medicine, 100 Church Street South, PO Box 7611, New Haven, CT 06516, attn: B. Sargent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOREST, HELEN
description: FOREST-Helen. Beloved wife of Shep. Loving mother of Steven, Marc and Nancy. Cherished grandmother of Nicole and Dylan. Devoted sister of Eleanor Kiel. Services 11:15 AM, Tuesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Record Companies Are Wary Of New Microsoft Technology
description: The Microsoft Corporation is expected on Tuesday to enter the battle to deliver music to consumers who download the files through the Internet, according to people close to the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBER, HARRY
description: SILBER-Harry. We mourn the passing of Harry Silber, beloved brother of our devoted members Sam and Evelyn Silber. Sincere condolcences to the entire family. Park East Synagogue

title: Serbian Populace: Innocent or Guilty?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Guest Visits Broncos and Other Mysteries
description: Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China took his tour of America to the heartland today, tossing footballs with Denver Broncos, inspecting a Black Angus bull and listening to a Tibetan sing Chinese nationalist songs.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Editorial Observer; Enduring the Unendurable in Postwar Japan
description: The United States occupied and ruled Japan with an iron grip for six years and eight months after World War II, a period nearly twice as long as American involvement in the war itself. Yet because of lingering sensitivity over that anomalous moment in history, little discussion or reflection has occurred in either country about what happened and how people felt during the occupation, at least compared with commentary about the war and Japan's economic rebirth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, IRVING
description: SCHWARTZ-Irving. On April 9, 1999. Husband of Alice Lee Kuhn Schwartz. Father of Barry and Kay Schwartz. Grandfather of Aaron, Adam, Chad and Ryan. Brother of Norma. Brother-in-law of Harriet Sterling, Bernard and Jae Jacovitz. Uncle of Roni, Meyer and Elyse Liberman, Billie Oxenberg, Richard Jacovitz, Lisa Williams, Jeffrey and Moni, Louis and Holly Cohen. Memorial service Monday, 2:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Ovation Sends Torre On an Emotional Run
description: Joe Torre was unsure whether he should wear his Yankee uniform for the first time this season during the World Series ring presentation yesterday until Don Zimmer persuaded him to slip on the pinstripes. Torre had figured he would walk out to the Yankee Stadium mound to scoop up the oval-shaped ring -- with 24 diamonds for the Yankees' 24 championships -- until the fans interceded.

title: Car Kills Bronx Man, 27, Leaving His Bachelor Party
description: Just two weeks before he was to have been married, a Bronx man was struck and killed by a car early yesterday as he left his bachelor party.

title: Finding the Right Contract In a Most Unusual Hand
description: Trying to count the number of bridge players in the world is an impossible task, although there have been many wildly overoptimistic guesses. The first step is easy: Add the membership figures of the national bridge organizations and you get 681,000. The second step, far more difficult, is to count those who play in clubs but do not belong to their national organizations. The third step, about as easy as enumerating undetected murders, is to count those who play socially in their homes.

title: Tafi Finally Wins After Coming Close
description: Andrea Tafi, a workhorse for the Mapei team, has won some big bicycle races but eagerly admits that the one he has always wanted to win is Paris-Roubaix. He especially wanted to win it, he said yesterday, while wearing the jersey of the Italian national champion because in 1980, he saw his boyhood idol, Francesco Moser, win Paris-Roubaix in that same jersey.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the decision by the Austrian branch of the Rothschild family to sell a collection of art and objects confiscated by the Nazis and recently restored to the family misidentified the auction house that will conduct the sale. It is Christie's, as the article reported, not Sotheby's.

title: South Carolina College Student Disappears on a Trip to the City
description: A college student from South Carolina who came to New York on a school trip disappeared after attending an advertising symposium on Friday, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STALFORD, RITA
description: STALFORD-Rita. Formerly of New York City. Passed away April 10, 1999. Beloved wife of Alfred D. Stalford. Services held in Boca Raton, FL. For information, ''Gutterman's,'' 800-992-9262.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNN, JAMES L.
description: DUNN-James L. On April 10, 1999. Loving husband of Mary (nee Spillane). Loving father of Patricia, Thomas, Kathleen and Kevin. Loving brother of Matthew, and brother-in-law of Sheila. Devoted grandfather of Christopher, Timothy, Kate, Laura, Michael and his dog Woodrow. Ex-P.O.W. and Bronze Star veteran of World War II. Visiting hours Monday and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx. Funeral Mass at Incarnation Church, Wednesday, April 14, at 10 AM. Donations in his memory may be made to Incarnation School, 570 W. 175th St, NYC 10033.

title: Some Backtracking on Term Limits
description: George R. Nethercutt Jr. was the big giant slayer five years ago when, in his first race for public office, he unseated a Speaker of the House of Representatives for the first time since the Civil War.

title: Media Talk; Retooling Columbia Journalism Review
description: Faced with an environment in which media practices are scrutinized by every outlet from consumer magazines like Brill's Content to an ever-multiplying band of Internet scribes, The Columbia Journalism Review is rethinking its approach.

title: Florid, Yes, But Modern All the Same
description: With a strong cast, good musicians and deft direction, Handel in the modern opera house confounds its critics. Prior speculation on the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Giulio Cesare'' has been justifiably dim: the wrong space, the wrong instruments, the wrong style. Yet the Met's new production captivated its audience on Saturday night and with reason.

title: Four Men Are Arrested In Stabbing on Subway
description: A 19-year-old man was attacked and stabbed numerous times by four men on a subway train in the Bronx early yesterday, the police said. Four suspects were arrested a short time later, said Officer Valerie St. Rose, a police spokeswoman.

title: Yugoslavs Reported to Be Digging In
description: Serbian forces are heavily fortifying their positions in Kosovo, particularly around Pristina airport, and are moving antiaircraft batteries, tanks and other heavy weapons into villages and large civilian buildings like factories, refugees arriving here said over the weekend.

title: India Tests Missile Able to Hit Deep Into Neighbor Lands
description: Eleven months after exploding a series of nuclear bombs, India test-fired an intermediate-range missile today that reportedly traveled more than 1,250 miles in 11 minutes and left no doubt about the nation's plans to develop a modern system for delivering the megaton punch of its new weapons.

title: Remote Control of Cable Sports; Region by Region, Murdoch's Fox Networks Now Rule
description: Although Rupert Murdoch has an obsession with sports, no one has ever accused him of being a team player. And last week he put on a remarkable individual performance.

title: Bright Lights, Big City After Super-Saver Trip
description: Last season, the Expos were particularly hard on the Mets. So far this year, the Mets have again experienced tough going against Montreal, though not on the scoreboard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKMAN, SHIRLEY
description: MARKMAN-Shirley. Beloved wife and best friend for 54 years of Martin. Loving mother of Barbara and Bruce Spiegel, Marcia and Irwin Siegel and David and Deborah Markman. Adoring grandmother of Erica, Richard, Lilly, Jared and Meredith. Cherished sister of Stanley and Cynthia Gingold, Ruby and Herbert Janof and Dorothy and the late Al Weintraub. Devoted aunt, cousin and friend. We will miss your loving kindness and generous spirit which inspired us all.

title: All That Dazzles Is Not Dietrich, However Real She Looks
description: ''Kitsch!'' growled the voice of Marlene Dietrich, again and again, in Maximilian Schell's 1984 documentary about her life. The screen goddess, by then reclusive, whose octogenarian self was never seen but was very much heard in the film, applied the German word to anything she regarded as cheaply sentimental. This ranged from undue attachments to countries to the famous scene in her 1931 film ''Dishonored'' in which she coolly applied lipstick before being executed by a firing squad.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of the golfer Thomas Bjorn in some editions yesterday, with a Sports of The Times column about changes at the Augusta National Golf Club for the Masters Tournament, was published in error. Bjorn was shown on the 13th hole, which is not one of the holes that have been altered; he was not on the 17th.

title: Corrections
description: A byline was omitted from the Religion Journal on Saturday, about Walter Cronkite's efforts to counter the political activities of religious conservative groups. The writer was Gustav Niebuhr.

title: A Trickle of Year 2000 Lawsuits
description: A trickle of new lawsuits in recent months is expanding the legal landscape of the Year 2000 computer problem. But so far, the cases offer little support for the dire predictions that courts will be choked by litigation over Y2K, as the problem is known.

title: Serbian Populace: Innocent or Guilty?
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; Another Apology By '60 Minutes'
description: For the second time in four months, the CBS News program ''60 Minutes'' is acknowledging that it was snookered.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about a criminal investigation into Duke & Company, a defunct New York brokerage firm, misstated the trading status of the stocks of two companies that Duke took public. Shares of the companies, Sel-Leb Marketing Inc. and IFS International Inc., are still trading on Nasdaq's small-capitalization market; Sel-Leb's shares closed Friday at $9.8125, while IFS's shares closed at $2.125.

title: NEWS BRIEFS      INTERNATIONAL   A3-14    SQN##182460##FEWER BOMBS DROPPED ON CLOUDY DAY IN BALKANS  NATO held back from intensive bombing on a day of cloudy weather over Kosovo, even as alliance officials accused the Serbs of carrying out new atrocities against ethnic Albanians in their southern province. Alliance officials released aerial photographs, including one of freshly turned earth, that they said could be mass graves, and another of clusters of people described as ethnic Albanians driven from their homes.   A1      SQN##177113##A Russian relief convoy headed for Yugoslavia was stopped by Hungarian authorities after they determined that it was carrying fuel and equipment that could be used by Belgrade's military, officials said.   A8
description: SQN##177814##Gunmen killed Slavko Curuvija, a well-known opposition publisher, outside his apartment building in central Belgrade, sending a message to the few remaining independent news outlets in Yugoslavia. The Government has moved to shut down all independent media in recent weeks. A10

title: Losing Track of the Main Objective of War
description: As the United States faces the prospect of a deepening but ambiguous military involvement in Kosovo, some observers have been judging this campaign against the criteria for overseas military intervention that I suggested during the Reagan Administration. This comparison tells us much not only about NATO's strategy in Yugoslavia, but also about the state of the United States military in general.

title: GOLF: Five Years Later and the Coat Still Fits; Olazabal Wins His Second Masters, Outshooting Love and Norman
description: Three years ago, Jose Maria Olazabal suffered through days when he couldn't walk, crippled by intense pain in his feet.

title: A Rich, Inscrutable He; A Rich, Vulnerable She
description: When rich people go bad, at least in fiction, they do it in one of two ways. Like Andrew Makepeace Ladd 3d, they shut down emotionally and rely on taste and convention to make life seem controllable. Or like Melissa Gardner, they seek out sensation and, intoxicated by the freedom that money allows, eventually drown.

title: Potential Profits Seen in Fan-Oriented Web Sites
description: Wait a second. Wasn't entertainment supposed to be a flop on the Internet?

title: Raul Silva Henriquez, 91, Chile Cardinal, Dies
description: Raul Cardinal Silva Henriquez, who led Roman Catholicism in Chile for more than two decades, championing human rights and sharply criticizing Gen. Augusto Pinochet's military dictatorship, died on Friday in a home for retired priests in Santiago, Chile. He was 91.

title: 11 Miles of Turnpike Shut To Re-Create a Shooting
description: In an extraordinary investigative action, law enforcement officials shut down an 11-mile stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike this morning to re-enact a 1998 shooting that focused allegations of racial profiling against the State Police.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WESTCARR, MILDRED
description: WESTCARR-Mildred. April 12, 1981. In God always loving; in God forever loved. Daughters, Shirley and Lorraine; Brother, Archibal

title: Serbs Shift Strategy, Fortifying at Border
description: Several factors indicate that Serbian forces are fortifying positions in Kosovo, particularly around the Pristina airport, in a way that suggests they foresee a NATO invasion.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on March 8 about a performance of ''Lizzie Borden'' at the New York City Opera on March 6 misstated the year that another work based on the Lizzie Borden story had its debut. Agnes de Mille's ballet ''Fall River Legend'' was first performed in 1948, not 1954. This correction was delayed when a reader's letter pointing out the error was misdirected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, DR. HOWARD, DVM
description: KESSLER-Dr. Howard, DVM. Thank you for your kindness to me and all your animal friends. We will miss you. God bless. Little Buddy

title: Machine Tool Orders Drop
description: Domestic orders for machine tools declined in February for the fifth straight month, according to an industry survey.

title: Rings, a Rout And a Taste Of Perfection
description: Orlando Hernandez blew hot air into his right hand before every pitch on this chilly and nearly memorable day, staring at catcher Jorge Posada with his serious brown eyes and focusing on his next task. Hernandez wanted everything to be perfect, from the warmth of his hand to the kick of his leg to the delivery of his pitch. Everything almost was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASTNER, HANNAH
description: KASTNER-Hannah. In Jerusalem, age 91. To our Safta, a noble and courageous woman who survived many battlefields of Jewish history. Your memory will live on in our hearts, our deeds and in our future commitments to the state of Israel. We will miss you here. Zohar, Tal, Ariel, and Asaf

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCBRIDE, RODNEY LESTER
description: McBRIDE-Rodney Lester. On April 10, 1999, at Greenwich, CT, of esophageal cancer. Loving husband of Judy Winslow. Father of Douglas of Scottsdale, AZ, and Cheryl of Denver, CO. Brother of Laurence of Colorado Springs and Judy of Denver, CO. Born in Denver, CO, on September 1, 1941. Graduated from the University of Colorado and earned his M.B.A. at the University of California at Berkeley. Chartered Financial Analyst and Chartered Investment Counselor. Member, American Financial Analyst Federation. Managing Director at Furman Selz Capital Management, New York City. Highly respected by his peers and clientele for his talent and professionalism. Enthusiastic golfer. Memorial service at Second Congregational Church, Greenwich, CT, on Wednesday, April 14, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Cancer Society, 1175 Post Road East, Westport, CT 06880.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SONZ, FRANCES B.
description: SONZ-Frances B. May 17, 1913-April 12, 1998. Love, Benedict

title: Help for Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Hundreds Rally to Save Community Gardens
description: For the second day in a row, several hundred people gathered yesterday for a rally in the hopes of saving the city's community gardens from the auction block.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, KONSTANTIN
description: GREGORY-Konstantin. Of Stamford, CT (formerly Thousand Oaks, CA) on April 8. Beloved husband of Marcelle, adoring father of Cynthia and proud grandfather of Lloyd. Devoted brother of George, Mary, Michael and Theodore. Requiem Saturday, April 10 at St. Michael the Archangel, Greenwich, at 11:30. His life was wholly devoted to the happiness of others. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Glaucoma Research Foundation, 490 Post St., San Francisco, CA 94102.

title: Road to the Derby; Menifee Sets Up a New Baffert-Walden Shootout
description: Wondertross, the favorite who ran sixth in the Blue Grass Stakes on Saturday, went to the hospital today with a case of colic that probably added him to the list of casualties for the Kentucky Derby.

title: Jury Selection in Louima Case Is Moving Into Second Phase
description: After scrutinizing the answers that 785 prospective jurors gave on a questionnaire, lawyers and a Federal judge are to begin the second stage of jury selection this week in the trial of four New York City police officers accused of brutalizing Abner Louima.

title: With Each Step, a Hope for More Humane Jails
description: The streets of this Westchester town, where shiny sport utility vehicles grudgingly share space with joggers, featured an unusual sight today: eight people walking single file, one holding aloft a long purple ''prayer banner,'' another holding a banner heralding a ''Prison Reform Walk.''

title: Serbian Populace: Innocent or Guilty?
description: To the Editor:

title: Poor Workers Lose Medicaid Coverage Despite Eligibility
description: Hundreds of thousands of low-income people across the United States have lost health insurance as an unintended consequence of the 1996 welfare law, Federal and state officials and health policy experts say.

title: Bosnian Croat Leader Goes on Trial Today in War Crimes
description: An influential Bosnian Croat politician, a former ally of the Croatian President, goes on trial on Monday before the international war crimes tribunal here, a process that is likely to throw the spotlight on Croatia's role in the Bosnian conflict.

title: From Grieving Mother to Forceful Celebrity
description: Since the Feb. 4 killing of her son Amadou in a barrage of 41 police bullets, Kadiadou Diallo has made a journey that has taken her further than the 4,300 miles from her home in the West African nation of Guinea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SOPHIE
description: BERNSTEIN-Sophie. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Sophie Bernstein, beloved sister of our devoted members Evelyn and Sam Silber. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Once Again, Ammann Is Stellar in a Shootout for the MetroStars
description: As the MetroStars and the Tampa Bay Mutiny began a shootout today after battling to a 1-1 tie in regulation, MetroStars goalkeeper Mike Ammann thought to himself: this is my time.

title: The Victimless Income Gap?
description: Presidential aspirants since Ronald Reagan have urged us to ask whether we're better off now than we were four years ago. At any time from 1945 to the early 1970's, the answer for most Americans would have been a resounding yes. Throughout that period, incomes grew at about 3 percent a year for families up and down the income ladder.

title: Gunmen Kill Opposition Publisher in Belgrade
description: In a vicious message to the few remaining independent news outlets in Yugoslavia, gunmen today shot and killed a well-known opposition publisher outside his apartment building in central Belgrade.

title: Essay; The Eager Beavers
description: After four of the blossoming Japanese cherry trees on the edge of the Tidal Basin were mysteriously hacked down, park police lay in wait at night to catch the vandals.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Faiths View War Scenes Through Distinct Pasts
description: The war in Kosovo is producing images of destruction that have lent special intensity to the conflict's ethnic and religious dimensions.

title: INSIDE
description: India Test-Fires Missile

title: 'Giselle' Accents Romanticism's Play on Reality
description: The San Francisco Ballet has never included ''Giselle'' in its permanent repertory. As if to compensate for this not-so-dreadful omission, Helgi Tomasson's new staging for the company has an opera house grandeur that ''Giselle'' deserves but rarely receives.

title: Eliminate Hurdles for Second-Career Teachers; High-Stakes Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Mergers That Foster Competition
description: It seems that barely a day passes without word of some new linkup within the once-separate industries of telephone, television and the Internet. Deals worth billions -- in stock -- are made by companies that have yet to earn $100 million in profits.

title: Briton Wins the Pritzker, Architecture's Top Prize
description: Sir Norman Foster, the British architect whose work celebrates the power of modern building technology, has been awarded the Pritzker Architecture Prize for 1999. The prize, which includes a stipend of $100,000, is to be presented at a ceremony on June 6 in Berlin, where Sir Norman has recently completed a redesign of the historic Reichstag building.

title: Jaywalkers Take the Safe Route
description: To the Editor:

title: Clutter on TV Hit New High in '98
description: Clutter on television -- the time devoted to nonprogramming content like commercials and promotions -- reached a new high in last year, according to an annual report.

title: I.R.S. FIGURES SHOW DROP IN TAX AUDITS FOR BIG COMPANIES
description: Tax returns from Americans earning more than $100,000 a year and from the biggest corporations are increasingly escaping the scrutiny of the Internal Revenue Service, new agency figures show.

title: Treasury Sale Is Limited to Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GRASSO, MARY
description: GRASSO-Mary. We love you and miss you, our love has not diminished since you left us 13 years ago. You are ever in our hearts and minds. Pat, Linda, Donald and Tommy

title: Hidden Creek's Alvaretto Wins
description: Margie Goldstein-Engle and her mount, Hidden Creek's Alvaretto, put in the only clear round within the time allowed to capture the $150,000 Budweiser American Invitational Grand Prix in Tampa, Fla., on Saturday.

title: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce; As Web portals push to sell more goods themselves, on-line merchants that pay the sites for access have grown uneasy.
description: ANY Internet merchants are feeling nervous these days about their partnerships with portal sites, the gateways to the Web for millions of Internet users.

title: How One Man Used Corporate Affirmative Action in Ameritech Deal
description: Chester C. Davenport, the managing director of a private investment firm in Bethesda, Md., does not deny that he got a piece of the Ameritech Corporation's $3.3 billion sale of half of its wireless telephone business, at least in part, because he is black.

title: A retrospective issue offers grist for debate over slogans: How much credit for the Marlboro Man?
description: IS there anything that the folks who work in advertising enjoy more than gossiping about their competitors? Perhaps it is strolling down that side street off Madison Avenue named Memory Lane to judge the merits and demerits of campaigns, slogans, jingles and characters, not to mention the executives who have led the major agency, marketing and media companies.

title: Guiding Hip-Hop Toward Operatic Leaps; Prince Paul Imagines a Movie as He Makes Rap Relevant for the Suburbs
description: Hip-hop magazines like Blaze are hailing Prince Paul as a genius, an Einstein. Another magazine, Request, says his new CD, ''Prince Among Thieves,'' is ''a social and musical masterwork.'' Vibe calls ''Prince Among Thieves'' ''the world's first hip-hopera.''

title: Virtual Reality: The Perils of Seeking a Novelist's Facts in Her Fiction
description: Before my last, recent book tour, I made myself memorize a quotation from an interview with John Cheever that began, ''It seems to me that any confusion between autobiography and fiction debases fiction.'' Thus girded, armored, I hoped to silence forever the questioner who sits there in the third row waiting to ask, ''How much of your work is autobiographical?''

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: There Are Those Times When Logic Doesn't Matter

title: Compressed Data; An On-Line Gambling Site Adds a Bet on the Dow
description: As if Internet investing weren't enough of a gamble, an on-line gambling company has begun taking bets on the ups and downs of the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Ammirati Executive Moving to Ayer
description: A top creative executive at Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York is leaving to take the top creative post at N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York. Jonathan Mandell, 44, an executive vice president and managing director for creative at Ammirati Puris, is joining Ayer, a MacManus Group unit, as worldwide chief creative officer, effective on May 3. He assumes duties that had been handled by Steven Feinberg, executive vice president and executive creative director, who left last May.

title: Jaywalkers Take the Safe Route
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Springsteen's America Plays Europe
description: ''As You Know, You Are the Boss,'' read a red, white and blue banner flung over the highest balcony of the Palau San Jordi arena here on Friday night, hailing Bruce Springsteen in the oddly formal language of translation, as he began his European tour in the same arena where Michael Jordan displayed a different form of prowess during the 1992 Olympics.

description: To the Editor:

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LE BERMUTH, JACQUES
description: LE BERMUTH-Jacques. Remembered with love always. L A S

title: Nationalist Critical of U.S. Air Base Is Elected Governor of Tokyo
description: Voters humiliated Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party in elections on Sunday, choosing a maverick nationalist as the new Governor of Tokyo.

title: Charges of Forgery, And of Betrayal; Friendship and Trust Lie at Heart of Case Challenging Validity of Kennedy Papers
description: John M. Reznikoff remembers that August day two years ago, when he sat with his family on a beach on Cape Cod and felt on top of the world. He had established himself as a respected dealer in stamps, coins and other collectibles, even locks of hair from famous people. But he was best known for his vast collection of autographs of noted figures, tens of thousands of them, including every President, from Washington to Clinton.

title: Knee Injury For Piazza Leaves Him Frustrated
description: The Mets announced today, as expected, that the All-Star catcher Mike Piazza would be placed on the 15-day disabled list with a sprained right knee.

title: Patents; Finally, a vaccine that may help prevent painful shingles from occurring or recurring.
description: CHICKEN POX is a classic childhood ailment that can leave a kid housebound with a sore throat, fever, and itchy sores. After two weeks, the chicken pox symptoms usually have vanished, but the varicella-zoster virus lingers behind, hiding in sensory nerve cells near the spinal cord. It lies dormant through adulthood when, for some people, it becomes active again, causing another disease -- shingles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHRER, MARTIN M.

Mentor, friend and loving father of sons Paul and Steven. Adored father-inlaw of Marjorie and Nancy. Much loved grandfather of Matthew, Andrew, Rebecca, Steven, Jr., and Jessica. Received his Bachelor of Science degree from Upsala College and his Master of Science degree on a fellowship from Rutgers University. Commissioned a lieutenant in the U.S. Navy during World War II, and Chairman of the Board of Lehrer and Company until his retirement. He was an avid boatsman. With many beautiful memories, his caring, wisdom and guidance will be sorely missed. You were so special to us all! In lieu of flowers, family suggests contributions be made to the charity of your choice. Memorial services 3 PM, Tuesday, April 13, 1999, at Temple Bat Yam of East Fort Lauderdale, FL. For information, Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL; 800992-9262.

title: Compressed Data; Pioneer Site Finds Itself At Home With New Owner

title: Will the Voices Grow Ever Quieter?; Conductors Ponder the State of Choral Music After Robert Shaw's Death

title: ONEX IN $90 MILLION DEAL FOR AUTOMOTIVE PARTS MAKER
description: The Onex Corporation agreed yesterday to buy a controlling interest in J. L. French Automotive Castings Inc., a maker of aluminum die-cast automotive parts, for $135 million (Canadian), or about $90 million (United States). Onex, which is based in Toronto, has interests in parking lots, auto parts, computer parts and Hollywood films. Under the deal, which is expected to close by the end of this month, Onex will acquire 51 percent ownership, plus voting control. It made the deal in partnership with its Hidden Creek Industries unit. French, based in Sheboygan, Wis., has two plants in Wisconsin, five in Britain and one in Spain. It has annual revenue of about $300 million. Certain French shareholders will retain a collective 20 percent stake.

title: Doubts Rise On Takeover Of Shipbuilder

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: WENK-Eugene J., PH.D. The New York Medical College community is deeply saddened by the passing of one of its own, Eugene J. Wenk, Ph.D. '72, Emeritus Professor of Cell Biology & Anatomy. Dr. Wenk made a difference in the 45 years he was a part of the universityfirst as co-founder of the Graduate Student Association during his doctoral studies, then as the faculty member who guided thousands of students through the course in gross anatomy. After retiring from his regular teaching position, he continued to direct postgraduate anatomy programs for residents in surgical sub-specialties and consult with clinical departments in their research. For his professional integrity & dedication to teaching, we offer our gratitude. We extend heartfelt condolences to his daughters & family. Rev. Msgr. Harry C. Barrett, President and CEO Ralph A. O'Connell, M.D., Provost and Dean, School of Medicine New York Medical College.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: ELROD-Harold G., Professor. 80, of Old Saybrook, CT. Died suddenly on April 14, 1999. Prof. Elrod was born November 19, 1918 in Manchester, NH. He was educated in Montreal, at Phillips Exeter, MIT, and Harvard, receiving his Ph.D. from Harvard in 1949. He served as a naval officer in World War II from 1942-1945, retiring from the Naval Reserve as a Lt. Commander. Prof. Elrod was a professor of engineering and science at Columbia University from 1955 to 1985. He also taught and did research at the U.S. Naval Academy, Case Western Reserve University, Michigan State University, INSA (Lyons), and the University of Southampton. In 1994, the American Society of Mechanical Engineers presented Prof. Elrod with the Hersey Award for his fundamental contributions to hydrodynamic lubrication theory and bearing design and performance. He had continued as an active contributor and consultant in the field of mechanical engineering. He was a member of the ASME, AIAA, past president of the Old Saybrook Historical Society, one of three founders of the Saybrook History Buffs, and an avid tennis player. Prof. Elrod leaves his wife, Allison Elrod, of Old Saybrook; three children, Dr. Terry Elrod, Professor at the University of Alberta, Joanne Williams of Glastonbury, CT and Caroline Taylor of Thornwood, NY; and six grandchildren. Memorial services will be held on Monday, April 19, 1999 at 11AM in the First Church of Christ Congregational of Old Saybrook. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Old Saybrook Historical Society, Hart House. For more information contact Swan Funeral Home, 1224 Boston Post Road, Old Saybrook, CT 06475.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: KAHN-Samuel Sidney. It is with deep sorrow that we mark the passing of Sidney Kahn, a member of The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art, whose sudden death was a great loss to us all. He was an avid collector who also enjoyed an active involvement as a supporter of the arts and the endeavors of contemporary artists. title: Cancer Trailblazer Follows the Genetic Fingerprints
description: Cancer was once thought to be a single disease that attacked different tissues. Then it was recognized to be a hundred different diseases as determined by the particular tissue involved and the kind of cells within that tissue that were growing out of control.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: SAMPONARO-Dr. Nicholas. of North Hutchinson Island, FL, formerly of Litchfield, CT died on April 13, 1999 after a brief illness. For 60 years he was the loving husband of Marie and the devoted father of Frank, Philip and Peter. Born in Hartford, CT in 1903, he graduated from Trinity College in 1925 and Johns Hopkins Medical School in 1929. After interning at Union Memorial Hospital in Baltimore, he joined the staff of Hartford Hospital (with a speciality in Eye, Ear, Nose & Throat) where he remained until World War II. During the war, he was a commander in the US Navy. After service, he joined the staff of Charlotte Hungerford Hospital and practiced in Torrington, CT until his retirement in 1983. He was a dedicated physician, a man of great integrity who gave his time generously to those unable to provide for themselves. A deeply spiritual man, he lived his faith and loved his family unconditionally. He was blessed with three wonderful daughter-in-laws (Marsha, Tish and Diana) and eight grandchildren. We, whom he loved, will never forget what he accomplished and the tenets by which he lived his life.

title: Revisiting Some Old Friends

Every spring the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, which Mr. Wadsworth created in 1969 and ran as artistic director for 20 years, celebrates his birthday with a pair of concerts in which he participates as pianist and harpsichordist. The 30th anniversary of the society coincides with Mr. Wadsworth's 70th birthday next month, so he was invited to present any sort of celebratory concert he wanted.

description: PEARL-Eleanor. The Tourette Syndrome Association (TSA) is deeply saddened by the passing of its cherished founder, Eleanor Pearl. An invaluable full-time volunteer since the opening of our office in 1972, she served with distinction as a Charter Member of our Board of Directors as National Secretary and as Editor of our Association newsletter. In 1996 she received the first-ever National TSA Volunteer Recognition Award. From the very beginning she has been intimately involved in every step of our growth. Her sensitivity, insight and quiet efficiency were an inspiration to all who were privileged to work alongside her. She cannot be replaced; she can only be remembered with love and gratitude. Funeral services will be on Monday, April 19th at 12 noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: BAUM-Ruth, 74. Died peacefully at home on April 17 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. An innovator in the prepared food business, a cookbook author, artist and a philanthropist, Ruth considered her family to be her greatest achievement. She was intensely proud of her children and their spouses, her grandchildren and her great-grandchild. She was the loving wife of the late restaurateur Joseph Baum for fifty-five years. She loved gardening and beating her husband at paddle tennis. She created Lifespice, a line of salt-free sauces and dressings and with her daughter, Hilary, she wrote ''The Lifespice Salt-Free Cookbook''. She volunteered in public schools and at the Northside Center for Child Development, she served as a board member and director of development. She is survived by her brother, Dr. Sol Courtman; daughter, Hilary, and son-in-law, Richard; her son, Charles and daughter-in-law, Jennifer; her son, Edward and daughter-in-law, Lise, as well as her grandchildren, Alexander, Alexandra, Trevor, Graham, Kiva, and Anna; her grandson-in-law, Mauro and her great-granddaughter, Anaia. Ruthie, thanks for all your gifts, we love you. Services Tuesday, 11:15 AM, April 20 at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam. Please send contributions to the North Side Center for Child Development.

title: Signs Seem To Point To Gretzky Farewell
description: Wayne Gretzky carefully guided the puck to Mathieu Schneider, who blasted it from just inside the blue line. John MacLean deflected it into the net for the decisive goal in the Rangers' 2-1 victory over the Tampa Bay Lightning. In the stands, children dressed in No. 99 jerseys held up signs pleading with him to return next season. Gretzky is not sure. With two games remaining in the Ranger season the question hangs in the air: will he or won't he retire after 20 seasons?

title: Adelphia in $1.17 Billion Deal To Buy Harron's Cable Systems

D'Ambrosio (Trudi), Zosia, Karen and Laura Zaks, and great-grandfather of Anthony Jacob D'Ambrosio. Born in Valle Agricola, Italy, in 1905, Colonel Rega came to this country as a young boy. He was predeceased by his first wife, Sylvia Miller Neidich, and his eldest son, Perry. A graduate of New York University and NYU Law School, Mr. Neidich founded his own shopping center leasing and management company in Yonkers, New York, in the 1950's and built it into the leading retail leasing and brokerage firm in Westchester County. He was a former New York State Director of the International Council of Shopping Centers and served as Chairman of the Mayor's Committee for the Redevelopment of Yonkers. title: Why the Chinese Are Fretting: Is Clinton Fickle?

title: Corrections

title: Reviews/Fashion; South of Seventh, Or Off the Map?
description: Outside the Puck Building in SoHo last week, a couple of photographers were lolling around when one, an old guy with the alert expression of a trauma nurse, spied a young woman coming through the downtown crowd. Suddenly he was alive, crouching low to snap her leather sandals and then rising to capture the full bohemian length of her: the long gray dress made of sweatshirt fabric, the old Levi's jacket with its sleeves hacked off, the blond hair wound around a piece of wood -- a twig -- with a clump of knotted leather streaming down her back like a jungle vine.

title: NATO Ministers, Looking for Kosovo Accord, Urge Russia to Take Part
description: NATO foreign ministers pledged today to keep up the air attacks against Yugoslavia but at the same time searched for the shape of a political settlement in Kosovo and urged Russia to be part of it.

title: Gasping for Air Under a Blanket of Pollen
description: In an awesome burst of friskiness, the trees of northern Georgia have coated Atlanta with a thick yellow veil of fertility, and the city is beginning to wheeze under the weight.

title: The Messages From Little Rock
description: Yesterday's decision by Federal District Judge Susan Webber Wright holding President Clinton in contempt of court was a fitting judicial response to what she termed his ''false, misleading and evasive'' testimony about his relationship with Monica Lewinsky in the Paula Jones sexual harassment case. The 32-page ruling puts into the legal and historical record that Mr. Clinton was untruthful and deliberately misleading, and assigns a legal sanction to uphold the rule of law.

Family and Friends

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: PUTNAM-Jane Garnett. A longtime Stamford, CT resident died peacefully at home Monday, April 12, 1999. The cause was lung cancer. She was pre-deceased by her husband William Bradford Dowse Putnam. She was born Jane Mitchell Garnett on May 27, 1924 in Baltimore, MD to Walter Lowry Garnett, M.D. and Corrie Lee Conway of Brownwood, TX. Her childhood was spent in Mexico City, Mexico where she graduated from the American School. A 1945 graduate of Mills College in Oakland, CA., Jane moved to New York City where she met and married her husband, an advertising executive. She is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Wolf of Dallas, TX. She is also survived by her children William G. Putnam of Tuckahoe, N.Y., Dorothy Delano Putnam of Windham, CT., Caroline Putnam LeDuc of North Truro, MA. and by five grandchildren. She is also survived by her dearly loved friends Cissy and Donald Horning of Westport, CT. and Naples, FL. The memorial service will be held privately at a later date. Memorial contributions would be greatfully accepted by the American Cancer Soc., 1175 Post Rd. East, Westport CT. 06880. She faced her death as she lived her life, with great courage, grace and dignity. She will be missed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: DURSO-The Hon. Anthony N., Sr. (former Kings County Clerk). Of Amityville, LI, on April 16, 1999, after a brief hospital stay. Commissioner Durso was Kings County Clerk, Commissioner of Jurors, and Clerk of the Supreme Court for 20 years prior to his retirement in 1989. Durso served as Executive Secretary of the Kings County Republican Committee under the late John R. Crews, County Chairman. From 1948 to 1952 he served as a Deputy Commissioner of the State Athletic Commission. Commissioner Anthony N. Durso, Poppi to his family, is survived by his loving wife of 56 years, Grace S.; his four children, Patricia Forte, Joan Serra, John Robert, Anthony Nicholas, Jr.; daughter-in-law Peggy; sons-in-law Bernie and Matt; 13 grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Reposing today (Monday), 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM, at the Powell Funeral Home, Inc., 67 Broadway (Route 110), Amityville. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:30 AM, St. Martin of Tours R.C. Church, Amityville. Entombment Pinelawn Memorial Park. Family would appreciate donations to Hospice Care Network Development Department, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, NY 11590.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday and others recently about reports from Kosovo refugees who said Serbian troops were herding Albanians into a town near the Macedonian border referred incompletely to the availability of confirmation from foreign journalists in Kosovo. While many foreign journalists were expelled soon after NATO began its bombing of Serbia on March 24, some remain. Paul Watson, for example, has been filing dispatches for The Los Angeles Times from Pristina, the Kosovo capital, but not on that specific subject.

title: Court Officials Seek to Limit Sequestration
description: Jurors in trials involving violent crimes, except for the handful of death penalty cases that arise each year, should no longer be required to be sequestered during deliberations, according to a report released yesterday by New York State court officials.

title: PENSKE TO TAKE $83 MILLION STAKE IN UNITED AUTO GROUP
description: United Auto Group Inc. said that an investment firm led by Roger S. Penske would take an $83 million stake in the company and that Mr. Penske would become chairman and chief executive. Mr. Penske, the former race-car driver who is known for revitalizing transportation companies, will replace Marshall Cogan, and Penske Capital Partners will hold a majority of seats on United Auto's board. The move lets Mr. Penske expand his auto dealership business.

title: Inside the World of Osama bin Laden
description: Given that he is one of the dangerous men in the world, the probable source of considerable death and destruction and ''the most wanted man on earth'' with a $5 million bounty on his head, surprisingly little is known about Osama bin Laden. Computer hackers tend to get more press than he does. ''The Terrorist and the Superpower,'' a production of Frontline and The New York Times, is an ambitious attempt to profile the elusive Mr. bin Laden and to investigate the motives behind last summer's terrorist bombings at embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, for which he has been blamed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST

title: Former City Official Named Chief of Black-Owned Bank
description: Deborah C. Wright, the president of a program that has been funneling millions of dollars in government funds into Harlem, has been named president and chief executive of the struggling Carver Bancorp, the parent company of the nation's largest black-owned bank.

title: A Power Play, Figuratively Speaking, Spans the Seine
description: With all the symmetry that Parisians love, the Pont des Arts links the painting and sculpture of the Louvre Museum with the philosophy and letters of the Institut de France. It is a footbridge, but a serious bridge nonetheless, its iron arches resting on stone foundations and 19th-century lampposts adding elegance to its wide wooden walkway across the Seine. It is, one might say, an unlikely place to find fierce American Indian warriors and naked African wrestlers.

title: Winning Record for Valentine (but Who's Counting?)
description: That was not just another victory the Mets gained in their Shea Stadium opener yesterday. The 8-1 conquest of the Florida Marlins gave the Mets' manager a winning record in his 11-year major league managerial career. The team doesn't play today, so Bobby Valentine can savor his over .500 mark -- 775 victories, 774 losses -- at least until tomorrow night.

title: INTERTAPE POLYMER TO BUY TWO SPINNAKER TAPE UNITS
description: Intertape Polymer Group agreed yesterday to acquire Spinnaker Industries' two industrial tape units for $105 million and 300,000 warrants to buy Intertape shares for $35 each over the next seven years. The two units are the Central Products Company, a maker of carton-sealing tapes, and the Spinnaker Electrical Tape Company, a pressure- sensitive electrical tape business. The Lynch Corporation of Rye, N.Y., owns 61 percent of Spinnaker, a Dallas-based maker of adhesive-backed paper label stock. Intertape, which is based in Montreal, makes polyolefin plastic and paper-backed packaging products for industrial use. Shares of Spinnaker closed at $13.375, down 25 cents.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR PLUNGES. Sugar prices fell to a 12 1/2-year low on expectations that big harvests in Brazil and Europe would add unneeded supply to world markets. In New York, sugar for May delivery fell 0.18 cent, to 5.25 cents a pound.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about the dispensing of drugs on the Internet misidentified the one ordered on line from a Spanish pharmacy by Keith Lamb of Columbus, Ohio, who suffers from back pain. It was codeine, not oxycodone.

title: Saving the Human Details of Jerome Robbins's Art
description: The studio where Jerome Robbins danced out his ideas before rehearsals was filled with packing boxes. Posters, photographs and costume and set sketches were propped up against the pristine white walls and wall-length mirror in this top-floor room of Robbins's handsome, austere Upper East Side town house. The air resonated with murmurs of ''Oh, look at this!'' one recent afternoon as artifacts of Robbins's work and life were examined and tagged for delivery to a new destination.

title: Mets Ride Rising Tide of Good Pitching and Defense
description: The Mets woke up yesterday to a morning rain. And hours later, when they came off the field after their home opener, they were greeted by a clubhouse flood. In between, though, there was more than enough sunshine as the Mets drubbed the Florida Marlins, 8-1, and continued their impressive start to the season.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: RICHARDS-Nancy. Wife of Peter Richards of Moultonboro, NH and Phoenix, AZ died Monday, April 12, 1999 of cancer at Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center, Hanover, NH. Born Nancy Slocum in Washington, DC, she attended Madiera School and graduated from Vassar College in 1950. After her marriage in 1951, she and her husband lived in Duxbury, MA., and Phoenix, AZ, moving permanently to Moultonboro, NH in 1990. Always committed to conservation, she was a founding member of the Manomet Center for Conservation Sciences where she introduced the ''Birds Go To School'' program. She was trustee of the Massachusetts Audubon Society and a director of the Science Center of New Hampshire with particular interest in its Kirkwood Garden. She held the position of director of the Squam Lakes Conservation Society for many years. Her love of flowers in general and her own wildflower garden in particular allowed her to gain a wealth of knowledge regarding the natural world. In 1998, she was presented The New England Wild Flower Society's ''Kathryn Taylor Award for Private Gardens''. She is survived by her husband, Peter, three daughters, Elizabeth Tully of Concord, MA, Harriet Richards of Wayne, PA, and Linda Bolesta of Staten Island, NY and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at The Old South Church, 645 Boylston St, Boston at 11:30AM on Wednesday, April 28, 1999. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Manomet Center for Conservation Sciences, Manomet, MA or Science Center of New Hampshire, Holderness, NH.

title: Waltzing Digitally and Interactively at a Columbia Festival
description: What would the best audience have been for the program of digitally enhanced or generated music and dance presented on Wednesday night at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio? Ideally that audience would be engineers with vast computer experience who had once been composers or choreographers.

description: KESSLER-Rabbi Martin. Age 101. We record with sorrow the passing of our oldest member. Ordained in Hungary, he served as rabbi in Oak Ridge, TN. A metallurgical engineer by training, he resumed his scientific career in 1957 in the Boston area. In his later years, he was renowned for his wood and metal sculptures. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Rachel, his children Anne and Jack and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Seymour L. Essrog, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Chips Off the Old Block, and Stump
description: Skimming the headlines last month, more than a few Rhode Islanders must have felt a tug of confusion. One day, the big news was that ''Chafee'' would retire from the United States Senate. The very next day, the story was that ''Chafee'' would run for the seat.

title: Jerold Hoffberger, 80, Owner of Series-Winning Orioles, Dies
description: Jerold C. Hoffberger, who owned the Baltimore Orioles when they won five American League pennants and two World Series titles in the 1960's and 1970's, died last Friday at Sinai Hospital in Baltimore after collapsing during a business meeting. He had celebrated his 80th birthday two days earlier.

title: W.N.B.A. Players Get A Female Negotiator
description: When officials of the Women's National Basketball Association resumed talks yesterday with the players union, they found a new player at the bargaining table: Pamela M. Wheeler, a 31-year-old lawyer who arrived on the scene Sunday from the Continental Basketball Association.

Condolences can be sent to 2727 South Ocean Blvd., Highland Beach, FL.

title: Avoiding Confusion on Serving Size Is Key to Food Pyramid
description: Many Americans, upon seeing the number of servings of foods that the Food Guide Pyramid suggests should be consumed each day, say, ''Impossible!'' Among typical responses to these recommendations from the United States Departments of Agriculture and Health and Human Services: ''If I ate that much, I'd turn into a blimp'' and ''I can't possibly fit in all those grains and vegetables in the course of a normal day.''

title: 3 Newspaper Concerns Post Profits Above Expectations
description: The Gannett Company and two other newspaper publishers, Dow Jones & Company and E. W. Scripps & Company, reaped better-than-expected first-quarter profits as advertising revenue grew robustly and newsprint prices fell, the companies said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: WHITTAM-James H., Ph.D.. Dr. Whittam, President and CEO of the San Francisco based Shaklee Companies, died April 15, 1999, at Stanford University Hospital after a long and heroic battle with cancer. He was 49. Both a scientist and business leader, Dr. Whittam played key roles in the operations of the domestic and international Shaklee marketing operations as well as science and technology functions. Dr. Whittam spearheaded the establishment of Yamanouchi Shaklee Pharma (YSPharma, Inc) in 1997. Located at Stanford Research Park, YSPharma, Inc. is dedicated to the development of novel drug delivery technologies, representing the pharmaceutical division of Shaklee Corporation. His professional experience also included top management research and development positions at Proctor & Gamble, Vidal Sassoon and The Gillette Company. Successfully operating in the academic, scientific and business worlds, he was unique in the industry as the only scientist to head a major direct selling company. ''Dr. Whittam will be remembered as an outstanding executive, an accomplished scientist and, above all, a caring person,'' commented Dr. Earl Cheit, Chairman of the Board of Shaklee Corporation and Dean Emeritus of Haas Business School at the University of California, Berkeley. Born in Queens, New York in 1949, Whittam was graduated magna cum laude from New York City College in 1972 with a bachelor's degree in chemical engineering. He taught chemistry at City Univeristy of New York (CUNY) while earning his Ph.D. there in chemistry and biochemistry in 1975. CUNY honored Dr. Whittam with the Curtman and Myron Pantzer Awards. He then went on to complete an MBA degree from Boston University School of Management in 1977. A Bay Area resident for over 20 years, Dr. Whittam served on various community boards, including UCSF Foundation's Science Committee. He is a member of numerous professional and scientific organizations and has published extensively in scientific and trade journals. An avid runner and athlete, Dr. Whittam competed in both the Boston and New York marathons as well as numerous local races. He served as a member of the U.S. Ski Team Sports Medicine Council and as nutritional consultant to the U.S. Ski Team for eight years. Along with William L. Haskell, Ph.D. of Stanford University and the American College of Sports Medicine, he initiated one of the first academic conferences on ''Nutritional Determinants in Athletic Performance.'' Dr. Whittam is survived by his wife Sibylle, daughter Lauren, and sons Christopher and Alexandre, of Hillsborough, CA, as well as his mother, Barbara Whittam, sisters Denise Whittam and Barbara Schechter, and brother Dennis Whittam, all from the New York area. The family asked that contributions in his memory be made to the James H. Whittam Charitable Fund care of Peninsula Community Foundation, 1700 South El Camino Real, Suite 300, San Mateo, California 94402.

title: Adidas-Salomon Warns Of Drop in Profits
description: The German sporting-goods maker Adidas-Salomon A.G. warned yesterday that its pretax income would come in 35 percent to 40 percent below results a year earlier in the first quarter, because of deteriorating sales at its Taylor Made Golf Company unit. The company, the world's second-largest manufacturer of sports equipment, said first-quarter sales were flat, at 2.7 billion marks ($1.50 billion).

title: Electronics Boutique In Bid for a Rival
description: Electronics Boutique P.L.C., a British-based video game and software retailer, said yesterday that it had offered to acquire Game P.L.C., a rival retailer of electronic games in Britain, for $:99.2 million, or about $160 million. The offer values Game at 134.3 pence, an 11 percent premium above Game's closing share price Friday. The offer consists of 41.1 pence in cash and 1.0994 new shares of Electronics Boutique.

title: A $3,000 'Fire Extinguisher' To Put Out Heart Attacks

A previously healthy 62-year-old jogger and public health officer in Boston, Mr. Tighe stopped breathing and had no pulse or blood pressure. His heart was beating chaotically, unable to send blood to his brain or other vital organs.

title: Do-It-Yourself Term Limits
description: Representatives George Nethercutt, a conservative Republican from Washington, and Martin Meehan, a liberal Democrat from Massachusetts, share a peculiar problem. They first ran for office promising self-imposed term limits. Now they have come to the point when they vowed they would quit. Both are wondering if their constituents would object to a self-imposed reprieve.

title: Just Bus Riders, Caught Up in Shuttle Diplomacy
description: The buses, like this shiny white one, run back and forth between New Delhi, India, and Lahore, Pakistan, four days a week now, each a fragile thread suturing the wound inflicted 51 years ago when these two nations were hacked from Britain's Indian empire at independence.

title: More Reports of Villages Near Border Being Emptied
description: Two hundred more Albanian refugees from Kosovo crossed into Macedonia today, bringing with them fresh accounts of an apparent Serbian effort to force Albanians out of an area near Kosovo's border with Macedonia.

title: Technology Shares Aside, Stocks Rally
