title: Albanian Kosovar Leader Forced to Collaborate With Serbs, German Report Says
description: What happened to Ibrahim Rugova, the leading ethnic Albanian advocate of nonviolence in Kosovo, during the Serbian offensive against ethnic Albanian civilians there has preoccupied NATO since the allied bombing campaign against the Serbs began on March 24.

title: Yeltsin's Opposition Delays Impeachment Vote
description: Russian parliamentary leaders voted today to delay indefinitely a planned vote on the impeachment of President Boris N. Yeltsin, stepping back from another showdown between the Kremlin and the Parliament.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: HOWELL-William B. Of Southampton, NY and Houston, TX, died Sunday, April 11, 1999. He was born at Chemung, NY on March 7, 1909. He began his coal career in 1934 with the Consolidation Coal Co. at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, New York City. After retiring from the U.S. Navy as a Lt. Commander in 1946, he joined the Berwind White Coal Mining Co. and became Vice President of Foreign Sales. In 1962 he was appointed President of the Pittston Co's Export Coal Companies and retired in 1966. He was Class of 1930 at Hobart College and Class of 1935 at the United States Military Academy, West Point. He was a co-founder and the first President of ''The Howell Family Association'' and was an eleventh generation descendant of Edward Howell, who headed the group from Lynn, MA that founded ''The Village of Southampton'' in 1640. He was a member of the Metropolitan Club and the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club. He was previously married to Mary Edington of Penn Yan, NY and Edna Finney of New York City. He is survived by his wife Eleanor Mott Howell and three grandchildren, Allison & Andy Peara, Sarah and Thomas Nesbit, and Kevin Cantril; great grandchildren, Madeleine, Emma, and Leland; a sister, Eleanor Howell Rossiter of Bedminster, N.J. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Church, Southampton, New York at a later date. In lieu of flowers a contribution to the charity of your choice is suggested.

title: Restraint, Passion and Politesse to the Rescue of Minimized Mozart

The order is valued at more than $340 million and was awarded by the state-owned China Power Grid Development Company.

It looked as if a cosmic skywriter had left a fat, upside-down comma hanging out there in the direction of the constellation Sagittarius.

title: Sorting Out Identities, From Sexuality to Stardom
description: On the surface Imperial Teen's songs are amiable pop-tinged rock with fond memories of new-wave rock from the Cars to the Cure to the Pixies. Roddy Bottum and Will Schwartz strum guitar chords and trade off modest lead vocals; Jone Stebbins on bass and Lynn Perko on drums knock out succinct rhythms and sing airy harmonies. But serious discontents and snowballing noise wait just under that surface, and they came rushing out when the band played at the Knitting Factory on Thursday night.

title: Giuliani Takes New Step Toward Race for Senate
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani set up a committee yesterday to finance a possible run for the Senate next year, as aides to Hillary Rodham Clinton, also a potential candidate for the seat, announced that she would spend three days traveling New York next week.

title: Corrections
description: An essay in Science Times on March 30 about evolutionary psychology misstated the affiliation of Dr. David Buss, a leading researcher in the field. He is at the University of Texas at Austin, not the University of Michigan.

title: IXC IN $178 MILLION SWAP PACT WITH ELECTRIC LIGHTWAVE
description: IXC Communications Inc. and Electric Lightwave Inc. will swap part of each other's fiber optic networks under a $178 million deal announced yesterday. IXC, a voice, data and Internet carrier in Austin, Tex., has a coast-to-coast network. Electric Lightwave, in Vancouver, Wash., is building a network from Salt Lake City to Denver and Denver to Dallas, offering local phone, long distance, Internet access and data, video and network access to regional businesses. Their 20-year deal covers dark fiber, the unused line that is a result of overbuilt internal networks. IXC will get Electric Lightwave's dark fiber for Seattle-Portland, Portland-San Francisco and Seattle-Spokane for $77 million. Electric Lightwave will get IXC's dark fiber for $101 million.

title: Potvin Too Tough for Devils' Best Shots
description: The Devils set a franchise record tonight for most shots in a game with 57, but Felix Potvin of the Islanders tied the team's franchise record for saves, turning aside 55 attempts as the usually hapless Islanders gained a 4-2 victory at Continental Arena.

title: A Cheeky Sense of Humor, In the Music Hall Tradition
description: The English actress and singer Imelda Staunton certainly deserves points for pluck. In her American cabaret debut at the Firebird Cafe, Ms. Staunton, who plays Gwyneth Paltrow's nurse in ''Shakespeare in Love,'' mixed songs from classic American soul (''Do Right Woman'') to Irish ballads (''Danny Boy'') to Noel Coward (''If Love Were All'') into a bubbling musical potpourri.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Diamonds in the Cold; New Canadian Mine Seeks Its Place in a DeBeers World
description: To dig rough diamonds out of the Canadian tundra, operators of the first major diamond mine in North America face some of the most hostile conditions on earth -- blinding snow, bitter temperatures and a desolation so complete that for all but two months of the year, when roads cross frozen lakes, no truck can get within 150 miles of the mine.

title: Federal Jury Acquits McDougal On One Charge and Is Split on 2
description: A Federal jury today acquitted Susan H. McDougal of obstructing justice when she refused to testify before a grand jury about the Arkansas financial dealings of President Clinton and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton. But the jury, in its third day of deliberations, deadlocked on two counts of criminal contempt, and the judge, George Howard Jr., declared a mistrial on those charges.

title: A Crucial Debate on Kosovo
description: As the air war over Yugoslavia heads toward its fourth week, pressure is building on President Clinton to send ground forces into battle. Senator John McCain and other critics of the NATO campaign are right to open a national debate about military and diplomatic options, and the planning for all contingencies should begin. But there should be no illusions about the difficulties and potential costs of a land war. A great deal more bombing and diplomacy should be employed before Mr. Clinton and the nation make any fateful decisions about the use of ground troops.

title: Pentagon Plans to Add 300 Planes to Battle Yugoslavia
description: The Pentagon plans to approve the deployment of 300 additional warplanes in the fight against Yugoslavia, deepening American involvement so significantly that President Clinton will almost certainly have to call up reserves for the first time, senior officials said today.

title: Pataki Rejects Whitman's $120 Million Deal to Keep Shipping Lines

Christine Todd Whitman agreed yesterday to provide about $120 million in state funds to keep two of the largest shipping lines in New York Harbor from moving to Baltimore, but just a few hours later Gov. George E. Pataki rejected the deal.

title: Justo Rodriguez Santos, 83, Cuban Poet in Self-Imposed Exile
description: Justo Rodriguez Santos, a Cuban poet who became disenchanted with Fidel Castro in the 1960's, exiled himself from his native land and became an advertising executive in the United States, died on Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Recognition at Last for a Poet of Elegant Complexity
description: She is 77. She has raised seven children, mostly on her own. She has published only four books of poetry in a lifetime. But last month Marie Ponsot won one of the nation's most prestigious literary prizes, the National Book Critics Circle Award, for her latest collection, ''The Bird Catcher.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: HOFFBERGER-Jerold C. The Board of Governors, Executive and staff of The Jewish Agency for Israel (JAFI) mourn the loss of our Past Chairman, Jerold C. Hoffberger. His career as a leader of the Jewish Agency was devoted to rescuing and bringing to the Jewish Homeland thousands of Jews from countries of distress, and to building bridges between American Jews and Israel. As Chairman of our Board of Governors between 1983 and 1987, he was instrumental in the success of Operation Moses which rescued, brought to Israel and provided new lives to seven thousand Ethiopian Jews. May his memory be for a blessing. Charles H. Goodman, Chairman, JAFI Board of Governors Sallai Meridor, Acting Chairman, Jewish Agency Executive

title: China's Exports Fall 7.9%, Though Those to U.S. Grow
description: China's exports fell 7.9 percent in the first quarter, the Government said today in a report that illustrated a weakness in one of the most important growth engines in the Chinese economy. Sharp declines in exports to Europe more than offset increased exports to the United States.

title: Nazareth Journal; God's Half Acre, but Whose God? A Town Is Torn
description: In modern history, this sleepy Israeli Arab town, the traditional childhood home of Jesus, has been a stranger to the tensions roiling the Mideast. Christian and Muslim Arabs lived together here in harmony. Together they depended on the Christian pilgrims who sustained their feeble tourist economy, and together they took pride in their sweets, exported as delicacies throughout the Arab world.

title: Lawmakers Tell Clinton To Clarify U.S. Mission
description: On their first day back after a two-week recess, Congressional leaders told President Clinton tonight that they were prepared to hold off floor votes on the American involvement in Yugoslavia but that he must make a better case, to them and to the public, particularly if the United States decides it is necessary to send ground forces to the Balkans.

title: New Recruits in the War    on Sprawl
description: Talk to John Williams for five minutes, and he will begin preaching to you about the importance of sidewalks. ''We have to interconnect people again,'' he says. ''We have to go back and re-create the neighborhood, all the things that humans feel comfortable in. We can't keep putting shopping centers in the middle of cornfields. We need sidewalks, and we need to get people out on those sidewalks.''

title: Some S.& L. Shares Fall on Court Ruling
description: Shares of the Golden State Bancorp fell today, as did other securities tied to lawsuits by other savings and loan associations against the Government, after a judge awarded Golden State, the nation's second-largest savings unit, less than expected for a broken promise of special regulatory treatment.

title: Mayor Defends Safir on Wedding Security
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani found himself defending Police Commissioner Howard Safir once again yesterday, acknowledging that the Commissioner had used eight on-duty detectives to provide security at his daughter's wedding but calling it ''perfectly appropriate.''

title: Broadcast.com Loss Less Than Expected
description: Broadcast.com, a provider of multimedia events over the Internet, said today that its first-quarter loss was less than expected, as more companies used its service for events like conference calls.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; At G.M., Speculation on Chairman's Successor
description: Harry J. Pearce, the vice chairman of the General Motors Corporation, has largely recovered from leukemia and is again a leading candidate to succeed John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, who turned 61 last Tuesday, auto industry executives said.

title: In New Role, Venezuela Army Runs Clinics and Shops
description: After decades in the background, the Venezuelan military has begun playing a more active and prominent role under a new President who is himself a former army colonel and paratrooper. But it nevertheless came as a shock to Judith Gonzalez to find soldiers selling meat and cheese out of the back of a truck at a weekend market in her working-class neighborhood here.

title: Like Elgin Baylor? Artest Has a Shot
description: He is full of youthful bravado and more than the occasional bout of bluster, but on one January day Ron Artest sounded like a self-aware adult. He said he was ready to learn the game at a higher level in the National Basketball Association.

title: Police Defend Their Inquiry Into Clinic Doctor's Slaying
description: Responding to questions about why it took almost six months to find a rifle that may have been used to kill a Buffalo-area doctor who performed abortions, law enforcement officials defended the thoroughness of their investigation yesterday and said metal detectors had been used soon after the killing to scan the area around the doctor's home, though with no success.

title: Closed Review Started By Starwood Hotels
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide in White Plains said yesterday that it was beginning a closed review for three assignments now handled by Ogilvy & Mather New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group P.L.C. Billings were estimated at $65 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: LAWLER-Richard F. Age 82, of Woodbridge, CT. Husband of Priscilla Lenihan Lawler. Father of Richard F., Gregory E., Paul J., Peter C., Quentin J. and Alexander J. Lawler. Also survived by a brother, a sister and 12 grandchildren. He was an executive with Uniroyal for 35 years, prior to retirement in 1980, and served with the US Navy in the South Pacific in WW II, earning the Purple Heart. Graduate of Boston University and Harvard Business School. Coached swimming at Notre Dame H.S. of West Haven for 12 years, winning two New England titles and six state championships. Honored as a Notre Dame Knight of Honor in 1990. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10 AM, in Assumption Church, 75 Center Road, Woodbridge, CT, followed by private interment in Calvary Cemetery, Boston, MA.

title: Apathy Is No Longer the Rage on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: PERLMUTTER - Hannah. On Monday, April 12. Beloved wife of the late Julius Jay. Loving mother of Regina and Joel and the late Lawrence Porter. Dear sister to Bob and Etty. Devoted grandmother to Marjorie and Jimmy, Chip and Candace, and Carolyn. Adoring great grandmother to Joey, Carly, Jake, Samantha, Scott, Nicole, and Caitlin. Devoted friend, a kind and dignified lady, and always there to listen. We will miss you.

title: An Enzyme to Challenge Rogue Colors in the Washer
description: Joel Cherry is a scientist, but he is a bit of a drill sergeant as well. In the boot camp that is his laboratory, he has been whipping an enzyme into shape, preparing it for the rigors of that domestic battlefield known as the washing machine.

title: Treasuries' Prices Rise, Aided By Purchases Made by Fed
description: Treasury bond prices rose on optimism that Government reports expected today will show subdued inflation, and after the Federal Reserve bought Treasuries.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: MAYER-Elizabeth Hamburger. Daughter of Florence M. and Leon L. Hamburger, beloved aunt of Mary Hamburger O'Neil of Easton, CT, Lois Mann Hamburger of Bridgeport, CT, died on March 24, 1999. She is also survived by four grandnieces and three grandnephews. Mrs. Mayer was predeceased by her beloved husband Frederick T. Mayer, her brother Lewis Hamburger of CT, her sister Margaret H. Stern of Michigan. She will be sadly missed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: POTOR-Aurelia, M.D. On February 22, 1999. Sister of George Jr. and the late Valentina Potor Barnes. Known for her diagnoses & beloved by her patients, a lover of travel and of the performing arts. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, May 4, at 5 PM at New York Hospital/Cornell Medical College in Uris Auditorium.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: GENTILE-Stella. On April 11, 1999. Dear friend of Jerrold Morgulas. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street, NYC, Thursday, 2-5, 7-9. Funeral on Friday, at 10 AM.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: CHANDROSS-Mollie (nee Bobrick). On Tuesday, April 13, 1999, of Elizabeth, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Samuel J. Chandross, loving mother of Edwin, David and Robert Chandross, cherished grandmother of five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Funeral services were conducted on Thursday, April 15, 1999. For more information contact Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: RIND-Beatrice. At home on April 5, 1999 at age 87. Beloved mother of Joyce and David Rind. Sister of Leonard Reider and Dr. Augusta Goldin. Services were private.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: CARTER-Barbara Porter. On April 10, 1999. Beloved mother of Barbara Brush Wright and grandmother of Christina Pinkham Wright. A memorial service will be held Friday, April 23rd, 3:30PM at Second Presbyterian Church, 6 W. 96 Street, NYC. Memorial gifts may be made to either the Humane Society of N.Y., 360 E. 59 St, NY NY 10022, or the Lighthouse, 111 East 59 Street, NY, NY 10022

title: When it Comes to Williams, Teams Are Missing the Point
description: There was a time when all that mattered about Texas running back Ricky Williams was his performance on the field. Then came the hair issue. Some teams did not like his braids. Then there was the agent issue. Some teams thought his manager, the rapper Master P, would be a hindrance in contract negotiations. Then the weight issue. He was supposedly 20 pounds too heavy.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: SOLOWAY-Reta Burns., 89. Formerly of Franklin Square, LI. Passed away peacefully on April 9, 1999. Well known artist and past President of Allied Artist of America, Inc., member of Catherine Lorillard Wolfe Art Club, National Arts Club, Pen & Brush Club and listed in Who's Who in American Art. Her works are owned by The Gregory Museum and National Arts Club as well as banks, schools and private collections. Beloved wife of the late Dr. David Soloway, devoted mother of Roger, Linda Martinez, Martha Zarkowsky, Michael, and seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in her memory to: Allied Artists of America, Inc., 10 Harvale Dr, Florham Park, NJ 07932 or The Parkinson's Foundation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: BLUMENSTYK-Victor, age 75, of Tamarac, FL, formerly of Fair Lawn, NJ. Retired President of H and D Sportswear. Beloved father, grandfather and brother.

title: Judge Disallows Seizure of Illegal Gun
description: Amid a public debate over the tactics of New York City police officers, a Federal judge in Manhattan has ruled that the police violated the rights of a man who was stopped, searched and arrested in 1997 for carrying an illegal handgun and fake immigration papers.

title: Caucasus and Central Asia Look to Pipeline Opening Saturday to Cut Reliance on Russia
description: The new nations of the Caucasus and Central Asia will take a giant step away from their former masters in Moscow this weekend.

title: The Pulitzer Prizes
description: ARTS

title: Man Arrested As Glass Pane Falls 28 Stories
description: The window, a four-by-six-foot sheet of glass weighing 100 pounds, was supposed to be held in place with 43 brackets. Juan Battista, the construction worker who installed it, used only 3, the police said.

title: In Kosovo, Time For All to Save Face; Aid Groups Do Best
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: HOWARD-Louleila Katherine. On April 11, 1999 at the age of 92. Beloved daughter of the late Dr. James A. and Blanche Morris Howard. Survived by her brothers W. E. Howard and Harold Howard. Miss Howard was a teacher with the Edgewater Public Schools and worked with developmentally disabled children. Interment private.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: PIERCE-Robert, age 84. Author & illustrator of more than twenty children's books and a former Art Director of Sesame Street Magazine and Sesame Street Records, died Sunday at his home in Essex, CT. Mr. Pierce was a graduate of the University of Nebraska and The Cooper Union Institute. As a fighter pilot in World War II, he served with distinction in the Southwest Pacific. He operated a successful design studio in Dallas after the war, returning to New York in 1963. Survived by his wife, Carole, three children and six grandchildren.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: BERKELHAMMER - Allen. On April 12, 1999. Cherished son of Phyllis. Loving brother of Wendy Grammas. Services Wednesday, 1PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A 'Flow' to Fuel the Reluctant Athlete
description: For 28 years Bill Gaston, 41, has been running, and for 28 years he has veered in and out of the ''zone,'' a state of heightened attention in which exercise seems effortless and time passes easily. During one recent 3,000-meter race, Mr. Gaston, a long and lean magazine editor, re-entered that familiar territory: ''I grew strong. I got a beautiful feeling of being in gear. I was concentrating so much I felt like I was floating.'' Sighing, he added, ''You live for these kinds of experiences.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: BERKOWITZ-Michael A. On Appril 18, 1999, at age 37, peacefully in his sleep at home surrounded by his family. Beloved soulmate of Lisa and father of Alana Peri. Son of Seymour and Lorraine, son-inlaw to Harold and Libby Grill. Brother to Lynn and Brad, Joanne and Ted, Ricki and David. Loving uncle to Sara, Greg, Sam, Sam, and Jake. Friend to many. Mike was a respected member of the Bankruptcy Bar in New York where he practiced at Thacher Proffitt and Wood. He was an active supporter of many charities and very involved in community affairs. He was admired by many and will be missed by all. Kindly make donations to Michael Berkowitz Lung Cancer Research Fund, c/o Beth Israel Medical Center; contact Michelle Geller at 212387-6800.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: DEL CIELLO-Angelo. April 15, 1999, formerly of Queens, NY. Interior designer and partner in Druss-Del Ciello for 35 years. Survived by his four children, brother, step-sister, eleven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Funeral mass Tuesday, 11AM St. John Bosco Church, 235 E. County Line Road, Hatboro, PA. where friends may call after 10AM. Interment St. John Neumann Cemetery, Chalfont, PA. Memorials to Special Olympics of PA, Chester County, PO Box 1061, Exton, PA. 19341, Attn: Ruth McGuire

title: Better Than the Best? Yanks' Season to Tell
description: The 1999 Yankees could be better than the 1998 Yankees, who won 125 games and have ''Best Ever'' inscribed on their World Series rings. Do not flip the page with derision at this suggestion. Do not scoff at this possibility. Do not speculate that it is a belated April Fool's joke. It is not.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: WYNNYK-John (a.k.a. Iwan). Beloved husband of Sophie. Devoted father of Lida and Andrew. Loving father-in-law of Christina Kusznir. Reposing Peter Jarema Funeral Home Inc., 129 East 7th St., NYC, Monday, 2 PM-9 PM. Services Monday, 7:30 PM. Funeral Mass Saint George Ukrainian Catholic Church, Tuesday, 9:30 AM. Interment Holy Spirit Ukrainian Catholic Cemetery, Hamptonburgh, NY.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: MESTEL-Jean. The Board of Trustees, the Administration and the Medical Staff of The Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center express great sorrow on the passing of Jean Mestel, beloved mother of A. Lawrence Mestel, M.D., our esteemed Emeritus Physician In Charge of Pediatric Surgery and member of the Board of Trustees. We extend our profound and heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May memories of this wonderful woman help ease their grief. Edwin L. Schulman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Frank J. Maddalena, President and CEO Sheldon S. Berman, MD, Senior Vice President and Chief Medical Officer

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: MASON-Eugene W., Jr. Age 80. Of Peapack, NJ, on Tuesday, April 13. Husband of Mary Young Mason. Father of Mary M. Johnson and Eugene Mason IV, both of New York City. Brother of Elizabeth Mason Walbridge and grandfather of Christina Johnson. Funeral service will be held on Saturday, April 17, at 11 AM, at St. John on the Mtn. Church, Bernardsville, NJ. Memorial gifts may be made to St. John on the Mtn. Church, Mt. Harmony Road, Bernardsville, NJ 07924. For information, call Bailey Funeral Home, Inc., Peapack, NJ.

title: NEWS SUMMARY      INTERNATIONAL    SQN#
description: LOEB-Helen S.. On April 17, 1999, in her 92nd year. Beloved and devoted wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Maron L. Waxman and Roberta L. Guerette. Dear mother-in-law of Nahum J. Waxman and Donald R. Guerette. Much loved grandmother of Nathan L. Guerette, M.D., Marc E. Guerette, Sarah B. Waxman, Joshua J. Waxman and his wife Aimee. Sister of Ray Feinberg. Service Sunday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to American Parkinson's Disease Association, Inc, 1250 Hylan Blvd, Staten Island, NY, or to the Arthritis Foundation.

title: Speaking Out About Kosovo
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Internet Providers' Demands On High-Speed Data Rejected
description: The battle over access to high-speed Internet connections moved today to the Senate Commerce Committee, whose chairman, John McCain, said he would seek a study on how to make the technology more widely available.

title: Top Executive To Change Duties
description: True North Communications in Chicago, in the first big change since David Bell became chairman and chief executive two weeks ago, said yesterday that another top executive, Charles D. Peebler Jr., would relinquish his operational duties as of the annual meeting next month.

title: An Hourlong Attack by Serbs On a Post Inside Albania
description: Serbian troops briefly took over an Albanian border post this afternoon, lobbing mortar shells onto Albanian territory and setting five houses ablaze, international observers and Albanian officials said.

title: Caja Madrid Sells Its Stake in Telefonica
description: Corporacion Caja Madrid, a large Spanish savings bank, said yesterday that it had sold its 3 percent stake in the Spanish telecommunications giant Telefonica S.A. for 1.3 billion euros, or $1.41 billion. Caja Madrid said the sale marked a change in strategy to own stakes greater than 3 percent.

title: COMMANDER SAYS NATO BOMBS HURT ALL SERB FORCES
description: The NATO commander today delivered the first comprehensive assessment of the campaign against Yugoslavia, saying that the allies had damaged every broad sector of the Serbian military. He said, however, that President Slobodan Milosevic appeared determined to ride out the air war and showed no sign of withdrawing from Kosovo.

title: Intel's Results Slightly Beat Expectations
description: The Intel Corporation reported today that first-quarter earnings increased 57 percent, slightly higher than analysts' estimates, with slower sales offset by improved profit margins.

title: Betty's Bay Journal; Poachers Will Rustle Anything, Except Big Game
description: Poachers take their chances when they raid the small but fertile section of coastline that Mike and Linda Tannett watch from the porch of their retirement getaway here.

title: PHILLIPS BUYS STAKES IN NATURAL GAS FIELDS FROM KELLEY
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company agreed yesterday to buy stakes in two natural gas fields from the Kelley Oil and Gas Corporation for $83 million in cash to expand production in northern Louisiana. Phillips, based in Bartlesville, Okla., said it would explore and develop the fields. Two-thirds of Phillips's natural-gas production comes from United States fields, many of them in the Gulf Coast region.

title: The Shrimp and the Lobster Get Competition
description: LIKE many immigrants to the United States, the little crustaceans known as langoustines have been arriving here in greater numbers because of bad times elsewhere in the world.

title: Grasping the Appeal Of the Fascist Mystique
description: THE FASCIST REVOLUTION

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: In Texas, Bush And Giuliani Swap Praise In Tete-a-Tete
description: The Republican Party's most-talked-about potential Presidential contender and its most-talked-about potential candidate for United States Senate met for 90 minutes this afternoon at the Governor's Mansion here.

title: If NATO Wins, What Will It Do?; Korean Parallel
description: To the Editor:

title: Mickens Signs One-Year Contract
description: Ray Mickens, the Jets' No. 3 cornerback who participated in almost half the team's defensive plays last season, signed a one-year contract yesterday for slightly under $1 million.

title: The Twisting Hunt for an Officer's Killer
description: The pursuit of the killer of an Orange, N.J., police officer, a case that at first seemed so linear and logical, has evolved into a perplexing tangle of events that are billowing to transform the matter into something well beyond the death of an officer in a city where police officers do not get killed.

title: Signs of Stability Are Identified in Russia's Economy
description: After months of decline, the Russian economy is beginning to show some stability, according to a monthly report issued today by an independent research organization and the Government.

title: Slaney Suing the I.A.A.F. In Dispute Over a Drug Test
description: The battle between Mary Decker Slaney, the former world champion middle-distance runner, and international sports officials over her testosterone level has extended to two continents, with neither side backing down.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Saturday headed ''Hot and Cold,'' listing stocks with large percentage gains and losses in trading on Friday, misstated the amount of stock the Winfield Capital Corporation, an investment company, bought in Modacad Inc., a software maker that recently began selling apparel on line. It was $516,000, not $11 million.

title: Traditional Business Schools More Open for Gays, Students Say
description: When Evan Bachner attended Columbia Business School 15 years ago, he could always tell who the gay students were.

title: Acquisitions By 2 Companies
description: Two agency companies said yesterday that they would make acquisitions.

title: Malaysia's Ousted Deputy Premier Found Guilty of Corruption
description: Anwar Ibrahim, the ousted Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia, was found guilty today on four counts of corruption in a trial that has set off the greatest political unrest this country has seen in recent years.

title: Hague Panel Builds Case For Indicting Milosevic
description: Prosecutors at the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague have built a strong case to indict President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, diplomats and lawyers close to the tribunal say. But they say the prosecutors are depending on NATO governments for crucial links that they need to bolster their case.

title: One by One by One: Tragic Views From the Lodz Ghetto
description: Can the camera lie? Does it bear false witness? Can its lens simultaneously see and conceal?

title: NATO Warns Belgrade Against Attempting to Expand the War : Albania Accuses Serbia of an Infantry Incursion
description: BRUSSELS  Albania asserted Tuesday that Serbia had sent infantry across the frontier during the day to raid a remote northern border post and village and burn houses after days of shelling there.

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about a recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday by the soprano Kathleen Battle, who sang an aria from the opera, repeated the error.

title: Transit Officials Respond to Complaints of Metrocard Flaws
description: As if to prove that nothing is perfect, New York City Transit's hugely popular Metrocard came under fire yesterday, with members of the City Council and transit advocates pointing to flaws that cause some customers to pay twice for the same ride or to be denied entry to subways and buses.

title: MASCO TO ACQUIRE CARY GROUP, AN INSULATION INSTALLER
description: The Masco Corporation, a household-products maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Cary Group, an insulation-services company. Terms were not disclosed. Masco, based in Taylor, Mich., makes home-improvement and building products and had revenue of $4.34 billion last year. Cary, based in Fair Haven, N.J., specializes in installing fiberglass insulation and has more than 30 branches serving local and national builders.

title: Chief Resigns At Barclays; Bank Cites Poor Health
description: Barclays P.L.C., Britain's second-largest bank, is looking for its fourth chief executive in six months after Michael O'Neill resigned because of ill health, Barclays announced today, touching off speculation that the bank may be vulnerable to a takeover.

title: Costs of Ignoring a Financial Mess
description: More than two decades ago, as the savings and loan crisis was growing, the Federal Government tried to ignore it in the hope that it would somehow go away. One part of that delaying strategy was to sanction an accounting fiction allowing institutions that took over sick thrifts to pretend they now had valuable assets. To do otherwise would have meant closing down thrifts when Congress did not want to appropriate the money needed to pay off depositors.

title: Seagate Reports 3d-Quarter Profit
description: Seagate Technology Inc., the No. 1 independent computer disk-drive maker, reported a third-quarter profit today that beat analysts' forecasts on stronger new product sales.

title: Steroids Found to Strengthen Patients Weakened by Illness
description: Two anabolic steroids, muscle-building male-hormone substitutes, have given renewed strength to patients who had been severely weakened from being on kidney dialysis and to patients who suffered marked weight loss from the AIDS virus, researchers report.

title: Whitman Signs Bills Cutting Property Taxes
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bipartisan package of bills today giving New Jersey residents the first installment of promised property tax relief and giving herself a powerful new talking point in her race for the Senate.

title: Old Movies Everywhere, But Not a One to Watch
description: Along with other customers or prisoners of Cablevision who reside in lower Westchester and have a taste for old movies, I am a member of a deprived class. For amid the dozens of channels that cater to viewers who want to hear about the weather or meet cheery chefs or keep up to the minute on lacrosse or buy something they didn't know they needed from earnest hucksters, there is a gap that strikes at the heart of movie fans: you will not find Turner Classic Movies (TCM) on the menu.

title: In Pettway's Corner, Few Believers
description: When Felix Trinidad defends his International Boxing Federation welterweight title against Vincent Pettway next month, it could be an embarrassing mismatch.

title: James D. McCawley, Linguist Who Stirred a Rift, Dies at 61
description: James D. McCawley, an internationally renowned linguist who sought wherever possible to combine in his work his three consuming passions -- language, music and ethnic food -- died on Saturday after collapsing on the campus of the University of Chicago, where he had taught for more than three decades. He was 61 and lived in Chicago.

title: Yankees' Blueprint Is a Bounce and a Bash
description: Peter Angelos is a high-powered lawyer and the owner of the Baltimore Orioles in his spare time. He says he is convinced that along with being a reasonably talented team, the Yankees are lucky, blessed with the good fortune needed to win the lottery.

title: Enemies Try to Explain
description: At a time when India and Pakistan are worrying the world's diplomats with contradictory signals -- one moment scheduling tit-for-tat nuclear tests, the next having their Prime Ministers embrace at the border -- an unheralded public television program in New York managed to bring the Indian and Pakistani Ambassadors in the United States together last week to be interviewed. It is believed to be the first time officials of the two countries have appeared on one program.

title: 'Saving' Social Security as a Guise to Raise Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Rules on Vehicles and Gas Are Likely to Be Toughened
description: The Clinton Administration is preparing to announce as early as next week that it will require cleaner gasoline and tougher pollution standards for autos, including forcing large sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks to meet the same emission standards as cars, people involved in the issue say.

title: If NATO Wins, What Will It Do?; Guilt All Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Notebook; Teachers Do Well in Study
description: It has been widely reported that high school students who intend to major in education in college earn lower scores on the College Board tests than prospective majors in other fields. But how do actual teachers read and compute compared with other college graduates?

title: Couple Convicted of Conspiring to Steal Wreckage From Flight 800 as Part of Research
description: A Federal jury convicted a Virginia couple today of conspiring to steal evidence from the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 to back up their theory that the jetliner had been hit by an errant Navy missile.

title: The Fudgsicle Refined
description: EVERY restaurant menu has to have at least one chocolate dessert. I offer two: a classic ganache cake and, for those who want a little more fun, a warm, gooey chocolate tart garnished with a fudgy sorbet. At the end of a long meal, I think most people are ready for something fun.

title: ZAPATA PLANS TO SPIN OFF ITS ZAP.COM INTERNET BUSINESS
description: The Zapata Corporation, the fish-meal processor that added an Internet operation to its business, said yesterday that it planned to spin off its Internet unit, the Zap.com Corporation, in a future stock offering. Zapata said it would offer its shareholders the right to buy one Zap.com share for $8 for each Zapata share they hold. Up to 13.612 million shares of Zap.com are eligible for sale if all rights are exercised, making the offering worth $109 million. Zapata will still control Zap.com after the offering because it holds 10,000 preferred shares. Last year Zapata purchased two Internet magazines, Word and Charged, and announced its intention to turn Zap.com into an Internet portal. The main business of Zapata, which is based in Houston, is the production of marine protein for animal feed. Its shares fell $1.6875, to $10.375, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Auto Emission Rules May Be Toughened
description: The Clinton Administration is expected to announce as early as next week requirements for cleaner gasoline and tougher pollution standards for the nation's automobiles. The expected regulations would also force sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks to meet the stricter standards for passenger cars for the first time.

title: Kvaerner to Sell Its Shipyards and Cut About 25,000 Jobs
description: The reorganization of European industry reached into the heartland of Norway today, when the Continent's biggest shipbuilder announced plans to sell all its shipyards and other money-losing businesses.

title: AMERISOURCE GETS CONTRACT TO SUPPLY MORE PHARMACIES
description: The Amerisource Health Corporation, a wholesale pharmaceutical distributor, said yesterday that it had been awarded a $2.25 billion, three-year contract to supply the Pharmacy Provider Services Corporation, a national buying group and regional pharmacy-benefits manager. Under the new contract, Amerisource has the opportunity to expand from serving 300 Pharmacy Provider Services retail pharmacies -- worth $200 million in contracts annually -- to serving 1,200 pharmacies. Shares of Amerisource, based in Malvern, Pa., rose 87.5 cents, to $29.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Los Angeles's Chance to Recover Its Fumbles
description: This metropolis unblushingly bills itself as the entertainment capital of the world, and from Hollywood studios to thrill-ride theme parks, oxygen bars and big Pacific rollers, it can back up the boast. But when it comes to professional football, the most popular sport in the country, Los Angeles has been stuck in its own end zone.

title: Sinn Fein Rejects a Proposal to End the Impasse Over Disarmament
description: The political wing of the Irish Republican Army said today at peace talks in Belfast that it rejected a proposal by the British and Irish Governments to resolve the impasse on guerrilla disarmament that is blocking the formation of a new Northern Ireland Government.

title: Tales From Kosovo Villages: Thousands Expelled by Serbs
description: In the week since President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia announced that he had halted offensive military operations in Kosovo, Serbian paramilitary groups and Yugoslav soldiers have systematically expelled tens of thousands of Albanians from a swath of southeastern Kosovo, according to refugees arriving here today.

title: Push to Turn Diallo Rally Into a Broader Movement
description: Terence Tolbert answered one of the room's eight phones with a one-word salutation: ''Coalition.''

title: Motorola Reports Earnings Rose 20% in First Quarter
description: Motorola Inc., the world's No. 2 maker of cellular telephones, said today that its first-quarter profit rose 20 percent, helped by cost cuts and improved sales of new mobile phones and semiconductors.

title: After Criticisms, Clinton Moves To Restart Talks With Chinese
description: Facing sharp criticism over his failure last week to reach a trade deal with China, President Clinton telephoned China's Prime Minister this afternoon to restart the negotiations in Beijing this month.

title: Dresdner Bank Seeks To Raise $4 Billion
description: Dresdner Bank A.G., Germany's third-biggest bank, said yesterday that it would ask shareholders to approve issuing as much as 3.6 billion euros ($4 billion) in stock to pay for acquisitions over the next five years. Dresdner Bank wants to be able to offer as many as 96.15 million shares, equivalent to about 19 percent of its capital, to pay for acquisitions. That could raise as much as 3.6 billion euros based on yesterday's share price of 37.30 euros.

title: DaimlerChrysler Is Accused Of Anticompetitive Practices
description: The European Union commission is accusing DaimlerChrysler A.G. of using anticompetitive practices, a commission spokesman said today.

title: The President's Words: 'We Must Stay the Course'
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's statement on Kosovo at the White House yesterday and from an exchange with reporters, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: If NATO Wins, What Will It Do?; Serbs' Human Nature
description: To the Editor:

title: Using the Law to Take On Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Vatican Acquires a Large Menorah, and a Dispute
description: Catholic and Jewish leaders today erected a stark reminder of the Holocaust in a garden that belongs to the Vatican: a 4-foot-high bronze menorah specially fitted with six candles to symbolize the six million Jews who were killed by the Nazis.

title: Unarmed Boy Is Fatally Shot By the Police In Hartford
description: An unarmed 14-year-old boy died early today when he was shot in the back by a Hartford police officer who said later that he had believed the youth was reaching for a gun as he ran away, police officials said. Instead, the police said they found a gun-shaped cigarette lighter.

title: Minority Drivers Tell of Troopers' Racial Profiling
description: One by one, they stepped up to the microphones at the New Jersey State House today to testify to a phenomenon that has long been accepted as a sad fact of life among black and Hispanic drivers: the contention that the state police routinely stop motorists for no other reason than the color of their skin.

title: Laporte Backs Out Of Merger Discussions
description: Just a day after confirming it was in takeover talks, Laporte P.L.C. said yesterday that the discussions were off. Shares of Laporte fell 95 pence yesterday, to 667.5, after rising 29 percent on Monday.

title: Notebook; No More Pencils for G.R.E.
description: A healthy supply of sharpened No. 2 pencils is no longer necessary for taking the Graduate Record Examinations. But agility with a mouse is.

title: Shipping Lines Weigh Lease Plan After Whitman Sweetens Offer
description: In a move that gives New York and New Jersey yet another chance to resolve a dispute that has plagued the Port Authority for months, two shipping lines that carry a quarter of the cargo moving through New York Harbor said yesterday that they would consider an offer made on Monday as a final lease proposal before deciding whether to remain or move to Baltimore or Nova Scotia.

title: The Fledglings Rub Minds With Some High Fliers
description: As Ellen Taaffe Zwilich ends her four-year term at Carnegie Hall as resident composer, she can look back on a happy success. Her association was useful publicly in showing the hall's engagement with contemporary music, and no doubt internally, within administrative ranks, as a reminder and a spur.

title: Hemingway Gets a Kick In a Kickoff
description: ''I'm not leaving anything behind,'' the writer Tobias Wolff declared. ''I'm just throwing everything out.''

title: IRON MOUNTAIN BUYS 4 RECORDS-MANAGEMENT COMPANIES
description: Iron Mountain Inc., the world's largest records-management company, has purchased four companies for a total of about $162 million, adding new markets from Maine to Oregon. Iron Mountain, which is based in Boston and stores both paper and electronic documents, said it paid about $46 million in stock and the rest in undisclosed amounts of cash and assumed debt. The largest company purchased was Data Base Inc. of Bellevue, Wash., which Iron Mountain bought for about $115 million and which handles documents in North Carolina, Ohio and Virginia. The others were First American Records Management Inc. of San Jose, Calif.; Information Storage Service Center of Albuquerque, N.M., and Confidential Records Center Inc. of Portland, Me.

title: Belgrade Voice Against Misuse Of Patriotism
description: The most liberal member of the Yugoslav Government has sharply attacked the use of Serbian wartime patriotism for ideological and political ends, throwing down an indirect challenge to President Slobodan Milosevic and his nationalist and leftist allies, including Mr. Milosevic's wife.

title: NATO Commander Says Train Was Hit Not Once, but Twice
description: The NATO warplane that destroyed a passenger train crossing a bridge in Yugoslavia spotted the train after it was too late to abort its first attack, but then circled back for a second strike against the bridge, NATO's senior general said today.

title: Using the Law to Take On Guns; An Adult Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Great Watch on the Hudson for Gretzky
description: Late last week, as speculation increased about his possible retirement, Wayne Gretzky said that ''I don't want to be the center of attention,'' and that John Muckler, the Rangers' coach, would be the first to know of Gretzky's decision. As to whether Rangers management would be willing to pick up his $5 million contract option for next season, Gretzky said, ''I don't think either one of us wants to embarrass the other side. So, that's not a factor.''

title: On Home Turf, Artest Says He Will Enter Draft
description: Ron Artest greeted guests yesterday as if he were a mayor at City Hall, signing autographs, posing for pictures with police officers and kissing babies. A dozen reporters and hundreds of his neighbors from the Queensbridge Houses in the Long Island City section of Queens turned out at the Jacob Riis Community Center. Inside the small gym they could see articles chronicling Artest's career and the certificate from the Big East Conference naming him to its all-rookie team last year.

title: Law Firm to Pay Longtime Foe $50 Million
description: Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, a New York law firm that has grown rich by suing corporate America, agreed to pay $50 million yesterday to its longtime foe, Lexecon Inc., a Chicago consulting firm, which had contended in court that the law firm had tried to destroy its reputation.

title: Sunbeam Given Year to Repay $1.7 Billion
description: The Sunbeam Corporation said today that it would have until next year to repay $1.7 billion in credit that was due as of last week.

title: America Online Is Facing Challenge Over Free Labor
description: For the last 10 years, America Online Inc., the nation's largest on-line service, has relied on volunteers to help maintain the virtual community it offers its members. The volunteers, who are known as ''community leaders,'' perform tasks like answering questions from subscribers, supervising chat rooms and enforcing the service's rules.

title: Clinton Lawyers Said to Oppose Appeal of Contempt Citation
description: President Clinton's legal advisers are strongly leaning toward recommending that he not challenge a Federal judge's finding that he was in contempt of court for giving false testimony in the Paula Jones case, a lawyer who has spoken with members of the legal team said tonight.

title: Of the Body and Not: Daydreaming, Dancing and Swimming
description: The Vera of ''Vera's Body'' has died only minutes before the dance begins, presented by Troika Ranch on Saturday night at the Joyce SoHo. She had lived a long and seemingly productive life, shot through with moments -- daydreaming on a hill top, dancing a tango, baking bread and swimming in a warm ocean -- when she became so at one with her body that she lost her sense of body and mind.

title: Call for Cease-Fire Comes After UN Appeal : Indonesia Seeks Panel To Broker Timor Peace
description: SINGAPORE  In a move to prevent violence in East Timor from spiraling out of control, the Indonesian government said Tuesday that it would set up a broadly representative commission to restore peace in the disputed territory.

title: The Egg Returns, Brazenly In the Raw
description: NOTHING unusual about the egg yolk staring up at me from a plate of tagliatelle at Babbo one night last week. Except that the egg was raw. Totally uncooked. Cold. A little disconcerting at first, but once mixed in with the buttery pasta and bacony chunks of cured pork, the egg and the dish warmed up into an irresistible indulgence, with an aftertaste of danger.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: If NATO Wins, What Will It Do?; The West Pushes East
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Saving' Social Security as a Guise to Raise Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: With the Congress Divided, Leaders Shun an Early Vote
description: With some members of Congress pushing for ground troops in the Balkans and others adamantly opposed to such a deployment, Congressional leaders worked today to head off any vote this week that would showcase the divisions and undercut the bombing campaign.

title: Tipping the State
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the arraignment of a suspect in the killing of an Orange, N.J., police officer misstated as unbruised the condition of the man's face during his court appearance. In fact, the suspect had a black left eye and an abrasion on his left cheek, injuries that his lawyer said he suffered after being arrested. (A reporter in the courtroom did not observe the injuries because he could see only part of the suspect's face, but the bruises were visible in a photograph taken in court that accompanied the article.) The article also misspelled the suspect's surname. He is Terrance Everett, not Everrett.

title: Hambrecht & Quist Will Advise Inprise
description: The Inprise Corporation, a maker of corporate software formerly known as Borland International, said today that it had hired the investment bank Hambrecht & Quist to help it evaluate strategic alternatives, including splitting into two separate companies.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Day Traders Are Formidable Market Force
description: Having evolved from a nation of savers to one of investors, America is rapidly becoming a country of traders.

title: 'Another World' Leaves Orbit
description: When NBC decided to cancel its soap opera ''Another World'' this week, some heavy considerations came into play.

title: Police Charge El-Amin With Drug Possession
description: Khalid El-Amin, the star point guard who helped lead the University of Connecticut to the national basketball championship, was charged with possessing marijuana tonight after the police here had stopped him on suspicion of running a red light.

title: Boxcar Willie, Country Music's 'Hobo,' 67
description: Boxcar Willie, a country singer and songwriter who fashioned himself as a hobo, died on Monday at his home in Branson, Mo. He was 67.

title: Belle Is the Only One To Make Orioles Smile
description: They stood at the batting cage in Estadio Latinoamericano, laughing. Albert Belle, whose menacing stare is legendary, was laughing.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Monday about a performance of Handel's ''Giulio Cesare'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday characterized the production incorrectly. It is a revival, not a new staging.

title: Frame-by-Frame Briefing: Arson by Serbs and 'Collateral Damage' by NATO
description: Following are excerpts from a briefing today by Gen. Wesley K. Clark, the NATO supreme commander, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private company:

title: Jeter, The Most Valuable Yankee
description: There is a confidence about Derek Jeter that is evident every time he strides onto the baseball field. Watch him move toward the plate lugging the bat like a shovel, watch him glide to his left to snare a grounder effortlessly and watch him scoot around the bases, and his confidence spills forth. Jeter is totally composed.

title: INSIDE
description: Malaysian Leader Convicted

title: Misinformation From H.M.O.'s
description: Two troubling reports by the Federal General Accounting Office show how difficult it can be for Medicare beneficiaries to get accurate information about their health coverage from their managed-care plans. These plans now provide health care to about 7 million out of 39 million Medicare recipients, a figure that has doubled in the past three years. Yet a check of 16 managed-care organizations found that all of them provided enrollees with either inaccurate or misleading information.

title: At The Daily News, Changes for the Better; Readers Turn to Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Broken Hill Sells Assets to Phillips
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company, the seventh-largest United States oil company, said today that it would buy the Australian natural-gas assets of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company as it positions itself to reach more Asian customers.

title: Petty Still Polishing Verities of the 60's
description: Tom Petty writes songs about stubborn folks: taciturn, determined, ordinary people who may get snubbed or pushed around, but who won't back down. He's mighty stubborn himself. Since he arrived in the 1970's, his musical taste has been unswerving.

title: Can This Be Paris?; The French Learn to Speak Fusion
description: THERE is a dessert in Paris called the wonton kumquat Nutella. It cannot be found in Escoffier, or anywhere else, for that matter.

title: Thornton A. Wilson, 78, Ex-Boeing Chairman and Chief Executive
description: Thornton A. Wilson, a former chairman and chief executive of the Boeing Company, died on Saturday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 78.

title: Using the Law to Take On Guns; Concealed Weapons
description: To the Editor:

title: Cisco, Ericsson and Nortel Make Deals to Expand Reach
description: The worlds of cyberspace and traditional telecommunications continued their clash yesterday as the leading maker of data-networking equipment announced a $2 billion acquisition to expand into telephone software while two of the biggest makers of traditional phone systems said they would acquire private data-networking companies.

title: A Cozy French Spot in a Village Square
description: ON a clear day, you can see Columbus Circle,'' Aldo Gharnit said. Mr. Gharnit was standing proudly in the doorway of his handsome new bistro, Le Gans, at the corner of Gansevoort and Greenwich Streets, and looking up Ninth Avenue. Columbus Circle was not quite visible in the distance, but there was enough to see in the neighborhood, a jumble of short streets and low buildings that give it a human scale and spaciousness that's fast disappearing in Greenwich Village.

title: Gores and Clintons Release Figures From Tax Returns
description: Vice President Al Gore and his wife, Tipper, who were criticized for giving only $353 to charity in 1997, sharply increased those donations last year to $15,197, according to tax returns they filed today.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Radio City's No-Show

title: Simms to Miss Governor's Bowl
description: With hopes of reaching the popularity of other interstate high school all-star games, organizers of the second Governor's Bowl, which pits New Jersey's best college-bound players against New York's best, unveiled the rosters yesterday at the Downtown Athletic Club in Manhattan.

title: Passing On The Pain At the Met; As Charitable Funds Drop, Museum Visitors Pay More
description: Visitors to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the past several weeks got a big surprise: The museum raised its suggested admission price to $10, from $8, without telling people until they climbed the granite steps and read signs disclosing the 25 percent increase above the ticket booths inside.

title: Malaysian Troops Set For Verdict on Anwar
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysian police deployed troops and water cannon Tuesday outside the courthouse where Anwar Ibrahim, the dismissed deputy prime minister, will hear the verdict Wednesday in his corruption trial.

title: Dark Night of the Soul Within a Roach Motel
description: Apartment dwellers convinced they know everything there is to know about cockroach extermination might be well advised to study Alex Draper's performance in ''The Pitchfork Disney.'' He plays a recluse by the name of Presley Stray, and in the course of Philip Ridley's creep show of a comedy, Presley is called upon to eat the bugs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 5 about the growing practice of downloading music from the Internet misstated the surname of the chief executive officer of MP3.com, a Web site offering free songs for downloading. He is Michael Robertson, not Robinson.

title: If NATO Wins, What Will It Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Surplus Widens Again in Germany
description: Germany's trade surplus widened in February, for the second consecutive month, indicating that customers abroad are growing more willing to buy German goods and help Europe's largest economy recover. Germany's trade surplus widened to a bigger-than-expected 11.5 billion marks ($6.5 billion) in February from 8.8 billion in January. Exports declined six-tenths of a percent from a year earlier, down from a 5.6 percent drop in January, and imports shrank 1.3 percent.

title: Sports of The Times; For Coaches, Indulgence Is Bad Recipe
description: THE psychiatrist called the hotel room 10 minutes after Larry Brown finished talking about Allen Iverson on sports talk radio yesterday afternoon. He was offering a personality quiz for Brown so he might then determine the best approach to take with his young star.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 'Saving' Social Security as a Guise to Raise Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about high pollen counts in Atlanta misspelled the name of an allergy drug. The drug is Zyrtec, not Zyrtac.

title: Qwest Joint Venture Plans a Stake Sale
description: Royal KPN N.V. and Qwest Communications International Inc. plan to sell shares in a joint venture that provides data services later this year and to sell $800 million in debt to pay for their European network.

title: New U.S. Plan for Wetlands Around City Reservoirs Criticized
description: Federal officials, stung by recent criticisms of their proposal to enact strict new rules protecting wetlands around New York City's reservoirs, unveiled several less stringent options today for preserving marshes and bogs that help filter pollution.

title: Vote by P.B.A. Rebukes Safir And His Policy
description: The union representing New York City police officers cast a vote of no-confidence in Police Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday, questioning many of his actions in recent months and saying that officers are under tremendous pressure to make arrests and issue summonses.

title: China Leader Concentrates On Capitalism In New York
description: Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China swept through New York yesterday, shunning all ceremony to focus on the thing that makes his pulse race: capitalism.

title: Police Believe Doctor's Killer Hid Rifle Days Before Shooting
description: Law enforcement officials say they think that the killer of a doctor who performed abortions probably buried the rifle in the ground days before the shooting, unearthed the weapon to fire the fatal shot, then hurriedly reburied it before fleeing.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: A Report on Breast Implants Is Tainted, Plaintiffs Assert
description: Lawyers representing women who contend that their health has been affected by their silicone breast implants sought yesterday to dismiss the report of a panel of scientists who evaluated the issue, saying that one panel member had a conflict of interest.

title: CALENDAR
description: For a Wine Scholarship

title: U.S. and Russians Meet To Try to Ease Tensions
description: The Russian Foreign Minister said today that Moscow remained opposed to an international security force in Kosovo as part of a peace plan without the approval of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.

title: Toyota Picks Aide to Founding Family as President
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation ended months of speculation today about who would succeed Hiroshi Okuda as its president, appointing a close aide of the Japanese auto maker's founding family to replace him.

title: Judge Cites Conflict In City's Aid to Officers
description: Lawyers for the City of New York represented four police officers for months after the Police Department had filed a complaint of excessive force against the officers, a Federal judge in Manhattan said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a meeting of NATO foreign ministers on Kosovo misstated the site of a news conference at which Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations said he was prepared to meet with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia if that would help resolve the conflict. Mr. Annan spoke in Madrid, not at United Nations headquarters in New York.

title: In Paint-by-Numbers Garden, Corn Is Red, Carrots Yellow
description: GARDENERS are always searching for the latest vegetable varieties to brighten the year's crop. Cooks constantly crave the new ingredient that thrills the taste buds while catching the eye. Gardeners who are cooks, and vice versa, are discovering that they can have the best of both worlds with superb-tasting vegetables in startling colors: red sweet corn, yellow carrots, purple asparagus, even black tomatoes.

title: TBWA Executive Moves to Ogilvy
description: Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of WPP Group P.L.C., said yesterday that Paul Simons, a top executive at the British operations of TBWA Worldwide, part of Omnicom Group, would join its British unit, effective on May 4.

title: Democrats Drop Novel Fund-Raising Idea
description: Concerned about perceptions that campaign finance laws could be violated, an adviser to Hillary Rodham Clinton now says it is highly unlikely that Democrats will form a committee to raise money for an unspecified Senate candidate from New York.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economists Starting to See A Payoff From Technology

title: Metro Business; Independence Bank Plans Acquisition
description: Independence Community Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Statewide Financial Corporation of Jersey City for about $102 million in cash and stock.

title: The Police Commissioner's Gaffes
description: For starters, Police Commissioner Howard Safir needs to repay New York City the $3,600 that it cost taxpayers to provide eight on-duty detectives for his daughter's wedding. Then he needs to either explain more fully or apologize for an earlier blunder. That was the charge made in a lawsuit against Monica Nascimento, a citizen, that she was intoxicated when she ran into Mrs. Safir's car. Mr. and Mrs. Safir have already dismissed the lawyer who filed their original lawsuit. The new attorney says the charge is not included in the amended suit because it does not ''comport with reality.''

title: Individual Assessments Ordered for Workfare
description: A state judge has ordered New York City to assess welfare recipients individually before assigning them to workfare jobs.

title: Malaysians Sent Abroad Rankle Mahathir at Home
description: KUALA LUMPUR  It was a February evening in London and several hundred Malaysian students, a long way from home, were packed into a basement meeting hall, listening to a special guest, Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad, talk about how fortunate they were to be studying abroad.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER RISES. Copper prices rose to a three-week high on expectations that a recovery of Asian demand would help erode inventories. Copper for May delivery rose 2.1 cents, or 3.3 percent, to 65.65 cents a pound.

title: A Brisket Fast Enough For Everyday
description: FEW slow-cooked foods are as rewarding as a well-cooked beef brisket. But getting it tender, juicy and flavorful takes so long -- my favorite recipe is a 12-hour job -- that I'm lucky to do it once a year.

title: About New York; Albanians Aim To Refresh Tree of Liberty
description: AN unlighted cigarette dangled from Male Hoti's lips as he inspected a rack of green and brown camouflage fatigues at Frank's Sport Shop in the Bronx. He took a pair of pants, tugged at the waist, then asked the salesman for a smaller size.

title: Military Starts Giving Detailed Data On Bombing
description: After refusing for more than two weeks to share detailed information about the progress of Western air strikes against Yugoslavia, NATO and the Pentagon have begun slowly to open the spigot of information.

title: U.S. Cost of War May Exceed $4 Billion
description: As the air campaign against Yugoslavia continues to widen, the Clinton Administration presented Congress with the bill today: over $4 billion.

title: Sexual Misconduct Grievance Filed
description: Craig Maurizi, who has accused his former coach and colleague, Richard Callaghan, of sexual misconduct, filed a formal grievance yesterday with the United States Figure Skating Association, seeking to revoke Callaghan's membership in the sport's national governing body.

title: Hershiser Trip to Mound a Trip to the Past
description: It has been 11 years since the most memorable season of Orel Hershiser's career.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Lingerie Shower

title: A Balm for Spring Fever
description: THE Union Square Greenmarket shows all the symptoms of serious spring. There's the fellow stripped to the waist sunbathing, and there are the young women in pastel sleeveless shirts eating ice cream as they stroll through on their lunch hour. And especially, there are the riotous spring flowers: magnolias, hyacinths, daffodils and tulips.

title: Who Is the Man With the Golden Arm?; No, Oregon's Smith Is the Pro Passer
description: O.K., so Tim Couch is 6 feet 4 inches and the golden boy. He was the darling quarterback throughout the college football season, and for good reason. Full of range. Throws the short stuff with precision. Smart. An aw-shucks, down-home Kentucky fella. I would draft him No. 1, too, if not for one other quarterback: Akili Smith.

title: Fourth Lynx Dies, and Colorado Scales Back Its Restoration Effort
description: An effort to reintroduce the lynx to Colorado suffered another setback this week after a fourth cat died of starvation.

title: At The Daily News, Changes for the Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Kiwi's Hearing Is Delayed
description: Kiwi International Air Lines must wait another week to make its argument in an administrative hearing that it should be allowed to resume flying.

title: An Office Whose Lure Exceeds Its Powers; With Races 2 Years Away, Borough President Posts Draw Early Contenders
description: In an Indian restaurant in the Glen Oaks section of Queens, Sheldon S. Leffler, a City Councilman, hosted a group of 125 people who paid $100 apiece to dine on a sumptuous buffet of Punjabi cuisine and to assist Mr. Leffler in his political ambition: to succeed Claire Shulman as the Queens borough president.

title: In School; Bucking imposing odds, P.S. 115 turns around from failing statewide tests to winning honors
description: Carmen Serrano, to put it modestly, loves cats.

title: Knicks Put a Clamp on 76ers, but Ewing Is Hobbled
description: They played padlock defense on Allen Iverson, never trailed and resembled a playoff team. But with every sparkling development for the Knicks, there is an expensive toll.

title: A Tenor Whose Style Is Reminiscent of Piaf's
description: In a vocal world overflowing with great sopranos, mezzo-sopranos and baritones, the big question in recent years has been, where are the spectacular young tenors? Ian Bostridge, an Englishman still in his 20's, is clearly one answer.

title: American Diners Stick to American Labels
description: IN a survey 10 years ago, Wine & Spirits magazine discovered that the wine most frequently ordered in well-known American restaurants was chardonnay from Sonoma-Cutrer Vineyards in Sonoma County, Calif. In the magazine's most recent survey, the winner, once again, was Sonoma-Cutrer's chardonnay.

title: Mary Jane Rathbun, 77, Baker Known for Marijuana Brownies
description: Mary Jane Rathbun, who became known as the grandmotherly Brownie Mary who handed out brownies laced with high-grade marijuana to sick people to relieve their pain and nausea, died on Saturday at a hospital in San Francisco. She was 77 and lived in San Francisco.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The dollar rose on concern a skirmish on the Albanian-Yugoslav border could step up the conflict, which has sent investors fleeing to dollars. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0754, down from $1.0820.

title: Can an Essay a Day Keep Asthma or Arthritis at Bay?
description: In a powerful demonstration of how intimately mind and body are linked, researchers have shown that writing about traumatic experiences measurably improves the health of some patients suffering from chronic asthma or rheumatoid arthritis.

title: Who's the Man With a Golden Arm?; Kentucky's Tim Couch Should Be Top Pick
description: There could be at least five quarterbacks picked in the first round of this week's National Football League draft. The player to be chosen at No. 1 depends on which of the 50 million draft analysts, scouts, coaches, personnel men or stat geeks you talk to. The group is cluttered, like a menu at a tourist restaurant on Broadway.

title: Judge Approves Acquisition of Mobilemedia
description: The Mobilemedia Corporation, one of the country's largest paging companies, has won a judge's approval of a bankruptcy reorganization plan calling for the sale of the company to a competitor, Arch Communications Group, for more than $500 million in cash, stock and assumed debt.

title: Pizzas and Salads Warm Up a Midtown Trattoria
description: THE busy block of West 55th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas is home to some of the most elegant, expensive dining rooms in New York, including La Caravelle and La Cote Basque, as well as fast-food joints. Almost absent, though, are restaurants in the middle range, places where shoppers or anyone going to the nearby Museum of Modern Art or Carnegie Hall can enjoy a bite and a glass of wine in attractive surroundings.

title: Liberties; Contempt, She Says
description: As though our President didn't have enough to worry about, with the confusion on Kosovo policy and the collapse of the China World Trade Organization deal, now he must finally face the music on being contumacious about his concupiscence.

title: Starr to Ask Congress to End Law That Gave Him His Job
description: Kenneth W. Starr, who came to embody the independent counsel law as he pursued a variety of allegations about President Clinton for almost five years, now says he believes that the nation would be better off if the law is allowed to expire.

title: Only Indonesia And China Find Reasons to Object : For Asians, Battle for Kosovo Is Distant
description: BANGKOK  About a week into NATO's bombing campaign against Yugoslavia, the United States' recently arrived ambassador to Thailand, Richard Hecklinger, made his first public appearance before a group of journalists. The only question he was required to field about the fighting came from Izvestia's man in Bangkok.

title: Metromedia Fiber to Split
description: Metromedia Fiber Network Inc. said yesterday that it would split its shares 2 for 1. The stock split will double the number of shares to about 153.2 million. The new shares will be issued May 19 to shareholders of record as of May 3. Metromedia, based in New York, operates a fiber optic communications network in the New York metropolitan area. Metromedia's shares soared 14.6 percent yesterday, gaining $9.9375 to close at $77.9375 in Nasdaq trading.

title: A Land Of Reluctant Warriors
description: The debate, in the White House and Congress, about the use of ground troops in Kosovo is becoming more serious. This is happening despite the belief, strongly held in Washington, that recent experience from Lebanon to Somalia has made Americans unwilling to risk the lives of soldiers.

title: Peru Joins the Ninth Ave. Mix
description: SINCE the friendly little RINCONCITO PERUANO opened a year and a half ago in a storefront on Ninth Avenue in Clinton, I've enjoyed the unusual Peruvian cooking but have hesitated to send people there. It's small and not exactly comfortable, and you could probably fly to Peru in the time it takes to get your order. Taking the food home eases those problems, and these dishes travel well.

title: Tipping With Good Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: Low-Tech Serb Tactics Stymie NATO Plan : Escalation of Air War Underscores Its Flaws
description: PARIS  NATO's announcement of major reinforcements, confronting Serbia with a U.S.-led air armada of more than 1,000 warplanes, underscored signs Tuesday that the alliance's initial battle plan had failed to deliver the expected results and needed an urgent escalation in firepower to offer a realistic prospect of military victory in Kosovo.

title: Computer Age Gains Respect of Economists
description: In a nation of technophiles, where Internet millionaires are minted daily, it seems heresy to question the economic payoff from information technology -- the billions upon billions spent each year by companies and households on everything from computers to software to cell phones.

title: A Volkswagen spot has not one, but two punch lines.
description: AN unconventional commercial for the Volkswagen Passat, with a twisty plot that curves more than a rain-slicked highway in a traditional automotive spot, has people talking -- and buying, too.

title: The Photographic Treasures of a Secret Collector
description: Before he died suddenly last year at 81 of a heart attack, David Feigenbaum led the secret life of a collector of Citizen Kane-like obsessiveness. He filled almost every inch of his two-story house in Marblehead, Mass., with things, including books, guns, model boats, Civil War and World War II paraphernalia and an old Scottish Bible collection.

title: Yoko Ono Sues Ex-Aide Over Photographs
description: Frederic Seaman was a close friend of John Lennon, at least according to a television special on the murdered Beatle that was broadcast in February. During the Fox Family Channel program, which featured him as a ''an expert on Lennon's childhood and adult life,'' Mr. Seaman showed off snapshots of Lennon taken in the two years before his murder in December 1980.

title: Youngsters Lend a Sporty Innocence to Ballet
description: Very young dancers bring an extra verve and emotional wholeheartedness to performing that is seldom sustained as they mature and become full-fledged professionals. Those qualities are celebrated in the Kids Dance matinee programs presented by Eliot Feld's Ballet Tech company on Saturdays and Sundays at the Joyce Theater, in a season that ends on May 9. The programs, performed for the most part by children training in the company school, also offer the chance to see interesting new commissions as well as highlights of the senior repertory, danced with a special twist.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Pearson Obtains Right To Rename a Building
description: The illuminated signs atop the 40-story office building on the east side of the Avenue of the Americas between 53d and 54th Streets shine the letters ITT across the New York skyline in four directions. But the signs are out of date.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VALUE ASSET MANAGEMENT INC., Stamford, Conn., a fund management holding company, said it was acquiring 70 percent of Hillview Capital Advisors, a money management firm. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Accounting Dispute Endangers Newbridge Deal for Korea First
description: A financial deal widely interpreted as a sign that South Korea was recovering from its economic malaise is in danger of coming undone.

title: Bell Atlantic Says Network Is Fully Open
description: Continuing its long march toward the $80 billion long-distance market, the Bell Atlantic Corporation, the nation's biggest local telephone company, told New York State regulators yesterday that it had fully opened its network to competition.

title: Dude's MTV Year Is Up, but Not His Fame
