description: SINCE last spring, many things have changed in the life of young Jesse Camp, former East Village street punk, hitchhiker and wannabe rock-and-roll god.

title: Patients Lobby for Cash For Research Into Illness
description: In the official Government record, the hearing that began today in Room 2358 of the Rayburn House Office Building will be listed as ''public witness testimony.'' Unofficially, Room 2358 was long ago called Mother Teresa's Waiting Room, a name that could not be more apt.

title: Chants of Tibetans Follow Chinese Premier on Visit
description: The chanting of the two dozen protesters across the street from the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel could barely be heard over the din of Manhattan traffic yesterday, but they persisted, hoping their message would somehow reach Prime Minister Zhu Rongji as he conducted meetings inside the hotel.

title: Aiming for Greener Pastures; Farm-Equipment Makers Step Up Efforts to Diversify
description: The name John Deere conjures up tractors, farm equipment, big green machines lingering in the distance, on a huge corn field somewhere in the Midwest.

title: Kevorkian Sentenced to 10 to 25 Years in Prison
description: A Michigan judge sentenced Dr. Jack Kevorkian today to 10 to 25 years in prison, despite emotional courtroom pleas on his behalf from the widow and brother of the terminally ill man he was convicted of killing.

title: Photographer Reunites What Has Been Put Asunder
description: It nearly came apart over the red jackets.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You had the audacity to go on national television, show the world what you did and dare the legal system to stop you. Well, sir, consider yourself stopped.''

title: Futility Bowl: Hapless Clippers Stave Off Nets
description: The Nets' blowout loss to the Knicks on Sunday was no aberration. But apparently, their stretch of five victories in six games that preceded it was.

title: Business Travel; Best Western is expanding its share of corporate travelers by aiming at those on a tight budget.
description: PROBABLY few people think of Pokhara, Nepal, and business travel in the same breath. But Best Western recently opened its newest hotel there, the New Hotel Crystal, about 90 miles west of Katmandu. Along with 40 air-conditioned rooms, satellite television and currency exchange facilities, it has a business center with fax, E-mail and copy services.

title: Not a Civil Action
description: In her electrifying announcement that she will punish President Clinton for civil contempt because he gave ''false, misleading and evasive answers'' during the deposition taken by Paula Jones's lawyers, Judge Susan Webber Wright of Federal District Court was right on the facts, but wrong on the law. Indeed, if Mr. Clinton chooses to appeal her ruling, he should win.

title: Treasuries' Prices Fall, With Big Debt Sales Planned
description: Treasury bond prices sagged yesterday under the weight of the large calendar of corporate and agency borrowers planning to sell their debt over the next few days.

title: Verniero Treatment Angers Whitman
description: Incensed by what she called a ''smear campaign'' against her nomination of Attorney General Peter G. Verniero for the Supreme Court, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today attacked members of a New Jersey Bar Association committee that has been conducting a confidential review of his qualifications.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Savvy About Gratuities
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Acts on Complaints Over City's Upstate Men's Shelter
description: Facing heated community complaints about a 1,000-bed homeless shelter that New York City operates in Orange County, the Giuliani administration is stepping up efforts to weed out shelter residents wanted on outstanding criminal warrants and is considering putting a fence around the 365-acre grounds of the shelter, called Camp La Guardia.

title: Can This Be Paris?; Meanwhile, Back in the Bistros, It's Thoroughly Classic
description: FOR generations, bistros have been the culinary soul of Paris, casual neighborhood restaurants where regulars drop in for local gossip and a reassuringly familiar meal. Almost as important as the food is the setting -- usually small, intimate and aglow with stained or painted wood, etched glass and mirrors, bric-a-brac, prints and posters, all against the rippling hum of voices and the tinkle of glass and silver that signify contentment.

title: U.S. CONCERNS TO BUY A CHILEAN ELECTRICITY DISTRIBUTOR
description: Sempra Energy and the Public Service Enterprise Group said yesterday that they had agreed to acquire the Chilean electricity distributor Chilquinta Energia for $830 million. The companies said their international units would buy 90 percent of the shares of Chilquinta Energia from its parent, Chilquinta S.A., and the remaining 10 percent of stock through a subsequent tender offer. Chilquinta is Chile's third-largest distributor of electricity, with 405,000 customers in central Chile. Sempra, based in San Diego, is a utility holding company whose subsidiaries include San Diego Gas and Electric and the Southern California Gas Company. Public Service is based in Newark, and its principal subsidiary is Public Service Electric and Gas.

title: On a Ferry, Kosovo Expatriates Return to Fight the Serbs
description: Fifty men. Each with his own scars, his own past and his own vision of vengeance. They came from half a dozen different countries, in a dozen different ways, but they all ended up on the same high-speed ferry crossing the Adriatic Sea and they all planned to fight for Kosovo, the place where they all were born.

title: Algeria Looks to the Ballot Box
description: Algeria's presidential election tomorrow offers an opportunity to end a seven-year civil war between the army and Islamic guerrillas that has cost more than 80,000 lives. But for that to happen, the ruling generals must permit an honest vote count and allow the winner to govern freely.

title: If NATO Wins, What Will It Do?; Blind to Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD STUFF
description: For Serious Cooks, A Serious New Store

title: SIERRAPINE TO BUY WEYERHAEUSER COMPOSITE BOARD UNIT
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, the nation's third-largest forestry company, agreed yesterday to sell its composite-products business and a ply-veneer plant in Springfield, Ore., to Sierrapine Ltd. for an undisclosed price. It said the division was too small to be competitive. Weyerhaeuser said it would take a one-time first-quarter charge of $60 million, or 30 cents a share, for the sale. The unit, which produces and sells industrial-grade particleboard and medium-density fiberboard, employs 550 people and had about $116 million in 1998 sales. The closely held Sierrapine is based in Sacramento, Calif. Shares of Weyerhaeuser, based in Federal Way, Wash., rose $2.3125, to $64.4375, an all-time closing high, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Principles of Physics: A Real Scream!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Russia Refuses to Extend Deadline on Bonds
description: The Russian Finance Ministry said today that it would not extend its deadline for holders of defaulted Treasury debt to exchange it for new bonds and cash.

title: Filtering the Filters
description: To the Editor:

title: New Kind of Convergence: Writers and Programmers
description: NEARLY everyone at the conference at Brown University here looked the same, with drab shirts and pants, shaggy hair, unfashionably comfortable shoes and the aura of people who spend altogether too much time in front of computer screens.

title: A Closed Review At Microsoft
description: The Microsoft Corporation in Redmond, Wash., is undertaking a closed review for the part of its account that advertises the Windows operating system in the United States, after withdrawing that assignment from Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore. Spending has not been determined pending the formulation of plans to introduce Windows 2000; spending for previous versions ranged from $10 million to $100 million.

title: Technology You Can Dance To
description: At the House of Blues here on Tuesday night, there were all the makings of a good rock concert: excitement, fear, confusion, seduction, revolutionary fervor, cynicism. These emotions were inspired not by music, however, but by music-related technology. The occasion was a high-profile announcement by Microsoft of its entry into the businesses of downloading and streaming -- or listening in real time -- music from the Internet with its Windows Media Technologies 4.0. The excitement wasn't so much over Microsoft's announcement, though it is news that such a major corporation is making digital download software available before the major record labels have even completed their plans for getting into the business. The buzz was over the atmosphere surrounding the conference.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Who's lagging now? So far this year, some very big hedge funds.
description: INVESTORS kicking themselves as their portfolios fall further behind index funds and Internet stocks can take comfort in this: They've got prestigious company.

title: Mandated Mental Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Creative Media Gets Cable Account
description: Discovery Networks U.S., the cable television company, said yesterday that it had awarded its media services account, with billings estimated at $40 million, to Creative Media in New York, a division of Omnicom Group. Those duties had been handled for nine years by DeWitt Media in New York.

title: China Leader Ends U.S. Visit With Trade Talk at M.I.T.
description: Prime Minister Zhu Rongji has a theory about China's trade surplus with the United States, and he went on a shopping spree to prove it.

title: Champ Makes an Overtrick With an Unbelievable Trick
description: Here is a trick question: Is it possible to win a bridge title without leaving your home and without touching a computer? Yes, but it may take a long time. If you enter monthly for the Master Solvers competition, which has been an institution in The Bridge World magazine for more than half a century, you can become a champion at the end of the year.

title: Allied Signal Plans to Sell Car-Care Unit
description: Allied Signal Inc., whose Prestone antifreeze is the top-selling auto-engine coolant in the United States, said yesterday that it planned to sell its car-care division.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a test of how the nation's air traffic control system might operate when the date rolls over to the year 2000 incorrectly described the part of the drill involving a Federal Aviation Administration plane. While the computer that controlled the radios between the plane and the air traffic controller were rolled over to simulate the year 2000, the radar screens monitoring the plane used the correct current date so that the plane could be safely watched.

title: Organizing Electronic Resources for America's Swimmers
description: JUNE KRAUSER, a 72-year-old swimmer who holds 15 Masters Swimming world records and has been named to the International Swimming Hall of Fame, helped start United States Masters Swimming, the first national program for competitive swimming for adults, in the early 1970's. Today, Ms. Krauser is helping the organization take a new step, offering her advice and expertise on how best to streamline the group's emerging presence on the World Wide Web.

title: Cold-War Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Hired Organizers Can Create Order Out of Computer Chaos
description: SALLY SILBERMAN says a prayer to St. Anthony, the patron saint of lost things, whenever she goes hunting for a file on a floppy disk. It usually takes 15 minutes and repeated requests for divine intervention to find what she is after.

title: In America; Hospitals in Crisis
description: A deep financial crisis is spreading like a virus through the nation's teaching hospitals. It is undermining their honorable and historic mission, which has been to train new generations of physicians, to conduct critically important medical research and to provide treatment for, among others, the poor.

title: Newsman Buried; Freedom Mourned
description: About 1,000 citizens of Belgrade came out today to bury Slavko Curuvija, an independent publisher assassinated on Sunday. As air raid sirens sounded their own peculiar dirge through the lime and chestnut trees, his mourners tried to take courage from one another's public presence -- their refusal to be intimidated in a troubled time.

title: A Snapshot of 1920's Greenwich Village
description: THE World Monuments Fund has its list of endangered monuments. The National Trust for Historic Preservation has its roster of endangered places. Preservationists in New York City might well compile a list of endangered apartments. If they did, the interior of this Lilliputian five-room apartment at 64 Barrow Street in the heart of Greenwich Village -- an apartment that is now for sale for $275,000 -- would probably be on it.

title: War and Peace in Kosovo
description: Wars are easier to start than to stop, and the diplomatic initiatives now in play on Kosovo are likely to mutate several times before a political settlement draws within sight. But yesterday, for the first time since the combat began, the diplomats were as active as the generals, with Germany leading the way. The most difficult challenge for the United States and NATO is to blend force and diplomacy to bring Slobodan Milosevic into negotiations without sacrificing the alliance's objectives.

title: Accounts
description: * CompUSAnet.com, Marlborough, Mass., the electronic-commerce division of CompUSA Inc., to Mullen Advertising, Wenham, Mass., as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: ORACLE PLANS TO REPURCHASE UP TO 85 MILLION SHARES
description: The Oracle Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back as many as 85 million of its shares, worth more than $2 billion at the current price. The buyback, which will take place over an unspecified time, represents about 6 percent of Oracle's 1.4 billion shares outstanding. Oracle said the repurchase program was mainly intended to offset shares issued under the company's stock-option and employee stock-purchase plans. Oracle, based in Redwood Shores, Calif., is best known for its information management software. It has annual sales of about $8.3 billion. The shares closed at $24.125, up 50 cents.

title: The Low-Budget Realities Of Making Indie Films; A Hollywood Director Takes Off on His Own, Even if He Can't Get His Movie Distributed
description: Despite his success as a Hollywood director, Phil Joanou was visibly relieved when he left a screening of his new movie, ''Entropy,'' in a nearly empty theater and was met by a group of producers who offered lavish praise for his humorous, autobiographical tale of a director's misadventures in filmmaking and love.

title: Argentine Official Coming to U.S. for More Help on Budget Deficit
description: Argentina will send a top finance official to the United States this week to discuss financing a budget deficit that is expected to widen by $2 billion because of a weakened economy and slowing tax revenue.

title: Bratskeir Acquires G & A Communications
description: Bratskeir & Company in New York, a public relations agency specializing in consumer accounts like Burger King, Chiquita and Revlon, said yesterday that it had acquired G & A Communications in New York, a public relations agency specializing in business-to-business and industrial clients like Phillips Petroleum. Financial terms of the cash deal were not disclosed.

title: Mandated Mental Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; Bush Speaks Out
description: ''I believe we ought to be slow to engage our military, slow to commit our troops,'' says Gov. George W. Bush, ''but when we do so we must do so to win.''

title: Hartford Courant Buys 5 Weeklies, Tabloid Offspring Of 60's Voices
description: Two weeks ago, the irreverent editors at The Hartford Advocate published an April Fool's parody of the city's only daily, The Hartford Courant, lampooning ''America's Oldest Continuously Published Newspaper'' as ''America's Lamest Continuously Published Newspaper.''

title: Some in Panel Expect Unrest From Verdict On Louima
description: As a Federal judge in Brooklyn began yesterday to interview prospective jurors for the trial of four police officers charged with brutalizing Abner Louima, most of the 24 people he questioned said they thought that there was a possibility of social unrest following a verdict.

title: From Virtual Petz to Babyz; 15 Months' Worth, Anyway
description: Who says geeks can't bond? Mindscape Entertainment, the creators of the Dogz and Catz virtual pets software, is introducing a virtual baby

title: Showing Good Form at I.R.S.; New Commissioner Has Agency Minding Its Manners
description: He gets up before dawn every day and runs five miles, then heads for his Government job without eating breakfast. He does not need the work -- after all, he's sitting on a $40 million fortune he made running his own business -- but this may be his biggest challenge yet.

title: NATO Must Be Clear About Kosovo's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Continental Tire Forecasts Profit Growth
description: Continental A.G., the world's No. 4 tire maker, forecast double-digit profit growth this year with sales growth of 33 percent, as its strategy of diversifying into car parts helped results. The company, a German concern that makes Continental, General and Uniroyal tires, said sales this year would climb to 17.5 billion marks ($9.66 billion), from 13.2 billion marks in 1998. The prediction includes 4.5 billion marks from its Continental Teves automotive systems unit, which was acquired last year from ITT Industries for $1.93 billion.

title: A Prosecutor Resigns Post Amid Inquiry In a Killing
description: As questions continued to mount over the investigation into the murder of a policewoman in Orange, the No. 2 official in the Essex County's Prosecutor's office resigned suddenly today, a county official said.

title: A New Backup Power Supply That Can Fit Inside a PC
description: Uninterruptible power supplies, once considered necessary -- and affordable only for mainframe computers and mainframe budgets --

title: EUROPEAN UNION ASKS KOSOVO ROLE
description: Joining in the search for a diplomatic solution to the crisis in Kosovo, leaders of 15 European Union countries presented a plan today under which the province would be placed under temporary international European administration if President Slobodan Milosevic agreed to withdraw his forces and allowed hundreds of thousands of Albanian refugees to return.

title: Hackers Reveal the Identities Of On-Line Police Tipsters
description: After last month's riot at Michigan State University, the city of East Lansing posted pictures on its Web site of suspects it said had been involved in the violence and asked for tips to help track them down. The police started to receive tips but soon learned that their promise of anonymity to tipsters had a hole in it.

title: NATO Must Be Clear About Kosovo's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Chip Makers' Performance Hurts Nasdaq
description: With the market already limping from Tuesday's earnings report by the Intel Corporation, the huge first-quarter loss reported today by Advanced Micro Devices Inc. sent investors in technology stocks scrambling for the exits, leaving Nasdaq with a 76-point drop, its eighth-largest point decline ever, closing at 2,507.28.

title: Fidelity's Net Income Dropped 17% in 1998
description: Fidelity Investments Inc. said today that its net income for 1998 fell 17 percent, to $445.7 million, from $535.6 million a year earlier.

title: CASELLA WASTE PLANS TO CANCEL ACQUISITION OF KTI
description: Casella Waste Systems Inc., a waste handler based in Rutland, Vt., said yesterday that it planned to call off its acquisition of KTI Inc., a recycler. Casella said KTI had failed to meet the terms of the agreement. Shares of Casella jumped $3.0625, to $23.5625, while shares of KTI fell $1.6875, to $7.875. Casella agreed in January to buy KTI, which is based in Guttenberg, N.J., in a stock transaction then valued at $338 million. Casella provides waste collection, disposal and recycling services in six Northeastern states. KTI, which operates in 21 states and Canada, turns waste into electricity or other products.

title: Bayer Sets June Date For Agfa-Gevaert Offer
description: Bayer A.G., Germany's biggest drug and chemical company, set June 1 yesterday as the date for its initial offering of as much as 55 percent of Agfa-Gevaert, its photographic-products unit, when it will also sell a 15 percent stake to Gevaert N.V. of Belgium. Bayer will set the price range for the shares next month. The sale could raise more than 6 billion marks ($3.3 billion) altogether, if Gevaert later takes up its option to buy another 10 percent of Agfa, analysts said.

title: INSIDE
description: Savings Plan Fleshed Out

title: Two Charged As Killers Of Witness, 8
description: Two brothers were charged yesterday in a Connecticut criminal court with killing an 8-year-old boy and his mother, apparently to prevent the boy from testifying against one of the brothers in a murder trial.

title: Peekaboo! Anonymity Is Not Always Secure
description: LAST week in this column, I described the promise of anonymity on the Net, and some services and products that provide it. But skepticism and the impetus to challenge any product or program reign in cyberspace.

title: W.N.B.A. and Union Reach a 4-Year Pact
description: The Women's National Basketball Association and its players union reached an agreement in principle yesterday on a new four-year contract, managing to negotiate differences that had once threatened to delay the start of the season.

title: POSITIVE REPORT ON CANCER DRUG LIFTS ENTREMED SHARES
description: The shares of Entremed Inc. jumped yesterday as researchers reported that large-scale production of its developmental cancer drug endostatin had yielded a compound with the same tumor-fighting effects seen in earlier studies in mice. That is a crucial step toward the first human trials of endostatin because it confirms that the compound can be made in sufficient quantities and with characteristics suitable for use in humans. The findings, presented at the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research, are the first to confirm the effectiveness of endostatin resulting from Entremed's clinical grade, or large-scale, production methods. Shares in Entremed, a money-losing company in Rockville, Md., closed at $27.1875, up $2.0625, after trading as high as $34.75.

title: J. P. Morgan Profit Jumps 64% in Quarter
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, regularly cited as vulnerable to a takeover after successive quarters of weak profits, posted stellar first-quarter earnings yesterday, kicking off a year in which management says the bank will finally prove its mettle.

title: A Little Bit of Ella, Betty and Frances
description: Like a pugilistic clown, the popular lesbian comic Lea DeLaria is as aggressively exuberant singing be-bop as she is delivering politically charged punch lines. And on Mondays through May 3, Ms. DeLaria, who during the rest of the week is appearing in ''The Most Fabulous Story Ever Told,'' will perform a mostly musical show at Joe's Pub.

title: As High Gloss as Mary Janes
description: Conference rooms enclosed by white laminated glass as delicate and luminescent as rice paper line a central ''street'' inside new offices, above, in a former brass foundry. The architect Finn Kappe made the finely wrought minimalist space for Epoch Films, a television-commercial production company. Mr. Kappe, son of the modernist architect Ray Kappe, has his father's clarity in planning and detailing, and in the mixture of natural and man-made materials. The high-gloss, epoxy-painted floor contrasts with the rugged wooden trusses overhead. The Post-it notes that invariably get stuck on the translucent partitions bring a comfortable homeyness to the space. Epoch Films is at 9290 Civic Center Drive in Beverly Hills, (310) 275-9333.

title: Walking the Floor in Style
description: IF you're looking for new flooring, it may be time for a walk on the wild side. Bamboo, maybe. Or if you're more comfortable in the urban jungle, there's fake concrete or glass to put underfoot. For something really on the edge, how about linoleum? Two Los Angeles designers are creating linoleum ''area rugs'' that are perfect for sandy beach houses or muddy country homes. If you prefer a wall-to-wall look but don't want to damage your floor with installation glue, there is new tongue-and-groove linoleum flooring -- no adhesive required.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about the appointment of Peter Singer, a defender of euthanasia, to a chair in bioethics at Princeton University misidentified the university where he now teaches. It is Monash University in Melbourne, Australia, not the University of Melbourne.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: East Meets West, Minimally
description: Axe, a Santa Monica European-Asian restaurant, came, conquered and, in 1995, closed. (Axe, pronounced ash-ay, is Yoruba for ''Go with blessing.'') Now its owner, Joanna Moore, has reopened this minimalist's delight in Venice. Fresh dishes are served in a serene, austere space, which is lined with bolstered benches, square tables and stools. The counter area and large cupboard, designed by Ms. Moore, who studied painting, has open shelves, above, which serve as a partition between the kitchen and dining area. Ms. Moore also designed the restaurant's hanging jute lampshades. Axe is at 1009 Abbot Kinney Boulevard; (310) 664-9787.

title: GLOBAL TELESYSTEMS TO BUY CONTROL OF FRENCH CONCERN
description: Global Telesystems Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a controlling 52 percent interest in the French telecommunications concern Omnicom for about $210 million from the company's founders and managers. The deal would make Global Telesystems one of the leading providers of telecommunications services in France. Global is based in McLean, Va., but its telecommunications assets are all in Europe and Russia. The company, with 3,000 employees and expected 1999 revenue of $1 billion, was founded by the investor George Soros, who retains a big minority stake. Omnicom provides telecommunications services to 11,500 small and midsize businesses in France. Shares of Global rose 50 cents yesterday, to $74.5625.

title: 10 Drug Makers Join in Drive to Find Diseases' Genetic Roots
description: Ten pharmaceutical companies and the Wellcome Trust of London said yesterday that they would pool efforts to create a fine-scale map of the human genome. Their goal is to speed the discovery of the genetic variations that underlie disease, and hence of new drugs.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell for a fifth day against the Japanese currency, this time amid reports that Japanese life insurers were reducing overseas investments. In New York, the dollar fell to 118.68 yen, from 119.83 Tuesday.

title: Draft Is Strong Where Giants Are Weakest, the Offensive Line
description: The Giants will draft a big offensive lineman this weekend, a tackle who might learn to play guard. In fact, they will probably take two hulking but agile athletes among the linemen in the draft. Maybe even three.

title: India's Ruling Party Loses Its Partner, and Its Majority Standing
description: The Hindu nationalist-led coalition that has governed India for the past year lost its parliamentary majority today when its largest coalition partner, a state party from Tamil Nadu headed by the temperamental former actress Jayalalitha Jayaram, formally withdrew its support.

title: Pakistan Tests New Missiles, Matching India in the Arms Race
description: Days after India launched a missile able to carry a nuclear warhead, Pakistan has tested two missiles, showing its desire to stand up to India.

title: Memo From Moscow; Yeltsin's Back in the Swim, Frustrating the Sharks
description: Just a week ago, things were looking dire for President Boris N. Yeltsin. The Communist opposition had set a date for his impeachment. A fast-moving corruption inquiry was knocking on the gates of the Kremlin itself. NATO bombs over Yugoslavia threatened to damage not only Russia's relations with the West, but also the tenets of the country's fragile democracy.

title: NATO Must Be Clear About Kosovo's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: James V. Blevins, 87, Is Dead; Made a Kingdom of Popcorn
description: James Victor Blevins, who liked to be known as the Popcorn King after he began to market his own version of the snack to movie and grocery chains in the 1940's, died on Monday at his home in Nashville. He was 87.

title: Political Briefing; N.A.A.C.P. President Sought as Candidate
description: Ever since Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke of Baltimore announced last December that he would not seek a fourth term, many top business and political figures in the city and elsewhere in Maryland have been casting about for a strong candidate to replace him in this fall's election. Without the right candidate, they fear, the impressive urban rebirth that Baltimore has enjoyed over the past quarter of a century might falter.

title: A Valhalla Found in the Details of Domesticity
description: Old ideas of theater tell us that the highest emotions are reserved for special human beings. Richard Strauss's ''Intermezzo,'' new to the New York City Opera on Tuesday night, suggests that silly people suffer as genuinely as gods or heroes, and in precisely the same way.

title: Groundwork For Fledglings
description: The soaring canopies at the First Flight child care center, near the Los Angeles International Airport, evoke flight. (The freestanding flying canopies, left, also provide shade with corrugated fiberglass.) The new center, which cares for children from infancy to 5 years, was designed for the offspring of workers at the airport by the emerging young firm of Marmol & Radziner.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Quicken Legal-Help Software Is Banned in Texas by a Judge
description: In Texas, it is now illegal to seek legal advice from a computer program. A court ruling filed Monday put into effect a judgment that the Quicken Family Lawyer Version 8.0 and Quicken Family Lawyer '99 home legal-advice software can't be sold in Texas because using them constitutes the unauthorized practice of law.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's sort of like hazardous waste. When you bring in something that is potentially dangerous, which inmates are, what, if any, obligations do states have to regulate them?''

title: Malaysia's Low Tide
description: East Asia's current distress over moral and economic choices is reminiscent of the crisis that gripped Europe and America about three-quarters of a century ago. In 1933, Germany and the United States took different paths out of the Great Depression. Franklin Roosevelt was inaugurated President and promised a New Deal. In Germany, Hitler and the Nazis became a legitimate force in Parliament.

title: Taking the Garbles Out of Internet Phone Calls
description: IN the telecommunications industry, making a phone call over the Internet using a personal computer and a modem is considered something for ''hobbyists,'' a nice way of saying that it is frustrating and produces dubious results. Anyone who has tried making a call over the Internet will know what they mean.

title: Jack McDonald, 88, Ex-Chief Of Imperial, S.& L. Company
description: Jack H. McDonald, a former chairman and chief executive of the Imperial Corporation of America, a savings and loan company that long after his retirement fell victim to the nation's savings and loan crisis, died March 19 at Sharps Memorial Hospital in San Diego from complications of Parkinson's disease, leukemia and pneumonia, his wife, Loraine, said. He was 88.

title: Kennedy and Nixon Are Invoked as Forgery Trial Opens
description: A man accused of forging papers in the handwriting of John F. Kennedy and selling them for millions of dollars to unsuspecting investors also suggested to a business partner that he wanted to sell a trove of secret papers of Richard M. Nixon, the Government charged yesterday.

title: Senate Panel Sees I.O.C. Dallying
description: While members of a Senate committee harshly reprimanded two United States members of the International Olympic Committee today for a ''culture of corruption,'' and suggested varying timetables for reform, Senator Ernest Hollings lent an air of blunt impatience to the proceedings with a call for immediate action.

title: Yugoslavia Neighbor Fears An Effort to 'Destabilize' It
description: The Prime Minister of Macedonia today accused President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia of trying to ''destabilize'' Macedonia by driving tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians across the border and upsetting his country's fragile ethnic and religious mix.

title: Littlest Of Pitchers Can Soon Clock Their Speed
description: THANKS to technology and a retired baseball coach with an engineering degree, kids of all ages have a new way to answer one of life's most pressing questions: how fast can they throw a baseball?

title: Yeltsin Chooses Former Premier As Envoy to Balkan War Talks
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin today chose his former Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, as his personal envoy in talks to settle the Yugoslav conflict. More than a few outsiders said the appointment was driven as much by domestic as foreign necessity.

title: Rebels Seem to Be the Target As Serbs Fire Inside Albania
description: A remote and increasingly dangerous stretch of the mountainous Albanian border with Yugoslavia was hit today by Serbian shells and automatic-weapons fire.

title: Civic Groups Seek 2d Review of Safir Trip
description: Three civic groups announced yesterday that they had filed a complaint against Police Commissioner Howard Safir with the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board because of concerns that Mr. Safir violated ethics rules by accepting a trip to the Academy Awards last month from a corporate executive.

title: On 125th St., a Plan for Shopping Center and 10-Screen Multiplex
description: A Long Island developer is proposing to build a $23 million shopping center with a 10-screen multiplex on 125th Street in Harlem, a neighborhood that has only one existing theater showing English-language films.

title: Drivers, Remember, A Car Is Not an Office; Injuries Beyond Count
description: To the Editor:

title: To increase sales, Burger King plans an image-building overhaul of its 10,000 restaurants.
description: MOVING to improve its image, food and sales, Burger King said yesterday that it would overhaul its 10,000 restaurants with new kitchens, modifications to drive-through windows and elaborate redesigns of the buildings and the company logo.

title: Now, to Make the Bed You Bought
description: LOOK before you leap. The jump from a normal-height mattress to an oversize one might sound cushy, but dressing the thicker one can be a nightmare.

title: CIVILIANS ARE SLAIN IN MILITARY ATTACK ON A KOSOVO ROAD
description: Civilians in southern Kosovo came under fire today. An unknown number were killed, and the Yugoslav Government and NATO exchanged bitter accusations over who had carried out the attack.

title: Baby Sitter In Boston Takes Prize In Lottery
description: It was last Wednesday that Chris Gabrieli, a venture capitalist, discovered that his live-in baby sitter was a multimillionaire like him.

title: A Hero Twice Over, Whether Daring Flames or Atlanta's Mayor
description: The loudest cheers at the City Hall ceremony honoring Matt Moseley this afternoon came from his fellow firefighters, and not just because he transfixed the country on Monday in the breathtaking rescue of a construction worker trapped high above an inferno.

title: As More Prisons Go Private, States Seek Tighter Controls
description: The trouble started soon after the prison opened two years ago.

title: Adventures In Legoland
description: How lovely to be a child visiting Carlsbad, Calif., now that Legoland No. 3 has just opened its doors. (Other Legolands are in Denmark and England.) Thirty million Lego pieces went into the construction of the 40 rides and attractions in this theme park, which includes models of landmarks like the Taj Mahal, the Sydney Opera House, the Manhattan skyline (above left) and Capitol Hill (left). Legoland was built for young children (2 to 12) and, like Legos themselves, aims to stimulate a child's intelligence. (For example, riders of the cars, above, are allowed to choose their own route.) Legoland is 80 miles south of Los Angeles. The entrance fee is $25 for children ages 3 to 16 and $32 for adults. Information: (760) 918-5346.

title: New Gramercy Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: One True Prediction
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumers Warm To 'Free' PC's
description: FOR Barbara D. Fontenot, last Friday was the big day. She practically hugged the United Parcel Service man who lugged the big box up the stairs to her sparsely appointed second-floor apartment.

title: Variations on Murano
description: A West Coast variant on Murano glass? That's what Jim Henderson, the lighting designer, decided he wanted after several trips to northern Italy. He tapped the glass-blowing talent in the San Francisco area for his new company, 2,000 Degrees (the melting temperature of glass). The company's line includes dappled white and zebra-striped conical pendants, top ($660), as well as table lamps in similar designs and in vibrant colors. The exuberant Galaxy light fixture, above ($3,500), created with the interior designer Jonathon Straley, is a florid reworking of George Nelson's classic Sputnik chandelier. The lamps can be found at Plug, 8017 Melrose Avenue, (213) 653-5635. For other stores, call 2000 Degrees: (510) 234-6886.

title: Reservation Service Deal
description: USA Networks Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Hotel Reservation Network, which offers discount hotel accommodations by telephone and the Internet. The terms were not disclosed. A USA Networks spokeswoman said the company expected Hotel Reservation Network to have $125 million in revenues for 1999. Its co-founders, Robert Diener and David Litman, will remain president and chief executive, respectively.

title: HOCKEY: NHL LAST NIGHT
description: MAPLE LEAFS 3, ISLANDERS 2

title: Sports of The Times; Strickland Heats Up Furor at Point Guard
description: IN an odd way, Stephon Marbury, the Nets' impetuous point guard, has thrown down the gauntlet, issued a challenge to the Knicks that will either provide the impetus to push the team into the playoffs or expose them as pretenders. Following Sunday's blowout loss to the Knicks, Marbury blasted Chris Childs and Charlie Ward, declaring that the Knicks would never win a championship with them. Never. Ever.

title: More Bad Advice From Ken Starr
description: The renewal of the Independent Counsel Act should not be a referendum on Kenneth Starr and his conduct in office. Nor should Congress or the American people take Mr. Starr's advice on the future of the law. Mr. Starr, having been empowered under the act to investigate the Clintons for nearly five years, believes that the statute should not be renewed when it expires in June. His comments before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee had an odd self-pitying quality. He blames the law for flaws that were, in fact, the fault of his investigation. His lack of prosecutorial experience, his tin ear for public relations and his conflicts of interest have had a great deal to do with causing the law to fall into disrepute.

title: Time Warner Posts Profit, After Loss a Year Earlier
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it posted a solid profit in the first quarter based on strong growth at its cable television networks and the Warner Brothers film studio.

title: (Immortal?) Yanks Rout (Hapless) Baltimore
description: To err is human, the saying goes, and many humans participated in the Yankees' crazy 14-7 victory over Baltimore at Yankee Stadium last night.

title: N.T.T. Says It Has Edge In Acquiring Rival Concern
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the world's largest phone company, intends to buy all the shares of International Digital Communications Inc., taking advantage of a new Japanese law on acquisitions, a person close to N.T.T. said today.

title: Union Again Files Lawsuit Seeking End To Workfare
description: Calling the city's workfare program illegal and exploitative, the union representing municipal employees asserted in a lawsuit filed yesterday that the Giuliani administration has illegally replaced nearly 2,000 unionized clerical workers with unpaid welfare recipients in three agencies.

title: Teen-Ager Is Given 70-Year Sentence in Boy's Murder
description: After his mother had been ordered out of court for an angry outburst at prosecutors, a teen-ager who pleaded guilty to strangling a boy selling candy door to door was sentenced today to 70 years in prison.

title: Drivers, Remember, A Car Is Not an Office
description: To the Editor:

title: The Still-Dignified but Angrier Ex-Mayor
description: HE still dresses as if he is going to dinner with Brooke Astor, who by the way sent him ''the nicest note'' the other day. He is still courtly, elegant, fussy, decent and remote. But today, when David N. Dinkins, the former Mayor, takes his place as expected in the front lines of a large rally for police reform alongside his combustible former antagonist, the Rev. Al Sharpton, New Yorkers will be seeing an angrier man.

title: Criminal Inquiry on Judging Set
description: State Senator Roy Goodman said yesterday that he has turned over evidence of a potentially criminal nature involving the judging in the undisputed heavyweight championship fight between Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis last month at Madison Square Garden.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a plan to toughen Federal pollution standards for gasoline and automobiles misstated the reaction of Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma. He is drafting legislation to modify the new standards, which have not yet been issued. His bill would not cancel them.

title: Devils Tie Road Victory Record
description: DEVILS 2, SABRES 1

title: U.S. Blocks Hostile Bid For Shipbuilder
description: Saying that the potential savings did not justify the deal, the Defense Department yesterday rejected an unsolicited $1.4 billion offer by the General Dynamics Corporation for Newport News Shipbuilding Inc. Within minutes of the Pentagon's announcement, General Dynamics withdrew its offer.

title: Former Union Head Indicted In Scheme to Defraud Local
description: The former president of a union local that represents New York City municipal janitors was indicted yesterday on charges of stealing more than $110,000 through various schemes, including submitting fake bills for sandwiches for Labor Day picnics, prosecutors announced.

title: Elizabeth Dole Questions Clinton's Policies on Iraq and Serbia
description: Elizabeth Dole accused the Clinton Administration tonight of conducting a Balkan policy that ''encourages adversaries to shift strategies, wait it out, or attempt to break our alliances.'' She called on President Clinton to ''build up and deploy the forces necessary to win the war'' in Kosovo, including sending ground troops if necessary.

title: Times Company Posts Decline In Net Income as Revenue Rises
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that gains in advertising at its newspapers lifted the company's revenue 2.3 percent in its first quarter, while net income declined.

title: From Japan's Ailing Economy, A Tale of Murder in the Family
description: Shigeru Ishimura was hard at work at his father's bankrupt welding company when he heard a groan from across the small yard that separated the office from the factory.

title: The New Beds: A Step (or Two) Up
description: THE place of repose has reached new heights.

title: City to Expand Its Crackdown on Dogs
description: Calling New York City's limited crackdown on unleashed dogs a success, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said yesterday that the program would be expanded to several parks around the city.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about exercise machines that allow users to surf the Internet misstated the given name of the chairman and chief executive of the Can Do Club, a fitness center in Wayne, N.J., that has the equipment. He is Stuart Polevoy, not Steve.

title: Collecting Taxes, Effectively
description: As Americans file their tax returns this year, they are dealing with a tax collection agency that has been significantly hobbled in its ability to enforce the laws. Congressional budget cutters have constrained the funding for the Internal Revenue Service in recent years while simultaneously expanding its responsibilities into new areas, with the result that fewer agents are available to conduct tax audits and investigations. Unless Congress reverses this trend, compliance with tax laws may begin to plummet.

title: Sports of The Times; Samaranch Wise to Duck The Senator
description: IT all goes back to ''good old Jim McKay.'' That's how Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, explains his personal interest in the nasty little Olympic corruption scandal.

title: Political Briefing; Senator Faces Challenge By Washington Tribes
description: Senator Slade Gorton of Washington has been at odds with Native Americans going all the way back to the 1970's when, as the State Attorney General, he tried to limit the amount of salmon tribes could take from Washington waters. As chairman of the Interior Appropriations subcommittee, Mr. Gorton, a Republican, has further antagonized tribes, not just in the state but also elsewhere, by advocating tighter tribal budgets and tougher tribal laws.

title: It's a Checkless Payday for Budgetless Lawmakers in Albany
description: State legislators did not receive their scheduled paychecks today, the start of what could be a long financial drought for them, under a new law -- one that they passed -- that bars them from being paid as long as the state budget is overdue.

title: As Deadline Nears, No Trade Successor
description: With little more than two weeks before its current Director General departs, the World Trade Organization's 134 countries are still struggling to agree on who will replace him.

title: Robert V. Cox, Pulitzer Winner, 72
description: Robert V. Cox, a Chambersburg, Pa., newspaper reporter who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1967 for writing about the hunt for a sniper, died on Monday at a health care center in Chambersburg. He was 72 years old.

title: Hyman R. Faine, 88, Leader Of Performing-Artists' Union
description: Hyman R. Faine, a former executive of a union that represents performing artists, died last Thursday at a hospice in Los Angeles. He was 88, and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Serbs Step Up Expulsions in Kosovo Area
description: Yugoslav forces in southeastern Kosovo are stepping up a campaign of expelling ethnic Albanians from across southeastern Kosovo, according to refugees crossing the border here today.

title: Whitman Strongly Backs Embattled Court Nominee
description: With the nomination of Attorney General Peter G. Verniero for a seat on the State Supreme Court encountering unexpected opposition, the Whitman administration stepped up its aggressive defense of the nominee today, and six former presidents of the New Jersey Bar Association lent their help.

title: In Bloom, Precariously, for Centuries
description: IT'S easy to get lost trying to find America's oldest living botanical garden. A few miles off Route I-95, just south of Center City, Philadelphia, anonymous boulevards crisscross miles of industrial parks, vast stretches of treeless tarmac and boxy buildings. Plant hunters looking here would just find grass.

title: Interrupting An iMac Nap
description: Q. Sometimes when I put my iMac to sleep, it won't wake up when I want it to. How can I fix that?

title: Problems With Home Pages Are Being Addressed, AOL Says
description: A glitch in America Online's Personal Publisher 3 editing tool has prevented many users from creating or editing AOL home pages in the past few weeks. Instead of getting an error message when the program isn't running correctly, users are simply left hanging.

title: Off Screen, a Union Divided; It's Actor Against Actor as Guild Election Turns Bitter
description: Riding around Manhattan on her bright blue bicycle, Kelly Craig resembles a lot of other young actresses in New York, with her klieg-light smile, her willowy figure and her cheerful willingness to live on a shoestring while working to make it big.

title: Shelter Made of the Earth's Own Dust
description: ON a windy March day in a park here, Australian Aborigines, American survivalists and members of a rain forest action group teamed up to mix a slurry of earth, water, sand and cement to help build a museum. They pumped the mixture into plastic sandbags hundreds of feet long, laying the sandbags in a large coil. Later they sat inside an intricate brick dome as the four Aborigines sang ancient songs. It was, said Samuel Parish, one of the group, ''incredible to hear their voices echoing in the dome.''

title: Investor A.B. of Sweden Rises 15% in Value as Scania Booms
description: Investor A.B., the main financial company of the Wallenberg business empire, said today that the net asset value of its investments increased 15.3 percent in the first quarter, mainly from a surge in the value of its holding in Scania A.B., the Swedish truck maker.

title: Investors Take Profits, With the Dow Gaining by 16.65
description: In a session showing exceptional shifts in focus, investors cashed in profits in high-flying technology and consumer stocks and switched their money into neglected issues that would benefit from revived world economic growth.

title: A Guide to Surfing (the Ocean, Not the Net)
description: CITY SURFER: NYC

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Teacher Is Arrested on Charges That She Hit Student With Ruler
description: Hundreds of New York teachers are accused of hitting students each year, but rarely does the teacher land in jail. Yesterday, however, a math teacher at a Queens public high school was charged with felony assault after she hit a 16-year-old boy with a wooden ruler, raising a bruise and a welt on his shoulder blade, law enforcement officials said.

title: Duke's Brand, Player of Year, Enters N.B.A. Draft Early
description: The wave of underclassmen defecting to the National Basketball Association finally washed over Duke yesterday, when the sophomore center Elton Brand, the consensus player of the year, announced that he would forgo his final two years of eligibility to enter this summer's draft.

title: Setting Storage Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Books or Movies?

title: Seating for Plastic Man
description: Yes, they were the talk of the Milan Furniture Fair last year. But Ron Arad's sensuous, multipurpose Fantastic Plastic Elastic chairs have reached stores in this country. (Until now, you could find them in places like the Adidas Sport Cafes in France, but not here.) Made of an aluminum frame and a molded plastic called techno-polymer, the chairs ($520 for two) come in clear red, smoke gray, blue, light yellow, lavender and gray. They are available at Diva in Los Angeles, (310) 278-3191, and at Kartell, 45 Greene Street (Grand Street) in Manhattan, (212) 966-6665.

title: Playing Big Brother at the Amusement Park
description: SURE, you've built 19th-century railroad monopolies on your computer screen. You've been a 20th-century Sim City mayor. You've run your competitors into the ground. You've come out miles ahead in the polls. What are you going to do now?

title: Three Gay Guys On British TV: What's the Fuss?
description: It burst onto British television in February, an explosion of graphic language, male nudity and explicit sex guaranteed to offend as many people as it enthralled. It was called ''Queer as Folk,'' and it set out to venture where British television had not gone before, chronicling the lives and loves of a trio of gay men from Manchester who were not role models, victims or martyrs.

title: Do Feminists Ask What Cowboys Want?
description: To the Editor:

title: KDD of Japan Weighs Cutting 2,000 Jobs
description: The KDD Corporation, Japan's largest international communications carrier, announced yesterday that it was considering reducing its work force of 5,800 by 2,000 by the end of March 2004 to counter growing competition. The job cuts will probably come mainly through attrition and early retirement programs, but details are not firm yet, according to a company spokesman, Keiichi Tanaka.

title: Reality Check: Wizards Haul Knicks Back to Earth
description: Allan Houston exhaled a sigh of disbelief in the far corner of the locker room. As Houston gathered his things and his thoughts, he could not come up with any reason that he and Latrell Sprewell keep bringing each other, and the Knicks, down.

title: NATO Must Be Clear About Kosovo's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: House Democrats Renew Effort To Pass Campaign Finance Bill
description: House Democrats today began a petition drive to buck Republican leaders and force a vote on a campaign finance overhaul. It was the opening salvo in a battle that promises to be as spirited, convoluted and perplexing as it was last year.

title: Separating Divas From the Hit Makers
description: Add ''diva'' to the list of words -- along with ''classic,'' ''frankly'' and ''original'' -- that are well on their way to devaluation. For ''VH1 Divas Live '99,'' the sequel to last year's five-woman ''VH1 Divas Live,'' the cable channel nearly doubled the number of singers on the bill. But it came up with only two whose outsize voices and commanding presences qualified them as divas: Tina Turner and Whitney Houston. They showed up at the beginning and end of the concert on Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater; the show is in frequent reruns.

title: Bill Wendell, 75, Announcer On David Letterman Show
description: Bill Wendell, a radio and television announcer whose crisp authoritative voice provided an ironic foil to entertainers from Ernie Kovacs to David Letterman, died yesterday at a hospice in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 75.

title: Shopping in Auto City
description: Richard Longstreth, a professor of American civilization at George Washington University, analyzes the evolution of Los Angeles retailing in his latest book, ''The Drive-In, the Supermarket and the Transformation of Commercial Space in Los Angeles, 1914-41,'' below (MIT Press, $55). In the new book, he builds on his earlier academic work on related subjects. But it will fascinate with its black and white photographs of the first drive-in markets, circa 1924 (the precursors of shopping centers).

title: How Push by China And U.S. Business Won Over Clinton
description: It took a five-day road trip through America by a stalwart of the Chinese Communist Party, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, and the anger of a lot of American capitalists to force President Clinton into hastily restarting trade talks with China.

title: Strawberry Is Arrested
description: Darryl Strawberry was arrested for solicitation of prostitution and for possession of cocaine in Tampa, Fla. last night, according to Officer Steve Buchanan of the Tampa Police Department. The 37-year-old Strawberry offered an undercover police officer $50 for sex and was arrested at 10:10 P.M., police said. After he was searched, Officer Buchanan said that three-tenths of a gram of cocaine were discovered in Strawberry's wallet. Strawberry was then transported to the Orient Road Jail and, according to ESPN, was later released after posting a bond.

title: Franco Gets 400th Save, And It's for Hershiser
description: John Franco had been especially quiet lately, not wanting too talk too much about anything. Franco knew that an amazing milestone was one inning away for him. All Franco needed was one more successful ninth to achieve a special place in baseball history, and the thought of it turned the talkative Franco silent.

title: Swimming on Skateboards Is Just the Start
description: Anything goes in ''Felix: The Ballet,'' the first new work that Eliot Feld has choreographed this season for his company, Ballet Tech. By the time all the prone dancers in flippers glide by swimmingly on skateboards, then bounce on beach balls and goose step along in a Nazi salute as Mr. Feld, in a fright wig, conducts a silent Wagnerian singer with feathers in her helmet, you begin to wonder what the choreographer eats for breakfast.

title: Scotland Yard's Dalgliesh Swims Among the Lawyers
description: That word ''certain,'' as cleverly deployed by P. D. James in the title of her most recent book and its adaptation for television (''A Certain Justice''), allows for contrary meanings. Most commonly, of course, it is a synonym for ''sure,'' as in a sure or certain conviction. But it can also mean ''sort of,'' as in a doubtful victory for the law, less satisfactory than fans have learned to expect of Comdr. Adam Dalgliesh of Scotland Yard.

title: Clinton Proposes New Grants As Way to Encourage Savings
description: President Clinton today proposed giving low- and middle-income taxpayers up to $300 a year as seed money for a new type of retirement account intended to create powerful incentives for increased savings.

title: Gretzky Straddles Blue Line As the Ice Starts to Get Mushy
description: As he contemplates retirement after 20 seasons in the National Hockey League and 21 as a professional athlete, Wayne Gretzky of the Rangers hears many opinions, from old and young, both inside and outside his profession and family. He recently spoke with Gordie Howe, who called to congratulate Gretzky on goal No. 1,072, which surpassed Howe's career total.

title: Wiring the Schools For E-Mail and More
description: AT Stuyvesant High School on a Friday not long ago, students in Nautica jackets and flared jeans lounged in the hallways and played with a football on their way to class. In the library, seniors finished last-minute revisions of their college essays.

title: Carnegie Hall Site Shines Spotlight On New Production
description: Carnegie Hall has long provided on-line introductions to its programs, but the coming performance of Bernd Alois Zimmermann's ''Requiem for a Young Poet'' seemed to demand something more ambitious. The ''Requiem,'' which has its North American debut at the hall next Tuesday, involves a full symphony orchestra, three choirs, two vocal soloists, a jazz band and two loudspeakers playing four separate tape tracks of prose, poetry and political speeches.

title: MCI Executive Talks Down a Wireless Deal
description: The directors of Nextel Communications Inc., one of the nation's biggest wireless telephone companies, convened yesterday to consider whether to sell their company to MCI Worldcom Inc., even as one of MCI Worldcom's top executives said his company was in no hurry to build a wireless business.

title: A Dot on a Map Connected By People
description: NORTHAMPTON, a city of 30,000 in western Massachusetts, has been raising issues of community for more than 300 years -- charity, self-interest, tolerance and division. They are issues as fresh today as they were in the 19th century, when Northampton was painted as a heavenly view by Thomas Cole and described with affection by Henry James in his first novel, ''Roderick Hudson.'' They were raised when it hanged two innocent immigrant Irishmen in 1806 for suspected murder and when it tried a police officer, a native son, for the rape of his own child, during the four years that Tracy Kidder spent reporting his new book, ''Home Town'' (Random House), to be published in May.

title: Political Briefing; California's Governor Is Facing Quandary
description: Gov. Gray Davis of California is in a political quandary.

title: Quayle Enters G.O.P. Race With Vow to Protect Values
description: Proudly resurrecting one of the most controversial episodes of his Vice Presidency -- his denunciation of the Murphy Brown television character -- Dan Quayle today formally announced his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination and vowed to make protecting American values a centerpiece of his campaign.

title: Sam Spade, M.B.A.: Changed Detectives
description: A sun half-cut by the thick cloud blushed its glimmer through trees sparkling with recent raindrops. It was about noon, mid-April. I was wearing my blue pin-stripe suit, a bit shiny from too many cleanings, with a dark blue shirt and tie and black Gucci loafers, which had seen better days, but were highly polished. A red pocket handkerchief splashed color on the jacket. It used to be the way a private investigator dressed before he lay down for the big sleep.

title: Drivers, Remember, A Car Is Not an Office; Waiting for That Light
description: To the Editor:

title: RAYMOND JAMES FINANCIAL TO ACQUIRE RONEY & CO.
description: Raymond James Financial Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Roney & Company, a Detroit-based brokerage firm, from the Banc One Corporation for $80 million. Raymond James, based in St. Petersburg, Fla., said Roney's 28 offices in the Midwest would increase its presence in a region where many of its Florida clients have roots. Roney had $112.6 million in revenue last year, while Raymond James Financial had $1.1 billion. Bank One said it was selling Roney as part of its consolidation after acquiring First Chicago NBD, which bought Roney in May 1998 for $95 million. Shares of Raymond James fell $1.875, to $20.9375, and Bank One slipped 87.5 cents, to $57.25.

title: Blind Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz Musician's Dreams Still Lead Him Home
description: Once, decades ago, on an ordinary afternoon outing with friends, a teen-age boy in Cape Town stumbled upon a strange looking house on a hill. It was an old house, with a corrugated tin roof and a sprawling yard out front, and just the sight of it filled him with an unfamiliar feeling of peace.

title: Senate Panel Applauds Changes at I.R.S.
description: A year after sharply criticizing the Internal Revenue Service, saying it abused taxpayers, members of the Senate Finance Committee praised the new tax commissioner, Charles O. Rossotti, today for beginning fundamental reforms.

title: Jail Time for Dr. Kevorkian
description: That was a harsh sentence a Michigan judge imposed on Dr. Jack Kevorkian this week for his murder conviction in the ''mercy killing'' of a seriously ill patient. Some may think that a sentence of 10 to 25 years in prison -- with the possibility of parole after 6 years and 8 months -- is even too harsh, given that Dr. Kevorkian is 70 years old and performing what, from his skewed perspective, was an act of conscience. But quibbling over whether the sentence should have been a few years lighter pales against the important message sent by Judge Jessica Cooper's tough sentence and blistering statement to Dr. Kevorkian. No one can openly flout the law on murder and expect to get away with it.

title: Taking a Close Look With Satellite Images
description: Want to be the first on the block to have an aerial shot of your house? Images taken from a Russian satellite -- with resolution said to be sharp enough to see specific homes and even cars -- can be ordered at www.terraserver.com.

title: Starr Puts Up His Defense While Faulting Counsel Law
description: Rebuked by Democrats at a Senate hearing today, Kenneth W. Starr defended his prosecutorial tactics and judgment in the investigation of President Clinton's relationship with a former White House intern.

title: Economic Scene; The Tax Bite Comes With Saw Teeth
description: It's April 15, time to complain about how taxes have become too high. And the House will vote once again today on a constitutional amendment that would require a two-thirds majority to pass future tax increases. But the real problem with the income tax system, many economists say, is not that the typical family pays too much tax but rather that Washington has made the tax code numbingly complex, wasteful and irrational.

title: Alta Vista Invites Advertisers to Pay for Top Ranking
description: Alta Vista, one of the leading services that search for information on the World Wide Web, is inviting advertisers to pay for the right to be listed atop its search results.

title: The Unzipped 'Zipper'
description: IN February, I spent a few days in the Netherlands with Peter Noever, the director of the Austrian Museum of Applied Arts in Vienna, and Sarah Lerfel, the owner of Colette, a shop in Paris that mixes design, fashion and art, when we were judging the entries for the Rotterdam Design Prize. Our mission was to select one winner from 47 examples of Dutch graphic, industrial and architectural design.

title: Dry Weather Is Striking Fear Of Wildfires Across Florida
description: It has been fine weather for the tourists here in Florida, with day after day of blue skies, but firefighters across the state have learned to despise these perfect days.

title: A Modern Fairy Tale of the Dark North Woods
description: THE GIRL WHO LOVED

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Apple Posts Strong Results When Rivals Are Struggling

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: J. ALEXANDER'S CORP., Nashville, a restaurant operator, rejected a $33.8 million buyout bid from the rival O'Charley's Inc., Nashville.

title: $660 MILLION BUYOUT FOR BERKSHIRE REALTY
description: The Berkshire Realty Company, a real estate investment trust, agreed yesterday to be acquired by a management-led group for $660 million in cash plus assumed debt of $600 million. Berkshire, based in Boston, owns more than 80 apartment communities in Florida, Texas, the mid-Atlantic region and the Southeast. Under the agreement, Berkshire's chairman, Douglas Krupp; its chief investment officer, David Olney; Blackstone Real Estate Advisers, an affiliate of the Blackstone Group, and Whitehall Street Real Estate Funds, an affiliate of Goldman, Sachs & Company, will pay $12.25 a share for the company. Last month, Berkshire rejected an offer of $11.05 from the Krupp team. The shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $11.625.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 24 about a leadership void at the City University of New York misstated its peak enrollment figure, reached in the fall of 1974. It was 252,956, not 212,634.

title: Heavy Bombing of Serbia
description: NATO warplanes mounted a withering new attack tonight against targets across Yugoslavia, including numerous strikes on the capital, Belgrade, Pentagon and NATO officials said.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE FALLS. The price of gasoline futures fell after the American Petroleum Institute reported an unexpected increase in inventories. In New York, gasoline for May delivery fell 1.4 cents, to 50.84 cents a gallon.

title: House Approves Bill to Allow Local Challenges of 2000 Census
description: After a partisan brawl, the House tonight approved a bill that would allow local officials to challenge the accuracy of next year's census and to demand a recount of any neighborhoods where they suspected errors.

title: Netanyahu, a TV Guy, May Still Need Lessons
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is usually the supreme master of the television screen, his gaze more direct than any anchor's, his language more focused, authoritative and articulate than any other politician's in this country.

title: Schools and Web Safety; Balancing the Dangers and the Discoveries As Students Go on Line
description: THE image of a cherubic fourth grader sending E-mail to a cherubic fourth grader in another school is a heartwarming reminder of the promise of the Internet. The image of a cherubic fourth grader unwittingly sending E-mail to a pedophile, or finding pornography or hate speech on the World Wide Web, is a chilling reminder of the technological dangers that many parents and teachers fear.

title: Symantec Makes Executive Change at Top
description: The Symantec Corporation, the No. 2 maker of anti-virus and computer security software, said today that it had named John W. Thompson president and chief executive, replacing Gordon Eubanks, a software pioneer.

title: Apple, Against the Grain, Reports Strong 2d Quarter
description: Reporting its second-quarter earnings today, a resurgent Apple Computer Inc. again beat analysts' earnings estimates. Apple said strong demand for its iMac and G3 machines increased unit sales by 27 percent, or nearly twice the industry average.

title: State's School Commissioner Proposes $5.4 Billion Budget
description: The new State Education Commissioner today proposed a budget of $5.4 billion for the 1999-2000 school year, $380 million more than the current year, in the state that already has the highest per pupil spending rate in the nation.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of the Media Business page on April 7 about the appointment of Paige Powell as West Coast marketing and editorial strategist at Paper magazine, referred incorrectly to her role at Paige Powell Productions. She remains its president.

title: Do Feminists Ask What Cowboys Want?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Teetering Balkans
description: NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia is destabilizing neighboring regions in which the United States and Europe have stationed tens of thousands of troops, spent billions of dollars and invested years of work in trying to secure peace, build democracy and improve moribund economies.

title: A Virus Precaution
description: To the Editor:

title: AVT BUYS AN ELECTRONIC DOCUMENT DELIVERY COMPANY
description: The AVT Corporation, a maker of software for fax and other communications services, said yesterday that it had acquired the Mediatel Corporation, a closely held electronic document delivery company based in San Francisco, for $48 million in stock to strengthen its E-commerce operations. AVT said it had issued 1.6 million new shares for the acquisition, which will allow the company to broaden its electronic document delivery services through the Internet and telephone networks. AVT, based in Kirkland, Wash., had 1998 sales of $81.2 million. Its shares rose $1 yesterday, to $24.

title: Do Feminists Ask What Cowboys Want?
description: To the Editor:

title: A New President For MacDonald
description: The MacDonald Communications Corporation in New York has named Barbara J. Litrell president, succeeding J. C. MacDonald, who remains chief executive.

title: Regressing At 10-28? With Nets, It's Possible
description: The Nets have apparently abandoned the idea of guarding people. Just a week after building a reputation as a budding defensive force, the most disappointing team in the Eastern Conference has reverted to being the permeable club that lets opponents drive the lane for resounding dunks and shoot wide-open jumpers.

title: Station Casinos Settlement
description: Station Casinos Inc. said today that it had settled a lawsuit against Crescent Real Estate Equities Inc. for pulling out of an agreement to buy the casino company last year. Station said Crescent had agreed to pay $15 million to settle the suit. Station had been seeking $400 million in damages.

title: Rejection at an Early Age
description: The letters arrived last week, quick and cutting. ''We regret to inform you,'' they began. Harvard, Yale, Princeton? No, this was nursery school, and our son had not been admitted. He was waitlisted, actually, at four schools and rejected at one.

title: 5,000 Rally for Union Labor at Bus Depot
description: For John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, it was a perfect homecoming -- the New York janitors' union he long headed held one of the city's most spirited labor demonstrations in years yesterday as 5,000 union members rallied at the Port Authority midtown bus terminal to protest the use of nonunion janitors.

title: Web Phone: The Next Big Thing?
description: MARK DAHM, a 37-year-old sales director in San Mateo, Calif., depends on his mobile phone for far more than phone calls. He uses it to tap into his contact list at work and to send and receive E-mail. He retrieves stock quotes from the Internet and looks up directions while driving. If he needs a printout, it's no problem. While waiting for a flight at an airport executive lounge, he can send information from his phone straight to the lounge's fax machine.

title: Soros Giving $15 Million for Program on Medical Ethics and Money
description: George Soros, the billionaire financier, plans to spend $15 million on a new program to de-emphasize profit in medical care, develop altruistic service programs for young doctors and encourage consumer groups to join with physicians to monitor the quality of care better.

title: Guilty Verdict for Ex-Official in Malaysia Sets Off Noisy Protests
description: Anti-Government riots erupted in the heart of this orderly city today after Anwar Ibrahim, the ousted Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia, was found guilty of corruption and given an unexpectedly harsh sentence of six years in prison.

title: A Police Vote Against Safir And the Past
description: A day after the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association cast a vote of no confidence in Police Commissioner Howard Safir, the true meaning behind that unanimous vote remains as clear as the inner workings of the P.B.A. itself -- which is to say, not clear at all.

title: Price of Civilian Deaths: NATO Debit, Serb Asset
description: As NATO ratchets up its air campaign over Yugoslavia, relentlessly bombing Serbian armored forces in the field, the inevitable is happening: civilians are dying, some at the hands of the alliance.

title: NATO Must Be Clear About Kosovo's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Army Builds Balkan Village in Rockies
description: Armored personnel carriers scooted across beige hills, the thump of tank cannon came from a distant firing range, and a construction crew broke ground today for a new ''Balkan'' training village.

title: Contest, Yes, but a Contest Among Equals
description: Most of the big opera stars in this country at the moment first twinkled as winners in the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions. On Sunday afternoon 11 new contestants were at the Met in hopes of joining the galaxy, each of them singing two arias with the sympathetic if sometimes untidy assistance of the orchestra under Edoardo Muller. Five prizes were handed out at the end of the concert, and all were so well deserved that it seems fairest to mention the winners, not ranked in this competition, in alphabetical order.

title: Prize-Winning Prose
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE PLUNGES. Orange juice dropped sharply on expectations for a large crop next year in Florida, the nation's top grower. In New York, orange juice for May delivery fell 2.10 cents, to 80.60 cents a pound.

title: Japanese Companies Cut Output Capacity
description: Japan's manufacturers cut production capacity in February as the country's sprawling industrial groups began to shed money-losing businesses. Production capacity, which measures the maximum amount manufacturers can produce, fell two-tenths of 1 percent from January and three-tenths of a percent from a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said yesterday. That was the first decline in eight months.

title: In Good Times, Who Really Gains?; Taking Homes Away
description: To the Editor:

title: To Save the Kosovars, Go After Milosevic
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Regional Banks Report Quarterly Profits
description: The First Union Corporation, the BankBoston Corporation and three other big regional banks posted quarterly earnings today.

title: Trade With the Chinese
description: Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China did not end his visit to America this week with the trade deal he wanted, but he is likely to get it soon. Thanks in part to Mr. Zhu's energetic lobbying of businessmen as he traveled around the country, the Clinton Administration will probably endorse Chinese membership in the World Trade Organization. Though other important issues continue to divide the two countries, China's commitment to lifting trade barriers qualifies it to join the W.T.O., and President Clinton is right to try to close the deal in the days ahead.

title: Jones Takes Aim At Third Title
description: Roy Jones Jr. could not be happier. He has two light-heavyweight belts -- from the World Boxing Council and the World Boxing Association -- and on June 5 he will get a shot at a third, Reggie Johnson's from the International Boxing Federation.

title: Complicated Mind Games: Life Is Good, Then Goes Bad
description: What is waking? What is dream? What is reality? What is fantasy? What is sanity? What is madness?

title: Prodi to Have Wide, New Powers as Head of the European Commission
description: BRUSSELS  With support from European governments and extensive new responsibilities, Romano Prodi seemed assured on Thursday of becoming virtually the prime minister of the European Union.

title: Suffolk County Executive Will Seek Re-election
description: Flanked by members of the Suffolk County Republican leadership, Robert J. Gaffney announced yesterday that he would seek re-election for a third term as the county executive.

title: Patty Chang
description: Jack Tilton Gallery

title: Texas Appeals Court Overturns Conviction of Girl, 14, in Killing
description: A Texas appeals court today overturned the conviction of a 14-year-old girl serving a 25-year sentence in the beating death of a young child.

title: Mattel Reports Loss and Says It Will Cut Jobs
description: Mattel Inc., after reporting a loss in the first quarter, said today that it would dismiss more than 3,000 employees, or about 10 percent of its work force.

title: Refreshing Copspeak
description: Many New Yorkers were taken aback by the sharp language James Savage, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, used this week in criticizing Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's zero-tolerance approach to crime. ''If we don't strike a balance between aggressive enforcement and common sense,'' Mr. Savage said, ''it becomes a blueprint for a police state and tyranny.''
