title: Woman Killed Resisting Thief On a Busy Street
description: A 34-year-old woman walking to the dry cleaners along the busy sidewalks of Morningside Heights was shot and killed yesterday morning when she tried to keep a man from stealing her purse, the police said.

title: Woman Arrested in Death Of Husband, 5 Years Later
description: Andrew G. Vlasto, a member of a prominent Greek-American family active in publishing and politics, was 85 when he married for the first time to a woman who was 57 years his junior.

title: Foreign Affairs; Our Buddy Boris
description: Last week the West got a lesson in why we can't live with Boris Yeltsin and why we dare not live without him.

title: Restraint Policy Changed For Pregnant Inmates
description: Responding to reports that inmates recovering from childbirth have been routinely kept in shackles, the New York City Department of Correction said yesterday that it had changed its procedures so that prison officials can more quickly determine whether restraints are necessary.

title: Old Favorites Propel Wall St. as Dow Hits Another High
description: Investors piled into basic-industry stocks again yesterday in what increasingly appears to be a shift away from the household names that had dominated the market's long advance.

title: CHESAPEAKE AGREES TO SELL TWO UNITS FOR $186 MILLION
description: The Chesapeake Corporation, the third-largest United States supplier of tissue products to businesses, agreed yesterday to sell its timberlands and building-products units for $186 million as it focuses on its main business. The company will sell 278,000 acres of woodlands in Virginia, Maryland and Delaware to the Hancock Timber Resource Group, a unit of the John Hancock Insurance Company. Chesapeake also agreed to sell two sawmills, a lumber processing plant and a wood-chip mill in Maryland and Virginia to St. Laurent Paperboard Inc. of Canada. Chesapeake's shares rose $2.625, to $31.1875.

title: Record of the Week
description: KREIDLER: ''APPEARANCE AND THE PARK'' -- (Mute). In the 1970's, German bands like Can and Neu wandered from psychedelic jamming to the minimalistic delights of laying pattern upon pattern.

title: Thousands Mourn an Officer Noted for Putting People First
description: Thousands of police officers from as near as Little Ferry and as far as Washington, as well as hundreds of civilians, lined the edge of a park outside the St. Matthew A.M.E. Church here today for the funeral of Joyce Anne Carnegie, the Orange police officer who was fatally shot last week in what the police said was an encounter with a robbery suspect.

title: Pilots in Sickout Told to Pay Airline $46 Million
description: A Federal judge ordered the pilots' union at American Airlines to pay the carrier nearly $46 million yesterday for defying his order to return to work in February after hundreds of pilots called in sick in a dispute that forced the airline to cancel thousands of flights. The assessment was greater than the net assets of the union.

title: UNOCAL DEAL FOR UP TO 46% OF CANADIAN ENERGY PRODUCER
description: The Unocal Corporation said yesterday that its Unocal Canada Resources unit had agreed to acquire up to 46 percent of Northrock Resources Ltd. for $175 million. Unocal, based in El Segundo, Calif., said the Northrock equity stake would complement its North American gas strategy, which includes a strong natural gas base in the Gulf of Mexico and an equity stake in Tom Brown Inc., the Rocky Mountain energy producer. Northrock, based in Calgary, Alberta, has proven reserves of about 35 million barrels of crude oil and liquids and 363 billion cubic feet of gas, Unocal said. Unocal said that it would begin a tender offer for an initial 32 percent stake in Northrock, and that the stake would be raised to 46 percent in a second-stage purchase.

title: On My Mind; Lessons of Kosovo
description: The way adults of any intelligence can find out how well they are dealing with a crisis, personal or national, is to ask themselves two questions. Would we do the same things again if we had the chance? If not, what do we now do to get out of this mess? So:

title: Pakistan Sentences Bhutto To 5 Years for Corruption
description: A Pakistani court today convicted Benazir Bhutto, who was twice removed as Prime Minister on corruption charges, of having taken kickbacks while she was in office in the mid-1990's. She was sentenced to five years in prison and barred from holding political office.

title: Editors Seek More Information on the Air War
description: Editors and executives of seven major United States news organizations have written a letter of protest to Defense Secretary William S. Cohen urging him to loosen the current controls on information about the NATO campaign against Yugoslavia, saying that ''on many days, the state-controlled Yugoslav media has been more specific about NATO targets than the United States or NATO.''

title: MCN ENERGY AGREES TO SELL 18% OF NATURAL GAS RESERVES
description: MCN Energy Group Inc. agreed yesterday to sell 18 percent of its natural gas reserves to a group led by the Williams Companies for $146 million. The properties, mainly in Wyoming, are the first of four packages that MCN intends to sell to exit the gas exploration and production business. MCN, a Detroit-based utility holding company, has proven gas reserves of 1.2 trillion cubic feet equivalent. Williams, based in Tulsa, Okla., is a gas transmission company and provider of fiber optic networks. Its portion of the purchase price is $106 million.

title: Clinton's View of U.S. Goal: 'Peaceful Time for Europe'
description: Following are excerpts from an address by President Clinton yesterday in San Francisco to the American Society of Newspaper Editors, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: 2 Spanish Companies To Sell Airtel Stakes
description: Endesa S.A., Spain's biggest electric company, and Union Fenosa S.A., the No. 4 power company, said yesterday that they would sell their combined 16.2 percent stake in Airtel, Spain's second-largest wireless phone company, and earn 272 billion pesetas ($1.8 billion) in capital gains. The price of 148 billion pesetas announced for each of the 8.14 percent stakes values Airtel at 1.8 trillion pesetas.

title: Schwab's Profit Up, but Trade Growth Lags
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the nation's largest on-line brokerage firm, said today that its first-quarter profit doubled, matching expectations. Growth in trades handled daily was below the industry average, however, and the company's stock plunged.

title: CADBURY AGREES TO BUY HAWAIIAN PUNCH FROM P.& G.
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the British soft drink and candy company, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $:126 million ($203 million) to buy Hawaiian Punch, the leading United States fruit-drink brand, from the Procter & Gamble Company. Hawaiian Punch will be distributed to soft-drink outlets, which account for nearly 70 percent of sales, through Cadbury's Dr Pepper/Seven Up unit. Distribution to juice outlets will be handled by the Mott's unit's warehouse and broker network. Hawaiian Punch generated net sales of $133.3 million in the 12 months that ended on June 30. Procter & Gamble's shares fell $2.625, to $96.50, and the American depository receipts of Cadbury dropped $1.5625, to $58.6875.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: New campaign by Wendy's seeks young dudes with attitudes to munch a bunch of burgers.
description: WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL INC. is embarking on an ambitious effort that stops just short of replacing its pigtailed little girl mascot with a photograph of Pamela Anderson Lee downloaded from the Internet.

title: LVMH and Gucci Continue To Spar Before Court Hearing
description: The takeover battle between the luxury goods maker LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. and Gucci Group N.V. escalated today, with each accusing the other of posturing to gain favor with the Dutch court arbitrating their dispute.

title: Streak Survives For Clemens, Not for Yanks
description: A multiple choice quiz for the morning after:

title: Girl Sexually Assaulted At Bronx Middle School
description: A 13-year-old girl was sexually assaulted in the stairwell of a Bronx middle school yesterday afternoon by a man who entered the building after school, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day last Friday with an article about a rise in spending on medical devices misspelled the name of a manufacturer of one such device, the gamma knife. It is Elekta A.B. of Sweden, not Elektra.

title: Chinese Restaurants
description: New York's love affair with Chinese restaurants seems eternal. Here are a dozen places for a taste of what keeps it going. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Rabbi in Plot to Siphon Millions In Public Money to Private School
description: It was an elaborate scheme that somehow went undetected for nearly two decades, investigators said yesterday: a prominent Hasidic rabbi and a Brooklyn public school district conspired to place dozens of Hasidic housewives in no-show jobs on the district payroll as part of a plot to siphon more than $6 million to a private Jewish girls' school and its affiliates.

title: Fans Want One More Year
description: The message from hockey fans to Wayne Gretzky was simple: please come back for one more season.

title: Safir Says Police Need To Deal Better With Public
description: Hours before thousands of protesters massed in lower Manhattan, Police Commissioner Howard Safir acknowledged yesterday that his force needed to do a better job of reaching out to New Yorkers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Pilots' Union Ordered to Pay $46 Million to American Air

title: Michael Crichton Giving Computer Games 2d Try
description: Michael Crichton, the author of ''Jurassic Park'' and the creator of ''ER,'' is trying to revive his career -- as a computer game designer, that is.

title: Hans Bellmer: 'Photographs and Drawings From the 1930's'
description: Ubu Gallery

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about the linguist James D. McCawley described the evolution of linguistics scholarship incorrectly. It was from 1957 until the late 60's, not before 1957, that the field was defined by Chomskyan generative grammar, a theory that focuses almost exclusively on syntax, or the rules of sentence formation.

title: Lett Failed Drug Test Again, Team Official Says
description: The National Football League draft has taken on a new urgency for the Dallas Cowboys. When they stare at the long list of players to choose from tomorrow, they will probably circle the name of a defensive lineman because Leon Lett, one of their best defensive tackles, may again be removed from their roster by a drug suspension.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: No Ordinary Night For Playwright

title: To Save the Kosovars, Go After Milosevic
description: To the Editor:

title: Sugar Companies Play a Pivotal Role in Effort to Restore Everglades
description: Alex Thompson wheeled his giant harvester around, lined it up to mow a strip of scorched sugar cane and, over the engine noise, allowed as how he had heard just about enough from environmentalists who blame the sugar industry for the slow erosion of the Everglades.

title: Buffalo Braces for Another Storm; Residents Uneasy as a Week of Abortion Protests Is to Begin
description: When Martha Hulings's 21-year-old daughter became pregnant two years ago, her family went through a wrenching discussion over whether she should have an abortion. She was unmarried, after all, and still in college. But in the end, she kept the child, named Alyah, a playful girl with dark curly hair. And because of that experience, Martha Hulings stands squarely in the anti-abortion camp.

title: 'Another Girl, Another Planet'
description: Lawrence Rubin-Greenberg Van Doren

title: The Pony Car Turns 35
description: TOMORROW is the 35th anniversary of the introduction of the Mustang, which was unveiled at the New York World's Fair in April 1964. Although it may be too late to park your Mustang among the 3,000 expected at Lowe's Motor Speedway (formerly Charlotte Motor Speedway) in Concord, N.C., where the Mustang Club of America is holding its anniversary get-together through Sunday, there are plenty of products on sale all year to help one celebrate.

title: Civilian Deaths Inevitable In Warfare, Clinton Says
description: President Clinton said today that the accidental bombing and killing of Albanian civilians Wednesday was regrettable but an inevitable result of modern warfare and would not undermine his resolve to use American military might to end the years of Balkan atrocities.

title: In Good Times, Who Really Gains?
description: To the Editor:

title: Songs and Tears (if No Umbrellas) on the Streets of Paris
description: Only France could have produced a charmingly eccentric bonbon like ''Jeanne and the Perfect Guy,'' a bittersweet movie musical that suggests an unlikely collision of ''The Umbrellas of Cherbourg'' and ''Rent.'' Giddily romantic one moment, gawkily militant the next, this emotional seesaw of a movie switches back and forth between dreamy love scenes and Act-Up demonstrations without its feet ever touching the ground.

title: Rat-a-Tat Of Collections Up for Sale
description: The adage that antiques are passed down ''from generation to generation'' is being given new meaning by recent activity in the international auction markets. Between sales just completed and others coming up, no less than five major collections of mostly 18th- and 19th-century furniture and decorations, which each took decades to assemble, are being dispersed. It certainly seems as if baby boomers are shopping somewhere besides Pottery Barn.

title: Bush, With $7.6 Million in Donations, Eclipses Rivals for G.O.P. Nomination
description: In the first real measure of support for candidates in the 2000 Presidential race, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas reported today that he had amassed $7.6 million in contributions in just 28 days, dwarfing what every other Republican hopeful raised in the first three months of the year.

title: To Save the Kosovars, Go After Milosevic
description: To the Editor:

title: INTEGRATED ELECTRICAL AGREES TO BUY 9 MORE COMPANIES
description: Integrated Electrical Services Inc., the No. 2 United States electrical contractor, has agreed to acquire nine electrical companies with combined annual sales of $153 million, pursuing its strategy of growth through purchases. Integrated Electrical did not disclose the names of the companies or the terms. The companies provide electrical contracting and maintenance services. Last month, Integrated Electrical agreed to acquire six electrical companies and in January agreed to acquire five others. The company has made or agreed to make at least 43 acquisitions since it went public in January 1998. Shares of Integrated Electrical, which had sales of $470.2 million for the year ended Sept. 30, rose $1.1875, to $18.375.

title: Marry Me, Marry Me, or Maybe Not
description: When Richard Crane learns that his ex-wife plans to marry her much younger lover, he is determined to leave a medical conference in Iceland and get to Manchester in time to prevent her from making a fool of herself. Though Richard is played by the urbanely attractive Michael Kitchen, he looks quite foolish himself in a furry anorak, trekking home by dog sled and kayak early in ''Reckless, the Sequel.''

title: U.S. Officials Suspect Deadly Chemical Weapons in Yugoslav Army Arsenal
description: The United States believes that the Yugoslav army has stocks of lethal and nonlethal chemical weapons and that some of the less deadly forms have probably been given to the Serbian paramilitary forces that have terrorized Albanians in Kosovo, according to Pentagon and other Clinton Administration officials.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Yanks Are in the Way If It's a Gretzky Finale
description: The Rangers-Penguins game on Sunday afternoon may be Wayne Gretzky's farewell, but the full New York television market will not have full access to the complete game.

title: At Long Last, a New Sun With a Family of Planets
description: The solar system is not alone as an array of planets orbiting in the gravitational embrace of a shining star.

title: Blood Vessels Are Grown in Lab From the Cells of an Animal
description: Using a container built to pulse like a heart and act like a nurturing mother, a biomedical researcher has succeeded in growing blood vessels from a few cells of an animal and using them in the blood-vessel system of the same animal. Her achievement raises the hope that scientists can grow human blood vessels to help treat cardiovascular disease.

title: The Logic of Jaywalking
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.

title: Kittles's Slump Turning Into A Lost Season
description: It was the fourth quarter of the Nets' loss to the Los Angeles Clippers on Tuesday night, and Coach Don Casey was imploring his team to make one last push. He told Stephon Marbury to shoot 3-pointers, Keith Van Horn to draw fouls and Kendall Gill to make steals.

title: Big Yuks in the Big House For Two of the Old Jailbirds
description: ''Life'' packs Eddie Murphy and Martin Lawrence off to a Mississippi state prison and lets them trade quips while doing hard labor. It's hard to miss the basic unfunniness of this situation. (Nobody who saw last year's prize-winning prison documentary ''The Farm: Angola U.S.A.'' is liable to be in stitches.) But this mild-mannered comedy proves more likable than it sounds.

title: Britain Decides to Let the Pinochet Extradition Case Proceed
description: Britain gave an official go-ahead today to extradition proceedings against Gen. Augusto Pinochet, dashing his hopes of being freed to return to Chile and setting the stage for months of legal maneuvering over the request by Spain to try him on charges of crimes against humanity.

title: Stardom Drives 'Amy's View'
description: Pity the poor soul who has to argue that theater is dead while Judi Dench is standing nearby.

title: Court Backs Guiding Jury on Racial Factor
description: Supporting an argument that people frequently have a hard time identifying members of racial groups other than their own, the State Supreme Court has ruled that jurors in some circumstances should be given specific instructions about the potential problem of ''cross-racial recognition.''

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Colts Trade Faulk to Rams
description: The Indianapolis Colts traded running back Marshall Faulk to St. Louis yesterday, clearing the way for the Colts to go after Ricky Williams with the fourth pick in tomorrow's draft.

title: Recasting the Upbeat Spirits Of Swing and Dixieland
description: The powerful echoes of Stephane Grappelli and Bix Beiderbecke are the most pronounced influences that mesh in the seamless swing music of the Howard Fishman Quartet, an ensemble devoted to resurrecting the upbeat spirit of early-20th-century jazz and swing. The group, which is appearing at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel through April 24, homogenizes several currents of late-1920's and early-30's swing, adding flavors that include early bluegrass and extend back into the 19th century.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Pulls In Contributions

title: Costly Museum Visits
description: To the Editor:

title: German Account Posts a Surplus
description: Germany's current account swung into surplus in February, the Bundesbank said yesterday, as the deficit in ''invisible goods'' such as tourism and payments declined. Germany posted a current account surplus of 200 million euros ($216 million) in February, compared with a deficit of 4.3 billion euros the previous month. Analysts had expected a deficit of 700 million euros.

title: All-Star Cafe Chefs Charged in Theft of Actor's Rare Baseball Cards
description: Two chefs from the Official All-Star Cafe and two colleagues were charged in Federal court yesterday with pilfering rare baseball cards from the collection of the actor Charlie Sheen that were on display at the Times Square restaurant.

title: Mental Patient Testifies at a Hearing on His Release
description: Twenty years after he tortured, shot to death and cannibalized a Poughkeepsie teen-ager, Albert Fentress testified in court today for the first time, hoping to persuade a Suffolk County jury that he should be freed from a state psychiatric hospital.

title: IMI of Britain to Buy Plastic Pipe Maker
description: The British engineering company IMI P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $:337 million ($544 million) in cash for Polypipe P.L.C., a maker of plastic pipes, fitting systems and other plastic products.

title: Governor Seeks Compromise On Aid to Illegal Immigrants
description: Punting on the most politically fraught decision of his fledgling administration, Gov. Gray Davis announced today that he would ask a Federal appeals court to mediate the legal fight over Proposition 187, the ballot measure to end government services for illegal immigrants. The Governor's cautious step could be a way to reach a negotiated settlement without rankling his Hispanic supporters.

title: El-Amin Told To Give a Day To Community
description: Khalid El-Amin, the stocky point guard who led the University of Connecticut to the national basketball championship two weeks ago, will perform a day of community service after acknowledging in court today that he had possessed 4 grams of marijuana.

title: Life With Mother Can Be Erratic, to Say the Least
description: Kate Winslet knew best when she took on the offbeat adventure of ''Hideous Kinky'' after the outsized travails of making ''Titanic.'' She knew, among other things, that the central role in Gillies MacKinnon's voluptuously exotic new film would offer any actress a field day, and she makes the most of its rich possibilities. The time is 1972, the setting is Morocco, and the heroine is a young mother seeking a path to enlightenment no matter where that path leads her two young daughters. As such, ''Hideous Kinky'' belongs to the striking sub-genre in which it is the baby-boom adults, not their children, who most need to come of age.

title: Stock Split at Qualcomm
description: Qualcomm Inc. is splitting its common stock 2 for 1. On May 10, shareholders will receive one additional share for each share held as of April 21, the wireless communications company said late Wednesday. Qualcomm, based in San Diego, has about 70 million shares outstanding. The company had 1998 revenues of about $3 billion. Shares of Qualcomm closed at $157.75, down 18.75 cents, in Nasdaq trading.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about students' gains at Public School 115 in Washington Heights misstated the source of its ''far above average'' ranking for academic performance. Such rankings are issued by the New York City Board of Education on the basis of scores on citywide reading tests; they do not appear on New York State school report cards.

title: Rap Revolutionaries Plan an Internet Release
description: The rap group Public Enemy plans to release its new record through Atomic Pop, an Internet record label and Web site, allowing buyers to download the album from their computers. Executives at music and Internet businesses say this is the first time a well known, platinum-selling recording act has released a new album this way.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Pop is the latest downtown club-restaurant, yet another place with no sign out front, but one of the few that give the food star billing. The chef, Brian Young, was chef de cuisine at Le Bernardin, and here he has put together a menu to pique jaded taste buds. It's tucked into a white three-ring binder among list after list of wines and cocktails, single-malt Scotches, cognacs, eaux de vie and dessert wines.

title: United States Team Loses Davenport
description: Although the United States Fed Cup team gained home-court advantage for this weekend's first-round competition against Croatia, it lost half of its anticipated singles firepower yesterday when second-ranked Lindsay Davenport pulled out because of a nagging wrist sprain.

title: Record Revenues and Earnings Reported by Sun Microsystems
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. reported today that it had record revenues and earnings for its fiscal third quarter, as the maker of work stations and servers continued to gain market share. While Sun's earnings were just a penny above the consensus estimate, revenues were substantially higher than analysts' expectations.

title: Mireia Sentis: 'Black Suite'
description: Tribes Gallery

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Regrets Over 'a Loss of Innocent Life'
description: Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday to the Senate Armed Services Committee by Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen and Gen. Henry H. Shelton, Chairman, Joint Chiefs, as recorded by Federal News Service, a private company:

title: Six Decades of Transforming Persons Into Personas
description: As subjects for the camera, famous people are different from you and me. For one thing they have better props: for those in the cultural field, a piano, an easel, paint-stained clothes, rows of empty theater seats stretching behind them; for world leaders and politicians, an imposing office, a stately room or a columned facade. Then of course there is their fame, which lends a certain aura to even the most ordinary face.

title: Republicans Are Seizing the Democrats' Banner on Social Security
description: By tradition, it is the Democrats who speak of protecting Social Security. But today the Republicans were stealing their lines.

title: In Good Times, Who Really Gains?; Social Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Matter Over Mind: A Freudian Trove
description: How should we interpret the writings of Sigmund Freud? One way to regard him has always been as a literary figure rather than as a scientist. Thomas Mann once even endorsed Freud's nomination for the Nobel Prize in Literature.

title: Giulianis Report Income of $507,646 for '98
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his wife, Donna Hanover, released tax returns yesterday that showed the couple earned $507,646 last year, their highest annual income since Mr. Giuliani took office in 1994.

title: Korean Issue Signals a Possible Upturn in Emerging Markets
description: There were several new signs yesterday of healing in emerging financial markets as the Korean Development Bank sold $1 billion of bonds and Brazil indicated that it would soon be ready to return to the capital markets to borrow.

title: Don't Expect Safir to Hear The Bell Toll
description: THE League for the Hard of Hearing called this week, offering to test these old ears free on ''International Noise Awareness Day,'' next Wednesday. Can't make it, sorry to say.

title: Woman Who Shot Mother Will Not Face Charges
description: In yet another twist in an already convoluted case, an Essex County judge said yesterday that he would dismiss murder charges against a 41-year-old woman who recently confessed to killing her mother when she was 14 years old.

title: Grisly Accident in Kosovo
description: The whole point of NATO's air campaign against Serbia is to stop the killing and reverse the expulsion of Kosovo's persecuted ethnic Albanians. Yet on Wednesday a NATO pilot mistakenly bombed a convoy of Kosovo refugees headed toward the Albanian border, killing 72 of them, according to Serbian figures. It was a tragic and painfully ironic accident of war. But as President Clinton rightly noted yesterday, accidents are inseparable from war, and it would be a greater tragedy to slacken the bombardment or unduly restrict the military target list.

title: The Hills Are Alive, but, Alas, Ben's Dead
description: Easily the most bizarre creation of ''Goodbye Lover,'' a comically tinged film noir whose characters appear to be re-invented with each hairpin turn of its preposterous plot, is Sandra Dunmore (Patricia Arquette), a scheming femme fatale who spends nearly every waking minute listening to and singing along with the soundtrack of ''The Sound of Music.'' As the movie opens, Sandra is a Los Angeles real-estate agent married to Jake (Dermot Mulroney), a sullen public relations executive with a major substance abuse problem. At the same time, Sandra is secretly carrying on an affair with Jake's older brother, Ben (Don Johnson), whom she likes to handcuff to the furniture of her clients' fancy homes while they're out of the house.

title: In Good Times, Who Really Gains?; The Blame Game
description: To the Editor:

title: It's All but Over for Gretzky
description: Wayne Gretzky, one of Canada's best-known natural resources and the subject of great debate, both within his mind and among those all around him, was saluted tonight in what might have been his last game in his native land.

title: Residential Real Estate; Luxury Condominiums Seeing Strong Demand
description: Although the Chatham, a condominium tower taking shape on East 65th Street at the corner of Third Avenue, is not to be completed until the summer of 2000, contracts have been signed or are pending on 82 of its 92 apartments since sales began 10 weeks ago.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Anthony Newley, Film and Stage Showman, Dies at 67
description: Anthony Newley, the versatile British entertainer who achieved international stardom in 1961 with the musical ''Stop the World -- I Want to Get Off,'' died on Wednesday at his home in Jensen Beach, Fla. He was 67.

title: Give Mediation Another Try
description: Before our country steps any deeper into the Balkan conflict, it is essential that we stop and examine the Kosovo crisis in light of our vital national interests, our humanitarian obligations and our enduring need for a more peaceful, stable world. It would be a grave error to replace no long-term policy, which is what the Clinton Administration has executed thus far, with the wrong long-term policy.

title: Roche Holding Says New Products Lift Earnings
description: Roche Holding A.G. said today that sales rose 3.7 percent in the first quarter, fueled by revenue from its testing systems and new drugs, including the obesity treatment Xenical.

title: Fake Web Posting Leads to Fraud Charge
description: A 25-year-old computer engineer employed by Pairgain Technologies Inc. was arrested yesterday in North Carolina and charged with securities fraud in connection with the posting of a fake announcement on the Internet last week about a takeover of the company.

title: Uncompromising Views Of a Craggy Individualist
description: SEA BATTLES ON DRY LAND

title: Pfizer's Income Climbs by 18%
description: Pfizer Inc. posted an 18 percent increase in net income, matching forecasts, on revenue growth of 29 percent yesterday, driven by sales of products like the anti-impotence drug Viagra and the hypertension drug Norvasc.

title: Grey Official Quits Over Job in London
description: Carol Reay, deputy chairwoman at Grey Advertising U.K. in London, has resigned in a dispute over the top job there.

title: Law Isn't Clear On Assisted Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE ART
description: Museum Closes A Bank Deal

title: With a Field Reduced to One, Algerians Vote
description: Algeria went ahead today with a presidential election that seemed to mock the democratic process that the military rulers had promised, with a sole active candidate, favored by the army, nearly deserted polling places in many urban areas and a political outlook that appeared bleaker than when the election was called last fall.

title: Law Isn't Clear On Assisted Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: It's a Tough Job, but Someone Has to Be a Punk in Utah
description: Q: How does a punk apply for a job in a clothing store?

title: Big Bills on Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: Sony and I.B.M. Create Alliance On Delivering Music Over Net
description: Striking an alliance in the struggle to establish standards for delivering music over the Internet, the International Business Machines Corporation and Sony announced late yesterday that they would make their competing standards mutually compatible.

title: Shackleton and the James Caird
description: By coincidence, the work of the Australian photographer Frank Hurley, who died in 1962 at the age of 76, appears in two recently published books, ''The Endurance,'' by Caroline Alexander, and ''The Pity of War,'' by Niall Ferguson. Hurley's Antarctic photographs will also hang at the American Museum of Natural History through Oct. 11 in an exhibition called ''The Endurance.'' They capture the duress and beauty of Ernest Shackleton's miraculous Antarctic expedition with an immediacy that makes it seem strangely timeless. That is how it must have felt to Shackleton's men, too -- a case of infinite travail in a place cut off from what the rest of the world called time.

title: Legislators Told Air Plan Needs Time
description: President Clinton's two top military advisers today urged patience with an air campaign that they asserted could level the playing field for a resurgent Kosovar rebel force, a position that some lawmakers called an effort to deflect growing sentiment in Congress for ground troops in Kosovo.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in some editions on Wednesday about New York restaurants that are establishing branches in other cities misidentified the hotel in Las Vegas where Nobu plans to open. It is the Hard Rock Hotel, not the Venetian.

title: Robert Bordo: 'New Paintings'
description: Alexander and Bonin

title: FAMILY FARE
description: From White Cells To Weimaraners

title: Nicola Trussardi, 56, Who Led Family Fashion House in Italy
description: Nicola Trussardi, who diversified and expanded his family's small-town glove business into a multimillion-dollar fashion house, died on Wednesday in Milan of injuries suffered in an automobile accident. He was 56.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Tony Guessing Heats Up

title: Environment Chief Shifts Stand on Watershed
description: Retreating from a stance that had drawn widespread criticism, Joel A. Miele Sr., the New York City Commissioner of Environmental Protection, told a City Council committee yesterday that the wetlands around the city's upstate reservoirs need special Federal protection to preserve the quality of drinking water.

title: Erotica Dresses Up for Javits Show
description: The Baroness surveyed the wares at her booth at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in midtown Manhattan yesterday: the glistening black latex dresses and trousers, the hot pink plastic tank tops and bike shorts, the racks and racks of accessories for men, women and other customers who might quarrel with either classification.

title: The Message in the March
description: A rally near New York's fortified City Hall yesterday drew far fewer than the 25,000 protesters organizers had predicted to make their latest pitch against Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and his police policies. Still, the Mayor would be wise not to misread their numbers as a lack of concern in the city. The angry chants, the bitter placards, the voices of State Comptroller Carl McCall, Ossie Davis and Harry Belafonte all spoke for many residents who are deeply worried about relations between police and the minority community and dubious about Mayor Giuliani's ability to respond to their concerns.

title: NATO Admits the Mistaken Bombing of Civilians
description: NATO acknowledged today that an allied warplane had mistakenly bombed a civilian vehicle in southern Kosovo on Wednesday while trying to stop Serbian forces from attacking ethnic Albanians.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Eurotunnel's Revenue Rises on Freight Use
description: Eurotunnel P.L.C., the operator of the Channel Tunnel, said today that its first-quarter sales rose 18 percent as freight traffic soared to a monthly record in March.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- The Five Hundred; The Performance of S.& P.'s Benchmark Index Leaves Stock Funds in the Dust
description: Why is it so difficult for professional money managers to beat the market these days? And why does it seem to be getting tougher all the time?

title: 3 Are Killed And 5 Hurt In Shootout In Utah City
description: A gunman entered a genealogical library today at Temple Square, the heart of the Mormon Church, killed two people, wounded five more and died after a gun battle with police officers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GRAHAM-FIELD HEALTH PRODUCTS INC., Bay Shore, N.Y., a medical supply company, said it had hired the investment firm of Warburg Dillon Read L.L.C. to help it explore a sale of the company.

title: Earnings Are Flat at Deutsche Telekom
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. said today that its earnings were little changed in the first quarter and that it would sell as much as $12.7 billion in stock to finance acquisitions abroad.

title: Veterans of 60's Protests Meet the Newly Outraged in a March
description: They came because they always came. And they came because they never came.

title: Refugees, Scared and Scarred, Tell of Eviction by Serbs, Then a Bombing by Jets
description: A fierce roar split the sky and awakened her from an uneasy sleep. Before Ymer Qela knew what was happening she heard an explosion and tried desperately to protect herself, covering her head with her hands and folding herself into the cab of the crowded tractor on which she had been riding since Serbian troops emptied her village six hours before.

title: More Refugees Are Allowed To Flee, but Not All of Them
description: More than 3,000 new refugees fleeing from Kosovo crossed into Macedonia today, but ominous reports emerged from refugees that Yugoslav forces had ordered a train and two buses filled with Albanians back into the war-ravaged province just after they arrived within walking distance of the Macedonian border.

title: Jail Term Does Not Deter An Israeli Seeking Votes
description: Can a key Israeli power broker still make and break governments from a jail cell?

title: Big Utilities Are Cool to Plan To Make Market Competitive
description: The Clinton Administration's plan for opening the nation's $250 billion electricity market to competition received a lukewarm reception today from many of the largest power companies.

title: General Directs Air War, and His Son
description: The American general selecting the targets and directing the allied air war against Yugoslavia is also commanding his only son, who is piloting one of the A-10 jets flying missions over Kosovo.

title: Drawing on a Rich Lode of Shinto-Buddhist Culture
description: The Japanese-born artist Mariko Mori, 32, has been an art-world darling in the past few years, and it's easy to see why. Her videos and billboard-size computer-generated photographs, in all of which she appears, are smart, beguiling things, technologically at the head of the class and as laced with addictive riffs as inspired pop songs.

title: In Good Times, Who Really Gains?; Signs of Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: MacArthur's Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Cornell
description: Joseph Helman

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Houston's in Rush but Going Nowhere Fast
description: Allan Houston is not one to get a speeding ticket, cut in line at the grocery store or pry open a closing subway door. So it is a curious phenomenon to watch Houston, with his what's-the-rush personality, pick up the frenetic traits of the player he works beside, Latrell Sprewell.

title: Revisions And Revisionists
description: Unlike most documentaries, Joseph Dorman's ''Arguing the World'' has now touched all points of distribution since its completion in 1996. In 1997 it was shown at the Jewish Film Festival in New York, and in 1998 there was a short commercial run at Film Forum. In March it was on PBS, and on Tuesday it was released on home video by First Run Features.

title: Sports of The Times; Boss Owes Nothing To Darryl
description: THE phone rang at 8 in the morning, a little early for anything but trouble. It was the news that Darryl Strawberry had been picked up for solicitation and possession of cocaine -- the other shoe dropping. When it comes to dropped shoes, Darryl Strawberry is a veritable centipede.

title: China Says It's Official: Premier Zhu's U.S. Visit Was a Success
description: Officials and foreign policy experts here are calling Prime Minister Zhu Rongji's American visit a success.

title: Insurgent Slate Wins Postal Union Election
description: An insurgent slate won election this week to head the New York Metro Area Postal Union, which represents nearly 14,000 mail-sorting workers.

title: DeVito/Verdi Wins On Bottled Water
description: A bottled water company for which Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the advocate for clean water, is managing partner has named DeVito/Verdi in New York as its first agency. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.

title: Air of Change, Not Despair, In New Films From Britain
description: Nowhere more than in ''The Scar,'' a magnificently acted love story set in a desolate coal-mining town in County Durham on the northeastern coast of England, are the country's growing pains portrayed with more excruciating exactitude. The relationship that embodies those strains is a love affair that develops between May (Charlie Hardwick) and Roy (Bill Speed), two proud working-class Britons now in their 50's. May was once a fiery activist in the 1984-85 miners strike. Roy manages a nearby private open-cast mine run by a development company with plans to revitalize the region. May has two bitter teen-age children looking for a foothold in a community that disintegrated after the British Government closed the local mine and left the town in economic ruins. By falling in love with Roy, May, who is having severe physical problems connected with menopause, is, in effect, sleeping with the enemy. But if the two are on opposite sides of a political divide, the movie also shows them to be soul mates who share a salty humor and a fondness for the same 1950's show tunes.

title: U.N. Is Asked To Enlarge Iraq Inquiry
description: Britain and the Netherlands proposed today that the United Nations Special Commission, known as Unscom, be replaced by a new enlarged body to carry out more intrusive inspections of Iraq's suspected weapons sites.

title: William Bailey: 'Studio Fictions'
description: Robert Miller

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: She Wants To Direct. Soon.

title: PENTAGON TO ASK FOR WIDE CALL-UP AMONG RESERVISTS
description: The Pentagon plans to ask President Clinton for the authority to call up as many as 33,000 reservists and National Guard members to bolster the attack against Yugoslavia, significantly widening the American contribution to NATO's war in the Balkans, senior military and Administration officials said today.

title: The Anchor and the Anchor Who Held Her
description: FOR years after her dismissal by WWOR-TV, Sara Lee Kessler refused invitations to barbecues and bar mitzvahs, instead hiding out in her bedroom and wearing the same clothes day after day.

title: WESTLINKS WITHDRAWS BID FOR STAKES IN 40 COMPANIES
description: Westlinks Resources Ltd. withdrew a two-day-old bid to buy stakes totaling about $1.7 billion in more than 40 Canadian petroleum companies after regulators refused to let the offer proceed. Westlinks said the Ontario and Alberta securities commissions had told the company that its plans to create a sort of mutual fund containing interests in some of Canada's biggest oil companies was not in the public interest. Westlinks, a Calgary, Alberta, petroleum company with market capitalization of less than $4 million (Canadian), wanted to issue 1.68 billion shares that it would trade for stakes in Anderson Exploration Ltd., Poco Petroleums Ltd. and a host of other companies.

title: Doubts Raised on a Breast Cancer Procedure
description: Four major studies reported yesterday show that high-dose chemotherapy followed by a bone-marrow transplant, a grueling procedure held out as a hope to many women with advanced breast cancer, does not prolong their survival over all. But the medical group that announced the findings cautioned that it was still too soon to pass final judgment on the procedure.

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review on Wednesday about Le Gans in Greenwich Village mistranslated a French dish that is served there. Carre d'agneau en croute is rack of lamb in pastry, not saddle of lamb in pastry.

title: Trustee for School Construction Agency Named
description: A lawyer known for representing clients with intricate legal difficulties was named yesterday as a trustee of a state agency that might well benefit from his skills.

title: Solzhenitsyn, the Son, in a Spotlight All His Own as Pianist and Conductor
description: At this point in Ignat Solzhenitsyn's fledgling career as a pianist and conductor, people who have not heard him before inevitably come to his concerts with the combination of curiosity, hope and skepticism that attends performances by children of the famous.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Brazil Rebuts Currency Insider Charges
description: The president of Brazil's central bank sought today to defuse a potentially explosive congressional investigation into Government support of the banking system during the nation's currency crisis in January, rejecting assertions by lawmakers that his institution acted illegally.

title: Ford and G.M. Post Increases in Earnings
description: Cashing in on very strong sales of high-profit sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks in the United States, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company today posted increases in operating earnings during the first quarter that were even larger than financial analysts had expected.

title: Boeing Profits Beat Forecast By 7 cents a Share
description: The Boeing Company showed yesterday that it can build a lot of airplanes and make money, too, something that many on Wall Street had begun to doubt.

title: New Video Releases
description: A Bug's Life

title: A $2.7 Billion Purchase In Chemicals
description: The Huntsman Corporation said yesterday that it would pay $2.7 billion for control of four businesses owned by Imperial Chemical Industries of Britain, a deal that would make Huntsman the world's largest privately held chemical company.

title: Solzhenitsyn, the Son
description: The 26-year-old Ignat Solzhenitsyn (above) has been performing publicly as a pianist since his teens. Since 1994 he has been conducting the Concerto Soloists Chamber Orchestra in Philadelphia, and in January he became its principal conductor. And though his famous father, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, may have brought him attention that other young musicians must fight harder to win, he has proved that he can hold the spotlight on his own.

title: Zimmer Hopes to Regain Former Seat in Congress
description: Richard A. Zimmer, who represented central New Jersey for three terms in Congress, announced yesterday that he would try to regain his old job next year.

title: Blackened Bodies and a Half-Eaten Meal
description: Along a seven-mile stretch of the Djakovica-Prizren road in southwestern Kosovo, lined with the burned-out houses of ethnic Albanians, about a dozen blackened bodies lay today for journalists to see.

title: Mike Kelley
description: Metro Pictures

title: And Tonight's Star Will Be . . .
description: The women of a certain age are smiling. Looking into the faces up and down the aisles, you can see the pleasure in their eyes, sense the frisson the moment holds. Now they are breaking into warm and unexpectedly sustained applause: it's only a kiss, for Pete's sake. More to the point, it's only ''The Sound of Music.''

title: Diallo Rally Focuses on Call For Strong Oversight of Police
description: A multiracial throng of thousands marched in memory of Amadou Diallo yesterday, shutting down half the Brooklyn Bridge and several streets in downtown Brooklyn and lower Manhattan during the afternoon rush as they chanted about justice and peace.

title: Culpepper, a Big Quarterback, Is Seeking His Fit
description: Daunte Culpepper stood in a Gentleman's Quarterly fitting room yesterday afternoon, slipping on GQ styles. The National Football League draft had gone Madison Avenue. And Culpepper, Central Florida's Herculean quarterback in town for tomorrow's draft, liked the fit.

title: Accounts
description: * PNC Bank Corp., Pittsburgh, to Doner, Southfield, Mich., to handle its account, which had been divided between Ketchum Advertising Pittsburgh, part of Omnicom Group, and McKinney & Silver, Raleigh, N.C., part of U S Web/CKS Group. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: STERICYCLE IN $440 MILLION DEAL WITH ALLIED
description: Stericycle Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $440 million for the medical waste operations that Allied Waste Industries will acquire when it completes the purchase of Browning Ferris Industries. With the purchase, Stericycle, a medical waste disposal company based in Deerfield, Ill., will add 200,000 customers to its current base of 78,000, as well as $198 million in annual revenue to the $67 million it reported for last year. Allied Waste, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., a waste collection and disposal company, described the unit as a noncore asset. Last month, Allied Waste agreed to acquire Browning Ferris of Houston, the nation's second-largest waste-hauling company, for $45 a share, or $7.3 billion. Allied is No. 3.

title: Met Streak Is Halted In a Flurry Of Hits
description: First, the Mets' starting pitcher failed. Then the bullpen, which had been nearly flawless, followed suit. And on one strikeout, the Mets drew mock cheers when catcher Mike Kinkade threw the ball into left field while trying to toss it around the horn.

title: TERUMO SAYS IT WILL BUY 3M'S CARDIOVASCULAR DIVISION
description: The Terumo Corporation, Japan's largest medical equipment supplier, said yesterday that it would buy the cardiovascular division of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company for more than $100 million in cash. Terumo did not disclose the acquisition terms. The acquisition of 3M's cardiovascular business, which has annual sales of $100 million, will enable Terumo to supply all the equipment needed for open heart surgery. 3M, the maker of more than 50,000 industrial and consumer products, is undergoing a reorganization. Shares of 3M rose $4, to $79.25.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro fell after a European Central Bank official warned the nations using the currency to handle more of the burden of reviving their economies. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0703, down from $1.0800.

title: Equipment Snarls Emissions Tests
description: REVISED New York State emissions testing program is leaving its own trail of exhaust. Service stations and dealers complain about late installation and frequent breakdowns of the new high-technology equipment used to check vehicle emissions, and some motorists have had difficulty finding stations that can test their cars before the inspection stickers expire.

title: Two in the Top 10 No Longer Unbeaten
description: Duke and Delaware, second and sixth in this week's Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association poll, each lost for the first time on Wednesday, leaving Loyola of Maryland, No. 1 in the poll, as the only unbeaten team in Division I.

title: James Nares
description: Paul Kasmin Gallery

title: Estelle Sapir, 73, Who Fought Bank Over Holocaust Assets
description: Estelle Sapir, a Holocaust survivor who won a rare recovery of the family funds she had sought for half a century from a Swiss bank, died on Tuesday at her home in Far Rockaway, Queens. She was 73.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Here for the first time, we can see a kinship between these planets and our own solar system.''

title: New Rules Seek to Aid Global Phone Rate Cuts
description: United States regulators adopted new rules today aimed at cutting the cost of international telephone calls.

title: Earnings Up at Delta as Continental's Sag
description: Delta Air Lines Inc., the nation's third-largest carrier, said today that its fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 10.8 percent, surpassing expectations, as it picked up business from canceled flights at American Airlines. Meanwhile, Continental Airlines Inc. said its first-quarter profit fell 3.7 percent, a smaller drop than expected.

title: 2 Agencies Formed In Several Deals
description: Two agencies are being formed through mergers and acquisitions.

title: City Council in Capital Backs Tax Cuts to Stimulate Growth
description: In the latest measure of the District of Columbia's march from annual budget deficits to surpluses, a majority of the City Council members today proposed cutting taxes for residents by $418 million as an economic stimulus.

title: Strawberry's Arrest Could Put an End To a Career
description: In the latest chapter of his troubled life, Darryl Strawberry now awaits the outcome of his arrest Wednesday night on charges of cocaine possession and solicitation of prostitution. Others who will control his future in baseball are waiting, too.

title: '174th Annual Exhibition'
description: National Academy of Design

title: A Top Citigroup Executive Plans to Retire This Year
description: Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services concern, said yesterday that William I. Campbell, co-head of its lucrative and far-flung consumer banking business, will retire later this year to ''pursue other interests.''

title: Ski Weekend: It's Very Warm in the Lodge
description: The only glimmer of humor to be salvaged from ''Friends and Lovers,'' an inept farce with the mentality of a tittering 15-year-old boy peering under the bedcovers with a flashlight, emanates from Robert Downey Jr.'s clownish portrayal of Hans, a bogus German ski instructor. During a Christmas weekend in Park City, Utah, Hans successfully lures Carla (Claudia Schiffer), a dim-witted aspiring model, from the clutches of her Neanderthal suitor, Jon (Stephen Baldwin), by teaching her how to meditate.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the European Union's plan for settling the Kosovo crisis described the union incorrectly in some copies. It does in fact deal with defense issues and is striving for a common foreign and defense policy.

title: Metro Business; Jobless Rate Plunges In New York City
description: The unemployment rate in New York City dropped sharply in March, to 6.4 percent, a level not seen for a decade, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

title: Movies' Greatest Hits, With the Big Hit Makers
description: Catherine Deneuve, Alain Delon, Robert De Niro and Gerard Depardieu all make brief guest appearances in Agnes Varda's 1995 film ''A Hundred and One Nights'' opening today at Cinema Village. And those are just the D's. For this delirious birthday party in honor of filmmaking's first century, Ms. Varda has made every grand allusion she can manage and drawn upon every droppable name and celebrity connection. She creates a whirl of film's greatest hits, an overripe variety show that plays like the ultimate round of Trivial Pursuit.

title: Reactions of Women With Cancer
description: Until a few months ago, Donna Bowers's life mirrored a million other women's lives. She juggled family and career, rearing her two little girls and working as a lawyer and health information manager at Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas. The future stretched ahead to a far horizon, and like most people, she did not think about the prospect of her time running out.

title: Investigating Roots, and Everything That Nourishes, or Devastates, Them
description: Robert Frank's recent photographs have messages scratched into them and labels scrawled onto them. They are packed with recycled objects and pictures, verbal and visual puns and frames within frames within frames. Describing them is a lesson in madness. So here goes.

title: St. Louis: The River Runs by It, History Through It
description: In 1904, St. Louis was the fourth largest American city. It was rich, river-rich, thanks to the Mississippi, then the nation's main north-south artery. Although Chicago had developed into the dominant railroad hub, St. Louis deemed itself the rightful capital of the Middle West.

title: To Save the Kosovars, Go After Milosevic
description: To the Editor:

title: Algerians Protest Election With an Unsurprising Winner
description: Police officers with batons broke up street demonstrations in central Algiers and two other cities today after a candidate backed by the army, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, was declared the winner of a presidential election marred by allegations of extensive vote rigging. At the last minute, all other candidates withdrew from the ballot in protest.

title: About New York; Air and Light: Helping a City Keep Its Soul
description: FRED KENT walked toward Seventh Avenue along West 43d Street, pausing in mid-stride to enjoy -- nothing. He beheld the intersection's southwest corner, where a building had been razed months earlier to create -- for now -- an open space. Mr. Kent could see the tip of the Empire State Building looming elegantly beyond. Standing on 43d Street, he could actually get an unusual panoramic view of the buildings and billboards.

title: ALBEMARLE RAISES OFFER FOR ALBRIGHT & WILSON
description: The Albemarle Corporation increased its friendly bid yesterday for Albright & Wilson P.L.C., the world's No. 1 maker of phosphates for detergents, to $810 million from $657 million, topping a bid from Rhodia S.A. Albemarle, a United States specialty-chemicals maker, offered to buy Albright for $2.56 a share, after its offer of $2.08 last month was beaten by Rhodia's bid of $2.35 a week later. The battle for Albright pits the Richmond-based Albemarle against the world's No. 4 specialty-chemical maker, Rhodia, which is seven times its size in sales and is 67 percent owned by the French drug maker Rhone-Poulenc S.A. The purchase would more than double Albemarle's $821 million in annual sales and give it a leading position in phosphates.

title: J.D. Had the Great Schmooze, But Without the Big Question
description: John Davidson, the Rangers' MSG Network and Fox analyst, never asked Wayne Gretzky about retiring. Three times since last week, Davidson told television audiences with increasing certainty that the end was near for Gretzky's career. He said on Fox last Sunday that retirement was an 80 percent possibility.

title: Price for Patients' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Beijing Journal; Why China Picks on the Hatchbacks
description: All morning long, a steady stream of grumpy, forlorn-looking drivers dutifully steered their cars out of the flowing traffic on Changan Avenue, made a sweeping right turn and landed in the far-as-you-can-see gridlock of the Second Ring Road.

title: Gretzky, Hockey's No. 1 Scorer, Retires With Rinkful of Records
description: Wayne Gretzky was a hockey artist in a sport often stereotyped for brute force and violent intimidation, using his stick as a paintbrush and his skates as dance slippers. Over two decades, he became the National Hockey League's career leader in points and goals, a nine-time most valuable player who not only dominated his sport competitively but helped spread its popularity past the borders of his native Canada to new markets in the United States.

title: U.S. Gets No Support For China Resolution
description: The United States submitted a resolution criticizing China's human rights record to the main United Nations rights body today, but it was unable to get any other country to sign on as a co-sponsor.

title: Crackdown on Schizophrenics Is Urged After Utah Shooting
description: For the second time in three months, this conservative city grappled today with news that a schizophrenic resident who refused to take medication had walked up to strangers and shot them dead.

title: Clinton Should Work Toward a Deal on Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Marine Training to Be Moved Out of Italy
description: With the United States strictly observing Italian rules on low-altitude flights since a Marine jet severed a ski gondola cable last year, killing 20 people, Italy is now unsuitable for some essential training, an American admiral said today.

title: New Nassau Democratic Leader Seeks Party Unity
description: State Assemblyman Thomas P. Di Napoli, who was elected chairman of the Nassau County Democratic Party at a raucous but harmonious convention on Thursday night, today called on party workers to stay united and work for the defeat of Republicans in the fall.

title: Halt for War Over, Clinton Resumes Fund-Raising
description: Ending his self-imposed moratorium on fund-raising, President Clinton was back on the money circuit today after 23 days, bringing in $1.3 million for Democratic candidates at two events.

title: In Kosovo, Empty Towns, Burned Homes and Shops
description: The evidence of ethnic purging here in Kosovo is written upon the doorposts of their houses and upon their gates.

title: Price for Patients' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hacker's Haunting Vision of a Reality Within Illusion
description: Forget about waking up as an insect, or whatever it is that Gregor Samsa becomes in Kafka's tale. Judging from ''The Matrix,'' the nation's top grossing film the last three weeks, when we awaken we won't find that we have become bugs. We'll find that we're their servants. Or at least the servants of creepy machines that look like bugs.

title: Delta Suspends Tie With Korean Airline
description: Delta Air Lines Inc., the third-largest United States carrier, said today that it had suspended its flying partnership with Korean Airlines because of accidents on the Asian airline.

title: Sports of The Times; Under That Hair Is Glimpse Into Future
description: EXPERTS are calling today's National Football League draft revolutionary, largely because the sport's most exalted position -- quarterback -- appears to be undergoing a fundamental change.

title: To Retain Power, India's Rulers Woo Small Parties
description: For the moment, small-time politicians are kingmakers here.

title: L.A. Gets Serious. Seriously.
description: Stanley Sheinbaum, the publisher of New Perspectives Quarterly, was standing by the window lamenting the lack of ideological commitment among Hollywood executives. ''They give their money away purely for ego rather than because they identify with any particular cause,'' he said, his black turtleneck setting off his white hair.

title: Spare Me the Galactic Humility
description: ''Isn't it humbling?'' This is the question that typically greets an extraordinary cosmological breakthrough, like Thursday's announcement that astronomers have for the first time identified a solar system with planets that revolve around a star other than the Sun. Often this sentiment is accompanied by an elaboration on our insignificance: we are but the blink-of-an-eye inhabitants of one of several specks of dust circling an ordinary star at the edge of an average galaxy among 125 billion others in the universe!

title: Chief Was Paid $73 Million In Last Year, Ford Discloses
description: Alex Trotman received more than $73 million in his last year of leading the Ford Motor Company, although Graef Crystal, the compensation expert, said Mr. Trotman might have deserved more during a period when Ford's shares rose 82 percent.

title: Most Get Work After Welfare, Studies Suggest
description: From Idaho to South Carolina, a growing collection of state reports are coalescing into a preliminary but increasingly suggestive picture of the fates of the millions of Americans who have left the welfare rolls under new restrictions, from the success many have at finding jobs to the hunger some endure.

title: Haitink Leads the Boston In an Impassioned Brahms First
description: Boston Symphony Orchestra

title: Turkey's Missed Chance
description: More than 10,000 Kosovo refugees have arrived in Turkey since the beginning of the NATO air strikes in Yugoslavia. Turkey, NATO's only Muslim member and a key American ally linked to the Balkans by 500 years of Ottoman rule, is playing an active role in the crisis. Its planes are involved in the air operations, the Government has signaled its willingness to send ground troops if necessary, and it has been active in humanitarian efforts.

title: Refugee Flow Resumes
description: Ten days ago, thousands of refugees waiting to enter Macedonia were herded back into Kosovo by Serbian forces. The flow has reversed, and some newly arrived Kosovars tell of their ordeals. Page A9.

title: Greenspan Denounces Growing Protectionism
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, waded into the escalating debate over trade policy today, denouncing growing protectionist pressures and arguing that pockets of workers sometimes had to suffer in order for the nation to prosper.

title: 3 Men Are Shot Inside Brooklyn Movie Theater
description: Three men were shot and wounded in a crowded movie theater in Brooklyn last night by a man who then fled, the police said.

title: Prosecutor Releases Man Charged in Policewoman's Death
description: Six days after they charged a man with murdering an Orange, N.J., policewoman, the authorities let him go last night, saying that he could not have been at the scene of the shooting when it happened.

title: LANCE AGREES TO ACQUIRE CAPE COD POTATO CHIP
description: Lance Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Cape Cod Potato Chip Company, a manufacturer of kettle-cooked potato chips and other salty snacks that are distributed in the United States, Canada, Spain and England. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Annual sales of Cape Cod, a privately held company based in Hyannis, Mass., are about $30 million. Lance, Inc., with headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., manufactures and markets snack foods.

title: U.N. Accuses Yugoslavia
description: The United Nations refugee agency today accused Yugoslavia of trying to expel the entire ethnic Albanian population from Kosovo, where Albanians had made up 90 percent of the population.

title: Canucks Sign Steve Kariya
description: The Vancouver Canucks today signed the free-agent wing Steve Kariya, a younger brother of the Anaheim Mighty Ducks star Paul Kariya.

title: In Letter to Environmental Groups, Clinton Firmly Defends Gore Record
description: President Clinton sent environmental groups a letter today that aggressively defends Vice President Al Gore's record on their issues -- a highly unusual move that underscores the President's commitment to promoting Mr. Gore's Presidential prospects.

title: House Panel Subpoenas Democratic Fund-Raiser
description: A Congressional committee sent a subpoena today to Johnny Chung, the former Democratic fund-raiser who has told Justice Department investigators that he funneled tens of thousands of dollars from two high-level Chinese military officials to President Clinton's re-election effort in 1996.

title: Leader of Chirac Party Quits, Citing French Right's Disarray
description: The leader of President Jacques Chirac's Gaullist party resigned unexpectedly today, indirectly accusing Mr. Chirac of undermining his position and throwing France's conservative opposition into fresh disarray.

title: Couch to Browns Is Likely, the Rest Is Uncertain
description: When quarterback Tim Couch worked out with the Cleveland Browns for a second time last week, his passes had more zip and his step had an extra bounce. The Browns' management saw enough to feel comfortable with the fact that Couch could lead the team for the next 10 years.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the Macedonian Government's fears that Yugoslavia is trying to destabilize the country recounted the history of the 12,000 NATO troops in Macedonia incorrectly. Some 1,800 arrived last October and the rest this year. They have not been there since 1995.

title: Beliefs; For religious leaders and ethicists, there is a need for clarity in addressing the moral questions raised by the war in Serbia.
description: Charles W. Colson, once a proud tough guy for the Nixon Administration but for many years now a prominent conservative religious leader, says NATO's air war against Serbia fails to meet the traditional Christian criteria for a morally just war.

title: A Remarkable Partnership Now Includes Two Writers
description: The world's best players rarely write books on the game, perhaps because they have no writing skill or perhaps because they do not wish to reveal their secrets to their rivals. One exception is Zia Mahmood, a colorful character who was born in Pakistan and now lives in Manhattan when not touring the bridge world. His partner, Michael Rosenberg, has now followed on that path with ''Bridge, Zia . . . and Me,'' available from Baron Barclay Bridge Supplies for $18.95 including shipping at (800) 274-2221.

title: Woman Is Sentenced In Faked Drowning
description: A woman who admitted to helping her boyfriend fake his drowning during a hurricane last summer was sentenced yesterday to three years' probation and ordered to pay a $5,000 fine, county prosecutors said.

title: Clinton: U.S. Is Fighting For the World's Future
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's speech yesterday in Roseville, Mich., as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private company:

title: Nuclear Labs Open After Scare Over Spying
description: Energy Secretary Bill Richardson has authorized the resumption of work on computer networks containing the nation's most sensitive nuclear secrets, two weeks after he ordered them shut down over concerns about lax security at weapons laboratories.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Either we are the envy of the nation or the laughingstock. I haven't decided.''

title: Telling Stories to Survive The Absence of a Future
description: The genuine raconteurs of this world often occupy the lower orders of society. It is the vagrants, street people, laborers and menials who practice the gift of anecdote with such superior grace, for telling things well is for them an act of survival. Listen to Robert Ashley, the central voice in his new opera, ''Dust,'' at the Kitchen on Wednesday night:

title: Mary Lutyens, English Editor, Novelist and Biographer, 90
description: Mary Lutyens, a well-born English biographer and novelist who was applauded by critics on both sides of the Atlantic, died on April 9 in London. She was 90 and lived in London and the English county of Dorset.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Jones Industrials Rise To Fifth Consecutive High

title: A New Player Enters Italian Phone Contest
description: Telecom Italia S.p.A., trying to thwart a hostile takeover bid by its main domestic rival, is discussing a possible merger with Deutsche Telekom A.G., Italian officials and others close to the companies said today.

title: Fairfield Students End Sit-In Backing Janitors
description: Thirty-nine students ended an 11-hour sit-in at Fairfield University in Connecticut yesterday after the university made a modest concession to their demand that its 60 janitors be granted union recognition.

title: Earnings Slip at Caterpillar, But Drop Is Below Forecast
description: Caterpillar Inc., which had sounded an earnings warning last month, posted a decline in quarterly profit today that was smaller than analysts' latest forecasts.

title: Hasta la Vista, Oil Kings; Venezuela Tightens Grip on State Petroleum Company
description: The giant state-owned oil company Petroleos de Venezuela S.A. typically holds important meetings in its sleek, towering headquarters here. In late March, however, the country's new President, Hugo Chavez Frias, convened a special session of the company's board at Miraflores Palace, where he has his office.

title: Helping The Refugees
description: These are some of the organizations with workers on the ground helping Kosovo refugees. Updates on their activities are at:

title: Does Ethicist's Theory of Cumulative Happiness Really Add Up?; A Common Creed
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Finds Bias at Hospital In Dealings With Deaf Man
description: Mount Sinai Medical Center illegally discriminated against the deaf husband of a pregnant woman by refusing to provide a sign language interpreter while the couple were attending Lamaze classes, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the News Corporation's growing role in regional sports television misidentified the company that is working with the News Corporation's Fox Sports Net unit to create a service called Fox Sports Net Interactive. It is ACTV Inc., not Access TV.

title: Hernandez Struggles, and So Do Suddenly Sluggish Yanks
description: Orlando Hernandez came to this country 13 months ago, knowing little English beyond the names of baseball teams. He conducted his first full post-game interview in his second language tonight.

title: Quarantine Zone Created To Contain Asian Beetle
description: Two months after local officials spotted the Asian long-horned beetle in Bayside, Queens, the State Department of Agriculture and Markets has created a 7.5-square mile beetle quarantine zone in the northeast corner of Queens. Under the quarantine, any firewood or yard waste that includes wood would have to be inspected by state or Federal officials before it is removed from the area.

title: As Fires Afflict a Parched Florida, More Are Expected
description: Severe drought, coupled with record high temperatures and high winds, have fueled dozens of fires across Florida this month. Several were still burning late today, and officials said they expected more fires over the weekend.

title: Tom Patten, 73; Helped Develop North Sea Oil
description: Tom Patten, a British marine scientist and offshore engineer who played a key role in unlocking the gas and oil deposits beneath the North Sea, died on April 10 at a hospital in Edinburgh, where he lived. He was 73.

title: Clash of the Spokesmen, Confusion of the Media
description: The confusion about whether NATO accidentally bombed civilian refugees in Kosovo reflects both the novelty of the first real air war that the alliance has ever fought and the determination of its American military commander to control everything NATO says about air strikes even while he runs the war.

title: Preaching to the Converted About the Problem of Evil
description: If truth were art, this world would brim with poetry.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: The Last Thousand Years
description: Big birthdays are occasions for reflection as well as celebration, and it is difficult to imagine a bigger birthday than the one that is fast approaching: the birth of a new millennium. Starting tomorrow, The New York Times Magazine will mark the occasion with six special issues that look back on the last 1,000 years.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Prices rose 2.7 percent as members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries reduced deliveries as part of an agreement reached last month. The May contract rose 46 cents, to $17.33 a barrel.

title: At Home Abroad; Engine For Change
description: ''Optimism is the engine for change,'' Nerea Abasolo said. ''In a climate without hope -- which is where we were in the Basque Country -- even people with money won't invest. But when you see things are happening around you, you want to join in.''

title: Baseball Wants to Have Strawberry Take Test for Drugs
description: In the aftermath of Darryl Strawberry's arrest Wednesday night on charges of cocaine possession and solicitation of prostitution, Major League Baseball has sought to administer a drug test to the Yankees outfielder.

title: Wary Wife Forms Party As Malaysia Jails Spouse
description: For 75 days, she sat in the gallery of an austere courtroom here, bearing silent witness to the trial of her husband, Anwar Ibrahim, the ousted Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN STRENGTHENS. The dollar fell for the sixth day in seven against the yen after Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said Japan might consider a tax cut. In New York, the dollar fell to 117.90 yen, from 118.83 Thursday.

title: Dr. Edmund Braun, 81, Health Advocate for Poor
description: Edmund M. Braun, a psychiatrist and labor advocate who worked to obtain better health care for the poor and Social Security coverage for physicians, died April 10 at his home in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: A Crusade of Children; Teen-Ager Enlists Peers in a Fight Against Child Labor
description: The 40 teen-agers did not know what to expect when they piled into their school library to listen to the 16-year-old boy from Canada.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Illustrating a Fairy Tale With the Orchestration
description: New Millennium Ensemble

title: In Britain, $9.6 Billion Retail Merger by Kingfisher and Asda
description: Kingfisher P.L.C., Britain's sixth-largest retailer, will buy the supermarket chain Asda Group P.L.C. for $9.6 billion in stock, the companies announced today. Such a merger would create the biggest British retailer, with the ability to expand through acquisitions into Continental Europe.

title: Clinton Should Work Toward a Deal on Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: The Generosity of John Singer Sargent
description: In a room full of John Singer Sargent's portraits, a certain augustness smites the viewer. The figures of Lord Dalhousie and Lord Ribblesdale, of Sir Frank Swettenham and Madame X form a striking assembly.
