They could not, at first glance, be more unlike the casual crowd that wanders, in the loose clothing and comfortable shoes of resolute sightseers, through the National Gallery in Washington, where the Sargent exhibition is on display until May 31. No matter how you dress, there is something a little intimidating about Dalhousie, Ribblesdale et al., even if it is nothing more than the height at which they hang from the walls, a height that forces them to look down upon you.

title: Valhol Camp Denies That Jockey Used a Shock Device
description: Valhol, the 30-1 shot who won the Arkansas Derby and touched off an investigation, galloped over the Churchill Downs track in Louisville, Ky., for the first time yesterday morning in preparation for the Kentucky Derby while his owner and trainer issued strong denials of any wrongdoing by their jockey.

title: Are Girls Not Letting Boys Be Boys?
description: In a twist on the sexual harassment charges that provide television with a steady stream of horror stories, the participants in ''The War on Boys,'' tomorrow's edition of ''National Desk,'' make a case that boys are being maltreated by women. In feminists' drive for ''gender equity,'' these cheerleaders for masculinity charge, fundamental differences between boys and girls are being ignored to the detriment of the boys.

title: Price for Patients' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils Face a Finale of Double Signifiance
description: The Devils' regular-season finale Saturday night in Nashville will have double significance. A victory would capture first place in the Eastern Conference and break Montreal's record for road victories in a season.

title: Praise Pours In For a Legend
description: ''The game is always bigger than any individual. Maybe with the exception of Wayne, who has really transcended the game when he first came into the National Hockey League and changed the way the game was looked at and the way it was played.''

title: Dow Gains 31.17 as Shift From Technology Continues
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose to a fifth consecutive record as Eastman Kodak soared on unexpectedly strong earnings. Two stocks rose for every one that fell on the New York Stock Exchange, the best performance in six weeks.

title: A Limit on Jury Sequestration
description: A new study by New York's Office of Court Administration provides ample justification for abandoning the state's foolish policy of requiring the sequestration of deliberating jurors in all trials involving violent crimes. That policy, ostensibly designed to insure the integrity of criminal proceedings, requires that jurors be housed overnight and guarded round the clock even in low-profile cases where there is scant danger of outside pressure.

title: Clinton Should Work Toward a Deal on Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: California Governor Ducked Immigrant Feud, Some Say
description: A day after Gov. Gray Davis asked a Federal appeals court to mediate a dispute over a ballot measure that would end government services to illegal immigrants and their children, some advocates for immigrants expressed their dismay, contending that the Governor had taken the easy way out.

title: A Kind of Shy Counterpoint That's Rarely Heard Today
description: The music made by the pianist Lennie Tristano and his students doesn't come out and shake a listener. You have to follow it into the dark corners where it's gone to hide; the music is shy and seemingly anti-dramatic. At Birdland on Thursday night, two of Mr. Tristano's students, the saxophonists Lee Konitz and Ted Brown, put on a show that, like Lewis Carroll's Cheshire Cat, nearly disappeared in its self-effacement.

title: Gigante's Lawyers Say Jurors Improperly Discussed His Case
description: Lawyers for the imprisoned Mafia boss Vincent Gigante say they will seek to overturn his conspiracy-to-murder and racketeering convictions because they have evidence that the jurors at his 1997 trial improperly discussed the case among themselves throughout the trial.

title: Birth Mix-Up Avoidable, Inquiry Finds
description: In the case of mixed-up embryos that caused a white Staten Island woman who underwent in vitro fertilization to give birth to two sons of different races, a state inquiry has concluded that the embryologist knew another couple's embryos had been implanted but failed to tell anyone at the time or to act to correct his error.

title: Majoli Plays RubinIn First Match
description: Iva Majoli of Croatia decided she liked the luck of the Fed Cup draw yesterday in Raleigh, N.C. In the first of five matches against the United States this weekend, Majoli, the 32d-ranked player, is scheduled to face No. 23 Chanda Rubin, the last-minute singles replacement for the injured Lindsay Davenport. In the second singles match, third-ranked Monica Seles, who has an 8-0 Fed Cup record, will meet 70th-ranked Silvja Talaja for the first time.

title: After Convoy Bombing, U.S. Accuses Milosevic of 'Orwellian' Misstatements
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen today accused President Slobodan Milosevic of an ''Orwellian twisting of language and logic'' to describe the bombing of a Kosovo refugee convoy on Wednesday, while ''not allowing his people to see the kind of horrific damage that he is causing to hundreds of thousands of people.''

title: A Cancer Treatment Under a Cloud
description: Nearly 15 years ago, when some cancer experts began to promote the use of high-dose chemotherapy followed by bone marrow transplant as treatment for late-stage breast cancer, other scientists objected strenuously. The latter pointed to holes in the evidence and argued that the high-risk treatment needed more investigation. Insurers, who by contract do not pay for experimental treatments, tried to hold the line.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FPL GROUP INC., an electric utility holding company, said it would take a pretax charge of $160 million to $180 million against second-quarter earnings to reflect a drop in the value of newly acquired power plants in Maine.

title: Leiter and Mets Can't Figure Out How to Bounce Back from a Bad Bounce
description: Al Leiter is still looking for his first victory. He was undermined last night by a fluke hop on a little grounder that left Robin Ventura staring at the third-base line with a dazed expression on his face.

title: Ventura Is Leading, but Is Offering No Examples
description: In a state Capitol reception room ornamented with marble fireplaces and crystal chandeliers, Gov. Jesse Ventura, wearing blue jeans and white socks and looking like someone who could use a shave, was talking -- roaring, actually -- about running for President.

title: Serbian Bombs Fall Close To City Full of Refugees
description: The shelling of the outskirts of this city full of Kosovo refugees and the increasingly bold presence of the Kosovo Liberation Army here have raised concerns that the city itself may come under attack by Serbian shelling.

title: On Tax Day, I.R.S. Prepared To Fire Star Whistle-Blower
description: As millions of Americans were filing their returns on tax day, the Houston office of the Internal Revenue Service was in the process of firing the first internal revenue agent to publicly blow the whistle about agency abuses.

title: A Rap Performer Is Charged With Assaulting a Producer
description: Sean Combs, the rap performer and producer, was arrested yesterday and charged with taking part in battering an executive at Universal Records with a Champagne bottle, a chair and a telephone.

title: Hunting for Fun and 'Charity'
description: Visitors to the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History will soon have a chance to tour the new Kenneth E. Behring Family Hall of Mammals, named for the trophy hunter who shot some 200 of the mammals and then graciously donated them to the Smithsonian, along with $20 million. Missing from the collection will be the carcass of Mr. Behring's rarest prize -- the endangered Kara-Tau argali sheep that he took in Central Asia.

title: A Rapper More Gauche Than Gangsta
description: Eminem set out to shock people, and he now has a million albums sold to show for it. ''I only cuss to make your mom upset,'' he asserts on ''The Slim Shady LP'' (Aftermath/ Interscope), the album that has made him a new antihero among the high-schoolers who packed the Hammerstein Ballroom for his show there on Thursday night.

title: Americans View Attacks With Idealism, Ambivalence and Some Alarm
description: For all the wrenching scenes of Kosovo refugees and burning buildings, of starched military men talking damage assessment, of monochromatic video clips of exploding targets, the bombing campaign against Yugoslavia was beginning to fade to a remote concern for many people.

title: Pataki Criticizes Clinton on Balkans Strategy
description: Testing a foreign-policy theme as he made the second political trip to New Hampshire in less than a month, Gov. George E. Pataki criticized President Clinton's policies on Kosovo tonight, saying they had ''raised the risk of trouble in the Balkans.''

title: Turning Protest Signs Into Substance
description: To underscore the message of their march, 10 politicians and community leaders led thousands of people across the Brooklyn Bridge on Thursday with special signs slung around their necks, each highlighting a specific point in their proposal for police reform.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the On Stage and Off column in Weekend yesterday about the 1999 Outer Critics Circle nominations referred incorrectly to the eligibility of the Broadway production of ''Side Man'' for a best play nomination. Under the group's guidelines, ''Side Man'' was not eligible for the 1999 awards. It received a nomination for best Off Broadway play from the group in 1998.

title: Two Top Officers at KPMG Canada Resign
description: KPMG Canada said today that its chief executive and chief operating officer had resigned, 11 days after calling off a planned merger with Arthur Andersen L.L.C.

title: Moving Widely In a Narrow Vocabulary
description: Ballet Tech

title: No Appeal Seen On Trade Ruling
description: The European Union does not plan to appeal a ruling by the World Trade Organization that its policy on banana imports illegally hurts United States-based growers, the European Trade Commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, said yesterday.

title: Strike Vote At Reuters
description: The United States employees of Reuters Group P.L.C., who are members of the Newspaper Guild, voted this week to authorize a strike, the union said yesterday.

title: Patakis Post Sharp Decline In '98 Income
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and his wife, Libby, reported income of $246,417 last year, a sharp drop from the previous year, but the tax returns they released yesterday also showed that Mrs. Pataki has begun a new job in which she is paid to give speeches on behalf of a medical products company, with a salary of $90,000 a year.

title: INSIDE
description: Greenspan the Free Trader

title: Enrollment Is Up at Catholic Seminaries
description: In a sign that a long downward trend in enrollment may be ending, the number of men studying at the nation's graduate-level seminaries to become Roman Catholic priests has risen to the highest level in five years, according to a study by a Catholic social science research center.

title: Does Ethicist's Theory of Cumulative Happiness Really Add Up?; Idea Is Outdated
description: To the Editor:

title: Closure Will Complicate Pyongyang's Receipt of International Aid : North Korea to Lose Main Foreign Bank
description: North Korea will soon lose its main conduit for receiving international funds, including millions of dollars in donor assistance used to alleviate the country's persistent famine.

title: Clinton Should Work Toward a Deal on Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: On Draft Day, Parcells's Jets Will Sit and Wait
description: Under the dominating influence of Bill Parcells, who had to reshape the team in his image, the Jets drafted 23 players over the first two years of his regime. Only the Miami Dolphins, led by the equally exigent Jimmy Johnson, drafted more.

title: Electra Investment Thwarts Hostile Bid
description: Electra Investment Trust, a British venture-capital firm, said yesterday that it had defeated a hostile takeover bid, valued at $:1.25 billion, or $2.01 billion, by the rival 3i Group, which withdrew its offer.

title: U.S. Immigration Service Is Sued Over How It Treats the Disabled
description: The Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service was accused in a lawsuit yesterday of arbitrarily rejecting the applications of disabled immigrants who seek exemptions from the English language and civics parts of the citizenship exam.

title: Led by Burrell, the New-Look Nets Blow Away Seattle
description: By their own admission, the Nets are hard to figure out. Without explanation, they lose convincingly to two of the worst teams in the league and tonight play nearly flawless basketball.

title: Developer Buys Former Plant of Daily News in Brooklyn
description: A Manhattan-based developer has bought the former Daily News printing plant on Pacific Street in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn, hoping to convert it into movie theaters and stores, with apartments above.

title: Pollution for Sale
description: To the Editor:

title: When a Lush, Pretty Tone Might Be the Wrong Choice
description: Jasmin Lin, violinist

title: Bronx Teen-Ager Is Shot to Death Over a Jacket, Police Say
description: Lamar Harris died Wednesday night with five dollars in his pocket, still wearing the stock-car racing jacket that led to his slaying.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about an earnings projection by the Storage Technology Corporation referred incorrectly to a planned reduction in employment at the company. Storage Technology plans to cut 500 jobs through an early-retirement program and attrition; it does not plan to lay off 500 workers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the Pentagon's plans to ask President Clinton for the authority to call up reservists and National Guard members misstated at one point the amount of money the White House is expected to request from Congress to cover the costs of American involvement in the NATO campaign against Yugoslavia. As stated elsewhere in the article, the request is expected to be for $5.9 billion, not $4 billion.

title: Easy, Generous Authority
description: The club's owner had asked him to use the microphone for talking to the audience, but Johnny Griffin balked. ''I'm an acoustic person,'' he shrugged, hoisting his tenor saxophone to begin another tune. Well said. Even in his relationship to the microphone while playing -- he worked around it, using it as a helpful but inessential tool -- he demonstrated a great lack of anxiety about playing. He filled the Village Vanguard with an easy, generous authority. Mr. Griffin, now 70, works in New York about once a year, traveling from his home in Europe; he's been abroad since the early 60's and comes across as a man who has never known jazz to be an unglamorous occupation.

title: Sports of The Times; For Hockey and History, a Singular Star
description: He would have been the Great Jones or the Great Napier or the Great Swenson. His name just happened to be Gretzky.

title: Pilots Lose A Battle, Not the War
description: A Federal judge's decision Thursday to order the pilots union at American Airlines to pay the carrier more than $45 million in damages is hardly the end of the conflict between the union and the airline.

title: Lewis and Holyfield Testify
description: Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis, the participants in last month's controversial heavyweight championship at Madison Square Garden, gave testimony in Manhattan yesterday before the New York Senate Committee on Investigations, which is looking into reforms in boxing.

title: Robert Sachs, Theoretical Physicist, Dies at 82
description: Dr. Robert G. Sachs, a theoretical physicist who once served as director of the Argonne National Laboratory near Chicago, died on Wednesday at the University of Chicago Medical Center. He was 82 and lived in Chicago.

title: Clinton Should Work Toward a Deal on Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Words Go Right to the Brain, But Can They Stir the Heart?; Some Say Popular Software Debases Public Speaking
description: Good Morning.

title: Does Ethicist's Theory of Cumulative Happiness Really Add Up?; Hope on Hemophilia
description: To the Editor:

title: Sound Ideas for Police Reform
description: The marchers at Thursday's rally on police reform in New York City used the event to promote a 10-point plan for improving police policies first proposed by a group of community and business leaders last month. While we differ on some details, the plan is a useful outline for change. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani should welcome a serious dialogue on its principles, several of which were recommended by a task force on police conduct that he himself appointed after the attack on Abner Louima in 1997.

title: BIOGEN PLANNING A 2-FOR-1 SPLIT OF ITS STOCK
description: Biogen Inc., maker of the No. 1 multiple sclerosis treatment, said yesterday that it would split its shares 2 for 1, as its stock price has more than doubled in the last 12 months. The company, a biotechnology concern in Cambridge, Mass., will split its stock on June 25 to holders of record on June 11. Shares of Biogen, which had 1998 revenue of $557.6 million, have gained on sales of its Avonex once-a-week injection treatment for multiple sclerosis, a disease that attacks the central nervous system.

title: Vanished Refugees Reappear, With Grim Tales of Life on Run
description: Ten days ago, thousands had suddenly disappeared. After waiting days at a border crossing near here to enter Macedonia from Kosovo, ethnic Albanians had been rousted from their hillside camps, from their cars and from their tractors and ordered by Serbian forces back into the war zone they were trying to flee.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Knicks Unravel Once More, Falling Below Playoff Line
description: This was close to being a revival for Allan Houston. He was about ready to raise his hands and say, Amen, in the city where his demons live and lead his team out of its eternal misery on the road.

title: After Guilty Plea, Rabbi Explains Actions in a Fund Diversion Scheme
description: The rabbi at the center of a scheme that funneled millions of public school dollars from a Brooklyn district to a Jewish girls' school said yesterday that he knew dozens of Hasidic housewives were collecting paychecks and insurance benefits for no-show jobs, but that he justified the arrangement in his own mind because he believed it benefited the children who attended his school.

title: Editors' Note
description: A chart on March 16 presenting results of a New York Times poll showed how white, black and Hispanic New Yorkers viewed the police. It did not report figures for Asian-Americans because Asians are a smaller part of the city's population and there were insufficient respondents to provide an accurate measure of their views. The chart should have included a footnote stating this limitation.

title: Serb Officer, Captured By Rebels, Held by U.S.
description: Albanian rebels in Kosovo have captured a Yugoslav Army officer and turned him over to Albania, which today turned him over to the United States Army in Albania's capital, the Pentagon announced tonight.

title: Albany Notes; In Partisan Budget Bickering, Little Things Count Big
description: First it was a luge run. Then the Harlem Boys Choir. What next?

title: ALLIANCE REPORTS SUCCESSFUL NIGHT OF BOMBING SERBS
description: NATO pilots claimed one of their most successful nights in the air campaign against Yugoslavia, destroying several tanks and artillery sites and damaging a large air base on Thursday night. The warplanes also gathered new photographic evidence to back up reports of mass killings of Kosovo refugees, NATO and Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Nissan Losses Take a Turn for the Worse
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation, Japan's second-largest car maker, reported a revised estimate of fiscal year losses today that were more than three times as bad as the company had anticipated. Nissan also eliminated the shareholder dividend for the first time since it became a publicly traded company a half-century ago.

title: Pollution for Sale
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's Lenders Balk at Lending
description: Japan's most-watched measure of money supply rose in March at its slowest pace in five months, indicating that banks are not lending the money injected into the banking system by the central bank.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about first-quarter profits at the Charles Schwab Corporation misstated the firm's relative standing in the industry in terms of growth in daily trading volume. Schwab exceeded the industry average in the quarter; it was not below the industry average.

title: Does Ethicist's Theory of Cumulative Happiness Really Add Up?
description: To the Editor:

title: Alliance Message
description: A Belgrade resident studying one of thousands of leaflets dropped on the city by NATO planes yesterday. NATO provided the following translation of the leaflet, one side of it visible above. Kosovo-Metohija is the Serbian name for Kosovo.

title: Two Sisters With a Century of Wisdom
description: If the television version of ''Having Our Say'' had been only a vivid history lesson, that would have been enough to justify what is clearly a labor of love. But this film is more, an engrossing drama built on characters who are at once exceptional and accessible. If you've already met the formidable Delany sisters through their books and the play they inspired, you'll be delighted to be in their presence again. If not, you're in for a memorable surprise.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: AES OF VIRGINIA IS IN DOMINICAN REPUBLIC VENTURE
description: The AES Corporation said yesterday that its subsidiary AES Distribucion Dominicana Ltd. had successfully bid for 50 percent of the electricity distributor Empresa Distribudora Electrica Este (Ede Este) from the Dominican Republic Government for $109.3 million. Ede Este serves about two million people in the eastern region of the Dominican Republic, which includes part of the capital city, Santo Domingo. AES will have operating control of the business. AES, based in Arlington, Va., is a global power company with stakes in 94 power facilities in countries that include the United States, Canada, Australia, Argentina and Britain.

title: CENTEX PURCHASES FAIRCLOUGH HOMES OF BRITAIN
description: The Centex Corporation, the fourth-largest United States home builder, said yesterday that it had bought Fairclough Homes Group Ltd. of Britain from Amec P.L.C. for $170 million to expand into Europe. The acquisition gives the Dallas-based Centex a company that sold 1,717 homes last year and generated pretax profit of $25 million on $322 million in revenue. Fairclough, which builds homes and apartments in the northwest, Midlands and southeast of England, also owns 3,762 lots. Centex told analysts and investors in February that it planned to expand into Europe as it tries to double earnings over three to five years. Its shares rose $2.9375, to $39.375, on the Big Board.

title: RECKSON SERVICE ADDING TO ONSITE ACCESS STAKE
description: Reckson Service Industries, a provider of business services, said yesterday that it would increase its investment in Onsite Access, an integrated communications provider, by $60 million. The equity injection, which is intended to finance the national expansion of Onsite's broadband Internet, data and voice network, is being made in combination with a private equity investor group. Other investors include Spectrum Equity Investors, Crosspoint Venture Partners, J. P. Morgan Capital, AT&T Ventures and Veritech Ventures. After the new investment, Reckson, based in Melville, N.Y., will be the largest shareholder of Onsite Access with an approximate 33 percent stake on a diluted basis. Reckson's stock surged $3.75 a share, to $9.375.

title: LYCOS, INTERNET DIRECTORY, REPORTS ON OUTLOOK
description: Lycos Inc., an Internet directory company being acquired by USA Networks Inc., said yesterday that its third-quarter loss would equal analysts' estimates and that revenue gains remained strong. The company, the No. 3 online search service, is expected to lose 3 cents a share in the quarter ending on April 30, according to the average estimate of analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation. Lycos expects revenue to more than double in the fiscal year ending on July 31 on strong advertising and electronic-commerce sales. Lycos is trying to win over the support of shareholders for the USA transaction, which is facing opposition by the largest Lycos investor, CMGI Inc. The Lycos shares fell $2.3125 each, to $92.3125.

title: Film Sales Lift Kodak Profit, Sending Stock Up Sharply
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, buoyed by six months of steady growth in film sales, announced yesterday that its net profit in the first quarter, excluding one-time charges, rose 9.3 percent, to $259 million, or 80 cents a diluted share, from $237 million, or 73 cents. Sales rose 6.5 percent, to $3.1 billion from $2.91 billion. The company also said it would buy back $2 billion in stock over the next four years.

title: 3Com Plans Job Cutbacks
description: The 3Com Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 150 jobs, or 1 percent of its work force, and reassign 150 other people to faster-growing parts of the company, as it devotes more resources to its emerging high-speed, home-networking and wireless businesses this year. The struggling maker of computer networking gear has been shifting to high-profit opportunities such as routing phone calls over the Internet and providing high-speed connections to the Internet. Most of the job cuts and reassignments will come from 3Com's modem division, based in Chicago and Salt Lake City.

title: Clinton Should Work Toward a Deal on Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: S. Sidney Kahn, 62, Arts Patron, Investor and Venture Capitalist
description: S. Sidney Kahn, a venture capitalist and patron of the arts, died in Osaka, Japan, last Sunday while on a tour with the International Council of the Museum of Modern Art, an art study group. He was 62 and lived in New York and Locust Valley, N.Y.

title: Fox Gretzky Move Rankles the N.H.L.
description: Gary Bettman, the commissioner of the National Hockey League, and another top league executive both criticized Fox Sports yesterday for not guaranteeing that Wayne Gretzky's farewell game tomorrow at 3 P.M. would be seen by the entire New York market on Channel 5.

title: Chile and the Pinochet Case
description: The case of Gen. Augusto Pinochet has left a lasting imprint on international law. England's decision last month that even former heads of state may be tried anywhere for torture committed at home is a landmark, and now Britain's Home Secretary has ruled that Spain can keep seeking Mr. Pinochet's extradition. But the case has also exposed how Chile's military has limited its new democracy.

title: Born With H.I.V., Struggling With Teen-Age Lives
description: Renell Grant learned something new about her adopted teen-age son the other day when she was summoned to his high school in the Bronx. He was seeing a girl.

title: Best Revolution; The Peacemaker
description: In the spring of 1930, Mohandas K. Gandhi -- the unprepossessing former barrister -- led a small group of followers on a 240-mile march across India, from Sabarmati to Dandi on the seacoast, to protest the British Government's imposition of a small tax on salt. Everywhere he went, farmers and villagers turned out in larger and larger numbers to hear his message of personal and national liberation. By the time he reached the coast, where he illegally made salt by boiling seawater, his journey had mobilized thousands of Indians in opposition to British policies and stunned the Raj itself by demonstrating, almost for the first time in history, the enormous power of peaceful, nonviolent revolution. The shaken British viceroy wrote to London that ''the personal influence of Gandhi threatens to create a position of real embarrassment. . . . He has already achieved a considerable measure of success in undermining the authority of the Government.''

title: Patrice Murphy and Stephen Petri
description: Patrice Regina Murphy and Stephen William Petri were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Nils Blatz.

title: Only on the Stage Does 'Iceman' Truly Come Alive
description: FORGET the theorists for the moment. The first thing you should know about ''The Iceman Cometh,'' Howard Davies's brilliant Anglo-American production of the Eugene O'Neill classic, is that it sends you out of the Brooks Atkinson Theater on a high of excitement you probably haven't experienced in years. Like some spellbinding pitchman, it psychs you up. You will want to talk about it immediately, but not only about O'Neill's subversive genius and the mastery of this particular production.

title: ON THE TOWNS: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural ad recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212)556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The Value of Stock Options
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Team That Cooks Up a Dream
description: BRIAN SCHLITT'S food makes an impression. It did in the summer of 1996 at the Seafood Barge in Southold and it still does at his new Table 48 in Glen Cove. Among the memory makers then and now are fluffy crab cakes set atop a mint-cilantro vinaigrette, fried calamari so light and greaseless that they nearly float from the plate, and a sensational pasta dish of bowties, shrimp, scallops, olive oil, lemon and crunchy garlic bread crumbs.

title: Editorial Observer; A Booming Economy That Confuses the Fed
description: It's boom time in America. The United States economy is acting as if it just got a new wind, and growth -- which virtually every forecaster was sure would slow this year -- seems to be accelerating. Unemployment is low and so is inflation.

title: Jersey Dots and Dashes Join Tribute to Marconi
description: To the average AM or FM radio listener, the high-pitched, monotone string of blips and bleeps written as -.-. --.- .-- .- ..--- --. -- -..-. .. -- -. might, at most, be an intriguing audio abstraction some seven seconds long.

title: Robyn Nish and Daniel Friedman
description: Robyn Claire Nish, a daughter of Kathleen and Robert Nish of Morris Township, N.J., was married yesterday in Morristown, N.J., to Daniel Robert Friedman, a son of Shari L. Friedman of Rumson, N.J., and Robert N. Friedman of Manhattan. The Rev. William Cramer Jr., a Roman Catholic priest, officiated in the St. Lucy Chapel at the Villa Walsh Academy in Morristown. Cantor David Benedict took part in the ceremony.

title: Rachel Davidson, Jeffrey Janger
description: Rachel Mai Davidson and Jeffrey Lowell Janger were married last evening by Rabbi Leonard Beerman in the North Courtyard of Union Station in Los Angeles.

title: War and Analogy
description: Every war is conducted in the shadow of its predecessors, and the conflict in Kosovo is no exception. The nation is haunted by memories of the Second World War and Vietnam as it considers how intensely to prosecute the war in the Balkans. That is entirely appropriate, for the history of those struggles is relevant to this one. But neither analogy exactly fits Kosovo, and seeing beyond them is essential if the country is to make a searching examination of the proper course to follow in Yugoslavia.

title: April 11-17; Another Solar System
description: We are not alone -- we as in the solar system. Astronomers had long assumed that some star out there had the requisite planets in regular orbit, but now it's official. Our solar fellow, spotted by two different teams, is called Upsilon Andromedae and is 44 light-years away. In the words of one scientist, ''This is exciting stuff.'' HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Do Computers Help the Economy?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bad Seed?
description: Cries Unheard

title: On the Low Road
description: Federico Fellini's film LA STRADA (1954), about a traveling strong man (Anthony Quinn) and his feeble-minded assistant (Giulietta Masina), is an extraordinary parable of a movie, demonstrating the pain of loneliness and the need for love. The story is set in the picturesque Italian countryside, where the brutish hero and his helper tour from town to town and eventually deal with the intrusion of an acrobatic stranger (Richard Basehart). One powerful component of the film, in addition to its low-key performances, is the haunting musical theme by Nino Rota. Chances are, if the picture doesn't hook you, the music will - WEDNESDAY at 8 P.M. on Turner Classic Movies.

title: State Listens to the Students
description: THE effectiveness and reasons for suspending or expelling misbehaving public school students is a perennial issue for the Connecticut Board of Education, never far from the foreground even when it's not specifically on the board's agenda.

title: Mapping the Millennium; Best View Of the World
description: Battista Agnese's flat map of the world, created in Venice during the mid-16th century, was praised for its beauty and precision. More than just a map, it can be read as a topography of the European mind in transition. Previously, medieval maps of the world squeezed the continents into a circle, with Jerusalem at the center; they were no more accurate than the Geography of Claudius

title: Asian Markets Hint at the End of a Crisis
description: The end is near, at least it seems, for the Asian financial slump. One sign of its possible demise was the robust performance of stock markets from South Korea to Hong Kong during the week.

title: The 50-Cent Dog Has Had Its Day at Gray's Papaya
description: By noon on Tuesday at Gray's Papaya, the hot-dog emporium at Broadway and 72d Street famous for its 50-cent franks, the lines were already out both doors.

title: Following the Path Of Refuse on The Way to Re-use
description: FOR millions of bottles and cans and mountains of dog-eared magazines and newspapers, the road to re-use is long. Most of it -- more than 280 tons a day -- leads through a cavernous building off I-87 in Yonkers.

title: Bastille Days
description: THE FRENCH AND

title: Value Is Suddenly Looking Nifty
description: For years, stock market investors have resembled the fellow Oscar Wilde once described as knowing the price of everything and the value of nothing.

title: Best Idea; When Tristram Met Isolde
description: In the ancient world, romantic love would seem to have been virtually unknown, and rarely celebrated. Our generic term ''love'' didn't exist. The sentiment of romantic love as we know it was the homoerotic love of older Greek men for boys; marital love, which surely existed, seems oddly not to have been much honored, at least in surviving literature. Plato's elaborately extended metaphor of the republic, or the perfectly balanced state, discusses marriage primarily as mating; by contrast, Plato's ''Symposium'' celebrates homoerotic love in the most blushingly romantic terms. How different this is from the extramarital erotic attraction of heterosexuals, which results in devastation and violent death. In Euripides' ''Hippolytus,'' for instance, the young Queen Phaedra falls in love with her husband's illegitimate son, who rejects her, and causes her to commit suicide; Phaedra is no romantic, but rather the victim of an ungovernable, unwished-for passion imposed upon her by Aphrodite. Such sexual desire is akin to a curse.

title: Best Herb; This Bulb's Life
description: At the turn of the current millennium, herbalism flourished, as did the notion of food as medicine. As the Church grew, however, ecclesiastical and medical considerations became more intertwined, especially at the dinner table. Six hundred years later, there was a growing tendency toward milder food -- an early attempt, some food historians suggest, at a holier-than-thou cuisine. Other historians consider this new blandness a reaction against the traditional use of boisterous aromatics, including garlic, to mask the taste of spoiled food.

title: SOAPBOX; Steep Price for Higher Standards
description: ALTHOUGH experienced educators and members of almost every Board of Education in the state have raised concerns about the state Education Department's new, higher academic standards, the state Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, is like a general going into battle, seemingly content with the knowledge that there will be large numbers of academic casualties as students fail to make the grade and are denied a high-school diploma.

title: Rubin, a Sub, Sets Tone as U.S. Takes 2
description: While Billie Jean King, the Fed Cup team captain, bounced around in her courtside consulting chair like a battery-driven beach ball, Chanda Rubin and Monica Seles concentrated their energies on giving the United States a 2-0 lead in this weekend's three-of-five-match meeting between the United States, owner of 15 Fed Cups, and Croatia, which has never passed the first round. King's effervescence was well founded.

title: Best Trial; Order in the Court
description: The millennium has given us dozens of epochal trials -- Charles I, Joan of Arc, the Salem witches, Captain Dreyfus, even O.J. Yet no matter how consequential or dramatic, their impact in retrospect was more as a forum for the clash of rival social forces than for outcomes that changed history.

title: Girl Talk and High-Fives
description: To the Editor:

title: The Great Gretzky
description: Just as the name Michael Jordan registered with those who pay no attention to basketball, so Wayne Gretzky infiltrated the consciousness of a much larger group of Americans who care little for professional hockey. Athletes cannot do that unless they are transcendently good. Gretzky was that good, over a 21-year career that began in Edmonton, Alberta, and will end with one last appearance in a New York Rangers uniform at Madison Square Garden today.

title: Of Course, Trenton Tunnels Were Used by Bonaparte
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing the 60's Through a 90's Corrective Lens
description: A WHIFF of incense mixed with marijuana smoke drifts through two recent movies, ''Hideous Kinky'' and ''A Walk on the Moon,'' both of which conjure an era that Hollywood, in its devotion to snugly happy endings, has largely avoided. In the countercultural dream that has so intimidated Hollywood, a hippie Pied Piper with stringy shoulder-length hair, a fringed jacket and reeking of patchouli oil is banging a tambourine on his knee with one hand and flashing a peace sign with the other. Beside him are a trio of spaced-out go-go girls shimmying and gazing groggily into the purple haze.

title: I Love Your Work, Now Get Outta Here!
description: For the second time, Richard D. Parsons, president of Time Warner, has succeeded in recruiting Deborah C. Wright away from himself. New York's Carver Bancorp, the nation's largest bank controlled by blacks, announced last week that she would become its new chief executive June 1. She is now president of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, a community development group where Mr. Parsons is chairman.

title: Best Come-From-Behind-Victory; The Shortstop Who Went Long
description: The millennium has been rife with implausible comebacks -- from Wellington at Waterloo to Reggie Miller scoring eight points in the final 17 seconds to lead the Indiana Pacers to victory over the New York Knicks in a 1995 playoff game. But the greatest comeback ever was the work of a team that should not have been in the position of staging a comeback in the first place.

title: Rushdie Unplugged
description: Last September the Iranian Government finally rescinded its nine-year fatwa against the novelist Salman Rushdie, and it appeared that his life had been given back to him. For much of the past decade, Rushdie had lived like a prisoner, guarded round the clock by ''the boys,'' as he fondly called them -- agents from the Special Branch of the London police. In recent years, owing largely to Rushdie's own determination, the conditions of his confinement had relaxed somewhat. He ventured out to parties and public events, and even traveled abroad. But the official lifting of the fatwa seemed to restore what Rushdie missed most -- spontaneity, the ability to do whatever he wanted whenever he wanted -- until, a few days later, certain hard-line groups in Iran declared that they would continue to offer a bounty for his death. It's over, went one analysis of the Rushdie situation, except it isn't over.

title: Unhappy Surprise
description: To the Editor: Since my son and I were visiting San Diego to see our grandson and great-grandson, respectively, we jumped at the Frugal Traveler column on Dec. 6 about Tijuana and decided to make a trip there.

title: Dartmouth Outing
description: To the Editor: In the article ''Hanover's Snowy Playground'' (March 7), Amanda Hesser mentions a bluegrass band consisting of college students, saying it ''proved to be the best entertainment of the weekend.'' The band is the Riverbed, its members the current and former Dartmouth students Chris Pandolfi '01, Jonah Blumstein '98, Ken Luallen '01, Daniel Zimmerman '01, Derek Hansen '02 and my son Andrew Allport '01.

title: No Role on Mall For Hempstead Supervisor
description: An article about a proposal to expand Roosevelt Field [''How Mega Can a Mall Be?'' March 28] quoted the Hempstead Town Supervisor, Richard V. Guardino Jr., on the decision to deny the permit. The town's Board of Zoning Appeals, which issued the decision, is an independent, quasi-judicial board of which Mr. Guardino is not a member. He played no role in the decision of this case and only learned of the decision after it was made public at a regularly scheduled board meeting.

title: Sitting Down, or Sitting In, at the Piano Bench
description: In performance, Peter Serkin's manner at the piano suggests that he is less an emcee or interpreter than a medium. The serene atmosphere of his recitals offers space to contemplate the visions of composers old and new, and music neglected or feared.

title: Frequent Flier
description: To the Editor: How does one get a call through to the T.W.A. Aviators Club, (800) 325-4815, to redeem frequent-flier miles? We had been planning a trip for this month, hoping to use our accumulated miles. Starting in January I called repeatedly (7 A.M. to midnight, Eastern time, Monday to Friday, 9:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, closed holidays) from early morning until late at night.

title: Beaujolais That's Berrylike
description: Beaujolais is the soul of joie de vivre, and the soul of the Jea Descombes 1997 Morgon, a prized estate in the fold of Georges (King of Beaujolais) Duboeuf, is a distinctive, lovely strawberry-raspberry flavor, almost a berry preserve itself. The perfume and soft texture deliver a bonus.

title: Penn Varsity Wins First of Season
description: The University of Pennsylvania's men's varsity heavyweight crew won its first race of the season yesterday, capturing the Blackwell Cup in convincing fashion over Yale and Columbia in Derby, Conn. Racing in a downpour that tended to flatten Yale's home-course water on the Housatonic River, Penn got off to a blazing 49-stroke start, gaining a two-seat lead on Yale with Columbia right alongside the Bulldogs. Penn lengthened its lead to four seats at the 500-meter mark of this 2,000-meter course, and from there the teams dueled down the course.

title: Correction
description: An article on March 28 about the pitfalls of new stock trading systems known as electronic communications networks misstated the date and price of a trade that left an investor dissatisfied. The trade, by Greg F. Mazzeo in shares of Network Event Theater, was on Jan. 20, not Jan. 15; he sold shares at $13.5625, not $13.4375.

title: Luxury Hotel Opens Near Covent Garden
description: London's newest hotels go for cool, not chintz. One Aldwych is no exception. It occupies a triangular landmark building that was built in 1907 as the headquarters of the Morning Post, designed by the team of Mewes & Davis, who were responsible for the Ritz hotels in London and Paris. It's at the corner of The Strand and Aldwych, in the West End and near Covent Garden.

title: Mets Manufacture the Runs As Jones Drafts the Victory
description: On the 35th anniversary of the first game played at Shea Stadium, the Mets managed a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Expos yesterday. The victory relied on a formula the Mets often won with last season before Mike Piazza arrived -- good starting pitching supported by maximum offensive efficiency.

title: Scores Hint at Hurdles Under New Rules
description: DR. JOHN J. RUSSELL, the Superintendent of Schools in Hastings-on-Hudson, is proud -- but with limitations -- of the district high school's ratings as a top scorer on the 11th Grade English Regents exams taken last year.

title: New Skin for the Tower Leads Off The Renovation of the Courthouse
description: THE County Courthouse is enveloped these days in scaffolding, which goes about three-fourths of the way up the 20-story building, the tallest building in the county. Fences block access through what was the main entrance, with signs diverting visitors to the left. No loitering on the patio, please, or one could be hit by something from above.

title: In the Region /Connecticut; Drug Maker Buys Vacant GTE Building in Stamford
description: PURDUE PHARMA, a division of Purdue Frederick, a 100-year-old pharmaceutical company that relocated from New York City to Norwalk a quarter-century ago, bought the vacant GTE building in Stamford on March 27 for $77 million.

title: Police Arrest 14 in Drug Raid At a Nightclub in Manhattan
description: Undercover police officers arrested 14 people on drug charges early yesterday at a Chelsea nightclub owned by Peter Gatien, the nightclub magnate who pleaded guilty to tax evasion this year after repeated legal battles with the Giuliani administration.

title: Life: The Instructions
description: HOW TO DO IT

title: Best Stage Comedy; Just for Laughs
description: Who wrote the best comedy of the last thousand years? At first sight this looks like a straight contest between Moli re and Shakespeare, generally acknowledged as the two greatest dramatists of the millennium who wrote comedy. Don't expect much hesitation from French judges of this competition. But chauvinism aside, Moli re must be a strong candidate, because he was a specialist -- he wrote practically nothing but comedy. Unfortunately, I know Moli re in performance only through the distorting medium of translation. I appreciate the consummate craftsmanship of the plotting, but his rhyming couplets tend to sound like doggerel in English. Moli re remains a foreign country: great to visit, but you don't really feel you belong there. Shakespeare presents a different problem. His finest comedies -- A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' ''As You Like It,'' ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' ''Twelfth Night'' -- are not pure comedies, or, to put it another way, not just comedies. Lysander in ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' can sound like Romeo: ''Or if there were a sympathy in choice,/War, death or sickness did lay siege to it,/Making it momentany as a sound,/Swift as a shadow, short as any dream..../So quick bright things come to confusion.''

title: Now Cinderella Can Return To Staten Island on Time
description: When Patricia Hollingsworth and Philippa Addison talk about the Department of Transportation's new midnight run of the Staten Island Ferry from Whitehall Station to St. George, they finish each other's sentences. Clearly, they have thought about the subject.

title: He's Self-Involved, He Does Headstands, He's Will's Pal Jack
description: RIGHT up there on Sean Hayes's list of Worst Jobs Ever was the time he was paid to entertain guests at a lavish Bel Air party by performing the Charleston. ''It was so embarrassing,'' said Mr. Hayes, who doesn't blame Jack Nicholson, Don Rickles or the other assembled celebrities for blithely ignoring him and his partner when they simply merged into the crowd, hunched over and began frantically waggling their knees. ''Everybody was standing there, chatting, not watching. Then every so often, someone would turn their head and give us this look like, 'What are you doing?' ''

title: A Surge in On-Line Ticket Sales, Too
description: FIRST books and music, now event tickets: Another area of electronic commerce is far exceeding expectations.

title: Article 1999041800000254398 -- No Title
description: Charmane Angela Wong, a social services administrator, and Paul Henry Dunn Jr., a community development manager, were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr. performed the nondenominational ceremony at Riverside Church.

title: Brand Opts to Go for Professional Basketball
description: ELTON BRAND of Peekskill, who started his sophomore season at Duke saying he would not turn professional and gradually retreated from that position as the Blue Devils marched to the finals of the N.C.A.A. championships, made it official Wednesday. In a news conference at Duke, he said he was opting for the National Basketball Association draft to realize a dream and earn the money professional basketball can provide for his family.

title: Habitats /Sutton Place; For a Designer, the Agony Of Renovation Is a Joy
description: EVERYONE talks about how difficult it is to renovate: the time, the energy, the angst. Potentially wonderful apartments sit on the market for months, even in this economy, because they require extensive work, and nobody has the nerve to take them on.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: LOST DAUGHTERS

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: COLD HEART By Lynda La Plante. Random House, $24.95.

title: Do Computers Help the Economy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Sex Scandal; Tough Love
description: Sorry, America, but you have been outclassed. A sex scandal that imperils a President is strictly second league. There is only one that withstands the millennium test, for it changed the laws of God and man, created a saint, destroyed a courtier of Machiavellian brilliance and led to accusations of incest, multiple adulteries and political plots. I am speaking, of course, of England's Anne Boleyn and Henry VIII.

title: In the Region /Long Island; Commercial Builders Are Stepping Up Landscaping
description: FROM his fourth-floor office at 7600 Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury, Peter Tilles, one of the principals of the Tilles Companies, can look down on a three-acre spring-fed pond that his late father, Gilbert, donated 38 years ago to the Town of Oyster Bay for a town park.

title: Ms. Friedland and Mr. Templeton
description: Patricia Anne Friedland, the daughter of Alice and Lawrence Friedland of New York, was married last evening to G. Cresswell Templeton 3d, the son of Mary Patricia Templeton of Indianapolis and the late Gilbert C. Templeton Jr. Rabbi Martin M. Solomon officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Marina del Rey, Calif.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ANGELA THE UPSIDE-DOWN GIRL

title: There Is a Reason Math Scores Appear Higher
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton in Contempt: Ruling Was Fair; An Abuse of the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Dartmouth Outing
description: To the Editor: I am writing in response to a statement about the Cafe Buon Gustaio in the article about Hanover.

title: Police Are Right to Complain About Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Escape; The End Was Near
description: For much of the millennium, if one place or people came to a bad end, it would not necessarily affect others: the regions of the world lived separate lives. By the 20th century, however, the world had become one. Thus, the clouds of totalitarianism that formed over Europe in the 1920's and 1930's cast their shadow over the entire planet. By 1941, when almost every country in Europe was ruled by a dictator of one sort or another, it was questionable whether freedom had a future.

title: A Film and a Filmmaker, Each as Fragile as Life
description: THE experimental filmmaker Warren Sonbert died of AIDS complications in 1995 before he could complete ''Whiplash,'' an aching evocation of the fleetingness of experience, but not before leaving detailed instructions on how the film should be edited. What he did not specify, however, was who should do the work. In distress, his companion, Ascension Serrano, consulted a psychic, who assured him that help with the work would come by sea.

title: Best Poem; Hamlet Alone
description: The greatest poem of the millennium? It is no betrayal of the lyric if I name ''Hamlet,'' a work as lyric as it is dramatic. Its ''carnal, bloody, and unnatural acts,/. . . accidental judgements, casual slaughters'' -- I quote from the play -- make up the linear plot, but its lyric structure gives us ''the book and volume'' of Hamlet's high consciousness, tragic and mocking, arching like a glittering spider web over the dramatic action. Though the dramatic Hamlet is provoked by a murder, the lyric Hamlet is moved by all deaths: death walking like a ghost, disinterred in a skull, slumping behind an arras, floating on a brook, hanging on a baited sword, waiting in a poisoned chalice.

title: Best Lawyer; Pure Law
description: What makes a great lawyer? Maimonides preserved and passed on Jewish legal traditions. Grotius invented international law. Chief Justice John Marshall created the principle of judicial review. Perhaps a great lawyer is one who delves into the very nature of law. Though not well known in the United States, his adopted country, Hans Kelsen was such a lawyer. He drafted Austria's 1920 Constitution and designed its constitutional court, Europe's first. But Kelsen's greatness as a lawyer derived most of all from his continuing inquiry into the concepts and constructions that all legal systems have in common.

title: The Role of Actors
description: To the Editor:

title: Cosmic Knowledge
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: PARK SLOPE

title: Best Mistake; By Accident
description: My favorite proverb is from the Portuguese: ''God writes straight with crooked lines.'' Its meaning: the oddest happenings make sense -- if only in the long run and, of course, in hindsight. So is history paved with millions of mistakes, including big mistakes with splendid consequences. Here are three.

title: COALITION TOPPLES IN INDIA, DEFEATED BY JUST ONE VOTE
description: The Hindu nationalist-led Government that turned India into a declared nuclear power collapsed today. It lost a vote of confidence by 269 to 270, the narrowest parliamentary defeat for a government in independent India's 51-year history.

title: N.Y.U. Student Center Would Mar Dramatic Vista
description: To the Editor:

title: Katharine Davis, David Middleton
description: Katharine Carson Davis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Asa B. Davis 3d of Savannah, Ga., was married yesterday to David James Middleton, the son of Constance Middleton of Tallahassee, Fla., and David Jones Middleton of Ponte Vedra, Fla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Michael Carreker at St. John's Episcopal Church in Savannah.

title: Outside Help Enlisted For EZ-Pass Installation
description: The company that has missed several deadlines to install a center to catch cheaters on the state's EZ-Pass electronic toll collection system has called in another company for help.

title: The Youngest Gretzky Is Waiting for His Break
description: A familiar name graces the back of the sweater worn by the speedy center for the Wolves, this city's independent minor league hockey team. He can play behind the net, pass with deadly accuracy, and coaches say he sees the ice almost as well as the man who shares his last name.

title: A Handy 'Andy'
description: Long Island's producers rarely give special vineyard designations to their wines. Although the industry is 26 years old, most estates have not been around long enough to wholly define vineyard blocks with special characteristics or, through advanced vineyard practices, to enable the grapes and wines from certain tracts to outshine their peers year in and year out.

title: Best Question; Did God Have a Choice?
description: History teaches that most ideas are flops, in science and otherwise. But every once in a while a hunch that began as pure thought, a wild gem of poetry about the way nature should be, blossoms into a theory that turns out to fit the world so miraculously that its authors cannot help feeling that they have tapped into the secret order of reality -- into God's ''mind,'' as Stephen Hawking once put it. Einstein knew that giddy feeling back in 1915 when he realized that his theory of general relativity correctly predicted a puzzling motion of the planet Mercury that had bedeviled astronomers for decades; he later confessed to a friend that he had had heart palpitations. Today those same palpitations are being provoked in his successors by something called M theory, a shadowy concept posited to lie at the end of a mathematical labyrinth known as superstrings. The theory seems to contain everything that physicists ever wanted to know about the forces of nature but were afraid to ask. Curiously, nobody claims to know what M theory actually will say, only that it seems to be there at the end of the mathematical rainbow, still undiscovered, a metaphysical headwaters of the Nile. The source perhaps of the River Why.

title: Books and Computers Easing a Visit With a Father in Jail
description: Until last week, children visiting their fathers or other relatives at the Brooklyn House of Detention had few ways to while away the time in the cinder-block-walled waiting room. They could watch television or stare at the linoleum floor.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 18, 1999
description: Weeks

title: NATO Commander Confers on Possible Use of Ground Troops
description: Top American military officers flew here today in an apparent effort to lay the basis for deploying more American forces -- possibly including ground troops -- in NATO's effort to stop Serbs from driving ethnic Albanians from Kosovo.

title: N.Y.U. Student Center Would Mar Dramatic Vista
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; No. 99 Always Gave A 100 Percent Effort
description: THERE isn't much to write or say that would improve upon the tribute paid to Wayne Gretzky by Mike Lalor, who brought his sons to the retirement news conference Friday and said: ''Guys, history. Once in a lifetime.''

title: Political Briefing; Republicans Decide To Ignore David Duke
description: Ever since Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana's First Congressional District resigned, opening the way for a special election on May 1 to choose a successor, there has been little doubt that the winner almost certainly will be a Republican, like Mr. Livingston.

title: An Unexpected Detour Into the Balkan War
description: The errant phone calls are beginning to tail off, but he still gets dozens a day, and Steve Penisten wonders what his next phone bill will look like.

title: Best Story; The Book That Killed Colonialism
description: About 50 years ago, at a diplomatic reception in London, one man stood out: he was short by European standards, and thin, and he wore a black fezlike hat over his white hair. From his mouth came an unending cloud of aromatic smoke that permeated the reception hall. This man was Agus Salim, the Republic of Indonesia's first Ambassador to Great Britain. Referred to in his country as the Grand Old Man, Salim was among the first generation of Indonesians to have received a Western education. In this regard, he was a rare species, for at the end of Dutch hegemony over Indonesia in 1943, no more than 3.5 percent of the country's population could read or write.

title: Renee Hill, Alfred Fisher
description: Renee Hill and Dr. Alfred Leo Fisher were married yesterday by the Rev. Jerome Conroy at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Siena in New York.

title: POSTINGS: A.I.A. Buys Space in Greenwich Village; Architects Get A New Home
description: Seeking a higher profile and more engagement with the public, the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects has purchased a street-level storefront and two below-ground floors in a co-op building at 534 LaGuardia Place in Greenwich Village for $1.2 million.

title: Soft-Boiled
description: Sam Spade never rooted for his daughter to get a good role in her school play. Philip Marlowe didn't worry about stretching a pound and a half of ground beef when company drops in. But Carrie Carlin has both of these distractions while trying to solve the slaying of a wealthy local businesswoman, in ''Shooting Stars and Other Deadly Things'' (Dell, $5.99), Nancy Tesler's third Carrie Carlin mystery. We have lately noted a number of murder mysteries in which the author and the crime solver (these are amateur detectives) are women and live in New Jersey. Carrie Carlin is a biofeedback clinician who lives in Norwood and works across the border in Piermont, N.Y. Her two children are in therapy to help deal with their parents' messy divorce. Her boyfriend (she hates the term) is a Bergen County police officer. Ms. Tesler, who lives in Tenafly, suggests women are writing murder mysteries because ''lots of us have reached a point in our lives when there's somebody we want to kill'' and choose to commit the deed in fiction. Why New Jersey? Ms. Tesler notes that women are feeling vulnerable in places they once felt safe, leafy residential roads or shopping mall parking lots. In fact, she will be soon speaking to a meeting of mystery writers on the subject of ''suburban fright.''

title: Q&A/Dr. Anthony Stern; Psychiatrist Puts Faith in Practice
description: GOD answers prayer in mysterious ways, said Dr. Anthony Stern of Hastings-on-Hudson, a Jewish psychiatrist who has edited a collection of the meditations of Mother Teresa in a new book, ''Everything Starts From Prayer'' (White Cloud Press), aimed primarily at non-Catholics.

title: GOING, GOING . . . BIDDING FOR BARGAINS
description: On-line auctions are a growing segment of the Web. A pioneer, Ebay, started in 1995 and now lists a couple of hundred thousand items every day; Amazon.com, which began life as a bookseller, recently cobbled on an auction subsection.

title: Julio and Marisol, Act XII, in a Subway Car Near You
description: When last we saw Julio, he was anxiously awaiting the results of his H.I.V. test, after learning that his former lover, Rosa, had been diagnosed as H.I.V. positive. Then he learned that his brother, Luisito, was gay.

title: Best Building; Opposites Attract
description: For much of the past thousand years, the pendulum of Western architectural taste has swung between two esthetic poles: Gothic and classical, they eventually came to be called. Because it fuses elements of both positions in a supremely elegant whole, the Seagram Building is my choice as the millennium's most important building.

title: Chamber Recitals On Stage
description: CHAMBER and vocal music dominate the concert scene today, starting at 2:30 when the Kosmos Wind Quintet appears in the ''Chamber Music from Yale'' recital at the Pequot Library in Southport.

title: Best Story; Morality Bites
description: Imagine a novelist looking at the 500-year-old morality play ''Everyman'' and wondering if there might be something he can use. He considers reading it, but is put off by the prospect of working through a medieval text.

title: With Kosovo Conflict, Cruises Change Course
description: A number of cruise lines are replacing calls at Dubrovnik and at ports in Croatia with ports along Italy's east coast. Cunard and Seabourn lines, both owned by Carnival, have changed the itineraries of 21 cruises by five vessels -- the Vistafjord, Sea Goddesses I and II, the Seabourn Spirit and the Seabourn Legend -- to avoid warfare on the eastern shores of the Adriatic. Holland America's Maasdam is also making calls in Greece and Italy instead of Dubrovnik. Windstar Cruises' Wind Surf will eliminate calls at Dubrovnik and Rab Island, Croatia, on all 12 of its Rome-Venice sailings this summer; alternative Italian calls will be made, and Venice remains as a home port.

title: Applied Whimsy
description: Technology companies have long had a taste for fanciful names like General Magic and U.S. Robotics that perhaps say more about the founders' teen-age reading habits than about their businesses.

title: April 11-17; The End of the World
description: The NBC soap opera ''Another World'' is all about high drama and emotional torment; but this time it's coming from the viewers. NBC decided to cancel its longest-running soap opera after 35 years, probably believing that with ratings diminishing, it could do so relatively quietly. The network cited the paltry total of 50 phone calls in Los Angeles and about 150 in New York from fans unhappy with that decision.

title: THEATER; From Hard Facts Comes Comfortable Music
description: A WALL of cannons atop a grassy, open slope. Forty thousand men killed or wounded in three days near Gettysburg, Pa. It was the numbers that got to Frank Wildhorn, the composer of ''The Civil War,'' the new Broadway musical opening on Thursday at the St. James Theater.

title: Cross-State Hiking Trail Proposed to Mark Millennium
description: Al Kent, a 73-year-old veteran hiker from West Orange, would like to see New Jerseyans mark the millennium by hiking 100 miles from Liberty State Park on the Jersey City waterfront to the Delaware Water Gap. Mr. Kent, a part-time employee of the Morris County Parks Department, has submitted the plans for a trail that goes through cities, suburbs and forests.

title: Food and Drink With a Merengue Beat
description: A dance lesson, a radish-and-spinach empanada, pork chops with rice and beans or what Casey Torres, a co-owner, calls a ''great margarita'': customers can have them all at Latin in Manhattan. This bar, restaurant and club opened two weeks ago at 217 East Third Street (between Avenues B and C).

title: Orchestra Fostered Pulitzer Prize
description: WHEN Melinda Wagner received a phone call from her music publisher an hour before the Pulitzer Prizes were announced last Monday with news that it looked as if she would win the Pulitzer prize in music, the composer was making formula for her 10-month-old daughter, Olivia.

title: On Island, Books of Individualism; Tuning In to Dylan, On Radio and in Book
description: STEVE MATTEO has been listening to music, studying it, writing about it or talking about it for as long as he can remember.

title: Welcome Simplicity With Italian and More
description: LUNA, a new restaurant on the same grounds as (and next door to) the Westport Country Playhouse in Westport, is a sibling of the Barcelona Restaurant and Wine Bar in South Norwalk, but not related to Sole e Luna, which formerly occupied the premises near the Playhouse.

title: Afraid of Husbands, and the Law; Deportation Risk Grows for Abused Illegal Residents
description: Shy and soft-spoken, the 26-year-old Dominican woman uses pictures rather than words to tell about the nightmare that was her marriage.

title: April 11-17; For Campaign Finance, Another Push
description: Campaign finance overhaul hit an unyielding gantlet of Republican opposition last year and promised to be met by the same obstacles this time around, but that did not stop House Democrats from taking up the cause once again. They launched a petition drive to force Republican leaders in the House to allow, in the next few months, a vote on an overhaul bill.

title: The Good, The Bad And the Feline: A Philosophy
description: I see I'm running out of time to earn the appellation ''one of the great philosophers of the 20th century,'' so I hereby offer what shall become known as the Jersey Postulate:

title: Ms. Hendrie, Mr. Bloomfield
description: Barbara Ellen Hendrie, an independent consultant on Africa to international aid organizations, and Stephen Bloomfield, a British trade union official, were married yesterday in Richmond, England. Angela Johnson, a registrar for Richmond-Upon-Thames, officiated at Cambridge Cottage, the manor house on the grounds of the Royal Botanic Gardens in Kew.

title: The Artist Is a Glamour Puss
description: IT was an early spring night. The air was chilly and damp, but in the art gallery on 57th Street the scene was so steamy all coats had been shed. Amid the crowd of 500 who flocked to the opening of ''Another Girl, Another Planet,'' an exhibition of photographs by and about young women, the dozen artists in the show were as easy to spot as fireflies at dusk.

title: Correction
description: A picture and caption with the Gazetteer chart on March 28 about Lynbrook, N.Y., were published in error. The house at 91 Hendrickson Avenue is no longer on the market.

title: Our Towns; Nonbelievers In a Land Of Much Faith
description: THE priests, the pastors and the rabbis of the Cranford Clergy Council were having their usual Monday morning breakfast meeting at the Family Diner on North Avenue the other day when one of them asked, ''Did you see where the atheists have moved to town?'' and someone else said, ''Well, we've got to find out where they are and invite them to our Monday meeting.''

title: Report Cards for Middle and High Schools
description: Annual state report cards for Westchester show that some students may face a struggle to meet new state graduation requirements being introduced in the next few years.

title: It's Not Just the Rich Who Are Getting Richer
description: To the Editor:

title: F.Y.I.
description: Once and Future Station

title: Best Nuisance; Earth Mother
description: Octavia Hill was born in Wisbech, Cambridgeshire, England, in 1838, the youngest but 2 of a family of 11 children, 10 of them girls. She had no formal education, for her strong-minded mother believed in letting her children do what they were best at, and in letting them be outdoors as much as possible. When Octavia was 14, the family moved from the country into London: she never forgot the loss of green fields and fresh air.

title: In the Industrial Back Alleys of Beijing, a Little Bit of Gotham
description: WHO knew what China really needed was a bagel factory?

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Serbian public's culpability for war crimes misspelled the surname of the dictator who ruled Albania from 1945 to 1985. He was Enver Hoxha, not Hoxa.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SISTER OF MY HEART

title: Elder Gotti Is Still Trying To Run Mob, Experts Say
description: With his son and reputed successor about to follow him into Federal prison, John J. Gotti is trying to cling to the reins of the Gambino crime family through his brother Peter, Mafia experts say.

title: Celebrating a Grand Era of Children's Book Illustration
description: IT may have all started with the Owl and the Pussycat. Then Peter Rabbit got into the act. Winnie the Pooh, perpetually in search of hunny, started hanging around. And the regal pachyderm Babar, thanks to a stunning makeover by the kindhearted Old Lady, brought a certain dignity to the whole literary menagerie.

title: Ideas & Trends: From Eyeglasses to Wheelchairs; Adjusting the Legal Bar for Disability
description: IN 1994 Vaughn L. Murphy applied for a position as a truck mechanic with United Parcel Service in Topeka, Kan. Because the job included driving the vehicles he serviced, Mr. Murphy was required by Federal law to pass a Government physical. He did, and started working for U.P.S. He was by all accounts an able engine doctor but was soon asked by the company to take another blood-pressure test. This time, despite medication, Mr. Murphy's blood pressure slightly exceeded the limits -- making him, in theory, a risk for stroke or heart attack on the road. The company gave him a pink slip.

title: Do Computers Help the Economy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sonnet in Gross National Product
description: A talent for economics and a way with words coexist as rarely as, say, welfare states and low taxes. During their single meeting, Franklin Delano Roosevelt was nettled by John Maynard Keynes's failure to communicate clearly, accusing the century's greatest economist of sounding like a mathematician. Nobel Laureate Wassily Leontief claimed that Keynes's influence was due largely to prose that required deciphering by legions of disciples.

title: Finding Savings At Closings
description: FEW people would hesitate to pick up a $10 bill lying on the sidewalk. But real estate lawyers say that some people leave much more money than that ''lying on the table'' when buying or selling a house or apartment.

title: Uta Who? If You Don't Know, It's Time to Find Out
description: COME to the cafe at the George Street Playhouse here, and consider the walls. Only a theater historian or a critic of found photographic art could summon the objectivity to describe an exhibition assembled by happenstance and inspired by reverence. Don't expect a rational statement from an ardent longtime theatergoer.

title: Joanna Westrich And Marc Brody
description: Joanna Lynn Westrich and Marc Jeffrey Brody were married last evening by Rabbi Chava Koster at Estherwood, a historic house in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't want him to mess around on the street and end up in a box for something other than the virus. The virus ain't killing him. It's stupidity that's killing him.''

title: Early Start in Battle For Pivotal House Seat
description: The moment Rush Holt, a Democrat, had broken the Republicans' grip on the 12th Congressional District last November, both political parties decided that central New Jersey would be a major battle zone in the fight for control of the United States House of Representatives in 2000.

title: Lawyer Hired by Rye
description: Despite a conflict of interest charge pending against J. Henry Neale Jr., a lawyer in White Plains, Rye has hired him to be its next Corporation Counsel. The alleged ethics violation supposedly occurred while Mr. Neale was a member of the county's Parks, Recreation and Conservation Board. Frank J. Culross, City Manager of Rye, said the seven-member City Council interviewed eight candidates for the position and selected Mr. Neale, based on his municipal experience and ability. The half-time position pays $62,500 a year.

title: Joy De Vries And John Heinze
description: Joy Barbara DeVries and John Ambrose Heinze were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. J. Barrie Shepherd performed the ceremony.

title: Best Invention; Invention Is the Mother Of Necessity
description: My 11-year-old twin sons just told me what they learned today in school. ''Daddy, Johannes Gutenberg invented the printing press, and that was one of the greatest inventions in history.'' I learned that, too, when I was a child. I suspect that the same view is taught in most other American and European schools. What we are told about printing is partly true, or at least defensible. Personally, I would rate it as the best single ''invention'' of this millennium. Just think of its enormous consequences for modern societies. Without printing, millions of people wouldn't have read quickly, with no transmission errors, Martin Luther's 95 Theses, the Declaration of Independence, the Communist Manifesto or other world-changing texts. Without printing, we wouldn't have modern science. Without printing, Europeans might not have spread over the globe since 1492, because consolidation of initial European conquests required the emigration of thousands of would-be conquistadors motivated by written accounts of Pizarro's capture of the Incan emperor Atahualpa.

title: 'Missing Footage' in Nyack
description: AS a playwright, Gen LeRoy has big really big and oh, so serious -- notions. But ''Missing Footage,'' a lumbering title for a preposterous play about a luminous ballerina, is, if anything, more a pilot for a soap opera than a metaphor for art and life, even though Ms. LeRoy writes about ''fueling souls,'' ''cutting wings'' and other such activities.

title: Bailing Out Banks
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Miserable in Brooklyn
description: The walls are literally catching fire in GEOGRAPHIES OF HOME (Viking, $23.95), Loida Maritza Perez's vivid first novel about a family in crisis. For Iliana's Dominican parents, who are eking out an existence in a dilapidated Brooklyn town house, the troubles seem insurmountable. One daughter, Marina, is a rape victim who burns imaginary spiders off the kitchen walls and is descending into schizophrenia. The eldest daughter, Rebecca, routinely brutalized by her husband, is neglecting her small children. Yet another daughter, Beatriz, has simply disappeared. While at college, Iliana is visited by the apparition of her mother, who teases her and beckons her to come home. When she does, Iliana is little prepared for the dire conditions she encounters -- she is struck by her parent's helplessness, their material and emotional poverty. Her transplanted family has not taken root in its adopted country, and is losing its strength and identity. Perez relates much of this story in eerie flashbacks. Memories of a plentiful island life in the Dominican Republic collide with Brooklyn's alienating landscapes. The result is a deluge of intense imagery where the magical and the real occupy the same awful and sometimes sensual space. This novel's narrative is too often fragmented by kaleidoscopic shifts in tense and perspective, dispersing the tension that numerous emotionally chaotic passages build. This is not a flawless book, but one suspects Perez's next one could be. Erica Sanders

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: And So to Bed
description: Gay Lives

title: Best Fable; Dead Poet's Society
description: When the Roman epic poet Virgil conducted his hero Aeneas down into the underworld and brought him back again, he demonstrated a legendary knowledge of magic and shamanism: Virgil could penetrate the mysteries of the afterlife and emerge unscathed. More than a thousand years after his ''Aeneid'' was composed, Virgil's reputation for wizardry and wisdom stood so high that he was chosen by Dante to be his guide to the Inferno. This medieval Virgil -- magician, prophet, necromancer and proto-scientist -- resembles the historical Virgil not at all, but he flourished in many of this millennium's fables, several of them foolish, some of them wise, all of them bizarre and fanciful.

title: Strawberry In Jeopardy Of Losing His Job
