description: Even if Darryl Strawberry passes the drug test administered to him in the aftermath of his arrest Wednesday on charges of cocaine possession and solicitation of prostitution, he is in jeopardy of losing his $2.5 million deal with the Yankees. Virtually his entire salary is tied into a consulting agreement with the team, instead of being compensation for playing baseball, and the consulting agreement hinges on a strict behavior clause.

title: Goodbye to One Phase, Hello to the Next
description: SEPTIME WEBRE, director of American Repertory Ballet, does not consider beheading to be a topic for casual discussion. But he has no problem with its role in ''Seven Silences of Salome,'' a ballet the company is bringing to Brentwood on Saturday.

title: April 11-17; Kevorkian Gets 10 to 25 In Assisted Suicide Case
description: Saying the law does not bluff, a Michigan judge meted out a 10-to-25-year sentence to Dr. Jack Kevorkian, who had dared the courts to jail him for giving a lethal injection to a terminally ill man. The death of Thomas Youk, who suffered from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease, was broadcast on a television program last fall. The man's widow and brother issued emotional courtroom appeals on behalf of Dr. Kevorkian. But the judge, Jessica Cooper, said Dr. Kevorkian had no right to take the law into his own hands. ''Consider yourself stopped,'' she told him. DIRK JOHNSON

title: Ivy Becker, Paul Schaeffler
description: Ivy Ann Becker and Paul Michael Schaeffler were married last evening at the National Arts Club in Manhattan. The Rev. Tracey Lind performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: POSTINGS: New $23 Million, 23-Story Glass and Limestone Building; 127 Rentals for Upper East Side
description: When completed next spring, a sleek 23-story glass-and-limestone residential rental building at 400 East 66th Street, at the corner of First Avenue, will, its owners and designers believe, offer a sharp contrast to brick tenements and high rises in the neighborhood.

title: Assuming a Karpovian Style, Kramnik Beats Its Originator
description: The Eighth Melody Amber Quickplay Tournament in Monte Carlo, won by Vladimir Kramnik this year, remains the most unusual event on the circuit. Each of the 12 contestants plays two games with every opponent at the rate of all moves in 25 minutes, with a 10-second bonus added for each move. One of the games is played blindfold, or without sight of the board. In this one, the player makes his move with a mouse on an electronic board of otherwise empty squares. The move remains visible for only a few seconds. Outside of the view of the players, a demonstration board reveals the moves to the referee and the spectators as the game develops.

title: Witnesses to a Golden Era, Linda McCartney's Eye for Life
description: ONE consolation baby boomers have as they grow older is that they grew up with the best rock music, and it will likely get piped into the rest home. This generation witnessed rock and roll from its birth to its full flowering. Fortunately, many turned to other cultural pursuits and so escaped the disappointment of rock's eventual watering down.

title: April 11-17; A Loss for Starr In the McDougal Case . . .
description: The once-sprawling investigation by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor, wound down and its Arkansas phase appeared to end on a note of defeat when an Arkansas jury acquitted Susan H. McDougal of obstruction of justice. The jury deadlocked on the two remaining counts of criminal contempt, and the judge declared a mistrial on those charges. The case stemmed from Ms. McDougal's refusal to testify about President and Mrs. Clinton's financial dealings. NEIL A. LEWIS

title: Don't Worry. You're New.
description: Q. I recently started work at a public relations firm. As the new kid on the block, I don't yet have a stable of clients, so I keep getting pulled away for projects that no one else wants to handle -- and that often require expertise or experience I lack. I want to be a team player, but I worry that I am being set up to fail, or at least to disappoint my bosses. I would say something to the person who hired me, but I don't want to get a reputation as being difficult. Any advice?

title: Classic Losers
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Hung Out to Dry
description: THE widely recognized need to defend our open space and quality of life from suburban sprawl has recently become a state and national priority.

title: Boldly Into Spring
description: Bold plaids are adding their character to spring coats and suits. A head turner was a man in midtown wearing a shadow-gray coat and suit with a flowered vest and rose shirt. Other men went as boldly. Burberry has now elevated its signature plaid lining to the outside of women's coats (top, near and far right). A young woman, right, tossed a blue-plaid mohair coat over a T-shirt and jeans with dressed-down attitude.

title: With Howls of Joy, Huskies Fans Take Hartford
description: More than 200,000 faithful fans took to the chilly streets here today for a parade saluting the University of Connecticut men's basketball team, which won this year's national championship after years of late-season heartbreaks.

title: Jacqueline Cinguina, Bruce Ellerstein
description: Jacuelin Cinguina and Bruce Adam Ellerstein are to be married today at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Msgr. James Lisante is to officiate, with Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz taking part.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: I LEFT MY BACK DOOR OPEN

title: Best Innovation in Painting; Everything in Perspective
description: The signal art work of the millennium (let's narrow it down and stick to the West) no longer exists, and is only mentioned in a text from the 1480's, a biography of Filippo Brunelleschi written by a man named Antonio di Tuccio Manetti. Brunelleschi, the Florentine architect, is credited with inventing perspective, the system for representing three dimensions in two -- so that in a painting or drawing, your backyard barbecue, say, would look closer than your neighbor's rose garden. Perspective works by having a vanishing point, or single spot at which all parallel lines going from near to far theoretically converge, the effect of which creates an illusion of depth.

title: April 11-17; Jeepers, Bullwinkle. . .
description: You're one of the world's biggest airlines, and a shipment of live squirrels has broken open. You can't send them on, and the shipper won't take them back. What do you do? Don't put them in a shredder.

title: Bars Want Patrons Who Want to Keep Cars
description: NURSING his second beer at the Boulder Creek Saloon in Syosset last week, Mike Keyes was thinking about his 1998 Mitsubishi Eclipse and how difficult it would be to get around without it.

title: Modern, and Unwelcome in Historic Areas
description: Residents of three historic districts in Brooklyn and Queens are complaining about pale green cabinets, containing electronics and fiber optic equipment, that Time Warner Cable has been planting on neighborhood sidewalks as it upgrades its cable system. And the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission has said Time Warner installed them without permission.

title: Best Leader; 'Just Look How Well She Governs!'
description: Elizabeth I of England was neither the most influential nor the most inspirational leader of the millennium, but she was perhaps its best all-around player. She was a 16th-century monarch with modern instincts -- abhorrence of the cost of war, distaste for religious extremism and a keen interest in balanced budgets. ''God send her as good a health as she has a heart,'' said one of her ministers when she began her reign, and his prayers were answered: she ruled from 1558 to 1603.

title: Young Should Listen
description: To the Editor:

title: A Legendary Life
description: RIGOBERTA MENCHU AND THE STORY OF ALL POOR GUATEMALANS

title: At a Book Signing, Kissinger Creates a Stir
description: The center of this normally serene country village in western Connecticut was teeming today with hundreds of people eager to either celebrate or excoriate Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, who was signing copies of his newly published memoir, ''Years of Renewal,'' at the Hickory Stick Bookshop.

title: Boy George
description: GEORGE III A Personal History. By Christopher Hibbert. Illustrated. 464 pp. New York: Basic Books. $27.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Surfers Lose Appeal Over Storm-Wave Rides
description: Three surfers who rode the waves of Tropical Storm Bertha into Spring Lake Municipal Court nearly three years ago, have lost the appeal of their convictions for surfing when beaches were closed to the public.

title: Where Stables Yield to Antiques' Glow
description: ANTIQUES are coveted for memories of generations of family members who once owned them, of stories and historical events that add to their significance.

title: Annual Communist Art Sale Might Be the Last
description: Every spring the treasures are pulled from a dusty storage room, and a visual slice of history goes on sale: boldly colored posters celebrating the Cuban revolution, political cartoons skewering rapacious capitalists, Depression-era drawings lionizing the working class.

title: At This Sunday Brunch, Pancakes and Matches Are Made
description: Handing a bag of blueberries to their host, two sharply dressed women hesitantly entered Philip Kessler's one-bedroom apartment in the West 70's last Sunday morning. For many Upper West Siders, a trip out of the house before noon on a weekend means sweat pants and a baseball cap, hairbrush optional. But these two looked as if they could have been heading out for cocktails on a Saturday night.

title: Corrections
description: A column last Sunday about Jon S. Corzine, a potential Democratic candidate for United States Senate, misstated his position on abortion. Mr. Corzine supports a woman's right to have an abortion.

title: Michael Culp and Deborah Bronston
description: Deborah Tamar Bronston and Michael Culp, securities research specialists in Manhattan, were married yesterday. Judge Arlene H. Hahn of New York City Housing Court officiated at the St. Regis in Manhattan.

title: A Performer of Many Faces, All Brazilian
description: ANTONIO NOBREGA, a Brazilian performer who will be making his United States debut at the Kennedy Center's American Dance Festival April 27 through 29, trots out a variety of characters in ''Figural,'' the one-man show he will use to greet North American audiences. The figures he conjures, through mime, dance, music and acrobatics, are not simply creatures of the artist's fancy but a string of types meant as a showcase for Brazil's culturally rich northeast.

title: In the Light Of the Pyre
description: HOUSEBOAT of American hippie men,'' announced our oarsman and self-appointed tour guide, nodding toward a dilapidated, peeling wreck that bobbed in the Ganges a few yards upstream from Dasaswamedh Ghat, one of the most popular of the sets of steps lining the river's edge. My husband, Bob, and I were in the sacred Hindu city of Varanasi, a shrine for pilgrims and considered a most fortunate place to die: If your spirit departs from the envelope of your body in Varanasi it will bypass the endless cycle of birth and rebirth and ascend directly, nonstop to heaven.

title: It's the End of the Line For a Number of Rangers
description: Wayne Gretzky probably won't be the only Ranger playing his final home game at Madison Square Garden today when the regular season concludes against the Pittsburgh Penguins. Mediocre teams that miss the playoffs for a second consecutive season, even with respectable improvement, rarely stay intact.

title: For Private Schools Ingenuity Is a Key To Expansion Plans
description: THE battle of Waterloo may have been won on the playing fields of Eton, but for the private schools of New York City it is the battle to find even a postage-stamp size site for baseball and tennis, or Latin and math, that has led to a range of resourceful tactics.

title: Tribe in Utah Fights for Nuclear Waste Dump
description: The desert here is silent, but for birdsong and wind. The vegetation is springtime green, the mountaintops covered with snow for the next month or so, and all is still except for the jack rabbits, hawks and occasional antelope, and a rare car on the two-lane blacktop road. But this is a rough neighborhood, environmentally speaking.

title: SERB FORCES PRESS SWEEP OF KOSOVO
description: Tens of thousands of Albanians poured out of Kosovo today, driven from their homeland despite NATO's continuing air war of attrition against Yugoslavia and what the alliance called successful attacks on Serbian tanks.

title: The New York Artist Is Now From Everywhere
description: WHAT defines a New York artist at the end of the 20th century? The question surfaced with the announcement that the works to be exhibited at the next Whitney Biennial, due to open in March 2000, would be chosen by a team of art professionals who neither work at the museum nor live in New York. Maxwell L. Anderson, the museum's director, spoke of giving the show a ''national perspective.'' Hugh Davies, director of the Museum of Contemporary Art, San Diego, La Jolla, and one of the biennial's outside organizers, said that the biennial had been a ''New York event'' since the 1970's, and that California's representation had been ''limited.''

title: Best Tool; One Good Turn
description: Some years ago my wife and I built a house. I mean really built it -- ourselves, from the ground up. Electricity being unavailable, we used hand tools. I did not have a large toolbox. It contained different-size saws, a mallet and chisels, a plane, several hammers (for friends conscripted into our work force) and, for correcting major mistakes, a heavy sledge. In addition I had a number of tools for measuring: a tape, a square, a spirit level and a plumb line. That was all we needed.

title: Ideas & Trends; Your Mind May Ease What's Ailing You
description: MEDICAL science, focused on curing the ills of the body, has often treated the mind like an annoying younger brother: a presence to be ignored whenever possible, humored when unavoidable and used as a scapegoat when the need arises.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: THIS week's choice screen fare includes a television remake of a 1934 film, a movie adapted from a famed crime novel, a frontier musical and a sharp comedy-drama.

title: Loved the LP, Waiting for the CD
description: TIME was when most pre-LP jazz recordings were rarities available only to resourceful collectors with deep pockets. But the introduction of the compact disk -- together with Europe's copyright laws, under which both European and American records enter the public domain 50 years after their initial release -- led to a revolution in the accessibility of classic jazz. With a few glaring exceptions (the early 78's of Red Nichols and His Five Pennies foremost among them), nearly every historically significant commercial recording of jazz made before 1948 has been transferred to CD or is slated for future release.

title: Hong Kong
description: It has been nearly two years since this former British colony reverted to Chinese rule. But some residents are still startled when they see the words ''Hong Kong, China'' on a television report or travel brochure.

title: Don't Ban Nude Olympics, Sell Advertising Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Within the Whirlwind, a Tireless Worker
description: Who in the world today can't picture Michael Jordan? His sky-borne frame is a global icon; his smiling face sells underwear and telecommunications; his intense looks of concentration brought millions of new viewers to the National Basketball Association. Scott Turow, the novelist, wrote, ''Michael Jordan plays basketball better than anyone else in the world does anything else,'' and even though Jordan has retired from the game, no one has contradicted that assessment. His court moves are mimicked by so many young players that it's hard to imagine any of them wanting to be like anyone but Mike.

title: Painter and Sculptor In Show of Versatility
description: MOSES ROS, who is featured at the Hostos Community College art gallery here, is a painter and sculptor who also has a degree in architecture. He specializes in designs for public buildings. This may sound workaday, but a glance at some of his work in several media indicates that he is at least in part a visionary.

title: April 11-17; World's Richest Babysitter
description: Chris Gabrieli, a Boston venture capitalist, discovered that his live-in babysitter was a multi-millionaire like him. The babysitter, Maria J. Grasso, a 54-year-old immigrant from Chile, told Mr. Gabrieli's wife, Hilary, who then told him, that she had won the $197 million Big Game jackpot, the largest lottery prize ever won by one person in the United States. ''I'm a very down-to-earth person,'' Mrs. Grasso said at a news conference, with the Gabrielis beaming nearby. ''I work hard in my entire life. I'm one of six children, and so I always try to be low, down-key, and I'm going to continue that way.'' Mrs. Grasso chose a lump sum payment of $104 million -- $70,244,814 after taxes. SARA RIMER

title: Bush's Savvy Answers
description: To the Editor:

title: In Timor, Separatists Attacked By Militias
description: Militant supporters of the Government unleashed an orgy of attacks today against supposed separatists in the capital of East Timor, leaving more than 30 people dead, scores injured, and homes and cars burned, diplomats and human rights workers said.

title: Sports of The Times; From Deep in His Serbian Heart
description: THE best hour to call is 2 or 3 in the morning, New York time. That is when his brothers return home from the air-raid shelters in Belgrade.

title: The Best of the First Millennium; The Ice Age Cometh
description: The millennium before ours will be remembered not for the events that fill our textbooks -- the triumphs of barbarism and religion over ''classical'' civilizations -- but for the fact that for the first time cultures reached out and touched or almost touched. The Thule Inuit crossed the American Arctic, while in the opposite direction, the Norse navigated the Atlantic. Polynesians fanned across the Pacific. The Indian Ocean was crisscrossed with cultural contacts. The ideas and inventions of China spread west along developing trade routes. The heat of Arab imperialism forged the Middle East we know today. Indian missionaries and colonists spilled beyond the subcontinent. In Europe, heavy plows threatened the environment, and the stirrup transformed war.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph of bombs being loaded on an airplane at a base in Britain misidentified the plane. It was a B-1 bomber, not a B-2.

title: British Summer, Camp Included
description: IT'S sad but true: a lot of teen-agers would rather stay at home with their friends than go on vacation with their parents -- even if offered a trip to Europe. Unless you're prepared to leave the kids at home with grandparents or cousins or send them to summer camp, a European venture could be marred by gloomy faces and a perpetual chorus of ''Oh, do we have to go there?'' One solution is to take the kids to Europe -- and then pack them off on a mini-holiday of their own.

title: Alleghany/Chicago Trust Growth and Income Fund
description: ''I SORT of shudder at the word 'hot,' '' said Jerold L. Stodden, lead manager of the Alleghany/ Chicago Trust Growth and Income fund. ''That sort of denotes a nearer-term outlook on things.''

title: A Feast Where Not Everything Looks Good Enough to Eat
description: THE title ''Food for Thought'' suggests contemplation, but the show at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts is much too raucous for that. It is also quite witty, the way a food fight might be at the Algonquin Round Table.

title: Fight Over Needle Exchange
description: As the Staten Island AIDS Task Force and Staten Island University Hospital await word from the state on whether they can begin the borough's first needle exchange program, in Mariners Harbor, Bloomfield and Stapleton, debate over the plan has intensified.

title: On Island, Books of Individualism; Great Expectations, But for Whose Life?
description: LONG ISLAND wouldn't seem to be fertile ground for a book about being an Asian-American. But in ''Warrior Lessons,'' Phoebe Eng, now a Sag Harbor resident, uses her experiences growing up in Westbury, in relative isolation from the metropolitan area's Chinese-American community, to tackle the staggering archetypes that create a certain invisibility for Asian-American women.

title: Once Stylish but Now 80, Faded, Seedy and a Star
description: WEARING a Borsalino pushed back on his salt-and-pepper hair and woolen trousers with ankle slits and vertical stripes of blue and olive that speak in no uncertain terms of foreign climes, Wim Wenders eyes a sagging Los Angeles storefront where a sign, painted a vivid Highway Department yellow, promises adult videos and ''ruber toys.'' The March breeze sweeping downtown's Main Street is more North Sea than Sun Belt, and the window, where the director's reflection competes with a crudely painted cartoon character, is as dark as the noontime sky. Indeed, to those unfamiliar with the vagaries of a Southern California spring, it might seem that the man often credited with inventing German cinema's New Wave has brought the raw weather with him.

title: ART / ARCHITECTURE; Elegant, Dramatic, Witty: Is It Really a Post Office?
description: WAITING in line to buy higher priced stamps at the post office may seem tedious, but think what it's like for the clerk behind the counter or the mail sorters in the back. A decade ago, Paul Quiles, the French Minister of Postal and Telecommunications Services, set about investigating those conditions. In addition to working in dreary environments, he discovered, most Parisian postal employees, who arrive early and work late, must commute long hours to find affordable housing.

title: Are Sects Necessary?
description: THE SEA CAME IN

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Liberties; Cold, Cold Hearth
description: I sense the hidden hand of Harold Ickes.

title: Nude and Now Also 'Lewd,' a Beach May Be Closed
description: Jack Roche has seen it all on Higbee Beach, ''plenty of nudes, but nothing lewd.''

title: Best Idea; Every Dictator's Nightmare
description: With the blood-soaked banner of religious fanaticism billowing across the skies as one prominent legacy of this millennium, Martin Luther's famous theses against religious absolutism struck me early as a strong candidate for the best idea of the last thousand years. By progressive association, so did the microprocessor and its implications -- the liberalization of access to knowledge, and a quantum boost for the transmission of ideas. There is, however, a nobler idea that has spread by its own power in this millennium and that has now begun to flourish: the idea that certain fundamental rights are inherent to all humanity.

title: Fluoride, A Missing Ingredient
description: Barker Hamill's children take fluoride pills every other day. The reason: Morrisville, Pa., where they live, does not have fluoridated water. ''Our pediatrician recommended taking them,'' Mr. Hamill. ''There's no lack of evidence that it helps to prevent tooth decay.''

title: Writing for Readers
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Battle; Benedict Arnold, Hero
description: On June 22, 1777, 8,200 seasoned soldiers, including a German brigade in blue, Indians in war paint and more than seven regiments of British infantry in scarlet headed south from their base in Canada. Their commander was Gen. John Burgoyne -- Gentleman Johnny, they called him -- a playwright, bon viveur and Member of Parliament. He was headed straight into the battle of the millennium.

title: Song of India Migrates as Tabla Hip-Hop
description: ON a Saturday night this month at Constitution Hall, young women in long braids and shimmering, sequined outfits sashayed onto stage, carrying water jugs and swinging their hips to Punjabi folk songs. Young men with sky-high turbans, some with two-headed drums, whirled, leaping and heaving their shoulders in rhythm, their arms raised to the roof. Every now and then, dancers clasped their legs around a partner's torso and spun at breakneck speed. At other times, they built human pyramids atop one another's shoulders.

title: The World: Born Again; The Doves of Yesteryear Fly Off to a Different War
description: THINK of NATO's 50th anniversary summit meeting as the first war council of the cold war's anti-warriors.

title: Tigers and Cannolis
description: The White Plains High School Tigers, New York State basketball champions, received their just desserts on April 8 when County Executive Andrew J. Spano presented the team with four dozen cannolis, courtesy of one of their rival teams.

title: The World; How Globalism Ruined An Asian Success Story
description: HIS children were weeping and his wife looked shell-shocked. But as the guards led him away to serve a six-year prison sentence last week, Malaysia's ousted Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, seemed to be prepping himself for the next round of a boxing match.

title: Tennis Solution
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Q & A/Mary Travers; When Life Is a Song, and Also a Cause
description: MARY TRAVERS, folk music icon, mother, grandmother and idealist, lives quietly with her husband, Ethan Robbins, two cats and a dog named Peaches in an exquisitely restored 250-year-old Redding farmhouse. The house is filled with books, antiques and memorabilia from worldwide touring as part of the group called Peter, Paul and Mary.

title: Correction
description: The Good Eating column on April 4 misstated the telephone number of the restaurant Alouette. The correct number is (212) 222-6808.

title: Finding All of the Piano's Voices
description: AT the beginning of her solo program ''The Exploding Piano,'' Kathleen Supove sits at a keyboard in deep concentration and makes graceful, delicate motions. But the audience does not hear the sound of a piano; Ms. Supove is playing a synthesizer programmed with her own voice, so that each time she presses a key, a spoken phrase resounds.

title: Stephanie Lynch, Andrew Douglass
description: Stephanie Carlin Lynch, the daughter of Jered Ann and James Brent Lynch of Quogue, N.Y., was married last evening to Andrew Behan Douglass, a son of Linda and Robert Royal Douglass of Greenwich, Conn. James Martin, a deacon, officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Charles M. Cary, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: American Sailor in Distress Discovers Many Friends
description: Neither wind nor rain nor broken mast will keep the American solo sailor Brad Van Liew from the completion of his appointed round. Or so it appears.

title: East 14th to 19th: A Global Sampler
description: BAMBOU **

title: A Vessel for China's Treasures
description: AT the center of China's largest and most cosmopolitan city, Shanghai's city fathers have completed a showcase of urban planning that reflects the times. A park in the middle of Shanghai, a long-neglected city that has been pegged by Chinese leaders as a model for the entire country, now embodies the best of China's efforts to become a more sophisticated and a culturally richer society.

title: Best Vision; Many Moons
description: It wasn't until the year 4.5 billion or so (reckoning from the birth of the planet) that an earthly life form managed to hurl some stuff into orbit -- beyond the atmosphere, to permanent residence in outer space, high enough to look down and see our tiny globe for what it is.

title: Welcome to Real Football World, Draftees
description: Usually, the top players and their families arrive for the National Football League draft full of hope and optimism and leave with even more. Often the day is one of smiles all around, an oozy feeling of warmth among the families after an exhausting process that finally leads to a new address along with new riches. Instant peace.

title: Picking Quarterbacks as Easy as 1-2-3
description: Few quarterbacks have undergone the kind of scrutiny Kentucky's Tim Couch received this month, of everything from the way he selected an agent to his grip on the football.

title: Old Sewers and a New Stink
description: When the tide is high and the rain comes down in buckets, people who live in western Chelsea brace themselves for a devilish brew that's been known to surge from the area's old sewers. Now some residents are making an issue out of it.

title: As Beijing Pretties Up, Migrants Face Expulsion
description: ''How can they get rid of us?'' said a disbelieving Yang Zhuju, sitting with her shoe-repair equipment in the ruins of the Dragon Temple street market. ''What we do benefits the everyday life of Beijing residents.''

title: The Biggest Anniversary; Reflections On a Thousand Years
description: Big birthdays are, even more, occasions for reflection -- and that is the purpose of the series of six special issues of The Times Magazine beginning today. The idea of reviewing 1,000 years is daunting, but its closing offers a promontory from which it is possible to scan the past for insight into the future. It would be presumptuous to approach such a long span of history from merely one perspective, no matter how symmetrically it is, like an orange, split apart. On the contrary. These issues are intended to offer six wholly different perspectives.

title: Party Animals
description: Artists, writers, humanitarians and a few dogs and cats find enough reason to celebration.

title: The Installment Plan Can Be a Bad Deal
description: ALMOST every guarantee of investment performance isn't worth the paper on which it's printed. But there is an exception: the guarantee that comes with the strategy called dollar cost averaging. People who use this approach know that in at least one respect, they will always do better than average.

title: April 11-17; A Medicaid Gap
description: A side effect of the 47 percent drop in welfare rolls has been an increase in the number of low-income people who have lost their Medicaid and have no other health insurance. Almost everyone who leaves welfare for work is entitled to keep Medicaid, but studies show that some states have improperly discouraged people from seeking it. ROBERT PEAR

title: Best Treaty; The Empire Strikes Out
description: International treaties are generally agreements between the strong and the weak in which the latter agrees to do what the former asks. As the ancient historian Thucydides put it, ''The strong do what they can; the weak do what they must.'' But some treaties also mark the birth of whole new concepts of international relations.

title: We All Came From Mars!
description: THE FIFTH MIRACLE The Search for the Origin and Meaning of Life. By Paul Davies. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: The View From/Mamaroneck; Job Matchmaker's Goal: Keeping Workers Close to Home
description: THEY are not generally the kinds of places that everyone associates with joblessness. Mamaroneck and Larchmont have upscale reputations and in the public consciousness seem to typify affluent Sound Shore communities.

title: Giants Make Petitgout Their Surprise First Pick
description: When it was the Giants' turn to announce their first-round choice in today's National Football League draft, unlike every team before them, they took less than a New York minute.

title: Best Sermon; A Pilgrim's Progress
description: When I think of a definitive sermon, I turn to that formative moment in 1630 when John Winthrop, Governor of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, preached to his fellow immigrants aboard the ship Arbella. Winthrop's sermon, ''Christian Charity: A Model Hereof,'' would have remained known only to the elite class of Puritan scholars were it not for his use of the biblical image of the ''city set on a hill'' to describe the moral purpose of the Pilgrim adventure into the unknown. That image, from Jesus' Sermon on the Mount in Matthew's Gospel, is what gave Winthrop's sermon life and Matthew's text a new context, providing perhaps the most enduring metaphor of the American experience -- that of the exemplary nation called to virtue and mutual support.

title: Campus Safety
description: The state's new Campus Safety Act, signed into law this month by Gov. George E. Pataki, requires the prompt investigation of violent felonies on college campuses. The law also requires colleges to file prompt reports on missing students.

title: Best Speech; Faithful, Even in Death
description: The second millennium boasts a stirring address by Ireland's Robert Emmet on the gallows. (''Let no man write my epitaph.'') The American patriotic rouser rivaling Patrick Henry's ''Give me liberty or give me death!'' was the grandiloquent and yet eloquent Fourth of July speech that Representative Daniel Webster suggested might have been given by John Adams: ''Sink or swim, live or die, survive or perish, I give my hand and my heart to this vote.'' Toward the millennium's end, Winston Churchill told an embattled House of Commons, ''I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears and sweat.'' F.D.R. and J.F.K. knew how to provide oratorical uplift, as did the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., with ''I have a dream.'' The best closing line was from Anatoly Shcharansky, who, after addressing his dissidence to the courtroom and beyond, turned to the rubber-stamp Soviet judges with, ''To you I have nothing to say.''

title: What the Material Contributes to the Work
description: 'Paper'

title: Silver Town Stakes New Claim to Fame: No Phones
description: At the turn of the last century, this mountain town had 300 residents, six hotels, five saloons, four general stores, a newspaper, its own band and a small local phone company. But as the ''Bonanza Queen'' and other silver mining claims became unprofitable, the town lost most of those amenities, including phones.

title: Best Naval Battle; Full Nelson
description: These last 1,000 years have been shaped by battles, and perhaps most decisively by sea battles. There was the great galley action at Lepanto in 1571, when from the naval point of view the Ottoman Turks were firmly checked -- 117 Turkish galleys were taken and 80 destroyed; only 12 Christian vessels were lost. There was the Spanish Armada, so ferociously pursued and battered right up the Channel and beyond by Sir Francis Drake and his companions that Spain's moral power and reputation were permanently damaged.

title: Art From West Unveiled in New Nagoya Museum
description: There is a new museum to visit in Japan, filled not with hanging scrolls or woodblock prints, but mainly with Impressionist paintings and Mediterranean antiquities.

title: 21 Years After Unofficial Finish, Jennings Will Count
description: Lynn Jennings's memory plays tricks.

title: April Arlow, Roderick McConnell
description: April Elizabeth Arlow, a kindergarten teacher, and Roderick McConnell, a cruise ship officer, were married last evening in Huntington, N.Y. Cantor Jeffrey Forman officiated at the Huntington Townhouse.

title: A Manager Who Moved From Innings To Arias
description: WHEN a headhunter called him in 1986 to ask if he wanted to become house manager for the Met, James H. Naples Jr. immediately thought of shortstops at Shea Stadium, not coloraturas at Lincoln Center. At the time, Mr. Naples, then 35, was in charge of a staff of 900 as manager of Yankee Stadium.

title: A Modern Folk Tradition Woven From Many Older Ones
description: CALL it a gathering of the clans.

title: Isaiah Berlin, Friend
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Clown; Rebel in a Housedress
description: Any comic playwright worth her salt would cite Shakespeare's ''All's Well That Ends Well,'' Sheridan's ''School for Scandal'' and Lucy Ricardo's ''A Tree Grows in Havana'' as seminal influences. In the 17th episode of the ''I Love Lucy'' TV series, which ran from 1951 to 1957, Lucy pens a heartwarming drama about a Cuban tobacco picker, hoping that her nightclub-star husband, Ricky, will play the lead. Ricky, however, refuses to perform for the Wednesday Afternoon Fine Arts League, so Lucy rewrites the play, creating a refined English version that will star her neighbor Fred. On opening day, Ricky finds out that a Hollywood bigwig will be in the audience and wants back in. He appears onstage in what he believes is the Cuban story, while Fred, his wife, Ethel, and Lucy hold forth in an English drawing room. The resulting play within a play is a farce worthy of the classics.

title: Is Mr. Gates Pouring Fuel On His Rivals' Fire?
description: THE worthies of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology had just finished thanking William H. Gates profusely for paying for a planned new computer science building with a handwritten personal check for $20 million. No sooner had Mr. Gates walked out the door last week than a procession of leading researchers at the university's renowned Laboratory for Computer Science sketched out projects and visions of the technological future that all headed in one direction: away from the personal computer.

title: For Artist, It All Begins With Children
description: GRIPPING a palette knife with his fist, Alex Gates splotched mustard-colored acrylic paint onto a large sheet of paper. The artist from Lido Beach studied the glob intently, then wiped his knife clean on a rag. He dipped the tool into a cupcake tin and streaked red paint across his canvas.

title: Temporarily Yours
description: TEN years ago, I took a job stuffing envelopes. It was a necessity: I had just graduated from college and had no idea what I wanted to do with my life, but the lenders who had financed my college education weren't sympathetic to my existential crisis.

title: Struck by Lightning
description: AN UNFINISHED MEMOIR By Jose Limon. Edited by Lynn Garafola. Illustrated. 207 pp. Hanover, N.H.: Wesleyan University Press/ University Press of New England. $29.95.

title: A Downer for the Noshers
description: For the past 64 years, the Grossinger family's strudels, Hungarian scones and praline ice cream cakes have claimed a loyal following for their Columbus Avenue bakeries, first at the 76th Street shop, which closed in 1991, and then for Grossinger's Uptown Bakery at 570 Columbus Avenue, near 88th Street.

title: Best of Breed; Mongrel Nation
description: I like to tell people she is a Sicilian goat hound. (Very rare breed, only a handful in this country.) I wax eloquent about her conformation. (Compact but diminutive: excellent for chasing goats across craggy landscapes.) I even make wistful noises about showing her. (Too bad the goat hound isn't recognized by the American Kennel Club -- she'd be a real contender for Best of Breed.)

title: Long May His Story Be Told
description: INVENTING WYATT EARP

title: The Orpheus of MTV
description: THE GROUND BENEATH HER FEET

title: Change the Knicks At the Top
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Suzanne Grotto, Christopher Calarco
description: Suznne Lura Grotto, the daughter of Vivian and Joseph Grotto of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Christopher Paul Calarco, a son of June Harden of Darien, Conn., and Rod Calarco of White Plains. The Rev. John H. Branson 3d performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Christ and Holy Trinity.

title: Keeping Good Count Of Film Festivals
description: Contrary to ''How Long Island Woos Lights, Camera and Action'' [April 11], there are actually five film festivals on Long Island, not four. The Stony Brook Film Festival is now heading into its fourth season and for the past two years actually incorporated the Long Island Film Festival into its larger and wider-reaching festival.

title: April 11-17; Quayle Tries Again
description: Announcing his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination, former Vice President Dan Quayle declared, ''I will lead the fight for our values -- and our families.''

title: 9 Groups Join in a Marriage of Art and Cultural Institutions
description: The gathering at the National Black Theater on East 125th Street Tuesday morning had the trappings of a wedding ceremony, with catered hors d'oeuvres and waiters in tuxedos. There was even a performance by a gospel choir.

title: Maria Bucaoto, John Marks
description: Maria Elena Bucaoto, the daughter of Reynalda and Paulino Bucaoto of Jamaica, Queens, was married yesterday to John Richard Marks, the son of Annette and Richard Marks of Mineola, N.Y. The Rev. Jeremiah P. O'Neill performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in Manhattan.

title: A Concerto For a Flute, A Prize For a Writer
description: When Melinda Wagner received a phone call from her music publisher an hour before the Pulitzer Prizes were announced on Monday, the composer was making formula for her 10-month-old daughter, Olivia.

title: My Dinner With Ross
description: Richard H. Brown, the new chief at Electronic Data Systems, has recruited a secret adviser with an E.D.S. past. A few weeks ago, he met with Ross Perot, the company founder, for a dinner lasting several hours in the private back room of a Dallas restaurant.

title: By Ballot, a Way to Influence Who Runs Schools and How
description: School board races throughout the state on Tuesday have drawn a variety of candidates, from a high school senior in Carteret to a college professor seeking to become the first black elected to public office in West Orange.

title: When a Rooster Makes Himself at Home
description: There's nothing unusual about being awakened by a rooster, but on Long Island, in the middle of Nassau County? Yet this has been the case for me most mornings since sometime last spring.

title: ISLANDERS 7, PENGUINS 2
description: The finale yesterday was simply a sweet end to a bitter season for the visiting Islanders. Once again, most things did not go right for them.

title: Perhaps Only Death Is Really Inevitable
description: Predicting where its business will be expanding, the Internal Revenue Service projects that the number of dead people who pay taxes will rise more than seven times as fast as the number of living taxpayers. Part of the reason may be that living Americans are not using opportunities to make gifts to children and grandchildren.

title: Making the Radish Patch More Exotic
description: THE usual vegetables that have been growing in gardens for eons are still popular. But as leisure and business travel increase, culinary tastes are expanding. Even produce markets are reflecting the changes.

title: Do Computers Help the Economy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Medical Insight; Pox Britannica
description: In early 18th-century English society, the beauty and intelligence of Lady Mary Wortley Montagu inspired the admiration of royals and the poetry of Alexander Pope. In 1717, she fell ill with smallpox while living in Constantinople with her husband, England's ambassador to Turkey.

title: Recidivist Bachelors
description: To the Editor:

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Best Feat of Engineering; Nearer My God
description: The instructions were simple. Build it of stone so it might stand forever against the ravages of time, wind, water and fire. Don't clutter the space with columns, but make it big. Replace as much of the walls as possible with glass to let the light of God shine through. Oh, and try not to go over budget. It was thus, during the 12th and 13th centuries, that teams of highly skilled builders and craftsmen created magnificent stone structures of unprecedented height and unrivaled beauty. The most impressive of these Gothic cathedrals still punctuate the landscape of northern France, standing in tribute to human ingenuity and faith in God.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the front page of the Arts and Leisure section today referring to an article about the composer of the new opera ''Resurrection'' misstates his given name. He is Tod Machover, not Tom.

title: OUTDOORS; Preparing to Survive Avalanche Season
description: Record snowfalls this year contributed to disastrous slides in North America and Europe, and avalanche centers continued to report fatalities such as a skier buried and killed near Ophir, Colo., on April 7. Now, even as warmth creeps up to the high Alpine, avalanche risk continues for spring and summer adventurers.

title: LeslieAnne Wade, Kevin McGinn
description: LeslieAnne Wade and Kevin Michael McGinn were married yesterday by the Rev. Patrick G. O'Donovan at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

title: Best Shot; War of Words
description: As every schoolkid used to know, the Battle of Hastings, at which the Normans defeated the Anglo-Saxons, changed the world -- 1066 and all that. Practically overnight, England, a loose federation of earldoms and baronies, became a feudal society and a European power. And with the gradual infusion into England of French, the language of the conquerors, English itself was transformed. Had the Saxons won, people in England, and even in America, perhaps, would still be named Tostig and Hrothgar, and English prose would include sheep-meat instead of mutton, work but not pleasure, and swiving but no romance.

title: Miss Mellifont And Mr. Teevan
description: Shevaun Marie Mellifont, a daughter of Kevin M. Mellifont of Bedminster, N.J., and the late Kathleen M. Mellifont, was married yesterday to Martin Owen Teevan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Teevan Sr. of Holmdel, N.J. Msgr. Kieran McHugh performed the ceremony at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Holmdel.

title: New Suspect Jailed in Death Of an Officer
description: Less than 24 hours after releasing a man wrongly held for almost a week as the prime suspect in the killing of an Orange, N.J., policewoman, the Essex County authorities said yesterday that another suspect, a 25-year-old Newark man, had been arrested and charged with the officer's murder.

title: Best Utopia; God Is in the Details
description: Utopia is a paradoxical concept. As a motivating idea -- improvement is desirable'' -- we can't do without it. But every time we try to implement it on a grand scale, we accomplish its disastrous opposite. Perhaps that is why the word itself means ''no place.''

title: Robust Italian Dishes Served in Yonkers
description: VALENTINO'S may lack the iconic aproned nonna moving about the room, decreeing that one and all, ''Mangia, mangia,'' but that spirit is here nonetheless. For more than a dozen years, Valentino Roina has been the driving force behind his restaurant, this consummate gentleman greeting friends with kisses and strangers with courtesy, shaking hands at departure. Despite the absence of the padrone's lofty chair -- apparently lost in the redecoration -- Valentino's vital hands-on approach is clearly responsible for the long success of this restaurant.

title: Q. & A.
description: Allocating Shares In a Co-op

title: The World: Clinton Foreign Policy; China: a Hot Issue That Takes the Back Burner
description: IN their new book ''Preventative Defense'' (Brookings Institution Press), former Defense Secretary William J. Perry and a former Pentagon colleague, Ashton B. Carter, argue that 10 years into the post-cold war, Washington forgets that some nations matter a lot more than others.

title: Political Briefing; National Party Rules? Forget About Them
description: The way Democratic leaders in South Carolina figured it, the Republicans, already on a roll in the state, would get a free publicity ride if they were the only party on the Presidential primary ballot next Feb. 26. So when the State Democratic Executive Committee met on Tuesday, it voted unanimously to hold the South Carolina Democratic primary on that date, too.

title: Best Port
description: There is no landfall like Venice -- and no port of departure either. Through Venice, the goods of Europe found their way to the East, and the treasures of the Orient came back in return. Out of its lagoon sailed the fleets that made Venice ''Lord of a Quarter and a Half Quarter of the Roman Empire''; back to its quays returned the victorious admirals, trailing from their sterns the waterlogged ensigns of defeated enemies. It was the port of Venice that sustained not only one of the most long-lived of all political entities -- the Most Serene Venetian Republic, which lasted from 697 to 1797 -- but also a virtuoso civilization of artists and architects, clever statesmen and complacent bankers, merchants and glassmakers and silken courtesans. Once a year the republic celebrated the allegorical marriage of Venice with the sea -- its citizens set out on barges to throw a single golden ring into the waters, sealing the union forever. Forever? Talk has been of Venice sinking beneath the flood. But it has not been so. So rich is the port in experience, so incomparably hemmed around by beauty, that it still remains a prodigy among the havens, a true bride of the sea, a port of a thousand years. Jan Morris, author of ''The World of Venice''

title: The Best Of the Last 1,000 Years
description: Big birthdays are occasions for reflection as well as celebration, and it is difficult to imagine a bigger birthday than the one that is fast approaching: the birth of a new millennium. Starting today, The New York Times Magazine will mark the occasion with six special issues that look back on the last thousand years.

title: Girl Talk, or Just Smoke?
description: To the Editor:

title: Suddenly, a Big Score for the Nets
description: It was like a gift from above, one night of nearly perfect basketball for a team that has experienced a season filled with hardship in the form of injuries, embarrassment and poor play. The Nets, in their finest performance of the year, closed their disappointing West Coast trip Friday night with a dominating 121-91 victory over the talented Seattle SuperSonics.

title: Rooms With a View, From the Inside Out
description: AT Dwight Elementary School in Fairfield, students, faculty and staff got a pleasant surprise this year when they returned from summer vacations. There, in bright, bold beautiful color along an 8-by-16-foot expanse of vestibule wall, was a mural depicting the school and the myriad of activities that reflect the academic and social events of the school calendar.

title: Best Love Song; Two Girls and a Guy
description: Opinions on music can be stubborn and lonely things. I believe, for instance, that the 20th century's most intoxicating waltz is ''Let's Go Fly a Kite'' from ''Mary Poppins.'' But don't ask me, with any strenuousness, to justify it, or I will gnaw my fist and stare forlornly out the window. Nonetheless, a calm certitude can descend when considering the finest love song of the millennium. Such a song is really a matter less of opinion than of clear fact, the determination of which can be helped along by the following scientific method.

title: The Great Escape
description: THE LEPER'S COMPANIONS

title: Every Good Marigold Deserves Favor
description: ADJECTIVALLY speaking, the most coveted garden flowers tend to be choice, delicate, exquisite or elegant, and preferably also fragrant. Roses, in other words, or lilies or lilacs or masses of sky-blue flax on gracefully nodding stems, but definitely not marigolds.

title: Skepticism In Algeria: Failed Ballot Dashes Dream of Democracy
description: When Algeria's presidential campaign began last month, the talk among optimists was of setting a new standard for the Muslim world by installing a leader recognized by the 30 million Algerians as the people's choice.

title: As Two Far-Off Executions Proceed, a Protest Plays
description: A fierce wind blew through the traffic island on Broadway at 46th Street Tuesday evening, but the idea that two men would die at the hands of the Government was more chilling to members of the Living Theater. They went ahead with their performance of ''Not in My Name,'' a piece they mount in Times Square each time an execution takes place in the United States.

description: So what position is favored by most National Football League teams as far the overall first pick of the draft?

title: Best Toy
description: One day in the late 17th century, the British philosopher John Locke noticed a friend's children playing with wooden blocks inscribed with letters of the alphabet. The oldest child, Locke discovered, had learned to spell by playing with the blocks. Intrigued, Locke described the blocks in his popular 1693 book, ''Some Thoughts Concerning Education.''

title: Watching the People Who Watch Over The Mentally Ill; Questions Disturb State Health Officials After Guard Admits Raping 4 in His Care
description: THE item that tipped it was a pair of Fila sneakers.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: MUSIC; A Complex Outburst of Despair
description: THE recorded voices of Pope John XXIII, Hitler, Stalin and Churchill; the rattle of artillery fire and the cheering of crowds; the writings of Ludwig Wittgenstein, James Joyce, Ezra Pound and Albert Camus; excerpts from Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' and the Beatles' ''Hey Jude,'' and the liturgy of the Roman Catholic Mass for the Dead: these are just some of the materials layered into a swirling stream of consciousness that becomes a portrait of our times in the ''Requiem for a Young Poet'' by the German composer Bernd Alois Zimmermann.

title: Warding Off the Buying Hordes
description: Few mutual funds have benefited as much from the stock market's recent rally as Janus 20, the $26 billion fund whose strategy of holding 20 to 30 mostly large-capitalization growth stocks has more than doubled its investors' money since the beginning of 1998.

description: Wayne Gretzky's incomparable career finally comes to an end today.

description: A 5-year-old boy was struck and killed by a van yesterday as he crossed the street near his home in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Dancing and Skiing With the Yaks
description: BEFORE the Yellow River turns yellow, before it is even much of a river, its blue-green waters meander gently through the sandstone crags of China's Qinghai Province. A one-lane road, rutted and unpaved, winds alongside. Last spring, two friends and I hired a guide and a car and traveled this road for three days, until we reached its terminus high in the Anyemaqen Mountains.

title: Knicks Look Extinct As Raptors Emerge
description: John Wallace used to be a Knick. John Thomas and Doug Christie, too. Did we mention Charles Oakley, the manual laborer who outfoxed and outboxed his former team last night?

title: Best Town Square
description: The Piazza del Campidoglio in Rome, laid out as we see it today by Michelangelo on the height of the Capitoline Hill, tells us more about the man-made environment than any other public square. Once, the Etruscan temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus Capitolinus crowned the summit. The god owned the hill. In time he failed; the temple crumbled. The place filled up with inessentials. Then, Michelangelo was given a chance at the site. He cleared out a space defined at the sides by palazzi opening diagonally from it. In the center he placed an equestrian statue of Marcus Aurelius with his arm stretched out, as if pushing the buildings back. High above Rome, the Emperor rides forward, saying, Mankind creates the city, opens up a place to live in it and moves onward beyond it, alone. Vincent Scully, Sterling Professor emeritus of the History of Art at Yale

title: With Process Server, Where's the Justice?
description: Re ''What Happens If Process Server Doesn't Serve?'' [April 4]: Where is the prosecutorial zeal that would treat the criminal actions of Norman L. Yellon and complicit lawyers with penalties commensurate with the harm caused? People lost their homes! People's financial security was destroyed! Most distressing, family court matters were placed in jeopardy and turmoil. The average citizen feels put upon by a conspiracy of arrogance within the court system. Why not use this case to bring about reform?

title: Clinton in Contempt: Ruling Was Fair

title: Best Species; Microbes 3, Humans 2
description: Let us mince words. When we say ''best,'' we mean some kind of success, implying the existence of goals, which in turn are the exclusive property of organisms and not of species. Where the goal of a runner in a track meet is to break the tape, where a dragonfly succeeds when it snatches a fly from the air for dinner, where even a colon bacterium reverses the spin of its flagella, causing it to tumble and depart in a new direction that leads to dissolved sugar, it takes an organism to have a best.

That's why this 22-year-old left-hander was the fifth quarterback selected in yesterday's National Football League draft, behind Tim Couch, Donovan McNabb, Akili Smith and Daunte Culpepper.

title: Correction

Stearns disinterred the old Times essay and, while finding it not without insight, noted the conspicuous omission of ''an amazing number of developments that we now consider to have been crucial in the 19th century.'' Among the missing were the abolition of slavery, the artistic revolution of Impressionism and virtually the entirety of Asia.

description: To the Editor:

description: AT first glance it seems pretty simple. A food processing company with a strong brand in a relatively narrow niche finds the competition toughening and the niche's sales trend flattening. To grow, it needs to extend its brand to new product categories, to make acquisitions, or both. That calls for a big financial commitment, which most companies can raise by tapping capital markets.

title: Cartoons to Lull the Children While Parents Buy Them Clothes
description: Except for toys, it seems, most children hate to shop. But children need clothes and adults have to shop for them. N.Y.C.K., or New York City Kids, at 495 Seventh Avenue (between 36th and 37th Street) is a new children's clothing store that provides diversionary television sets, tuned to endless cartoons, while parents hunt for clothes.

description: Private Hospital Rooms No Longer a Luxury

description: Sow cool-weather crops like lettuce, chard, spinach and rhubarb. Keep seedbeds well watered: greens, particularly lettuce, will be bitter if the soil dries out.

description: HURRICANES 1, SENATORS 1

title: A Photographer's Many Faces
description: The art stars of the early 1980's are mostly in eclipse these days, but not Cindy Sherman, who remains the darling of critics and audiences alike, thanks to her haunting and sardonic photographic impersonations of stereotypical female images. Her artistic influence and critical recognition were capped in 1995 when the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan paid an estimated $1 million for a complete set of her 69 black-and-white ''Untitled Film Stills'' (1977-80), generally considered the artist's first mature work.

title: A Positive Note
description: To the Editor: Like Barbara Comins, I have found solace in the street and Metro music of Paris (''The Melody Lingers On,'' Feb. 28.) After an exhausting day trying to do business with curt bank tellers and postal clerks hidden behind thick glass partitions, I became disheartened as I began my first month as a student in France. Later that day, on my way to the Rodin Museum to meet the rest of my group, a reggae musician walked into my subway car, stood next to me and sang Bob Marley's ''Three Little Birds.'' I was lifted by his music and left a hefty tip. His simple song put my bad day into perspective and helped launch my year abroad on a positive note.

title: Afraid of Shakespeare? Not These Students
description: JAMES ANDREASSI JR. loves to tell about a tough-talking teen-ager with an arrest record who was a reluctant student in his Shakespeare program.

description: THE cover of Revlon Inc.'s latest annual report could easily be mistaken for the front of a glamour magazine, with the model Cindy Crawford and the actress Cybill Shepherd looking flawless in the company's ''tawny'' blush and ''hot cocoa'' lipstick.

title: Managing When Profit Isn't the Goal
description: NONPROFIT organizations, long known as an invisible sector in the economy, have grown rapidly over the last two decades, now accounting for 8 percent of the gross domestic product.

title: Revving Up the Candle Power
description: UNTIL the invention of electricity, the world was obsessed with light: how to get it, how to increase it, how to use it. And no century explored it with more style than the 18th.

title: April 11-17; Tougher Rules Planned For Sport Utility Vehicles
description: Large sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks may not be allowed to go on emitting several times as much pollution as cars. The Clinton Administration is in the final stages of drafting rules that would tighten emissions standards for cars, mini-vans, small sport utility vehicles and small pickups by 2007 and would require large sport utility vehicles and pickups to meet the new, more stringent standards by 2009.

title: Out of Egypt
description: A BORDER PASSAGE

title: Best Story; Narrate Or Die
description: The best story ever told? Perhaps the story of the two brothers, both kings, who found that their wives were unfaithful, took bloody vengeance, and set out into the world to travel until they found someone less fortunate than they were. They encountered a demon who kept a woman in a glass chest with four locks; she came out while he slept and showed them 98 rings she had collected from chance lovers and insisted on having sex with the princes to make it a round 100. The princes decided that the demon was more unfortunate than they were and returned to their kingdoms. There the elder brother, Shahrayar, still angry over his wife's betrayal, instituted a reign of terror, marrying a virgin each day and handing her to his vizier for execution at dawn. The vizier's daughter Shahrazad, a woman both wise and learned, beseeched her father to give her to the king. On the wedding night, the bride asked that her younger sister, Dinarzad, might sleep under the bed, so that when the king had ''finished with Shahrazad,'' the younger girl, as the sisters had agreed, might ask Shahrazad to tell a story to while away the time until dawn. When dawn came, the story was not finished, and the curious king stayed execution for a night. Shahrazad continued to tell tales, which gave rise to other tales, all of which were unfinished at dawn. The king's narrative curiosity kept Shahrazad alive, day after day. She narrated a stay of execution, a space in which she bore three children. And in the end, the king removed the sentence of death, and they lived happily ever after.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday on Sister Rose Thering, a Roman Catholic nun who works to improve relations between Christians and Jews, misstated the title of an anthology in which her study of Catholic textbooks was published. It is ''Faith and Prejudice'' (Paulist Press).

title: Patrick Cashin and Terry William
description: WHILE growing up in Old Bridge, N.J., Patrick Cashin often performed as a clown at birthday parties, which horrified his three brothers. ''My being a clown was always a source of embarrassment for them,'' he remembered. ''The other kids in the neighborhood were like: 'Your brother's going down the driveway wearing a clown costume. What goes on in your house?' ''

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: The Skinny Women; Thin in a Den of Fat
description: ''I FEEL testosterone surging through my veins,'' said Susan Sistrom, a doll-size woman engulfed in a swelling pool of portly men at Sparks Steak House in midtown on Wednesday night.

title: Hampton Bays Lifts Ban on Development
description: A six-month moratorium on development in Hampton Bays has been lifted as the Southampton Town Board considers alternative plans for the hamlet, which sits astride the only overland approach to the South Fork.

title: Long-Distance Passes For Buses to Be Sold
description: Passes good for unlimited bus travel along three routes in the western and eastern United States and Florida (and part of southern Canada) are being sold by Ameribus, a new service set to start April 22 in the West and May 11 in the East and Florida.

title: Susan Weinberg, Michael Walden
description: Susan Lynn Weinberg, the daughter of Karen and Stanley Weinberg of Jamesburg, N.J., was married last evening to Michael Henry Walden, the son of Barbara Walden of New York and James A. Walden of Jupiter, Fla. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Letting Litter Lie Is No Way to Run a Railroad, Locals Say
description: In this quiet neighborhood of single-family homes, the streets are marked by well-manicured lawns and colorful flower beds. That is, except Sacket Avenue.

title: Streetscapes /The Adlon and the Aljomor, at 54th Street and Seventh Avenue; A 1912 Trove of Design and Show-Business History
description: IN the shiny glitz of the revived theater district, the 12-story apartment house at 200 West 54th Street doesn't look like much at first. Parts of its unusual facade are missing, balconies have been removed, and its gaudy storefronts are reminiscent of old-style Las Vegas. But the building, the Adlon, is one of the most complex apartment houses designed by the architects George and Edward Blum, and a group of co-op residents is struggling to reclaim this delicate 1912 masterpiece from decay.

title: The World; On Killing From Beyond Harm's Way
description: I FLEW on a B-52 raid once. The enormous plane took off from Guam, refueled over the Philippines, dropped its bombs on North Vietnam through a dense overcast, turned around, refueled again and landed safely back on Guam. In 16 or 18 hours, we sighted no enemy. All we saw was sky and clouds, and the whole mission felt antiseptic and unreal compared with the nasty, muddy, often lethal reality that the foot soldiers faced.

title: Best Christian; Wayward Christian Soldiers
description: In the entire history of Christendom, the darkest chapter is that of the Crusades. Jerusalem, which had fallen to Islam in 638, was reconquered by the First Crusade in 1099, after which the Christian conquerors slaughtered all the Muslims in the city and burned all the Jews alive in the main synagogue; the Second was a fiasco; the Third, after the Muslim recapture of the city in 1187, failed to regain it, and the Fourth, proclaimed by Pope Innocent III in 1198, wasn't a Crusade at all -- merely a series of deceptions, born of a cynicism almost unbelievable.

title: Southwest Airlines On Islip Service
description: Southwest Airlines said last week that new service the Dallas-based discount airline began from MacArthur Airport in Islip last month is meeting company expectations.

title: A Century Of Art: Just How American Was It?
description: ARTWISE, was this really the American century? We take the cliche for granted because, well, because we are so arrogant. Never mind that it's just a catch phrase cooked up in 1941 by Henry Luce, the most thoroughly unreconstructed of American chauvinists, partly out of missionary zeal and partly to sell his magazine.

title: From Horses To TV Shows
description: To the Editor:

title: For Gretzky, the Final Practice for the Final Game
description: There were more smiles and laughter than usual today for a team already out of the running and going through the motions of a final practice. At least until the end, when Rangers Coach John Muckler gathered the team and demanded that Wayne Gretzky skate a couple more laps up and down the ice.

title: Lucy Hahn, James Burks Jr.
description: Lucy Ann Hahn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kon Soo Hahn of Moosic, Pa., was married yesterday to Dr. James Alton Burks Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burks of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: A Spring Feast of Roasted or Marinated Vegetables
description: THERE is nothing like spring in London when it is not raining. When I was there recently, the parks were filled with flowers and people were sprawled on deck chairs, their faces turned to catch those rare rays of sun that put the whole town in a good mood. In the markets, there were all kinds of young vegetables on display: ivory-colored new potatoes the size of walnuts, baby carrots and turnips, fresh peas, fava beans, thin stalks of asparagus, artichokes and leeks like pencils. I wanted to try them all -- so I did.

title: Give Them Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Flather-Morgan and Mr. Cist
description: Dr. Alexandra Wright Flather-Morgan and David Bishop Cist were married yesterday afternoon in Annapolis, Md. The Rev. John R. Price performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Episcopal Church.

title: Best Meal; Nouvelle World Order
description: The most important meal of the first millennium was a seder. And it was extremely well documented; for 2,000 years artists have been painting what was on the table at the Last Supper.

title: Follow the Bouncing Passers
description: Boomer Esiason, who managed to keep his sense of humor after buffetings in Cincinnati and New York, had a smile yesterday as he contemplated the Bengals' first-round pick, Oregon quarterback Akili Smith.

title: Among Hill Tribes In Northern Thailand
description: TRAVELERS to the mountainous rural province of Mae Hong Son, near Thailand's northwest border with Myanmar, will find it still wild and exotic, populated by Chinese and Burmese ethnic immigrants and protected by its remote location in the Himalayan foothills. Waterfalls, caves, raft able rivers, working elephants and vast tracts of teak forests make it attractive for adventure travelers, as well as some group tours.

title: JERSEYANA; He Calls Himself the 'Ultimate Pop Artist'
description: ''Get into trouble . . . 10 cents'' reads a weathered sign on a makeshift booth labeled ''House of Trouble.''

title: Best Garden; Empire Under Glass
description: The Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew hold a singular place in our ken, as one of the first, and perhaps still supreme examples, of a garden that was conceived as a representation of the world. Not simply a metaphor of the world, a symbolic abstraction like Le Notre's Versailles in 17th-century France, but a quintessence drawn from the geographical and biological world of history, a world that emerged in the 18th century with the great explorers and exploitations that radiated from and returned to Europe -- and consistently to England. The pictures of Kew in the late 1700's afford a view of a moment poised between the regular symmetries and elegant perspectives of the late Baroque gardens and the flowing lines and elusive prospects of the Romantic Age. The garden reflects the aspiration of the time: to rediscover Nature and what was called natural.

title: Handling Hazards: Slow Elevator, Picky Doorman
description: Here are three quick-witted, anecdotal paperback guides to experiencing and appreciating New York in all its diversity -- from the tried-and-true favorites to the weird and wacky.

title: 89-Year-Olds Need Not Apply
description: THE SETTING -- A room with a toy bin, finger paintings on the wall and children playing just outside in the hall might seem an unlikely place to find a group of people whose average age is 95.

title: Where Cocktails and Dinner Are Made for Each Other
description: For many, the choice used to be as simple as red wine with meat and white wine with fish. But at Blackbird, a two-week-old restaurant at 60 East 49th Street (between Madison and Park Avenues), the prevailing belief is that cocktails and food can pair just as easily.

title: Best Ergonomic Design; Bound to Succeed
description: Engineering is easy -- you can go to school and learn it. Art is hard. An ergonomic masterpiece is a feat of engineering that is so beautiful, it has turned into art and gone into orbit. Locating the ergonomic masterpiece of this millennium depends on how we play the game. The book came into its own with the invention of the printing press around 1440 but originated in classical Rome, or maybe earlier. Some unknown genius looked at a scroll and figured, Why not fold this thing up and bind it at one end? An astonishing thought; who knew what ''bind it at one end'' even meant? The result is so compact and handy, so durable and easy to operate, it ranks as the ergonomic masterpiece of all time. Replacing books by computers is like replacing cut flowers with plastic ones.

title: Now 'Wit' Belongs To the World
description: IT is no news that regional theater is the commercial theater's lifeline, but the time is right for reiteration, now that ''Wit,'' by Margaret Edson, no surprise, landed the Pulitzer Prize last Monday.

title: Competition for Patients Spurs Some Hospitals Toward Providing Only Private Rooms
description: Private rooms in hospitals were once only for those affluent patients willing to pay as much as $300 a day extra for some peace from the chatter, beeping machines and groans coming from the next bed. Now a growing number of hospitals are eliminating shared rooms and offering all patients -- Medicare and Medicaid, rich and indigent -- their own rooms, often at no extra charge.

title: The Nation: Guns and Poses; Political Props and Campaigns That Take Off, or Crash
description: LAST week in Washington, the Titanic was involved in another disaster. Just before advocates for senior citizens planned to hoist on stage a 24-foot cabin cruiser bearing the slogan ''Medicare Vouchers Are a Titanic Mistake,'' the Capitol Police sank their efforts. Judging the symbolic Titanic too heavy for the stage, authorities banished it to the side, depriving Senator Edward M. Kennedy and other speakers of a camera-friendly backdrop.

title: IN MY...TOTE BAG: KATE WHITE
description: Kate White has had to rethink her life since moving to Hearst's Cosmopolitan magazine as editor in chief last fall from the more circumspect, mom-oriented Redbook.

title: Best Fashion; A Perfect Set of Teeth
description: Zip! I was reading Schopenhauer last night.

title: Backtalk; Fine Lines For Ethics In Sports
description: ''Medicine is just about life and death,'' said the graybeard Welsh philosopher Andrew Edgar last weekend. ''Sports is more important than that.''

title: Best Musical Instrument; Of Thee I Sing
description: Of all the gifts of nature that humans have had to fashion into musical instruments, none have proved more versatile and sublime than the most common: the human voice. Alone, as part of a chorus, chanting in prayer or in furious outbursts of wordless sound, the voice is a blessed paradox, for it uses the same medium as speech to allow us to escape the limits of language.

title: Karen Milrod and Neil Roth
description: Karen Lisa Milrod and Neil Adam Roth are to be married today by Rabbi Donald S. Milrod, an uncle of the bride, at the Essex House in Manhattan.

title: Political Briefing; A Bleak Forecast For a Matching Fund
description: More bad news from the tax man for those who would be President . . .

title: Edith Anderson, 83, Chronicler of Life in East Germany, Dies
description: Edith Anderson, an American writer who defied postwar ruin and harsh political realities to resettle in divided Berlin with her German Communist husband and lived just long enough to see her cold war memoir published and praised as a literary event, died on Tuesday at her home in Berlin. She was 83.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph last Sunday in The Guide, showing Grace Soffer's painting ''Watergarden II,'' was printed upside down.

title: Company Adds Magic Twist to Businesses
description: PICTURE this: the chairman of the board of a Fortune 500 company takes the podium at a sales motivation meeting; suddenly he disappears. The audience gasps. All eyes are riveted to the spot when -- presto -- the chairman materializes. The tone is set. Attention has been captured. Measurably increased sales are a result.

title: The World; Missile Test Success! (Next Time We'll Hit the Target.)
description: THE Pentagon's missile defense enthusiasts have a long history of exaggerating claims going back to the Reagan Administration's ''Star Wars'' plan to zap incoming warheads. But the spinmeisters spun out of control last month when they claimed that the military's latest attempt to blast an attacking missile out of the sky had achieved 16 of 17 objectives -- even though it failed to shatter the target.

title: Blue-Collar Verse
description: The Mercy

title: E.P.A. to Give States Edict On Clean Air for U.S. Parks
description: On some days in Acadia National Park in Maine, the air pollution is so bad, visibility is half what it might be on a clear day.

title: New Life for Great Theater (Even Olivier)
description: AS Basil Hero tells it, the saving of Dustin Hoffman, Meryl Streep, Faye Dunaway and Wendy Wasserstein began three years ago in a Burger Heaven in midtown Manhattan.

title: Spending Bill Feared Likely to Repeat 1998 Fiasco
description: Congress tells itself year after year to craft a budget carefully and stick to it when spending the tax money Americans send in. Last year, it failed miserably, but this year could be worse, many members say.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Under Gemini: A Memoir

title: Monique Vasilchik and Bruce Kelson
description: Monique Maria Vasilchik and Bruce Borders Kelson were married last evening in Chestnut Hill, Pa. The Rev. William Gipson, the chaplain at the University of Pennsylvania, performed the ceremony at the Wharton Sinkler Estate.

title: Purgatory, U.S.A.
description: MY PEOPLE'S WALTZ

title: In Asian Markets, Some Signs of Spring
description: ECONOMICS is not accounting, but the sense seems to be spreading that Asia may be the FIFO region of the developing world: First in, first out of recession.

title: Composers Mining the Music of Their Youth
description: GOING to a contemporary-music concert in the 1970's to hear new works by young Americans could often be a discombobulating experience. The composers were baby-boomers who had grown up with Motown, rhythm-and-blues and 60's rock. Yet from some of the music they composed, you would have thought that they had been living in gas-lit garrets in Vienna during the 1920's, completely in thrall to the radical 12-tone works of Schoenberg, Webern and Berg.

title: Corrections
description: A report on the Travel Advisory page on April 4 about the Venetian Resort Hotel Casino in Las Vegas included an outdated reference to its opening date. After the section went to press, the opening was postponed from April 22. On Monday a hotel spokeswoman said it had been rescheduled for a date near the end of this month.

title: Best Magic Trick; Witchcraft As Statecraft
description: In September 1856, the French Government persuaded France's celebrated magician Jean-Eug ne Robert-Houdin, ''the father of modern magic,'' to come out of retirement and help suppress tribal revolutions against the French colonial government in Algeria.

title: There's More Than One Way to Fight a Fire
