description: VOLUNTEER firefighters were less than a mile away when the call came in on Feb. 17: a frame house was on fire in the Rowayton section of Norwalk, near the community's private beach. Less than four minutes later, according to Rowayton firefighters, Hose Company No. 1 had its equipment at the scene and called for reinforcements, not from any of the five other fire companies in Norwalk, which employ paid firefighters, but from companies in nearby Darien that are staffed by volunteers.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Any Known Blood

title: All The World Loves A Runway
description: ONE Tuesday afternoon in mid-March, a flock of junior stylists and fashion editors debarked from a cloud of limousines and stepped into a gallery at the World Financial Center. After being ceremoniously greeted by some junior administrators and helping themselves to grilled chicken sandwiches, they were escorted to a long table, where there were tins of Altoids and a score sheet and pencil at each setting. ''This looks like fun,'' Shyama Patel, the fashion-market editor of New York magazine, said. ''I mean, I always wanted to be a panelist when I grew up.''

title: Such a Gorgeous Kid Like Him
description: TRUFFAUT

title: Silas May Have Ally in Jordan
description: Michael Jordan and George Shinn, owner of the Charlotte Hornets, are moving closer to a partnership that would result in Jordan's owning 50 percent of the team, a first for a former National Basketball Association player.

title: Now You Drive, the Andrettis Pump
description: WHEN Mario Andretti and his twin brother, Aldo, came to the United States from Italy as teen-agers in the 1950's, their first jobs were at a gasoline station in Nazareth, Pa., owned by their uncle, Lewis Messenlehner. Now, after a racing career that earned an Indy 500 victory, a Formula One world championship and worldwide fame, Mario Andretti finds himself back in the service-station business.

title: Skip Spence, Psychedelic Musician, Dies at 52
description: Alexander (Skip) Spence, a pivotal figure in psychedelic San Francisco rock, died Friday at Dominican Hospital in Santa Cruz, Calif., where he had lived. The cause was advanced lung cancer, said his son Omar. He was 52 years old.

title: A Relic of Imperial Aspirations
description: THREE local Chinese tourists were harrumphing their way down the mountain, indignantly complaining about what they had seen. I was heading up and paused to let them pass on the trail, so one of them advised me helpfully, ''No point in going on. There's nothing there but a rock.''

title: Yankees Can Do Anything, Even Slump
description: The Yankees of 1999 will help define the greatness of the 1998 Yankees before this summer is over. These Yankees are exceptional, with deep starting pitching and an even more explosive Derek Jeter and a hungry Roger Clemens. They will win many games, and they are the favorite to win the World Series.

title: God Bless Taxes
description: The Cost of Rights Why Liberty Depends on Taxes. By Stephen Holmes and Cass R. Sunstein. 255 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95.

title: ASIA-PACIFIC ISSUE; Bhutan, Remote and Rich in Tradition
description: FOR decades, the Himalayas have captured the popular imagination like few other destinations. But the once-legendary kingdoms of Tibet, Ladakh and Sikkim all now exist as Shangri-Las of the imagination. They have vanished from the map as independent states, having been absorbed by China or India. Many of their temples have been destroyed, their quiet isolation broken forever. And Nepal, which remains independent, has opened its arms wide to tourism and foreign aid, with predictably mixed results.

title: In the Region /New Jersey; Builders Rush to Meet Call for Flexible Structures
description: MOVING to capitalize on what they say is an increasing demand from tenants to combine several different operations under one roof, developers are constructing a spate of buildings that can accommodate uses from office to distribution and from research and development to light manufacturing and storage space.

title: A Word of Praise
description: To the Editor: Recently I had to return from Florida to New York University Hospital for a medical consultation. My car was parked at Avistar, an off-airport parking area at La Guardia. It had been raining on and off for three days. After numerous attempts by attendants to start the car, my old battery went dead. Jumping it did not help.

title: Play Spaces Pack Up Their Plastic Balls and Leave
description: THEY had giant balls and snaking tunnels, and for some parents, particularly those with very small children inhabiting very small apartments on miserably wet weekends, they were nothing short of salvation. They are indoor playgrounds, those Crayola-colored spaces that popped up across Manhattan in the last decade, letting kids be kids and parents stay sane.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 4 about countertenors misstated the given name of one of the first two of them to sing at the Metropolitan Opera. He was Michael Dash, not Daniel.

title: April 11-17; . . . and Some Questions From the Senate
description: In Washington, Mr. Starr defended his prosecutorial tactics and judgment in the investigation of the Lewinsky matter and reacted indignantly when senators referred to him as a legal zealot. During more than three hours before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, which is considering changes in the independent counsel law, Mr. Starr insisted he had followed Justice Department rules.

title: Explosion in London Wounds 40 Shoppers
description: An explosion tore through a packed south London street market today, leaving more than 40 people wounded by flying nails, shattered glass and debris. The police said the blast did not seem to be linked to the Northern Ireland conflict or the current impasse in peace negotiations there.

title: Best of All Road Teams Is Home for the Playoffs
description: DEVILS 4, PREDATORS 1

title: A First Test On Executions For Judges In Colorado
description: Three judges in Colorado made history this week in the state's first case in which a panel of judges, rather than a jury, decided whether a convicted murderer should be sentenced to death.

title: House Rules Too Tough, Tenants Say
description: A new rule that limits visiting hours at the Greenpoint Hotel, a single-room-occupancy hotel at 1109 Manhattan Avenue near Clay Street, has chafed tenants, who argue that the restrictions treat them like children and violate their rights.

title: Brooklyn Man, 21, Is Dead After Shooting in a Theater
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn man who dreamed of rapping his way to a better future died hours after he was shot in the back at a Flatbush movie theater during a Friday night screening of the film ''Life.''

title: By Your Lawn Statue, They Will Know You
description: BUSINESSES come and go along Long Island's crowded highways. Today's party store becomes tomorrow's mattress heaven; metamorphosis turns the tattoo parlor into a nail boutique and then into a kung fu school.

title: In Battle for Kosovo, Two Views of Reality
description: Until last week, the clampdown on information about Kosovo had been fairly thorough.

title: Where Academic and Career Skills Merge
description: IT was not a pretty sight. An array of computer boards lay splayed open, their wires dangling, as young workers juggled instruction manuals and precision tools trying to figure out how to turn them into usable computers again.

title: Kelley and Mills Among 4 Named
description: The 91-year-old John A. Kelley, Billy Mills, Francie Larrieu Smith and Nina Kuscsik were named yesterday to the National Distance Running Hall of Fame in Utica, N.Y. They will join the five members of the inaugural class -- Bill Rodgers, Frank Shorter, Ted Corbitt, Joan Benoit Samuelson and Kathrine Switzer.

title: Performance-Driven?
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Bumpy Going
description: I USED to go to action movies like ''Beverly Hills Cop'' when I wanted to see a car speeding down narrow residential streets, hitting bumps and flying into the air like some hapless elephant who has tripped over its own feet. Now I just look out my window. The speed bumps have arrived.

title: In Australia's Capital, Good Eating
description: CANBERRA, the capital and seat of Australia's Federal Government since 1927, is a showcase city. A totally planned urban entity -- even the central lake is man-made -- it is home to the National Library, the National Archives, the National Gallery, the newly opened National Portrait Gallery, the National Botanic Gardens and the National Museum of Australia.

title: League Studies Ways To Avoid Coach Stress
description: At this time of year, National Football League general managers and coaches get to the office at 6 A.M. and leave well after the sun comes down. And for the coaches, that kind of schedule is nothing new. Whether it is this weekend's draft, or the scouting combine, or coaching in the Pro Bowl, five hours of shut-eye is sleeping in to the average coach. Vacations? What are those?

title: Best Idea; Eyes Wide Open
description: By any human measure, a millennium is a considerable chunk of time. It is the longest fixed unit of time with a distinct name in common usage. At the beginning of our spent millennium and at frequent intervals throughout it, vexed to nightmare by the calendar, believers have awaited Christ's imminent return to rule over a new heaven and earth in a kingdom that was to run for the unthinkable span of a thousand years. Near the millennium's end, the Nazis, refiners of another one of the period's most persistent concepts, predicted their own third kingdom would last for a thousand years. They were off by 988.

title: Old Records In High Tech And Low
description: NEWS of Rachmaninoff's return from the grave by way of technology appeared in this space not long ago and has generated considerable response. I now have in hand CD's of Granados playing Granados and Debussy playing Debussy, both thanks to the same kind of updated player-piano technology that made the great Russian pianist and composer rematerialize before our ears.

title: Lily Chu, Joseph Bortolussi
description: Lily Hui-Hua Chu, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kuang-che Chu of Santa Barbara, Calif., was married yesterday to Joseph Louis Bortolussi, a son of Bernadette Bortolussi of Nyack, N.Y., and the late John B. Bortolussi. The Rev. Maurice K. O'Mahony performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel in Montecito, Calif.

title: Dances With Ghosts
description: GARDENS IN THE DUNES

title: Howdy, Neighbor
description: The guy at the next desk helps himself to your stash of chewing gum without asking. Or the woman behind you keeps erupting into laughter reminiscent of the Wicked Witch of the West. What kinds of co-worker behavior have tortured you at the office - and how have you dealt with them? Send your stories to On The Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10035. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Best Invention; How the Bean Saved Civilization
description: In 1918, at the age of 40, my maternal grandfather was stricken by a form of viral influenza, popularly known as the Spanish flu, which was decimating much of Europe. Within a week, despite the best efforts of three physicians, he died. In 1972, at the age of 40, I was stricken by a serious illness that seemed very similar to la spagnola. Thanks to penicillin, after a week I was up and about. So it is easy to understand why, forgetting about atomic energy, space travel and the computer, I persist in thinking that the most important invention of our century is penicillin (and, more generally, all those drugs that allow people today to reach the age of 80, whereas in the past they might have died at 50 or 60).

title: Alatia Bradley And John Iszard
description: Alatia Bradley, the daughter of James Howard Bradley Jr. and Phyllis Bradley Boone, both of Dallas, was married yesterday to John Fassett Iszard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert French Iszard Jr. of Dundee, N.Y. The Rev. Park McD. Bodie performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Keeping It Private at Andersen
description: With even Goldman, Sachs & Company going public, executives at other private partnerships are often asked when they will follow suit. At least for Andersen Consulting, the global techology giant, selling shares is not in the plans.

title: An Incubator's Children Come Home to Say Thanks
description: IN the not too distant past it was my good fortune to chance upon the performance of an arresting, unconventional work. A luminous fabric comprising music both vocal and instrumental, literary fragments from varied centuries and civilizations, and everyday movement functioning as dance, it projected an irresistible aura of good will and celebrated the wonderful power of artistic persuasion. And, for the best of reasons, it reminded me instantly of the Judson Dance Theater, that whirlpool of restless creative spirits performing at Judson Memorial Church at Washington Square in the 1960's. This was not just because the performance I was experiencing was being given in the St. James Memorial Chapel of Union Theological Seminary and had been conceived and directed by Meredith Monk, but because its unrelated elements had been juxtaposed so imaginatively into an expressive whole.

title: Oh the Pain!; Putting Up With It Is One Thing, Inflicting It Quite Another
description: IN a city often as hard as the rock on which much of it is built, some New Yorkers regularly share a particular intimacy with strangers. Their jobs involve making others physically or psychologically uncomfortable. In other words, they inflict pain.

title: Dept. of Silly Grooves
description: To the Editor:

title: The Kissinger Papers
description: To the Editor:

title: Pilots Get Preparation For Rarest Of Mishaps
description: Airline pilots typically learn in simulators how to handle engine failure, stormy winds and other disruptions in flight. But now United and other airlines are tossing them more radical problems -- like what to do when a jumbo jet rolls nearly upside down.

title: Grumman Retirees Win but Don't Rejoice
description: IN its glory years, the Grumman Corporation built planes that helped win World War II, and its lunar module won the space race by landing the first man on the moon.

title: Making the Radish Patch More Exotic
description: THE usual vegetables that have been growing in gardens for eons are still popular. But as leisure and business travel increase, culinary tastes are expanding. Even produce markets are reflecting the changes.

title: Statements of United States' policy on Kosovo:
description: ''In the event of conflict in Kosovo caused by Serbian action, the United States will be prepared to employ military force against the Serbians in Kosovo and in Serbia proper.'' President George Bush in a letter to Slobodan Milosevic, then Serbian President, Dec. 25, 1992.

title: Despite Deregulation, Utilities Avoid New York
description: For years, officials here and in other state capitals have hailed competition as a way to lower electricity bills, and New York is one of just five states that have actually begun letting some customers choose their supplier of power.

title: Word for Word / Political Memoirs; See Dick Recall His Clinton Days; See George Beg to Differ
description: POLITICAL memoirs are like the film ''Rashomon,'' in which an experience is transmogrified by sharply different memories. Case in point: George Stephanopoulos's ''All Too Human: A Political Education'' (Little, Brown) versus Dick Morris's ''Behind the Oval Office: Getting Re-Elected Against All Odds'' (Renaissance). The books often convey utterly dissimilar points of view, reflecting the cutthroat infighting that prevailed when their authors were advisers to President Clinton.

title: Cosby Wiley, Timothy George
description: Cosby Ford Wiley and Timothy Martin George were married yesterday by the Rev. John Martiner at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenville, Del.

title: Starting the Rehabilitation Journey at Parkchester
description: AT the annual meeting of the South condominium of the sprawling Parkchester housing complex in the Bronx last January, Howard Hall made a vehement speech. He said he bought an apartment last November and was deeply dissatisfied with the conditions he found when he moved in. ''If I have to pay a few more dollars to fix the place up, I'm for it!'' he declared.

title: Credits
description: Picture research by David E. Brown.

title: Corrections
description: A chart accompanying a story on the relationship between joblessness and inflation was mislabeled. The correct figures for gross domestic product, in 1992 dollars, are: $6.2 trillion in 1992, $6.4 trillion in 1993, $6.6 trillion in 1994, $6.8 trillion in 1995, $7 trillion in 1996, $7.3 trillion in 1997 and $7.6 trillion in 1998.

title: Amy Tulman and Jonathan Radick
description: Amy Ellen Tulman and Jonathan Robert Radick are to be married today by Rabbi Chava Koster at the Woodcliff (N.J.) Lake Hilton.

title: Should Artists Give Way to Parking Space?
description: THE twin brothers Enzo and Germano Russo arrived in the United States three decades ago, after graduating from the School of Fine Arts at the University of Florence in Italy.

title: Rethinking Blanche
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A THOUSAND SUNS

title: A Deal We'd Be Likely To Regret
description: No sooner had President Clinton pulled the plug on the deal to bring China into the World Trade Organization than he called China's Prime Minister last week to restart the negotiations.

title: Supermarket Closing Leaves the Elderly Waiting for the Bus; As Chains Leave Downtowns, Amenities Decline, Creating Hardships and Social Vacuums.
description: THE A. & P. on Main Street used to provide more than groceries to elderly residents of downtown apartment buildings. It was a social center, a place where they could pick up both a quart of milk and a bit of news about how a friend was doing.

title: Seton Hall Endowment Inspired by Rose Thering
description: To the Editor:

title: Walk This Way, or How the Japanese Kept in Step
description: ALMOST any reference book on Japanese history includes the dates of the most obscure shogun or emperor. But then there are the more basic historical puzzles, like -- how did the Japanese walk?

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Prospect Heights, Brooklyn; A Diverse Neighborhood Spruces Up in a Turnaround
description: IN the eyes of many Prospect Heights residents, the Alcazar is a metaphor for the change the neighborhood is undergoing.

title: Slipping Knicks Get Another Nudge From Oakley
description: Marcus Camby heard the sound of a long jumper by Vince Carter going splat against a rim. His back to the basket and his body planted to the chest of the weathered Charles Oakley, Camby looked up at the pinwheel ceiling of Madison Square Garden like a bird watcher.

title: An Opera Lures a Futurist Back to the Present
description: ''RESURRECTION,'' the new work being given its premiere on Friday by the Houston Grand Opera, centers on a 19th-century Russian nobleman and the peasant girl he seduced and abandoned. The Prince is a baritone, the peasant girl a mezzo-soprano. The staging includes a courtroom scene, a party in a magnificent Moscow palace, a death march in plodding C minor in a desolate Siberian prison camp. The libretto is woven from Tolstoy's final novel, a story echoing the classic Wagnerian theme of redemption through love, culminating in a stirring prison-scene climax. There is nothing odd about any of this. And that is precisely what is so odd about it.

title: Open House for the Ancients
description: I ENTERED the Metropolitan Museum for the first time nearly 50 years ago. In the spring of 1950, the Austrian Government had lent some of Vienna's greatest treasures for exhibition in New York, and so at the age of 14 I was able to see marvels like the luminous Roman cameo known as the ''Gemma Augustea,'' Cellini's gold salt cellar and Vermeer's ''Artist in His Studio.'' It was a bewildering experience to pass with a few steps from ancient Rome to Renaissance Italy and on to 17th-century Holland. The jumble of paintings, gems and furniture reminded me of visits to my grandmother, but the museum was obviously not someone's home.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Vox Pop With Pix
description: From ''The Arkansas Traveler'' to ''The Unsinkable Mrs. Brown,'' AMERICAN FOLK: Classic Tales Retold (Abrams, $39.95) is a treasury of stories. What's more, it is fun for children and adults and has been beautifully illustrated by Warren Infield. Since many folk tales are anonymous and ever changing, Charles Sullivan has done the retelling of what he calls the most interesting American tales, carefully sorting the 60 stories into categories like ''Characters Larger Than Life'' and ''Incredible Animals.'' Sullivan writes with a relaxed, modern tone (''easy come, easy go,'' as Jesse James used to say) but never slangy. Although he skillfully slips in details of history and geography, he also conveys a sense of spirit and energy. There are Davy Crockett, ''fed up with politics, still looking for a good fight''; the Presidential trio, Honest Abe, George and his cherry tree and Teddy and his bear; the irrepressible Kilroy. Paul Bunyan's Babe the Blue Ox astounds Winifred Winslow, Radcliffe graduate, by sending 12-foot logs flying out of her sawmill ''like bullets from a machine gun.'' Joe Magarac from Hungary is the man of steel: people ''shut up quickly when Joe lifted two of the 1,000-pound steel bars together in his right hand.'' Bertrand Charpentier from Paris had a plan to saw off Manhattan. Eliza, daughter and granddaughter of slaves, wanted to name her baby Freedom. Infield's simple watercolors and thematic borders give Rosie the Riveter's lunchbox and Uncle Sam's hat a mythological flair. Finally, each chapter ends with helpful notes on where to find more tales. Patricia Ryan

title: Yugoslav Efforts to Shape Coverage of the War
description: The new technologies of war reporting provide very little more clarity about the truth on the ground than the old ones, but they have certainly added to the bizarre and sometimes contradictory efforts by the Yugoslav Government to shape the reporting of foreign correspondents.

title: Russia's House Betroths Belarus and Yugoslavia
description: Politics makes strange bedfellows. Then there is Russian politics, which seemed this week hellbent on the downright weird: a menage a trois of Russia, Belarus and Yugoslavia, bedding a wobbly democracy, a Soviet-style dictatorship and an international pariah three borders removed from either of them in death-do-we-part union.

title: When Command is 'Heal,' These Dogs Obey
description: CAROLE COTLER had been taking her dog, Berklee, to long-term care facilities and nursing homes all over Long Island. She had seen how her friendly bulldog-boxer mix brightened the days and lifted the spirits of the sick and the aged, and had read about the patients jarred from comas and the catatonics smiling for the first time when exposed to the increasingly popular discipline known as animal-assisted therapy.

title: Jets Use Their 2 Picks to Try to Strengthen Offensive Line
description: The Jets twiddled their thumbs for almost eight hours in today's draft -- their first pick was the 57th over all, late in the second round -- but discovered when it was their turn that their most highly rated guard was still available.

title: Stepping Back, to Go Forward
description: IN 1998, the National Basketball Association players were locked out and buyers of athletic shoes went on strike. Hurt by changing fashions, foreign recessions and the job dispute that gave the league's shoe spokesmen a collective bad name, shoemakers saw their earnings plunge. As a result, Reebok, for one, lost more than half its stock market value last year.

title: MAKING IT WORK; Four-Alarm Symbols
description: IN his 1921 poem ''The Great Figure,'' William Carlos Williams wrote: ''I saw the figure 5/in gold/on a red/firetruck. . . .''

title: Fellow Melodists
description: To the Editors:

title: At Joe's Pub, a Hip Club, Velvet Rope, Cigarette Smoke
description: PICTURE Adolph Green. Sprightly, white-haired musical-theater octogenarian. Screenwriter, with his partner, Betty Comden, for ''Sing in' in the Rain''; lyricist, with Ms. Comden, for ''Wonderful Town,'' ''Bells Are Ringing'' and ''On the Town.'' Picture them both. Ms. Comden is the elegant woman in black.

title: Keeping Causes Straight When Using Ribbons
description: Several weeks ago, I noticed a slew of pink ribbons tied to mailboxes, fenceposts, and telephone poles in Stony Brook, and wondered with horror who in that neighborhood had been recently diagnosed with or died from breast cancer. Then I learned [''Housing Developer's Plan Roils Stony Brook,'' April 4] that the pink ribbons were symbols not of breast cancer, but of the neighborhood's opposition to a proposed housing development near the village center.

title: White Sox Failing To Attract the Fans
description: In New York, New York, the Bronx is up and the Battery is down. But in Chicago, the Cubs are up and the White Sox are so far down, they are practically invisible. Their fans may be invisible before long. The White Sox did not have many for their first series of the season, and the outlook is bleak.

title: Best Land Deal; A Canal Runs Through It
description: On Dec. 16, 1875, the H.M.S. Malabar set sail from Egypt, bound for Portsmouth, England, with a precious cargo stored in seven zinc boxes: 176,602 shares of stock in the Suez Canal Company, recently sold by the Khedive of Egypt. The buyer was the British Government, bolstered by a timely advance of 4 million [pounds] from N.M. Rothschild & Sons in London. Spiced with intrigue and flush with flamboyant figures, the affair has all the flair of a thriller. There have been bigger real-estate bonanzas -- notably the $15 million deal that won the Louisiana Purchase from France and the $7 million payment that wrested Alaska from Russia. But none have had quite the elegance, speed and daring of the Suez Canal transaction. It briefly established the House of Rothschild as a sovereign state on a par with -- or perhaps even slightly ahead of -- Her Majesty's Government.

title: Cambodia, Now at Peace, Hopes for Tourists
description: FROM time to time these days, an unfamiliar sight appears on the streets of this threadbare, battle-weary city: a tour bus.

title: Safety in Mexico
description: To the Editor: On the subject of safety in Mexico, specifically in the state of Chiapas, I would like to concur with Marcia Garcia-Starkey (Letters on Travel, March 7) that it is better to plan your own trip. We have just come back from Chiapas and it was an interesting and lovely experience. We visited Palenque, a very special Mayan ruin, rafted pristine rivers, saw magnificent waterfalls, and stayed at a macadamia nut farm.

title: Julie Schrader, Jeffrey Gordinier
description: Julie Marie Schrader and Jeffrey Scott Gordinier were married in New York yesterday. Msgr. Thomas Leonard performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Church.

title: Commercial Property /The First Quarter of 1999; The Office Market Softens a Bit, but It's Still Strong
description: THE pace of office leasing in Manhattan softened somewhat in the first quarter of 1999, after two torrid years. But asking annual rents continued to increase -- exceeding $70 a square foot in some locations, although the average remains much lower -- and real estate executives say they see nothing on the horizon to prevent the industry from having another prosperous year.

title: Best Punctuation; Point of Order
description: Diminutive as a mote of dust, a mere peck of the pen, a crumb on the keyboard, the full stop -- the period -- is the unsung legislator of our writing systems. Without it, there would be no end to the sorrows of young Werther, and the travels of the Hobbit would have never been completed. Its absence allowed James Joyce to weave ''Finnegans Wake'' into a perfect circle, and its presence made Henri Michaux compare our essential being to this dot, ''a dot that death devours.'' It crowns the fulfillment of thought, gives the illusion of conclusiveness, possesses a certain haughtiness that stems, like Napoleon's, from its minuscule size. Anxious to get going, we require nothing to signal our beginnings, but we need to know when to stop: this tiny memento mori reminds us that everything, ourselves included, must one day come to a halt. As an anonymous English teacher suggested in the 1680 ''Treatise of Stops, Points or Pauses,'' a full stop is ''a Note of perfect Sense, and of a perfect Sentence.''

title: Julie McNally, Christian Daher
description: Julie McNally, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McNally of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christian Daher, the son of Catherine Daher of Paris and the late Emile Daher. The Rev. John E. Brooks performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville.

title: A Message to Loved Ones Safe on Shore
description: THE hospital wants Mom to go away. It has decided either that it can do nothing more to improve her condition or that her continued intensive care is not cost-effective. Maybe it has decided both. The chief administrator said it was responding to Medicare guidelines.

title: Bar Closing Times
description: Calling it an idea whose time has come, George S. Latimer, Democrat of Rye and chairman of the Board of Legislators, and Paul J. Noto, Republican of Mamaroneck, the Board's minority leader, have proposed moving up by two hours the closing times at bars in Westchester to 2 A.M.

title: A Search For Growth On the Vine
description: LAST year was a good one for plenty of newly released wines, from Oregon pinot noirs to Napa chardonnays. For investors in wine-company stocks, however, 1998 left a generally unpleasant aftertaste.

title: When Fear Of Firing Deters Hiring
description: OVER the last few years, several people have spoken to me about their reluctance to hire people whose race, color, creed or national origin -- or age, disability or sex -- put them in protected classes under anti-discrimination law.

title: INVESTING; How Best to Hitch a Ride On a Highflying Index?
description: WITH a flurry of newspaper advertisements and cable television commercials, the Nasdaq-100 Shares unit trust made its debut last month, and it is now safe to call it a major marketing hit. The trust, listed on the American Stock Exchange, trades an average of over 4 million shares a day, making it the most successful product rollout in Amex history in terms of volume.

title: Best Game; Where Have All the Young Men Gone?
description: This past summer, more than a million people gathered on the Champs-Elysees to celebrate France's victory in the World Cup. By all accounts, it was the largest demonstration of public happiness seen in Paris since the liberation from the Germans in 1944.

title: On Island, Books of Individualism; Doctor With a Diet Has a New Message
description: ROBERT C. ATKINS is the best-selling author of ''Dr. Atkins' Diet Revolution,'' published in 1972 and the first of what has become an industry of diet books. He is also the engineer of a weight-loss method known universally as ''the Atkins Diet.''

title: The Preparations Needed to Build a Staircase
description: BUILDING a staircase is a job for a master carpenter, but an experienced do-it-yourselfer can usually construct a simple set of stairs for a backyard deck. Cutting the pieces and assembling them are relatively simple. The hard part is measuring the rise, calculating the number of steps needed and marking the layout on the boards. This part may take some trial and error, in adjusting the dimensions of the steps, to get the number of steps to come out even.

title: Reviving a Century's Worth of Memories
description: Eight years ago Sarah Louise (Sadie) Delany, who was 104, and her younger sister, Annie Elizabeth (Bessie), who was 102, welcomed Amy Hill Hearth, a freelance writer for The New York Times, into their Mount Vernon, N.Y., home.

title: Best Pope; The Pontiff Who Quit
description: I choose as my favorite Pope of the millennium one who was poor, semiliterate and perhaps rather less than sane: Celestine V.

title: Massage Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Foolproof Formula For High-Speed Grip
description: IN a sport utility or in a sports car, all-wheel-drive systems move power to the wheels with the best traction. In sports cars, which tend to spin the rear wheels on wet pavement, all-wheel drive temporarily diverts power to the front, helping to stabilize the car. Of course, all-wheel drive is also useful on dry roads during ''performance'' driving -- how you would travel to the hospital, say, if your hair were on fire.

title: The Solipsisters
description: Surveying the recent spate of books about women, even the most dedicated feminist might find herself muttering, ''Be careful what you ask for, you might get it.'' I'm thinking of the way ''the personal is political,'' that watchword of 1970's feminism, has morphed and mushroomed into something quite other than originally intended -- indeed, almost the opposite. As originally articulated in the consciousness-raising groups of the 70's, ''the personal is political'' was a way of saying that what looked like individual experiences, with little social resonance and certainly no political importance -- rape, street harassment, you doing the vacuuming while your husband read the paper -- were part of a general pattern of male dominance and female subordination. It was a way of understanding your experience and connecting it to the hitherto unsuspected experiences of others -- Wow, your husband always interrupts you too? -- the point being to challenge the social and political and legal structures that shape our lives.

title: Ward Courts Controversy
description: Before last night's game against Toronto at Madison Square Garden, Knicks point guard Charlie Ward handed out copies of a newspaper article that said that female sportswriters did not belong in the locker rooms of male professional athletes.

title: Dixie Sullivan, David De Luca
description: Dixie Virginia Sullivan, an insurance executive, and David Laurence De Luca, a financial executive, both in New York, were married last evening at the Palmer Memorial Episcopal Church in Houston. The Rev. Samuel R. Todd Jr., an Episcopal priest, officiated at the ceremony, in which the Rev. Edward T. Coles, a Roman Catholic priest, took part.

title: By Hammer and Hand, Stickley's Home
description: A LOG house, a relic, sits by the highway here. From April to November, when the surrounding trees take leaf and hush the sound of traffic, a kind of peace falls over the place. And visitors make a pilgrimage to the house that Gus built.

title: HOT PINK
description: Wintry gray is gone. This season, things pink are the hottest sellers in town. From cupcakes to men's briefs, here is a shopping bag of items moving feverishly, plus a few on the horizon.

title: Crime
description: Storytellers are always digging up the past, but few bring to that melancholy task the exquisite delicacy achieved by Peter Robinson in his new police procedural, IN A DRY SEASON (Avon Twilight, $24). When a drought dries up a reservoir in the Yorkshire dales and uncovers the ruined village of Hobb's End, Inspector Alan Banks of the North Yorkshire Police is given the punishing assignment of identifying the human skeleton that also emerges from the mud.

title: Trying to Read a Hazy Future; Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
description: WHEN Leonard Riggio was a night student at New York University, he coped with the droning tedium of business lectures by snatching a strategic seat behind a student with a broad back and, he says, losing himself in the pages of the ''History of the Peloponnesian War.''

title: On a Farm Far From the Andes, a Home for Alpacas
description: Alpacas, normally found in the Andes and first imported to the United States in 1984, are beginning to appear on a handful of New Jersey farms where they are raised for breeding and for the luxurious hair that is spun into cashmere-like wool. The largest in the state is Woodsedge Farm in Delaware Township, Hunterdon County, where 200 alpacas and 30 llamas graze and play in the tidy, fenced fields that surround the barn.

title: Britain's Prescription for Health Care: Take a Seat
description: Every patient in Britain knows about the notorious National Health Service waiting list, which tells how many people are waiting for hospital treatment for anything from varicose vein removal to hip replacement surgery. Never a short list, it currently boasts 1.12 million sick and generally tired members.

title: When Latin Pride Took to the Streets
description: The Young Lords Party fought hard for the empowerment of poor Hispanic people back in the 60's and 70's. The group, formed in Chicago, gained particular fame when the New York branch, begun in 1969, engaged the city's hospital, sanitation and prison systems in a series of bold street actions.

title: The World: Checkered Flags; Sovereignty Isn't So Sacred Anymore
description: AT the century's last session of the Commission on Human Rights, Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations unveiled a doctrine with profound implications for international relations in the new millennium. The air strikes against Yugoslavia, he said on April 7, showed that the world would no longer permit nations intent on committing genocide to ''hide'' behind the United Nations charter, which has traditionally safeguarded national sovereignty.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Deep Thinking
description: ON weekends, Robert W. Fournier Jr. likes to get together with friends, drink a few beers and eat some sushi. That wouldn't seem remarkable, except that Mr. Fournier is director of husbandry at the New Jersey State Aquarium here, responsible for the welfare of more than 1,600 fish in the third largest aquarium tank in the world.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Duke Hamilton is Dead!

title: Despite the Frown, Safir Paints Himself In Brighter Terms
description: For three years now, Police Commissioner Howard Safir has dutifully taken his place behind Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at news conferences, his hands folded, his face set in inscrutability. It is the enduring image of a friendship forged by time shared in Federal service, one in which roles are understood and discretion is a given.

title: Some School Races Lack Runners
description: In the first school board elections to be held since the State Legislature removed much of the boards' authority, many veteran members have decided not to run again. And, for the first time in recent history, two school districts among the city's 32 have a shortage of candidates.

title: Beaches, Billy Joel and, Oddly, Swindles; The Island Has Become Home to Stock Scams, But Regulators Are Cracking Down
description: IN the rest of the country, Long Island tends to have a rather mixed image, concocted from television clips of beautiful beaches, Billy Joel and epic traffic tie-ups on the Long Island Expressway. But nothing has tarnished that image, in the minds of thousands of Americans, as much as another unpleasant element of Island life: stock-market scams.

title: Digging for Scholarship Gold
description: There is a new addition to the many Web sites for high school seniors and college students seeking scholarships for the fall semester. While Collegenet (www.collegenet.com) does not have the largest data base of scholarships, it also does not sell demographic information about users to companies selling services or products to students, as some sites do, and the registration form it requires users to complete is shorter than many. The search portion of the site, called Mach 25, has information on 7,000 scholarships.

title: Americans Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: F.A.A. Deal With Kiwi Gives Airline a Chance to Fly Again
description: Kiwi International Air Lines, which was grounded by Federal regulators last month, reached a settlement with the Federal Aviation Administration late Friday that allows it to apply to regain its operating license.

title: It's the Sprawl, Stupid. The Economy's Always Good.
description: The governor is running for the United States Senate, and in her campaign she will remind voters how much the state's economy has improved since she took office in 1994. Quite a change from her early days in State House, when she frequently worried aloud about the New Jersey's competitiveness with the Carolinas and points south.

title: Passaic Accused of Bias Against Hispanic Voters
description: Bill Lann Lee, acting director of the Federal Division of Civil Rights, has threatened to sue Passaic City and County under the Federal Voting Rights Act for discriminating against Hispanic voters. In letter sent earlier this month, Mr. Lee charges that the city and county have failed to adequately staff polling places with Spanish-speaking poll workers, and that the city council of seven at-large members results in fewer Hispanic council members than would be elected under a ward system. Only one council members is Hispanic, while Mr. Lee's letter says 46.1 percent of the voting-age population are Hispanic.

title: Best Piano Composition; Six Parts Genius
description: The keyboard music of Johann Sebastian Bach cannot be called piano music, but there is one magnificent exception. Many musicians consider the six-voice ricercare from ''The Musical Offering'' to be his greatest fugue, and I would choose this as the most significant piano work of the millennium, as it is perhaps the first piece composed for the recently invented piano -- at least, the first piece that a composer knew would certainly be played on a piano.

title: Carlos Caballero and Diana Crespo
description: Diana Crespo, a daughter of Gladys and Aurelio A. Crespo Jr. of Brooklyn, is to be married this afternoon to Carlos Caballero, a son of Beatriz C. Caballero of Manhattan and Conrado Caballero Sr. of Howard Beach, Queens. The Rev. Joseph R. Gurdak is to perform the ceremony at Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: Dueling Perspectives: Two Views of Reality Vying on the Airwaves
description: Until this week, the clampdown had been fairly thorough, the details relatively scarce.

title: School Districts Ready Bond Issues for Vote
description: WHEN a pipe burst recently at Port Chester High School, it was bad enough that the bill to fix it was $1,200. What was worse was the cost to remove asbestos around the pipe, which came to $9,750.

title: For Schubert, Age Yields Its Rank
description: ART isn't a question of age. I can't think the way someone else does just because he's older and famous. One argument that never counts is 'I'm right, because I have more experience.' ''

title: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE ROAD TO WAR -- A special report.; How a President, Distracted by Scandal, Entered Balkan War
description: On Jan. 19, President Clinton's top aides met in the Situation Room in the White House basement to hear a fateful new plan for an autonomous Kosovo from Madeleine K. Albright, the Secretary of State. NATO, she urged, should use the threat of air strikes on Yugoslavia to force a peace agreement to be monitored by the alliance's ground troops.

title: The Nation; Contempt: Sometimes A Great Notion
description: IN the climactic scene of the 1979 film ''. . . And Justice for All,'' Al Pacino, playing an idealistic young lawyer named Arthur Kirkland, has to defend a distinguished judge accused of raping and battering a young girl. Learning that his influential client is guilty and has manipulated the system to get off, Mr. Pacino turns on him in the courtroom, calling him ''a slime'' and declaring, ''If he's allowed to go free, then something really wrong is going on here.''

title: Three Women Wait Anxiously for Their Spacecraft to Reach Mars
description: Sarah A. Gavit is leading an invasion of Mars. Built under her direction are two craft now speeding toward a December rendezvous with the red planet to help see if it harbors life.

title: Princeton Romps
description: Princeton achieved a rare trouncing of Harvard in the Compton Cup regatta yesterday on Lake Carnegie in Princeton, N.J. The Tigers won by two boat lengths in 5:50.7 to the Crimson's 5:58.2.

title: Archeology Find: Capital's Best Little Brothel
description: Enough of ''Monica's Story.'' Archeologists digging in the Mall have happened upon the historically tantalizing story of Mary Ann Hall, a determined 20-something who built and managed one of this city's finest 19th-century bordellos.

title: A Trumpeter Returns
description: IF the Philadelphia Orchestra has a concert scheduled this afternoon, it will be without its principal trumpeter, David Bilger, who a number of years ago was principal trumpeter with the Philharmonia Virtuosi. He is returning as guest soloist with his former colleagues today at 3 P.M. at Purchase College. Mr. Bilger will play the Trumpet Concerto by Johann Fasch and will mark the Ellington centennial with a medley of the Duke's standards. Rounding out the program will be Locatelli's ''Labyrinth'' Violin Concerto with the concertmaster, Mela Tenenbaum, as soloist and the music director, Richard Kapp, on the podium.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Masterpieces in Hartford

title: Robyn Fried, David Radulescu
description: Robyn Lynne Fried and David Constantine Radulescu were married last evening by Cantor Richard Berman at the Seawane Club in Hewlett Harbor, N.Y.

title: Robust Italian for the Budget Conscious
description: PITY predictable Italian restaurants with menus that look a lot like those at many of their numerous counterparts. Diners find it difficult to muster much enthusiasm for yet another one and critics wonder what they can possibly write that has not already been said.

title: Leasing Activity Down
description: The countywide availability rate for commercial real estate rose at the end of the first quarter of the year despite two positive factors: a decline in the number of large blocks of space returning to the market and the continuing strength of smaller transactions, which contributed to nearly 45,000 square feet of property leased or bought in Westchester.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Portraying Mae West

title: In America; A Travesty in Texas
description: I remember thinking during a meeting last fall with the District Attorney of Travis County, Tex., and several of his top aides that their minds were closed, that they would do anything in their power to keep a teen-ager named Lacresha Murray in prison, that they had so much invested in the case, and had reaped so much positive publicity from her arrest and conviction, that they were incapable of admitting they might have been wrong. The case no longer was about justice but about public officials saving face.

title: U.S. and Britain, After Complaints, Vow to Give War Court Data on Top Yugoslavs
description: Responding to complaints from the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague, the United States and Britain have pledged to provide more information to prosecutors that may enable them to indict the top Yugoslav civilian and military leadership.

title: Queens Prosecutor to Seek Capital Punishment for Man Charged in 2 Killings
description: The Queens District Attorney, Richard A. Brown, has decided to seek the death penalty for a man charged with killing two people in separate robberies last year.

title: So Are They Shopping Until Their Shares Drop?
description: Internet companies went on a buying spree in the first quarter of 1999, using the sky-high valuations of their shares to buy up other companies -- almost all of them Internet-related, too -- at a record pace.

title: Time in a Capsule
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Man Said to Have Confessed to Killing of Policewoman
description: The man charged with killing an Orange, N.J., policewoman confessed to his mother and to the authorities over the weekend that he had committed the crime, a person close to his family said yesterday.

title: Why Must Parents Test Toddlers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Risky Dog Walking
description: To the Editor:

title: Results Today For Strawberry
description: Major League Baseball expects to receive results today from the drug test Darryl Strawberry took last Tuesday, according to a baseball official. Strawberry also submitted a test at the end of last week, subsequent to his arrest Wednesday night on charges of cocaine possession and solicitation of prostitution in Tampa, Fla. Should Strawberry, 37, fail either test, he will be subject to immediate suspension and probably would not play this season, and his career could be over.

title: Gretzky's Father Coaches To the End
description: Like any father watching one of his son's hockey games, Walter Gretzky looked on intently from the stands yesterday, his hands cupped around his mouth. Sometimes he offered his son advice, sometimes encouragement and sometimes well-deserved criticism.

title: Political Memo; A New Test Of Whitman: Standing By Her Nominee
description: As captain of New Jersey's ship of state, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has shown time and again that she is not given to dawdling when it comes to throwing a political albatross overboard.

title: With 6 Guards, Jets Still Don't Know if Any Can Start
description: In the draft, the Jets did everything they could to solve their major problem -- no one to play right or left guard -- by drafting yet another guard today. Over two days, they selected three players at that position.

title: Animated Characters Imitate Life, Even Transcend It
description: It is really a shame that the entertainment industry continues to believe that if a good thing works once it will work even better twice, thrice and then as many times as ratings and profits allow before going bad.

title: Medical School in 6 Days; Mount Sinai Mini-Courses Try to Demystify What Doctors Do
description: The doctors were losing the patient. His heart was racing at 120 beats a minute. His blood-oxygen level was abysmal. The tone from the heart monitor dropped from high and cheerful to low and ominous, as if the batteries were running down.

title: Capital One, a marketer steeped in information about its customers, picks its first outside agency.
description: A FINANCIAL services giant that is helping to rewrite the rules of consumer marketing with intensive data mining -- using information to sell in unconventional ways -- is hiring its first outside agency.

title: NATO Said to Focus Raids on Serb Elite's Property
description: In listing its bombing targets in Yugoslavia, NATO has generally described them as installations that feed Slobodan Milosevic's war machine. What the alliance does not usually say is that some of the refineries and factories have also been chosen as targets because they are run by close cronies of the Yugoslav President.

title: Grace Zia Chu, 99, Guide to Chinese Cooking
description: Grace Zia Chu, who introduced a generation of Americans to Chinese cuisine though her cooking classes in Manhattan and her landmark book ''The Pleasures of Chinese Cooking,'' died Thursday at a nursing home in Columbus, Ohio. She was 99.

title: A Week of Abortion Protests in Buffalo Begins Loudly but Peacefully
description: On the first day of a much-anticipated weeklong rally, anti-abortion protesters returned to the streets of Buffalo in full-throated fashion today, seven years after raucous anti-abortion protests here triggered more than 600 arrests.

title: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report; As on-line auctions move into pricier mechandise, escrow services offer those about to be scammed a little safety.
description: INTERNET auctions are promoted for their ability to rid the world of middlemen and let buyers and sellers strike deals in free-market harmony. But as auction sites look to cash in on the trend by selling more costly goods, this Internet utopia is coming under threat. Higher prices can mean lower levels of trust.

title: Accounts
description: * Crate and Barrel, Northbrook, Ill., to Tucker Tapia, Chicago, to handle the creative account of the home furnishings retail chain, which had been at McConaughey Stein Schmidt Brown, Chicago. Billings were estimated at $7 million.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
description: Each time a revolutionary new technology has arrived, the governments of the day have been leery of its capacity for mischief and criminality. Centuries ago, there were calls for giving the authorities the power of prior restraint lest the printing press become an instrument of sedition and slander. Later, there were qualms about selling automobiles to the public because crooks could use them to escape the police.

title: Penguins Are Next In the First Round
description: The Devils' first opponent in the National Hockey League playoffs will be the Pittsburgh Penguins, whom they dominated during the regular season.

title: A 3-Winner Send-Off for Krone
description: It may not have drawn as much attention as Wayne Gretzky's goodbye at Madison Square Garden, but Julie Krone also said farewell yesterday when she rode three winners at Lone Star Park in Grand Prairie, Tex., on the final day of her career at the races.

title: Skip Spence Is Dead at 52; Psychedelic Rock Musician
description: Alexander (Skip) Spence, a pivotal figure in psychedelic San Francisco rock, died on Friday at Dominican Hospital in Santa Cruz, Calif., where he lived. The cause was lung cancer, said his son Omar. He was 52.

title: U.S. Official Calls Tallies Of Kosovo Slain Too Low
description: The number of ethnic Albanians killed by Serbs in Kosovo may be far higher than the few thousand cited by NATO officials in recent days, the Clinton Administration's top official assembling evidence of war crimes said today.

title: The Slow Work of Picking Louima Case Jurors
description: One prospective juror said her judgment could be affected because her father was a retired police detective. She was excused.

title: Ecevit, Left-Leaning Premier, Takes Strong Lead in Turkish Voting
description: Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit appeared to run well ahead of all challengers in Sunday's national election, according to returns tabulated early this morning. The result suggested that he would be in a strong position to form Turkey's next Government.

title: Yankees' Poor Play Results in Sweep
description: The cold and cracked steel and cement of Tiger Stadium are 88 years old, and echoes rattle here, like lockers in a high school hallway. ''Sweep,'' somebody in the small crowd yelled in the bottom of the eighth inning today, a concept that sounded so hollow and outdated that a minute or two passed before others joined in the chant. And then they were all yelling.

title: Compressed Data; Edison, the Company, This Time From Texas
description: The Wizard of Menlo Park may no longer be with us, but that isn't stopping Thomas A. Edison from selling Web servers.

title: City's Cable Monopoly
description: To the Editor:

title: Wondertross Will Miss the Big Race
description: For some 3-year-old colts, meanwhile, the Kentucky Derby grew more remote. In Lexington, where four or five horses advanced their causes in the Blue Grass Stakes one week ago, the beaten favorite, Wondertross, was back in his barn yesterday after recovering from a case of colic. But his trainer, Nick Zito, said the horse would not go in attempt the Derby. We couldn't do that to him, Zito said. He is feeling well. But we want to take our time and make sure everything is perfect. We've got to remember that he was a very sick horse.

title: Why Must Parents Test Toddlers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about a blood test to diagnose a heart attack misstated the affiliation of Dr. Robert Roberts, who studied the test. He is a professor at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, not Baylor University.

title: Brookhaven Says Landfill Is Cleaner Than Ever
description: For decades, Long Island's trash-hauling industry has been the province of mobsters and crooked politicians, of everyday kickbacks and the occasional murder for hire, and the reputation of the Town of Brookhaven's landfill here was nearly as unsavory.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a protest march in memory of Amadou Diallo gave an incorrect age for Anthony Baez, who was killed by a police officer in the Bronx in 1994, in some copies. He was 29 at his death; he was not a teen-ager.

title: The Assault on Sprawl Is Starting a Bit Late
description: To the Editor:

title: CNN Excludes Arnett From War and Future
description: When bombs fell on Baghdad in 1991, he was there, live, describing the action in what became the defining achievement for CNN; but when the bombs began falling on Belgrade last month, Peter Arnett, the most recognizable correspondent in the history of the all-news network, was nowhere to be seen.

title: Paging Allies Focus Strategy On the Internet
description: Threatened by the specter of irrelevance in an era of near-ubiquitous cellular phones and E-mail, most of the nation's largest paging companies have formed an alliance to deploy inexpensive hand-held computers that use a new two-way wireless technology developed by Motorola Inc.

title: Rookie Is in Awe as Torch Is Passed
description: Manny Malhotra, a wide-eyed and grinning 18-year-old, may not have looked much different from any other fan crammed into Madison Square Garden yesterday. But he was wearing a Rangers jersey with No. 6 and his name stitched on the back rather than the No. 99 jerseys that pervaded the arena.

title: Fox Is a Late Arrival To Gretzky's Farewell
description: Heading into Wayne Gretzky's finale yesterday, we knew that Fox-owned Channel 5 would not carry the pre-game ceremony live. The Yankees-Tigers game was to take precedence. One option, to show the ceremony and the Yankee game on a split screen, was ruled out because shortsighted management inside Fox felt a highly rated Yankee game meant more than Gretzky's farewell.

title: The Interplay Of Beauty And Shame
description: One of the Metropolitan Opera's great recent productions, Berg's ''Wozzeck,'' is back, but only for two more performances, tomorrow evening and on Saturday afternoon. It demands to be seen and heard and felt and thought about. The cast is superb, from Franz Grundheber and Hildegard Behrens in the main roles to the players of bit parts. Not only is every scrap of vocal music put across with startling force, but the acting in Mark Lamos's production is consistently vivid.

title: Executives Named To New Positions
description: Two agencies have named executives to new, nontraditional positions.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Desperation on the Dance Floor To a Horrific 'Waltzing Matilda'

title: With Seles at Her Best, U.S. Romps in Fed Cup
description: Fifteen years ago, a stunning prospect named Monica Seles moved from Yugoslavia to Florida, seeking the ideal setting in which to become a world No. 1. Five years ago, Seles, in the midst of a 27-month exile from tennis after her 1993 stabbing in Germany, became an American citizen.

title: Redraw the Map, Stop the Killing
description: President Clinton is still clinging to his position that NATO should accept nothing less than a settlement giving autonomy to the Albanian Kosovars inside Serb-dominated Yugoslavia. But this goal is not only unattainable, it's also undesirable. Does anyone seriously believe the Albanian Kosovars and Serbs can live together again?

title: Train Kills a Woman Who Jumped in Its Path
description: A woman jumped to her death in front of a subway train at an Upper West Side subway station yesterday, officials said.

title: Plebiscite Seen In Jeopardy After Rampage : Timor Militia Killings Raise Doubts on Future
description: SINGAPORE  A bloody weekend rampage by militiamen who want East Timor to remain part of Indonesia threatens to undermine talks this week on the future of the territory and raises new doubt about whether the Indonesian government can control the military, foreign officials say.

title: Experts Fear War Accident Could Spread Lab Uranium
description: International nuclear inspectors are worried that 60 kilograms of highly enriched uranium at the Vinca Institute of Nuclear Science, 10 miles from Belgrade, Serbia, may be used improperly or may be hit by an errant NATO missile.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: To Just Plain Weirdness Add a Dollop of Sexual Guilt

title: For Most, Brutality Isn't the Issue
description: There is no doubt in anyone's mind that the shooting of Amadou Diallo was a tragedy, affecting New Yorkers in every community -- civilians and police officers alike. It has raised many questions, but only the judicial system can produce answers for the events of that horrible night.

title: Those Tricky Tax Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Driver Stopping to Help Is Injured by a Truck
description: A man who stopped to help a driver whose car had crashed on the Cross Bronx Expressway was critically injured yesterday morning when a tractor-trailer truck crashed into his car, the police said.

title: Media; Intel's chairman tells newspaper publishers to supply more insight. But who's going to write it?
description: THE gloom-and-doom predictions were nothing new to the members of the American Society of Newspapers Editors, but there was still something arresting about hearing the chairman of the Intel Corporation saying that the newspaper business had three years to live. Their eyes may have rolled in ''not-this-again'' circles when Andrew S. Grove offered his jeremiad, but editors do know a good sound bite when they hear one.

title: Rebels Describe an Officer's Life in the Struggle Over Kosovo
description: Down a narrow back street, inside a safe house somewhere in Macedonia, six men in their late 20's and early 30's are sitting on mattresses on the floor. They are dressed in jeans and rough shirts, thin and fit. They are self-described officers of the Kosovo Liberation Army, just out of Kosovo and on their way to Albania.

title: Rivals Harvard and Yale Hold Labor Conferences
description: Yale and Harvard Universities have long dueled over who has the best students, best football team and best law school, but this weekend they competed with conferences aimed at building academia's bonds with the labor movement.

title: Seeking Final Glimpse of the Great One
description: If yesterday was a sad day to be Canadian, it was an even sadder day to be a Canadian standing outside Madison Square Garden at 3:14 P.M., holding a small sign that said, ''I need 1 please.''

title: Sports of The Times; THE GREAT GOODBYE
description: The other great ones never had an advertised last game. Babe Ruth hit three home runs one day for the Boston Braves, and left soon after. Michael Jordan's last shot won a sixth title for the Chicago Bulls six months before he walked away. Joe Montana threw his last pass, then announced his departure.

title: Who Pays for Doctors?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Notebook Choice From I.B.M.: Svelte or Bulkier
description: Pity the poor notebook computer designer. Everyone complains his notebook is too heavy. But when manufacturers try to make more svelte machines, users say the screens are too small and the floppy disks and CD-ROM drives are missing.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Border Crossings Delayed As Blast Kills 5 Refugees
description: As the Serbian authorities resumed their brutal purge of Kosovo, a further tragedy today temporarily halted the hordes crossing into Albania. Five refugees, including three children, died when their small car was blown to bits by a powerful antitank mine placed just before the border as a Serbian defense against a possible NATO assault.

title: Compressed Data; Privacy Groups 'Honor' Some Institutional Foes
description: Forget the evening gowns and the corny acceptance speeches. In fact, it was one award ceremony to which the honorees were not even invited.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column on Friday about the playwright David Hare misstated the location of the Booth Theater in some copies. It is on West 45th Street, not West 44th Street.

title: Of Soldiers Lost, but Not Forgotten, in Vietnam
description: At the end of April, on the 27th anniversary of her son's death on the battlefield at Dak To, a tired-looking woman named Pham Kim Hy will kneel before a glass bottle filled with dirt and pebbles, light sticks of incense and pray for his soul.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Compaq Computer Ousts Chief Executive
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, the world's largest personal computer maker, ousted its president and chief executive, Eckhard Pfeiffer, yesterday in a dramatic boardroom coup that reflects just how much the Internet is shaking up the computer industry.

title: Far From Bluegrass, Dubai Runs Stealthily for the Roses
description: It was a hazy early morning in this glitzy desert kingdom, and Simon Crisford and Saeed bin Suroor were staring silently at the last turn of their mile-and-an-eighth training track.

title: INSIDE
description: Making Old Seeds Obsolete

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Ben S. Stephansky, 85, Dies; Former Ambassador to Bolivia
description: Ben S. Stephansky, President John F. Kennedy's Ambassador to Bolivia at a complex time in its history, died on Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 85.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Oh, to Be Back Home in Wyoming
description: It doesn't take a strict Freudian to figure out what's ailing Peter Emmons, the hero of ''Dream True.'' Wrenched as a boy from the home and the people he loves, and sent into the care of a rich uncle of complex inner torments, Peter spends the rest of his life trying to undo the damage of this devastatingly bad decision and recreate the nurturing cocoon of his childhood in Wyoming.

title: The Assault on Sprawl Is Starting a Bit Late
description: To the Editor:

title: Watson Has Rough Hometown Debut
description: It was as if Manager Bobby Valentine could see it coming.

title: In Her Hands, Security at a Gathering of World Leaders
description: OF ALL the crowds Kathleen Hickman has warily surveyed for security risks in 15 years with the Secret Service, none come close to the exotic high-wire gathering of world leaders massing on her watch this week.

title: Party of Nehru Finds Itself Pushed Onto Center Stage
description: A day after the fall of the Hindu nationalist-led Government, leaders of the opposition Congress Party began trying to patch together a new coalition to govern this nation of 980 million people.

title: Europe Markets to Close
description: Finance Ministers of the European Union nations agreed Saturday to close European financial markets on Dec. 31 to prevent potential computer problems from disrupting trading during the changeover to the year 2000. The Finance Ministers decided that financial contracts in euros ''shall neither, as on a public holiday, become due nor enforceable'' on New Year's Eve.

title: Airline Contract Deal May Cost 400 Jobs
description: British Airways reached a tentative agreement over the weekend with union leaders that if ratified by the union members would close the airline's telephone sales office in Queens, threatening about 400 New York City jobs.

title: Patents; New thrills from New Zealand: Strapped down and harnessed, piloting a 60-horsepower aircraft.
description: STRUNG across a valley in Queenstown, New Zealand, is an amusement park ride that makes bungee-jumping look tame. It combines bungee features with elements of trapeze and aircraft flight, allowing thrill-seekers to swing through the air at the end of a tethered cable at speeds up to 120 miles an hour, piloting a one-man craft shaped like a B-movie rocket ship in any direction they want.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: The Assault on Sprawl Is Starting a Bit Late
description: To the Editor:

title: Thin, Loved, Famous: How Nice It Would Be
description: FAMOUS AFTER DEATH

title: Appointments Made By Knight Ridder In News Divisions
description: A corporate reshuffling in the top ranks of Knight Ridder's news division is bringing an old Washington hand back to head the newspaper chain's Washington bureau, while the executive editor of The San Jose Mercury News in California is taking over as Knight Ridder's vice president for news.

title: The Net's Real Business Happens .Com to .Com; A Market That Dwarfs Retail E-Sales
description: Each month, Patricia Ruszkay, a purchasing agent for BOC Gases, a global distributor of industrial gases with American headquarters in Murray Hill, N.J., pulls a chair up to a computer, logs on to the Internet, and looks for a bargain.

title: Essay; Bush's Foreign Policy
description: In our last episode, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas reluctantly began to expound on his foreign-policy mindset. To continue:

title: With a Few Tears and a Final Assist, Gretzky Says Goodbye
description: After most hockey games, Wayne Gretzky is a quick-change artist, out of uniform and out of the locker room before anyone else on the team. But yesterday was different, for so many reasons, and Gretzky still wore his Ranger jersey and pants more than an hour after the conclusion of the final game of his brilliant career.

title: A Growth Spurt Is Transforming TV for Children
description: Public lamentation over the dangers to American children from too much sex, violence and repetitious fare on television has been around almost as long as television itself. But today, alongside the hue and cry lies a quieter appraisal.

title: Black Police Group Assails 'Hateful' Rhetoric
description: A group of black police officers said yesterday that they agreed with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's criticism of the ''hateful'' rhetoric employed at several recent demonstrations against police brutality, but added that they hoped the same standards would apply to the police union and the Police Commissioner.

title: He Who Must Be Busy: No Rest for Mortimer
description: As the creator of ''Rumpole of the Bailey,'' and as a novelist, playwright and man of letters, John Mortimer receives many offers. But one invitation struck a particularly responsive note. About a year ago he was sitting quietly in his home in Henley-on-Thames, presumably sipping a glass of port, when the telephone rang. Mr. Mortimer recently recalled the conversation: ''The man said: 'This is Judge Rehnquist. We're having a banquet for the Supreme Court, and the only person we want to address us is you as the author of Rumpole.' ''

title: City Pledges $22 Million To Expand A Museum
description: A dispute between the city and the state over the financing of $22 million toward the expansion of the Holocaust museum came to an end yesterday when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki issued a joint statement announcing that the city would finance the project.

title: New Assignments For 3 Agencies
description: Three agencies have been awarded new assignments for which billings have not been determined.

title: Congress Party Seeks Center Stage in India
description: A day after the fall of the Hindu nationalist-led Government, leaders of the opposition Congress Party began trying to patch together a new governing coalition. But any new alliance drawn from the contentious collection of opposition parties is likely to be as rickety as the one that just lost power, political analysts say.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph in Weekend on Friday with the Art in Review column, showing the artist Patty Chang slurping water off a mirror, appeared incorrectly. The image, from the video ''Fountain'' in her current show at the Jack Tilton Gallery in SoHo, should have shown the mirror on the floor, not on a wall at the right.

title: Two European Phone Giants Keep Talking
description: Italy and Germany gave their approval today for Telecom Italia S.p.A. to continue discussions about a possible merger with Deutsche Telekom A.G. The decision is expected to complicate the struggle for control of Telecom Italia, which faces a $65 billion hostile bid from its Italian rival, Olivetti S.p.A.

title: Campaign Reform, Again
description: The fight over campaign finance reform has now begun in earnest. By the close of business Friday, 189 Democrats in the House of Representatives had signed a petition to force a floor vote on legislation that would outlaw the unlimited, unregulated donations to political parties that are known as soft money. The petition strategy has been forced by the resolute refusal of the House Speaker, Dennis Hastert, to move quickly on the bill and thus leave enough time to rally support in the Senate before the campaign season begins next year -- and hundreds of millions of dollars from special interests start polluting the system all over again. Because the petition needs 218 signatures to succeed, and there are only 211 Democrats, the Republicans will have to help.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery results yesterday misstated the numbers for Saturday's New York Lotto game. The correct numbers were 6, 16, 24, 29, 38 and 43. The supplementary number was 37.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about Apple Computer's first quarter earnings report misstated the speed of the company's latest iMac computers. They run at 333 megahertz, not 300 megahertz.

title: Florida Rain Fails to Remove Threat of Fires
description: A hard but all too brief rain helped bring a major brush fire in the Everglades under control today, as firefighters steeled themselves for what forecasters have predicted to be another hot, dry week in Florida's wildfire season.

title: Marbury's Defense Keeps Iverson in Check
description: NETS 86, 76ERS 79

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Compressed Data; First, the 'Free' PC; Now the 'Free' Server
description: In the spirit of a new breed of companies offering ''free PC's'' -- tempered with the reality that there's invariably a catch -- a Silicon Valley company says that it plans to start distributing ''free'' server computers.

title: Kenyan Claims 'Record' and $330,000
description: Joyce Chepchumba, a 28-year-old from a Kenyan farming family, earned at least $330,000 for winning the London Marathon yesterday in 2 hours 23 minutes 22 seconds. Chepchumba's earnings, the biggest financial reward for a single competition in women's track and field history, includes a bonus of $125,000 for what the London Marathon organizers claim is a women's world record time and an appearance fee of at least $100,000.

title: Editorial Observer; Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Balkan Quagmire?
description: The birth announcements for the new, isolationist Republican Party seem to be somewhat premature. True, there has been a lot of dark muttering about morasses and quagmires -- Yugoslavia has been compared to every kind of bad-driving terrain known to mankind, except perhaps really deep potholes. But this is a Congressional sentiment from the rapidly aging partisans of the Gingrich revolution, most perfectly articulated by the House majority leader, Dick Armey, the guy who declared that having been abroad once, he saw no reason to ever go back. The Republican candidates for President are a different matter entirely.

title: DNA Tests Are Freeing Scores of Prison Inmates
description: It was a gruesome slaying. Debra Sue Carter, a 21-year-old barmaid, was found on the floor of her garage apartment in December 1982 in Ada, a town of 16,000 people southeast of Oklahoma City. She had been raped, and words were written on her nude body in ketchup and fingernail polish.

title: Lost Horizons: The Billboard Prepares to Give Up Smoking
description: Unhitched by riggers, the vinyl billboard in Times Square advertising Kool Natural cigarettes slid down like an old curtain last week and was quickly carted away.

title: Pivotal Rulings Ahead for Law On Disabilities
description: Beginning on Wednesday with a case that some lawyers have labeled the Brown v. Board of Education of the disability rights movement, the Supreme Court is embarking on an unusually extensive review of a single Federal statute, the Americans With Disabilities Act.

title: For Police, Sympathy but Disapproval
description: Marvin Lewis, a 46-year-old resident of this town who was pushing his daughter in a swing in Orange Park today, admitted being conflicted about recent police actions.

title: Media Talk; Statistics Are Mixed on Hiring of Minorities
description: One of the most contentious issues at the annual convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors last year -- the degree to which the newspaper business is trying to hire journalists from underrepresented groups, particularly members of minorities and women -- was less of a sore point this year at the society's convention in San Francisco. Still, amid a strong push for more hiring of members of minorities -- including job fairs and increased proselytizing about the newspaper business, the percentage of minorities remained little changed.

title: Couch Gets Squeezed Before First Game
description: About 12 hours before the National Football League draft, Leigh Steinberg, the agent for Oregon quarterback Akili Smith, had reached a tentative deal with the Cleveland Browns, owners of the first pick. Steinberg is one of the most skilled negotiators in the business, and, being a draft-day veteran, he can smell a setup. Something just did not feel right. So Steinberg went to the Browns and pleaded with them: draft Kentucky's Tim Couch if you want, but don't use Smith to make Couch more signable.

title: Beautiful Blossoms, Shaky Reputation
description: Those white flowers floating over so many city streets in recent weeks are Callery pears, or Pyrus calleryana, if you want to get technical about it. Their tiny five-petaled flowers are loosely clustered, allowing plenty of light to play among the dark branches, so that to walk down a street lined with these tall trunks is to feel embraced by soft clouds.

title: Giants Turn Spotlight On Draft's Dark Horses
description: When the Giants made the uncelebrated tackle Luke Petitgout their first-round pick on Saturday, their choice was met with a certain amount of wonder and surprise. He was a lesser-known, smaller player in a field of big-name, mammoth linemen.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: An Unfamiliar Tale of Pride and Prejudice
