description: For a good hundred years after its premiere in 1835 at the Paris Opera, ''La Juive'' (''The Jewess''), the five-act French grand opera on which the reputation of Jacques-Francois Fromental Halevy largely rests, enjoyed worldwide acclaim. It was presented 562 times at the Paris Opera alone. Caruso made a specialty of the daunting role of Eleazar, a tormented Jewish jeweler in Constance, Switzerland, during the early 15th century, who is deeply proud of his religious heritage in the face of the hysterical prejudice and fanatically consumed with revenge. Wagner admired and conducted ''La Juive,'' and Mahler though it ''wonderful and majestic . . . one of the greatest operas ever created.''

title: So Many Programs, So Few Bodies
description: In an earlier time of broadcast news, marked by far-flung correspondents and high-roller budgets, individual news programs fought for turf, for talent and for money. A correspondent for the NBC ''Nightly News'' would not be assigned to do a report for, say, a news magazine, nor would a CBS News domestic reporter be sent to cover a war.

title: Messier Joins In an All-Star Celebration
description: While waiting in the tunnels off the ice before the start of the tributes to Wayne Gretzky, seated behind the goal watching the game and appearing at the post-game interviews, Mark Messier never removed his sunglasses. It was not a look he sought to affect. It was simply that he wanted protection from the flashing cameras if he could not hold back the tears.

title: A Genuine Budget Crisis
description: The current budget impasse in Albany involves a disagreement that is far more profound than New York's normal partisan squabbling. The state is in danger of turning sane financial priorities upside down, while undermining its own efforts to improve public-school standards. Gov. George Pataki is the politician most responsible for creating the mess, and it is up to him to chart a way out.

title: Media Talk; Conde Nast Seeks New Advertisers
description: In a shift aimed at bringing new advertisers to the pages of its magazines, Conde Nast has begun churning out special issues with targeted audiences that attract new advertisers to Conde Nast, a unit of Advance Publications.

title: A Family Revisited: Bombs a Wrenching Routine
description: Little Sara, nearly 5, gets to watch her beloved ''Ninja Turtles'' on tele vision, and ''Power Rangers,'' too. But NATO bombs and missiles keep striking Rakovica and Zarkovo, near this southern Belgrade suburb. So she has been sleeping in the basement every night for the last 25 nights -- and counting -- of NATO's air war against Yugoslavia's President, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Safir May Use Data on Frisks To Back Unit
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir plans to defend his department's Street Crime Unit at a City Council hearing today by using an analysis of police data to argue that officers have not unfairly singled out blacks to be stopped and searched on the streets, a police official said yesterday.

title: Media Talk; Awkward Moment for White House?
description: When Bill Clinton stands on stage at the White House Correspondents Dinner in the Washington Hilton on May 1, he is scheduled to shake hands and stand for photographs with the three journalists who have won awards for their coverage of the White House this year.

title: Is It Time to Play or Defend? A Champion Has to Choose
description: Three decades ago a young man named Shapour Mohtashami made a considerable mark on the New York bridge world. Nowadays he lives in Paris and made an appearance at the world championships in Lille in August. In the Mixed Pairs as South, he played the diagramed deal, which can be considered a play-or-defend problem. Which side would you choose in four spades?

title: California Federal Bank to Appeal Award
description: California Federal Bank said today that it would appeal a judge's award in its lawsuit against the Federal Government for a broken promise of special regulatory treatment.

title: Four-Horse Photo
description: At Aqueduct yesterday, in the New York Stallion Series for 3-year-old colts and fillies, Shut Out Time wasted no time showing why he was the solid favorite in the colt division. He is trained by Michael Gorham, had Joe Bravo riding, and he led all the way to outrun a small field of five by more than four lengths. He ran the mile in 1:36 3/5 and paid $2.60 for a $2 bet to win. Olive Flu ran second, with Courageous Comet third.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Top Executives at Compaq Quit Amid Financial Turmoil

title: Judge Overlooked Kevorkian's Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Overlooked Kevorkian's Protest; More Palliative Care
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sanctuary for the Avant-Garde
description: Greenwich Village got the bohemian seal of approval in 1916 when Marcel Duchamp and several friends climbed to the top of the arch at Washington Square, opened up a picnic dinner and declared the Village a ''free republic, independent of uptown.'' By the early 1960's, life in the Village had become an intoxicating maelstrom of new music, theater, art and film. Headiest of all, though, was the iconoclastic work being done at the sober-looking Judson Memorial Church on Washington Square South.

title: Judge Overlooked Kevorkian's Protest; Sidetracking the Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect in Journalist's Slaying Is Arrested
description: In an arrest that could end the seven-year investigation into the execution-style killing of a crusading antidrug journalist in Queens, the police in Colombia on Saturday captured a man who has been considered a major figure in the slaying.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I was a boy that happened to love a game and got lucky and the good Lord gave me a passion for it.''

title: Corrections
description: The Metropolitan Diary column last Monday rendered one word incorrectly in a poem titled ''Signs of Spring'' by Thomas Froncek. The passage should have read ''Now add as well, 'neath the too-short shirt; What lures the eye and tempts the flirt; The bellybutton wink of a sweet young thing.'' It should not have read ''too-short skirt.''

title: Plant Sterility Research Inflames Debate on Biotechnology's Role in Farming
description: Seven years ago, Melvin Oliver had one of those middle-of-the-night ''aha!'' inspirations that normally occur only in researchers' fantasies and campy movies. Suddenly, he could visualize how to grow generation after generation of plants and then, whenever he desired, insure that the next generation would be the last -- because all its seed would be sterile.

title: Leaping To the Stage From Tragic Headlines
description: Is there a more timely play in New York right now than ''Tesla's Letters''?

title: U.S. IS ASKING NATO FOR SEA BLOCKADE OF YUGOSLAVS' OIL
description: The United States wants NATO to plan ways of blocking deliveries of oil to Yugoslavia by sea, which have continued even as allied warplanes bomb refineries and oil storage installations on land, allied officials said today.

title: Knicks Need a Hero; So, Any Volunteers?
description: The Knicks have taken on the look of survivors watching the air leak out of their life raft. There is panic and fleeting hope. Won't someone save them?

title: Albany's Majority Parties Lord It Over the Underdogs
description: In an office near the Capitol is a collection of computers that look as if they belong in a Museum of Woefully Antiquated Technology -- crotchety curios from the mid-1980's that can barely be used to write reports, never mind send E-mail or access the Internet. To the researchers for the Republican minority in the Assembly who have to work on these machines, every keystroke is a reminder that in Albany, it isn't easy to be out of power.

title: Santo Domingo Memo; Caribbean Unity? Bananas Are Getting in the Way
description: Venezuela's New President, Hugo Chavez Frias, was supposed to deliver a closing thank you speech at this weekend's Caribbean summit meeting here, but speaking with the candor of the recently elected, he grumbled that he had already attended six meetings of heads of state in only 73 days in office.

title: Candidates Set For Internet Registry Work
description: The first five companies to compete with Network Solutions Inc. in the business of registering Internet addresses will be selected this week, even though the Government has not yet made final the terms under which the company will open its data base.

title: Red Tape Delays Expansion Of Overfilled Refugee Camps
description: Most refugee camps in Macedonia are filled to capacity and delays in getting the Government's approval for camp expansions are causing severe overcrowding, aid workers said today.

title: U.S. Missed the Chance to Remake Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: A Family Feud Over a Picasso (On Wheels); A New Car's Logo Divides The Heirs of a Lucrative Name
description: Children of the rich, famous and powerful rarely have it easy. But Picasso's four children suffered more than most. The great artist was not, in his later years, a great father. He routinely ill-treated his one legitimate son, and he neglected the son and two daughters he had outside of marriage. Still, when he died in 1973, they inherited some of the fruits of his talent and, in three cases, his name.

title: Scandal-Tainted 2002 Games Losing Sponsor
description: Johnson & Johnson, the health care product company, has withdrawn as a potential sponsor of the 2002 Winter Olympics, partly as a result of the bribery scandal that has engulfed the Salt Lake City Games, the United States Olympic Committee said yesterday.

title: Treasury Plans to Sell Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Energy Dept. Bars Releasing China Spy Data
description: The chairman of the House select committee that found that China had stolen American nuclear weapons secrets said today that the Department of Energy was improperly holding up the release of some of the committee's still-classified report.

title: Despite a Passion for the Net, Many On-Line Volunteers Want Pay
description: David Mann has played piano and written arrangements for Frank Sinatra, serenaded President Truman on his yacht and written popular music like the song ''In the Wee Small Hours of the Morning.''

title: Rodgers Returns With a Passion
description: Bill Rodgers always loved running a marathon. He did not mind the routine aches. He dismissed the late-race pain that racked his glucose-starved body. But in 1992, tired of a new injury every other day, he ran (he said then) his last marathon.

title: Stellar Discoveries That Are Out of This World
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROKMAN, BERNARD
description: BROKMAN - Bernard. Beloved husband of Leila, devoted father of Michael (Honey), Robert (Susan) and David (Lynda). Loving brother of Elsie Itkin. Devoted grandfather. Graveside services Wednesday 10:30 AM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale. For information call WeinsteinWest End 1-800-452-9597.

title: Williams Inspires Nets, but That Isn't Enough
description: After meeting with Jayson Williams for the first time since he suffered his season-ending leg injury, the Nets played with the vigor and the resolve that their inspirational leader always displayed. But the spirit of Williams was not enough against the rejuvenated Charlotte Hornets, who shot down the hustling Nets to win by 120-113 tonight at Continental Arena.

title: Aerolineas Argentinas Orders 12 Airbus Jets
description: Aerolineas Argentinas, Argentina's flagship airline, signed a contract yesterday for the purchase of 12 four-engine Airbus A340 jets. The airline, in which AMR Corporation, American Airlines' parent company, and the Spanish Government own minority stakes, ordered six high-capacity, long-range A340-600 planes, four A340-200's and two A340-300's. It is the first carrier in Latin America to order the four-engine plane, which is made by Airbus Industrie, the passenger jet consortium jointly owned by four European companies.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE SOARS. Prices for orange juice rose on expectations that a dry spell in Florida is damaging crops. In New York, frozen concentrated orange juice for May delivery rose 4.6 cents a pound, to 85.15 cents.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Rally throughout Asia buoys hopes that the economic crisis has bottomed out.
description: STOCK markets from Seoul to Singapore soared yesterday, extending a rally that many analysts here say is proof that foreign investors are returning in large numbers to the recession-ravaged economies of Asia.

title: Strawberry Is Only Part Of Left-Field Problems
description: Deeply disturbed that he wasn't on the Yankees' roster, Darryl Strawberry returned nine days ago to Tampa, Fla., where he subsequently was arrested on charges of cocaine possession and solicitation of prostitution, placing his baseball career in jeopardy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOULD, MILTON S.
description: GOULD-Milton S. A memorial service for Milton S. Gould will be held today at 4:00 P.M. in the Rotunda of the State Supreme Court Building at 60 Centre Street in lower Manhattan. All are welcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUBEN, MAXWELL M.
description: HAUBEN-Maxwell M. Devoted and adoring husband for 64 years of Betty. Loving Dad of Kenneth and Barbara Stein and Richard and Ellen Hauben. Darling grandfather of Elissa and Ross Patterson, Edward and Elisabeth Wolfe, Erica and Jakub Karras and Jessica Hauben. He is survived by one brother, Louis, and sisters-in-law Pauline and Bea Hauben and Dorothy Kaufman. Mac was an electrical engineer and the founder of Superior Instrument Co., Accurate Instrument Co., and Moss Electronics. Service today 11:30 AM at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pine Brook Blvd., New Rochelle, New York.

title: Sitting in the Parlor as the World Turns
description: There are only seven characters in ''The Exact Center of the Universe,'' and three of them are named Mary. Mary Lou (Tracy Thorne) is the pretty blond young woman in a tight peachy-pink sweater being interrogated by the imposing Vada Love Powell (Frances Sternhagen). Mary Ann (also Ms. Thorne) is Mary Lou's twin sister, who is at that exact moment marrying Vada's overadored 35-year-old son, Appleton (Reed Birney), in a secret ceremony. Marybell (Marge Redmond) is Vada's longtime friend and canasta partner who reveals her deep, dark secret: her maiden name was Ferrara. She's Italian, which in the Protestant, Anglo-Saxon Deep South of the 1950's is something to keep quiet about.

title: Newly Armed Bengals Release O'Donnell
description: The Cincinnati Bengals yesterday released Neil O'Donnell, the onetime Super Bowl quarterback who was their starter for most of last season after being released by the Jets last June.

title: In Search of Minority Officers
description: Only days after Amidou Diallo's death, concerned New Yorkers across the political spectrum called for stronger ties between the New York City Police Department and minority communities.

title: Trenton Charges 2 Troopers With Falsifying Drivers' Race
description: In the first official sign that the New Jersey State Police may have illegally singled out black and Hispanic motorists, the Attorney General today announced the indictments of two troopers accused of falsifying documents to make it appear that some of the black motorists they had stopped were white.

title: Kosovo's Reality: People Die in War
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Struggling Starter Files for Protection
description: After reporting lagging sales, Starter Corporation, a leading maker of athletic clothing, filed for Chapter 11 protection yesterday in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYRNE, DOROTHY M.
description: BYRNE-Dorothy M. Of Bronxville, NY on April 18, 1999. Wife of the late John J. Byrne. Mother of Dr. Mary Byrne and Rev. Peter Byrne. Mother-in-law of Thomas Rogan. Grandmother of John and Brendan. Sister of Martin, James Nolan, Marie Nolan Buxton, Julia Nolan Gnocchi and Patricia Nolan Allen. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville 7:00-9:00 PM Tuesday, 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 Wednesday. Mass of Christian burial Immaculate Conception Church, 14th St. at First Ave., NYC on Thursday, April 22 at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, RUTH
description: BAUM-Ruth. The Board of Directors, staff, children and families of Northside Center for Child Development, Inc. note with great sadness the passing of our longtime friend and Board member, Ruth Baum. Ruth became part of the Northside family over 30 years ago and throughout that time fervently championed its cause. Ruth's dedication to the children of Northside and the Jane Allen Emil Library of Northside will always be remembered. We thank you for your many years of caring, kindness and commitment. You will be missed. Northside extends its deepest sympathy to the Baum Family.

title: Bradley Takes Early Party Prize: He Goes One-on-One With Gore
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey likes to tell audiences that in 1988 he looked at himself in the mirror and said, ''You're not ready.'' He decided not to run for President.

title: Kosovo's Reality: People Die in War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGLASS, GENEVIEVE M.
description: DOUGLASS-Genevieve M. Former Principal, Woodward Parkway School, Farmingdale, Died April 17. Zaumetzer-Sprague Box 127, Au Sable Forks 12912.

title: In the Dark as the Black Plague Festers
description: The year is 1348. Philip VI is on the throne of France; Clement VI is on the throne of Peter; the Black Death is ravaging Europe. It is a time of fear, conflict and confusion. Tom Dulack's play ''1348'' mostly reflects the confusion.

title: Legislators File Suit to End Freeze on Their Paychecks
description: A group of Democratic legislators filed a lawsuit today challenging a new law that requires the state to withhold the pay of all 211 members of the Legislature until they approve a state budget.

title: Jobless Pro Players Try to Save Careers
description: They were stars in the American Basketball League, but that women's pro league folded at Christmastime.

title: N.Y.'s Tunnel Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITHEILER, SAUL
description: WITHEILER-Saul. Age 89, died peacefully at home on April 19. Beloved husband of Paula (nee Greenspan), loving father of Karen W. Kern and Alan. Cherished grandfather of Joshua and Michael, Nicole and Matthew. Caring brother of Goldie Yaver and Flora Thomsen. Dear father-in-law of Eugene M. Kern, M.D. and Jordanna Witheiler. Services Tuesday, 12 Noon at ''Guttermans, Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Missing Connecticut Lawyer Returns and Surrenders to Police
description: F. Mac Buckley, the Connecticut lawyer and boxing promoter who vanished on his way to a hearing seven weeks ago, turned himself in to the state police this morning and appeared in court a few hours later looking trim and bronzed.

title: Lowered Drinking Age?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rutgers Named in Suit Over Alumni Ad Dispute
description: The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey sued Rutgers University yesterday in an effort to force the alumni magazine to publish an advertisement by a group opposed to what it considers the university's emphasis on big-time athletics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, JACK L.
description: RUBIN-Jack L. Of Pompano Beach, FL. Beloved husband of the late Lillian, devoted father of Earl and Irma, loving grandfather of Jeff and Marc. Services on Thursday. Information ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800 322-0533.

title: Slap on the Wrist
description: To the Editor:

title: Sniffle-and-Sneeze Hotbeds in a Hot Race
description: Early last week, Atlanta was in the news for its astonishingly high pollen count: 4,371 grains of tree-spawned pollen per cubic meter. The National Allergy Bureau, a nonprofit pollen counting network that provides local readings three times each week from stations across the United States, considers up to 15 pollen grains per cubic meter a low count, and any reading over 1,500 as ''very high.''

title: Must Medicine Wait for Science?; When Advocacy Harms
description: To the Editor:

title: Holbrooke's U.N. Nomination Is Reported Close to a Deal
description: Senate leaders and the State Department said today that they were close to a deal that could rescue the long-delayed nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke to lead the American delegation to the United Nations.

title: Take Some Strychnine and Call Me in the Morning
description: Go to the zoo and gaze deep into the eyes of a chimpanzee, and you will know exactly how it feels to leaf through the first edition of the Merck Manual, the venerable medical textbook first published in 1899 and reissued this week in a commemorative centennial package along with the 1999 edition. There is that same fascination at something so alien and primitive, that same surge of relief that we have come so far . . . and that same sudden flash of recognition too -- isn't that just a little touch of Grandpa around the hairline?

title: G.O.P. Congressman On Belgrade Mission
description: A New Jersey Congressman has been in Belgrade, possibly meeting with a high-ranking Yugoslav Government official, on a mission that a National Security Council spokesman said tonight took the Administration by surprise.

title: U S West to Buy Equipment From Lucent
description: U S West Inc., which provides local phone service in 14 Western states, agreed to buy more than $300 million of telecommunications switches and software from Lucent Technologies Inc. to increase network capacity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COCKCROFT, EVA S.
description: COCKCROFT-Eva S. Muralist, painter and writer, with more than thirty murals in New York, New Jersey, California, Nicaragua and Berlin, died on April 1, in Los Angeles, of breast cancer, at age 62. The co-author of ''Towards a People's Art,'' her writing also appeared in ''Art Forum'' and ''Art in America''. Eva is survived by her father, Dr. Otto Sperling; three sons, Ben, Eric and Peter; her companion Bruce Snyder; and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Social and Public Art Resource Center, 685 Venice Boulevard, Venice, CA, on May 1, 1999. For information call 323-256-1853.

title: These Bacteria Are So Big, the Microscope's Optional
description: Heide Schulz remembers thinking that the single-cell organism she examined under a microscope that day back in 1997 was unusual. Sifted from sulfurous muck on the ocean floor off the coast of Namibia in Africa, it seemed to be a microbe. But Ms. Schulz, a doctoral student at the Max Planck Institute for Marine Microbiology in Bremen, Germany, was astonished at its size.

title: Special NATO Pilot Was Ordered to Bomb Convoy, Belgrade Says
description: While NATO was making its own efforts today to explain what happened last Wednesday on the Djakovica-Prizren road in Kosovo where, Yugoslav authorities say, 74 ethnic Albanians died in a NATO attack on a convoy, a most decidedly alternative version has appeared in the state-run Serbian press.

title: Defining 'Disability' Down
description: Nearly a decade after it was enthusiastically signed into law by President Bush, the Americans with Disabilities Act faces a major review by the Supreme Court. Over the next two weeks, the justices are to hear four cases that will help define the true dimensions of the law. The Court's role should be to reaffirm the nation's commitment to fair treatment of people with some kind of physical or mental impairment.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Speedy Crustaceans

title: Reading and Commerce
description: To the Editor:

title: In Congo or Kosovo, a Compulsion to Help
description: THEY tell each other it's because of the ''3Ms'' -- in other words, they're convinced they have the characteristics of martyrs, misfits and masochists. They see each other at the world's most horrific disasters. They dig wells, rehydrate children with intravenous fluid and live on adrenaline. Kosovo (and Rwanda and Uganda and Congo) are how they make their living.

title: I.B.M. to Revamp British Telecom Systems
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the No. 1 computer maker, won a $200 million contract today to install new mainframes and software for British Telecom P.L.C., bolstering I.B.M.'s services business.

title: Brazil Bounces Back, Offering $1 Billion in Debt for Sale
description: When Brazil devalued its currency in January, the nation was faced with rising inflation, soaring interest rates, the threat of default and a recession. Most foreign investors crossed Brazil off their dance cards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, GEORGE
description: REISS-George. Died suddenly at the age of 78 on Saturday, April 17th, 1999. Loving father of Johnny. Dearest life's partner of Rena. Devoted brother-in-law of Gordon and of Louise. Beloved husband of the late Helga and brother of the late Eric. Born in Vienna, he came to the U.S. in 1939. He was a World War II veteran, a husband, a father, a lawyer, and a gentleman who graced all those who knew him with his friendship and kindness. A memorial service will be held today at 11 AM at the Park West Riverside Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Judge Halts Efforts to Build 5 Golf Courses in Suffolk
description: In a decision that could eventually affect golfers from Saratoga to Staten Island, a judge has ruled that Suffolk County may not build any new courses until it has studied the feasibility of creating and maintaining organic, pesticide-free golf courses.

title: Airlines' Customer Service Decreased in '98, Study Says
description: The major airlines are getting worse at many of the parts of their jobs that passengers care about the most: being on time, handling baggage and treating travelers decently.

title: A New Trial for India
description: India's divisive ethnic and regional politics have produced one political crisis after another in recent years. Now these tensions have caused the collapse of the Hindu nationalist Government led by Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, which lost a vote of confidence by a single vote last Saturday. The beneficiary could be the troubled Congress Party, which has governed India for most of the last 15 years and is now led by Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born widow of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. Even if Mrs. Gandhi manages to form a government, the chances of it lasting very long are considered slim.

title: Crossing Flaming Swords Over God and Physics
description: What if Jerry Springer decided to do a show pitting one particle physicist who believed in God against another who did not? And if he asked them to hash out, before a live audience, whether the universe is the product of divine design?

title: Raghubir Singh, Photographer Who Depicted a Vivid India, Dies at 58
description: Raghubir Singh, who photographed the pulsating expanse of India in all its varied shades and hues, died on Sunday in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 58.

title: Israel Sets Forth Compromise Plan on Nazareth Mosque Dispute
description: Israel has adopted a compromise plan to resolve a violent dispute in Nazareth between Muslims and Christians. The plan would allow a small mosque to be built next to a planned plaza for millennium pilgrims.

title: Sports of The Times; 2 Runners, 2 Mind-Sets, 2 Letdowns
description: BY the time Bill Rodgers reached the top of Heartbreak Hill, his legs were fading and, much worse, his eyes were lying.

title: 2 Rivals Join To Take Over Revived Fund
description: Ask Wall Street experts to name two financiers whose fortunes are tied most closely to the bond market and they would most likely settle on Jon S. Corzine, the chairman of Goldman Sachs Group, and John W. Meriwether, founder of the hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management.

title: PLAINS ALL AMERICAN TO BUY WEST TEXAS OIL PIPELINE
description: Plains All American Pipeline L.P., a subsidiary of the Houston-based Plains Resources Inc., plans to buy a West Texas crude oil pipeline and gathering system from the Chevron Pipe Line Company. for about $40 million. Under terms of the deal, Plains All American would gain around 400 miles of crude oil pipelines and storage capacity for three million barrels of crude oil in Texas. Plains All American recently agreed also to buy Scurlock Permian L.L.C. and certain other pipeline assets from Marathon Ashland Petroleum L.L.C. Scurlock's key asset is an 800-mile pipeline in West Texas.

title: Despite Intense Criticism, US Airways Increases Fares in New York
description: The only airline with jet service within New York State quietly raised ticket prices over the weekend, pushing fares as much as 67 percent higher than a year ago. The airline, US Airways, is already under intense criticism from corporate and political leaders for charging high fares within the state.

title: David, 71, and Joan McCall, 57, Die in Crash
description: David B. McCall and Joan Mills McCall, who excelled separately in the worlds of advertising, philanthropy and the arts and together as fiercely dedicated advocates for the world's displaced people, died in a car accident Sunday while on an aid mission in Albania.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's Al Gore and I, one-on-one, for 11 months.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGIDOR, SARAH
description: MAGIDOR-Sarah. We deeply mourn the passing of Sarah Magidor, the mother of Professor Menachem Magidor, President of The Hebrew University of Jerusalem. We extend our deepest condolences to Professor Magidor and his family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Keith L. Sachs, President Fred S. Lafer, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President

title: SERBS REINFORCING TROOPS IN KOSOVO DESPITE BOMBING
description: Despite four weeks of NATO air and missile strikes, Yugoslavia's Army and police forces have sent thousands of reinforcements into Kosovo and stepped up the use of helicopters and aircraft to press their campaign against the province's Albanians, NATO and Pentagon officials said today.

title: BASEBALL: My Two Sons, Cuban Style; Arnaldo Hernandez, the Original El Duque, Watches From Another World
description: In his 50's, Arnaldo Hernandez still moves with an easy, athletic stride, his long arms swinging in graceful arcs, the same way they did in 1969, when he pulled off the rare feat of playing all nine positions for one of this country's fabled baseball teams, the Villa Clara Azucareros.

title: DIME BANCORP TO BUY CITIBANK'S AUTO-FINANCE UNIT
description: Dime Bancorp Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the automobile-finance business of Citigroup Inc. Terms were not disclosed. The deal includes a $930 million loan portfolio and the assumption of certain commercial deposit relationships. Dime said the addition would raise consumer loans as a percentage of its total loans receivable to 13 percent, from 8 percent and add more than $150 million in related business loans.

title: White House Tangles With China Now, With Congress Later
description: President Clinton's negotiators leave for Beijing on Tuesday to try to clinch a sweeping market-opening deal with China. But some of the most intensive talks are going to take place with a skeptical Congress.

title: Yankees: That's Life, Shot Down in April
description: Good thing the Yankees were off yesterday. They needed a break after their lost weekend in Detroit. The Yankees weren't the first people to ever waste a weekend there, but they endured a particularly tough visit and now they have people wondering what is wrong with them and if they will ever recover.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Zoran, the Master of Deluxe Minimalism, Still Provokes
description: The remarkable thing about Zoran, the 52-year-old fashion designer, is not that he has grown rich by selling clothes that have changed little in 20 years or that he enjoys provoking retailers and clients with the occasional insult. No, the amazing thing is how someone with his practical wisdom and perverse assurance could still be such a fashion secret.

title: STOCK MARKET HIT AS INVESTORS FLEE TECHNOLOGY AREA
description: In a stunning reversal, investors piled out of technology stocks and other market darlings yesterday, pummeling the very shares that propelled the broad market averages to records last week.

title: Pataki Is Accused of Hurting Giuliani Bid
description: The Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, accused Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday of orchestrating an effort by some New York State Republicans to ''scuttle'' Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's fund-raising efforts and other preliminary plans to run for United States Senate.

title: The Shy, Conflicted Man Who Loved the Movies
description: TRUFFAUT

title: Kosovo's Reality: People Die in War
description: To the Editor:

title: Abortion Protests Continue Peacefully
description: Braving numbing rain and whistling winds, more than 80 abortion protesters fanned across the suburbs of Buffalo this morning in the second day of a highly publicized week of demonstrations, delivering their message at high schools, public thoroughfares and at the area's biggest bookstore, which they said was promoting child pornography.

title: Editorial Notebook; The Edifice That Pierpont Morgan Built
description: The English art critic Roger Fry, who perplexed what might have been a straightforward relationship with Pierpont Morgan, once wrote that Americans ''have a desperate desire to get at real things . . . they jump at enlightenment.'' Even so, Fry and his fellow critic Bernard Berenson had deeply ambivalent feelings about Morgan and his art collecting, feelings that had as much to do with commerce -- the marketing of art -- as they did with esthetics. Berenson, being as kind as he was able, could only say: ''It seems Morgan's desire now is to re-value the masterpieces of Italian art. The worst of it is he will succeed. The fact that he liked a picture will probably be remembered for years.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIANA, CAROL YORK
description: DIANA-Carol York. On April 17, 1999 at the age of 53. Beloved wife of Michael; loving mother of Elisabeth and Weldon; dear sister of Dr. Harold York. Interment private. Memorial Mass was held. Contributions in her memory may be made to Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St, NY, NY 10021.

title: Prosecutors to Present Clinic Doctor's Slaying to Grand Jury
description: With the finding of a buried rifle 11 days ago, the authorities in the Buffalo area say they have gathered enough evidence in the October slaying of Dr. Barnett Slepian to begin presenting a murder case to a state grand jury as early as next week.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Condo Roadblock For an Agnelli

title: Capital Invokes Framers in Voting-Rights Suit
description: ''Relief, 200 years late, can be ordered,'' the lawyer for the District of Columbia told a special three-judge court today in arguing in its lawsuit against the Federal Government that residents of the city should be allowed to vote for members of Congress.

title: Clinton Presses Yeltsin to Help As Peacekeeper
description: President Clinton called President Boris N. Yeltsin today to press for Russian participation in a political resolution in Kosovo that would involve Russian troops in an international security force there, White House officials said.

title: Yvette Pierpaoli, 60, Aid Worker Who Devoted Life to Refugees
description: Yvette Pierpaoli, a dynamic French woman who traveled the world seeking to help war widows, displaced persons, land-mine victims, homeless families, street children and other refugees, was one of three aid workers killed on Sunday in an automobile accident near Kukes, Albania. She was 60.

title: NATO's Blasting of Bridges Outrages Novi Sad's Citizens
description: Army-green barges ferry people across the Danube now, under what would have been the shadow of the Varadinski Bridge.

title: Citigroup Posts 9% Rise In Its Profits
description: Citigroup, displaying the kind of raw earnings power promised by the merger that created the financial services giant last year, said first-quarter profits jumped 9 percent, surpassing analysts' estimates and earnings posted by such well-known titans as the General Electric Company and the General Motors Corporation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Symbol of Welfare Reform, Still Struggling
description: She had practiced her lines and prayed with her mother. She had bought her children new clothes. After 10 years on welfare, Michelle Crawford was leaving her rundown home to speak to the Legislature, at the Governor's personal request. She clenched her notes so tightly in the back of the car, it seemed she was trying to choke them.

title: Two Advertisers Decide on Accounts
description: Two advertisers have made decisions involving accounts.

title: Closing Is Seen for Hospital in 2 to 3 Years
description: The chief executive of New York City's public hospital system said yesterday that North Central Bronx Hospital, with 1,200 unionized health care workers and room for 450 beds, would almost certainly close in the next two to three years because of a steady decline in the number of patients it treats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARTEN, ISIDORE
description: KARTEN-Isidore. Beloved husband of Julia, devoted father of Berne Bookhamer, Marcia Toledano & Harry. Loving grandfather of Talya, Keren, Michal, Bryant, Devon, Jonathen and Sharone. Service Wednesday, 10:00AM, at Park East Synagogue, 163 East 69th St. For information, Plaza Memorial Chapel: 212-769-4400.

title: Nasdaq Weighs Evening Trading
description: The Nasdaq stock market may extend trading hours to 9 P.M. as early as this summer, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Worthy and a Bargain
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Brains Can Learn New Language Tricks
description: Pity the Japanese tourist asking for directions in New York City: ''Which way to Times Square?''

title: Tailoring Drugs to Fit the Genes
description: The 10 pharmaceutical companies that announced last week they were setting up a genome mapping consortium are hoping to buy a seat at a revolution that may soon start to sweep over their industry. But like all revolutions, the impending advance, known as pharmacogenomics, is unlikely to be bloodless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUBART, FREDA
description: NEUBART-Freda. On April 18, 1999. Beloved sister of Margaret, Julia, Herman, and the late Emil. Cherished aunt and great-aunt. We will greatly miss our beloved ''Auntie Mame.'' Services Tuesday 1:30 at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Dorot Inc. 171 W. 85 St, NYC 10024

title: 2 Who Share a Past Are Rivals for Israel's Future
description: On the wall behind his desk, Ehud Barak, the Labor Party candidate for prime minister, keeps an old photograph of himself dressed in white mechanic's overalls, descending the gangway of a Sabena Airlines jet.

title: A Master of the Trend of the Day, a Slave to None
description: Two of the most coveted spaces in the Parisian museum world are being given over to a 61-year-old English artist whom few people have known quite what to make of. His name is David Hockney.

title: Puritanism and Baseball
description: To the Editor:

title: 2-State Dispute Over Shipping Lines' Lease Clouds Port Authority Future
description: The intense political wrangling to keep two large shipping companies from leaving New York Harbor for Baltimore has opened a larger struggle between New York and New Jersey that threatens to tear apart the Port Authority, the agency created 78 years ago to prevent such squabbling.

title: Karstadt in Talks On Schickedanz Merger
description: Karstadt A.G., Germany's largest department-store operator, said yesterday that it was in talks with Schickedanz Handleswerte G.m.b.H. on a merger of their retail activities under which Karstadt would combine with Schickedanz's Quelle mail-order business, the world's second largest. That would create one of Europe's biggest retail companies, with annual sales of more than 30 billion marks ($16.3 billion). Karstadt's shares surged 33.75 euros, to 399.75 euros ($424.69).

title: Johnson Gets Set for Olympic Encore
description: The remarkable track and field career of Michael Johnson will continue for another two years at least, he said.

title: Metro Business; More Caldor Stores Sold
description: Caldor Corporation, which is going out of business, is selling nine more store sites, including one in New Jersey, for $17.3 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERENBERG, BENJAMIN
description: ERENBERG-Benjamin. Beloved husband and life partner for sixty years of Lillian, devoted father of Elissa Erenberg, & Joel Erenberg, loving grandfather of Marc Barron Erenberg, Robin Hilary, and Michael Marc Erenberg, dear brother of Harry. Tireless worker on behalf of Jewish health, welfare and secular causes. Service 1:30PM, Wednesday, ''GuttermanMusicant'', 402 Park St, Hackensack. Memorial contributions may be directed to the Trauma Education and Injury Prevention Fund at Hackensack University Medical Center, Attention: John Lo Curto, MD, 30 Prospect Ave, Hackensack, NJ 07601 or to Friendly Neighbors, C/O Jewish Community Center on the Palisades, Attention: Debra Turitz, 411 E. Clinton Ave, Tenafly, New Jersey 07670.

title: A Real-World Economist; Krueger And Empiricists Challenge Theorists
description: As he pulled up the charts one after another on his office computer, Alan B. Krueger grew enthusiastic. Children do better all through their schooling, he declared, if by fourth grade they have spent just one year in a class of only 15 students. The tall green bars and rising red lines on Mr. Krueger's charts told the story in simple-to-understand detail. Poor children in particular are helped by early attention from a teacher.

title: Procedure Helps Detect Cancers Of Breast
description: A new procedure for testing the lymph nodes of women with early-stage breast cancer is so promising and is gaining in popularity so rapidly that leaders in the field are concerned that some surgeons may try it without being properly trained. And any errors that result can be fatal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANEKI, ARTHUR
description: MANEKI-Arthur. Age 59. Of NYC. Died April 10 in New York University Hospital. He was a New York State government bank examiner. Survived by brother Raymond and sister Marjorie Determan, both of Honolulu.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELOV, SIDNEY M.
description: SHELOV-Sidney M. The Board of Trustees, alumni/ae and faculty of Bard College mourn the passing of Sidney M. Shelov, trustee, alumnus, and long-time friend of the College. His lasting contributions to Bard include his design of Tewksbury Hall on the Bard College campus. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Faith, his children, and his grandchildren. He will be greatly missed by us all. David E. Schwab II, Chairman Leon Botstein, President

title: For the Very Ill, Steroids Can Offer Hope
description: Experts who study the effects of synthetic anabolic steroids are encouraged, for two distinctly different reasons, that two new trials of their use show a benefit for two groups of very sick people. One reason is the possible long-term benefits for the patients. But the other is that the trials may serve as a reminder of whom the drugs were not intended for: healthy people who use them in ways that can destroy their health.

title: Viacom Bolsters Its Buyback Plan
description: Viacom Inc., the world's fourth-largest entertainment company, raised its stock-buyback plan yesterday to $600 million to include warrants, the latest move by the chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, to help the share price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, LUCILLE
description: JACKSON-Lucille. Dearest friend, you will be sorely missed and certainly long remembered. There will be a memorial Mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89 St, NYC at 2PM on April 30.

title: Hemingway's Wishes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, PAUL
description: Siegel-Paul. Was born June 7, 1912, in Brooklyn, New York and died April 18, 1999 in Boca Raton Florida, surrounded by friends and family. He is survived by his wife, Mrs. Mae Siegel; his son and daughter-in-law, Mr. S. Jay and Joan Siegel; his daughter, Dr. Irene S. Kessler; his grandchildren, Mr. Ted Kessler, Esq., Mr. Michael Kessler, Ms. Ronnie Kessler, Mr. Spencer B. Siegel, Esq., Mr. Mark Siegel and Ms. Heather Siegel and his great-grandchildren Mr. Richard Kessler, Miss Sarah Kessler, Mr. Matthew Kessler and Miss Shana Kessler. He will be greatly missed by all. Mr. Siegel was best known for his successful antique dealership, Paul Siegel Antiques, Inc. which was formerly located at 808 Broadway in Manhattan, New York. The family wishes to acknowledge and thank all of his friends and colleagues who contributed to his life-long success and happiness. Services will be held at 11:00 AM on April 20, 1999, at Temple Beth El in Boca Raton, Florida. The family will welcome friends at 10233 Spyglass Way Boca Raton, Florida following the service.

title: Kosovo's Reality: People Die in War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEINBERG, HAROLD
description: STEINBERG - Harold. Goodbye dear friend and mentor. Karyn Gullen Brown

title: The One Place NATO Could Turn for Help
description: There cannot be security and stability in the world without Russia.

title: Kosovo's Reality: People Die in War
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrities join efforts to persuade people to read more books.

title: Refugees Crossing Kosovo Border Tell of Rapes and Killings
description: Refugees arriving in Macedonia from Kosovo are increasingly reporting rapes and killings by Serbian forces, international observers said today.

title: Arnett in Agreement to End His 18-Year Career at CNN
description: After weeks of steadfastly refusing to comment on the status of Peter Arnett, its onetime leading foreign correspondent, CNN said yesterday that it had reached a financial settlement with Mr. Arnett that would end his 18-year career at CNN.

title: It's a Single for Chebet and a Boston Triple for Roba
description: Joseph Chebet of Kenya enjoyed his trips to the United States, even if he was always second best. He ran second in the 1997 New York City Marathon, second in last year's Boston Marathon, second in last year's New York City Marathon.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, MARCUS
description: MARTIN-Marcus (Marty) April 19, 1999. A passion for his family, friends and love of life was the gift he shared each day. Our dear ''papa'' will be missed by his adoring family; wife Ruth, children Dianne and Jonathan, son and daughterin-law Philip and Cheryl, grandchildren Jared, Caroline, Zachary. Services on Wednesday, April 21, at 10 AM, at Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont. Family will be sitting Shiva Wednesday, Thursday, Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANCUSO, BENEDETTO, J.
description: MANCUSO-Benedetto, J. of New Hyde Park, NY in his eighty-first year on April 19, 1999. Loving father of Margherita Holler, Christina Lyon, Alfred and Regina, cherished grandfather of Joey, Eric and Angelina, dear brother of Connie Contiguglia, proud World War II combat photographer, recipient of numerous medals and citations for his service in the South Pacific, proprietor of Impact Photo Inc., and a member of the New York Press Photographer Association, devoted member of the American Legion Post #

title: VITAL SIGNS: PROGNOSIS; What's Wrong? Ask Patient, Not Doctor
description: Sometimes the doctor doesn't know best. In a study from Purdue University, published this month in the American Sociological Review, researchers suggest that people, particularly African-Americans, may be better predictors of their health than doctors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, FRIEDA
description: COOPER-Frieda (Nee Wekselblatt). On April 17, 1999. One day before her 87th birthday. Devoted wife of the late Benjamin, loving mother of Bob and Sharon Cooper, Ira and Marsha Cooper and Nancy and Paul Lewittes. Dear grandmother and great-grandmother to Joel, Brian and Ruth, Kevin and Robin, Adam, Billy, Andrew, Betsy, Ryan, Matthew and Erin. A ''Woman of Valor'' whose example set the high standard by which we live. Services were held on Monday at The ''Riverside''. In lieu of flowers, donations to the National Chapter of Hadassah would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIBLEY, ELVIRA T.
description: SIBLEY-Elvira T. At her home in Brownfield, Maine, April 16, Elvira Throwbridge Sibley aged 86 years. Beloved widow of Retired Major General Alden K. Sibley who died February 18, 1999. A memorial service for both will be held at 2:30, Saturday, May 1, 1999 at the Brownfield Maine Community Church. For further information: the York Funeral Chapel, Maple Street, Cornish, Maine.

title: Must Medicine Wait for Science?; Paying Young Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: NCO GROUP TO ACQUIRE LOUISIANA COLLECTION AGENCY
description: NCO Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Co-Source Corporation, a provider of commercial-collection services, for $121 million in cash plus stock rights. NCO, based in Fort Washington, Pa., provides accounts-receivable management and other services. It mainly serves the financial-services, health care, retail, commercial, education, telecommunications, utilities and government sectors. It had revenues of $179 million last year. Co-Source's Milliken & Michaels commercial-collection unit, based in Metairie, La., had annual revenue of $57.6 million last year. Besides the $121 million in cash, NCO gave Co-Source the rights to purchase 250,000 of its common shares.

title: A Writer Haunted by Virginia Woolf
description: When Michael Cunningham was a sophomore in high school in Pasadena, Calif., he knew hardly anything about world literature. His cultural life centered around popular music, and he wrote papers about Bob Dylan's lyrics. One day, trying to impress a sophisticated young woman in the senior class, he spoke admiringly about the poetry of Leonard Cohen. As he recalled in a recent interview, ''She took a deep drag of her Marlboro and said, 'Well, yes, but I wonder if you've ever heard of T. S. Eliot or Virginia Woolf.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MINTZER, SYLVIA
description: MINTZER-Sylvia. My Beloved Mother, you are always in my heart. Always missed. Freya

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Foreign Affairs; The Globalution Game
description: A few years ago I was interviewing a dissident Indonesian news editor who was telling me how he managed to get critical things about the corrupt Suharto family into the heavily controlled Indonesian press. He said that when President Suharto's son was being given government subsidies for a wacky idea he had for building an Indonesian car industry, the local press was reluctant to come out openly against this nepotism. What the Indonesian press did instead was wait for the World Trade Organization to bring a case against Suharto's son for unfair trade practices and then splash that on the front pages. The message was, ''Gosh, we would never say anything bad about the President's son, but these folks at the W.T.O. sure think he's up to no good.''

title: Five Men Are Stabbed In a House in Queens
description: Five men were stabbed in a house in Queens last night, the police said.

title: NATO Admits Pilot Bombed 2d Convoy on Kosovo Road
description: NATO acknowledged for the first time today that it had bombed two separate groups of vehicles last week near a Kosovo town, Djakovica, and might have killed civilians.

title: There's Plenty of Choice in a Diet for a Healthier Heart
description: Is your cholesterol level a little too high? Have you been told to de-fat your diet or take costly medicines to bring it down? Eating a la Dr. Dean Ornish (about 10 percent of calories from fat) is too much of a challenge for most people, and many currently healthy people would rather not take cholesterol-lowering medications (all have some side effects) if there are safe, effective and more pleasant options to achieving a desirable cholesterol level and a reduced risk of heart disease.

title: Latest Banana Squabble: Retroactivity of Sanctions
description: The United States received the World Trade Organization's formal approval today to impose $191.4 million in punitive tariffs on European goods in a protracted fight over European banana imports. But the effective date of the sanctions was still in dispute.

title: Kosovo's Reality: People Die in War
description: To the Editor:

title: A Virtuoso Marks Time For Schubert
description: Schubert, like the rest of us, lived his life knowing that time was short and that opportunity had an end. In his last year, 1828, some part of him, conscious or otherwise, must have known that time was even shorter than he had expected. Set in motion by some unexplained process was a creative clock that proceeded to run at extraordinary speed.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Ads and Doctors' Drug Choices: a Link?
description: A team of researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston have found that advertising may influence the choice of hypertension drugs that doctors prescribe for their patients.

title: Correction
description: A chart in Business Day on Friday tracing changes in the makeup of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index misidentified a company that has recently been added. It was Compuware -- not Compuserve, which is a unit of America Online.

title: Hillary Clinton Begins Non-Campaign Swing
description: Presenting herself as a New Yorker in spirit and in politics, Hillary Rodham Clinton began a two-day tour through Manhattan and Long Island yesterday, praising the state's history and culture as she expounded for the first time on why she might want to be a Senator from a place she has never called home.

title: Walter Straley, Executive, 86; School Leader
description: Walter William Straley, who, as an American Telephone and Telegraph vice president for public relations in New York City, was a member of the city's Board of Education in the late 1960's, died in Seattle on Wednesday. Mr. Straley, who was 86, had moved to Seattle with his wife in 1976 and was prominent in civic affairs there.

title: In Plethora Of Planets, New Fields Of Science
description: A major discovery announced last week has given birth to a new field of science, the comparative study of planetary systems.

title: Victory Eludes Knicks; Post-Season May, Too
description: The two of them, Patrick Ewing and Larry Johnson, were standing on corroded legs tonight as they took their places on opposite sides of the free-throw lane.

title: Interpublic Forming A Brand Group
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York is forming an umbrella group named Future Brand to oversee its operations in the fields of corporate and retail brand identity, strategy, design and packaging.

title: Fuzzy Perceptions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GASSMAN, MILDRED
description: GASSMAN-Mildred. The partners and employees of Gassman, Rebhun and Co., P.C. extend our deepest sympathy to Robert S. Gassman, one of our founding partners, on the passing of his mother on April 17, 1999. We extend our deepest to the bereaved family.

title: Judge Bars Curfew Pending Legal Review
description: A state judge yesterday halted enforcement of a curfew for minors in West New York while he decides on the constitutionality of the law.

title: Lilly Profit Increases 12%, But Not With Prozac's Help
description: Eli Lilly & Company said today that its first-quarter profit rose more than 12 percent even as sales declined for its biggest drug, the antidepressant Prozac.

description: PINCUS-Pearl Plesser (Schreiber). A woman of valor. Beloved mother of Zachary and Arlene Plesser, Tully and Michele Plesser; grandmother of Lauren and Paul Haskin, and Stuart Plesser; greatgrandmother of Danielle and Max Haskin. Funeral Tuesday, April 20, at 2:30PM, Boulevard Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Contributions in her memory to Shaare Zedek Hospital in Israel.

title: Marching Off to Other Nations' Wars, Americans Must Tiptoe Around a 1794 Neutrality Law
description: Americans who involve themselves in the Balkan wars, like the ethnic Albanians who have joined the Kosovo rebels, are venturing into a no man's land, legally speaking.

title: Apple Media Software Challenges 2 Rivals
description: In a direct challenge to both the Microsoft Corporation and Real Networks Inc., Apple Computer today introduced a new version of its Quicktime multimedia software designed to permit computer users to receive video and audio programming over the Internet.

title: LVMH Reports Sales Rose 13% in Quarter
description: The French luxury-goods company LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. said yesterday that its sales rose 13 percent in the first quarter of 1999 to 11.5 billion French francs ($1.86 billion). The company, which is seeking to acquire Gucci N.V., said it was confident of meeting growth targets for 1999. Sales rose 18 percent in March.

title: NATO Admits It Hit 2d Convoy in Kosovo
description: NATO acknowledged for the first time that it had bombed two separate groups of vehicles last week near a Kosovo town, Djakovica, and might have killed civilians.

title: Making the Marble Come Alive: Just Let the Daylight Stream In
description: When the architect Kevin Roche went in search of direction for the Metropolitan Museum of Art's new Greek Galleries four years ago, he had luck on his side. A trove of bulletins, meeting minutes, photographs and some of the original McKim, Mead & White drawings for the galleries had recently been unearthed in a tunnel under the museum.

title: Q. & A.
description: Flying Fish

title: Reinventing Compaq: Tasks for Next Chief
description: As the Compaq Computer Corporation begins its search for a new chief executive, it is clear that the prospective leader's first challenge will be to chart a course from the brick-and-mortar retailers that have been the company's lifeblood to the direct-sales model that is increasingly defining the industry's future, analysts and consultants said yesterday.

title: Testing the Smells of Joy and Fear
description: ''If you're happy and you know it, clap your hands,'' goes the song. But if a new study is correct, a better suggestion might be to cover your armpits.

title: Against Virtual Reality, the Spiders Lose
description: So what is it that spiders do besides populating nightmares and hanging around in corners of the house where they have not been invited? Mainly, as Alan Alda learns in tomorrow night's final episode of this season's ''Scientific American Frontiers,'' they busy themselves with weaving their remarkable silky webs, an art they have perfected over the last 400 million years.

title: Results in Turkish Election Reflect Kurdish War's Fault Line
description: Results announced today from the national election on Sunday underlined the gap that separates Kurds living in the impoverished southeast from the rest of Turkey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORN, ERNEST
description: HORN-Ernest. Of Teaneck, NJ on April 18, 1999. Beloved husband of Valerie for sixty years. Devoted father of Lawrence and Richard. Dear brother of the late Dr. Paul Horn. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 402 Park St, Hackensack, on Wednesday, April 21, at 12:30. For information 1-800-522-0588.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISTRETTA, FRANCES V.
description: MISTRETTA-Frances V. Formerly of Murray Hill, died at 2:45PM on April 2, 1999 of complications brought about by a stroke at Good Samaritan Nursing Home's Alzheimer Unit in Jasper, IN, where she had resided since 1996. She was born in Brooklyn on August 10, 1911 to Francesco and Christina (Angelo) Mistretta. Surviving are a sister, Lillian Rubino, of Lakehurst, NJ and several nieces and nephews. She had been a travel agent for over 30 years and had previously worked for the City of New York as an Inspector for the Department of Marine and Aviation. She was a graduate of Adelphi College. She was buried at the family plot in Holy Cross Cemetery in Queens.

title: With Smoked Salmon and Beer, Berlin Greets Parliament
description: With solemnity but little pomp, and with Europe at war in the Balkans, Germany returned its Parliament to the Reichstag today, 66 years after a fire there ushered in Hitler's dictatorship.

title: Safir Defends Frisking Policy Before a Panel of Skeptics
description: At a City Council hearing punctuated by testy exchanges, Police Commissioner Howard Safir provided his most detailed portrait yet of the department's Street Crime Unit yesterday and defended the unit from allegations that it stops people because of their race.

title: Exercise That Gives a Rower Wings
description: Until last summer, my hometown of Louisville, Ky., was better known for horse racing and baseball bats than the genteel sport of sculling. Then, a 35-year-old Louisvillian named Tori Murden set out from the North Carolina coast in a 23-foot boat with the hope of becoming the first woman to row solo across the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, SIDNEY
description: KATZ-Sidney. 92. On April 19. Services Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY today, 11am. His loving sons, Robert, Howard and Alan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Plummets 5.6% As Investors Shift Focus

title: Ex-Officer Gets 8 Years in Race-Tinged Beating at L.I. Nightclub
description: A former New York City police officer was sentenced to up to eight years in prison today for his part in the near-fatal beating of a Long Island man in a racially tinged brawl outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub nearly three years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, SIDNEY
description: KAHN-Sidney. The World Policy Institute, its Board of Advisors, its Senior Fellows, and its staff, and the New School University, note with great sadness the passing of Sidney Kahn. He was a devoted friend of the World Policy Institute, serving as a Trustee of the Institute from 1982 to 1990, and thereafter on the Publishing Board of the World Policy Journal. His contribution to the work of the Institute and the Journal was immeasurable. His loss will be deeply felt by all of us. Our sincerest sympathy is extended to his wife, Elizabeth, and his children, Anne, Jeffrey, Robin and Stephen, and his family.

title: Art Review; Glory Comes Home to the Classics
description: The most spectacular space to be opened in New York City since the renovation of Grand Central Terminal is being unveiled today, and like Grand Central it is also a refurbished landmark: the 140-foot-long neo-classical barrel-vaulted corridor south of the main lobby, or Great Hall, in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Case Has Loss In First Quarter
description: The Case Corporation, the No. 2 United States maker of farm equipment behind Deere & Company, said today that it had a first-quarter loss, as slumping crop prices forced farmers to curb spending on tractors and machinery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINDEN, ERIC A.
description: MINDEN-Eric A. Beloved husband of Molly. Devoted father of Vivian and Monica. Father-in-law of Hans. Cherished grandfather of Janet and Kaethe. Dear brotherin-law of Margot. Services were held Monday, April 19, 1999.

title: Mets Get To Meet The Other N.L. Teams
description: Finally, the Mets will encounter somebody other than the Florida Marlins and the Montreal Expos.

title: Feet Planted in Berkeley, Eyes Fixed on the Sky
description: The uninitiated crack jokes. They mention ''The X-Files'' and little green men. They wonder if he attends alien-abductee conventions. They have a good old time.

title: A Traditional (but Not Early) View of Mozart
description: The early-music movement seems to have passed Colin Davis right by. Perhaps not entirely. The eminent English conductor is too musically curious not to have taken note of what those in the field have had to say about the use of historically appropriate instruments and the Classical-era penchant for light textures and fleet tempos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REPP, ELLEN
description: REPP-Ellen. aged 97 Great of heart, revered voice teacher, exceptional woman and loved by many. Passed away in Mt. Vernon, WA, April 18. Brava, Maestra.

description: BERKOWITZ-Michael. The physicians, nurses and staff of The Cancer Center of Beth Israel and St. Luke's - Roosevelt acknowledge with deep sadness the passing of our dear friend and benefactor, Michael Berkowitz, who touched countless lives through his generous support and, most importantly, the dignity in which he shared with others his valiant battle against cancer. To his wife Lisa, his daugher Alana, his parents, the entire Berkowitz family and all his loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Roy Sessions, M.D., Acting Medical Director Marilyn Halper, Exec. Dir. Paul Stelzer, M.D. Stephen Malamud, M.D. Members of the Medical Staff Karen DeVries, R.N. Rosa Lopez, R.N. Eileen Heron, R.N. Members of the Nursing Staff

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MID-STATE BANCSHARES CO., Arroyo Grande, Calif., a bank holding company, agreed to merge with City Commerce Bank, Santa Barbara, Calif., in a transaction valued at $40 million.

title: Land-Mine Stockpiles
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 EUROPEAN GIANTS SET TO CLOSE DEAL
description: Telecom Italia and Deutsche Telekom, two formerly state-owned telephone giants of Europe, are expected to announce an agreement as early as Tuesday to merge in a deal valued at about $94.5 billion, creating the world's largest telecommunications company.

title: DOMINION WON'T RAISE BID FOR CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS
description: Dominion Resources Inc. said yesterday that it would not top Columbia Energy Group's bid of $9 billion for the Consolidated Natural Gas Company. Dominion, the largest electric utility in Virginia, said its offer, made in February, was better than Columbia's, made on Sunday. The Dominion offer would be tax-free to Consolidated shareholders, it said, unlike Columbia's. CNG has said only that it will review the Columbia offer of $70 a share, divided into $24.50 in stock and $45.50 in cash. Dominion's offer is worth about $60 a share. Columbia shares fell $1.50, to $46.75. Consolidated rose $3.5625, to $56.

title: Letting the Audience Share Private Moments
description: It's not surprising that the low-fidelity recording style in rock, which became popular in the 90's through records by Tom Waits, Pavement, Guided by Voices and others, hasn't traveled far beyond white middle-class Americans. If you subscribe to the sensible theory that rock music transmits much more information than rock lyrics, it's not a stretch to understand that self-consciously scuzzy recordings have social implications, in the same way that a child from a comfortable family who goes to school looking bedraggled on purpose has a social implication. One who grows up with an abundance of options isn't necessarily compelled to keep his songs, or his clothes, clean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, MARY B.
description: KELLY-Mary B. (Nee Murray), of Radburn NJ, entered into eternal rest on April 17, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Horace F. Kelly. Devoted mother of Frank J. Kelly, loving aunt of Cornelius A. Heaney, Jr. Daughter of the late Patrick J. Murray, M.D., former Chief Surgeon of the New York Police Department, Mary F. Murray, and sister of the late Eileen Heaney. Funeral Mass Wednesday 11:00 AM St. Catherine RC Church, Glen Rock, NJ. For information contact Feeney Funeral Home at 201444-7650.

title: Sounds That Touch the Hearer Just by Being There
description: Wednesday evening's concert by the Absolute Ensemble at Merkin Concert Hall opened a useful window on European music of the last 10 years. The program's common theme was supposed to be the influence of rock, but any such parentage could easily have been disputed. Much more evident was the influence of American minimalism, especially on the two works the conductor, Kristjan Jarvi, had summoned from his native Estonia: Erkki-Sven Tuur's ''Architectonics III'' and Lepo Sumera's ''Play for 10.''

title: Allied Pilots Must Rely On Camera And Eyes
description: Peering down at the ground from 15,000 feet or higher, NATO pilots like those who appear to have attacked civilians in Kosovo by mistake last week rely on technology and their own eyesight to identify targets, but ultimately they make judgment calls under trying conditions.

title: French Research Links Sudden Cardiac Death to Heredity
description: French scientists say they have documented that sudden cardiac death, like cardiovascular diseases, may be hereditary.

title: Metro Business; Break for Casino Workers
description: In an effort to keep and attract quality employees in an industry known for its turnover, Showboat Casino-Hotel has become the first of Atlantic City's dozen casinos to open a parking garage for its workers.

title: Admen Throwing and Facing Tough Pitches
description: You might think that Latrell Sprewell, the Knicks guard who is still best known for choking his former coach, P. J. Carlesimo, might not be an alluring pitchman.

title: A Trophy, A Song, Let's Play
description: The 1999 Women's World Cup caravan rolled into Manhattan yesterday and unleashed a whirlwind of announcements exactly two months before the start of the tournament (June 19 at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.) that has everything to do with matters off the field. The sizzle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANCY, MARY VIRGINIA WOOTEN
description: DANCY-Mary Virginia Wooten. On April 17, 1999. Wife of the late Marshall Freeman Dancy. Beloved mother of Marsha Dancy Ambler and Virginia Dancy Webb. Loving grandmother of Michael Nash Ambler, Jr., and Christian Dancy Ambler, and adoring greatgrandmother of Elizabeth, John and Michael. Services will be held Wednesday, April 21, at 4 PM, at St. James' Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street. In lieu of flowers a contribution may be sent to St. James' Church.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO DROPS. The European single currency fell further as the Balkan war threatens to inflate European nations' budget deficits and slow economic growth. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0638, down from $1.0702 Friday.

title: L-3 COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY A SCOTT TECHNOLOGIES UNIT
description: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., a maker of aircraft communications equipment and flight data recorders, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Interstate Electronics Corporation in a deal worth about $60 million. Interstate Electronics, based in Anaheim, Calif., and a unit of Scott Technologies Inc., makes positioning and tracking systems for aircraft and weapons. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed, although L-3 said the deal would include more $10 million worth of real estate. The New York-based L-3 Communications expects the merger to add to its earnings in 1999 after the deal closes, which is expected in the second quarter.

title: By Design; Pockets, Pockets Everywhere
description: Last year cargo pants were all the rage. This year's versions are called utility pants, which include painters' and carpenters' pants and any that have multiple pockets in odd places.

title: Daewoo Plans to Sell Shipyard for $4 Billion
description: Daewoo Group, South Korea's second-biggest business group, said yesterday that it planned to sell its shipbuilding unit for $4.1 billion and focus on making cars. Daewoo's chairman, Kim Woo Chong, said the shipyard, one of the world's largest, would be sold to a Japanese company, possibly the Mitsui Engineering and and Shipbuilding Company. Daewoo will also sell its commercial vehicle business for $927 million.

title: With Gretzky Retired, Leetch Is the Priority
description: The Rangers cleaned out a season's worth of clutter from their lockers today and stuffed their cars with Wayne Gretzky memorabilia. When they return from summer vacation, they don't want to find Brian Leetch's locker empty, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKENNA, PATRICK JOSEPH
description: McKENNA-Patrick Joseph. Of Eastchester. On April 18, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Margaret, loving father of Helen Walsh, Sister Margaret McKenna, RSHM, Joseph McKenna, Fran Locher, Kevin McKenna. Dear brother of Catherine Kennedy, Agatha Musitano, Xavier and Ignatius McKenna. Also survived by nine grandchildren and three great grandchildren. The family will receive friends at the Westchester Funeral Home, Inc., Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Wednesday, April 21, 9:45 AM, Immaculate Conception Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRUYN, LAVERNE LOUER
description: PRUYN-LaVerne Louer. The National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York records with deep regret the death of its distinguished former Board member. Gillette M. Brown, President

title: Giuliani to Propose Some Height Limits On City Skyscrapers
description: Moving to overhaul New York City's zoning laws for the first time in 40 years, the Giuliani administration today will propose the city's first broad limits on the height of skyscrapers. The rules would curtail a longstanding practice that permits developers to build higher buildings in exchange for creating plazas or other public amenities at ground level.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTENFELD, SAUL
description: GERSTENFELD-Saul. The National Jewish Outreach Program mourns the untimely passing on March 31st, 1999 of its special friend and generous supporter, Saul Wayne Gerstenfeld. A devoted Jew and loyal American, Saul dedicated his life to helping others and we will miss him greatly. A memorial service will take place at Cong. Machane Chodosh, 67-29 108th St., Forest Hills, Sunday, May 2, at 10 AM. Yehi Zichro Baruch. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: State Ordered to Adopt Coastal-Protection Rules
description: Six years after passage of a law to regulate coastal development, a judge ordered the State Department of Environmental Protection yesterday to enact the regulations necessary for the law to take effect, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENDMAN, WILLIAM M.
description: Lendman-William M. age 72, died on Friday April 16, 1999. He began a Wall Street career as an unpaid trainee to Phil Carret, President of Pioneer Fund. He grew to become President and CEO of the Wall Street firm Blair & Company. Upon his retirement from Blair he became an independent Financial Consultant. In 1973 he was asked to become an Associate Administrator of the SBA. In 1976 he became President and CEO of POREX Technologies, then he became President and CEO of Glasrock Home Health Care, Inc. In 1984 he founded Lendman Capital Associates, L.P. but was called back to Wall Street in 1985 to become Vice Chairman of Gruntal & Co. Upon his retirement he volunteered for I.E.S.C. to advance stock market growth in countries such as Kenya and Colombia. His remaining years were spent as a private investor. Surviving are his wife Sandy and his daughter and son-in-law Kathy and Jerry Seldin. Funeral services are Tuesday April 20, 1999, 10:30 am, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel in Paramus, NJ.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Volvo Says Profits On Trucks Increased
description: Volvo A.B., the world's second-largest maker of heavy trucks, said yesterday that its first-quarter operating profit, excluding earnings from cars, rose 15 percent from the period a year earlier, as strong demand for trucks more than offset a loss in the bus business. Operating profit rose to 1.215 billion kronor ($146 million) from 1.061 billion in the first quarter of 1998. Net income, including the gain from the sale of the car business to the Ford Motor Company, rose to 27.557 billion kronor from 1.581 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOOP, ROBERT L.
description: KOOP-Robert L. The Board of Directors, Administration, Medical Staff and all the employees of the Trump Pavilion for Nursing and Rehabilitation at the Jamaica Hospital Medical Center note with profound sorrow the passing of our respected First Vice President of the Board of Directors, Robert L. Koop. His dedication, guidance and impossible-to-duplicate energy will never be replaced. Our sincerest condolences to his wonderful and supportive family. William Erhardt, President Gregory R. Bradley, Executive VP

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, DAVID LEE
description: WHITE-David Lee. On April 17, 1999. Of White Plains, New York, formerly of Rye. Beloved husband of Janet (Murch). Devoted father of Kristen M., Lynne J. and the late David L., Jr. Dear brother of Richard B. Also survived by a nephew, Duane S. Biasi, and several nieces. Memorial services will be held at the Rye Presbyterian Church, Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY, Thursday, April 22, 4 PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Rye Presbyterian Church or New York United Hospital Medical Center, Portchester, NY. For information, William H. Graham Funeral Home, 914-967-0129.

title: Decisive Moment on Parkinson's Fetal-Cell Transplants
description: In the 14 years since discovering he has Parkinson's disease, Steve Ashworth has slowly lost control of his muscles. Two years ago, with simple tasks like brushing his teeth becoming next to impossible, he eagerly signed up for a chance to stave off his slide into immobility, the first Government-financed study of brain-cell transplants using tissue from aborted fetuses.

title: Must Medicine Wait for Science?; Choice and Mercy
description: To the Editor:

title: JWGENESIS AGREES TO SELL CLEARING UNIT TO FISERV
description: The JWGenesis Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Clearing Corporation unit to Fiserv Inc. for $58 million. JWGenesis, based in Boca Raton, Fla., provides financial services to individuals, businesses and other brokerage firms. Clearing Corporation performs such tasks as executing trades, maintaining client records and sending out trade confirmations. The sale will allow JWGenesis, formerly known as JW Charles & Company, to concentrate on its main retail-securities and investment-banking businesses. Fiserv, based in Brookfield, Wis., provides data-processing and related services to the financial industry.

title: ACCOLADE IS BOUGHT BY INFOGRAMES ENTERTAINMENT
description: Infogrames Entertainment S.A., Europe's No. 1 maker of video-game software, said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held Accolade Inc. of San Jose, Calif., for $50 million in cash to broaden its product line and increase its sales in the United States. Infogrames, based in Lyons, France, makes the ''Mission: Impossible'' game and has a license to make games based on characters from Time Warner Inc.'s Looney Tunes cartoons.
