Both companies make software for personal computers and for video game systems such as those made by Sony and Nintendo.

title: BellSouth Agrees to Acquire 10% of Qwest
description: Seeking to expand into data communications, the BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 10 percent of Qwest Communications International Inc., the No. 4 long-distance carrier, for about $3.5 billion in cash.

title: Ex-Director Accused of Theft From Head Start
description: The former director of a Head Start program for poor children in East Harlem was charged yesterday with stealing $250,000 from the organization and using some of it to subsidize a film production company run by her son.

title: After 17 Healthy Years, Hope of 'Safe' H.I.V. Dies
description: The ultimate dream of AIDS researchers is to find a nonvirulent strain of H.I.V. and turn it into a safe, effective vaccine. Since the late 1980's, a team of Australian scientists has believed such a strain existed in a small group of people inadvertently infected with H.I.V. through transfusions from one blood donor.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Supreme Court to Decide On Self-Representation
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether people convicted of crimes have a constitutional right to represent themselves on appeal.

title: A Campaign That Involves Quiet Waiting
description: YOU needed nearly all your fingers to count the events that had Hillary Rodham Clinton tearing up and down Manhattan yesterday -- eight of them, and those were just the ones on her public schedule. Heaven knows what she will do if she indeed decides to run for United States Senator from New York. Probably take whirling lessons from a dervish.

title: Authorities Defend Work In Investigating Officer's Death
description: As the latest suspect in the shooting death of an Orange, N.J., police officer was arraigned here today, the Essex County Prosecutor spoke extensively about the investigation for the first time, defending the ''diligence'' of her office's work on the case, which has seen four people taken into custody.

title: Patterns
description: Shades of Anna Sui

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, LUDWIG
description: LIEBERMAN-Ludwig. On April 19, 1999. Survived by his wife, sisterin-law, son and daughter-in-law. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, at ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 114-03 Queens Blvd (76 Rd) Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Abhay Ashtekar; Taste-Testing a Recipe for the Cosmos
description: Dr. Abhay Ashtekar, the leader of a worldwide effort to unify the two most profound, abstract and mathematically baroque theories of physics discovered in this century, is sprinkling frozen mango cubes on scoops of vanilla ice cream.

title: U.S. Not Seeking Extradition in Journalist's Killing in Queens
description: Officials at the United States Justice Department said yesterday that they would not ask the Colombian Government to extradite a prisoner suspected of plotting the 1992 murder of a journalist in Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOPATE, FRANCES
description: LOPATE-Frances. Died Saturday, April 17, 1999, at 6:45 P.M., of a massive heart attack at age 81. Beloved mother, actress, and in all respects a trouper. Born Frances Berlow, orphaned at 11, facing hardships in her Depression youth, she was married young to Albert Lopate and raised four children, while holding a variety of jobs, including factory worker, storekeeper and textile clerk. She never gave up her dreams of show business, and at 50 began performing in cabarets, musicals, movies and TV commercials. She was Mama in the immortal Alka Seltzer ads (''Mama Mia, What a Spicey Meatball'') and a frequent Golda in touring companies of ''Fiddler on the Roof.'' She went back for a college degree in her 60's, taught children with disabilities in her 70's, and performed in a troupe for senior citizens into her 80's. Her indomitable life-force, creativity and will power inspired her four children: Leonard, a talk show host, Phillip, a writer, Bettyann, a nurse, and Joan, a teacher. Good-humored friend and surrogate mom to dozens who crossed her path, she is survived by her four children, her older sisters Gladys and Dorothy and her grandchildren Michael, Stephen and Lily. She will be intolerably missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, SOPHIE
description: HERMAN-Sophie. 92. On April 19, 1999. Loving wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Arthur and Ernest. Dear mother-in-law of Shelby and Linda. Beloved grandmother of Dorothy. Dear sister of Sol and the late Tessie, Eddy and Joe. Services at Garlick's, 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx, NY on Thursday, April 22, at 12 Noon.

title: BLOUNT TO BE BOUGHT BY LEHMAN PARTNERSHIP
description: Blount International Inc., the world's largest maker of tree-harvesting machinery, said yesterday that a Lehman Brothers investment partnership had agreed to acquire it for $1.16 billion in cash and assume $190 million of its debt. Under the agreement, most Blount stockholders will receive $30 a share in cash, although a limited number may hold onto their stock. The partnership, Lehman Brothers Merchant Banking, and Blount's management will end up owning about 90 percent of the company, which is based in Montgomery, Ala. Blount's pre-acquisition shareholders will own the rest. Blount makes timber-harvesting, industrial goods and outdoor sporting equipment. Its class A shares rose 43.75 cents, to $28.125, and the class B shares rose 25 cents, to $27.50.

title: INSIDE
description: Poor Marks for Airlines

title: Taking Aim at Violence in Schools
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Kim Blames Family Firm For Korean Air Fatalities
description: SEOUL  President Kim Dae Jung lashed out Tuesday at the family owners of the nation's flagship airline, Korean Air, blaming them for a series of mishaps and the crash on April 15 of a McDonnell Douglas MD-11 cargo jet in Shanghai.

title: 500 Mourn Teen-Ager Shot by Hartford Officer
description: More than 500 people jammed a funeral parlor yesterday to mourn Aquan Salmon, an unarmed teen-ager who was killed by a Hartford policeman last week.

title: HELLER FINANCIAL AGREES TO $483 MILLION DEAL
description: Heller Financial Inc. said late Monday that it had agreed to buy Healthcare Financial Partners Inc. in a $483 million stock-and-cash deal. Heller, based in Chicago, is a commercial finance company partly owned by Fuji Bank Ltd. of Japan. It has assets of $13.59 billion. Healthcare Financial is a commercial finance company that provides secured financing to small and midsized health care providers. The company, based in Chevy Chase, Md., has assets of $533 million. The offer values Healthcare Financial at $35 a share. Under the agreement, Heller will pay 59 percent in cash and 41 percent in common stock. Heller's stock rose $1.375, to $27.625, and Healthcare Financial jumped 17 percent, gaining $4.8125, to $33.3125.

title: Law of Gravity Applies to Bordeaux Prices
description: FOR the first time in four years, the prices of Bordeaux wines are beginning to fall, in some instances significantly below last year's levels. Among some of the better-known chateaus, Margaux is down 14 percent, Cos d'Estournel 25 percent, Ducru-Beaucaillou 16 percent and Gloria 11 percent.

title: Sports of The Times; Bad Sport, Bad Owners, Bad Hoops
description: DARRYL. Gretzky. Olympic Scandals. The Draft. Piazza Hurt. Darkness Looms for Garden. Zim Sasses Boss.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, HERMAN
description: ROSENBERG-Herman. April 21, 1902-April 1, 1998. Happy Birthday in Heaven! We miss you. Ruth and Carla

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, GEORGE ''GEO''
description: SMITH-George ''Geo''. December 19th, 1945-April 14, 1999. Artist. Activist. Powerful chronicler of the African diaspora experience and imagination. Survived by his mother, Mrs. Florence Smith, his sister, Dottie Thompson, brother, David Smith, nieces, nephews, grand-niece and grand-nephews, and loving, extended family.

title: Big Gains For Public Service
description: The amount of time and space donated to public service campaigns produced by the Advertising Council rose significantly last year from 1997, the council reported yesterday, fueled by large percentage gains in several media categories.

title: Strong Earnings Lift Pharmaceutical Stocks
description: A steep weeklong selloff in pharmaceutical stocks halted yesterday, after three large drug makers reported strong first-quarter earnings and Merck & Company received a recommendation from a Government panel that its new drug for arthritis and acute pain be approved.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The inflation rate is likely to rise this year. But why worry.
description: THE rate of inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, is likely to jump this year, from the exceedingly comfortable 1.6 percent of last year to more than 2 percent.

title: Hillary Clinton Checks Out Suburbs
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton made a campaign-style trip yesterday into the heart of the Long Island suburbs that would be crucial to winning a race for United States Senate, then came back into Manhattan for two more events to finish off a 13-hour day.

title: A Region Pins Hopes To the Backs of Fish
description: WITH a cultural trove containing more than a dozen museums, several amusement parks and professional football and baseball teams, this port city would seem to have more than enough attractions for every visitor.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SUTTER, MEYER
description: SUTTER-Meyer. 2/1/14-4/21/97. Dear father, his love and humor are missed every day. Larry and Bett

title: The Marks of a Good Exhibit? Few Words, Flying Sparks
description: CONSIDER the following: In the middle of Los Angeles, there is a famous hole in the ground. It's full of goo. Thousands of years ago, it was a very, very dangerous place to be. Now it's a really spectacular one, if you think about what you're looking at.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about proposed zoning regulations for New York City omitted the context for a quotation from Donald J. Trump. In saying, ''I think that is one of the most brilliant things I've heard proposed in city zoning,'' he was referring to one aspect -- an increase in the number of parking spaces allowed in large residential developments -- not to the overall proposal.

title: Massacres of '94: Rwanda Seeks Justice in Villages
description: The word gacaca in the Kinyarwanda language spoken here refers to the grass that village elders once sat on as they mediated the disputes of rural life in Rwanda: a cow trampled someone's crops, or bad blood arose between two families.

title: U.S. Urges New Rules to Guard Privacy of Children on Internet
description: The Federal Government proposed new rules today to protect the privacy interests of children on the Internet.

title: Top Executive Becomes Consultant
description: Charles Taney, a longtime top executive at the New York office of Foote, Cone & Belding, a unit of True North Communications, is leaving, the agency said yesterday, to join a consulting company, effective on April 30.

title: Neat Place, but Where's the Cafe, and What's That Smell?
description: IN the same elegant Paris district as the Musee d'Orsay, the Impressionist art museum that was once a railroad terminal, a guide at another museum was standing in front of a display of a stuffed rat the size of a rabbit. ''We don't want to eliminate all the rats,'' she explained in a cheerful French accent, ''because they eat three times their weight in waste.''

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN DROPS. The dollar rose against the Japanese currency after the International Monetary Fund said Japan's economy would not recover this year. The dollar settled in New York at 118.78 yen, up from 117.58 Monday.

title: Chase Posts 61% Rise in Net Earnings
description: Several of the nation's big banks reported sharply higher earnings yesterday, with one of the biggest, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, posting robust trading gains comparable to the outsized results already turned in by most of the country's big trading houses.

title: On Campus; A gift Volvo spotlights questions about the company's involvement in Columbia's environmental education programs.
description: The shiny dark blue Volvo parked on Columbia University's College Walk is attracting attention on campus -- though not in a way that anyone seems to have expected.

title: Culture's Power Houses; The Museum Becomes An Engine of Urban Redesign
description: I want to hold on to the moment after I checked into my hotel in Bilbao, Spain, dropped off my bags in the room and rushed out to walk around the city's new Guggenheim Museum. By chance, I ran into the museum's architect, Frank Gehry, outside the hotel, and he asked if I wanted to go look at the building with him.

title: Romania and Bulgaria Approval Will Allow Campaign to Expand : NATO Gets Right To Use Airspace Bordering Serbia
description: PARIS  Seeking to throw more airpower into the Kosovo campaign, NATO got approval Tuesday from Bulgaria and Romania to use their airspace in an expanded bombing campaign.

title: President's Remarks on Shootings at Colorado School
description: Following are remarks by President Clinton last night at a news conference in Washington about the shootings at a school in Littleton, Colo., as recorded by The New York Times:

title: A Few Thousand Years of Museums, in a Nutshell
description: THE story of the museum as an institution is a story about power, plunder, wacky acquisitiveness and inquisitiveness, the blossoming of a middle class, social posing, romantic notions of democracy and the tension between art and architecture. It wouldn't make a very good movie.

title: After 45 Years, the Forgotten Star Blazes Coolly at Tully Hall
description: Most pianists with talent and ambition yearn to be signed by managers and recording executives who can foster major careers. The Slovenian pianist Dubravka Tomsic, who gave an extraordinary recital at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, could probably have had such a career. But she chose a more modest path, which is why she lacks the renown she deserves.

title: In a World Full of Wonders, Here Are Six That Stand Out -- The Museum for African Art; A Continent Crammed Into 2 Floors
description: GOOD museums offer us sanctioned objects of beauty, power and value. They also offer us private, hopefully less sanctioned encounters with whatever objects we find compelling.

title: Rustic Touch of Tuscany in the East Village
description: THE young couple stood uncertainly in the doorway at I Coppi, an eight-month-old Tuscan restaurant on East Ninth Street near Avenue A. He held a toddler by the hand, she was pushing an infant in a stroller. They had no reservation and the place was full. To the couple, the crowd probably looked like just a lively bunch from the neighborhood.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Extra-Bitter Chocolate

title: Report Finds Power Plants Dirtier in '98
description: Air pollution from 21 aging power plants across New York State rose significantly last year, according to a report released yesterday by several private environmental, health, and consumer groups.

title: In a World Full of Wonders, Here Are Six That Stand Out -- Manhattan District Attorney's Office; A Nostalgic Stroll Down Felony Lane
description: FIRST the metal detectors, then the guards at the door, then the slow elevator ride with witnesses, criminals, police officers, suspects, lawyers, jurors and victims. It's hard to think of a cheerful reason you would be going in the side entrance of the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building -- unless you have come to look at the photographs.

title: Budget Panel Irks Mayor With Proposed Cap on Stadium Subsidies
description: City tax subsidies for stadium projects for the Yankees and Mets should be limited to a maximum of $46.2 million annually, a nonpartisan watchdog group said yesterday.

title: Shoeless in the Kitchen
description: PARTIES catered by Ina Garten of the Barefoot Contessa in East Hampton, N.Y., are characterized by dauntingly lavish, artfully arranged displays of vegetables, breads, fruit, cheeses and cakes. But as her ''Barefoot Contessa Cookbook'' (Clarkson N. Potter, $32.50) now reveals, the food from her shop could not be more accessible.

title: Democrats Seeking Medicare Coverage for Prescription Drugs
description: Democrats in Congress kicked off a major effort today to secure Medicare coverage of prescription drugs, one of the biggest expenses for millions of elderly people.

title: Technology Companies Rebound From Monday's Selloff
description: Shares of technology companies rebounded in heavy trading yesterday after Monday's huge selloff, and investors were seen moving out of economically sensitive cyclical stocks, like industrial and oil companies, which have been rallying for a week or more.

title: In Light of Turkey's Vote, Party Chiefs Are Pressed to Quit
description: Several of Turkey's veteran political leaders are under growing pressure to resign after poor showings in the national election on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, PHILIPP K.
description: STERN-Philipp K. On April 19, 1999 at his home in Lakehurst, NJ. Beloved husband of Sylvia, loving father of Erica Stern of Lakewood, NJ, Leda Walker of Morris, New York, and Sheera Stern of Metuchen, NJ, adoring grandfather of Jeffrey vom Saal, Emily Marvel, Daniel vom Saal and Laura Milanette, Associate Emeritus of The Casualty Actuarial Society. He found great satisfaction in overcoming adversity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHURCH, EDWIN, MD.
description: CHURCH-Edwin, MD. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute and Society express deep sorrow at the loss of an extraordinary colleague and 1964 graduate. Under circumstances, none would choose, Dr. Church modeled resolve and valor in his eleven year confrontation with ALS. During this time he remained as fully engaged in the real world as he could and, by example, exhorted others to carry on life's struggles with courage and tenacity. It falls to us to maintain his profoundly psychoanalytic legacy. May this serve as some comfort to his family, friends, and patients. Marylou Lionells, Ph.D., Director, White Institute Robert I. Watson, Jr., Ph.D., President, White Society

title: Scandal Inquiry Hurts Brazilian Markets
description: Nervousness over a legislative inquiry into reported irregularities during a Government bailout of two banks earlier this year unsettled Brazilian financial markets today, cutting some recent gains.

title: Cable and Wireless Plans To Offer More for I.D.C.
description: An official of Cable and Wireless P.L.C., the British telecommunications concern, said yesterday that it would sweeten its bid to acquire the International Digital Corporation, which recommended last week that shareholders accept an offer from the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation. Cable and Wireless holds a stake of 17.6 percent in I.D.C., a small Japanese provider of international telecommunications services, while N.T.T., Japan's former national telecommunications monopoly, has no equity stake.

title: The Senators No Longer a Surprise
description: This season, the Ottawa Senators did not sneak into the playoffs at the last possible moment, hoping to catch a top-seeded team by surprise in the opening round. Unlike last year -- when they shocked the Devils -- the Senators will not take anyone by surprise when the Stanley Cup tournament begins today. By finishing just 2 points behind the Devils in the Eastern Conference, the Senators are considered legitimate contenders.

title: People
description: * Ruth Wooden, who is leaving as president of the Advertising Council, New York, was named president at the National Parenting Association, New York, effective in July. She succeeds Sylvia Ann Hewlett, who will become chairwoman.

title: Glynwed Sells Metals Unit
description: Glynwed International P.L.C., a British engineering company, reached agreement on Monday to sell its remaining metals activities to the Niagara Corporation, a New York-based company, for $:21.2 million ($34.1 million). Glynwed said the sale reflected its decision to exit from its traditional metals activities to concentrate on the development of its pipe systems and food service equipment operations. The businesses being sold are Glynwed's hot-rolling and bright drawn steel processing activities together with Britain's leading engineering bar distributor, Macreadys.

title: Browser Foes Drop Enmity to Run Start-Up Together
description: For the last few years, Hadi Partovi has been a front-line warrior in the ''browser war'' -- the blood feud between Microsoft and Netscape in the market for Internet browsing software, the focus of the Government's sweeping antitrust case against Microsoft.

title: Summons-Writing Drops 11 Percent in Week
description: In the week since the president of the city's largest police union called on officers to use their discretion before issuing summonses, officers wrote 11 percent fewer tickets for minor violations than they did during the same period last year, according to preliminary Police Department statistics released yesterday.

title: Reuters Quarterly Sales Rose Less Than Expected
description: Reuters Group P.L.C., the big financial information provider, said yesterday that its first-quarter sales growth was only 5 percent, with sales rising to $:771 million, or $1.25 billion, because revenue from its foreign exchange trading systems was lower than had been expected. Analysts had forecast an increase of 6 to 9 percent.In London trading yesterday, shares of Reuters fell 70.5 pence, or 7.5 percent, to 861.5 pence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNINO, DINO
description: SONNINO-Dino. Died in New York City on April 17th, 1999, at the age of 86. Dearly and devotedly loved by his wife Eva and son Edward who survive him, brother of Saverio, Giorgio and Mario, son of Leo and Eloisa, he was born in Rome, Italy, on November 8, 1912, graduated from the University of Rome with a Business Degree in 1935, and moved to New York City in March 1939, becoming an American citizen and joining the United States Army during World War II. An avid mountain climber and skier, he was a ski instructor in the Army's 10th Mountain Division in Colorado before being transferred to the Pacific frontthe Aleutian Islands-in the last year of the war. On April 20, 1946, he married Eva in Rapallo, Italy, and they settled in New York City. In 1951 he acquired a small women's shoe business, Bernardo Sandals, which he turned into a successful high fashion company with his wife as the designer, selling it in 1969. With Eva he returned to Rome for his retirement years which he enjoyed fully, playing golf as well as skiing and hiking in Klosters, Switzerland. The service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest on 5th Ave. & 90th Street, Thursday, April 22, at 1PM.

title: One Moving Part, No Batteries: Who'd Ever Buy It?
description: FOR all the thrill and efficiency of the whirl of a food processor and the hyperbuzz of a spice grinder -- smooth sauces form instantly, spices are reduced to a powder -- they are about as sensual as a vacuum cleaner.

title: About New York; Changing View Of the Writing On the Wall
description: SIRIO GUERINO looked at old photographs of even older buildings whose crumbled facades were covered with graffiti. In real life, the sight of names scrawled on gates and walls in his Bronx neighborhood sends him to the streets with a paintbrush to obliterate the offending tags. But he was looking at art, not life, standing as he was in the Bronx Museum of the Arts. Behind him, aged black books filled with graffiti designs lay in a display case like relics in a chapel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBIN, JOAN
description: ROBBIN-Joan. Joan dear, you were a special part of our lives. We will miss you and your friendship always. Sue and Irv

title: Nabokov As Mounted Specimen; A Centennial Celebration Encases the Writer's Life
description: The novelist, lepidopterist, translator and teacher known as V N, V. Sirin, Vasily Shishkov, Vivian Dark bloom and Vladimir Nabokov would have turned 100 this Friday. The birthday party has begun without him. If he had scripted it himself, he could not have produced a better nightmare.

title: CALENDAR
description: Remembering Patrick Clark

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINSKY, FRANCES
description: KAMINSKY-Frances. Of New York City, April 19, 1999. ''Mother and wife extraordinaire.'' She touched the lives and hearts of all those whom she came in contact with. Services at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam, Wednesday 12:15PM. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Indian photographer Raghubir Singh yesterday misstated his age. He was 56, not 58.

title: Republicans Pledge Billions for the Military
description: Republicans in Congress, charging that President Clinton has weakened the nation's military, pledged today to add billions of dollars for defense to his emergency request for funds to finance NATO's air strikes on Yugoslavia.

title: 2 Cases Test Immunity Of States From Lawsuits
description: The fault lines within the Supreme Court over basic questions of federalism were on full display today as the Justices heard arguments in two cases on whether states can be forced into Federal court to defend their business practices.

title: Technology Can Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, DANIEL
description: BARRY-Daniel. Beloved husband of Ruth and the late Bertha. Devoted father of Stanley and Marilyn, Rosanne and Paul Jones. Loving grandfather and great grandfather of Richard and Jill, Joann and Eric, Mitchell and Pam and Laurie. Graveside services Thursday 11:30AM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York. For further information please call ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 516-764-9400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERENBERG, BENJAMIN
description: ERENBERG-Benjamin. Beloved husband and life partner for sixty years of Lillian, devoted father of Elissa Erenberg, & Joel Erenberg, loving grandfather of Marc Barron Erenberg, Robin Hilary, and Michael Marc Erenberg, dear brother of Harry. Tireless worker on behalf of Jewish health, welfare and secular causes. Service 1:30PM, Wednesday, ''GuttermanMusicant'', 402 Park St, Hackensack. Memorial contributions may be directed to the Trauma Education and Injury Prevention Fund at Hackensack University Medical Center, Attention: John Lo Curto, MD, 30 Prospect Ave, Hackensack, NJ 07601 or to Friendly Neighbors, C/O Jewish Community Center on the Palisades, Attention: Debra Turitz, 411 E. Clinton Ave, Tenafly, New Jersey 07670.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BITTKER, EVELYN BROWN
description: BITTKER-Evelyn Brown, 91. Died April 20, 1999 at her home in Las Vegas. Born in New York City, she spent many years as Head of Reservations at the Grossinger Hotel in Ferndale, N.Y. Several years after her marriage to Arthur Bittker, they bought property in Tucson and started the El Dorado Ranch which had a highly successful run of over twenty years. Arthur and Evelyn then moved to Las Vegas where she has lived for almost over 30 years. Adoring wife of the late Arthur, revered aunt of seven, great aunt of 14, great grandaunt of 29. She will be missed by family and numerous friends alike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELOV, SIDNEY M.
description: SHELOV-Sidney M. The Board and staff of the Salvadori Center mourn the passing of their longterm Board member, Sidney M. Shelov. His sage counsel, expertise and warm friendship will be sorely missed. We extend our sincerest condolences to his family. Dr. Charles H. Thornton, President Dr. Lorraine Whitman, Executive Director

title: Boldness Of Spirit, In a Chicken
description: ROAST chicken is a fallback dish for many cooks -- it's the simple weeknight meal, the main course that almost every dinner guest will eat. But if you don't bother to make a sauce or a dressing, roast chicken can also be boring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, GEORGE
description: ROSS-George. March 1, Palm Beach, FL. Survived by wife, Bette Flamm Ross, and children, John Ross and Susan Gardner Brooks. His career as a producer, publicist and writer included a stint on the NY World-Telegram, a 1944 play, ''Sophie'', WW II USO shows, and as a publicist for many major Broadway shows. Posthumously he will appear on the A&E May 10th ''Barbara Hutton Story.''

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page last Wednesday about a conference at Harvard for gay and lesbian M.B.A. candidates misspelled the surname of a participant from the Columbia Business School. He is Mark Gazdik, not Guzdik.

title: The Impressionists Sure Move the Merchandise
description: SEVEN years ago, after John Curran left Gumps in San Francisco to become vice president of merchandising activities at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he found himself in an elevator heading up to the Trustees' Dining Room. He could not help but overhear a conversation between two blue-haired dowagers.

title: In a Land of Plenty, Twins Teach Simplicity
description: BOLOGNA is a city that lives on its stomach. True, it has Italy's leading university. It fields a pretty good soccer team, too. But Bologna's real study and its true sport is food. Its markets are unrivaled in Europe. The legendary Tamburini food shop is paradise on earth. And then there are the Simili sisters.

title: The Met's Greek Galleries
description: One of the most important traditions in Western culture is the act of restating the centrality of ancient Greek civilization. The images and artistic forms of ancient Greece exude an air of familiarity, which reaffirms our sense of cultural ancestry. But that familiarity is deceptive. What we know about the people depicted in red-figure and black-figure paintings on ancient Greek kraters and amphorae obscures what we do not know about those vessels and the people who used them. The same is true of the funerary sculpture, the marble grave steles that do so much to reinforce our sense of the primacy of the human figure.

title: Microsoft Says Earnings Outdo Expectations
description: Sailing above the price wars that have battered personal computer makers, the Microsoft Corporation reported third-quarter earnings yesterday that exceeded Wall Street's expectations.

title: HOCKEY: PLAYOFF MATCHUPS
description: EASTERN CONFERENCE

title: Phone Giants Say Merger Hinges on Role Of Germany
description: Telecom Italia and Deutsche Telekom tentatively agreed on a merger pact tonight to form the world's largest telecommunications provider, but they said a final deal required assurances that the German Government abdicate its voting rights in the combined company.

title: Lessons of Fruit Flies, From the Finch's Friend
description: TIME, LOVE, MEMORY

title: Operas That Are Not Exactly Grand, but Certainly Succinct
description: Less than an hour's worth of music might seem short measure for an orchestral concert. Yet what the Eos Orchestra presented in some 58 minutes on Thursday evening at the Ethical Culture Society was six complete ''10-minute'' operas, and no one seemed to feel shortchanged.

title: Bonds Joins the Long List Of Stars Who Are Injured
description: Barry Bonds, the pivotal player on the first-place San Francisco Giants, yesterday joined a growing roster of star players who are out of action and on the disabled list.

title: Hairy-Chested History
description: Some say the History Channel ought to be called the War Channel, or perhaps the Murder-and-Mayhem Channel, because of its fondness for programs about war, the military, fighter planes, guns, secret police forces, dastardly crimes and prisons.

title: Charlie Whittingham, 86, California Horse Trainer, Dies
description: Charlie Whittingham, the Hall of Fame horse trainer and the dean of racing on the West Coast for most of the last half-century, died yesterday in Pasadena, Calif. He was 86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, J. WALTER, M.D.
description: KAYE-J. Walter, M.D. Of Saddle River, NJ on April 19, 1999. Beloved husband of Michelle, cherished son of Rachel Kratzenstein and the late Jossef, devoted father of Dr. Peter and Robert. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, Wednesday, 2:15PM. Should friends desire, contributions to Hadassah, 12 Howell Avenue, Hillsdale, NJ 07642 would be appreciated.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Now, Organic Produce With the Morning Paper

title: Will Better Manners Mean a Better Police Force?; Ruling by Poll
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Violent Instant, Routine Gives Way to Panic
description: When he heard the noise in the hall, Adam Foss leaned out of the choir room, the room where the confident singers of Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., rehearse the kinds of songs that student choruses have sung for generations.

title: Science Should Be Done, Not Just Seen, Read or Heard
description: ''HANDS-ON'' has become an important adjective describing the exhibits in science and technology museums. In fact, ''hands-on'' has come to characterize the museums themselves -- and with good reason. Even elementary schools are recognizing that for children to understand science, they have to somehow do science.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARTEN, ISIDORE
description: KARTEN-Isidore. Beloved husband of Julia, devoted father of Berne Bookhamer, Marcia Toledano & Harry. Loving grandfather of Talya, Keren, Michal, Bryant, Devon, Jonathen and Sharone. Service Wednesday, 10:00AM, at Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th St. For information, Plaza Memorial Chapel: 212-769-4400.

title: CARAUSTAR IN $72.5 MILLION DEAL FOR TENNECO BUSINESS
description: Caraustar Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Tenneco Packaging Inc.'s folding carton business for $72.5 million in cash. Caraustar, based in Austell, Ga., which makes recycled paperboard and converted paperboard products, said the acquisition would give it a share of about 4.7 percent of the folding carton market. Caraustar said that including the Tenneco Packaging operations its 1998 sales would have been $284.3 million. The operations being acquired include five folding carton plants and five sales and technical support centers, and had 1998 sales of $106.1 million.

title: In a World Full of Wonders, Here Are Six That Stand Out -- Museum of the Art and History of Judaism; A House of Memories Great and Terrible
description: I have been going to Paris regularly for more than half a century, but still find the city capable of surprise. I was reminded of this recently when I came upon the Museum of the Art and History of Judaism, which opened late last year in a grand town house called the Hotel de Saint-Aignan, in the Marais section.

title: HORSE RACING: Road to The Derby; Menifee, and the Three Men Behind Him
description: Two have traveled from Bob Baffert's richly stocked stable in California, and they are the favorites. Two have traveled from Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum's richly stocked stable on the Persian Gulf, and they are the mystery horses. One is a filly who, against the heaviest of odds, will try to win the Kentucky Derby one week from Saturday against a full and intriguing field of colts.

title: 2 STUDENTS IN COLORADO SCHOOL SAID TO GUN DOWN AS MANY AS 23 AND KILL THEMSELVES IN A SIEGE
description: In the deadliest school massacre in the nation's history, two young men stormed into a suburban high school here at lunch time today with guns and explosives, killing as many as 23 students and teachers and wounding at least 20 in a five-hour siege, the authorities said.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Barber Maps Recovery From His Lost Season
description: Everybody who watched Tiki Barber run the football last season wondered the same thing: what's wrong with him?

title: Reading, Writing and Runny Noses; For Those Without Insurance, School Health Clinics Fill In
description: At Intermediate School 218 in Washington Heights, 12-year-old Billy W. Vargas had severe chest pains one morning during class and could not catch his breath. He was having an asthma attack, a nurse determined.

title: New Zoning Leaves Room For Skyline Of the Future
description: Joseph B. Rose wants to make New York safe for architecture once again.

title: True North takes the lead in aiding agencies and media owned by members of minorities.
description: EFFORTS to increase the consideration given to multicultural consumers are gaining momentum as one of the 10 largest agency companies, True North Communications in Chicago, takes two big steps to embrace media outlets and agencies specializing in advertising aimed at members of minorities.

title: After 16 Years in Prison, Ayala Starts Road Back
description: Tony Ayala Jr. walked out of Bayside State Prison in Leesburg, N.J., yesterday morning under a drizzling sky and declared it a beautiful day. Ayala, a former No. 1 junior-middleweight contender, was released after serving 16 years of a 35-year sentence on a 1983 rape conviction.

title: A Worm Finds a Fallen Star, And Big Adventures Begin
description: With gentle charm, visual beauty and an array of puppets from a tap-dancing spider to an enormous creature that conceals a stage in its belly, Le Theatre de l'Oeil of Montreal tells a story that extends from the glittering heavens to the depths of the sea in ''The Star Keeper.''

title: THERMEDICS TO BUY A GERMAN MEDICAL EQUIPMENT MAKER
description: Thermedics Inc., a diversified high-technology company based in Woburn, Mass., said yesterday that it had signed a nonbinding agreement to acquire Erich Jaeger G.m.b.H., a privately held German company that makes specialty medical equipment, for $42 million, including assumed debt. Thermedics, which makes products ranging from airport screening systems to heart pumps, said the acquisition reflected the company's strategy of refocusing on medical products. Jaeger, based in Hochberg, Germany, makes diagnostic and monitoring equipment used to treat ailments of the heart and lungs, as well as sleep disorders. It had revenues of $41.7 million in 1998.

title: 25 Years of Searching, Unsentimental Atonality
description: Parnassus celebrated its 25th anniversary on Monday night. Anthony Korf's brave band of virtuosos is one of a handful of musical groups that make sure that New Yorkers, in spite of themselves, know what is new and substantial in one small world of composition. Parnassus's relatively long life represents a triumph of endurance. For a small and not easily penetrated school of music to survive in a cultural atmosphere indifferent or downright hostile to its activities has been difficult.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, JOSHUA. DR.
description: ROSS-Joshua. Dr. Joshua Felix Ross died peacefully in his sleep on April 20 at home in Boca Raton, FL. Born in NYC in 1917, he was the beloved husband of Grayce; brother of Raymond; father of Mark, David and Robert; father-inlaw to Roni, Margaret and Donna, and grandfather to Lindsay, Emily, and Colin. He was a gentle, loving, and thoughtful man whose life was devoted to family and friends. His passing will be mourned by all who knew and loved him. Funeral services will be held at Temple Beth El in Boca Raton, Thursday, April 22 at 3PM.

title: A New Studio For Dreamworks
description: Dreamworks SKG said today that it had bought 47 acres of land at the Playa Vista development in southwestern Los Angeles to build a new studio, the first to be built in the city in 60 years.

title: Time Inc. Unit to Buy Family Life Magazine
description: The Parenting Group Inc., a subsidiary of Time Warner's Time Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with Hachette Filipacchi magazines, a unit of Lagardere Group, to purchase Family Life magazine.

title: A New Jerseyan's Mystifying Mission
description: Representative Jim Saxton, a New Jersey Republican, left Yugoslavia today after spending more than two days in Belgrade meeting with high Government officials on an unofficial mission whose purpose remains a mystery to most of official Washington and even to some of his staff.

title: Senor Wences, Ventriloquist Who Was a TV Regular, 103
description: Wenceslao Moreno, who started his career as an unsuccessful bullfighter in Spain and then became Senor Wences, a gifted ventriloquist who was able to transform his thumb and forefinger into a convincing dummy that endeared itself to millions of American television viewers in the 1950's and 60's, died yesterday, his 103d birthday, at his home in Manhattan.

title: Spade's New Cartoon
description: Even NBC has noticed the strength of animation. The network has commissioned its first original prime-time animated series, a skewed take on family comedy, created by one of NBC's stars, David Spade of ''Just Shoot Me.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, SOPHIE
description: HERMAN-Sophie. 92. On April 19, 1999. Loving wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Arthur and Ernest. Dear mother-in-law of Shelby and Linda. Beloved grandmother of Dorothy. Dear sister of Sol and the late Tessie, Eddy and Joe. Services at Garlick's, 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx, NY on Thursday, April 22, at 12 Noon.

title: Will Better Manners Mean a Better Police Force?; More Than Race
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Continues to Balloon, Hitting $19.4 Billion
description: The nation's trade deficit jumped unexpectedly to previously unheard of levels in February as consumers bought growing quantities of imports and declining demand from abroad hurt exporters, the Government reported today.

title: INSIDE
description: Prayers for a Scarred City

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the relationship between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Ehud Barak, a challenger in the election on May 17, misstated the year in which Mr. Barak led the storming of a Sabena jet hijacked by terrorists in Tel Aviv. It was 1972, not 1976. A picture caption misidentified the operation in which Mr. Netanyahu served under Mr. Barak. It was the storming of the jet, not the 1976 Israeli raid to rescue hostages in Entebbe, Uganda.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: LHS PLANS TO BUY PRIORITY CALL FOR $162 MILLION IN STOCK
description: LHS Group Inc., which makes billing systems for telephone companies, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the closely held Priority Call for about $162 million in stock, giving LHS new services to offer its customers. LHS said it would pay 5.2 million shares for Priority Call, based in Wilmington, Mass. Together, the companies had 1998 revenue of about $194 million and have about 1,400 employees. The Atlanta-based LHS said adding Priority Call allowed it to offer services such as prepaid calling, credit and debit card calling and enhanced messaging. Shares in LHS fell 68.75 cents, to $31.25.

title: Liberties; Hoop Nightmares
description: He says he's at the top of his game.

title: Accounting For Mergers May Change
description: The board that sets the nation's accounting rules is expected to vote today for strict limits or even a ban on the use of an accounting method that played a prominent part in many of the largest corporate mergers and acquisitions in recent years.

title: A Divided Kosovo Would Please No One
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton, 'Shocked and Saddened,' Hopes for Prevention
description: A somber President Clinton said tonight that he was ''profoundly shocked and saddened'' by the school shooting in Colorado, and he expressed the hope that the country would, somehow, find ways to prevent future bloodshed.

title: Bonilla Breaks Tie, and His Drought at the Plate
description: John Franco and Bobby Bonilla are the two Mets most likely to be booed -- by their own fans, that is.

title: NATO Missiles Strike a Center Of State-Linked TV and Radio
description: NATO conducted its first air strikes against Serbian television and radio stations early this morning, firing three cruise missiles at a 20-story office building and putting three channels off the air.

title: A Divided Kosovo Would Please No One
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER FALLS. Copper prices declined amid expectations that sluggish growth in Europe would exacerbate a ballooning surplus of the metal. In New York, copper for May delivery dropped 1.75 cents a pound, to 68.65 cents.

title: Radcliffe Packing Up and Going to Harvard
description: After more than 100 years of arm's-length interaction between the his-and-hers institutions at the pinnacle of academic prestige, Radcliffe College has agreed to be fully absorbed into Harvard University, officials announced today.

title: Kosovo Family's Journey From Torment to Torment
description: The moment he crossed into Albania and registered with the police at the shabby border station about 10 miles east of here, Ymer Behrami was given four blankets, a large green tarp and what he believed was a chance for him and his family to leave behind the madness in Kosovo.

title: Restraint as a Euphemism In Psychiatric Hospitals
description: Every year scores of thousands of mentally ill people are confined at one or another of the dozens of hospitals belonging to Charter Behavioral Health Systems, the nation's largest chain of for-profit psychiatric hospitals. About half the patients are children, whose parents will find little comfort in tonight's hourlong report on ''60 Minutes II.'' With the help of an undercover investigator, a hidden camera and some former Charter employees, CBS News has unearthed evidence of deaths and injuries of patients and falsification of records.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PURCELL, ELIZABETH
description: PURCELL - Elizabeth. Former specialized nurse at the New York University Medical Center. Died April 16, 1999. A memorial service will be held Saturday, April 24, 2 PM, at the Mt Kisco Presbyterian Church, Millwood Road, Mt Kisco, New York. (914-666-7001).

title: Calvin Klein's Partner Defines a Long Shot
description: STONEWALL FARM, Westchester: The long-legged foals are nursing. There's a servant in a white jacket in front of the hilltop house, so perfectly turned out in Kentucky horseman style that if he had a metal rod coming out of his back he could be a lawn ornament. When Sheryl Schwartz, the lady of the farm, gets inside a paddock to plant a nice big kiss on one of the foals, the three-inch heels of her chocolate brown Manolo Blahnik lizard boots sink into the dirt.

title: Wave of the Present: Conservation Centers
description: AARON DOUGLAS'S 1930 gouache ''Jungle Dance'' arrived at the Williamstown Art Conservation Center in dire peril, but Leslie Paisley saved it with, of all things, a Teflon spatula and a ginger grater.

title: I.M.F. Warns Global Economy Could Slow This Year and Next
description: The International Monetary Fund warned today that global economic growth could slow in 1999 and perhaps into 2000, hurt by weakness in Russia, Asia, Brazil and some regions of Europe, notably those ravaged by the Kosovo conflict.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDS, VIOLA C.
description: FIELDS-Viola C. On April 18, 1999 in Florida. Predeceased by lifelong friend, Violet A. (''Pat'') Waltenberg, who died on November 17, 1998. Survived by nephews, grand nephews, grand niece, members of the extended Lewis family, members of the extended Waltenberg family, and many, many friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, DAVID LEE
description: WHITE-David Lee. On April 17, 1999. Of White Plains, New York, formerly of Rye. Beloved husband of Janet (Murch). Devoted father of Kristen M., Lynne J. and the late David L., Jr. Dear brother of Richard B. Also survived by a nephew, Duane S. Biasi, and several nieces. Memorial services will be held at the Rye Presbyterian Church, Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY, Thursday, April 22, 4 PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Rye Presbyterian Church or New York United Hospital Medical Center, Portchester, NY. For information, William H. Graham Funeral Home, 914-967-0129.

title: NBC Can't Lose Persistent Fox
description: Fox may not pull off the upset it hoped for this season, beating NBC for the top ratings position among viewers between the ages of 18 and 49, the category that both use to determine which network is really television's leader.

title: Museums Click on to the Web, And the Favor Gets Returned
description: LESS than two years ago, museum sites on line were little more than electronic brochures listing hours, fees, parking restrictions and bare-bones information about exhibits. Now, museums are finding that the Web can have as many uses as they have ideas: as an infinite exhibition space for collections stuck in the basement, for instance, or as a tour guide who lets you get much closer to the artwork than a security guard ever would.

title: Experts Doubt NATO Raids Will Halt Flow of Fuel Soon
description: Even as Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen asserted again today that NATO was succeeding in cutting off the supply of fuel for Yugoslav troops, a growing number of American and European military experts and planners say that goal will not be reached for many months, if at all.

title: SPECIAL TODAY: Museums
description: No longer mere repositories of art and artifacts, museums have become the engines of urban transformation, helping cities from Spain to California to reinvent themselves. With articles on art vs. architecture, the museum expansion boom, the gray eminence of exhibition design, the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame and what's hot in the museum merchandise. SECTION G.

title: Man Is Indicted in 10 Church Fires in Indiana and Georgia, One in Which a Firefighter Died
description: An Indiana drifter with a history of dabbling in satanic rituals was charged in dual Federal indictments yesterday with setting 10 church fires in Indiana and Georgia, including one last year in which a firefighter died.

title: Ewing Whistling in Dark As the Days Dwindle
description: Patrick Ewing's patented stubborn streak used to be born of his unflappable pride. These days, it sounds more like denial.

title: Metro Business; Conrail Faces Suit Over Old Rail Line
description: Conrail Inc. and CSX Corporation face a $150 million lawsuit from Manhattan property owners who claim that the two freight haulers have refused to repair or remove a deteriorated rail line that has been cited by the city as a safety hazard.

title: Business Travel; Passengers to Western Europe may face delays if U.S. troops go to the Balkans in civilian aircraft.
description: ALTHOUGH the Clinton Administration has said it has no plans to send American troops to the Balkans, if in fact it does order large numbers of troops there, many G.I.'s as well as tons of cargo will likely be airlifted on civilian planes. And depending on the duration of the airlift, travelers bound even for Western Europe can probably expect delays and inconvenience.

title: Times Mirror Quarter Profit Rises 7.8%
description: The Times Mirror Company, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, said today that its first-quarter profit rose 7.8 percent on advertising gains, particularly at its Eastern papers.

title: Coca-Cola Enterprises Reports Lackluster Sales
description: Reporting sales that were weaker than expected, Coca-Cola Enterprises, the Coca-Cola Company's largest soft-drink bottler, said yesterday that first-quarter volume rose just 1 percent, one of the smallest increases in years.

title: All Too Often, the Art Itself Gets Lost in the Blueprints
description: PRACTICALLY speaking, Frank Lloyd Wright's Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum was a nightmare of a design, and for pretty much the same reason was a landmark in the history of architecture. Wright, you might say, started a skirmish between art and architecture 40 years ago that has since expanded into war.

title: A Divided Kosovo Would Please No One
description: To the Editor:

title: He Turns the Past Into Stories, and The Galleries Fill Up
description: RALPH APPELBAUM has a lot of projects underway, but none has proved quite as daunting as the World Religions Museum in Taiwan. ''It's unbelievable,'' he said the other day. ''I give my presentation to a monastery in the mountains. Here I am, plugging in my computer as the clouds are going out the door. Do you know what it's like working with Buddhists? Have you ever had a video conference with dharma masters and their nuns? They say there is no past and there is no future; there is only now. And I say, 'What do you mean? We have to plan.' ''

title: Students on the Fringe Found a Way to Stand Out
description: Rendered virtually invisible among the athletes and popular classmates who surrounded them, a small group of students at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., found their way out of anonymity by banding together and dressing in Gothic-style clothing highlighted by long, black coats.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Palladin in New York

title: Monsanto vs. Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGA, JOHN A., COLONEL, U.S. ARMY, RETIRED
description: REGA-John A., Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired. Of Old Tappan, New Jersey, formerly of Silver Spring, MD, and Huntsville, Alabama, on April 2, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Mary G. (nee Palombo). Cherished father of Mary L. Zaks (Arthur), Judith D. D'Ambrosio (Anthony) & Jane L. Rega. Loving grandfather of Joseph M. D'Ambrosio (Trudi), Zosia, Karen and Laura Zaks, & great-grandfather of Anthony Jacob D'Ambrosio. Born in Valle Agricola, Italy, in 1905, Colonel Rega came to this country as a young boy. He entered military service in 1922, serving for thirty years in the U.S. Army. He is a veteran of World War II and the Korean War. He worked for the state of Connecticut, Office of Civil Defense and for NASA at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, AL. A Christian Mass and military burial will be held at Arlington National Cemetery at 12:45 PM, on May 12, 1999. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Colonel Rega's memory to the Arthritis Foundation or the St. Jude's Children Hospital in Memphis, TN.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, SARAH
description: SEGAL-Sarah. On April 20 at the age of 99. Beloved mother of Elaine Heffner, mother-in-law of Richard. Devoted grandmother to Daniel and Andrew Heffner and great grandmother to Alexander, Jeremy & Zachary. Loving sister of Dr. Samuel Dinin. ''Her ways are pleasant ways and all her paths peaceful.'' We love you Mom and thank you for all you gave us. Services on Thursday, 12:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Congregation B'nai Jeshurun would be appreciated.

title: High Seas, Higher Costs; As Imports Swamp Exports, Shipping Lines Try to Cope
description: Come May 1, the ocean-shipping business will be largely deregulated, setting off a scramble among shipping lines to lure customers with discounts. The same day, however, virtually all ships carrying goods from Asia to the United States plan to raise their rates by the same, mutually agreed, amount.

title: Beyond Talent, Fledglings Show They Have Aplomb in a Crisis
description: The show must go on. And indeed it did in a very startling manner on Sunday afternoon at the Joyce Theater.

title: Corrections
description: A theater listing in the events calendar of the Long Island section on Sunday misstated the site of ''An Evening of Comedy With Rabbi Bob Alper,'' this Saturday at 8. It is at Temple Beth El in Huntington, not the synagogue of the same name in Great Neck. Information: (516) 421-5835.

title: McDERMOTT ENDS TALKS TO BUY REST OF J. RAY McDERMOTT
description: McDermott International, a maker of oilfield and power-generation equipment, said yesterday that it had ended discussions to buy the rest of J. Ray McDermott S.A., as the companies could not reach an agreement. McDermott last month offered 1.15 of its shares for each J. Ray McDermott share it did not own, valuing the stake about $375 million at the time. McDermott owns about 63 percent of J. Ray McDermott's stock. Shares of J. Ray McDermott fell $4.0625, to $30.6875, and McDermott fell 68.75 cents, to $29.25. Both are based in New Orleans.

title: Officer Guilty in '96 Killing After a Night of Drinking
description: A Bronx Supreme Court justice found a New York City police officer guilty of second-degree manslaughter yesterday in the off-duty shooting of an Irish immigrant after a night of drinking in 1996.

title: Private School Choice Plan Draws a Million Aid-Seekers
description: A billionaire Wall Street financier who raised $170 million in scholarships to send low-income children to private schools said yesterday that more than a million families had responded to his offer, or nearly one out of every 50 schoolchildren in America.

title: Commercial Real Estate; On 9th Ave., Upgrading Takes Fringe Out of Area
description: The 18-story, 333,000-square-foot office building at 440 Ninth Avenue, at 35th Street, seems typical for its neighborhood, long considered a fringe area on the far West Side of Manhattan. It was put up in 1927, and its neighbors include delicatessens and parking lots, aging restaurants and the local police station. Across Ninth Avenue is an eight-story building owned and occupied by G.H.I., the health insurer; down the block, green-and-white signs lead trucks and commuters to the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: Russia Seeks to Mediate Kosovo Crisis
description: Four weeks after NATO dropped its first bombs on Yugoslavia, Russia -- one of the few countries to have lent a sympathetic ear to Belgrade and turned a blind eye to reports of atrocities in Kosovo -- is now eagerly auditioning for the role of mediator.

title: The Job Description Reads, 'Do It All'
description: ''THE biggest challenge is keeping all the balls in the air,'' said Gary Garrels. ''You're a combination of politician, bureaucrat, therapist and teacher, and hopefully you get to be an intellectual and a connoisseur in the margins.''

title: Reversal Has Some Questioning Attorney General's Motives
description: For the last decade, in countless court hearings and thousands of pages of legal briefs, William H. Buckman and other defense lawyers repeatedly argued that state troopers patrolling the New Jersey Turnpike often used race as the sole basis for stopping and searching black and other minority drivers.

title: China Stole Design Of Atom Warhead, A U.S. Report Finds
description: A comprehensive new analysis by United States intelligence officials has concluded that China stole design information related to America's most advanced nuclear warhead from a Government nuclear weapons laboratory, Government officials say.

title: Fearing Attacks at Border Posts, Refugees Cross Elsewhere
description: For the second day, only a few refugees trickled through official border crossings from Kosovo while thousands more, saying they were fleeing attacks, crossed at other points.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REBHUN, WILLIAM C., DVM
description: REBHUN-William C., DVM. Services were Saturday, March 27, 1999, in Raymertown, NY, for William C. Rebhun, DVM. The professor of internal medicine and ophthalmology at Cornell University's College of Veterinary Medicine died March 24, in Ithaca, NY, at 51 years of age. He was a graduate of Cornell University's College of Agriculture and Life Sciences (1967) and College of Veterinary Medicine (1971). Dr. Rebhun was a diplomate of the American College of Veterinary Ophthalmologists and American College of Veterinary Internal Medicine. He joined the faculty of the College of Veterinary Medicine in 1977 and served as director of its Large Animal Hospital from 1985-88. He received the Presidential Award of the New York State Veterinary Medical Association in 1987. He was a member of the American Veterinary Medical Association, American Society of Veterinary Ophthalmology, American Association of Bovine Practitioners, American College of Veterinary Ophthalmology, American College of Veterinary Internal Medicine, New York State Veterinary Medical Association, and Southern Tier Veterinary Medical Society. He will be remembered by thousands of colleagues, clients, and students as a warm and caring clinician and teacher who touched the lives of many people and animals. He is survived by his wife, Bridget M. Barry, DVM; a son, Robert B. Rebhun; and a daughter, April E. Rebhun. A memorial service is being planned for Saturday, June 19 at Cornell University. Contributions may be made to the William C. Rebhun Memorial Fund, c/o the Office of Public Affairs, Box 39, College of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853-6401

title: Misreading the Enemy
description: Will the war in Kosovo become another Vietnam? After barely a month of bombing Yugoslavia, it is far too soon to make such analogies. Nevertheless, there is a widespread fear that the two sides will be caught in a cycle of escalation, as occurred in Vietnam. As awful as Kosovo is now, the odds of a long-term tragedy will be far greater if we don't apply the lessons the Vietnam conflict taught us.

title: Preservation Chic: Tables With a View of the Past
description: GRAY KUNZ, the four-star chef without portfolio, has generated nearly as much talk about his search for a space for his own restaurant as he did while cooking at Lespinasse. Finally, he is hoping to open in Lever House, the landmark office building on Park Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOTOS, PHILIP
description: ZOTOS-Philip. On April 19, 1999, of Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of Julie. Loving father of Reina Bonocore and Tricia Christiansen. Loving ''Papou'' of five granddaughters. Dear brother of Lillian Demos. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, 2-5 & 7-9 PM, Wednesday. Religious service at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. Paul, Hempstead, at 10 AM, Thursday. Interment Greenfield Cemetery, Hempstead, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TACKABERRY, WILLIAM R.
description: TACKABERRY-William R. Of Madison, NJ on Tuesday, April 20, 1999. Husband of Patricia A. (nee Carroll) Tackaberry. Loving father of William J. Tackaberry and Richard P. Tackaberry, both of Chatham, NJ. William is also survived by four grandchildren. Funeral service will be held on Friday, April 23, 1999 at 10:00 AM at Burroughs, Kohr & Dangler Funeral Home, 106 Main Street, Madison, NJ followed by a Funeral Mass at 11:00 AM at St. Vincent Martyr Church, Green Village Road, Madison. Interment will be at St. Vincent Cemetery. Visiting will be Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: In a World Full of Wonders, Here Are Six That Stand Out -- Brooklyn Botanical Gardens; Over the Subway, the Apricot Blooms
description: I chart the seasons by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. In the winter, the blowsy hellebores hang their heavy heads and I pause to wonder why they are such a craze. They look such a mess to me, like a herd of chartreuse sheep in desperate need of grooming. This is part of the ritual of familiarity, grousing at part of the garden that goes against your grain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORLANS, BERNARD
description: ORLANS-Bernard. On Friday March 26, 1999, in Washington, D.C. Devoted father of Melvin Howard Orlans (Barbara Jackier), loving brother of Sidney Orlans and Mildred Orlans. Loving grandfather of Joshua and Sarah Orlans, and husband of Sarah Munty Orlans.

title: Russians Cling to Deadline To Accept Their Bond Terms
description: Ignoring the protests of several international banks, Russia held foreign investors to a deadline of today for agreeing to a plan that restructures $40 billion in defaulted Government debt at a fraction of its face value.

title: Metro Business; Towns Lagging on Y2K
description: Connecticut is about 80 percent finished with preparations for the Year 2000 computer problem, but some towns and cities might be falling behind, state computer experts said yesterday.

title: In Its Debut, A Big Prize For Freedom Helps Writer
description: The Lannan Foundation of Santa Fe, N.M., announced yesterday that it would give its first $250,000 Prize for Cultural Freedom to the Uruguayan writer Eduardo Galeano. As part of the award, one of the cultural world's largest monetary prizes, the foundation will also donate $100,000 to three charities of Mr. Galeano's choosing.

title: Hong Kong Resuming Sale of Land
description: The Hong Kong government held its first land auction in almost a year today and raised about 20 percent more money than analysts expected.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about the Callery pear trees blooming all over New York City referred incorrectly to the corner shown. It was the northwest corner of 22d Street and Ninth Avenue in Manhattan, not in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn.

title: Quarterly Profit Surges at Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc., the biggest maker of semiconductors used in cellular phones, said today that first-quarter profit surged, fueled by demand for the specialized chips.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: All-Male Sextet In Quiet Rituals

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: All Major Indexes Rebound A Day After a Big Selloff

title: Behind Palazzo Walls, An Exclusive Charm
description: ONCE a year, and only once a year, a strange ritual takes place in a soot-covered 16th-century palazzo in the city's center.

title: Strawberry's Minor Salary
description: Darryl Strawberry is not being paid from his $2.5 million contract with the Yankees while he awaits the outcome of charges that he solicited a prostitute and possessed three-tenths of a gram of cocaine last Wednesday in Tampa, Fla. Strawberry is being paid the nominal amount of his minor league contract, but a baseball official said that the Yankees have frozen the more lucrative payments until Strawberry's status is resolved.

title: With Abundance of Confusion and Few Facts, Nonstop Coverage
description: Network news came on in time to report that the local police chief estimated that 25 people had been killed in a high school in Littleton, Colo., probably by two people in long coats and masks, perhaps members of a group known as the trench coat mafia, who had then killed themselves. The Chief referred to them as ''gentlemen,'' then apologized for his undue politeness.

title: Will Better Manners Mean a Better Police Force?; Community Dialogue
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; For Senator From the Great State of America
description: Hillary Clinton's potential Senate candidacy reached a new plane this week when she and the citizens of the Empire State moved into the same pronoun. ''We have everything in New York that we have in America,'' she said. In some kind of agrarian flashback to her Arkansas days, she added that the New York press corps might be surprised to know the kind of crops that are grown in their state. If this candidacy blossoms, flash cards and spelling tests are sure to follow.

title: Unions Tell Mayor They'll Want More
description: New York City's municipal unions warned Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday that they planned to take a hard line in coming contract negotiations and they called on him to set aside $1 billion a year to pay for future wage increases.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MELLON BANK CORP., Pittsburgh, will split its stock 2 for 1 and increase its dividend 11 percent, to 40 cents from 36 cents. The company has 261.7 million shares outstanding.

title: CITIGROUP TO SPLIT ITS SHARES 3 FOR 2 AND RAISE DIVIDEND
description: Citigroup Inc. said yesterday that it would split its stock 3 for 2 and increase its quarterly dividend 16.6 percent on a post-split basis. The stock split means that a shareholder would receive three shares for every two shares currently owned. As of Dec. 31, Citigroup had 2.3 billion shares outstanding. The New York-based financial services giant said the post-split dividend would be 14 cents a share. The dividend is equivalent to 21 cents on a pre-split basis, up from the 18 cents paid last quarter. Both the split and the dividend are payable on May 28 for shareholders of record as of May 3. Shares of Citigroup rose $2.1875, to $72.8125, yesterday.

title: Envoys Aren't Enemies
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Says Troopers Used Racial Profiling
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and her Attorney General conceded today for the first time that some state troopers singled out black and Hispanic drivers on the highway, and that once they were pulled over, they were more than three times as likely as whites to be subjected to searches.

title: New Low-Fare Airline to Buy Airbus Industrie Jets
description: New Air, a start-up airline that plans to offer low-fare service from Kennedy International Airport in New York beginning early next year, has decided to buy narrow-body jets made by Europe's Airbus Industrie, dealing a blow to the Boeing Corporation's competing 737 jet.

title: Bradley, in First of Issues Talks, Turns to Diallo Shooting and Race
description: Invoking the shooting of Amadou Diallo as evidence of persistent racial discord in America, Bill Bradley said yesterday that he would make the ''quest for racial unity'' a central pillar of his White House if he was elected President. Mr. Bradley called racism the ''defining moral issue of our time'' and pledged to raise the subject regularly as he seeks the Democratic nomination.

title: A Divided Kosovo Would Please No One
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rock Hall of Fame Seeks Its Groove
description: THERE is some argument over the first rock-and-roll song, the first use of the term ''rock-and-roll,'' the site of the first rock-and-roll concert. ''But there is absolutely no dispute about the first rock-and-roll film,'' Terry Stewart said. ''It was 'Blackboard Jungle.' ''

title: Cojimar Journal; The Old Man, at 101, Muses on the Sea and 'Papa'
description: Gregorio Fuentes is 101 years old, but he still welcomes paying visitors to his small living room here to regale them with stories about Ernest Hemingway from a rocking chair.

title: It Takes More Than A Village To Raise A Museum
description: EVERYTHING begins somewhere, and if the Museum of the Mississippi River ever opens, it will have begun with a closing -- more precisely, the closing of five department stores, all within a few months of each other just over a year ago, along a short stretch of Canal Street.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: From Fearful to Amorous

title: A Divided Kosovo Would Please No One
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rite of Spring: Vegetable Ragout
description: UNLIKE asparagus, which some chefs can't resist putting on the menu in August or December, real spring vegetables can be served only for a limited season. Some, like ramps and fresh morels and fiddlehead ferns, are pleasures as fleeting as daffodils in the park, and New York chefs are making the most of them by assembling what amounts to bouquets in a soup plate.

title: SERBS REPORTED TO PUSH ALBANIANS FROM 2D REPUBLIC
description: NATO and Pentagon officials said today that Serbian forces had begun driving ethnic Albanians from Montenegro, signaling a widening of the Balkan conflict.

title: Gun Spree at Columbine High
description: Once again a routine school day was interrupted by blasts of gunfire when two young men clad in masks and long black trench coats began shooting yesterday at fellow students at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo. Their automatic-weapons fire and explosives claimed as many as 25 lives, including their own. It was the largest death toll in an act of terrorism at one of the nation's schools. At least 20 people were taken to local hospitals with gunshot and shrapnel wounds, including one girl who suffered nine shrapnel wounds to the chest.

title: New Holbrooke Inquiry Begins, This Time on Lecture Fees
description: The State Department Inspector General has opened a new investigation of Richard C. Holbrooke, President Clinton's nominee as chief American diplomat to the United Nations, and is examining whether he improperly accepted thousands of dollars for making speeches about the Balkans when he was a special envoy to the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCALL, DAVE AND PENNY
description: McCALL-Dave and Penny. The Board, staff and clients of STRIVE salute our partner, Dave McCall and his wife Penny. They died giving to others as they did to our organization from the time of its founding. We will try to live up to their ideals and will remember them always.

title: BIG FLOWER CONSIDERS SELLING A PORTION OR ALL OF ITSELF
description: Big Flower Holdings Inc., the largest United States printer of advertising inserts, said yesterday that it was considering alternatives, including a possible sale of all or part of the company. Shares of the New York-based Big Flower rose $4.125, or 15 percent, to $32. The total value of the company's stock exceeds $630 million. The company's chairman, Theodore Ammon, left the buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company in 1992 to found Big Flower and buy the advertising-circular printer Treasure Chest Advertising. Since then, the company has snapped up other marketing businesses, tripling its revenue over the last four years to $1.74 billion in 1998.

title: Elite U.S. Force Lands in Albania, to Guard Helicopters
description: Hundreds of paratroopers from the American elite rapid-response force have begun arriving at the scruffy airport here.

title: A Modest Suggestion From Blowout Victim
description: THE Yankees' 4-0 victory over the Texas Rangers at Yankee Stadium last night did not qualify for the 10-run rule that Johnny Oates, the Rangers' manager, talked about before the game. But it might as well have, so dominant was David Cone. The Rangers, with three harmless singles against Cone in eight innings, did not have a chance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HODES, FLORENCE
description: HODES-Florence. On April 20, 1999, aged 96, at Madison, Connecticut. Wife of the late James, mother of Dorothy and Robert, grandmother of the late Anthony Edward and of James, Lisa, Maria Paz, Paul and Peter and greatgrandmother of Ariana and Max. Interment private.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: A Joyous Imp Turns Spider Woman? O.K.

title: Paying for Kosovo
description: The war in Kosovo ought not to be the occasion for budget gamesmanship in Congress. Unhappily, some Republicans are trying to manipulate an emergency spending bill for the war to inflate the Pentagon budget and to lay the groundwork for cuts in domestic programs. Both schemes should be soundly rejected by the House and Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, MARTIN (MARTY)
description: MARCUS-Martin (Marty). April 19, 1999. A passion for his family, friends and love of life was the gift he shared each day. Our dear ''papa'' will be missed by his adoring family; wife Ruth, children Dianne and Jonathan, son and daughterin-law Philip and Cheryl, grandchildren Jared, Caroline, Zachary. Services on Wednesday, April 21, at 10 AM, at Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont. Family will be sitting Shiva Wednesday, Thursday, Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIANA, CAROL YORK
description: DIANA-Carol York. The Board of the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy mourns the loss of a committed member and devoted educator on the Children's Education Committee. We will miss her joyous enthusiasm in sharing her love and knowledge of Central Park with students. Our sincere condolences to her husband, Michael, her children, Elizabeth and Weldon, and her family. Toni Peebler, President Women's Committee Mikel Witte, Chair Children's Education Committee

title: Spaghetti From the Sea
description: THEY are merely baby eels, thin as string, frantic flutterers like tadpoles and so young that their noodlelike bodies are absent of color. In the spring, they pass through tidal areas along the East Coast en route to lake waters. During this fragile stage, predators are a problem, none more so than the chefs who will do anything and pay almost any price -- this year, about $100 a pound -- to get hold of them during their three-week season.

title: The Royal Academy Puts on a New, Fresher Face
description: WHEN the blockbuster ''Monet in the 20th Century'' closed on Sunday, the Royal Academy of Arts had good reason to cheer. With more than 813,000 visitors during a 12-week run, the show was the most popular art exhibition ever held in Britain. No less impressive, with each visitor paying a steep $15 entrance fee and many also buying catalogues, scarves, posters and the like, is that in one fell swoop, Monet -- pronounced money, the quip goes -- lifted the Royal Academy out of the red.

title: In a World Full of Wonders, Here Are Six That Stand Out -- American Museum of Natural History; Base Camp for Travels Through Time
description: GROWING up, I lived far from the country's great museums, and travel restrictions during World War II kept them out of reach. Early memories have me here and there, passing through rooms with glass cases full of Indian arrowheads or with displays of faded antebellum furnishings. I must have been 8 or 9 before I visited what might be considered a proper (though hardly major) museum, in the War Memorial Building in Nashville.

title: The Lost Art of Cooking Oysters
description: SUPERFRESH raw oysters on the half shell with just a spritz of lemon juice are one of life's great gustatory treats. But these plump, briny little creatures are also wonderful cooked with other flavorful ingredients. And the cooking takes only minutes.

title: Allies Seek a Way to Promote Prosperity in Restive Balkans
description: The Western military alliance has begun promoting the idea of a sweeping reconstruction of the Balkans, even as it destroys refineries, bridges, roads and buildings in Yugoslavia.

title: Of Money, Cookie Dough, a Dance and 250 Young Playwrights
description: On a stage set for a high school production of ''Arsenic and Old Lace,'' with bubble-gum-pink walls and floral curtains, three students push aside the props and cluster together downstage, scripts in hand.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHLER, IRA J.
description: HECHLER-Ira J. The Board of Directors, staff and friends of the Hudson Guild note, with deep sorrow, the passing of our generous and devoted friend. Mr. Hechler's commitment to the mission of the Hudson Guild and community empowerment will continue to inspire us long after his passing. He will be greatly missed.

title: Pataki-Giuliani Rift Sows Concern Over Senate Race
description: The tensions between Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani are causing growing concern among Republican officials on Capitol Hill, many of whom want Mr. Giuliani to run for the Senate next year and are worried that the feud will hurt the party's chances of winning the seat, particularly if Hillary Rodham Clinton is the Democratic candidate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MILDRED
