description: KLEIN-Mildred. Devoted wife of the late David. Loving mother of Sheron Rosen. Dear sister of Pauline Platt. Adored grandmother & great grandmother. Services Thursday 1:15 PM at ''Gutterman's'' (Riverside Building), 180 W. 76 St., Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Will Better Manners Mean a Better Police Force?
description: To the Editor:

title: Under One Roof, Prayers for Diallo and a Hug for Giuliani
description: In a two-hour service filled with preaching, prayer and psalms about healing and reconciliation, the most profound statement came from a simple, silent gesture.

title: Lawsuits and Falling Markets Cannot Contain Philip Morris
description: Showing considerable strength despite financial pressure from shrinking demand for cigarettes and the cost of tobacco-related lawsuit settlements, the Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 1.4 percent.

title: Giuliani Plans $157 Million In Tax Cuts
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will propose $157 million in new tax cuts when he unveils his budget plan tomorrow, including a tax credit that would benefit 600,000 low-income families, his aides said yesterday.

title: Visitor Leads An Orchestra To Lyricism And a Bauble
description: Because the New York Chamber Symphony's season is so compact, with only eight programs, most of its performances are conducted by its founder and music director, Gerard Schwarz. But Mr. Schwarz, who also directs the Seattle Symphony, knows better than to keep the podium entirely to himself; it's better for the orchestra to have a different point of view once or twice in a season, and it keeps things lively for the audience as well. So for the penultimate program of the season, on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall, Stanislaw Skrowaczewski took the orchestra's reins. Mr. Schwarz returns to close the season on May 19 and 22.

title: Struggling to Be Noticed in the Big City
description: WHEN Queen Sofia of Spain was in New York last November, she was asked whether she had seen the Jackson Pollock show at the Museum of Modern Art. ''That's the problem with New York,'' she replied. ''There is too much to see.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLANAN, NANCY
description: CALLANAN-Nancy. Suddenly on April 19, 1999. Beloved daughter of Charles and Julia. Cherished sister of Carol, Christopher and Matthew. Loving aunt of Nora and Evan Wolf. Friends may call Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, NYC.

title: Once Unforgettable, Now All But Forgotten
description: BETWEEN the time ''The Dinner Party'' opened at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in 1979, toured worldwide and was finally shown in Australia in 1988, the mixed-media work by Judy Chicago had attracted tens of thousands of viewers and inspired a book, fan mail, hate mail and ardent debate. As late as 1990, Congressmen were denouncing the $2 million installation -- a table with 39 settings representing women of myth or history -- as ''genitalia served up on plates.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, FRANCES
description: BLOOM-Frances. Beloved wife of the late Hyman Bloom. Devoted mother of Robert and Stephen. Loving mother-in-law of Felicia and Dale. Cherished grandmother of Scott and Cindy, Jodie and Mark, Steven, and Joshua; and great-grandmother of Judith Rose. She will be sorely missed, and remain in our hearts forever. Services will be held at Community Synagogue, Rye, NY on Thursday, April 22, at 11:30 AM.

title: Income Higher At 4 Major Telephone Companies
description: Several of the nation's largest phone companies -- the Sprint Corporation, the BellSouth Corporation, the Ameritech Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. -- reported strong gains in first-quarter earnings yesterday as customers bought extra services like voice mail and businesses used more high-profit data services.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: THE CHEF
description: MY favorite part of my job is playing with unusual flavors and coming up with interesting combinations. But sometimes I worry that I have gone too far. This was at first the case with these cornmeal biscotti, flavored with fresh rosemary and orange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULLER, KEMP JR.
description: FULLER-Kemp Jr. Of Bronxville, N.Y. on April 19, 1999. Husband of Barbara C. Fuller, father of Kemp Fuller III, stepson of Mrs. Robert E. Cole. Memorial service at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, on Friday, April 23, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St, Tuckahoe, N.Y. 10707.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about William Welch, the first professor to hold an academic chair devoted to searching for intelligent life beyond Earth, misstated the affiliation of Dr. Frank Drake, a pioneer in the field. He is a professor of astronomy at the University of California at Santa Cruz, not Santa Clara.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is a cultural virus. We have to ask ourselves what kind of children we are raising.''

title: New Unrest Fuels Fears Of Breakup In Indonesia
description: SINGAPORE  Indonesian officials, fearing that violence could sabotage the country's first democratic elections in more than 40 years and strain national unity to the breaking point, appealed for calm Tuesday following the bombing of the country's largest mosque in Jakarta and a retaliatory attack by Muslims on a Roman Catholic church complex in eastern Ujung Pandang.

title: Arizona Finds Cost Savings In Treating Drug Offenders
description: Arizona, the first state to begin treating all its nonviolent drug offenders rather than locking them up, says its new policy of diverting addicts from prison into treatment has already saved the taxpayers money.

title: The Doughnut Hole as Muse, No Irony Intended
description: The blue-gray New England spring light sweeps through the huge paned windows of Emily Eveleth's studio and splashes across the white of her 1000-square-foot studio space, large by Manhattan standards but average for an old industrial building, once a hat factory.

title: The View From the Bridge: A Modernized Diner
description: CALLING a diner Diner is like naming a dog Dog: it seems direct and to the point, and no one can argue with it, but you just know there was laughter when the owners chose such a deadpan name.

title: Cone's Arm Puts Out Fire Of Yankees' 4-Game Skid
description: It rained for most of the day before sunlight peeked briefly over Yankee Stadium, about 90 minutes before last night's first pitch. That was about the time David Cone strolled casually into the clubhouse, looking as if he could take a nap.

title: A Divided Kosovo Would Please No One
description: To the Editor:

title: Burrell Could Be A Bargain For Nets
description: With three productive starts behind him, Nets forward Scott Burrell can afford a laugh over his difficult season.

title: 2 U.S. Auto Makers Delay New Factories in Brazil
description: Citing the pressure from other priorities on his state's finances, an opposition Governor in southern Brazil has disrupted plans by General Motors and the Ford Motor Company to build two car factories regarded as prototypes for automobile manufacturing of the future.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Verse, But Not Terse

title: Confident Devils Want to Avoid Another Eye Opener
description: All it took was a walk through the Devils' dressing room on the first day of practice for the playoffs to sense the change in attitude between this season's team and last season's. This Devils team, with Robbie Ftorek behind the bench instead of Jacques Lemaire, is a more relaxed bunch, far less afraid of making a mistake. And this season's Devils are brimming with confidence and certain that last spring's debacle -- a first-round elimination by the eighth-seeded Ottawa Senators -- will not be repeated.

title: A Different Picture for Ewing
description: Patrick Ewing stood in front of a crowd of children yesterday, joking and easing them out of their nervous shells. He seemed relaxed to be away from the basketball court, talking about his love of painting. Ewing was at F.A.O. Schwarz to promote a book he co-authored with Linda Louis titled ''In the Paint'' (Abbeville Publishing Group).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, MICHAEL
description: BERKOWITZ-Michael. A dear friend and member of the Woodmere Club. Our deepest sympathy to the family. The Woodmere Club

title: In a World Full of Wonders, Here Are Six That Stand Out -- Mount Koya; Peace and Prayers on a Mountain Height
description: EVERY country has its holy mountains, which are objects of devotion and goals of pilgrimage: Mount Athos in Greece, Badrinath in the Indian Himalyas, even Mount Rushmore with its king-size all-American deities lording it over South Dakota.

title: Call Her Professor
description: For eight years, Carol A. Gresser was a force on the New York City Board of Education, serving as president for three years and helping decide the fate of three Schools Chancellors. Last year, Mrs. Gresser lost her seat after years of battling with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: They're Building a Lot More Than Their Collections
description: Asoaring structure, resembling a bird taking flight, is rising on Lake Michigan's shores, where it is soon to be a wing of the Milwaukee Art Museum. The erstwhile Home for Needy Confederate Women in Richmond was just rechristened as the education center of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts. The Old Main Library in San Francisco and an abandoned Nabisco factory in Beacon, N.Y., are about to be converted, respectively, into the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco and a branch of the Dia Center for the Arts.

title: Gaining on Inflation
description: With inflation low and budgets loosening, faculty members at the nation's colleges and universities have received their biggest average pay increase in more than a decade, according to an annual survey by the American Associ 2/3ation of University Professors.

title: Taking 'Laid Back' All the Way Down
description: Just in the first half of the Monday night show at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, there were three old men in Neil Young's lyrics, standing there as symbols of ancient knowledge and the mystery of time. But oldness settled into his set in another way, too: though Mr. Young sang and played in top form and though he is only 53, the show had a strangely geriatric level of energy.

title: Harvesting the Seeds of Technology
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Expulsion Of Kosovars To Be Total, U.S. Says
description: New evidence indicates that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia intends to sweep all of Kosovo and not allow ethnic Albanians to remain even in the province's most sparsely populated areas, the State Department's top authority on atrocities said today.

title: A Writer Finds the Facts Don't Support the Image
description: MORGAN

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STAR TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC., Santa Barbara, Calif., a provider of long-distance services, said it would spin off its European operations into a wholly owned subsidiary to be known as Apollo Communications.

title: LIVENT SAYS 3D-QUARTER LOSS INCREASES TO $46 MILLION
description: Livent Inc., the Toronto-based theater company under bankruptcy protection, said yesterday that its third-quarter loss had increased to $68 million (Canadian), or $46 million (United States), after it wrote down assets and took charges. The loss swelled to $67.98 million (Canadian), or $3.01 share, for the period ended Sept. 30, from $23.8 million, or $1.32, a year earlier. Livent filed for bankruptcy protection in November, three months after new managers discovered what they said was fraud by previous management to inflate the company's earnings. Federal regulators later charged two former Livent executives, Garth H. Drabinsky and Myron I. Gottlieb, with fraud.

title: Why Subsidize the Wrong Kinds of Plants?
description: To the Editor:

title: House Tour, Exhibitions, Flower Show
description: Victorian Brooklyn

title: American Pennies In French Fountains
description: CATHERINE HAMILTON, president of the American Friends of Versailles, has spent 18 months losing sleep in her penthouse, a 10,000-square-foot duplex designed around a collection of 18th-century paneled rooms imported from France.

title: LUCENT GETS $780 MILLION SUPPLY CONTRACT FROM SPRINT
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said it had received a $780 million contract from the Sprint Corporation for equipment and services to expand the Sprint PCS wireless operation. The equipment and services will enable Sprint PCS to expand coverage and increase network capacity, Lucent said. The three-year $780 million contract is in addition to $2.5 billion in contracts between Lucent and Sprint for the first two phases of the Sprint PCS rollout of the digital PCS nationwide wireless network. Lucent shares jumped $4.875 yesterday, to $59.125.

title: Can It Happen Here? Across U.S., Schools Wonder
description: Flags flew at half-staff; moments of prayer silenced the halls; special assemblies gathered. But even more than posting outward signals of distress over the killings in Littleton, Colo., schools around the country turned inward today with an intensity inspired by no previous school mayhem, seeking solace and answers and assurance.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about the NATO bombing of targets in Belgrade early in the day referred incorrectly to the owners of the television station BK, which was knocked off the air. Their family name is Karic. (Braca Karic means Karic Brothers in Serbo-Croatian.)

title: At Munich 'Virtual' Center, Visitors Compete, Too : The Olympic Experience
description: MUNICH  The 1972 Olympics projected a new, go-ahead image of Munich, which it has benefited from ever since. The city has now been chosen to host a permanent, "virtual" Olympics experience, holding out the prospect of a wholesome alternative to the scandal-ridden recent reality of the actual Games.

title: The Theremin: Music at Your Fingertips, or Your Elbows or Knees
description: WE all harbor secret ambitions, and often they're of the exploits we're least likely to be able to achieve. People with tin ears fantasize that they can sing like Caruso or play like Horowitz.

title: Dow Jones Annual Meeting Used as Forum for a Protest
description: Spearheaded by two Wall Street Journal reporters who just won the Pulitzer Prize, about 100 employees told the annual stockholders meeting of Dow Jones & Company yesterday that proposed cuts in pension benefits for more than half of the company's 8,300 employees are sapping loyalty and could provoke a strike.

title: Visit by British Royals Gives Fillip to Seoul
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea  Prince Philip of Britain received the standard tourist's briefing Wednesday as he gazed upon the desolate brown hills of North Korea from a guard post overlooking this truce village in the demilitarized zone that has divided North and South since the Korean War.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: ASEAN Struggles to Change Its Reputation as Weak, Helpless and Divided
description: SINGAPORE  Even as Southeast Asian countries prepare to complete their formal political unity this month with the admission of Cambodia as a member of the Association of South East Asian Nations, officials are calling for new steps to restore the group's credibility.

title: Kevorkian's Disobedience
description: To the Editor:

title: At First Psychedelia, And Later Acid-Rock
description: Between the studio and the stage, Mercury Rev's music switches eras. On its albums since 1990 this band has been thoroughly of the late 1960's, flashing back to an era when bands wandered into the studio and tried whatever instruments, effects and structures came to their wandering minds.

title: Downloading More Speed For a Modem
description: Q. I read that I can upgrade the speed of my modem by downloading software from the Web. How does this work?

title: Good Grades, Good Teams and Some Bad Feelings
description: Columbine High School is like a lot of suburban high schools, proud of its high S.A.T. scores, proud of its winning sports teams. Last Friday the school had a giant pep rally, followed Saturday night by a junior-senior prom. Parents had raised $50,000 for a no-alcohol after-prom party, to keep their children safe.

title: City to Require Taxis To Use E-Z Pass System
description: The city is planning to require all yellow taxis to use the E-Z Pass system, a move that officials said would speed up traffic, reduce air pollution and save passengers money.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE POUND IS LOWER. The British currency declined after minutes from the Bank of England's April meeting suggested that interest rates could fall further. In New York, the pound eased to $1.6064, from $1.6098 on Tuesday.

title: Yoshii Crumbles in 4th As Mets Fall to the Reds
description: The Mets were so convinced that Masato Yoshii was the weak link in their pitching staff during spring training that they were desperately trying to trade him.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the New Jersey Attorney General's report on racial profiling referred incorrectly to a Trenton lawyer who has argued that clients were stopped by the police because of their race. The lawyer, Robin Kay Lord, is a woman.

title: HEALTHEON STRIKES $460 MILLION DEAL FOR MED E AMERICA
description: The Healtheon Corporation, a medical data company, agreed yesterday to acquire the Med E America Corporation for $460 million in stock. Healtheon, in Santa Clara, Calif., is developing ways for medical providers to use the Internet to swap patient data and handle billing. Med E America, in East Meadow, N.Y., provides electronic claims processing, transaction data routing, eligibility, enrollment and data management systems. Under the deal, Healtheon will exchange 0.6593 share for each Med E America share. The price may be adjusted if Healtheon's stock price moves above $63.70 or below $38.68. Yesterday, Healtheon shares rose $1.72, to $47.4375.

title: From Fascist Avenue to a Balcony on Ancient Rome
description: A broad swath of the center of Rome is being dug up on a site that archeologists describe as the largest excavations anywhere and that city officials say will one day become the world's biggest outdoor archeological museum.

title: Small-Scale Choreography For Small-Scale Spaces
description: To the Pointe is an organization dedicated to producing new ballets. Its offerings do not seem intended for grand theaters. Rather, it favors what could be called choreographic chamber music, small-scale creations for intimate spaces. As the program on Friday night at the Church of the Holy Trinity revealed, some of these miniatures can be striking.

title: Hints of Success in Fetal Cell Transplants
description: In the first Government-financed study using tissue from aborted fetuses to treat Parkinson's disease, a team of researchers announced today that they had relieved the symptoms of some patients, a discovery that experts say suggests that scientists are on the verge of being able to repair the damaged brain.

title: ZERO TO THREE
description: www.zerotothree.org

title: Federal Rights Investigation Focuses on 2 Arrests in Killing of an Officer
description: Federal authorities have started an investigation into possible civil rights violations in the arrests of two men during the tangled search for the killer of a police officer in Orange, N.J.

title: Smithsonian Is Set Back On a Museum
description: The Commission on Fine Arts today rejected plans for an American Indian museum on the Mall, dealing a temporary setback to the Smithsonian Institution, which said it would resubmit the plans.

title: 'Revenge' Cited as Motive Of 2 Outcast Students; Experts Check for Bombs : Slayings of 15 at School Shock America
description: WASHINGTON  In the stunned aftermath of the worst school shooting in U.S. history, bomb experts checked lockers, combed through debris and examined parked cars Wednesday in and near the Colorado high school where 15 people were killed Tuesday in a devastating rampage by two young gunmen, who were among the dead.

title: Willi Stoph, 84, Premier, Twice, in East Germany
description: Willi Stoph, a two-time Prime Minister of East Germany, who reluctantly helped reconcile the two Germanys and held office until days before the Berlin wall fell in 1989, died on April 13 in Berlin. He was 84.

title: Corrections
description: A jazz review of the saxophonist Johnny Griffin on Saturday misstated the given name of the bassist who appeared with him at the Village Vanguard. The player was John Webber, not George.

title: European Phone Merger Implications
description: Some details of the deal between Deutsche Telekom and Telecom Italia may remain uncertain, but many executives close to the Global One partnership of Deutsche Telekom, France Telecom and Sprint agree that at least three things with important implications for the future structure of the global communications industry have become clear.

title: Filtering the Wrong Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Earnings Prove Happy Surprise For Wall Street
description: First-quarter earnings reports are pouring in, and they are pleasing. Citigroup beat Wall Street estimates by 16 percent. I.B.M. had a robust quarter. Boeing pleasantly surprised. International Paper's earnings fell less than expected while its executives pointed to rising paper prices and returning demand in Asia.

title: Accounting Official Leaving Deutsche Bank
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., Europe's largest bank, said today that Jurgen Krumnow, the board member responsible for accounting, would leave at the end of this year, earlier than planned, to take up other business opportunities.

title: Community College Offers A Nest for Digital Ventures
description: A community college in Manhattan is teaming up with some big-name investors to create a business incubator for emerging companies in digital television and other digital media.

title: Pataki and Giuliani Agree on Housing for the Mentally Ill
description: Ending a protracted dispute, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced today that they had reached a compromise on expanding a landmark program for housing mentally ill homeless people in New York City.

title: Female Prisoners, From Salem to Rikers
description: In the first scene of Theodora Skipitares's ''Body of Crime II,'' a priest is castrated in front of the audience. Later a woman is hanged. And in one scene, half a dozen women accused of witchcraft are tied to a giant wooden wheel and spun faster and faster. There is one woman -- she looks like a girl, really -- whose arms flop back and forth as the wheel spins. The audience can't be sure if she has died or only passed out from the torture.

title: Impressive Throne Unearthed At a Mayan Temple Complex
description: In rain forests at the foot of the Yucatan Peninsula, Mexican and American archeologists have uncovered a monumental art work that appears to be one of the most revealing artifacts that has been found from the resplendent but mysterious final years of ancient Mayan civilization.

title: Can New Generation Claim 'Normal ' Identity?: The Heavy Burden of History
description: FRANKFURT  It might not be easy for an outsider to understand why a nation occupies itself again and again with the question whether it is "normal" and whether its "normality" is allowed. But in Germany the concept of normality has been the focus for all debates on the country's history in this century and on the political and moral consequences of that history for the present.

title: What Good Old Ernie Required Was Vision
description: ERNIE GRUNFELD was a plumber hired to do an architect's job. And when he could not fix the leaks, he lost his job.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR PLUNGES. Sugar prices plummeted on expectations that surging output from Brazil will overwhelm demand from buyers in Russia and Asia. In New York, sugar for July delivery fell 0.23 cent, to 4.52 cents a pound.

title: Kosovo Shows the Need for a United Nations Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Attacker Slashes Youth On Face in Subway Train
description: A 16-year-old boy was slashed in the face yesterday afternoon by a stranger on a subway train in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Despite Yeltsin, Prosecutor Investigating Kremlin Retains Post
description: The upper house of Parliament rejected both lobbying and a personal plea from President Boris N. Yeltsin today and voted lopsidedly, for the second time, to retain a prosecutor investigating corruption at the heart of the Kremlin.

title: Elizabeth Tilberis, 51, Magazine Editor, Dies
description: Elizabeth Tilberis, the editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, who transformed it from a tired magazine into a viable voice in fashion while she battled ovarian cancer and raised awareness of the disease, died yesterday morning at Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 51 and had homes in Manhattan and East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Kosovo Shows the Need for a United Nations Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Next-Generation Game Player Is on the Way From Sega
description: In the video-game universe, most of the hottest action has migrated from consoles to CD-ROM's in recent years. No more, promises Sega of America, an arm of Sega Enterprises, based in Tokyo. On Sept. 9 the company will release in

title: Violence by Youths: Looking for Answers
description: The fact that the worst school shooting in modern times happened in one of those places where Americans tend to move because they are seeking good schools -- in this case, Jefferson County, Colo., one of the fastest-growing areas in the nation -- came as no surprise to Suzanne Wilson.

title: REAL SOFTWARE OFFERS TAVA TECHNOLOGIES $190 MILLION
description: Real Software N.V. of Belgium offered yesterday to acquire Tava Technologies of Denver for $8 a share, or $190 million. The deal would increase Real Software sales in the United States to more than 40 percent of total sales, from 21 percent, by the end of the year. Tava management would reinvest 50 percent of the sale proceeds. The managers' stake would drop to 4 percent from 8 percent. Real Software and its more than 20 subsidiary operations provide information technology services to clients in Europe, Asia and the United States. Tava shares surged 16 percent, gaining $1 to close at $6.9375.

title: Father of Victim Says Son Had Dispute With Suspect
description: The father of a victim in the Colorado shooting said yesterday that his son had ''had a conflict'' with the presumed gunmen last year and believed that his son was a target of the rampage at Columbine High School.

title: Tidbits That Survived Editing
description: The hum in publishing is a book about itself, written by Michael Korda, who is editor in chief at Simon & Schuster and with this book is also sort of the minstrel of the business. At any rate the anecdotes of his publishing reminiscence, amusing, often wry and exhilaratingly frank, are being talked about and laughed over wherever those in the industry gather and someone in the crowd has actually read the page proofs and is sharing favorite stories.

title: D'Amato Joins Firm Known For Lobbying
description: Former United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said today that he had joined a prominent law firm that is one of the top lobbying firms in Albany.

title: Mary C. Rockefeller, Governor's Former Wife, Dead at 91
description: Mary Clark Rockefeller, who was prominent in the education of nurses and was New York State's First Lady when she was married to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, died yesterday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 91.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Jury Decides Hospitalized Killer In Cannibalism Case Can Go Free
description: A Suffolk County jury decided yesterday that Albert Fentress, a former school teacher who has spent the last 20 years in psychiatric hospitals after the torture, killing and cannibalization of a Poughkeepsie teen-ager, is no longer a danger to society and should go free.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: With Fanfare, First Attack Copters Arrive but Active Role Is Days Away
description: The first of the long-awaited American Apache attack helicopters touched down here this evening in a frenzy of media attention and Army vows to transform NATO's thus far ineffective campaign to halt Serbian attacks against Albanians in Kosovo.

title: Patients Are Victims of the Politics of Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: North Sea Gas Sale
description: The British oil company Lasmo P.L.C. said today that it had sold some of its southern North Sea gas assets to GDF Britain, a subsidiary of Gaz de France, for $:90.2 million, or about $145.3 million, in cash. The company said it expected to make a profit of $:14 million, about $22.5 million, on the sale and would use the proceeds to reduce debt and to invest in the company's key locations in Venezuela, Pakistan and Algeria. Gaz de France is a French state-owned gas company.

title: A Convergence of French And American Accents
description: The young California-born baritone Rodney Gilfry is best known for creating the role of Stanley Kowalski in Andre Previn's operatic version of ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' last year, a San Francisco Opera production that was broadcast on public television. He was a hunky and volatile Stanley. Vocally, however, the underwritten role did not serve to reveal the range of Mr. Gilfry's gifts.

title: Revisiting Outrageous In the Twilight Of Outrage
description: They don't make leaders like they used to. When ''That Championship Season'' had its stirring debut at the Public Theater in the spring of 1972, Americans had not yet been forced to confront the traumatizing moral questions that would forever change the nation's perceptions about leadership. The resignation of Richard M. Nixon was still in the future, not to mention Ronald Reagan's Iran-contra scandal and Bill Clinton's impeachment trial.

title: Honors for Jerkens, The Giant Killer
description: Not many trainers are greeted on their birthdays by having a race named in their honor, and none in memory has been toasted by having every race on a track's program named for them or their horses. But when Allen Jerkens turned 70 yesterday, Aqueduct race track honored him by naming all nine races for celebrated horses that he trained, including some who pulled major upsets.

title: New Drought Cuts Into Livestock in Texas
description: On the J. E. White & Sons Brite Ranch in far West Texas, the breeding stock is typically considered sacred, their future secure long after other parts of the herd have been sent to market.

title: Duke Energy Ends Chile Company Bid
description: The Duke Energy Corporation withdrew its $2.8 billion offer for Chile's biggest energy generator today, conceding defeat to the rival Endesa S.A. of Spain.

title: Sunbeam Reports Losses Of $898 Million in 1998
description: The Sunbeam Corporation, still struggling with the effects of excessive inventories and heavy debt, turned in another round of dismal financial results yesterday, including an $898 million loss for 1998.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Tokyo Journal; A Tojo Battles History, for Grandpa and for Japan
description: Yuko Tojo stiffens in her chair as she recalls how her beloved Grandpa vanished at the end of World War II and her mother eventually told her that he had been killed on the battlefield.

title: Kosovo Shows the Need for a United Nations Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Turnpike Drivers Are Skeptical of Quick Reform
description: Jacques Alexandre has been stopped only once by state troopers on the New Jersey Turnpike, but the experience was enough to make him doubt promises of change that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and law enforcement officials made on Tuesday.

title: A Landmark of the 60's Defies Transformation
description: On days when the sun looks kindly on it, People's Park can seem like a quaint little town.

title: Designing In the Smile
description: IT came as a disappointment to the executives of Lufthansa when marketing surveys showed that the German airline was respected for its fine record of safety and punctuality, but not liked. Specifically, customers noted that the airline's flight attendants rarely smiled.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on March 31 about ''Encounter in the Third Dimension,'' at the Sony Imax Theater in Manhattan, misstated the brand of the film's giant-screen format. It is Iwerks, not Imax.

title: Gore Says U.S. Will Open Door to 20,000 Kosovars
description: The United States is offering to bring 20,000 Kosovar refugees to the American mainland for temporary placement with families, Vice President Al Gore announced yesterday. The offer represents a new policy, and formal abandonment of the much-criticized earlier proposal to relocate thousands of the refugees to the naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Coca-Cola Posts 13% Drop In First-Quarter Net Income
description: Continuing a recent pattern of weak results, the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its first-quarter net income fell 13 percent as the company struggled to expand its business.

title: Sol LeWitt Throws Curves Into a Bastion of the 30's; Christie's Brings a New Mural to Rockefeller Center
description: Soaring three stories inside the entrance to 20 Rockefeller Plaza is a mural by the Conceptual artist Sol LeWitt, its colors so intense and its surface so glossy that it still looks wet.

title: RYDER SYSTEM MAY NEED TO SELL SOME ASSETS, CHIEF SAYS
description: M. Anthony Burns, chief executive of Ryder System Inc., said yesterday that the company was exploring ways to improve profitability, which might include the sale of assets. ''We may need to sell some assets and free up equity,'' he said. He said the company, which is involved in truck leasing and rental as well as integrated logistics, was speaking with investment bankers but declined to name them. ''We have talked to a couple of firms about ways in which we can make the company less cyclical, less asset-intensive and grow the business through acquisitions,'' Mr. Burns said. He said investment bankers were advising Ryder about the valuation of its stock and whether it needed to divest itself of parts of its three business units.

title: 15 Bodies Are Removed From School in Colorado
description: After a long day of agony for victims' parents and anxiety for police officers searching for explosives, the authorities this evening removed the bodies of 15 people killed in a massacre at Columbine High School on Tuesday.

title: Time In a Bottle; As the Millennium Approaches, Gadgets Are Piled Into Capsules As a Present for the Future
description: IT'S time capsule time. As the new century approaches, instant archeology is being created by civic groups, schools, churches, businesses and a surprising number of families and individuals who have chosen to encapsulate the present for the presumed benefit of the future.

title: Doubleheader Set for June 19
description: The June 19 heavyweight doubleheader at the Theater at Madison Square Garden appears to be set. Michael Grant and Lou Savarese will fight in the main event, and Hasim Rahman and Jeremy Williams will be the co-featured bout.

title: In Politics, A Hug Isn't Just a Hug
description: From last month's acts of civil disobedience to last week's march across the Brooklyn Bridge, symbolic moments and gestures have punctuated the public debate over the fatal police shooting of an unarmed black immigrant two months ago. And the latest in these image-rich moments, a prayer service at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Tuesday, carried symbols within symbols.

title: Panel Talks Of Air War And Echoes Of Vietnam
description: Congressional Republicans raised the specter of the Vietnam War today at a hearing on President Clinton's emergency request for more than $5 billion in military funds for NATO's air campaign against Serbian forces.

title: Germans Perform Army, Navy and Air Missions in Balkans : Dealing Again With War
description: WHEN Germany went to war again last month, for the first time in over half a century, the German armed forces assumed a full role in the NATO campaign, including to the surprise of many observers  missions for all three services, army, navy and air force.

title: Public Plazas That Turn the Public Off
description: It would be hard to design a chillier, more unwelcoming public plaza than that of the Grace Building, at 43d Street and Avenue of the Americas. It has a long, wide expanse of pale limestone, with dark rectangles that echo the skyscraper's dark walls looming above. A narrow stone bench runs along the edge of the building from steps to revolving doors.

title: Hungary's Precarious Perch
description: Hungary, one of NATO's three new members, is a reliable provider of support to the alliance in its strange war with Yugoslavia, as an ally should be. Except for a tiny coalition of West-hating orthodox Communists and far-right xenophobes, the public supports NATO's humanitarian and democratic objective: stopping Slobodan Milosevic's ethnic cleansing. But the West must take into account Hungary's unique and precarious situation before encumbering its loyalty with roles the country cannot take on.

title: NATO Confronts a New Role: Regional Policeman
description: As heads of NATO countries began arriving here today for the 50th anniversary of the alliance, they were embarking on a summit meeting transformed from a celebration of triumph to a war council on the Balkans.

title: In the Desert, Grass Bricks and Pedestrian Ways
description: Isn't Arizona the land of superrefrigerated suburban sprawl? Last week, Tucson became home to Civano, a 1,200-acre development built with new materials and techniques. Civano uses ecological buzzwords like sustainable resources, conservation, pedestrian-friendliness and emerging technology. The developers also envision an ''environmentally sensitive 18-hole golf course.''

title: Kosovo Shows the Need for a United Nations Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Scholarship Winners Gather in Celebration
description: A few months ago, Sandy Lombardo saw a full-page newspaper ad for a scholarship that promised to send his child to the private school of his choice. Driven by his dissatisfaction with the local public schools and a yearning for a better life outside the neighborhood, Mr. Lombardo filled out the application, mailed it off and forgot about it.

title: Giuliani Altering School Voucher Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's spending plan for the coming fiscal year still includes $12 million for a school voucher program, despite intense opposition from Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and the City Council, city officials said yesterday.

title: Jagr Is on Their Mind As Wary Devils Prepare
description: The Devils worked hard and then had some fun this morning toward the end of their practice to prepare for the playoff series beginning at home against the Penguins on Thursday night. As in the last two years, the Devils will be going into the Stanley Cup playoffs as the top-seeded team in their conference, meeting the eighth-seeded team.

title: Headstrong, Abrasive And on the Rise; Torricelli's Growing Stature Defies His Ability to Irritate Even His Allies
description: To the uninitiated, it might seem odd that Senator Robert G. Torricelli, one of President Clinton's strongest defenders throughout the Monica Lewinsky scandal, should become one of the harshest critics of the President's Kosovo policy this month.

title: Starwood President Resigns After a Bumpy Year
description: Richard D. Nanula, president and chief operating officer of Starwood Hotels and Resorts Inc., resigned yesterday, just over a year after he was chosen by his friend, Barry S. Sternlicht, Starwood's chairman and chief executive, to help run the world's largest hotel company.

title: Belfast Team Travels Hard Road to Relays
description: When the St. Malachy's boys of Belfast, Northern Ireland, compete tomorrow in the high school distance medley at the 105th Penn Relays in Philadelphia, they will not only seek to become the first squad in 47 years to capture three straight titles but also to do something considered dangerous at home: run in their team uniforms.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Study Finds Big Jump in Computer-Related Employment
description: Without a lot of hype -- or government help -- the computer-software industry has been booming in New York City, where the number of jobs at software firms more than doubled from 1992 to 1997, according to a report released yesterday by Alan G. Hevesi, the City Comptroller.

title: Where No Car Has Gone Before
description: Edward Grinberg, a French architect and urbanist, asked, ''Would you park your piano on the street?'' The question makes sense when it becomes clear that Mr. Grinberg thinks cars are like pianos. He came up with his Domobile System (above), an idea for storing tiny electric cars compactly. The trick is that his notional cars come apart and can be stacked at rental machines called Domomats. Or they can be hoisted and locked into the wall of a building.

title: Exxon Reports 40% Drop in Earnings
description: The Exxon Corporation reported a 40 percent decline in first-quarter earnings yesterday, as crude oil prices and gasoline profit margins remained at historically low levels in January and February.

title: Navistar Awards Fallon an Account
description: The Navistar International Corporation in Chicago has awarded its branding account to Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: PC vs. iMac: The Grass Is Always Greener Across the Divide
description: I'M conflicted. The iMac is a sensation, with more than a million units sold since its release last August. And like a lot of former Mac users who had made the switch to a Windows 98 PC, I have found myself drawn, even taunted by the iMac's cool esthetic. It has conjured up that old Apple magic for me, that self-righteous promise of a better-built mousetrap that not only compelled me to use Apple computers once but also prompted me to move west and go to work for the company.

title: Report Warns Of Big Gains To Chinese From Spying
description: China is likely to use stolen advanced American nuclear weapons secrets to upgrade its weapons within years, not decades, a senior intelligence official said today.

title: Compaq Reports Earnings Of 16 cents a Share for Quarter
description: Confirming the bad news that led to the ouster of its chief executive this week, the Compaq Computer Corporation announced yesterday that it earned $281 million in the first quarter, or 16 cents a share, half of what analysts had expected only two weeks ago.

title: Appeal Unlikely in Clinton Contempt Case
description: President Clinton has all but decided not to appeal a civil contempt of court ruling for what a Federal judge called intentional false testimony in the Paula Jones lawsuit, senior Clinton advisers say.

title: Essay; Celebrating Defeat
description: Manhole covers are being sealed and sharpshooters are preparing to patrol rooftops as this capital braces for the biggest turnout of world leaders since the Kennedy funeral.

title: Rising Crime in Argentina Fuels a Listless Presidential Campaign
description: Crime is emerging as a major political issue for the first time in the big cities of Argentina, a country where people have traditionally stayed out well past midnight to hop from cafes to tango clubs without any fear.

title: Libraries Enter Digital Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Unemployment's natural rate may have a mind of its own.
description: ECONOMISTS are compulsive naysayers -- professionally dedicated to tweaking anyone naive enough to overlook the fact that good things have a cost and not all good things are affordable or possible. This spinach-eating mentality partly explains why they failed to predict the relentless good news in the 1990's, during which the growth rate of productivity rose and unemployment and inflation rates fell by half.

title: The Mouse That Wove
description: People like cute. Cute things are small, fuzzy versions of familiar objects, and they have cute names. Mouse Rugs are velvety Lexan mouse pads, which mimick Pendleton blankets, which mimick American Indian rugs. The company also reproduces Oriental rugs from museums. The 7-by-10-inch rugs ($24.95) are available by phone at (800) 896-2314), in museum shops, at the Store of Knowledge and from www.mouserug.com. Yes, they're fringed.

title: GLOBAL INDUSTRIAL IN TALKS WITH UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY
description: Global Industrial Technologies Inc., which makes industrial products for metal producers, is discussing a possible merger with an undisclosed company. Global, which also reported a 1998 loss from continuing operations of $6.5 million, or 30 cents a share, said the talks were in preliminary stages. The Dallas-based company asked its financial advisers last month to help evaluate ways to raise its stock price. In December, the WHX Corporation, a steelmaker, made a hostile bid of $10.50 a share for the 90.1 percent of Global that it does not already own. WHX said 41 percent of Global's outstanding shares had been tendered as of last Friday. Shares of Global rose $1.375 yesterday, to $12.25, giving the company a market value of $270 million.

title: Knicks Are Not Surprised by Grunfeld's Job Loss
description: One by one, the Knicks emerged from one entrance of the locker room, while near the other entrance, Dave Checketts's long, black limousine sat parked like a vision of a grim reaper.

title: G.O.P. Senators Rally to Giuliani Candidacy
description: Facing a possible challenge to his probable bid for the Republican nomination for the Senate in New York, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani came here today to a display of Republican support by senators, who proclaimed Mr. Giuliani the strongest candidate the party could field in the 2000 race.

title: Robot Olympics? Live on the Net
description: Will robots one day rule the world? Probably not, but they may have taken over recess for a day. On Friday and Saturday, NASA will broadcast this year's finals of the National Robotics Competition live over the Internet (quest.arc.nasa.gov/firstrobots). The event pits robots built by high school students against one another in tests of strength and skill. Pictured at right is Chief Delphi, the entry from Pontiac Central High School in Pontiac, Mich., in regional competition.

title: Corrections
description: A fashion review of the designer Zoran on Tuesday misspelled the surname of a theatrical producer who is one of his customers. She is Joan Cullman, not Coleman.

title: Where Better to Find Out About Spiders Than on the Web?
description: SPIDERS belong on the Web, and not just to make a bad pun. They are interesting, colorful and far more useful than harmful to humans. Unfortunately, Internet menus are cluttered with listings for ''Web spiders,'' a term for wide-ranging search programs.

title: A Dervish Who Is in Control
description: There was freshness in the pianist Satoko Fujii's performance at Tonic on Friday night, and if it wasn't entirely in the sound of her music -- impressionist sketches full of wide, doleful intervals, set off by hot patches of free improvisation -- it was in the structure, and how her trio played it.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I thought we lived in a bubble.''

title: NATO Raids Send Notice To Milosevic: Businesses He Holds Are Fair Game
description: When NATO struck hard at Yugoslavia's political and media elite early this morning, it sent a clear message that after weeks of hesitation, the alliance would now hit the business interests of President Slobodan Milosevic's family and friends.

title: Couch Could Get $8.75 Million Bonus
description: If quarterback Tim Couch leads the Cleveland Browns in any passing category once during the next three seasons, the Browns will have to pay him an additional $8.75 million bonus or risk losing him through free agency, under terms of his contract.

title: Profit Gains Help Spur a 132.87-Point Climb in the Dow
description: Strong profit reports helped fuel a rally in stocks yesterday as technology and consumer issues appeared to regain the leadership they long enjoyed. Stocks tied to the business cycle, meanwhile, mostly paused after their recent run-up.

title: DaimlerChrysler Weighs Sale of Stake in Unit
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. said yesterday that it was considering the sale of a minority stake in its DASA aerospace unit to finance acquisitions as it gives up on the creation of a single European aerospace and military company. The move shows that DASA is not counting on alliances in Europe. DaimlerChrysler has said that plans to create a single pan-European military company are dead.

title: Goth Genres, Fringe Rock And Germany
description: Like generations of teen-age misfits and outcasts before them, the post-pubescent gunmen in the Colorado school shootings apparently found comfort in the words of the darker bards of their age -- in this case in the depressive, anarchic, nihilistic and suicidal musings of the disparate strands of fringe rock music genres known as Goth and industrial.

title: Williams's Thing: Pins, Not Popularity
description: Walter Ray Williams Jr., the best professional bowler of his era, will never win a popularity contest. A fellow pro and friend, Randy Pedersen, concedes that Williams can be abrasive and that bowling might benefit by having a more personable star at the top.

title: Kosovo Shows the Need for a United Nations Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Cliff Freeman Wins 14 Awards
description: Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York took top honors at the 14th annual presentation of the Best of New York American Advertising Awards, known as the Addys, which are sponsored by the Advertising Women of New York.

title: All Factions in the Violence in East Timor Sign a Peace Accord
description: The warring factions in the former Portuguese colony of East Timor took a tentative step toward reconciliation today with the signing of a peace accord.

title: Credit Suisse Replaces Real Estate Leader
description: As part of a larger shake-up, Credit Suisse First Boston said yesterday that it had replaced Andrew Stone, one of the pioneers of the $250 billion market for bonds backed by commercial mortgages, as head of its real estate finance business as it reduces its risks.

title: Littleton, Then and Now
description: It's a routine with me. Where are you from, I am asked. Oh, a little town in Colorado -- you wouldn't have heard of it. It's got an appropriate name, though: Littleton.

title: America Online to Compete in Assigning Internet Domains
description: America Online, the world's largest on-line service, was one of five companies chosen today to compete with Network Solutions Inc., which currently enjoys a Government-backed monopoly in the lucrative business of assigning the Internet addresses known as domains.

title: Day of Violence Threatens Residents' Sense of Safety and Faith in the Future
description: The good life is gobbling up the old life in every direction around here. Where not too long ago there was prairie and small-town America in the shadow of the foothills, now there are new and expensive houses, lush golf courses, shopping malls, multiplex movie theaters and modern walled communities with bygone names like Country Farms and Grant Ranch.

title: Rubin Proposes Modest Limits on Lending Risk
description: Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin outlined a modest five-point American plan today for warding off the kind of financial crisis that rocked three continents over the last two years. He called for strengthened financial disclosure rules and guidelines that would ''discourage countries from taking too many risks'' when they borrow money.

title: Accord Comes After Promise of No Meddling
description: Two of Europe's largest telecommunications companies, Telecom Italia S.p.A. and Deutsche Telekom A.G., reached a formal agreement tonight to merge in a share swap valued at nearly $82 billion after the Italians obtained assurances that Germany would not interfere in the new combined company's operations.

title: As Boat Rocks, Grunfeld Is Pushed Overboard
description: Someone had to be held responsible for the Knicks' plunge into mediocrity this season, their perilous flirtation with missing the playoffs and the acrimony that had developed within the organization. Yesterday, on the heels of a four-game losing streak, Ernie Grunfeld took the fall when Madison Square Garden President Dave Checketts dismissed Grunfeld from his position as team president and general manager.

title: Some Local Governments Unprepared for 2000, Report Says
description: Nearly all the Federal Government's computers will be ready for the year 2000, and so will those of most states, but those of some local governments and small businesses will not be, the official supervising computer preparation for 2000 said today.

title: Racial Profiling in New Jersey
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Attorney General Peter Verniero of New Jersey have belatedly acknowledged that state troopers have improperly stopped and searched black and Hispanic motorists on the New Jersey Turnpike because of their race. But both officials largely avoid broader questions of the state police culture and leadership. Mrs. Whitman, who harbors senatorial and national ambitions, needs to exert a firm hand in demanding true systemic reform before this issue becomes a turning point in her career. For starters, she should withdraw her nomination of Mr. Verniero to the New Jersey Supreme Court because of his tardiness in rooting out racial profiling in the state police, an agency that his office oversees.

title: PARENTTIME
description: www.parenttime.com

title: Sonia Gandhi Says Party Has, Barely, the Votes to Govern
description: A diverse, bickering collection of parties united long enough in Parliament on Saturday to bring down the Hindu nationalist-led Government by a single vote. But they are having a lot more trouble figuring out how to form a new government.

title: 'Sesame Street' Site: Serious Child's Play
description: THE office of Children's Television Workshop Online in Manhattan is a preschooler's decorating dream, with a wall-size blackboard, armchairs that fairly beg for someone to curl up and tell a story and a mesmerizing carpet of crayon-bright red, blue and orange that could have been designed by a ''Romper Room'' Martha Stewart. The only thing missing is . . . children.

title: Ward for Open Locker Room
description: Charlie Ward, in the center of a debate about female sportwriters in the locker room, issued a statement yesterday in what he said was an attempt to clarify his position. The Knicks' point guard called attention to the issue over the weekend when he cited a published article by Reggie White, the former Green Bay Packer, who wrote that female journalists did not belong in the locker room.

title: Monkeys' Own Cells Reported To Reverse a Nerve Disorder
description: Scientists have reported that they reversed a Parkinson's-like disease in monkeys by transplanting their tissue into their brains.

title: Kosovars Balk at Leaving the Camps
description: After five mornings of chilling rain left his children coughing and wheezing, Ilir Januzi could take no more. Just after daybreak today, he took his wife and children -- including an 8-month-old son -- from the old car that had been their only shelter and boarded a bus for Vlora, 220 miles south of here.

title: Great Art for Your Page? You Can Get It From Gates
description: For nearly a decade, Bill Gates's other company, the Corbis Corporation in Seattle (www.corbis.com), has been quietly acquiring the electronic reproduction rights to 25 million images, including some of the world's great art and historical photographs, like Monet's ''Poplars,'' Ansel Adams' ''Moonrise Over Hernandez,'' John F. Kennedy Jr.'s salute at his father's funeral and the Challenger explosion.

title: MORE ON THE MASSACRE
description: A CHANGING TOWN -- In Littleton, Colo., residents are mourning not only the loss of lives, but the area's old-fashioned sense of safety. Page A26.

title: Framing Flights of Fantasy With the Sonata's Formality
description: Horacio Gutierrez's performances have always offered an inviting combination of innate musicality and technical power, but at his recital on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, there seemed to be a brighter spark of imaginative introspection than his playing has shown in the past. In retrospect, a listener might have guessed that this would be the case from a glance at his program. He began and ended with sonatas, works that adhere -- or at least refer -- to strictly defined structural forms. Between them he played a pair of fantasies, works in which a composer pursues his inspiration unfettered by formal prescriptions.

title: Two Slices of Americana, With Meat From Europe
description: The New Juilliard Ensemble, conducted as usual by Joel Sachs, presented a sandwich of three recent European works inside American music of the 1980's on Friday night at Alice Tully Hall. Not much else gave a pattern to the evening, except that the outside pieces were far more tightly composed than those within, and were also virtual inverses of each other. Conlon Nancarrow's Piece No. 2 skips with the levity of old age, while Christopher Rouse's ''Iscariot'' moves with a young man's heaviness.

title: Soft Forms Ease Winds of Worry
description: WRIGGLING derrieres replaced chattering into cell phones as the signature gesture at the Milan furniture fair, the world's premier showcase of forward-thinking design.

title: The Volkswagens of Houses
description: Most affordable housing looks worse than it sounds. But in Gainesville, Fla., the nonprofit Neighborhood Housing Development Corporation has been revamping the aging Pleasant Street neighborhood and filling empty lots with homes like the one above. This prototype, built for $45 a square foot, was designed by the New Haven architects Robert Orr & Associates and specifies wood siding, windows, porches and cabinets. The house contains four bedrooms, is 2,200 square feet and would sell for $60,000. Developers always ask Mr. Orr to make expensive-looking houses that cost nothing. Mr. Orr recommends, ''Keep them boxy and simple.''

title: S.E.C. Files Suit In Pairgain Hoax
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused Gary D. Hoke Jr., an employee of Pairgain Technologies Inc., of stock price manipulation in connection with a fake news report about a takeover of Pairgain that was posted on an Internet site earlier this month.

title: BABYCENTER
description: www.babycenter.com

title: Smart, Miserly Meters Stir Revolt
description: THE former New Yorkers were tanned and rested, but in revolt. The city of Miami Beach was testing 20 new parking meters. ''Smart meters,'' the city called them, proudly deploying them on busy Washington Avenue. The former New Yorkers called them something unprintable.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A European Connection; More Deals May Follow a German-Italian Phone Merger
description: A year ago, even a month ago, it still seemed unthinkable. Today, it began to look unavoidable.

title: For Clemens, the Count Has Reached 17-0
description: Roger Clemens heard the boos in the first inning and again in the fourth last night. They were scattered and lasted only a few seconds, but the fans berated Clemens because he did not throw strikes consistently and he allowed a homer. Clemens expects a lot from himself, and New York expects a lot from him, too.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Museums section yesterday about some small institutions in New York misidentified a former neighbor of the Hispanic Society of America on Audubon Terrace, at 155th Street and Broadway. It was the American Geographical Society, not the National Geographic Society.

title: In Playoffs, Two Refs Are Better Than One
description: The Stanley Cup playoffs began last night, and the second or third round might provide what many hockey fans crave: defending champion Detroit against Colorado, a bitter rivalry in the Western Conference. Because of recent trades, forwards Claude Lemieux and Dale Hunter of the Avalanche might be bearing down on defensemen Chris Chelios and Ulf Samuelsson of the Red Wings.

title: Clavijo Named Assistant Coach
description: Coach Bora Milutinovic of the MetroStars got the man he wanted as his assistant yesterday, Fernando Clavijo, a native of Uruguay and a naturalized American who started three games for the United States under Milutinovic in the 1994 World Cup.

title: Clinton to Announce That U.S. Will Keep Sample of Lethal Smallpox Virus, Aides Say
description: Defying international pleas, President Clinton has decided to retain America's sample of smallpox virus, Administration officials said yesterday.

title: Mouse With a Camera Sees Rather Than Feels
description: With its sleek silver back and glowing red underbelly and taillight, the Microsoft Intellimouse Explorer, which will become available in September, is the most visually striking computer mouse yet.

title: Recounting the Civil War In a 90's Vaudeville Show
description: ''The Civil War'' may have the music of Frank Wildhorn, but ''Reunion: A Civil War Musical Epic in Miniature'' has footnotes.

title: SUPERIOR ENERGY AGREES TO A $197 MILLION ACQUISITION
description: Superior Energy Services Inc., an oilfield-equipment company in Harvey, La., agreed to buy the Cardinal Holding Corporation for $197 million in stock, forming a Gulf of Mexico provider of well-servicing vessels to oil and gas companies. Superior said it would issue 30 million shares to owners of the closely held Cardinal, which is based in New Iberia, La. Cardinal shareholders will contribute $45 million of equity to the combined operation and will own 51 percent of it, Superior said. Superior, which said the deal would more than double its business, dropped a plan earlier this year to be acquired by the Parker Drilling Company for $127 million in stock and assumed debt.

title: Experts Urge Swift Action to Fight Depression, Isolation and Aggression
description: Child psychologists and other experts on youth violence say the killings in Colorado on Tuesday are evidence of a woeful lack of mental health services for young people at a time of decreasing family strength and increasing access to the tools of violence.

title: Congress Passes Measure Giving Schools Flexibility on Spending
description: Congress today overwhelmingly approved legislation that gives states and local schools more flexibility in how they spend more than $10 billion in Federal education money each year. President Clinton immediately said he would sign the bill.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Raising Voices About Noises

title: U S West and Qwest Post Income Data
description: U S West Inc., which provides local phone services in 14 Western states, said today that its first-quarter profit was little changed, and Qwest Communications International Inc. reversed a loss from the quarter a year earlier.

title: Slip in Open Short Sales On Big Board
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange decreased 1.1 percent in the most recent month, to 3.65 billion shares, the exchange said yesterday.

title: Creating a Mystique of the English Horn
description: When Thomas Stacy was a 14-year-old in rural Arkansas, he made a decision that must have struck his friends as odd. Having already studied the piano, violin, clarinet and oboe -- moving from one to another as he became captivated by their sound on recordings -- he resolved to take up the English horn, the instrument he now plays in the New York Philharmonic, and sold his motorcycle in order to buy one.

title: Behind Every Door, Different Tales of Terror
description: They will never forget where they were when the alarm went off.

title: Board and Beach
description: To the Editor:

title: Europeans Threaten Ban on U.S. Beef Imports
description: The European Union's executive agency threatened today to ban beef imports from the United States, a move that intensifies a long-running feud over beef from hormone-treated cattle.

title: Radio Reporter Who's Not Easy-Listening
description: IT would be nice to say that Amy Goodman, the award-winning Pacifica Radio producer and reporter who uses grant money or her own frequent-flier miles for overseas assignments and who has been beaten and threatened with execution for her reporting of human rights violations, has the universal affection of her colleagues.

title: The $44,100 Pickle Jar
description: ''DID you hear about the guy who bought an old pickle bottle for $30 at Brimfield and sold it on Ebay for $32,000?'' That was the buzz at a flea market in Adamstown, Pa., earlier this month. It was almost the truth.

title: A Master's First Success, on the Futility of Violence
description: There is a bit of farce in any tragedy. Few playwrights understood that more clearly than Sean O'Casey, and few tragedies have at times seemed more farcical than this century's episode of the Irish-English conflict. As Seamus Shields observes in O'Casey's ''Shadow of a Gunman'': ''It's the Irish people all over. They take a serious thing as a joke and a joke as a serious thing.''

title: Doctors Revive A Desert Oasis
description: A MANSION called the Willows, tucked into the flank of Mount San Jacinto here, was best known in the 1950's as the home of Marion Davies, an actress famous as the mistress of the newspaper magnate William Randolph Hearst. Before that, the Mediterranean-style house was known as the place where Clark Gable and Carole Lombard stayed on their honeymoon. But perhaps the best reason to know the Willows is that it was bought shortly after it was built in 1927 by Samuel Untermeyer, a New York civil rights lawyer and passionate horticulturist. (Untermeyer gave the Untermeyer Fountain with three maidens to Central Park's Conservatory Garden.)

title: Kosovo Shows the Need for a United Nations Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Palm Pilot May Be Powerful, But That Screen Is Fragile
description: Unlike your PC, when Palm Pilots crash, they really crash. According to a representative in Palm Computing's repair information department, the most common complaint -- an estimated 90 percent of the calls -- are from users with cracked or broken glass screens that have rendered the units inoperable.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Shares Climb As Stock Rally Continues

title: 20 Are Charged in Insurance Fraud Schemes Netting $360,000
description: Twenty people, including the executive director of the Rockville Centre Housing Authority, were arrested yesterday and charged with stealing more than $360,000 in worker's compensation benefits by lying about on-the-job injuries, cashing the checks of dead relatives and other forms of insurance fraud, officials said.

title: 2 Exchanges Said to End Merger Plan
description: The American Stock Exchange and Philadelphia Stock Exchange have terminated their planned merger, according to people close to the negotiations.

title: In America; Addicted to Violence
description: Again.

title: Sports of The Times; The Knicks' Problems Run Deeper
description: ON the day Ernie Grunfeld's head would roll, like another loose ball eluding a sore-kneed Knick, he awoke to the latest explosion set off by his own failed chemistry test.

title: Whitman Fails to Appease Critics of Troopers' Action
description: A day after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman vowed to revamp the New Jersey State Police to end racial profiling, there were few indications today that the Governor's assurances had eased the public furor over the issue or defused the political threat it poses to her nominee to the State Supreme Court, Attorney General Peter G. Verniero.

title: High Court Hears Arguments On States' Care of the Disabled
description: Hearing arguments in an important disability rights case, Supreme Court Justices wrestled today with what they appeared to see as a pair of unpalatable alternatives: permit states to continue confining people with severe disabilities in big institutions, when such settings are not medically necessary, or prompt the mass discharge of people who actually need close supervision and care.

title: Collegium the String Band Revels in Italians
description: It is hard to get a definitive fix on the New York Collegium in its first season since by its nature as a period-instrument ensemble it changes shape from one concert to the next, and since it works under a different leader almost every time out. But no question about it, the group hit on a winning formula on Friday evening at Town Hall.

title: The Trend's a Nontrend
description: If furniture follows fashion, then the International Home Furnishings Market, which opened here last Thursday and ends tomorrow, is a cashmere twin set: luxurious, understated, pretty and comfortingly familiar.

title: PARENT SOUP
description: www.parentsoup.com

title: GAME THEORY; A Hero Who, Oddly, Doesn't Look the Part
description: THE eponymous hero of Abe's Exoddus doesn't fit the description of a video game superman. He's not a lantern-jawed commando armed with assault weapons, inexhaustible ammunition and a rippling physique.

title: Mattress Misfit
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Spock Yields to the World Wide Web
description: WHAT'S a new parent to do? Dr. Spock has been knocked off his pedestal by pans of his real-life fathering. Dr. T. Berry Brazelton, as dear to many parents' hearts as was Dr. Spock, is locked in battle with his fellow best-selling child-raising author, John Rosemond, over toilet training, of all things. And from somewhere in your apartment rises a wail that, with luck, might belong to a rousing velociraptor -- but is more likely coming from the lungs of a far fiercer creature: your baby.

title: Portrait of Outcasts Seeking to Stand Out
description: Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, students at Columbine High School, worked last Friday making pizzas. On Monday, they went bowling. And on Tuesday, it seems, they committed mass murder.

title: Help for Abused Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Keeping Ethnic Tension From Turning Violent
description: If the world is permitted any nostalgia for Communism, let it note that alongside the many horrors was the virtue of a relative measure of ethnic peace. It is often so with empires -- and when they fall, the ethnic, religious and nationalist conflicts they smothered with their harsh repression can erupt. The fall of Communism, and the end of American and Soviet sponsorship of political wars in the third world, have made these ethnic conflicts into the face of war today, exemplified by the former Yugoslavia.

title: CENDANT TO SELL TRAVEL MARKETING AND COUPON UNITS
description: The Cendant Corporation, whose businesses include hotel franchising and direct-marketing services, agreed yesterday to sell its business that markets cruises and vacation packages, the National Leisure Group, to the America West Holdings Corporation and to put its entertainment coupon unit up for sale. Terms of the cash sale were not disclosed; America West is the parent of America West Airlines. The other business to be sold, Entertainment Publications Inc., had revenue last year of $197.2 million. The Cendant chairman, Henry R. Silverman, has been selling businesses to focus the company on franchising hotel brands, real estate brokerages and direct sales of related products like mortgage loans. Cendant shares rose 68.75 cents, to $18.5625.

title: Gary Bauer, Drawing on Shootings in Colorado, Declares for President
description: Invoking the deadly shootings at a school in Colorado as the agonizing measure of a country that had lost its moral bearings, Gary L. Bauer announced his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination today and pledged to put America back on a righteous track.

title: Artest Wins Haggerty Award
description: St. John's forward Ron Artest, who averaged 14.5 points and 6.3 rebounds a game in helping the Red Storm achieve a 28-9 record and its first regional final since 1991, won the Haggerty Award last night as the metropolitan area's best college player.

title: Linux's Popular Creator Steals Show From Microsoft
description: At the annual Comdex-Windows World conference this week, William H. Gates, the Microsoft chairman, standing with an eight-foot high model of the new optical mouse, attracted the usual overflow crowd for his opening day keynote speech. But the real star of the conference was not the head of Microsoft, but a lone programmer who gives away his work: Linus Torvalds.

title: ATRIUM COMPANIES TO ACQUIRE HEAT INC. FOR $85 MILLION
description: The Atrium Companies, a manufacturer and distributor of residential windows and doors, agreed yesterday to acquire Heat Inc. for about $85 million. Heat owns Best Built Inc., which makes and distributes vinyl window and door products under the Best Built brand name, and Thermal Industries, which makes vinyl replacement windows, doors and patio enclosure systems. Atrium, a closely held concern based in Dallas, will have revenue of more than $525 million.

title: 2 ALLIES PRESS U.S. TO WEIGH THE USE OF GROUND FORCES
description: On the eve of the NATO summit meeting in Washington, Britain and France are pressing the United States to start thinking seriously about sending ground forces into Kosovo without a peace settlement.

title: The Vatican's Menorah
description: To the Editor:

title: ABB Asea Brown Boveri Posts 17% Income Rise
description: ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., the Swiss-Swedish electrical and engineering company, said yesterday that its net income climbed 17 percent in the first quarter, to $302 million, as revenue rose and costs fell. Revenue rose 11 percent, to $6.89 billion, in the quarter. The company said an 18 percent gain in operating earnings, to $534 million, reflected both higher sales and lower costs.

title: Making Television Searchable
description: TODAY marks the beginning of National TV-Turnoff Week, an annual event in which several million people vow to leave their television sets dark for seven days no matter how many tantrums their children throw.

title: Trying to Make Beautiful Music While Customers Fret on Hold
description: IT'S 11:30 P.M., your hard drive has crashed and you have been on hold to the manufacturer's support line so long you would swear you had heard that Bob Seger song three times already. Your computer may be irreparable. But would some different music help?

title: Where Rubber Meets the Road, a Chip
description: SOMEDAY your tires might be full of more than hot air. They may have minds of their own, keeping track of their air pressure and letting you know when they need to be replaced.

title: Batsheva de Rothschild, 84, a Patron of Graham
description: Baroness Batsheva de Rothschild, a patron of Martha Graham and of modern dance in Israel, died on Tuesday at her home in Tel Aviv. She was 84.

title: At NATO's Birthday Party, Chilling Specter of Kosovo
description: The word ''gala'' still appears on some official schedules of NATO's 50th anniversary celebration. But the word rings unseemly now as the bombs continue to fall on Yugoslavia from NATO warplanes.

title: I.B.M. Reports A 42% Rise In Its Profit
description: In another sign of continued health for high-technology makers, the International Business Machines Corporation reported first-quarter earnings yesterday that were well in excess of analysts' estimates. I.B.M. said its results were led by strong sales of services and software, which accounted for 60 percent of gross profit.

title: Why Subsidize the Wrong Kinds of Plants?
description: To the Editor:

title: As agencies hold their annual conference, the accentuation is very much on the positive.
description: THE sunny skies over Madison Avenue, metaphorically speaking, are likely to extend to northern Florida at the 81st annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: Police Corner a Big Rat, and Its Union Makes a Federal Case
description: It's no secret that the Mayor has been trying to crack down on rodents in New York City, making them just one of many targets in his campaign to improve the city's quality of life.

title: Borders Chief Ousted as Not 'a Good Fit'
description: Just a little more than five months after boasting about hiring Philip M. Pfeffer, a longtime book industry executive, as its chief executive, Borders Group Inc. unceremoniously announced his abrupt departure yesterday.

title: Brick Floors and Cypress Beams in Louisiana
description: Today, real architects don't do charm, but long before it fell out of style, A. Hays Town, born in 1903, was building Acadian cottages, Creole villas and Spanish courtyards in his native Louisiana. After retiring from his commercial practice in the 1960's, he designed even more of these houses, which are beloved by Southerners. Now everyone can visit 25 of the 500 he built in ''The Louisiana Houses of A. Hays Town'' (Louisiana State University Press; $39.95). The sparse text is by Cyril E. Vetter, and the 200 photographs by Philip Gould prove that good proportion and materials work. White-painted brick walls with red brick floors under high ceilings with cypress beams work even better. This is true regional architecture, handsome and useful.

title: 1950's Flair Shines Bright Again
description: FIFTIES design is appealing now because of its diversity,'' said George Marcus, the author of ''Design in the Fifties'' (Prestel, 1998). And nowhere is that appeal more evident than in the ceramic lamps of the era.

title: A Program That Can Remove Advertising on Internet Pages
description: A German electronics company is tackling those banner advertisements with a product that strips most advertising off Web pages. Web Washer was developed by engineers at Siemens A. G. who wanted to get rid of advertising they thought was obtrusive. During testing on the company's intranet, they discovered that it also reduced the time pages took to load in a browser.

title: INSIDE
description: Smallpox Wins Reprieve

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Blueberries in Shade

title: Time Machines to the Truman Era
description: Fifty years ago, young modernists took design to the masses. Now the humble furniture of that era (renamed midcentury modern) has skyrocketed in price and led Evan Lobel down a new career path: a used furniture store (below). ''It took 12 years on Wall Street to learn a simple lesson,'' he said. ''Life isn't about duking it out and making a gazillion dollars. It's about warmth.'' His warm store offers glass, pottery and sleek furniture in mahogany, walnut and exotic woods at $100 to $15,000. Lobel Modern is at 207 West 18th Street, (212) 242-9075.
