title: The Colorado School Slayings
description: On the screen, the images are too familiar -- emergency personnel bent double in concentration, anguished parents, weeping, puzzled and wounded students, the ordinary buildings of a school that is no longer ordinary. With the first reports of a shooting like the one that occurred in Littleton, Colo., on Tuesday morning, a mental accounting begins, an effort to tally the reasons, or the absence of reason, that lie behind such a pitiless event. Reporters ask questions about motive, scarcely differing from students and parents in this respect, and those questions contain the unstated hope that a predominant motive will emerge, a cause that somehow encapsulates the tragedy and allows it to be set apart from everyday life.

title: Claims Heard To $18 Million Left by Writer
description: Lawyers for the executor of the estate of Frederick P. Lenz 3d today asked a judge to dismiss the National Audubon Society's claims that it is the rightful heir of the $18 million estate and instead award it to a charitable foundation the executor set up shortly after Mr. Lenz's suicide last year.

title: Politically Astute Generals Picked to Lead Services
description: President Clinton nominated new chiefsfor the Army and Marine Corps today, turning to the highest-ranking Japanese-American officer in the Army's history and a close aide of Defense Secretary William S. Cohen.

title: Patients Are Victims of the Politics of Cancer; Doctors Know Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Winning With the Four On the First Trump Trick
description: If there were an award for the best trump trick of 1999, it would probably go to Dick Budd of Portland, Me. On the opening day of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Vancouver, British Columbia, last month, he found himself playing three spades doubled as South on the diagramed deal. His partner was David Treadwell of Wilmington, Del., who at 86 is one of the oldest active players on the tournament circuit and was inducted into the Hall of Fame last July.

title: No Jordan, No Kukoc, No Fun in Winning for the Nets
description: Needless to say, these were not Michael Jordan's Chicago Bulls who visited Continental Arena tonight. But to the dismay of the 15,874 fans, they were not even Toni Kukoc's Bulls, or Ron Harper's, or Brent Barry's.

title: Attitude Makes The Pitcher; Pinstripes Don't
description: The Metallica hat was in place and the hole prominent in his left earlobe. But only at the end of a half-hour conversation did David Wells start sounding like himself. The carefully considered statements, the even words about having gotten over the devastating trade that blew him out of his dream, and about expecting Friday to be just another start, were wearing away.

title: Hemispheric Basins on Columns
description: For thousands of years, architects have been trying to erect spherical buildings. Architects like Boulee and Ledoux in the 18th century drew spherical buildings, but only a few designers like Buckminster Fuller actually built any. Lately, the ironic architect Michael Graves has revived the traditional fantasy in miniature, by designing little geometric works of architecture in ceramics and acrylic: pitchers, sinks, toilets, tubs and more. The geometry Mr. Graves likes best is the clunkiness of hemispheres on square columns. Witness his new Dreamscape collection of bath fixtures and furniture for the German companies Duravit, Dornbracht and Hoesch. The Duravit half-grapefruit sink, above, with a frosted glass and laminated cabinet, costs $2,520. Information from (888) 387-2848.

title: A Walk Through History
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: High Museum Fees May Cost Us Future Picassos
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKEFELLER, MARY CLARK
description: ROCKEFELLER - Mary Clark. April 21st. Beloved mother of Rodman, Ann, Steven, Mary and the late Michael C. Rockefeller, loving grandmother to 15 grandchildren and 23 great grandchildren, she was a tireless supporter of nursing education and the nursing profession. The example of her life and love is an inspiration to all who knew her. Services at Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive at 2:00pm Sunday April 25. Memorial contributions may be made to the Mary C. Rockefeller Fund of the Riverside Church.

title: Lucent Profits Sharply Higher; 3 Phone Companies Also Gain
description: Lucent Technologies Inc., the world's leading phone-equipment maker, said today that its second-quarter earnings more than doubled as customers spent more to improve their networks.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Meredith Monk

title: What Was Behind Colorado Shooting?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMULA, CLAIRE
description: LAMULA-Claire, 81, widow of Assemblyman John J. Lamula, passed away April 20, 1999. An NYC native, she resided in Connecticut and later Maryland. She was an elegant and honorable lady who established her own insurance agency, assisted Mr. Lamula in his brokerage firm and volunteered at CASA. She is survived by 3 children, Dr. Pamela R. Hartley (Atlanta, GA), JoD Straub (Columbia, MD) and Harry B. Rosen (Merritt Island, FL), and 2 grandchildren, Ashleigh J. Snell and Christopher J. Snell (Columbia, MD). Remembrances may be sent to the Humane Society.

title: City Rejects $2 Million Offer for Gardens
description: A private conservation group, working with a coalition of 25 donors, has offered the Giuliani administration $2 million to buy 165 community gardens, most of them slated for auction next month. But City Hall has rejected the offer as a bad deal for taxpayers.

title: Describing a 'Hard-Fought Year,' 4 Men in Turnpike Shooting File a Lawsuit
description: A year ago, a seemingly random traffic stop placed them at the center of a public outcry over racial profiling, triggering numerous investigations into its practice, and if the pronouncements of public officials hold true, its end.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA DOWN SHARPLY. Cocoa fell on expectations that an abundant harvest in the Ivory Coast, the biggest producer, would increase supplies. Cocoa for July delivery fell $49, or 4.5 percent, in New York to $1,030 a metric ton.

title: Off Welfare, Life Is Still Tough
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Elizabeth Peyton

title: Wells Hopes to Weave His Old Stadium Magic
description: Soon after David Wells's depression over being traded from the Yankees to the Blue Jays evaporated enough for him to think clearly, he looked at Toronto's schedule and searched for his redemption day. It was still two months away, but Wells implored the Jays in February to let him start tonight against the Yankees, and they obliged.

title: Plea for Mercy For Lives Lost To Drug Laws
description: THE ISSUE for Elaine Bartlett's family and friends is fairness. No one is absolving her of sin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERT, MOLLIE
description: SILBERT-Mollie. Devoted wife of the late Herbert. Loving mother of Gerald, Robert, Ramie and Phyllis. Adoring grandmother of Terry, Joanne and Donna. Proud greatgrandmother of Matthew, Bennett & Steven. Passed into her eternal sleep in her 96th year on April 21, 1999. Graveside service.

title: Calls for Change Receive A Hearing in Washington
description: Muhammad Ali's muted presence packed a Senate Commerce Committee hearing into Federal boxing reform today, and through his friend, Howard Bingham, he said he could not remain silent ''while the sport he gave his life to has become a travesty.''

title: Ah, Home on the Range, An Especially Green One
description: Sometimes it's comforting to watch a film that lets you know in its first minutes just where it's headed. ''Durango'' telegraphs its trajectory immediately. It gives you a decent young man with a Big Idea who asks his neighbors to believe in him. Will they do so? Will their faith be rewarded? Will the young man's success help him win the hand of his beloved?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGESCU, MARIA
description: GEORGESCU-Maria. Of Nutley, NJ formerly of Queens on April 21, 1999, mother of Valeria Andrusca, grandmother of Eric. She was an adjunct professor of Dental Materials at Kriser Dental Center of N.Y.U. for 12 years. Visiting at S.W. Brown & Son Funeral Home, 267 Centre St., Nutley, NJ Friday 7-9 P.M. Funeral Saturday 10 A.M.

title: Residential Real Estate; Tenant-Led Loft Conversion to Co-op Paying Off
description: It was a risk most of those living in the 10-unit loft building in TriBeCa were willing to take: Give up their status as rent-regulated tenants to buy their weathered building at 38-40 North Moore Street and turn it into a co-op.

title: Europe Phone Deal: Clearly, a Work in Progress
description: The chief executives of the former telephone monopolies in Germany and Italy outlined their shared vision for a global telecommunications giant today, but could not explain how they would increase efficiency, conquer cultural barriers, penetrate the United States market or share management in their $82 billion merger.

title: INKTOMI IN $113 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR IMPULSE BUY
description: The Inktomi Corporation, an Internet navigation company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Impulse Buy Network, a developer of on-line merchandising software, in an all-stock deal valued at nearly $113 million. Inktomi, based in San Mateo, Calif., said it would pay 900,000 common shares to acquire Impulse, which is based in Burlingame, Calif. Inktomi's shares were down $1.50 each, at $124. Impulse Buy's software enables customers to buy brand-name goods via banner ads on a variety of Web sites. Inktomi intends to integrate Impulse Buy's software into its shopping search software.

title: Indonesia's Responsibility in East Timor
description: Deadly violence returned to East Timor last week, and militias backed by Indonesia's army are clearly to blame. Their goal is to thwart a plan by Indonesia's President, B. J. Habibie, to let Timor's people choose between autonomy and independence. A tentative cease-fire signed Tuesday is encouraging, but not enough. The United States and other countries must insist that Mr. Habibie disarm and disband the militias.

title: Both Founder Of a Nation And Designer
description: In New York, George Washington is more than a household name. Streets, avenues, a park, two bridges and a magnificent marble triumphal arch all bear his name. And this year, the city is marking the bicentennial of his death with exhibitions, books and lectures. New York loves George Washington.

title: Cartoon Art In Subways
description: Art is continually being produced for New York's subway stations, but little finds its way into the subway cars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEBE, PETER F.
description: STEBE-Peter F., of Flushing, NY, on April 21, 1999. Professor of Mathematics at the City College of New York. His wit, humor, love and friendship will be remembered always by his family and life-long friends. Son of John and Mary (nee Byrne); brother of Joan and Nicholas. Husband of Joan (nee Kaletchitz), father of John, Julia, Kathleen and Nicholas, father-in-law to Ivetta, Christian, and Joseph, grandfather of Sara, Christiana, and Alexander. Born in Brooklyn, NY, on November 27, 1934. He received his B.S. from Queens College, his M.S. from NYU and his Ph.D. in Mathematics from the Courant Institute with Wilhelm Magnus, specializing in group theory. He also received a Ph.D. in Economics from CUNY. He taught throughout the CUNY system and enjoyed his bright students immensely. Prior to joining the faculty at CCNY, he served in the Army as a 1st Lieutenant and worked at RCA and the Institute for Defense Analysis. Visitation will be Sunday, April 25, from 2-5 and 7-9 p.m. at Hillebrand Funeral Home, 63-17 Woodhaven Blvd. A funeral mass will be held Monday, April 26, at 9:45 a.m. at Saint Margaret's RC Church, 80 St. & Juniper Valley Rd., Middle Village, followed by interment at Calverton Cemetery. Donations in his memory can be made to the American Mathematical Society.

title: Returning to High School, But Not as a Geek This Time
description: Never Been Kissed

title: An Overabundance Of Counseling?
description: Shortly after the police, paramedics and television crews screeched onto the scene at Columbine High School, the grief counselors arrived. Coming in by the busload, such experts are now a fixture of tragedy's aftermath in America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDOFF, MINNIE P.
description: DAVIDOFF-Minnie P. On April 21, 1999. Wife of the late Eli Davidoff, mother of Richard S. Davidoff, Susan Gilbert and Phyllis Rose, grandmother of six and greatgrandmother of ten. Family will be receiving Thursday 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, service Friday 10am.

title: Vietnam Experience Unites Senators on Everything Except Kosovo
description: A generation ago, John Kerry, a decorated Navy lieutenant, came home to lead protests against the Vietnam War that he had served in. Max Cleland, a young Army captain, lost his legs and an arm when he reached for a loose grenade that exploded. Chuck Hagel, an Army sergeant, was wounded alongside his brother. John McCain, a Navy pilot, was shot down, imprisoned and tortured in Hanoi.

title: Land-War Delay Gives Choices to Milosevic
description: NATO's reluctance to make ground forces a viable option in Yugoslavia may make it harder to compel President Slobodan Milosevic to meet the alliance's demands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXAY, ALEXANDER
description: ALEXAY-Alexander. On April 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Hiromi and father of Mario. Funeral service will be held on Saturday, April 24th, at 9 A.M., at Quinn-Fogarty Funeral Home, 162-14 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, NY, followed by a memorial service at 1:30PM at NYC Baha'i Center, 53 East 11th Street in Manhattan. www.rrussell. simplenet.com/alexay.html

title: In Comics, Anything but Normal
description: ''You don't want your characters to be perfect,'' said Mark Bode, looking spiky, disheveled and agreeably imperfect himself in his Felix the Cat T-shirt, black sneakers, earrings and slouchy, conspiratorial demeanor. ''You want them to have problems, quirks, personality. Just as long as they're not normal. Normal isn't very interesting, is it? You want your characters to have something wrong with them.''

title: Father Sees Officer as Victim of 'Lynching' in Louima Case
description: The father of one of the New York City police officers accused of torturing a Haitian immigrant charged yesterday that his son was the victim of a ''modern-day lynching'' by prosecutors and by a judge who he said had approved several possible jurors who would not give the officers a fair trial.

title: Bones in Ethiopia May Help to Settle The Ape-Man Link
description: Digging beneath a sere plain in Ethiopia, paleontologists have found a skull and other fossils of what they say is a new prehuman species, possibly the long-sought connecting link between apelike ancestors and the human family.

title: New Video Releases
description: Elizabeth

title: INSIDE
description: Genes and Sexuality

title: Change Sought in Listing All Those Accused of Child Abuse
description: Two years ago, a stranger approached Michael Divon in a grocery store. How, she asked, did his 6-year-old son get that ugly bruise on his face? Mr. Divon explained that Jonathan had fallen against a sandbox in the school playground.

title: Pop's 15 Minutes Keeps on Ticking
description: The most sought-after trophies of the Pop Art era are paintings, of course, with their big, catchy images of consumer products and media scenes. But printmaking, too, by the very fact of its populist, disseminative nature, was an important Pop activity. A well-rounded reminder of this is the Modern's bright, snappy show, ''Pop Impressions Europe/ U.S.A.: Prints and Multiples From the Museum of Modern Art,'' whose 90 objects are drawn entirely from the museum's collection.

title: Down and Out at Failed Chinese Company
description: In another blow to foreign banks, a Chinese court said today that it expected to salvage only $783 million in assets from one of China's largest and most troubled state companies.

title: AT&T Makes Competing Bid For Mediaone
description: Bidding to become the largest cable television provider in the United States, the AT&T Corporation yesterday made an unsolicited offer to acquire Mediaone Group Inc. for about $58 billion in cash and stock.

title: Our Violent Inner Landscape
description: Monday night I got home from a long business trip. I was going to watch a video of the new British production of ''Richard III'' that someone had left me, but as I was turning on the television, I caught a spectacular explosion, some gunfire and a half-naked body darting across the screen. It was Rambo. I slumped on the couch and my road-frazzled nerves relaxed at last, adrift in a comforting sea of macho inanity. So much for ''Richard III.''

title: A Trailer-Size Camera for Some Low-Tech Image Building With Nature
description: In the increasingly fashionable tradition of post-modernists like James Casebere and Cindy Sherman, the 31-year-old French artist Laurent Millet photographs constructed fantasies. For the images in the first half of an exhibition at the Robert Mann Gallery in Chelsea, he built ''petite machines'' out of tree branches, twine and fishing traps found in the Pyrenees and set them up by the water's edge. In the second half of the show, Mr. Millet appears in his photographs and collages as a kind of Everyman grappling with a ''windtrap,'' usually fashioned haphazardly out of white cloth and branches, that is forever blowing in the wind.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: 2 Youths Wanted to 'Destroy the School,' Sheriff Says
description: The two students who launched a murderous rampage here on Tuesday were out to ''destroy the school,'' the local sheriff said today, a conclusion he reached after investigators found a large homemade bomb fashioned from two propane tanks and a gasoline canister in the kitchen at Columbine High School.

title: Dutch Aides And El Al Draw Rebuke On '92 Crash
description: More than six years after an Israeli cargo plane crashed into an apartment complex near Amsterdam, killing 43 people, an official investigation sharply criticized the Dutch Government and the Israeli airline El Al today for their slow and inadequate responses after the crash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDINER, BERTRAM
description: BENDINER-Bertram. On April 21st, 1999 in his 87th year. Beloved husband for 58 years of Ruth (nee Marcus), father of Gareth and Kenneth, brother of Robert and Elmer, grandfather of Ezra, Zachary, and Claire. Esteemed labor consultant UAW, great fisherman, and author. We will miss his whimsical humor and gentleness. Private services.

title: Dubai Colts Test Churchill's Strip
description: There was no nameplate on Barn 45 and no chatter from the 10 stable hands who were flown here from Dubai to tend to the Kentucky Derby's most mysterious horses. Instead, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum let Worldly Manner announce his Godolphin stables arrival at Churchill Downs.

title: Of Course the Mind Can Heal the Body
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking a Waft or a Drift And Seeing Where It Leads
description: Bernard Rands, the subject of a ''Works and Process'' evening of music and conversation at the Guggenheim Museum on Monday evening, must be the first American composer in a long while to speak in the warm earth tones of northern England. Since he settled in this country more than 20 years ago, he has had all the marks of success as an American, including a Pulitzer Prize and a professorship at Harvard. But something in his music has stayed, like his voice, gentle and European. He carries with him the lyricism and polish of Italy, where he was a pupil of Luciano Berio, and deeper down there is perhaps a trace of English folk song.

title: U.S. Cracking Down on Internet's Information Brokers
description: The Federal Government today began cracking down on the deceptive practices of a proliferating number of private investigators who advertise on the Internet that they can inexpensively provide confidential details about bank accounts and telephone records.

title: Finding Peace at a Warrior's Tomb
description: The first time somebody asked me the inevitable question -- who's buried in Grant's Tomb? -- I had no idea what the answer might be. I must have been about 12 and had eyed the great granite monument every time my family drove along the West Side Highway into Manhattan from Westchester, where we lived. I had a vague sense of Ulysses S. Grant, I certainly knew what a tomb was, but the thought that he might actually be in there was somehow shocking.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Paul Bloodgood

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, COL. LLOYD R.
description: GRAHAM-Col. Lloyd R., U.S. Army retired, 77, on Wednesday, April 21, 1999 of Dataw Island, SC. Colonel Graham served in the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers during W.W. II. He was most recently employed by Moran Towing Corp of NYC where he was Vice President of Sales. He is survived by wife Ann Ludgate Graham, sons Jeffrey of Northfield, MA, and Robert of Rockaway, N.J., a daughter Nancy Graham - Motavall of Greenwich, CT, and one grandson. Services will be Saturday, April 24, 2:30PM at Sea Island Presbyterian Church, Beaufort, SC. Interment will be at a later date, Noroton Presbyterian Church, Darien, CT. Memorial contributions to: Sea Island Presbyterian Church, P.O. Box 966, Beaufort, S.C. 29901.

title: Pfizer Plans a Stock Split
description: The pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that it would split its common stock 3 for 1. On June 30, shareholders will receive two additional shares for each share held as of June 2. The stock split is the pharmaceutical company's ninth of its common stock since it was first publicly traded in 1942. The shares gained $4.9375 each yesterday, to $128.3125. Pfizer, based in New York, had 1998 revenues of about $13.5 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACNAB, JOHN BROWN
description: MACNAB-John Brown. Age 77. From 1955 to 1992 beloved pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, died Tuesday, April 20 in Rehoboth, DE. Mourned by his wife Mary, daughters Jean, Mary Dee and Nancy, grandchildren, family and the congregation. A Memorial Service will be held at First Presbyterian Church, Sunday, May 9th at 3PM. Memorial gifts to Amyloid Research Fund, 715 Albany St, Boston, MA. 02118-2526.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LYNAUGH, GEORGE L.
description: LYNAUGH-George L. With love on your birthday, George. We miss you. Doogie and the Kid

title: Pepsico Reports Better-Than-Expected Net
description: Pepsico reported better-than-expected first-quarter earnings yesterday, beating analysts' estimates by one cent. Even so, shares of the parent of Frito-Lay, Pepsi-Cola and Tropicana fell after the company's chief financial officer, Michael D. White, said Pepsico would spend $75 million to upgrade its computer systems.

title: Kittles Showing His Old Touch
description: On a Nets team playing out the schedule, perhaps the most compelling plot line revolves around Kerry Kittles. Can the 6-foot-5-inch guard, who was given a whopping contract extension for the all-star potential he showed in his first two seasons, break out of a prolonged scoring funk?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAVIN, J. GREGORY
description: GAVIN-J. Gregory. April 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Cathy, loving father of Grreer, Ashley, Regis, Justin, and Greg. Cherished grandfather of William, Nicholas and Tripp. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Friday, April 23, 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday April 24, 11M at St. Dominic's Church, Anstice St, Oyster Bay, Long Island. contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: A Mahler Work Has Its Day
description: New York has seen an extraordinary ''Lied von der Erde'' season this year, with three performances already of the imposing, deeply personal work by Mahler, left, and one more to come on Sunday when James Levine conducts the Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.

title: High Museum Fees May Cost Us Future Picassos; Pay What You Can
description: To the Editor:

title: A Requiem Cries Out, In Anguish and in Public
description: Can one imagine the German composer Bernd Alois Zimmermann as an old man -- he would be 81 now -- going to the stage of Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night to acknowledge the enthusiastic, if chastened, applause for his ''Requiem for a Young Poet''? There is, rather, a terrible inevitability to the path he in fact took, from the sounds of desperation in this piece -- shrieks and silences against a tapestry of recorded voices telling of the ills of the world -- to suicide the year after the first performance in Dusseldorf.

title: How the Midwives of NATO Prevailed
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization, whose 50th anniversary will be ceremonially commemorated by the leaders of its 19 member nations here this weekend, was the brainchild of a portly, rough-hewn former trade union leader with a grade-school education, the illegitimate son of a serving girl.

title: Greenspan View on Wider Use of Dollar
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, joined the Clinton Administration today in saying the United States would be open to proposals from other countries that want to adopt the dollar as their national currency.

title: How a City Clerk Got on the Main Card
description: Last Dec. 12, Eugenia Williams was at ringside in Atlantic City to judge a lightweight rematch bout between Arturo Gatti and Ivan Robinson. The first fight between the highly regarded boxers had gone 10 bruising rounds, with Robinson gaining a split decision, and the rematch was just as brutal. Williams scored it 97-92 for Robinson in what was a unanimous decision for the promising Philadelphian.

title: Democrats Ask Whitman To Withdraw Court Choice
description: Senate Democrats stepped up their efforts to quash the nomination of Attorney General Peter G. Verniero to the State Supreme Court today, asking the Governor to withdraw the nomination. They also asked a court to force Mr. Verniero to release confidential documents about his involvement in five controversial cases, including the investigation into racial profiling by state police.

title: HOUSE G.O.P. CHIEFS FORGOING REVISION OF SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Republican leaders in the House have abandoned the idea of making fundamental changes in Social Security before the next election, just as the top Republicans on the House Ways and Means Committee are putting the final touches on a plan to base the retirement program partly on private investments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORDLINGER, ALAN
description: NORDLINGER-Alan. 87. Died Sunday, April 18, 1999. Leaves behind his wife, Annetta, and her family; his children, Steve, Joan and James; their spouses, Carol, Steve and Michelle; his grandchildren, Alejandro, Jacob and Samuel; and a niece, Yvonne, and her husband, Charles Cannon. Respected attorney and partner at Guggenheimer & Untermeyer, valued for his integrity and insight. Actively participated in the New York Real Estate Board and the New York Bar Association. Past President of the Shorefront YM-YWHA of Brighton-Manhattan Beach. Past Vice President, Board of Education, East Williston School District, and Past President of North Shore Community Arts Center. A veteran of World War II. With love. We are proud of you.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: I Trulli, the Marzovilla family's Apulian and southern Italian restaurant on East 27th Street, has a new chef. He is Mauro Mafrici, a native of Trieste, in northern Italy.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Amy Fisher Apologizes to Her Victim and Could Be Released Soon
description: With tears in her eyes, Amy Fisher apologized today to Mary Jo Buttafuoco for shooting her in the face seven years ago when she was having an affair with Mrs. Buttafuoco's husband, Joey.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Alexander Ross

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Bankers, Too, Chart Internet's Stratosphere
description: The quickest way for a chief executive to bolster his company's stock price, it appears, is to announce a connection to the Internet. In recent weeks, the banking industry has become accustomed to such announcements -- and with the associated stock-trading frenzy.

title: A Series of Their Own
description: FOR three days in January, men were shut out of the Road Atlanta race track in Georgia. All the drivers were women, there to vie for a place in an automotive league of their own: the new Women's Global GT Series.

title: Vegetarian Fare
description: Vegetarian dishes are often thought to be dull products of dogmatic chefs, served in places that sacrifice flavor for a cause. These 12 restaurants, though, which are not strictly vegetarian, do wonderful things with vegetables. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: What Makes Us Human
description: To the Editor:

title: World Trade Study Says Export Growth May Slow Further
description: The rate of growth in world merchandise exports fell to 3.5 percent last year, only one-third of its 1997 growth rate of 10.5 percent, mainly because of the Asian economic crisis, the World Trade Organization said here today.

title: RJR Nabisco Earnings Slid By 54% in the First Quarter
description: In its final quarter as an international tobacco and food company, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell 54 percent because of costs to settle tobacco litigation and declining cigarette sales.

title: History Soldiering On
description: In the wake of any war come questions, dazed, wondering questions. What, finally, did we gain from fighting? What did we learn? Why did this conflict have to happen in the first place?

title: U.S. Confirms It Will Keep Deadly Virus Cells
description: President Clinton's decision to retain samples of smallpox virus in the United States is likely to lead to more scientific cooperation and biological research with Russia at a time of badly strained relations, Administration officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, MILTON
description: ROSENBLATT - Milton. (Milton Rose), of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Elmont, NY. Passed away April 18, 1999. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Babette. Loving father of Richard Ross and Kenneth Rosenblatt. Wonderful father-in-law of Renda and Betty. Cherished grandfather of Lorin, Seth, Allison & Tiphanie. Beloved brother of Moe, Miriam and the late Saul. He will always be remembered as a charmer.

title: Even Triviality Has Its Occasional Place
description: Rossini's ''Comte Ory'' is seldom seen in New York, the last major performances having been those staged by the New York City Opera in 1980 and by the inventive Opera Francais de New York in 1993. That is probably as it should be, ''Le Comte Ory'' being both flimsy and long, though by no means bereft of the charm and vocal fireworks that make Rossini worth enduring at all.

title: Back to the Shadows Of Sacco and Vanzetti
description: Maxwell Anderson has always been something of a puzzle in the American theater. For one thing, many directors, actors and theatergoers are not always comfortable with blank verse. For another, Anderson's work is not easily classified; he wrote history plays (''Anne of the Thousand Days''), antiwar plays (''What Price Glory''), suspense plays (''The Bad Seed''), political plays (''Both Your Houses''), musicals (''Knickerbocker Holiday,'' with music by Kurt Weill) and social conscience plays.

title: N.F.L. Commissioner Visits Boston in Bid to Stop Patriots Move
description: Worried about losing yet another team in a big-city television market, the Commissioner of the National Football League is making a last-ditch effort to persuade Massachusetts leaders to come up with a stadium deal that would satisfy the New England Patriots and prevent a move to Hartford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COULLET, ARMAND
description: COULLET-Armand. Husband of Anita Gillette, on April 22, after a long illness. We all will miss you. Skeet

title: Albanians Find Room To Harbor Refugees
description: Fetie Rreci, at age 50, was hoping to be adopted by a nice family, but she knew she was not at her best. Her clothes were crusted with mud. She was not smelling so good. She stood in a public building with her husband, son and daughter. They had also been sleeping on the ground. They also stank.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUCKMANN, DONALD J.
description: BRUCKMANN-Donald J. January 4, 1929-April 21, 1999. A resident of New York, N.Y., and Easthampton NY. Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Animal Medical Center. Survived by his wife of 42 years, the former Polly Thudium, three nephews, William, Bruce and Kurt Bruckmann, and two nieces, Elizabeth McShane and Beverley Place. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be welcome to the Animal Medical Center in NY and the New York Botanical Garden. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, April 28 at 11AM at St. Thomas Church, 53 Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, WILLIAM J.
description: GROSSMAN-William J., died April 21, 1999, at Boca Raton, Florida. Husband of the late Marjorie. Dear brother of Irwin. Devoted father of Laurie Gioia, John and Robert Grossman. Beloved grandfather and uncle. Cherished friend of Naomi Orgel. Services Friday, April 23, 1999, at 1 PM, at Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, NY. Should friends desire, contributions to Temple Beth Sholom would be appreciated.

title: Challenge for a Good-Times Budget
description: Yesterday, before Mayor Rudolph Giuliani detailed his spending plan for the next fiscal year, he and City Council Speaker Peter Vallone reminisced companionably about the dark days when they had been forced to slash the work force and worried about whether New York City could maintain the balanced budget necessary to preserve its financial autonomy. Now the city has a $2.1 billion surplus. Both the Mayor and Mr. Vallone deserve credit for their ongoing efforts to keep the budget under control and bring down taxes.

title: Pentagon Details New Damage and Says It Is Succeeding in Demoralizing the Serbian Forces
description: As the Balkan conflict reached its 30th day, the Pentagon today offered one of its most detailed assessments of the damage that is being inflicted on Yugoslav military and police forces, saying that NATO was succeeding in isolating and demoralizing those forces.

title: Late to DiMaggio Orbit, but Staging Send-Off
description: THIS story starts with the heel spur, the one in Joe DiMaggio's right foot, that sidelined him for 65 games in the Yankees' 1949 season and then sent him, 41 years later, to the office of Dr. Rock

title: Kosovars Relocated to U.S. Would Be Eligible to Remain
description: A White House plan to bring 20,000 refugees from Kosovo to the United States will make all of them eligible for permanent legal residence, a senior Administration official said yesterday. He said the Clinton Administration expects that many of the refugees will choose, after the war in Yugoslavia ends, not to go back to Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNERSON, DEBORAH C. (NEE SALZBERG)
description: SNERSON-Deborah C. (nee Salzberg). Adored wife of the late Morris H. Devoted mother of Roberta Troeder & the late Roger A. Much loved mother-in-law of Jane Snerson and the late Louis Troeder. Cherished Nana of Betsy and Denise Troeder, Margot (Snerson) Podtburg and Sarah (Snerson) Luginbuhl. Delighted G.G. of Russell A. and Myles S. Luginbuhl and Adam T. & Rachael N. Podtburg. Loving sister of the late Jessie Pinsly & Murray Salzberg. Treasured sister-in-law, special aunt and great-aunt. Services are private. Contributions made to the Autism Society of Rhode Island Inc., 86 Mt. Hope Ave., Providence R.I. 02906, or Beth El Synagogue, North Field Road at North Ave., New Rochelle, New York 10804.

title: Clinton Seeks to Console Students but Falters
description: With two dozen students as his sounding board, President Clinton puzzled today over the causes of school violence and mulled how to prevent it. But in the end, he could not guarantee the students the protection they sought from the kind of fatal chaos that erupted on Tuesday in Littleton, Colo., where 14 high school students and a teacher lay dead amid bombs and guns.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: The Tony Show Is a Mystery Too

title: State Prosecutor to Take Over Inquiry Into Death of a Man in Police Custody
description: A spokesman for the State Attorney General's office said today that it had decided to ''supersede'' the Essex County Prosecutor's office in the investigation of the death of a man in police custody on Sunday.

title: U.S. Professional Circuit Signs 100
description: Track and field, a once-amateur sport that has become professional at the elite level, plans to run a springtime pro circuit in the United States.

title: Tightrope for Republicans on Campaign Finance
description: When Democrats lined up on the floor of the House last week to sign a petition that would force Republican leaders to allow a vote on campaign finance legislation, Representative Christopher Shays, one of the bill's two authors, was among them, or rather beside them, thanking them for their support, even shaking their hands.

title: NATO and a New Europe
description: The caterers and champagne producers may be disappointed that NATO has scaled back its 50th anniversary gathering in Washington this week because of the conflict in Kosovo, but the alliance need not mourn the change. After unsuccessfully seeking a new purpose since the end of the cold war, NATO has found a difficult but worthy challenge in Yugoslavia.

title: A Farcical 'No' (Meaning No, and, Yes, a Pun on Noh)
description: The notion that history will sooner or later repeat itself as farce is given an intriguing twist in the Canadian director Robert Lepage's amusingly knotty film ''No.'' It isn't just repeated history that can be ludicrous, the film asserts. It can be pretty silly the first time around, especially when recalled a decade later by the people who lived through it.

title: Off Welfare, Life Is Still Tough
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth's Bloom Is Not Wasted On Dancers, Program Shows
description: Bette Midler revealed herself as a demure closet ballerina when she performed at the gala benefit for the Ballet Tech school on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Sketch of Killers: Contradictions and Confusion
description: It was just 11 weeks ago that a court officer released Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold early from a juvenile diversion program, saying they had learned the intended lessons in the months since their arrest and had promising futures.

title: Sykora Shows Veterans How It's Done in Playoffs
description: The Devils' Stanley Cup run in 1998 lasted six games. Petr Sykora played in two of them. It was difficult to blame him for the stunning first-round ouster by the Ottawa Senators.

title: In a Grisly 'Virtual' Game, Flesh and Blood Are Not
description: Most films that explore the possibilities of virtual reality have some aspirations to sleek science fiction. Not David Cronenberg's. His ''Existenz'' has the oozing, throbbing, ghoulish hallmarks of other Cronenberg fever dreams (''Naked Lunch,'' ''The Fly''). And sometimes it even has enough coolly remote style to make them palatable. Detachment helps when a film's weapon of choice is called a gristle gun and defined this way: ''A pistol made of bone and gristle, almost like the half-decayed body of a small mammal whose snout is the barrel, and whose rigid hind leg is the trigger. Instead of bullets, the gun shoots human teeth.''

title: Truce in a turf war: Consultants to look at ways that clients' and agencies' groups can cooperate.
description: THE advertising industry has long been enamored of hyperbole in the service of size. So it was appropriate that the opening general session here yesterday of the 81st annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies was all about bigness: a big client, a big agency company and big news about a big contentious issue.

title: Swiss Bank Says Profits Rose 21%
description: UBS A.G. of Switzerland, Europe's largest bank in terms of assets, reported yesterday that its profit climbed 21 percent, to 1.62 billion Swiss francs ($1.08 billion), in the first quarter, partly because of a rebound at its Warburg Dillon Read investment-banking unit. The company also said it had repurchased 1 percent of its shares in the open market since March 12.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Chuck Nanney

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIR, MINNIE
description: SCHNEIR-Minnie. On April 21, 1999, at the age of 93. Beloved wife of the late Saul M. Schneir, mother of Harriette Ruden and the late Alan Shaw, grandmother of Ed and Rich Ruden, and great grandmother. We will always love you.

title: Crossing Borders in Songs and Readings
description: The alluringly titled Opulent Music series at the Miller Theater is meant to show an alternative history of 20th-century music. In this version, a lush Romanticism based on Wagner's harmonic expansions and the chromaticism of the French Impressionists remained dominant, and the musical skies were unclouded by Serialism and the neo-Classical and neo-Romantic responses to it. It is a celebration of music that slipped between the cracks and is now staking a claim to our attention. In the current climate of musical reconsideration that claim is plausible, as is the central tenet of the series that this music is both innovative and seductive.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: William Kentridge

title: Kick Up Your Heels! Housework Can Be A Whole Lot of Fun
description: Ralph Bartholomew Jr. united two important inventions of this century: the strobe light and the active American woman. He did not invent either of these but put them together in a winsome photographic way, with the active woman in her unmentionables yet. This ingenious combination is one aspect of Bartholomew's advertising photographs at the Keith De Lellis Gallery uptown.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCCALL, DAVID AND PENNY
description: McCALL-David and Penny. The family gratefully acknowledges the outpouring of love and remembrances. Memorial services will be held Friday, May 7th, at 11AM at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 Odell Clark Place, New York City (formerly 132 W. 138 St, between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and Malcolm X Blvd., also known as 7th Avenue and Lenox Ave.). Donations in honor of David and Penny may be made to either Refugees International or 14 Angels, Inc., C/O Susan Pollack, Shepardson Stern + Kaminsky, 568 Broadway, 11th Floor, New York, New York 10012.

title: The Candidate: Dirty Tricks and Even Dirtier Minds
description: ''I really must insist you help me win the election tomorrow,'' declares Tracy Flick (Reese Witherspoon), a tough little cookie running for president of her high school in Omaha. Unfortunately, she's praying at the time. Doesn't matter. Tracy sees herself as the class winner and she brooks no interference. She finds it best to talk to everyone that way.

title: What Was Behind Colorado Shooting?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARNA, EDWARD J.
description: SARNA-Edward J. On April 20, 1999 at 76. Beloved husband of Phoebe (nee Jacobs). Loving father of Barry, Randy and Marie. Grandfather of three.

title: Casting Henry James as an Artistic Cad
description: A PRIVATE LIFE OF HENRY JAMES

title: Netanyahu Sees Enemies All Around Him
description: There was a deserted quality to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's offices last Friday afternoon, several hours before the Sabbath. It magnified the sense that Mr. Netanyahu, surrounded by bodyguards, is alone at the top.

title: Silas Turns Disarray Into Hornets' Delight
description: The hottest team in the National Basketball Association is a crew full of castoffs, a coach and players who have been disregarded or underappreciated for a significant stretch of their careers. But after winning their last nine games and turning a once-pathetic season into a potential joy ride, Paul Silas and his Charlotte Hornets can no longer be discounted.

title: Old Diary Plays Role in New York Court's Attempt to Resolve Accusations of Nazi Past
description: The crumbling pages of a German soldier's wartime diary are at the center of a new dispute in the Government's case against Jack Reimer, a retired Brooklyn businessman accused of hiding his Nazi past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, WILLIAM
description: GROSSMAN - William. Officers and Directors of the Clothing Mfrs. Ass'n. of the USA mourn the loss of William Grossman, retired president of Grossman Clothing Co. A drama student, Bill switched from opening lines to line openings, winning respect and esteem for his wit and wisdom and as a strong supporter of industry and humanitarian causes. Deepest condolences to his brother and long-time partner, Irwin, and to the Grossman family. Homi B. Patel, President Harvey J. Weinstein, Board Chairman Robert A. Kaplan, Executive Director Bernard Ferster, Counsel

title: Van Gundy Remains Standing, but the Ground Is Unstable
description: Jeff Van Gundy was working a roll of ankle tape in his hand. He had walked down a gray hallway inside Madison Square Garden, flipping the roll against the wall and catching it as he made his way to an interview room.

title: P.& G. Profit Up 8.2% in Quarter
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the nation's largest maker of household products, said today that its third-quarter profit rose 8.2 percent but warned that continued slow sales abroad would hold fourth-quarter profit below forecasts.

title: Cleaner Air Over the Parks
description: As Earth Days go, yesterday was uneventful except for one important decision by the Clinton Administration that will improve visibility in the country's wilderness and its national parks. The decision, announced by Vice President Gore during a visit to Virginia's Shenandoah National Park, gives states a firm, if distant, deadline for eliminating the smoggy haze that now ruins many of the country's most famous scenic views.

title: Xerox Reports 14% Increase in Earnings
description: The Xerox Corporation said today that first-quarter earnings rose 14 percent, mostly through cost cuts, though its stock fell because revenue did not increase.

title: Players and W.N.B.A. Call Off the Agreement
description: The Women's National Basketball Association announced yesterday that the agreement in principle it reached last week with the players union had fallen apart and, as a result, it was postponing next Tuesday's draft.

title: Strong I.B.M. Report Helps Propel Dow to Another High
description: I.B.M.'s strong profit report helped propel the stock market to another big advance yesterday as large growth stocks, which had fallen out of favor as perhaps too expensive just a couple of weeks ago, continued to rebound.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Ralph J. Perk, 85, a Republican Who Led Cleveland in the 1970's
description: Ralph J. Perk, the hard-luck Mayor of Cleveland whose misfortunes included accidentally setting his own hair on fire at a ceremonial appearance, died on Wednesday at the Cleveland Clinic Hospice unit of the Corinthian Skilled Nursing Center in Westlake, Ohio. He was 85.

title: Profit at Nokia Rises Sharply; Ericsson's Income Falls by Half
description: Nokia of Finland, the world's largest cellular phone maker, bolstered its first-quarter profit with smaller, stylish and more affordable phones, while earnings at a big rival, Ericsson of Sweden, dropped as Ericsson struggled to keep up.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Royal Philips Reports Small Quarterly Gain
description: Royal Philips Electronics N.V., Europe's largest consumer electronics maker, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 1.3 percent, beating analysts' expectations, as the company cut losses at its mobile phone business. Profit from operations, excluding gains from the sale of a components business, rose to 325 million euros ($345 million) from 321 million euros a year ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, MOLLIE (NEE KAHN)
description: LEVY-Mollie (nee Kahn), on April 21st, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Jacques M. Levy. Loving mother of Edna Doigan (Paul) of Schenectady, NY, Vivian Pollock (Elliott) of Chevy Chase, MD and Joel H. Levy (Felecia) of Chevy Chase, MD. Also survived by 9 devoted grandchildren and 16 adored great-grandchildren. Service Friday, April 23rd, 1:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment at Mt. Hebron Cemetery. Shiva will be observed at her late residence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, HAROLD J.
description: ROSEN-Harold J. Passed away April 21, 1999. Of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Lawrence, L.I. Loving husband of Jeanette to whom he was married fifty years. Adored father of Sheldon (Hope) Rosen and Vicki Bloom. Cherished grandfather of Ashleigh Bloom. Services on Sunday, April 25, 1999, at 1 P.M. at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton. For further information, call toll free 1-800-992-9262.

title: Study Questions Gene Influence on Male Homosexuality
description: Underscoring the difficulty scientists face in finding genes that underlie complex human behaviors, a team of researchers reported today that they had been unable to confirm a widely publicized study linking male homosexuality to a small region of one chromosome.

title: Potatoes Jazzed Up By Twists So Tangy
description: Being old-fashioned has started to bother Wilco, the band from Chicago that started a sold-out two-night stand at Irving Plaza on Tuesday night.

title: Audacious Charmer
description: When Francois Truffaut was sent to a juvenile detention center at the request of his parents in 1948, his first letter home requested the essentials: jam, and his files on Charlie Chaplin and Orson Welles. In retrospect, it's clear why that would sustain him. By the time his stay at the Observation Center for Minors was immortalized on film, fictionalized 11 years later at the end of ''The 400 Blows,'' he had acquired an encyclopedic film education (after making three earlier short films) and weathered enough turmoil and amour to tell stories laced with precocious wisdom. He began his feature filmmaking career with enough experience and subtle finesse to last a lifetime.

title: Though Far From Colorado, One High School Is Feeling a Sense of the Terror
description: They are two days and 1,650 miles removed from the death and disbelief consuming Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., but in the minds of students at Somers High School here in northern Westchester County, visions of the carnage linger.

title: What Was Behind Colorado Shooting?
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Wild, Wild Hollywood

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: Shootings Firm Up Gun Control Cause, At Least for Present
description: With gun manufacturers already on the defensive over lawsuits and other challenges, outrage over the nation's worst high school shooting in memory is suddenly altering the gun debate, bolstering, for the time being, the political power of gun control advocates.

title: Giuliani Budget Proposal Calls for Tax Cuts
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a $35.3 billion spending plan for New York City yesterday, emphasizing tax cuts, school vouchers and other initiatives favored by the national Republican Party at a time when he has all but declared himself a candidate for the United States Senate.

title: Chef Finds A Recipe For Love: It's a Dog
description: Can a leering, chicken-chested twerp who does the worst Neil Diamond impersonation you've ever seen win the heart of a beautiful, cultivated French cellist? In Hollywood comedies where adolescent arrested development is celebrated as an exalted state, no pubescent daydream is beyond realization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAMSI, HAIDER H., M.D.
description: SHAMSI-Haider H., M.D. The faculty and staff of the Sloane Hospital for Women, Columbia-Presbyterian Center, mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague, Dr. Haider Shamsi. During the years of his education in Pakistan, Kenya and England, he was elected to Fellowship of the Royal College of OB/GYN, England, in recognition of his continued academic career in OB/GYN. He joined the St. Luke's/Roosevelt Hospital in 1978, and was appointed Director of Obstetrics there. Later, he joined the faculty at Columbia's Sloane Hospital for Women, where he taught residents and students and worked in the various outreach programs. Always interested in scholarly activities, Dr. Shamsi was a warm, empathetic gentleman beloved by everyone who had the opportunity to know and work with him. Our deepest sympathy to his family at this terrible time of loss. Roger A. Lobo, M.D., Chairman

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Next Stop: Big Adventure

title: Birth of Land-Assault Plan Darkens Already Grim Eve of Summit
description: On the eve of the opening of the NATO summit here, President Clinton and NATO leaders vowed to intensify the military and economic punishment of Serbia even as they reserved judgment on a possible peace proposal from Belgrade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, MAUDE E.
description: MARTIN-Maude E. Of Darien, CT at the age of 107 on April 15, 1999. Wife of the late John Leon Martin. Mother of Sheila Martin and the late John Eddy Martin. Private burial was held at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx.

title: Foreign Affairs; Stop the Music
description: It is said that a camel is a horse designed by a committee. It may not be pretty but it gets the job done, especially in the desert.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the special Museums section on Wednesday about the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame and Museum misstated the history of site selection for the hall's annual induction ceremony. The event was in Cleveland in 1997; New York City and Los Angeles have not been the sole sites.

title: A Charitable Safari
description: To the Editor:

title: Buckle Up for Romantic Turbulence
description: ''Pushing Tin'' betrays its origins as a magazine article (in The New York Times Magazine) with more atmosphere and data than built-in story. As it describes the stressful lives of air traffic controllers in the New York area, it makes no automatic point beyond noting that the work is demanding and crazy. But as directed by Mike Newell, it gets past its initial ''M*A*S*H''-style comic chaos and becomes a four-character story with four characters worth watching. Mr. Newell's ensemble timing and breezily sardonic style make it work better than might be expected.

title: Gateway Says Profit Rose 31% in Quarter
description: Gateway Inc., the direct marketer of personal computers, reported yesterday that its profits increased 31 percent in the first quarter, slightly ahead of Wall Street estimates.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Blacks, Citing Bias at Work, Sue Coca-Cola
description: A group of black employees filed a class-action lawsuit today accusing the Coca-Cola Company of discriminating against African-Americans in pay, promotions and performance evaluations.

title: On My Mind; Secrets of the War
description: The train pulls in and the refugees are herded out. Then they are sold to waiting merchants, into slavery.

title: SNAP-ON AGREES TO BUY SANDVIK'S SAW AND TOOL BUSINESS
description: The hand tool maker Snap-On Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the saw and tool business of Sandvik A.B. of Sweden for $393 million. Sandvik Saws and Tools, which makes hand tools for professional users, had annual sales of $319 million last year. With the sale, Sandvik is narrowing its focus to three main businesses: tooling, specialty steel, and mining and construction. Snap-On, based in Kenosha, Wis., makes mechanics' tools, diagnostics and shop equipment. It had 1998 sales of $1.77 billion, with sales in North America and Europe accounting for $1.1 billion and about $357 million respectively. Snap-on estimates that the combined company would have 1998 sales of $2.1 billion.

title: Nation's Legacy, Icon By Icon
description: ''The American Century: Art and Culture, 1900-1950,'' which opens today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is the first half of a two-part marathon end-of-an-era survey and a show of substantial if limited pleasures.

title: A Grim NATO Summit
description: NATO leaders vowed to intensify the campaign against Serbia, while reserving judgement on a possible peace feeler. Page A10.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORD, JERE W. JR, M.D.
description: LORD-Jere W. Jr, M.D. On April 20, 1999 of Bedford, New York. Vascular Surgeon. A pioneer of heart surgery. A Professor of Clinical Medicine at University Hospital. Graduate of Gilman School, Princeton University 1932 & Johns Hopkins Medical School 1937. Member of The American College of Surgeons, The American Surgical Association, The Southern Surgical Association, The Eastern Surgical Society, President in 1982, James IV Association of Surgeons, Assistant Secretary from 1965 to 1967 and Secretary from 1967 to 1975. New York Heart Association, President from 1957 to 1959. Survived by his beloved wife Margot Graham Lord. Loving father of Harrah Lord Argentine, Jere W. Lord, III & Lonna Lord Davis. Also survived by six grandchildren. Memorial service at Saint Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford, New York, on Friday, April 23 at 11AM. Interment is private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Hospice Care in Westchester, 100 South Bedford Road, Mount Kisco, New York 10549.

title: Lazard to Pay $11 Million To Settle Federal Charges
description: Lazard Freres & Company, the Wall Street investment bank, agreed yesterday to pay $11 million to settle Federal charges for its role in an industrywide scandal of overcharging in the sale of billions of dollars worth of bonds in the early 1990's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, ELLA
description: AUERBACH-Ella. On April 20, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Richard. Loving mother of Brigitte Prusoff and Robert Auerbach. Sister of Bernhard Heiden and the late Margaret Sterne. Grandmother of Laura and Alvin Prusoff and Emily and Richard Auerbach. Great-grandmother of Sarah, Douglas and Zachary Prusoff, David, Beth, Robert, Rachel and Sophie Auerbach, Melanie Meyer and Adam Stahl. Service Sunday 1:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILBERIS, ELIZABETH
description: TILBERIS-Elizabeth (Liz). On behalf of the Board of Directors and staff of The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, Inc. (OCRF), we deeply mourn the passing of our beloved friend and President, Liz Tilberis. Liz Tilberis was an extraordinary woman and a visionary leader. Her commitment and dedication to raising funds for research and educating women has brought OCRF to new heights of excellence and has propelled ovarian cancer into the public eye. The courage and grace with which she fought ovarian cancer is an inspiration to all women battling the disease. With all that she has done, we are certainly closer to conquering this devastating illness. We will miss her terribly. Carmel J. Cohen, MD, Chair Sol Schreiber, Founder & Co-Chair Jamie Boris, Executive Director Board of Directors, OCRF

title: Grizzle Leads Florida To Victory in Relay
description: For Tamieka Grizzle, it was a double homecoming. She comes from the Bronx and spent her first two college years at nearby Villanova, so when she ran yesterday for Florida in the Penn Relays in Philadelphia, she had plenty of support in the stands.

title: People
description: * Andy Fenning was named to the new position of chief learning officer at J. Walter Thompson New York, part of the J. Walter Thompson Worldwide unit of WPP Group P.L.C. He had been executive vice president and director for worldwide strategic planning.

description: EUROPE

title: Peace Infuses Grant's Tomb
description: Despite the fame of its presiding spirit, its prominent site, its view of the Hudson and the joke about who's buried there, Grant's Tomb (above) may be one of the least visited places in New York.

title: An Abundant Mahler Harvest Ends, Lingering in the Mind Like the Music
description: So the ''Lied von der Erde'' season, which was peculiar to begin with, ends prematurely on Sunday, when James Levine conducts the Met Orchestra in that Mahler masterpiece at Carnegie Hall. Their performance of this imposing work is the fourth in New York since October, when the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented it in Schoenberg's arrangement for chamber orchestra, conducted by David Golub at Alice Tully Hall. Seiji Ozawa and the Boston Symphony presented Mahler's original in November at Carnegie, as did Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic in February at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Leiter Calmly Proves That He's Still in Control
description: There is a popular saying in sports: Act like you've been there before. Still, it would have been understandable if Al Leiter were a little more excited than he seemed tonight.

description: Sue Coe

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Caracas Journal; The Squatters Have Their Day, Shaking Venezuela
description: Until a few weeks ago, Elena Vasquez and her six children lived in a single cramped rented room here. But now she and thousands of other poor Venezuelans inspired by their new President's promises of social justice have seized vacant buildings and plots of land, upgrading their own housing while setting off a passionate national debate about property rights.

title: Tobacco Lawyers Look at Bonds to Speed Fees
description: A group of plaintiffs' lawyers, including some who have already been awarded billions of dollars in fees for representing states in tobacco lawsuits, are exploring the possibility of having bonds issued so they can collect the money faster.

title: Raze School System, Giuliani Says
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sparked yet another test of his personally warm but professionally cool relationship with Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew yesterday by resurrecting his school voucher proposal and by peppering his budget address with criticisms of a school system that he said should be ''blown up.''

title: CBS Agrees to Buy a Stake in Office.com
description: The CBS Corporation agreed yesterday to buy a 33 percent stake in Office.com, an on-line business service owned by Winstar Communications, in exchange for $42 million in advertising and promotion.

title: Seoul's Leader Irked by Opposition Criticism at U.N. Over Rights
description: President Kim Dae Jung has been lionized around the world for his lifetime of struggle for human rights in Korea, and he is often mentioned as a candidate for the Nobel Peace Prize because of his efforts to achieve peace and democracy on the Korean peninsula.

title: Of Course the Mind Can Heal the Body
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRUNG, ANITA
description: SPRUNG-Anita, on April 21st. Beloved wife of the late Norman. Devoted mother of Lauren Siegel, and Leslie and Erich Bennett. Adored grandmother of Lloyd, Brooke, Samantha and Taylor. Dear sister of Julian and Kari Spitz. Services Friday, 1PM, ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI.

title: U.S. Inquires Why Suspect At Atom Lab Kept Access
description: Energy Secretary Bill Richardson is investigating how a computer scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory kept his access to United States nuclear secrets long after he was suspected of being a Chinese spy, officials said tonight.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell as traders played down the likelihood that finance ministers would try to influence the dollar-yen exchange rate when they meet next week. In New York, the dollar fell to 119.52 yen from 119.73.

title: PROFITS DOWN, SCHLUMBERGER WILL CUT 2,500 MORE JOBS
description: Schlumberger Ltd., the world's second-largest oilfield services company, said yesterday that it would cut 2,500 more jobs by the end of June as first-quarter profit fell 53 percent. The company said it had already cut 7,500 jobs, or 11 percent of its work force, since July, as slumping oil prices reduced demand for its services. It expects the latest cuts to help it save $300 million a year, on top of $300 million in annual savings achieved by last year's cuts. Although first-quarter crude oil prices rallied from December's 12-year low, they still averaged 17 percent less than a year earlier and oil-company spending remained depressed. Schlumberger's shares rose $3.25, to $63.625.

title: Ayala Considers Options Inside the Ring and Out
description: The afternoon sun glinted off the water in the swimming pool as Tony Ayala Jr. basked in his second full day of freedom. After being released from the Bayside State Prison in Leesburg, N.J., on Tuesday following 16 years behind bars for a rape he committed on New Year's Day 1983, Ayala, a former No. 1 junior middleweight contender, can now turn his attention to the future.

title: Bankrupt Athletic Club Gets Deal to Pay Debt and Stay Put
description: The Downtown Athletic Club, the bankrupt private gymnasium that is home to college football's Heisman Trophy, has reached an agreement with its creditors that will let the club stay in its Art Deco building near the southern tip of Manhattan.

The three finalists in the review, which began in March, are Ingalls in Boston; Jordan McGrath Case & Partners/Euro RSCG in New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, and Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass. A decision is expected in May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLINS, DR. PAUL F.
description: BELLINS-Dr. Paul F., 90, died April 21, 1999 in Troy, NY. Professor of marketing at Pace University 25 years. Survived by wife Mary (Riley) of Troy; brother John of Delhi, NY; sister Frances Bonamico of Brooklyn; nieces and nephews. Funeral and burial in Cambridge, NY under the direction of Ackley & Ross Funeral Home.

description: CUSHING-Mary Margaret (Loring), of Beverly Farms, Massachusetts, on April 20, 1999. Wife of the late Boston photographer George M. Cushing. She is survived by her four children: Margaret C. Cushing of New York City, George L. Cushing of Beverly Farms, Edward B. Cushing of Ipswich & John D. Cushing of Essex; five grandchildren: G.L. Cushing Jr., Matthew S. Cushing, Amelia C. Cushing, Mae L. Cushing and Samuel A. Cushing; and a great granddaughter, Isobel Brewster Cushing. Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, April 24, at 3 P.M. in St. John Episcopal Church, Hale St., Beverly Farms. Relatives and friends invited. Burial private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Animal Rescue League of Boston, MA. 02117. For more information, contact J.S. title: Banca di Roma Rejects A Takeover Offer
description: Banca di Roma S.p.A., the target of a $9.7 billion all-share bid from San Paolo-IMI, Italy's largest bank, rejected the offer yesterday and gave management a mandate to seek another merger partner. Banca di Roma called the all-share bid ''absolutely unsatisfying'' and said it based its criticisms on the share exchange ratio, forecast results, shareholders' interests and corporate governance.

title: A Survival Tale In the Ice Floes
description: An engrossing if partial account of an incredible feat of survival, Frank Hurley's film ''South: Ernest Shackleton and the Endurance Expedition'' (1919) also must rank as one of the better dog movies.

description: CROWLEY-Jane. On April 21, 1999. Beloved cousin of Mildred McDermott Cavanaugh. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Friday, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Blessed Sacrament Church, 152 West 71 Street, Saturday, 11 AM. Interment Ellicottville, New York.

title: Back From Belgrade, Congressman Says NATO Is Worsening Refugee Crisis
description: Just back from a stealthy three-day mission of personal diplomacy to Belgrade, Representative Jim Saxton of New Jersey asserted today that the NATO bombing had succeeded mainly in hurting Serbian civilians and worsening the refugee crisis in Kosovo, but not in weakening the Yugoslav military.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELL, DENNIS GARY
description: MANDELL-Dennis Gary. I love you so, we will always be together. ''The Mandell Brothers'' we are the champions of the world. No one can overcome us, we are each other's backbone. You will live forever. Don't ever let go. Mandell Mandell by Arnold

title: Brazilians Raise $2 Billion in Sale of Notes
description: With strong demand from investors, Brazil sold $2 billion of five-year notes yesterday, finishing the first leg of a bond sale that could hit $3 billion, three times the original size.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on April 11 about The Daily News's recent financial setbacks referred incompletely to circulation at The New York Post. While The Post's circulation decreased from March 1992 to March 1994, its daily circulation has since increased in each twice-yearly reporting period, reaching 437,467 in September 1998. Since 1996, when The Post began Sunday publication, its Sunday circulation has increased, not decreased; it stood at 382,382 last September.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Baroness Batsheva de Rothschild yesterday misstated her relationship to Baron James de Rothschild. She was his great-granddaughter, not his granddaughter.

title: A Narrow Victory Leaves Questions for U.S. Women
description: With the women's World Cup approaching in June, the United States appeared to have lost its scoring touch and any certainty that it was still head and shoulders above every other team in the tournament.

title: Portraits of 12 Killed At the Colorado School
description: Following is biographical information about 11 students and 1 teacher killed on Tuesday at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo. One other student, Kyle Velasquez, was killed, but neither information nor a photograph were available.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: PADE COOLEY AND THE WESTERN SWING DANCE GANG: ''Shame on You'' (Bloodshot). It's funny that Bloodshot, a Chicago independent label devoted to roughing up country music for a generation used to alternative rock, should be re-releasing the music of Spade Cooley. Cooley was a western-swing band leader who, during the music's greatest point of popularity in the 1940's, devoted considerable musicianly skill to creating the smoothest, sweetest band in the two-step business. Cooley's band, based in California, stood in contrast to Milton Brown's Musical Brownies, Bob Wills's Western Playboys and the more jazzlike and rowdy Texas-style swing sound.

title: Accounts
description: * Digital Chef Inc., St. Helena, Calif., to Grant, Scott & Hurley, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle the account of the on-line retailer of food and kitchen ware. Billings were estimated at $15 million.
