title: Intel Planning Big Move Into Internet Services
description: The Intel Corporation, the leading maker of microchips, said yesterday that it was planning a big move into the Internet services business by building and running data centers around the world.

title: Miscellany
description: * William Morris Agency, New York, will represent two athletes in areas including commercials and endorsements. They are Lennox Lewis, heavyweight champion of the World Boxing Council, and, in conjunction with Strickland & Ashe, Washington, Daunte Culpepper, the University of Central Florida quarterback who was the first-round draft choice of the Minnesota Vikings.

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS SAYS IT REJECTED OFFER FROM SARA LEE
description: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, the New York-based coffee maker, said yesterday that it had received a bid for the company of $10.50 a share, or $113 million, by the Sara Lee Corporation, but it rejected the offer, calling it an attempt to acquire a competitor at an unfair price. Marvin I. Haas, chief executive at Chock Full o'Nuts, said Sara Lee's proposal ''fails to adequately value the strength of the Chock Full o'Nuts brand.'' Sara Lee, based in Chicago, disclosed in a regulatory filing that it had acquired a 5.3 percent stake in Chock Full o'Nuts and was seeking to buy the rest. Chock Full o'Nuts stock closed yesterday at $6.375, up 37.5 cents.

title: Adauction.com Expanding Services
description: Adauction.com in San Francisco, which operates an on-line service for buying and selling ad space in interactive media, is expanding into traditional media by starting divisions for print and broadcast. The company plans to hold its first on-line auction of print media today, selling regional ad space in national magazines, and to add auctions of broadcast commercial time later this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERGEEV, MICHAEL
description: SERGEEV-Michael. On April 22, 1999, of cancer. Despite multiple personal catastophes, he never lost his dreams of America.

title: Knicks Players Are Puzzled By the Fining of Sprewell
description: In his first act as president and general manager of the Knicks on Wednesday, Dave Checketts fined Latrell Sprewell $25,000 for comments made by his agent, Robert Gist, that criticized the way that Sprewell was being used and were also critical of Ernie Grunfeld and Jeff Van Gundy. Checketts also told Charlie Ward that he would not accept the guard's using the locker room as a pulpit.

title: What Was Behind Colorado Shooting?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Country Gentleman's Broadway Visits; Or, How a Kentucky Colonel Assembles a Summer Stock Cast
description: The name -- Col. Eben C. Henson -- conjures up images from Faulkner, of a grand Southern gentleman with a hunting dog at his feet.

title: CANANDAIGUA BRANDS AGREES TO BUY FRANCISCAN ESTATES
description: Canandaigua Brands Inc., a maker and distributor of wine, beer and spirits, agreed yesterday to acquire the vintner Franciscan Estates for $220 million. It will also assume about $20 million in debt. Canandaigua said Franciscan's 1998 sales were about $50 million on volume of about 600,000 cases of wine. Franciscan's sales have grown more than 17 percent a year since 1995. Canandaigua will manage both Franciscan Estates and Simi Winery, which it is acquiring from LVMH Moet-Hennessy Louis Vuitton, as a separate unit. Canandaigua, based in Fairport, N.Y., had sales of $1.5 billion for the year ended Feb. 28.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Ellsworth Kelly

title: Sports of The Times; The Devils Extinguish The Torch
description: JUST call him the Torch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELTER, NICOLE
description: ZELTER-Nicole. On April 21, 1999. Loving daughter of Vivian and James and sister of Elizabeth. She leaves four wonderful grandparents and numerous caring aunts, uncles and cousins. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory to The Nicole Zelter Fund Greater New York March of Dimes, 233 Park Ave South, NY, NY 10003. Family will receive friends on Saturday, April 24, from 3:30-6pm at The Town Club, 9 East 86th St, NYC.

title: Can Rookie Catch It? Catch On?
description: The idea is not to drop anything.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BELDEN INC., St. Louis, an electronic wire and cable maker, said it planned to sell its Cord Products unit to Volex Group P.L.C., Warrington, England, a producer of electrical power cords and interconnect cable assemblies, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Police Say Man Beat His Wife With a Barbell
description: Enraged by the threat to end their 20-year marriage, a 58-year-old man bludgeoned his wife with a barbell as she slept in their Upper East Side town house yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Seattle's Teachers Walk Out in a Pay Protest
description: Seattle's 4,000 teachers and classroom assistants shut down the school system today by staying away from work in a one-day protest against what they called inadequate pay increases during the last six years.

title: What Was Behind Colorado Shooting?
description: To the Editor:

title: There's a Lot of Grit in Brazil; A Once-Jittery Economy Is Getting Under Self-Control
description: Three months after the largest economy in Latin America seemed on the verge of an Asian-style meltdown, provoking alarm in markets around the world, Brazil is bouncing back.

title: Broadcast Deal For Major Events
description: Mark Miles, chief executive officer of the men's ATP Tour, confirmed yesterday from Monte Carlo, Monaco the completion of a $1.2 billion deal that sells the overall television and sponsorship rights of the circuit's nine major events, currently known as the Super Nine, to ISL Worldwide, a Zurich-based sports marketing agency.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption inside section A yesterday about the arrival of American Apache helicopters in Albania located the scene incorrectly. The craft were preparing to land en route in Brindisi, Italy. They were not arriving in Albania.

title: NATO Strikes Serb State TV; Casualties Seen
description: NATO knocked Serbian state television off the air in the middle of a newscast early this morning, leaving the building that housed the main Government propaganda arm in flames, with reports of many casualties.

title: Buddy Rogers, Star of 'Wings' And Band Leader, Dies at 94
description: Charles (Buddy) Rogers, the handsome leading man and band leader who starred in ''Wings'' (1927), the first film to win an Academy Award, and who later married Mary Pickford, ''America's Sweetheart,'' died on Wednesday at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. Mr. Rogers was 94.

title: Man Arrested in Driver Attack A Suspect in Other Robberies
description: A man who has been arrested in the stabbing and robbery of a livery cab driver in Queens may be responsible for as many as a dozen similar crimes over the last year, the police said last night.

title: Of Be-Bop And a Bit Of Vaudeville
description: The defining points of American culture over the last century have often brought together a high level of esthetic sophistication with sheer entertainment. A good example of the mix is the saxophonist Lou Donaldson, one of the great living be-bop saxophonists and a barely closeted vaudevillian. At his second set on Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard, where he'll be performing through tomorrow, he sang an old novelty blues song, ''It Was Just a Dream,'' setting it up with a long story about various intoxicants, the Bronx and a half-dozen other details.

title: Cost of Guns Goes Beyond the Loss of Lives; Blaming Video Games
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about the police seizure of an inflatable 30-foot rat that union leaders use as a prop at protests referred incorrectly to the date of a demonstration at the ABC building on the Upper West Side. It was in November, not this Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Somers High School in Westchester County, N.Y., where students reacted to the Colorado killings, misstated the Somers enrollment. It is 650, not 50.

title: Thomas H. Davis Dies at 81; Founder of Piedmont Airlines
description: Thomas H. Davis, the founder of Piedmont Aviation, which grew to employ more than 20,000 people before it was acquired by USAir Group, died on Thursday at a hospital in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 81 and lived in Winston-Salem.

title: The Tactics and Psychology Of Going for the Grand Slam
description: At any form of scoring, a bidder will stop short of a grand slam if it appears to be even money at best. But if the prospects may be much better, he should venture it.

title: From 19 Nations, Messages of Thanks, Hope and Determination
description: Following are excerpts from comments yesterday at the opening of NATO's anniversary ceremonies by the leaders assembled in Washington as they signed a special proclamation. The comments were recorded by Federal News Service, a private agency:

title: Sun Eventually Shines on Ordonez
description: The game began with a stiff wind blowing in at Wrigley Field, a blinding sun in right field and the Mets' Gold Glove shortstop Rey Ordonez on the bench for the second straight day.

title: Sir Laurence Kirwan, 91; Helped Plan Ascent of Everest
description: Sir Laurence Kirwan, an archeologist and the former director of the British Royal Geographical Society, and a man for whom harsh and forbidding deserts, mountaintops and polar ice caps were irresistible attractions, died April 16 in a hospice in London. He was 91.

title: Pirate-Proof Digital Music? So Far, That Does Not Compute
description: The recording industry and electronics manufacturers are trying to hammer out a universal, pirate-proof technology for distributing commercial music to a new generation of portable digital music players. But the two sides are at such loggerheads that it may not be possible for manufacturers to meet the record industry's goal of getting authorized players onto store shelves for the Christmas season.

title: Cost of Guns Goes Beyond the Loss of Lives; No Substitute for Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Phone Talks In Europe Come Under Fire
description: Only two days after formally reaching an agreement on the biggest merger in European history, Deutsche Telekom and Telecom Italia came under attack today from Italian Government leaders, shareholders and competitors, raising doubts about the deal's future.

title: Petitgout (Who?) Is Ready To Make a Name for Himself
description: When it was time for the Giants to make their first draft pick, it was a surprise to hear the name Luke Petitgout.

title: United Airlines Has a New Union Accord
description: United Airlines, the world's largest airline, reached a tentative first contract today with its newly unionized ticket agents and reservations clerks, who are among the industry's lowest-paid workers.

title: Mercedes Opens Brazil Plant To Build A-Class Compacts
description: Betting that Brazil's car market will recover from a steep decline in sales, DaimlerChrysler A.G. opened a factory today to produce Mercedes-Benz automobiles.

title: Cost of Guns Goes Beyond the Loss of Lives; Can Hearts Kill?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The On the Road column in Weekend on April 16, about visiting St. Louis, misstated the number of American cities that had more than one major league baseball team in the World War II years. There were five, not four: Boston also had two teams, as did St. Louis, New York, Philadelphia and Chicago.

title: Official to Oppose Power Deal in Chile
description: An antitrust watchdog in Chile wants to block the $2.1 billion takeover of the nation's biggest power generator, Empresa Nacional de Electricidad S.A., by Endesa S.A. of Spain because it would put too much of the nation's energy system under one owner.

title: Economic Status Quo; A Lesson in Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: Comcast Is Seen As Unlikely To Raise Bid For Mediaone
description: Investors who had hoped that the Comcast Corporation would touch off a bidding war with a counter offer for Mediaone Group after Thursday night's surprise bid from the AT&T Corporation may be disappointed. Comcast executives told several Wall Street executives privately yesterday that it was unlikely the company would sweeten its initial offer.

title: In the New West, Violence Is Real
description: Five years ago, I spent a summer researching the wars between the United States and various Indian peoples. Most of that summer I was an insomniac, waking every night to thoughts of bleeding bodies, fractured bones and internal organs exposed to the air. Here is one of a thousand stories that made each night too long.

title: BP Amoco May Seek Tighter Sidanco Rein
description: BP Amoco P.L.C., which bought 10 percent of the Russian oil producer OAO Sidanco for $571 million in 1997, may invest more money to revive the company while tightening control over its operations. At a special shareholders meeting yesterday called by BP Amoco, Sidanco's shareholders elected Norrie Stanley, the BP Amoco vice president for Russia, Ukraine and Eastern Europe, to head Sidanco's new board as a first step ''in the process of restructuring and recapitalization.''

title: Wells's Return to Stadium Is Far From Perfect
description: David Wells badly wanted to beat the Yankees. They all knew that. But if the Boomer wanted to stick it to them, one of his former teammates said last night, that was O.K., because the Yankees wanted to stick it to him, too. Nothing personal.

title: A Military Alliance, and More
description: Our common fight in Kosovo will dominate the NATO summit that opened yesterday in Washington. I'm sure that America, Britain and all the other NATO countries will make clear our determination to see this military engagement through to the end. President Slobodan Milosevic should be in no doubt about the alliance's strength, commitment and resolve.

title: Survivors of NATO Attack On Serb TV Headquarters: Luck, Pluck and Resolve
description: After surviving a NATO missile attack on Serbian state television headquarters early this morning, an anchor, Zeljko Pantelic, said that he felt reborn, but not converted.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: It's Not Romantic or Oedipal: It's Just the Family Business
description: Toby Stephens is the son of Dame Maggie Smith, and when he was growing up in the English countryside his neighbors included Alec Guinness, Laurence Olivier and Joan Plowright. But Mr. Stephens says his childhood was ''actually very normal.''

title: Excerpts From Tape of 2 Emergency Calls at Columbine High
description: Following are excerpts from a tape of two emergency calls made from Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., after the shootings began on Tuesday, as recorded by The Associated Press:

title: Alexander Alexay, 97, Pianist and Coach
description: Alexander Alexay, a pianist who coached and accompanied opera singers and recitalists, and who worked for many years with the composer Sigmund Romberg, died on Tuesday in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 97.

title: Man Guilty of Murder In Pizza Delivery Case
description: A 20-year-old New Jersey man was convicted of murdering two pizza deliverymen he lured to an abandoned cabin in what the authorities called ''thrill killings.'' The man, Thomas Koskovich, could face the death penalty for killing the deliverymen, Jeremy Giordano and Giorgio Gallara in a wooded area of Franklin, N.J.

title: EARLY RETIREMENT TO SALARIED WORKERS IS OFFERED
description: The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest auto maker, is offering early retirement incentives to United States salaried workers as it cuts jobs to reduce costs and improve efficiency. The auto maker set no target, and the number who retire may be more or less than the 1,000 reported yesterday by The Detroit News, a spokesman, Pat Morrissey, said. Eligible employees can make their decision through Nov. 1. G.M. and its Delphi Automotive Systems unit have reduced their United States white-collar work force by 1.1 percent, to 66,439, and the hourly employment by 16 percent, to 207,302, since 1995.

title: Strawberry Resolution Nears
description: With Darryl Strawberry's career in jeopardy, a determination of his future in Major League Baseball was imminent as the Yankees headed into the weekend. Results from drug tests Strawberry took subsequent to his April 14 arrest on charges of cocaine possession and solicitation of prostitution were expected late this week, and his status could be resolved early next week.

title: Harold E. Samuel, 75, Music Librarian and Professor at Yale
description: Harold E. Samuel, a former music librarian and professor at the Yale University School of Music, died after a long illness on Tuesday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 75.

title: Grandpa Had a Hammer
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLOU HEALTH SELLS STAKE IN ITS ON-LINE UNIT
description: Allou Health and Beauty Care Inc. said yesterday that it had sold a controlling interest in its on-line unit to an investor group for $37.5 million in cash and notes. The unit, Fragrance Counter, sells perfume and beauty products. Allou, a Brentwood, N.Y., distributor of beauty and health care products, began its Internet business in 1995. Samuel Waksal, a venture capitalist and chief executive of Imclone Systems Inc., a New York biotechnology concern, leads the group. Allou said it would retain a minority stake.

title: Should Looted Works Be Published?: Dealers and Scholars In Uneasy Dilemma
description: NEW YORK  How right is it for art historians to publish works of art that may tumble into the art market, greatly enhanced by their seal of approval? The problem becomes acute when the art concerned only begins to be known through pioneering research work carried out by a few specialists who feel they can ill afford to ignore any new material.

title: At Home Abroad; Deeper Than Politics
description: ''An election in Israel is not just about politics,'' Shlomo Ben-Ami said. ''It is anthropology: one more chapter in the Kulturkampf,'' the conflict of cultures.

title: Corrections
description: A movie review in the Television section last Sunday misidentified the setting for ''Anne of Green Gables,'' which was seen on the Disney Channel Tuesday night and Wednesday morning. It is Prince Edward Island, not Nova Scotia.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: HAVE ATTACK AD, WILL TRAVEL
description: American campaign consultants have taken their sound bites, overnight polls and other weapons to Israel's life-or-death politics. Is the country ready? A report by Adam Nagourney, in The Times Magazine.

title: Editorial Notebook; Giving Public Schools a Good Name
description: Few book reviewers are paid more quickly or have a more appreciative audience than Corey Sheen. He reviews novels and nature books for the newspaper of the bookstore at Public School 161 in Brooklyn's Crown Heights neighborhood, which pays him in books. Every Wednesday morning, students can buy books for one dollar. They depend on reviews like Corey's to help them choose. At the moment he is recommending ''Salmon,'' about the fish, which in a recent review he called ''full of intriguing information'' and ''easily read and understood by young children.''

title: Spending on Balkans Opens Door to Other Tests of Limits on the Budget
description: After outdoing each other for months in their pledges not to dip into the Federal budget surplus, both parties in Congress have quickly agreed that the costs of the Balkans conflict should be an exception.

title: NATO's 50th-Anniversary Celebration Reflects Its Pride and Its Frustration
description: NATO's bifurcated commemoration day allowed for no diplomatic slack at the regular Yugoslav bombing briefing, transferred from the European war theater for the occasion.

title: A Nigerian Region Warms to an Unfavorite Son
description: Resting his feet on a table before him, the youngest of his 22 children sitting beside him, a succession of supporters prostrating themselves beneath him, Lamidi Adedibu looked very much the part he ascribes to himself: a Yoruba kingmaker.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Devils' Offensive Defenseman Slows Down Jagr
description: A convincing victory over Pittsburgh in the opening game of their Stanley Cup playoff series did not stop the Devils from holding a team meeting this morning to discuss ways of playing even better for the second game Saturday afternoon.

title: About New York; Poverty Vow Wasn't Meant To Go So Far
description: ED PHELAN took a vow of poverty when he joined the Christian Brothers, a Roman Catholic religious order. He is in no danger of breaking that sacred promise. He runs the Highbridge Community Life Center in the Bronx, directing an 80-person staff that provides welfare recipients and high school dropouts with counseling, job training and an education. It's front-line social service work that gives him more psychic income than the green kind would.

title: Chock Full o'Nuts Shares Bought After Merger Bid
description: Three directors of the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, including the chairman of the board, bought company stock in the months after they rejected an unsolicited takeover offer but before that offer was disclosed to the public. The suitor remains interested, however, and this week disclosed that it had approached the company recently, sending the stock up almost 50 percent.

title: Cost of Guns Goes Beyond the Loss of Lives; Many Empty Houses
description: To the Editor:

title: Pirates Do God's Work On Jerusalem's Airwaves
description: Wasted by drugs, his voice broken, the addict on the line begged for help from Herzl Ben-Aharon, the late-night host on an ultra-Orthodox pirate radio station, the Voice of Kindness.

title: MAY STORES PAYS $302 MILLION FOR MERCANTILE CHAIN
description: May Department Stores Inc., the owner of the Lord & Taylor, Hecht's and other chains, paid about $302 million for the 11 former Mercantile stores it bought in September from Dillard's Inc., according to a regulatory filing. The purchase price includes inventory, May said in its annual report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, the No. 4 United States department-store retailer, bought the stores to enter markets in Kansas, Indiana, Kentucky and Colorado. The purchase resulted from Dillard's efforts to eliminate redundant operations and satisfy the Federal Trade Commission regarding its acquisition of the Mercantile Stores Company in August. May operates 393 department stores.

title: Casey Feels He Deserves Nets' Job
description: The Nets have won seven of their last 12 games with William Cunningham and Jamie Feick playing center. Six of their last 10 victories came against teams that are either in the playoffs or contending for one of the final spots. All the Nets players have smiled, laughed, joked and worked hard because they enjoy and respect their coaching staff.

title: After Poor Scores, Experimental West Side School Will Close
description: In October, the superintendent of Community School District 3 in Manhattan sent a letter to the director of the West Side Community School, saying she was ''charmed'' by the ''delightful young children'' who were learning to knit as part of an experimental art-based curriculum.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose against the euro after NATO officials rejected President Slobodan Milosevic's latest attempt to end the bombing of Yugoslavia. The dollar rose to 1.0605 euros from 1.0614.

title: Paris-Based Animalier Avoids Commercial Scene : One Artist's Novel Path
description: PARIS  Ann Murchison represents the hidden facet of contemporary art, the one that barely comes out into the open and gets no publicity. How do you approach the art of someone who does not claim to belong to a movement with some slick name and takes no interest in -isms or labels of any kind?

title: A Historical Alchemist Turns Medicine Into Gold
description: The British medical historian Roy Porter was embarking on his first sabbatical in nearly three decades of frenetic teaching and writing when he fell spectacularly ill last fall. ''I got a gigantically enlarged testicle,'' he said cheerfully. What was particularly notable about his condition, which turned out to be a cluster of easily removable benign cysts, was that it was the first time he had been sick in decades.

title: European Group Cites Evidence of War Crimes
description: The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said today that it had collected testimony and other evidence that Serbian paramilitaries and bands of armed civilians have raped, killed and mutilated ethnic Albanians in Kosovo in the last month.

title: Debt-Relief Plan Is Flawed, 5 Nations Say
description: With the number of people living in absolute poverty on under $1 a day likely to reach 1.5 billion next year, five major industrialized powers -- the United States, Canada, France, Germany and Britain -- have acknowledged that a plan devised three years ago to forgive debts of the poorest countries is not working well.

title: Cost of Guns Goes Beyond the Loss of Lives; Ridicule of Outcasts
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HOGS JUMP 3.6 PERCENT. Lean hogs rose on expectations that supplies will fall in the coming weeks as farmers spend more time planting crops than selling livestock. The June contract jumped 2 cents, to 57.6 cents a pound.

title: Fans From Box Seats and Bleachers Pay Tribute to DiMaggio
description: The most private of men, Joe DiMaggio, was memorialized yesterday in the most public of places, St. Patrick's Cathedral, where his teammates from the Yankee glory years joined Manhattan's celebrity elite and baseball die-hards from the outer boroughs to say goodbye to a bona fide hero.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Continues to Climb On Strong Earnings Reports

title: Munir A. Khan, 72, Managed Nuclear Program in Pakistan
description: Munir Ahmad Khan, an administrator of Pakistan's nuclear energy programs when Pakistan was developing a nuclear weapon, died on Thursday in Vienna of complications after heart surgery. He was 72.

title: In the Universe, Are We Really No. 1?
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Are Better Off With Clemens's Magic
description: They stood on the rain-soaked bleachers in right field, trying to keep their balance as they clutched cups of beer and peered toward the third-base dugout to see David Wells swagger to the mound. It was the first inning at Yankee Stadium and the fans in the bleachers were unusually calm. But that changed dramatically when Wells emerged wearing a gray, red and blue uniform.

title: In Horrific Circumstance, Sense of Lost Pomp
description: Autumn Hettinger, 18, and her mother, Cheryl, baked a cake today to celebrate Shakespeare's birthday, just as Autumn had planned to do all along for her advanced-placement English class. She wore her special English class famous writers T-shirt that says Homer on the front and lists everyone from Chaucer to Wordsworth on the back.

title: Lemieux's Plan Is Seen As Best Bet for Penguins
description: The National Hockey League and its players union described Mario Lemieux's financial plan to bring the Pittsburgh Penguins out of bankruptcy yesterday as the best hope to keep the team from moving.

title: Rare Blake Book Sells for $2.5 Million at Sotheby's
description: A rare, magnificently illustrated, hand-printed copy of ''The First Book of Urizen'' by William Blake, which has been hidden away in a private collection for more than 50 years, was sold yesterday at Sotheby's New York for $2.5 million.

title: City Hall Notes; On Council's Budget List: More Funds to Sue Mayor
description: Flush with the largest budget surplus in New York City's history, the City Council wants to increase its own internal budget by almost 20 percent next year. Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, wants to hire more budget analysts, more community outreach workers and -- most important -- a team of litigators to represent the Council in a growing number of lawsuits against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Russia, Captive of History
description: If Russia is ever to break free of the heritage that stunts its development, it must overcome its reflexive allegiance to bloody-minded tyrants like Slobodan Milosevic and Saddam Hussein. As hard as it may be for Boris Yeltsin, he should use this critical moment in Europe to push Russia toward an enduring partnership with the West. Only then can Russia hope to build the modern economy and democracy that its people want and deserve.

title: Sounds From a Massacre: 'Oh God, Kids, Stay Down'
description: ''The school's in a panic, and I'm in the library,'' the teacher is desperately trying to explain to the police dispatcher as she begs for help. ''I've got students down.''

title: One Month: No NATO Victory, No Serb Loss
description: As NATO leaders gathered today behind closed doors to consider their next moves against Yugoslavia, the alliance's commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, offered a strikingly optimistic view of the progress so far. ''We are winning,'' he declared today. ''He is losing. And he knows it.''

title: Guns in School Shootings Are Identified
description: Officials said four weapons were involved in the Littleton shootings -- a 9-millimeter pistol and a carbine, both of which were initially bought in Colorado, and two older sawed-off shotguns.

title: Gandhi Party's Bid for Power Dissolves as Votes Slip Away
description: The dream of the Congress Party to once again govern this nation of 980 million people by itself, with a member of the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty to lead them, turned out to be a mirage today.

title: Atom Agency Tries to Avoid Financing Fallout Drug
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has quietly backed away from its offer to give states with nuclear power plants stockpiles of a drug that cuts the risk of thyroid cancer in people exposed to fallout in an accident.

title: High Priorities for India
description: To the Editor:

title: What Tojo Knew
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets to Make Zolak Backup
description: The Jets continue to rebuild with missing pieces while picking apart the New England Patriots.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the New Jersey Attorney General's takeover of the investigation of a suspect's death in police headquarters in Orange, N.J., misstated the day that the Essex County prosecutor's office was notified of the decision. It was Wednesday, not Monday.

title: Social Security Still on Agenda Of Republicans, Speaker Says
description: The Speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert, insisted today that Republicans still saw an opportunity to reach a bipartisan agreement on shoring up Social Security.

title: Theme Song on the Internet: The Pain of Social Ostracism
description: In classrooms and around the dinner table, teen-agers' reactions to the school killings in Colorado this week may have been dominated by fear for their own safety and horror at the violence that ended the lives of young people much like themselves.

title: Big Board Profit Falls 16%
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that its first-quarter profit fell 16 percent as the number of new companies that listed on the world's No. 1 exchange declined. Quarterly net income fell to $27.9 million, from $33.3 million in the first quarter of 1998. The number of new listings dropped 42 percent, to 30. The exchange said quarterly revenue rose 3 percent, to $177.2 million, from the quarter a year earlier.

title: Economic Status Quo
description: To the Editor:

title: Arizona Shows the Way on Drugs
description: Arizona voters, tired of paying the exorbitant costs of imprisoning drug users and addicts who might be helped more cheaply, voted twice to provide a treatment alternative to jail. Now an Arizona Supreme Court study of the first year of probation with mandatory drug treatment -- instead of prison -- has shown the apparent wisdom of that decision. Congress and the legislatures of New York and other states should take heed.

title: Sprewell Gets Out Of Paying His Fine
description: Dave Checketts's attempt to bring order to the Knicks was diluted yesterday when the $25,000 fine slapped on Latrell Sprewell was picked up by an apparel company the guard endorses.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel misidentified the position formerly held by David Levy, who has joined a party opposing him in the May 17 election. Mr. Levy was Foreign Minister under Mr. Netanyahu, not Finance Minister.

title: Sports of The Times; Big Game, Big Victory For Knicks
description: ABOUT 10 days ago, the Knicks were in the midst of another maelstrom when Don Casey, the Nets' interim coach, advised nervous Knicks fans not to worry. The Knicks are a veteran team, he said, ''they're a big game team.''

title: W-WESTMONT TO PURCHASE UNIHOST OF CANADA
description: The W-Westmont Corporation, a partnership that includes Goldman, Sachs & Company, agreed yesterday to buy the Unihost Corporation of Canada, which manages Quality Inn and Comfort Inn hotels, for almost $265 million (Canadian) in cash. W-Westmont will also take on about $300 million of Unihost debt. It sweetened its bid to $7 a share after Unihost's board rejected its earlier $6-a-share bid as too low. W-Westmont, run by Goldman Sachs's Whitehall Street Real Estate Funds and Westmont Hospitality Group, will add Unihost's properties to its group of 45 hotels across Canada.

title: River Feeds the Poor as Lab's Pollutants Worry Critics
description: Joyce Anne Miles Johnson spends warm days on the muddy banks of the Peconic River. She lives in a corrugated steel box built by the government on a dusty lot. In her home is a chest of drawers, a mattress, a muttering old man and two fishing nets. She eats government food: cheese and cereals in plain white wrapping. She eats at the Congregational soup kitchen, and now that the weather has turned, she eats whatever can be pulled from the river.

title: Earnest Movements Transformed by Time
description: The past and the present came together in unexpected and thought-provoking ways in ''Breaking Ground: Judson Dance Theater and Beyond'' on Thursday night at the Judson Memorial Church. It was there that the Judson Dance Theater, the seedbed of post-modernist dance, came into being in the early 1960's.

title: Religion Journal; To the Clerics of Littleton, Words of Experience
description: One dreadful week last May, the Rev. Zane O. Wilson, pastor of Springfield Lutheran Church in Springfield, Ore., got telephone calls from fellow Lutheran clerics in far-off places like Jonesboro, Ark., and Paducah, Ky.

title: On This Day, the Weather Wins
description: For 105 years, the Penn Relays have been run through sun and rain, winterlike cold and summerlike heat, hail and thunder and lightning.

title: Valderrama Is Reassigned
description: Carlos Valderrama, who was banned by Coach Ivo Worthman last week after arguing over the Miami Fusion's style of play, was reassigned to Tampa Bay yesterday by Major League Soccer and will play against the MetroStars at Giants Stadium tomorrow.

title: ENERGY EAST TO ACQUIRE CONNECTICUT ENERGY
description: The Energy East Corporation signed an agreement yesterday to acquire the Connecticut Energy Corporation for about $617 million, payable 50 percent in stock and 50 percent in cash. Energy East, based in Ithaca, N.Y., said Connecticut Energy shareholders would receive $42 a share and could specify the percentage they wished to receive in stock and in cash. Based on Energy East's closing price on Thursday, Energy East would swap 1.6 shares for each Connecticut Energy share. The final number of shares could vary between 1.43 shares and 1.82 shares. Shares of Connecticut Energy, based in Bridgeport, Conn., jumped $4.4375, to $35.75. on the New York Stock Exchange, where Energy East fell $1.25 a share, to $25.

title: Japanese Brokerage Firms Report Big Losses
description: Japan's biggest brokerage firms reported huge annual losses today, led by the Nomura Securities Company, which cited a $3.3 billion loss on its overseas bond trading and aid to an affiliate.

title: Kosovo Overshadows Subdued NATO Event
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization marked its 50th anniversary today with minimal retrospective self-congratulation, focusing soberly instead on the critical challenge it faces in Kosovo.

title: Judges' Unanimous Verdict On DNA Lessons: 'Wow!'
description: There were the most unmagisterial comments coming from a great many distinguished justices of the Massachusetts Superior Court today.

title: Cost of Guns Goes Beyond the Loss of Lives; Our 'Winner' Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston Plan for Patriots Is Welcomed at Statehouse
description: Business leaders and the Commissioner of the National Football League blitzed the Statehouse today in an attempt to build support for a last-minute plan to keep the New England Patriots in Massachusetts, and received encouraging signs that they might yet wrest the team back from Hartford.

title: On Ground Troops Issue, Clinton Takes Back Seat
description: Is President Clinton leading or following on Kosovo?

title: Computer Issues Continue Surge and Push Nasdaq Higher
description: Computer shares rallied yesterday for a fourth day on optimism about profits, while AT&T pulled the Dow Jones industrial average lower on concern that the phone company's $58 billion bid for Mediaone would hurt earnings.

title: Cost of Guns Goes Beyond the Loss of Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Cases Added to Investigation of Jail Medical Care
description: Seven months after city officials promised to monitor the quality of medical care in the city's jails more vigorously, the Manhattan District Attorney is investigating two new cases in which inmates, one of whom died this week, may have received substandard care, said an official involved in the investigation.

title: Soros Says Sale of Debt Means End of World Crisis
description: George Soros, the financier, said yesterday that Brazil's $2 billion note sale showed that the world's financial markets had recovered after their turmoil last year.

title: A Son's Simple Diagnosis of His Father's Complexities
description: Next week The American Scholar will publish an article by James Trilling, the son of Lionel and Diana Trilling, titled ''My Father and the Weak-Eyed Devils,'' in which he writes that his father was so blinded by his love of Freud and psychoanalysis that he missed his real disease.

title: Seven Sisters, Minus One
description: The diplomas that Harvard's female graduating seniors receive at commencement this June will most likely be the last ones ever to bear the seal of Radcliffe College. One hundred twenty years after its founding as a Harvard annex, Radcliffe is about to be absorbed completely by its brother college.

title: U.S. Says It Will Deploy Armor Units To Albania
description: The Pentagon announced tonight that it was sending sizable armored combat units, equipped with tanks and howitzers, to Albania to back up the Apache helicopter gunships that began to arrive there with much fanfare this week.

title: Dream House With Scenic View Is Environmentalists' Nightmare
description: Perched on a gusty bluff high above the Columbia River, the dream house that Brian and Jody Bea are trying to build here looks out on a spectacular vista. Evergreens and basalt hills are all around. And, across the way in Oregon, 620-foot Multnomah Falls, one of that state's most popular tourist sites, cascades into the broad river.

title: Where Poor Share With Those Even Poorer
description: And still they come, thousands of refugees straggling over the ice-packed mountains, freezing, exhausted and bereft, carrying mud-caked clothes on their backs, whimpering children in their arms, horror in their heads.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Amy Fisher's court apology to Mary Jo Buttafuoco on Long Island for having shot her in 1992 misspelled the given name of Mrs. Buttafuoco's lawyer in some copies. He is Dominic A. Barbara, not Dominick.

title: Wave of Copycat Threats Leads To Swift Responses Across U.S.
description: A wave of copycat threats of violence prompted by the Tuesday massacre at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., led school and law-enforcement officials across the country to respond quickly to any new sign of trouble, even if the threats were pranks brought on by a dose of youthful spring fever.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: INSIDE
description: Guilty in Pizza Killings

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: In the Universe, Are We Really No. 1?
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of NATO's Reach: Yugoslavia's Treetop War
description: NATO's growing armada of warplanes dominates the skies over Yugoslavia, but only down to a few hundred feet off the ground.

title: Donations Mix Philanthropy With Publicity and Tax Breaks : The Corporate Art Giveaway
description: NEW YORK  Ever since the mid-19th century, when America's railway companies commissioned artists to portray the expanding western frontier, American corporations have been building significant art collections in an effort to enhance both the workplace and their public image. Corporate art collections also serve philanthropic purposes when shared with a wider audience through museum exhibitions, loans and donations.

title: China Escapes Censure in Vote by U.N. Human Rights Agency
description: Human rights advocates failed to secure international condemnation of China's rights record today, but they eked out, by one vote, a censure of Cuba by the United Nations' top rights organization.

title: Less-Known Artists Can Be Underpriced : How Cheap Can Old Masters Be?
description: LONDON  It happened on Dec. 16, on one of those days when world records tumble and only multimillionaires seem to stand a chance. The setting was Christie's, London, where the most expensive Isaac Soreau ever at auction (573,500, or $924,300), for an extremely beautiful still life of the 1620s was followed by a mind-boggling 1 million for an imaginary harbor view by Joseph Vernet in Rome. The entire sale of Old Master pictures added up to 14.8 million. It was a triumph duly echoed in the ringing press release put out by Christie's PR people.

title: Escaping Life's Rectangle of Isolation
description: Eliot Feld creates eye-catching choreography. He knows how to attract and hold an audience's attention, both by having dancers make surprising shapes in space and by having them perform on and around unusual surfaces. Some of the results are merely gimmicky. But at his best Mr. Feld can be simultaneously ingenious and expressive.

title: Belfast Team Sets Record
description: Thriving in the kind of foggy and rainy conditions of its hometown of Belfast, St. Malachy's High School registered its third straight victory in the boys' distance medley relay today at the Penn Relays.

title: Assessing Italy's Debt to Dutch-Flemish Painters : Northern Lights
description: FLORENCE  Almost every museum in Italy, not to mention scores of churches, contain Dutch and Flemish pictures. Contemplating this fact in general and a previously unlisted Cornelis Verspronck portrait in an Italian collection in particular, the young Dutch art historian Bert Meijer first formed the idea of one day compiling a comprehensive catalogue of Low Countries paintings to be found throughout the country.

title: Grand Strategy: Round and Round On U.S. Interests; Kosovo Rekindles a Debate, Dormant for Nearly a Decade, Of America's Global Role
description: The American involvement in Kosovo has started the most furious debate since the end of the cold war over what constitutes United States strategic interests.

title: Crew Removes 5 in District Tainted by Corruption Case
description: The New York Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, removed the Acting Superintendent and four board members from Community School District 14 yesterday in an attempt, he said, to root out the corruption that allowed a Brooklyn rabbi to steal $6 million from the district during the course of two decades.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NAVISTAR INTERNATIONAL CORP., Chicago, the world's No. 4 truck maker, said it would spend $250 million to buy and renovate an Alabama factory to make diesel truck and bus engines, creating as many as 600 jobs.

title: Giuliani and Vallone Ally in Bid To Shift Control of School System
description: After years of criticizing the Board of Education from separate corners in City Hall, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone have agreed to pursue legislation that would abolish the board and replace it with a system more beholden to the Mayor and the Council, representatives of both sides said yesterday.

title: Finally, Ewing Hits One, Knicks Win One
description: Patrick Ewing stared down the shot clock as he stood on the fringe of the paint with his back against Derrick Coleman and the ball in his palm. Several seconds ticked off, and the crowd bubbling inside Madison Square Garden grew edgy. What was he thinking?

title: Verniero Says Bias Issue Got Lost in Workload
description: Defending his office against charges that it waited nearly two years to address accusations of racial bias by the New Jersey State Police, Attorney General Peter G. Verniero suggested today that the issue simply became lost amid the crush of daily concerns he faced as the state's chief law enforcement officer.

title: Politics of Weaponry Set Back Security
description: To the Editor:

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: Um, Did Somebody Say McBagels?; Dough With a Hole in the Middle, but Will New Yorkers Bite?
description: Eli Zabar stands over the specimen like a coroner on his first autopsy of the day. He pokes and pinches and cuts, and bends close to take a sniff, and then straightens to render his opinion.

title: E*TRADE GROUP, ON-LINE BROKERAGE FIRM, TO SPLIT STOCK
description: E*Trade Group Inc., the third-biggest on-line brokerage firm, said yesterday that it would split its stock 2 for 1 in its second split this year. The announcement by E*Trade, based in Palo Alto, Calif., came a day after the Charles Schwab Corporation, the biggest on-line broker, said it will split its stock July 1 for the seventh time since the company went public in 1987. E*Trade last split its stock, on a 2-for-1 basis, on Jan. 29, after a ninefold rise since Oct. 8. The stock rose $8.0625 yesterday, to $104.0625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Woman, 97, Keeps Land After Fight With Nyack
description: A 97-year-old woman has won her battle with officials of this Hudson River village who sought to seize her debris-strewn backyard and turn it into a wetland and bird sanctuary as part of a plan to revive the waterfront.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Argentina's Rising Oil Fortunes; Privatized Company Gets Knack of Not Losing Money
description: For decades after its founding in 1922 as the world's first state-owned oil company outside the Soviet Union, Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales was the butt of one of Argentina's most enduring jokes as ''the only oil company in the world that knew how to lose money.''

title: OBITUARY : Munir Khan Dies; Developed Pakistan Bomb Project
description: PARIS  Munir Ahmad Khan, 72, chief architect of Pakistan's nuclear program and a former chairman of the International Atomic Energy Agency, died Wednesday in Vienna after heart surgery.

title: Old and Seamy Practice of Jolting Horses Becomes Topic at Kentucky Derby
description: It is sometimes referred to as ''plugging in'' a race horse -- the act of shocking the animal with a crude, hand-held electrical device to prod it to go faster. Though it is prohibited and reviled within the industry, the longtime practice has become one of the seamier, and bizarre, story lines as American thoroughbred racing's grandest moment approaches.

title: NATO Approves Naval Embargo on Oil Going to Serbs
description: On the opening day of the NATO summit meeting, the alliance agreed today to impose an oil embargo on Serbia and to enforce it by searching ships in the Adriatic Sea suspected of carrying fuel for forces fighting in Kosovo.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's like Wonder bread in a circle. A New York bagel fights with you. It's tough on the outside, and chewy on the inside, and you struggle with it.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Jackstraws

title: Open Scoring Is Used In 3 Championship Bouts
description: Open scoring at the MCI Center in Washington is the norm when the Wizards are in the main arena. But when you have three world championship boxing matches, and the card is stacked with local favorites, open scoring can be a recipe for disaster.

title: The Indexing Giant Nobody Knows
description: IN an era when being biggest in any endeavor brings hubris and hype, Barclays Global Investors stands out by being nearly invisible to the untutored eye.

title: The Nation; The Stresses of Youth, The Strains of Its Music
description: THE killing spree by two young fans of computerized gladiator matches and gut-wrenching industrial rock last week in Littleton, Colo., was a calamity measured in lives lost and damaged. But the tragedy at Columbine High School also marked yet another battle over the meanings and effects of youth culture.

title: Correcting the Errors of a Benefactor's Ways
description: HENRY FRANCIS DU PONT probably did not know where history ended and fantasy began when he devised the American period rooms for the museum here that bears his name. Apparently nobody else has known the difference either. Museum officials long insisted that the rooms reflected life in America between 1640 and 1860.

title: April 18-24; Signs of Bygone Days
description: The age of the American tobacco billboard is over as part of last year's settlement between tobacco producers and 46 states to resolve all state claims for health costs related to smoking.

title: One Concerto With Two Distinct Violists
description: EVEN among string instruments, the viola is not a star. The dashing violin and the omnipotent piano are much more visible, with dance cards full of concertos. If those two were race horses, the viola would be the plow horse, plodding without complaint, resigned to being the butt of cruel viola jokes, which are the musical equivalent of Polish jokes, only worse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKINLEY, GEORGE
description: McKINLEY - George. Lawyer, born in New York City, August 11, 1903; died April 15, 1999. Son of Thomas and Agnes Magill McKinley; husband of the late Joy Johnston McKinley (November 10, 1939). BA Columbia, 1929; LL.B. Yale, 1933. Retired partner, 1978, of Hawkins, Delafield & Wood. 1939-45: Partner, Earle, Rust & Reilly. American Bar Association; American Judicial Society; New York State Bar Association; Association of the Bar of the City of New York, Bronx County Bar Association (President 1969). Advising Counsel, Housing Part of the Civil Court, City of New York. Citizens Union New York (Former Chair & Vice Chair, director 195479); 20 years as Chair of the Committee of Local Candidates and appeared on TV ''Searchlight'' Citizens Union program for over 15 years. NY Chamber of Commerce & Industry (former member, Executive Committee, NY Chamber of Commerce; former chair, Law Reform Committee). Former member, City Midday Club; NY Athletic Club; Ex-Members Squadron A; St. George Association (former President of the Business and Professional Chapters); Sigma Chi & Phi Alpha Delta (Legal); former elder of the Fourth Presbyterian Church; Mason. He is survived by his three children: Linda Miller, Barton McKinley and Nancy Hawkins and six grandchildren. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation. Interment is a private family service.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Gimme Shelter
description: Andre Dubus 3d's second novel, HOUSE OF SAND AND FOG (Norton, $24.95), describes in sensitive detail how otherwise normal people employ society's rules and systems to dismantle one another's lives -- it's about good people gone crazy. An Iranian immigrant, Col. Genob Sarhang Massoud Amir Behrani, accustomed to the trappings of power, now works at menial jobs. He seizes an opportunity to make money by purchasing, at a county auction, a nice bungalow in Corona, Calif. Kathy Lazaro, who lost the bungalow because of a bureaucratic tax error and whose husband has abandoned her, struggles to reclaim it. When a deputy sheriff named Lester Burdon becomes involved, he falls in love with Lazaro, losing everything else he values in the process. Dubus builds a sturdy narrative about how these characters' visions of the American dream (shelter, security, even love) collide and collapse. Set amid the frequent, flowing fogs and unsteady sands of Pacific suburbia, the novel examines what happens when ordinary men and women move across that tenuous barrier between the normal and the irrational. This is a story, told in highly visual, descriptive language, about how people you might choose to be your neighbors are repeatedly trapped by circumstances and transformed by events until finally they can -- and do -- destroy one another. Bill Sharp

title: Reports of Another Massacre, With 40 Dead
description: Serbian paramilitaries reportedly rampaged through two ethnic Albanian villages in central Kosovo last Sunday, killing as many as 40 people, including four or five young women who were raped and then executed, refugees arriving here said today.

title: Theater Curtain Company Will Stay in City for Encore
description: Housed in a nondescript two-story building between a crab house and a trophy maker is a small company that has played a large part in dressing the stages of dozens of Broadway theaters, as well as opera houses and concert halls across the country. It now looks as if the 100-year-old company will remain there.

title: Political Memo; Giuliani Takes Aim at Hillary Clinton's Out-of-State Address
description: For a peek at how Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani might run a campaign against Hillary Rodham Clinton for Senate next year, go no farther than the Giuliani Web site devoted to a daily electronic thrashing of the First Lady. ''Born in Illinois and carried to power in Arkansas, with no connection of any kind to New York, Hillary has set her sights on the New York Senate seat,'' the site, HillaryNo.com, tells visitors.

title: The Nation: After the Madness; Violence, Even Before the Internet
description: LONG before two teen-aged boys began their shooting rampage last week at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., long before violent video games, the Internet and nihilistic industrial rock music, America's young were committing occasional acts of destruction and violence. If the following examples fail to show a pattern, it may be because there is none.

title: Griffin Is M.V.P.
description: The former Seton Hall guard Adrian Griffin was named most valuable player for the Continental Basketball Association after helping the Connecticut Pride to the league finals.

title: NATO Missed Best Chance at Peace; Young Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Child With a Way With Words, Maybe
description: HER real name is Barbara but her grandmother Dorothea calls her Echo. A believer in the truth of the spirit, not of the body, Dorothea raised Echo and taught her the alphabet when she was 3 months old. Calculus had to wait until Echo was 9 years old.

title: WHAT PRICE GLORY?: A special report.; Cuban Players Defect, but Often With a Cost
description: Reynaldo Ordonez Fiallo received a gift from America one day last month -- a new, unmarked baseball glove made of beautiful tanned leather. As a bonus, the glove came with a tag bearing a color photograph of his father, the slick-fielding shortstop for the Mets, who is also named Rey Ordonez.

title: New Meaning for Knicks-Heat Game
description: Sometimes it seems as if Allan Houston is waging two wars on the court. One is with his defender. The other is with his confidence.

title: Student Critics Push Attacks on an Association Meant to Prevent Sweatshops
description: Just as it is about to get off the ground, a factory-monitoring association backed by the White House is facing strong attacks from students at more than a dozen universities who assert that the association will not be tough enough in ferreting out sweatshop conditions.

title: A View and Eclectic Menu in Dobbs Ferry
description: AT the Chart House here, the play's the thing. Arrive before dark on any evening to witness great theater performed by sun, sky and water. The architecture at this waterside dining spot merges with the landscape: angular walls are of glass and seem to meet the water, and almost every table has a long view. That view from the far end of the dining room includes two bridges, a bonus, each turning on its running lights sometime during dinner.

title: Taking Over the Joystick of Natural Selection
description: THE brightly colored creatures gyrate along the curved bank of 12 computer monitors, at once artificial in their sharp-edged geometry yet thoroughly lifelike in their movements. Jointed flagella stroke the disembodied medium; valves open and close; propellers twirl. They possess both the variety and the structural similarity of biological organisms, ranging from elegant simplicity to a Rube Goldberg intricacy of moving parts.

title: Faster Food
description: The Theater Square Grill in Newark has been touting its pre-theater dining since the New Jersey Performing Arts Center opened in late 1997. Now, sans-theater dining takes center stage as the restaurant adds a lunchtime ''grill express,'' a daily special of salad and pasta served in 15 minutes or less. other items on the expanded lunch menu, with the clock ticking slightly longer, include soups, salads, pastas and entrees ranging from Jamaican jerk chicken to Southern pan-fried catfish with hush puppies to chicken mole quesadilla. The express lunch is served Mondays through Fridays from 11:30 A.M. to 2 P.M., with a soup-and-sandwich special for $10 and the highest-priced entrees at $12. Timewise, it may not beat the five-minute lunch guarantee at your local pizza chain, but the food is probably better and the setting is certainly more elegant. Information: (973) 642-1226. DIANE NOTTLE

title: Creatures of the Deep, On View in Monterey
description: An exhibition of living deep-sea animals, most never seen before in an aquarium, opened last month at the Monterey Bay Aquarium in central California. ''Mysteries of the Deep'' features more than 40 species collected from as deep as 3,300 feet below the ocean's surface.

title: Pesticides In Schools
description: Regarding the article ''Allergies and Pesticides: Spraying in Schools'' (April 4):

description: False Dawn

title: In Picking Williams and Sacrificing Future Drafts, Ditka Is Going for It
description: Some National Football League coaches say there is no mystery about what Mike Ditka, coach of the New Orleans Saints, did at last weekend's draft. When Ditka traded all of the Saints' picks, and first- and third-round selections next year, to Washington for the chance to take running back Ricky Williams, they felt they knew what his motives were.

title: Cleanliness and Godliness At a New Beauty Salon
description: D. Esse, a new West Village beauty salon, is inspired by flowers -- like white roses from Provence -- and is decorated with rose carpeting and scented with rose oils. The 2,000-square-foot duplex with six treatment rooms, owned by Daphne Selig, is at 350 Hudson Street (near Charlton Street), and derives its name from the French word for goddess, ''deesse.''

title: A 'Newsroom' Where the News Is Irrelevant
description: THERE'S always a breaking story at the nightly ''Toronto News.'' For example, George Findlay, the show's producer, throws a racist tantrum when he doesn't get his bran muffin. Or when his BMW needs a $3,200 muffler system. Or when he has once again hit on a woman half his age (late 40's) and she has complained to management.

title: INSIDE
description: Sold Into Freedom

title: Why Should Teaching Art Struggle for Respect?
description: It is wonderful that the arts are being integrated into the teaching of science and math [''The Art and Economics of Teaching Creativity,'' March 7]. But why should art have to always prove its worthiness? Art in itself incorporates science and math. Mix red and yellow and you get orange. To lay out your artwork, you must calculate the position to place your design.

title: Bon Voyage, Internet Stocks!
description: WEBSTER'S Third New International Dictionary defines the phrase ''miss the boat'' as ''to blunder badly by failing to grasp an opportunity in time.'' A 1999 edition of that dictionary might add, ''e.g., to have missed buying certain Internet stocks.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-25-99; Live, From Hell
description: It has become a televisual cliche. The 45-second parade of refugees' vignettes, followed by the reporters' brow-creased displays of concern. Then the question from the anchor, in response to which reporters soften their voices to tell us how the personal dimension of the tragedy pierced their professional husks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOOPER, ANDREW H.
description: KOOPER-Andrew H. Devoted son of Bernard and Arlyne. Beloved brother of Wendy Saltzman.

title: Derby Trial Second Fiddle to Derby Heavyweights
description: One week before the 125th Kentucky Derby, Churchill Downs opened its springtime season of racing today with Patience Game winning the Derby Trial in a mild upset. But the real action was on the backstretch, where the barns were filled with at least 25 star horses hoping to make the cut for the Run for the Roses next Saturday. A maximum of 20 will run and, if need be, the field will be whittled to the top 20 earners in graded stakes races.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, BEN
description: ROTHSTEIN-Ben. Died April 19, 1999. Retired, The New York Times, Sunday Art Director of The Week in Review, The New York Times Magazine, Fashions of the Times, Report on Men's Wear, Children's Fashions and the Home sections. Retired Senior Assistant Art Director and Studio Manager, Newsweek Magazine. He served his country during World War II as the Head of Regimental Training Aids at Fort McClellan, Alabama. A highly artistic, caring man, who melded professionalism with creativity, Ben won numerous awards for his editorial design. Ben was a member of The Sunday Department, under Lester Markel, when it received a 1953 Pulitzer PrizeSpecial Awards and Citations, for the ''Review of the Week''. He made the first illustration of the then to be built United Nations, which appeared in The New York Times Centennial Exhibit at The New York Public Library. He art directed for The New York Times Magazine's World's Fair section in the April 18, 1965 issue, the most comprehensive map to appear in any publication of the New York World's Fair. Ben taught newspaper graphics and designed a minority student publication for the ''Michele Clark Fellowship Program for Minority Journalists'' at Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. As a volunteer, he taught art to children in the slums of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Ben loved to travel. He also lived and worked in London for Mercury House Business Publications Ltd and in Jerusalem for the ''Israeli Economist''. An accomplished painter, he won many awards for his watercolors and oils; having studied Design and Painting in New York, Pratt Institute and New School; as well as the Fountainbleu School of Fine Arts, France. Ben was a member of New York's Salmagundi Club. He is survived by his wife, Fanny, daughter Linda Rothstein-Sosnick, both residing in Jamesburg, NJ.

title: One-Woman Election: Parent vs. Taxpayer
description: WENDELL WILLKIE once said that any person who isn't something of a socialist before age 40 has no heart, but anyone who is still a socialist after 40 has no head.

title: THE WRONG MAN: A special report.; Innocent Suspect Was Held in Officer's Death Despite Signs of Error
description: By late in the morning of April 10, several hours after heavily armed, masked state troopers broke down the door of a house near here and arrested Terrance Everett in the murder of an Orange police officer, seasoned investigators in the office of the Essex County Prosecutor were certain that Mr. Everett was innocent.

title: POSTINGS: Play About Home Ownership, for Latinos; Fannie Mae As Joe Papp
description: At a cost of $20 or $25 a ticket a theatergoer may go to the Gramercy Arts Theater at 138 East 27th Street and see Dolores Prida's new Spanish-language play ''Casa Propria'' (''A House of Her Own''), which a New York Times reviewer described in March as a high-spirited comedy that is preserved by memorably funny characters from the ''intrusions of the playwright's social conscience.'' A simultaneous English translation is supplied through earphones.

title: Elway Is Expected to Retire
description: First came Michael Jordan, then Wayne Gretzky. Now Denver Broncos quarterback John Elway is apparently ready to join those superstars in retirement. Elway, playing in a golf tournament in Pebble Beach, Calif., all but announced his retirement during an interview yesterday with the Denver television station KCNC.

title: 2 Gentlewomen of Viola
description: Even among string instruments, the viola is not a star. It is actually the butt of terrible jokes, like the one recently told by a 9-year-old boy to a girl near his age: ''If you're lost in the desert, would you rather get directions from a good violist, a bad violist, or the Easter Bunny?'' The answer: ask the bad violist, since the other two are figments of the imagination.

title: Princeton Wins Sixth Straight Year
description: Princeton's unbeaten men's varsity crew defeated Yale and Cornell yesterday on Lake Carnegie at Princeton to win the Carnegie Cup for the sixth straight year. The Tigers won easily in 6 minutes 21.3 seconds, a slow time because of a headwind.

title: Jogger Talks About Beating In Brooklyn
description: A 29-year-old Brooklyn woman was released from the hospital yesterday morning, a day and a half after being beaten unconscious by a group of youths as she jogged near the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, the police said.

title: Keara O'Donnell, Leonard Gordon
description: Keara Marie O'Donnell and Leonard Lee Gordon were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Joseph DeSanto at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: 516 Divided by 2 Equals a Confused Island
description: SOMEWHERE buried in a computer, or perhaps locked in a black box, a secret three-digit number is waiting to divide Long Island as surely as the Nassau-Suffolk county line.

title: Gift-Giving Retirees Angry at J. P. Morgan
description: Some shareholders of J. P. Morgan & Company, the banking giant, were concerned enough about its plans to stop matching its retirees' charitable contributions to raise the issue at the bank's annual meeting earlier this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, BERNARD, JUDGE
description: NEWMAN-Bernard, Judge. Universally acclaimed for his integrity by all who knew him, including Bishops, Deans, Governors, Legislators, Judges and fellow citizens on the streets of New York, Bernard Newman consistently credited his parents, and his wife for 59 years, Kathryn Bereano, and his life time friend and surviving spouse, Fritzi W. Rudolph, for his sterling reputation. A Governor of New York, once marveled how Bernard ''could engage in political activities and in a post of leadership and retain his...reputation for integrity.'' Born on October 28, 1907 to Isidor J. and Sarah C. Newman, and life time resident of New York City, Bernard Newman was a gentleman of profound wisdom, integrity and generosity, and a man of great compassion. More significantly Bernard Newman was a man completely devoted and dedicated to his family, and tremendously adored and loved by his family and friends. An honor graduate of the college and law school of New York University and an Associate Editor of the Law Review, Bernard Newman was a lawyer's lawyer and a judge's judge. As a young attorney, Bernard was attracted at an early age to public service. First as an Assistant Corporation Counsel assigned to the office of Chamberlain A.A. Berle, Jr., and next as a law secretary to New York State Supreme Court Justice, Samuel H. Hofstadler. For 16 years, presiding justices David W. Peck and Bernard Botein designated lawyer Newman an official referee of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. On December 12, 1965, Mayor Robert F. Wagner, Jr. appointed him to the family court, which was followed by an appointment to the State Supreme Court by Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller. Then, on July 21, 1968, President Lyndon B. Johnson, nominated the Judge to the Customs Court, situated in New York. The jurisdiction of which was expanded by Congress in 1980 under the name United States Court of International Trade. Judge Newman, who delighted in the distinction of having been appointed by Mayor, the Governor, and the President, presided for more than 30 years over complex Federal Customs and international trade cases, while also sitting in recent years in the federal district court in Manhattan. Judge Newman also once served as Council to, and Chairman of, the New York County Republican Party; as a delegate to Republican National Nominating Conventions; as a referee on special panels of the New York State Labor Relations and Mediation Boards. Judge Newman also was a Director of the Civic Center Synagogue, Community, Synagogue Center, Metropolitan Advisory Board of Anti Defamation League, and Laguardia Memorial Association. He was also the recipient of the Judge Edward Weinfeld Award, and Man of the Year Award. In addition to his wife Fritzi, the Judge is survived by daughters Phyllis Cechini and Helene Bernstein, grandchildren Craig and Kathy, John and Kathy, Mark and Hayley Cechini, Scott and Marcia, Brad and Annette Bernstein, and eight great-grandchildren. Services will be held on April 25, 11:30 AM, Plaza Memorial, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st Street), New York.

title: 'Go,' Camp Refugees Are Told, but Leave Valued Tractors
description: After being given just minutes to make the heartbreaking choice of what to take with them and what to leave behind as they were being expelled from their homes in Kosovo, thousands of refugees here now are being forced to make another hard decision.

title: Doorless Restrooms Make Students Blush, Officials Battle
description: For students like Luis Martinez, the carpenters at Intermediate School 126 could not work fast enough last week putting in doors on the bathroom stalls, stalls that for more than a decade have afforded children little privacy in the privy.

title: Central American Setbacks
description: Two Central American nations struggling to become truly democratic have seen recent defeats for the rule of law. In both cases -- Honduras and Guatemala -- old habits of corruption and intimidation threaten to slow or reverse efforts to hold public officials accountable for wrongdoing.

title: A Manifesto for The Fast World
description: If a thread of policy can be discerned in Thomas L. Friedman's post-modern approach to foreign affairs (March 28), it is the simple formula made famous by the British in the 19th century: open world markets and keep them open by superior force of arms. The new rationale is ''globalization,'' a quasi-mystical concept, with New Age connotations, well on the way to becoming an ideology in this supposedly postideological time.

title: A-Frames and Other G-Rated Fantasies
description: Long before ''This Old House'' there was the house I grew up in. The attic and the basement belonged to my father, who spent every possible weekend at his workbench downstairs, sawing and planing boards to finish the unfinished upstairs of our small suburban Cape Cod.

title: Backtalk; Wolves' Walk on the Wild Side Proved Deadly
description: Cisco, a Mexican gray wolf, sits among the brittlebrush and desert willows in the wolf exhibit area of the Living Desert Wildlife and Botanical Park, at the center of the only quarter-acre of land he has ever known. He regards all that lies beyond with indifferent amber eyes. A faint breeze ripples across his light coat. It is barely 9 A.M., and the park is empty of people.

title: Penn Stuns Harvard
description: Pennsylvania's men's heavy-weight crew upset Harvard yesterday in winning the Adams Cup in Philadelphia for the first time since 1991. Before the race, Larry Connell, Penn's freshman coach, predicted the varsity race would be a ''thriller,'' and it lived up to its billing.

title: BOOKEND; Invitation to a Transformation
description: There was a Chinese philosopher who all his life pondered the problem whether he was a Chinese philosopher dreaming that he was a butterfly or a butterfly dreaming that she was a philosopher. . . .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, FREDA
description: ABRAMS-Freda. On April 22, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Devoted mother of Stan, Marion, and Len. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Sunday, 12:15 PM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRYAN, PAULINE (POLLY)
description: BRYAN-Pauline (Polly). April 12, 1999, in La Jolla, CA. Descendant of John Alden. From early life in Joplin, MO. to school in the East: Vassar (AB 1933), Columbia (MA 1935). Teacher, editor, proofreader (American Heritage Dictionary, 1969), writer. On the staff of British Information Services (latterly as Head, Press Section, News Division), awarded M.B.E. by Queen Elizabeth II in 1972 for more than twenty-five years devoted to promoting understanding between the USA and Britain. Polly served Vassar College in many capacities: as a member of the AAVC Board of Directors, Chairman of the Alumnae House Committee, AAVC Representative to the Investor Responsibility Committee, President of the Class of 1933 and Chairman of the Class's 50th Reunion. As a volunteer for Vassar, whenever writing was needed to be lucid, fluent and concise, it was Polly who was called upon. Her love affair with the English language, merry companionship, generous spirit and enduring friendship endeared her to many. In retirement, she was active in seeking to alleviate pollution in all its forms and enjoyed happy avocations: travel, ballet theater, birdwatching-until the day in 1987 that her life was shattered by the carelessness of a bicyclist in Central Park. Friends may wish to honor Polly's memory by contributing to Vassar College Alumnae House, to which Polly gave so much of herself. Address: 61 Raymond Avenue, Poughkeepsie, New York 12603. Messages to Polly's good friend in La Jolla will be forwarded. A Long-time Vassar Friend

The couple -- Kenneth and Judy Launhardt -- said it was love at first sight and nothing could have stopped them. And while officials in the field of developmental disabilities have supported the union, they also acknowledge its difficulties and fragilities.

Pearce, the 56-year-old vice chairman of General Motors, went in for his annual physical a year ago, he had every reason to believe that his fitness program had kept him healthy. But his white blood cell count was low. Just in case, he had a bone marrow test. On May 26, during a meeting of G.M.'s top executives, he was told by phone that he had to hear the results in person.

title: Violists Are the Twin Stars Of an Orchestral Galaxy
description: COMPARISONS are especially odious in the arts. To try to prove that the New York Philharmonic has, in Cynthia Phelps, the ''best'' principal violist of any orchestra would be futile and unsatisfying in the extreme. Still, it is tempting simply to declare that the Philharmonic has the best pair of violists of any orchestra in the United States, if not the world.

title: Who's on Tape
description: ''Good night to all my friends in Paterson,'' Lou Costello would say after his radio broadcasts with Bud Abbott. Lou Costello, born Lou Cristello, never forgot the city of his birth, and Paterson - with a statue of Lou on Cianci Street and a municipal pool and sports club named for him - hasn't forgotten him. A fan, Larry Harrington, also born in Paterson, has put together a two-hour amateur videotape, ''Memories of Bud and Lou,'' , with strong emphasis on Costello and his roots. (Bud Abbott was also New Jersey-born, in Asbury Park.) As the tape documents, Lou's journey to Hollywood included plenty of trips back to Paterson, to buy a house, to entertain on the steps of City Hall before one of his movies opened in town or to organize a benefit to renovate his boyhood church, St. Anthony's. The tape also documents an Abbott and Costello convention (held in Clifton), and a bus tour of Paterson narrated by Lou Rege, a cousin of Costello's. The tape, $34.95, which includes tax ($1.80, rebated to those from out of state) and shipping, is available by writing to Larry Harrington 75 Belgrade Avenue, Clifton, NJ 07013 or by calling (973)523-5239.

title: Seeing a Century Out, Venturing Into the Next One

Last Tuesday, when the first half of the Whitney Museum of American Art's ''American Century,'' a behemoth exhibition featuring 1,200 works of art, was to be unveiled, the opening proved bittersweet for Lisa Phillips. Ms. Phillips had been organizing exhibitions at the Whitney since 1977 and was one of four people who pulled together this show. But that evening she was to be a guest rather than a host, for earlier that day she was scheduled to begin her new job as director at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo.

While my answers to the first two questions are yes and no, I have dodged the third, for fear that any child-bearing plans might cost me a new job. Is it true that employers aren't supposed to ask? This is not, however, because it has the best restaurants in the country -- it does not -- but because it is a singularly exciting and entertaining place to eat. First of all, there are a number of venerable restaurants that set high standards -- Zuni Cafe and Hayes Street Grill, for example. And secondly, San Francisco is one of the country's capitals of culinary experimenta tion.

title: Everything but the Angst: Items from Woody Allen Films Sold

But the thousands of objects crowding the shelves and floor in the cavernous space potently evoked other places and eras: there were mahogany radios and clunky microphones from the 1930's and 40's, a tall wooden phone booth with folding doors, the kind Superman would use, and a collection of halberds, pikes and tridents of the sort you might see in hell.
