title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Cropping the World
description: W. Eugene Smith's powerful convictions and high aspirations drove him to produce this century's best-known photo essays and some of its most powerful images. His pictures for Life magazine shot between 1948 and 1954 -- Country Doctor,'' ''Nurse Midwife,'' ''A Man of Mercy'' (Albert Schweitzer) and ''Spanish Village'' -- set the standard for photojournalists who followed him. Contrary to the journalistic ethic of objectivity -- producing an undoctored version of events -- Smith often manipulated both his subjects and the photographic process to create what he called intensified reality. He produced dramatic prints by means of cropping, burning, dodging and bleaching. Before he started shooting he meticulously researched his subjects, and once on the job he consistently extended deadlines to get deeper into his story. If Smith envisioned a shot that would make his point, he was not above orchestrating the resulting image by, for example, renting cattle to block a truck on a rural Welsh road to illustrate the intersection of modern and traditional life. He called this ''rearranging for the truth of actuality.'' Despite his reputation as one of the seminal figures of 20th-century photography, his legacy and reputation are complicated. W. EUGENE SMITH: Photographs 1934-1975 (Abrams, $75), edited by Gilles Mora and John T. Hill, presents a balanced assessment of this talented and troubled figure. The 350 photographs are richly reproduced and reflect the scope of Smith's work from banal early magazine pictures to the searing image of a mother holding her deformed daughter. The layouts of his Life stories and sample pages from a projected autobiography (to be told through photos) remind us that Smith's works were meant to be read like stories, not treated as precious art objects. Interspersed throughout are informative essays that deal with Smith's psyche, technique and enduring influence. Rosemary Ranck

title: W. H. Armstrong, 87, Teacher Praised for the Novel 'Sounder'
description: William H. Armstrong, a teacher and writer best known for his 1969 children's novel ''Sounder,'' died on April 11 at his home in Kent, Conn. He was 87.

title: Airport Vans
description: To the Editor: We returned from our annual trip to Jerusalem the day you published the article ''What's Doing in Jerusalem'' (April 4). What struck us was the absurd suggestion that a trip from the airport should cost $41.66. Most visitors to Jerusalem take a sherut, a van or long Mercedes -- drivers teem in front of the airport -- that holds eight, drops you at your door and picks you up there for your return. Nesher, the company that has provided the airport drive for many years, is reliable, drivers speak enough English to manage, and the whole trip, no matter where you're going in Jerusalem, costs 37 shekels, or $9.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, WILLIAM J.
description: GROSSMAN-William J. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of William J. Grossman, a generous supporter and cherished friend who was deeply committed to the Jewish community and humanitarian causes. A longtime contributor to UJA-Federation through the Isidore Grossman Foundation, he inspired others to support our efforts by helping to establish the Philanthropic 50 group. We extend our sincerest condolences to his brother, Irwin; his daughter, Laurie Gioia; his sons John and Robert; and his grandchildren. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. title: Commercial Property /Office Space; A Small Business Hunts for a Home in Manhattan
description: DONNA TORRANCE did not think it would be all that hard to find a few thousand square feet of office space to establish a New York studio for VIA, a design and marketing firm based in Portland, Me. After all, there are more than 400 million square feet of office space in Manhattan. Surely something could be found.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Adaptations of two best sellers and two melodramas of lawmen at work enliven the lineup of films of television this week.

title: Emily Davis, Paul Bryan Knight
description: Emily Davis, a daughter of Martha Mathers Davis and Brian Davis, both of Louisville, Ky., was married yesterday to Paul Bryan Knight, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Knight of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Thomas K. Tewell performed the ceremony at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Linda McCartney: An Eye for Life In a Golden Era
description: ONE consolation baby boomers have as they grow older is that they grew up with the best rock music, and it will likely get piped into the rest home. This generation witnessed rock and roll from its birth to its full flowering. Fortunately, many turned to other cultural pursuits and so escaped the disappointment of rock's eventual watering down.

title: Mucha in Prague
description: To the Editor: Steven Erlanger's ''Prague: Admiring a Master of Art Nouveau'' (in ''Fresh Perspectives on Past and Present,'' March 14), mentions briefly Alfons Mucha's 20-painting ''Slav Epic.'' These masterpieces, now in Moravia, have an interesting history.

title: April 18-24; G.O.P. Campaign 2000
description: He has never held elective office, lags behind rivals in polls and as yet lacks the luster of a dark horse. But Gary L. Bauer's entry into the race for the Republican Presidential nomination subtly alters the dynamic. The president of the conservative Family Research Council, Mr. Bauer will probably bring God most forcefully into the campaign, forcing more moderate Republicans like George W. Bush to defend their nuanced positions on abortion and homosexuality to the religious right. FRANK BRUNI

title: April 18-24; No Fond Farewell
description: CNN parted ways with Peter Arnett, who helped established the cable network's pre-eminence in breaking news with his live reports from Baghdad during the gulf war.

title: Chasing Mame
description: Say ''Mame'' to a musical theater buff, and a wish list will follow. Say ''Christine Ebersole'' to the people who do the casting at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, and you'll be told she was at the top of theirs. Now, she's Mame.

title: And You Think Your Commute Is Long?
description: FOR Al Zuber, the workday begins at 7:15 A.M. as he pulls his bus out of the garage in Wayne and heads for the park-and-ride stop at the Willowbrook Mall for his first run, an express ride into Manhattan. His trip is one of more than 2,000 bringing the more than 60,000 commuters that New Jersey Transit carries into the Port Authority bus terminal each day.

title: African Traditions at Home in the Opera House
description: I WAS weaned on opera. A strange sounding claim, I am certain, to anyone who knows very well that to a child reared in the small town of Abeokuta in western Nigeria in the 1930's and 40's, the name Verdi or Puccini probably meant no more than some exotic candy or a new brand of tinned pilchards in the local expatriate shops. That claim is true, however. Most Nigerians of my generation were weaned on opera, complete with every structural component, from overture to stand-and-deliver arias to tragic climaxes. The overture went by a different name, of course; it was called the Opening Glee, which meant that our opera went one better than others in that it also boasted a Closing Glee. The idea of ''cloture'' in European Romantic opera would be a near profanity: ruin the climax, dissipate the catharsis and curb those interminable curtain calls?

title: Sunday Best
description: Adams may have ''spent the last 25 years portraying life'' in Appalachia, but this article has nothing to do with portraying life or people; it is about using people. Next, I expect we'll see the stylishly dressed Tilda Joseph in her coffin.

title: Signs of Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISHNOFF, MALCOLM M.
description: LISHNOFF-Malcolm M. Of Virginia Beach, VA., died there on April 11, 1999. Survived by wife, Muriel (Mikula); daughters, Yvette Geary of NYC and Jane Ellen Glasser of Norfolk; granddaughter, Hara Brooke Glasser of Aventura, Fla.; brother, Al Lishnoff, and sister, Pauline Reinish of NYC; and many loving nieces and nephews. Also survived by Muriel's three children and eight grandchildren. Mr. Lishnoff was predeceased by granddaughter, Jessica Rachel Glasser.

title: Society of Outcasts Began With a $99 Black Coat
description: Tad Boles's mother bought him an Australian duster for Christmas in 1996 because the coats were on sale at Miller Stockman, a western wear outlet, for $99.

title: KENT Snaps Slump With 27-Pin Victory
description: Doug Kent's victory yesterday in the Johnny Petraglia Open in North Brunswick, N.J., gave the 11-year pro a boost of confidence and a critical infusion of cash.

title: Circumnavigator
description: To the Editor: Now that Daisann McLane has returned from her global circumnavigation, as she reported in ''Chronicle of a Circumspect Circumnavigator'' (April 4), I am sure that she will be happy to know that she is eligible for membership in the only organization for those who have crossed every meridian in one direction.

title: A Chairman Bets Big On a Turnaround
description: With timing like this, who needs a salary? Dr. Thomas Frist Jr., chairman and chief executive of Columbia/HCA Healthcare, bought $49.9 million of the company's stock in March as the shares traded near five-year lows.

title: You Can Copy Off Me
description: THE MEME MACHINE By Susan Blackmore. Foreword by Richard Dawkins. 264 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: Bosnia's Loss is an American City's Gain
description: AN unexpected side effect of the turmoil in the Balkans has Steve Hrdlicka hopping.

title: Why a Priest
description: When I was a Jesuit seminarian, in pre-Vatican Council days, the argument against birth control (we didn't even consider homosexuality) was that sexual intercourse was ordered toward conception. Any act that was not open to conception was intrinsically immoral. Apparently the argument has shifted away from the scholastic and toward the existential: you must give yourself totally to the other.

title: Playing Chicken With Milosevic
description: Until Milo Djukanovic's new best friends in the United States and Western Europe began to drop bombs on Montenegro in late March, life had been going along swimmingly for the handsome young President of this Yugoslav republic.

title: ATTACK AT SCHOOL PLANNED A YEAR, AUTHORITIES SAY
description: The two young men who shot and bombed their way through their high school here planned the assault a year in advance, monitored cafeteria crowds to determine the busiest times and scheduled their suicide attack for Hitler's birthday, the authorities said today, citing a handwritten diary.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, LAWRENCE I.
description: COHEN-Lawrence I. 4/20/89. In cherished and loving memory of our dearly beloved father, grandfather and brother. Sadly missed. Always in our hearts. Richard Jay and daughters Lindsey & Ashley and sister Lucille

title: This One's on the House, But It'll Cost You
description: THE flat roof was perfected in Egypt 3,000 years ago. It worked well enough, sheltering the inhabitants from dust, heavy-footed birds and the neighbor's sacred cats. But it didn't keep out the rain. The Egyptians were and are willing to live with this inconvenience, because it almost never rains there; the place is a desert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILCHMAN, HERMAN
description: MILCHMAN-Herman. On April 22, 1999, in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 94 years old. Founder and past president of Carter, Milchman & Frank, Inc. Beloved husband of Sally. Devoted father of Arline Bassel and the late Philip, Claire and Neil Rechtweg. Caring grandfather of Larry (Wendy), Peter (Cindy), Joanne (Alan), Jay, Leslie (Brian), David and Heather. Proud great-grandfather of Jennifer, Alison, Erica, Andrew, Perri and Daniel. He was a self-made man respected by his industry and much admired and loved by his family. He will be missed. Graveside Sunday, April 25.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FUTERSACK, SONIA
description: FUTERSACK-Sonia: One year, Ten years or one hundred years, I'll never forget you. Rest with the angels my friend.

title: A Time Capsule From A.B.T.
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER

title: Advocating That Butterflies Be Caught With a Lens, Not a Net
description: The North American Butterfly Association, based in Morristown, has grown from its founding in 1993 to include more than 3,000 members in 25 chapters across the United States, Mexico and Canada. The group promotes net-free butterflying and speaks out against such commercial use of butterflies as releasing them at weddings. The association's founder, Jeffrey Glassberg, editor of American Butterflies magazine and author of two butterfly field guides, recently spoke about his work.

title: Norman Williams, 85, Lawyer And Expert on Stamp Collecting
description: Norman Williams, a British lawyer best known as a prolific writer about stamps and stamp collecting, died on April 9 in London. He was 85.

title: Beth Neelman and Louis Silfin
description: Beth Karen Neelman and Louis Salem Silfin were married last evening by Rabbi Ira M. Flax at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, HENRY
description: SMITH-Henry. Of Palm Beach, FL on April 22, 1999 at age 91. Beloved husband of the late Theodora A. Smith. Loving father of Gordon and Norma Smith and Fran Heller. Cherished grandfather of Randy Smith and Peter Aberg, Dr. Robin Smith and Dr. Kaare Kolstad, Melissa Haveson Pavese and John Pavese & Kim Haveson. Adoring great grandfather of Ashley Aberg and Alan Aberg. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday 11:30AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Horace Mann School.

title: PULSE; Selling By the Closet Full
description: ''As soon as Jerry Falwell mentioned it, I couldn't keep Tinky Winky in the store,'' said Roger Roth, an owner of the Roger & Dave gift shop, at Eighth Avenue and 22d Street. He has reordered Tinky Winky Tel etubby dolls, shown here in his window, four times since February, when Mr. Falwell accused the purse-toting television character of ''modeling the gay life style.''

title: A Hospital Expands by Closing Its Doors
description: When it was founded in 1869, the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital announced its mission as nothing less than ''the alleviation of the sufferings of the poor'' and ''the prevention of pauperism.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, ROBIN MILLER
description: FELDMAN-Robin Miller. The family of the late Robin Feldman wish to thank all of our friends and relatives for the many expressions of condolence in loving memory of our beloved mother, daughter, sister and grandmother. She was a true and devoted friend to many with exceptional character. Thank you for helping us through this trying time in our lives. Anne and Gary Miller Douglas, Todd & Gregg Feldman

title: NATO Missed Best Chance at Peace; The First Miscalculation
description: To the Editor:

title: A Leveraged Buyout Fund For the Run-of-the-Mill Rich
description: Leveraged-buyout funds for individuals are here. Or at least buyout funds for pretty rich individuals.

title: Gold-Dust Twins From California
description: The '97 Napa Valley sauvignon blanc from Beringer, a great winery, and '97 sauvignon blanc from Matanzas Creek in Sonoma, are gold-dust twins. You can't easily find higher standards of taste and finesse in California's treatment of this grape.

title: Whites' Bias Lawsuit Could Upset Desegregation Efforts
description: One could hardly blame Bill Capacchione for wanting his 6-year-old daughter Cristina to attend Olde Providence Elementary School.

title: Starting Over
description: Melinda Henneberger said my style of interview was like answering questions ''from a friendly cabby on the way to the airport.'' Thank you, Melinda. Friendly (curious) cabdrivers learn more in 45 minutes than most newspaper writers learn in a week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FLORANT, ANNE
description: FLORANT - Anne. Respected WILPF leader and U.N. representative. Memorial service, April 29, 11AM, at U.N. Church Center.

description: To the Editor:

title: Clark Munnell and Esra Ansay
description: Esra Ansay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Engin A. Ansay of New York and Istanbul, Turkey, was married on Friday to Thomas Clark Munnell Jr., a son of Alicia H. Munnell of Boston and Mr. Munnell of Duxbury, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Pike performed the ceremony, combining Episcopal and Islamic traditions, at the Essex House in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOSLOFF, JUDY
description: KOSLOFF-Judy. Always in our thoughts, we miss you very much. Love, Mike, Janie, Chuck, Andrea and Andrew

title: London Theater
description: To the Editor: I was surprised by the 23 percent surcharge Anita Gates paid for tickets ordered over the Internet. She would have paid much less had she used Good Show! London Theatre and Booking Service (www.goodshow.com). Good Show! charges a flat $25 fee for two plays with a maximum of six tickets per show. For each additional show there is a $10 fee, again for a maximum of six tickets. The site provides reviews of everything in London, including the West End, the Royal Shakespeare Company (both London and Stratford), and the National Theater, plus fringe productions.

title: Diplomat Says Serbs Want Some Albanians in Kosovo
description: Serbian authorities in Kosovo say they are trying to remake the demographic balance of the province and sharply reduce Albanian power there, according to a senior European diplomat who was recently in the province.

title: High Technology's Ebb and Flow
description: THE selloff in technology and Internet stocks that climaxed last Monday illustrated a Wall Street adage: When the tide goes out, you can see who has been swimming naked.

title: Where Chaplains Find Pastoral Training
description: ONE member of the group is a state welfare case worker. Another is a crisis intervention aide at a Norwalk elementary school. Still another is a former alcohol and substance abuse counselor. In all, the group is composed of three women and two men, all of whom dedicate a minimum of 16 hours a week to being a student chaplain in the Clinical Pastoral Education program at Norwalk Hospital.

title: Jets' Rookie Offensive Guards Will Get Their Chances
description: They tiptoe around the subject, which isn't easy if you're 300 pounds.

title: A Bill to Increase Bond Transparency
description: Investors frustrated by the dearth of bond price data may soon be getting some help from Washington. The House of Representatives is expected to consider a bill this week that would require corporate bond traders to disclose the same kind of price, volume and other data as stock traders do. The bill, the Bond Price Competition Improvement Act of 1999, instructs the Securities and Exchange Commission to insure that transaction information is made public. The S.E.C. would decide how to disseminate the data.

title: The Bard, By the Book
description: NOW is the spring of content for friends of the Bard. With ''Shakespeare in Love'' still drawing audiences, they can look forward to ''The Taming of the Shrew'' this summer at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. Before that, comes a movie of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' with Kevin Kline as Bottom, and, later this year, the screen will bring us Julie Taymor's version of the rarely performed ''Titus Andronicus,'' with Anthony Hopkins as that much-suffering monster.

title: Who Needs Corps of Engineers? Nature Replenishes a Beach
description: A year of mild weather and no significant storms has allowed a sand bar six miles long to migrate to the shore at Avalon and Stone Harbor, more than doubling the size of the beach in some places.

title: Musings at Spring Cleaning Time
description: MY husband's out of the closet. It's not an alternative life style -- he's simply seeking square footage. Our 1930 Tudor chalet has lots of charm, but few closets. Robert gave me the bedroom hole-in-the-wall, while he transformed a photographer's darkroom into a fashion mausoleum. But his wardrobe is expanding because of end-of-season sales and incoming catalogues. There are so many garments so tightly packed that, although on hangers, the clothes don't really hang but seem suspended in midair. It's like a science experiment, like the high-pressure process that turns anthracite into diamonds and fossil remains into fuel. I wonder if the fibers can sustain the pressure?

title: Circumnavigator
description: To the Editor: Thanks to Daisann McLane for giving such a detailed description of her round-the-globe travel wardrobe. But one essential item was missing: shoes.

title: China in Orlando
description: To the Editor: Another place near Winter Park, Orlando, that Sarah Ferrell (''Frugal Traveler,'' March 14), could have visited is China's theme park, Splendid China, two miles west of Disney World off U.S. 192. It is a wondrous, 32-acre exhibition of China's historical, social and religious landmarks (although tickets, $28.88, are not cheap).

title: Hilary Vartanian, Andrew Borinstein
description: Hilary Meris Vartanian and Andrew Bruce Borinstein were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, officiated at the home of Jane Fire-Kalymnios, a sister of the bridegroom, and her husband, John Kalymnios.

title: Lives; Hi, I'm Louisa. I Mean Eliza. I Mean Sam.
description: I lie when I travel. I've made up stories about who I am and what I'm doing and even what my name is. Blame the recirculating air, blame the peanuts or simply blame me -- the lies seem to just fall out of my mouth.

title: NATO Missed Best Chance at Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. McDonald And Mr. Odell
description: Therese Marie McDonald, a daughter of Diane McDonald and Dr. R. Emmett McDonald of Houston, was married last evening to Christopher Mohr Odell, the son of Susan A. Odell of Philadelphia and the late Peter N. Odell. The Rev. Edward L. Stein, the Episcopal chaplain of Rice University, officiated at the Houston Zoological Gardens.

title: A French Painter's American Links
description: The Parisian artist who arrived in New Orleans on a sunny fall day in 1872 to visit his mother's American family, the well-connected Mussons, stepped into the midst of stylish Creole society. He left in March with a rich record of his visit, work that can be seen in an exhibition that opens Saturday at the New Orleans Museum of Art, ''Degas and New Orleans: A French Impressionist in America.''

title: Handbags That Hold A Bit of the Past
description: A designer handbag popularity sweepstakes has many contenders. Every top fashion designer, along with the traditional quality-leather-goods houses, has started a collection of bags, making this the year of the accessory. Now leading the race are Fendi and Gucci. Both have dipped into their archives and revived softly unconstructed bags that fit snugly under the arm, an idea that came from Chanel earlier in the century to free women's hands. The Fendi bag (top row, except far right), which returned in 1997 in one fabric, took the lead last year after it started to use other materials too. This spring, its supremacy is being challenged by Gucci's revival of a 1960's winner (bottom row), in both the original green-and-red-banded monogram model and in a bevy of new and flowery colors. A new contender may soon challenge the duo: an oversize bag by Louis Vuitton (top row, far right) is gaining status as a weekend carryall.

title: Did He Inhale?
description: GORE

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Americans with Disabilities Act misstated an Equal Employment Opportunity Commission guideline for ''reasonable accommodation'' under the act. The Commission requires employers to change supervisory methods for a disabled employee, not to change the supervisor.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: MISTRESS OF UDOLPHO

title: April 18-24; Dismissed, Handsomely
description: A pair of prominent corporate chiefs with similar surnames had something else in common: both were casualties of the Internet economy.

title: Mucha in Prague
description: To the Editor: I was told on a recent visit to the Mucha Museum that the ''Slav Epic'' paintings were soon to be installed in a building across the street from the newly restored municipal house in the Old Town.

title: Talking Their Way Around the Truth
description: IN Bren's Bar, the tables are solid; the tablecloths are just so; the lighting is subtle; the booze is brand-name, and the talk is cheap.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: BURNING GIRL

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart last Sunday with an article about financial disappointments at Revlon Inc. misstated the 1998 sales of L'Oreal of France, and the percentage gain from 1997. Using the average daily 1998 exchange rate of the franc to the dollar, L'Oreal reported 1998 sales of $10.4 billion, not $9.9 billion -- up 8.6 percent, not 2.4 percent.

title: ART REVIEWS; Bidding a Century Farewell With Sculpture
description: '20th-Century Sculpture'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAVIN, J. GREGORY
description: GAVIN-J. Gregory. Students, parents and teachers of House 32 at The Dalton School mourn the passing of Gregory Gavin, father of Greer and Ashley and husband of Cathy. We extend our deepest sympathies.

title: A Nation Turns Its Eyes to Center Field, One More Time
description: The most haunting question in all of sports -- ''Where have you gone, Joe DiMaggio?'' -- should be answered today. Joe DiMaggio has gone to the monument valley beyond center field in Yankee Stadium. While his body is not buried there, his spirit will be consecrated in that hallowed ground.

title: Nabokov's Perfect Reader
description: VERA (Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov). By Stacy Schiff. Illustrated. 456 pp. New York: Random House. $27.95.

title: Swing Keels Now Available For Recreational Use, Too
description: Nontraditional sailboats with swing keels are making news in professional round-the-world races these days. But now a new production boat for recreational sailors using the same kind of keel mechanism is about to be launched.

title: For Newcomers, an Archive in Human Form
description: SOMEWHERE in a studio at American Ballet Theater at any given moment in the months leading up to the company's season at the Metropolitan Opera House, which opens tomorrow, there was a dancer waiting to learn about the history of the classical ballet. The lesson would not be learned from books or written notes or even videotapes, though all contribute to an intellectual sense of the centuries-old art and the specific work to be studied that day. It was a history that walked quietly through the door, turned to the pianist and clapped its hands for the rehearsal to begin.

title: Sports of The Times; Jeter Has All Ingredients for Making of Another Yankee Great
description: DEREK JETER, on several occasions, had the pleasure of meeting Joe DiMaggio, and the pleasure, at least on the surface, was usually all his.

title: April 18-24; Backlash in Turkey
description: Turkey turned inward as its voters favored two nationalistic parties, one from the far right, the other leftist. Twenty years ago the two parties, Democratic Left and Nationalist Action, fought in the street. Now they are poised to join in a ruling coalition under Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit. The election results reflected anger at the European Union's refusal to accept Turkey as a candidate for membership. STEPHEN KINZER

title: Q & A
description: Greenwich Dome Tickets

title: April 18-24; Another Link
description: Fossil hunters in Ethiopia think they have added a new branch to the human family tree. They announced the discovery of the skull and other fossils of a previously unknown 2.5 million-year-old species they named Australopithecus garhi. It is, they said, ''in the right place, at the right time'' to be a descendant of the famed ''Lucy'' species and the long-sought immediate ancestor of the genus Homo. JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

title: Getting Silly, for the Love of a Parade
description: The Doo Dah parade is all about inviting ridicule, so it made sense that its main event this year was the brigade of the basset hounds, about 200 of them right behind the high school marching band. It was a mile-and-a-half march for dogs that are not good at walking.

title: It's Sometimes Live! It's on Saturday Night!
description: AT the Hollywood sound stage where ''Mad TV'' is filmed, a pair of sketches were being shot recently that perfectly encapsulated this late-night show's fascinating inconsistency. In one of the pop culture parodies at which the show excels, Aries Spears, a series regular, was using an impression of the hothead prizefighter Mike Tyson to spoof a Gap clothing commercial. ''This is easy!'' Mr. Spears exclaimed in a high-pitched lisp, shortly after burying his head into the neck of one of the extras swing dancing around him, then rearing back with a bloody prosthetic ear jiggling from his mouth.

title: Power Quest Drives Leader As Venezuela Goes to Polls
description: For the last month, Venezuela's new President, Hugo Chavez, has been demanding that Congress be dissolved and threatening to declare a state of emergency, which would allow him to rule by decree.

title: Giving Dress in Modern Art Its Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Welcome to the Neighborhood
description: WHEN a Jewish family moves into our neighborhood, representatives of our synagogue welcome them with wine and challah, staples of the sacred Sabbath meal. We are currently reining in our hospitality, though, so as not to offend our newest neighbors here in central New Jersey, the American Association of Atheists, who moved their headquarters from Texas to Cranford this month. Their local presence in the past was actually a source of collaboration on some, if not all, issues.

title: Starting Over
description: Political preferences aside, my biggest objection to Dan Quayle's obtaining any national platform or office is his inability to speak intelligible English. In your article, he misuses the word ''reference'' when he must mean ''comparison'': ''We do not make any references of Marilyn to Hillary.'' Although these errors can be amusing, such a serious lack of precision in language should be unacceptable in anyone aiming for public office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, PETER
description: FRANK-Peter. On April 24, in his 68th year. Beloved husband of Marcia. Cherished father of David and Ann, and Kathy. Loving stepfather of Richard and Karen, Peter, and Larry and Debbie. Services Monday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to ''Chapel Haven'' School for the Learning Disabled, 1040 Whalley Ave., Westville, CT 06515.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIDEMANN, EVE
description: WEIDEMANN-Eve, 83, of San Francisco. Widow of Walter. Daughter of Dr. Harry and Bessie Lipkin. Survivors: son Dr. Myles Lippe, daughter Sheila Leader, granddaughters Alexandra and Danielle Leader.

title: The Fight for the Future Of Florida's Fisher Island
description: To the Editor:

title: April 18-24; China Stole Design Of U.S. Nuclear Warhead
description: Soon after the furor over China's theft of America's nuclear secrets began last month, President Clinton said he wasn't so sure any spying had taken place. But a Government report seems to have stopped the debate. The new analysis concludes that in the 1980's China stole design information related to America's most advanced nuclear warhead from Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLERAN, LEO BAKER, JR.
description: HALLERAN-Leo Baker, Jr. Age 50, of East Lyme, CT, passed away at his home peacefully, April 23, 1999, after a courageous battle with cancer. Born in NYC, he was the son of the late Dr. Leo Baker Halleran and Virginia Ella Ros Halleran. He attended St. David's and the Allen Stevenson schools in NYC, and the Cardinal Farley Military Academy in Rhinebeck, NY. He is survived by his wife, the former Judith Andrade, his son Baker, and daughter Julia, his four siblings, Virginia Halleran Church of Brooklyn, NY, David Halleran of Jamesville, NY, Michael Halleran of Seattle, WA, and Nancy Halleran Killie, of Richfield, CT. Calling hours will be held at the Molloy Funeral Home, 906 Farmington Ave., West Hartford, CT, Monday from 4 to 8 PM. Funeral services will be Tuesday, at 11:30 AM, in St. Agnes Church, Columbus Ave., Niantic, CT. Donations in his memory may be made to Hospice of Southeastern Connecticut, PO Box 902, Uncasville, CT 06382-0902.

title: Our Towns; Ah, Hamptons: Sun, Sand And Lawsuits
description: IF Cindy Adams were dishing this particular item, she might give it a new twist on her famous kicker: Only in the Hampton, kids, only in the Hamptons.

title: New Adoption Law Works Against Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Man of the Hour

title: Another Entry Into Steakhouse Country
description: LONG ISLAND'S longstanding love affair with steakhouses continues. A few years ago a wave of big beef restaurants swept over the Island: $10.95 steak places, a few middle-priced chains and a number of top-of-the-line prime beef restaurants. The trend seemed to ebb for a while but in the last six months there has been a resurgence: Rothmann's opened in East Norwich over the winter, as did the Smithtown branch of the Original Frank's of Wantaugh. The site on 25A in Great Neck that had been Salute and before that the North Street Grill, is, at present, being converted to an upscale steakhouse.

title: Life and Death in the 90's
description: THE night before we set my mother free, I went to my first political fund-raiser as a paying guest. Two grown-up events within 24 hours.

title: Sound Bites Over Jerusalem
description: It was a warm and sunny saturday morning, the heart of the Sabbath, and most of Jerusalem was shuttered -- except for a second-floor corner suite in the King David Hotel, looking out over the Jaffa Gate and the rough stone walls guarding the Old City. Inside, the fax machine beeped, a cell phone trilled and Israeli newspapers and campaign memos were scattered across the floor. An easel displaying scribbled poll numbers was perched in a corner, and dirty plates, half-filled coffee cups and wineglasses littered the tables, the remnants of 12 hours of breakfast and dinner meetings. There was no sign on the door, but the suite served as the headquarters for the re-election campaign of Benjamin Netanyahu, the Prime Minister of Israel, if only for one reason: Arthur J. Finkelstein, the Republican political consultant from the United States, was in Jerusalem today, and this is where he was staying.

title: Moscow Says It Will Defy Oil Embargo Against Serbs
description: Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov of Russia responded today to NATO's decision to impose an oil embargo on Yugoslavia, saying Russia would continue to ship oil there ''in keeping with our international commitments.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WINTER, DORA
description: WINTER-Dora. Our dear mother, grandmother, great-grandmother -her memory is a blessing to four generations. April 30, 197

title: The Blue-Collar School of Fine Art
description: ART historians and critics have striven for decades to describe the paintings of Joe Zucker, but he continually confounds the experts by shifting gears.

title: Weimar
description: Anyone who imagines the former East Germany as grim, gray and dominated by Stalinist architecture is in for a surprise in Weimar. Even during the four decades of Communism, this small city in Thuringia was protected as a cultural jewel. Because of Weimar's history as home to many of Germany's greatest writers and composers, notably the poet Goethe, Communist authorities took pains to preserve many of its stately homes and historic flavor.

title: Treating the Doctor's Bedside Manner
description: IT was bad enough that Maryanne had major abdominal surgery, ended up in the critical care unit for a bad reaction to medication and missed six weeks of work, and that her best friend never visited her in the hospital. The 40-year-old woman from East Williston, who asked that her last name not be used, said the worst part was that during her most difficult days she was never visited by a doctor who ''listened to me, told me what was happening or even said hello.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When I was growing up, most of the ministers I knew were women. I never had to wonder, could women be ministers?''

title: What Rivalry?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Kancelbaum, Mr. Weine
description: Barbara Rebecca Kancelbaum and Kenneth Neil Weine are to be married today by Rabbi Andrew N. Bachman at the Picnic House in Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

title: Confessions of an Over-Age 'Star Wars' Conscript
description: THE Force wasn't with me, and my little niece and nephew didn't like it. I am, after all, their epic-making uncle, the one who orchestrates sea battles in the bathtub, death scenes in the elevator and costume dramas on demand. But when ''Star Wars'' became part of their world view (their parents bought the trilogy on video last year) they started spinning into a Luke- and Leia-centric universe without me.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, ELLA
description: AUERBACH-Ella. The Board and staff of Selfhelp Community Services note with sorrow the passing of a devoted member of our community. One of the first professionals employed by the agency, she brought an understanding of the needs of new arrivals to this country and a willingness to help them find their way. Her interest in the agency continued in recent years as an active member of the Concert Committee well into her 90's. Her work will continue.

title: Correction
description: An entry in the Benefits column last Sunday about a reception at Gallery Henoch in SoHo this Thursday to raise money for Court Appointed Special Advocates, a group that helps children in foster care, misstated the telephone number for tickets and information. It is (212) 334-4010, extension 149.

title: Giants' Rookie Traveled Winding Road to N.F.L.
description: Reared in Evansville, Ind., Sean Bennett didn't have to look far for an athletic role model. Everybody in town was a fan of Evansville's Don Mattingly.

description: ROSEN-Harold. Delaire Country Club and its Board of Governors mourns the loss of its member, Harold Rosen, and extends its deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Jeanette, and his bereaved family. Robert Goldberg, President

description: Dr. Jeralyn Anise Bernier, a pediatrician, and Dr. Brian Richard Jacobs, a specialist in pediatric critical care, are to be married today in Washington. Rabbi Gerald Serotta is to officiate at the Sequoia, a restaurant.

title: Robert Johnston, 80; Naval Engineer Designed Hydrofoils
description: Robert James Johnston, a naval engineer who became an innovative designer of hydrofoils and other high-speed watercraft, died on April 16 at his home in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 80.

title: Peace Through Patience, Not Air Power
description: Fifty-four years ago this month, I became the director for overall effects of the United States Strategic Bombing Survey. After some months of work with a talented staff, the interrogation of Albert Speer and other German officials and the examination of excellent German records, we concluded that the great strategic air attacks had not appreciably reduced German war production. Nor had they effectively shortened the war. That was won by ground troops with tactical air support up from Normandy and across the vast plains of Russia.

title: Charlotte Rolls Over The Nets
description: HORNETS 97, NETS 82

title: Kathleen Killen and Paul Veteri
description: Kathleen Marie Killen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Killen of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Paul Michael Veteri, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Veteri of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Leonard J. Kempski performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Wilmington.

title: How the Russians Marched from One Esthetic to Another
description: IT is sometimes said that artistic development depends on social stability -- that times of great upheaval make real achievement difficult, if not impossible. That notion can be easily demolished by a glance at the amazing fecundity of Russian art and literature in the period stretching for about a dozen years on either side of the 1917 revolution.

title: April 18-24; Limits on Scraping the Sky
description: The zoning theory behind Manhattan's landscape since 1961 is called ''tower in the park.'' As in: throw down some concrete, call it a park and build the building higher. Developers move air rights around like chess pieces, and those ''parks'' become giant ashtrays for the shiver-and-puff crowd. Now city planners, calling the old ways ''flawed,'' want strict limits outside midtown and downtown.

title: FILM; A Well-Mannered Mamet Retells A Victorian Tale
description: THIS is not the David Mamet one reads about. There is no reticence, no sarcasm, no intimidating the interviewer with silence. He smiles. He's chatty and avuncular; the soul of graciousness. This David Mamet radiates neither disdain nor self-absorption, but instead that most un-Mametian quality: contentment.

title: Davis's Late Blast Is a Boost For Yanks
description: Chili Davis has admitted that this could be his final season in major league baseball. He is 39 years old, and he sometimes trudges around the bases so slowly that it seems he might be better off just walking swiftly. Davis does not really run. He lumbers.

description: Roy Halladay is not that far removed from Arvada West High School. Only four years, to be exact. As a baseball and basketball player there, he played against teams from Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., 18 miles southeast of Arvada.

description: The Long Island economy will remain strong through 1999 but cool ever so slightly in the year 2000, a regional economist, Thomas Conoscenti, told the Long Island Regional Planning Board this month.

title: Political Briefing; In Fund-Raising Race, Democrats Set Pace
description: The race is on to see which party can raise the most campaign cash for next year's contest for control of the House of Representatives. Given that Republicans now control the 435-seat body by only about a dozen seats, only the Presidential race is likely to see more money-grubbing over the next 19 months.

title: April 18-24; Reichstag Reopens
description: The new Germany, exquisitely sensitive to its past, informally welcomed back its Parliament to a refurbished Reichstag in Berlin. Topped with glass to symbolize the political transparency on which the country has based its postwar revival, the building was restored at a cost of $330 million by the British architect Sir Norman Foster. Chancellor Gerhard Schroder said it was the success of ''Bonn democracy'' that ''makes the Berlin Republic possible.'' Later an oompah band played and meatballs and beer were served.

title: Refugees From Kosovo May Arrive Friday
description: Refugees from Kosovo may arrive at Fort Dix, N.J., as early as Friday, officials in neighboring Pemberton Township were told by military officials last week.

title: In the Region /Westchester; Assisted Living Proposed for Iona Yonkers Campus
description: PLANS for this city's first facility serving both the independent elderly and assisted-living residents , with a total of 250 apartments, are shaping up for a bluff overlooking the Hudson River on a former campus of Iona College.

title: Knocked Down, Yes. Knocked Out, Never.; The Town of Orange, No Stranger to Bad News, Struggles to Make Sense of Police Shooting and Its Aftermath
description: TO better understand this fraying, rough-and-tumble town of 30,000 people, it helps to know a bit about Orange's most cherished native son, Two-Ton Tony Galento, the man who survived four bloody rounds with Joe Louis during a 1939 bout at Yankee Stadium.

description: The Disobedience of Water

title: Q&A/Roland J. Harris; Advocate for Mohegans, and Sovereignty
description: ROLAND J. HARRIS is the Tribal Chairman of the Mohegan Pequots, who operate the Mohegan Sun casino in eastern Connecticut. The casino consists of a 650,000-square-foot complex that holds 25,000 to 30,000 visitors a day. In addition, the tribe has proposed a $950 million expansion that will include 100,000 square feet of gaming space, a 10,000-seat arena, 37-story hotel and 300,000 square feet of retail space. The Mohegan Pequots are one of two Federally recognized Native American tribes in the state (the other is the Mashantucket Pequots). Four other tribes are in various stages of the process of being recognized. Mr. Harris is one of the advocates of a state-level council out of the Governor's office that would coordinate with the tribes to work on state tribal relations.

title: Sports of The Times; Mia Hamm Raises Bar for U.S. Soccer
description: SHE has not scored in six games. In some sports that would be a disaster, in others a slump. In soccer, six games without a goal could be considered a mere statistical blip, but not for the productive and marketable Mia Hamm.

Brother of Jennifer Weiler of Chicago, IL. Also survived by nine nieces and nephews. Funeral from Quinn Hopping Funeral Home, 145 E. Mt. Pleasant Ave. (Route 10), Livingston, NJ, on Tuesday, April 27, 1999, at 9:30 AM. Funeral Mass will be offered at St. Rose of Lima Church, East Hanover, NJ, at 10:30 AM. Mr. Goodwin, an associate professor of sociology at New York University, goes into the streets and videotapes demonstrations to judge them as theater.

title: Corrections
description: The article on April 4 about young Catholic priests and seminarians misidentified the religious order of Fra Angelico, the 15th-century painter and friar. He was a Dominican, not a Franciscan. The article also misspelled the name of the fourth-century doctrine that taught that Jesus was not God but merely a higher being. It is Arianism, not Aryanism.

title: Rediscovering the Work of a Great Self-Deprecator
description: IF the average American knows the name of the French composer Paul Dukas at all, it is probably in connection with an image of Mickey Mouse wearing a baggy red robe and a wizard's hat, battling anthropomorphic broomsticks to the strains of Dukas's ''Sorcerer's Apprentice.'' Walt Disney's use of that piece in the movie ''Fantasia'' made Dukas more famous than he might have dreamed, or even hoped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, WILLIAM
description: BROWN-William. Peacefully on April 22, 1999, at home in East Rockaway, NY, after a brief illness. Loving husband of Gertrude, his wife of more than 60 years, and proud father of Robert, Alan and Carol, and grandfather of Nicholas, Deborah, Joshua, Rachel and Wendy. After graduating from Pratt Institute, Bill became a sound man in the radio studios of CBS in 1939. From 1941 to 1947 he was a senior engineer at RCA. In 1951, he founded Hermetic Aircraft Instrument Corporation, a facility to test and repair aircraft instruments, which became a worldwide full-service repair station with close links to the French aircraft industry. He also co-founded Aerospace Lighting Corporation, a manufacturer of aircraft lighting systems for business jets, which was recognized in 1998 as one of Long Island's 25 fastest growing companies. Bill served as a Director of Norstar Bank and as a member of the East Rockaway Board of Education. He will be remembered for his enthusiasm, vigor and devotion to family and friends. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, April 25, at 1:30 p.m. at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the National Tuberous Sclerosis Association, 8181 Professional Place, Landover, MD 20785-2226 or Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchant Concourse, Westbury, NY 11590.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWN, DAVID A.
description: DAWN-David A. 87, of Boca Raton, FL and Southampton, NY, died April 21 in Boca Raton surrounded by his family and friends. He is survived by his beloved wife Helga Roswitha Dawn, two daughters Alice Rosemarie Dawn and Carolyn May Dawn; his son Robert Stuart Dawn, his stepsons Dr. Peter Joseph Weiden and Dr. Michael David Weiden; his grandchildren Michael Scott Leland and Deborah Dawn Leland; his step granddaughter Aurora Garber Weiden and a great grandson, David Andrew Leland. David Dawn was born in Brooklyn, NY. In his youth he was a world class swimmer and remained an avid athlete throughout his life. Founder and president of Alice Stuart, a division of Jonathan Logan, he became Jonathan Logan's first president. As board member and president of the National Association of Sportswear Manufacturers, he was a pioneer in the sportswear industry. Recipient of the Citizens' Merit Award for Services to New York City by Mayor Beame. Trustee and president of the Board of Trustees of the Jewish Memorial Hospital of New York in the '60s. After retiring from business 22 years ago, he applied his life-long passion for horticulture to creating a rose garden at his Southampton home which, over the years, has become one of the most renowned private rose gardens in America. He generously shared his expertise with the community at large and his garden was open to many charities. The Garden Club of America awarded him the prestigious Jane Richter Rose Medal in 1988. He was also a consultant at the New York Botanical Garden for the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden. He will be remembered for his strength of character, dedication, energy, integrity, and great sense of humor. His family and friends will never forget him. Funeral arrangements are private and a memorial service will be held at his rose garden in June. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Southamption Fresh Air Home, P.O. Box 244, Southampton, NY 11969

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCALL, DAVID
description: McCALL-David. Board members, officers, and friends of the Humpty Dumpty Institute mourn the loss of their friend and colleague, Mr. David McCall and his wife Penny. His deep commitment to humanitarian causes will be remembered by all who accompanied him on our trip to Africa last year to establish a new program to remove landmines in Africa and to return land to productive use. Our deepest sympathy to his family at this terrible time of loss. Michael W. Sonnenfeldt, Co-Chair William J. Rouhana, Jr., Co-Chair Constance J. Milstein, Vice Chair

description: RICHARD MORGAN was sitting in his kitchen one morning with his wife, Sandra, when a tapping sound distracted them from their breakfast. He looked up to see a bird, a tufted titmouse, perched next to his windowsill, pecking on the glass.

description: If you would like to rent a luxury car in London, Avis has inaugurated a program that it says can guarantee you the make and model you want within 24 hours of your request -- a distinction that those who get ''or similar'' will appreciate.

title: Apartment Insurance Coverage
description: WHEN Marilyn Scarano returned home from work on March 18, she saw smoke billowing from the roof of her 96-unit co-op building in Long Beach, N.Y. Watching firefighters pour water into the building, Ms. Scarano said, her only consolation was that she and her husband, Bob, had insurance coverage for the furniture, fixtures and personal belongings in their apartment.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-25-99 - The Ethicist; War Games
description: I play board games depicting historical battles. It seems like innocent fun to command Macedonian forces against the Persian Army, but what about commanding the Germans in a W.W.II simulation -- and really playing to win? Are some subjects above a recreational pastime? -- Ananda Gupta, Washington

title: Nina Burleigh and Erik Freeland
description: IN many ways, Nina Burleigh, 39, seems like a cross between a ballerina and a full-fledged hippie. She is a dark-haired, sprightly beauty with a regal bearing who rarely follows protocol in her personal life or in her clothes. ''She has her own quirky, individual style,'' said Maer Roshan, a friend. ''She wears gingham miniskirts and big boots, little weird chains and brooches, all mixed together.''

title: This Factory's Bats Are Going, Going, Gone; As Home of McGwire's 'Big Stick,' Struggling Upstate Town Gets a Lift
description: The folks here have nothing against Sammy Sosa, calling him a fine fellow and a great ballplayer. But for a year now, there has been no more passionate a group of Mark McGwire fans than the people of this wooded little village on the southwest shoulder of the Adirondacks.

title: A Bloom With A View
description: Despite dire pronouncements that its 15 minutes of fame are up, the orchid is still the flower of choice in the world of style. Pop your head into any fashion editor's office and you'll invariably find arcs of Phalaenopsis and sprays of Dendrobium as sleek and unfussy as the editors themselves. High society is mad for them, too: in January, the New York Botanical Garden's 13th annual Orchid Dinner -- which was graced with orchid centerpieces by design luminaries like Martha Stewart and Bill Blass -- raised $350,000. And just last month, at the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan, an estimated 75,000 visitors oohed and aahed over the 5,000 orchid plants on view at the New York International Orchid Show. Best flower: a cascading Dendrobium superbum that looked like a bridal veil of white blossoms.

title: Spurs Sporting an Edge in the West
description: He had scored San Antonio's last 10 points, including the game-winning 3-pointer with one-tenth of a second left to beat Houston. Mario Elie, fresh from shooting down his old team, then blew kisses to the crowd and cursed at his former Rockets teammates.

description: Jean Helen Osnos and William Joseph Volonte are to be married this evening at the Empire Hotel in Manhattan. Robert T. Snyder, an administrative law judge with the National Labor Relations Board in Manhattan, is to officiate.

title: Housing for Elderly Is Issue
description: A fight has broken out between city officials and Staten Island conservationists over the Economic Development Corporation's request for proposals to build a housing complex for the elderly. The complex would be on 40 acres of vacant city land next to Sea View Hospital and Rehabilitation Center and Home on Brielle Avenue.

title: 300th Birthday Party For Williamsburg, Va.
description: Three hundred years ago, in 1699, the Virginia Colony moved its capital five miles inland from Jamestown and named it Williamsburg for the reigning English king, William III. The city remained the capital until 1780 (when it was moved to Richmond), and this year is celebrating the anniversary of its founding with a series of exhibitions and programs. Through objects, manuscripts, photographs, paintings, rare books and prints, visitors can view the historical legacies of three centuries: the 18th at the John D. Rockefeller Jr. Library in Colonial Williamsburg, the 19th at the Swem Library at the College of William and Mary, and the 20th at the Williamsburg Regional Library.

title: April 18-24; Picasso the Car
description: Picasso's heirs can hardly be faulted for wanting to cash in on his name. Everyone else does, from makers of coffee mugs and T-shirts to museums that draw record crowds to the maestro's shows. Four heirs support the sale of his name and signature for a new auto, the Citroen Xsara Picasso, to be launched this fall. But Marina Picasso objects, saying her grandfather's genius is being ''exploited outrageously.'' Her share of the royalties will go a foundation for Vietnamese orphans, she says. ALAN RIDING

title: Q&A/Susan Arterian Chang; Paper Finding Pulse In Community Beat
description: SUSAN ARTERIAN CHANG, who is the founder, publisher and editor of The White Plains Watch, the newest newspaper in White Plains, said she ''won't be a Pollyanna'' but she does want to bring the city together, applaud its diversity and help mom-and-pop stores survive.

title: IN MY... BRIEFCASE: RICHARD S. STRONG
description: HE runs a company that manages $35 billion in assets, and he never needs batteries. That means no Palm Pilots, calculators or electronic organizers for Richard S. Strong, the founder and chairman of Strong Capital Management in Menomonee Falls, Wis., near Milwaukee.

title: Thoroughly Modernist
description: Now that the 20th century is almost over, nostalgia for it is setting in -- particularly among collectors and admirers of what are rapidly becoming the period's antiques. So the Lambertville-based Modernism Magazine is sponsoring ''20th-Century Design for the 21st Century,'' a discussion featuring the renowned furniture makers Vladimir Kagan, Mira Nakashima (daughter of George) and Richard Schultz. The panelists will share their insights on their work, its influence on contemporary crafts and its future as an industry. ''There are so few living legends of modern design that we decided to get them together,'' said Elizabeth England, a spokeswoman for the magazine's publisher, David Rago Auctions Inc., specializing in the Arts and Crafts movement and Modernist (defined as post-World War I) design. The discussion takes place on May 1 at 8 P.M., preceded by a cocktail reception at 7, at the Rago auction house, 333 North Main Street, Lambertville. Tickets are $25, with proceeds going to Fighting the AIDS Crisis Together. Information: (609) 397-9374. DIANE NOTTLE

title: A Locksmith, an Audience
description: THE SETTING -- A reading Tuesday night by Joel Kostman, a locksmith and the author of ''Keys to the City,'' a collection of short stories published in paperback by Penguin last month. About 60 people, many of them customers of Mr. Kostman, gathered at the Barnes & Noble bookstore at Seventh Avenue and Sixth Street to hear him read excerpts from the book. Mr. Kostman, who has been a locksmith for 20 years, based his stories on his work experiences.

At 13, he said, he bought personal computers for $1,500 each and resold them to less technologically savvy neighbors for $2,500. Four years ago, fresh out of law and business schools, Mr. Brotman, then 26, decided that the Internet would be a terrific place for people to post classified advertisements, and for him to make money. He rented a cramped 20-by-10-foot office a few blocks north of City Hall and started up Ad One Classified Network.

title: Giuliani Defends Proposal To Disband School Board

Giuliani vowed yesterday to forge ahead with his proposal to abolish the New York City Board of Education in the face of resistance from the State Legislature, describing the plan as an ''altruistic'' effort to eliminate a bureaucracy that hampers the instruction of children.

title: The Federalist
description: ALEXANDER HAMILTON, AMERICAN

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: SECOND SIGHT

title: Kristin Herron, Scott Gurney
description: Kristin Stacy Herron, an associate in the museum program of the New York State Council on the Arts in Manhattan, and Scott Grennon Gurney, a Federal park ranger, were married yesterday afternoon in Ann Arbor, Mich. The Rev. John S. Nieman performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: Trying to Make Police Force Diverse In New Haven
description: THE New Haven Police Department says it has begun its largest recruitment campaign ever, seeking to make the police force more representative of the community.

title: Country Life
description: THE SPELL

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Why a Priest
description: It is too bad that the Roman Catholic seminarians in Jennifer Egan's article (April 4) see themselves mainly preaching against masturbation, premarital sex and homosexuality. That good church also preaches strongly against capital punishment and the exploitation of God's people by runaway capitalism. It also stands for better education and social services.

title: Showing Off Flavors of the Middle East
description: MOTION picture sequels are often faint, inferior versions of the original. That's true for restaurants as well. The chefs, owners and managers who make a success of the first restaurant can't be in two places at one time. But there are exceptions like the dazzling new Ayhan's Shish Kebab Restaurant in the Plainview Shopping Center on South Oyster Bay Road (827-5300), an offspring of Shish Kebab in Port Washington. This most appealing Middle Eastern entry has the spirit of a Greek taverna and the look of a sun-baked Santorini villa.

title: Deidre Holmes, Paul Hespel
description: Deidre Ellen Holmes and Paul Wilfried Hespel were married yesterday by the Rev. Marilyn Morgan, an interfaith minister, at the Water Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHORR, RABBI SEYMOUR
description: SCHORR-Rabbi Seymour. 10 Iyar. Darling, two impossible years without you, missing you and loving you always. Your adoring family, Audrey, Ira and Nanette

title: A Cabinet Member's Middle-Class Values
description: The Clinton wealth redistribution program begins with his Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin. The editor of The New Yorker, David Remnick, interviewed Mr. Rubin, a former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs, last week before a well-off audience that included Laurence A. Tisch, the co-chairman of Loews; Bruce Wasserstein, the investment banker; John Gutfreund, the former Salomon Brothers chief, and Mike Wallace of CBS News.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGLAS, ROSLYN (NEE ROBERTS)
description: BERGLAS-Roslyn (nee Roberts). Of Forest Hills, NY on April 24, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Frank, Judi, Gaye and Kenneth. Loved by her grandchildren Brett, Allison, Austin and Diane. Adoring greatgrandmother of Oliver, and beloved sister of Sidney. Funeral service Sunday 1:30 PM at ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 114-03 Queens Blvd. Interment at Maimonides Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Strawberry Placed on Leave
description: Darryl Strawberry has been placed on administrative leave while an investigation continues into the circumstances surrounding charges that he solicited prostitution and was in possession of three-tenths of a gram of cocaine April 14 in Tampa, Fla., Bud Selig, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, said yesterday.

title: Where 'Little Women' Grew Up
description: MY daughter will tell you, if you ask, that she is named after Jo March, the strong-willed heroine of Louisa May Alcott's ''Little Women.'' She will say it with a tinge of apologizing for a parent's folly, and if I am nearby I will often interject some lighthearted comment about other famous Josephines -- Baker or Beauharnais, for example. But the truth is, she was named after Jo March and she knows it. Almost every year on her birthday, we somehow end up at Orchard House, the wooden house in Concord, Mass., where Alcott lived with her parents and her sisters, and where she wrote ''Little Women'' more than a century ago.

title: Surviving an Era Of Maoist Tumult With Calm Intact
description: Wu Tianming is well acquainted with the whims of fortune: During the 1980's, as an acclaimed director, he headed Xian Film Studio, the cradle of the New Chinese Cinema, which burst upon the international scene with the force of a revelation. Less than a decade later, he was reduced to running a video store in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAKER, FLORENCE
description: BAKER-Florence. April 25, 1994. Cherished Mother, we are missing your caring and sharing. Love always, Paula and Beau and Bobby

title: Gay Man Charged in a Killing Can Use a 'Battered Wife' Defense
description: John Stagno was a controlling and jealous boyfriend who threatened his live-in partner with a knife and a bottle, and kept the only key to their Crown Heights apartment, a lawyer contends in papers filed in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KILEY, RICHARD
description: KILEY-Richard. A memorial for the actor Richard Kiley will be held on Monday, May 3 at 12pm at The Helen Hayes Theatre, 240 West 44 Street, Manhattan. Mr. Kiley who created the dual roles of Don Quixote and Cervantes in the musical Man of La Mancha died in March. Participants in the memorial which is open to the public will include Arvin Brown, Jane Alexander, Albert Marre, Phillip Langner, Diahann Carroll, Shirley Verrett and Julie Harris among others.

title: The World; It's a Wonder This Alliance Is Unified
description: FOR most of the half-century it is celebrating in Washington this weekend, NATO's very existence has been rooted in the idea of a grand design -- to guarantee the safety of the West against the East, to forge a common defense of democracy against tyranny, to prepare, in effect, for World War III.

title: Ordinary Girls With Extraordinary Stories
description: A young girl moves with her family to a new home where everything is strange but also fresh and exciting. She makes friends with the neighbors and scribbles her impressions in her journal. A familiar tale but for the details: the girl is named Remember Patience Whipple (Mem for short), her family is a group of Pilgrims, and the neighbors she befriends are Squanto and his American Indian family.

title: Apostle of Inner Struggle and Redemption
description: A WOMAN among composers; a freethinker among Soviet apparatchiks; a Christian among atheists; an Easterner, half Tatar, among Europeans; a modernist among reactionaries, and a reactionary among modernists: Sofia Gubaidulina has lived with many conflicts, both with the outside world and within herself. Her arrival, in her 50's and 60's, at moments of extraordinary musical power has been a triumph of persistence and self-searching. Ms. Gubaidulina, now 67, has become a great light, and her achievement has happily been matched by steadily increasing public recognition, which reaches a culmination in New York on Thursday evening, when two big new works will be presented almost simultaneously: ''Two Paths,'' at Avery Fisher Hall, and ''In the Shadow of the Tree,'' at Carnegie Hall.

title: On the Wild Side In the Camargue
description: IT was approaching midnight when the guitarist threw his head back, fingers fanning down the strings, his nasal, almost hoarse Spanish directed at the dark-haired young woman to his right. She looked away, tilted her head and just perceptibly smiled. Then her hands flashed into castanetlike clapping, and the other diners in the darkened restaurant joined her. Two more men picked up guitars, a passer-by sang through the window, and almost everyone in the restaurant joined the chorus of ''Caminando por la Calle,'' the song made famous by the Gipsy Kings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, LAURA
description: PETERS-Laura. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Antony and Adrian, Michael and Barbara, Holly and Marc. Adored grandmother of Mark and Joan, Scott, Bradley, Kimberly, Amy and Robert, Elyssa, Rebecca and Jenna. Dear great grandmother of Emma Hope. Services will be on Sunday, 9:30am at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris. Interment to follow at the Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: 82% of School Budgets Are Approved by Voters
description: Voters approved more than 82 percent of the school budgets in the annual school board elections last week, the highest rate since 1986. Board members and budgets were considered in 551 districts, and 456 approved their budgets, according to the New Jersey Schools Boards Association. Last year, 75 percent of budgets passed.

description: The Sun, the Genome,

description: Paige Ellen Chabora, a daughter of Dr. Alice Chabora Tobias and Dr. Peter C. Chabora, both of Bayside, Queens, is to be married today to Jared Oliver Freedman, the son of Dr. Bathsheba Freedman and James O. Freedman of Cambridge, Mass. Mayor Paul Janos of Tarrytown, N.Y., is to officiate at Tappan Hill there.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKENNA, PATRICK J.
description: McKENNA-Patrick J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Patrick J. McKenna, associated with The Times from 1927 until retiring in 1977.

title: The Nation; The Trouble With Looking for Signs of Trouble
description: THE boy stalking victims through a video dungeon in the game Doom, or laughing at the slaughter in Oliver Stone's movie ''Natural Born Killers'' might well be the next person to shoot up a school in some polished American suburb. But then again, he might be a quiet scholar with an odd side.

title: From a Professor, Wines Worth Studying
description: Cabernet franc, Atlantic County, 1995, $13.50.

description: Amy Beth Poll, a daughter of Julie M. Poll of New York and Richard Poll of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Steven David Schell, the son of Elaine and James Gasiorowski of Syracuse. Rabbi David M. Posner is to officiate at the National Arts Club in New York.

title: NATO Bombing Tears at Greek Loyalties, Reawakening Anti-Americanism
description: Anti-American demonstrations, like dinner, start late in Athens. But for some Greek teen-agers, too young to remember similar riots of the 1960's and 1970's, protesting against the United States is still novel.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Mellon's Favorite Artist

title: Conceptual Art: Over, And Yet Everywhere
description: IS it going too far to say that Conceptual Art has been to the second half of the 20th century what Cubism was to the first half -- that is, a great divide, a demarcation after which nothing was quite the same? Maybe, but not by much. Conceptual Art produced far fewer masterpieces than Cubism, having disavowed the very term, and overall it probably did not turn out as many art objects, dematerialization of art being one of its goals. But in some weird, insidious way, it may have had a greater impact on art, our view of art and its relationship to life. Conceptual Art announced a recess from conventional art-making; when class resumed, it was conducted according to a different set of rules.

title: Access to Guns Sets U.S. Apart; We're Paying Attention
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLEY, ISABEL
description: BERLEY-Isabel, on April 23, 1999. Beloved wife of William. Cherished mother of Richard, and Jan Sublett. Loving grandmother of Marcus, Heather, Adam and Caryn. Funeral services Sunday, 11 AM, at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 W. 68 St. Memorial contribution may be made to Cornell University's Scholorship Fund or Johnson Museum.

title: Starting Over
description: Your writer finds great meaning in a half-finished sentence, a facial expression, a joke by the candidate's wife and a recollection of a meeting with Richard Nixon. If she had included some news about the size of Dan Quayle's organization in Iowa, his success at grass-roots fund-raising or his high-level endorsements, we might have learned something.

title: Compaq at a Crossroad: The Challenges for the Next Chief
description: AS it searches for a new chief executive, the Compaq Computer Corporation will be forced to confront the question of just how complex a business it really wants to be.

title: Bernard Newman, 91, G.O.P. County Leader, Dies
description: Judge Bernard Newman of the United States Court of International Trade, who as a former chairman of the New York County Republican Party was the counterpart and rival of Tammany Hall's Carmine De Sapio, died Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. A Manhattan resident, he was 91 and still serving as a judge.

title: PLUS: CREW -- GOLDTHWAIT CUP
description: The Princeton lightweight varsity was the victor in Boston, taking the Goldthwait Cup for the third time in four seasons. The Tigers were first in 6 minutes 20 seconds, followed by Harvard (6:24.5) and Yale (6:25.5). These three are the top-ranked lightweight crews.

title: Kosovo Now Bellwether as Well as Battlefield
description: The leaders of NATO tried to turn away from the war in Kosovo and devote the second day of their summit meeting to the lofty subjects for which they had gathered. But they could not escape the conflict.

title: Wedding Cake and Other Morsels
description: UNTIL a fund drive makes possible a new space for the Westport Arts Center, it is camping at the Westport Nature Center. Its exhibitions face the difficulty confronting all art has when it has to compete with displays of the natural world: there isn't too much that can beat a diorama full of once-chirping and warbling birds. But those who run the nomadic Arts Center know that the universal way to make oneself welcome is to bring food, and that is what they've done with the current show.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHERNER, MARSHALL
description: CHERNER-Marshall. With love on your birthday. Marshall, we miss you and you are always in our hearts and thoughts. Love, Joan and family

title: Finding Jobs for 'Too Many Executives'
description: WHETHER it is consolidation, financial reorganization or a takeover, the result is the same. ''Too many extraneous executives,'' said Norman Zarkin, head of the Zarkin Group in Harrison, an executive search concern. ''Some have to be let go.''

title: Birth Pains of a Black Community
description: IT was 1880, a year of hope. The freed slaves were moving on. Their mission is mostly unsung today, but their voices were raised in a hymn to the North, the ''land of fairness'' where the hope was. For the founders of Lost Creek Township in Vigo County, Ind., the time of bondage was over. Pride and opportunity were the working words.

title: IN PERSON; A Hollywood Connection, Made With Vines and Branches
description: SOMETIMES when one career path fades, another springs from the shadows. So it was with Tom Southard, a naturalist from Nesco, a tiny town near here, who is a leading provider and designer of exotic flowers, branches, vines and driftwood for the television and movie industry.

title: After Your Preparation, It's Time to Build the Stairs
description: BUILDING a simple set of stairs is not difficult, but it does require taking accurate measurements, making a few calculations and taking care to lay out the figures carefully on the carriage boards. When you have taken all the required measurements, you can estimate how much lumber you need for the project. If possible, buy extra lengths. This will allow you some latitude if you have to cut out sections that have knots or cracks.

description: To the Editor:

title: Special Unit Treats Rape Victims
description: ON a recent warm spring night, a rape victim arrived at the emergency room of the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla. The woman -- whose life had been threatened and who suffered a black eye and bruises in addition to the sexual assault -- was traumatized but not in critical condition.

title: Tarred and Feathered, With Humor
description: Thank goodness for humor. Sometimes when life on the job is at its most tense, when a situation is at its bleakest, a witty word and a good laugh come along to save the day. Readers offered so many cases in point that a second serving of their stories became obligatory.

description: ''I have worked with computers since I was 12 -- I even built my own computer. Now I am a freelance systems and database programmer. We saw the paramilitaries coming down our street block by block, so we started to pack. It took me 20 minutes to dismantle my computer, and I took with me all the main parts -- the hard disk, the CPU and memory chips -- and I hid the other parts around the house in case we were looted. I also brought some backup

description: ADRIENNE **** [Rating: Four Stars]

title: Now May Be the Time To Close The Circle
description: ROTATION, rotation, rotation. That, seers say, is what the stock market needs to sustain its run. Unless stocks that have missed most of the run-up the last year or so start to do better -- and that is most stocks -- the market's gains rest on shaky ground.

description: Anne Clarke Malinak, a project coordinator at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, and Stephen Spencer Black, a United Nations weapons inspector, were married last evening in the Cullen Sculpture Garden at the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston. Judge Ewing Werlein Jr., of Federal District Court in Houston, officiated.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Feeling Groovy Doesn't Come Cheap
description: I LIKE a guy who says ''nice to meet you'' while he's kissing both your cheeks. A guy who inventories his outfit -- ''Karan pants and top, Gucci belt, Prada shoes and overcoat'' -- and answers the question ''How much do you cost?'' with a hoot, declaring: ''It's a fortune, darling. But after you wear good clothing, it's so hard to go back.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, ANNA
description: MOORE-Anna. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Anna Moore, associated with The Times from 1958 until retiring in 1976.

title: Glittering Colors, Dense Orchestration
description: BARTOK: VIOLIN CONCERTO NO. 2, RHAPSODIES

title: The World; All in Favor of This Target, Say Yes, Si, Oui, Ja
description: AS Commander in Chief during the Vietnam War, Lyndon B. Johnson insisted on having almost absolute control over what to bomb and when to bomb it. ''They can't even bomb an outhouse without my approval,'' he once declared of the American pilots conducting raids over Vietnam.

description: HERSHKOWITZ-Murray. Beloved father of Jacqueline (Irwin) Walkof, Michael (Barbara) Hirst, much loved grandfather of Sindi (Peter) Schorr, Craig (Mary) Silverstein, Jeff Silverstein, Scott (Mimi) Silverstein, Marissa Hirst, Kate Hirst, loving great grandfather, uncle, and stepfather. He will be deeply missed and remain in our hearts forever. Funeral from the Saunders-Dwyer Home for Funerals, 495 Park St, New Bedford, MA. Monday, 9AM. Visiting hours Sunday 4-7PM.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Tito Puente; Living 'La Vida Loca' With the Mambo King
description: THE Bronx belonged to Tito Puente last Tuesday night. As dusk fell, stars were heading uptown on the Major Deegan, and local Bronx heavyweights like the rapper Fat Joe were suiting up in their flashy best. All were coming out to pay homage to Mr. Puente, the godfather of Latin music, who was celebrating his 76th birthday in grand style at Jimmy's Bronx Cafe.

title: Correction
description: The What's Doing column on April 11, about Rio de Janeiro, described the decor at the Copacabana Palace Hotel incorrectly. It is Art Deco, not Art Nouveau.

title: Chinatown Without Bounds
description: THERE is no painted red gate into Oakland's Chinatown, no boundary marking safe haven for a traditionally beleaguered Chinese minority. Oakland's Chinatown sprawls without boundaries, a fitting geography for what may be America's most integrated city.

title: On the Road to 2000
description: Planes, boats and trains will carry travelers on their appointed rounds as they celebrate New Year's Eve 1999. Following is a sampling of the packages and tours available.
