Prices are per person, double occupancy, unless otherwise noted; prospective travelers should be sure to ask about deposit and refund policies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, BERNARD
description: NEWMAN-Bernard, Judge. Universally acclaimed for his integrity by all who knew him, including Bishops, Deans, Governors, Legislators, Judges and fellow citizens on the streets of New York, Bernard Newman consistently credited his parents, and his wife for 59 years, Kathryn Bereano, and his life time friend and surviving spouse, Fritzi W. Rudolph, for his sterling reputation. A Governor of New York, once marveled how Bernard ''could engage in political activities and in a post of leadership and retain his...reputation for integrity.'' Born on October 28, 1907 to Isidor J. and Sarah C. Newman, and life time resident of New York City, Bernard Newman was a gentleman of profound wisdom, integrity and generosity, and a man of great compassion. More significantly Bernard Newman was a man completely devoted and dedicated to his family, and tremendously adored and loved by his family and friends. An honor graduate of the college and law school of New York University and an Associate Editor of the Law Review, Bernard Newman was a lawyer's lawyer and a judge's judge. As a young attorney, Bernard was attracted at an early age to public service. First as an Assistant Corporation Counsel assigned to the office of Chamberlain A.A. Berle, Jr., and next as a law secretary to New York State Supreme Court Justice, Samuel H. Hofstadler. For 16 years, presiding justices David W. Peck and Bernard Botein designated lawyer Newman an official referee of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. On December 12, 1965, Mayor Robert F. Wagner, Jr. appointed him to the family court, which was followed by an appointment to the State Supreme Court by Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller. Then, on July 21, 1968, President Lyndon B. Johnson, nominated the Judge to the Customs Court, situated in New York. The jurisdiction of which was expanded by Congress in 1980 under the name United States Court of International Trade. Judge Newman, who delighted in the distinction of having been appointed by Mayor, the Governor, and the President, presided for more than 30 years over complex Federal Customs and international trade cases, while also sitting in recent years in the federal district court in Manhattan. Judge Newman also once served as Council to, and Chairman of, the New York County Republican Party; as a delegate to Republican National Nominating Conventions; as a referee on special panels of the New York State Labor Relations and Mediation Boards. Judge Newman also was a Director of the Civic Center Synagogue, Community, Synagogue Center, Metropolitan Advisory Board of Anti Defamation League, and Laguardia Memorial Association. He was also the recipient of the Judge Edward Weinfeld Award, and Man of the Year Award. In addition to his wife Fritzi, the Judge is survived by daughters Phyllis Cechini and Helene Bernstein, grandchildren Craig and Kathy, John and Kathy, Mark and Hayley Cechini, Scott and Marcia, Brad and Annette Bernstein, and eight great-grandchildren. Services will be held on April 25, 11:30 AM, Plaza Memorial, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st Street), New York.

title: Springtime Clash: Sidewalk Cafes
description: Ah, springtime in the city, when the sun grows warmer, the days grow longer and the annual battle over sidewalk cafes begins anew along Eighth Avenue. The latest skirmish erupted over two tables that 18th and 8th, a popular corner cafe, wants to put on the avenue.

title: Lisa Schwartz and Scott Golodner
description: Lisa Helene Schwartz, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin H. Schwartz of Cortlandt Manor, N.Y., is to be married today to Scott Michael Golodner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Golodner of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk is to officiate at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: MUSIC; Trying On New Names to Plumb the Mystery of 'I'
description: IDENTITY is the crisis can't you see,'' declared the female singer Marion Elliott, better known as Poly Styrene, in a 1978 punk rock song. Proving the prescience of Ms. Elliott's words, a number of musicians have begun to explore notions of identity, so often a part of pop music's appeal, by adopting not just one pseudonym but many. They make the continual reinventing of musical personas perhaps as entertaining and meaningful as the music itself.

title: 2 Post-Collegians Take Spotlight at Penn Relays
description: The Penn Relays consist of three days of nonstop running, jumping and throwing, mostly for college and high school athletes. Today, before a crowd of 44,639, the fourth largest in the 105-year history of this track and field carnival, a handful of races for post-collegians had the knowledgeable spectators screaming in delight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, HARVEY
description: BROWN-Harvey 86, died April 22, 1999. Devoted husband of Ida. Beloved father of Susan and Michael. Caring grandfather. A life-long resident of New York's garment district. He was dedicated to his family and proud of their achievements, especially the 1985 Nobel Prize awarded to his son. Memorial service at the ''Riverside'' Sunday April 25 at 9:45am. Burial at Mt Ararat Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Kosovo Casts a Shadow Over Adriatic Resorts
description: THE bombing and the refugee crisis in Yugoslavia are affecting vacation travel in some areas on the Adriatic Sea, and not others -- so far.

title: Building Homes for the Single Homeless
description: NEW YORK CITY, which has seen its stock of last-resort housing for poor single adults withered by waves of market-rate development since the end of World War II, is seeing the return of apartments built specifically for those still hunkered below the bottom rung of the real-estate ladder.

title: Julia Moskin, Darren Kapelus
description: Julia Kate Moskin and Darren Brett Kapelus were married on Friday in a civil ceremony by Marianne Snow, an executive assistant, at the New York City Municipal Building. Last evening, Anne Ebersman, a rabbinical student, led a religious ceremony in a loft space in the Chelsea Market in New York.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-25-99 - On Language; Eye Roller
description: ''The numbers came in high,'' a senior Administration official told John Harris of The Washington Post, about an estimate of NATO troops needed to protect Kosovo. ''No one said yes, no one said no; it was taken off the table.. . .It was a complete eye-roller.''

title: At Home With Whims and Waggish Puns
description: A CENTURY from now, perhaps, Westchester historians will look with absorption on the mischievous murals of John Hastings.

title: In America; Bill Bradley's Challenge
description: I looked around to see who might be yawning or nodding off. Bill Bradley had been speaking for more than half an hour and there had been no jokes, no glorious turns of phrase, no splendidly worded calls to action. In fact, the former Senator who is now running for the Democratic nomination for President had a tendency to botch this line or that, and then go back and dutifully say it correctly.

title: Fight on Immigrant Measure Splits California Democrats
description: Last fall, when Cruz Bustamante, a softspoken Assemblyman from California's farm-rich Central Valley, was campaigning to become the first Hispanic official elected statewide in more than a century, he ran a series of television commercials that brought new meaning to the phrase ''low-key.'' In them, Mr. Bustamante talked quietly of parents and children and ended by saying, ''I'd appreciate your consideration for Lieutenant Governor.''

title: The Scourge of School Violence
description: There is of course no certain antidote to the kind of violence that claimed 15 lives at Columbine High School last week, no simple way to predict its occurrence, no magic cure for the pathologies that make it possible in the first place. President Clinton himself confessed to a feeling of mystification when he visited a Virginia high school last Thursday to share his grief.

title: Where the Shoppers Can Also Catch a Plane
description: AMERICANS, it has been learned, are willing to buy underwear at airports. Also shoes, golf shirts, cosmetics, Caesar salad and stuffed animals. Especially stuffed animals.

title: Single-Country Funds Seeking New Horizons
description: IS the closed-end country fund becoming a thing of the past? Perhaps.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE; This Craftsman Makes Holes
description: They call him the Doughnut Man.

title: The Word on Parking Signs; Street Signs Deserve No Prizes Either
description: To the Editor:

title: A Small but Choice Taste of Japan
description: IN San Francisco, it's the tourists who go to Chinatown. The locals are more likely to head for Japantown.

title: Residents Upset Over New School Returning to Old Spot
description: Construction on an empty lot in the Frederick Douglass housing project on Amsterdam Avenue and 102d Street has been turning heads in the neighborhood lately. In just eight weeks, builders have installed a foundation, erected a frame and piled up rooms. Though the project has resembled an enormous toy Lego set, it is actually a $27.5 million high school, scheduled to open this fall.

title: Even in Abbreviated Games There's Room for Creativity
description: The time limit used for world champion matches and elite tournaments has been cut back in recent years from 40 moves in 2 1/2 hours to 40 moves in 2 hours. The main reason for this has been to get the games finished in a single day so that the overnight adjournments of yesteryear are eliminated. Why abolish them? Because in this computer era of enormous databases, one could run one's machine all night for a complete analysis. The engagement of human vs. human would be gone.

title: On 'Streetcar' At Hartford Stage
description: Alvin Klein's characterization of the Hartford Stage's production of ''Streetcar Named Desire'' contained in his recent review (April 4) of ''Glass Menagerie'' at the Yale Rep, deserves a response.

title: Bonnie Gold, Chad Steinwolf
description: Bonnie Michelle Gold, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Gold of Bellmore, N.Y., was married last evening to Chad Steinwolf, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Steinwolf of Monsey, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Agin performed the ceremony at the North Shore Synagogue in Syosset, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONAGH, REVEREND MONSIGNOR CHARLES G.
description: McDONAGH-Reverend Monsignor Charles G. On April 23, 1999. Devoted priest of the Archdiocese of New York. Beloved son of the late Hannah and Charles McDonagh. Cherished brother of Margaret Douglas, Joan Ferrara, Ann and the late Genevieve, and Eugene. Cherished uncle of six, and adored great-uncle of 12. He was a Chaplain at St. Vincent's Hospital, Staten Island, and formerly Secretary to Terrence Cardinal Cooke and John Cardinal O'Connor. Viewing at the David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, 899 McLean Ave. (near Kimball), Yonkers, NY. Mass of the Christian Burial Tuesday, Saint Patrick's Cathedral, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to the Society for the Propigation of the Faith, 1011 First Ave, NYC 10022.

title: Liberties; Hunker In the Bunker
description: This is the actual text of a letter sent Thursday to the N.R.A.'s members by its president, Charlton Heston. We offer simultaneous captioning, in italics, conveying what Mr. Heston must really think.

title: The Word on Parking Signs; Street Signs Deserve No Prizes Either
description: To the Editor:

title: A Successful Solution To Sports on Sunday
description: I was disappointed in the failure of the article ''On Sunday, 'Let Us Play' or 'Let Us Pray' '' [April 4] to include Mastics, Moriches, and Shirley community's very successful solution to the problem. In our community, the children have a choice between Saturday morning soccer with the All-Faith Soccer League or the Sunday morning program offered by Mastic Sports.

title: Why a Priest
description: These young men came off sounding smug, elitist and dangerously enamored with an anti-intellectual approach to Catholicism. ''Custody of the eyes'' works if you're a nun from the 1950's, not a vibrant and informed parish priest at the end of the millennium.

title: Great Dancers in Double File
description: GREAT PAS DE DEUX

title: Style; The Chow Dynasty
description: It's Saturday night before the Oscars and Mr. Chow's in Los Angeles is the place to be -- unless you're a squab or a lobster. Elton John is feasting there, as are Tommy Mottola, Uma Thurman and Rupert Everett. Gwyneth Paltrow is there, with her father, Bruce Paltrow, and is there anyone left on earth who doesn't know that Blythe Danner is her mother? Tom Ford of Gucci is there, presumably not yet disappointed by Gwyneth's choice of dress the following evening. ''Babyface'' Edmunds is there. Elizabeth Saltzman of Vanity Fair is there. Mike Medavoy is there with his wife, Irena, and Ronald Perelman is there, happily unattached. It's all fabulous people, eating fabulous food. And the most amazing thing of all -- it's just another Saturday night at Mr. Chow's.

title: Streetscapes /Jeffrey Greene and EverGreene Painting Studios; Continuing, and Restoring, a Colorful Tradition
description: JEFFREY Greene started out by slipping fliers under doors, and this year his company will gross $16 million. A computer genius on the Internet? No -- he's a painter who wanted to move people with art. And now he handles hundreds of projects in paint and plaster restoration, mural design and decorative finishes.

title: Selling Sudan's Slaves Into Freedom
description: Over the last few years, evidence has slowly solidified that slavery not only exists, but may be widespread in parts of Sudan. On a recent day in this tiny, scorching village, there seemed little to dispute that. Seated under trees, on dirt baked so hard that a child's foot barely made a mark, were several hundred women and children. They told stories of abduction and rape, of tending goats and wringing dirty clothes for their captors.

title: Mobile Home Park Residents Struggle for Its Existence
description: PHILIP COBB is no stranger to a good fight. The 81-year-old veteran saw combat as a machine gunner in four campaigns, including the Battle of the Bulge, while serving in France and Germany during World War II. Mr. Cobb said he thought his biggest battles were behind him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULVIHILL, EDWARD B.
description: MULVIHILL-Edward B. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Edward B. Mulvihill, associated with The Times from 1963 until retiring in 1978.

title: Political Briefing; Is Name Recognition A Bush Achievement?
description: Poll takers often include a caveat when they report the results of Election 2000 surveys in which Gov. George W. Bush of Texas runs unusually well, which is most of the time. They warn that at this early stage, name recognition probably accounts for much of the strength that Mr. Bush is demonstrating in theoretical primary matchups with the 10 or so other hopefuls in the huge, sometimes confusing Republican field.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, PAUL
description: ROBBINS-Paul. On April 23, 1999 at 79. Loving and devoted husband of Ruth. Beloved father of Joan. Dear uncle, great uncle and brother-in-law. Services Sunday, 9:45 AM, Kirchenbaum Bros., 1700 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Interment Beth-El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUARINO, LT. COL. HAROLD B.
description: GUARINO-Lt. Col. Harold B. Of Chester, VA. On April 16, 1999. Devoted husband of Col. Judith M. Guarino. Loving father of Kenneth and Jane Guarino and Maj. Nickolas and Noel Guarino. Proud grandfather of Benjamin, Johanna and Gabriel Guarino. Beloved brother of Charles. Born in NYC in 1938 and retired from the U.S. Army after serving in an illustrious career as a Green Beret where he was the first officer to lead a Special Forces Operation in Southeast Asia. Burial with full military honors Tuesday April 27, 8:30 AM in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: 'For the Time Being'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Aaron Deserves to Inherit DiMaggio's 'Greatest Living' Title
description: FOR years Joe DiMaggio was always introduced at Yankee Stadium as ''baseball's greatest living player.'' But with his memory joining those of Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Mickey Mantle and Miller Huggins today in the Stadium's monument park beyond left-center field, it's time to identify the heir to that ''greatest living'' label.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDERMAN, MAE
description: LINDERMAN-Mae. Life partner for 67 years of Morris. Devoted mother of Estelle Linderman Resnick and Martin Resnick, and Gary Linderman. Devoted and loving grandmother of Corey Blake Resnick and grandmother of Jennifer and Jeffrey. Dear sister of Philip Morse. Services Tuesday, 9:45 AM, Riverside Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: The World: Propaganda Wars; Pictures Can Lie, After All
description: FOR all the words that have been spilled to describe the strategic, military, and bruisingly human dimensions of the conflict in Kosovo, it is the images that linger. A crying child. A hillside of houses, burning in unison. The corpse of an ethnic Albanian lying in the rubble of an explosion. A grainy black-and-white video of a railroad bridge in a NATO bomber's sights, then a train coming out of nowhere, and an explosion.

title: A Vintage Takeover
description: When Bernard Arnault likes a wine, he buys more than a case. Last week, he and his company, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, gained control of Bordeaux's Chateau d'Yquem after years of battling in court against Count Alexandre de Lur-Saluces, whose family has owned d'Yquem since 1785. The sweet sophistication of d'Yquem, made from grapes shriveled with noble rot, has drawn devotees from Thomas Jefferson to those who today pay about $245 for the 1990 vintage. Mr. Arnault, who privately bought another prime Bordeaux chateau, Cheval Blanc, with a partner a few months ago, has eagerly posed for photographs with a golden glass of d'Yquem in his hand. ALLEN R. MYERSON

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-25-99 - Questions for Susan Mcdougal; Ex-Prisoner's Dilemma
description: Q: What was your first thought when you were ordered to jail for refusing to testify about Whitewater?

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLIT, ROMAN A.
description: BLIT-Roman A. Died peacefully on April 23, 1999 at age 92. He left Warsaw after the German Occupation of Poland in 1939, and through Russia and Lithuania, came to New York in April 1941. He was an intelligent and educated man who worked closely with the Labor Movement. He was employed by the ILGWU for many years. He was devoted to his family. His passing is marked with great sorrow by Helen, his wife of 49 years, his daughter Barbara, his grandson Zachary, and all who knew him. Burial will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, PAUL
description: SCHWARZ-Paul. Born June 1, 1911, originally from Amsterdam. Beloved husband and companion of Suzy. Internationally known jeweler (associated with the House of Harry Winston), passed away April 13 in Miami, FL. after a long and courageous struggle with illness. Gentle, kind and full of humor, his urbane charm and wit made him many friends. He is sorely missed by his wife of 32 years, Suzy & the entire Thevenin family, notably Charles and Sallie of Vevey; Louis, Nicole and Sophie of Sydney; James and Paul and Jean of Paris; also his nephew Harry Mulisch of Amsterdam; Jeanette, Kim, Amber & Milagros. May his soul rest in peace.

title: Why a Priest
description: Your article touched only briefly on what is truly countercultural about these seminarians: that they are willing to live lives that reject consumerism and to give most of their time, attention and love to the poor and sick. You can't get more radical than that.

title: Ogden's New Tack: Divide and Conquer
description: THE Ogden Corporation is paying the price for breaking the 11th commandment, analysts say. For years, they contend, Ogden neglected the imperative to maximize shareholder value, and though the company seems to have finally gotten religion, it remains largely shunned by investors.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on page 33 of the Arts & Leisure section today about the Fox late-night comedy show ''Mad TV'' omits part of a quotation from Terry Sweeney, a writer for the show. His full comment was: '' 'Mad TV' is just more woman-friendly; on 'S.N.L.,' the men are always being characterized as a woman's victim. Here, we're not hostile to women. We just make them powerful in themselves, and the world is just going to have to deal with them.''

title: AS LEADERS MEET, NATO AIR CAMPAIGN ENTERS 2D MONTH
description: NATO began its second month of bombing against Yugoslavia today with new strikes against military targets that disrupted civilian electrical and water supplies, as the alliance's leaders took steps to expand the war effort, including an agreement to use air bases in Hungary.

title: One-Third of Mothers Collect Court-Ordered Child Payments
description: About 34 percent of mothers in New Jersey who have court orders requiring fathers to make child support payments actually receive the money, making New Jersey about average for the country, according to a survey conducted by the Urban Institute in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINO, LEONARD D.
description: MARTINO-Leonard D., 69. Died on April 6. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y., he lived in Hohokus, NJ for the last 3 years. He retired in 1996 after a career of 52 years in the printing industry, where he was Production Manager of Skillcraft Inc. in Manhattan. He served in the Army during the Korean conflict, in Germany, attaining the rank of Corporal. Later he served in the Army Reserve. He was an active member of the Bensonhurst Italian American Mutual Aid Society (BIAMAS) and was an avid model train enthusiast. Leonard was predeceased by his parents, Michael and Rose Martino; by his brother Luke and by his first wife Theresa. He is survived by his wife Cheryl Derby Martino of Hohokus, a sister Phyllis Young of Sun City West, AZ., three children, Robert of Staten Island, Richard of Brooklyn and Patricia Rusolo also of Brooklyn and three grandchildren, Frank, Robert and Christina. A funeral service was held at Miraglia Funeral Chapel in Brooklyn followed by a funeral mass at Our Lady of Guadalupe Church. Interment followed at Moravian Cemetery in Staten Island. Donations in memory of Leonard may be made to the National Emphysema Foundation in Norwalk, CT or to the American Cancer Society.

title: Political Briefing; Maybe It's the District, And Not the Politician
description: Robert K. Dornan has been accused of a lot of things. But nobody has ever called the hard-right Southern California Republican a quitter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MURRAY J.
description: MILLER-Murray J. Of New York City, on April 22, 1999. Beloved companion of Mario Paiva. Leaves two brothers and a sister. Late Art Director for Reader's Digest. For information, BrezniakRodman Funeral Directors, Newton, MA.

title: Stepping Out From Behind the Camera
description: IN more than five decades as a photographer and documentary film maker, George Pickow has done it all: covers and photo essays for magazines like Life and National Geographic; album covers for recordings by Theodore Bikel, Clark Terry, Nina Simone and Lawrence Welk; portraits of legendary artists; nature photography like the images of the Grand Tetons that grace the cover of the Sierra Club handbook, and a series of films about American folklore.

title: In the Region /New Jersey; Another Tool to Save Meadowlands Open Space
description: OF the nearly 20,000 acres that made up the Hackensack Meadowlands, 8,400 of them remain a sweep of meadows and marshes blanketed with brown reeds, some rising 12 feet tall.

title: The Fight for the Future Of Florida's Fisher Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A headline last Sunday about a rape case involving a Union County Jail prisoner misstated the date of a ruling by the New Jersey Supreme Court. It was 1997 when the court ruled that rape victims can bring civil lawsuits against the state; 1991 was the year the prisoner was assaulted.

title: Whitman Panel Proposes Plans To Insure More Children
description: The Governor's Children's Health Insurance Work Group announced programs last week to help low-income working parents pay for health insurance and day care for their children. One plan would earmark more than $17.7 million to subsidize policies for about 72,000 children whose parents can buy employer-sponsored health insurance.

title: A Manifesto for The Fast World
description: I was annoyed by the criticism of the conservative political impulse (the ''let them eat cakers'') while Friedman assured us that his safety-net proposals need not be expensive or radically redistributive or remakes of ''lavish welfare programs that violate the basic, neoliberal free-market rules of the system.'' Such were the very ideas that brought the ''infamous 1994 class of freshman Republicans'' to power.

title: Miss Beaumont And Mr. Fischer
description: Kathryn Epping Beaumont, a daughter of Eleanor R. Beaumont of Summit, N.J., and Philip Beaumont of Washington, was married yesterday to Gregory Mark Fischer, the son of Marlene and Mark Fischer of Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. Thomas J. Mullelly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRHARDT, EMMA A.
description: EHRHARDT-Emma A. On April 22nd, 1999. Of Miami Shores, FL. Formerly of Forest Hills, NY. Wife of the late Christian R. Beloved mother of Eleanor, Audrey and Arthur. Devoted grandmother of Deborah & Ornan, Arthur & Doris. Also survived by many loving friends. Services Grace Lutheran Church, 103-15 Union Tpk., Forest Hills, New York, Wednesday, April 28 at 10:00 AM. Interment Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Maspeth, New York.

title: Claims Collide In 2 Accidents As Next of Kin Await Redress
description: The surviving relatives of the Germans killed in the cable car accident in Italy were getting close to receiving compensation from the United States, until the kin the crew killed in an Air Force C-141 Starlifter got in the way.

title: Carter Brown, Clifton Williams
description: Erwin Carter Brown, the daughter of Erwin Parrott Brown and Hobson Brown Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Clifton Trent Williams, a son of Barbara M. Williams and Clement Monroe Williams of Eagle Springs, N.C. The Rev. Steven E. Woolley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Ganell Giagu, Galen Criqui
description: Ganell Giagu, the daughter of Lynn Giagu of Port Washington, N.Y., and the late John Giagu, was married yesterday to Galen O'Donnell Criqui, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Don Criqui of Essex Fells, N.J. The Rev. Dr. William D. O'Rourke performed the ceremony at St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MERESMAN, HELEN CHAFETS
description: MERESMAN-Helen Chafets. Your beauty, kindness, love and generosity Remain fixed images for all eternity.

title: Fashion Divas, Art Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, FRANCIS C.
description: TOBIN-Francis C. Of Belle Harbor, New York, on April 21, 1999. Memorial service Sunday, April 25th at 11:30AM at Denis O'Connor Funeral Home, Rockaway Beach, NY. Memorial Mass at Our Lady of Victory, New York, NY, date and time to be announced.

title: Works Created as Reactions to Injustices
description: ON the outer fringes of downtown here, tucked away at the southeast end of a large parking area, sits a freshly painted, nondescript, white building where a complete ceramic center and gallery space is housed. Founded in 1957 by Katherine Choy and Harry Okamoto, the Clay Art Center remains relatively obscure.

title: NATO Missed Best Chance at Peace; Is This Genocide?
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald Bruckmann, Banker, Is Dead at 70
description: Donald John Bruckmann, a New York investment banker who was the board chairman of the Animal Medical Center, a trustee and former chairman of the New York Botanical Garden and an enthusiastic gardener, sailor and conservationist, died Wednesday at his home on Manhattan's Upper East Side. He was 70 and also lived in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Au Pair, the Luxury Model
description: Au Pair in America, which operates in more than 35 states, is hoping to satisfy parents' needs and attract better-qualified young women from overseas to work in American households with a program called Au Pair Extraordinaire. Participants are at least 20 years old, compared with the usual minimum of 18, and have studied child care or worked full time in the field for two years.

title: Telling Our Terrible Stories to the Tube
description: So shall you hear of carnal, bloody, and unnatural acts,'' Horatio tells the armies that arrive at the end of ''Hamlet.'' He's relating the story because Hamlet, dying, requested that he do so: ''If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart, absent thee from felicity awhile, and in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain, to tell my story.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, JOHN BUCKHOUT
description: JOHNSTON-John Buckhout. In San Rafael, California, April 22, 1999. Age 79 years. Formerly of New Canaan, CT. Loving husband of Emma S. Johnston. Dear father of Alexa Horne, Cynthia Alexander, and John B. Johnston, Jr. Grandfather of four grandchildren. A native of St. Paul, Minnesota. He was Managing Director of Marsh and McLennan, New York City, Director of the New York Philharmonic. Private services have been held. Private inurnment, Oakland Cemetery, St. Paul, Minnesota. Memorial contributions preferred to NY Philharmonic, Avery Fisher Hall, 10 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BLACK AND WHITE ON WALL STREET

title: Habitats /The 70's, Near Third Avenue; East Side Hip-Hopper
description: IT is definitely not cool for a guy who wants to make it big in hip-hop to live with his parents in a fancy Long Island suburb. But for three years Lee Resnick did just that, commuting with all the suits from Lawrence to his minuscule office in Times Square, where he and a friend had started a music business.

title: 'We Know These Faces'
description: How can the Holocaust not come burningly to mind? Yet the differences are acute. Half a century ago, the Jews of Europe had no land dispute with their annihilators. They were loyal citizens everywhere. They had neither arms nor hope of rescue. The Serbs, in that merciless period, were among that minuscule fraction of Europe's Christian population who actively resisted Hitler's murderous pursuit of Jews. Now this once-principled nation has, unaccountably, given birth to Slobodan Milosevic, promulgator of the term ''ethnic cleansing'' and relentless proponent of its brutalities. At the same time, the Kosovo Liberation Army, seeking full independence for the largely Muslim ethnic Albanians of Kosovo, receives financing from fanatical Iran, backer of Hezbollah and inciter of religious terrorism abroad. And meanwhile German bombers are once again in Europe's skies. The political kaleidoscope shifts and shifts; the old patterns are unrecognizable.

title: Night and Day, Day and Night Between Washington and the Balkans
description: NATO's anniversary pageant is playing on two stages, as political theater and in the theater of war, and its powerful rhetoric clashes with the forces of battle in Belgrade and the Balkans.

title: Making Their Name Early In the Restaurant World
description: Alex and Max are 2 1/2-year-old fraternal twins who are getting an early start on the restaurant scene. Their father, Craig Meltzer, has named his new spot, where he is also the chef, after them. Alex and Max's opened last month at 38 West 39th Street (between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas), formerly the site of Grappino's. Mr. Meltzer, who has worked at Mortimer's and the Union Square Cafe, calls his menu modern American. Appetizers include mussels steamed with white wine and tomato broth ($8) and tomato salad with mozzarella and portobello mushrooms ($9). Among the main courses are lobster shepherd's pie ($20) and barbecued salmon with jalapeno-and-cheddar cornmeal cake ($17).

title: Seven Students Sue Board Over Training
description: SEVEN disgruntled adult students from a computer technology course at the Putnam/Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services here have brought suit against the board.

title: London Bomb Injures at Least 7, Week After Nail-Bomb Hurt 39
description: At least seven people were injured today when an explosion tore through a street market in an area of east London that has a large Bangladeshi population, one week to the day after a home-made nail-bomb went off in a crowded market in another racially mixed area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILBERIS, ELIZABETH
description: TILBERIS-Elizabeth. It is with great sadness that we mourn the loss of Elizabeth Tilberis. She will be sorely missed. Alfredo Canessa and MALO

title: Ideas & Trends: Why Governments Tumble; India's Poorest Are Becoming Its Loudest
description: SINCE the Hindu nationalist-led Government collapsed a week ago, the noisy, gaudy spectacle of Indian democracy has played out here in the capital on familiar public stages: the steps of Parliament House, the courtyard of the President's residence and at the closed gates of the Gandhi family compound.

title: South Koreans on Vacation Try Out the North
description: Thousands of South Korean tourists will spend time this summer in an unlikely place: North Korea.

title: The Sperminator
description: Harvesting sperm -- or eggs -- without consent is merely an ethical warm-up for the hoarier, but imaginable, ''Jurassic Park'' scenario of cloning complete replicas of people long dead from single stem cells, either directly or via computer mapping (Lori B. Andrews, March 28). The millennium presents a conveniently jarring date for such deep reckonings with our mastery over life, matter, being, mind, time and space.

title: Editorial Observer; A Night When Bad Food and Big Stars Collide
description: For decades, the White House Correspondents Association dinner in Washington was simply a tiresome annual affair. The faint smell of mothballs always hovered over the Washington Hilton ballroom where uncomfortably overdressed journalists sat down once a year for a long evening with their sources. Even with the President at the head table, a fog would quickly spread over the room, disseminating the kind of boredom that reporters tolerate only if they inflict it on themselves. The food was almost as heavy as the speeches. Entertainment was judged by whether it could be heard over 2,700 people. One favorite was the Mummers, a marching band from Philadelphia that specialized in eye-catching feather headdresses.

title: Why a Priest
description: As someone still recovering from a three-year gig of studying to be a priest, I found Egan's article a vivid reminder of the mental gymnastics, the Orwellian double-think, necessary to render ''radical'' a young man averting his eyes from the prurience of a magazine cover and worrying about Seinfeld's sex life.

title: NATO Missed Best Chance at Peace; Reporters Were Right
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 + 2 = Metaphor
description: ONCE UPON A NUMBER The Hidden Mathematical Logic of Stories. By John Allen Paulos. 214 pp. New York: Basic Books. $23.

title: Suffolk Shows Interest In Stony Brook Site
description: The Suffolk County Legislature voted last week to add a 43-acre site near the heart of Stony Brook village to a list of properties to be considered for county acquisition.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KURZ, ARNOLD WOLFGANG
description: KURZ-Arnold Wolfgang. My sweet prince-my heart is with your soul. For April 26, with all my love. Forever, Your Donna

title: Mother to Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILBERIS, LIZ
description: TILBERIS-Liz. We are heartbroken at the loss of our second mother. Every day was filled with the gift of laughter, friendship and the warmth of her indelible spirit which will live on in the lives of all who knew her. We will love and miss her always and extend our deepest sympathies to Andrew, Rob and Chris. Steph and Louisa

title: Amanda Urish, Alan Goodstadt
description: Amanda Ilene Urish, the daughter of Cecilia and Jerrold Urish of Glen Cove, N.Y., was married last evening to Alan Goodstadt, a son of Marion and Seymour Goodstadt of Douglaston, Queens. Cantor David Benedict officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Separation of Corporate Powers
description: Annual studies of proxy filings by Russell Reynolds Associates, an executive search firm, show that companies that separate the posts of chairman and chief executive are becoming scarcer, especially among the largest companies.

title: POSTINGS: Converting Madison Ave. Offices to a Boutique Hotel; A 60-Room Luxury Library
description: Inside the 12-story building at 299 Madison Avenue offices have been stripped away and new mechanical systems are being installed as part of a $9 million renovation to turn the 87-year-old structure into a luxury boutique hotel.

title: Karen Frenkel, Edward Volchok
description: Karen A. Frenkel and Edward Volchok are to be married today at the St. Moritz Hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi Gerald I. Weider is to officiate.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOFFMAN, EDWARD N.
description: HOFFMAN-Edward N. April 21 1919 -April 23, 1998 TO MY HUSBAND WHEREVER YOU ARE THE GLOW OF YOUR BEING OUT SHINES EVERY STAR! AND PARTING IS NOT GOODBY WE'LL BE TOGETHER, AGAIN FOR EVER, AND EVER, AND EVER MORE! I LOVE YOU, LOLA

title: A New Paradox Of Corporate Spydom
description: Here's a conundrum worthy of an Ian Fleming novel: Corporate spies are becoming more and less numerous at the same time.

title: Plan to Merge Scouts Upsets Some Leaders
description: A VOTE less than two weeks ago to seek the merger of the Nassau and Suffolk Boy Scout councils, which have been separate for 80 years, has some scout leaders wondering what's the rush.

title: A Queen of the Ballroom Learns a Red-Hot Tango
description: MY 40-something neighbor cut to the chase: ''What are you doing with that old-folks car in your driveway?''

title: Failing to See Humor in 'Skinny'
description: To the Editor:

title: Adkins Defeats Field In 400-Meter Hurdles
description: Derrick Adkins won the 400-meter hurdles in 48.99 seconds over a strong field yesterday at the Drake Relays in Des Moines, Iowa.

title: 4 Children Are Critically Hurt In Fire in a Queens Apartment
description: Four children were critically injured yesterday afternoon when they were trapped in a bedroom during a fire in their Queens apartment, fire officials said. They said the blaze apparently started when one child began lighting matches near a bed.

title: School District Statistics Can Be Misleading
description: Statistics about school districts [April 4 and 11] can be misleading. A low student-teacher ratio and a high expenditure per student could indicate a large enrollment of special education students. In special education, class sizes are regulated and there is no cap on the amount of money that can be spent.

title: Park Official Says Yacht Club Barge Doesn't Belong on Pier
description: In one of his first official acts, the chairman of the new Hudson River Park Trust, James Ortenzio, last week rejected a bid by the Manhattan Yacht Club to park an 85-foot barge at Pier 25, which will be part of a new park along the waterfront.

title: West Babylon Neighbors Split Over Drug Recovery Program
description: TEEN CHALLENGE, a drug rehabilitation program that claims to cure addiction solely through the Christian Gospel, was found in a 1975 Federal study to have an 86 percent success rate. The program has won accolades from officials like Gov. George E. Pataki, the Nassau County District Attorney, Denis Dillon, and the Town of Babylon Supervisor, Richard Schaffer, not to mention former Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush.

title: Fighting Heartache, A Family Endures G.I. Son's Capture
description: Andrew Ramirez was watching a news program when Max, his son's dog, began barking in the night. Hours before, he had heard the latest on Kosovo, that three American soldiers were missing in Macedonia, but had not connected them to his own quiet life.

title: Ex-Strongman's Next Move Intrigues Dominicans
description: In a dusty neighborhood of wooden barracks here that house 1,600 families left homeless in a hurricane last year, Yudelki C. Savinon said she appreciated President Leonel Fernandez's efforts to help the victims, including starting construction on permanent housing nearby.

title: Amy Cohen and Christopher Phillips
description: Amy Lee Cohen, the daughter of Carol J. Cohen of Little Silver, N.J., and the late Michael D. Cohen, was married in New York yesterday to Christopher Lawrence Phillips, a son of Elizabeth B. Phillips and W. Irving Phillips, both of Houston. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne officiated at the nondenominational ceremony at the New York Athletic Club.

title: Ideas & Trends; Sham Surgery Returns As a Research Tool
description: IN 1939, long before high-tech drugs came along to treat the chest pain known as angina, an Italian surgeon named Fieschi devised a simple technique. Reasoning that increased blood flow to the heart would ease his patients' pain, he made tiny incisions in their chests and tied knots in two arteries. The results were spectacular. Three quarters of all patients improved.'' One third were cured.

title: Melissa Lautenberg and Douglas Cifu
description: Melissa Beth Lautenberg and Douglas Anthony Cifu were married last evening at Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J., by Rabbi Harvey Goldman.

title: Southampton Approves Golf Atop Aquifer
description: The Southampton Town Planning Board has given final approval to plans for a 281-acre private golf course over an area where rainwater replenishes the aquifer that provides Long Island's drinking water.

title: PULSE; Hot Nights in Lebanon
description: The East Village club Downtown Beirut is no more, but its namesake is alive and hopping in the Middle East.

title: Q. & A.
description: Dispute on A Shared Driveway

title: Boys Impress at Penn Relays
description: Northwestern of Hyattsville, Md., Potomac of Virginia and Rickey Harris of Centreville, Va., turned in impressive victories today in boys' high school events at the Penn Relays. Northwestern's 4 x 400-meter relay, with James Graham recording a sizzling anchor split of 45.8 seconds, posted a time of 3 minutes 10.35 seconds in winning by 25 meters over Chester of Pennsylvania. The time was the third-fastest ever at the Penn Relays and the best ever by an Eastern school.

title: Asylum Plea Denied For Woman in Fear
description: Three years ago, the practice of female genital cutting was outlawed in the United States, and immigration authorities recognized the practice -- performed on millions of women in about 26 African nations -- as a form of persecution that those seeking asylum could claim. But advocates for refugees say the story of Adelaide Abankwah, a 29-year-old woman who fled Ghana, shows that those decisions have had little effect.

title: A Jewelry Boutique Extends Southward
description: For four years Elma Blint has owned a boutique, Amle (Elma spelled backward) Arte, at 455 Columbus Avenue near 81st Street. ''It has a funky feel for uptown,'' Ms. Blint said. ''People come in and say, 'You should be downtown.' '' So two months ago, she opened Elma Blint et al at 245 Elizabeth Street (near Prince Street). She sells jewelry, handbags and belts of her own design, as well as work by other designers. She stocks her jewelry in silver but does custom work in other metals. Silver rings with semiprecious stones range from $120 to $250 and pendants from $70 to $250.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWLEY, ALEXANDER STEWART
description: COWLEY - Alexander Stewart. Died April 21, 1999, in New York. Devoted father of Steph and adoring grandfather of Sven. Known to all as Stewart, as the founder and President of Stewart Models, Stewart Men, Stewart Artists, and Model of the Year Pageant, he was an innovator and respected leader of the modeling industry for many years. A private burial will take place at the Cowley family site at Homewood, Pittsburgh, PA, on April 26. A celebration of his life will be held shortly in New York City for his many friends at a time and place to be announced. He will be missed.

title: When Violent Fantasy Emerges as Reality
description: They are Hollywood words, describing fantasies of revenge that flicker, in some form, through the minds of thousands of hurt and raging adolescent boys, yet are almost never acted on. ''You all better hide in your houses because I'm coming for everyone, and I will shoot to kill and I will kill everything.''

title: Tropicalia, Agora!
description: At the time Claude Levi-Strauss was traveling through Brazil in the 1930's, a brilliant new generation of samba composers was emerging in Rio, writing popular songs as cosmopolitan as Cole Porter's. But Levi-Strauss -- who loved music, Italian opera and Stravinsky especially -- never noticed, or so you'd have to conclude from ''Tristes Tropiques,'' his famous anthropological travelogue. Everything about Rio left him sad. Contact with the West had corrupted the tropics, he was convinced; Rio and Sao Paulo, too, where he taught for a time, were little more than modern urban ruins, their up-to-date streetscapes masking an epic loss of human difference. Only when he ventured deep into the interior, and encountered the Bororo -- the pure, unadulterated Other -- did he like what he heard. At night, the men of the tribe, naked except for straw penis-sheaths, shook gourd rattles and chanted in a low-pitched guttural tongue; the ''intensity and quality'' of the principal players was so remarkable, he wrote, ''that no conductor of a large European orchestra could have surpassed them.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about Prime Minister Tony Blair when he was a college student misstated the location of St. John's College. It is at Oxford, not Cheltenham.

title: In the Region /Long Island; For Hospital Site, Baseball, Shops and a Law School
description: A 268,000-SQUARE-FOOT shopping center and a minor league baseball stadium will soon be under construction along Carleton Avenue in Central Islip. It will join a college campus, Federal and state courts, industrial buildings and housing on what had been the grounds of the former Central Islip State Hospital.

title: Escaping Fascism In Italy
description: JOINED by her husband, three children, two grandmothers and a French nursemaid, Carla Pekelis, an Italian Jewish woman, fled Italy in 1938 and traveled through France, Spain and Portugal before coming to live in the United States in 1941. On Tuesday, panelists including Carla's daughter, Simona Pekelis McCray, will discuss her life in Italy and her complicated escape in the second of a four-part series on Italian fascism called ''A Jewish Experience: ''La Mia Versione dei Fatti'' (''My Version of the Facts''), at Casa Italiana at New York University.

title: Sail On, Sail On, Merry Ship . . .
description: In the vigorously held opinion of Albert Bergeret, Gilbert and Sullivan's operettas will live forever -- with judicious tweaking. This week, Mr. Bergeret and his lively New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players are bringing a newly tweaked production of ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' to New Brunswick after their ''Mikado'' at Raritan Valley Community College last week. ''We think the generic format is about issues that repeat themselves throughout history,'' Mr. Bergeret said. ''We just need to find a topical reference to give a quaint joke more punch.''

title: When the News Drives the Music
description: SINCE the grainiest days of early television, when NBC's three famous chimes announced dire dispatches from cold war outposts, Americans have grown used to a little music with their news. Offering cues for what's next, the tunes are used as teasers for stories ranging from robins in spring to nightmares in Kosovo and Colorado.

title: London Theater
description: To the Editor: By starting a day early on a February business trip to London with a Monday morning meeting, we were able to emulate Anita Gates's West End adventure (''Curtain Up on a London Weekend,'' March 28).

title: Paying More for the Privilege of Paying the Rent
description: Brian Ullman and Jacqueline Donohue knew that getting a Manhattan apartment would be expensive. But they were surprised by the cost of not getting one.

title: Send In the Swans: At 50, City Ballet Embraces a Classic
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE once told Peter Martins: ''You know, dear, we should call all ballets 'Swan Lake.' People will come.''

title: Access to Guns Sets U.S. Apart; Lonely and Different
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAMRAU, JUNE HIRSHFIELD
description: DAMRAU-June Hirshfield. On April 23, 1999 at age 92. Lover of animals, piano teacher and composer. Daughter of Henrietta and Morris Hirshfield (the noted American primitive painter). She is survived by her nephew Robert Dennis Rentzer, and great-nephew Spencer Schaefer and great-niece Brenda Schaefer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YATES, ELIZABETH HIPPLE
description: YATES-Elizabeth Hipple, on April 16, 1999. A concert pianist residing in Riverside, CT. Formerly of Jenkintown, PA and New York City. Predeceased by her husband, playwright and journalist, Ray Baker Yates. The first piano soloist with the National Symphony Orchestra at the White House. Mrs. Roosevelt served tea. Performances included recitals at Town Hall, Wigmore Hall and Oxford University and there were lecture-recitals from Maine to Florida. In memorium donations to the Shubert Club Scholarship Fund, PO Box 2338, Stamford, CT.. 06907 or the First Church of Christ Scientist, Greenwich, CT. 06830 would be appreciated. A Memorial Service with performances by former students is Sunday, May 2nd, 4:00PM at the First Presbyterian Church, 1101 Bedford Street, Stamford, CT.

title: A Small Town Finds Itself Under Scrutiny
description: The scenes of children fleeing Columbine High School here on Tuesday afternoon are now seared into the memories of people around the world.

title: Prince Panache Jumps Into the Lead
description: Karen O'Connor and her Irishbred Prince Panache jumped the entire cross-country course without a fault yesterday to take the lead after two phases of the Rolex-Kentucky Four-Star Three-Day Even in Lexington, Ky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, DR. PAUL H.
description: SCOTT-Dr. Paul H. On August 4, 1920-April 10th, 1999. Devoted husband of the late Dr. Dorothy Gregg; cherished father of Kim Alzerreca and Gregg Scott; loving grandfather of Xoli Redmond and Sophia Alzerreca. Compassionate dentist, outstanding sportsman and a heck of a dancer. Longtime mover and shaker at the New York Athletic Club, Chairman of Boxing, Chairman of Personal Defense and Chairman of Ballroom Dance. He will be missed by countless people whose lives he touched. Memorial service to be held at the New York Athletic Club, Tuesday June 1st, at 6PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOLF, DONALD V. (DON)
description: WOOLF-Donald V. (Don). Died at age 69 on April 21 in Green Valley AZ. Survived by his wife, Ellen (O'Meara Rhodin); two children from a previous marriage, Andrew of Boston MA, and Elizabeth of Enfield, England; a stepdaughter, Andrea Tebbets of Washington, DC; and two grandchildren.

title: Long Ago, When Ships Set Sail From Fairfield
description: FAIRFIELD'S Age of Sail lasted about 75 years. Congress had designated Fairfield among the state's first three ports of entry in 1789. And during the middle of the 19th century, Fairfield's harbors in Southport and Black Rock ranked among the busiest on Long Island Sound.

title: Growing Berries Can Be as Easy as Eating Them
description: PLUCKING a perfectly ripe raspberry or blackberry from a plant and popping it in your mouth is an ambrosial experience. And these berries, collectively known as bramble fruits, are easy to grow.

title: Let the Young Be
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Decker, B. J. Finneran
description: Karen Ann Decker and B. J. Phoenix Finneran were married yesterday by the Rev. Leo J. O'Donovan at St. Cassian Roman Catholic Church in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN VALLEY/HARLEM; When Stores Close on 125th Street, Artist's Gallery Opens
description: It's early Sunday morning on Harlem's busiest thoroughfare, 125th Street, and the stores are closed. Across from the Apollo Theater, tour buses are parked bumper to bumper against the curb. For Franco Gaskin, this means business is booming.

title: Shadows: They Led Glory Days Of Alliance
description: History bestows its favors with an uneven hand. No politician thinks otherwise. Yet it was poignant to see some of the commanding figures in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's great triumph in the cold war languishing in the shadows this weekend as the alliance commemorated its 50th anniversary.

title: Is Old Hatter Headed for the Shelf?
description: After 40 years on Madison Avenue near 43d Street, Worth & Worth, the venerable hatter, will be moving or closing for good at the end of May.

title: A Nation of Spies
description: STASI

title: The Word on Parking Signs; Interest in Water Park Shows Shortsightedness
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Work That Offends
description: To the Editor:

title: Bel Canto Returns to Caramoor
description: VOICES of spring (to use the title of the Strauss Waltz) are being raised in opera, chorus and a children's musical today and next weekend.

title: Sunday Best
description: I was enchanted by your fashion feature (April 4). The mountain residents from eastern Kentucky, photographed by Shelby Lee Adams, had the substance and ''innate grace'' that gave your fashion article more punch than any I have ever seen.

title: Correspondence/Black and Middle Class; Both a Victim of Racial Profiling -- And a Practitioner
description: THE spring day was bright and sunny enough for sunglasses, yet cool enough to require a sweatshirt and baggy sweat pants. As I walked along a busy street in the predominantly white northwest Washington neighborhood where I lived, I hardly thought that my clothing or, more important, my dark skin would attract the attention of the police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELL, DENNIS G.
description: MANDELL-Dennis G. The Board of Directors and shareholders of 911 Park Inc. express their sadness at the passing of our long-time attorney and friend. Our condolences to all of his family.

title: Who Needs Jagr? Not Penguins, Who Crush Devils Anyway
description: The Devils found out 45 minutes before today's game that they would not have to face Pittsburgh's Jaromir Jagr, the National Hockey League's leading scorer this season.

title: BEST SELLERS: April 25, 1999
description: Weeks

title: April 18-24; Keeping Smallpox Virus
description: President Clinton has granted a reprieve to a deadly killer scheduled for execution.

title: Euro Has Plenty of Time To Challenge the Dollar
description: WESTERN EUROPE'S new currency, the euro, ought to be a powerhouse, already diminishing America's place in the global economy. Such was the advance billing. But nearly four months into its existence, the euro is hardly noticeable on this side of the Atlantic.

title: VOTES IN CONGRESS
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey, and New York.

title: Playoffs Veer Toward 2 Months of Invisibility
description: All seats were not filled in Continental Arena yesterday, but there were enough Devils fans around before the game to muster one, big, loud, misguided cheer. They welcomed the announcement that Jaromir Jagr, the Pittsburgh Penguins star, was out with an injury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAMSI, HAIDER H., M.D.
description: SHAMSI-Haider H., M.D. The faculty and staff of the Department of Anesthesiology, The Mount Sinai Medical Center, extends heartfelt sympathy to their colleague and friend, Adiba Shamsi, M. D., and to her family on the death of her beloved husband, Haider Shamsi, M.D.

title: Airports Redraw Car-Rental Map
description: WITH so many airports undergoing major renovation these days, getting in and out of them in a rental car can be almost as annoying as a waiting for landing permission on a packed plane. Many major airports, like Kennedy International in New York, were long overdue for modernization or expansion. Others, like Minneapolis-St. Paul, renovated once and now must do it again because of a swell in the number of passengers.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: JOYCE KILMER RECITES AT BARNES & NOBLE

title: Nations Not Yet in NATO Preen in Hope
description: The Embassy of Bulgaria, five diplomats strong, was humming with hope. The second secretary, a world-class linguist and stateswoman, was dashing about, even making coffee for any visitor who asked.

title: In Case The River Rises
description: Once the ridicule of grade-school playgrounds, high-water pants have turned from fashion faux pas to a fad championed by men's wear designers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILHELM, PAUL
description: WILHELM-Paul. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Milton Bickerman, associated with The Times from 1965 until retiring in 1982.

title: A Symphonist Stakes Her Claim
description: QUICK, who's the greatest woman symphonist? If you're up on your women composers, many names may flash to mind: Clara Schumann, Fanny Mendelssohn, Lili Boulanger, Cecile Chaminade, Ruth Crawford, Thea Musgrave, Joan Tower, Betsy Jolas, Barbara Kolb, Nancy Van de Vate, Lucia Dlugo szewski, Katherine Hoover, Vivian Fine, Ursula Mamlok. There's a lot of orchestral music here, all right, but not a symphony among them.

title: Can Europe Learn to Love Americans At the Gate?
description: IF it is true that history repeats itself, the spirit of junk-bond king Michael Milken had to be present when representatives from several of Wall Street's most influential leveraged-buyout firms and a gaggle of European executives gathered at the opulent Claridge's hotel in London last November for two days of schmoozing.

title: Upscale Housing in a Downscale Cincinnati Area
description: WHEN David C. Imboden bought his first waterfront house in the unfashionable East End neighborhood in 1987 he was struck by the stunning views of the Ohio River and the emerald hills of Kentucky. And, not incidentally, by the development possibilities.

title: April 18-24; Trade Gap Widens
description: The American economy is booming and increasing its imports while much of the world is drifting in economic doldrums with a diminishing appetite for American goods. The result has sharply increased the American trade deficit, which in February reached $19.4 billion. The deficit renewed debate over just how ''free'' the nation's trade policies should be.

title: A Higher Level of Child's Play
description: SAN FRANCISCO, a Western outpost for adult entertainment since Gold Rush days, has finally revealed a soft heart for children. A 10-acre entertainment and education center for the young -- both residents and visitors -- called the Rooftop at Yerba Buena Gardens opened last fall. And in June, Metreon, with interactive family entertainment based on the worlds of Maurice Sendak and David Macauley, will open across the street.

title: A Spano State of the County: Campaign '99
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew J. Spano's recent State of the County speech offered a blueprint of sorts for the re-election campaigns of the Democratic majority on the Board of Legislators later this year. Likewise, the ''pre-response'' issued by the Republicans, previewed that party's strategy to regain control of the Board in November.

title: From Opera to Chorus to Folk
description: VOICES are being raised in opera, chorus, theater and folk music this week. This afternoon in Jorgensen Auditorium, at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, youngsters can see ''101 Dalmatians'' in a fully staged musical at 1, 3 and 5 P.M.

title: BENEFITS
description: Max Roach Tribute

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, CHARLES
description: AARON-Charles. On April 23, 1999. The most devoted husband of Pearl. Most beloved father of Deborah Aaron and Jay Cantor. Cherished brother of Nettie Katcher and Ruth Franklin. Charles was a resident of West Caldwell, N.J. for 43 years. He received a Master's Degree in Mechanical Engineering from CCNY in 1936; he also held a Professional Engineer's degree. He held eighteen United States patents in printing and converting machinery. Services Sunday, April 25th, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, N.Y., N.Y.

title: The United State of NATO
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Study Suggests Repetition Gets Drug Warnings Across
description: Parents who talk to children about the risks of illicit drugs sometimes despair that their warning goes in one ear and out the other. But the message just might stick in a young brain if it is repeated enough, according to a study of parental and adolescent attitudes released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, HENRY
description: SMITH-Henry. Of Palm Beach, FL on April 22, 1999 at age 91. Beloved husband of the late Theodora A. Smith. Loving father of Gordon and Norma Smith and Fran Heller. Cherished grandfather of Randy Smith and Peter Aberg, Dr. Robin Smith and Dr. Kaare Kolstad, Melissa Haveson Pavese and John Pavese and Kim Haveson. Adoring great grandfather of Ashley Aberg and Alan Aberg. Services were held. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Horace Mann School.

title: Making a Mess of Disability Law; Improper Rejections
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Falls to His Death at Yankee Stadium
description: A man fell more than 90 feet to his death at Yankee Stadium yesterday after losing his balance while sitting on the handrail of an escalator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, IRVING
description: FRANK-Irving. 86, of Monroe Township, NJ (formerly of Larchmont, NY) on April 23, 1999. Dearly beloved husband of Shirley Leibowitz Frank. Devoted father of Denise Birnbaum. Brother of Murray. Service 12 PM, Monday, at Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ. Burial Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: Artist Arrested After 150 People Pose Nude for Him in Times Sq.
description: A Brooklyn artist who says he has persuaded people in all 50 states to pose nude in public was arrested after coaxing more than 150 people to lie naked in the middle of Times Square early yesterday so he could photograph them.

title: Let's Help Russia Help Us
description: Since the NATO campaign against Yugoslavia began, Western leaders have tried to persuade Russia to help mediate a settlement and get them out of the hole they have got themselves in.

title: Children's TV: Too Much of a Good Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, DAVID
description: GOLDMAN-David, age 71. On April 25, 1999. Author of ''Full Time Restless.'' Beloved husband of Ramona. Loving father of the late Louise Hoelscher. Father-in-law of Jeffery Hoelscher. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 1 PM. Interment to follow at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Lord Killanin, Olympic Leader, Dies at 84
description: Lord Killanin, the president of the International Olympic Committee from 1972 to 1980, a tumultuous period when the Olympic movement was buffeted by political boycotts, died yesterday at his home in Dublin. He was 84.

title: Don McGuire, 80, Writer for Films and TV
description: Don McGuire, a writer, director and producer in Hollywood, died on April 13 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 80.

title: Apple and PC's, Both Given Up for Dead, Are Rising Anew
description: Ask Jon Rubinstein, the man in charge of hardware at Apple Computer Inc., about the supposedly imminent ''post-PC era,'' and he answers like someone who works for Microsoft or Intel, the twin pillars of the personal computer industry, rather for than this quirky California computer maker.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; All those who deny any linkage between violence in entertainment and violence in real life, think again.
description: BY producing increasingly violent media, the entertainment industry has for decades engaged in a lucrative dance with the devil.

title: NATO Can Wait, But Can Kosovars?
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Deutsche Telekom Seen As a Suitor for One 2 One

title: Torre Ready to Travel With Team
description: Joe Torre is expected to join the Yankees in Kansas City late this week, but he said yesterday that he might not immediately return to his post as manager of the team. Rather, Torre may take some time to readjust to the unusual demands of traveling with a baseball team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, SALLY P.
description: GRAHAM-Sally P. Age 50. On April 24, 1999. Beloved daughter of Howard and the late Helen. Loving sister of Susan Hurley of Denville, NJ, and Sheilah Markham of Commerce, MI. Devoted aunt and great-aunt with many loving and caring friends. Sally was a fun loving and beautiful person. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Tuesday, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. at 84 St., Wednesday, 9 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Cardinal Cooke Health Care Center, 1249 Fifth Ave., NY, NY 10029.

title: Sun Plans Introduction of New Network Product
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. plans to introduce a software product on Monday that is designed for companies that want to let their employees use various devices to connect to corporate computer networks, secure from unauthorized access.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIFER, GOLDIE (ALTSTOCK)
description: SEIFER-Goldie (Altstock). 71, of Tel Aviv (formerly of Brooklyn) on April 23, 1999. Mother of Dena Friedman and Barbara Turoff. Grandmother of Jennifer Friedman, Stephanie Friedman and Melissa Turoff. Funeral Monday, 11:30 AM, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 312 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. Burial New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, HERBERT ISRAEL
description: DIAMOND-Herbert Israel. Of the Bronx, on April 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Lea, dear father and father-in-law of Lois and Thomas Gueli and Sharon Diamond and Roger Nathaniel. Adored grandfather of Emma, Jasper, Jeremy, Lydia, Jonathan and Allison. Shiva will be observed from 3 PM to 8 PM today (April 26) at the home of Sharon Diamond. Donations may be made to Temple Beth Shalom, 740 Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY 10706 or for research into depression to NARSAD 1-800829-8289.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEARNS, HESTER HEWLETT
description: STEARNS-Hester Hewlett. Of Delray Beach, FL, on April 23, 1999. Wife of the late James Britton Stearns. Graveside service today, 2 PM, in Memorial Cemetery of St. John's Church, Laurel Grove, NY.

title: Mania for 'Pocket Monsters' Yields Billions for Nintendo
description: Lisa Chapman and her two sons camped out in their car in the parking lot of the Oxford Valley Mall here on a recent Friday night so they could beat the crowd at the Pokemon Trading Card Game Tour the next morning. The line formed at 7 A.M., and by the time the event began four hours later, it had swelled to 4,000 children and their parents.

title: 80% of Vote Reported to Back Rewrite of Venezuela's Charter
description: Venezuelans today overwhelmingly approved a Government-backed proposal to convoke a national assembly to write a new constitution. The decision signals the disintegration of the political system that has been in place here for more than 40 years.

title: Web-Page Distribution System Could Unclog Internet Traffic Jams
description: Tax time was crunch time for the World Wide Web site of Intuit Inc., the supplier of personal finance software. Traffic shot up to as much as 20 times its levels the rest of year, as customers downloaded the latest revisions to Intuit's Turbotax tax preparation program.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Bribe Report Pulls Embassy Into Scandal In Malaysia
description: A Washington limousine driver has drawn the Malaysian Embassy here into the worst political scandal in the modern history of that Southeast Asian nation.

title: Essay; Defeat's 19 Fathers
description: Public statements conflicted with the private, unattributable thoughts of celebrants at Washington's NATO golden anniversary weekend.

title: Footwork That Digs To the Heart Of the Music
description: ''Savion Glover/Downtown'' is an intimate, stylishly informal tap revue. Mr. Glover has assembled a group of four good young tappers and a superb musical ensemble for his latest show, subtitled ''Live Communication,'' which runs through May 22 at the Variety Arts Theater. There are guest dancers and musicians at each performance. Essentially, however, ''Savion Glover/Downtown'' gives this committed artist another opportunity to work at his art in public.

title: Subverting Hatred With Quiet Luminosity
description: Lawrence Goldhuber and Heidi Latsky describe their new ''Worst Case Scenario'' as an exploration of the role that hatred plays in people's lives. Violence threads through the hourlong piece, most powerfully in combative partnering, angry solo dancing and photographic imagery of seeming hate messages printed on parts of the body. But the effect of the dance, presented by Goldhuber and Latsky on Friday night at Performance Space 122, is far more visual than visceral.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGER, RUTH
description: LANGER-Ruth. At the age of 74. Beloved wife of the late Isaac. Devoted mother of Marcelle Langer Sheehan, the late Gabe and the late Esther. Cherished grandmother of Spencer and Melinda Sheehan and Elaine Langer. She was a Holocaust survivor from the Lodz ghetto and her strength and memory will live forever in our hearts. Services Monday, 11:30 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Squatters in Venezuela
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the City Hall Notes column on Saturday about criticism of Police Commissioner Howard Safir over a rhetorical question about wife-beating misstated the surname of the Yale librarian who traced the question's origin. He is Fred Shapiro, editor of the Oxford Dictionary of American Legal Quotations, not Fred Siegel.

title: Ambulance Service Is Faster, but Medical Gains Are in Doubt
description: Three years after the Fire Department took over New York City's Emergency Medical Service, fire officials have begun to make good on some of the bold promises made during their aggressive campaign to seize control of the beleaguered public ambulance system.

title: Pact Reached on Using Welfare Recipients to Clean Subway
description: The city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority have reached an agreement in principle to allow welfare recipients to clean up trash in subway stations in exchange for their benefits, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday. Administration officials said they hoped the first few dozen of what will ultimately be 1,000 workfare subway cleaners would begin work next month.

title: 'Internet Governor' Woos Silicon Valley
description: James S. Gilmore 3d, the Governor of Virginia, stood on the steps of the Netscape Communications Corporation's headquarters last Tuesday and smiled in the morning sun. The man Virginians know as the ''Internet Governor'' was 3,000 miles from his constituents but he insisted he felt at home in Silicon Valley.

title: Sports of The Times; In Mind's Eye, Forever Flawless
description: THROUGH smooth, singular voices was Joe DiMaggio most artfully remembered yesterday. Bob Sheppard recited the last lineup. Paul Simon sang a fond farewell. The grainy black-and-white video screen images paled in competition with recollections of the way things were, or we have wished them to be.

title: Sports of The Times; One Huge Comeback For Checketts's Team
description: THERE were lots of hugs to go around yesterday afternoon. With six-tenths of a second left and the Knicks on the verge of stealing a game from the despised Miami Heat, Larry Johnson hugged Kurt Thomas and Patrick Ewing hugged Charlie Ward. Herb Williams was hugging everyone he saw on the bench. This was like a giddy college team on the verge of winning a tournament game, or a team of Davids who had just defeated Goliath.

title: Refugee From the Nashville Factory Finds Her Own Audience
description: Country music often prides itself on how much it can say and still be taken at face value, but there was a lot of subtext coursing through Kelly Willis's show on Friday night at the Mercury Lounge. She delivered a pointed introduction for each song -- from the fact that her current and former husbands were co-writers of one of them (''that qualifies me to be a country singer,'' she joked) to the pride she took in set-list juxtapositions (placing a morose, oblique song by the English cult songwriter Nick Drake before ''Heaven's Just a Sin Away,'' the cheery 70's honky-tonk hit by the Kendalls.)

title: Hundreds Take Up the Cause of a Killer
description: Little more than a week before his appointment with the state executioner, Manny Babbitt has more friends than in all his nearly 50 miserable years.

title: INSIDE
description: A Lag in Saving Lives

title: Dubai Connection and Fillies Spice Derby
description: Michael Osborne, manager of the racing stable that sent two colts halfway round the world to the Kentucky Derby, put it bluntly: ''We are going into the unknown.''

title: Editorial Observer
description: Question: What do you get when you add two and two?

title: Compressed Data; New Ratings Give Lycos A Reason to Celebrate
description: In the Internet business, the top of the heap is a very unsteady place. And nobody knows that better than Bob Davis, chief executive of Lycos Network Inc.

title: Jim Copp, 85, a Producer Of Humorous Children's Music
description: Jim Copp, a creator of children's records with loony tunes, literate lyrics, occasional dark themes and wacky characters like the Dog That Went to Yale, died at Midway Hospital in Los Angeles on April 7. He was 85.

title: Unbowed and Only Slightly Bitter; An Indonesian Writer and Survivor Preaches Courage
description: For three decades Pramoedya Ananta Toer, Indonesia's greatest modern writer, felt the full force of President Suharto's military state.

title: Speakers at a Four A's meeting urge agencies to meet competition from management consultants.
description: THE 81st annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, which concluded here on Saturday, closed with exhortations to the estimated 350 attendees to tackle enthusiastically the challenges confronting the industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACNAB, JOHN BROWN
description: MACNAB-John Brown. Age 77. From 1955 to 1992 beloved pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, died Tuesday, April 20 in Rehoboth, DE. Mourned by his wife Mary, daughters Jean, Mary Dee and Nancy, grandchildren, family and the congregation. A Memorial Service will be held at First Presbyterian Church, Sunday, May 9th at 3PM. Memorial gifts to Amyloid Research Fund, 715 Albany St, Boston, MA. 02118-2526.

title: Compressed Data; Antivirus Companies Sound a New Alarm
description: When the clock strikes midnight tonight, it will set off a nasty version of a computer virus known as CIH 1.2 that is capable of deleting part of the contents of hard drives and preventing computers from booting up.

title: Little Urgency on the Eve Of World Bankers' Meeting
description: When the finance ministers and officials of the world's biggest economic powers last met in Washington six months ago, President Clinton declared that he and other leaders were confronting ''the biggest financial challenge facing the world in a half-century.''

title: Lawmakers Want an Asylum Rule for Sex-Based Persecution
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer and Representative Carolyn B. Maloney said yesterday that the case of a 29-year-old woman from Ghana, who says she fled to the United States because she feared that her tribe's leaders were going to cut her genitals, demonstrated the need to turn immigration guidelines on sex-based persecution into binding regulations or laws.

title: The Global Village Is Here. Resist at Your Peril.
description: THE LEXUS AND THE OLIVE TREE

title: Quick Strikes Leave Devils Looking Up
description: Some members of the Devils called the mental lapse that led to two quick Pittsburgh goals a brain cramp. Whatever the choice of words, the Devils, the top-seeded team in the Eastern Conference, now find themselves trailing the eighth-seeded team, just as they did last season in their first-round elimination by the Ottawa Senators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLEY, ISABEL
description: BERLEY-Isabel. The Board of Trustees, clergy, staff and congregation of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue mourn the passing of our beloved Honorary Trustee and cherished member, Isabel Berley. We lovingly remember her with gratitude for her years of devoted service. Our deepest sympathy to her husband, Bill, and their children and grandchildren. Gary Bretton-Granatoor, Sr. Rabbi Balfour Brickner, Rabbi Emeritus Ellen Stettner, Cantor Maron L. Waxman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, LOUISE C.
description: ROTHSTEIN-Louise C. Of Brooklyn, NY, died an untimely death in Tampa, FL, on April 24, 1999. Survived by her mother Rose Rothstein, sister and brother-in-law Jane and Jonathan Bell, nephews and niece Stephen, Marc and Jennifer; daughter of the late Ira Rothstein. Served as Deputy Director of Personnel for the Board of Education, City of New York. Funeral service Wednesday, April 28, at 9:30 AM, ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERTHEIMER, JOHN B.
description: WERTHEIMER-John B. On April 24, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Suzanne and father of Ralph and Alan. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, BERNARD, JUDGE
description: NEWMAN-Bernard, Judge. The officers and members of the LaGuardia Memorial Association mourn the passing of a longtime member and distinguished jurist. He will be missed. Morton B. Lawrence, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, MARGARET R.
