description: GILBERT-Margaret R. Age 77. On April 25, 1999. Devoted wife of John. Loving mother of Margot and mother-in-law to Allan Frank. Funeral service to be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, today, Monday, 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to your favorite charity.

title: New University Head Vows Closer Ties to Neighbors
description: Walter Harrison was inaugurated today as the fifth president of the University of Hartford, and said in his inaugural address that his goals included reinvigorating the university's civic involvement and physically reconnecting it with its neighbors.

title: Media Talk; Promotional Stunt Irks Journalists
description: It sounded like a letter from a love-smitten stalker.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: A Conflagration, but No Riot This Time
description: Students with bellies and backpacks full of beer were just beginning to clump in merry groups of a dozen or so on a parking lot at the University of Connecticut a little after 11 Saturday night when -- fwoom! -- a bonfire stoked by junk mail, shrubs and pizza boxes lighted up the chilly finale to spring weekend.

title: O'Connor Wins
description: Despite a knockdown at the ninth jump on the stadium jumping course, Karen O'Connor and Prince Panache captured first place in the Rolex-Kentucky Four-Star horse trials yesterday in Lexington, Ky.

title: Sharing Anguish, Guilt and Hope
description: Four days before the shootings, the principal of Columbine High School, Frank DeAngelis, told his students at an emotional pep rally that he did not want to bury another young person. With the prom set for the next night, Saturday, he implored them not to drink, or drink and drive, or put themselves at risk in any way.

title: Syria Sneaks Iraq's Oil Out As Old Foes Become Friends
description: In a brazen violation of United Nations sanctions, scores of Syrian trucks laden with Iraqi oil now shuttle past this desert oasis every day, reflecting the ties that have turned the former foes into friends.

title: A New Take on the Shipping News
description: Coverage, circulation and advertising have peeled away from The Journal of Commerce for two generations. Stock and bond tables disappeared two decades ago, commodities coverage was hijacked by competitors and the advertising base eroded as large shipping companies merged. But as the newspaper has sputtered economically, it has continued to provide a mix of trade policy analysis and coverage of the shipping industry.

title: Yale's Property Line Expands Again, to Neighbors' Ire
description: Residents' anger over expansion by Yale University, the city's largest employer and landowner, goes back decades.

title: Political Memo; Political Heir Is Challenged From Within
description: It is unusual enough for a New York City Congressman to face opposition within his own party for re-election. So when three public officials band together to openly plot an incumbent's downfall, it borders on the extraordinary.

title: Donald Pritchard, 76, Professor At SUNY and an Oceanographer
description: Donald W. Pritchard, an oceanographer and expert on the Long Island Sound and the Chesapeake Bay, died on Friday at the University of Maryland Hospital in Baltimore. He was 76 and lived in Severna Park, Md.

title: New York Teachers Have a Pretty Good Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, GERTRUDE R.
description: DEUTSCH-Gertrude R. Died Friday, April 23, 1999 at Leisure Park Center, Lakewood, NJ. She was 87. She, along with her late husband, Samuel, owned Peterson's Sunset Cabin in Lakewood and were proprietors of numerous hotels in Lakewood, the Catskills, and Miami Beach. She is survived by three sons: Stephen of Scarsdale, NY, Lewis of Toms River, NJ, and Warren of Lakewood; seven grandchildren and one greatgranddaughter. Memorial donations to any cancer research center.

title: They Didn't Live So Long for This
description: It is thought that as many as half of all women over 65 in the United States and a third of all men will spend some of their remaining time in a nursing home. The American population is aging, and as new assisted living communities draw off the more able and affluent retirees, and as increased Federal funding allows others to be supported by health care visits at home, nursing homes have acquired the sickest and most dependent of the old.

title: New York Teachers Have a Pretty Good Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Comes Forward, Without the Hood
description: Last Monday, a New York City police officer named Yvette Walton hid her face behind dark glasses and the tightly drawn hood of a sweatshirt and testified at a City Council hearing that her old unit, the Street Crime Unit, was inhospitable to black and Hispanic officers and violated people's rights by searching them without justification.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Donald John Bruckman yesterday referred incorrectly in some copies to one of Mr. Bruckman's accomplishments as chairman of the New York Botanical Garden. He oversaw the restoration of the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, not the Garden Conservancy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the United Nations Commission on Human Rights misstated the vote on a resolution censuring Cuba. It was adopted by a vote of 21-20, not 22-21. Because of an editing error, the votes of Russia and China were misstated. They voted against the measure; they did not abstain.

title: Patents; Viagra's success has brought to light a second big market for sexual dysfunction therapies: women.
description: WITH the recent success of Viagra, the impotence drug for men, a number of companies are scurrying to develop sexual-dysfunction therapies aimed at an even larger market: women.

title: At N.A.A.C.P. Dinner, Gore Praises Affirmative Action and Declares War on Prejudice
description: Proclaiming that his father had been voted out of the Senate largely for his support of civil rights legislation, Vice President Al Gore tonight affirmed his commitment to fighting ''the cruelties of the heart that have been attributed to prejudice.''

title: Meet the Small Family, A Year After the Divorce
description: It must take a great deal of effort to turn out an animated show that looks and sounds like a clever rough draft. The producers of ''Home Movies,'' which starts its run tonight on the UPN network, are clearly proud of their techniques, which they also use in their Comedy Central hit, ''Dr. Katz: Professional Therapist.'' They have aptly named their sketchy, jumpy visual style Squigglevision. And if the dialogue seems hastily ad-libbed and out of sync with the animation, that's on purpose, too. The dubbing technique had been dubbed Retroscripting.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you are a parent, they need your attention. If you are a grandparent, they need your time. If you do not have children, there are kids who need your example and presence.''

title: Speaking Up for Guns, Lots of Them, for Nearly Anyone
description: Larry Pratt said that his first thoughts after hearing about the bloodshed in a Colorado school were, ''This is bad, and there's going to be a feeding frenzy on the gun issue, and I'll probably have to wear a coat and tie to work for the next few days.'' The television cameras would surely be coming. He should look nice.

title: Compressed Data; Taking to the Road With a New Internet Pitch
description: He is flush from the recent initial public offering of iVillage.com, in which he got insider stock as a participant in the Web site's Armchair Millionaire section. Now, Lewis Schiff, a New York-based Internet marketer, is touting his latest venture, Invest-o-rama, an on-line listing of some 10,000 financial information sites on the World Wide Web.

title: Putting Echoes Of the Past To New Use
description: Not long ago the English tenor Ian Bostridge was a postdoctoral fellow in history at Oxford, and his only recitals were informal events in small college halls before audiences of two or three dozen invited friends.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, PETER
description: FRANK-Peter. The Otis Woodlands Community of Otis, MA, is deeply saddened by the loss of our beloved friend and former President Peter Frank. We will always be grateful for his wise counsel and dedication to the continuity of our community. Peter drew us close to him with his loving kindness, devotion, high spirit, boundless energy, and his passion for life's pleasures. We feel blessed to have known him.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Unusual Issues Complicate Louima Jury Selection
description: More than in most cases, the process of selecting a jury for the trial of four police officers accused of brutalizing a Haitian immigrant has been slow and painstaking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALSAM, JEROME
description: BALSAM-Jerome. On April 25, 1999, in his 75th year. Beloved husband of Rita. Devoted father of Mark Balsam and Joan Galinkin. Loving grandfather of Chris, Jenna and Jesse. Services 10:45 AM, Tuesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to Cystic Fibrosis Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Clinton and Yeltsin Agree to Share Ideas on Kosovo
description: President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia agreed in a telephone conversation today to work closely together in the search for a solution to the conflict in Kosovo. They spoke as leaders of NATO concluded a summit meeting with pledges to intensify their air campaign against Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARUTT, BARBARA (POLICOFF)
description: ARUTT-Barbara (Policoff). 57, of Westport, CT. Beloved wife of Daniel. Loving daughter of Isabel Rogers. Devoted mother of Amy, Cheryl and Robin. Loving sister of Martin, Jerry and Peg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDERMAN, MAE
description: LINDERMAN-Mae. Life partner for 67 years of Morris. Devoted mother of Estelle Linderman Resnick and Martin Resnick, and Gary Linderman. Devoted and loving grandmother of Corey Blake Resnick and grandmother of Jennifer and Jeffrey. Dear sister of Philip Morse. Services Tuesday, 9:45 AM, Riverside Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Boeing Considers Building 800-Seat Plane
description: The Boeing Company said today that it was considering developing a jet capable of carrying as many as 800 passengers, pitting the world's largest airplane maker against Airbus Industrie in the market for so-called superjumbo jets.

title: Seminarians Seek to Teach Through Their Disabilities
description: When four students from Union Theological Seminary held a worship service in November, each one talked about her disability or emotional impairment and how it related to her spirituality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGER, VICTOR
description: SAGER-Victor. Beloved husband of the late Mildred (nee Cohen). Loving and dearest father of Linda, Andrew, Richard, Wendy, Lawri and Jinny. Devoted and loving brother of Edna and Irving, and the late Harriet, Norma and Stephen. Adoring grandfather, great-grandfather, uncle and great-uncle. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., 11:30 AM, Tuesday, April 27.

title: Interpublic Unit Gets Novartis Work
description: Novartis Consumer Health North America in Summit, N.J., a unit of Novartis Inc., has expanded its relationship with Western Initiative Media Worldwide in Los Angeles, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Western will handle media duties for national cable, syndication and spot broadcast for Novartis over-the-counter product brands like Exlax, Maalox and Theraflu. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: MEDIA: Gentlemen's Disagreement; GQ and Esquire Grapple for a Manly Market
description: Esquire and GQ, nominees for National Magazine Awards this week, are rival men's publications headed by two former colleagues and sharing a demonstrated interest in what might politely be called male anatomy. But they approach the subject -- as they do many other things -- very differently.

title: The Day Violence Eclipsed The Sunlight in Los Angeles
description: Although ''L.A. Riots Revisited'' comes up with no revelations, it does bring back the striking failure of the Los Angeles police to contain, much less control, the April 1992 riots that left much of the city ablaze. While mobs ran through South-Central Los Angeles, looting and burning and attacking whites who found themselves in the wrong place, the police dithered, retreated and for a time surrendered to violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELL, DENNIS G.
description: MANDELL-Dennis G. Her body's gone to rust but her spirit prevails. We watch the formations fly overhead by the sea. Blues, humor, grace. You are with us. Marina Malchin

title: Broadcom to Acquire Epigram In a Deal Worth $316 Million
description: Seeking to offer high-speed Internet links within homes, the Broadcom Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Epigram Inc., a private maker of microchips for data communications, for $316 million in stock.

title: Gandhi Cabinet Bid Fails; India May Call New Election
description: A week after the Hindu nationalist-led Government collapsed, India appeared to be headed for its third general election in three years as the opposition's efforts to form a new government disintegrated today in acrimony and finger-pointing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENKRANTZ, STEVEN J.
description: BLUMENKRANTZ-Steven J. 52, of the town of Maryland, NY. Died Tuesday, April 20 of an apparent heart attack. Beloved husband of Carole. Father of Katie. Son of Renee and the late Harris. Brother of David. He practiced law in New York City and Oneonta, NY. He was an Assistant Professor at the State University at Oneonta. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Center for the Advancement of Youth, Family & Community Services, Inc., P.O. Box 816, Glastonbury, CT 06033; The National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 1000 Elmwood Ave., Rochester, NY 14620; or Wegener's Granulomatosis Support Group, P.O. Box 28660, Kansas City, MO 64188.

title: A Port With a Political Storm; As Governors Feud, Dockworkers Fear for Their Jobs
description: In the 29 years since James Stolpinski arrived on the finger piers of Staten Island as an 18-year-old with a broad back and a longshoreman's union card, he has unhappily watched New Jersey supplant New York as the region's cargo hub. He blames New York governors for being ''asleep at the wheel'' for decades as New Jersey ports ascended at the expense of those in Brooklyn and on Staten Island.

title: Dance Service Award For 2 Festival Directors
description: Charles and Stephanie Reinhart, co-directors of the American Dance Festival and co-artistic directors of dance for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, are to receive the Dance Notation Bureau Distinguished Service Award at 6:30 tonight.

title: Machismo Disguising A Sensitive Inner Core
description: Eric Comstock, a lusty-voiced singer and pianist in the tradition of Bobby Short and Steve Ross, has learned well from these debonair masters of the small but hardy piano-bar genre. The singer, who opened a four-weekend engagement in the Blue Room at the Supper Club (240 West 47th Street, in Manhattan) on Friday evening, confidently wields a style that balances an urbane bonhomie against the intimacy of material that often uses wit to mask emotional fragility.

title: Children's TV: Too Much of a Good Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, SUSAN H.
description: GOLD-Susan H., age 63 of Tenafly, NJ. A learning disabilities consultant, on Sunday, April 25, 1999. Survived by her children Lisa, Howard and Reva; sister Alice Furst and granddaughter Hallie. Alumna of Brandeis, Columbia Teacher's College. Services are Tuesday, 10 AM, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Liability for the Millennium Bug
description: With 249 days to go until the year 2000, many experts are alarmed and others are only mildly concerned about the danger of computer chaos posed by the so-called millennium bug. One prediction seems safe, however. Whatever the damage, there will be lots of lawsuits. In anticipation, some in Congress, mainly Republicans, want legislation to limit the right of people and businesses to sue in the event of a Y2K disaster. Their reasoning is that the important thing is to get people to fix their computer problems now rather than wait and sue. But the legislation is misguided and potentially unfair. It could even lessen the incentive for corrective action.

title: Police Warn Of Hate Bombs In Britain
description: After two nail-bomb attacks on racial minorities here in the last eight days, the police ominously warned today that extreme right-wing groups may try to spread their campaign of race hatred to other parts of Britain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, J. BUCKHOUT
description: JOHNSTON-J. Buckhout. The Philharmonic Symphony-Society of New York, Inc., deeply mourns the passing of J. Buckhout (''Bucky'') Johnston, a loyal friend of the Orchestra. Mr. Johnston served as a member of the Philharmonic's Board of Directors for many years, and was elected an Honorary Director of the Society in 1995, in recognition of his years of dedicated efforts on the Philharmonic's behalf. His caring and support will long continue to enrich our lives. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Emma, and their family. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Deborah Borda, Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONAGH, REVEREND MONSIGNOR CHARLES G.
description: McDONAGH-Reverend Monsignor Charles G. On April 23, 1999. Devoted priest of the Archdiocese of New York. Beloved son of the late Hannah and Charles McDonagh. Cherished brother of Margaret Douglas, Joan Ferrara, Ann and the late Genevieve, and Eugene. Cherished uncle of six, and adored great-uncle of 12. He was a Chaplain at St. Vincent's Hospital, Staten Island, and formerly Secretary to Terrence Cardinal Cooke and John Cardinal O'Connor. Viewing at the David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, 899 McLean Ave. (near Kimball), Yonkers, NY. Mass of the Christian Burial Tuesday, Saint Patrick's Cathedral, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to the Society for the Propigation of the Faith, 1011 First Ave, NYC 10022.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: This Time, Final Period Belongs To Knicks
description: Marcus Camby and Kurt Thomas passed an initiation today and found themselves in a club reserved for those whose animosity for the Miami Heat obliterates common logic.

title: AT&T Has Set Itself Some Tough Challenges
description: Following the AT&T Corporation under C. Michael Armstrong has become an experience akin to watching one film sequel after another in the ''Jaws'' series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, SYLVIA
description: PARKER-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Devoted mother of Allan and Gary. Dear sister of Ruth and Jack. Loving grandmother of Brett, Jill and Casie. With love, Allan and Gary. Services were held Sunday, April 25.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, RITA
description: KATZ-Rita. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Fredi Schuster on the loss of his sister. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVICK, RONALD E.
description: LEVICK-Ronald E. 4/26/29-3/23/98. Remembering you on your birthday. You are always in our hearts and thoughts. Love, Your Family

title: Clinton's Positive Thinking: The NATO Alliance Is Alive and Kicking
description: The timing could hardly have been worse, and the commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was largely obscured by savagery in Kosovo and Colorado.

title: Gershwin Suaveness As the Art of Quick Change
description: Clothes may make the man, but they surely shouldn't make the musical. Yet what lingers in the memory about ''The Gershwins' Fascinating Rhythm'' is not the way the cast members treat the old material; it's the way they wear the new material.

title: With Peace Accord at Hand, East Timor's War Deepens
description: With the energy of a football rally, a convoy of cheering enthusiasts with red-and-white headbands wound through this tiny seaside capital of the territory of East Timor this month. Then, shouting, ''Kill them! Burn their houses,'' they jumped from their trucks and started shooting and lobbing hand grenades.

title: Fitting Tribute To DiMaggio: Williams Gives Yanks a Victory
description: In his day, Joe DiMaggio liked to lounge at his locker, drinking coffee and smoking cigarettes. On Joe DiMaggio Day at Yankee Stadium, Bernie Williams lounged at his locker and played guitar with Paul Simon, royalty in these parts because of the lyrics he wrote about Joltin' Joe.

title: Piazza Back With a Hit, But Sosa Gets the Big Hit
description: It was supposed to be a day for celebration. Instead, the Mets' 8-4 loss to the Chicago Cubs left Mike Piazza feeling only frustration today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWLEY, ALEXANDER STEWART
description: COWLEY-Alexander Stewart. A celebration of Stewart's life will be held for his many friends, appropriately at P.J. Clarke's, on Tuesday, April 27, from 5-7 PM.

title: Russia's Wide Influence
description: To the Editor:

title: A Portrait Of Two Killers At War With Themselves
description: Something in Dylan Klebold's voice had spooked his mother that morning.

title: A Gap in the Curriculum
description: The ghastly horror in Littleton, Colo., makes all of us repeat our favorite remedies for eliminating violence.

title: Summit Officers Find Solace In the Computer War Game
description: It seemed a far lovelier war being waged today in the embattled nation of Azure.

title: Making a Mess of Disability Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Once the Friends of NATO, Belgraders Have Become Its Furious Victims
description: A year ago, Yugoslav Government ministers and the policy elite seriously pondered joining NATO's Partnership for Peace program, a sort of training ground and waiting room for alliance membership.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Great Rivalries In the Women's Game
description: THIS summer's Women's World Cup gained instant credibility yesterday. This was apparent from the steamed looks on the faces of the American players, who discovered they can, in fact, lose on the green, green grass of home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASHER, CHARLES
description: KASHER-Charles. I'll miss you, Charlie. Ursula

title: 70,000 Mourn In Quiet Tears, Song and Rain
description: Jonathan Cohen, a slender 17-year-old lost in an oversized sweatshirt, stood today before a sea of silent faces, closed his eyes, and sang in a clear tenor, ''Do you still hear raging guns, ending dreams of precious ones?''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTER, STANLEY D.
description: CANTER-Stanley D. 75, of New York, NY, and Richmond, MA, died on Saturday, April 24, in New York City of cancer. Devoted husband of Florence, beloved father of Robert and Leonard and daughter-in-law Julie. He is also survived by two grandchildren, Alexandra and Samuel. A former Partner and President of the marketing consultancy Canter Achenbaum Associates, and onetime Senior Vice President of Ogilvy & Mather, one of the world's largest advertising agencies, Stanley Canter held a Master of Arts degree in mathematical statistics from Columbia University and a Bachelor of Arts degree from the City College of New York. He was a longtime member of the Market Research Council, the Copy Research Council, and ARC, a professional advertising research organization of which he was a founder. Canter was well-known in advertising circles as a prolific speechmaker and lecturer. According to his wishes, he was cremated. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: NATO Can Wait, But Can Kosovars?
description: To the Editor:

title: CULT'S FOLLOWERS RALLY IN BEIJING
description: More than 10,000 followers of a religious cult surrounded China's leadership compound today, demanding recognition from authorities who are wary of any group not easily controlled. It was the biggest protest here since the democracy movement in Tiananmen Square in 1989.

title: Oscar Board Rethinks Fate Of the Short Documentary
description: Margaret Lazarus had been making films about social issues for 17 years before she won an Academy Award in 1994 for ''Defending Our Lives,'' a 30-minute documentary recording the experiences of battered women who were convicted of killing their husbands.

title: Joker Is Wild: Baffert Bids for No. 3 in Derby
description: The camera crews hustled to get out of his way and their subject was uncharacteristically oblivious to them. Bob Baffert was working. He had a two-way radio in one hand, a stopwatch in the other, and a chestnut gelding barreling around the turn beneath those twin spires that make Churchill Downs horse racing's signature postcard.

title: People
description: * Cheryl Kroyer was named senior partner at Select Resources International, Los Angeles. She had most recently been the media services director at Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, a unit of Omnicom Group.

title: Deutsche Telekom Shows Interest in One 2 One
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G., which is trying to merge with Telecom Italia for more than $80 billion, may also have its sights on a mobile telephone acquisition in Britain.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TISHMAN, MARCIA
description: TISHMAN-Marcia. Mom, we miss you and think of you every day. Your light still shines bright. Love, Steven, Andy, Michael and Robert

title: Economist at Harvard Awarded Prize
description: Andrei Shleifer, a Harvard University economist who immigrated to the United States from Russia when he was a teen-ager, has won the John Bates Clark Medal, the most prestigious prize in economics short of the Nobel. The medal, awarded every two years by the American Economic Association, goes to an outstanding economist under 40 years old.

title: Rich Newcomers Closing the Wilds of Montana
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: In Renewed Battle Over Weapons Control, Both Sides Use Attack to Advance Agendas
description: Just hours after the gunfire had stopped on Tuesday in Littleton, Colo., another battle erupted as lobbying groups and others on warring sides of the nation's gun debate moved to turn the shootings to their advantage.

title: Exiled Intellectuals Hold Fast to Kosovo
description: Like Bosnia's Muslims, the Albanians of Kosovo are finding that the Serbs are scattering and destroying those who could be deemed leaders.

title: Children's TV: Too Much of a Good Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials See Little Chance For Vouchers
description: Aides to Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's revived plan for school vouchers would still need Board of Education approval, giving it little if any hope of succeeding.

title: Uprooted and Idle, Kosovo's Cultured Pace Streets and Cafes of Their Haven
description: Here they stroll, up Marshal Tito Street, some of the most recognizable faces of Kosovo's diaspora. Their lives are now scattered pieces, some parts irretrievable -- homes lost, loved ones missing, work destroyed, faith worn down to the nub.

title: Julian Cole, 74, Mathematician
description: Julian David Cole, a professor at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., and an internationally acknowledged expert on the applied-mathematics technique known as perturbation, died April 17 at Albany Medical Center Hospital. He was 74 and lived in Loudonville, N.Y.

title: NATO Can Wait, But Can Kosovars?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in some copies yesterday about an auction record set by the sale of a watercolor at Sotheby's misspelled the first word in the title of the painting. It was ''Violet Munnings's Horse 'Chips' at Chantilly,'' by Sir Alfred J. Munnings, not ''violent.''

title: Intricate Rhythms Simplified for Dancing Into Ecstasy
description: A few months ago ''Reich: Remixed'' (Nonesuch) came out as a series of dance music remixes of pieces by the composer Steve Reich. It was a good idea. Mr. Reich's music, grounded in his study not just of the European composing tradition, but of West African drumming, is rhythmically astute. Classical orchestras tremble when the scores arrive; they're difficult.

title: Margeotes Wins Triton PCS Account
description: Triton PCS Inc. in Malvern, Pa., an affiliate of the AT&T Corporation, has awarded its account to Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners in New York, a unit of the MDC Communications Corporation. Billings for the account of the wireless communications company were estimated at $10 million to $12 million. Christine Davies, a spokeswoman for Triton, said the decision came after a review that had been narrowed to Margeotes/ Fertitta and two other finalists, Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York and Warwick Baker O'Neill in New York. West & Vaughan Inc. in Durham, N.C., which had handled the account since July, was not invited to take part, Ms. Davies said.

title: Next Door, 6 States Face $2.4 Billion In War Costs
description: The war in Kosovo will effectively cost the six most affected Balkan countries bordering Serbia at least $2.4 billion this year if fighting is prolonged and no refugees return home, Western analysts have estimated.

title: Cable and Wireless Is Said to Sell Unit
description: Global Crossing, which operates a worldwide fiber optic network designed for Internet transmissions, is expected to announce today that it is acquiring the Global Marine subsidiary of Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain, according to people close to the companies.

title: The Heat Is Bruised by Fourth-Quarter Collapse
description: The Miami Heat today developed what might be described as a Knicks hangover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, JULIA C
description: LEVY-Julia C. On April 24, 1999. Devoted wife of the late Murray H. Beloved sister, aunt and greataunt. She will always be remembered.

title: Pre-emptive Maneuvering By a French Connoisseur
description: A French expert, Paul Chemla, has had an astonishing run of success in the last 20 months. In 1997 he was a member of the French team that won the world team championship. A year ago he won a silver medal in the European Mixed Pairs and a gold medal in the European Mixed Teams. Two weeks after that he won the Generali World Individual title. In Lille in August he was named personality of the year by the International Bridge Press Association. And last month he won the European Pairs with one of his regular teammates, Alain Levy.

title: Kosovo Rebels Surface to Speak Publicly About Their Struggle
description: For the first time since NATO began bombing Yugoslavia, leaders of the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army in northern Albania spoke openly today with Western reporters, detailing what they said were crippling shortages of ammunition and food in Kosovo, and confusion within the rebel force itself.

title: Dow Jones Will Offer Free Site On the Web for Business Users
description: The niche market for business-oriented sites on the World Wide Web is getting a little more crowded. Dow Jones & Company, which has already attracted 283,000 paid subscribers to The Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition, is introducing dowjones.com, a free site for business users.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EREN, SUHA S.
description: EREN-Suha S. On April 23, 1999. Beloved husband of Emine. Father of Selcuk and Sinan. Grandfather of Scott and Stephen. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Tuesday, 2-5 PM. Interment private.

title: S. R. Macdonald, 74; Newspaper Executive
description: Stewart R. Macdonald, a former executive of the American Newspaper Publishers Association who started its foundation and helped it raise millions of dollars for education, died on April 18 in the Hospice of Northern Virginia in Leesburg. He was 74.

title: Dieste in Venture With Ad Rendon
description: Dieste & Partners in Dallas, an agency specializing in campaigns aimed at the Spanish-speaking population, and Ad Rendon Communications in Los Angeles have teamed up to form a joint venture called Dieste & Partners/West. The new joint venture will have 10 employees working on accounts with billings estimated at $6 million to $8 million for clients like the Anaheim Angels baseball team, Hyundai Motor America and Los Angeles International Airport.

title: NATO Again Knocks Serbian TV Off the Air
description: NATO warplanes knocked Serbian television off the air again today for several hours when they attacked large television transmission towers south of Belgrade, the Yugoslav capital.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Saturday about the NATO meeting in Washington misidentified the leader shown at the far left. He was President Suleyman Demirel of Turkey, not Prime Minister Costas Simitis of Greece.

title: Dirty Power Plants
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Treasury Is Set to Auction Bills and Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week offers today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a 52-week bill to be auctioned tomorrow and a two-year note to be auctioned on Wednesday.

title: Accounts
description: * The Federal Emergency Management Agency, Washington, to Bozell Worldwide, New York, a unit of True North Communications, to retain duties for its account. Billings were estimated at $11 million.

title: Setting Up a Blockade Is Simple, but the Risks Are Many
description: The mechanics of imposing an oil embargo against Yugoslavia enforced by NATO warships plying the Adriatic Sea should be fairly straight-forward, military officials said today. The legal, political and diplomatic risks are far greater, particularly with Russia, which has furiously denounced the plan and thus raised the specter of clashes at sea.

title: Sports of The Times; Lemieux's Next Goal: Save Penguins
description: IN gold, black and white with the Penguins' logo, the ''Lemieux 66 1984-1997'' banner hangs high in the Civic Arena, while the franchise's future hangs in bankruptcy court.

title: Nets Follow Marbury's Lead But Lose Van Horn to Injury
description: Perhaps it was a glimpse into the future: Stephon Marbury running the offense to near perfection, Keith Van Horn scoring on jump shots and powerful drives, the other Nets contributing in various ways and, maybe, just maybe, Don Casey on the sideline planning the strategy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINGON, HELEN RUTH
description: KLINGON-Helen Ruth. On April 23, 1999. Dedicated teacher, devoted aunt of Dr. Gerald H. and Judith Klingon, Sylvia and Charles Eisen, M. Richard Klingon, and Martin & Doris Fisher. Graveside services will be held at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, NY, at 1PM Monday.

title: Media Talk; Coverage of Shootings Raises Questions
description: Many people watching CNN's live coverage of the high school shootings in Littleton, Colo., last week were shocked to hear the voice of a student still inside Columbine High School, who spoke by cell phone to the local television station, KUSA, and told where he was hiding.

title: S. Warner Pach, 79; Headed Gillette Unit
description: Stewart Warner Pach, who ran the Gillette Company's razor business in the 1960's, died April 14 at New England Baptist Hospital in Boston following a heart attack, according to his son, Peter B. Pach. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WALSEY, BETTY
description: WALSEY-Betty. Always in our hearts and minds. Never to be forgotten. Milton, Steven, Elliot and Joann

title: Valderrama by the Numbers Is Too Much for MetroStars
description: When Carlos Valderrama got the ball near the center of the field at Giants Stadium in the opening minute of today's game, he turned and, without a thought, found a teammate with a pass that caught him in stride. He repeated that exercise time after time, drawing more and more defenders, slipping the ball deftly to teammates as if it were a practice drill.

title: A Reluctant Muse Embraces His Task, and Everything Changes
description: The wholesale transformation of my writing life began, I suppose inevitably, with just a notion. I was beginning a new novel, a comic novel about horse racing, and I have to say I was inordinately pleased with it.

title: Equity and Convertible Offerings This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Lowe Executive Moves to Merkley
description: Alex Gellert, a longtime executive at Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is leaving to join Merkley Newman Harty in New York, in the latest in a recent series of top executive changes following the shift of DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s Mercedes-Benz account from Lowe to Merkley Newman in March.

title: Replacing Missing Links in the Evolutionary Chain
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNUR, BERNARD M., M.D.
description: SCHNUR-Bernard M., M.D. Of Princeton, NJ on April 25, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth, devoted father of Stephen, Ronald, Daniel and Susan. Dear brother of Seymour and Sidney. Cherished grandfather of Lincoln and Anna. Services Wednesday, 12 PM, at Adath Israel Congregation, Lawrenceville, NJ. Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, Trenton, NJ.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA FALLS 3 PERCENT. Cocoa prices reached a five-and-a-half-year low as supplies from West Africa overwhelmed weak demand from chocolate makers. In New York, cocoa for July delivery fell $32, to $994 a metric ton.

title: Internet Auctioneer Ebay to Add Land-Based Rival
description: In one of the first cases of an Internet company buying its traditional competitor, the electronic auction service Ebay Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Butterfield & Butterfield Auctioneers Corporation, San Francisco's largest auction house, for $260 million in stock.

title: Malaysia Shy About Cost as a Grand New City Arises
description: PUTRAJAYA, Malaysia  Quietly, or as quietly as hundreds of dump trucks, cranes and an army of construction workers can be, Malaysia is proceeding with one of Southeast Asia's biggest and most ambitious construction projects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTER, STANLEY D.
description: CANTER-Stanley D., 75. April 24, 1999. He was a man of great dignity and modesty, of elegant taste, intellectual clarity and profound generosity. His thoughtfulness, his kindness, his concern for those he loved and who loved him knew no bounds. His passions for music and painting enriched his life andours. The world has lost a rare breed of man.

title: UPN Hires Dweck For an Assignment
description: The UPN television network said yesterday that it had hired Dweck Inc. in New York, formerly Dweck & Campbell, to handle a creative assignment that could lead to Dweck's being named agency of record on the network's account, with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: MANPOWER INC., Milwaukee, the employment services company, promoted Jeffrey Joerres, 39, from senior vice president to president and chief executive, succeeding Mitchell Fromstein, 71, who is retiring the end of the month.

title: Politics of Color, Issue of Style
description: Nicknames are nothing new to the N.B.A. certain ones - from Wilt the Stilt to Air Jordan - are natural, even self-explanatory. And they stick. Others are more complicated. That is the case with White Chocolate, the nickname given to Jason Williams, the rookie guard for the Sacramento Kings. The nickname is meant to play on the fact that Williams, who is white, plays with an athleticism and flair that over the years have come to be associated with black players. The nickname has caused both delight and discomfort. Here is a sampling of each. By MIKE WISE

title: READ-RITE CUTTING 2,500 JOBS AS PRICES AND SALES SLUMP
description: The Read-Rite Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 2,500 workers, or 14 percent of its global work force, as the company, the No. 1 maker of recording heads used in computer disk drives, grapples with falling prices and sales. The company, which is based in Milpitas, Calif., said it expected to take a charge of $25 million to $30 million in the third quarter and that the cuts would save $10 million to $15 million a quarter once fully carried out. Makers of computer hard drives and other data-storage devices have been cutting their prices and using fewer of Read-Rite's heads in their devices. Read-Rite shares fell 31.25 cents, to close at $6 each, before the announcement.

title: Lipitor Maker Says Profit Rose by 36%
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said today that its first-quarter profit rose 36 percent as sales almost doubled for Lipitor, the nation's best-selling drug for reducing cholesterol.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLKEN, SELMA
description: OLKEN-Selma. We are saddened at the passing of Selma Olken. Dorothy and Buddy Martin and Family

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRABITZ, JULIUS
description: TRABITZ-Julius. April 27, 1901April 27, 1998. We miss your humor, energy, generosity, fierce independence and the pride you took in your children and grandchildren. We were so fortunate to have had you with us for so many years. Gloria, Tania, and families

title: Disney's Breach-of-Contract Trial Begins
description: The Walt Disney Company created a secret ''Project Snowball'' in 1991 to deprive Jeffrey Katzenberg, its former film studio chief, of a huge bonus if he left the company when his contract ended, a lawyer for Mr. Katzenberg said today.

title: F.D.A. Approves Fat-Blocking Anti-Obesity Drug
description: Until now, Americans looking for a pill to help them lose weight have had only one option: appetite suppressants. That changed today, when the Food and Drug Administration approved the first in a new class of anti-obesity drugs that work by blocking the body's absorption of dietary fat, as opposed to tricking the brain into ignoring hunger.

title: Uncovered Short Positions Are 3% Higher on Nasdaq
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market rose 3 percent in the most recent monthly period, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the market, said yesterday. The rise followed an increase of 0.93 percent in the previous month and five consecutive months of declines in short-interest positions.

title: An Empire of Leather Goods Still Driven by a Driving Shoe
description: Shoes and bags, not clothes, are the status symbols of the moment. Think Fendi. Think Gucci. Think Prada.

title: Can We Buy Safer Schools?
description: The tragedy last week in Littleton, Colo., has left some in Congress searching for a legislative response. But before they create new programs or increase financing for existing ones, lawmakers should look hard at the Safe and Drug-Free Schools Act, the primary Federal program that finances violence-prevention projects in the public schools.

title: G.E. of Britain in $4.5 Billion Acquisition
description: The General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain, accelerating the European rush into the data networking business, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Fore Systems Inc. for $4.5 billion in cash.

title: Sharing the Poetry Of Words and Movement
description: Company Appels

title: A Composer and His Hairdo Are Seldom Parted
description: Kitaro Town Hall

title: In Macedonia, Lost Children Wait Helplessly for Reunions
description: Each time a busload of refugees rumbles into the dusty refugee camp here, Murat Beqiri, 14, scans the faces peering from the windows. One day, when he heard his family name called over a bullhorn by an aid worker searching for a specific refugee, he scrambled expectantly out of his tent hoping that he might find his mother or father. Every day he tries to call home to Pristina, even though the line has been dead for days.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Well-Suited Group At Museum Lunch

title: A.& P. IS SHUTTING ITS LAST ATLANTA-AREA STORES
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said yesterday that it was selling or closing its 34 remaining A.& P. supermarkets in the Atlanta area in a final move to focus on regions where it had a stronger presence. The operator of more than 830 stores under A.& P., Waldbaum's, Food Emporium and other names, and which is controlled by Germany's Tengelmann Group, said it had agreements to sell 14 of the stores. The remaining 20 are to be shut or sold by the end of June. The company expects to take a charge of $9 million to $12 million this fiscal first quarter related to exiting Atlanta. A.& P. announced in December that it would close or sell underperforming stores, while opening 175 to 200 superstores, over three years.

title: AT&T Is Said to Join N.T.T. In a Japanese Phone Venture
description: Appearing to hedge its bets for a planned expansion into Japan, the AT&T Corporation intends to announce a partnership today with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, Japan's dominant telephone company, to manage the communications networks of big multinational companies, executives close to the deal said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOWALSKY, ROSE
description: KOWALSKY-Rose. The Board of Directors and Staff of F.E.G.S. note with great sorrow the passing of Rose Kowalsky mother of Zora Miller, Frank Kowalsky and the late Steven Kowalsky. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Zora and Alfred P. Miller, Executive Vice-President/CEO of F.E.G.S., Frank and Helen Kowalsky, grandchildren Julie, Greg, Amy, Sharon, Josh, Daniel, David and Jeannie and great grandchildren, Ashley and Sidney. Joseph Stein, Jr. President /Chair, F.E.G.S. Board of Directors

title: TREDEGAR TO BUY EXXON UNIT'S PLASTIC FILM BUSINESS
description: Tredegar Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the plastic film business of the Exxon Corporation's chemical unit. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Tredegar's film-products division, which had 1998 sales of $287 million, produces plastic films used in diapers, feminine-hygiene products and other goods. The company has its headquarters in Richmond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, DAVE (DAVEY G)
description: GOLDMAN-Dave (Davey G). Our ENY-Brownsville biographer/historian/raconteur, teller of tales at Mike's Barbershop has left us suddenly. Who can fill his shoes? We will all miss him. Condolences to Ramona. Victor and Judy Beja

title: Persistence Gets a Job For a Doctor, In the Balkans
description: Freed briefly from the rigors of the emergency room at Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx, Dr. Jennifer Walser was anticipating fishing around Lake Tahoe a couple of weekends ago, passing part of her flight there idly reading a magazine cover story about Kosovo.

title: Case Against Parents Would Be Hard to Prove
description: Attorney General Janet Reno and Gov. Bill Owens of Colorado have suggested that if the parents of the teen-age gunmen at Columbine High School had any hint of their plans and failed to act, the parents might be held criminally responsible for the young men's actions.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about an American decision to deploy armored combat units to Albania to back up helicopter gunships misidentified the vehicle shown. It was the type of armored car known as a Bradley Fighting Vehicle, not a tank.

title: F.A.A. Says System Can't Yet Handle Heavy Air Traffic
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that a new traffic control system for lower-altitude aircraft, already several months behind schedule, still could not run fast enough to serve in busy environments.

title: NATO Ground War: A Balkan Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Work's New Life and a Composer's Race Against Death
description: The program in which Colin Davis led the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening was unusually weighty. Before the intermission Mr. Davis conducted the United States premiere of ''The World's Ransoming,'' a work by James MacMillan based partly on the Roman Catholic liturgy for Maundy Thursday and, by implication, the events of the Last Supper. The rest of the concert at Avery Fisher Hall was devoted to Bruckner's Ninth Symphony, the work Bruckner knew would be his last and that he raced death to complete.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, JULES H.
description: SCHWARTZ-Jules H. Died peacefully at Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. too soon at the age of 72. He was the most beloved husband and friend of Sandy and the proud and loving father to Marcy, Andy and Barrie. He was also the most adoring Gramp to Michael, Evan, Yoni, Asher, Bradley, Ari and Sarah. He was owner and president of Highway Displays Inc. for 50 years and co-author of the book ''Support Group'', a book about coping with and treating prostate cancer. He served in the Occupation Force of the U.S. Army at the close of WW II. He was a member of Temple Beth El, Poughkeepsie, sat on the board of directors for Poughkeepsie South Rotary Club, was a member of the Jewish Community Center, Parents of North American Israelis, Jewish Veterans of Foreign Wars, the Man To Man Support Group, and was past president of the regional Israel Bonds and United Jewish appeals. Memorial donations may be made to Vassar Brothers Hospital, Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: Designated, Dominant, Delightful: It's Davis
description: The date for Yankee position players to report to spring training was still seven days away, but Chili Davis was already huffing and puffing at the team's minor league complex in Tampa, Fla. Davis ran sprints across the empty outfield on a sunny morning this past February, the sweat spilling off his 39-year-old body and the scene revealing so much about the designated hitter.

title: Politicians Court South Africa's Tribal Chiefs
description: Tony Leon, the head of South Africa's liberal Democratic Party, a man with the slight lock-jaw accent of those educated at this country's best English-style boarding schools, came here recently to pay homage to Chief Samuel Mpumulana Muhlava II and to make his pitch to the Tsonga people who live nearby.

title: Cabernet Sauvignon, the Healthy Toast?
description: Almost 30 years ago, researchers discovered that Europeans in Mediterranean countries were less likely to suffer from heart disease than people elsewhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, WALTER L.
description: WEINBERG-Walter L. In his 78th year, of Long Island, NY. Devoted husband of Janet (nee Newton). Beloved father of Matthew, Joshua and Asher. Loving brother of Shirley Kotcher and Joan Devine. Services today, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Ex-Priest Takes the Blasphemy Out of Evolution
description: Dr. Francisco J. Ayala, former Dominican priest, present day wine-grape grower, art collector, author of 12 books and 650 articles on genetics, and a professor of biological sciences and philosophy at the University of California at Irvine, is known in the science world as the Renaissance man of evolutionary biology.

title: Straphangers Prepare to Make Do With One Less Bridge to Cross
description: Trembling every time a subway train rumbled by it, the elevated platform at Marcy Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, provided a panoramic stage yesterday for Joshua Brown to vent his complaint about the latest transit snag, as he waited just across the Williamsburg Bridge from Manhattan.

title: Malaysia's Recovery
description: To the Editor:

title: A Matinee Romp Lures the Young With the Young
description: The season by Eliot Feld's Ballet Tech continued merrily along when Mr. Feld created a hoedown in ''Apple Pie,'' the new work presented on Sunday afternoon during a Kids Dance program at the Joyce Theater. Whereas Mr. Feld's main company performs at night, Kids Dance matinees feature students from Ballet Tech's school.

title: Woody Allen and Wife Have a Baby Daughter
description: Woody Allen and his wife, Soon-Yi Previn, have a new baby daughter, Bechet Dumaine Allen.

title: Bears in Winter
description: Q. Help settle a family dispute: do bears hibernate, or not?

title: God and/or Science
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Committee's Top Fund-Raiser Resigns
description: Efforts to attract Olympic sponsors, stalled by the Salt Lake City bribery scandal, grew more uncertain yesterday when John Krimsky resigned as chief marketing director and fund-raiser of the United States Olympic Committee to enter private business.

title: Now It's Bonilla on a Wounded Knee
description: There were more than a few double takes in the visiting clubhouse at Wrigley Field on Sunday afternoon when Mike Piazza walked out of the trainer's room wearing a protective brace on his left knee.

title: Host of BBC Crime Program And TV Evening News Is Slain
description: Jill Dando, a well-known BBC television news broadcaster, was found shot dead today outside the front door of her home in London.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Arizona's policy of ordering nonviolent drug offenders into treatment instead of jailing them misstated the cost. The state spends $16.06 a day for probation supervision for each nonviolent offender, but that figure does not include the cost of drug treatment. The article also misstated the year voters approved the policy. It was 1996, not 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWLEY, ROBERT KENNETH
description: LAWLEY-Robert Kenneth. Born in Belfast, Northern Ireland on 11 January, 1913, was educated at the Royal Belfast Academical Institution. In 1932 he entered the British Civil Service as officer of Customs and Excise. Shortly after the outbreak of war in 1939, he was promoted and transferred to the War Office and with the rank of Major served in the British army at HQ in North Africa; Middle East HQ in Egypt and the Supreme Allied HQ in Sri Lanka (then Ceylon) and Singapore. In 1947 on return to civilian status he was seconded to the UN in New York City by the British government in the capacity of Chief Registrar with the responsibility for the organization and control of the correspondence records of the United Nations Secretariat. From 1954 to 1973 his assignments as an International Civil Servant included, inter alia, Deputy Administrator of Administration in the Economic Commission for Latin America in Santiago, Chile; Chief Administrative Officer of the United Nations Military Observer Group in India and Pakistan in Srinagar, Kashmir and Rawalpindi, Pakistan; and Senior Executive Officer in the United Nations Technical Assistance Program involving the administration and implication of large scale development projects in less developed countries in Europe, Africa and the Middle and Far East. He retired from the United Nations in 1973. He is survived by his beloved wife Anna of 48 years. Children Elizabeth Lawley & Robert Lawley.

title: Knicks Are Making Themselves at Home on Road
description: It was like watching a structure built to sway, bend and give during an earthquake when Chris Dudley contorted his cinder-block frame in a most remarkable moment, in a most remarkable game for the Knicks.

title: Central Park Is Closed After Anonymous Caller Tells of a Bomb
description: The police closed the entrances to Central Park early last night after a bomb threat, and hundreds of officers were searching the entire 843 acres early this morning looking for an explosive device.

title: Love Goddess To Her Fans, Needing Love In Her Life
description: ''For years women have told me, My husband fell in love with you in 'Summer of '42,' '' said Jennifer O'Neill, who played the 22-year-old ''older'' woman who seduces the 15-year-old boy in the classic 1971 film. ''Now they say, 'My husband is in love with you and so is my son.' ''

title: God and/or Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Players Competing In America
description: When it comes to the balance of trade in international soccer, the United States has been a debtor nation. In men's soccer, it has a distinct taste for imports, quickly nationalizing players (David Regis and Roy Wegerle, to name two) so they can play as instant Americans for the national team.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHEVELL, ARLENE WALTERS
description: SHEVELL-Arlene Walters. On this day of memoriam and every day, you are always loved and in our thoughts. Jon, Nancy & Susan

title: After Tragedy, Counselors Can Help the Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Ground War: A Balkan Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, J. BUCKHOUT
description: JOHNSTON-J. Buckhout. The Philharmonic Symphony-Society of New York, Inc., deeply mourns the passing of J. Buckhout (''Bucky'') Johnston, a loyal friend of the Orchestra. Mr. Johnston served as a member of the Philharmonic's Board of Directors for many years, and was elected an Honorary Director of the Society in 1995, in recognition of his years of dedicated efforts on the Philharmonic's behalf. His caring and support will long continue to enrich our lives. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Emma, and their family. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Deborah Borda, Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WURF, SYLVIA
description: WURF-Sylvia. On April 26. Devoted mother of Linda Susan Wurf, sister of Phyllis Taub, sister-in-law of Melvin Taub and Ray Spinrad, aunt and great aunt. Service Wednesday, 12 Noon, The Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 St, NYC.

title: Identical Cousins, Fascinating As Ever
description: Be honest. Are you really expecting much from the ''Patty Duke Show'' reunion movie?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STALLINGS, ROGER W.
description: STALLINGS-Roger W., 87, died Sunday, April 25, 1999 at the Teresian House in Albany. He was born and raised in St. Louis, Missouri and was a longtime resident of Rye, NY. A graduate of St. Louis University with honors, he served as a Lieutenant in the Navy during World War II. He continued to serve in the United States Naval Reserve. After more than 40 years of service, he retired as a financial executive with Mobil Oil Corportation. He was also a member of the National Association of Accountants. Roger was a life member of the Masonic Temple of Webster Groves, MO. and a member of the Coveleigh Club in Rye. He enjoyed golf, badminton, tennis and racquetball. He is survived by his wife, Helen Stallings; his daughter Pamela R. Brondo and son-in-law Edwin T. Brondo of Albany; two grandchildren, Kristen L. Brondo of NYC and Edwin T. Brondo Jr. of Albany. He was predeceased by his brother Donald Stallings and his sister Lucille Stallings. Funeral services will be private. There will be no calling hours. Information: New Comer-Cannon Family Funeral Home 343 New Karner Road, Albany, New York.

title: A Square Peg Finally Finds A Role to Fill
description: Every time you looked, Marcus Camby was swooping in from the other side of the court. He rejected shots and dunked with malice. His teammates were pumping their fists and chest-bumping their waif of a forward into the first row. Sometimes he got knocked around, and sometimes he rebounded the ball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEESON, EVELYN (TALBOT)
description: LEESON-Evelyn (Talbot) April 26, 1999. Wife of the late Robert Leeson. In Providence, RI. A memorial service will be held in Grace Church, Westminster St., Provid ence, Sunday May 9, at 1:30 p.m.

title: Patricia Bowman, a Ballerina Who Linked Two Eras of Dance
description: Patricia Bowman, a founding member of American Ballet Theater, a ballerina of the Radio City Music Hall and the first American ballerina to win critical acclaim and wide popularity as a classical and a musical-theater dancer, died on March 18 in Las Vegas, Nev., her home since 1977. She was believed to be in her early to mid 90's.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a front-page article on Sunday about evidence of interbreeding between Neanderthals and modern humans omitted a passage at the continuation in some copies. The affected paragraph should have read:

title: Brodeur Is Struggling to Save the Devils
description: The Devils, having fallen behind the underdog Penguins, two games to one, in their opening-round series, have had only a handful of players performing at a level acceptable for playoff success.

title: Jailed Rapist Is Awarded $900,000 Over Beating From Inmates
description: A Federal jury yesterday awarded $900,000 in damages to a convicted rapist who was beaten by fellow inmates at the Nassau County jail, saying jail officials showed ''deliberate indifference'' to the safety of prisoners accused of sex crimes.

title: Fitch Agency Raises Malaysia's Credit Rating
description: Malaysia's sovereign credit rating was raised to investment grade yesterday by Fitch IBCA Inc. The action may accelerate the nation's plans to sell $2 billion in bonds to recapitalize its banks and expand its economy. Fitch, a New York-based credit rating company, raised the rating two notches, to BBB-, the lowest investment grade, from BB, just below investment grade. It said Malaysia's widening current account surplus had bolstered foreign reserves.

title: Kosovo Strategies
description: Like President Kennedy's naval quarantine of Cuba during the 1962 missile crisis, NATO's planned embargo on oil shipments to Serbia is not called a blockade by diplomats, for fear that term of war could widen the conflict. But the intent is clear -- use a naval armada in the Adriatic Sea to deny Slobodan Milosevic's forces the fuel they need to operate in Kosovo. If executed with a healthy regard for Russian sensibilities, it can sap Serbian strength and speed the way to a political settlement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, HYMAN
description: SCHNEIDER - Hyman. Beloved brother of the late Max, Al, Isaac and Anne. Loving uncle of Irma De Bruyn, Rae Birnbaum and Dr. Joseph Schneider. Graveside services Wednesday, 10:30 A.M., at Wellwood Cemetery. For further information, call Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel 212-477-6334.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGER, VICTOR
description: SAGER-Victor. Beloved husband of the late Mildred (nee Cohen). Loving and dearest father of Linda, Andrew, Richard, Wendy, Lawri and Jinny. Devoted and loving brother of Edna and Irving, and the late Harriet, Norma and Stephen. Adoring grandfather, great-grandfather, uncle and great-uncle. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., 11:30 AM, Tuesday, April 27.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMANO, FRANCIS J., M.D.
description: ROMANO-Francis J., M.D. On April 25, 1999. Family practitioner for over 50 years in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Beloved husband of the late Bertha Nancy Romano (nee Miller). Loving father of Mary Anne Burlinson, Frances Flanagan, Robert M., Bernadette, Rose Mary and Richard. Proud grandfather of Robert F. X. and Katrien, Kate & Andrew Burlinson, Tolley & Dan Pierson, Elizabeth Casparis, Mark Gatlin and Erin Flanagan, Katherine, Amy & Michael Romano, Grace and Mollie Handley and Alexa Romano. Great grandfather of Dylan Gatlin. Visiting Tuesday, 7-9 PM, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, 10 AM, St. Anselms Church. Family requests in lieu of flowers donations to Manhattan College, Director of Development, Riverdale, N.Y. 10471 in memory of Dr. Francis J. Romano, ''Class of 1935''.

title: God and/or Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARE, ANNE ''NANCY''
description: O'HARE-Anne ''Nancy'', 86. Of Newburgh passed away April 24, 1999. She was the wife of Stephen P. O'Hare. She is survived by her Husband Stephen, sons William of LaGrangeville, Stephen P. Jr. of Granada Hills, CA., Fintan O'Hare of White Plains, Rev. Daniel O'Hare of Maybrook, Gerard O'Hare of Tawaco, New Jersey. Daughter Sister M. Anthony OP of Cleveland, Ohio, brother: John O'Connor of Ireland, sisters: Sister M. Bernadette SM of England, and Delia O'Connor of Ireland, 22 grand-children, 31 great grandchildren. Visitation will be Tuesday April 27, from 2-4, 7-9 P.M. at Coloni Funeral Home, New Windsor. Mass will be 11:00 A.M. Monday at St. Patricks Church, Newburgh. Burial at St. Peters Cemetery.

title: After Tragedy, Counselors Can Help the Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: Airbus, With $4 Billion Orders, to Build A318
description: Airbus Industrie officially announced today that it would build the A318, a 107-seat passenger jet that is considered a potential threat to the Boeing Company's best-selling 737.

title: Brazil Arrests Ex-Chief of Central Bank
description: A former president of Brazil's central bank, Francisco Lopes, was arrested today after he refused to sign an affidavit backing his testimony disputing accusations of income tax evasion and favoritism.

title: NATO Ground War: A Balkan Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: French Deal Creates Global Billboard Leader
description: Decaux S.A., a French advertising company, agreed yesterday to buy the Avenir billboard unit of Vivendi S.A. for six billion francs ($972 million) in cash and assumed debt, overtaking Clear Channel Communications Inc. as the world's biggest outdoor advertising company. The family-owned Decaux, which also makes outdoor toilets and bus shelters, will assume debt of 250 million francs, while Vivendi will post a capital gain of 2 billion francs. Avenir, founded in 1880, is France's oldest poster advertising company.

title: Notoriety Now for Movement's Leader
description: On Sunday, followers of Buddhist Law staged the largest protest in Beijing since the Tiananmen Square movement 10 years ago, but the New York-based spiritual leader who developed the doctrine rarely shows his face.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERGER, LEON J.
description: WEINBERGER-Leon J. Father of TV writer/producer ED. Weinberger, passed away April 25 in Los Angeles at the age of 100. He is also survived by his beloved wife Helen of 66 years, daughter-in-law Carlene and two grandchildren, Jack and Sam. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Compressed Data column of Business Day yesterday about the computer virus known as CIH 1.2 misstated the time the virus was expected to become active. It was was midnight Sunday, not midnight yesterday.

title: Clinton's New Gun Proposals Include Charging Parents of Children Who Commit Gun Crimes
description: President Clinton plans to announce a package of gun-control proposals on Tuesday, including a measure to halt imports of clips that allow assault weapons to fire more than 10 shots without reloading and another to hold parents responsible when their children commit crimes with guns.

title: An Ill-Timed N.R.A. Meeting
description: After the Littleton school shootings, the National Rifle Association said it would shorten its annual meeting in Denver next weekend from three days to one, and cancel exhibits by gun dealers and manufacturers. The N.R.A. should listen to Denver's Mayor and cancel the conference altogether.

title: After Tragedy, Counselors Can Help the Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: Watson May Earn New First as A's Owner
description: Bob Watson is proud of his accomplishments in baseball, but he has grown weary of one aspect. ''I would like to get rid of the distinction of being first,'' he said. ''I am really tired of being the first of anything in baseball -- first assistant general manager, first general manager, first African American to win a World Series.''

title: Starvation Intrudes in a Bid to Save the Lynx
description: An ambitious effort to reintroduce the elusive lynx into southwestern Colorado has encountered widespread criticism from animal rights advocates and even many of the plan's proponents since the death by starvation of 4 of the 13 cats released in February and March and the emergency recapture of an emaciated fifth.

title: From Alpha Dog to Wound-Licking in Iraq
description: PBS is a tad tardy in getting around to ''Spying on Saddam,'' considering that Scott Ritter, that disaffected former United Nations inspector, has been telling his story in print, on television and to Congress for many a month. Tonight's account, produced by the BBC in cooperation with ''Frontline,'' nonetheless puts the quarrels involving the United Nations, the State Department, the Central Intelligence Agency, Israel and other players into perspective, albeit a sometimes fuzzy one, and may help viewers get a sense of what went wrong.

title: Verniero Rejects Blame in Profiling Issue
description: Attorney General Peter G. Verniero insisted to a Senate committee today that he had responded appropriately to racial profiling allegations against the New Jersey State Police. He testified that it would be unfair to hold him personally responsible for the hundreds of drivers who were subjected to discrimination during the two years that his office delayed starting an investigation.

title: A Liberal Threatens Milosevic With Street Protests
description: A Deputy Prime Minister of Yugoslavia, Vuk Draskovic, pledged tonight to lead street protests against President Slobodan Milosevic if military control over the Studio B television station here was not immediately lifted.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR SLIPS. The dollar traded in narrow ranges as top finance officials from around the world shuttled among meetings in Washington. In New York, the dollar settled at 119.26 yen, down from 119.41 on Friday.

title: Perseverance Paid Off Big For Elway
description: AS quarterback for the Denver Broncos for the last 16 years, John Elway has lost two miles and maybe three city blocks during football games, or 3,780 yards. This is a National Football League record for going backward.

title: Clinton Tells Palestinians To Go Slow on Statehood
description: On the eve of a meeting of the Palestinian policy-setting body in Gaza, President Clinton today warned the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, against unilaterally declaring Palestinian statehood but edged toward support for eventual independence for the Palestinian people.

title: German Postal Giant Expands in Scandinavia
description: Deutsche Post A.G., Europe's largest provider of postal services, said yesterday that its Danzas freight unit would expand in Scandinavia by acquiring ASG A.B. for 374 million euros ($396.8 million). ASG is a leading provider of air-freight services in the region and also has road-transport, ocean-freight and special-services operations.

title: Ernst to Pay $185 Million To Settle Suit
description: Ernst & Young L.L.P., the world's fourth-largest accounting firm, agreed today to pay $185 million to settle a lawsuit concerning advice it gave Merry-Go-Round Enterprises during its bankruptcy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPF, SOLOMON WOLFE
description: KOPF-Solomon Wolfe. Age 82, on April 21, 1999. Formerly of Jamaica Estates, NY. Recently of Rockville, MD. Devoted husband, father and grandfather. He leaves behind his beloved wife, Sydell, dedicated daughters and sons-in-law, Randi Kopf Rothenberg, Dr. Russell Rothenberg, Lisa Kopf Krizman and Robert Krizman, adoring grandsons, Mitchell, Jeffrey. Mr. Kopf was a WWII veteran, noted philanthropist in Jewish, Israeli and medical charities; charter member of The National Holocaust Museum, Ellis Island Foundation, WWII Veteran Memorial; founder Brighton Candy and Tobacco, Brooklyn, NY; former member of Fresh Meadows Country Club, NY and recently of Norbeck Country Club. Interment King David Cemetery, Thursday, April 22, 1999.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Rose Payne, 89, Scientist Who Aided Transplants
description: Dr. Rose Payne, whose research into tissue compatibility at Stanford University over more than three decades helped advance the field of organ transplants, died on April 18 at Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in Santa Clara, Calif. She was 89 and had been living in Cupertino, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, ARTHUR
description: HABER-Arthur. On April 25, 1999 of ALS in Sarasota, Fla. (late of Englewood, NJ). Dearest husband of Aileen. Loving father of Kathryn, Joy Haber Lavietes and sonin-law David Lavietes. Beloved grandfather of Madelyn Jennie. Memorial donations may be made to ALS Foundation (Los Angeles) or Hospice of Southwest Florida.

title: Illinois Town Hopes to Exile Its Gang Members to Anywhere Else, U.S.A.
description: This is the place that welcomed Al Capone, along with his bootlegging, betting parlors and bordellos, after Chicago gave him the boot.

title: Four British Players Excel In Works by Their Countrymen
description: Vellinger Quartet

title: Op-Art
VITAL SIGNS: PREVENTION; A Plan to Keep Drivers Free of Seizures
description: Seizure disorders can be controlled by medication, but not for all patients and not always perfectly. That makes driving a gamble, which is why most states require people with epilepsy to be seizure-free for a specified length of time before they get behind the wheel.

title: Pay Issue Snarls City Charter School Talks
description: A negotiating session over converting 11 existing public schools to charter schools was canceled yesterday after discussions among the teachers' union, school administrators and city officials broke down when the city said the newly independent schools might increase teacher salaries.

title: Chronic Heartburn, an Ominous Warning
description: We have all had heartburn now and then, if at no other time, then after consuming a highly acidic or spicy food or when bending over or exercising vigorously soon after eating a full meal. And in most cases, if any treatment was needed, an over-the-counter antacid took care of the temporary discomfort.

title: New York's Vital Patches of Green
description: To the Editor:

title: Redskins Are Sold For $800 Million
description: Daniel Snyder, a partner in Howard Milstein's unsuccessful bid to acquire the Washington Redskins, agreed yesterday to buy the football team for $800 million from the estate of the late owner, Jack Kent Cooke.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Built-in Sunblock

title: Japan's Tale of Two Pills: Viagra and Birth Control
description: Japan normally takes many years, even decades, to approve foreign medications. But last year the middle-aged men who run the Ministry of Health and Welfare decided to rush the process for an American drug that they apparently deemed so critical that Japan could not wait another moment.

title: 3 Boys to Face Charges Of Murder After Beating
description: Three teen-agers arrested on Friday and accused of severely beating a 17-year-old boy in Queens will face murder charges now that the youth has died, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Power Plants Lure Investors, And Critics
description: For the first time in more than two decades, companies are asking permission to build large power plants in New York City and the Hudson River Valley, all spurred by the deregulation of the electric power industry.

title: Safir Denies Retaliation in Officer's Firing
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday angrily denied a New York City police officer's allegation that she was dismissed for testifying critically about the department before the City Council. The Commissioner said that he had authorized the officer's dismissal a full week before the Council hearing.

title: Fossils of Armored Tanklike Dinosaurs Found in Utah
description: A site in Utah has yielded a trove of fossils of some of the biggest armored dinosaurs ever found, paleontologists announced yesterday, and they said the discoveries might compel scientists to revise the chronology of dinosaur migrations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLITZ, MURRAY
description: BLITZ-Murray. On April 26, 1999 in his 96th year. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Dear father of Lenore Lerner and Dr. Marvin Blitz. Loving grandfather to Jill, Douglas, Jonathan, Erica, Kenneth and Caroline and great grandfather to Matthew, Talia and Nicole. Services 9 am Wednesday at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Latter-Day Warbucks, Helping Children
description: WHEN a 59-year-old bachelor who is also a Wall Street titan puts up $50 million of his own to help 40,000 poor children attend private school, it seems only reasonable to ask, Why is he doing this?

title: The Schools in New York City; Be Fair About Funding
description: Whatever happens with vouchers and governance, New York City's schools most urgently need to gain their fair share of funding from the state. The annual battle over state school spending is aggravated this year by Governor Pataki's reneging on an earlier commitment, made when he was running for re-election, to increase aid for preschool and reading programs. The city and other large urban school districts were counting on the money to pay for teachers, remedial programs and new classrooms. Now those plans are in jeopardy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUGHLIN, WILLIAM
description: COUGHLIN-William. The Officers and Members of the Bronx Realty Advisory Board mourn the passing of a cherished Board Member. Bill will be greatly missed and remembered with respect and affection. Heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Margaret, and his daughters, Elizabeth and Meghan. Michael Laub, President Ruben Klein, Chairman

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BMC SOFTWARE INC., Houston, a corporate software maker, said it would realign the company into five business units based on customer and market segments as part of a bid to consolidate recent acquisitions.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about the NATO summit meeting in Washington misidentified the building where delegates occupied a pentagon-shaped table. It was the Mellon Auditorium, not the Pentagon.

title: A Plan by Jesse Jackson to Free Soldiers Is Stalled
description: A combination of canceled flights, logistical problems and antagonism from Administration officials stalled the plans of religious leaders to travel to Belgrade today to seek the release of three captive American servicemen.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Disgruntled Shareholders Unite; Using Web to Try to Get a Piece of a Bankrupt Company
description: It's a long way from cyberspace to Wilmington, Del.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about Audrey Hepburn's enduring influence on style and fashion misstated the age at which she won an Academy Award as best actress for her role in ''Roman Holiday.'' She was 24, not 21.

title: God and/or Science
description: To the Editor:
