title: Arts in America: Sustenance for the Soul And Something for the Gut; New Orleans Jazz Festival Struts Into Its 30th Year
description: In a tradition that is older than jazz, a parade was on the march on Sunday afternoon. Members of the Revolution Social Aid and Pleasure Club swaggered in fluorescent-green suits, carrying big feather crests emblazoned with peace signs, crowns and the letter R. Joining them were the Untouchables, strutting in purple and gold. The beat came from the New Birth Brass Band, huffed out of a battered sousaphone and tapped on cymbals with wire loops bent from coat hangers. As in any New Orleans parade there was also a second line: spectators and stragglers who turned into dancers as the music grabbed them.

title: Reinvigorated by Youth, a Pirate Plies Harmonic Seas
description: Every time one hears Dukas's three-act opera ''Ariane et Barbe-Bleue,'' one thinks how gloomy-gorgeous it is, and how long. Sunday afternoon's concert performance at Avery Fisher Hall, part of Leon Botstein's continuing exploration of the late Romantics with the American Symphony Orchestra, not only reconfirmed these impressions but did so with clarity and force.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Roman L. Hruska Dies at 94; Leading Senate Conservative
description: Roman L. Hruska, who served 22 years as a conservative Republican senator from Nebraska, died on Sunday at Clarkson Hospital in Omaha. He was 94 and had wielded considerable influence on the Judiciary Committee.

title: His Game, and Name, Create Stir; Jason (White Chocolate) Williams Sets Off Debate on Stereotypes
description: It began innocuously enough, with a media relations assistant asking a rookie point guard if he had a nickname yet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAROM, DIANA MERSON
description: MAROM - Diana Merson. 1919-1999, of NYC, died on April 25. Beloved mother of son Peter, widow of Herman, and loving sister of Sarah and Bernice. Your family and friends celebrate your life, your spirit, and passion for living.

title: After Tragedy, Counselors Can Help the Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: Tagliabue Fakes Out the Patriots
description: From November through last week, the National Football League did nothing publicly to upset the proposition that the New England Patriots would move from the team's creaky old home in Foxboro, Mass., to a $375 million stadium in Hartford that would be fully subsidized by Connecticut taxpayers.

title: Health Care Systems in U.S. Called Separate and Unequal
description: Middle-income blacks, Hispanics and whites have significantly different attitudes toward health care, a new national survey confirms with a range of new statistics. This research raises concern among minority leaders that two separate and unequal systems of care have developed in the United States.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I mean, I wouldn't have been surprised if people had wanted to spit on me or yell at me. But that hasn't ever happened. It has been our blessing that this community has let us go on.''

title: Diary of a High School Gunman Reveals a Plan to Kill Hundreds
description: As he planned the assault on Columbine High School here, Eric Harris envisioned killing as many as 500 students and going on to attack neighboring homes and even hijack a jet and crash it in New York City, police investigators said today after reviewing a diary that he had kept for more than a year.

title: First Union Agrees to Buy Everen in $1.1 Billion Deal
description: The First Union Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest bank, agreed today to buy the Everen Capital Corporation for $1.1 billion in stock, its second acquisition of a securities firm in a little more than a year.

title: NATO Ground War: A Balkan Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Proposal For Cutoff Inflates Oil Prices
description: NATO's planned oil embargo of Yugoslavia has already created a black market in which Serb-backed buyers pay up to a 50 percent premium for gasoline and other refined products, European petroleum traders and other sources said yesterday.

title: A Concert On the Web For Poverty
description: The organizers of two benefit-concert extravaganzas, ''Live Aid'' and ''Farm Aid,'' are turning to the Internet for their latest fund-raising effort: three simultaneous benefits to combat world poverty that are to be broadcast live over the World Wide Web.

title: A Winter of the Soul Brings a Chill to Spring
description: Matthias Goerne, baritone, and Alfred Brendel, pianist

title: Bozell Worldwide Is Reorganizing
description: Bozell Worldwide in New York, part of True North Communications, is reorganizing itself and forming an office of the chairman. The change comes shortly after Leo-Arthur Kelmenson, chairman, assumed the duties of chief executive from David Bell, now chairman and chief executive at parent True North.

title: Three Ring Goes Where Fillies Fear to Run
description: With only two days left before the draw for the Kentucky Derby, only one filly on the backstretch at Churchill Downs remained an announced candidate today to challenge the 19 best 3-year-olds in America in a race that only three fillies have won in 124 years.

title: Plea for a Choice On Vaccinations
description: Lyla Belkin of Manhattan got her first hepatitis B shot last August, when she was 6 days old. A month later, she got a second shot. Early the next morning, Lorna Belkin found her infant daughter pale and cold.

title: New York's Vital Patches of Green
description: To the Editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: REMEDIES; For Broken Teeth, It's Low-Fat Milk
description: Answer: Pour a glass of milk and see me right away.

title: AZTEC TECHNOLOGY HIRES FIRM TO EXPLORE OPTIONS
description: Aztec Technology Partners Inc., which was spun off from the U.S. Office Products Company last year, said yesterday that it had hired the investment banking firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to help it explore strategic options. Aztec, a computer-services company based in Boston, said it was considering a possible recapitalization, privatization or merger. The company also said its chief financial officer, Douglas Johnson, had resigned to join an Internet software company. The company is conducting a search for a replacement.

title: Border War Over the Peace Bridge
description: Since the days of Prohibition, the Peace Bridge has been the infrastructural equivalent of a warm handshake between Canada and the United States: an economic, recreational and cultural lifeline for people on both sides of the Niagara River.

title: 2 Centuries Later, Good News for Quake Area, Maybe
description: Midwesterners who worry about earthquakes got some good news last week: their risk of catastrophe may have been vastly overstated.

title: Big Dutch Candy Maker In Finnish Acquisition
description: CSM N.V., the leading candy maker in the Netherlands, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Leaf confectionery unit of Finland's largest food-packaging and candy company, Huhtamaeki Oy. The terms are 390 million euros ($413 million) in cash. The purchase of Leaf, which has annual sales of about 420 million euros and operating profit of 30 million euros, will strengthen CSM's position as the leading candy supplier in Scandinavia and the Netherlands.

title: Patterns
description: Style From Vintage Fabrics

title: Metro Business; Tool Maker Is Acquired
description: Goldman Industrial Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Bridgeport Machines Inc. for $10 a share, or $56 million. Bridgeport Machines, which makes cutting machine tools, said that the deal required the approval of its shareholders, 40 percent of whom had agreed to vote in favor of the deal. Bridgeport Machines, based in Bridgeport, Conn., had 1998 revenues of $213.7 million. Goldman Industrial, based in Boston, is a privately held provider of metalworking machinery. Shares of Bridgeport Machines soared 54 percent, gaining $3.2188 each, to $9.1875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Van Horn Out for Rest of Season
description: While the Nets practiced yesterday at the Champion Center in East Rutherford, N.J., Keith Van Horn was at the office of Dr. Charles Melone, learning that he had become the latest in a long line of Nets to see the season end prematurely.

title: NATO Ground War: A Balkan Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Rejects Inmate's Plea To Hear Case Of Jail Murder
description: A State Court of Appeals judge has rejected a request to hear an appeal by an illegal Chinese immigrant who was convicted of killing a fellow inmate in an upstate prison in 1986.

title: India Dissolves Parliament; Calls 3d Election in 3 Years
description: After the collapse of the Government led by Hindu nationalists and the failure of opposition parties to put together a majority, President K. R. Narayanan dissolved the lower house of Parliament tonight to make way for India's third general election in three years.

title: Devils Could Go Without A Go-To Guy
description: How should hockey fans react when their team loses two of its first three games to a presumably inferior opponent in a four-of-seven-game playoff series? The Devils' supporters have had plenty of experience in recent seasons with premature elimination from the Stanley Cup tournament. With their favored Devils trailing the Penguins by two games to one, some might wonder if New Jersey lacks a Mark Messier/Steve Yzerman type, a leader around whom to rally. If so, is this because the franchise plays down individual stardom in favor of a group personality?

title: Full Throttle for Mahler's Grand Ruminations
description: However vehemently critics and opera fans may debate production values and casting decisions at the Metropolitan Opera, it is generally agreed that James Levine has turned the company's orchestra into a superb instrument that bears comparison with the world's great symphonic ensembles. Now it lives a double life, working in the pit but also stepping out for its own series at Carnegie Hall and annual tours. It is ending its Carnegie season with two performances in close succession. The first was on Sunday afternoon, and the second is next Sunday.

title: Portadown Journal; Front Line in Ulster Conflict Is Measured by Feet
description: Wars often turn on who controls the high ground, and in Northern Ireland the battle between the province's two major religious groups has centered in recent troubled years on a rise on the outskirts of Portadown known as Drumcree.

title: God and/or Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Aid to Poor Could Miss Targets And Stall, World Bank Reports
description: A generation of helping the poor is in danger of stalling, the World Bank warned today.

title: 2 Sentenced to Prison For Immigrant Smuggling
description: Eleven months after 23 Chinese men washed ashore in Bay Head in a wayward attempt at immigrant smuggling, the captain and mechanic of a ship that carried the men to New Jersey received Federal prison terms yesterday.

title: Town in Texas Discusses Own School Crisis
description: Three days after four eighth graders were charged with plotting to blow up Danforth Junior High School here, more than 400 teachers, parents and students crowded into the school cafeteria tonight to ask law-enforcement officials about the case.

title: The Schools in New York City; Abolish the Board
description: Education issues have now risen to the top of the agenda for some of New York's most powerful and ambitious politicians, offering an opportunity both to strengthen New York City's school system and reform it for the future. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, Gov. George Pataki and City Council Speaker Peter Vallone have all decided that public schools, especially in the city, are in a state of emergency.

title: In Beijing: A Roar of Silent Protesters
description: The most amazing thing about the well-organized protest that occurred here on Sunday was the ease with which more than 10,000 adherents of a spiritual movement materialized at the door of China's leadership and then vanished.

title: Chile General Sees Pinochet in Private
description: Gen. Ricardo Izurieta, the commander in chief of the army and an avid bridge player, has cautiously kept his cards close to his chest since October, when Gen. Augusto Pinochet was arrested in London on a Spanish warrant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITELMAN, IDA
description: MITELMAN-Ida. We mourn the passing of the mother of our esteemed member, Rabbi Meir Mitelman and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Technology Issues Push Nasdaq and S.& P. to Records
description: Rising technology shares pushed the Nasdaq and the S.& P. 500 to records yesterday, but the activity was much more sedate compared with last week's hectic pace.

title: 'Role Model' With a Past Clouds Medical Triumph
description: In the seven months since an Australian man received a new hand and forearm in France, he has defied medical dogma. His body has not rejected the graft, and nerves are regenerating faster than his doctors expected. Yet the relationship of the transplant pioneer, Clint Hallam, 48, and the doctors is strained over his lack of further progress.

title: MAYOR'S REMARKS ON SCHOOL SYSTEM ASSAILED BY CREW
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew accused Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday of dismissing the city's school system and everyone in it ''as no good and beyond redemption,'' sharply escalating the recent series of disagreements between the two men and raising questions anew about whether the Chancellor intends to remain in New York.

title: Take My Mother-in-Law, Now
description: ''Exactly Like You'' appears to have been plucked from a time capsule buried in the year 1962, when the entertainment world was still safe for mother-in-law jokes.

title: As Jonesboro Shooting Fades, A Killer's Family Still Lives It
description: When Gretchen Woodard heard about the two boys in Colorado who had shot 12 classmates and a teacher to death, some of her reactions were those of everyone else. She thought: ''Where were these boys' parents? How could they not have known these kids were building bombs in their garage? Why didn't they pay attention to the trench coats and other warning signs of trouble?''

title: Doctors Fighting Backlash Over Vaccines
description: An overload of conflicting and often alarmist information about vaccinations is leading some medical experts into a new field of research: not the effectiveness and safety of vaccines, which they consider proven, but the public's questions, doubts and fears.

title: Owner of Crack House Is Given Probation
description: After forfeiting his family's Lakewood rooming house to the authorities in October, a Toms River man was sentenced yesterday to two years' probation for failing to report a drug deal he had seen there.

title: Doctors Urge Screening For Disorder
description: The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists is now recommending that Jews of Central and Eastern European descent be offered screening to determine whether they are carriers of Canavan disease, an inherited neurological disorder that causes most children with the disease to die before age 10.

title: TELESCAN TO BUY INVESTOOLS IN $49.2 MILLION STOCK DEAL
description: Telescan Inc., an on-line financial-information company, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Investools Inc. for $49.2 million in stock to increase its Internet investment advisory business. Telescan will pay about 2.4 million shares for Investools, based in Redwood City, Calif., and which has annual revenue of about $3 million. Investools provides investment newsletters and advice to subscribers via the Internet. Telescan, with 1998 revenue of $15.5 million, develops and operates Internet sites and on-line networks for the financial, publishing and entertainment industries.

title: Accounts
description: * Radio Shack, Fort Worth, a unit of Tandy Corp., to Dieste & Partners, Dallas, to handle its account for campaigns aimed at Hispanic consumers. The account had been at Bravo Group, San Francisco, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Applying Sunscreen to a Playground
description: In an effort to protect children from damaging ultraviolet rays, three agencies plan to build what they describe as the nation's first intentionally sun-safe playground.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, CHAJA
description: LIEBERMAN-Chaja. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved sister of its esteemed member, Mrs. Mala Holmes, and expresses heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi, David Yagoda, Chairman, Dr. William Schwartz, President

title: St. John's Is Leaving The Conference
description: St. John's University, a charter member of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference Football League, will leave the conference on June 1 and play the 1999 season as a Division 1-AA independent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, HENRY
description: SMITH-Henry. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopaedic Institute mourns the passing of Henry Smith, beloved father of Gordon Smith and our distinguished Trustee, Norma Smith. Henry Smith will always be remembered as a committed friend of HJD and through the support of the Smith Family, The Theodora & Henry Smith Admissions Suite stands as a memorial to his and his dear wife's memory. We grieve his passing and extend our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. William A. Perlmuth Chairman of the Board John N. Kastanis, FACHE President & Chief Executive Officer Victor H. Frankel, MD President Emeritus Joseph D. Zuckerman, MD Surgeon-in-Chief

title: Brazil Completes a Crucial Bond Issue
description: Brazil wound up its first bond issue yesterday since the devaluation of its currency in January, swapping $1 billion in new five-year notes for existing Brazilian Brady bonds.

title: 89, and 2,000 Miles to Go for 'Democracy'
description: The morning sun had barely crested the low, tawny mountains to the east of this city when Doris Haddock hit the road.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISOLA, MARY (NEE MCCABE)
description: ISOLA-Mary (nee McCabe). Beloved wife of the late John, loving mother of Charles. Reposing Vanella Funeral Chapel, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Wednesday, 9:30 AM, St Joseph's Church, 6th Ave and Washington Pl, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Convent of Mercy, 273 Willoughby Ave, Bklyn NY 11205.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: PRISONERS

title: Private Spy In Space To Rival Military's
description: If all goes well today, years of planning, delay and debate will culminate in the launching of the world's most powerful civilian spacecraft for observing the Earth and its human dramas, inaugurating the first real rival to military spies in the sky.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Supreme Court to Consider F.D.A. Rules on Tobacco

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, LEO
description: GOLDMAN-Leo. On April 25th after a short illness. Devoted father of Debbie Plant and Amy London. Dear father-in-law of Frank Plant and Joel London. Beloved Papa of Matthew and Marissa Plant, Elizabeth and Stephanie London. Cherished brother of Frieda Lefkowitz. He was a professor of Counseling Psychology and had been affiliated with a number of universities, including CUNY Graduate Center. He served as Editor of the Personnel and Guidance Journal from 1969 to 1975, and as President of the APA Division of Counseling Psychology from 1989 to 1990. In recent years he continued to teach, travelled extensively, performed volunteer work and was an irreplaceable presence in his grandchildren's lives. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Contributions in his memory to The Natural Resources Defense Council, 40 West 20th Street, New York, NY 10011, would be greatly appreciated. He will be deeply missed by many.

title: Some highs and lows of the annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
description: HERE is a look at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the 1999 management conference and annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, held last week in Amelia Island, Fla.:

title: Republicans May Add Billions to Balkans Bill
description: Republicans are preparing to add $5 billion or more in Pentagon programs to President Clinton's emergency request for $6 billion in spending on the Balkans, key members of Congress said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHU, GRACE
description: CHU-Grace. The Trustees and staff of China Institute are saddened by the death of Grace Chu, first instructor of Chinese cooking at China Institute and a founding member of China Institute Women's Association. We are grateful for her many contributions during her long association with China Institute.

title: Ukraine's Balancing Act
description: The noise about a so-called Slavic Brotherhood made up of Russia, Belarus and Yugoslavia is not likely to have much practical influence in stopping NATO's air strikes in the Balkans. Yet the West cannot afford to play down the threat such an alliance poses in one crucial quarter: the battle for the support of Ukraine.

title: Safety Accord in West Side Apartment Fire
description: The tenant association and the landlord of an Upper West Side apartment building where four people died in a fast-spreading fire last December have reached an agreement on what may turn out to be extensive safety improvements in the high-rise building. But litigation is continuing in which the tenants are seeking $20 million in damages.

title: As More Aircraft Are Sent, Reserve Call-Up Is Imminent
description: The Pentagon will begin calling up reservists as early as Tuesday, a top official said today, and will immediately send in 30 refueling aircraft to support the air campaign.

title: Frank Pasquerilla, 72, Builder and Benefactor
description: Frank J. Pasquerilla, 72, a builder and philanthropist who started as a state highway clerk and became one of the richest men in Pennsylvania, died last Wednesday in a Johnstown, Pa., hospital. He made a fortune in shopping malls, department stores and hotels and gave away millions to support schools, churches and the performing arts, from western Pennsylvania to the Vatican.

title: Metro Business; St. Martin's Acquires Golden Books Unit
description: St. Martin's Press Inc. has acquired the adult publishing unit of Golden Books Family Entertainment Inc., a children's book publisher struggling to emerge from its financial troubles.

title: U.S. Tells Global Partners That It Can't Be Sole Engine of Growth
description: The United States told Germany and Japan today that the world economy could not run for long on only one engine: an American economy that keeps expanding as Europe slows and Tokyo prays that a seven-year recession is ending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, MEYER
description: WALLACH-Meyer. On April 23, 1999 in his 95 year. Loving husband of the late Pauline Wallach, devoted father of Lorraine and Don Carren and Anita Dimendberg. Dear grandfather of Rachel Carren Young, Elizabeth Carren Amidon, Deborah November and Edward Dimendberg and greatgrandfather of Emily and Benjamin Young and Adam and Pauline November. A gentleman to all fortunate enough to have known him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EREN, SUHA S.
description: EREN-Suha S. On April 23, 1999. Beloved husband of Emine. Father of Selcuk and Sinan. Grandfather of Scott and Stephen. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Tuesday, 2-5 PM. Interment private.

title: Giuliani Defends Assignment of 20 Officers to Police Museum
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday defended the Police Department's decision to assign 20 uniformed officers to work at the new Police Museum, saying the officers would help improve the department's reputation ''in an era when there are a lot of distortions'' about the police.

title: NATO Ground War: A Balkan Quagmire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Owner of Derby Hopeful Sues
description: The owner of Valhol filed suit in Arkansas yesterday demanding that the state's racing commission release the $300,000 purse his horse earned for winning the Arkansas Derby, money that may determine whether the 3-year-old qualifies to run in the Kentucky Derby.

title: Instruments, Original; Compositions, Early
description: The members of Quatuor Mosaiques met in Vienna as players in the early-music orchestra Concentus Musicus Wien, and joined in forming an original-instrument string quartet in 1985. Since then they have played throughout Europe and won a following beyond from their recordings of Haydn and Mozart. So it's surprising that it took until recently for the quartet to go on its first United States tour, which included a New York debut on Sunday afternoon at the Frick Collection.

title: Now the N.F.L. Is Losing a Legend
description: The National Football League is about to go where it has not been in almost two decades -- to life without John Elway. First Jordan retires, then Gretzky, and now football's No. 7.

title: The Schools in New York City; Reject Vouchers
description: The one idea that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani should not be pursuing is school vouchers. In last week's budget he proposed spending $12 million over the next two years to establish the administrative structure for a voucher program in a volunteer school district. The money would be distributed through his office to avoid involving Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, who opposes the idea. But once the structure was in place, the money for vouchers to be used at private and parochial schools would presumably come out of the regular Board of Education budget.

title: INSIDE
description: Justices Take Tobacco Case

title: Frailty Myth Haunts Women in Sports
description: In a recent article published in The British Journal of Sports Medicine, a sociologist proposed a theory that could launch a thousand hours of talk-radio discussion.

title: KREMLIN SAYS NATO AS WELL AS SERBS MUST COMPROMISE
description: As an American envoy arrived here for talks on Kosovo, Russia's Foreign Minister said today that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia was prepared to make concessions, but that NATO would also have to bend if the conflict was to be brought to an end.

title: Imports That Hurt
description: To the Editor:

title: By Design; For a Brassy, Sassy Spring
description: Usually, spring brings out pastels, but this year colors are bright. Orange, hot pink, turquoise and red are cheerful antidotes to the black and gray of winter.

title: Red Cross Leader Visits 3 American Captives
description: Three American soldiers, captured by Yugoslav forces a month ago, appeared to be in good condition today during a brief visit by the president of the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLEY, ISABEL
description: BERLEY-Isabel. We mourn the loss of Isabel Berley, our close friend and patron. She will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences go to Bill Berley and his family. Associates and Staff, Print Department, The Museum of Modern Art

title: For These Bonded Souls, Some Luck but Little Joy
description: There are amusing moments in Susan Kim's sprawling, even unwieldy play, ''The Joy Luck Club,'' based on Amy Tan's novel and presented by the Pan Asian Repertory Theater. But at the end one leaves with a deep feeling of melancholy. The conflicts between four young Chinese-American women and their mothers and the understanding finally reached across the generations do not bring the sense of fulfillment the novel gives, no matter how harrowing some of its incidents.

title: Labor Party's Hawkish Dove Zigzags to the Israeli Center
description: As a young commando, Ehud Barak placed a woman's wig on his head, squeezed into high heels and stuffed an oversized purse with explosives as he set off on a derring-do -- and ultimately successful -- mission to eliminate a Palestinian terrorist cell in Beirut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESOTO, DEMOSTHENES E.
description: DeSOTO-Demosthenes E., April 24th, 1999, age 74. Veteran U.S. Army, W.W. II. Beloved husband of Georgie, loving father of Yvonne and Demi, fond grandfather of Mychal, 7, and Matthew, 5. Memorial service 7PM, Wed., April 28, at the Peter J. Geis F. Home, 57-34 Catalpa Ave., Ridgewood, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARKAS, PETER, M.D.
description: FARKAS-Peter, M.D. Age 55. On April 25, 1999. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father of Esther and Andrew. Son-in-law of Jozsef Illovszky. Also survived by many dear friends. Dr. Farkas was a renowned cardiologist in Hungary before coming to the U.S. and continued to practice in the Detroit area. According to his wishes, memorial services will be held in Hungary. Memorials may be directed to Karmanos Cancer Institute or Karmanos Hospice, 110 East Warren Avenue, Detroit, MI. 48201-9987.

title: New York's Vital Patches of Green
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAVITT, JOSEPH M. DDS
description: LEAVITT-Joseph M. DDS. Beloved husband of Harriet for 52 years; father of Marc and Trudie; grandfather of Allegra, Josh and Emily. Died gracefully April 25, 1999 in Waterbury, Ct. after a long illness. Born April 23, 1915 and raised in Brooklyn. Joe graduated from the University of Oklahoma in 1936 and earned a DDS degree from Columbia Dental School in 1940. U.S. Army Captain during WWII in the Pacific. Joined Faculty of Columbia and was involved in early research resulting in designation by the ADA in 1963 of Endodontics (root canal therapy) as a specialty. Greatly respected by his colleagues in N.Y. and worldwide, he taught and lectured extensively. Diplomate of American Association of Endodontics. Founding Director of Division of Endodontics at Columbia and active fundraiser for the school until retirement in 1989. He also maintained a private practice dedicated exclusively to endodontics. Services Tuesday 11am at Plaza Memorial, Amsterdam Ave at 91 St. Contributions may be made to Columbia Dental School to create a memorial fund.

title: Pataki Seeks Stronger Penalties for Violence in Schools
description: Citing the Colorado school killings in his effort to push for new laws in New York, Gov. George E. Pataki presented a package of proposals today that would stiffen penalties for violence in schools and make it easier to remove disruptive students from classrooms.

title: Medical Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: New Ford Division to Focus On Recycling of Auto Parts
description: The Ford Motor Company intends to become the world's largest automotive recycler by buying existing recyclers and building its own auto recycling centers to provide used parts, the company announced today.

title: Gun Measure Would Address Internet Sales
description: As an aide sitting at a computer clicked through Web sites showing automatic handguns, assault rifles and other weapons for sale on the Internet, Senator Charles E. Schumer yesterday urged Congress to enact a law to further regulate the on-line gun trade.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: 2 Nutrition Brands Are Sold by Novartis
description: The Swiss drug company Novartis has sold both its Wasa and Eden units, completing its plan to sell its noncore nutrition brands, Novartis said yesterday. The Wasa unit was sold to Barilla Alimentare of Italy for 475 million Swiss francs ($315 million), while Eden was sold to De-Vau-Ge Gesundkostwerk of Germany for an undisclosed sum.

title: Eastern Forests Change Color As Red Maples Proliferate
description: The forests of the Eastern United States are turning increasingly red, and the growing brilliance of color signals a historic change in the ecological character of a vast region stretching from the Great Lakes to the Atlantic and from Canada well into the South.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, HORTENSE S.
description: SACKS-Hortense S., 96, on April 24, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Robert Sacks. She is survived by her son, Robert, and daughter, Elinor Prockop; by her niece, Cornelia Marwell, grandchildren Michael Sacks, Susan Prockop and David Prockop; and by two great granddaughters. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKINLEY, GEORGE
description: McKINLEY-George. The Officers, Directors and members of the Bronx County Bar Association mourn the passing of our distinguished past President and extend our deepest sympathy to his bereaved family.

title: Pension Fund Wins a Vote at Lubrizol
description: The Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association-College Retirement Equities Fund, the world's largest pension fund, has won 68 percent of the vote on its resolution asking the Lubrizol Corporation to eliminate a stringent anti-takeover device.

title: Time Warner To Shut Down Its Pathfinder Site on the Web
description: In a move that symbolizes a passage from the early experimental era of the World Wide Web to a mature publishing platform, Time Warner will shut down Pathfinder, its pioneering outpost in cyberspace.

title: Behind a Sorcerer's Magic, a Formidable Assistant
description: VERA (MRS. VLADIMIR NABOKOV)

We extend to her, her husband Cash, Stephen's wife Laura, and his sister Catherine Sidamon-Eristoff and all his family our heartfelt sympathy. Cheryl Kelly, Director Anita Brickell, Board President

title: They Call It the Blues, but They Sure Look Like They're Having a Ball
description: ''It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues,'' which opened for a limited run at the New Victory Theater in Times Square on March 26, has reopened at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center. Following are excerpts from Lawrence Van Gelder's review, published on April 1.

description: Articles about the shootings at Columbine High School contained two sets of initials you don't often see together: N.R.A. and AOL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'KUHN, DR. SHERWOOD R.
description: O'KUHN-Dr. Sherwood R., 75, of Delray Beach, Florida, and formerly of Verona, New Jersey, died April 25, 1999. Beloved husband of Nancy, loving father of Steven, Peter, Ryan, Susan, and Stacy and spouses.

title: Court to Decide F.D.A. Power on Tobacco
description: The Supreme Court offered itself today as the next battleground in the tobacco wars, announcing that it would decide whether the Food and Drug Administration has authority to regulate tobacco products as drugs and cigarettes as ''drug delivery devices.''

title: Successor Is Selected to Run American Express
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that Kenneth I. Chenault would succeed Harvey Golub as chief executive in 2001. That move would elevate a black executive into the ranks of the country's top corporate leaders.

title: Tribes and Tribulations
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: ASSOCIATES FIRST TO SELL MORE BRANCHES TO CITIGROUP
description: The Associates First Capital Corporation, the largest publicly traded United States finance company, has agreed to sell 41 consumer finance branches in Canada to a Citigroup Inc. unit for an undisclosed price. It is the second time in two months that Citigroup's Commercial Credit Corporation has agreed to buy branches from Associates First. In March, it said it would buy 128 United States branches. Associates First, based in Irving, Tex., has been closing or selling branches to eliminate duplication since it bought Avco Financial Services Inc. in January. It said that 28 of the 41 branches it is selling in Canada were acquired when it bought Avco.

title: Levy, Agent for Female Players, Is in the Eye of the Storm
description: Minutes after the Women's National Basketball Association announced last week that a preliminary contract between the league and its players union had collapsed, the phones in Bruce Levy's Manhattan office began ringing.

title: Disney Earnings Fall 30%; Weak Video Sales a Factor
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that its second-quarter profit fell 30 percent because of weaker home video and merchandising sales and higher costs at ABC, while profit from operations at Viacom Inc. rose 44 percent.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar had its biggest gain against the yen in a week on speculation that Japan will not spend more to help its economy out of recession. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.40 yen, up from 119.26.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, NATHAN
description: HARRIS-Nathan, age 95, jeweler. Retired president of B. Harris and Sons, Jewelers, originally established as the first retail jewelry store on West 47th Street in 1926, died last Monday at the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, CT. Together with his late brother, Charles, he owned and lovingly piloted one of the leading antique jewelry establishments in NYC for nearly seven decades, striving always to provide the right object for the right occasion, at a reasonable price consistent with the high quality of the merchandise, and his clientele included many of the artistic, literary, musical and theatrical leading lights of the time. The store, evolving through later reincarnations on East 48 and East 61 Streets, finally closed in 1991 with his retirement. He was as well a rare chamber musician, occupying first violin chair in his ''Tanglefoot String Quartet'' for some sixty years of joyous amateur music-making. Born on Thanksvgiving Day 1903, he was a liferaft and an anchor for many, at a time when there are few human heroes. When asked what mattered to him most, he said, ''Each day, to give meaning to the lives touched by mine.'' He will be sorely missed by many. Mr. Harris' wife, the former Denah Josephson, predeceased him in 1993. He is survived by a son and a daughter, Michael Harris of Easton, CT., and Susan Harris of Bridgeport, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANG, DONALD KWANG, CHENG
description: CHANG-Donald Kwang-Cheng. Age 62, of Queens, passed away February 27, 1999. Born in Beijing to Wo-Jun & Hsin Hsiang Lo Chang. Obtained B.A., foreign languages, National Taiwan University, 1960; M.A., photographic art, Pratt Institute, 1967. Appointed tenured Senior Lecturer, Department East Asian Languages and Cultures, Columbia University. Renowned for Audio Visual teaching programs, translation and interpretation of classic literature. Survived by his mother and brothers, Kuang-Sheng (Beijin), Kwang-Chih (Boston), Kwang-Poo (Chicago). Memorial service 12:30-1:30 PM, on May 8, St. Paul Chapel, Columbia university. Reception and exhibition of Donald's art work follows the service in Room 403, Kent Hall. In lieu of flowers, donations to Donald K. Chang Memorial Fund recommended. See www.columbia edu/cu.ealac/dchang for details.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESSBURGER, LENA (NEE LANG)
description: PRESSBURGER - Lena (nee Lang). Of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved wife of Selly. Devoted mother of the late Mark. Mother-in-law of Priscilla. Loving aunt and great aunt. Loving grandmother of Roger and Lara. Services will be held at Teaneck Jewish Community Center, 70 Sterling Place, Teaneck, NJ. on Wednesday, April 28th. at noon. For further information ''Wien & Wien'', 800-322-0533.

title: Aide Says Safir Will Not Meet With P.B.A.
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir announced through his spokeswoman yesterday that he would consider meeting soon with every police union except the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which cast a vote of no confidence in him earlier this month.

title: Police Officers Charged With Taking Bribes From Brothel
description: Two New York City police officers were indicted yesterday on charges of taking bribes of sex, cash and gifts from a Manhattan brothel in exchange for giving the brothel advance notice of police raids.

title: Sports of The Times; Hockey Pioneer Takes the Sport to Another Level
description: WILLIE O'REE sat in a glass-enclosed conference room at National Hockey League headquarters, holding his own place in an emotional and expectant week. Wayne Gretzky had retired the previous Sunday, the Stanley Cup playoffs were beginning, and the 64-year-old O'Ree was in the midst of an East Coast swing, preaching the hockey gospel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICARLO, HON. DOMINICK L.
description: DiCARLO-Hon. Dominick L. on April 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Susan and the late Esther. Loving father of Vincent, Carl, Robert and Barbara Basgaard. Devoted grandfather of eight. Dear brother of Rose Cucci, James, Vincent, Constance Testa, Michael, John and the late Anna Pugliesi. Reposing at the Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79 St, Brooklyn. Visiting Wednesday 7-10pm and Thursday and Friday 2-5 & 7-10pm. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:30am at St. Bernadette RC Church. Interment in St. Charles Cemetery.

title: New President for Colgate
description: Charles Karelis, director of a public foundation for higher education, will succeed Neil R. Grabois as president of Colgate University on July 1, the university announced yesterday.

title: For some students at an upstate New York university, Kosovo is near at hand.
description: It would be easy to walk the campus of the State University of New York at Binghamton here, 200 miles northwest of New York City in a wooded valley where the Susquehanna and Chenango rivers meet, and detect few signs that the nation is involved in an armed conflict, or that the conflict is weighing on young people's minds.

title: Microsoft to Join Research on the Next Internet
description: The Microsoft Corporation, which was forced to scramble to catch up after a sluggish start on the Internet a few years ago, is moving to insure that it is at the forefront of Internet research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINKLER, ROY
description: WINKLER-Roy. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved Life member Roy Winkler. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELPS, MIRIAM E.
description: PHELPS-Miriam E. April 26, 1999. Beloved sister of Elinor Schmitt. Loving aunt of Deborah Bussert, Janet Lordi and Gary Schmitt. Service on Wednesday, April 28th, 1 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: BORON, LEPORE FORECASTS A LOSS AND PONDERS OPTIONS
description: Boron, LePore & Associates, a pharmaceuticals marketer, said yesterday that it had hired Bear, Stearns & Company to explore alternatives, including a sale of the company, as it predicted a first-quarter loss. Boron, LePore, of Fair Lawn, N.J., forecast a loss of 8 cents to 10 cents a share; it had been expected to earn 10 cents, based on the average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. Boron, Lepore said the loss was mostly from delays in customer programs, contract modifications and a write-down related to the purchase of Decision Point Inc. The shares, which were above $43 a share in October, fell 75 cents, to $9.

title: Liberties; In the D.C. Matrix
description: Right before the Littleton shootings, Al Gore was telling everyone that he and Tipper just loved ''The Matrix.''

title: Judge Bars Reopening Of Reactor At Millstone
description: In a rare victory for environmentalists, a Connecticut judge issued an order today barring the restarting of the Millstone 2 nuclear reactor on Long Island Sound, just one day before the generator was to produce commercial power for the first time in three years.

title: House Passes New Rules for Satellite TV
description: The House approved broad legislation today that rewrites the rules for the satellite television industry, permitting companies to broadcast local television programs and long-distance signals that have until recently been either restricted or more costly.

title: A Caffe Latte Spot on West 125th Street
description: Starbucks Coffee Company, which has blanketed much of New York with scores of coffee stores with soft chairs and soft lighting, has teamed up with Magic Johnson to expand into a new market: Harlem.

title: Artist Draws And Crosses Lines in War
description: DIVIDING lines figure often in the drawings of Miro Stefanovic. The editorial cartoons he did for publications in his native Yugoslavia reflected the religious, ethnic and political divisions that racked the country. The lines pop up everywhere, between people or buildings, even over a loaf of bread, as if they were laid down by a wayward road painter.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AUDITORE, STEPHEN
description: AUDITORE-Stephen. April 23, 1999. To know Stephen was to love Stephen and I always will. Adieu

title: New Jersey to Use Fund To Help Keep Port Lines
description: A New Jersey task force that holds the purse strings to a harbor-dredging fund yesterday approved spending $100 million to keep the state's two biggest shipping lines in New York Harbor.

title: Prices Mixed in Heavy Trading, With Dow Rising 113.12
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday in fairly heavy trading. Two major market averages rose to new highs even as investors took profits in bellwether technology and Internet issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENIHAN, EDWARD J.
description: LENIHAN-Edward J. Of Verona, New Jersey, formerly of Nutley, on April 25, 1999. Husband of Lynn, father of Lili and Joanne. Brother of Priscilla Lawler, the late Rita Lenihan & the late Paul Lenihan. A Mass will be offered in Our Lady of the Lake Church, Verona on Wednesday at 10AM. Memorial donations to St. Benedict Prep, 520 Martin Luther King Boulevard, Newark; St. Vincents Academy, 228 West Market Street, Newark; The Walsh Library (at Seton Hall), South Orange Avenue, South Orange or to the Center for Hospice Care, 3 High Street, Glen Ridge, would be appreciated.

title: Critic's Notebook; Cries of Anguish From the Front Lines of Capitalism
description: ''Attention must be paid.'' Linda Loman's plea resounds through ''Death of a Salesman,'' but in fact attention has long been paid to America's salesmen. The problem for them is not being ignored but being kidded or put down. Whether the attention comes from academics or journalists or a playwright or two, the salesman is most commonly a figure of mockery, particularly if he is a traveling man (did you hear the one about Hickey's wife and the iceman?), or he may be a peddler of all that is most tawdry about the free market. Or perhaps he's just a desperate case, on the psychological edge, but never -- except maybe at trade banquets, where worth is measured by the bottom line -- is his calling held up as an exemplar of high aspirations or edifying values.

title: Palestinians Seem Resigned to a Delay in Statehood
description: Several miles from the seaside compound where Palestinian leaders locked themselves away today to deliberate the timing of a declaration of statehood, Motee and Ali Anan sat shrugging amid porcelain toilets in their luxury-bathroom store on the main boulevard in town.

title: Giuliani and Crew Agree School Board's Structure Is Faulty
description: Lost in the sharp clawing between Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over the Mayor's proposed takeover of the Board of Education is an idea that they both agree on: the current structure of the central board is substantially flawed.

title: Florida Will Award Vouchers for Pupils Whose Schools Fail
description: In a move that critics say will cause an exodus from struggling inner-city schools but that advocates believe will save them, Gov. Jeb Bush and leaders in the Florida Legislature have agreed on a plan to let children in the state's lowest-rated schools attend private schools with state-paid tuition.

title: GIULIANI EXPLAINS SCHOOLS REMARKS
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, reacting to charges from Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew that he was being ''reckless'' and ''destructive'' in attacking the school system, said yesterday that he was trying to save the system, not destroy it.

title: IRI INTERNATIONAL IS IN PRELIMINARY TAKEOVER TALKS
description: The IRI International Corporation, a maker of oil-servicing rigs and equipment, said yesterday that it was reviewing an offer from an undisclosed bidder. IRI, of Houston, said the talks were preliminary. The offer comes as IRI and other oilfield service companies are struggling with low oil prices, which have depressed earnings as oil companies spend less on products and services for oil exploration and production. Shares of IRI rose 68.75 cents, to $5.1875, giving the company a current market value of about $207 million.

title: Diageo Weighs Shedding 4 of Its Liquor Brands
description: Diageo P.L.C., the world's largest liquor company, said yesterday that it was considering the sale of Cinzano vermouth along with three other European liquor brands. Analysts said the brands could fetch $:350 million ($565 million). Diageo said it had hired Warburg Dillon Read to consider selling Cinzano, the world's No. 2 vermouth; Metaxa, the top-selling liquor from Greece; Vecchia Romagna, the top brandy in Italy, and Asbach brandy in Germany.

title: Ghosts of Berlin
description: A few years ago in Berlin I picked up an innocuous-looking pamphlet marked ''Bus Stop'' and threw it on the passenger seat of my rental car, along with a handful of similar brochures.

title: School Attack May Bring Changes in Police Tactics
description: After a decade of the largest buildup of special weapons squads by American police departments, the siege at Columbine High School has shown many officers a new kind of domestic terror -- and one that tests the limits of training and tactics.

title: Buck Rogers in the Kitchen
description: WHEN my car overheated, the gas station guy pulled a big gun-thing out of his tool chest, pointed it under the hood and pulled the trigger. Obviously, he was putting the old '88 out of its misery.

title: Finding the Bright Side of the Marquis de Sade
description: THE MARQUIS DE SADE

title: Cao Huoxing, 75; Wrote Patriotic Chinese Music
description: Cao Huoxing, a Chinese farmer's son who wrote a Communist song that has become familiar to hundreds of millions of Chinese, died on April 16 in Tianjin, in northern China, the official New China News Agency reported.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture in Business Day on Monday depicting a thumb-wrestling contest between the rival magazines GQ and Esquire carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Naum Kazhdan of The New York Times.

title: The New York Times Bans Cigarette Ads
description: Joining a small group of newspapers, The New York Times will ban cigarette advertising in its pages, effective Saturday.

title: Central Park Reopens After Bomb Threat
description: Central Park was safe for a stroll again yesterday, a day after an anonymous caller said there were several explosive devices in the park. Hundreds of officers began to secure the park after the call at 7:30 P.M. Monday, as the department's emergency service unit and bomb squad began their hunt around 830 Fifth Avenue, near 64th Street, the police said. Nothing was found, and the search was called off overnight.

title: The Internet vs. the First Amendment
description: As we try to make sense of the school massacre in Littleton, Colo., we suddenly find ourselves swept up in a national debate about whether the Internet, with its dazzling array of interactive mayhem and violence, is partly to blame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROSSEAU, SALLY E. (CONDON)
description: BROSSEAU-Sally E. (Condon). April 23, formerly of Mt. Vernon, NY, of Hudson, Mass. Beloved mother of Wayne Brosseau of North Hampton, NH, and Denise Brosseau of Hudson, Mass. Beloved grandmother of Alex, Eric and Elizabeth. Wife of the late Alphonse Brosseau. Graduate of Boston Latin and Vespa George School of Art, Boston. Services and burial were at the convenience of the family.

title: A Gun Control Moment
description: The Colorado school massacre has generated what amounts to a national conversation about causes and cures, raising issues as simple as school security, as delicate as parental responsibility and as complex as the biological and cultural roots of teen-age violence. This discussion could well lead to a more alert and safer society. But there is one blindingly obvious issue that should be addressed right away -- the issue of gun control. Congress, nervous about the gun lobby, is divided on the subject. The public, we suspect, is not divided at all, at least on the matter of keeping guns and explosives out of the hands of young people. Our own view is that the Colorado tragedy has provided the right moment to take the issue of gun control off automatic pilot, where it has been for four years, and move it forward in a dramatic way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSCICK, CAROLUS (NEE WENZLIK)
description: RUSCICK-Carolus (nee Wenzlik) of Alpine & Naples, Florida on April 27, 1999. Beloved wife of the late R.M. James. Devoted mother of Cary R. Sheren, Robert James and Barbara Procida. Dearest sister of Edna Medford. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass Thursday 9:30 am, Mt. Carmel Church, Tenafly. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Memorials to Holy Name Home Care, Teaneck NJ, or Mt. Carmel Church Tenafly, NJ would be appreciated.

title: Today's Big Schools Polarize Students
description: To the Editor:

title: China's Muffled Protesters
description: The large, silent demonstration in Beijing last Sunday by members of a spiritual sect was the biggest protest in China's capital since the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square 10 years ago. Yet China's leaders allowed the peaceful sit-in to go on all day right outside the top leadership's compound, and there are reports that Prime Minister Zhu Rongji met with several members of the group. The Government has responded cautiously because the group represents a popular social movement. China's leaders are hoping to control a phenomenon whose ancient antecedents brought down several Chinese dynasties, and which presents a challenge of uncertain dimensions to Communist Party rule.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Of a Politician, and What Makes Him Run
description: THE big question right now about Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican from Suffolk County, is whether he is audacious or a fool.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Homes Wired to Internet Now Seeking More Speed

title: Clinton Asks Hunters to Back His Proposals Curbing Guns
description: President Clinton today beseeched the sportsmen who make up much of the nation's gun culture to accept certain regulations and restrictions as a trade-off to help curb the easy access to firearms and try to save lives.

title: Flamed, Not Stirred: A Cocktail With a History
description: GREAT drinks are like folk tales, dreamed up by bartenders and preserved by their admirers. The drinks sometimes change as bartenders add their own touches. The good ones live on intact.

title: From the Mediterranean, A Match Made for Spring
description: AT this time of year, many restaurants on the Mediterranean offer a traditional combination that is outrageously good and completely foreign to Americans: artichoke bottoms with cuttlefish, squid or octopus. The best artichokes mature in cool weather, and the long, gradual spring of southern France and northern Italy gives them perfect growing conditions. The catch of cephalopods is also good in spring, and the marriage of these seasonal foods is probably as old as fishing and agriculture.

title: Spring Giveaway at the City Council
description: Politicians' urge to bestow giveaways on potential campaign benefactors seems especially strong in the spring, when legislators start preparing for summer vacation by passing outrageous benefits for special-interest groups. Right now, the New York City Council is considering a raid on the treasury on behalf of the corrections officers' union that could cost $100 million a year and undermine the collective bargaining process.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARPENTER, DAVID LYON
description: CARPENTER-David Lyon, 75, of Kinnelon, on April 22, 1999. Employed as an executive for Johns Manville Corporation. He was a graduate of Yale University. He also attended the Woodward School and Brooklyn Poly Prep. Husband of Joan (nee Bruce) Carpenter; father of Jon, David W. Carpenter and Jennifer Rizzo; step-father of Jacqueline Lutman. Brother of Robert, Marion Lockwood, and Ruth Carpenter. Also 4 grandchildren. Memorial service Saturday, 11:00 AM, at Saint David's Episcopal Church, Kinnelon. In Lieu of flowers, donations to the church at 91 Kinnelon Road, Kinnelon, N.J. 07405 would be appreciated. Information: The Morrison Funeral Home, 86 Bartholdi Avenue, Butler, New Jersey.

title: Roger Troutman, 47, Influential Funk Musician
description: Roger Troutman, a renowned funk-music innovator who recorded with his brothers in the band Zapp in the early 80's, died on Sunday at the Good Samaritan Hospital and Health Center in Dayton, Ohio. He was 47 and lived in Dayton.

title: A Bit of Bolivia, in Jackson Heights
description: WHEN a friend recently invited me to Tajibos, a Bolivian restaurant she liked in Queens, I couldn't wait to go. I'd never been to a Bolivian restaurant. But when we showed up at the address in Jackson Heights one afternoon, it was no longer there.

title: Today's Big Schools Polarize Students
description: To the Editor,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSCHMIDT, FLORENCE G.
description: GOLDSCHMIDT - Florence G. Born in Brooklyn, New York on July 15, 1918 passed away in Dallas, Texas on April 26, 1999. She is survived by her loving husband, Arthur; daughter and son-in-law Karen and Norman Lerner; daughter and son-in-law Joan and Dr. Alan Weinstock; and grandchildren Rachel, Elie and husband Naama, Yosef, Devora & Chana. Services will be held at 10:00 on Wednesday, April 28, at Shermans Flatbush M.C., 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. A shiva will be held at the Lerners residence.

title: Show of Support for Teacher Who Says Pregnancy Blocked Tenure Bid
description: More than 200 teachers and students, carrying signs with ''Justice for Kathy'' in red letters, rallied outside a school board meeting tonight in support of a teacher who says she is being denied tenure because she got pregnant.

title: Court Ruling Gives Valhol Derby Shot
description: Valhol, the Arkansas Derby winner whose jockey may or may not have used an illegal electrical device during the race, will get to run in the Kentucky Derby after all, although not with the same jockey.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Reincarnated Giraffe

title: Lois Rivkin, 69; Linked Schools and Museums
description: Lois Borwick Herman Rivkin, the founder and president of an organization linking business organizations and cultural institutions to New York City public schools, died on Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 69.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE PLUNGES. Orange juice prices fell on signs that a drought may be ending in Florida, the nation's biggest orange-growing state. In New York, orange juice for July delivery fell 4.4 cents a pound, to 83.30 cents.

title: Playground Safety Survey
description: Many American playgrounds are not safe, according to a new survey, noting that 150,000 children a year are injured on them. The survey, released last week by the National Program for Playground Safety at the University of Northern Iowa, assigned a grade of C- to playgrounds over all.

title: Business Travel; Medium-sized outlying airports can often be more pleasant than their big-city brethren.
description: BIG-CITY airports like to advertise themselves as vibrant, exciting transportation centers. But most business travelers collect and compare horror stories, not fond memories, about major airports, which tend to offer the ambiance of Federal minimum-security prisons -- without the amenities.

title: Ejido Pino Gordo Journal; All Across Mexico, a Chainsaw Massacre of Trees
description: The shepherds of this remote mountain settlement till the earth behind oaken plows and grind their corn between smooth stones. They have no television, telephones or electricity. Yet by one standard, the village enjoys vast wealth: it is surrounded by magnificent forests.

title: Police Evict Band of Squatters Barricaded in the East Village
description: Using sledgehammers, jackhammers and power saws, New York City police officers evicted a small group of heavily barricaded people yesterday from one of the few remaining tenements in the East Village still occupied by squatters.

title: U.S. Says Suspect Put Code On Bombs in Unsecure Files
description: A scientist suspected of spying for China improperly transferred huge amounts of secret data from a computer system at a Government laboratory, compromising virtually every nuclear weapon in the United States arsenal, Government and lab officials say.

title: Court Voids Theory In Espy Prosecution
description: The Supreme Court unanimously rejected the expansive legal theory behind an independent counsel's prosecution of Mike Espy, the Secretary of Agriculture in 1993 and 1994, and of those who bestowed favors on Mr. Espy.

title: Seeking Redemption in Siberia
description: For a time after the fall of the Berlin wall and the Soviet Union, everything seemed possible. Local upheavals, even brave individuals, could change the world if circumstances were right.

title: Massachusetts Unveils New Bid to Keep Patriots Out of Hartford
description: Challenging Connecticut's deal to move the New England Patriots to Hartford, Massachusetts officials announced tonight that they had put together a rival plan that is backed by the National Football League.

title: A Wider Audience
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took over City Hall in 1994, he embraced three main goals: reducing crime, creating more jobs and overhauling a school system that he said suffered from a bloated bureaucracy. But while he has largely accomplished the first two, even the Republican Mayor's supporters say he has not done nearly enough to improve the public schools.

title: Murder Charge Filed in Sledgehammer Attack
description: The authorities arrested a man yesterday who they say killed his girlfriend with a sledgehammer then dumped her body in an abandoned building where it was discovered last week during a demolition job.

title: Sports of The Times; John Franco Savors His Home Plate
description: ON his rare forays into the hinterlands, John Franco has made an amazing discovery. The pizza is not as good in the suburbs, and neither is the bread. It's a fact. Something about being outside the five boroughs curdles the dough, or spoils it, or whatever it is that goes wrong with dough.

title: Metro Business; Publisher Moves Office
description: The New York office of Ziff-Davis Inc., a publishing and broadcasting company based in San Francisco, completed a move yesterday to 28 East 28th Street, a 15-story building between Park Avenue South and Madison Avenue. The office was previously at 1 Park Avenue.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Nothing Toylike in Mattel Chief's Compensation
description: Barbie was a tough sell in 1998, but Jill E. Barad had a good year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONOVER, ROBERT N. JR.
description: CONOVER-Robert N. Jr. April 25, 1999 in New York City at Bellevue Hospital. Born August 3, 1995 in New York City. Son of Robert and Sarah Conover. Visitation Thursday, April 29th at William Coster Funeral Home, 3270 Main Road, Cutchogue, N.Y. from 2PM to 4PM and 7 PM to 9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday, April 30th at 10AM at Our Lady of Good Counsel Mission Church, Mattituck, New York.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's like when you got automatic door locks on your car, and at first you thought, 'Do I really need this?' Once you have them you can never go back.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLMEIER, HAZEL R.
description: DILLMEIER-Hazel R. Of Garden City, L.I., and Westhampton Beach passed away on April 27, 1999. Graduate of Florida College for Women now Florida State also graduate degrees from Columbia and Stanford in physical therapy. Beloved wife of William E. Dillmeier and widow of the late Basil O'Connor. Survived by granddaughter Cathy Culver Hively, William E. Dillmeier Jr., Robert L. Dillmeier and their children. A memorial service will be held at a later date at Westhampton Beach, NY. Private burial services will be held at Oak Lawn Cemetery, Jacksonville, FL. Donations in her memory to Roosevelt Warm Springs Endowment Fund, P.O. Box 1050, Warm Springs, GA. 31830.

title: City Is to Pay $2.7 Million In Beating Suit
description: The Giuliani administration has agreed to pay $2.75 million to a man who said he was beaten on his way to work by at least five police officers because he fit the profile of a black suspect they were seeking.

title: Barnaby's Efforts to Distract Only Serve to Detract
description: During last spring's Stanley Cup playoffs, Matthew Barnaby was sent to the dressing room early for one intermission for roughing. He was banished not by the referee but by his own coach, not for battling an opponent but for exchanging jousts on his own bench with one of his Buffalo Sabres teammates.

title: THE CHEF
description: IN creating a new dish, chefs often strive for harmony among the ingredients. In fact, that's the safest thing to do. When flavors clash, you're taking a risk. For better and sometimes for worse, I happen to be a risk-taker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILLO, OTTO EMIL, M.D.
description: BILLO-Otto Emil, M.D. of Bronxville, NY and Dorset, VT on April 25, 1999. Husband of the late Barbara L. Billo. Father of Barbara B. Alexander, Charles G. Billo and Suzanne B. Kaiser. Grandfather of six. Dr. Billo was a graduate of Williams College, Class of 1930, Harvard Medical School, Class of 1935. Dr. Billo was on the staff of Lennox Hill Hospital, New York Hospital and Lawrence Hospital. Memorial service at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on Saturday, May 8 at 2:00 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Harvard Medical School Alumni Fund, 25 Shattuck St., Boston, MA 02115, Rm. 306.

title: Political Briefing; In Missouri, Religion And Politics
description: Back in January, when Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri spared the life of a convicted murderer, Darrell Mease, he explained that he did so because he had received an ''extraordinary'' plea for mercy from Pope John Paul II, who was then visiting St. Louis. The commutation was a ''one-time act,'' the Governor said, pointing out that in his seven years in office he had approved more than two dozen executions.

title: Some Enter the Fast Lane To Get Access to the Web
description: The craving for speed seized John Drees the day after he bought his first personal computer late last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, W. HAZAIAH, THE REV. DR.
description: WILLIAMS-W. Hazaiah, The Rev. Dr. May 14, 1930-April 24, 1999. On Saturday, April 24, 1999, the Rev. Dr. W. Hazaiah Williams, Founder and Director for 35 years of Today's Artists Concerts and Founder and Artistic Director of Four Seasons Concerts for six years, passed away in Berkeley, CA. from complications due to a long diabetes illness. Dr. Williams presented international classical music artists annually at Carnegie Hall and at Alice Tully Hall since 1977. He presented a series of concerts in the San Francisco Bay Area & formed an annual summer music festival at Yachats, Oregon in 1981. William Hazaiah Williams, Jr. was born in Columbus, Ohio on May 14, 1930, the youngest of six children. He earned a Master of Theology from Boston University. He was awarded two honorary Doctor of Divinity degrees, one from Pacific School of Religion and the other from the Church Divinity School of the Pacific, both in Berkeley. In addition to his role as Impresario, Dr. Williams was Founder and Pastor of the Church for Today in Berkeley, California from 1956 until his death; he was Founder and President for 20 years of the Center for Urban Black Studies at the Graduate Theological Union in Berkeley. He played a leading role in the Civil Rights Movement, and lectured throughout the United States on the issues of race, religion and education. In the mid-1970s, he was a delegate to the World Council of Churches' Symposium on Black and Liberation Theology at Geneva, Switzerland. Funeral services for Dr. W. Hazaiah Williams are scheduled for Wednesday, April 28 at 11:00 AM at Evergreen Baptist Church, 408 MacArthur Boulevard, Oakland, California.

title: TV Notes; The 'Meeting' Format
description: The Littleton, Colo., high school killings last week got far more attention from the major television networks than previous school killings, and more than twice as many minutes (144) on the 6:30 evening newscasts than coverage of the crisis in Yugoslavia (63) that week.

title: Forstmann Sells a Stake
description: Forstmann Little & Company said yesterday that it had sold its remaining 5.4 million shares of General Semiconductor Inc. for $35 million to the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. unit of the Equitable Companies. General Semiconductor, based in Melville, N.Y., a maker of power supplies and transistors, was spun off from the General Instrument Corporation in 1995.

title: Textbooks on the Internet
description: Linking textbooks to the Internet has formidable problems: Web addresses may become obsolete, sites may decline in quality and they are beyond publishers' control anyway.

title: Differences of Opinion: Giuliani and Crew on Improvements in Education
description: For months, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew have debated education issues, including publicly financed vouchers to pay for tuition at private schools, the power of the Board of Education and the role of the Chancellor. Here are some highlights:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKFIELD, BERDIE
description: MARKFIELD-Berdie. On April 25, 1999. Loving and beloved wife of the late Herbert. Cherished mother of Tony and Gloria, and Robert and Elaine. Adored grandmother of Joshua, Sarah, Hugh, and Jed and great grandmother of Julia. Services were held privately.

title: Today's Big Schools Polarize Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVKIN, LOIS HERMAN
description: RIVKIN-Lois Herman. The family of Lois Rivkin mourns the loss on April 27, of their beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister, after a valiant fight against lymphoma. Her creation of Friends of the Public Schools exemplified her warmth, energy, optimism & love of New York City. A memorial service will be held Sunday, May 2, at 11 A.M. at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Congregation Rodeph Sholom, or to the Citizens Committee for New York City, 305 7th Avenue.

title: In Uniting Over Kosovo, A New Sense of Identity
description: A month of war in Europe has already brought deep changes to the continent, awakening a new sense of European patriotism, rekindling tensions over ''American imperialism'' and reviving the sagging fortunes of some leaders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHILL, JAMES M.
description: CAHILL-James M. April 25, at age 89. Funeral mass, 10 AM, Friday, at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Footlight
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBAN, SIGMUND
description: BARBAN-Sigmund. On April 26, 1999. Beloved uncle of Toni Levin Smith, Claire Bleiberg Schacht, Charles Levin and Simon Levin. Granduncle of Peter Bleiberg, Mona Bleiberg Bennett, Maureen Smith, Bryan Smith, Yale Levin, Michael Levin, Jacob Levin, Daniel Levin and Joshua Levin. Memorial services to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCALL, DAVID B. AND JOAN MILLS
description: McCALL-David B. and Joan Mills. The Bank Street Community, Board, faculty and staff extend our deepest condolences to the family of David and Joan McCall. David, a valued friend, distinguished Board Member and inspirational educator, will be sorely missed. Elizabeth S. Pforzheimer, Chair of the Board Augusta Souza Kappner, President

title: PAMIDA HOLDINGS SAYS IT IS CONSIDERING A BUYOUT OFFER
description: The Pamida Holdings Corporation, which operates 150 general merchandise stores in Midwestern, North Central and Rocky Mountain states, said yesterday that it had received a buyout offer from a suitor it would not identify. The shares rose $2, to $7.50. The Omaha-based Pamida sells appliances, housewares, seasonal goods and clothing in 15 states. It said that it was in talks with a potential buyer and that it had received an inquiry from another unidentified party about a business combination. The company, which said it was looking for increased capital to help its growth, added that it wanted to reach a conclusion quickly. At the current price, the company's stock is worth more than $68 million.

title: Political Briefing; Giuliani's Shadow In San Francisco
description: Five years ago, when term limits were about to force him out of his job as Speaker of the California Assembly, Willie L. Brown Jr. professed to have no interest in returning to his hometown, San Francisco, to run for Mayor.

title: TV Notes; Finding Drama In Basketball
description: Tom Fontana and Barry Levinson have found groundbreaking television drama inside a Baltimore homicide squad in NBC's ''Homicide,'' and a maximum-security prison in HBO's ''Oz''; but when they went looking for a new arena for drama they took ''arena'' rather literally.

title: U.S. Balkans Effort Points Up Difficulty Of Quick Response
description: Ever since the Persian Gulf war, the Pentagon has tried to transform its forces into lighter, mobile units able to intervene swiftly in the world's trouble spots. But as the war in the Balkans has shown, the military is anything but the ''expeditionary'' force it wants to be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, ALFRED J., M.D.
description: BERGER-Alfred J., M.D. of Delray Beach, Fl. died April 26, 1999. A graduate of Harvard Medical School, he retired in 1986. He is survived by his wife Page, and his son Robert B. (Buzz) Berger of Princeton, and daughter Barbara Berger of Larchmont, four grand children, and his sister Charlotte Feinswog of Bal Harbor, Fl.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Livery-Cab Driver Shot And Killed in Brooklyn
description: A livery-cab driver died early yesterday morning, shortly after being shot in the head by one of three fares he picked up in Coney Island, the police said. The driver, Naveed Iqbal, 24, was flagged down in front of 2874 West 33d Street shortly after midnight, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about three benefit concerts to be held in New Jersey, London and Geneva, for awareness of world poverty, included an erroneous reference, supplied by a sponsor and a publicity agent, to the series producers' past credits. The producers -- Ken Kragen, Jeff Pollack, Don Mischer and Harvey Goldsmith -- were responsible for ''Live Aid,'' ''We Are the World'' and ''Hands Across America'' but not for ''Farm Aid.'' (The coming series, to be broadcast live on the World Wide Web, is Net Aid.)

title: Too Scared to Save Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Man Admits to Scheme To Swindle Priest
description: A Manhattan man pleaded guilty yesterday to swindling an elderly Lavallette priest out of $1.4 million in church funds in a phony investment scheme, the State Attorney General's office said.

title: An Asia Empire Still on a Seesaw
description: Few Asian tycoons have suffered as abrupt a reversal of fortune as Anthony Salim, the chief executive of Indonesia's largest conglomerate, the Salim Group. Today, Mr. Salim had both a success and a setback in his effort to salvage his tottering empire.

title: A Supermarket as a Spur for Change; New Harlem Pathmark Promises Competition and Convenience
description: Like many Manhattan residents, Olga Hayes is used to doing her major grocery shopping outside the borough -- in her case, at the Pathmark on Bruckner Boulevard in the Bronx -- and picking up a few things between trips at her local food stores.

title: New Chairman Named at MGM
description: The movie studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc., owner of one of the largest film libraries, has named Alex Yemenidjian chairman and chief executive.

title: As Ewing Watches, Knicks Are Thriving
description: The final seconds were spinning off the clock Monday night when Patrick Ewing rose from the bench, brushed the creases out of his pinstriped suit and lumbered down the sideline until he reached midcourt.

title: McCann to Handle Hewlett Spinoff
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company in Palo Alto, Calif., said yesterday that it had selected the New York office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising to handle the global introduction of an unnamed spinoff company. The spinoff will operate Hewlett-Packard's test and measurement, components, chemical-analysis and medical businesses with revenue of $7.6 billion.

title: Is Spain Too Far for Takeout?
description: IS there anything more dramatic at a restaurant than the arrival of paella? The great pan of rice, heaped high with meats or seafood and served with ceremony, cannot help but impress.

title: TV Notes; Striving for Sensitivity
description: NBC found itself in something of a predicament last week after the school shootings in Colorado. The network's big mini-series for the May sweep, a two-part movie called ''Atomic Train,'' revolved around a threat that the city of Denver would be blown up by a nuclear bomb.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column on Thursday, about ''Another Life: A Memoir of Other People'' by Michael Korda, editor in chief at Simon & Schuster, misstated the number of American book publishing houses owned by Jews by the late 1920's, an era in which the author depicts the industry as ''a rather stuffy and self-important club.'' At least seven had been founded by Jews by that time, not just one.

title: From the Shock of Violent Deaths, New and More Public Rites of Mourning
description: In the week since two teen-agers killed 13 people at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., thousands of mourners have gone to a public park nearby, carrying flowers, memorial cards and banners, stuffed animals and balloons, building a rambling, multicolor memorial that spreads out across the lawn.

title: Maine's High Court Rejects Families' Bid to Use Vouchers for Religious School
description: The Maine Supreme Court has denied a constitutional appeal by five families who wanted to use taxpayer money to send their children to a church-affiliated school. In a 5-to-1 decision, the court upheld the state's policy of restricting publicly financed vouchers to nonreligious schools.

title: How Rituals Can Create A Reluctant Artist; Intimacy and Strangers Structure Her Life
description: From an early age, Sophie Calle organized her life around rituals. She gave her goldfish and pet birds elaborate funerals, with music and tiny coffins. She demanded to be awakened with a glass of orange juice when her mother returned home from a party, no matter the hour.
