In the week before her grandfather's birthday she would mail him countdown letters daily.

title: The Rich Little Secret Of Top Chefs: Fat
description: FAT. For years, it's been a four-letter word so repugnant to many of us that it required only three. And yet the best chefs know they can't be great without it. Sometimes they use a lot, sometimes a little. Sometimes it's actually splashed on by the ladleful, as just about any dish -- from fish to vegetables to beef -- gets ready to emerge through the swinging doors.

title: East Timor Vote On Autonomy Is Set for Aug. 8
description: President B. J. Habibie of Indonesia announced today that a referendum would be held on Aug. 8 in the territory of East Timor to allow residents to choose whether to accept a plan giving them autonomous status within Indonesia.

title: Arbit Blatas, 90, a Sculptor, Painter and Stage Designer
description: Arbit Blatas, a Lithuanian-born artist whose career bridged New York, Venice and the Paris of Picasso, Matisse, Braque, Dufy, Bonnard, Vlaminck, Utrillo, Soutine and Cocteau -- all of whom he rendered in paint, clay or bronze -- died yesterday at his studio home in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: AT&T Profit Surges 42% On Cost Cuts
description: Even as it continued its flurry of deal-making, the AT&T Corporation reported strong financial results for the first quarter yesterday, exceeding analysts' expectations. But investors did not rush to buy AT&T's shares as uncertainty continued about the company's unsolicited $58 billion bid to acquire Mediaone Group Inc., the big cable television company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, HOWARD (CHAIM)
description: WEINSTEIN - Howard (Chaim). Yeshivat Sha'alvim extends heartfelt condolences to his brothers, Board member and alumnus, Boruch, alumnus David, sister Joy, father Mordechai and wife Leah. Hamakom Yenachemchem.

title: Bomb Count Grows in Colorado, And a Woman Is Linked to Guns
description: A young woman who attended the prom with Dylan Klebold three days before he and Eric Harris carried out the assault at Columbine High School bought at least two of the guns used in the attack, the authorities said today as they announced that 51 explosives -- nearly twice as many as the original tally -- had been found in and around the school and in the Harris home.

title: INTERVOICE TO BUY BRITE VOICE FOR $164.4 MILLION
description: Intervoice Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Brite Voice Systems Inc. for $164.4 million in cash and stock, a deal that would bring together two providers of call automation and interactive voice-response systems. Intervoice, of Dallas, said it would pay $13.40 each for some 9.2 million Brite Voice shares and exchange stock for the remaining 3.1 million shares outstanding. Of the total, $122.7 million will be in cash and $41.7 million will be in Intervoice stock. Intervoice had revenue of $136.9 million last year, while Brite Voice had $153.4 million. Shares of Brite Voice, based in Heathrow, Fla., jumped $2.1875, to $12.75. Intervoice slipped 28.125 cents, to $10.75.

title: Jackson Leaves Today on Mission to Free 3 G.I.'s
description: A group of religious leaders led by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson plan to leave Wednesday on what they call a humanitarian mission to Belgrade, where they hope to persuade Yugoslav officials to free three captive American soldiers.

title: Yanks' Bats Rescue Clemens
description: Roger Clemens waited at the clubhouse door to congratulate teammates tonight after the Yankees rebounded from a five-run deficit to beat Texas, 7-6. Way to go, Clemens told them, but implicitly, he was thanking them.

title: Barolos Put on a Friendlier Face
description: I HAVE to confess it had been a long time since I'd had anything to do with Barolo, a treasure of Italian winemaking. You know how it is: so many wines, so little time.

title: Where Paprika Is Measured In Pounds, Not Pinches
description: DRIVING south from Budapest across the Alfold, the Great Hungarian Plain, you pass men walking behind horses, guiding plows through earth the color of Hershey bars. The willows are wearing gauzy-green spring outfits, and the forsythia is blooming. It is March, planting season in paprika country.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: A Spa Replants Its Organic Heritage
description: ENRIQUE CEBALLOS is showing two visitors through the organic gardens of Rancho La Puerta, a spa here on the Baja peninsula just across the border from California. As he talks, he picks his supper.

title: Arkansas Lawmakers Indicted in Vast Corruption Case
description: A Federal grand jury shook the Arkansas political establishment today with a long list of political corruption indictments that reaches to the apex of the state Legislature.

title: Russia Tries to Broker Peace; Despite Gaps, U.S. Is Supportive
description: Senior American and Russian officials met today to discuss competing notions of how Kosovo could be resettled and administered once hostilities end, as Moscow moved increasingly into a role as mediator in the lengthening Balkan conflict.

title: Heat Takes Out Its Frustrations On the Nets
description: Alonzo Mourning was in Florida nursing an injured right eye and still, it was not fair.

title: Devils Glady Except Their Gifts From Barrasso
description: In the previous two seasons, the Devils were frustrated during the playoffs by the goaltending of the Rangers' Mike Richter and Ottawa's Damian Rhodes. Tonight, they finally ran into an ineffective goaltender as the Penguins' Tom Barrasso allowed a couple of soft goals in the Devils' 4-2 victory at the Civic Arena.

title: Political Briefing; For Harold Stassen, There's No Giving Up
description: He turned 92 this month and he makes his home at an assisted-living center near Minneapolis. But don't count Harold Stassen out, not yet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, JOHN BUCKHOUT
description: JOHNSTON-John Buckhout. In San Rafael, California, April 22, 1999. Age 79 years. Formerly of New Canaan, CT. Loving husband of Emma S. Johnston. Dear father of Alexa Horne, Cynthia Alexander, and John B. Johnston, Jr. Grandfather of four grandchildren. A native of St. Paul, Minnesota. He was Managing Director of Marsh and McLennan, New York City, Director of the New York Philharmonic. Private services have been held. Private inurnment, Oakland Cemetery, St. Paul, Minnesota. Memorial contributions preferred to NY Philharmonic, Avery Fisher Hall, 10 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023.

title: Metro Business; ABC to Leave Web Site
description: Walt Disney Company's ABC television network said it would not renew a contract that put its on-line sports and entertainment news on the Web site of America Online, the No. 1 Internet service provider.

title: NATO Chief Admits Bombs Fail to Stem Serb Operations
description: The military commander of NATO acknowledged today that five weeks of intensive bombing had failed to reduce the size of the Serbian force in Kosovo or its operations against Albanians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORE, CAROL TILLES
description: SHORE-Carol Tilles. Age 77. Loving wife and better half of Allan for 58 years; beloved mother of Allan Shore Jr., William Shore, and Marylu Simon & devoted motherin-law of Jill Shore; cherished grandmother of Jennifer, Beth, Chris, Michael and Julie; greatgrandmother of three and sister of the late Roy Tilles Jr. Her compassion and zest for life touched all who knew her. Formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y., resident of Palm Beach, Florida for 25 years. Active volunteer for the Helen and Harry Gray Cancer Institute at Good Samaritan Hospital, Hospice of Palm Beach County and the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. Funeral service will be at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, Friday April 30 at 10AM. Visiting hours Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9. Burial at Woodlawn Cemetery, N.Y. For further information call Frank E. Campbell at 212-288-3500. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Helen and Harry Gray Cancer Institute at Good Samaritan Hospital, 1309 North Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, Florida 33401.

title: Be Quiet in the Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Herbert Young, Who Fought In World War I, Dies at 112
description: Herbert Young, who was decorated by the French Government in February for his service in World War I, died on Thursday at his home in Harlem. He would have turned 113 next week.

title: Officer in Queens Slashed in Face Answering a Disturbance Call
description: A police officer trying to subdue a disturbed man in a house in Queens last night was slashed in the face and needed 100 stitches, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A profile in some editions last Wednesday about Barry K. Schwartz, a founder of Calvin Klein Inc. who hopes to enter a filly in the Kentucky Derby, misspelled the surname of a Daily Racing Form writer who was doubtful about the horse's chances. He is David Litfin, not Lifton.

title: Bridging Loneliness Despite the Disguises
description: ''The King of Masks'' is a Chinese film with pageantry, a magic act and adorable children to recommend it. And the pet monkey doesn't hurt, either. Its story is told gently and without excess sentimentality, even if that story proves less exotic than the setting (provincial Sichuan in 1930) suggests. The film, a winner of multiple Oscar-like Golden Roosters in China, works nicely as the simple tale of a lonely old man, the child he befriends and the cross-dressing that affects everyone in various ways.

title: The President Orders 33,102 In the Reserves to Active Duty
description: President Clinton ordered a call-up of 33,102 reservists today to serve up to nine months of active duty in the Kosovo air campaign. It was the biggest military call-up since the Persian Gulf war.

title: Israel's Diverse Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWN, DAVID
description: DAWN-David. The Board and Staff of The New York Botanical Garden note with sadness the death of David Dawn. He was one of the nation's premier rose growers and a generous leader of the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden Committee. We offer our deep sympathy to his wife Helga and their family. Thomas J. Hubbard, Chairman Gregory Long, President

title: INSIDE
description: Palestinian Delay Likely

title: 2 Yugoslav Officials Raise Prospect of Negotiations
description: A senior Yugoslav Government official, the second this week, spoke optimistically today about the possibility of a negotiated settlement to the war over Kosovo.

title: Too Scared to Save Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Al Hirt, 76, Trumpeter and Symbol of New Orleans, Dies
description: Al Hirt, the portly Dixieland jazz trumpeter who was a symbol of the exuberant laissez-faire way of life of New Orleans, died yesterday at home in New Orleans. He was 76.

title: High Court Voids Theory Used to Press Independent Counsel's Cases Over Gifts to Espy
description: The Supreme Court today unanimously rejected the expansive legal theory behind an independent counsel's prosecution of Mike Espy, the former Secretary of Agriculture, and of those who bestowed favors on Mr. Espy.

title: Tokyo Lawmakers Pass Bill to Improve Military Ties With U.S.
description: The lower house of Parliament passed crucial legislation today to improve military cooperation with the United States, smoothing the way for Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi's departure Thursday for a meeting with President Clinton.

title: Home Resales Set Record Pace; Consumer Confidence Up Again
description: Sales of existing homes unexpectedly rose to a record pace in March, industry figures showed today, and consumer confidence in the economy increased in April for the sixth consecutive month, suggesting economic growth could accelerate in coming months.

title: A 'Quixote' Gala With Heroes to Spare
description: Opening its season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday night, American Ballet Theater tried out a festive novelty: a hero and heroine in ''Don Quixote'' multiplied by three.

title: Italian Regulators Reject Big Bank Merger
description: San Paolo IMI S.p.A., Italy's largest banking company, said yesterday that Italy's central bank had rejected its proposed merger with Banca di Roma S.p.A. San Paolo said it was informed by the Bank of Italy that the merger could not be authorized in the light of its rejection last Thursday by Banca di Roma.

title: CALENDAR
description: Sugar Sculpture, Such Sweet Art

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: For Now, Mayor Loses His Grip

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLITZ, MURRAY
description: BLITZ-Murray. The Officers, Board of Directors, and Members of Engineers Country Club mourn the passing of their beloved member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the Blitz family.

title: Better Nursing Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial Begins for Mother in Breast-Fed Infant's Starvation Death
description: Two strikingly different pictures of Tabitha Walrond were drawn yesterday in opening statements at her trial on charges of second-degree manslaughter in the starvation death of the infant son she had been breast-feeding.

title: The Advertising Council's new president is the first one to come from the media business.
description: FOR only the fourth time in its 57-year history, the Advertising Council has a new president.

title: Too Scared to Save Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigrant Planning a Window Factory in Queens
description: In 1982, when he was 27, Thomas Chen arrived in New York from Taiwan, looking for opportunities and planning to bring his wife and young son over to join him when he could afford it. He settled in Elmhurst, Queens, and found a job in a sweater factory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, HOWARD A.
description: MARKS-Howard A. On April 27, 1999. Of Searingtown, L.I. Beloved husband of Lorene; devoted father of Michael and Yvonne, Brian and Lynne, Jeffrey and Jill; dear brother of Florence Lando and Sis Schneider; loving grandfather of Jennifer, Amy, Melanie, Kelli, Madeline, Shelby, Aaron and Julia. Services Thursday 12 Noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I. Donations can be made to either Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, N.Y. 11590 or Whittingham Cancer Center, Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, CT. 06856.

title: In a Sea of Tents, Life Goes On and Hatred Festers
description: Those who want food by noon know to be up well before dawn, for the bread lines have become impossibly long. The wait is normally in the rain. Latecomers seem to leave without milk and with only two bananas instead of the usual four. The old plead with the young to save them a spot and spare them the wearying ordeal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFSTETTER, MAX
description: HOFSTETTER-Max, died on April 26, at age 81. Beloved husband of Mildred for 58 years. Cherished father of Neil, Steven and Rose Weiss. Dear brother of Herman. Adored grandfather of Michael and Karen, Donna and Tzvi, Allison and Scott, Jason and Tova, Lee and Matthew, Gregory, and Nathaniel. Great-grandfather to MacKenzie, Ilan, and Hannah Rose. Loving father-in-law of Estelle, Bruce, and Margy. Services Thursday, 1 PM, at Gramercy Chapels, 2nd Ave. and 10th St. Please make any donations to The Faculty Campaign, NYU Medical Center, 550 1st Ave., NY, NY 10016, in honor of Max Hofstetter. Shiva will be observed at the home of Dr. Steven and Mrs. Hofstetter.

title: Lukas Embraces Election Into Hall
description: It was maybe 10 years too late by his own reckoning, but the trainer D. Wayne Lukas was finally elected to thoroughbred racing's Hall of Fame today -- as he was preparing two horses for his 19th consecutive Kentucky Derby, three of which he has won, and as he was approaching the historic pinnacle of $200 million in earnings.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the ''Hot and Cold'' table in Business Day yesterday, listing stocks with large percentage gains and losses on Monday, misidentified the packaging businesses being sold by the Fort James Corporation, maker of Quilted Northern bathroom tissue and Brawny paper towels. The company sold 12 folding carton operations, which made health care, food and microwave packaging.

title: Telecom Italia Rejects Bid By Olivetti
description: Telecom Italia took new steps today to thwart the hostile suitor Olivetti S.p.A., formally rejecting its $65 billion offer and selling control of a pay-television subsidiary that the rival telephone company had assumed would be part of any takeover.

title: Park Place To Buy Casinos From Starwood
description: In a deal that will reshape the gambling business in Atlantic City and Las Vegas, Nev., Park Place Entertainment, a recent spinoff from Hilton Hotels, agreed yesterday to acquire the Caesars casino operations of Starwood Hotels and Resorts for $3 billion in cash.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Bermuda Takes the Risk; From Tourist Paradise to Haven for Insurance Business
description: The construction project in the middle of town tells the tale of how things have been going lately on this lovely island of pastel bungalows and perpetual spring. The grand old Bermudiana Hotel and its luxuriant gardens have been leveled; in their place two big insurance buildings are rising.

title: Gwynn Has Almost 3,000 Reasons to Smile
description: The date was July 19, 1982, and the Cincinnati Reds were playing the Padres in San Diego. The Reds had a first baseman named Pete Rose. The Padres had a rookie center fielder, Tony Gwynn. He was playing in his first major league game. In his first three times at bat, Gwynn didn't get a hit, but in the eighth inning, he lined a pitch from Sid Monge into the left-center-field gap for a double.

title: Unilever and Diageo In Thompson Deals
description: Two giant marketers -- Unilever and Diageo P.L.C. -- said yesterday that they had expanded their relationships with the J. Walter Thompson Company unit of WPP Group P.L.C. by awarding Thompson assignments for well-known brands.

title: Asylum Seekers' Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: City Gardens Endure
description: To the Editor:

title: Today's Big Schools Polarize Students
description: To the Editor:

title: As They Mourn, They Are Left to Wonder
description: For more than three hours, William David Sanders lay dying on a classroom floor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, ELMA PHILLIPSON
description: COLE-Elma Phillipson. The Board of Directors of James Lenox House Association mourns the death of our beloved board member and former President Elma Phillipson Cole, whose devotion, dedication and hard work to expand the mission of the organization have earned our respect and love. Memorial Service at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church to be announced. Dr. Ruth Alward, Board President Friedhilde Milburn, Executive Director

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FINOVA GROUP INC., Phoenix, a financial services company, said it would delay its first-quarter earnings report for a second time, until May 7, and restate results for prior years to resolve accounting issues raised by its auditor.

title: Today's Big Schools Polarize Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Central Food: No End to the Delays
description: TWO years ago Ilgar Peker signed a lease to open a branch of his restaurant, the Turkish Kitchen, at the glamorous new Grand Central Terminal. Like the other restaurateurs on the lower level of the terminal, he expected to open in October 1998, when the building was rededicated.

title: Casting Nihilistic Pearls From His Lofty Perch
description: His cold, hooded eyes gazing calmly into the void, traces of a bitter smile flickering around his withered lips, the author Paul Bowles, in Jennifer Baichwal's compelling documentary portrait, dispenses pearls of nihilistic observation like a sadistic oracle whose purpose is to extinguish fleeting hopes.

title: The Pop Life; Big Dreams And Short Shorts
description: Let's administer a test. In the spring and summer, major record companies roll out records by their latest pop contenders, hoping that by Christmas they can turn a newcomer into a superstar. Below are a few such up-and-coming acts executives say they are banking on this year, investing from hundreds of thousands to millions of dollars in promotional campaigns in hopes that record buyers will take notice.

title: I.B.M. INCREASES DIVIDEND AND AUTHORIZES A BUYBACK
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer maker, raised its dividend 9 percent yesterday and authorized a $3.5 billion stock buyback. I.B.M. raised its dividend to 24 cents a share from 22 cents, the first increase in a year and the fourth in four years. The dividend, payable June 10 to shareholders of record as of May 10, coupled with I.B.M.'s ninth buyback since 1995 are moves by the chairman, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., to reward investors who have stayed with the company. The shares, which have risen eightfold since Mr. Gerstner took over in April 1993, rose $2.125, to $212, a record close.

title: Zolak to Be Backup
description: Scott Zolak, a backup quarterback to Drew Bledsoe under Bill Parcells with New England, rejoined Parcells in the same role with the Jets yesterday when the team officially announced Zolak's signing as a backup to Vinny Testaverde.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILL, MARIE A.
description: BILL-Marie A., on April 27, 1999 of Garden City, N.Y. Beloved wife of Edmund. Loving mother of Helen B. Casey and the late Edmund G. Jr. Cherished grandmother of Richard C. Casey Jr. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th St., Garden City, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City, Thursday 10am. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Calvary Hospital 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461, appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about violence in East Timor misstated the year the territory was annexed by Indonesia. It was 1976, not 1996.

title: Yashin Goes Quietly As Buffalo Advances
description: SABRES 4, SENATORS 3

title: People
description: * Gini Talmadge, vice president for marketing and sales at Upside Media Inc., San Francisco, was named president, a new position, and publisher, assuming that title from David Bunnell, who remains chief executive and editor.

title: America Online Reports That Net Tripled
description: Continuing its vigorous growth, America Online Inc. reported profits of $420 million for the first three months of the year, a figure that included a number of one-time items.

title: The Name, but Not the Decor, Is Familiar
description: DEAR David Liederman:

title: NATO Bombs Reported to Kill 20 Civilians in Southern Serbia
description: Belgrade experienced heavy NATO bombing early this morning, hours after NATO bombs had killed at least 20 civilians in the southern Serbian city of Surdulica, Serbian state television and Western news agencies said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAHN, MARTIN I.
description: HAHN-Martin I. The New York Power Squadron announces with sadness the death on April 25th of Past Commander Martin I. Hahn in his 92nd year. Commander Hahn, who had been a member of the New York Squadron for 62 years, will be missed for his leadership and warmth. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, April 28 at 7:15PM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Cdr. Sidney White Cdr.-Elect David Zeller

title: Another Tempestuous Night in Leenane (Sure, It's Not a Morn in Spring)
description: Ah, the sounds of the Irish countryside: the patter of rain, the lowing of cattle, the gentle hiss of scalding human flesh. Welcome back to Leenane, that quaint rural town where the skies are always gray, the people are always angry, and domestic homicide and mutilation are the No. 1 recreational activities.

title: Bout Set at Garden
description: At 6 feet 7 inches and 250 pounds, with a size 18 neck, Michael Grant of Norristown, Pa., looks like a big small forward or a king-sized tight end. Instead, at 26 and with a 29-0 record, he is probably boxing's best heavyweight prospect, and he will defend the North American Boxing Federation's title June 19 against Lou Savarese (39-2) of the Bronx at the Theater at Madison Square Garden.

title: DuPont's Profit Down 4.2% in Quarter
description: The DuPont Company, the nation's biggest chemicals company, said today that its first-quarter profit fell 4.2 percent, less than expected, helped by a rebound in demand from Asia and lower costs of raw materials.

title: Patience on Kosovo?
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Out of the Bronx, Cookies Inspired by Africa

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOLYA, ANDREW
description: LLOLYA-Andrew. The New York City Ballet Orchestra deeply mourns the loss of our principal flutist, Andrew Llolya. His artistry and dedication to our orchestra will be sorely missed. New York City Ballet Orchestra

title: Lawmakers Drop Plea to Be Paid Now Despite Budget Deadlock
description: A group of legislators who are suing over a law that withholds their paychecks during budget negotiations dropped a request today for a restraining order that would force the state to resume paying them immediately.

title: Justices Wrestling With the Definition of Disability: Is It Glasses? False Teeth?
description: The Supreme Court began grappling today with the definition of disability, in the first of three cases that raise the question of whether a person who can restore normal functioning by taking a daily pill, wearing glasses or even strapping on an artificial limb can be considered disabled, and therefore protected against discrimination on that account under Federal law.

title: City Gardens Endure
description: To the Editor:

title: Marketing of Cloned Beef in Japan Unsettles Many Consumers
description: The Japanese Government says at least 66 head of cloned cattle have been slaughtered and sold on the beef market in Japan, raising concerns among consumers about the safety of the meat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTER, STANLEY D.
description: CANTER-Stanley D., 75. April 24, 1999. He was a man of great dignity and modesty, of elegant taste, intellectual clarity and profound generosity. His thoughtfulness, his kindness, his concern for those he loved and who loved him knew no bounds. His passions for music and painting enriched his life and ours. The world has lost a rare breed of man.

title: Hospital Officials Say Mother Endangered Baby
description: The mother of a hospitalized 3-month-old boy was charged yesterday with assaulting and endangering him after hospital officials in Brooklyn caught her on videotape interfering with his medical treatment, the police said.

title: Yoshii Losing His Grip On Spot in the Rotation
description: When Masato Yoshii was booed off the Shea Stadium field last night he knew he would have company. One of the first teammates to console him in the dugout was Bobby Bonilla, the target of choice for frustrated Mets fans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSCOMB, CAROLINE KNOWLTON
description: LIPSCOMB-Caroline Knowlton of Charleston, SC died April 26, 1999 at her residence. Funeral services will be held at 10:00 AM, Friday, April 30th, 1999 in St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Charleston. Burial directed by J. Henry Stuhr, Inc. will be in Elmwood Cemetery, Columbia, SC. She is survived by two daughters; Caroline L. Winn of New York City and Claudia L. Douglass of Galletin, TN.; one son: Charles Thomas Lipscomb III of Dallas, Texas; Five grandchildren; one sister: Claudia K. Finlay of Columbia, SC. Memorials may be made to St. Michael's Episcopal Church, 14 St. Michael's Alley, Charleston, S.C. 29401.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THROOP, BARBARA WILLIAMS
description: THROOP-Barbara Williams. Formerly of Lawrence, NY, beloved wife of the late Enos Thompson Throop, IV, daughter of Thomas Resolved Williams, died on April 26, 1999 in St. Michaels, MD. Mrs. Throop graduated from St. Timothy's School in 1931. An avid squash player, she represented the United States internationally, defeating Britain's top-seated player in the Wolfe-Noel Cup Competition in 1937. She is survived by her two sons, Enos Thompson Throop V, of St. Michaels, MD and Garrow Throop of Newtonville, MA, and two grandchildren, Julia and Nicholas Throop. Services will be held at 11:00 AM on Friday, April 30, at Trinity-St. Johns Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the U.S. Driving for the Disabled, Inc., P.O. Box 264, Jarrettsville, MD 21084 would be appreciated.

title: Is the Internet Igniting Violence?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Not by Its Cover, But by Its Title?
description: If you walked into a bookstore and saw the title ''Trimalchio* in West Egg'' would you be seduced into grabbing it off the shelf? How about ''The High-Bouncing Lover''? Perhaps a bit more alluring and at least fathomable. Or ''Gold-Hatted Gatsby.'' Closer maybe, but it doesn't sing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATE, IDA LOUISE
description: PATE-Ida Louise, 83, died April 26, in North Branford, CT. Mother of Carlton O. Pate III, William T. Pate, Louise Pate Perdew, sister of Beatrice Allen Tobey, Grandmother of five. Services will be held at 10:00 A.M. Saturday, May 1, in Christ Church Chapel, 254 East Putnam Ave, Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, ETHEL
description: HERMAN-Ethel. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Michael and Nancy Herman and Francine and Murray Frischer. Cherished grandmother of Irene and Laurence Herman and Mitchell and Lynda Frischer. Service ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. today, 9:30AM.

title: Economic Scene; A soft-spoken plan for global reform that lacks a big stick.
description: TREASURY Secretary Robert E. Rubin's proposal for reforming international financial institutions, announced on the eve of this week's gathering of the world's finance officials in Washington, was greeted mostly with yawns. His ideas were described as modest or cautious -- tinkering in a financially hazardous world that cries out for bold architectural overhaul.

title: Callers to 911 System Find Random Delay
description: Some calls to the city's 911 emergency response system were inexplicably delayed for about 10 to 30 seconds yesterday, city and phone company officials said, but the calls were ultimately connected and the system was never completely out of service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, ARTHUR
description: ABRAMS-Arthur. The Board of Directors and Staff of The American Friends of the Israel Museum, and of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem, mourn the sudden death of Arthur Abrams, beloved father of our esteemed President, Judy Steinhardt. He will be deeply missed by the Israel Museum family. Our heartfelt condolences to Ruth Abrams, Judy and Michael Steinhardt, Ellen Abrams and Rick Stossel, Annie and John Lutz, grandchildren and great-grandchild. Maureen Cogan, Int'l Chmn. James Snyder, Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir., I M Carolyn Cohen, Exec. Dir., AFIM

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell against the Japanese currency after economic reports suggested that Japan's economy may be emerging from recession. In New York, the dollar settled at 119.22 yen, down from 120.40 on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, ALFRED J., M.D.
description: BERGER-Alfred J., M.D. of Delray Beach, Fl. died April 26, 1999. A graduate of Harvard Medical School, he retired in 1986. He is survived by his wife Page, and his son Robert B. (Buzz) Berger of Princeton, and daughter Barbara Berger of Larchmont, four grand children, and his sister Charlotte Feinswog of Bal Harbor, Fl.

title: PPG TO BUY AUTO PAINT UNITS FOR $684 MILLION
description: PPG Industries, the world's No. 2 maker of auto paint, agreed yesterday to buy the vehicle-coatings businesses of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. of London for $684 million, moving to keep pace with acquisitions by the DuPont Company. PPG, which is based in Pittsburgh, will buy auto-repair paint units that had combined 1998 sales of $459 million. Imperial Chemical, the world's fourth-largest chemical company, will have a pretax gain of $:190 million ($307 million). The purchase bolsters PPG in the $5.5 billion vehicle-repair paint industry, after DuPont became the No. 1 maker of auto paints in March with its purchase of Hoechst A.G.'s Herberts unit. I.C.I.'s American depository receipts rose $1.8125, to $44. PPG shares rose $2.375, to $61.875.

title: What Can We Do About Web Hate?; No Need for Bans
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAHN, MARTIN I.
description: HAHN-Martin I. The New York Power Squadron announces with sadness the death on April 25th of Past Commander Martin I. Hahn in his 92nd year. Commander Hahn, who had been a member of the New York Squadron for 62 years, will be missed for his leadership and warmth. A memorial service was held Wednesday, April 28 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel. Cdr. Sidney White Cdr.-Elect David Zeller

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, ELMA PHILLIPSON
description: COLE-Elma Phillipson. The Board of Directors of James Lenox House Association mourns the death of our beloved board member and former President Elma Phillipson Cole, whose devotion, dedication and hard work to expand the mission of the organization have earned our respect and love. Memorial Service at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Wednesday, May 5, 11am, Dana Chapel. Dr. Ruth Alward, Board President Friedhilde Milburn, Executive Director

title: An Air War Can Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesians, Nervously but Eagerly, Prepare for Free Election
description: Indonesia is holding its breath. Ready or not, it is about to leap into the second phase of its transition from 32 years of dictatorship with an election -- just six weeks away -- that will shape the post-Suharto era.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWN, DAVID
description: DAWN-David. The Board and Staff of The New York Botanical Garden note with sadness the death of David Dawn. He was one of the nation's premier rose growers and a generous leader of the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden Committee. We offer our deep sympathy to his wife Helga and their family. Thomas J. Hubbard, Chairman Gregory Long, President

title: What Can We Do About Web Hate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Hear Cases on Vision Disability
description: The Supreme Court continued an unusually intensive review of the Americans With Disabilities Act today as the Justices struggled to find a definition of disability that would be faithful to the law without also sweeping everyone with a readily correctable physical problem into its protective net.

title: Laser Bomb Missed Target And Hit Houses, NATO Says
description: NATO acknowledged today that at least one laser-guided bomb had missed its intended military target Tuesday afternoon and exploded in a neighborhood of civilian houses in southern Serbia. Yugoslav authorities, who reported the incident last night, said 20 people had been killed.

title: Capturing the Kindness of the Dalai Lama
description: ''I'm not one for causes unless it's film preservation,'' Martin Scorsese observes dryly near the end of Michael Henry Wilson's documentary film, ''In Search of Kundun With Martin Scorsese.'' Then he hesitantly adds: ''But compassion and love are the only way to go. The other way is violence.'' The director's remarks illustrate the degree to which the making of ''Kundun,'' his empathetic biography of the early life of the 14th Dalai Lama, was a labor of devotion and perhaps a kind of atonement for some of the more brutal imagery in movies like ''Mean Streets'' and ''Goodfellas.''

title: British Aerospace Discussing Joint European Missile Venture
description: British Aerospace P.L.C., the British military giant, acknowledged today that it was exploring a deal with French and Italian companies to create a European missile industry to challenge Raytheon of the United States, the global leader in missile manufacturing.

title: Seoul Journal; Out at Last, Prisoner 3514 Catches Up on 40 Years
description: For four decades in prison, Woo Yong Gak coolly handled just about every challenge life could throw at him, from the most brutal tortures to endless spells of solitary confinement.

title: From Cookies to Catered Photo Shoots
description: When Nigel Briand, an Australian architect in New York, was asked to design Milk Studios, a complex of four photo studios and a cafe in a 40,000-square-foot section of a West Village building, he knew what to do.

title: Jazz Festival's New Name And an Internet Concept
description: This year's alternative summer jazz festival has a new sponsor and a new concept.

title: More Scrutiny Is Sought for Firms That Run or Lend to Hedge Funds
description: Worried that Wall Street will soon forget its brush with financial meltdown six months ago, Federal regulators are proposing to further scrutinize the trading practices of investment banks and closely examine the books of private investment funds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILL, MARIE A.
description: BILL-Marie A., on April 27, 1999 of Garden City, N.Y. Beloved wife of Edmund. Loving mother of Helen B. Casey and the late Edmund G. Jr. Cherished grandmother of Richard C. Casey Jr. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City, Thursday 10am. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Calvary Hospital 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461, appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARPENTER, DAVID LYON
description: CARPENTER-David Lyon, 75, of Kinnelon, on April 22, 1999. Employed as an executive for Johns Manville Corporation. He was a graduate of Yale University. He also attended the Woodward School and Brooklyn Poly Prep. Husband of Joan (nee Bruce) Carpenter; father of Jon, David W. Carpenter and Jennifer Rizzo; step-father of Jacqueline Lutman. Brother of Robert, Marion Lockwood, and Ruth Carpenter. Also 4 grandchildren. Memorial service Saturday, 11:00 AM, at Saint David's Episcopal Church, Kinnelon. In Lieu of flowers, donations to the church at 91 Kinnelon Road, Kinnelon, N.J. 07405 would be appreciated. Information: The Morrison Funeral Home, 86 Bartholdi Avenue, Butler, New Jersey.

title: CISCO TO BUY AMTEVA TECHNOLOGIES FOR $170 MILLION
description: The computer-networking giant Cisco Systems Inc. of San Jose, Calif., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Amteva Technologies Inc. for about $170 million. Amteva, a closely held company with 144 employees based in Glen Allen, Va., is a maker of ''middleware,'' which sits between a company's data base systems and its Web site, allowing different applications and computers to communicate and work together. Cisco's routers, hubs, switches and controlling software are used by companies and Internet service providers to manage electronic traffic in computer networks.

title: Aetna Profit Rose 15% in Quarter
description: Aetna Inc., the nation's biggest health insurer, said today that its first-quarter earnings rose 15 percent, more than expected, as it raised premiums on employer health plans and shed unprofitable Medicare business.

title: Two Fillies Among 20 in Kentucky Derby
description: A full field of 20 horses was entered today in the 125th Kentucky Derby and, for the first time in 15 years, it included two fillies, Three Ring and Excellent Meeting, who was named half of the favored entry with her stablemate General Challenge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLUB, ROSLYN
description: GOLUB-Roslyn. On April 28, 1999. Loving friend and dear cousin. She will always be remembered. Service Friday, 11:30 AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn (near Ave. V).

title: Inside an Accident of War: Sirens. Blast. Grief.
description: ''We grew up together,'' said Momir Andjelkovic, his eyes veined and red, staring fixedly at the green, encircling hills. ''He was my finest friend.''

title: Back Button On the Blink?
description: Q. When I was surfing the Web, I noticed that the Back button on my browser was ''grayed out,'' and when I closed that window, I saw that several more windows were open underneath. Is something wrong with my software?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AUDITORE, STEPHEN
description: AUDITORE-Stephen. April 23, 1999. To know Stephen was to love Stephen and I always will. Adieu.

title: China's Press Says Rally by Sect Was 'Completely Wrong'
description: The official Chinese press broke its silence today on a recent demonstration in Beijing by more than 10,000 followers of a spiritual movement, calling the gathering ''completely wrong.''

title: Corporate Conduct Code Is Proposed for Third World Nations
description: Corporations around the world will be encouraged to offer employees stock-ownership plans and other profit-sharing incentives under a new code of good corporate conduct that finance ministers from 29 industrial countries are expected to endorse next month.

title: Man Is Pushed In the Subway And Loses Legs
description: In a scene witnessed by scores of horrified commuters, a Bronx man had both of his legs severed yesterday when he was pushed in front of an oncoming subway train in a midtown station at the height of the evening rush hour, officials said.

title: BECTON DICKINSON TO BUY CLONTECH LABS FOR $200 MILLION
description: Becton Dickinson & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Clontech Laboratories Inc., a closely held gene-based drug discovery and molecular biology research company, for $200 million in stock. Becton Dickinson, which is based in Franklin Lakes, N.J., is a medical supplies and diagnostic products company with 1998 revenue of $3.1 billion. Clontech, in Palo Alto, Calif., has 330 employees and posted 1998 revenue of $47.8 million. Since 1994, Clontech's sales have been growing at a compounded annual rate of 33 percent. Becton Dickinson shares fell $1.6875, to $39.125.

title: Infidelity Comes Out Of the Closet
description: OVER the course of his 12-year marriage, Bob M., a 40-year-old executive from Annapolis, Md., had racked up a considerable extramarital track record. One night in bed, his wife, Bernadette, 39, asked him whether he had ever strayed, and Bob, sick of the deception, confirmed her worst suspicions. Two months later, their marriage held together with prayer and Scotch tape, Bob and Bernadette, who, to protect their privacy, spoke on the condition that their full names not be used, went to their first session with Frederick DiBlasio, a therapist and professor of social work at the University of Maryland.

title: A Way to Answer Calls on Line Despite a Single Phone Line
description: Each Internet user with a single telephone line is always plagued by the suspicion that an important caller is trying to get through while the modem is hogging the phone connection. Now such surfers can develop a special form of multitasking anxiety.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about recent purchases of stock by directors of Chock Full o'Nuts referred incompletely to the circumstances under which a director, Henry Salzhauer, sold shares he had purchased in August 1998, when the board was considering a takeover offer from Sara Lee. Mr. Salzhauer says his purchase resulted from a longstanding order, placed in February 1997, to buy if the price fell to a certain level. When Mr. Salzhauer learned that the order was automatically carried out in August 1998, he told the company of the improper purchase and sold the shares at a loss.

title: Gun Control Advocates Split on Tactics for Goals
description: Gun control groups have seized on the mass shooting at Columbine High School as a new opportunity to gain command of the nation's firearms debate, but the moment has also intensified long-running divisions among the allies over the best way to reduce deaths from firearms.

title: Lewinsky Is Presence At Magazine Awards
description: To borrow a phrase from the world of psychotherapy, at yesterday's National Magazine Awards it seemed at times that the magazine world was trying to reach closure on the issue that dominated magazine covers over the last year: the Presidential intern.

title: Sheriff's Department Struggles in Spotlight
description: The shootings at a Colorado high school have put Sheriff John P. Stone and his modest-sized department under close and at times embarrassing scrutiny. There have been misstatements by the sheriff, criticism that complaints about one of the gunmen, Eric Harris, were ignored, and that a SWAT team was slow to enter the school after the attack.

title: Morgan a Journeyman, Emphasis on Journey
description: Mike Morgan speaks as rapidly as he pitches, firing one thought after another, rushing through conversation and changing topics as quickly and seamlessly as he has changed teams.

title: Looking at People, Seeing Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MYRA
description: FRIEDMAN-Myra. On April 27th, 1999. Beloved daughter of Ivan and the late Eva Kulick. Loving mother of Norman, Robert and Hal. Dear sister of Sandra Hecht and Roy Kulick. Cherished grandmother to seven grandchildren. Services Thursday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: The Uncertain Lineage of Giuliani's 'Blown Up' Remark
description: Though it may never be known whether Robert F. Wagner Jr., once the president of the Board of Education, ever said that the city school system should be ''blown up,'' he was known to express similar sentiments, particularly about the board's central bureaucracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGER, VICTOR
description: SAGER-Victor. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Victor Sager, a dedicated contributor and cherished friend. His brother and sister-in-law, Irving and Dorothy Sager, are deeply committed to Jewish and humanitarian causes through their generous support of our Real Estate Division. We extend our sincerest condolences to Irving and Dorothy; Victor's children, Linda, Wendy, Lawri, Jinny, Andrew, and Richard; and the entire Sager family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Andrew J. Singer, Chair, Real Estate Division Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: If You Can Stand the Ads, The Voice-Mail Service Is Free
description: A free voice-mail system is now available to anyone with the patience to listen to advertising spots over the phone. The system, called Echobuzz, is aimed at teen-agers -- a market that just might be willing to endure the advertising in exchange for a place to leave messages that can't be heard by Mom or Dad.

title: Executive Changes
description: ASARCO INC., New York, named Francis R. McAllister chairman and chief executive, succeeding Richard J. Osborne, who retired. Kevin R. Morano succeeds Mr. McAllister as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Morano had been chief financial officer.

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: U.S. EASES POLICY ON SOME SANCTIONS
description: The Clinton Administration announced today that it had decided to ease its sanctions policy to permit the sale of food and medical supplies to Iran, Libya, Sudan and other nations accused of supporting terrorists.

title: A German-Italian Merger
description: The economic integration of Western Europe, as signified by the common euro currency, was designed in part to help European businesses unify to become world-class competitors that could compete with giant American companies. A merger of Deutsche Telekom and Telecom Italia is unlikely to produce such a company.

title: Clemens May Miss Two Weeks
description: Roger Clemens continued to receive treatment for his strained left hamstring today, and the Yankees probably will not know until Thursday whether he will be able to make his next scheduled start Sunday, or if he must go on the 15-day disabled list.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, HOWARD A.
description: MARKS-Howard A. On April 27, 1999. Of Searingtown, L.I. Beloved husband of Lorene; devoted father of Michael and Yvonne, Brian and Lynne, Jeffrey and Jill; dear brother of Florence Lando and Sis Schneider; loving grandfather of Jennifer, Amy, Melanie, Kelli, Madeline, Shelby, Aaron and Julia. Services Thursday 12 Noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I. Donations can be made to either Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, N.Y. 11590 or Whittingham Cancer Center, Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, CT. 06856.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ANACOMP INC., Poway, Calif., a provider of document imaging services, will sell its Magnetics Solutions division to an investment consortium led by Windward Capital for $47.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLITZ, MURRAY
description: BLITZ-Murray. The Officers, Board of Directors, and Members of Engineers Country Club mourn the passing of their beloved member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the Blitz family.

title: What Can We Do About Web Hate?; Citizenship Nostrum
description: To the Editor:

title: De Niro and Miramax Plan a Film Studio at the Brooklyn Navy Yard
description: The actor Robert De Niro and Miramax Films plan to announce a tentative deal with city officials to build a $150 million Hollywood-style film studio at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the sprawling complex where tens of thousands of workers once built and launched warships and tankers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSCOMB, CAROLINE KNOWLTON
description: LIPSCOMB-Caroline Knowlton. Of Charleston, SC died April 26, 1999 at her residence. Funeral services will be held at 10:00 AM, Friday, April 30th, 1999 in St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Charleston. Burial directed by J. Henry Stuhr, Inc. will be in Elmwood Cemetery, Columbia, SC. She is survived by two daughters; Caroline L. Winn of New York City and Claudia L. Douglass of Galletin, TN.; one son: Charles Thomas Lipscomb III of Dallas, Texas; Five grandchildren; Charles Winn of Charlotte, NC, Cullen Douglass, and Andrew Douglass both of Nashville, TN, Ashley Buczik of Deleware, and William Lipscomb of NYC; one sister: Claudia K. Finlay of Columbia, SC. Memorials may be made to St. Michael's Episcopal Church, 14 St. Michael's Alley, Charleston, S.C. 29401.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKSBURG, ALVIN BRENT (AKA BLACKIE)
description: BLACKSBURG-Alvin Brent (aka Blackie). Died April 14, 1999. Friendship always came first. He met everyone on the level. Mason since May 24, 1960. Worshipful Master of Arcana Lodge, 1975. Past Assistant Grand Lecturer. Ritualist. Chemical Engineer. Lawyer. Chief Assistant District Attorney, Queens County-Rackets. Catholic Lawyers Guild-Board of Directors. Member, Brandeis Society. Judicial Review Board Member. A leader by example. A tireless worker. Role model, nonconformist, irreverent type, religious man. A genius with common sense, who shunned the spotlight. A precedent-setting lawyer. A champion of logic who could see through the superfluities of life. He loved family, friendship, food and the Yankees. Brother to Les, father of Michael, Shane and Jason. Husband and best friend of Sue Blacksburg. A man who was loved, admired and just plain fun to be with!

title: HUGHES COMPLETES $1.36 BILLION PRIMESTAR PURCHASE
description: Overcoming objections of bondholders who threatened to kill the sale, the Hughes Electronics Corporation completed its $1.36 billion purchase yesterday of most of Primestar Inc., the No. 2 United States satellite-TV company after Hughes's own DirecTV unit. Primestar agreed to raise its payout to creditors to about 97.5 cents on the dollar, from 67 cents. The payment consists of 85 cents in cash plus stock appreciation rights in Hughes shares for holders of $475 million of Primestar bonds and institutions that made a $350 million bridge loan to the company. The closing followed weeks of intense and sometimes contentious negotiations between Primestar and its creditors.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Principals Over Politics

title: An Art Book on Physics? Yup, With the Details
description: PHYSICS IN THE 20TH CENTURY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEFLORIO, JEANN. ''A.J.'' (CARBALLO)
description: DeFLORIO-Jeann. ''A.J.'' (Carballo), April 26, 1999, predeceased by her husband, Richard Carballo; beloved sister of Diane and Richard Dugan. Jeann was one of the top five make-up artists in New York City. A service will be celebrated in New York City at a later date, time to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINKLER, ROY
description: WINKLER-Roy. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved Life member Roy Winkler. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: New Reports of Charred Bodies in a Kosovo Town
description: United Nations officials said today that the latest group of refugees entering Albania from Kosovo -- almost exclusively women, old men and children -- are giving consistent reports of what appears to have been a mass execution near the city of Djakovica.

title: New Jersey Troopers Use Hotel Staffs in Drug War
description: In an aggressive effort to catch drug smugglers, New Jersey state troopers have quietly enlisted workers at hotels along the New Jersey Turnpike to tip them off about suspicious guests who pay for rooms in cash, make frequent phone calls or simply speak Spanish, according to participants in the program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, MILDRED
description: SILVER-Mildred. On April 27, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Solomon Silver. Cherished aunt and great aunt. Services were held privately.

title: Look, Ma, No Keyboard: It's One Hand Typing
description: COMPUTERS continue to shrink successfully, but not their keyboards. On the tiny keyboards of handheld computers, efficient touch typing remains a distant dream.

title: Clinton's Quandary: No Approach to End War Is Fast or Certain of Success
description: Five weeks into the NATO bombing of Yugoslavia, the Clinton Administration is faced with three choices in the Kosovo war, all disagreeable: an open-ended air campaign, the dispatch of ground troops, or compromise in a diplomatic solution.

title: In America; Unmasking Poverty
description: The cities have not been in the news much lately. Crime is down, unemployment is down and the ghettos are not burning down. What's to cover?

title: Metro Business; Power for Venezuela
description: Public Service Enterprise Group of Newark and Corporacion Industrial de Energia have said they will build three power plants and accompanying electric lines in Venezuela for $140 million.

title: Game Makers on the Defensive After the Columbine Shootings
description: In the aftermath of the killings of 12 students and a teacher in Littleton, Colo., last week, many commentators and some parents are wondering aloud about what influence -- if any -- video games may have had on the actions of the two gunmen, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold. Not surprisingly, video game manufacturers are reluctant to be drawn into the debate.

title: BB&T IN $500 MILLION DEAL FOR FIRST LIBERTY FINANCIAL
description: The BB&T Corporation said it would buy the First Liberty Financial Corporation for $500 million in stock. BB&T, which will have offices from northern Maryland to southern Georgia after completing four pending bank purchases, agreed to pay 0.825 share of its stock for each First Liberty share, valuing the bank at $33.25 a share. First Liberty shares rose 33 percent, gaining $7.8125, to $31.0625, while shares of BB&T, which is based in Winston-Salem, N.C., slipped 25 cents, to $39. First Liberty, in Macon, Ga., has $1.7 billion in assets and 39 branches. BB&T has $37.8 billion in assets and 581 branches.

title: Co-Founder Departs The Dweck Agency
description: Lori Campbell, who formed Dweck & Campbell Inc. in New York in 1993 with Michael Dweck, said yesterday that she had left the agency, which is now known as Dweck Inc.

title: Giuliani and Schools Chief Continue Feud at Arm's Length
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that he intended to keep working in New York despite tensions with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, as the Mayor repeatedly declined to say that he still had confidence in him.

title: Canadian School Shooting Kills Student and Wounds One; 14-Year-Old Boy Is Held
description: A 14-year-old boy shot two students at a Canadian high school yesterday, killing one, the police said. It was the most serious of many incidents in which young people have been charged with stockpiling weapons or preparing to use them at their schools after the shooting in Littleton, Colo., last week.

title: Kazakhstan Backs Russia on Kosovo
description: Kazakhstan, a former Soviet republic, is one of the most Asian of the Partnership for Peace countries that met last weekend with their NATO counterparts in Washington. Reaching from the Caspian Sea to China, it covers five times the area of France. President Nursultan Nazarbayev, who has been praised for maintaining stability in his country but increasingly criticized for autocratic rule, spoke in Washington to Brian Knowlton of the International Herald Tribune about his view, and the impact on Russia, of the Kosovo crisis.

title: For Women at Harvard, Little Has Changed
description: To the Editor:

title: New On-Line Offers At Morgan Stanley
description: Discover Brokerage Direct, the on-line unit of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, will begin this week to offer some customers access to shares in initial public offerings handled by Morgan Stanley.

title: Duke Ellington's Centennial
description: One hundred years ago today, Duke Ellington was born in Washington D.C., and if every city or town where he and his band performed during his lifetime were to commemorate him by hearing a song of his again, the earth would resonate with music. It should not be possible, today of all days, to walk down Broadway or look out over the rooftops of Harlem without hearing in the streets the sound of an Ellington composition. But even if you have to listen in your own mind, you will hear, if you listen closely, the echo of a pulse he memorialized again and again in music.

title: Panel Will Ask U.S. to Restrict Some Gambling
description: A Federal commission is preparing to recommend to Congress and the President a moratorium on gambling expansion and more Federal regulation of the giant casinos on Indian reservations.

title: Four Officers in Diallo Killing Are to Return to Modified Duty
description: The four police officers charged with murdering Amadou Diallo will return to modified duty by the end of this week, when their 30-day suspensions expire, officials said yesterday.

title: Paper and Chemical Issues Send Dow to One More High
description: Chemical, paper and other stocks sensitive to the business cycle turned in another strong performance yesterday while technology and other longtime market leaders sagged.

title: Questions Are Raised About Second Concrete Supplier
description: Last month, the Giuliani administration banned the Empire Transit Mix Company from supplying concrete for the renovation of City Hall Park after learning that Empire was affiliated with another company that had been disqualified from obtaining city contracts because of integrity problems.

title: Charles H. Pillard, 80; Led Electricians Union
description: Charles H. Pillard, the strong-willed president of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers for two decades, died on Monday in a hospital in Buffalo. He was 80 and had lived in Orchard Park, N.Y., a suburb of Buffalo, since 1988.

title: U.N. Panel Votes for Ban on Death Penalty
description: The United Nations Human Rights Commission voted 30-to-11 today in favor of a worldwide moratorium on executions, with 12 countries abstaining.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about screening for Canavan Disease, an inherited neurological disorder, misstated the risk of a child's contracting the illness when both parents are carriers. The risk is 1 in 4, not 1 in 6,400.

title: Unions File Complaint Against Merit Pay Plan
description: Six unions representing nearly 60,000 state employees announced yesterday that they had filed a complaint with the state Public Employment Relations Commission to block Gov. Chistine Todd Whitman's plan to impose a merit-based pay system.

title: AT&T in Record $30 Billion Loan Pact
description: The AT&T Corporation, the No. 1 United States long-distance phone company, has arranged a record $30 billion loan agreement with 18 lenders two days ahead of schedule.

title: Kurds Are Determined to Restore TV Station Shut by the British
description: Although the British authorities have shut down the world's sole Kurdish-language television station, its director has vowed to find a way to bring it back to life.

title: A Home Page Away From Home
description: KRISTINA JOHNSON and David Franke are circumnavigating the world, taking in sights as remote as the glaciers of New Zealand and the mountains of Nepal. But don't assume that this couple have dropped off the map.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAHM, JOSEPH BAKST, PH.D.
description: ZAHM-Joseph Bakst, Ph.D. Of New Rochelle, formerly of Manhattan, on April 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Ann Berry Zahm, loving father of Noah William Zahm, dear brother of David Leon Zahm. There will be a memorial gathering at the family's home on Thursday, April 29, after 6 PM, Saturday and Sunday, May 1 and 2, after 3 PM. Friends who wish may contribute to the Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St, Tuckahoe, NY 10707 in his memory. Please call Westchester Funeral Home, Inc. for more information, 914-337-4585.

title: Toll Rise Necessary, Turnpike Official Says
description: The New Jersey Turnpike's top official said yesterday that tolls could be raised more than 20 percent over five years to pay for roadway improvements, a move that Democrats warned would increase truck traffic on local streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, NATHAN
description: HARRIS-Nathan, age 95, jeweler. Retired president of B. Harris and Sons, Jewelers, originally established as the first retail jewelry store on West 47th Street in 1926, died last Monday at the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, CT. Together with his late brother, Charles, he owned and lovingly piloted one of the leading antique jewelry establishments in NYC for nearly seven decades, striving always to provide the right object for the right occasion, at a reasonable price consistent with the high quality of the merchandise, and his clientele included many of the artistic, literary, musical and theatrical leading lights of the time. The store, evolving through later reincarnations on East 48 and East 61 Streets, finally closed in 1991 with his retirement. He was as well a rare chamber musician, occupying first violin chair in his ''Tanglefoot String Quartet'' for some sixty years of joyous amateur music-making. Born on Thanksvgiving Day 1903, he was a liferaft and an anchor for many, at a time when there are few human heroes. When asked what mattered to him most, he said, ''Each day, to give meaning to the lives touched by mine.'' He will be sorely missed by many. Mr. Harris' wife, the former Denah Josephson, predeceased him in 1993. He is survived by a son and a daughter, Michael Harris of Easton, CT., and Susan Harris of Bridgeport, CT.

title: Keeping a High Profile In Cases Against Police; Legal Team Shadows the Prosecution
description: Just hours after the four police officers accused of killing Amadou Diallo were arraigned on murder charges late last month, a team of lawyers convened before television cameras in lower Manhattan and made their case against the officers.

title: DaimlerChrysler Has 23% Rise in Profits
description: Fueled by strong vehicle sales in the United States and healthy heavy-truck sales, DaimlerChrysler A.G. reported today that first-quarter profits increased by 23 percent, exceeding some analysts' forecasts.

title: A Potential 'Girl-cott' Imperils Grand Slams
description: If the Grand Slams don't pay, they won't play. Tired of receiving second-class treatment on the payrolls of three of the sport's four Grand Slams, the women who make their living from professional tennis may resort to a boycott to bite the hand that feeds them -- but feeds the men more -- if the three shallow-pocketed Slams don't make a millennial motion toward equality.

title: Web Surfers' Fears Prompt Privacy Seals
description: DEBATES over on-line privacy have led to the proliferation of seal-of-approval programs designed to signal privacy protection. Like the presence of a Good Housekeeping seal, which is supposed to designate a worthwhile product, the privacy seals are displayed by Web sites to indicate that they have met standards of trustworthiness.

title: Essay; The Deadliest Download
description: During President Clinton's watch, America's most vital nuclear secrets -- guarded intensely for five decades -- have been allowed to spill out all over the world.

title: Bittersweet Times for Collectors of Laser Disk Movies
description: WHEN they outgrew the shelves, Bill Griffin put them in crates, and finally in stacks on the floor of his home. He has amassed about 4,000 titles since he began collecting movies in 1983. ''I generally have a sense of what I own,'' he said, ''but locating it is a problem.''

title: Crease in Pinstripes: A Zimmer-Coach Clash, and Team Meets
description: Don Zimmer has maintained all along that he never wanted to manage the Yankees, that he is doing so only because Joe Torre, a close friend, asked him to take over. He must have been wondering tonight if it is worth the aggravation, after an 8-6 loss to Texas and an unhappy exchange with a coach that prompted a post-game team meeting.

title: Versailles Befouled
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Send A Message For Three Quarters
description: For three quarters, the Nets defied the odds. With precision, hustle and heart, they put a team fighting desperately for playoff position in jeopardy. Perhaps that is all one can ask of a club that is bereft of healthy big men and playing for nothing more than pride.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHILL, JAMES M.
description: CAHILL-James M. April 25, at age 89. Funeral mass, 10 AM, Friday, at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Outshining the Flames
description: Fu Tung Cheng, a kitchen designer in Berkeley, Calif., designs one-of-a-kind range hoods for his customers. Last year he began offering hoods to the public.

title: Inflation vs. Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Recalling a Composer's Two Sides, Light and Dark
description: There are two warring impulses in the music of Alfred Schnittke, the Russian composer who died last year. One is a sense of humor that takes the form of peculiar juxtapositions, allusions to other composers and styles, and thwarted expectations. The other is a seemingly implacable bleakness. Some works favor one of these qualities; in others, both fight for primacy.

title: With a Little Tuck Here and a Little Tuck There
description: WHEN people started having babies, that's when everyone began buying slipcovers,'' said Nana Colgrove, a television producer in New York with two small children. But universal-fit slipcovers have to be constantly retucked, especially after Arnie the Airedale has slept on the sofa and the children have used it as a trampoline. Paula Riley's Fitting Pretty kit of plastic rods ($30) promises to keep ''casual slipcovers secure and looking picture perfect.'' Do they?

title: Out of the House, but Still Focused on Family
description: CONSIDER the following tableau, circa 1956.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBAN, SIGMUND
description: BARBAN-Sigmund. On April 26, 1999. Beloved uncle of Toni Levin Smith, Claire Bleiberg Schacht, Charles Levin and Simon Levin. Granduncle of Peter Bleiberg, Mona Bleiberg Bennett, Maureen Smith, Bryan Smith, Yale Levin, Michael Levin, Jacob Levin, Daniel Levin and Joshua Levin. Memorial services to be announced.

title: Sports of The Times; The Devils Don't Dare Look Ahead
description: ON the Devils' road to what they hope will be the Stanley Cup, they are not only trapped in a backup at a toll booth, but they also know the highway is even more jammed beyond the next exit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARK, LEO
description: PARK-Leo. 1975-1999. Loving son and brother. Friend to all. His great compassion, his kindness and his smile will never be forgotten. He brought out the best in all of us. Leo, a place will always be saved for you at our table, at the game, and in our hearts. You showed us the joy of life, and blessed us all. We miss you. John, Mom and Dad, Your dear friends

title: In Clinton's Words: 'Speak With a Single Voice'
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's statement on Kosovo and questions and answers yesterday at the White House, as recorded by The New York Times, and a letter he wrote to House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert :

title: Ex-Home Depot Employees Settle S.E.C. Suit
description: Two former Home Depot Inc. employees have agreed to pay $127,415 to settle charges that they traded stock options based on inside information about the home improvement chain, regulators said this week.

title: Valhol Survives Fight Just So He Can Run
description: Even if it took a court fight, the Valhol camp is grateful that its horse is in the Kentucky Derby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANG, DONALD KWANG, CHENG
description: CHANG-Donald Kwang-Cheng. Age 62, of Queens, passed away February 27, 1999. Born in Beijing to Wo-Jun & Hsin Hsiang Lo Chang. Obtained B.A., foreign languages, National Taiwan University, 1960; M.A., photographic art, Pratt Institute, 1967. Appointed tenured Senior Lecturer, Department East Asian Languages and Cultures, Columbia University. Renowned for Audio Visual teaching programs, translation and interpretation of classic literature. Survived by his mother and brothers, Kuang-Sheng (Beijin), Kwang-Chih (Boston), Kwang-Poo (Chicago). Memorial service 12:30-1:30 PM, on May 8, St. Paul Chapel, Columbia university. Reception and exhibition of Donald's art work follows the service in Room 403, Kent Hall. In lieu of flowers, donations to Donald K. Chang Memorial Fund recommended. See www.columbia edu/cu.ealac/dchang for details.

title: Flying Toasters That You Can Play With
description: ONCE upon a time, there was a technological problem: computers would burn permanent patterns onto their screens if they were left on. Like most technological problems, this was solved. The solution: an ingenious piece of software we call the screen saver. After a specified number of minutes, the desktop would disappear and voila: tropical fish, mesmerizing geometric patterns, colorful bouncing balls, fireworks and flying toasters.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Russia Granted Loan
description: The I.M.F. announced a preliminary agreement to lend Russia $4.5 billion over 18 months, the first loans since the country defaulted last summer. But the money will not actually get to Moscow. Instead, it will be used to repay earlier I.M.F. loans.

title: Milosevic Abruptly Fires A High-Profile Maverick
description: A Yugoslav Deputy Prime Minister who had threatened street demonstrations against the Government over press freedom went quietly this evening after being fired by fax.

title: INSIDE
description: Birth Rate at New Low

title: Lab's Laxity In Spy Case Outrages Lawmakers
description: Senior lawmakers expressed outrage and frustration today over the Government's failure to monitor a scientist suspected of spying for China, who officials now say may have given away secrets to virtually every nuclear weapon in the United States arsenal.

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review in The Living Arts yesterday about Chez Louis, a new bistro in midtown Manhattan, misspelled the surname of the late French chef who inspired some dishes on the menu. He was Antoine Ma gnin, not Magin.

title: Clinton, Asking Quick Approval of Funds, Talks of a Campaign of Many Months
description: President Clinton warned today that NATO's bombardment and economic pressure on Yugoslavia would persist for many more months and called on Congress to quickly pass his request for $6 billion in emergency funds to pay the mounting costs of the conflict.

title: Insurer Studies Sale
description: The Acceptance Insurance Companies, a property-casualty insurer, said today that it had hired Warburg Dillon Read L.L.C. to study selling the company and other ''strategic alternatives.'' The move is aimed at helping investors recover from a steep decline in the shares of the company this year. Acceptance's shares jumped $1.3125, to $13.8125 today.

title: The Hawks Bring Van Gundy And the Knicks to Their Knees
description: An irate Jeff Van Gundy nearly spun to his knees in disbelief. He had just watched his Knicks scramble to make up for their unsightly effort tonight, and now he was hearing a whistle that sounded like fingernails across a chalkboard.

McStocker, two daughters, Marie A. Hulme and Maureen A. McStocker; and three grandchildren. Funeral Mass will be held on Saturday, May 1, 1999, in St. Luke Church, Westport, Ct. Friends may call on Friday, April 30, from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. in the Spear Funeral Home, 39 So. Benson Road, Fairfield, Ct.

title: Phone Company In Internet Deal
description: Intermedia Communications Inc., a local telephone company, said this week that it planned to expand its deployment of high-speed Internet access services through two strategic alliances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORE, CAROL TILLES
description: SHORE-Carol Tilles. Age 77. Loving wife and better half of Allan for 58 years; beloved mother of Allan Shore Jr., William Shore, and Marylu Simon & devoted motherin-law of Jill Shore; cherished grandmother of Jennifer, Beth, Chris, Michael and Julie; greatgrandmother of three and sister of the late Roy Tilles Jr. Her compassion and zest for life touched all who knew her. Formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y., resident of Palm Beach, Florida for 25 years. Active volunteer for the Helen and Harry Gray Cancer Institute at Good Samaritan Hospital, Hospice of Palm Beach County and the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. Funeral service will be at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, Friday April 30 at 10AM. Visiting hours Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9. Burial at Woodlawn Cemetery, N.Y. For further information call Frank E. Campbell at 212-288-3500. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Helen and Harry Gray Cancer Institute at Good Samaritan Hospital, 1309 North Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, Florida 33401.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; McKesson to Restate Earnings for 4 Quarters and Stock Falls 48%
description: In what is sure to become fodder for shareholder groups who oppose frequent mergers, McKesson HBOC Inc., the nation's largest drug wholesaler, announced yesterday that it would restate earnings for the last four quarters after discovering improperly recorded sales from its recently acquired software business.

title: State Finds Lilco Millions Irretrievable
description: The state Attorney General's office has determined that it is legally impossible to get back any of the $67 million in severance pay given last year to Dr. William J. Catacosinos and 25 other top officials of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCALL, DAVID B. AND JOAN MILLS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, SARAH
