Wife of the late Harry Bloom and mother of the late Henry Bloom. Services today graveside 11:00 a.m. at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. For information: Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels 1-800-247-5235.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVKIN, LOIS HERMAN
description: RIVKIN-Lois Herman. The family of Lois Rivkin mourns the loss on April 27, of their beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister, after a valiant fight against lymphoma. Her creation of Friends of the Public Schools exemplified her warmth, energy, optimism & love of New York City. A memorial service will be held Sunday, May 2, at 11 A.M. at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Congregation Rodeph Sholom, or to the Citizens Committee for New York City, 305 7th Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSCHMIDT, FLORENCE G.
description: GOLDSCHMIDT - Florence G. Born in Brooklyn, New York on July 15, 1918 passed away in Dallas, Texas on April 26, 1999. She is survived by her loving husband, Arthur; daughter and son-in-law Karen and Norman Lerner; daughter and son-in-law Joan and Dr. Alan Weinstock; and grandchildren Rachel, Elie and husband Naama, Yosef, Devora & Chana. Services were held on Wednesday, April 28, at Shermans Flatbush M.C., 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. A shiva will be held at the Lerners residence.

title: NBC Offers Buyouts to 20 In Affiliate Relations Unit
description: NBC is offering financial buyouts to all 20 members of its affiliate relations department, a move network executives said was part of a long-term strategy to redefine its relationship with affiliated stations.

title: Taming That One-Size-Fits-All Slipcover
description: THE slipcover probably made its appearance during prehistoric times, when a cave dweller threw an animal skin over a rock. Even back then, the slipcover slipped. Frescoes show that recumbent Romans preferred to cover their pallets with layers of cloth, which puddled on the mosaic floors. (Tailoring was hardly expected.)

title: A Gallic Night at the Ball, Romantic but So Chilly
description: Turning certain plays from French into English is like dragging vampires into the sunlight. They shriek, they curdle, they shrivel, while shedding the elegant, arrogant authority they display in their natural element. There is in particular a French brand of theatrical whimsy, extensively practiced around the middle of this century, that usually turns into dust in the mouths of American actors, however capable.

title: A Merger Deal By 2 Internet Firms
description: Two World Wide Web sites that are aimed at the advertising-agency industry are being combined. Warp 10 Technologies, which is based in Toronto and operates Adsgallery.com, is acquiring Portfolios Online, which is also based in Toronto and operates Portfolios.com.

title: Yes, I'm in a Clique
description: There are 193 independent countries on the face of the earth. And in the city of Littleton there must be at least as many independent cliques.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, HORTENSE
description: FRIEDMAN-Hortense. On April 28, 1999. Devoted wife of the late Irving Friedman. Beloved mother of Ruth Milberg-Kaye and the late Michael Friedman. Grandmother of George, Laurie and Seth.

title: 2 Key Republicans Press Ahead on Social Security, Offering Investment-Account Plan
description: Hoping to breathe life into the dying effort to shore up Social Security, two pivotal House Republicans laid out a plan today that they said would assure the retirement system's long-term health without cutting benefits or raising taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTER, STANLEY D.
description: CANTER-Stanley D., 75. April 24, 1999. He was a man of great dignity and modesty, of elegant taste, intellectual clarity and profound generosity. His thoughtfulness, his kindness, his concern for those he loved and who loved him knew no bounds. His passions for music and painting enriched his life and ours. The world has lost a rare breed of man.

title: Japan's Quiet Reforms
description: Japan is quietly becoming a different country from the one most Americans think they know. We are transforming ourselves into a nation much better prepared to contribute to peace and prosperity in the 21st century. This will be a central message of my visit to the United States this week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 21 about the birth centennial of Vladimir Nabokov misstated the position of his son, Dmitri, on ''The Origin of Laura,'' an unfinished novel by the author. Dmitri Nabokov does not intend to try to complete it.

title: Agency Selected For MTV Campaign
description: MTV: Music Television in New York, part of the MTV Networks unit of Viacom Inc., has named 180 Communications in Amsterdam to create a print trade advertising campaign aimed at media planners and buyers. The assignment, for which billings were not disclosed, is the first in the United States for 180, which was founded last year by former employees of Wieden & Kennedy.

title: Attic Gleanings: Not Just Junk?
description: For anyone who has wondered about the pedigree of a hand-me-down clock but was too lazy to ask, Saturday is the day. At the 1999 Treasure Fest, experts will give oral appraisals of furniture, jewelry, books and art. ''Put the objects on a dolly and bring them, if you can, because we need to look inside,'' said Rocco Leonardis, the director of the National Antiques Appraisers Association in Manhattan. At the New York School of Interior Design, 170 East 70th Street (Lexington Avenue), noon to 5 P.M.; $10 admission includes a free appraisal; additional ones $3 each. Information: (212) 472-1500, extension 404.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOUDREAU, HAROLD JOSEPH
description: BOUDREAU-Harold Joseph. Interior designer extraodinaire, left us on April 24th at the age of 41. He decorated many homes and many lives. We will miss our lively, lovely, talented friend. Diane and Henry Cowen

title: Orders Up in March For Durable Goods
description: Orders for big-ticket goods made in the United States rose in March for the fourth time in five months, a sign that the rebound in manufacturing is real, Government figures showed today.

title: Unsecure Codes Are Recipes for A-Bombs, Experts Say
description: The secret computer codes that were downloaded into a nonsecure computer at the Los Alamos National Laboratory and that Federal experts fear were given to China are the distillation of more than a half-century of research on how to perfect nuclear weapons, experts in and out of Government said yesterday.

title: Pataki Assails Clinton Policy On Balkans, Calling it Weak
description: Gov. George E. Pataki of New York assailed President Clinton's policy in the Balkans tonight as displaying ''weakness and indecision,'' and argued that Mr. Clinton's troubles in Kosovo were the result of unsteady Democratic leadership in foreign affairs extending to the Vietnam War.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COULOUCOUNDIS, CLEOPATRA
description: COULOUCOUNDIS - Cleopatra. Annual memorial service will be held Sunday, May 2, at 11 AM, at the Greek Cathedral, 323 East 74 Street, Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THROOP, BARBARA WILLIAMS
description: THROOP-Barbara Williams. Formerly of Lawrence, NY, beloved wife of the late Enos Thompson Throop IV, daughter of Thomas Resolved Williams, died on April 26, 1999 in St. Michaels, MD. Mrs. Throop graduated from St. Timothy's School in 1931. An avid squash player, she represented the United States internationally, defeating Britain's top-seated player in the Wolfe-Noel Cup Competition in 1937. She is survived by her two sons, Enos Thompson Throop V, of St. Michaels, MD and Garrow Throop of Newtonville, MA, and two grandchildren, Julia and Nicholas Throop. Services will be held at 11:00 AM on Friday, April 30, at Trinity-St. Johns Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the U.S. Driving for the Disabled, Inc., P.O. Box 264, Jarrettsville, MD 21084 would be appreciated.

title: Marines Rejected High School Gunman for Taking Antidepressant, Pentagon Says
description: Eric Harris, one of two gunmen responsible for last week's massacre at Columbine High School here, was rejected by the Marine Corps because he had been taking the drug Luvox, an antidepressant often used to treat obsessive-compulsive disorder, a Defense Department official said today.

description: Hedge Funds for Wealthy May Face Tougher Scrutiny

description: The Devils' Crash Line played an integral part in their Stanley Cup triumph in 1995. Two of the line's components, center Bobby Holik and right wing Randy McKay, are still together. But since Mike Peluso was traded three years ago, the left wing spot has been a revolving door.

Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: It Dawns on Hartford: Patriots May Never Arrive
description: The idea of luring a major league team like the New England Patriots to this blighted insurance town between the lights of New York and Boston had seemed so grand, so exciting, so downright unlikely, that many Hartford boosters had feared that they would wake up from their blissful dream.

title: Looking at People, Seeing Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Handheld Electronic Organizer Is Aimed at the Younger Set
description: The success of high-end handheld devices like the Palm organizers and the various flavors of Windows CE has inspired a number of imitators. The latest, and the one most likely to have an impact outside the world of business gadget freaks, is the Helio from Vtech.

title: Piazza Produces Last-Inning Lightning
description: The feeling of hitting a game-winning home run, Mike Piazza said last night after hitting one, is indescribable.

title: To Help A Little Town Out of the Woods
description: Droog is a Dutch design group best known for its wryly conceptual, technologically subversive household objects: a soft rubber sink, a lace chair, a candlestick made by dipping a sponge in porcelain. Now Droog has an even more ambitious task: to revitalize a small town in eastern Germany through product design. The commission is from a German cultural organization intent on restoring the formerly flourishing town of Oranienbaum, a 17th-century market town whose palace was built for a Dutch princess. (It's not far from Dessau, birthplace of the Bauhaus.) Four Droog designers have come up with 20 prototypes that celebrate local crafts and materials, comment on global homogenization and try to create an identity for the town. There's a willow swing that looks like a basket on steroids (right, with Marcel Wanders, its designer), bright crayoned packaging for the town's shops (inset) and a park bench (left) made of a tree trunk and bronze chair backs in historical styles. While they may not put Oranienbaum on the map, the designs hint that there is such a thing as pride of place. JULIE V. IOVINE

title: 8 Bidders Seeking Credit Lyonnais Stakes
description: At least eight European financial institutions offered to buy stakes in Credit Lyonnais, the bank France spent $25 billion to save, as they seek to sell financial products through the bank's 2,005 branches.

title: Five Boys, 13, Are Arrested In Plot to Bomb Junior High
description: Five 13-year-old boys were arrested at a junior high school in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, yesterday after a fellow student overheard them discussing a planned bomb assault at the school on graduation day. The authorities said the students were found to be carrying bomb-making instructions as well as a list of possible victims.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Hopes Grow In East Timor Of Disarming Militias Soon
description: SINGAPORE  Appearing to fall in line with orders from the Indonesian government and top commanders, the military chief in East Timor said Wednesday that pro-Jakarta militias  which have been widely blamed for killing and terrorizing supporters of independence in the disputed territory  would soon be disarmed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROSSEAU, SALLY E. (CONDON)
description: BROSSEAU-Sally E. (Condon). April 23, formerly of Mt. Vernon, NY, of Hudson, Mass. Beloved mother of Wayne Brosseau of North Hampton, NH, and Denise Brosseau of Hudson, Mass. Beloved grandmother of Alex, Eric and Elizabeth. Wife of the late Alphonse Brosseau. Graduate of Boston Latin and Vespa George School of Art, Boston. Services and burial were at the convenience of the family.

title: To U.S., With Friendship and a (Semi)Fast Ball
description: Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi prepared today for a meeting with President Clinton, working on his economic policy and on his pitching arm.

title: The War of the Rudys
description: The latest battle between Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew could not have come at a worse time. New York City's students face tough new testing standards, and politicians in Albany are squeezing funds from the city's schools. Cynics might be forgiven for wondering whether the Mayor and perhaps even the Chancellor are looking for a diversion.

description: Cherry Blossoms and a Sale

title: At Home Alone With Me, Myself and I
description: A PAIR of monumental wire columns filled with oranges stand sentry at the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club Decorator Show House. They are the latest indication that the American home has become a place for navel-gazing.

title: Hot Off Your Printer: Cards for All Seasons
description: AMERICAN GREETINGS

title: Good List to Have If a Child Is in Tow
description: The only problem with the Web site The Best Public Toilets in New York City (www.angelfire.com/ny/NYCtoilets /index.html) is that you can't take it with you, as anyone who has walked the city streets looking for a washroom might wish. That aside, the site's creator, David M. Vought, fuses urgency with simplicity in this Big Apple baedeker. A typical listing: ''Salvation Army Thrift Store, 46th Street btwn 10/11th Avenues. M/W restrooms on third floor.'' With the site's pithy observations (at the Forbes Magazine Galleries, the restrooms have a nautical theme) and historical notes, this alternative tour has appeal for even seasoned New Yorkers. LISA NAPOLI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSCICK, CAROLUS (NEE WENZLIK)

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Patents column of Business Day on Monday about the addition of images to some patents available through the Patent and Trademark Office's Web site misstated the address of a separate patents data base operated on the Web by I.B.M. It is www.ibm.com /patents.

title: Ewing or the Future Must Take a Back Seat
description: Before the Knicks played Charlotte on Monday night, Dave Checketts brought up a sensitive subject with Jeff Van Gundy. He discussed the issue of whether the coach should consider resting a pained Patrick Ewing for the remainder of the regular season.

title: U.S. Agency Says Employer Should Pay for a Woman's Infertility Treatments
description: In a decision hailed as a major legal victory for infertile couples, a Federal agency has ruled that a national publishing company violated disabilities laws by refusing to pay for an employee's infertility treatments.

title: For Women at Harvard, Little Has Changed
description: To the Editor:

title: Katzenberg Testifies Disney Reneged on Bonus
description: Jeffrey Katzenberg, testifying over the last two days about his angry relationship with his former employer, the Walt Disney Company, said his 10 years at the studio had proved to be ''a lie'' because of a dispute with Michael D. Eisner, the Disney chairman, over a huge bonus.

title: Intel Goes to Battle as Its Embedded Serial Number Is Unmasked
description: When privacy advocates first sounded alarms in January about a serial number that the Intel Corporation had embedded in its new Pentium III processor, the company quickly responded by distributing software that enabled owners of Pentium III computers to hide the number. But it now appears that the problem is not solved and is not about to fade away.

title: Looking at People, Seeing Race
description: To the Editor:

title: City Council Sweetens Correction Officers' Pension Plan
description: In a surprise vote that angered Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the City Council approved a plan yesterday that would increase retirement benefits for correction officers, a change that the Mayor said could eventually cost the city $100 million a year.

title: Germans Seek To Separate Serb Leader From Support
description: The German Government is pressing a Western diplomatic initiative aimed at isolating the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, rather than dealing with him. The strategy is driven by the conviction that he will almost certainly be indicted by the international war crimes tribunal.

title: Documents Say Microsoft Considered a Blow to Novell
description: Bent on breaking the spirit of the Novell Corporation, its Utah-based archrival in the network software market, the Microsoft Corporation in 1994 considered a recommendation that it lock up sales accounts at both the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and Brigham Young University, documents filed yesterday in Federal court contend.

title: Birth Rate at New Low as Teen-Age Pregnancy Declines
description: The teen-age birth rate, which has been dropping steadily for six years, has dipped so sharply that it has helped push the nation's overall birth rate to the lowest point since the Government began keeping records in 1909, according to data made public today by the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: For Women at Harvard, Little Has Changed
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Panel to Recommend Some Gambling Restrictions
description: A Federal commission is preparing to recommend to Congress and the President a moratorium on gambling expansion and more Federal regulation of the giant casinos on Indian reservations.

title: Andrew J. Loyla, 69, City Ballet Flutist
description: Andrew J. Loyla, a flutist who played in the New York City Ballet Orchestra for nearly 30 years and was a member of the executive board of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, died on April 17 at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 69 and lived in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, W. HAZAIAH, THE REV. DR.
description: WILLIAMS-W. Hazaiah, The Rev. Dr. May 14, 1930-April 24, 1999. On Saturday, April 24, 1999, the Rev. Dr. W. Hazaiah Williams, Founder and Director for 35 years of Today's Artists Concerts and Founder and Artistic Director of Four Seasons Concerts for six years, passed away in Berkeley, CA. from complications due to a long diabetes illness. Dr. Williams presented international classical music artists annually at Carnegie Hall and at Alice Tully Hall since 1977. He presented a series of concerts in the San Francisco Bay Area & formed an annual summer music festival at Yachats, Oregon in 1981. William Hazaiah Williams, Jr. was born in Columbus, Ohio on May 14, 1930, the youngest of six children. He earned a Master of Theology from Boston University. He was awarded two honorary Doctor of Divinity degrees, one from Pacific School of Religion and the other from the Church Divinity School of the Pacific, both in Berkeley. In addition to his role as Impresario, Dr. Williams was Founder and Pastor of the Church for Today in Berkeley, California from 1956 until his death; he was Founder and President for 20 years of the Center for Urban Black Studies at the Graduate Theological Union in Berkeley. He played a leading role in the Civil Rights Movement, and lectured throughout the United States on the issues of race, religion and education. In the mid-1970s, he was a delegate to the World Council of Churches' Symposium on Black and Liberation Theology at Geneva, Switzerland. Funeral services were held on April 28.

title: Max Hutchinson, Art Dealer In Big Pollock Sale, Dies at 73
description: Max Hutchinson, an art dealer and gallery owner who was instrumental in the sale of Jackson Pollock's large, late drip painting ''Blue Poles,'' to the National Gallery of Australia in Canberra, died on Friday at Community General Hospital of Sullivan County in Harris, N.Y. He was 73 and had lived in Kenoza Lake, N.Y., since 1986.

title: I.M.F. Agrees to Make Loan, But Not Send Cash, to Russia
description: The International Monetary Fund announced a preliminary agreement tonight to lend Russia $4.5 billion over the next 18 months, the first resumption of loans since the country defaulted on its debts and devalued its currency last summer.

title: Hess Enters Manhattan Hospital
description: Leon Hess has been hospitalized in Manhattan, a Jets spokesman said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLATAS, ARBIT
description: BLATAS-Arbit. Age 90. Renowned painter and sculptor on April 27, 1999. Survived by his beloved wife Regina Resnik Blatas. Loving father of Dorothee, son-in-law Achour Radji, stepson Michael Philip Davis and grandchildren Sara, and Michael. Burial Friday, April 30 will be private. In lieu of flowers tributes may be sent to the Regina Resnik-Arbit Blatas Scholarship Fund, Hunter College, 695 Park Ave. Memorials in New York, Venice, and Paris to be announced.
