description: WEINSTEIN - Howard (Chaim). Yeshivat Sha'alvim extends heartfelt condolences to his brothers, Board member and alumnus, Boruch, alumnus David, sister Joy, father Mordechai and wife Leah. Hamakom Yenachemchem.

title: Time and Again, That Sputtering Beat Goes Marchin' In
description: A lone sousaphone, unamplified, was all it took to rock the house at the Maple Leaf, a New Orleans club that was packed at 2:30 A.M. this morning. With the Rebirth Brass Band onstage, the tin-ceilinged room was full of happy feet, dancing to Rebirth's euphoric, recklessly improvisational medleys of its own rowdy call-and-response chants and songs from Marvin Gaye and TLC. The chunky stomp of funk was married to a rolling, sputtering carnival-parade backbeat that's at least a century old; the band played and sang without microphones. All the crowd cared about was that it made them dance.

title: Microsoft Questions Delay in Announcement of a Merger Last Year
description: A lawyer for the Microsoft Corporation tried today to show that the Netscape Communications Corporation and America Online delayed the announcement of their merger for several weeks last fall, apparently because they feared that earlier disclosure of it might hurt the Government's antitrust case against Microsoft.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHACHTER, JACK
description: SCHACHTER-Jack. April 29, 1995. Dearest Brother, there isn't a day that goes by that we don't think of you, speak of you and miss you. You are loved and will never be forgotten. Cindy and Slom

title: China Bans A Filmmaker For Eluding Censorship
description: The Chinese authorities have banned the actress Joan Chen from working in the country because she directed a film in a remote rural area that was shot without official permission.

title: An Air War Can Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial Focuses on Whether Mother Meant to Kill Her Baby
description: They were typical baby pictures: a snapshot of a smiling mother cradling her infant son; the proud father, cooing and making a silly face.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Audubon Society Stays In Suit Over an Estate
description: A Surrogate's Court judge has decided not to dismiss the claim of the National Audubon Society to the $18 million estate of Frederick P. Lenz 3d until the society's lawyers have had a chance to question his financial advisers.

title: Korea Telecom to Raise Internet Service Speed
description: The Korea Telecom Company, South Korea's largest telephone company, said yesterday that it would invest 350 billion won ($297 million) to increase tenfold the speed of its Internet service, Kornet. The state-run company will spend 70 billion won to speed its backbone network speed to one gigabit a second. Giga switches, or central operators, will be installed in 35 cities across the nation to increase the speed of intercity Internet service. Kornet, the nation's largest Internet service provider, has about 488,000 personal and corporate subscribers. It posted a profit of 3.8 billion won last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICARLO, SR. JUDGE DOMINICK L.
description: DiCARLO-Sr. Judge Dominick L. The Chief Judge, the Colleagues and the Staff of the US Court of International Trade express their deepest sorrow at the passing of a distinguished member of the Court, the esteemed and beloved Dominick L. DiCarlo and extend their heartfelt condolences to the bereaved members of his family.

title: Public Eye; Smog Gets in Your Ears
description: SUZANNE CIANI lives in seclusion at the end of a dirt road in Marin County, Calif., but her most famous piece of music is heard about 280 million times every day. In 1988, balancing commercial work with her career as a composer, she created what may be the world's best-known audio signature: the miniature chordal flourish that introduces every AT&T call.

title: The Drama! The Song and Dance! It's Tony Time!; With So Much at Stake, Producers Make Every Effort to Work the System
description: To many people in the theater, the decisions seemed unjust. ''Wit,'' this year's Pulitzer Prize-winning play, was ruled ineligible for Tony Award nominations because after vainly trying to move to a Broadway theater, it could only be performed off Broadway.

title: China Toughens in Negotiations on Trade Group Membership
description: China appears to have toughened its stance in talks aimed at gaining entry to the World Trade Organization, making United States negotiators pay for President Clinton's decision earlier this month to delay a final deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORIN, WALTER
description: FLORIN-Walter. Beloved husband of Esther. Loving father of Mark and Joel. Cherished grandfather of Daniella, Samuel, David and Michelle. Also survived by many dear friends. Founded Micro Essential Laboratory, Inc. in 1934. Developer and inventor of Hydrion PH Products, which have been used worldwide for educational, industrial and medical testing. Services Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island at 1:30 PM Thursday.

title: A Date With the Censor: Not Dinner and a Movie
description: And now for something completely different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFSTETTER, MAX
description: HOFSTETTER-Max, died on April 26, at age 81. Beloved husband of Mildred for 58 years. Cherished father of Neil, Steven and Rose Weiss. Dear brother of Herman. Adored grandfather of Michael and Karen, Donna and Tzvi, Allison and Scott, Jason and Tova, Lee and Matthew, Gregory, and Nathaniel. Great-grandfather to MacKenzie, Ilan, and Hannah Rose. Loving father-in-law of Estelle, Bruce, and Margy. Services today, 1 PM, at Gramercy Chapels, 2nd Ave. and 10th St. Please make any donations to The Faculty Campaign, NYU Medical Center, 550 1st Ave., NY, NY 10016, in honor of Max Hofstetter. Shiva will be observed at the home of Dr. Steven and Mrs. Hofstetter.

title: G.M. in Funeral Car Deal
description: The General Motors Corporation signed a three-year agreement today to supply the Service Corporation International with 1,500 cars and commercial vehicles annually. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The Service Corporation is a global funeral-services company that has a fleet of more than 13,000 vehicles.

title: Public Art Befouled
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Tuesday about Ehud Barak, the Labor Party candidate for Prime Minister of Israel, misstated a campaign goal of the incumbent, Benjamin Netanyahu, in some copies. He is trying to push Mr. Barak's public image to the left, not his own.

title: Rock Concerts Are Cancelled
description: Marilyn Manson, the dark, cross-dressing rock musician, said he was canceling the last five dates on a two-month concert tour because of last week's shooting in Littleton, Colo.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE P.O.W.'s; Jackson Panel Begins Mission To Free 3 G.I.'s
description: Jesse Jackson and a dozen religious leaders left tonight for Belgrade to seek the release of three American soldiers held captive by President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Political Memo; That Silence In Albany? Budget Talks
description: Even for Albany, this is bad.

title: Man Charged With Receiving 7 Years of School Pay Illegally
description: For more than seven years, James Hardy collected a paycheck, was given satisfactory evaluations and received cost-of-living raises. But in those seven years he never worked a day at his public school job, the Special Commissioner of Investigation for the New York City schools charged yesterday.

title: TALKING DESIGN WITH: Princess Christina of Sweden; Where Ordinary Is Beautiful, and Vice Versa
description: EARLIER this month, Christina Magnuson, a sophisticated 50-something Swede, sat in a Manhattan hotel suite and discussed well-designed juice glasses, toothbrushes, kitchen utensils, furniture, cars and houses. ''Design is one of society's largest cultural assets,'' she said, a gauge with which to measure the aspirations of a civilization.

title: Mullen Advertising, New England's biggest independent, is acquired by the Lowe Group.
description: THE largest remaining independent agency in New England remains independent no longer.

title: Fighter Brings Many Cultures to Bouts
description: Jeremy Williams has had one heavyweight title shot. In 1996, he fought Henry Akinwande for the World Boxing Organization title and was knocked out in three rounds.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: ENCYCLOPEDIA PREQUEL -- In another example of the Internet turning academic publishing on its head, MacMillan Reference is pre-releasing parts of its massive Encyclopedia of Life Sciences on the Web. The encyclopedia won't be completed until 2001, but in September 1999, MacMillan will begin previewing more than 700 articles in an electronic version, the Embryonic E.L.S. (www.macmillan-reference.co.uk). That will let academics and scientists participate in the evolution of what MacMillan is calling ''the most ambitious reference source ever to be published in the biological sciences.''

title: Smile! It's Digital
description: ON a recent visit to an amusement park in Florida, where he was supposed to be having fun, poor little Taylor was in agony. ''Taylor, take a bite of your hot dog,'' his father coached. ''Smile! That's it! Taylor, turn around and walk toward the roller coaster. No, walk the other way. Taylor, look over here. Over here! Wave to your grandpa. Say, 'Hi, Grandpa!' Show him your new T-shirt. Come on, Taylor, smile!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOYT, MURIEL CHRISTIE
description: HOYT-Muriel Christie. On April 27, 1999. Beloved wife of Henry H. Hoyt, Jr., loving mother of Heather Hoyt Neburka and Holly Heyward Hoyt, and dear sister of Margaret Christie Nelson and George Hamilton Christie. Funeral services and interment will be private. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Christ Church in Short Hills, Box C, Short Hills, NJ 07078, and The Unity Church of Cape Cod, to be sent c/o The Rev. Janet Smith, Minister, 5780 Aspendale Drive, Columbus, OH 43235.

title: Web Cameras Just for the Birds
description: FOR birds, spring is the season to build nests, lay eggs and poke a constant supply of fish and insects into the mouths of ever-hungry chicks. It is also the season when birds play a starring role on the Internet, their domestic lives shown on dozens of live video Web sites where the public can keep abreast of every flutter.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Calculators That Offer More Than the Solution
description: As soon as handheld calculators appeared in classrooms, educators warned that the devices would undermine the learning of mathematics. Now at least one major calculator maker, Casio, acknowledges that the doomsayers were right.

title: A Clever Play Wins Points, But Not Enough to Prevail
description: Three of the four major team contests are played from start to finish at a national championship. The fourth is the Grand National Teams, which begins at the local level. The district champions then advance to national playoffs, which this year will be in San Antonio in July.

title: 'Marlene' Is Closing
description: ''Marlene,'' a play by Pam Gems about the actress Marlene Dietrich, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Cort Theater, 138 West 48th Street, Manhattan. The show, starring Sian Phillips and directed by Sean Mathias, will have run for 25 regular performances and 15 previews.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil prices jumped after a large drop in United States inventories signaled that OPEC might be succeeding in cutting production. In New York, crude oil for June delivery rose 64 cents a barrel, to $18.45.

title: Brooks Brothers, Unbuttoned
description: On the eve of the 21st century, Brooks Brothers is evolving out of its 19th-century men's club ambiance. A new Brooks Brothers will open on Tuesday at 666 Fifth Avenue (53d Street) in a modernistic glass box, above. Enormous photographs will punctuate the glass exterior; inside, merchandise will be displayed out in the open, on tables. The only thing under glass will be cuff links, said Paul Sadowski, the store's visual director.

title: Penalty Phase Begins for Man Convicted of Slaying 2 Pizza Deliverymen
description: The ambush murders of Giorgio Gallara and Jeremy Giordano two years ago were senseless and depraved, a prosecutor argued today, saying that their convicted killer, Thomas Koskovich, deserves the death penalty.

title: Baan, Dutch Maker Of Software, Posts Loss
description: Baan N.V. of the Netherlands, the worst-performing stock on the Bloomberg Europe 500 Index last year, posted a first-quarter loss of $19 million, smaller than analysts expected, as the company struggled to cut costs amid slowing demand for its software. Baan, Europe's No. 2 business-management software maker, lost 9 cents a share, compared with a per-share profit of a penny in the comparable period a year earlier when it made $2.4 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOLYA, ANDREW
description: LLOLYA-Andrew. The New York City Ballet Orchestra deeply mourns the loss of our principal flutist, Andrew Llolya. His artistry and dedication to our orchestra will be sorely missed. New York City Ballet Orchestra

title: Congress and Kosovo
description: Prosecuting a war in consultation with Congress is not always easy for the White House, but it is necessary under the Constitution. Given the sensitive military and diplomatic ground in Kosovo, the House is for the most part steering a reasonable if spendthrift course this week in acting on several measures involving the war in Yugoslavia.

title: Court Papers Show Open Style Of Many Microsoft Executives
description: In April 1995, long before the browser wars erupted, the Microsoft Corporation had recognized the challenge posed by the Internet. Its strategic response, its top technology executive urged, should be clear-cut: control as much of the crucial technology as possible, just as it does in the personal computer market with its industry-standard Windows operating system.

title: Students Search the Web for Their First Real Jobs
description: IT was 3 o'clock on a Wednesday morning, and Carla Arellano was sitting in front of her computer in her off-campus apartment, trying to keep her eyes open. In just a few hours, her resume was due at Georgetown University's career center.

title: This Little Piggy Gets Mail
description: Australians are putting their own mark on a folk art form: kooky mailboxes. ''The pig is a little milk can with added bits of metal that are welded on,'' said Cal Swann, ''and the elephant is made of an old silencer'' -- a car muffler. Mr. Swann, a professor of design at the Curtin University of Technology in Perth, is the author and photographer of ''Nifty Places: The Australian Rural Mailbox,'' a 24-page booklet published by Pentagram about mailboxes made from, among other things, toolboxes, tubs and bread bins. It's $3 from (212) 802-0255.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAUER, ROLF W.
description: LANDAUER-Rolf W. On April 28, 1999 of Briarcliff Manor, New York. Husband of Muriel (Jussim) Landauer. Father of Karen Walsh, Thomas and Carl Landauer. Grandfather of 3. Funeral service Friday 1 PM, Temple Beth El, 229 Bedford Rd. (Rt. 117), Chappaqua, New York. Interment Mount Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to American Society for Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, 810 7th Ave, NY, NY 10102-0660. Info: Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY.

title: Picnicking With Portable Propriety
description: WHAT does it take to get a picnic off the ground? Quite simply, a proper dining table and something comfortable to sit on. This spring, it is easier than ever to find truly lightweight portable gear, much of which rolls up and slings over a shoulder.

title: Deadlocked House Denies Support for Air Campaign
description: In a sharp challenge to President Clinton, the House voted today to bar the President from sending ground troops to Yugoslavia without Congressional approval and then on a tie vote refused to support NATO air strikes against Serbia.

title: Big Steel's Problems Are Home Grown; Low-Cost U.S. Mills Play a Bigger Role Than Imports in Eroding Profits
description: It was a scene that summed up so much about this quintessential steel town, here where the Alleghenies roll seamlessly into Appalachia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILLO, OTTO EMIL, M.D.
description: BILLO-Otto Emil, M.D. Of Bronxville, New York, and Dorset, VT on April 25, 1999. Husband of the late Barbara L. Billo. Father of Barbara B. Alexander, Charles G. Billo & Suzanne B. Kaiser. Grandfather of six. Dr. Billo was a graduate of Williams College, Class of 1930, Harvard Medical School, Class of 1935. Dr. Billo was on the staff of Lennox Hill Hospital, New York Hospital and Lawrence Hospital. Memorial service at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on Saturday, May 8 at 2:00 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Harvard Medical School Alumni Fund, 25 Shattuck St., Boston, MA 02115, Rm. 306.

title: In Glare of Spotlight, the Sheriff's Office Struggles
description: Sgt. Jim Parr of the Jefferson County Sheriff's office was not sure he would still have a job today.

title: Tour Time: Spring Becomes the Northeast
description: FROM an 1811 farmhouse in Doylestown, Pa., to ocean-front gardens in Rye, N.Y., to a Park Avenue duplex, show houses and house and garden tours are preparing for visitors in the Northeast.

title: Louisiana G.O.P. Facing David Duke, Again
description: On the surface, the special election to be held here on Saturday is about who will replace Robert L. Livingston, the veteran Congressman who admitted to marital infidelity and abruptly resigned last year as he was about to ascend to the most powerful position in the House.

title: One Point Holds Up W.N.B.A.
description: The Women's National Basketball Association and its players union were close to completing their first collective bargaining agreement last night, with the only sticking point being the number of union-sponsored events players may participate in, the union said.

title: RCN TAKES 47.5% STAKE IN JUNIORNET FOR $47 MILLION
description: The RCN Corporation, a provider of telecommunications services based in Princeton, N.J., said yesterday that it had acquired a 47.5 percent stake in the Juniornet Corporation, a commercial-free on-line learning service for children that was introduced last month, for about $47 million in cash. At the same time, Juniornet bought RCN's Lancit Media Entertainment subsidiary, which creates children's television programming, for about $25 million in cash. Juniornet, based in Boston, uses a technology combining a CD-ROM and an on-line connection, which increases bandwidth and reduces download time, while preventing access to the Internet at large.

title: D.M.B.& B. Retains Australian Account
description: The Australian Tourist Commission in Sydney has retained D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications in New York, a unit of MacManus Group, as the agency of record for its worldwide account for another two years. Billings were estimated at $75 million annually.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLMEIER, HAZEL R.
description: DILLMEIER-Hazel R. Of Garden City, L.I., and Westhampton Beach passed away on April 27, 1999. Graduate of Florida College for Women now Florida State also graduate degrees from Columbia and Stanford in physical therapy. Beloved wife of William E. Dillmeier and widow of the late Basil O'Connor. Survived by granddaughter Cathy Culver Hively, William E. Dillmeier Jr., Robert L. Dillmeier and their children. A memorial service will be held at a later date at Westhampton Beach, NY. Private burial services will be held at Oak Lawn Cemetery, Jacksonville, FL. Donations in her memory to Roosevelt Warm Springs Endowment Fund, P.O. Box 1050, Warm Springs, GA. 31830.

title: EASTMAN CHEMICAL PLANS A $400 MILLION ACQUISITION
description: The Eastman Chemical Company agreed yesterday to acquire Lawter International Inc. for $12.25 a share in cash, or about $400 million. It will also assume debt of about $100 million. Lawter shares soared 34 percent, rising $3.0625, to $12. Lawter, which is based in Kinosha, Wis., had revenue of $212.8 million in 1998. It makes specialty chemicals that allow inks and coatings to be applied to a variety of surfaces. Eastman Chemical said the deal would expand its presence in the coatings, inks, resins and adhesives markets to about $1 billion in annual revenue. Eastman is a former subsidiary of the Eastman Kodak Company. Its shares rose $1, to $50.9375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONOVER, ROBERT N. JR.
description: CONOVER-Robert N. Jr. April 25, 1999 in New York City at Bellevue Hospital. Born August 3, 1995 in New York City. Son of Robert and Sarah Conover. Visitation Thursday, April 29th at William Coster Funeral Home, 3270 Main Road, Cutchogue, N.Y. from 2PM to 4PM and 7 PM to 9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday, April 30th at 10AM at Our Lady of Good Counsel Mission Church, Mattituck, New York.

title: Standard Chartered Acquiring Thai Bank
description: Standard Chartered P.L.C., a British bank with two-thirds of its assets in Asia, agreed yesterday to buy 68.4 percent of Nakornthon Bank of Thailand for about 6.2 billion baht ($165 million), becoming the latest Western bank to acquire an Asian bank battered by the region's recession. The London-based Standard Chartered will be aided by the Thai Government, which will inject 13.3 billion baht into Nakornthon to write off bad loans and take a 20 percent equity stake. Standard Chartered may buy the Government stake later and expects to own 82 percent by 2005. Nakornthon has 67 branches, two-thirds of them in Bangkok, and 2,000 employees. Its founding shareholders, the Wanglee family, have been in sale talks for the last two years.

title: Hollywood Journal; With the Force, in the Movie Line
description: A long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away, there might have been something like it. But even Mann's Chinese Theater, the gaudy ground-zero of movie fandom, has never seen anything quite like the global village that snakes along its scarred old sidewalk in the heart of Hollywood these days.

title: Sony Posts Decline in Profit As Product Demand Falls
description: In a sign of how Japan's faltering economy is hurting even its healthiest businesses, the Sony Corporation reported a nearly 20 percent decline in fiscal-year earnings today and a net loss in the final quarter, its first quarterly loss in four years.

title: Informer's History Clouds Biggest Drug-Money Case
description: As Federal prosecutors went to trial here against a group of Mexicans implicated in the biggest investigation ever into the laundering of illegal drug money, their evidence seemed overwhelming.

title: Putting the Truth in Writing
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE VRIES, LION J.
description: de Vries-Lion J. Beloved husband of Tilly, loving father of Christina and Eveline, grandfather to Bridge and Michael, passed away on April 29, 1999. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, May 2nd, his birthday, at 4PM, Marble Collegiate Church, 29th St., & 5th Ave.

title: Struggles Of Tibetans Under China
description: Earnest and committed, ''Windhorse'' dramatizes the plight of the Tibetan people under Chinese occupation and repression by means of the story of the disintegration of a single family.

title: Susan Derges -- 'The River Taw Series'
description: James Danziger Gallery

title: Following the Paper Trail: Ellsworth Kelly's Adventure
description: Ellsworth Kelly's drawings and collages, particularly those he produced in France and New York near the start of his career, make up one of the most stimulating bodies of work on paper by any high-profile postwar American artist.

title: Ford Drops Factory Plan For Brazil
description: In a decision highlighting how government overspending has hampered foreign investment in Brazil, the Ford Motor Company has abandoned plans to build an innovative $1 billion factory in a southern Brazilian state, which refused to honor a pledge to provide the company with financial incentives because of a budget crisis.

title: City Agrees to Drop Delay In Food Stamp Applications
description: Bowing to pressure from Federal authorities, the Giuliani administration has agreed to allow the poor to apply for food stamps and Medicaid on their first visit to a city welfare office, city officials said yesterday.

title: Arnold Is Winner At Andy Awards
description: Arnold Communications in Boston, a unit of Snyder Communications, was the top winner last night at the 35th annual International Andy Awards ceremony, winning the grand prize, known as the Grandy, as well as the most awards.

title: Jackson Arrives in Belgrade; Hopes to Talk to G.I.'s Today
description: Yugoslav Government officials welcomed the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and a group of American Christian, Jewish and Muslim leaders today at a border crossing with Croatia, providing them with an escort to the capital and a promise that they would meet President Slobodan Milosevic and three captive American soldiers during their three days here.

title: Judge Dominick L. DiCarlo, 71, Narcotics Fighter Under Reagan
description: Dominick L. DiCarlo, a Federal judge and a former New York State Assemblyman from Brooklyn, died on Tuesday after suffering a heart attack while exercising at a gym at the Federal court complex in Manhattan. He was 71.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLATAS, ARBIT
description: BLATAS-Arbit. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of artist and sculptor Arbit Blatas. Mr. Blatas created the ''ADL Holocaust Memorial Wall,'' commemorating the night of December 5, 1943, when the first 200 of Venice's Jews were rounded up and deported to their deaths. The plaques, a recasting of the original series in Venice's old foundry district, are on permanent display outside ADL's national headquarters. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Regina Resnik, and their family. Howard P. Berkowitz, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THROOP, BARBARA WILLIAMS
description: THROOP-Barbara Williams. Formerly of Lawrence, NY, beloved wife of the late Enos Thompson Throop IV, daughter of Thomas Resolved Williams, died on April 26, 1999 in St. Michaels, MD. Mrs. Throop graduated from St. Timothy's School in 1931. An avid squash player, she represented the United States internationally, defeating Britain's top-seated player in the Wolfe-Noel Cup Competition in 1937. She is survived by her two sons, Enos Thompson Throop V, of St. Michaels, MD and Garrow Throop of Newtonville, MA, and two grandchildren, Julia and Nicholas Throop. Services will be held at 11:00 AM on Friday, April 30, at Trinity-St. Johns Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the U.S. Driving for the Disabled, Inc., P.O. Box 264, Jarrettsville, MD 21084 would be appreciated.

title: On Yugoslavia, Congress Must Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; For Knicks, New Time Is Here
description: THE Knicks celebrated the career of Red Holzman last night. The organization handed out orange towels with the number 613 (Holzman's Knick victories) inscribed. The team crushed Philadelphia, 85-70, in a game it had to have. The Knicks paid homage with a dazzling performance that captured the spirit -- 90's style -- of Holzman's signature concepts: team play, tenacious defense and wise shot selection.

title: Bombing Unites Serb Army As It Debilitates Economy -- Yugoslav Rift Heals, NATO Admits
description: The NATO bombing that was intended to cripple and demoralize Slobodan Milosevic's military machine has instead invigorated the Yugoslav Army and has helped him heal his long-poisoned relationship with the officers corps, American and NATO officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, HOWARD
description: MARKS-Howard. To our brotherin-law Jeffrey and our sister Jill, we extend our deepest condolences on the loss of Jeffrey's father, Howard Marks. We were privileged to know him and our lives were truly blessed by his kind heart, generous spirit and thoughtful insight. To Lorene, Michael, Yvonne, Jennifer, Kelly, Amy, Brian, Lynne, Madeline, and Aaron and to our nieces Melanie, Shelby and Julia please know that our thoughts are with you. Howard will live on through each of you forever and we hope that you will use this time to reflect on all the wonderful times you had at home in New York, on the mountains of Vermont and traveling the world together. It was a full and wonderful life and he loved you all. Jeffrey, Nancy, Andrew, Sam and Elizabeth Siskind, Stephen, Laura, Max and Cara Siskind

title: Columbine Students Talk Of the Disaster and Life
description: Before the gunshots rang out in fifth period at Columbine High School on April 20, students there were busy with the everyday life of American teen-agers. Now, after a massacre that took 15 lives, including those of the two classmates who were the gunmen, the students wonder where they and their school go on from here.

title: Sending Up 'Gaslight' of '44 (With Emphasis on 'Gas')
description: Remember ''Gaslight''? Not the 1939 British film with Anton Walbrook and Diana Wynyard, which is superb. No. The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer version of 1944 with Ingrid Bergman and Charles Boyer. For years I've longed for someone to make that bag of bloat explode with just a pinprick of humor. Now the Pearl Theater Company does it. Its production of ''Angel Street'' -- the American title of Patrick Hamilton's play that inspired both films -- is a marvelous romp.

title: The Wonder of Innocence Revives Washington's Grace
description: ''You see those trees, kids?'' I said to my children, Aaron and Sarah, as our cab headed down Pennsylvania Avenue toward the White House. ''Those are cherry trees. Washington's famous for them. And it's a special time when the blossoms are coming out, like now.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAKLEY, DELPHINE M.
description: SHAKLEY-Delphine M. On April 28, 1999. Beloved wife of Mark, mother of Alexander, Jonathan, Oliver, Jennifer, and Jacob. Daughter of Jane and the late James McCosker, sister of Maureen, Timothy and Muriel. Funeral mass at St Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84 St, Saturday, 12 Noon. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the National Brain Tumor Foundation, 785 Market St, Suite 1600, San Francisco, Ca. 94103

title: Praneet Soi and Kriti Arora
description: A Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, NATALIE
description: MARCUS-Natalie. April 18, 1999. Mother of Katie Behrens and grandmother of Evan and Jack. Contributions to Elem c/o Bialkin, 211 Central Park W, NY NY 10024.

title: Karen Yasinsky -- 'No Place Like Home'
description: Casey Kaplan

title: An Ailing Zimmer Is Ready to Go Home When Torre Returns
description: Early this afternoon, a veteran member of the Yankees -- the team with the $84 million payroll and the 24 championships and the rich tradition for organization -- was asked this: ''Who is going to manage your team Friday?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKERMAN, BESSIE
description: BECKERMAN-Bessie. Age 93. On April 29, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Henry; dear mother of Ruth (Robert) Goldschlager and Nancy (the late Stuart) Leavitt; dear grandmother and great-grandmother. Past president and life member of Hadassah to whom contributions in her memory may be made or to the Stuart J. Leavitt Memorial Foundation for Pediatric Oncology. Graveside services will be held Friday, 11AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: The 'Wild West' Isn't to Blame; N.R.A. Can Help
description: To the Editor:

title: The Power Of a Tony Jolt
description: The Broadway season effectively ended on Wednesday, the deadline for Tony nominations, bringing to a close what most theater veterans say has been an odd year, devoid of the spark of a blockbuster new musical and witness to the continued invasion of British and Irish plays.

title: Everything Old May Be New Again
description: AS Rover's current owner, BMW, fishes through the British auto maker's closet, it keeps coming across old relics that stir the imagination of automotive artists.

title: Long Week of Funerals Finally Comes to an End
description: It was the last one, and from the look of it, everyone on earth had showed up.

title: CMP Media to Be Bought for $920 Million
description: United News and Media P.L.C. said today that it would spend $920 million to buy CMP Media Inc., the United States publisher of Information Week and Computer Reseller News and an operator of several business Internet sites.

title: John Rielly
description: Spencer Brownstone Gallery

title: Mayor Wants Explanation From Crew
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he expected the Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew, to ''explain his actions'' at a meeting at City Hall on Monday, as the feud between the two men showed little sign of abating.

title: A Week To Branch Out
description: There are trunks filled with treasure at the New York Botanical Garden, but none are under lock and key. They don't need to be; they're rooted to the ground. Dubbed ''Terrific Trees,'' these forest residents are the spring theme of the Everett Children's Adventure Garden.

title: Jail Failed to Diagnose Inmate's Cancer
description: Tony Fleming, a 35-year-old inmate at Rikers Island who is mentally ill, went to a medical clinic at the jail in December complaining of lower-back pain, according to two jail clinicians who reviewed his medical records. Blood tests revealed abnormal liver function and other possible signs of cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, MARILYN SWORD
description: WILSON-Marilyn Sword. Of Smyrna, DE, died on Thursday, April 29. She was 73. She was born September 10, 1925, the daughter of the late William Oscar and Viola Schad Sword. She attended St. Ann's Academy in Wilkes-Barre, PA; Wyoming Seminary, Kingston, PA; and New York University. She received a BA in English from Hood College, Frederick, MD. Mrs. Wilson was a partner with Cottage Dale Acres, Smyrna. She had been employed by Emerson Real Estate, Smyrna, as a broker; Resident Buying House, working in advertising; and was with Kirby Block and Fisher in New York. Her affiliations included the Junior League of Wilkes-Barre, New York and Wilmington, DE; Delaware Arts Council; Children's Bureau of Delaware; Kent General Hospital Junior Board. She was a member of Maple Dale Country Club, Dover, Delaware and St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Smyrna, where she served on the Altar Guild. She enjoyed tennis, golf, bridge, sculpturing, painting, horticulture and the piano. She is survived by her husband of 48 years, John E. Wilson, III; a son; four daughters; a brother, William Harris Sword of Princeton, NJ; 11 grandchildren; seven nieces and nephews. Services will be held 12 PM Saturday, May 1, at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 22 North Union Street, Smyrna, DE. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 22 North Union Street, Smyrna, DE 19977 or to Delaware Hospice, 911 So. DuPont Highway, Dover, DE 19901.

title: Residential Real Estate; After 7 Years, East Side Condominium Is Selling Quickly
description: The Gotham, a 239-apartment building at 170 East 87th Street, at Third Avenue, was designed as a condominium. But its opening in 1992 was buffeted by the ups and downs of Manhattan's housing market, and for the last seven years it has been used mostly as a rental building.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR SOARS. Sugar prices rose more than 8 percent, the biggest gain in six years, on speculation that Russia is stocking up on cheap supplies. In New York, sugar for July delivery rose 0.34 cent, to 4.42 cents a pound.

title: '7 Lb. 9 Oz.' -- 'The Reintegration of Tradition in Contemporary Art'
description: Asian-American Arts Center

title: On Yugoslavia, Congress Must Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEEMAN, RICHARD K.
description: ZEEMAN-Richard K. 58, April 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Joanne, devoted and loving father of Andrea and Nicole. Brother-in-law of Harold and Sue, uncle of Alan and Marnie. Your generosity and unselfishness has had a major impact on our lives. We will miss you. Sue, Harold, Alan and Marnie

title: AMERISOURCE HEALTH IS BUYING C. D. SMITH HEALTHCARE
description: The Amerisource Health Corporation, the No. 4 United States drug wholesaler, agreed yesterday to buy a competitor, C. D. Smith Healthcare Inc., for $79.9 million in stock. It will also assume $89.1 million of C. D. Smith debt. C. D. Smith, the seventh-largest United States drug wholesaler, is owned by employees. It is based in St. Joseph, Mo. Amerisource, which is based in Malvern, Pa., and C. D. Smith will have about 3,500 employees and 22 drug distribution facilities. (Bloomberg News)

title: Surprise on Capitol Hill: No! And Then Billions
description: For Congress, or even one house of Congress, to refuse to endorse current combat missions is about as unusual as Congress's keeping pork out of an urgent spending bill.

title: Cutups On Cable: Odd Ones In
description: For the next month the network sweeps period will bring specials based on a premise programmers cling to as if it were a life raft: that viewers can never get enough of treacly inspirational dramas, bloated historical pageants and exploding vehicles of any kind. But while Joan of Arc struggles to disarm a nuclear bomb on a high-speed train while singing ''Baby Love'' with Diana Ross (or something like that), the true signs of television life are elsewhere.

title: How a Dazzling Visual Barrage Began
description: Graphic design, the hard-sell branch of the visual arts, came out of Futurism and Dada and took off with Russian Constructivism, grabbing the consumer's eye with clever effects and images. Its heyday occurred between the two world wars, when its practitioners included the Europeans Aleksandr Rodchenko, Kurt Schwitters, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Liubov Popova, El Lissitzky, George Grosz, John Heartfield and the Americans Man Ray, Lester Beall and Otis Shepard, artists who could and would turn their innovative hands to commercial or propaganda purposes. Graphic design today, now extending to television and the Internet, pales by comparison. But alas the giants in the field are gone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSON, ESTHER
description: LIPSON-Esther. On April 29th, 1999. Beloved mother of Marcia Lipson. Dear sister, aunt and cousin. Services today, April 30th, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Chosen for the Wines
description: Great wine lists are not just compendiums of expensive wines. Ideally they should reflect a restaurant's identity and ambitions while offering bottles that complement a restaurant's food at all price levels. Here are 12 restaurants with some of the most interesting wine lists in New York. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, LAWRENCE
description: KAHN-Lawrence. Of Flushing on April 28, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice; devoted father of Robert Kahn and Diana Taylor; loving grandfather of Brian and Rebecca Taylor; beloved brother of Joseph and the late Henry; dearest father-in-law of Harris Taylor and Patrice Lyons; loving grandfather-in-law of Marguerite Taylor. A tower of strength, integrity, devotion and love, he set an example of humanity at its finest. He was respected and loved deeply by family and friends. We will miss him forever. Services on Sunday, 9:45 AM, Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. Contributions may be made to Temple Gates of Prayer, Fund for Education.

title: Who Will Run the World Trade Group?
description: With only hours left before a deadline expires today to choose a new leader of the World Trade Organization, bruising divisions and mistrust among member nations were keeping them from reaching an agreement.

title: Sports of The Times; Jockeys Sign For a Dollar And a Dream
description: THE rain left town and the sun came out and it finally felt like spring, like Kentucky Derby week at Churchill Downs. But for a couple of hours yesterday, the race became secondary for about half the jockeys in the 20-horse field. The potential winnings, from tomorrow's 125th running of the most famous horse race there is, mattered less than a few jars stuffed with one dollar bills.

title: France Restores a Looted Monet to Owner's Heirs
description: Almost 60 years after the collection of a wealthy French-Jewish art dealer and collector was plundered by German occupation forces, the French Government today returned a Monet painting to the man's heirs in a ceremony that suggested greater French enthusiasm for settling claims to looted art than has so far been apparent.

title: British Tour Operator Bids for a Rival
description: Airtours P.L.C., Britain's second-largest tour operator, made a bid of $:852.1 million ($1.37 billion) yesterday for a rival, First Choice Holidays P.L.C. If the bid succeeds, Airtours will overtake Thomson Travel Group P.L.C. as Britain's largest tour operator, with a capitalization of around $:2.8 billion. But First Choice has already agreed to merge with Switzerland's Kuoni Reisen Holding A.G.

title: INSIDE
description: Suspect Said to Delete Files

title: House G.O.P. Adds Billions for Military In Balkans Package
description: House Republicans moved today to add billions in military spending to the package the Administration had requested for NATO's air war, one day after denying the President political support to fight the war.

title: Argument Ends in Killing Of Teen-Ager In Brooklyn
description: An 18-year-old man was fatally shot after an argument on a Brooklyn sidewalk yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Political Briefing; Democratic Feud Boils in California
description: The feud rages on between California's two top elected officials, Gov. Gray Davis and Lieut. Gov. Cruz Bustamante. The two Democrats pledged a partnership when they took office last January, but that was before Mr. Davis rejected Mr. Bustamante's strong suggestion that the state not appeal the court decision killing the statewide proposition mandating an end to state aid for illegal immigrants, most of them Hispanic. Mr. Bustamante is the state's highest elected Hispanic official.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COULOUCOUNDIS, CLEOPATRA
description: COULOUCOUNDIS - Cleopatra. Annual memorial service will be held Sunday, May 2, at 11 AM, at the Greek Cathedral, 323 East 74 Street, Manhattan.

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Neighbors Laud Victim As Loving Family Man
description: Edgar Rivera is the sort of father who worries whether he's giving equal attention to his three children. He is quiet and circumspect, a man who takes his pleasure from hard work, faith, family and, when he can, good jazz.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ESTELLE KOSCHES
description: KLEIN-Estelle Kosches, 99 years of age. At her home in Manhattan on April 29, 1999. Devoted wife for 73 years of the late George Washington Klein. Survived by eight nieces and nephews; 13 grandnieces and nephews; and nine great-grand-nieces and nephews. Services will be held on Sunday, May 2nd at 10:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. to be followed by a private burial at Mt. Neboh Cemetery, Glendale, NY. The family suggests that in lieu of flowers contributions be made to Estelle's favorite charities: The Council for Jewish Women (New York Section) or the U.J.A. Federation of Jewish Philanthropies or the Anti-Defamation League.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Zoning's Flawed Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COTTER, WILLIAM J.
description: COTTER-William J. Darling Will, Happy Birthday in Heaven. Memories of you are very dear. Love always, Elaine

title: U.S. Scrutinizing Aetna Proposal to Buy Prudential Unit
description: Doctors and consumer advocates have flooded the Justice Department with evidence they say suggests that Aetna's plan to buy Prudential Health Care would harm competition in the health insurance industry. But Federal antitrust officials say they have found potential problems in only a few states, including Texas and New Jersey.

title: Brazil Pushes Ahead on Bank Inquiry
description: Brazilian lawmakers pressed forward today with an inquiry into allegations of inside information leaks at the country's central bank.

title: COVANCE SAYS IT IS ACQUIRING PAREXEL FOR $612 MILLION
description: Covance Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the Parexel International Corporation for $612.7 million in stock and combine the two drug research and development companies under the name Covance Parexel Inc. The combined company, with sales of $1.3 billion, would be one of the largest providers of drug development and introduction services for the pharmaceutical industry. Covance offered 1.184 of its shares, worth about $24.12, for each of Parexel's 25.4 million shares. Covance's shares fell 19 percent, losing $5.1875 each, to $22.3125. Parexel's shares jumped $3.9375, to $23.25. Parexel, based in Waltham, Mass., had sales last year of $285.4 million. Covance, of Princeton, N.J., had 1998 revenues of $731.6 million.

title: Unions to Protest Cuts, Vouchers and Workfare
description: New York City union leaders announced yesterday that they would hold a rally on May 12 to protest the budget policies of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Two Convicted In Spying Case
description: Two Taiwan executives who paid an employee of the Avery Dennison Corporation to pilfer corporate secrets from the United States adhesives maker were convicted of economic espionage on Wednesday in the first case tried under a United States law designed to combat trade-secret thefts.

title: Neanderthal Cousins?
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE RACING: Road to The Derby; At End of the No. 19 Post, Menifee Camp Sees a Light
description: Two days before the Kentucky Derby, the gloom surrounding Barn 35 at Churchill Downs was lifting after being pierced by the old-fashioned trust -- and maybe the piety -- of the team inside. Its members needed all the uplift they could get after Menifee drew the dreaded No. 19 post position in a field of 20, placing one more hurdle in their path to great expectations for their hometown horse.

title: Parasites, Not Pollution, May Produce Frog Deformities
description: Trailing tangles of a dozen limbs or missing legs altogether, the deformed frogs found in rising numbers around the country have become a powerful symbol of what many fear is an ever more poisoned environment. But at least in some areas, scientists report today, evidence shows that the frog deformities are being caused not by toxic substances but by parasitic worms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, CHARLOTTE (NEE BERNER)
description: COHEN-Charlotte (nee Berner). Of Teaneck NJ, on April 28, 1999. Beloved wife of Raymond. Devoted mother of Andrew Cohen and Alice Cohen. Dear sister of Ruth Latz. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 402 Park St. Hackensack, NJ on Sunday at 11:30 a.m.

title: N.J. Prosecutor Is Accused Of 'Profligate' Overspending
description: Since taking office a year ago, the Essex County Prosecutor, Patricia A. Hurt, has increased staff salaries by more than $500,000 a year and purchased a huge $248,541 customized mobile command post, and is now asking the county for more money to cover extra expenses, top county officials said this week.

title: History of Mental Illness Detailed For Man Held in Subway Attack
description: A homeless man accused of pushing a commuter into the path of an oncoming subway train on Wednesday had a history of mental illness and told detectives that he had spent the day of the attack roaming city streets, convinced people were trying to kill him, a police official said yesterday.

title: The Gaming of Violence
description: What Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold saw as they made their murderous way through Columbine High School last week looked nothing like the images they saw while playing the video game called Doom. Instead of heavily armed, square-chinned men and prognathous monsters roaming a fortress set in a vaguely Asiatic mountain range, the two teen-agers saw ordinary students lying prostrate in the blandly over-lit hallways and classrooms of a modern American high school. How that hideous reality compared to the fantasy of Doom in the minds of those two boys is impossible to judge.

title: Defending a Son's Honor at All Costs
description: David Mamet's handsome, stately adaptation of Terence Rattigan's play ''The Winslow Boy'' does not embellish upon its source material. Instead it skillfully pares the play down to its essentials, arriving at a faithful but tighter version of this drama about a family defending the honor of its young son. Especially notable for their absence are Mr. Rattigan's stage directions about the characters' emotions, the ones specifying when anger or relief, humility or confidence is an appropriate reaction. Mr. Mamet likes his principals trickier than that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOLYA, ANDREW
description: LOLYA-Andrew. The New York City Ballet Orchestra deeply mourns the loss of our principal flutist, Andrew Lolya. His artistry and dedication to our orchestra will be sorely missed. New York City Ballet Orchestra

title: A Marciano Docudrama Gets Much of It Wrong
description: Toward the end of ''Rocky Marciano,'' a coming Showtime docudrama, the retired boxer flies to Denver on the final day of his life to visit Joe Louis in a psychiatric hospital. When he leaves, Marciano hands the hospital administrator a bag full of cash to upgrade Louis's care.

title: MARKETWATCH.COM TO PAY $166 MILLION FOR BIGCHARTS
description: Marketwatch.com Inc., a Web-based provider of business news, agreed yesterday to acquire Bigcharts Inc. of Minneapolis, one of the 10 most visited financial Internet sites, for about $160 million in stock and $6 million in cash. Marketwatch.com is to exchange about 2.175 million shares of its common stock and pay $6 million in cash for all outstanding Bigcharts stock. Marketwatch.com, based in San Francisco, is a joint venture between CBS Broadcasting Inc. and the Data Broadcasting Corporation, a financial information provider. Marketwatch.com's shares slipped $1.125, to $72.50.

title: 'Limbo' Means What It Says
description: It is a season of certainty in Hollywood, at least as far as story lines in popular movies are concerned. There is often a very pronounced difference between the good guys and the bad guys, and movies tend to end on a note of clarity. There is a winner and a loser, a resolution. It is no accident that many movies now are based on comic books, which tend to have a clear conception of good and right.

title: Distilling The Dance Of Time
description: There is much to appreciate and to contest in ''Dance for a City: 50 Years of the New York City Ballet,'' an exhibition that the New-York Historical Society is presenting through Aug. 15 on the occasion of the City Ballet's golden anniversary season.

title: For Vietnamese, a New Apocalypse
description: ''Three Seasons'' is a wistful, rain-streaked elegy for a Vietnamese culture that is being swept away on the flood-tide of globalization. Too tender-hearted and lyrical to deliver a political indictment, this touching film, which was chosen best dramatic feature at the Sundance Film Festival in January, is a dreamy cinematic poem whose interwoven voices offer different variations of the same sad story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, ARTHUR L.
description: ABRAMS-Arthur L., 86, of Scranton, PA, on April 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth Friedman. Cherished father of Judy Steinhardt, Ellen Abrams Stossel, Ann Lutz. Loved by his grandchildren, David and Daniel Steinhardt and Sara Berman, Lauren and Max Stossel, Emily and Ben Kaplan. Adoring great-grandfather of Jacob Berman. Devoted brother of Mildred Golden and Natalie Gossels. Shiva Sunday, May 2, 3-8 p.m., 211 Central Park West, Apt. 15K, and Monday, May 3, 12-9 p.m., 1158 Fifth Avenue, Apt. 16A.

title: Club Med Gets Serious; The Purveyor of Packaged Hedonism Tones Down a Bit
description: The 85-acre Club Med resort here, like many of its counterparts around the globe, has lured millions of vacationers to the tropics by offering them a simple choice: work on their tans or keep active from sunup until exhaustion playing tennis, hiking, snorkeling or wind surfing.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. *denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Initial Jobless Claims Are Down; Purchases of New Homes Climb
description: More Americans are buying new homes and claims for jobless benefits are falling, Government reports showed today.

title: Art Rediscovers a Home On the Upper East Side
description: As an art gallery scene, the Upper East Side may have an identity problem. The phrase itself lacks the cutting-edge hipness of those charmed double syllables, ''SoHo'' and ''Chelsea.'' And the actual area -- less a neighborhood than an aggregate of them -- is amorphously vague of border and devoid of geographical cohesion.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Political Briefing; Democrats Say Bush Is Waffling on Guns
description: In the aftermath of the Colorado school shootings, just about every Presidential candidate, announced and otherwise, has voiced an opinion on what should be done to control such violence, including whether there should be more gun laws.

title: Pizzeria Co-Worker Is Tied To Gun in School Shootings
description: Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold got the high-powered, semiautomatic pistol used in last week's high school massacre here with the help of a man who worked with them at a pizza delivery store, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Teen-Age Boys in Love and in Pain
description: Steven Carter (Ben Silverstone), the hero of Simon Shore's likable British film ''Get Real,'' is a bright-eyed, principled high school student who has known he was gay since the age of 11. Now in his late teens, he has taken to cruising the public restroom in a local park. While waiting in a stall one day, he exchanges notes through a hole in the partition with a stranger who, to his shock, turns out to be John Dixon (Brad Gorton), a popular fellow student.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACK, EUGENE F., AKA THE JUDGE
description: BACK-Eugene F., aka The Judge, passed away April 27, 1999. A retired major, attorney and judge, he is survived by his daughter (Ellen) T'Brin, step-sons, Kenneth and Jeffrey Morgen, and his most beloved cat, Mooki.

title: ONEOK SAYS IT WON'T RAISE ITS BID FOR SOUTHWEST GAS
description: Oneok Inc. said yesterday that it would not top the Southern Union Company's bid for the Southwest Gas Corporation, saying its lower offer is superior. Oneok raised its offer on Monday to $30 a share in cash, a total of $912 million, plus the assumption of $860 million in debt and preferred stock. Southern Union, which made an unsolicited offer of $32 a share in February, raised that offer on Tuesday to $33.50 a share, or $1.02 billion plus the assumption of debt. Oneok said that unlike Southern Union it had the financial muscle to complete the purchase and finance Southwest Gas's expansion. Southern Union shares rose 50 cents, to $22.25; Southwest Gas fell 25 cents, to $28.75, and Oneok rose 37.5 cents, to $28.625.

title: Palestinian Leaders Decide Not to Declare Statehood Next Week
description: Palestinian leaders decided today against declaring statehood next Tuesday, retreating from a pledge that the Israelis saw as a threat, and so defusing a volatile situation.

title: Broken, but Not Unfixable
description: A decade after watching Carlos Pimentel graduate from Seward Park High School on the Lower East Side, I spotted his lanky form on a subway platform. We had stayed in contact in the intervening years, and I knew he had graduated from college and earned a law degree.

title: Almost a Microsoft Witness, But Definitely a Hot Potato
description: He was personally asked to be a witness in the Microsoft antitrust trial by the software giant's chairman, William H. Gates, but he was quickly dropped from the company's witness list after he was questioned by a Government lawyer last fall.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Investors Show More Interest In REIT Stocks
description: Until now, Warren E. Buffett's best-known real estate gamble was on a bank.

title: Melba Liston, 73, Trombonist And Prominent Jazz Arranger
description: Melba Liston, a trombonist and arranger who worked with some of the best bands in jazz, died on Friday after a series of strokes, said a friend, the pianist Randy Weston. She was 73 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRODEN, GERALD D., ESQ.
description: GRODEN-Gerald D., Esq. Devoted husband of the late Sylvia. Beloved father of Lewis & Machelle and Jim & Diana. Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Elizabeth and Heather. Loving friend of Lea. Services Sunday, 10 AM at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, LI.

title: Hedge Fund Report Raises Few Hackles on Wall Street
description: Hedge fund managers, who six months ago were beside themselves that regulators might clamp down on their freewheeling partnerships in the wake of Long-Term Capital Management's near-collapse, are breathing easier.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: On My Mind; Spies and Character
description: How come they can do it right here in America and how come our Government does not take action when the crimes are discovered?

title: Tribunal Chief Plans to Quit, Causing U.S. to Fear for Fate of Milosevic Case
description: The chief prosecutor of the international war crimes tribunal is planning to leave her post, a move that officials worry would weaken the tribunal at a time when the Clinton Administration is looking to the court to prosecute atrocities committed to Kosovo.

title: Yanks Act Conservatively, Sit Clemens Out for 15 Days
description: Roger Clemens, the five-time Cy Young Award winner acquired in the spring, was placed on the 15-day disabled list today, one of a series of moves intended to restructure the balance on the Yankees' roster.

title: Metro Business; Computer Testing Is Urged
description: Bell Atlantic Corporation, the country's largest local telephone company, should do more testing of its computer systems before being allowed to offer long-distance service, the New York State Attorney General has recommended.

title: A Keyboard Revolutionary Detonates Another Recital
description: The excellent pianist and contemporary-music champion Kathleen Supove calls the adventurous series of performances she has been presenting over the years ''The Exploding Piano.'' Although the title sounds incendiary, the piano itself has always been exploding. Think of Beethoven pushing the capacities of the instruments of his day with visionary works like the ''Hammerklavier'' Sonata, or Cage turning the piano into a wondrous music box by inserting all manner of screws and sticks into the strings.

title: Mother's in Jail, but Her Daughter Is the Prisoner
description: WHITE OLEANDER

title: Most Crime Guns Are Bought, Not Stolen
description: The teen-agers who killed 12 of their classmates and a teacher last week in Colorado got their guns the way most violent juveniles and adult criminals get theirs: by purchasing them from gun dealers or at gun shows or by buying them using friends as intermediaries, law enforcement officials and criminologists say.

title: Informatica Shares Soar
description: Shares of the Informatica Corporation closed today more than 80 percent above the initial public offering price. The company, based in Palo Alto, a maker of software to help businesses manage information flow, sold 2.75 million shares at $16 each. It plans to use proceeds from the offering for general corporate purposes, including working capital. Shares of Informatica closed today at $29.375 on the Nasdaq stock market on volume of 4.43 million shares.

title: New Video Releases
description: You've Got Mail

title: Corrections
description: A review of the 2000 Buick LeSabre in the Automobiles section on Sunday referred incorrectly to the engine of another Buick model, the Park Avenue. It is a V6, not a V8.

title: Aging at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY PLANS TO FORESTALL SUIT ON RACE PROFILING
description: Trying to forestall a Federal civil rights lawsuit, New Jersey's Attorney General, Peter G. Verniero, said today that the state had agreed to negotiate a settlement with Federal officials over allegations that state police engaged in widespread racial profiling against black and Hispanic motorists.

title: Pharmacia Profits Increase 17%
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc., the drug company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profits rose 17 percent, while Hoechst A.G. and Rhone-Poulenc S.A., which plan to merge later this year, posted lower-than-expected quarterly earnings.

title: Wage Growth In '99 Below Expectations
description: Despite declining unemployment and a shortage of workers in some industries, wage and benefit increases slowed markedly in the first three months of the year, the Government reported today.

title: Killer of Deliverymen Portrayed as Neglected
description: A social worker portrayed Thomas Koskovich yesterday as a victim of neglect and rejection, abandoned by his parents by 11, raised by a domineering, alcoholic grandmother and reminded often that he resembled his uncle, a lifelong criminal.

title: Olivetti Opens Latest Phase Of Phone Bid
description: Olivetti S.p.A.'s $65 billion hostile offer to buy Telecom Italia S.p.A. officially opens Friday, putting pressure on Italy's largest phone company to rally investor support for its alternative, an $82 billion merger with Deutsche Telekom A.G.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORIN, WALTER
description: FLORIN-Walter. The Rabbi, Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst, NY and its Affiliates express deepest sympathy on the passing of its member. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

title: Poor Nations and the Debt Trap
description: Last year when Uganda became the first country to get some relief of its external debt under a new program of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, it used the money it saved largely to eliminate fees charged for primary school. The impact was dramatic. While two years ago 54 percent of Uganda's children attended primary school, this year 90 percent do. In contrast, neighboring Zambia, which spends five times more each year on debt service than on primary education, had to raise school fees. Enrollment there is dropping.

title: Jonathan Winters Wins Twain Prize
description: The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts announced today that its second Mark Twain Prize for humor would go to Jonathan Winters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, HONEY
description: GOTTLIEB-Honey. On Thursday, April 29, 1999, from Long Beach, NY. Beloved wife of the late Morton D. Devoted mother of Lois Ann Tropp. Grandmother of Richard Jr., William and Joseph J. Goldstein. Great-grandmother of five beautiful girls. Graveside service 1 PM today at Montefiore Cemetery, Queens, New York.

title: Rory Calhoun, 76, Star of Many Cowboy Movies
description: Rory Calhoun, a heartthrob-handsome actor who starred in scores of cowboy movies and the television series ''The Texan,'' died Wednesday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Burbank, Calif. He was 76.

title: Israeli Police Said to Recommend Bribery Indictment of Sharon
description: Israeli radio and television reported tonight that the police have recommended to the State Attorney that Foreign Minister Ariel Sharon be indicted on charges of fraud, bribery and witness tampering.

title: Stock Funds Get $12.7 Billion in Month
description: Investors put $12.7 billion in net new cash into equity mutual funds in March, more than 17 times February's $712 million in net sales, the Investment Company Institute, an industry trade association, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AUDITORE, STEPHEN
description: AUDITORE-Stephen. April 23, 1999. To know Stephen was to love Stephen and I always will. Adieu.

title: Sprewell Picks Up Knicks and Shoots Down 76ers

title: SHAW IN $312 MILLION DEAL FOR FUNDY COMMUNICATIONS
description: Shaw Communications Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy Fundy Communications Inc., for $312 million, including $102 million of class B shares. Fundy, a privately held company in Saint John, New Brunswick, operates cable television systems serving 192,000 subscribers, mainly in New Brunswick. With Fundy's fiber backbone network, Shaw said it would be able to introduce digital cable and high-speed Internet access service in New Brunswick and Nova Scotia. Shaw, based in Calgary, Alberta, is also a cable television company. It had revenue of $291 million in the six months ended Feb. 28.

title: One of baseball's most colorful figures finds he is in demand again.
description: SOME 35 years after he stopped playing ball, Yogi Berra is having something of a renaissance as a pitchman. For the former Yankee catcher, it really is deja vu all over again.

title: Wall St. Passes Year 2000 Test
description: Wall Street firms and exchanges completed extensive mock trading of stocks, bonds and other securities simulating the end of December and the start of next year with almost no interruptions from Year 2000 computer problems, according to a summary of the results released yesterday by the Securities Industry Association.

title: Monitor Unit Says City Fails On Jail Care
description: Seven months after city officials promised to address medical-care problems on Rikers Island, a city watchdog agency has charged that those officials have done a poor job monitoring care and have acted as an ally, rather than as an overseer, of the hospital that treats inmates in the jails.

Graveside service today at 11:30 AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Arthur Schawlow, 77, Nobelist for Lasers, Dies
description: Arthur L. Schawlow, co-winner of the 1981 Nobel Prize in Physics for his role in the development of lasers, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 77 and lived in Palo Alto.

Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-4 & 7-9pm at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc in Larchmont, NY. Mass Mon 11am at Sts. John & Paul Church in Larchmont. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, New York.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose against the single European currency as the conflict in Yugoslavia continued to rattle Europe. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0591, down from $1.0627 on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRESSLER, ALFRED W.
description: BRESSLER-Alfred W. A lawyer and partner in the firm of Moses & Singer for over sixty years. A memorial service will be held on Monday, May 3, at 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65 Street, Manhattan.

description: RIVKIN-Lois Herman. The family of Lois Rivkin mourns the loss on April 27, of their beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister, after a valiant fight against lymphoma. Her creation of Friends of the Public Schools exemplified her warmth, energy, optimism & love of New York City. A memorial service will be held Sunday, May 2, at 11 A.M. at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Congregation Rodeph Sholom, or to the Citizens Committee for New York City, 305 7th Avenue.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Walking into the Lombardy Hotel is like walking into a time warp. Jean Harlow and Clark Gable could be sipping martinis in the lounge, listening to the soft piano music and waiting to go to dinner in the almost as retro hotel dining room. Only the contemporary prints and paintings on the walls of Soma Park suggest someone is trying to update the restaurant's Art Deco look and feel.

title: Pay of Nassau Police Supervisors Will Rise %24 by 2002
description: A state arbitrator has ruled that Nassau County, which already pays among the country's highest police salaries, must increase the pay of police supervisors by more than 24 percent by 2002.

title: Millstone Unit Approved, But Judge Blocks Restart
description: Millstone Unit 2, which has been shut for three years due to safety concerns, won approval yesterday from the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission to start generating electricity again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUQUA, STEPHEN O. JR

He is survived by his wife Frances Hathaway Fuqua at home, four sons and one daughter, four stepchildren. Funeral service will be at Old Cadet Chapel U.S. Military Academy at West Point NY 1:30pm May 3, burial West Point NY.

title: TRW Will Reorganize Into Two Segments
description: TRW Inc., the world's No. 2 maker of automobile air bags, said this week that it would reorganize into two business segments -- TRW Automotive and TRW Aerospace and Information Systems -- after its purchase of Lucas Varity P.L.C.

title: Grant's Tomb, Then
description: To the Editor:

title: Album of the Week
description: KREIDLER: ''APPEARANCE AND THE PARK'' (Mute). In the 1970's, German bands like Can and Neu wandered from psychedelic jamming to the minimalistic delights of laying pattern upon pattern. Kreidler, a four-member band -- bass, drums, samplers, turntables -- from Dusseldorf, is part of the rediscovery of that era, when eager, goofy futurism was expressed in the shallow tones of early synthesizers. Kreidler brings back the lightweight clanks and blips and hand claps, the hisses and gurgles and tootles of those instruments, while tucking its more realistic modern sounds behind the vintage analog timbres. Its pieces are unhurried and sparsely arranged; only one, luckily, has vocals. And after the tinniness provides its amusements, Kreidler's ingenuity takes over. Mechanized repetitions, just out of phase, turn into dizzying polyrhythms; vaguely ominous melodies float into earshot and linger. Somehow, the limited sounds become poignant as well as funny, as if even simple machines had hearts. JON PARELES

title: A Minefield Is Crossed, But at What Sad Cost
description: When they came upon the minefield in the rugged mountains near the border, the 64 Kosovo Albanian refugees were warned to stay in single file and not stray from the narrow path or stumble on a branch or rock in the predawn gloom.

title: So Hot They're Cool, or Just Right
description: The four 20-something idols of 98 Degrees surveyed the audience on Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, a forest of girls advancing the way Birnam Wood encroached upon Macbeth. The men did what had to be done: They dropped to their knees and thanked the little soldiers for support that has brought bounty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUSTEIN, MAX
description: BLAUSTEIN-Max. The League Treatment Center extends our heartfelt sympathy to Tommye Feit, our dear colleague, and her family on the loss of her beloved father Max Blaustein. Mr. Blaustein is survived by his wife Lillian and his three daughters Tommye Feit, Ellen Safeer, Vicki Ehren, eight grandchildren and twelve great-grandchildren. Mr. Blaustein was a retired Deputy Chief Probation Officer for the New York City Court System.

title: Hess Remains Hospitalized
description: Leon Hess, the 85-year-old owner of the Jets, remained hospitalized yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan, three weeks after breaking a hip. The Jets and the hospital declined to give any information about his condition or prognosis.

title: SPRINT RAISES OFFER FOR WIRELESS TELEVISION OPERATOR
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it had raised its offer for the People's Choice TV Corporation to $10 a share from $8 in response to investors who ''controlled a sizable block of stock'' in People's Choice. The group went to Sprint after People's Choice, a Shelton, Conn., wireless cable television operator, said on April 12 that it had agreed to be acquired by Sprint for $8 a share, a Sprint spokesman said. By agreeing to terms with that group, Sprint insured that it would get ''enough of the stock so that we feel the deal is a certainty,'' the spokesman said. The value of Sprint's offer now stands at about $150 million, or about $25 million more than the original offer.

title: Volvo Raises Stake In Scania to 14.5%
description: Volvo A.B., the world's second-largest truck maker, said yesterday that it had raised its voting stake in a Swedish rival, Scania A.B., to about 14.5 percent. Scania has rejected Volvo's advances.

description: Loyola's 19-11 conquest of Delaware on Wednesday left the top-ranked Greyhounds (10-0) two victories short of a rare undefeated season. Remaining regular-season games are against Hobart at Geneva, N.Y., tomorrow and at North Carolina next Saturday.

description: Of course there was corruption under former President Suharto, his half-brother said recently, acknowledging a fact of life well known to all Indonesians.

title: Clinton Plans Meeting
description: President Clinton said yesterday that he planned to summon high-ranking leaders of the entertainment industry and other experts to the White House ''in the near future'' to discuss how violent incidents like the school shootings that killed 15 people in Colorado might be prevented. In an interview to be broadcast this morning on the NBC program ''Today,'' Mr. Clinton said questions to be addressed included these: ''What should we do about guns? What should we do about culture?''

title: B-52's to Carry Less Accurate Gravity Bombs
description: With stocks of cruise missiles dwindling, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen announced today that the Pentagon is providing 10 more B-52 bombers to NATO forces to be used for the first time to drop traditional bombs on Serbian military targets, as well as to fire guided missiles.

title: OPEN TEXT SAYS IT IS MAKING ANOTHER BID FOR PC DOCS
description: The Open Text Corporation made an all-cash takeover bid yesterday for PC Docs Group International Inc. of $5.76 a share in cash, or $134.5 million. Shares of PC Docs closed yesterday at $5.40625. Open Text said its bid was superior to an all-stock offer made by Hummingbird Communications Inc., which offered to exchange one-third of a share for each PC Docs share. In December, Open Text offered to acquire PC Docs for stock but withdrew the offer after the PC Docs board rejected the proposal. Open Text, based in Waterloo, Ontario, provides intranet software technology. PC Docs, based in Toronto, makes document and data base management software. Hummingbird, also in Toronto, provides enterprise connectivity software.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORENKO, CATHERINE HINES
description: GORENKO-Catherine Hines. 93 years. Of Charlotte, NC. Died April 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Victor. Fond sister of Mary H. Bartscherer, Arthur J. Hines and Helen H. Carson. Former elementary school teacher in Brooklyn, NY, for 50 years. Funeral was Thursday from the ''McManus Funeral Home,'' 2001 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, Hudson, NY. title: Electronic Data Systems to Cut 5,200 Jobs
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the big computer-services company founded by H. Ross Perot, said today that it was cutting 5,200 jobs, or 4.3 percent of its workers. The company took pretax charges of $379.8 million that resulted in a first-quarter loss of $20.6 million, or 4 cents a share. A year earlier it had net income of $184.2 million, or 37 cents a share.

title: Peace Effort By Russian So Far Shows Slim Progress
description: A Russian-led peace initiative for Kosovo appeared to make little headway today, with Moscow and the West divided over the composition of any international force in Kosovo and the Yugoslav Government in defiant mood.

title: India's Angry Poor: A Political Question Mark
description: The farmer rode his shiny blue bicycle to the village blacksmith's hut today to get his wheat thresher repaired. But as the two men sat on a string cot in the withering 110-degree heat, with a haze of flies periodically rising from a pile of sugar-cane fodder to engulf them, the talk turned to politics.

That's the jaunty, absurdist view of existence offered by ''Testamento,'' a colorful, good-natured yarn that examines the life and times of Napumoceno da Silva Araujo (Nelson Xavier), the wealthiest man in Cape Verde.

title: U.S. Approves Deal for Taiwan To Buy Radar to Monitor China
description: The United States has decided to sell an early-warning radar system to Taiwan that will allow it to monitor the launch of Chinese ballistic missiles or manned bombers, Clinton Administration officials said today.

description: After a rampage that took 15 lives at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., last week, questions emerged about teen-agers and the often-violent popular culture they are immersed in.

title: Wimbledon To Maintain Prize-Money Gender Gap
description: Wimbledon, the Grand Slam event at the heart of a volatile debate over its tradition of awarding significantly less prize money to women than men, turned a deaf ear yesterday on an official request from the WTA Tour to upgrade the women's prize money this year.

description: Nasdaq stocks slumped for the third consecutive session yesterday as investors took profits in high-technology shares, casting a further pall over the market in general.
