title: Repsol Pursues Buyout of Argentine Oil Concern
description: In a deal that would create the world's eighth-largest oil company, Repsol S.A., Spain's largest oil company, said yesterday that it was offering $13.4 billion in cash to buy the 85 percent of YPF, the Argentine oil company, it does not already own.

title: They're a Devilish Match, But Who's Conning Whom?
description: The caper film ''Entrapment'' summons the days when being a thief with taste was the profession of choice for the soigne movie hero. It resurrects that art of gamesmanship by casting Sean Connery as Robert (Mac) Macdougal, the kind of baronial art connoisseur who has assembled his collection by unorthodox means. He presumably meets his match in Catherine Zeta-Jones's Virginia (Gin) Baker, the most glamorous of insurance investigators. When the story sends these two to an elegant party, extras swivel their heads to gape at Ms. Zeta-Jones in ways that don't look rehearsed.

title: W.N.B.A. Players to Vote On a 4-Year Contract Deal
description: Labor peace finally came to women's pro basketball yesterday with the first collective bargaining agreement in women's team sports in the United States.

title: Violence, Real and Imagined, Sweeps Through the Schools
description: A 14-year-old boy was charged with murder in Canada, five Brooklyn youths were accused of conspiracy, a pipe bomb was found in an Oklahoma school and school districts across the nation were on heightened alert yesterday as bomb threats, talk of hit lists and fears of more violence in the wake of the Littleton, Colo., massacre continued to ripple outward.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have to react to every little thing now because we can't separate the real from the imagined.''

title: Housing Officer, Awaiting Trial, Is Arrested Again
description: A housing police officer awaiting trial on several sex and weapons offenses was arrested again yesterday and charged with exposing himself on a subway train in Brooklyn, the police said.

description: The CBS Corporation reported an unexpected first-quarter profit yesterday as the company benefited from revenue growth at its radio and billboard operations and a turnaround at its TV businesses.

title: Valparaiso Journal; A Voice of the Left Is Heard Again in the Land
description: This gritty port of steep cliffs and shantytowns was the domain of the left until Gen. Augusto Pinochet smashed the unions representing the dockworkers, metalworkers, railroad workers and printers in the 1970's.

title: Bombing Unites Serb Army As It Debilitates Economy -- Production Cut in Half, Experts Say
description: The Zastava factory in Kragujevac made cars and trucks, as well as munitions. NATO strikes destroyed it completely, putting more than 15,000 people out of work, plus an additional 40,000 who worked at 120 subcontractors.

title: Mets Walk on the Padres' Wild Side
description: After seven innings yesterday afternoon against the San Diego Padres, the Mets -- who had rallied from an early 4-0 deficit -- had six runs on only three hits.

title: Swimming to Oblivion
description: John Guare's new play, ''Lake Hollywood,'' opened last night at the Signature Theater Company, the last production in a season that the group has devoted to Mr. Guare. Starring Kate Burton and Adam Grupper, below, the play is about the futility of the wish for redemption among people who find life all too forlorn and ordinary. Though not as fully integrated as Mr. Guare's finest works, the play is a testament to the consistency of his vision and a reminder that he builds imagery as carefully as any poet.

title: Cambodia Gains Full Status in Southeast Asia
description: Starting on Friday, Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia will finally have a chance to show off his golf game. He will be invited to sing karaoke, too.

title: Accounts
description: * Bristol-Myers Squibb Cardio-Vascular Global Marketing Group, Princeton, N.J., to GHBM Healthworld, New York, a division of the Healthworld Corp., as the first agency to handle the account for Omapatrilat, a new antihypertensive agent. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, HERBERT
description: RAPPAPORT-Herbert. On April 29, 1999 at age 86. A gentle man and a gentle soul, admired for his keen intelligence and quick wit. He was devoted to his late wife, Eleanor, and dearly loved by his daughters, Judy Tobey and Ruthann Lehrer. He will be missed by his grandchildren, Jackie, Emily, Deborah, Daniel, Ben and Rachel, and his five great-grandchildren. Services at ''Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave, Sunday at 11:45.

description: A judge cleared the way yesterday for the trial of a twice-convicted pedophile whose sexual relationship with Sam Manzie, now 17, may have pushed Mr. Manzie over the edge just before he killed 11-year-old Eddie Werner.

title: No Suicide Link To Drug Taken By Eric Harris
description: Luvox, the drug taken by Eric Harris, belongs to the same class of antidepressants as Prozac, Zoloft and other newer medicines used to treat depression and a variety of other psychiatric conditions.

description: Strong interest from fund managers and even the hint of an Internet frenzy have prompted such a scramble for shares of Goldman, Sachs & Company that it could increase the size of its public offering by a factor of eight and still leave some investors disappointed.

description: Old Masters, New Focus

title: Victim Who Lived Only a Day Is Buried, the Killer Unknown
description: In death, Mary Faith received all that she had been denied during her one short day of life.

Father-in-Law of Nancy Phair of Greenlawn, NY. Pre-deceased by a son, Joshua Phair in 1991. Father of Laura Rudin of Long Island, NY. Calling hours are Saturday, May 1, 1999 from 1:00 PM to 2:00 PM at the Edward Lawrence Funeral Home, 2119 Post Road, Darien, CT. Memorial donations may be sent to the American Lung Association, 12 Byington Place, Norwalk, CT 06850.

title: 'The Absent Irascible' -- 'Weldon Kees in Postwar New York'
description: Gallery Gertrude Stein

title: Magnetism on Mars Suggests a Geology Once Like Earth's
description: A telling magnetic pattern in the ancient surface of Mars appears to show that the planet in an early epoch churned with internal heat and other powerful forces, remarkably like the geology of Earth today, scientists reported yesterday.

title: Plan by SBC Advances a Step
description: Texas regulators yesterday signaled conditional approval of SBC Communications Inc.'s application to offer long-distance services in the state.

title: A Learning Experience For a Prominent Visitor
description: Cheyenne Phillips, a kindergartner at Public School 107 in Flushing, Queens, rushed through her lunch yesterday, chewing almost nonstop, in anticipation of a matinee performance of ''Peter Pan.'' She had never been to a Broadway show before. ''But I saw a commercial for it on TV,'' she quickly offered.

title: When 'They' Are 'Us'
description: Nearly all the commentaries about the massacre in Colorado seem to share the assumption that the behavior of the killers reflects some deep failure in the nation's culture -- in our treatment of violence and in the way we bring up our children. Even the tough-talking William Bennett has been moved to suggest that our young boys need more love and attention.

title: States of Mind, With Emphasis on Professionalism
description: The probing of states of mind was the most popular theme at Dance Theater Workshop on Tuesday night in the latest edition of the venerable Fresh Tracks program, a series for emerging choreographers and performance artists. Interestingly, the emphasis was more on craft and professionalism than invention in most of the six pieces.

title: A Schubert Song Cycle, With Poets Rearranged
description: Alfred Brendel has taken up a residency of sorts at Carnegie Hall these last few weeks, performing as a concerto soloist, a recitalist and a collaborator in song recitals, with another concerto appearance and a reading of his poetry still to come. In two concerts, Mr. Brendel accompanied Matthias Goerne, the young German baritone, in Schubert songs.

title: Devils Intent on Distracting Barrasso in Game 5
description: With the Penguin star Jaromir Jagr expected to return for Game 5 Friday after missing three games with a groin problem, the Devils' defense will again be strongly tested in in the National Hockey League opening-round playoff series. New Jersey's offensive plan, however, remains simple: take shots from any distance and create traffic in front of Pittsburgh goalie Tom Barrasso.

title: Foreign Affairs; Japan's Nutcracker Suite
description: For the past decade whenever anyone told me Japan was finally opening its economy and lowering its trade barriers, I always thought of that story of the prisoners who were in jail together for so many years that they didn't need to actually tell each other their jokes anymore. They would just say ''Joke number 3,'' and everyone would laugh. In my case, the simple phrase ''Japan is really opening up its economy this time'' always had a similar laugh-inducing effect.

title: Chief Judge in Turkey Urges Lifting of Curbs on Free Speech
description: Turkey's highest-ranking judge, speaking in terms rarely if ever used by a senior official here, has surprised the country by sharply condemning restrictions on freedom of speech.

title: Potential Mayor of Baltimore Has City Guessing
description: State lawmakers shortened a city residency requirement to allow him to run. Prominent civic, business and church leaders formed a draft committee to encourage him to run. Three former mayors have implored him to run.

title: New Jersey's Trooper Scandal
description: The racial profiling and drug interdiction offenses at the New Jersey State Police keep looking worse and worse. It was outrageous when state troopers were found to be stopping and searching a disproportionate number of black and Hispanic motorists on the New Jersey Turnpike in an effort to intercept illegal drugs. Now it turns out that the State Police have enlisted hotel workers along the turnpike to spy on guests and report behavior as common as speaking Spanish. This civil liberties nightmare has all the earmarks of a program that has spun out of control.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Eames Chairs Are Bending The Market
description: In 1928 Charles Eames, an architecture student, was kicked out of Washington University. Then he went on to have one of the most distinguished careers in design.

title: Patriots Reject Ultimatum By Connecticut Governor
description: The owner of the New England Patriots, Robert K. Kraft, refused a demand tonight by Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut that the team reject a last-minute stadium offer from Massachusetts, but Mr. Kraft said he would continue working with Connecticut for now.

title: Students Charged in Bomb Threat Were Elite
description: They seemed the most unlikely of conspirators: five eighth graders in an accelerated academic program who shared a love of computers and never had so much as a blemish on their disciplinary records.

title: Government Loosens Standards On Tuna Deemed 'Dolphin-Safe'
description: In a decision that has outraged many environmental groups, the Commerce Department yesterday announced that it was broadening the definition of ''dolphin-safe'' tuna to include fish caught by a method that was banned under a 1990 law.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Museums section on April 21 about offbeat institutions referred incompletely to a book by Sandra Gurvis. Originally called ''The Cockroach Hall of Fame and Other Off-the-Wall Museums'' (Citadel Press), it has been reissued under the title ''America's Strangest Museums.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAVEMEYER, HOWARD L.
description: HAVEMEYER-Howard L., of Brooklyn, NY, on April 29th, 1999. Beloved husband of Virginia A. Loving father of Christina and Michael B. Havemeyer. Devoted son of Arline Havemeyer. Dear brother of Elizabeth Wright and Richard. Friends may call at the Howard E. Williams, Inc. Funeral Home, 181 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, NY. Visiting hours 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Saturday and Sunday. Religious service 8 PM, Sunday, at the funeral home, the Rev. Richard Edwards officiating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORDLICHT, HAROLD
description: NORDLICHT-Harold, on April 28, 1999. Wonderful and loving husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Ira Shale Nordlicht and Lea Nordlicht Shedd. Cherished grandfather of Ian, Donny, and Jenny. Loving brother-in-law of Sonia Mirsky. Services Friday, 11 AM, at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.L

title: A Demon Hand, a Cleaver And a Druid Named Debi
description: If timing is everything, then the recent carnage at Columbine High School indicates that now could scarcely be less opportune for the opening of ''Idle Hands,'' a cheap-thrills horror film built around a teen-age murder rampage that reaches its climax among panic-stricken students at a Halloween dance in a small-town high school.

title: Sanitation Chief Seeking to Keep Transfer Stations in Service
description: Facing stiff opposition to a plan to build mammoth new garbage transfer stations once the Fresh Kills landfill is closed, the new Sanitation Commissioner said yesterday that he was seeking ways to make existing stations capable of handling the city's trash for shipment out of state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTCHINSON, MAX
description: HUTCHINSON-Max. Affectionate regrets from Louise Bourgeois and Gerry Gorovoy.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Swimming to Oblivion, Running Out of Wishes
description: Few people drop names as poetically as John Guare does. References to all sorts of celebrities, from the Pope to Sidney Poitier, figure prominently in this ever wistful dramatist's plays, but they're never there merely to glamorize. Celebrities are, in a sense, what Mr. Guare's characters pray to. The ''rich and famous,'' to borrow an early Guare title, are hope-inspiring gods, representing the promise of lives lived large and freely to people who feel helplessly small and confined.

title: Principals for a Day, Potential Political Rivals for a Season
description: It was just another quiet day in the New York City public schools.

title: Civil Rights Groups Plan Boycott Over Antidrug Effort
description: Leaders of several New Jersey civil rights organizations said today that they were organizing a boycott of motels participating in a secret New Jersey State Police drug interdiction program that uses desk clerks as informers and reportedly singles out West Indian and Latino travelers.

title: Sheik's 2 Colts Train Late
description: The usual early-morning horsiness of life in the Churchill Downs stable area was thrust into a new dimension today when the two mystery colts from the Middle East were visited by their owner, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum of Dubai.

title: Assemble 150 Nudes. Don't Forget Permit.
description: THE artist admits it: he was not totally truthful when he applied for a permit from the city to photograph a group of people in Times Square at 6 A.M. last Sunday. The numbers, for instance. The artist, Spencer Tunick, 32, said he would be photographing 50 people; there were closer to 150. Mr. Tunick also neglected to say his subjects would be nude. But can you blame him? Mr. Tunick asks. In 1995 he applied for a permit to photograph 200 people nude in Times Square and he was refused.

title: Political Briefing; Another Senate Race Heating Up in Nevada
description: When Senator Richard H. Bryan of Nevada announced in mid-February that he planned to retire next year, he jolted Democratic hopes for regaining control of the Senate, or at least reducing the Republican majority. Hardly any Democrat up for re-election looked more like a sure winner. So with Mr. Bryan out, how is the race shaping up?

title: Bill on Year 2000 Liability Is Set Aside in the Senate
description: Legislation to limit lawsuits arising from Year 2000 computer breakdowns was shelved indefinitely by the Senate today, a victim of partisan politics and the running battle between lobbyists for business interests and those for trial lawyers.

title: American Topics : Cicero, Illinois, to Gangs:Get Out of Town
description: In a move evoking visions of the Old West, the town of Cicero, Illinois, has voted to order local gang members to leave town, not by sundown, but within 60 days. The town council of the blue-collar Chicago suburb  which the mobster Al Capone once called home  has passed an ordinance that would bar evicted gang members even from returning to visit their families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, RUDOLPH
description: STEWART-Rudolph. We mourn with great sadness the passing of Rudolph Stewart, Associate House Manager of Carnegie Hall, who for more than 28 years greeted artists, patrons, and everyone to the Hall with unforgettable warmth and grace. Rudy's wonderful smile, and his friendship, will remain linked with our Carnegie Hall memories, and in our hearts forever. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his daughter, Kim, and to his entire family. Isaac Stern, President Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Claus Jacobs, Treasurer The Board of Trustees and Staff of Carnegie Hall

title: 86 Are Chosen for Panel as Prospective Jurors in Louima Case
description: A Federal judge completed selection yesterday of a preliminary panel from which a jury will be chosen in the trial of four New York City police officers charged with brutalizing a Haitian immigrant.

title: Aging at Home; Gaps in Nursing
description: To the Editor:

title: China Spy Suspect Reportedly Tried to Hide Evidence
description: A scientist suspected of spying for China tried to hide evidence that he had transferred nuclear secrets out of a computer system at a Government nuclear weapons laboratory two days after he failed an F.B.I. polygraph examination in February, according to United States officials.

title: Metro Business; Suit Filed Over Plan To Sell a Hospital
description: Medical residents at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital filed suit against the hospital's administrators yesterday in Supreme Court in Manhattan, charging that the hospital's plans to sell its building on the Upper East Side would leave them and incoming residents with no place to continue training.

title: An Eclectic Collection Is Back Under One Roof
description: In 1929, at the peak of his career as an advertising artist, painter and art collector, Earl Horter, sporting a beret and velvet smock, was photographed in an intense head-to-head encounter with ''Muse'' (1929), Brancusi's elegantly stylized bronze bust of a woman. It was one of a formidable group of works that Horter (1880-1940) had acquired in a passionate love affair with Modernist European art.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: NATO Missile Goes Astray and Hits House in Bulgarian Capital
description: A straying NATO missile fell on the outskirts of Bulgaria's capital, Sofia, on Wednesday night, going through the roof of a house without exploding.

title: Breathing Life Into Unrelenting Death
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra's concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday, with Wolfgang Sawallisch conducting, offered different prospects of Richard Strauss and different shades of death, largely in the same pieces.
